3.4 Stomach
The stomach is a sac-like enlargement of the alimentary 
canal between the esophagus and duodenum. It receives 
boluses from esophagus, temporarily stores and initiates 
enzymatic and chemical digestion by producing gastric 
juices. Near the pylorus, a muscular valve (torus pyloricus) 
is present which facilitates the food materials toward the 
small intestine.
3.5 Small intestine
It is subdivided into duodenum, jejunum, and ileum. The duo-
denum is the initial segment of the small intestine. The small 
intestine is used to secrete some digestive enzymes which help 
in the breakdown of proteins and carbohydrates. Bile and pan-
creatic duct open into the duodenum and release the secretion. 
Along with these substances break down the foods. As these 
substances have broken down the food, they can be absorbed 
into the body and remain passed into the large intestine (Fig. 4).
3.6 Large intestine
The large intestine extends from the termination of the il -
eum to the anus and consists of cecum, colon, and rectum. 
There is little difference between the diameter of the small 
and large intestines of cat. The cecum is comma-shaped in 
the cats. However, in dogs it is irregularly twisted and its 
blind end is bent and often pointed cranially. It opens into 
colon by cecocolic orifice. It helps in the absorption of wa-
ter and salt from the materials that have not been digested 
as food and then pass out the waste products from the body. 
The rectum is the terminal most segment of the large intes-
tine entirely situated within the pelvis region. The anus is 
the muscular closure at the end of the large intestine.
3.7 Liver
It is the largest gland in the body and is located on the right 
side of the abdominal cavity. It is reddish brown in color. In 
well-nourished and younger animals, it is light brown and 
dark reddish brown in emaciated and older animals. The 
liver of the dog is divided into right lateral, right medial, left 
medial, left lateral, quadrate, and caudate lobes by deep in-
terlobar notches which converge toward the root of the liver. 
The right and left lobes are subdivided into right medial, 
right lateral and left lateral, and left medial lobes. Between 
the two medial lobes and ventral to porta is tongue-shaped 
quadrate lobe. The deep renal impression for a right kid -
ney is formed by the caudate process and the right lateral 
lobe. The caudate lobe is dorsal to porta and has a caudate 
process on the right and a papillary process on the left. The 
left medial lobe is prismatic while the left lateral lobe is 
the largest lobe of the liver and is oval in shape. The gall 
bladder lies in the fossa between the quadrate and the right 
medial lobe. The liver helps in the detoxification of toxins. 
It makes useful proteins that aid in blood clotting. It stores 
essential nutrients like vitamins, minerals, fats, and sugars. 
It produced bile to aid in the digestion of fats (Fig. 5).
3.8 Pancreas
In dogs and cats, it is a “U” or “V”-shaped lobulated gland 
located transversely in the dorsal part of the abdominal cav-
ity almost to the right of the median plane. The pancreatic 
ducts are two, the minor duct unites with the bile duct and 
opens into the duodenum about 5–8 cm distal to the pylorus, 
while the larger accessory duct opens into the duodenum 
a few centimeters distal to the opening of the minor duct. 
The pancreas contains the endocrine part called the Islets

24 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
of Langerhans. It produces insulin that is essential for the 
utilization of blood sugar. Diabetes is a condition in which 
there is a lack of insulin.
4 Respiratory system
The respiratory system of dogs and cats comprises of the 
nose including nostrils and nasal cavity, nasopharynx, lar -
ynx, trachea, principal bronchi, and lungs. It begins at the 
nostrils and ends in the lungs. This system facilitates the 
exchange of gases between the air and the blood. It transfers 
the oxygen from the air to the blood and removes carbon di-
oxide from the blood and exhales out from the body into the 
air. Oxygen is vital for breathing. The cat breathes through 
the nose and mouth. The nose and mouth communicated in 
the posterior part of the oral cavity at the pharynx. The tra -
chea is a tubular structure that extends from the pharynx to 
the lungs. The epiglottis covers the initial part of the trachea 
when swallowing occurs to prevent food and water from 
entering the lungs. In the lungs, the tracheal branches get 
smaller tubules called bronchial tubes. The bronchial tube 
divides into several smaller bronchioles. Then, it becomes 
sacs like structure called alveoli. These alveoli are the  actual 
place of gaseous exchange (Fig. 6).
5 Male reproductive organs of dog 
and cat
The genital system of male dog and tomcat’s (male cat) 
comprises two testicles with their covering (scrotum) and 
epididymis, the ductus deferens which opens into the ure -
thra close to neck of bladder, prostate which open into the 
urethra, and penis with its covering, the prepuce. The tes -
ticle is suspended outside of the body into a sac-like struc -
ture called the scrotum. It is just ventral to the anus and 
largely hidden by dense hair. The testicles are responsible 
FIG. 5 Showing the digestive tract of cat.
FIG. 6 Showing the respiratory organs in cat.

Biological system of dogs and cats  Chapter | 2  25
for secreting male sex hormones, i.e., testosterone, and 
also produce and store sperm. The epididymis helps in the 
transportation of sperm from rete testes to vas deferens. 
Only the prostate gland of dog and cat is well prominent 
which produces seminal fluid, and helps in the transpor -
tation of sperm. The penis of the dog is nearly cylindri -
cal. A bone os penis is present in the glans penis and part 
of the body of the penis. This bone covered with tough 
periosteum shows ventrally except at the tip a groove for 
the lodgment of the urethra and corpus spongiosum. The 
proximal part of os penis is thick and tapers distally. The 
groove is continuous caudally with the urethral groove on 
the ventral surface of corpora cavernosa. The glans penis 
is very long and shows an anterior cylindrical long part, 
pars longa glandis with a pointed free end and surrounding 
slender portion of os penis with a tapered tip and a poste -
rior rounded short globular enlarged part, bulbus glandis 
surrounding thick proximal portion of bone. The bulbus 
glandis because of its elastic trabeculae is capable of con -
siderable distension during coitus and contributes to the 
so-called “tie” between partners lasting up to 30  min. The 
body shows a proximal cavernous part and a distal osseous 
part. The retractor penis extends forward to the bulbous 
glandis. Few bundles may enter the scrotal septum. The 
ischiocavernosus extends from the tuber ischii to the junc -
tion of the crura. The retractor penis originates from the 
sacrum or first two coccygeal vertebrae and ends in the 
region of the bulbous glandis. In cats the penis is short 
and cylindrical. The free part of the penis is conical and 
has small cornified papillae and spines. During mating, 
the tomcat ejaculates seminal fluids into the vagina of the 
female cat. The sperm in the seminal fluid moves through 
the vagina to the uterus and finally reached the oviduct 
(Figs. 7 and 8 ).

26 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
6 Female reproductive organs of bitch 
and queen
The female genital system consists of two ovaries, fallopian 
tubes (oviducts), uterus, and copulatory organs (vagina, ves-
tibule, and vulva). In bitch ovaries are small, elongated-oval 
in outline and flattened and the surface is rough and nodular 
or tuberculate because of many corpora lutea (multiparous). 
They are situated a little behind (1–2 cm) the posterior pole 
of the corresponding kidney in the sublumbar region at the 
level of the 3rd to 4th lumbar vertebrae. The uterine end of 
the ovary is attached by a very short proper ligament to the 
tip of the uterine horn. The ovary is attached cranially to the 
diaphragm in the region of the last rib by the suspensory 
ligament. Ovarian bursa, a peritoneal pouch with a slit-like 
ventral opening medially, is present completely around the 
ovary which hides it from view. The mesovarium is continu-
ous cranially with the suspensory ligament. On the lateral 
surface of the ovarian bursa is a round fat-free area through 
which the ovary can usually be seen. The mesosalpinx en -
closes the laterally flattened deep bursa into which the ovary 
projects from the medial wall and the fimbriae of the uterine 
tube can be seen through the narrow entrance of the bursa; 
however, in cats ovarian bursa encloses the ovary only partly. 
The oviduct is a small tubular structure that connects the 
uterus to the ovaries. In both species body of the uterus is 
short (2–3 cm long) and the horns are very long (12–15 cm), 
slender, nearly straight, and lie entirely within the abdominal 
cavity. The horns diverge from the body in the form of a “V” 
from the 6th or 7th lumbar vertebrae toward the vicinity of 
the kidneys. The horns are of uniform diameter and extend 
with a slight convexity from the uterine end of the ovary 
to body of the uterus. The mucosa shows low longitudinal 
folds. A cervix is an opening between the vagina and the 
uterus. At the time of birth, the cervix becomes relaxed and 
allows the kitten to come out from the uterus to the vagina. 
The vagina is a tubular structure just inside the vulva. The 
vulva is the external part of the female reproductive tract. 
The vulvar lips are located just below the anus. The vulva is 
covered with dense hair in the cat (Fig. 9).
7 Mammary glands
Mammary glands are characteristic of mammals and pro -
duce milk. In bitch, usually, 10 glands are present in two 
series from the posterior part of the pectoral region to the in-
guinal region. The teats are short and have 6–12 teat canals. 
In cats generally, four pairs of mammary glands are present.
8 Urinary system
The urinary system consists of paired kidneys, renal pelvis, 
ureters and unpaired urinary bladder, and urethra which is 
pelvic and extra pelvic parts in males and only pelvic part 
in females. The kidneys of dogs are smooth, unipyramidal, 
bean-shaped, and thick. The dorsal surface is rounded while 
the ventral surface is less convex. The perirenal fat is less 
developed. They have a dark brownish red or bluish-red 
color. The left kidney is less firmly fixed than the right and 
related laterally to the spleen and abdominal wall and ven -
tromedially to descending colon. The right kidney cranially 
lies in the renal impression of the liver and is ventrally re -
lated to descending duodenum, pancreas, and ascending co-
lon. Both kidneys may be palpated through the abdominal 
wall. The renal pelvis and renal crest are present. The renal 
pelvis is an elongated cavity which projects the renal crest. 
There are no calyces minor and major. The hilus is about 
the middle of the medial border. The right kidney is located 
under the bodies of the first three lumbar vertebrae, while 
the left kidney is located under the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th lumbar 
vertebrae. The left kidney is related to the spleen also. In 
cats, both kidneys are smooth and bean-shaped structures. 
The right kidney lies ventral to the first to 4th lumbar trans-
verse processes and the left lies ventral to the 2nd to 5th 
transverse process of lumbar vertebrae. The characteristic 
capsular veins lie in shallow grooves which radiate from the 
hilus. Kidneys involve in the filtration of blood and liquid 
waste product passed as urine. Blood is filtered through the 
kidneys and the liquid waste product is called urine. Urine 
is passed through the ureters into the bladder, and then, it is 
discharged through the urethra, a tube connecting the blad-
der to the exterior of the body.
9 Endocrine system
Dogs and cats have two thyroid glands which are situated 
on the ventrolateral aspect of the trachea, spanning the ini -
tial five to eight tracheal rings. In dogs, thyroid gland size 
FIG. 9 Showing the female reproductive organs in dog.

Biological system of dogs and cats  Chapter | 2  27
varies with breed and individual body size. In an adult 
 medium-size breed, the thyroid gland is approximately 
5 cm in length, 1.5 cm in width, and 0.5 cm in thickness. The 
cranial pole of the right cranial gland is at the level of the 
caudal border of the cricoid cartilage of the larynx, and the 
caudal pole extends to the fifth tracheal ring. The left gland 
is slightly more caudal, extending from the third through the 
eighth tracheal rings. In some dogs, there is a narrow com -
munication between the two glands. This bridge, composed 
of glandular parenchyma, called isthmus glandularis, passes 
across the trachea ventrally. In cats, the thyroid glands are 
flat and measure 10  mm long, 3–5  mm wide, and 1–2  mm 
thick. The parathyroid glands are small and four in number 
in dogs. Two are situated on the deep face of the thyroid 
lobes, the others are placed laterally near the anterior ex -
tremity of the thyroid lobes.
Adrenal glands are two in number and red-brown in 
color. A section of the gland reveals an outer cortex and an 
inner medulla. The cortex is yellowish and radially striated 
and the medulla is much darker and has a uniform appear -
ance. Dogs right adrenal is prismatic and pointed at either 
end while the left adrenal is elongated and flattened dor -
soventrally. The left adrenal is not in contact with the left 
kidney. The glands produce two important hormones that 
regulate a variety of body functions and are necessary to 
sustain life.
The pituitary gland is circular or ellipsoidal in outline 
and consists of adenohypophysis and neurohypophysis. It 
is situated in the hypophyseal fossa on the internal face of 
the body of post-sphenoid and connected by a hollow tube 
of gray matter called infundibulum to the tuber cinereum, 
a small gray prominence situated between optic chiasm in 
front and mammillary body behind.
The pineal gland of a dog is a small elongate lancet-
shaped organ darkly pigmented gland situated dorsally 
in the deep depression between the thalami and the cor -
pora quadrigemina of the brain. It is attached to the pos -
terosuperior quadrant of the III ventricle by a short stalk 
which is a small recess of the third ventricle, epiphyseal 
recess.
10 Sense organ
The eye is an organ of vision located in orbit and made up 
of eyeball and accessory structures including eyelids, con -
junctiva, eyeball muscles, and lacrimal apparatus ( Gelatt, 
2018). The transparent covering of eyeball is known as 
the cornea. Around the cornea, there is a ring of white, 
tissue called the sclera. The iris is a colored, circular area 
of the eyeball. It controls the amount of light that enters 
the eye by making the pupil larger or smaller. The pupil 
is the black area in the center of the eyeball. The pupil is 
controlled by the circular sphincter muscle. In a dark en -
vironment, the pupil becomes enlarges to let in more light, 
and in a bright environment, the pupil becomes smaller to 
let in less light ( Fig. 10).
The lens is situated behind the iris in the fossa hya -
loidea of vitreous humor. The lens consisted of strong, 
crystal-like fibrous tissue. The ciliary muscles of the eye -
ball contract to cause the lens to become thicker, which 
allows the lens to focus on nearby objects. In cats, these 
lens changes appear limited. The ciliary muscles relax to 
cause the lens to become thinner when it focuses on dis -
tant objects. The light rays passing through the lens are 
bent to rest on a very sensitive area on the back of the eye, 
the retina. It is richly lined with nerves. The nerves in the 
retina receive light and change it into nerve impulses or 
signals. Impulses are transmitted to the brain by way of 
the optic nerve. The brain interprets these impulses and 
the cats are able to see. All eyes reflect light, but some 
eyes have a special reflective structure called tapetum 
lucidum that creates the appearance of glowing at night 
(Fig. 11).
The eyes of a cat are very delicate organs that have ex -
ceptional eyesight. In the early evening and at night, they 
see better than human beings. Most of the cats can see kinds 
of light, such as ultraviolet, that are invisible to some other 
mammals. The glowings of cats eyes is due to presence of 
tapetum lucidum which is a layer of iridescent cells at the 
back of eye ball reflect the light, that enhance the ability to 
see at night ( Foss, 2008). The ability to see at night while 
hunting was more favored than the ability to see colors dur-
ing the day.
10.1 Ear
The ear shows three parts external, middle, and internal 
ears. The external ear is composed of the pinna and exter -
nal acoustic meatus. The middle ear comprises the tym -
panic cavity and its contents and the Eustachian tubes. 
Ear ossicles, i.e., malleus, incus, and stapes, extend from 
the lateral to the medial wall of the tympanic cavity. The 
FIG. 10 Showing the front view of eye ball of cat.

28 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
internal ear consists cochlea. When a cat listens to any 
sound, it will move its head toward the sound and turn 
its ears in that direction. The sound travels down through 
the outer ear canal and reached toward the eardrum. 
Through the ear ossicles, sound waves enter the internal 
ear (Fig. 12).
The cochlea is a snail-shaped tubular structure that 
contains the auditory nerve which changes sound waves 
to nerve impulses and relays sound messages to the brain. 
Near the cochlea are three horseshoe-shaped tubes known 
as the semicircular canals (Getty, 1975). They contain fluid 
and fine hairs called cilia that function to maintain the cat’s 
excellent sense of balance (Fig. 13).
10.2 Clinical importance of surface anatomy
● Femoral artery is used to take the pulse in dogs and cats.
● In dog and cat, cephalic vein and recurrent tarsal vein 
are used for intravenous injection, blood collection, and 
transfusion of blood.
● Iliac crest is the most convenient site for the collection 
of bone marrow in dogs; however, in cats proximal end 
of the femur through the trochanteric fossa is the best 
site.
● Suboccipital site (puncture of cisterna magna) is the 
most preferred site for cerebrospinal fluid collection in 
dogs and cats.

11 Common disorders of dog and its 
clinical management
Canine distemper: Canine distemper is a contagious and 
serious disease caused by a virus that attacks the respira -
tory, gastrointestinal, and nervous systems of puppies 
and dogs. All dogs are at risk but puppies younger than 
4 months old and dogs that have not been vaccinated against 
canine distemper are at increased risk of acquiring the dis -
ease. Initially, infected dogs will develop watery to pus-like 
discharge from their eyes. They then develop fever, nasal 
discharge, coughing, lethargy, reduced appetite, and vomit-
ing. As the virus attacks the nervous system, infected dogs 
develop circling behavior, head tilt, muscle twitches, con -
vulsions with jaw chewing movements and salivation, sei -
zures, and partial or complete paralysis. The virus may also 
cause the footpads and nose to thicken and harden due to 
hyperkeratosis leading to its nickname “hard pad disease” 
(Appel and Gillespie, 1972a, b ). Distemper is often fatal, 
and dogs that survive usually have permanent, irreparable 
nervous system damage.
Vaccination is crucial in preventing canine distemper. A 
series of vaccinations are administered to puppies to increase 
the likelihood of building immunity when the immune sys-
tem has not yet fully matured. Avoid gaps in the immuniza-
tion schedule and make sure distemper vaccinations are up 
to date. Avoid contact with infected animals and wildlife. 
Use caution when socializing puppies or unvaccinated dogs 
at parks, puppy classes, obedience classes, doggy daycare, 
and other places where dogs can congregate.
Hepatitis: It is an acute contagious viral disease of 
dogs caused by a DNA-containing virus that belongs to the 
 adenovirus group (Appel et al., 1973 ). The viruses present 
in the saliva, urine, and feces in acute illness and may ex -
crete in the urine for a prolonged period after clinical re -
covery. The disease occurs in any age group of dogs and is 
characterized by fever, vomition, diarrhea, and convulsion. 
After 1–3  weeks following the disappearance of clinical 
signs, a transient corneal opacity may develop due to irido-
cyclitis and corneal edema known as “Hepatitis Blue Eye.”
Symptomatic treatment may recommend. Broad-
spectrum antibodies may be given to control secondary 
bacterial infection and fluid therapy is also recommended. 
A combined vaccine made against distemper may be used 
to prevent this disease.
Leptospirosis: Leptospirosis is a disease caused by in -
fection with Leptospira (Spirochete) bacteria. Transmitted 
by contact with the urine of an infected dog. Symptoms of 
leptospirosis may include fever, shivering, muscle tender -
ness, reluctance to move, increased thirst, changes in the 
frequency or amount of urination, dehydration, vomiting, 
diarrhea, loss of appetite, lethargy, jaundice (yellowing 
of the skin and mucous membranes), or painful inflam -
mation within the eyes, kidney and liver failure. The dis -
ease can cause kidney failure with or without liver failure. 
Leptospirosis can cause bleeding disorders, which can lead 
to blood-tinged vomit, urine, stool, or saliva; nosebleeds; and 
pinpoint red spots (which may be visible on the gums and 
other mucous membranes or light-colored skin). Affected 
dogs can also develop swollen legs (from fluid accumula -
tion) or accumulate excess fluid in their chest or abdomen.
Leptospirosis is generally treated with antibiotics and 
supportive therapy. Avoid contact with the dog’s urine. When 
treated early and aggressively, the chances for recovery are 
FIG. 13 Showing the internal ear of dog.

30 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
good but there is still a risk of permanent residual kidney or 
liver damage. Currently, available vaccines effectively pre-
vent leptospirosis and protect dogs for at least 12 months. 
Annual vaccination is recommended for at-risk dogs.
Kennel cough:  Kennel cough is also known as in -
fectious tracheobronchitis. It is caused by Bordetella 
 bronchiseptica or a combination of viruses and bacteria. It 
is a highly contagious disease of dogs. Dogs that are in close 
contact with infected dogs from veterinary hospitals, stray 
dogs, boarding houses pet stores, and kennels are at higher 
risk of contracting the disease. Most commonly, dogs with 
kennel cough will have a snotty nose and a harsh and dry, 
hacking cough, lethargy, and anorexia. There are vaccines 
for kennel cough, but not all dogs need to receive the vac -
cine. Antibiotics and a 2% solution of hexidine may be used 
to control the epizootic of kennel cough.
Parvovirus infection: Canine parvovirus is a highly con-
tagious viral disease in dogs that causes acute gastrointesti-
nal illness in puppies of age group 6 months to 20 weeks, 
but older dogs sometimes may infect. Breeds at high risk 
are Dobermans, pinschers, Labrador, retrievers, American 
Stafford Shreterrians, and German Shepherds. The virus 
that causes the disease is known as Canine Parvovirus type 
2 (CPV-2). Affected puppies show symptoms like loss of ap-
petite, depression, and lethargy followed by sudden onset of 
high fever, vomiting restlessness. Animals then pass brown-
ish semisolid feces admixed with excess mucus followed by 
fowtidhemorrhagic/bloody diarrhea (Tiwari and Rao, 1987).
Clinical management:  Restoration of fluid and elec -
trolyte balance, preventing secondary bacterial infections, 
fluid therapy should be continued for as long as vomiting 
or diarrhea (or both) persists. A combination of penicillin 
and aminoglycoside (use cautiously) for the best antibacte-
rial spectrum. Antiemetics (Metoclopramide hydrochloride 
and prochlorperazine) have proved helpful in most dogs 
with persistent vomiting. CPV can be inactivated by bleach, 
cleaning with a solution of (1 part bleach mixed with 30 
parts of water) for disinfecting indoor areas like bedding 
food water bowls, etc. Administer the CPV vaccine in com-
bination with other vaccines-distemper, canine adenovirus, 
and parainfluenza vaccines.
Corona: Canine coronavirus is a highly contagious viral 
disease of puppies and older dogs. It causes gastroenteritis 
cause diarrhea similar to parvo but unlike parvovirus vomit-
ing is not common. Kennel environments and dog shows 
may lead to outbreaks of coronavirus. Fluid therapy, antibi-
otics, and supportive drugs are recommended.
Rabies: Dangerous as well as zoonotic viral disease of 
dogs that affects the brain and spinal cord. It is caused by the 
SSRNA Lyssavirus of the Rhabdoviridae family. The  virus 
spreads from the brain to the salivary glands where viral 
particles are able to be shed in the saliva and transmit the 
disease. The rabies virus may remain alive on the dog’s skin 
for up to 2 h. Symptoms appear in two forms: Furious form 
(Hyperactivity)—lasts from 1 to 7 days and exhibits changes 
in behavior like irritability, aggression restlessness, vicious, 
loss of appetite, hiding in dark places, eating unusual ob -
jects, fever attacking other animals and inanimate objects. 
Dumb form (Paralysis): in this form, a rabid dog has trouble 
walking moving keeps stumbling, and is finally struck by 
paralysis, resulting in death. The ability to swallow, drink, 
and speak is lost. It is because of these characteristic symp-
toms that animals often “foam at the mouth.” Exhibit hydro-
phobia. Rabid animals may also exhibit aggressive behavior. 
This makes them more likely to bite other animals allowing 
infection to spread. Once the onset of symptoms has begun 
the animal usually dies within ten days. Once symptoms ap-
pear, Rabies is close to almost 100% fatal.
Vaccination is the key element for preventing the disease. 
To prevent the disease spread rabid dogs are euthanized. A dog 
is considered immunized for 3 years after a single vaccination 
(Lakshmanan et al., 2006; Moore et al., 2015). If a booster 
dose is administered before the end of the 3 years, the vaccina-
tion episode is extended for 3 more years after the booster. If 
the booster is administered more than 3 years after the initial 
vaccination, a second vaccination episode is created.
12 Common endoparasitic infestation  
in dogs and cats
Internal parasites: Common endoparasites of dogs are 
intestinal parasites such as roundworms, hookworms, 
whipworms, and tapeworms lay eggs that are passed in 
the dog’s stool and infect other dogs when they eat con -
taminated soil, licking contaminated fur or paws, or drink 
water contaminated with the stool from infected dogs. 
Gastrointestinal parasites are more common in dogs in  
developing countries ( Perera et  al., 2013 ). Tapeworms 
are spread when dogs eat fleas, lice, or rodents infected 
with tapeworms. These worms can cause malnutrition and  
diarrhea, and hookworms can cause blood loss. Some kidney 
worms like Capillaria (Bladder worm), Ditophyma (Kidney 
worm) cause cystitis, painful urine, red urine, and hydrone-
phrosis. In cats similar to dogs, most common endoparasites 
are intestinal parasites such as roundworms, hookworms, and 
tapeworms. There are many products available to treat worms, 
and consult a veterinarian for the appropriate advice for pets.
Heartworm spread by mosquitoes damages an in -
fected dog’s pulmonary arteries, veins, muscles, and tis -
sue of the heart leading to congestive heart failure and 
death. Cats are atypical host for heartworms and it spread 
by infected mosquitoes. Outdoor cats are at greater risk 
because of increased exposure to mosquitoes. Despite its 
name, heartworm mainly causes lung disease in cats and 
causes life- threatening in kittens and older cats. It causes 
breathing difficulties and persistent cough and it is called 
 “heartworm-associated respiratory disease” (HARD).
Coccidia and Giardia are single-celled parasites that 
damage the lining of the intestine. Dogs can become in -
fected with coccidia by eating infected soil or licking

Biological system of dogs and cats  Chapter | 2  31
 contaminated paws or fur. Puppies are at the highest risk of 
infection and illness.
To control the endoparasitic infestations, periodic anti -
helmintic treatment (deworming) is to be rendered. Dog and 
cat houses should be kept to dry and clean and a hygienic 
environment has to be provided.
External parasites:  Includes ticks, mites, lice, flies, 
and fleas.
Ear mites in dog: Ear mites are microscopic, parasitic 
organisms that cause ear infections in dogs. They thrive in 
warm and moist areas of ear canals and feed on ear wax 
and epidermal debris. Dogs with long floppy ears are more 
prone to ear mites than others. Infected dogs will show 
intense irritation, continuously shaking of head, exces -
sive shaking causes damage to small blood vessels leads 
to hematomas, severe pain in the ear, foul odor from ears, 
an increase in ear wax production, restless behavior, per -
sistent itching and scratching if left untreated may cause 
deafness.
Mange infections in dogs are commonly two types sar -
coptic and demodectic mange.
Scabiasis (Sarcoptic Mange):  Canine scabies is a 
highly contagious zoonotic skin disease in dogs. It is caused 
by Sarcoptes Scabiei. Female mite forms a tunnel on the 
epidermal layer of skin and causes intense itching and rub -
bing of affected parts. Lesions are observed on the lateral of 
hock, elbow, margin of the ear, and root of the tail. Chronic 
cases show thickening, drying, and wrinkling of the skin, 
and secondary pyoderma may develop.
Various scabicidal, antihistaminic, and antibiotic drugs 
as well as tropical antiseptic preparations are used for symp-
tomatic relief. Cleansing with anti-seborrheal shampoo is 
used before miticidal treatment.
Demodicosis (Demodectic Mange): Demodicosis is one 
of the persistent challenging skin problems in a dog caused 
by Demodexcanis. It causes alopecia, erythema, edema, and 
seborrhea and later on develops pyoderma. Dogs produce 
rancid odor from their body if secondary bacterial infection 
occurs. Various miticidal agents like benzyl benzoate, ben-
zoyl peroxide, and ivermectin injections are used to control 
the disease. Antibiotic therapy and supportive therapy may 
also be given to combat secondary bacterial infections.
13 Common disorders of cat and its 
clinical management
Feline leukopenia/Feline distemper: This is a highly conta-
gious disease of cats. The disease is caused by a DNA virus. 
The disease is characterized by fever, anorexia, depression, 
dehydration, and a high fatality rate. There is frequent vomi-
tion and diarrhea result in severe dehydration. Animals may 
stop eating and prefer to remain in a sitting position with the 
head resting in between the stretched forelimb.
There is no specific treatment for the disease. Affected 
animals should be isolated and treated. The course of 
 broad-spectrum antibiotics may be used to prevent second-
ary bacterial infections. Strict sanitation and hygienic mea-
sures are to be adopted. Vaccination may be recommended.
Rabies: Rabies is an acute viral infection of the nervous 
system that affects mainly carnivores including cats. No cat-
to-cat transmission has been recorded. The most common 
way for a cat to become infected is through a bite from an in-
fected animal where the virus is transmitted by saliva. Rabies 
in cats are usually more furious in form than dogs. The first 
signs are changes in behavior like irritability, nervousness, 
and hyperexcitability. Loss of appetite, seizures, drooling, 
foaming at the mouth, and difficulty in swallowing.
There is no treatment for rabies in cats, and humane 
euthanasia is recommended if the disease is strongly sus -
pected. The rabies vaccine can prevent rabies infection. 
Additionally, immediate disinfection of bite wounds may 
help in the decrease in infection.
Take the cat to keep healthy and prevent infectious dis -
eases; care must be taken under the supervision of veteri -
narians and management practices like cleaning up urine 
poop or vomit in the house and disinfecting the area.
Protection of cat from ticks:  Ticks in the cat are very 
common in areas like under the front legs, between back 
legs, toes around eyelids, tails, and ears. To further reduce 
the chances that a tick bite will make a cat sick check the cat 
for ticks every day.
Prevention and control strategies are opted to prevent 
infection, to protect dogs and cats, personnel (owners, han-
dlers, trainers, staff), and the community.
● Early identification and isolation of potentially infec -
tious dogs and cats from other pets in the group.
● Using effective cleaning and disinfection practices for 
all indoor and outdoor pet areas and prompt removal of 
feces and debris, cleaning with detergent and water, and 
correct use of disinfectants.
● Practicing hand hygiene (washing hands with alcohol-
based sanitizer, soap, and water) by all people after han-
dling the pets. Proper cleaning and disinfection result in 
a cleaner, healthier environment and help to prevent the 
spread of disease to both animals and people.
● To reduce contamination, ectoparasites and other patho-
gens on hair coats owners should bathe dogs with a rou-
tine pet shampoo.
● Effective topical or oral flea and tick prevention prod -
ucts should be used prior to and during all events based 
on season, weather, and geography to reduce the risk of 
canine disease transmission.
● To ensure all dogs and cats receive the appropriate core 
vaccination and parasite preventives at the frequency 
recommended for pets.
Deworming schedule for canines:  Worms are one of 
the most common ailments of puppies and kittens, among 
them hookworms, roundworms, whipworms, and tape -
worms are most common. Most worm infestations cause

32 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
symptoms like diarrhea, weight loss or poor growth, dry 
hair, poor appearance, and vomiting. It is also impor -
tant to treat dogs for fleas because fleas are a vector for 
tapeworms.
Puppies: Every 2 weeks until 3 months of age. Once a 
month from 3 to 6 months of age. After 6 months, follow the 
adult recommendation.
Kittens: Every 2 weeks until 3 months of age, starting 
at 3 weeks of age. Once a month from 3 to 6 months of age. 
After 6 months, follow the adult recommendation.
Adult pets: For all dogs and cats—twice a year for life.
Inside cats—once a year and outside cats—up to three 
times a year.
New animals: Deworm immediately repeat in 2 weeks.
Vaccination:  Vaccination can help to protect the 
cat from dangerous diseases like feline leukemia, ra -
bies, and feline distemper and help them live a longer 
healthier life. Diseases like rabies are transmissible 
to both humans and other animals through a bite from 
 rabid  animals. So  vaccination is necessary to prevent the 
transmission of diseases zoonotic diseases also.
