Chapter 3
Nutritional strategies of dogs and cats
1 What is nutritionally balanced  
dog food?
A nutritionally balanced and complete food includes carbo-
hydrates, proteins, fats, minerals, vitamins, and water. This is 
generally present in the basic ingredients but has to understand 
how much of each nutrient is used in a dog’s body, under -
stand the processes, and know how much of each nutrient is 
required for a healthy dog at all life stages is very composite.
Generally, that process is so multifaceted that an entire 
specialty in veterinary medicine is devoted to small animal 
nutrition. But as a pet owner, the main things to know about 
dog food nutrition are. The owner has to keep in mind that 
pet food labels  are different from human food product la -
bels, which makes comparing food products difficult.
There are eight things that should be labeled on the dog 
food bag or can:
1. Brand and product name
2. Guaranteed analysis. This lists the percentage or volume 
of each of the nutrients in the food. It must be written in 
a particular order, in specified units, and as a minimum 
or maximum, depending on the nutrient.
3. Ingredient statement
4. Name of species for which the pet food is intended
5. Quality statement
6. Feeding directions
7. Nutritional adequacy which “indicates that the food is 
complete and balanced for a particular life stage, like as 
reproduction, growth, adult maintenance or a combina -
tion of these, or intended for intermittent or supplemen-
tal feeding only.”
8. Name with the address of manufacturer or distributor
Six essential nutrients that are required to support life 
and function in dogs are shown in Fig. 1.
1.1 Balanced dog food should meet your dog’s 
energy requirements
Depending on many factors, the energy requirements for 
dogs can vary. It is essential to meet your dog’s exact energy 
requirement to maintain their daily lifestyle. Some factors 
include:
● Adult age groups (young, middle, and older)
● Reproduction (intact vs altered)
● Growth
● Medical and behavioral conditions
● Activity level
● Breed
The requirement of energy in the diet mainly comes 
from fats and proteins, followed by carbohydrates. The 
energy content of a diet indicates the quality of the food 
and how much food should be consumed per day ba -
sis. The diet should meet the daily energy requirements 
of the individual dog. Nutrient requirement in dogs is 
shown in Fig. 2 .
All the nutrients should be balanced to make sure 
that they are absorbed suitably by the body and appro -
priately used by every body system. If the diet does not 
supply enough energy, the dog’s gastrointestinal tract 
will practically be unable to take enough of that diet re -
sulting in the required nutrient they will not be able to 
get. For example, a small volume of diet is consumed by 
dogs when the percentage of other essential nutrients is 
high enough to meet the requirement that is very impor -
tant to ensure.
The only way to decide if a diet has sufficient energy 
is to undergo a feeding study to ensure that the ingredients 
are enough to maintain a healthy daily life. Energy require-
ments per day in dogs are shown in Fig. 3.

36 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
2 Protein in dog food
Proteins are also important in the maintenance and forma -
tion of tendons, cartilage, and ligaments. Protein in dog food 
also helps the formation of nails, skin, muscles, blood, and 
hair formation. Broken down of protein creates amino acids 
which are essential nutrients for dogs. Amino acids help to 
create energy for sustaining the life of dogs. To maintain a 
healthy life in dogs, 10 essential amino acids are required. 
These nutrients must be supplied in the diet because they 
cannot be created within the body.
2.1 Sources of protein in dog food
Animal protein contains the highest amounts of essential 
amino acids. Plant protein tends to have a lower digestibility 
since dogs cannot digest plant fiber as simply as other sources. 
In theory, dogs can survive on a completely plant-based pro-
tein diet but such a diet may be required various sources of 
protein to reach a daily minimum that can safely be absorbed. 
It is very important to certify veterinary nutritionists that veg-
etarian diets have undergone food trials and are formulated.
For that reason, have a biyearly nutritional recheck to 
ascertain that the dog is in good health condition. These 
rechecks consist of an ideal body weight review, physical 
examination, blood and gastrointestinal absorption testing, 
and body condition scoring.
2.2 What does crude protein mean?
Crude includes all the ways that protein is calculated and de-
termined in the diet. It does not provide information about the 
protein quality or the nutritional value of the protein source 
in the dog’s diet. Among the many methods, biological value 
(BV) is used to determine protein quality. It measures the 
mass of nitrogen integrated into the body divided by the mass 
of nitrogen from protein in the food multiplied by 100.
A value of 100% means all of the dietary protein eaten 
and absorbed becomes protein in the body.
2.2.1 Protein quality
How much of the protein source is converted into essential 
amino acids that can be used by the body’s tissue treated as 
protein quality. It is dependent on the:
● Number of amino acids in the food
● Availability
● Protein source
Proteins that provide large portions of all essential 
amino acids are considered high-quality proteins. If that 
protein source is lacking essential amino acids (AA) or they 
cannot be absorbed by the body, then it is considered a low-
quality protein. In many cases, to avoid this, multiple pro -
tein sources may be fed in one diet to prevent the absence of 
certain amino acids.
2.3 How much protein does my dog need?
Dog protein requirement depends on the stage of life and 
activity of dogs. Puppies need more protein than adult dogs.  
FIG. 3 Energy requirements per day in dogs.
FIG. 2 Nutrient requirement in dogs.
FIG. 1 Nutritional requirements in dogs.

Nutritional strategies of dogs and cats  Chapter | 3  37
The protein needs of a puppy can be met by high-quality pro-
tein providing 20% to 25% of dietary calories. The minimum 
dietary protein requirement for a growing dog is 18% dry mat-
ter (DM) and 8% DM for an adult dog. This is based on feed-
ing a high-quality protein and again, is a minimum amount. 
Daily requirements for dog diets should contain at least 20%–
24% DM for growth and 17%–19% DM for maintenance.
Current research indicates that there is no added benefit 
to excess protein in the diet. The maximum amount for any 
life stage should not exceed 29%–31% DM. Excess protein 
is otherwise excreted from the body, and in some condi -
tions, it can be harmful to the body.
2.3.1 Low-protein diets
In veterinary nutrition, feeding a low-protein or high-protein 
diet for the prevention and management of certain diseases 
is a debated topic. Low-protein diets may be suggested for 
certain conditions to reduce the amount of ammonia that is 
present in the body. Ammonia is toxic to the cell as well as 
tissue also and is created as a byproduct of protein break -
down. Ammonia occurs in many sites in the body, but 90% 
of that is in the liver and kidneys. Reducing nonessential 
amino acids and total protein intake can help to minimize 
the workload on these organs. It is best to consult with a cer-
tified veterinary nutritionist if considering a protein-specific 
diet due to the dog’s condition.
2.4 Can dogs be allergic to certain proteins?
Food allergies in dogs are uncommon and are determined 
after ruling out environmental and seasonal allergies. About 
85% of itchy dogs have an allergy to insect bites (the con -
dition may be called flea allergy dermatitis , or FAD) that 
causes a mild-to-severe immune response that can mimic 
other conditions. Typically, dogs that present with skin and 
ear issues have a higher chance of having environmental 
or seasonal allergies. Common skin allergies can often be 
managed by therapies such as:
● Monthly parasite preventatives and repellants
● Supplements
● Canine-specific allergy medications
If concerned about the dog having a potential food al -
lergy or food aversion, speak with a primary care veteri -
narian or a board-certified veterinary nutritionist about a 
clinical food trial.
2.5 Taurine in cats
Taurine is the eleventh essential AA required by cat. All other 
species conjugate glycine with bile acids to form glycocholic 
acid. Cats use taurine instead of glycine and form taurocho-
lic acid. Taurine is found in muscles, retina, and CNS which 
again makes cats as an obligate carnivore (Fig. 4).
3 Fat in dog food
Fats are concentrated forms of energy. Fats are composed of 
triglycerides and are solid at normal temperatures. Dietary 
fats are the most concentrated form of energy in pet foods 
(contain 2.25 times more calories than carbohydrates or 
proteins). Fat digestion is more complex than that of protein 
or carbohydrates. Healthy dogs & cats can digest fats with 
great efficiency, approximately 90%–95%. Fat helps with 
the absorption of fat-soluble vitamins and also provides en-
ergy. Fat provides essential fatty acids (EFAs). This is es -
sential for dogs to maintain healthy skin and haircoat and 
also helps with inflammation at the cellular level. There are 
two important polyunsaturated fatty acids—omega-3 and 
omega-6 fatty acids. Animals fed diets too low in fat may 
develop dry, coarse hair, dry & thickened skin, decrease 
FIG. 4 Nutrient requirement in cats.

38 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
wound healing and they may boost up certain dermatologi-
cal conditions. High-fat diets may increase the risk of fat -
ness and also want to increase vitamin E supplementation 
though it is involved in antioxidant protection. Fat also con-
tributes to the palatability.
The requirement of fat for absorption of fat-soluble vi -
tamins is 1%–2% of the food. Cats are having limited activ-
ity of the desaturase enzyme involved in EFA’s metabolism. 
Arachidonic acid is dietary essential for cats; therefore, they 
require animal fat and because of the above-given reason, 
the cats are obligate carnivores.
3.1 Sources of fat in dog and cat food
Essential fatty acids support dog’s health. Healthy dogs & 
cats can digest fats with great efficiency, approximately 90%–
95%. Fat supplies essential fatty acid linoleic acid. Linoleic 
acid (LA) is the precursor of arachidonic acid (AA), which 
is an essential omega-6 fatty acid. Vegetable oils, chicken, 
and pork fat are good sources of linoleic acid. Omega-3 fatty 
acids, eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), and docosahexaenoic 
acid (DHA) may or may not be essential in a dog’s daily 
diet. Veterinarian generally recommends omega-3 fatty ac-
ids which help to reduce inflammation caused by conditions 
like arthritis, burns, certain cancers, inflammatory bowel 
disease, and dermatitis, and kidney disease. Omega-3 is also 
keeping cartilage functional and healthy. Canola, marine fish 
oils, and flaxseed are good sources of omega-3 fatty acids.
4 Carbohydrates in dog food
One of the most important reasons for carbohydrates in a 
dog’s diet is to supply energy. Carbohydrates are sugars, 
starches, and dietary fibers (not completely digestible). The 
body craves glucose, and if it is not available with carbohy-
drates, then it will take amino acids away from other pro -
cesses in the body. Supplied in the diet by cereal grains and 
sugars, such as glucose, sucrose, and lactose ( De Godoy 
et al., 2013) When consuming more carbohydrates than are 
needed, excess carbohydrate energy is stored in the form 
of glycogen in the liver and muscles and is converted to fat 
and stored in adipose tissues. Carbohydrates generate heat 
in the body and form the base for other nutrients. It can be 
converted into fat (some carbohydrates).
Growing animals and dogs require high energy, and 
need to feed a diet with at least 20% carbohydrates. During 
fasting, stress, or exercise, glycogen is broken down into 
glucose and delivered to the bloodstream where it is distrib-
uted to all body tissues.
4.1 Fiber from carbohydrates
Fiber is a form of carbohydrate, that has numerous effects on 
the gastrointestinal tract for its normal function and health. It 
keeps the colon healthy along with the microbes of the gut. 
Fibers have high water-holding capacity, contribute to easy 
passage of digesta due to bulkiness, and cause stomach dis-
tention, which reduces feed intake. Fibers decrease digestion 
and absorption of fat, vitamins, and minerals. As a protective 
mechanism, fiber can bind to some toxins and prevent their 
absorption into the bloodstream. Excessive dietary fiber is as-
sociated with loose stools, flatulence, increased stool volume, 
frequency, and decreased dietary caloric density. The measure 
of fiber is reported as crude fiber (the insoluble portions). Total 
dietary fiber is composed of both soluble and insoluble fibers.
4.1.1 Soluble fiber
Soluble fiber retains water and generally makes a dog’s fe-
ces softer. Common sources of soluble fiber are fruits and 
gums. Gums can improve canned food texture. Gum is a 
term used for a group of viscous and sticky polysaccharides 
found in seeds and plants. Many soluble fibers are also fer-
mentable. Fermentable fibers can be used by a dog’s normal 
gut bacteria to act as an energy source. Fibers also produce 
short-chain fatty acids, which can be used by intestinal cells 
as an energy source which is also called prebiotics.
4.1.2 Insoluble fiber
Insoluble fiber remains in grains. That fiber cannot ab -
sorb water; for that reason, it usually increases fecal bulk 
but does not soften feces. It is supplemented in the form 
of cellulose. Generally, supplemented fibers are mixed and 
soluble in nature. High-fiber diets are sometimes used to 
manage weight management, certain gastrointestinal condi-
tions, and diabetes mellitus.
4.2 Sources of carbohydrates
Basically, carbohydrates can be broken down into the fol -
lowing groups:
● Simple sugars
● Oligosaccharides
● Polysaccharides
All three play a crucial role in the daily diet of dogs. 
Polysaccharides, known as complex carbohydrates, are de -
fined based on how they are digested in the body. Fruits and 
honey contain sugar. Good sources of starches (a polysac -
charide) are corn, wheat, rice, barley, oats, and potatoes for 
dogs. Depending on the level of digestibility (slow, moder-
ate, or fast), wheat bran, rice bran, apples, and guar gum are 
good sources of starch for dogs. For a healthy dog, there is no 
such thing as a bad source of carbohydrates, but you can de-
fine them based on how they are digested in your dog’s body. 
Carbohydrates are lower on the glycemic index considered for 
dogs that have glucose intolerance and may be used in certain 
medical diseases that can be managed with these diets.

Nutritional strategies of dogs and cats  Chapter | 3  39
4.3 How much carbohydrates require for dog?
There is no specific required amount of carbohydrates for 
dogs. AAFCO does not have a requirement for carbohy -
drates due to the traditional preparations of commercial di -
ets. Commercial dog foods contain sufficient carbohydrates 
to meet up the daily amount of glucose required to main -
tain the nervous system for keeping it functioning normally. 
Dry dog foods naturally contain 32%–60% carbohydrates. 
Grains (i.e., wheat, corn, rice, oats, and barley) contain a 
maximum starch and are well digested and absorbed by 
dogs. It is vital to note that a diet without any carbohydrates 
will be higher in proteins and fats.
5 Vitamins in dog food
Vitamins are organic compounds that are necessary to per -
form many functions in a dog’s body, such as the creation of 
DNA, normal eye function, bone development, neurologic 
function, and blood clotting. There are some characteristics 
of a vitamin:
1. It is an organic compound but not a fat, carbohydrate, or 
protein.
2. It is essential in small amounts for normal function.
3. It hampers normal functioning if missing in the diet.
4. It cannot be synthesized in the body normally and 
minimum quantities are sufficient to support normal 
function.
Consumption of more vitamins over the recommended 
dose can lead to toxicity and other complications. It is very 
significant to observe sources of vitamins in a dog’s diet 
though deficiencies and excessive amounts can occur due 
to the inconsistencies in natural food products (liver, lungs) 
(Bischoff and Rumbeiha, 2012). It is ideal to use a vitamin 
and mineral supplement in proper amounts.
5.1 Which vitamins do dogs need?
There are quite a few vitamins that dogs require from their 
food. They can be separated into two categories: fat-soluble 
and water-soluble.
5.1.1 Fat-soluble vitamins
Bile salts and fats are required for the absorption of fat-  
soluble vitamins in a dog’s gut. The fat-soluble vitamins are 
A, D, E, and K.
Vitamin A
Vitamin A is also known as retinol. It is essential for normal 
vision, immune function, growth, healthy skin, and repro -
duction. American Association of Feed Control Officials 
(AAFCO) recommends 5000 IU/kg DM for dogs for all life 
stages. Vitamin A deficiency causes night blindness and skin 
issues. Toxicity also can occur with over-  supplementation 
which can cause bleeding and abnormal bone growth and 
formation. Natural sources with maximum amounts of vi -
tamin A include:
● Dairy products
● Fish oil
● Liver
● Egg
Deficiencies cause anorexia or decreased eating, stunted 
growth, weakness, and dull hair coat. Toxicities also cause 
stunted growth, anorexia, and bone fractures.
Vitamin D
Vitamin D, called cholecalciferol (D3) and ergocalciferol 
(D2), is essential for dogs because they are unable to pro -
duce naturally in the body. Vitamin D helps intestinal ab -
sorption and to keep calcium and phosphorus labeled in the 
bone. AAFCO recommends 500 IU/kg DM for dogs for all 
life stages.
Marine fish and fish oils are the richest natural sources 
of vitamin D and the other sources include freshwater fish, 
most dairy eggs, beef, and liver. The most common syn -
thetic sources are vitamin D3 and vitamin D2 supplements. 
Deficiencies can cause osteoporosis, rickets, enlarged 
joints, and other bone issues. Due to toxicities, there is an 
incidence of hypercalcemia, anorexia, and lameness.
Vitamin E
Vitamin E is also known as α-tocopherol and its acts as an 
antioxidant in the body. Toxicity is rare but can hamper the 
clotting times and mineralization of the bones. Deficiency 
can also create anorexia, skin and immune issues, and neu-
rologic concerns in dogs. It is the least toxic fat-soluble vi -
tamin among the four. AAFCO recommends 50  IU/kg DM 
for dogs. Only plants synthesize vitamin E. Vegetable oils, 
seeds, and cereal grains are the richest sources of vitamin 
E for dogs.
Vitamin K
Vitamin K, known as phytonadione, is helped in blood clot-
ting and bone development. AAFCO recommends 1.64 mg/
kg for puppies and adults. Deficiencies of vitamin K can 
cause increased clotting times and hemorrhage. Certain 
forms of vitamin K can cause anemia and jaundice. Alfalfa 
meals, oilseed meals, liver, and fish meals are rich sources 
of vitamin K.
5.1.2 Water-soluble vitamins
Water-soluble vitamins are readily absorbed by dogs. 
Deficiencies of those vitamins are common due to their fast 
use and no available storage in the body. There are nine es-
sential water-soluble vitamins in dogs:

40 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
Thiamin (B1)
Thiamin (B1) is concerned with many enzymatic reac -
tions in the body and also helps with the nervous system. 
AAFCO requires 1 mg/kg DM for dogs. Whole grains, liver, 
yeast, animal tissue, and meat are rich sources of thiamin. 
Deficiency causes anorexia, weight loss, muscle weakness, 
enlargement of the heart, seizures, and ataxia. Overdoses 
create decreases in blood pressure, heart, and respiratory 
issues.
Riboflavin (B2)
Riboflavin (B2) is concerned with many systems in a 
dog’s body. AAFCO requires 2.2  mg/kg DM for dogs. 
Deficiencies cause stunted growth and weight loss, as well 
as neurological, skin, heart, and eye issues. Toxicity has 
minimal side effects.
Pyridoxine (B6)
Pyridoxine (B6) helps in amino acid metabolism and the 
creation of neurotransmitters. The AAFCO recommended 
amount is 1  mg/kg. Vitamin B6 is found in meats, vegeta -
bles, whole-grain products, and nuts. Excess eating of B6 
causes signs of ataxia, signs of weakness, and falling down. 
Deficiencies result in anorexia, weight loss, stunted growth, 
anemia, convulsions, weakness, and kidney issues.
Niacin (B3)
Niacin (B3) helps in many enzymatic and physiologic re -
actions in a dog. The AAFCO requirement is 11.4  mg/
kg DM. The richest source of niacin is yeast, animal/fish 
by- products, cereals, legumes, and oilseeds. Deficiencies 
indicate anorexia, diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, stunted 
growth, necrosis of the tongue (soft tissue damage in the 
oral cavity), drooling, and may cause death also. Toxicities 
cause blood in the feces and convulsions.
Pantothenic acid (B5)
Pantothenic acid (B5) helps in the metabolism of fat, pro -
tein, and carbohydrates. It plays a vital role in the produc -
tion of energy. AAFCO recommends 10 mg/kg DM for the 
stages of the dog. It is found maximum in meats (liver and 
heart), rice and wheat bran, alfalfa, peanut meal, yeast, and 
fish. Calcium pantothenate is the major form added to pet 
foods. Deficiencies can cause weight loss, a weakened im -
mune system, and heart issues. It can cause gastrointestinal 
upset in large doses.
Cobalamin (B12)
Cobalamin (B12) is the largest and most complex of the 
Vitamin B. It is involved in the metabolism of folate and 
is essential to cell function. The AAFCO requirement is 
0.022 mg/kg for dogs. Plants have very small amounts of 
vitamin B12. Certain microorganisms are able to create co-
balamin. Meat and some milk products are good sources. 
Deficiencies are anemia, poor growth, and neurologic is -
sues. Long-term feeding of certain vegetable-based diets 
may lead to vitamin B12 deficiency. Toxicities cause abnor-
mal reflexes and other neurologic conditions.
Folic acid (B9)
Folic acid (B9) helps with the synthesis of DNA and pu -
rines. AAFCO recommends 0.18 mg/kg DM for dogs. Folic 
acid is found in liver, egg yolks, and green vegetables, but 
it can be damaged by heating, freezing, and storing in wa -
ter. Deficiencies cause decreased eating and an inability to 
maintain or gain weight, blood issues (anemia, clotting is -
sues), and decreased immune function. Certain medications 
(sulfa drugs) can obstruct the absorption. No toxicities are 
found in the case of dogs.
Biotin (B7 or H)
Biotin (B7 or H) helps with the metabolism of fats, sugar, 
and amino acids. It is present in low quantities in many 
foods. The maximum amount of biotin is found in oilseeds, 
egg yolks, alfalfa meal, liver, and yeast. Biotin may be sup-
plemented to the dog with commercial food. Deficiencies 
generally occur due to feeding raw egg whites and certain 
antimicrobials. Raw egg whites can bind with biotin and 
make it unavailable to a dog’s body. A deficiency of bio -
tin may cause increased production of keratin along with 
dermatitis, hair loss, and a dull coat. There may be signs of 
stunted growth along with neurologic issues. No toxicities 
are found.
Choline
Cell membranes contain choline. It hampers fat absorption 
in the liver, is important in clotting and inflammation, and 
also helps with other body functions. Dogs can synthesize 
choline in the liver. It is not considered as a vitamin but 
is essential, and for that reason, it is added to many com -
mercial diets. AAFCO recommends 1200  mg/kg DM for 
dogs. Animal sources are egg yolks, glandular meals, fish 
and while cereal germs, legumes, and oilseed meals are the 
plant sources.
Deficiencies cause fatty livers in young dogs, increased 
blood clotting times, stunted growth, kidney issues, and an-
orexia. No toxicities were found in dogs. All-natural fats 
contain some choline. Lecithin is an emulsifying agent in 
foods and is the form of choline ingested in most foods.
5.2 Do dogs need vitamin supplements?
A completely balanced and formulated diet has all the vi -
tamins which require daily basis. Most of the commercial 
pet foods are fortified with vitamins. Diets that have an

Nutritional strategies of dogs and cats  Chapter | 3  41
AAFCO statement should be complete and balanced with 
all required vitamins. It is very important when choosing 
a diet for the pet that the AAFCO statement is included. 
If dogs are feeding a nontraditional diet that does not have 
an AAFCO statement, have to consult with a veterinary 
nutritionist to ascertain that the pet is meeting their daily 
nutritional requirements. All over-the-counter canine sup -
plements in many states are not required to go through food 
studies or bioavailability testing. Bioavailability can only be 
established through clinical and safety trials, which show 
the percentage of what active and inactive ingredients are, 
what is available, and what can be absorbed.
6 Minerals in dog food
Minerals are major structural components of the body fluids 
and electrolytes, the body’s organs and tissues, and muscle 
contractions. They are concerned with enzyme and hormone 
systems. There are two types of minerals: macro-minerals 
and trace minerals. Minerals help with many functions of a 
dog’s body and support structures. Biological systems may 
stop functioning without a balanced mineral profile.
6.1 Which minerals do dogs need?
There are different types of macro-minerals and trace min -
erals that are required to complete a balanced dog food.
6.1.1 Macro-minerals
Requirement of macro-minerals is more than 100 mg/Mcal.
Calcium (Ca)
Calcium (Ca) requires for teeth and bones development 
for maintaining their shape. Ca is also vital in cell com -
munication and is also involved in blood clotting, nerve 
transmission, and muscle function. About 99% of calcium 
is stored in the teeth and bones. More or less amount of cal-
cium can create an imbalance in phosphorus-calcium lev -
els. Deficiencies in calcium can cause bone reabsorption, 
loose teeth, decreased growth, anorexia, limping, lame -
ness, fracturing of the bone, and convulsions. Low calcium 
can cause eclampsia, kidney failure, and pancreatitis also. 
Hypocalcemia may cause limb lameness, joint swelling, and 
secondary hyperparathyroidism. For that reason, require the 
supervision of a veterinarian during supplementation.
Phosphorus (P)
Phosphorus (P) is important for many tissues and functions 
in a dog’s body. It is the secondary structural component 
of bone, teeth, DNA, and RNA. It also plays a role in cell 
growth, cell energy use, and amino acid and protein forma-
tion. AAFCO recommendations are 0.8% for growth and 
0.5% for maintenance of adult dogs. Maximum phosphorus 
comes from animal-based ingredients than plant-based in -
gredients (phytic acid). Meat tissue (poultry, lamb, fish, and 
beef) is high in phosphorus, followed by grains, eggs, milk 
products, and oilseeds. Toxicity can cause calcification of 
tissues and organs, loss of bone mass, urinary stones, and 
the inability to gain weight. Deficiencies can cause bone 
fractures, pica, decreased growth, and poor hair coat.
Calcium to phosphorus ratio
The desired proportion of the Ca/P ratio in cats is 1:1 while 
in the case of dogs is 1.4:1. The sources such as meat, poul-
try, and fish supplies Ca/P of 1:15–20. This may lead to Ca 
deficiency and causes NSH, Eclampsia (usually occurs in 
nursing mothers).
Magnesium (Mg)
Magnesium (Mg) is concerned with the structural composi-
tion of bones, helps in the metabolism of carbohydrates and 
fats, and also is a part of neuromuscular activity. AAFCO 
recommends 0.04% DM for growth and 0.08% DM for 
maintenance in adult dogs. Bone meal, lamb meal, oilseed, 
flaxseed, soybean meal, fibers, and unrefined grains are good 
sources of Mg. Deficiencies cause stunted growth, muscle 
contraction, anorexia, and mobility issues. More levels can 
cause paralysis and stone formation. Kidneys play an impor-
tant role in the regulation of Mg. The use of certain drugs, 
i.e., diuretics, cyclosporine, etc., can cause an imbalance.
Potassium (K)
Potassium (K) is rich inside the cells of a dog’s body. It helps 
in the maintenance of acid-base balance and osmotic balance, 
transmitting nerve impulses and muscle contractility. It needs 
to supplement in the diet because it is not stored in the body 
for future use. AAFCO recommends 0.6% DM for dogs. 
Yeast, soybean meal, unrefined grains, and fiber sources are 
the major sources of K. Excess supplementation is uncom -
mon but may cause heart and muscle issues. Deficiencies can 
cause lethargy, anorexia, and trouble walking.
Sodium (Na) and chloride (Cl)
Sodium (Na) and chloride (Cl) help in maintaining the os -
motic pressure and acid-base balance. Na is also significant 
in Ca absorption and helps the absorption of water-soluble 
vitamins. Anorexia, weakness, hair loss, and fatigue are the 
deficiency symptoms. Excess supplementation does not 
naturally occur until good quality water is not readily avail-
able but it can cause constipation, seizures, and death also.
6.1.2 Trace minerals
Trace minerals may also call microminerals that are re -
quired in least amount at less than 100 mg/Mcal. Following 
are the trace minerals.

42 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
Iron (Fe)
Iron (Fe) helps in oxygen transport throughout the body. 
Deficiencies can cause anemia, a rough coat, stunted 
growth, and lethargy. AFFCO recommends 80  mg/kg for 
dogs. Fe is present in liver, spleen, lungs, and also in some 
fibers. More amounts in the diet can cause anorexia, weight 
loss, and liver issues.
Copper (Cu)
Copper is also important in the formation and actions of dif-
ferent enzymes in the body, hemoglobin formation (oxygen 
movement), cardiac function, bone and myelin formation, 
immune function, and connective tissue development. The 
liver is the main location of copper metabolism. AAFCO 
recommends a minimum of 7.3 mg/kg DM for dogs. Meats 
particularly from cattle are rich in Cu. Deficiencies cause 
neurological conditions, abnormal growth, changes in hair 
color, and bone issues. Some breeds of dogs (Skye Terriers, 
Bedlington, and West Highland White) are more suscep -
tible to liver toxicity (i.e., hepatitis and increases in liver 
enzymes) from excess copper.
Zinc (Zn)
Zinc helps with enzymatic functions, protein synthesis, 
carbohydrate metabolism, skin and wound healing, and the 
immune system. Excess supplementation of Zn can inter -
act with other minerals and causes decreased absorption. 
AAFCO recommends 120  mg/kg DM for dogs. Meats and 
fiber sources contain a high amount of Zn. Deficiencies in-
dicate stunted growth, hair loss, a weakened immune sys -
tem, and growth disorders. Some arctic breeds ( Siberian 
Huskies and Alaskan Malamutes) require supplementation 
even with adequate dietary food levels.
Manganese (Mn)
Manganese helps in fat and carbohydrate metabolism and 
bone and cartilage development also. AAFCO recommends 
5 mg/kg DM for dogs. Fiber sources and fish meals are rich 
in Mn. Deficiencies can cause poor growth and deformities 
of bone development.
Selenium (Se)
Selenium helps in normal thyroid function and is concerned 
with the immune system, protecting cells from oxidative 
damage. AAFCO requirements are 0.11  mg/kg DM for 
dogs. Liver, fish, and eggs are high in Se. Deficiencies are 
rare though Vit-E can act as a replacement for Se in some 
functions. Long-term deficiencies can cause anorexia and 
edema. More amount of Se causes foul-smelling breath, 
vomiting, muscle spasms, falling and weakness, excessive 
drooling, anorexia, trouble breathing, and odor from the 
mouth and nail issues.
Iodine (I)
Iodine helps in the proper function of the thyroid. It helps 
to regulate body temperature and is involved in growth and 
development, skin and hair repair, and neuromuscular func-
tion. AAFCO recommends 1.5  mg/kg DM for dogs. Fish, 
eggs, and iodized salts are high in iodine. Iodine also found 
in commercial foods includes calcium iodate, potassium 
iodide, and cuprous iodide. Deficiencies and excessive 
amounts cause goiter, including enlarged thyroid glands, 
hair loss, lethargy, weakness, and fever.
7 Water requirements for dogs
Water requirement is determined by the amount of food that 
the animal consumes. Generally, animals require 1  mL of 
water for each kcal of energy. If a dog requires 1000 kcal per 
day, it requires 1000 mL of water. As food intake increases, 
water intake also increases. When the water content of a diet 
increases, animal drinks less water.
Water is considered the most essential nutrient since it 
performs many important activities, such as:
● Protect the nervous system
● Body temperature regulations
● Given that shape and structure to the body
● Helps in the breakdown of carbohydrates, proteins, and 
fats
● Lubricate joints
● Keep the shape of the eyes
Pets acquire water through diet and by drinking water. 
Generally, on average, the daily water requirement for an 
adult dog is 2.5 times of the amount of dry matter they con-
sume. This depends on many factors that affect the body 
(age, gender, size, stress, etc.) and the volume of dry matter 
which is consumed through the diet. Generally, a dog fed a 
moist diet will drink a smaller amount of water throughout 
the day due to higher moisture content (about >75% less).
8 Homemade balanced dog food?
Homemade feed for dogs  is possible. Feeding companion 
animals with commercial foods is not popular for economic 
reasons in developing countries. Pets are fed with home -
made foods or leftovers of food consumed in a family. So, it 
is essential to ensure that the dietary nutrient requirements 
are met through such feeding practices. Judicious inclusion 
of supplemental nutrients, and deficits in homemade or left-
over food can overcome nutritional deficiency disorders & 
support healthier life (Morelli et al., 2021).
8.1 The right puppy food?
Puppies require about two times higher calories per pound 
of body weight compared to an adult dog of the same breed.

Nutritional strategies of dogs and cats  Chapter | 3  43
Have to start feeding puppies a nutritious and exactly for -
mulated puppy food at around 4  weeks of age when the 
mother’s milk becomes insufficient. Generally, all puppies 
below 10 pounds should be fed 3 times in a day and those 
who are heavier than 10 pounds can be slowly weaned to 
twice-a-day feeding. Feeding with a routine will get their 
appropriate health with house training. Overeaten some 
breeds allowed them to gain too many calories, so one has 
to keep in mind to monitor their weight gain regularly with 
consultation of a veterinarian. Puppy food contains 25%–
30% protein.
9 Classification of pet food based on 
the nutrient content
9.1 Complete food
It is a food that provides all the nutrients required by the 
animal for 24 h.
9.2 Complementary food
This food is a food that provides only a part of the nutrients 
required by the animal for 24 h and the rest is met from ad-
ditional supplements.
9.3 Mixer biscuit
Mixer biscuit provides only essential nutrients.
9.4 Snack/treat
Snack/treats are foods to entertain/reward pet animals.
10 Dog food recommendations for 
overweight dogs
Nowadays, fatness becomes a common problem with dogs. 
Stress on an overweight dog may increase the risk of:
● Arthritis
● Diabetes
● Low energy
● Joint pain
● Exercise intolerance
Obesity occurs when energy intake exceeds than its re -
quirements (or the number of calories burned through activ-
ity and exercise). The surplus energy is stored as fat which 
stored as fat causes obesity. A maximum of dogs become 
obese due to overfeeding along with lack of exercise. The 
best way to manage obesity is to:
● Modify Feeding Habits:  It includes feeding smaller 
amount of feed more frequently to keep the dog from 
excessive hunger.
● Correct dog’s diet: Overweight dog has to reduce cal -
orie and also increase the fiber in diet which includes 
vitamins and minerals to maintain coat and skin health 
during dieting. Canned foods may be a better option due 
to fewer amounts of carbohydrates.
● Increase Exercise:  Both frequency and duration of 
exercise should be increased daily or longer exercise 
sessions. Regular exercise burns reduce appetite, more 
calories, changes body composition, and also increases 
metabolic rate.
11 Nutritional strategy to prevent 
disease in healthy dogs and cats
11.1 Feeding the healthy dog and cat
Healthy pet animals usually consume a sufficient amount of 
food to fulfill the energy requirements. The most metabolic 
stress occurs during growth, gestation, and lactation and the 
minor diet is most likely to result in nutritional problems. 
The maximum of commercial pet foods is formulated to as-
certain the sufficient intake of all necessary nutrients on the 
basis of energy intake.
11.2 How much to feed?
Prior to the recommendation of an amount to feed, the pet 
should experience a thorough physical examination to ensure 
that it is fit. On the basis of the physical examination, the ani-
mal’s body weight and body condition score (BCS) should 
be noted, as this information is crucial to determine the final 
feeding recommendations. A BCS is a one-sided evaluation 
of body composition that has been validated to compare with 
more quantitative determines of body condition, dual-energy 
X-ray absorptiometry (Laflamme et  al., 1994). Some BCS 
systems have been planned using 3, 5, or 9 points. The fa -
vored system is different from man to man. The five-point 
system scored to the nearest 1/2 unit is equivalent in selective 
capability to a nine-point system scored to the whole unit. 
When using the 5-point system, a 3 out of 5 is measured per-
fectly. Each point on the 5-point scale highlights an increase 
or decrease of 21%–30% in body fat below or above the ideal 
(i.e., 1 very thin and 5 fatty). A 4 or 5 out of 9 is measured 
as ideal when using the 9-point system. Each consequent 
point on the 9-point scale reflects an increase or decrease of 
11%–16% in body fat below or above the ideal (i.e., 1 thin 
and 9 grossly fatty). More significant than the system that the 
selection of a system that is used constantly on every patient.
Preferably the volume of food to feed a pet should be de-
termined by combining the data from the exam, body weight, 
and body condition score with a diet record. Diet record 
forms should be gathered and updated for every patient reg-
ularly. Information that should be incorporated in every diet 
record form includes, form (i.e., dry, canned, or  semimoist),

44 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
the specific product name and manufacturer of the pet’s 
diet, quantitative data on how much the pet is consuming 
daily, details regarding names and amounts of snacks and 
treats, information about who feeds the pet and the setting 
in which the pet eats their food. When owners are preparing 
homemade feed for the pet’s meals, details of ingredients 
and supplements as well as preparation methods should be 
recorded. When the pets are in an ideal body status, weight 
stable, and otherwise healthy, the recommendation of the 
amount of feeding is currently consuming provided an exact 
and detailed diet record is available ( Morgan et al., 2017 ). 
Determination of number of calories to feed may be more 
difficult if a diet record is unavailable. Maximum pet foods 
give guidelines on the product label and these can be used 
as an origin point. However, it is vital to understand that 
these guidelines are imperfect. Controlled studies have rec-
ognized that energy requirements may vary among similar 
animals though they are housed in similar conditions (NRC, 
2006). If it is essential to calculate the pet’s energy require-
ments, the recommendations are to determine the animal’s 
maintenance energy requirement (MER) by using the rest -
ing energy requirement (RER) equation and then multiply -
ing by the factor for the appropriate life stage ( Thatcher 
et al., 2010) in spite of using the single MER equation. This 
approach is more conventional and leads to less frequent 
misjudging of the actual energy needs of the pet.
11.3 How to feed?
There are mostly three types of feeding practices that can use 
to feed their dog or cat. They are free-choice feeding (ad li-
bitum or self-feeding), time-restricted feeding, and portion-
controlled feeding (meal feeding). It is also not unusual to 
observe more than one of these used in the same pets. Ad li-
bitum feeding confirms that there is an excess of food avail-
able at all times and relies upon the pet maintaining its daily 
caloric intake. That type of feeding allows cats to eat several 
small amounts of meals throughout the day, closely mimick-
ing their natural feeding behavior ( Kane et al., 1981 ). This 
type of feeding provides a minimal amount of work on be -
half of the owner, ensuring that subsidiary animals in several 
pet households have the chance to eat and help to minimize 
the noise connected with feeding, and may relieve dullness 
in kenneled animals. In addition, there may be an advantage 
relating to energy balance due to meal-induced energy loss. 
The disadvantages related to ad libitum feeding practice in-
clude the likelihood of avoiding medical problems, anorexia, 
and the rejection of food to subsidiary animals. It has been 
suggested that 31%–40% of dogs and cats will eat too much 
if food is available at all times ( NRC, 2006), so this type 
of feeding increases the chance that an animal will become 
fatty. Dry food may feed by pets in this manner.
Like ad libitum feeding, time-restricted feeding depends 
upon the animal’s capability to control their daily caloric 
intake. At meal time, an excess of food is given and the pet 
is allowed to consume for a time period. This type of feed -
ing is most relevant to dogs but not sensible for cats. The 
major advantages of this type are that it does not necessary 
much effort by the owner may be used with any type of 
pet food and permits some concentration of the dog’s food 
intake. This form of feeding may be unsuitable for choosy 
animals and may support gluttony and aerophagia. With 
portion-controlled feeding, the dog or cat is given an ex -
act amount of food, frequently divided into two meals per 
day. This method of feeding is the best approach for both 
dogs and cats in all stages of life excluding gestation/lacta-
tion (Schlesinger and Joffe, 2011 ). This type allows care -
ful monitor of the pet’s food intake, lowers the chance of 
fattiness, and alerts the owner of any medical problems. 
Offering food to one’s pet is an important part of human-
animal bonding and should be incorporated into a diet plan 
for every patient. Intake from snacks should not exceed 
8%–10% of the animal’s total daily calories. Few marketed 
products for dogs and cats are shown in Figs. 5–7.
FIG. 5 Feed for gastrointestinal problem in dogs.

Nutritional strategies of dogs and cats  Chapter | 3  45
11.4 What to feed?
One question is, “What is the best food for the pet?” The 
answer is “There is not one diet best for every cat or dog 
specifically. Cats and dogs are individuals for that reason 
the best diet will vary from animal to animal.” It is impor -
tant to judge three factors; the animal in question, the vari -
ety of exterior factors that may control how and what the 
animal is fed, and then lastly the product itself. There are 
major factors related to the animal diet. Not only  consider 
the animal’s age, species, breed, and sexual status but also 
its body condition, activity levels, and food or texture pref-
erences. External factors can have a powerful influence on 
final dietary recommendations for the pet. The diet and how 
the animal is fed may be influenced by its environment 
which includes but is not partial to the number and type of 
the animals in the household, where the animal is housed 
(i.e., indoors versus outdoors), the human inhabitants of 
the house (i.e., a household with small children, elderly 
FIG. 6 Feed for renal problem in dogs.
FIG. 7 Feed for cats.

46 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
 individuals or adults only), and the feeding practices of the 
owner. After monitoring the patient and the other factors in 
that animal’s environment, reflection needs to be given to 
the product itself (Berschneider, 2002). It is vital to choose 
a diet that supports the life stage of the patient that one is 
feeding and a lean body status when fed with an appropriate 
amount. The recommendations are feeding foods produced 
by larger manufacturers, if there is any problem with a diet, 
likely to be detected sooner. Strong suggestion should be 
given to companies that occupied animal nutritionists and 
support research in an effort to repeatedly improve foods 
and the knowledge about dog and cat nutrition. When stat -
ing specific recommendations, the foods have undergone 
and passed feeding trials in accordance with the Association 
of American Feed Control Officials’ (AAFCO) guidelines 
(2009) (Wichert et al., 2009).
