Chapter 4
Clinical examination and diagnostic 
perspectives in dogs and cats
1 Introduction
The various physical examinations and diagnostic techniques 
are used by a doctor to determine the causes of illness accu-
rately, safely, and quickly and help to monitor the progress 
of treatments and conditions. Physical examination of dogs/
cats is a process for evaluating various anatomical findings 
through the uses of observation (looking at the body), pal -
pation (feeling the body with fingers or hands), percussion 
(tapping body parts with fingers, hands, or small instruments 
as part of a physical examination), and auscultation (listen-
ing to sounds) ( Swartz and Swartz, 2021). Diagnostic tests 
are used to find out the disease or condition of patients based 
on their signs and symptoms. These tests may also be used to 
help in planning treatment, finding out how well treatment is 
working, and making a prognosis. Diagnostic tests are either 
invasive or noninvasive. Invasive diagnostic testing involves 
puncturing to skin or entering the body. Examples are taking 
a blood sample, biopsies, and colonoscopies. Noninvasive 
diagnostic testing does not involve making a break in the 
skin examples that are X-ray, CT scan, etc.
2 Noninvasive diagnostic tests
The most common noninvasive diagnostic tests in pets are 
the following:
1. X-rays—A very simple cheap and less time-consuming 
procedure to detect the cause of pain, and fractures in 
various parts of the body ascertain the severity of an in-
jury, monitor the progression of diagnosed disease, and 
impact of ongoing treatment.
2. CT scan—A CT scan is a diagnostic imaging procedure 
that uses a combination of X-rays and computer technol-
ogy to produce images of the inside of the body. It shows 
detailed images of any part of the body, including the 
bones, muscles, fat, organs, and blood vessels. CT scans 
are more detailed than X-rays (Johns Hopkins Medicine, 
Based in Baltimore, Maryland, n.d. ). Diagnose muscle 
and bone disorders, such as bone tumors and fractures. 
Pinpoint the location of a tumor, infection, or blood clot. 
Guide procedures such as surgery, biopsy, and radiation 
therapy. Detect and monitor diseases and conditions such 
as cancer, heart disease, lung nodules, and liver masses 
(Mayo Clinic). Other well-known diagnostic technique 
helps veterinarian/practitioner to view cross sections of 
body parts. The cross-sectional images generate images 
that are high in detail as compared to a regular X-ray.
3. MRI—Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a type of 
scan that uses strong magnetic fields and radio waves to 
produce detailed images of the inside of the body. An 
MRI scanner is a large tube that contains powerful mag-
nets. You lie inside the tube during the scan (NHS). MRI 
involves the use of radio waves with magnetic fields as 
opposed to ionizing radiation used in CT scans. The lack 
of radiation makes MRI safer than CT scans but the cost 
is higher and quite time-consuming.
4. Ultrasound—An ultrasound is an imaging test that uses 
sound waves to create a picture (also known as a sono -
gram) of organs, tissues, and other structures inside the 
body. Unlike X-rays, ultrasounds do not use any radia -
tion. An ultrasound can also show parts of the body in 
motion, such as a heart beating or blood flowing through 
blood vessels. There are two main categories of ultra -
sounds: pregnancy ultrasound and diagnostic ultrasound.
a. Pregnancy ultrasound  is used to confirmation of 
pregnancy, the number of fetuses, and their posi -
tion in the uterus, also use to detection of gestational 
age, check for signs of down syndrome, and check 
for birth defects in the brain, spinal cord, heart, or 
other parts of the body. This test can provide infor -
mation about a baby’s growth, development, and 
overall health. Check the amount of amniotic fluid. 
Amniotic fluid is a clear liquid that surrounds a fetus 
during pregnancy. It protects the fetus from outside 
injury and cold. It also helps to promote lung devel-
opment and bone growth (Medlineplus).

48 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
b. Diagnostic ultrasound  helps in the detection of 
any abnormalities in internal parts (heart, blood ves-
sels, liver, bladder, kidneys, and female reproductive 
organs.) of the body. This test helps in identifying 
the cancerous and noncancerous growths on vital 
organs, and also detects any abnormalities in the ab-
domen and kidneys. Help in a guided biopsy proce -
dure. A biopsy is a procedure that removes a small 
sample of tissue for testing (Medlineplus).
3 Invasive pathology test
The most common noninvasive diagnostic tests in pets are 
the following:
3.1 Complete blood count (CBC)
The complete blood count or CBC gives information about 
a dog’s/cat’s blood clotting ability, hydration status, anemia, 
infection, and immune system response. CBC is essential 
for dogs/cats that have symptoms like fever, vomiting, di -
arrhea, weakness, pale gums, and loss of appetite. CBC is 
used to identify and quantify white blood cells, red blood 
cells, and platelets in a given amount of blood. This includes 
analyzing the shape and condition of the cells for health and 
functionality. This information is helpful in learning more 
about a dog’s/cat’s immune system (white blood cells) and 
oxygen-carrying capacity (red blood cell count) (Leelanau 
Veterinary Care).
A. Hematocrit (HCT): With this test, we can identify the 
percentage of red blood cells to detect hydration or 
anemia, RBC (red blood cells) are produced in bone 
marrow, to carry oxygen in the whole body. Red blood 
cells live in the bloodstream for about 100  days and are 
removed from the bloodstream by the spleen and liver. 
Red blood cell numbers can be decreased (anemia) if 
they are not produced in adequate numbers by the bone 
marrow, if their life span is shortened (a condition called 
hemolysis), or if they are lost due to bleeding. Numbers 
can be increased (polycythemia), usually due to the con-
centration of the blood due to dehydration. High levels 
of immature red blood cells can point to regenerative 
anemia. A complete blood count also includes a mea -
sure of hemoglobin, which is the actual substance in the 
red blood cell that carries oxygen (Leelanau Veterinary 
Care).
B. WBC (white blood cell) helps fight infections in pa -
tients. There are several types of white blood cells in 
the blood, including neutrophils (PMNs), lymphocytes, 
monocytes, eosinophils, and basophils. Lymphocytes 
are produced in lymph nodes throughout the body. The 
other white blood cell types are produced in the bone 
marrow. Neutrophils help to fight infection and also 
can be decreased in pets with bone marrow disease and 
some viral diseases. Lymphocytes also help fight infec-
tion and produce antibodies against infectious agents. 
Lymphocytes may be increased in puppies and kittens 
with an infection, and they can be decreased in severely 
stressed pets. Lymphocytes can be lost in some types 
of diarrhea. Certain drugs, such as prednisone, will de -
crease the number of lymphocytes in the bloodstream. 
Monocytes may be increased in pets with chronic infec-
tions. Eosinophils and basophils are increased in pets 
with allergic diseases, or parasitic infections (Leelanau 
Veterinary Care).
C. Platelets are produced in the bone marrow and are in -
volved in the process of making a blood clot. Platelets 
live for a few weeks and are constantly produced by the 
bone marrow. Low platelet counts occur in bone mar -
row damaged conditions, and does not produce them, 
or if the platelets are destroyed faster than normal. The 
two primary causes of platelet destruction are immune-
mediated destruction (ITP or IMT) and disseminated 
intravascular coagulation (DIC). Immune-mediated 
thrombocytopenia happens when the animal’s immune 
system destroys platelets. DIC is a complex problem 
in which blood clots form in the body using the plate -
lets faster than the bone marrow can produce new ones. 
Animals with a low platelet count bruise easily and may 
have blood in their urine or stool (Leelanau Veterinary 
Care).
D. Fibrinogen (FIBR): We can glean important informa -
tion about blood clotting from this test. High levels 
can indicate a dog is 30 to 40  days pregnant (Leelanau 
Veterinary Care).
3.2 Blood biochemistry
In blood biochemistry, several tests are recommended by a 
veterinarian, some of the common tests in pets (Rau Animal 
Hospital, n.d.) are the following:
A. Total protein  includes albumin and larger proteins 
called globulins, which include antibodies. Total pro -
tein can be increased if the dog or cat is dehydrated or 
if the pet’s immune system is being stimulated to pro -
duce large amounts of antibodies. The total protein is 
decreased in the same situations that reduce albumin or 
if the pet has an abnormal immune system and cannot 
produce antibodies (Rau Animal Hospital, n.d.).
B. Albumin is a small protein produced by the liver. 
Albumin acts as a sponge to hold water in the blood 
vessels. When blood albumin is decreased, water vol -
ume in the blood is low; the pressure created by the 
heart forcing blood through the blood vessels causes 
fluid to leak out of the blood vessels and accumulate in 
body cavities or tissues as edema. Albumin is decreased

Clinical examination and diagnostic perspectives in dogs and cats  Chapter | 4  49
if the liver is damaged and cannot produce an adequate 
amount of albumin or if albumin is lost through a dam -
aged intestine or in the urine due to kidney disease. The 
only cause of increased albumin is dehydration ( Rau 
Animal Hospital, n.d.).
C. Alkaline phosphatase originates from many tissues in 
the body. When alkaline phosphatase is increased in the 
bloodstream of a dog, the most common causes are liver 
disease, bone disease, or increased blood cortisol from 
specific drugs or because the animal has Cushing’s dis -
ease (hyperadrenocorticism). In cats, the most common 
causes of increased alkaline phosphatase are liver and 
bone disease (Rau Animal Hospital, n.d.).
D. ALT is an enzyme produced by liver cells. Liver dam -
age causes ALT to increase in the bloodstream ( Rau 
Animal Hospital, n.d.).
E. Amylase is an enzyme produced by the pancreas and the 
intestinal tract that helps the body break down sugars. 
Amylase may be increased in the blood in animals with 
inflammation (pancreatitis) or cancer of the pancreas 
(Rau Animal Hospital, n.d.).
F. Bile acids  are produced by the liver and are involved 
in fat breakdown. A bile acid test is used to evaluate 
the function of the liver and the blood flow to the liver. 
Patients with abnormal blood flow to the liver, a condi -
tion known as portosystemic shunt, will have abnormal 
levels of bile acids. The bile acid test measures a fasting 
blood sample and a blood sample 2  h after eating ( Rau 
Animal Hospital, n.d.).
G. Bilirubin is produced by the liver from old red blood 
cells. Bilirubin is further broken down and eliminated 
in both the urine and stool. Bilirubin is increased in the 
blood in patients with some types of liver disease, gall -
bladder disease, or when red blood cells are being de -
stroyed at a faster than normal rate (hemolysis). Large 
amounts of bilirubin in the bloodstream will give a yel -
low color to nonfurred parts of the body, which is called 
icterus or jaundice (Rau Animal Hospital, n.d.).
H. BUN (blood urea nitrogen)  is influenced by the liver, 
kidneys, and dehydration. Blood urea nitrogen is a waste 
product produced by the liver from proteins from the 
diet and is eliminated from the body by the kidneys. A 
low BUN can be seen with liver disease and an increased 
BUN is seen in pets with kidney disease. The kidneys 
must be damaged to the point that 75% are nonfunc -
tional before BUN will increase. Pets that are severely 
dehydrated will have an increased BUN (Leelanau 
Veterinary Care).
I. Calcium in the bloodstream originates from the bones. 
The body has hormones that cause the bone to release 
calcium into the blood and to remove calcium from 
the blood and place it back into the bone. Abnormally 
high calcium in the blood occurs much more commonly 
than low calcium. High blood calcium is commonly 
 associated with cancer. Less common causes are bone 
disease, poisoning with certain types of rodent bait, 
chronic kidney failure, and primary hyperparathyroid -
ism, which is overfunction of the parathyroid gland 
(Rau Animal Hospital, n.d.).
J. Low blood calcium may occur in dogs and cats just be-
fore giving birth or while they are nursing their young. 
This is called eclampsia and occurs more commonly in 
small-breed dogs. Eclampsia causes the animal to have 
rigid muscles, which is called tetany. Another cause of 
low blood calcium is the malfunction of the parathy -
roid glands that produce a hormone (PTH) that controls 
blood calcium levels. Animals poisoned with antifreeze 
may have very low blood calcium (Leelanau Veterinary 
Care).
K. Cholesterol is a form of fat. Cholesterol can be in -
creased in the bloodstream for many reasons in dogs. It 
is much less common for cats to have increased choles-
terol. Some of the diseases that cause elevated choles -
terol are hypothyroidism, Cushing’s disease, diabetes, 
and kidney diseases which cause the protein to be lost in 
the urine. High cholesterol does not predispose dogs and 
cats to heart and blood vessel disease as it does in people 
(Rau Animal Hospital, n.d.).
L. Creatinine is a waste product that originates from mus-
cles and is eliminated from the body by the kidneys. An 
elevation of creatinine is due to kidney disease or dehy-
dration. Both creatinine and BUN increase in the blood-
stream at the same time in patients with kidney disease 
(Leelanau Veterinary Care).
M. Creatinine kinase (CK) is released into the blood from 
damaged muscle. Elevation of creatinine kinase sug -
gests damage to muscle, including the heart muscle 
(Leelanau Veterinary Care).
N. Glucose is blood sugar. Glucose is increased in dogs and 
cats with diabetes mellitus. It may be mildly increased 
in dogs with Cushing’s disease. Glucose can temporar -
ily increase in the blood if the dog or cat is excited by 
having a blood sample drawn. This is especially true of 
cats. A quick test to determine whether a glucose ele -
vation is transient or permanent is to look at the urine. 
If the glucose is chronically elevated, there will be an 
increased amount of glucose in the urine as well. Low 
blood sugar occurs less commonly and can be a sign 
of pancreatic cancer or overwhelming infection (sepsis). 
Low blood sugar can cause collapse, seizures or coma, 
and depression (Leelanau Veterinary Care).
O. Lipase is another pancreatic enzyme that is responsible 
for the breakdown of fats. It can be increased in pa -
tients with pancreatic inflammation or cancer (Leelanau 
Veterinary Care).
P. Phosphorus—Elevations in this test are often associ -
ated with kidney disease, hyperthyroidism, and bleeding 
disorders. The bloodstream originates from bones and

50 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
is controlled by the same hormone, PTH (parathyroid 
hormone) that controls blood calcium. Phosphorus is in-
creased in the bloodstream in dogs and cats with chronic 
kidney disease (Leelanau Veterinary Care).
Q. Potassium is increased in the bloodstream in the pet 
with acute kidney failure. Potassium is lost from the 
body in vomit, diarrhea, and urine. Pets that are not eat-
ing may have low blood potassium, which can cause the 
pet to feel weak. Cats with low potassium may develop 
painful muscles. High levels can lead to cardiac arrest 
(Leelanau Veterinary Care).
R. Sodium is an electrolyte often lost in vomiting, diar -
rhea, kidney disease, and Addison’s disease. This test 
helps indicate hydration status, which may be slightly 
increased in the blood if the dogs and cats are dehy -
drated, although many dehydrated dogs and cats have 
normal blood sodium. Low blood sodium is commonly 
seen with Addison’s disease (hypoadrenocorticism) 
(Leelanau Veterinary Care).
3.3 Blood parasites in dogs
Different types of blood parasites are found in dog’s blood
A. Babesiosis is transmitted by ticks. It is a protozoan para-
site that infects red blood cells. Infection varies from 
a mild illness to a severe disease that rapidly results in 
death. Sometimes, the parasite causes a long-term dis -
ease with severe and progressive anemia. Babesiosis can 
be confused with other disorders that cause fever, ane -
mia, and destruction of red blood cells, jaundice, or red 
urine. Therefore, laboratory tests should be performed 
to confirm the diagnosis.
B. Hemotropic Mycoplasmas (Hemoplasmas)  
Mycoplasma haemocanis is a blood parasite that lives 
in the red blood cells of affected dogs. Infections do not 
cause any typical signs, but red blood cell destruction 
(hemolysis) can be seen in dogs. The parasites are trans-
mitted through the transfer of infected blood or through 
the bites of lice, flies, ticks, and mosquitoes. Blood tests 
help to diagnose the presence of parasites.
C. Hepatozoonosis—Hepatozoonosis is a disease of wild 
and domestic carnivores caused by a Hepatozoon pro-
tozoan. This organism is transmitted by ticks, its mode 
of transmission is unusual. The tick picks up the organ -
ism from an infected host while biting the animal. An 
uninfected dog gets the disease by eating the tick (or 
animals that ate a tick), not from being bitten by the tick. 
In most of the world, the protozoan Hepatozoon canis is 
transmitted by the brown dog tick, causing Old World 
hepatozoonosis. Infected dogs have no signs of infection 
or only mild signs. Having a suppressed immune system 
due to another disease appears to play an important role 
in the development of significant signs. Dogs older than 
4 to 6 months old are usually resistant to infection with 
H. canis. However, H. americanum causes severe signs 
even in adult dogs.
D. African Tsetse-transmitted Trypanosomiasis
i. Trypanosoma affects all domestic animals. In dogs, 
Trypanosoma brucei is most likely to cause disease. 
Infected tsetse flies inject the protozoa into the skin 
of animals, where they grow for a few days and cause 
localized swellings called chancres. They enter the 
lymph nodes, then the bloodstream, where they mul-
tiply quickly. The severity of the disease varies with 
the species and age of the animal infected and the 
species of trypanosome involved. The incubation pe-
riod is usually 1 to 4  weeks. The primary signs are 
fever, anemia, and weight loss. The eyes are often 
affected. Internally, the lymph nodes and spleen are 
usually swollen. The diagnosis is confirmed by labo-
ratory testing to identify trypanosomes in the blood 
of an infected dog.
ii. Surra (Trypanosoma evansi Infection)
Surra is usually transmitted by other biting flies that 
are found within and outside tsetse fly areas. It is 
mostly a disease of horses and camels, but all do -
mestic animals are susceptible. The disease can be 
deadly, particularly in horses, camels, and dogs. The 
development and effects of the disease, signs, physi-
cal changes, diagnosis, and treatment are similar to 
those of the tsetse-transmitted trypanosomes.
iii. Chagas’ disease (Trypanosoma cruzi Infection)
Chagas’ disease is caused by infection with another 
trypanosome, Trypanosoma cruzi . Insects transmit 
the disease between susceptible species of animals. 
Birds are not affected. The disease occurs most of -
ten in people and dogs. Dogs may become infected 
and introduce the trypanosome into houses where 
the bugs are present. People and dogs become in -
fected by contamination of wounds or by eating food 
contaminated with insect droppings that contain try-
panosomes. Affected dogs may die suddenly or have 
short- or long-term inflammation of the heart muscle. 
Other signs include swollen lymph nodes, decreased 
appetite and energy, weakness, vomiting, diarrhea, 
and an enlarged liver or spleen. Patients with long-
term infections can develop life-threatening heart 
failure. The disease is diagnosed by identifying the 
parasite or antibodies in an animal’s blood, Chagas’ 
disease is controlled by reducing the number of in -
sects that spread the disease.
3.4 Urine analysis
Urinalysis is the examination of normal and abnormal con-
stituents of urine. Complete urinalysis includes the exami -
nation of color, odor, turbidity, volume, pH, specific gravity,

Clinical examination and diagnostic perspectives in dogs and cats  Chapter | 4  51
protein, glucose, ketones, blood, erythrocytes, leukocytes, 
epithelial cells, casts, crystals, and organisms. It is used 
mainly to assess the health urinary system, can also reveal 
problems in other organ systems, and is important for diag-
nosing metabolic diseases such as diabetes mellitus. Urine 
samples examined as soon as possible after collection to 
prevent environmental artifacts.
3.4.1 Physical examination of urine
A. Color of urine in healthy dogs and cats is transparent and 
light yellow, yellow, or amber. The color intensity varies 
considerably with the concentration of urine, diet, medi-
cations, and the animal’s hydration status. Concentrated 
urine is dark yellow, whereas dilute urine is pale yellow. 
In comparison with standard yellow, darker yellow color 
is observed in the case of bilirubin and its associated 
products. Hematuria or hemoglobin may give red or 
brown color, whereas myoglobin gives a reddish-brown 
appearance. In cats, various drugs and foods have also 
been documented to cause urine discoloration. In cats, 
urine discoloration can occur after treatment with the 
antibiotics clofazimine (pink to brown) and rifampicin 
(orange-red) (Archer et al., 2005 ; Sink and Weinstein, 
2012). Some other abnormal colors of urine are seen in 
various causes, colorless or light yellow seen in dilute 
urine, milky white in pyuria, lipiduria, phosphate crys -
tals, and sperm in males.
B. Odor—Urine substances are intermediate or end prod -
ucts of several metabolic pathways, and they contain a va-
riety of structural patterns, such as ketones, alcohol, and 
sulfide, which often cause a particular smell. For certain 
instances, signature urine odors were specifically linked 
to particular biochemical conditions, and the sources of 
the odors were established (Mary, 2004). Standard urine 
has a faint odor of ammonia; nevertheless, the odor de -
pends on the urine quantity. It was reviewed that the odor 
can differ depending on the cat’s gender ( Reppas and 
Foster, 2016). Some odors suggest urinary infections: 
Ammonia (the urease-producing bacteria), putrid protein 
odor degraded by bacteria (gross hematuria and blood 
clots), and a hydrogen sulfide odor that may linger in uri-
nary tract infection induced by Proteus species ( Pages, 
2002). An acetone odor may be noted in urine from ani-
mals with ketosis/ketoacidosis (Mary, 2004). Urine odor 
may not be considered pathognomonic for any specific 
disease (Reppas and Foster, 2016).
C. Clarity/transparency/turbidity—Urine is usually 
clear. Semen, mucus, feces, and lipid can cause turbid -
ity in normal urine. Increased numbers of cells, crystals, 
casts, or organisms may increase urinary turbidity under 
disease conditions (Mary, 2004). As a result of changes 
in temperature and pH of urine sample, artifactual tur -
bidity can occur.
D. Volume—Urine volume depends on the state of hydra -
tion and the kidney’s ability to concentrate; it is inversely 
related to the specific gravity (Mary, 2004). Normal cats 
produce 18–28 mL/kg/day of urine (5–60  mL/kg/day in 
kittens); polyuria has a urine concentration of more than 
40 mL/kg/day ( Charles, 2006 ). Normal dogs produce 
20–100 mL/kg/day of urine (Reece, 2015).
E. Specific gravity —USG indicates the weight ratio of 
1 L solution to 1  L water and provides valuable infor -
mation on the kidney’s ability to concentrate or dilute 
the urine ( Wyness et  al., 2016 ). USG (Urine Specific 
Gravity) is measured by a refractometer. Refractometers 
are designed for the species being examined and several 
forms are usable, including automated refractometers. A 
drop of urine is put under the plastic cover on the glass 
and held to a light source as the inspector stares through 
the eye (Rizzi et al., 2017). Feline urine is more refrac -
tive than human urine, so feline USG is overestimated 
by around 0.002–0.005 when human-designed refrac -
tometers are used. While refractive indexes of humans 
and dogs are identical (Rubini and Wolf, 1956), USG in 
healthy cats and dogs range between 1.001–1.085 and 
1.001–1.075, respectively (Watson et al., 2015).
3.4.2 Chemical examination
A. Urinary pH —The normal urinary pH range of dogs 
and cats is 6–7.5 ( Kennedy et  al., 2016 ; Rizzi, 2014 ) 
Meat consumption, respiratory and metabolic acidosis, 
extreme vomiting and diarrhea, nausea, pyrexia, protein 
catabolic states, and urinary acidifier (ammonium chlo-
ride, ascorbic acid at high doses, citric acid, and me -
thionine) are several causes of acid urine ( Reppas and 
Foster, 2016) Causes of alkaline urine include a recent 
meal, diets low in protein, vegetable and cereal-rich 
diets, alkali ingestion (bicarbonate or citrate), urease-
producing bacterial ( Staphylococcus aureus , Proteus 
species, and Klebsiella species), renal tubular acidosis, 
metabolic, and respiratory alkalosis and drugs including 
acetazolamide, sodium bicarbonate, chlorothiazide, and 
potassium citrate ( Reppas and Foster, 2016 ; Thornton 
et al., 2018). Containers standing open for prolonged pe-
riods before testing, resulting in loss of carbon dioxide, 
can also cause artifact alkaline urine
B. Protein—The presence of protein in urine is called 
proteinuria, in dogs and cats proteinuria, can be classi -
fied as prerenal, renal, and postrenal. Prerenal includes 
hemoglobin from intravascular hemolysis, myoglobin 
from rhabdomyolysis, and immunoglobulin light chains 
from multiple myeloma or lymphoma. Renal causes 
identified are strenuous exercise, fever, seizure, expo -
sure to extreme heat or cold, causes of glomerular injury 
or dysfunction, any causes of renal tubular dysfunction, 
and intestinal nephritis. In postrenal proteinuria urinary

52 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
tract infection, urolithiasis, transitional cell carcinoma, 
and vaginitis are common causes (Harley and Langston, 
2012).
C. Glucose may appear in the urine if glycemia surpasses 
the renal threshold or even if renal tubular reabsorption 
is reduced ( Melandri et  al., 2020 ). Glucosuria usually 
develops when the blood glucose level surpasses ap -
proximately 200 mg/dL in dogs and 250–300  mg/dL in 
cats (Behrend et al., 2018 ). Common causes of glucos -
uria are diabetes mellitus, stress, especially in cats, and 
renal dysfunction (Rizzi, 2014).
D. Ketones—Ketonuria suggests a change from the me -
tabolism of carbohydrates to that of fat. This shift is 
most closely identified in small animals with ketosis 
secondary to diabetes mellitus, but hunger also leads to 
increased ketones. These conditions are influenced by 
metabolic demands which go beyond the level that car -
bohydrate metabolism can provide (Rizzi, 2014).
E. Bilirubin is not present in the urine sample of most do-
mestic animals, except dogs. Small amounts of biliru -
bin can be detected in healthy dogs, especially in dilute 
urine (Rizzi, 2014).
F. Blood—The presence of either hematuria (presence 
of intact erythrocytes in the urine) or hemoglobinuria 
(due to lysed erythrocyte) can be shown to be positive 
for blood or urine or myoglobinuria caused by skeletal 
muscle damage (Piech and Wyscilo, 2019).
3.4.3 Microscopic examination
A. Red blood cells (RBC) or erythrocytes —In assessing 
gross hematuria, it is important to verify the presence of 
RBCs by microscopy (Popa et al., 2017).
B. White blood cells (WBCs) or leucocytes—Small num-
bers of white blood cells in a free-catch sample may not 
be significant, but in general, an increased number of 
white blood cells indicate inflammation somewhere in 
the urinary system. Inflammation is often secondary to 
bacterial infection.
C. Epithelial cells—Low epithelial cell counts are found 
in the urine of healthy animals, especially catheterized 
samples that sluggish cells and substitute for new cells. 
It is difficult to distinguish epithelial cells based on their 
size in unstained wet mounts (Rizzi, 2014).
D. Transitional epithelial cells —As the catheter passes 
through the normal cells, catheterized samples will have 
an increased number of transition cells. Increased num -
bers are also noticeable in urinary tract infections and 
uroliths (Barger et al., 2017).
E. Squamous epithelial cells —The skin, distal urethra, 
vaginal tract, or prepuce can be the source of squamous 
epithelial urine cells. Squamous urine cells are usually 
caused by sample contamination and are not significant 
clinically (Barger et al., 2017).
F. Microorganisms—Urine is sterile, and thus the pres -
ence of bacteria, yeast, and fungi in urine is never natu-
ral (Piech and Wyscilo, 2019).
G. Crystals—Crystals in urine are a frequent finding and it 
is not always associated with the disease (Willems et al., 
2017). Urine crystals other than struvite and calcium 
oxalate dihydride are highly indicative of underlying 
disease. Struvite occurs chiefly in basic urine ( Remichi 
et  al., 2020 ). Cystine crystals predispose to uroliths 
due to its low solubility in acidic urine. Calcium oxa -
late monohydrate crystals create suspicion of ethylene 
glycol toxicity. Ammonium biurate or uric acid crystals 
are suggestive of underlying liver disease but can be 
normal in Dalmatians and English Bulldogs ( Piech and 
Wyscilo, 2019).
H. Casts—Urinary casts (Hyaline, Cellular) are cylindri -
cal molds formed by the lumens of the renal tubules. In 
urine from a healthy animal <2, hyaline casts per low-
power film and more than 1 granular cast per low film 
are observed.
I. Urinary casts (Hyaline, Cellular) are cylindrical molds 
formed by the lumens of the renal tubules. In urine from 
a healthy animal <2, hyaline casts per low-power film 
and more than 1 granular cast per low film are observed. 
Increased numbers of urine casts (cylinduria) localize a 
process of disease in the kidneys (Rizzi, 2014).
J. Lipid droplets—Lipid droplets are commonly found in 
feline urine samples (Rizzi, 2014).
K. Spermatozoa—The presence of sperm does not have 
clinical consequences when seen in a urine sample from 
intact male patients ( Vap and Shropsire, 2017 ). High 
numbers may suggest retrograde ejaculation in catheters 
or cystocentesis (Ridley, 2018).
3.5 Dog and cat fecal exams
A fecal examination of pets can help to check for intestinal 
parasites, which are a major cause of illness, or even death, 
in pets. Fecal exams are not just necessary for keeping your 
pets healthy, but they are also essential for keeping fam -
ily members healthy. Some dog and cat parasites can infect 
people, especially very young children, very old adults, or 
people with weakened immune systems. Fecal exam was 
performed for diagnosis of roundworms, hookworms, 
whipworms, giardia, and coccidia. Some of these parasites, 
including roundworms, hookworms, and giardia, are espe -
cially dangerous as they can be passed from pets to humans 
and cause zoonotic diseases. Infestation of parasites spread 
through contaminated water, food, and soil, by grooming 
themselves (licking their own skin and fur) from interaction 
with other pets, including mother to litter. Pets with intes -
tinal parasites that have common abdominal pain, diarrhea, 
dehydration, rough hair coat, distending abdomen, weight 
loss, vomiting, lethargic behavior, melena (blood in stool),

Clinical examination and diagnostic perspectives in dogs and cats  Chapter | 4  53
intestinal blockage have no symptoms and appear healthy 
and so regular testing as of pets is necessary.
There are four ways to conduct an Intestinal Parasite 
Screen (IPS).
A. Direct Fecal Smear—In this technique, a fecal sample 
is spread on a glass slide and analyzed under a micro -
scope. This type of test is limited to testing for a spe -
cific parasite and has less utility when testing a pet for 
general intestinal parasite infestation. Additionally, this 
test is performed in conjunction with other types of fecal 
tests and should not be relied upon as a sole indicator of 
possible infestation
B. Basic Fecal Flotation Test—The fecal sample is mixed 
in a special solution. After an hour, the eggs of worms 
and protozoan cysts float to the surface and can be ob -
served under a microscope. This is a common method of 
fecal examination in veterinary practices today.
C. Fecal Centrifugation/Flotation Test —The fecal 
sample is mixed with a special testing solution (salt or 
sugar), and then centrifuged it prior to flotation as de -
scribed above. This extra step increases the likelihood 
of recovering parasites in the sample versus the basic 
flotation alone. A microscopic analysis of the parasites 
will allow for worm identification based on the size and 
shape of eggs and larvae. This fecal test method pro -
duces more accurate results and is considered the stan -
dard for fecal testing in pets.
D. Antigen testing —This test recommends for the fecal 
samples that are sent to an outside reference laboratory. 
A special test is performed to detect antigens, or special 
proteins, in the sample which is produced by the para -
sites. This allows for the detection of the parasites even 
when they are not actively producing eggs or if eggs are 
not contained in the sample. As such, this test gives a 
much more accurate result than flotation results alone 
and can be used as an accurate test even when a large 
enough sample for flotation testing is not available. The 
results are typically reported within 24 to 48  h. When 
combined with fecal centrifugation and flotation, the di-
agnostic capability of the test increases, and the chance 
of missing a parasite infestation becomes very small.
Skin Scraping  is a test used in the diagnosis of every 
skin problem. This test is specially used for the detection 
of mites, which are microscopic in size. Mites could not 
see with the naked eye and were positively diagnosed by a 
skin scraping and subsequent analysis of the scraped ma -
terial under the microscope. There are two types of mites 
that are commonly diagnosed by skin-scraping Sarcoptic 
mange and Demodex (cigar-shaped). Mites burrow into the 
skin or hair follicles, some burrowing deeper than others. 
Sometimes we need to perform several scrapings at various 
locations to find mites. Some mites have a propensity to af-
fect certain areas, so these are the areas we emphasize when 
we perform the test. Demodex mites are relatively easy to 
find under the microscope, while Scabies (Sarcoptes) mites 
can be very difficult to find under the microscope. 
Method of skin scraping  gently scrapes the surface of 
the skin with a scalpel blade when a very small quantity 
of blood oozed out. This will yield skin, hair, dander, and 
sometimes mites if they are present. When the scraping is 
performed properly, there will be a small irritated area on 
the skin. This signifies that the scraping was done thor -
oughly enough to find mites that burrow deep. The minor 
irritation will resolve in a short time and does not need 
any medication. Then, scraped material was transferred 
on a slide for viewing under the microscope. The slide is 
methodically analyzed for mites, mite eggs, or infection 
of fungi.

55

Chapter 5
Maintenance of fluids, electrolytes, and 
acid–base therapy in dogs and cats
1 Introduction
In clinical medicine, fluid therapy is used to achieve goals 
such as compensating for dehydration deficits, maintain -
ing proper hydration, replenishing lost electrolytes and 
nutrients, and acting as a conduit for the administration of 
certain intravenous drugs. The goals are similar for criti -
cally ill animals, except for the urgency of treatment. The 
procedures used to administer fluids frequently have an im-
pact on how the situation turns out. Therefore, physicians 
should be knowledgeable about the pathophysiology of 
the illnesses they are treating and how these ailments are 
associated with different kinds of commonly used fluids. 
The bodily fluids are grouped in functional compartments 
that are dynamic but well organized. Normal metabolic and 
physiological processes must be maintained in such com -
partments in terms of both content and volume. The electro-
lytes that are dissolved in body fluids play an essential role 
in almost every activity of life. Electrolyte transmembrane 
movements play a key role in many enzymatically driven 
metabolic activities as well as electrical events that lead 
to nerve transmission and muscular contractions. The pH 
of body fluids is maintained within specified limits. This 
is essential for maintaining the structure and function of 
proteins for the regular operation of metabolic activities. 
Almost all organ systems take part in maintaining fluid bal-
ance and/or are negatively impacted by imbalances. A state 
of disturbed fluid and electrolyte balance can be due to poor 
fluid intake, excessive fluid loss, or organ injury and mal -
function in many clinical states (El-Sharkawy et al., 2014). 
Successful patient care depends on accurate evaluation and 
the right therapy, regardless of whether fluid and electrolyte 
changes are the main issue or are merely secondary symp -
toms of another disease process. To accomplish this, one 
needs a thorough knowledge of the anatomy and physiol -
ogy of body fluids, the pathophysiologic mechanisms by 
which normal processes diverge, the methods for precisely 
identifying these disturbances, and finally the techniques 
for promptly, safely, and effectively correcting such distur-
bances (Tobias et al., 2022).
2 Body Fluid compartments
Water is essential for life. Normal physiological functions 
are hampered without water and if preventive measures are 
not taken, this might eventually result in death. Total body 
water (TBW) and fluid balance between the major physi -
ological compartments are maintained by appropriate fluid 
intake. A large portion of an animal’s body (60%) is made 
up of water. Homeostasis is maintained through the admin-
istration of various fluids in the body and the management 
of certain problems. It is crucial to have an awareness of the 
protein and electrolyte composition inside the body. Before 
moving ahead with a discussion of the evaluation of fluid 
imbalances or deficits, we need to take into account the or-
ganization and composition of the fluid compartments from 
which these losses occur. A comprehension of the forces 
that regulate the corresponding volume and composition of 
the body’s fluid compartments is important for understand-
ing both the clinical and clinicopathological indications of 
altered fluid balance. The distribution of total body water 
(TBW) within the bodies of the dog and cat is shown in 
Fig. 1.
2.1 Total body water
The most prevalent constituent in human and animal bod -
ies is water, where all fundamental physiological functions 
take place. Despite variations among different species, the 
majority of domestic animals have total body water (TBW) 
around 60% of body weight (0.60 L/kg), thus accounting 
for about 300 L in a 500 kg horse and 12 L in a 20 kg dog

56 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
(Kohn and DiBartola, 1992 ). This figure, however, may 
vary depending on age, gender, degree of obesity, and 
leanness of body mass. For instance, young animals like 
newborn pups and kittens have a considerably larger pro -
portion of water in their bodies than adults. Adipose tissue 
can contribute to an increased proportion of water in obese 
animals since it retains more water than muscle does, so 
body fat has a significant effect on the relative TBW. The 
huge TBW is mainly because of the extremely high extra -
cellular fluid (ECF) volume, which surpasses 0.40  L/kg at 
birth for most species. Within the first few days to weeks 
of birth, there is a quick initial drop and by 6 months of 
age, the TBW and ECF volumes are reaching adult values 
(Ku and Smith, 2015 ). The body’s compartments for wa -
ter are dispersed but connected. Intuitively, the body can 
be partitioned into extracellular and intracellular compart -
ments. About half to two-thirds of the TBW is accounted 
for by the ICF, while the remaining portion is accounted for 
by the ECF. Water is easily diffusible between these two 
compartments even though their electrolyte compositions 
are significantly different and they are in osmotic equilib -
rium. The amount of osmotically active molecules in each 
chamber plays a significant role in determining the relative 
volume distribution of water among these two chambers. 
The sodium concentration of the ECF determines its vol -
ume, whereas the potassium concentration determines the 
volume of the ICF.
2.2 Extracellular fluid volume
Instead of being firmly defined anatomically, the ECF is 
seen as a physiologic region. Depending on the animal spe-
cies and volume dilution technique used, the extracellular 
fluid volume of adult animals varies from 0.15 to 0.30  L/
kg body weight ( Carlson and Bruss, 2008 ). Extracellular 
fluid, or fluid outside of cells, makes up around one-third 
(33%) of the water in the body as a whole. The intravascular 
and interstitial compartments are additional divisions of ex-
tracellular fluid. The fluid that is kept inside blood vessels 
is found in the intravascular area. Plasma fluid,  proteins, 
 biological constituents, and different electrolytes pass via 
these channels. The region outside the blood vessels is 
known as the interstitial extravascular region. Interstitial 
fluid comprises 24% of TBW, whereas intravascular fluid 
only makes up 8%–10%. The joints, cartilage, cerebral 
space, and gastrointestinal tract all contain extremely mod-
est amounts of transcellular fluid. ECF volume maintenance 
is a complicated process in which many variables interact. 
The extracellular fluid (ECF) is made up of all the fluids 
present outside of the cells, including the interstitial fluid, 
plasma fluids (0.05 L/kg), and lymph (0.15 L/kg). The fluid 
volume of the gastrointestinal system is included in the 
transcellular fluids, which are typically thought of as a sub-
component of the ECF. The amount of fluid in the gastroin-
testinal system is often low in smaller animal species. The 
gastrointestinal tract often contains a significant amount of 
fluid in large animal herbivore species ( Cymbaluk, 2013). 
This gastrointestinal fluid storage can be used to maintain 
an efficient circulation volume during periods when water 
is deprived and some other types of dehydration. Sodium 
is present in the ECF fluids at levels ranging from 130 to 
150 mEq/L of water. The osmotic framework of the ECF 
is provided by sodium and the sodium level is the single 
most crucial factor affecting the amount of the ECF (Webb, 
2017). ECF volume declines during the shortage of sodium, 
whereas its excess is typically linked to water retention, 
causing edema (Gary et  al., 2008). The total body water 
content of a healthy dog ranges between 534 and 660  mL/
kg. In dogs and cats, the total intravascular fluid volume has 
been found to be 80–90 mL/kg. The amount of intravascular 
plasma water has been calculated to be around 50 mL/kg in 
dogs and 45 mL/kg in cats.
2.3 Intracellular fluid volume
The fluid content within cells is represented by the ICF 
volume, which contributes approximately two-thirds (66%) 
of total body water. This volume is computed as the dif -
ference between the recorded TBW and the estimated ECF 
volume since it cannot be measured directly. In a similar 
fashion to how sodium supplies the osmotic skeleton for 
the ECF, potassium does the same for the ICF. Water read-
ily diffuses within and out of the cell, causing changes in 
the ECF’s tonicity, which are quickly mirrored by equiva -
lent alterations in the ICF’s tonicity (Rondon-Berrios et al., 
2017). The migration of fluid throughout the cell membrane 
and the resulting variations in ICF volume are substantially 
responsible for alteration in its tonicity. Consequently, even 
water retention results in a drop in plasma sodium content 
while ICF volume rises. In contrast, the ICF volume falls as 
a result of hypernatremia brought on by water loss ( Asim 
et al., 2019). The division of intracellular water among the 
numerous organelles and subcellular regions is a subject of 
investigation during various pathological conditions.
FIG. 1 Distribution of total body water (TBW) within the body of a dog 
and cat.

Maintenance of fluids, electrolytes, and acid–base therapy in dogs and cats  Chapter | 5  57
3 Regulation of electrolytes and body 
fluids
There are several disorders of domesticated animals that 
occur due to disturbances of body fluids (free water), elec -
trolytes, and acid–base balance. Reduced circulating blood 
volume and tissue dehydration are the outcomes of an im -
balance in body water due to a greater loss of fluid that is 
eliminated from the body than is retained. On the other 
hand, consuming a lot of water quickly might cause over -
hydration (water intoxication). Electrolyte imbalances fre -
quently occur as a consequence of electrolyte loss, shifts in 
particular electrolytes, or absolute concentration alterations 
brought on by water loss. The majority of electrolyte imbal-
ances are brought on by a significant deficit of electrolytes 
caused by gastrointestinal tract diseases. Hyponatremia, hy-
pocalcemia, hypochloremia, and hypokalemia are common 
electrolyte abnormalities. In Table 1, the concentrations of 
the major anions and cations in plasma are listed.
The aforementioned changes in fluid and electrolyte 
balance will often take place simultaneously in most cir -
cumstances, to varying degrees, depending on the initial 
cause. The following are the factors that regulate the fluid 
and electrolyte balances:
3.1 Effective circulating volume or ECV
The portion of the ECF inside the vascular space and ac -
tively perfusing the tissues is referred to as the “effective 
circulating volume” (Ashoor and Somers, 2015 ). Effective 
circulating volume and ECF volume often fluctuate together 
in relation to total body sodium reserves. The fluid volume 
rises after sodium is added but decreases after its removal. 
Variations in cardiac output, renal sodium, vascular resis -
tance, and water excretion regulate the effective circulation 
volume. Cardiac output, venous return, and blood pressure 
drop with a reduction in circulation volume. Specialized 
volume receptors in the cardiopulmonary circulation and 
kidney sense reduction in pressure and volume and activate 
sympathetic tone, thereby increasing arterial and venous 
contraction, cardiac contractility, and heart rate. These re -
actions often boost cardiac output and systemic blood pres-
sure to make up for the volume loss.
3.2 Antidiuretic hormone
The osmolality of bodily fluids is primarily regulated by 
antidiuretic hormone (ADH). The hypothalamus produces 
antidiuretic hormone, which is secreted in response to 
variations in plasma osmolality. ADH release and plasma 
sodium concentration have a strong correlation because 
plasma osmolality is mostly determined by sodium content. 
Receptors in the hypothalamus detect changes in plasma 
osmolality and the body often reacts by increasing thirst to 
encourage water intake and releasing ADH, which boosts 
water reabsorption from renal collecting tubules. Activation 
of adenyl cyclase, which produces cyclic adenosine mono -
phosphate (AMP) and protein kinases, antidiuretic hormone 
affects the collecting tubules by changing their permeability 
to water (Rose, 1984).

3.3 Renin–angiotensin–aldosterone axis
The homeostasis of circulating fluid volume is maintained 
by the renin–angiotensin system. The JG cells of the glo -
merular afferent arteriole secrete rennin, a proteolytic en -
zyme, in response to decreased renal perfusion caused by 
hypotension, volume depletion, or elevated sympathetic 
activity. Renin changes the circulating globulin angioten -
sinogen into angiotensin I, which is further converted to 
angiotensin II, a potent vasoconstrictor, by the angiotensin-
converting enzyme (ACE) in the lung and vascular endo -
thelial cells, which rectifies hypotension. By promoting 
aldosterone production from the adrenal cortex, angiotensin 
II enhances renal retention of salt and water to correct hy -
povolemia (Scott et al., 2022).
Aldosterone plays an important role in the preservation 
of efficient circulating fluid volume and potassium balance, 
primarily via its impacts on renal resorption of sodium in 
return for potassium and hydrogen ions. The adrenal cor -
tex produces aldosterone, which interacts with cytoplasmic 
mineralocorticoid receptors (MRs) to form the aldosterone–
MRs complex, which triggers the NA-mediated synthesis of 
certain aqueous channel proteins, causing retention of water 
by renal collecting tubules. Aldosterone also affects potas -
sium and sodium absorption in the gastrointestinal tract and 
reduces the loss of electrolytes from sweat glands to counter 
salt depletion.
3.4 Atrial natriuretic factor (ANF)
Atrial natriuretic factor (ANF), a group of peptide hormones 
widely recognized as atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) and 
formed in the heart and released into the bloodstream in 
response to mechanisms, increases central venous pressure 
and stretches the atrial wall. Transmembrane receptors reg-
ulate the activities of ANF, which have a tendency to lower 
cardiac output and systemic blood pressure. Guanylyl cy -
clase produces cyclic guanidine monophosphate as a conse-
quence (Briggs et al., 2014). In the kidneys, ANF produces 
natriuresis and diuresis and also controls fluid volume in 
the brain.
4 Physiology of acid–base balance
The hydrogen ion level in ECF, which is typically 
40 nmol/L, is kept within extremely small bounds. This is 
around one-millionth the level of the other major electro -
lytes or 40  × 106 mmol/L. Hydrogen ions combine with 
cellular proteins to influence metabolic processes even at 
incredibly low quantities. The relationship between pH and 
hydrogen ion concentration is important because if the pH 
drops, the animal experiences acidosis due to an increase 
in hydrogen ion concentration and alkalosis after a fall in 
the concentration of hydrogen ions in the blood, as shown 
in Fig. 2. The conventional theory of acid–base equilibrium 
includes buffering both within and outside cells, controlling 
alveolar ventilation to low carbon dioxide levels, and regu-
lating renal hydrogen excretion ( Bheemasenachar, 2010). 
A buffer system is composed of a mildly dissociated acid 
and the salt of that acid. Variation in hydrogen ion levels 
is reduced due to buffering capacity of the body to take in 
or release hydrogen ions. Both intracellular and extracellu -
lar buffers contribute to the body’s buffering capacity. The 
bicarbonate (HCO3
−/H2CO3) and phosphate (HPO4/H2PO4) 
pairs as well as plasma proteins are examples of extracellu-
lar buffers. Organic and inorganic phosphates, proteins, and 
hemoglobin found in red blood cells serve as intracellular 
buffers.
FIG. 2 Conditions related to acid–base imbalance.

Maintenance of fluids, electrolytes, and acid–base therapy in dogs and cats  Chapter | 5  59
4.1 Metabolic acidosis
An increase in bicarbonate and a fall in pH are indicators of 
metabolic acidosis. According to the traditional view, either 
a reduction of bicarbonate ions or an increase of hydrogen 
ions might result in metabolic acidosis. In ECF, particularly 
the bicarbonate–carbonic acid pairs act as the first buffer 
during an acid load (Rose, 1984). The buffering mechanism 
is helped by intracellular buffers, mainly protein and phos -
phate. In response to an acid load, the intracellular migra -
tion of hydrogen ions in exchange for potassium ions serves 
to prevent an extreme rise in the ECF hydrogen ion content. 
Although the body’s overall potassium reserve reduces as 
a result of gastrointestinal or renal losses, this exchange, 
known as the cation shift, can still cause hyperkalemia. The 
most frequent reasons include renal failure, which may lead 
to a diminished capacity to eliminate hydrogen and conse -
quently retain bicarbonate and lactic acidosis, ketoacidosis, 
and gastrointestinal loss of bicarbonate, leading to diarrhea 
and other conditions ( Kraut and Madias, 2012 ). The com -
pensatory respiratory response of enhanced breathing will 
start lowering the pCO2 within minutes after the recognition 
of metabolic acidosis. For each mEq/L drop in bicarbonate, 
the respiratory reaction in dogs will result in a 0.7  mmHg 
reduction in pCO2 causing a drop in pH; however, the pro -
tective benefits of the respiratory response are temporary, 
lasting for a few days.
4.2 Respiratory acidosis
Respiratory acidosis is indicated by a drop in pH and a 
rise in pCO 2 and occurs due to a decline in alveolar ven -
tilation. The intracellular buffers almost entirely serve to 
first buffer the acid load brought on by respiratory acido -
sis. Respiratory acidosis cannot be buffered by the main 
ECF buffer and the bicarbonate–carbonic acid pair alone. 
Because carbon dioxide migrates through the lung consid -
erably more quickly than oxygen, conditions that impair 
ventilation typically cause drops in pO 2 before appreciable 
rises in pCO2. Increased pCO2 often serves as the primary 
stimulus for breathing because the respiratory center is 
particularly sensitive to even small alterations in pCO 2. 
Therefore, if the arterial pCO2 is maintained at normal lev-
els or increases due to intrinsic lung disease, ventilation 
will start to be improved as soon as the arterial pO 2 drops 
below 70–80 mmHg. Respiratory acidosis can result from 
any condition that impairs normal efficient breathing. Renal 
retention of bicarbonate is the compensatory reaction to re-
spiratory acidosis. A compensatory rise of 0.35  mEq/L of 
bicarbonate is predicted in dogs with chronic respiratory 
acidosis for every mm Hg rise in pCO2. Enhanced renal hy-
drogen secretion determines the magnitude of the increase 
in plasma bicarbonate levels in chronic respiratory acidosis 
(Koeppen and Stanton, 2013).
4.3 Metabolic alkalosis
A rise in pH and bicarbonate are signs of metabolic alkalo-
sis. Domestic animals can get metabolic alkalosis occasion-
ally, but ruminants with digestive issues are frequently found 
to be susceptible to it. An initial mechanism that can produce 
alkalosis is needed for the generation of metabolic alkalosis, 
as are other elements that are required for its maintenance. 
Increased hydrogen loss, bicarbonate accumulation, or con-
traction alkalosis all lead to the development of metabolic 
alkalosis. Reduced ECF fluid volume causes alkalosis be -
cause sodium- and chloride-containing fluid is lost or se -
questered without a corresponding decrease in bicarbonate. 
Metabolic alkalosis can be triggered by severe hydrogen ion 
depletion. In dogs and cats, vomiting-related gastrointesti -
nal losses constitute the most important causative factor for 
enhanced hydrogen loss. All of the elements that maintain a 
metabolic alkalosis compromise the renal bicarbonate out -
flow. The reduced glomerular filtration of bicarbonate found 
in some forms of renal failure may also be one of these con-
tributing mechanisms. However, the most frequent cause 
is enhanced renal tubular bicarbonate resorption, which is 
linked to the kidneys’ reactions to potassium and/or chloride 
deprivation and decreased effective circulating fluid volume. 
Hypokalemia is also another component that contributes to 
the maintenance of metabolic alkalosis (Rose, 1984).
4.4 Respiratory alkalosis
A rise in pH and a reduction in pCO2 are linked to respiratory 
alkalosis. Respiratory alkalosis is attributable to hyperventi-
lation, which may be induced by hypoxemia linked with con-
gestive heart failure, pulmonary disease, or severe anemia. 
In addition, neurologic conditions like salicylate poisoning 
or gram-negative bacterial sepsis that activate the medul -
lary respiratory center may be linked to hyperventilation. 
Animals in distress or experiencing pain may exhibit respira-
tory alkalosis. Dogs and other nonsweating animals requir-
ing respiratory evaporative mechanisms for heat loss to avoid 
overheating may experience hyperventilation (Tasker, 1980).
4.5 Mixed acid–base imbalances
Mixed acid–base disturbances occur when many primary acid–
base imbalances coexist. Respiratory acidosis or alkalosis may 
occur in conjunction with metabolic acidosis and/or alkalo-
sis disorders. Mixed acid–base disorders are unquestionably 
present in animals and have been described in the veterinary 
literature. The proper assessment of clinical and clinicopatho-
logical findings depends on an understanding of the possibil-
ity of the emergence of mixed abnormalities. When examining 
suspected mixed acid–base imbalances, it should be ensured 
that enough time has passed for the emergence of predicted 
compensatory reactions (Bhagavan and Ha, 2015).

60 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
4.6 Anion gap
The anion gap may be estimated as the difference between 
the detected cation (sodium) and the primary anions (chlo -
ride + bicarbonate) and is expressed as Anion gap = (Sodium 
+ Potassium) - (Chloride + Bicarbonate). Most domesticated 
animal species tend to have anion gaps that are similar to those 
reported for human beings, i.e., 10–20  mEq/L (Peter et  al., 
2017). Increased cationic protein polyclonal gammopathy 
(lgG), hyperchloremic acidosis, hypoalbuminemia and altered 
protein anionic equivalents decrease anion gaps, whereas 
 organic acids (lactic and keto acids), metabolic acidosis,  
hypovolemic shock, anaerobic exercise, diabetes, inorganic 
acids (sulfate and phosphate), grain overload, ketosis, uremic 
acidosis, nonmetabolizable acids, intoxication or poisoning 
with paraldehyde, salicylate, metaldehyde, metaldehyde, and 
poisoning with ethylene glycol and methanol increase anion 
gaps. The normal range of the blood gas and electrolyte deter-
minations in cats and dogs is shown in Table 2.
5 Assessment of imbalances
It is essential to know the difference between both volume 
regulation and osmoregulation. Osmoreceptors control 
 osmoregulation by affecting ADH and thirst; various vol -
ume receptors detect changes in volume and trigger effec -
tors like aldosterone. While increasing urine osmolality 
and increasing water absorption, the antidiuretic hormone 
has no effect on sodium transport. Aldosterone improves  
sodium absorption but not water absorption directly. As a 
result, volume regulation predominantly involves changes 
in sodium balance, while osmoregulation is accomplished 
by changes in the water balance. When water outflow from 
all routes equals water intake from all sources, water bal -
ance is attained. Water is accessible in three different forms: 
as drinking water, as feedstock water, and as metabolic wa-
ter produced by oxidative metabolism. After the oxidation 
of every 1 g of fat, carbohydrate, or protein, 1.07, 0.06, or 
0.41 g of water is produced, respectively. The four main 
ways that water leaves the body are through feces, urine, 
cutaneous water loss, insensible respiration, and in some 
animal species, sensible perspiration or sweat. Healthy 
animals are capable of keeping water balance within very 
small boundaries while at the same time ensuring the essen-
tial interaction between water balance and electrolyte bal -
ance, even though their day-to-day water intake and output 
may fluctuate significantly. Animals consume food to fulfill 
their caloric needs. Compared to animals eating dry hay or 
dried prepared pet food, which may contain less than 10% 
water, nursing or grazing animals may consume more than 
90% water in their feed.
5.1 Dehydration (water depletion)
In dogs and cats, dehydration is a somewhat common issue 
and occurs most often due to moderate to high fluid losses 
with inadequate water consumption. Serum sodium con -
centration and osmolality rise following water loss without 
or with little loss of electrolytes during panting or limited 
availability of feed and water. Hypertonic dehydration oc -
curs when fluid loss surpasses the loss of the replaceable 
sodium and potassium ions. The difference between total 
body water and exchangeable cations is referred to as a “rel-
ative water deficit.” ICF and ECF share water losses pro -
portionally and clinicopathological conditions result from 
excessive loss of water and electrolytes. Hypernatremia is 
attributed to the shrinkage of the ICF, leading to the con -
traction of the cells (Durrani et al., 2022). An isotonic fluid 
volume compression occurs when water losses are accompa-
nied by corresponding losses of exchangeable cations (i.e., 
130–150 mEq (130–150 retool) of sodium + potassium per 
liter of water lost). In many cases, isotonic dehydration de-
velops due to higher sodium loss than potassium. This form 
of dehydration is encountered in dogs and cats with severe 
diarrhea. The rise in serum sodium level from 140  mEq/L 
(140 mmol/L) to 155 mEq/L (155 mmol/L) indicates hyper-
tonic fluid volume contraction (Ackerman, 1990).
5.2 Overhydration (water excess)
Except in cases of sodium depletion and renal medullary 
washout, animals with psychogenic polydipsia are often ca-
pable of sustaining a proper water balance through sufficient 
renal water output. However, excessive fluid treatment for 
individuals with impaired renal function can lead to over -
hydration, which can happen iatrogenically. Plasma sodium
