content will decline if these fluids offer free water, such as 
with 5% dextrose, representing the shift in the relative wa -
ter balance. Saline or lactated Ringer’s solution, which are 
examples of isotonic sodium-containing replacement fluids, 
would enhance plasma and ECF volume without changing 
plasma sodium levels ( Epstein and Randall, 2006 ). This 
might result in cardiovascular overload, pulmonary edema, or 
systemic edema. The alterations in water balance in this case 
are secondary to sodium buildup, which is the main issue.
5.3 Sodium
About one-half to two-thirds of the body’s sodium is pres -
ent in the ECF volume. The majority of the sodium is bound 
in skeletal bone and only a small amount of it is quickly ex-
changeable. Thus, nearly all of the body’s easily accessible 
and exchangeable sodium is present in the ECF volume. 
The main factor affecting ECF volume is its transferable 
sodium content and sodium deficiency is the main factor 
contributing to reduced ECF volume ( Overgaard-Steensen 
and Ring, 2013 ). An increase in sodium concentration 
causes the ECF level to rise which may cause hypertension 
or edema. Regardless of the situation, the apparent plasma 
sodium content will mostly be influenced by relative water 
balance. Since it is difficult for dogs and cats to check their 
electrolyte balance on a regular basis, urine fractional ex -
cretion or creatinine clearance ratios have been considered 
as a substitute for daily consumption or possible imbalances 
of chloride, potassium, sodium, and other electrolytes.
5.3.1 Sodium depletion or hyponatremia
Sodium depletion is mostly related to extreme losses of 
sodium-containing fluid, usually arising as the consequence 
of gastrointestinal losses via diarrhea or vomiting. Dogs 
and cats with diarrhea that lasts for many days continue to 
lose a significant amount of sodium and the hyponatremia 
could get extremely bad. When animals with hyponatre -
mia are treated with solely sodium-free water or 5% dex -
trose, the condition might get worse (Elke and Kate, 2021). 
Additionally, dogs with proximal tubular dysfunction might 
develop hyponatremia. Both intrinsic renal impairment and 
the use of diuretics can cause increased renal sodium out -
flow. Hyponatremia causes an upsurge in the tubular secre-
tion of water in an effort to sustain normal osmotic pressure, 
resulting in a reduction in the ECF space, lowered circulat-
ing blood volume, peripheral circulatory failure, hypoten -
sion, and eventually renal failure. Common results include 
severe dehydration, hypothermia, and muscular weakness.
5.3.2 Excess sodium or hypernatremia
Sodium excess appears to occur mostly in combination with 
an excess of body water, contributing to an isotonic incre -
ment of ECF volume and the progression of hypertension 
or generalized edema. Failure to maintain an efficient cir -
culation volume can be caused by hypoalbuminemia, he -
patic fibrosis, and congestive heart failure, which in turn 
cause compensatory renal sodium retention ( Rose, 1984). 
Increased ECF volume in these situations is an attempt to 
regain effective circulating fluid volume; firstly, plasma vol-
ume may be reduced while ECF volume rises. ECF volume 
may be increased by 20%–30% before apparent edema. 
Sodium accumulation and edema can occur iatrogenically 
as the direct consequence of too much fluid, electrolyte, and 
acid–base balance sodium-containing fluid administration to 
patients with severely impaired renal function ( Lee, 2010). 
Dogs and cats can withstand high salt consumption as long 
as they have access to enough water to drink. Excessive salt 
consumption may take place when dogs that had been on 
salt-restricted diets are first allowed unlimited access to salt. 
Salt poisoning is typically accompanied by a rise in sodium 
concentrations in the plasma and/or cerebral fluid.
5.4 Potassium
Potassium is primarily an intracellular ion, with more than 
98% of the exchangeable potassium situated intracellularly. 
This potassium distribution tends to be associated with the 
active expulsion of sodium from the cells, which is sustained 
by an energy-dependent NaK pump at the cell membrane. 
The regulation of cardiac and neuromuscular excitability 
largely depends on potassium dispersion across cell mem -
branes. The overall rise in membrane potential caused by 
hypokalemia causes a hyperpolarization block that might 
cause weakness or paralysis. Hyperexcitability occurs as 
membrane potential falls due to hyperkalemia ( Robert and 
Bailey, 2019). These characteristics rely on the level of total 
body potassium concentration as well as on the quick occur-
rence of hypokalemia or hyperkalemia. Acute hypokalemia 
can result in a significantly higher change in membrane po-
tential and, thus, more pronounced clinical manifestations 
than hypokalemia that develops gradually with the same 
magnitude. The distribution of potassium between the ECF 
and ICF, in addition to external balance or the relationship 
between potassium input and output, is both regulated by 
potassium homeostasis (Rose, 1984). Variations in the acid–
base balance, exercise, catecholamine release, and admin -
istration of glucose and insulin have an impact on internal 
potassium balance.
5.4.1 Hypokalemia or potassium depletion
Potassium depletion results from an abnormal external bal-
ance where potassium losses from all sources exceed in -
take. In the majority of pet diets, potassium is available in 
quite high amounts. As a result, potassium depletion is not 
typically caused by dietary deficiencies alone. Moreover, 
dietary factors were related to hypokalemia in hospitalized 
cats, especially when attributed to conditions that caused

62 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
elevated potassium loss. Potassium depletion generally oc -
curs as the direct consequence of gastrointestinal losses 
from diarrhea or vomiting. Long-term administration of 
potassium-free fluids might increase tubular potassium 
excretion in animals with diarrhea and cause hypokale -
mia. Alkalosis may occur from a substitution of potassium 
ions for hydrogen ions in the renal tubular fluid, leading 
to hypokalemia. Increased mineralocorticoid administra -
tion, usage of diuretics, renal tubular acidosis, restoration 
of urinary obstruction-induced diuresis, and other factors 
can all lead to excessive renal losses ( Thomas and Du, 
2014). Potassium deficiency may cause changes in intracel-
lular pH, ICF volume, membrane potential, and potassium- 
dependent enzymatically mediated processes. Clinical signs 
include muscular weakness, rhabdomyolysis, ileus, renal 
failure, and cardiac arrhythmia.
5.4.2 Hyperkalemia or potassium excess
Potassium excess takes place infrequently and usually as 
a result of certain changes in the tubular secretion of po -
tassium. Potassium overload may be related to Addison’s 
disease, some types of renal illness, and clinical circum -
stances associated with hypovolemia and renal shutdown 
(Rose, 1984 ). Patients with substantially impaired renal 
function should be cautious when receiving large doses of 
potassium salts, either orally or intravenously. Compared 
to hypokalemia, hyperkalemia poses a greater risk to life. 
Cardiovascular function is significantly impacted by hy -
perkalemia (when exceeding 7–8  mmol/L). There is often 
pronounced bradycardia and arrhythmia, as well as the pos-
sibility of rapid cardiac arrest.
5.5 Chloride
Small variations in hydration usually cause shifts in plasma 
sodium and chloride concentrations that are generally 
proportionate to changes in sodium content. Variations in 
plasma chloride content are disproportionately correlated 
with acid–base variations. A disproportional hyperchlore -
mia is observed with low to normal anion gap metabolic ac-
idosis. In this form of acidosis, chloride concentration rises 
due to renal chloride resorption being elevated in propor -
tion to decreasing bicarbonate and correspondingly lower 
chloride losses than bicarbonate ( Thomas and Du, 2014 ). 
Consistently occurring disproportionate hypochloremia is a 
sign of metabolic alkalosis. These animals experience chlo-
ride deficiency as a result of the increased loss or sequestra-
tion of chloride-rich fluids. Modest variations in the relative 
proportions of plasma sodium and chloride can be attributed 
to shifts in water balance. A decrease in pure water results 
in a higher sodium concentration than a corresponding rise 
in chloride. Because of the rise in bicarbonate, this helps to 
establish a contractional alkalosis. The contrary is true and 
can lead to an extension of acidosis when there is an excess 
of pure water (Rose, 1984).
6 Clinical features of fluid and 
electrolyte balance
If an accurate initial assessment is to be made, good knowl-
edge of the interactions between particular impairments 
and their clinicopathologic effects is necessary. Once the 
medication has begun, overall clinical and clinicopatho -
logic findings will be affected not only by the main physical 
problem and compensatory reactions but also by the im -
pacts of chemotherapeutic drugs and fluid therapy. Accurate 
assessment of the fluid and electrolyte abnormalities, the 
related acid–base abnormalities, and the primary disease 
factors that cause these imbalances are necessary for ratio -
nal fluid therapy. An accurate history, a thorough physical 
examination, and a laboratory assessment of the necessary 
criteria are all required as part of the evaluation process.
6.1 History
Age, breed, sex, pregnancy, and lactation stage are funda -
mental signaling elements that affect the prevalence and se-
verity of numerous illnesses. Not only in the assessment of 
fluid and electrolyte abnormalities but also in the choice of 
fluid and patient care, the existence of a previous or concur-
rent disease state along with an appropriate drug history can 
be of utmost importance. Previous renal illness, the use of 
diuretics, or exposure to medicines that could be nephro -
toxic are particularly significant. It is really helpful to know 
how much feed and water are being consumed. The majority 
of animals that eat and drink normally are capable of keep-
ing their fluid levels balanced even when they are losing a 
lot of fluid. Dehydration can occur quickly, though, if fluid 
intake is limited or reduced while fluid losses are normal 
or increased. Neurologic conditions, head or neck trauma, 
as well as painful or obstructive lesions in the mouth, phar-
ynx, or digestive tract, can all cause an inability to drink 
enough water or eat enough food. These conditions can all 
lead to inadequate fluid intake. A lack of water intake is 
frequently caused by poor management, damaged or frozen 
water lines, etc. A history of polydipsia shows that there 
have been significant fluid losses. Diarrhea and vomiting 
are the main causes of fluid and electrolyte loss; however, 
these findings also represent gastrointestinal disturbances 
that could contribute to insufficient fluid and electrolyte 
consumption or absorption.
6.2 Clinical signs
Dehydration is characterized by the loss of body water. When 
fluid losses equal 4%–6% of body weight, clinical symptoms 
of dehydration are reported to become visible for the first 
time. Severe dehydration is considered prevalent when fluid 
losses exceed 12% of body weight and mild dehydration is 
characterized by fluid losses between 8% and 10% of body 
weight. It is crucial to understand that, even though these

Maintenance of fluids, electrolytes, and acid–base therapy in dogs and cats  Chapter | 5  63
recommendations have proved clinically helpful, there is not 
much evidence that most animal species exhibit this precise 
quantitative link. The most reliable indicator of variations 
in net water balance in emergency conditions is changes in 
body weight. The monitoring of individuals receiving fluid 
therapy is highly dependent on frequent measurements of 
body weight. If the regulation of kidney function is normal, 
urine volume is usually significantly suppressed. The clinical 
manifestations of dehydration rely considerably more on the 
trend of electrolyte loss than on absolute water loss. Clinical 
symptoms brought on by sudden drops in effective circu -
lation volume and hypovolemia are mostly responsible for 
acute sodium deficits. These symptoms include an elevated 
heart rate, drop in blood pressure, a longer time for capillar-
ies to refill, delay in jugular distensibility, and fall in pulse 
pressure. Urine output is usually reduced and urine chloride 
and sodium concentration levels are generally diminished. 
Reductions in ECF volume are always represented by de -
clines in plasma volume but the vice versa is not always true. 
The estimation of percent dehydration based on physical ex-
amination parameters is shown in Fig. 3.
7 Clinical and pathological indicators  
of fluid and electrolyte imbalance
7.1 Total plasma protein and packed cell 
volume
For the assessment of acute fluid and electrolyte abnor -
malities, total plasma protein (TPP) and packed cell volume 
(PCV) are simple, practical, and helpful measurements. If 
we suppose that there was no loss or gain of erythrocytes or 
protein from the vascular compartment, variations in PCV 
and TPP represent variations in plasma volume. There is a 
substantially greater range of normal for PCV than for TPP 
in the majority of animal species. For these estimates to be 
accurate, initial PCV and TPP levels must be recorded and 
there must not have been any protein or blood loss. Plasma 
volume reductions are most frequently caused by the se -
questration or loss of sodium-containing fluid, which can 
happen as a result of renal failure, obstructive bowel dis -
ease, diarrhea, and vomiting. In these conditions, plasma 
volume changes cause both PCV and TPP to rise, but not 
necessarily to the same degree. ECF volume gradually de -
creases to sodium deficiency is typically accompanied by 
alterations in plasma volume. As plasma volume declines, 
the PCV and TPP levels increase. When sodium-containing 
fluids are given to dehydrated volume-deficient patients, 
plasma volume re-expansion is represented by the return of 
PCV and TPP toward the normal limits. Decreasing PCV 
and TPP in responding to fluid treatment are the two most 
beneficial lab indicators of the return of effective circulat -
ing fluid volume and ought to be associated with clinical 
findings such as the return of regular pulse pressure, jugu -
lar distensibility, and capillary refill time (Daly, 2015). The 
electrolyte concentration that can be expressed per liter of 
serum or plasma water is:
Sodium mEq/liter H 2O Measured sodium (mEq/
liter) = % Water × 100.
7.2 Hyponatremia
Hyponatremia should be treated as a sign of relative wa -
ter excess. Hyponatremia is frequently but not inevitably 
FIG. 3 Estimation of percent dehydration based on physical examination parameters.

64 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
related to conditions that induce sodium reduction and 
eventual reduction in effective circulating volume. These 
conditions include excessive sweat loss, vomiting, diar -
rhea, and adrenal insufficiency. Dehydration and volume 
loss caused neurohormonal reactions that led to increased 
thirst and improved renal water and sodium storage, which 
in turn led to higher water consumption. Fluid losses in 
such types of dehydration are often hypotonic or isotonic 
and early fluid and electrolyte deficiencies do not result in 
hyponatremia until water intake and/or renal fluid reten -
tion interrupt the harmony between the residual exchange -
able cations as well as the total body water. Therefore, 
even if these conditions are linked with significant sodium 
and potassium losses, the assessment of sodium deficiency 
should be predicated on other factors because the plasma 
level of sodium does not necessarily reflect these deficien -
cies. The increase in sodium-containing fluid inside body 
cavities as a consequence of peritonitis, ascites, or a rup -
tured bladder is regarded as a “third space” issue ( Rose, 
1984). The fluid that collects in the “third space” has a 
composition that is comparable to the ECF. When this 
fluid retention occurs quickly, plasma volume decreases 
and serum sodium levels may decline as the compensat -
ing reactions occur in water retention. Excessive water 
retention- related hyponatremia can also happen in the ab -
sence of severe sodium deficiency or drops in the volume 
of effective circulation. Hyponatremia may be demon -
strated with psychogenic polydipsia if the amount of wa -
ter intake is greater than the kidney’s ability for free water 
clearance because of intrinsic renal impairment or renal 
medullary washout. Table 3 provides a list of the typical 
sources of hyponatremia.
Additionally, patients with renal impairment who have 
reduced free water clearance or who are under the effect 
of an improper ADH release may experience this. When 
large amounts of free water are given to patients who have 
impaired kidney function, hyponatremia, and related fluid, 
electrolyte, and acid–base balance, neurologic abnormali -
ties may arise ( Lakritz et  al., 1992 ). As shown in Fig.  4, 
the urine sodium level can be helpful in differentiating the 
origins of hyponatremia. Kidney adaptive reactions usually 
lead to sodium retention and the generation of urine with 
very low sodium levels in patients with sodium loss arising 
from elevated sweat loss, vomiting, diarrhea, or third space 
issues. The presence of hyponatremia and hypokalemia in 
adrenal insufficiency is typically accompanied by a com -
paratively high urine sodium content. In dogs with psycho-
genic polydipsia, the urine sodium level is more likely to be 
lower than it is in those with the syndrome of inappropriate 
secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH), which is char -
acterized by high levels of sodium in the urine when the 
hyponatremia is present. Dogs and cats with renal failure 
might have quite a range in the sodium concentration of 
their urine (Rose, 1984).
7.3 Hypernatremia
Elevated serum osmolality is often a symptom of hyperna -
tremia. Hypernatremia tends to happen in dehydrated pa -
tients when water outflow exceeds losses of both sodium 
and potassium and ought to be regarded as a sign of a rela -
tive water deficiency. This can happen in the early phases of 
vomiting, diarrhea, or kidney problems if the outflow of wa-
ter exceeds the electrolytes lost. In Table 4, a list of frequent 
causes of hypernatremia is provided. As water losses are 
restored by improved water intake and/or increased renal 
fluid retention, the serum concentration of sodium dimin -
ishes into or below the range of normal. Hypernatremia also 
begins to develop as the consequence of a primarily pure 
fluid loss, such as with the evaporative respiratory water 
loss in dogs. Food and water depletion in healthy subjects 
is linked to a significant decrease in urine and fecal output.

However, persistent cutaneous and respiratory insensible 
fluid loss may lead to hypernatremia. In young dogs, ab -

Hypernatremia may arise briefly following the administra -
tion of hypertonic saline or sodium bicarbonate if fluid in -
take is constrained or impaired (Shah et al., 2014).
7.4 Serum potassium
Serum potassium level does not always represent potas -
sium balance, but it is affected by variables that modify 
the internal balance, i.e., the distribution of potassium 
throughout the cell membrane between both the ECF and 
ICF, as well as variables that also change the external bal -
ance, i.e., potassium consumption and output ( Udensi and 
Tchounwou, 2017 ). However, variations in potassium lev -
els occur under many clinical conditions and have signifi -
cant consequences on the neuromuscular system, mostly 
as a result of variations in cell membrane potential. The 
compensating reactions to modify circulating fluid volume 
distribution and acid–base balance could consequence in 
conflicting findings.
7.4.1 Hypokalemia
Hypokalemia arises quite often in dogs and cats and may 
be a direct consequence of the exhaustion of the body’s po-
tassium stores or from the redistribution of potassium from 
the ECF into the ICF space. The most common cause of 
hypokalemia is high potassium loss from the digestive tract 
as a consequence of diarrhea or vomiting. Elevated renal 
loss of potassium outcomes from the activity of mineralo -
corticoid overflow, the activity of some diuretics, and as the 
consequence of changed renal tubular activity in animals 
with renal tubular acidosis or post-obstructive conditions. 
Chronic nutritional K + deficiency ultimately can give rise 
to moderate hypokalemia sometimes in normal subjects. A 
quickly evolving and complex hypokalemia may develop in

dogs with diminished dietary intake because of anorexia if 
combined with the other factors that cause extreme potas -
sium loss. Hypokalemia could develop without potassium 
exhaustion as the consequence of intracellular drift of po -
tassium from the ECF space. This occurs with acute alka -
losis and in subjects treated with insulin as well as glucose 
infusions (Chacko et al., 1998).
7.4.2 Hyperkalemia
Hyperkalemia can be developed iatrogenically by too much 
administration of potassium salts, but it does not typically 
arise from elevated dietary intake in subjects with nor -
mal kidney function. Hyperkalemia may build up in vitro 
in blood samples due to hemolysis or extended storage of 
blood specimens before the isolation of serum or plasma 
from RBCs in the sample. The majority of dogs and cats 
have erythrocytes with high sodium but low potassium 
concentrations. Minor hemolysis will have a minimal im -
pact on serum or plasma potassium levels in these species. 
Hyperkalemia may be associated with increased renal po -
tassium accumulation in conditions like Addison’s disease, 
acute renal failure, and renal shutdown secondary to insuf -
ficient effective circulatory fluid volume. In a number of 
cases, the transfer of intracellular potassium into the ECF 
without a shift in the external potassium balance leads to 
hyperkalemia. Hyperkalemia evolves in combination with 
metabolic acidosis, especially when the acidosis outcomes 
from volume reduction are confounded by the renal shut -
down. Hyperkalemia may be observed in diabetic patients 
or temporarily in animals with enormous muscle necrosis 
(Menegussi et al., 2018).
7.5 Serum chloride
Anion chloride, which also combines with sodium to pro -
duce common salt, generally follows sodium in the physi -
ological functions that control body fluid and electrolyte 
balance. It is getting more and more obvious that this might 
not always be the case and that many of the issues associ -
ated with sodium retention do not appear without an excess 
of chloride as well. The hyperchloremia and hypochlo -
remia that are usually seen in combination with roughly 
proportional shifts in sodium level are caused by modifica-
tions in body water balance. Variations in chloride content 
that are not linked with a similar trend in sodium level are 
generally linked with bicarbonate levels. A disproportion -
ate rise in chloride most frequently is attributed to a normal 
to low anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis and 
could be seen as a compensatory reaction for a primary 
respiratory alkalosis. Disproportionate declines in chloride 
levels are characteristically observed in metabolic alkalo -
sis and could also be considered a part of the compensat -
ing reaction for prolonged primary respiratory acidosis 
(Edwards, 2008).
7.6 Osmolality
It has already been demonstrated that the level of sodium in 
serum water is strongly related to serum osmolality across 
a remarkable range of physiological and pathophysiologi -
cal states, provided that adequate corrections for differ -
ences in glucose and urea levels are made. The assessment 
of serum osmolality has two particular and very beneficial 
purposes. Initially, to evaluate whether serum fluid content 
broadly differs from normal and furthermore, to monitor for 
the presence of external low-molecular-weight substances 
in the bloodstream. Assessment of serum osmolality for 
such reasons involves the simultaneous correlation of the 
measured osmolality and the calculated osmolality as as -
certained from the measured concentrations of the main sol-
utes in serum (sodium, glucose, and urea). The difference 
between the measured and the calculated osmolality might 
be regarded as the osmolal gap. The main cation in serum 
is sodium, which is balanced by a variety of anions such as 
sulfate, chloride, bicarbonate, phosphate, and protein. In the 
calculation of osmolality, the sodium content, which is of -
ten multiplied by a factor of 2, gives a good indication of the 
overall electrolyte concentration, including anions and cat -
ions in the sample. The water concentration of serum sam -
ples is generally 94%, as it was already stated. Modification 
of the fluid content of serum is not essential since, coinci -
dentally, it is mitigated by the assertion that sodium chlo -
ride does not really dissociate totally and has an osmotic 
coefficient of 0.93 in serum. Thus, the osmolality may be 
computed using the measured sodium content as well as the 
content of the two serum nonelectrolytes that are usually 
present in quantities high enough to affect osmolality:
mOsm kgHS odium GlucoseU rea/ 2 02/g32/g120 /g14/g14
This measurement is reasonable if levels of so -
dium, urea, and glucose are expressed in mmol per li -
ter. Converting glucose concentration from mg/dL to 
mmol/L involves dividing by 18, whereas urea content 
in mg/dL can be transformed to mmol/L by dividing by 
2.8. Reductions in the osmolar gap demonstrate labora -
tory error. An increase in the osmolar gap ( >10 mOsm/
kg) can also be the consequence of laboratory mistakes, 
although they often happen under one of two conditions: 
either a drop in serum water level or the presence of low-
molecular-weight compounds in serum. Reductions in 
serum water level appear with significant hyperlipidemia 
or hyperproteinemia and the calculated osmolality would 
then surpass the measured osmolality. The occurrence of 
a comparable imbalance between the measured and cal -
culated osmolality in the apparent lack of hyperlipidemia 
or hyperproteinemia should prompt an alert for the ap -
pearance of external compounds at unusually high lev -
els in the serum. These compounds may include a wide 
range of external and possibly harmful substances such as

Maintenance of fluids, electrolytes, and acid–base therapy in dogs and cats  Chapter | 5  67
mannitol, ethanol, ethylene glycol,  paraldehyde, metha -
nol, ethyl ether,  isopropanol, acetone, and trichloroethane 
(Saxton and Seldin, 1986 ) (Table 5).
8 Purpose of fluid therapy
What is being attempted to achieve? is a crucial question to 
address while selecting a fluid type for the patient. The most 
common indications for fluid therapy are: Replacement of in-
travascular volume deficiencies to enhance tissue  perfusion, 
replacement of tissue interstitial volume deficiencies (de -
hydration), providing maintenance fluid requirements in 
patients who are not taking enough fluid, and replacement 
of ongoing losses due to pneumonia, burns, vomiting, di -
arrhea, severe wounds, and fluid accumulation in the third 
body space are all treated with additional fluid therapy 
(Fig. 5). The majority of these cases just need crystalloid 
fluid treatment, while colloids or oxyglobin may also help 
supply intravascular volume. In some conditions, fluid di -
uresis is needed, including with renal disease, or to quicken 
the removal of toxins that are removed from the body by the 
kidneys. In these conditions, substitute crystalloid fluids are 
suggested. Rates needed to stimulate proper diuresis can be 
as high as 2.5- to 4.0-fold a patient’s maintenance needs; 
preferably, the rate must be aligned to urine output. Patients 
who are having surgery or receiving anesthesia should also 
receive fluid therapy. Anesthetics generally reduce cardiac 
output, vascular tone, or even both. When it happens, blood 
flow to the body tissue is reduced (i.e., poor perfusion). Fluid 
therapy expands the circulatory system which enhances 
perfusion. Additionally, several surgical procedures result 
in sufficient blood loss to significantly reduce intravascular 
volume. Recommended substitute crystalloid fluid adminis-
tration rates for normovolemic patients receiving anesthesia 
are 5 mL/kg/h for techniques in which limited blood loss is 
expected (e.g., orthopedic surgery, uncomplicated soft tis -
sue surgery) and 10 to 15  mL/kg/h for processes in which 
medium blood loss is predicted (e.g., liver and splenic sur -
gery) (Epstein and Waseem, 2022 ). In surgeries in which 
the patient is unstable or may lose huge amounts of blood, 
colloid fluids, crystalloid fluids, oxyglobin, blood products 
or even some combination of these could be  considered 
 necessary at significantly higher rates than those listed 
previously. Fluid treatment is also useful when a  particular

oncotic support. Eventually, intravenous nutrient fluids are 
suggested whenever the patient is not capable of eating ad-

9 Type of fluids
Currently, five basic groups of fluids are available for 
injectable use in dogs and cats: crystalloids, colloids, 
hemoglobin- based oxygen-carrying solutions, blood prod -
ucts, and intravenous nutrition. Each one of these fluid 
forms has particular indications for its use. The cornerstone 
of fluid therapy is crystalloid fluids. Crystalloid fluids pri -
marily consist of water with a sodium or glucose base, espe-
cially with the addition of other electrolytes or buffers. The 
varying amounts of these various solutes govern the selec -
tion of a specific crystalloid in diverse clinical conditions. 
There are four distinct forms of fluids in the crystalloid 
category: dextrose in water, replacement solutions, mainte-
nance solutions, and hypertonic solutions. A comparison of 
commonly used parenteral fluids in the dog and cat is listed 
in Table 7. Replacement crystalloid fluids contain soluble 
solutes that closely resemble the solute concentrations ob -
served in plasma water. These therapies are recommended 
for the quick replenishment of intravascular volume and 
electrolytes in cases of shock and hemorrhage as well as 
acute volume depletion caused by losses from vomiting, 
diarrhea, fluid loss from the third body space, and severe 
diuresis. When employing replacement crystalloid fluids, 
only 20%–25% of the administered volume of fluid stays 
inside the intravascular compartment 1 h following infusion 
(Saraghi, 2015). Hence, significant amounts of replacement 
crystalloids should be given to replenish intravascular vol -
ume. The widely available replacement solutions consist of 
normal saline (0.9% sodium chloride; NaCl) and balanced 
electrolyte solutions, such as Ringer’s solution (with lac -
tate or acetate), Normosol R (Hospira, Inc., Lake Forest, 
Illinois), and Plasmalyte A (Baxter Healthcare Corp., 
Deerfield, Illinois). Each form of replacement fluid indi -
cated here has a unique electrolyte content and may be ab -
sent (e.g., 0.9% NaCl) or contain a variety of buffers (e.g., 
lactate, acetate, or gluconate), which makes it preferable but 
not always necessary to use it.
10 Routes of administration
In general, fluids can be administered orally, subcuta -
neously, intraperitoneally, topically, intravenously, and 
intraosseously. For a severely ill patient, the two latter 
methods are favored because they provide easy access to 
the intravascular space. Medium- to large-sized dogs and 
animals that are very dehydrated should get fluids intrave -
nously. It permits a regulated delivery rate to accommodate 
the patient’s fluctuating requirements. For intravenous ad -
ministration, a cannula must be inserted into a vein with 
sterile technique and the intravenous delivery unit must 
then be kept sterile. A successful result depends on under -
standing these criteria and the potential risks that can arise 
from this kind of therapy. The more serious complication 
involves fluid overload, phlebitis, catheter sepsis, and the 
accidental flow of fluid into the neighboring perivascular 
subcutaneous tissue ( Al-Benna et  al., 2013 ). Intravenous 
catheters must be changed and repositioned to some other 
site every 72  h to prevent many of these iatrogenic prob -
lems. With the correct methods, the benefits far outweigh 
the drawbacks. When an intravenous method cannot be 
used, intraosseous fluid treatment is the preferable option 
for dogs and cats weighing less than 5 kg. Actually, because 
of the bone marrow’s direct connections to systemic circu -
lation, it can be considered a large, rigid vein through which 
most medicines can be securely delivered. The intraosseous 
method for fluid therapy is a safe and effective route for 
the seriously ill patient. After sufficient blood pressure is 
regained, the approach for fluid delivery is shifted to the 
intravenous route. In Table 8, the different fluid administra-
tion routes in dogs and cats are contrasted.
11 Monitoring fluid therapy
Fluid administration requires monitoring for both the de -
sired outcome and any potential negative effects, just like 
with any other medication. It requires “hands-on” work to 
monitor the condition properly when patients are receiv -
ing fluids. The patient’s weight, skin turgor, physical ap -
pearance, mental status, pulse rate, and respiratory rate 
and effort, periodic lung auscultation for crackles, mucous 
membrane color, and capillary refill time are all clinical 
assessment findings that ought to be assessed. Skin turgor 
enables a quick evaluation of hydration status. When dehy-
dration levels are between 6% and 8%, skin turgor is no -
ticeably prolonged and it is significantly prolonged when 
dehydration levels are above 8% ( Goucher et  al., 2019 ). 
Health status can affect the effectiveness of skin turgor 
evaluation since obesity can cover up declines in skin turgor 
as well as emaciation may artifactually aggravate skin tur -
gor. When an indwelling urinary catheter has been in place, 
serial assessment of fluid input and urine output could pro-
vide valuable information on whether too little or too much 
fluid has been administered. Additional helpful information 
is provided by renal function markers, such as BUN, serum 
creatinine, and urine-specific gravity. Elevated BUN and se-
rum creatinine levels, as well as high urine specific gravity 
(also known as prerenal azotemia), may be indicators that a 
patient is not getting enough fluids. Details regarding tissue 
perfusion can be obtained from blood gas analysis or the 
assessment of serum lactate level. Increased blood lactate 
levels or metabolic acidosis could be signs that tissues are 
not getting enough oxygen for metabolism and are therefore 
turning to anaerobic metabolism for energy. The clinical 
benchmark in veterinary medicine for assessing the efficacy 
of fluid therapy is sequential central venous pressure (CVP) 
evaluation, which estimates the potential of the right side of 
the heart to pump blood forward.

12 Contraindications for fluid therapy
Fluid treatment is not always vital to the patient’s care in some 
circumstances. Congestive heart failure is the most common 
such condition in patients. In this condition, the patient may 
develop congestion since the heart is not able to pump the 
quantity it currently has presented to it efficiently. However, 
fluid treatment is not completely contraindicated in cases of 
heart disease. In some circumstances, it may be necessary to 
utilize fluid therapy sparingly since there may be concurrent 
dehydration or a requirement for medicines to be adminis -
tered at a constant rate to correct heart disease. In such pa -
tients, hypotonic maintenance crystalloids or less frequently, 
D5W is suggested. Fluid therapy should be administered to 
patients with congestive heart failure, with meticulous at -
tention given to vital signs, urine output, and CVP (Pellicori 
et  al., 2015). The other condition where fluid therapy may 
not be required is when the patient has already been drink -
ing sufficient amounts of water and is normally hydrated. 
In this condition, fluid therapy may cause dilution of blood 
compartment components, renal medullary solute washout, 
or progression of pulmonary edema if occult cardiac disease 
exists. Even in this condition, however, fluid therapy may be 
permitted if diuresis is suggested because of the ingestion of 
a toxic substance or if a medicine must be injected by con -
stant rate infusion.
13 Discontinuation of fluid therapy
Discontinuing fluid therapy is as crucial as introducing fluid 
therapy. The majority of the time, fluid therapy should not 
be stopped abruptly, particularly if the patient is getting high 
flow rates. Fluid treatment may alter the solute gradient in the 
kidney while it is being administered (i.e., renal medullary 
solute washout). If fluid treatment is suddenly discontinued, 
the patient may not be capable of concentrating urine well 
and may continue to lose inordinate amounts of fluid in the 
urine for many days. This could be a major problem if the pa-
tient is also not consuming sufficient amounts of water, which 
may result in dehydration. Fluid treatment needs to be gradu-
ally discontinued for the patient. In an ideal condition, fluid 
treatment should be reduced to less than maintenance for a 
minimum of 24 h before the actual cessation of fluid therapy. 
However, it is not always practical to employ this strategy. 
The patient must have access to enough water if fluid treat-
ment must be abruptly stopped, and the owner should be kept 
informed of the patient’s additional water needs over the fol-
lowing few days. As mentioned throughout, the overall view 
described here is not intended to be thorough and exceptions 
to several of the “thumb rules” described here do exist.
14 Conclusion
Fluid management is essential for many dog- and cat-  
related medical issues. It is highly patient specific and af -
fected by several factors. Based on the patient’s condition, 
the fluid choice for a specific patient could differ during 
therapy. The use of fluids is essential to several aspects of 
small animal practice. Fluids are employed as a supportive 
strategy in surgical patients, as a source of nutrition in hos-
pitals, and as the mainstay of therapy in severely ill pets, 
giving them a varied role. Strategies for fluid therapy should 
be adjusted to each patient’s unique clinical situation and 
take into account apparent signs of vasoplegia, hypoperfu -
sion, cardiac failure, or hypoalbuminemia. Balanced crys -
talloid solutions are indeed the cornerstone of fluid therapy, 
even though caution is required to control edema formation. 
All these recommendations are intended to help the doctor 
prioritize goals, select suitable fluids and rates of adminis -
tration and evaluate the effectiveness of therapy on the pa -
tient. The learner needs to understand how fluid therapy is 
dynamic and highly individualized for each patient. It can 
be advantageous to have a connection with a referral facil -
ity for counseling because fluid management can be highly 
personalized in complex circumstances. Current fluid ad -
ministration dogma is being called into question by ongoing 
research, especially when it comes to rates for administra -
tion under anesthesia. Fluid administration in veterinary pa-
tients is a topic that has received little investigation and few 
evidence-based recommendations.

Chapter 6
Collection, preservation processing, and 
dispatch of samples for disease diagnosis 
in dogs and cats
1 Introduction
The collection of suitable and ideal samples is the account-
ability of the laboratory, even though the actual collection 
process is often carried out by persons who are not part of 
the laboratory staff. The healthcare provider may collect a 
sample in a clinic or farm setting. The laboratory can help 
to safeguard good samples by providing collection infor -
mation to healthcare personnel at the collection site, mak -
ing sure that proper containers and collection supplies are 
available, defining a good labeling system, and checking all 
samples carefully when they arrive in the laboratory.
The following considerations should be given while 
gathering samples for laboratory diagnosis.
● Serum samples should be collected in pairs when se -
rodiagnosis is required (about 2 mL sera). Two serum 
samples should be taken: one at the beginning of the dis-
ease and one after it has subsided (3–4 weeks), ideally 
on the 21st day.
● Urine samples should be collected and sent to the labo -
ratory as soon as possible for examination. Keeping it in 
the refrigerator will preserve the urine sample for 2–4 h.
● All the samples should be collected in leakproof glass or 
plastic bottles.
● Clinical examination always plays a very important role 
in disease diagnosis (Figs. 1–3).
● If death is reported, the postmortem examination should 
be conducted at the earliest as putrefied materials are 
unfit for laboratory examination. A detailed postmortem 
report should be attached along with the samples col -
lected during the postmortem.
● All the impression smears before packing should be 
fixed in methanol for 1–5 min unless otherwise specified.
● In case of outbreaks, try to collect materials from as 
many animals (5–6 or more) as possible at the height of 
body temperature/clinical signs.
2 Collection and preservation of 
specimen for histopathology examination
● Representative tissue/samples (tissue showing gross 
morbid samples along with normal tissue) should be 
collected for examination.
● Study of any neoplastic growth could be best studied by 
histopathology (Fig. 4).
● Sharp knife should be used for the cutting of the tissue 
samples.
● Collect the tissues directly in fixatives.
● Size of tissues should not be more than 1 cm for histopa-
thology examination for proper fixation in 10% formalin.
● Hollow organs should be taken on paper to avoid 
shrinkage.
● Hard organs like tumor tissues, liver, kidney, etc., should 
be cut carefully and collected along with the capsule.
● Tissue should be kept in fixatives for 24–48 h. before 
processing. The volume of fixatives added should be 10 
times the volume of tissues.
● Fixatives serve to harden the tissues by coagulating the 
cell protein, which allows easy manipulation of tissues.
● It prevents autolysis and putrefaction of the samples.
● An ideal fixative should preserve the architecture of the 
tissues and prevents shrinkage.
● The volume of the fixative should be 10 times the vol -
ume of the tissue/sample.
Common fixatives
1. 10% formalin:
40% formaldehyde—100 mL 
Distilled tap water—900 mL
2. Formal saline:
40% formaldehyde—100 mL
Sodium chloride—9 g
Distilled tap water—900 mL

76 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
3. Neutral buffered formaldehyde:
40% formaldehyde—100 mL
Distilled tap water—100 mL
Sodium dihydrogen phosphate monohydrate—4 g
Disodium hydrogen phosphate anhydrous—6.5 g
3 Collection and preservation of 
specimen for bacteriological examination
● Collect the tissue under sterile condition.
● Materials collected for bacteriological examination 
should be kept at refrigeration temperature (4°C) in case 
of delay of transportation. If a viral etiology is suspected 
the material can be stored at −20°C to −80°C.
● Use the new knife/blade/scalpel/spatula or sanitize the 
same on flame or in boiling water before use.
● Surface of the tissue should be sterilized by a hot spatula 
before the collection of the samples.

● Cut the surface of the tissue and try to collect the sample 
from the inner side of the tissue (tissue with less envi -
ronmental exposure).
● Specimens should be collected directly in media, i.e., 
nutrient broth, peptone water, normal saline, or PBS.
● Seal pack and transport the material to the laboratory in 
ice/under refrigeration condition as soon as possible.
4 Collection and preservation of 
specimen for virological examination
● Collect the tissue under sterile condition.
● Body fluids/blood should be collected in the sterilized 
syringe or pasture pipette.
● Tissues should be preserved in buffered glycerine (PBS 
pH 7.2%–5% and glycerine—50%).
● Avoid samples in glycerine in sensitive viruses, e.g., ca-
nine distemper or parvovirus infection.
● Seal pack, mark and transport the material to the labo -
ratory in ice/under refrigeration condition as soon as 
possible.
● The collected biological specimens should be trans -
ported on ice to the nearest laboratory as early as 
possible.
5 Collection and preservation of 
specimen for toxicological examination
● Collect the stomach and/or intestinal content for toxico-
logical study.
● In the suspected cases of poisoning, the stomach and in-
testinal contents should be sent after proper ligation at 
both ends and sent in ice to avoid putrefaction.
● Liver, kidney, and heart blood also can consider ideal 
samples for collection.
● Urine samples should be collected in clean glass jars.
● Avoid any kind of preservatives as they can interfere 
with the results.
● Collect the samples in ice/refrigeration instead.
● Seal, label, and transport to the laboratory as soon as 
possible.
● In veterolegal cases, all the specimens must be collected 
in the presence of police.
● Detail of the animals like history, signs, lesions, treat -
ment, etc., along with the poison suspected should be 
written in a letter which should be attached with samples 
before sanding to the laboratory.
6 Collection procedure of different 
biological material/specimen
Blood: In dogs and cats, blood should be collected 
from the saphenous or radial vein. The site should be 
prepared by removing hair and disinfecting it with 
spirit. Blood is collected by sterile syringe. In postmor -
tem cases, blood is collected from the right ventricle. 
For serological studies, the serum is separated by al -
lowing the blood to clot, keeping the syringe in a slant -
ing position. After complete separation, the serum is 
transferred to a sterile vial. For hematological studies, 
blood is not allowed to clot by using an anticoagulant 
(sodium citrate or EDTA). One part of the anticoagu -
lant is added to nine parts of the blood. Examination of 
blood samples provides a sufficient idea for health con-
dition of the animal. For example, an increased neutro -
phil count gives a fair idea of any infectious condition 
(Fig. 5).
Feces: Samples for examination of parasitic eggs or coc-
cidial oocysts are collected from the rectum or at the 
time of defecation.
Urine: It should be collected at the time of micturition 
or obtained with the help of a clean and sterile catheter. 
It can be examined to study various pathological condi-
tions like hematuria ( Fig. 6A and B), hemoglobinuria, 
cellular cast depositions, etc. (Fig. 7).
Pus: Smear is made on a clean glass slide. For cul -
tural examination, it should be obtained directly from 
the abscess in a sterile container, or a sterile swab is 
used.
Nasal/throat/uterine discharges : Samples should be 
collected on sterile cotton swabs, and then placed in 
sterile screw cap test tubes.
Exudates/transudates and body fluids : Collection 
has to be made with the help of sterile pipettes or sy -
ringes and to be dispatched in leakproof sterile screw 
cap containers.

Tissue, blood, and exudates smears : Tissue smears 
are to be prepared from cut surfaces of organs and fixed 
over a flame. Blood/exudates smears are drawn as thin 
film and fixed over a flame or in methyl alcohol.
Skin scrapping: Cases like dermatitis to be studied by 
skin scarping to come into the conclusion, i.e., parasitic 
dermatitis, bacterial dermatitis or allergic dermatitis, 
etc. (Figs. 8 and 9).
7 Processing and dispatch of material
Frequently, samples are collected outside the laboratory and 
must be transported for subsequent processing and testing. 
Transport may be for a short distance, but sometimes a dis-
tant clinic or collection site requires the use of vehicles or 
airplanes. In addition, it may be necessary for the laboratory 
to ship samples to referral laboratories. In all cases,  transport

must be managed carefully to maintain the integrity of the 
sample, giving attention to temperature, preservation needs, 
special transport containers, and time limitations. It is also 
important to ensure the safety of those handling the material 
before, during, and after transport.
All the types of samples have specific packaging in -
structions and labeling requirements depending on their 
classification. All potentially hazardous material requires 
triple packaging.
1. Primary container: it is a tube or vial containing the 
sample; it is made of glass, metal, or plastic. It must 
have a leakproof seal; if necessary, it can be wrapped 
with waterproof tape. The tube or vial must be labeled 
with a permanent marker.
2. Secondary container: it is a watertight polyethylene 
box intended to protect the primary container. It is sup -
plied with cardboard or bubble-wrap, or a vial holder in 
which several primary containers can be placed to pro -
tect them. Absorbent material (gauze, absorbent paper) 
must be added in a sufficient quantity to absorb the fluid 
completely in case of breakage.
3. Outer container: it is a strengthened cardboard box used 
to protect the secondary container. Both the secondary 
and outer containers are reusable as long as they are in -
tact, but old labels must be removed.
● Describe the clinical signs, lesions, tentative di -
agnosis, and treatment given to the animal in your 
letter. Also mention the type of test you wanted to 
be conducted in the laboratory, with your tentative 
diagnosis.
● Write the correct address on the letter as well as on 
the parcel, preferably with a pin code, if the material 
is sent via post.
● Mark the parcel by using terms like “Biological 
Material,” “Handle with care,” “Glass material,” 
“Fragile,” and “This side up” to avoid damage to the 
parcel. Also, mark the side to be kept on the upper 
side with arrows.
● Seal the container so that it does not leak in tran -
sit. Keep adequate material like thermocol, etc., in 
the parcel which will save the material from outside 
pressure/jerks.
● Use dry ice if available, otherwise, ice pack can be 
used.
● In the veterolegal cases, the material should be sent 
to the forensic laboratory.
● A copy of the detailed postmortem report should 
also be sent to the forensic laboratory.
● All the containers should be packed with cloth 
and sealed with sealing wax and should preferably 
be sent through a person to avoid any breakage in 
transit.
8 Essential pathological tests for 
diagnosis of disease in dogs and cats
8.1 Hematology
It is a very important clinical test that should be done be -
fore providing treatment for surgical procedures in dogs and 
cats. It provides the recent blood picture in detail that helps 
clinicians to decide their treatment protocol.
8.2 Postmortem examination
A systematic and thorough examination of carcasses for the 
study of the gross pathological lesions with an objective to 
ascertain the cause of death is called a necropsy or postmor-
tem examination. It is one of the most valuable, effective, 
and cheap diagnostic techniques available.
8.3 Serology
Diagnostic serology attempts to relate a disease condition 
to rising antibody titers. Serology for disease monitoring 
is performed to evaluate a dog’s and cat’s health program 
and disease diagnosis. ELISA is a widely applicable and 
accepted test routinely used nowadays for diagnosis and 
confirmation of infectious disease.
Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay:
● It can be used for the diagnosis of bacterial, viral, and 
parasitic diseases.
● A large number of samples can be tested at a time 
simultaneously.
FIG. 9 The abdominal area of a dog showing severe dermatitis.

80 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
● It is widely used as it is the most sensitive and specific.
● In this assay, the use of monoclonal antibody increases 
specifically.
● The use of automated dispensing, washing, and photo -
metric methods reduces the time.
8.4 Molecular diagnosis
Molecular diagnostics are increasingly used to guide patient 
management, from diagnosis to treatment, particularly in 
the fields of cancer, infectious disease, and congenital ab -
normalities. The increased demand for genetic and genomic 
information has led to the rapid expansion of molecular 
techniques within clinical laboratories. PCR (polymerase 
chain reaction) is now a common and often indispensable 
technique used in the molecular diagnosis of diseases in 
dogs and cats.
8.5 PCR
The polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is a method widely 
used to rapidly make millions to billions of copies (com -
plete or partial) of a specific DNA sample, allowing scien -
tists to take a very small sample of DNA and amplify it (or 
a part of it) to a large enough amount to study in detail. In 
this technique, DNA is denatured at 90–98°C into two seg-
ments through a deannealing process. The second step is 
annealing, in this step, the reaction temperature is lowered 
to 50–65°C (122–149°F) for 20–40  s, allowing the anneal -
ing of the primers to each of the single-stranded DNA tem-
plates. Two different primers are typically included in the 
reaction mixture: one for each of the two single-stranded 
complements containing the target region. The primers are 
single-stranded sequences themselves, but are much shorter 
than the length of the target region, complementing only 
very short sequences at the 3 ′ end of each strand. The last 
step is called elongation or extension. In this step, the DNA 
polymerase synthesizes a new DNA strand complementary 
to the DNA template strand by adding free dNTPs from the 
reaction mixture that is complementary to the template in 
the 5 ′-to-3′ direction, condensing the 5 ′-phosphate group 
of the dNTPs with the 3 ′-hydroxy group at the end of the 
nascent (elongating) DNA strand. The temperature at this 
step depends on the DNA polymerase used; the optimum 
activity temperature for the thermostable DNA polymerase 
of Taq polymerase is approximately 75–80°C (167–176°F).
8.6 Reverse transcriptase RT-PCR
Many clinically important viruses that cause serious dis -
eases in dogs and cats have genomes composed of RNA. 
RT-PCR is useful for detecting such viruses, e.g., ca -
nine distemper, parvovirus infection, feline pan leukope -
nia rabies, etc. RT-PCR may also be used to detect other 
 microorganisms ( bacteria, parasites, and fungi) by target -
ing their rRNA. This approach is better than the detection 
of DNA, as the presence of RNA is more likely associated 
with the presence of viable organisms. Reverse transcrip -
tase PCR (RT-PCR) is a variation of the polymerase chain 
reaction that amplifies target RNA. The addition of reverse 
transcriptase (RT) enzyme prior to PCR makes it possible to 
amplify and detect RNA targets. Reverse transcriptase en -
zyme transcribes the template RNA and forms complemen-
tary DNA (cDNA). Single-stranded cDNA is converted into 
double-stranded DNA using DNA polymerase. These DNA 
molecules can now be used as templates for a PCR reaction.
8.7 Real-time polymerase chain reaction  
(real-time PCR, or qPCR)
It is a laboratory technique of molecular biology based on 
the polymerase chain reaction (PCR). It monitors the ampli-
fication of a targeted DNA molecule during the PCR (i.e., in 
real time), not at its end, as in conventional PCR. Real-time 
PCR can be used quantitatively (quantitative real-time PCR) 
and semiquantitatively (i.e., above/below a certain amount 
of DNA molecules) (semiquantitative real-time PCR).
The PCR process generally consists of a series of tem -
perature changes that are repeated 25–50 times. These 
cycles normally consist of three stages: the first, at around 
95°C, allows the separation of the nucleic acid’s double 
chain; the second, at a temperature of around 50–60°C, al -
lows the binding of the primers with the DNA template; 
the third, at between 68°C and 72°C, facilitates the polym -
erization carried out by the DNA polymerase. Due to the 
small size of the fragments, the last step is usually omitted 
in this type of PCR as the enzyme is able to replicate the 
DNA amplicon during the change between the alignment 
stage and the denaturing stage. In addition, in four-step 
PCR the fluorescence is measured during short tempera -
ture phases lasting only a few seconds in each cycle, with 
a temperature of, for example, 80°C, to reduce the signal 
caused by the presence of primer dimers when a nonspe -
cific dye is used. The temperatures and the timings used for 
each cycle depend on a wide variety of parameters, such as 
the enzyme used to synthesize the DNA, the concentration 
of divalent ions and deoxyribonucleotide triphosphates 
(dNTPs) in the reaction, and the bonding temperature of 
the primers.
8.8 Cytopathology
It deals with the interpretation of cells from an animal’s 
body that either exfoliate/desquamate spontaneously 
from the epithelial surface or are obtained from organs/
tissues through biopsy. It is useful for diagnosis and 
prognosis of neoplasms, identification of benign neo -
plasms, and diagnosis of infectious diseases cytogenetics.

Samples for disease diagnosis in dogs and cats  Chapter | 6  81
Cytopathological diagnosis can be performed through two 
methods. 1. Exfoliative cytopathology and 2. Interventional 
cytopathology.
1. Exfoliative cytopathology: it includes examination and 
interpretations of cells that spontaneously shed off from 
the epithelial surface in body cavities of body fluids. 
Cells obtained from scraping, brushing, and/or washing 
of mucosal surface are also included in the exfoliative 
cytopathologic diagnosis.
2. Interventional cytopathology/biopsy: in this samples 
for the study were obtained from aspiration of surgical 
procedures. FNAC (fine-needle aspiration cytology) is 
one of the biopsies that are useful in palpable lesions 
of animals. In this technique, a thin needle is inserted 
into an area of abnormal-appearing tissue or body fluid 
to collect the sample which is further examined under a 
microscope after applying a suitable stain. It is used to 
examine swellings and lumps that could be cancerous. 
For known tumors, samples are taken for further studies. 
It is also done to establish the effect of prior treatment. 
It is also used to investigate an organ or tissue that is not 
in its original form, state, or functioning.
8.9 Histopathology
It is a branch of pathology that concerns with demonstra -
tion of minute structural alterations in tissues as results of 
disease. It is useful in establishing the pathogenesis and pa-
thology of any diseases caused by bacteria, viruses, para -
sites, fungi, toxins, etc. In some cases, the tissues from dead 
animals are the only available material for laboratory diag -
nosis. The histopathological procedures produce permanent 
slides, which can be stored for a long period, and one cannot 
manipulate the findings. Therefore, it is considered the most 
reliable technique. The procedure includes dehydration and 
clears the formalin-fixed (10%) tissue in acetone and ben -
zene, respectively, followed by wax impregnation, molding, 
section cutting and staining by hematoxylin and eosin stain.

Chapter 7
Necropsy procedure and basic laboratory 
methods in dogs and cats
1 Necropsy procedure
Examination of dead body by systematic dissection is called 
necropsy or postmortem examination. Performing a through 
PM examination requires a systemic and logistic approach, 
adequate time, and equipments. There are several reasons 
to perform a postmortem, but the most important reason is 
to determine the cause of death or the changes produced by 
diseases. However, the other reasons include confirming a 
clinical diagnosis, to obtain samples for laboratory investi -
gations, to assess the effect of treatment, to collect evidences 
in vetero-legal cases, or to prevent further spread and deaths.
Postmortem examination should be conducted only after 
getting consent from the owner, accompanied by a signed re-
quest form. It is also vitally important to obtain from the owner 
about details of anamnesis including identification, full clinical 
illness previous conditions, therapeutic and preventive mea-
sures adopted, and date and time of death. Before beginning a 
postmortem, read the history carefully, with this information, 
one can pay special attention to the organs which have given 
clinical signs of abnormality. As lesions are encountered, make 
a note of them. The history of the dog is important in interpret-
ing the results obtained, the information provided by the owner 
or person requesting postmortem, helps in postmortem exami-
nation and recording of lesions to make a conclusive diagnosis.
Under ideal circumstances, the animal should be sub -
mitted as soon as possible after death. Ideally, the autopsy 
should be performed immediately after the animal’s death 
to minimize postmortem tissue damage. If a period of time 
must elapse prior to submission, the animal should be kept 
cold, but not frozen. Basic personal protective equipments 
should be used for safety like disposable gloves, aprons, 
gum boots, head cover, antiseptics, etc.
A thorough knowledge of normal anatomy is critical in dis-
tinguishing lesions from normal variations. Lesions are classified 
by their characteristics: location, distribution, size, shape, color, 
and consistency. Findings are documented, either in writing, 
photographs, or both. The interpretation of gross lesions begins 
with the observation and characterization of abnormal findings. 
All the abnormalities in terms of distribution (focal, multifocal, 
diffuse), shape, color (discolored, bluishness, greenish), weight 
(heavy or lighter), size (shrinkage, enlarged, atrophied), consis-
tency (fluid, soft, firm, hard), odor (foul), or severity (mild, mod-
erate, severe) along with other parameters need to be recorded.
In addition, it is advisable to take as many samples as 
possible from the cadaver, and depending on the tentative 
findings, this approach would allow sequential complemen-
tary analyses. Identifying the underlying cause of death can 
help prevent mortality in nearby dogs, so it is important to 
continue the investigation of the immediate cause of death 
and to identify, ideally, the underlying causes.
1.1 Postmortem procedure
Start the PM procedure by removing the collars, bandages, and 
other materials (if any) and then weighing the animal. Before 
opening the body, carefully examine all external structures 
and surfaces like hair coat, skin, mucous membrane, natural 
orifices, discharges, burns, ectoparasites, wounds, trauma, 
etc. The body should be examined to note the state of nutri-
tion, postmortem change (like rigor mortis and algor mortis), 
and possible discoloration or anemia. Eyes, ears, anus, vulva, 
mouth, nares, etc., should be specifically examined for the 
presence of blood and any other lesion. Then place the dog car-
cass with its back on the PM table. The head is extended and 
the neck is straightened. Make a deep incision in both axillae 
between the thoracic wall and the forelimbs, reflect the fore-
limbs away from the body wall, and lay them flat to stabilize 
the body in steady distal recumbence. Reflect the pelvic limbs 
by cutting the coxofemoral joint and separate the hind limb. 
Make an incision from the point of symphysis of the mandible 
to the pubis. Separate the skin from the underlying tissue and 
distinguishing marks, wounds, etc., should be noted. Make a 
transverse incision from the midline to the dorsal extent to the 
body cavity. The abdominal cavity is exposed by removing the 
flap of muscle. Examine the diaphragm. Cut the sterna carti-
lage or tip to expose the thoracic cavity. The opening of the 
thoracic and abdominal cavities allows the in situ examination 
of the internal organs without severing the attachments. It al-
lows the detection of anomalies like displacement of organs,

84 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
accumulation fluid (serous, serosangunious, blood, pus, etc.), 
fibrinous or fibrous adhesions, parasites, abscesses, tumors, 
or any other visible modifications. If sampling for bacterial 
culture is to be performed, the thorax and abdomen surface 
should ideally be treated with iodine products before open-
ing both cavities. Carefully open joints to examine abnormal 
synovial fluid, ligaments, and articular cartilage.
Following the necropsy, the most important observations 
are grouped together in a report prior to the conclusion. 
Classically, all organs with macroscopic lesions should be 
collected for laboratory analysis. The precise sample collec-
tion for further tests will vary from case to case.
One of the important aspects of the P.M. examination 
is to determine the date and time of death. Generally, it is 
acquired from the owner of the animal. However, in vetero-
legal cases it has to be determined by the pathologist be -
cause the police and the court of law may like to know it.
However, there are other factors that affect the time of 
death such as environmental temperature, size of the ani -
mal, nutritional state of the animal, etc. (Figs. 1–9).

2 Basic laboratory diagnostic 
procedures
Apart from clinical examinations, in many cases the final 
diagnosis of an animal disease is dependent upon a labo -
ratory test. A basic laboratory procedure involves testing 
of a sample of blood, urine, or other substances collected 
from the animal body. The modern veterinary diagnostic 
laboratory performs specific organ function tests (liver, 
kidney), histochemical analyses, biopsies, etc. Laboratory 
tests are often part of a routine checkup in well-managed 
dogs with the aim to look for internal physiological changes 
taking place inside the body. But most of the time, labora -
tory tests can help to determine a diagnosis, plan treatment, 
check the progress of treatment, or monitor the disease with 
time. Thus, effective and accurate diagnosis is of prime 
importance for clinical care, pathogenesis, prevention, and 
control.
The different laboratory procedures that are commonly 
applied in the diagnosis of diseases, in general, in dogs and 
cats are the same. The different laboratory procedures are:
2.1 Blood examination
Blood tests are used to count blood cells or examine cell 
morphology, proteins, or other substances in the blood. 
Blood testing is one of the most common types of laboratory 
tests. Complete blood cell count (CBC) is an examination 
of blood and plasma for packed cell volume (PCV), hemo -
globin percentage (Hb.%), total leucocyte count (TLC), 
total erythrocyte count (TEC), differential leucocyte count 
(DLC), erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), etc. A CBC 
becomes essential when the animal is showing symptoms of 
fever, vomiting, diarrhea, weakness, loss of appetite, or any 
such changes. The hemogram obtained from performing a 
complete blood count provides a complete blood picture of 
a patient.
Site for collection of blood : Venous blood is collected 
from femoral, saphenous, or tibial vein.
General consideration:
1. Blood should be collected when the animal is at rest and 
without undue excitement to avoid alteration in the he -
mogram and some blood chemistry values.
2. Serum rather than plasma is preferred for most chemical 
analyses as anticoagulants may interfere.
Procedure for collection of blood:
i. Clip the hairs from the site of blood collection. 
ii. Apply antiseptic (ethanol/tincture of iodine) over the 
site.
iii. Raise the vein by pressure.
iv. Insert the needle into the vein and collect the blood in a 
dry syringe for the required quantity of blood (approx. 
2 mL).
FIG.  8 Showing section of kidneys with clear demarcation of cortical 
and medullary area.
FIG.  9 Showing dog urinary bladder distended with urine due to 
retention.
FIG. 7 Showing contracted kidneys with surface granularity suggestive 
of chronic glomerulonephritis.

Necropsy and laboratory techniques in dogs and cats  Chapter | 7  87
v. Disengage the needle and transfer blood from syringe to 
anticoagulant containing the vial. Mix the blood using 
rotational movements in the vials.
Commonly used anticoagulants: EDTA (K or Na salt) @ 
10–20 mg/10 mL of blood or 1  mL of 1% solution dried at 
room temperature. 
Commonly used dyes in staining of blood smears 
are: Leishman’s stain, Giemsa stain, or Wright’s stain. 
Leishman’s stain is good for routine hematological proce -
dures (Figs. 10 and 11).
2.1.1 Hemoglobin estimation
A hemoglobin test measures the amount of hemoglobin 
in the blood. Hemoglobin is found inside red blood cells 
that carry oxygen to different body’s organs and tissues. 
If a hemoglobin test reveals that a dog’s hemoglobin level 
is lower than normal, it means that your dog is suffer -
ing from anemia. It is usually done through Sahli’s acid 
hematin method or autoanalyzer. The basic principle in -
volved includes hemoglobin conversion to acid hematin 
using dilute hydrochloric acid and matching the developed 
color with a comparator/standard colorimeter. The value 
of hemoglobin decreases in case of poor nutrition, canine 
distemper, tick-borne diseases, bone marrow disease, in -
testinal bleeding, etc. 2.1.2 Packed cell volume (PCV) estimation
The packed cell volume is the measure of the ratio of the 
volume occupied by the red cells to the volume of whole 
blood in a sample of blood. It is also known as the hemato-
crit test and is done to diagnose polycythemia, dehydration, 
or anemia in affected dogs. Packed cell volume represents a 
number of RBCs/unit of blood. When anticoagulated blood 
is centrifuged at a standard speed, erythrocytes, which are 
heavier than white cells and plasma, will settle down at the 
bottom. Thus, PCV is the volume of red cells expressed as a 
percentage of whole blood.
PCV can be calculated as Hb. (%) × 3 or TEC (millions) × 6.
PCV less than normal indicates anemia while more than 
normal indicates hemoconcentration/polycythemia.
Normal plasma is straw colored while
i. deep yellow is indicative of jaundice,
ii. pale plasma is indicative of excessive blood loss and 
bone marrow depression,
iii. reddish is indicative of hemolysis, and
iv. creamy top is indicative of lipemia (Fig. 12).
2.1.3 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 
estimation
The ESR test indirectly measures the presence of inflam -
mation in the body. If an ESR test shows that a dog’s red 
blood cells sink faster than normal, it may mean he is suf -
fering from some inflammatory condition. But an ESR 
test alone cannot diagnose what condition is causing the 
FIG. 10 Showing blood smear prepared from a drop of blood for micro-
scopic examination.
FIG. 11 Showing a hemato-analyzer to be used in blood analysis.

88 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
 inflammation. Change in the shape and count of RBCs may 
affect the ESR. It is a nonspecific test to determine the in -
tensity of the disease process in the body. Normal ESR does 
not exclude the possibility of disease.
The distance that the erythrocytes fall during a given pe-
riod of time is measured. The results are expressed as a fall 
of RBCs in mm/h.
Values in dog and cat—1 mm/h
i. Increased ESR : Acute generalized infections, neo -
plasms, tissue injury, canine distemper, infectious ca -
nine hepatitis, bone fractures, etc.
ii. Decreased ESR: Liver disease, poor nutrition, immature 
RBCs.
2.1.4 Total erythrocyte count (TEC) estimation
The results of an RBC count can be used to help diagnose 
blood-related conditions, such as iron deficiency anemia. A 
low RBC count could also indicate a vitamin B6, B12, or 
folate deficiency.
Accurate dilution of a measured quantity of blood with a 
fluid that is isotonic with the blood and counts erythrocytes 
in the counting chamber. The blood specimen is diluted 
(usually in a 1:200 ratio) with the help of RBC diluting fluid 
which preserves and fixes the red blood cells.
Polycythemia (increased TEC with a corresponding in -
crease in HB and PCV): Dehydration, shock, burns, high 
altitude, chronic lung and heart disease, physiological, neo-
natal, renal tumor, cobalt toxicity, etc.
Oligocythemia (anemia): (Decrease below normal in 
TEC, Hb, and PCV): Chronic hemorrhages, bloodsucking 
parasites, deficiency of Fe, Cu, pyridoxine, riboflavin.
2.1.5 Total leukocyte count (TLC) 
determination
Thus, the total number of leukocytes in peripheral blood in 
a given unit of blood is the total leukocyte count. TLC deter-
mination is usually done through hemocytometer (Neubauer 
chamber). The cells are counted under low-power magnifi-
cation (×10) in four corner large squares (each is divided 
into 16 small squares) by following the exclusion principle 
of cells counting along the line (Fig. 13).

2.2 Differential leucocyte count (DLC)
The differential white cell count is the determination of the 
different types of white blood cells or leucocytes present 
in the blood. The WBCs exist in two forms, viz., granulo -
cytes and agranulocytes. Granulocytes are further classified 
as eosinophil, basophil, and neutrophil, while agranulocytes 
show lymphocytes and monocytes.
FIG. 12 Showing packed cell volume with upper plasma, middle buffy 
coat, and bottom RBC.
FIG. 13 Naeuber’s chamber meant for blood cell count purpose.

Necropsy and laboratory techniques in dogs and cats  Chapter | 7  89
The differential leucocyte count is done by counting dif-
ferent 100 leucocytes in an oil immersion field. However, 
the distribution of leucocytes in the smear is checked ini -
tially on high power. The counting is done on the feathered 
edge of the blood smear. The site where RBCs remain scat-
tered but neither scarcely populated and also not in large 
clumps is preferred for counting. The counting is done by 
the Battlement method. Here, counting is started from the 
periphery of the selected site for about three fields then 
move inwards at a right angle toward the middle portion for 
about three fields, again move straight to the edge and then 
move upwards making parallel lines (Figs. 14 and 15).
2.3 Interpretation of DLC
Leukopenia: (Decrease in absolute count of leukocytes): 
Canine distemper, feline panleukopenia, infectious canine 
hepatitis.
Neutropenia: (Decrease in absolute count of neutrophils): 
Overwhelming bacterial/viral infections, shock, bone mar -
row depression, deficiency of vitamin B12 and folic acid.
Eosinopenia: (Decrease in absolute count of eo -
sinophils): Stress, intoxications, trauma. Lymphopenia: 
(Decrease in absolute count of lymphocytes): Infectious 
canine hepatitis, canine distemper, immune suppressive 
drugs, and chronic enteric disease.
Leukocytosis: (Increase in absolute count of leuko -
cytes): Infections, acute blood loss.
Neutrophilia: (Increase in absolute count of Europhiles): 
Inflammation, trauma, neoplasia, localized suppurative 
processes.
Lymphocytosis: (Increase in absolute count of lympho -
cytes): Chronic infections, lymphadenitis/lymphangitis.
Eosinophilia: (Increase in absolute count of eosino -
phils): Parasitism, allergies.
Monocytosis: (Increase in absolute count of monocytes): 
All chronic supportive diseases, granulomatous conditions, 
stress.
Basophilia: (Increase in absolute count of basophils): 
Associated with eosinophilia, e.g., heartworms, chronic re-
spiratory disease, adrenocorticism in dogs.

in higher magnification.
