3 Urine analysis
This body fluid can be easily obtained from most species 
of animals. A urinalysis can include a variety of tests that 
detect and measure various compounds that pass through 
urine using a single sample of urine. Urinalysis is the physi-
cal, chemical, and microscopic examination of urine. A 
critical examination of urine is one of the most important 
of all veterinary laboratory diagnostic procedures. Urine is 
not only altered by disease occurring in the kidney but may 
also occur due to extra-renal conditions that may be of di -
agnostic significance.
Analysis of urine employs a wide array of techniques 
ranging from simple test tube reactions to very sophisti -
cated ones such as flow cytometry and computer analysis.
3.1 Collection of urine
Preservatives—Toluene/formalin/thymol/chloroform/boric 
acid/metaphosphoric acid.
Procedure:
i. Collect the urine sample from animals as it voids. It is 
advisable to clean the vulva to avoid any contamination.

Necropsy and laboratory techniques in dogs and cats  Chapter | 7  91
ii. An early morning sample from the house-trained pets is 
of more diagnostic significance.
iii. Collect the midstream urine sample as the first stream 
urine may be contaminated with cellular debris, leuko-
cyte, and exudates that are flushed from the urethra.
iv. At least 100 mL of urine must be collected.
v. For bacterial cultures and sensitivity testing, the sample 
should be collected in a sterile container using aseptic 
precautions either using a catheter or directly from the 
bladder in small animals, e.g., dog/cats.
vi. Collection is advisable before any fluid consumption 
(as it dilutes the urine) or meals (the sample is likely to 
have more sugar and protein than the morning sample).
vii. Examine the sample as early as possible. Delay will 
increase the alkalinity of urine (urea, ammonia) and 
formed elements like cells and casts will degenerate.
The examination of urine can be divided into four parts:
i. Physical/visual examination of urine. 
ii. Chemical examination of urine.
iii. Microscopical examination.
iv. Cultural examination.
3.2 Physical examination of urine
The urine is examined for volume, smell, color, and 
clearness.
(1) V olume—Record the amount of urine produced per day 
by a normal animal.
Increased volume: (Polyuria): Renal failure, diabetes 
mellitus, primary renal glycosuria, chronic pyelonephri-
tis, pyometra, and liver disease.
Decreased volume: (Oliguria): Acute renal failure, fe -
ver, edema, urinary passage obstruction, reduced blood 
pressure.
Normal range of daily urine output in the dog: 0.5–2 (1.0) L.
(2) Color—Record the color of urine by taking the sample 
in a clean transparent tube. Normally urine is yellow/
amber/wheat straw colored and is related to the concen-
tration of urochromes in urine. The depth of urine color 
is also a crude indicator of urine concentration.
(3) Odor—Normal order is urinoid.
(4) Transparency—Observe urine sample in a test tube 
against light. Abnormal transparency: Presence of 
epithelial cells, blood, leukocytes, bacteria, mucus, 
crystals.
3.3 Chemical examination of urine
The routine chemical examination of urine involves qualita-
tive tests for protein, glucose, hemoglobin, ketone bodies, 
and bile pigments. These components are mostly present in 
urine in healthy animals but in amounts undetectable by the 
routine tests. Various pathological conditions increase their 
concentration in urine.
To perform the chemical examination, most clinical 
laboratories use commercially prepared test strips. The 
most frequently performed chemical tests using reagent test 
strips are: Specific gravity, pH, protein, glucose, ketones, 
blood, bile pigments, and bile salts.
Specific gravity: It is a measure of urine concentration. 
It can be measured by urinometer. It is cheap and inexpen -
sive and routinely followed. Normal range of urine specific 
gravity: 1.015–1.045 (Av. 1.025).
pH: Any condition that produces acids or bases in the 
body such as acidosis or alkalosis, or the ingestion of acidic 
or basic foods, can directly affect urine pH. Normal range 
of urine pH: 6.0–7.0. Abnormal reaction in case of cystitis, 
alkalosis, starvation, fever, acidosis, prolonged muscular 
activity.
Protein: When urine protein is elevated, you have a con-
dition called proteinuria. The proteinuria can be detected 
by heat test, Heller’s test, or Robert’s test. The conditions 
that can produce proteinuria include hemoglobinuria, renal 
neoplasm, acute nephritis, pyelonephritis, and polycystic 
kidneys.
Glucose: If present, the condition is called glucosuria. It 
can be tested by Benedict’s test, Fehling’s test, or Clinitest 
reagent tablet. The condition for glycosuria and hyperglyce-
mia: diabetes mellitus, liver diseases, hemorrhage, encepha-
litis, fracture.
Ketones: Ketones are not normally found in the urine. 
Ketonuria can be detected by Rothera’s nitroprusside test. 
Increased value is seen in diabetes mellitus, high fever, and 
starvation (in puppies and kittens), starvation/fasting, and 
impaired liver function.
Blood: The presence of blood in the urine is known as 
hematuria while that of hemoglobin is known as hemoglo -
binuria. Benzidine test and orthotolidine test are used to de-
tect blood in the urine.
Hematuria (urine reddish-cloudy, clear with sediment 
on standing, and contains intact RBCs): Acute nephri -
tis, urolithiasis, cystitis, neoplasms of urogenital tract, 
estrus.
Hemoglobinuria (Urine port-wine/brown/coffee colored 
translucent uniform color without sediment and no intact 
RBCs): Due to excessive hemolysis of erythrocytes and ob-
served in condition, viz., leptospirosis, toxemia due to Cu, 
Hg, and sulfonamides.
Bile pigments: The presence of bilirubin in urine can be 
detected by: (i) Foam test, (ii) Gmelin test, (iii) Fouchet’s 
test, and (iv) Icotest (reagent tablets). It is observed in con-
dition, viz., obstructive jaundice, hepatocellular disease, 
e.g., leptospirosis infection, canine hepatitis, cirrhosis tox -
icities, and hepatic neoplasm.

92 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
3.4 Microscopic examination of urine
This test examines urine sample sediments under a mi -
croscope. It can see cells from the urinary tract, blood 
cells, crystals, bacteria, parasites, and cells from tumors. 
Microscopic examination of urine sediment is usually per -
formed in addition to routine procedures. The specimen 
used for microscopic examination should be as fresh as 
possible.
Pour 5–10 mL of midstream urine into a conical bottom 
test tube. Centrifuge it for about 5  min at 2000–3000  rpm. 
Decant the supernatant and resuspend the sediment in the 
residual urine that clings to the bottom of the tube by tap -
ping the tube against a hard surface several times. Place a 
drop of the resuspended sediment on a glass microscope 
slide and place a coverslip over the drop and examine it un-
der the microscope (Figs. 16 and 17).
In healthy dogs, the urine contains small numbers of cells 
and other formed elements from the entire urinary tract, and 
epithelial cells from the kidney, ureter, bladder, and urethra. 
In renal disease, the urine often contains increased numbers 
of substances discharged from an organ that is otherwise ac-
cessible only by biopsy or surgery. A microscopic examina-
tion of urine sediment detects the presence and amounts of 
(i) Organized sediments like blood cells, bacteria and yeast, 
casts, epithelial cells, mucous threads, parasites, sperma -
tozoa and (ii) unorganized sediments like crystals and fat 
droplets (Fig. 18).
3.5 Cultural examination of urine
Diagnosis of bacteriuria in a patient with a suspected uri -
nary tract infection requires a urine culture and sensitivity 
test. A colony count may also be done to determine if sig -
nificant numbers of bacteria are present. Generally, more 
than 100,000 bacteria of single organism per milliliter of 
urine indicate a urinary tract infection. A finding of multiple 
organisms usually reflects specimen contamination.
FIG. 16 Showing centrifuge machine used in microscopic examination 
of urine.
FIG.  17 Showing centrifuge tube with bottom sediments and upper 
supernatants.
FIG. 18 Microscopic view of urine sample showing urinary crystals.

4 Diagnostic cytology
Diagnostic cytology or cytopathology is a specialized di -
agnostic technique to examine individual cells extracted 
from tissues to determine the cause and nature of a dis -
ease. Diagnostic cytology is commonly used to investi -
gate diseases involving a wide range of body sites, often 
to aid in the diagnosis of cancer but also in the diagno -
sis of some infectious diseases and other inflammatory 
conditions. Thus, it can be defined as the study of cells 
that has either exfoliated or are obtained from various 
organs/tissue. Its interpretation is based upon alteration 
in morphology observed in single cells or group of cells. 
Exfoliative cytology involves the study of cells sponta -
neously shed off from epithelial surfaces into the body 
cavity or body fluids, while interventional cytology study 
samples that are obtained by clinical procedures or sur -
gical intervention. It is also known as fine needle aspi -
ration cytology or aspiration biopsy cytology. It is done 
for palpable mass example lymph node, mammary gland, 
thyroid, salivary gland, etc.
4.1 Collection of specimens
The sample can be collected by scrapping the lateral walls 
of the vagina, fresh early morning sputum, and bronchial 
washings. Buccal smears, gastric lavage, fresh catheterized 
urine samples, pericardial, pleural, and peritoneal fluids, 
CSF, semen.
4.2 Fixation of the specimen
All materials for cytological examination must be properly 
fixed to ensure the preservation of cytomorphological de -
tails. Methods of fixing vary depending on the type of stain-
ing employed. Materials are usually wet-fixed for use with 
Papanicolaou or H&E staining. Routine fixatives comprise 
a solution of equal parts of ether and 95% ethanol. 100% 
methanol, 95% denaturated alcohol, or 85% isopropyl alco-
hol may be used. Special purpose fixative may be buffered 
neutral formalin, Bouin’s fluid, and picric acid.
4.3 Papanicolaou staining
It is the method for routine studies. Gives excellent nuclear 
but weak cytoplasmic detail. They do not demonstrate bac-
teria and cytoplasmic changes as well as Romanowsky 
stains. Its procedure is as follows:
i. Fix in 95% alcohol for 15 min.
ii. Rinse in tap water.
iii. Stain in hematoxylin for 1–3 min.
iv. Rinse in tap water.
v. 10 dips in 95% alcohol.
vi. Stain for 1–2 min in Paps stain OG-6.
vii. 10 dips in 95% alcohol.
viii. Stain with EA 65 stain for 2–3 min.
ix. 10 dips twice in 95% alcohol.
x. Keep for 1 min in 100% alcohol.
xi. Put coverslip and examine under microscope.
4.4 Interventional cytopathology
It includes fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC), imprint 
cytology, and crush smear cytology. Fine-needle aspira -
tion cytology has gained importance in the last 3 decades. 
Almost all fine needle-accessible organs can be aspirated 
for cytological studies. It is used to investigate superficial 
(just under the skin) lumps or masses. In this technique, a 
thin, hollow needle is inserted into the mass to take samples 
of cells that, after being stained, are analyzed under a mi -
croscope. It is safer and less traumatic than an open surgi -
cal biopsy, and significant complications are usually rare, 
depending on the body site. If the lump or suspected tumor 
mass is very small, it might be necessary to use a scanning 
machine to help guide the needle to the right place. This 
may be done by an ultrasound scan or an X-ray of the organ 
(Figs. 19 and 20).
FIG.  19 Cytopathological examination of smear showing lymphoblast 
cells with prominent nucleoli.
FIG. 20 Cytopathological examination showing round cells with vacu -
olated cytoplasm.

Necropsy and laboratory techniques in dogs and cats  Chapter | 7  95
5 Diagnostic histopathology
Diagnostic histopathology is a practice in which patholo -
gists view tissues under a microscope to identify potential 
changes. A histopathologist can view potentially cancerous 
or atypical tissues and aid other medical specialists in mak-
ing diagnoses or assessing the effectiveness of treatments. 
Thus, histopathology is the microscopic examination of tis-
sues to observe pathological alterations. This involves the 
preparation of microscopic slides from tissues for histopa -
thology which includes a collection of morbid tissues from 
biopsy or necropsy, fixation, preparation of sections, stain -
ing, and examination under a microscope.
5.1 Cryo-sectioning/frozen sectioning
A fresh tissue is required for the procedure. The tissue is 
placed in the cryostat which is a microtome enclosed in a 
refrigerated chamber at ( −30°C) but can be operated from 
outside. Sections are then taken after the tissue has been 
hardened and are stained by the rapid H&E method so as to 
give an immediate diagnosis.
5.2 Paraffin embedding technique
Tissue pieces of one cubic cm, thickness are collected from 
organs showing gross morbid changes along with normal 
area. A portion of tissue is trimmed (block) and used for fur-
ther processing. The block with the identification number 
is transferred into a container having fresh fixative. Tissues 
should be kept in a fixative for 24–48 h at room temperature. 
Neutral buffered formaldehyde is the most widely used fixa-
tive because it is compatible with most stains, cost- effective, 
and easily available. Fixative is removed from tissues by 
keeping them overnight in running tap water or washing 
briefly in tap water followed by placing them in 70% al -
cohol. Alcohol removes formalin more rapidly. Thereafter, 
clearing is done in xylene to remove alcohol from the tis -
sues and prepare them for penetration by paraffin during 
embedding. Infiltration and impregnation are done using 
paraffin wax. Embedding is transferring of infiltrated tis -
sue into molten wax and solidifies into a block when cools 
down to room temperature. Microtomes are used for cutting 
thin uniform tissue sections. The section is cut in a (4–5 μm 
thickness) microtome.
5.3 Hematoxylin and eosin staining
i. Clearing—To remove the paraffin by giving three 
changes in xylene for 3 min each.
ii. Rehydrate in ascending grade of alcohol by keeping 
in 100%, 85%, and 70% grade of alcohol for 1  min in 
each, and then in tap water for 30 s.
iii. Stain with hematoxylin for 10 min.
iv. Keep in tap water for 30 s.
v. Few dips in ammonia water.
vi. Keep in tap water for 30 s.
vii. Few dips in acid alcohol.
viii. Keep in tap water for 30 s.
ix. Pass through 70% and 95% alcohol for 1 min each.
x. Stain with eosin for 3–5 min.
xi. Keep in 95% and 100% alcohol for 1 min each.
xii. Clearing in xylene, three changes for 1 min each.
xiii. Examine under a microscope.
xiv. Prepare permanent mounts with the help of mountants 
like DPX or Canada Balsam (Figs. 21–24).
FIG. 21 Showing dog affected with mammary gland tumor.
FIG.  22 Dog affected with mammary gland tumor being prepared for 
biopsy sample collection.

96 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
6 Parasitological examination
The parasitology examination provides laboratory tests of 
protozoa and various parasites (ecto or endoparasite) that 
may cause diseases in the body.
6.1 Examination of mites
The mites are deeply embedded in the host tissue. At the 
time of collection when an attempt is made to separate the 
embedded mites often the damage occurs.
Before going through the process of collection, a scalpel 
or knife blade is sterilized by passing it through a flame and 
then cooled by dipping it in water. For easy collection, the 
edge of the knife should be dipped in acetic acid glycerin. 
For collection, a fold of skin showing lesions is held be -
tween the thumb and forefinger, and the crest of the fold is 
scraped until blood begins to ooze. Here, care must be taken 
to avoid drawing blood. Now transfer scrapings from the 
scalpel, using a rotary motion, into a drop of acetic glycerin 
on a slide. If necessary, add a cover glass and additional 
acetic glycerin and observed under the low power of the 
compound microscope. To discourage the growth of molds, 
add a crystal of thymol.
6.2 Examination of specimens
● For field condition, a simple hand lens of 10 × can be 
used.
● In laboratory condition, a low-power stereoscopic mi -
croscopic is useful.
● Some of the specimens preserved in liquid may be easier 
to examine for surface features if the surface is allowed 
to dry. This type of specimen should not be kept out of 
the liquid preservative for too long. This can be rinsed in 
100% ethanol and dried under a bench lamp or by using 
blotting paper. The magnification of the objective lens 
used for mites is 10× to 40×.
6.3 Examination of fecal sample
A fecal sample should be collected from the rectum of sus-
pected animals. Smaller animals (lamb, kid, dog, and cat) 
can be induced to defecate by inserting a moistened little 
finger into the rectum and gently massaging in a rotator 
motion and then the sample may be collected. Samples 
should be collected in wider mouth screw cap bottles or 
plastic containers with lids. Disposable plastic gloves are 
used for collecting the samples. Each sample should be 
clearly labeled with animal identification, date, and place 
of collection.
Samples can be kept in the refrigerator for up to 
3 weeks without significant changes in the egg counts 
and the morphology of eggs. Collected feces should be 
preserved in 10% formalin for a few days and 70% ethyl 
alcohol may be used for a longer period of preserva -
tion. 10% formalin is prepared by taking formalin (40% 
formaldehyde-10 mL + Water-90 mL).
6.3.1 Gross examination of feces
Feces are examined grossly for the presence of adult worm. 
All the information regarding quantity, color, and presence 
of blood or mucus in feces, and consistency should be noted.
(a) 10–20 g of feces is spread in a large Petri dish for this 
purpose.
(b) Nematodes or segments of tapeworm or immature nem-
atode are searched with the camel hair brush. The para -
sitic stages are identified with or without staining.
FIG.  23 Histopathological view of a mammary gland tumor showing 
calcified material in the stroma.
FIG. 24 Histopathological view of a urinary bladder carcinoma in a dog.

Necropsy and laboratory techniques in dogs and cats  Chapter | 7  97
6.3.2 Microscopic examination of feces
i. Qualitative examination : It is done for knowing the 
kinds of infection without going into intensity. It is help-
ful in comparing the efficacy of anthelmintic, determin-
ing the correct interval between anthelmintic treatment, 
assessing the efficacy of control programs and knowing 
the drug resistance, etc. It is determined by the direct 
smear method, floatation method, sedimentation tech -
nique, and formal-ether method.
ii. Quantitative examination of feces:
Egg counting methods: For accurate information regarding 
severity of infection, egg count methods are very useful by 
estimating eggs per gram (EPG) of feces. 
Stoll’s dilution method: This method is mainly used for 
estimating the number of helminth eggs in feces. It is very 
simpler and needs less special equipment than then other 
techniques.
Mc Master method: The simplest and most effective 
method for determining the number of eggs or oocysts per 
gram of feces is with the help of Mc Master chambers. 
This technique is useful to count the number of eggs or 
larvae of most cestode, nematode, and coccidia in feces. 
Eggs per gram (EPG)  = Number of eggs in one (or two) 
chamber(s) × 100 (or 50).
Boray and Pearson method: This method was described 
by Boray and Pearson and widely used to determine the 
EPG of Fasciola species in the rumen (Fig. 25).
7 Clinical biochemistry
Clinical biochemistry is a part of the laboratory that deals 
with the measurement of chemicals (both natural and un -
natural) in blood, urine, and other body fluids. These test 
results are useful for detecting health problems, determin -
ing prognosis, and guiding the therapy of a patient. Organ-
specific function tests usually performed in animals are:
A. Kidney function tests
1. BUN/NPN—Normal values range from 10 to 30 mg/dL.
2. Creatinine—Normal values range from 1 to 2 mg/dL.
B. Liver function tests
1. Serum bilirubin.
2. SGPT—Serum glutamate pyruvic transaminase.
3. SGOT—Serum glutamic oxaloacetic transaminase.
4. SAP—Serum alkaline phosphatase.
5. LH—Lactic dehydrogenase.
6. SDH—Sorbitol dehydrogenase.

FIG. 25 Stained blood smear showing Theileria sp. inside RBC.

98 SECTION | A  Introduction of diseases
Uremia is a measure of renal function. The causes may 
be: prolonged vomiting, severe diarrhea, ulcerative colitis, 
glomerulonephritis, congenital cystic kidneys, and enlarge-
ment of prostate. Decreased serum urea levels could be due 
to pregnancy, intravenous infusion, low protein intake, and 
severe liver diseases.
Increased serum creatinine levels  are seen in renal 
failure, dehydration, congestive heart failure, shock, dia -
betes mellitus, calculi blocking the ureters, or neoplasms 
compressing the ureters.
Increase in serum total proteins occurs in : 
Dehydration, multiple myeloma, chronic infections, chronic 
liver disease, and autoimmune diseases.
Decrease in serum total proteins may result from : 
Heavy losses of proteins in urine as in nephritic syndrome, pro-
tein undernutrition, intestinal malabsorption, protein- losing 
enteropathy, shock, burns, crush injuries, and hemorrhage.
Decrease in serum albumin may occur in: Protein un-
dernutrition, intestinal malabsorption, protein-losing enter -
opathy, liver disease, wasting diseases, nephritic syndrome, 
and hemodilution.
Rise in serum calcium is seen in: Hyperparathyroidism, 
hypervitaminosis D, multiple myeloma, extensive meta -
static involvement of bones, and polycythemia.
Calcium level decreases in: Hypoparathyroidism, rick-
ets, osteomalacia, steatorrhoea, nephritic syndrome, renal 
failure, acute pancreatitis, starvation.
Serum inorganic phosphorus rises  in: 
Hypervitaminosis D, hypoparathyroidism, and renal failure, 
during the healing of fractures.
Serum inorganic phosphorus falls  in: Rickets, osteo -
malacia, steatorrhoea, hyperparathyroidism, and renal tubu-
lar acidosis, after injection of insulin.
Increase in serum albumin may occur in: Dehydration 
due to hemoconcentration.
Increased serum globulin  may be in: Multiple my -
eloma, chronic liver disease, or chronic infections.
Serum globulin may decrease  due to: Hemodilution 
shock, burns, hemorrhage, etc.
Elevation in the serum levels of ALT : Liver disease, 
cirrhosis, carcinoma of the liver, myocardial infarction.
Note: ALT is the more liver-specific enzyme although 
both AST and ALT are raised in liver diseases.
7.1 Hyperbilirubinemia
A. Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia (Retention jaundice):
i. Hemolytic (Prehepatic jaundice) due to: Increased 
hemolysis, abnormal RBC, e.g., in spherocytosis, 
G-6-p dehydrogenase deficiency, incompatible blood 
transfusion, organisms, e.g., plasmodium, etc., inef -
fective erythropoiesis, e.g., in pernicious anemia.
B. Nonhemolytic (Hepatic) due to: (i) Impaired hepatic up-
take, physiological jaundice of newborn. Particularly in 
premature infants not having a fully developed micro -
somal conjugating enzyme system.
ii. Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia (Regurgitation 
jaundice):
Due to regurgitation into circulation of conjugated bilirubin 
which would normally pass along the bilirubin system. 
8 Bacteriological examination
The bacteriological examination is a method of collecting 
samples and analyzing these samples to estimate the type 
and number of bacteria present. The primary purpose is to 
assist veterinarians and pet owners in providing optimal 
health care by identifying those bacteria causing disease 
and by determining the antimicrobial agents to which the 
bacteria may respond in vivo.
For proper isolation and identification of bacteria, it 
needs to be cultured by growing the organism in an artifi -
cial medium. Artificial culture media generally provides a 
necessary source of elements, energy, nutrients, and a pH of 
about 7.2. For routine purposes, many of these nutrients are 
supplied by aqueous extracts of meat and peptone, which 
is a product of digested protein. Some bacterial species are 
able to grow under a wide range of conditions: but others 
are very exacting. If more than one species or types of or -
ganism are present, then each of them needs to be carefully 
separated or isolated in pure culture. For this, it needs spe -
cial media enriched with specific inorganic salts or particu-
lar growth factors. There are two broad groups of media: 
(A) Liquid media and (B) Solid media. “ agar-agar” is the 
most common solidifying agent used in the preparation of 
artificial media but it does not add to the nutritive proper -
ties of the medium. Most bacteriological agar melts at about 
95°C and solidifies at about 42°C.
8.1 Isolation of pure culture by streak plate 
method
A pure culture is possible to get by transferring a single col-
ony of bacteria into a sterile medium. The term pure culture 
denotes that all the cells in the culture had a common origin 
and are simply descendants of the single cell.
Procedure
1. Melt and cool nutrient agar at 45–50°C. Pour 15–20 mL 
melted.
2. Take this nutrient agar into separate Petri dishes.
3. Let it solidify.
4. Take a loopful of mixed culture and streak it over a par-
ticular area. Sterile the loop by flaming and then draw 
parallel lines to the fresh surface of the medium. Repeat 
the process several times. The inoculums should be de -
rived from the most distal part of the immediately pre -
ceding strokes.

Necropsy and laboratory techniques in dogs and cats  Chapter | 7  99
5. Sterilize the loop, and allow cooling it, between each 
sequence.
6. Incubate at 37°C for 18–24 h in an inverted position.
7. Observe the plates for the presence of isolated or solitary 
colonies. Study the morphology and staining reaction.
8.2 Gram staining of bacteria
This method of classification is most useful; therefore, it 
is the most important staining technique employed for the 
diagnostic identification of various organisms. Certain bac-
teria when treated with one of the basic para-rosaniline dyes 
such as methyl violet, crystal violet, or gentian violet and 
then with iodine “fix” the stain, so that subsequent treatment 
with a decolorizing agent like alcohol or acetone does not 
remove the color. These bacteria are called “Gram positive” 
and are stained in violet color. Other organisms, however, 
are decolorized and can be counter-stained with neutral red. 
These are termed as “Gram negative” and are stained pink.
Procedure
1. Take a loopful of broth culture (or urine, sputum, pus, 
etc.) with the inoculating wire and spread thinly on a 
glass slide, and let it dry.
2. Fix the smear by over the flame.
3. Flood the slide with crystal violet solution and allow it 
to act for about 30 s.
4. Pour off the stain and pour on the iodine solution so that 
it washes away the dye. Cover the slide with fresh iodine 
and allow acting for about 30 s.
5. Wash with acetone and 95% alcohol (30:70 parts) until 
the smear ceases to lose color.
6. Wash with water.
7. Counterstain for 1 min.
8. Wash and dry with blotting paper.
9. Observe the slide under oil immersion.
8.3 Antibiotic sensitivity test by disc method
It is a method to test the ability of the organism to grow on 
artificial nutrient media containing different antibiotic and 
chemotherapeutic agents in different concentrations.
Method
1. Inoculate 5 mL of sterile nutrient broth with the test organism.
2. Incubate overnight at 37°C.
3. Pour 0.5 mL of broth culture on the surface of the sterile 
nutrient agar plate. The inoculums are well spread over 
the agar surface.
4. Inoculated plates are dried in an incubator for 10  min at 
37°C.
5. Put the antibiotic discs over the inoculated plates at 
equal distances.
6. Incubate this plate at 37°C overnight in an inverted posi-
tion and read the result the next day.
Quantify the diameter of the zone of inhibition made by 
different antibiotic discs and witness grades of sensitivity 
as sensitive, intermediate, and resistant by comparing the 
diameters of the inhibition zones with critical zone diam -
eters in published tables. 
9 Fungal examination
Fungal infections are relatively common in cats and dogs 
and include conditions such as ringworm. Ringworm can 
cause hair loss, itching, and a skin rash, but in most cases, 
it is treatable and not life threatening. The importance of 
fungal infections in cats and dogs has increased over the 
last decades.
9.1 Sample collection
Collect skin scraping from the inflamed margin of the 
growth with a curved disposable scalpel. Clean the lesion 
thoroughly with 70% alcohol. If vesicles are present, the 
tops should be removed with fine scissors and sent for ex -
amination. Alternatively, apply waterproof transparent vinyl 
adhesive tape firmly to the affected area and peel it off and 
apply to a sterile glass microscope slide for transport to the 
laboratory. This is usually used in the case of dermatophytes 
and yeasts. Nail clippings should be taken from the distal 
border with the help of clippers. Hairs should be removed 
by plucking with epilating forceps and never by cutting as 
the base of the hair shaft around the follicle which is most 
likely to harbor the fungus fails to be collected. In the case 
of sputum, 3-day collection is done. Swabbing needs to be 
done in case of exudates or pus. Rub the swab firmly over 
the lesion proper collection.
The collected sample should be allowed to dry out to 
prevent the overgrowth of saprophytic bacteria and fungi 
that occur if moisture is retained by holding these speci -
mens in air-tight glass bottles. Packeting in the black paper 
fold is most suitable.
9.2 Lactophenol cotton blue staining of fungi in 
wet mounts
Procedure:
1. Put a drop of 95% alcohol on the slide. Gently tease out 
a fragment of the culture in the alcohol with needles. 
When it is satisfactorily spread, let most of the alcohol 
evaporate and then add a drop of stain.
2. Apply a coverslip, and exert gentle pressure to flatten 
the fungal fragments.
3. Remove excess stain with the help of a piece of blotting 
paper. Let it penetrate for a few minutes, but differentia-
tion may go on improving for up to 24 h. For permanent 
preparations, seal the edges with nail polish.

Chapter 8
Behavioral disorders of dogs and cats
1 Introduction
Animals react differently to the same stimuli. Individual 
behavioral variations may result from a variety of circum -
stances. Among these influences include hereditary traits, 
prenatal dam modification, animal behavior at different 
periods of development, especially during the neonatal 
and socializing phases, maturational events, and the ef -
ficient functioning of the animal’s organ systems ( Kaiser 
and Sachser, 2005; Weinstock, 2008; Camps et al., 2019 ). 
When discussing the proper organ function in animals, it 
is affected by an array of medical complications that can 
cause behavioral problems directly or indirectly in our pet 
animals, and these complications include those that alter or 
eliminate external perception (e.g., blindness), information 
perception (e.g., a brain tumor), stress reactions owing to 
pain, and those that drastically alter internal processes due 
to hormonal or neurological issues (Camps et al., 2019; Haq 
et al., 2022). In general, behavioral disorders in animals are 
defined as abnormally unpleasant behavior observed by the 
animal owner that can be harmful to people or other animals 
and that can either directly or indirectly impair the patient’s 
well-being. Other ailments in companion animals, such as 
aggression, abnormal behaviors associated with pain, and 
behavioral issues associated with the vomeronasal organ 
and heart failure, must also be taken into consideration dur-
ing a clinical diagnosis ( Camps et al., 2019). For the treat-
ment and management of behavioral disorders in companion 
animals, veterinarians combine pharmacological interven -
tions, such as the use of tricyclic antidepressants, selective 
serotonin reuptake inhibitors, phenothiazines, benzodiaz -
epines, and occasionally pheromone-based therapies, with 
behavioral modification therapies or techniques ( Camps 
et al., 2019; Haq et al., 2022). A list of drugs that may help 
companion animals having behavioral issues is mentioned 
in (Table 1). Numerous contributing factors are thought to 
have an impact on the utilization of psychopharmaceutical 
treatment for aberrant behaviors. They include ideas held 
by veterinary teams and dog owners about what constitutes 
“normal” and acceptable canine behavior in addition to 
worries about cost, safety, and ease of administration. There 
is little published research on the use of pharmaceutical 
treatment to address unwanted behaviors in companion ani-
mals receiving routine veterinary care, despite the general 
consensus that greater knowledge on veterinary behavioral 
psychopharmacology is needed.
2 Noise-related anxiety
Canine and feline anxiety reactions to noisy stimuli are 
sometimes misdiagnosed with separation anxiety disor -
der. For example, urinating when the owner is not there 
is not always indicative of separation anxiety disorder; it 
can also happen in reaction to unpleasant loud stimulation. 
Fireworks, thunderstorms, and gunshots are the most often 
mentioned noise phobias. As a result of these unpleasant 
noise stimulations, a typical dog may become more sensi -
tive to the added stress of being alone ( Sherman and Mills, 
2008; Blackwell et  al., 2013 ). It is critical to thoroughly 
examine the relationship between primary and secondary 
issues. Therefore, to reduce the risk of delay or insufficient 
action, patients with one condition should undergo routine 
screening for the other. The severity of a patient’s distress 
response to noise can range from minor behaviors like pant-
ing, hiding, hyperactivity, or attempts to flee to more severe 
ones like destructiveness and self-trauma ( Sherman and 
Mills, 2008). As a result, many dog owners turn to veteri -
narians, animal behaviorists, and dog trainers for assistance. 
Alternatively, they may decide to abandon or put their pets 
to sleep. The majority of dog owners (between 40% and 
50%) believe that their dog is “frightened” of some kind 
of noise ( Sherman and Mills, 2008 ). According to reports, 
dogs that are not exposed to an urban environment, which 
typically entails the sounds of moving vehicles, are more 
likely to display evasive behavior and violent reactions 
(Sherman and Mills, 2008 ). Although it is frequently ad -
dressed poorly or ineffectively, noise sensitivity is a sig -
nificant behavioral issue and a severe welfare concern for 
pet owners. Treatment is usually delayed until problematic 
responses, including panic episodes or numerous stimulus

104 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
 reactions, become severe. Animals with these problems 
might seem normal and have a fearless personality at some 
point (McCobb et al., 2001).
Recent studies have assessed the efficacy of various 
treatment plans for different noise sensitivities; however, 
the study designs lacked placebo controls. In combination 
with behavioral modification, clomipramine and alprazolam 
have been used to regulate thunderstorm reactions (Crowell-
Davis et  al., 2003). Phenothiazines are not recommended 
for the general treatment of noise phobia. These drugs make 
the animal sleepy but do not lessen its subjective fear re -
action; in fact, they could make it more fearful ( Sherman 
and Mills, 2008). Products made from pheromones, such as 
dog appeasing pheromone, may also be useful for managing 
crises right away. Pets may still react with fear to unpleas -
ant noises because pheromone products do not sedate the 
animal, but the animal should recover more quickly. This 
is how owners must be notified (Sherman and Mills, 2008).
Long-term modification of the animal’s noise percep -
tion requires systematic desensitization using sound re -
cordings. First, sounds that are similar to the problematic 
stimulus but not exactly the same should be played at a 
 volume that the animal does not find offensive. The volume 
is being gradually turned up. Using a DAP pheromone dif -
fuser during training and playing the recordings for short 
intervals of time rather than for extended durations of time 
might speed up the program ( Sherman and Mills, 2008 ). 
The next phase, known as “counterconditioning,” involves 
encouraging a response that is the opposite of the problem-
atic behavior. This might be a pleasant or soothing exercise 
or a command that requires strict obedience, like “staying 
down.” Counterconditioning is especially helpful for con -
trolling the anxiety-related aspect of the issue. A tricyclic 
antidepressant (TCA) or a selective serotonin reuptake 
inhibitor (SSRI) may be administered during this period. 
Benzodiazepines are not advised throughout this process 
since they may hinder learning. If the issue is due to exces-
sive attention seeking, this behavior must also be addressed 
by fostering the pet’s independence. The first 4 weeks of this 
procedure should be when clients can expect to see the most 
development. Long-term success requires long-term man -
agement and scheduling regular follow-up conversations 
(Sherman and Mills, 2008). Group courses may encourage 
change, enable effective resource usage, and enable owners

to share their issues with others who are experiencing a sim-
ilar level of difficulty. Reexposure therapy is advised annu-
ally. This can be managed in real life by reminding people 
to repeat the behavioral training, similar to how annual vac-
cination reminders are sent out (Sherman and Mills, 2008). 
Fig. 1 shows a brief illustration of noise-related anxiety in 
companion animals.
3 Aggression
With around 70% of the cases, aggression is the most 
prevalent issue in referral clinics in North America, and 
around 5 million people are hospitalized each year in the 
USA alone for the treatment of dog bites. With the ex -
ception of predation, most kinds of aggression involve an 
activity that increases distance (i.e., the dog is attempt -
ing to actively increase the distance between itself and 
the stimulus). There are several aggressive behaviors with 
a variety of causes; nevertheless, in the majority of cases, 
fear, anxiety, conflict, genetics, and learned reactions are 
responsible (Fig. 2). In certain instances, the behavior may 
be pathological. Aggression develops as a result of early 
development (prenatal and postnatal), socialization, and 
prior experience. Threatening conduct or destructive at -
tacks are referred to as aggression, and it can take many 
forms, from minute adjustments in body position, expres -
sions on the face, and vocalizations, to biting. Because their 
physiologic condition influences their decision-making, 
readily stimulated dogs are more likely to become aggres -
sive (i.e., flee or fight). The pet’s fear and excitement must 
first be controlled by avoiding situations or keeping below 
the point at which aggressiveness could start. A combina -
tion of reward-based training, behavior products that can 
help to better manage the pet, and medications to help 
achieve a behavioral state most conducive to new learning 
is required to successfully change the behavior to achieve 
desired results and counter-condition the pet to the stimuli 
that incite aggression (Fig. 2). The practitioner must evalu-
ate the danger of damage before treating aggressiveness 
(https://www.msdvetmanual.com/behavior/normal-social-
behavior-andbehavioral-problems-of-domestic-animals/
behavioral-problems-of-dogs).
To guarantee initial safety, all triggers that could cause 
aggressiveness should be precisely recognized. Prognosis 
FIG. 1 Illustration of noise-related anxiety in dogs.
FIG. 2 Aggression in dogs, their causes, and management.

106 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
predictability is a crucial factor in creating a stimulus gra -
dient for therapy as well as preventing additional events. 
Additionally, it is crucial to consider the signaling, environ-
ment, history, and target of the aggressiveness when deter -
mining if the issue can be handled safely and efficiently. 
Another element is the type of aggression; some may be 
addressed and handled, while others need to be prevented. 
The doctor must also evaluate the owner’s capacity to safely 
and effectively prevent the issue. The prognosis is worsened 
by unpredictable aggression, aggression that occurs during 
largely benign interactions, aggression that involves targets 
that cannot reasonably be protected from the aggressive dog 
(like young children or other household pets), aggression 
that is committed by a large dog, or aggression that is com-
mitted in an unrestrained manner. Identification of any med-
ical disease that may contribute to or cause aggressiveness 
is important since it will affect the diagnosis, prognosis, 
and course of therapy. Establishing a schedule of controlled 
interactions in which the dog is not provided something it 
values (or desires) until it sits is a typical way to start to 
reduce anxiety, enhance communication and training, teach 
self-control, and let the dog determine its consequences and 
outcomes ( https://www.msdvetmanual.com/behavior/nor-
mal-social-behavior-and-behavioral-problems-of-domes -
tic-animals/behavioral-problems-of-dogs, MSD Veterinary 
Manual, 2022).
It is critical to determine which behaviors must be 
learned to achieve desired results during exposure training 
because the ultimate goal is to properly expose the dog to 
regulated levels of stimuli while achieving calm and happy 
outcomes. For instance, if issues emerge indoors, the dog 
might initially need to learn the commands for a concen -
trated sit, calm down, and a mat command. It can also be 
necessary to train a come or recall command and a drop 
or give the command. The best stimuli exposure options 
include loose-leash walking, backing up, or turning and 
walking away. Before the owners go to a progressive stim -
ulus, these behaviors need to be reliably and consistently 
acquired in a variety of situations with little distraction 
(https://www.msdvetmanual.com/behavior/normal-social-
behavior-and-behavioral-problems-of-domestic-animals/
behavioral-problems-of-dogs , MSD Veterinary Manual, 
2022). By applying pressure to three aggressive Great 
Danes, the research on using pressure to suppress canine 
aggression has been investigated ( Williams and Borchelt, 
2003). In a large wooden box, each animal was separately 
restrained. The dogs were placed in a standing position 
and blanketed with approximately 275  kg of triple-cleaned 
oats, leaving the head and neck exposed. Each dog was 
given more intense exposure to stimuli (either humans or 
other dogs) to which they were reactive. When the dog was 
restrained, all of its hostile behaviors quickly subsided, 
and it displayed calm behavior even when the stimulus in -
tensity was at its greatest ( Williams and Borchelt, 2003 ). 
The researchers concluded that tactile pressure may be a 
key tool in behavior modification after observing a lower 
heart rate reading than the baseline data ( Williams et al., 
2003).
4 Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD)
Both human and animal species struggle with this syndrome 
(Crowell-Davis, 2009; Ferdowsian et al., 2012; Craske and 
Stein, 2016; Haq et al., 2022 ), but in humans, it lasts for 
6 months with unrelenting, observable anxiety ( Craske 
and Stein, 2016 ; Haq et  al., 2022). Regardless of the cir -
cumstance, dogs with GAD exhibit persistent or almost 
persistent indicators of anxiety and concern, which lower 
their quality of life and daily functioning ( Crowell-Davis, 
2009; Haq et al., 2022 ). To diagnose GAD, patients must 
have experienced persistent anxiety symptoms in their dogs 
or cats for at least 2 to 3  months. These symptoms include 
shaking, vocalizing, peeing, defecating, drooling, hiding, 
and destructiveness ( Fig.  3) ( Crowell-Davis, 2009 ). The 
patient develops a propensity for behavioral issues, which 
is primarily influenced by genetic predisposition (demon -
strated in dogs by the existence of a fearful phenotype), 
environmental factors, and early life experiences (such as 
inadequate socialization, subpar nursing care, and negative 
experiences during the early stages of life) (Tiira and Lohi, 
2015; Zapata et  al., 2016 ; Craske et  al., 2017 ; Sarviaho 
et al., 2019). As a result of all these factors, pets are more 
likely to acquire GAD, which has a significant detrimental 
impact on the quality of life for affected animals (Blackwell 
et al., 2013). As anxiety develops, stress levels rise and can 
be measured by serum cortisol levels (Marques et al., 2010; 
Franzini de Souza et al., 2017 ; Wormald et al., 2017). As a 
result, GAD has serious emotional and physical effects on 
the person who has it, prompting the need to seek therapeu-
tic alternatives. Psychopharmacological therapies, which 
may be required in addition to behavioral modification ther-
apy, may safeguard well-being or facilitate behavioral con-
trol (Fig. 3) (Mills, 2003; Herron et al., 2008 ; Ibanez and 
Anzola, 2009; Karagiannis et al., 2015 ). The usage of nu -
merous medications, including alprazolam, clomipramine, 
and diazepam, is one of the pharmacological therapies 
(Haq, 2017; Crowell-Davis, 2009). For canines and felines 
that exhibit chronic anxiety, medication is a crucial com -
ponent of treatment. Azapirone, a selective serotonin reup -
take inhibitor or a serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake 
inhibitor, is beneficial for the majority of patients (Crowell-
Davis, 2009). To make a long-lasting change in the pet’s 
underlying mental condition, these drugs are given to the 
animal every day for a few weeks. Since benzodiazepines 
have a high risk of addiction, they should not be used exten-
sively (Crowell-Davis, 2009). Imepitoin has been demon -
strated to have an antistress effect when used to treat GAD 
in dogs at a dose of around 20  mg/kg orally twice a day.

Behavioral disorders of dogs and cats  Chapter | 8  107
The drug decreased serum cortisol levels, which indicated 
less stress (Forster et al., 2020). Imepitoin has been shown 
to have anxiolytic and anticonvulsant effects (Rundfeldt and 
Löscher, 2014) and to have benzodiazepine-like effects in 
a number of common anxiety models ( Engel et al., 2018 ). 
It has also been shown to have anxiolytic effects in dogs 
(McPeake and Mills, 2017 ). Trazodone hydrochloride was 
used as an adjunctive agent in conjunction with other be -
havioral medications to treat a variety of anxiety problems 
in dogs, according to Gruen and Sherman (2008). Their re-
search showed that the medication was well tolerated over a 
broad dosing range and improved behavioral calming when 
given regularly or as needed. Adjunctive agents are required 
to improve pharmacologic treatment for dogs with anxiety 
disorders who do not respond well enough to standard treat-
ment protocols as well as for dogs that respond to treatment 
at first but later relapse. This method may also be benefi -
cial in more complex cases and for dogs with a variety of 
behavioral issues. The patient’s health state and clinical 
symptoms may have an impact on the choice of appropriate 
adjunctive medication. The phenylpiperazine medication 
family includes the triazolopyridine derivative trazodone 
hydrochloride (Gruen and Sherman, 2008 ). Due to its pri -
mary pharmacologic mechanism of action, which antago -
nizes serotonin 2A receptors, and its secondary mechanism, 
which inhibits serotonin reuptake, it is classified as a SARI 
(serotonin antagonist and reuptake inhibitor). Trazodone 
also has agonistic actions on serotonin 1 receptors, as does 
its active metabolite, m-chlorophenylpiperazine (m-CPP). 
Recent research suggests that trazodone’s mechanism of ac-
tion as an antidepressant and antianxiety drug is  different 
from that of SSRIs, TCAs, and benzodiazepines. It also 
suggests that trazodone may increase serotonin concentra -
tions by attenuating the inhibitory tone of aminobutyric 
acid neurotransmitters in the cerebral cortex ( Gruen and 
Sherman, 2008). Stevens et al. (2016) reported a significant 
improvement in the cat’s signs of anxiety during transport 
and veterinary examination-related anxiety. Trazodone hy -
drochloride (50 mg orally per cat) was used in a single dose 
by the authors.
In livestock animals, like pigs and cattle with anxiety 
symptoms, the application of pressure to their bodies has 
shown induction of relaxation and sleep. Based on this, the 
use of pressure wraps (Thundershirt) for the treatment of 
dogs suffering from GAD (generalized anxiety disorder) 
and SAD (separation anxiety disorder) is being used along 
with medical and behavioral modification therapy that has 
revealed a decrease in elevated heart rates and abnormal 
stress behaviors like tongue flicking and yawning ( King 
et al., 2014).
5 Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)
The most crippling behavioral disorder is OCD, which has 
a long history of study. Obsessive-compulsive disorder 
(OCD) in companion animals is characterized by stereotyp-
ical and ritualistic behavior. OCD in dogs manifests itself in 
a variety of ways, including spinning, circling, tail chasing, 
trying to suck the flank (common in the Doberman breed of 
dogs), fly nibbling, fence jumping, self-mutilation, wind or 
hair smacking, pica, including feces consumption, staring 
and making noises, aggression, and cloth sucking or biting 
FIG. 3 Schematic figure of a generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) in pets.

108 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
(Haq, 2017; Haq et al., 2022; Overall and Dunham, 2002 ). 
OCD in felines may be related to social and environmental 
stress, and in cats, indications of self-mutilation, obsessive 
grooming, tail-chasing, and sucking or biting on wool or 
fabric are also observed ( Overall and Dunham, 2002; Haq, 
2017; Haq et al., 2022). Attention-seeking behavior, separa-
tion anxiety, generalized anxiety, and hyperactivity disor -
ders must be differentiated from OCD symptoms. In dogs, 
chromosome 7 (breed Doberman) has been found to sig -
nificantly increase the risk of developing OCD, indicating 
a hereditary component to OCD in dogs ( Fig. 4). A gene 
essential for the healthy growth of glutamate receptors is 
located at the chromosome 7 locus ( Fig. 4), and its failure 
contributes to the manifestation of obsessive-compulsive 
disorder (Overall, 1997; Overall and Dunham, 2002 ; Haq 
et al., 2022 ). In the same part of the brain where OCD is 
present in human sufferers, the hippocampus, canine chro -
mosome 7 is expressed in dogs. More proof that people and 
dogs exhibit symptoms and react to treatments in similar 
ways is provided by the fact that similar pathways are im -
plicated in pharmacological treatment responses in both 
species. Investigating obsessive-compulsive disorder in 
canines can help researchers create more effective and ef -
ficient treatments for OCD in people ( Haq et  al., 2022 ). 
Miniature bull terriers, Staffordshire bull terriers, and 
German shepherds are the dog breeds most prone to OCD 
(Nuwer, 2012; Overall and Dunham, 2002). Serotonin reup-
take inhibitors combined with cognitive behavioral therapy 
are the initial treatment for OCD ( Haq, 2017; Haq et  al., 
2022; Overall and Dunham, 2002 ). The most efficient 
and often prescribed medications for OCD are tricyclic 
 antidepressants (such as clomipramine and amitriptyline), 
selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (such as fluoxetine), 
and monoamine oxidase type B (MAO-B) inhibitors (such 
as selegiline) ( Fig. 4). Animals with a history of urine re -
tention or severe, uncontrolled cardiac arrhythmias should 
not be administered TCAs ( Reich et al., 2000 ; Overall and 
Dunham, 2002; Haq et al., 2022 ). Today, an interdisciplin-
ary approach is used for the effective management of ca -
nine dogs with obsessive behavioral disorders. To treat the 
compulsive disorder (specifically tail-chasing behavior) in a 
7-year-old intact male German shepherd mixed-breed dog, 
d’Angelo et al. (2022)  described using an interdisciplinary 
strategy that involved hiring a veterinary behaviorist and 
a rehabilitating dog instructor. Along with this strategy, a 
3-month pharmaceutical intervention utilizing fluoxetine 
and a-S1 casozepine was also carried out. Surprisingly, over 
the course of the next 3 months, medication and behavioral 
management led to the cessation of compulsive tail-chasing 
behavior. The primary protein in cow’s milk is the bioactive 
peptide a-S1 casozepine, which is known for its capacity 
to bind to the GABAA receptor, a pharmacological target 
for substances of the benzodiazepine class that are used to 
treat epilepsy, insomnia, anxiety, and panic disorders. In 
this regard, a-casozepine has been shown in numerous stud-
ies to have anxiolytic and sleep-inducing characteristics in 
a variety of species, including humans. Studies in rats also 
revealed that a-S1 casozepine has anxiolytic effects equiva-
lent to those of diazepam, with the exception that it did not 
cause the disinhibition state that is normally experienced 
following benzodiazepine administration in people ( Violle 
et al., 2006; d’Angelo et al., 2022).
FIG. 4 Schematic figure of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).

Behavioral disorders of dogs and cats  Chapter | 8  109
6 Separation anxiety disorder (SAD)
This behavioral condition is brought on when a dog or cat is 
left alone at home or is separated from its owner. Symptoms 
of this illness frequently appear when the animal anticipates 
being left alone, and they typically get worse between 30 
and 60 min after the owner departs. Excessive vocalization, 
disruptive behavior, impatience, early urine and feces, ex -
cessive salivation, psychogenic grooming in cats and es -
cape attempts are a few of the clinical indications of SAD 
in pets ( Fig. 5) (Amat et al., 2014 ; Haq, 2017; Haq et al., 
2022). Additionally, cases of vomiting, anorexia, and acral 
lick dermatitis have been recorded ( Haq, 2017; Haq et al., 
2022) (Fig. 5). The owners occasionally describe the dogs’ 
welcoming behavior as “excessively effusive.” According 
to several telephone marketing surveys of pet owners in 
the United States, between 14% and 17% of companion 
dogs who get veterinarian care exhibit signs of separation 
anxiety. According to Guthrie (1999) and Bradshaw et al. 
(2002), at least 20% of dogs in the United Kingdom are 
believed to have separation anxiety, and up to 50% of dogs 
living in the neighborhood may eventually exhibit clini -
cal symptoms. Clients with separation anxiety make up 
20%–40% of caseloads for behavior specialist practitioners 
(Horwitz, 2000; Wright and Nesselrote, 1987). Due to early 
separation from their mother, puppies with this ailment 
are frequently reported to be between 2 and 3  months old. 
Separation anxiety also has a negative effect on the relation-
ship between humans and animals, which can cause owners 
to abandon healthy dogs or decide to put their pets to sleep 
(Amat et al., 2014). One factor that causes SAD in dogs is 
their ability to anticipate the owner’s departure. This ability 
is based on the dog learning the correlation between the ac-
tual departure and a number of signals that go along with it 
and are given by the owner, usually unknowingly, like pick-
ing up the keys and donning a jacket ( Amat et al., 2014 ). 
Giving false departure signals by acting as though you are 
about to go is a tip that is frequently given to owners of dogs 
with separation anxiety disorder. By minimizing the dog’s 
dread and anxiety, this technique aims to diminish the ani -
mal’s anticipation of the owner’s real departure ( Horwitz, 
2002; Takeuchi et  al., 2000 ; Appleby and Pluijmakers, 
2003; Blackwell et  al., 2006 ; Sherman and Mills, 2008 ). 
Therefore, training the dog to endure the owner’s absence is 
the most successful SAD therapy, which is followed by the 
repair of specific problems like destruction, barking, and 
elimination. For the treatment of SAD, a combination of 
behavioral change and medication therapy has shown bet -
ter results (Fig. 5) (Simpson et al., 2007 ; Landsberg et al., 
2008). For the treatment of separation anxiety in dogs, two 
medications, clomipramine and fluoxetine, which are both 
extensively used antidepressants in humans, have received 
FIG. 5 Schematic diagram of separation anxiety disorder in pets.

110 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
approval in the United States ( Simpson et al., 2007 ). Dogs 
with separation anxiety that are left alone lessen their pac -
ing, scratching, and whining when given clomipramine 
at a rate of 1–2  mg/kg every 12  h ( Simpson et  al., 2007 ). 
Clonidine, a drug used to treat hypertension in humans, is 
also used with clomipramine to treat SAD, with behavioral 
benefits shown in dogs (Ogata and Dodman, 2011). A “dog 
appeasing pheromone therapy” administered via an elec -
tric diffuser has been reported to help with SAD symptoms 
in addition to pharmaceutical treatments ( Fig.  5). Dog-
appeasing pheromones are naturally released by the seba -
ceous glands (mammary glands) of nursing bitches shortly 
after parturition. In stressed-out juvenile and adult dogs, the 
vomeronasal organ, which eventually has a calming effect, 
may detect this molecule (Pageat and Gaultier, 2003). When 
the pheromone was dispersed without the owner around, it 
was shown that this therapy, together with behavioral modi-
fication, was just as effective as taking clomipramine and 
had fewer adverse side effects (Kim et al., 2010).
Recently, canine patients with separation anxiety disor-
der are increasingly being treated using pulsed electromag-
netic field (PEMF) devices ( Pankratz et al., 2021 ). Pulsed 
electromagnetic field (PEMF) therapy may complement or 
act as an alternative to medication treatment for SA. Targeted 
PEMF has a long history of usage for treating osteoarthritis 
pain in people and animals, as well as wound repair, edema, 
postoperative pain, and nonunion fractures ( Hattapoglu 
et al., 2019; Zidan et al., 2018 ; Pinna et al., 2013 ; Alvarez 
et al., 2019). Alternating magnetic fields produced by pulse 
generators control neuronal excitability but fall short of the 
threshold for action potential induction. Nitric oxide pro -
duced by PEMF is thought to have antiinflammatory prop -
erties and promote calcium signaling ( Marchionni et  al., 
2006; Grassi et al., 2004). Recently, considerable focus has 
been placed on the possible application of PEMF to men -
tal disorders. In a model of posttraumatic stress, research 
in mice has demonstrated the effectiveness of PEMF in 
lowering anxiety behaviors and boosting neurogenesis in 
the hippocampus ( Alizadeh et  al., 2019 ); however, other 
research has demonstrated no change in anxiety responses 
following electromagnetic field exposure ( Cosquer et  al., 
2005). In humans, PEMF has been demonstrated to have 
immediate mood-improving benefits in depressed people 
(Rohan, 2015; Rohan et al., 2014), as well as longer-lasting 
effects in people with depression that is resistant to therapy 
(Martiny et al., 2010).
A pilot study with 10 dogs with SA was carried out in 
2019 (Gruen and Korman, 2019). For 6 weeks, owners gave 
their dogs PEMF treatments twice daily, answered question-
naires every 2 weeks, and filmed their pets at home alone on 
weeks four and six. Positive findings from owner surveys 
included improvements in all enrolled patients after 4 weeks 
and symptoms being gone in more than half of patients by 
6 weeks. Footage of the dogs alone at home at 4 and 6 weeks 
old revealed an improvement over baseline videos in both 
good behaviors like relaxing and a reduction in undesir -
able ones like pacing and environment orientation ( Gruen 
and Korman, 2019 ). But since this study lacked a control 
group, a more meticulously planned investigation would be 
required to reach conclusions about its effectiveness.
7 Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)
Domestic animals, especially military dogs, are prone to 
developing posttraumatic stress disorder. It occurs when 
the subject is exposed to a dreadful condition such as brutal 
personal attacks, tragic events, natural or man-made disas -
ters, or violent conflict ( Fig. 6). Although there are many 
different situations in which domestic dogs might get this 
illness, it is estimated that 650 million army canines (5%) 
returning from the frontlines experience PTSD (Haq, 2017; 
Haq et al., 2022). A dog may get PTSD if he is abandoned 
in the wild, endures maltreatment, loses his owner, or en -
counters a storm or other natural calamity ( Fig.  6). Dogs 
with PTSD may exhibit symptoms such as persistent anxi -
ety, anorexia, unwillingness to urinate, pacing, loss of sleep, 
barking without cause, hiding, trembling or shaking, ag -
gressiveness, panting, uneasiness, being terrified and cling-
ing to their owners, hostility, hopelessness, and being too 
attentive. Canines commonly stop reacting and functioning 
in the military. Some of the most frequent triggers of fear 
that result in trauma, anxiety, and PTSD include thunder 
and fireworks. Any dog with PTSD must undergo difficult 
therapy, which varies depending on the situation. Treatment 
for PTSD involves both medication and behavioral change. 
Dogs do not have the same capacity for memory that people 
do, so with a little assistance from you, your dog can prog -
ress. Positivity and happiness will help your dog cope with 
PTSD. When a dog experiences a frightening scenario, you 
do not want to comfort him. That will just increase her anxi-
ety. Instead, show her you are happy and do not feel sorry 
for her. Teach her to connect the circumstance with posi -
tive things like a hug, a game, some nice words, or a treat 
(https://www.dogsnaturallymagazine.com/ptsd-in-dogs-
and-how-to-manage-it-naturally/, Dogs Naturally, 2022 ). 
As dog owners, we have a tendency to think we are the best 
people to make decisions for our dogs. But when dealing 
with a dog that has PTSD, things are different. Giving your 
dog the opportunity to do what she believes is correct can 
enhance her quality of life and lower her stress levels. Why 
is that relevant? When you go on walks, let your dog choose 
the route rather than leading the way. If your dog seems 
apprehensive, do not insist on bringing them on a car ride. 
Try your best to avoid any stressful situations. Always be 
alert for your dog’s signs of discomfort and provide her the 
freedom to act whatever she pleases ( https://www.dogsnat-
urallymagazine.com/ptsd-in-dogs-and-how-to-manage-it-
naturally/, Dogs Naturally, 2022).

Behavioral disorders of dogs and cats  Chapter | 8  111
A doctor must write a prescription for anxiolytic medi -
cations such as clomipramine, fluoxetine, and amitripty -
line as well as a behavioral program called desensitization 
(Fig. 6). The drug’s use was discontinued after positive re -
sults in dogs. Desensitization entails introducing the dog to 
the upsetting stimuli gradually. If the noise was the prob -
lem, the animal behaviorist would start by creating it at a 
very low volume. The dog is rewarded with food if it toler-
ates the noise. The sound is delivered in a way that gets 
increasingly louder with each presentation. Additionally, 
regular exercise, playtime, methodical desensitization, and 
positive reinforcement training are all part of the PTSD dog 
behavior plan. PTSD is routinely treated with many of the 
same medications that are used to treat canine SAD ( Haq, 
2017; Haq et al., 2022).
8 Behavior problems and pain
Changes in behavior are the most typical indication of pain 
in animals. Both the loss of typical behavior and the emer -
gence of novel, deviant behaviors are behavioral indicators 
of pain ( Camps et al., 2019 ). The most frequent behaviors 
labeled as “lost typical behaviors” are decreased ambulation 
or activity, less engagement with family members or other 
pets, a sluggish demeanor, decreased hunger, and decreased 
resting habits. Aggression, frightened responses, improper 
elimination, vocalization, changed facial expression, altered 
posture, restlessness, and concealment are the most  typical 
“aberrant behaviors.” Repetitive actions have also been 
linked to pain. From a clinical standpoint, pain should be 
taken into consideration when determining the differential 
diagnosis of aggressive behaviors, fear and phobia reactions 
sleep problems, incontinence in urination, vocalization, and 
repetitive behaviors (Camps et al., 2019).
9 Issues with vomeronasal organ 
and behavior
The VNO (vomeronasal organ, also known as Jacobson’s 
organ), a part of the accessory olfactory tract, is located on 
each side of the nasal septum. The pheromones that travel 
into the environment are detected by the vomeronasal organ, 
and these substances are in charge of changing the behavior 
of animals that are generally of the same species ( Camps 
et  al., 2019). According to postmortem studies in various 
species, the VNO can be damaged by inflammatory changes, 
and these changes may impact the function of any tissue. 
Therefore, inflammatory alterations in the VNO may cause 
behavioral problems. According to Asproni et al. (2018), ag-
gressive cat behavior may be connected to feline vomerona-
salitis. Therefore, the need for VNO imaging like MRI arises 
from its postulated possible involvement in various behav -
ioral pathologies, like aggression in cats. Investigating the 
possibility of identifying these inflammatory modifications 
in  vivo may be useful to improve the early diagnosis and 
treatment of the problem (Camps et al., 2019).
FIG. 6 Schematic diagram showing posttraumatic stress disorder in dogs.

112 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
10 Heart diseases and behavioral issues
Animals like dogs and cats with cardiac anomalies have less 
physical activity, which might result in behavioral disorders. 
However, it is uncommon for these issues to be referred to 
an animal behavior specialist, and they often get better after 
receiving cardiac care. Despite this, cognitive dysfunction is 
a disorder that is frequently handled as a behavioral issue and 
may be closely related to cardiac issues. Animals’ cognitive 
failure has traditionally been attributed to mitochondrial dys-
function, which, among other things, causes neuronal oxida-
tive damage. However, the CNS’s decreased or changed blood 
perfusion, which may be brought on by cardiac issues, may 
be the source of this oxidative damage. In human medicine, 
this relationship is firmly established (Gorelick, 2004; Camps 
et al., 2019). Epidemiological studies reveal that 61% of the 
human patients suffering from dementia have Alzheimer’s 
disease (AD), and 54% have cardiac issues, but vascular de-
mentia (VaD) and Alzheimer’s disease co-occur in the major-
ity of cases (Victoroff et al., 1995; Camps et al., 2019). When 
compared to the general population, those with V AD demen-
tia have a significantly lower life expectancy. Animal studies 
on the prevalence and physiopathology of this issue are lack-
ing. Though humans and animals may both benefit from us-
ing animals as medical models, more research into this topic 
must be carried out. In actuality, some of the vascular risk 
factors associated with dementia in humans, such as diabetes, 
hypertension, obesity, and high triglyceride levels, are also 
present in canine and feline patients ( Camps et  al., 2019). 
Even in aging, middle-aged, and elderly dogs that appear 
healthy, some of those risk factors are still present. In light of 
this evidence, it is recommended that all animals exhibiting 
cognitive impairment be checked for cardiac issues and given 
the appropriate therapies if any are found. Therefore, future 
veterinary medicine research should involve the investigation 
of vascular dementia (Camps et al., 2019).
11 Some adverse outcomes of drugs 
prescribed for behavioral disorders
By causing drowsiness and thereby lowering respon -
siveness to environmental stimuli in pets, Acepromazine 
anxiolytic medicine has historically been used to treat 
undesirable behaviors. When used as an anxiety medi -
cation, Acepromazine frequently has unsatisfactory re -
sults and may even have unfavorable side effects ( Craven 
et  al., 2022 ). Nowadays, serotonin reuptake inhibitors 
(SRIs) or benzodiazepines like diazepam are more fre -
quently used for behavioral problems. Diazepam is the 
second-most popular medication used to treat undesired 
behaviors, but pet owners have stopped using it because 
of unfavorable side effects like aggressiveness, sedation, 
and ataxia. Benzodiazepines have been shown to reduce 
conditioned responses, cause memory deficiencies, and 
perhaps impair learning-based behavioral change in the 
case of pets ( Simpson and Papich, 2003 ; Craven et  al., 
2022). When the medicine buspirone was used in pet 
animals, several veterinarians noted negative side effects 
like aggressiveness, disinhibition, and increased anxiety 
signs. Alprazolam and clorazepate usage similarly affect 
companion animals, causing agitation, ataxia, polyphagia, 
and drowsiness. Pets treated with selegiline have experi -
enced anxiety, confusion, and occasionally vomiting and 
diarrhea. Fluoxetine, paroxetine, and sertraline have been 
linked to side effects such as tremors, decreased seizure 
threshold, agitation, and inappetence. Constipation, re -
duced appetite, dry mouth, dry eyes, increased anxiety, 
drowsiness, tachycardia, and urine retention are side ef -
fects of using amitriptyline and clomipramine ( https://
todaysveterinarypractice.com/behavior/the-use-of-medi -
cations-in-canine-behavior-therapy/ ). Moreover, owners 
of pets should take into account a number of significant 
factors, one of which is the cessation of pharmaceutical 
treatment. A sudden drug stop may worsen behavior is -
sues or lead to rebound anxiety. Depending on the length 
of therapy, any medicine should be weaned gradually over 
weeks or months; a fair rule of thumb is a 25% reduc -
tion every 1 to 2 weeks. A reduced but the equally effective 
dose may be continued, or the old dose may be restarted 
if the owner reports any recurrence of the behavioral is -
sue ( https://todaysveterinarypractice.com/behavior/the-
use-of-medications-in-canine-behavior-therapy/ , Today’s 
Veterinary Practice, 2022 ). Based on the aforementioned 
information, a medical history (including a list of any cur -
rent drugs), physical examination, and blood and urine 
analysis are recommended before beginning any phar -
macological therapy in any animal, regardless of age, 
physical condition, or drug category. Treatment with be -
havior medicine can range in length from very brief (e.g., 
6 months for individuals whose anxiety has to be decreased 
for learning to occur) to longer-term therapy (e.g., years 
for animals whose behavior is not adequately responsive 
to behavior modification alone) ( https://todaysveterinary -
practice.com/behavior/the-use-of-medications-in-canine-
behavior-therapy/, Today’s Veterinary Practice, 2022).

Chapter 9
Respiratory diseases of dogs and cats
1 Introduction
Respiratory diseases in companion animals present a 
complex and multifaceted challenge in veterinary medi -
cine. These diseases can range from mild upper respira -
tory infections to severe and life-threatening pneumonia, 
with underlying pathologies that can be both infectious 
and noninfectious. The intricate clinical presentations and 
pathophysiological mechanisms of respiratory diseases 
in dogs and cats require a comprehensive understanding 
of the underlying etiologies, which can be augmented by 
cutting-edge diagnostic and therapeutic approaches. Recent 
advancements in diagnostic techniques, including advanced 
imaging modalities and molecular diagnostic methods, have 
enabled more rapid and precise identification of causative 
agents and underlying pathologies. This has led to improved 
accuracy and efficacy of clinical management. Moreover, 
emerging therapeutic approaches, such as immunotherapy 
and gene therapy, hold immense potential for the treatment 
of respiratory diseases in dogs and cats. Despite these ad -
vancements, the diagnosis and management of respiratory 
diseases in companion animals remain complex and chal -
lenging. The diversity of underlying causes and clinical 
presentations necessitates a multidisciplinary approach to 
veterinary care, with close collaboration between veterinar-
ians, diagnostic specialists, and other healthcare profession-
als. This chapter aims to provide a comprehensive overview 
of the current understanding of the pathogenesis, clini -
cal manifestations, diagnostic strategies, and therapeutic 
management of respiratory diseases in dogs and cats. The 
chapter will highlight the latest research on cutting-edge 
diagnostic and therapeutic approaches, including their im -
pact on clinical outcomes and quality of life for affected 
animals. Ultimately, the chapter seeks to promote a deeper 
understanding of respiratory diseases in companion animals 
and support the development of more effective and targeted 
approaches to their diagnosis and management.
2 Anatomy and physiology of the 
respiratory system in dogs and cats
2.1 The structure and function of the upper 
respiratory tract (nasal passages, sinuses, 
pharynx)
The upper respiratory tract is a complex system of intercon-
nected structures that work together to facilitate the entry of 
air into the lungs. The nasal passages are lined with mucous 
membranes that contain cilia and goblet cells, which help 
to filter and humidify inhaled air. The sinuses, which are 
air-filled cavities within the facial bones, are connected to 
the nasal passages and serve to further filter and humidify 
inhaled air. The pharynx, which is located at the back of the 
mouth, serves as a passageway for both air and food and is 
lined with specialized lymphoid tissue that helps to defend 
against pathogens (Vandenplas et al., 2018). The upper re -
spiratory tract plays a critical role in respiratory health by 
filtering and warming inhaled air and providing a defense 
against pathogens. The nasal passages and sinuses work to-
gether to filter out particulate matter and allergens, while 
the mucous membranes and goblet cells help to humidify 
and warm inhaled air before it enters the lungs. The pharynx 
serves as a passageway for both air and food and contains 
specialized lymphoid tissue that helps to defend against 
pathogens (Cervin, 2018).
2.2 The structure and function of the lower 
respiratory tract (trachea, bronchi, bronchioles, 
alveoli)
The lower respiratory tract is a complex system that plays 
a critical role in maintaining adequate oxygenation of the 
body tissues. The trachea is lined with ciliated epithelial 
cells that help to move mucus and debris out of the airway

116 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
and is also involved in immune defense. The bronchi and 
bronchioles are lined with ciliated epithelial cells and other 
cell types, such as goblet cells and Clara cells, which pro -
duce mucus and surfactant, respectively, to maintain airway 
patency and are also involved in immune defense. The bron-
chioles are surrounded by smooth muscle that can regulate 
airflow, and the alveoli are the site of gas exchange, with 
a thin layer of epithelial cells separating the air from the 
bloodstream.
2.3 The role of the respiratory system in gas 
exchange and regulation of blood pH
Efficient gas exchange is crucial for optimal lung function 
and is dependent on the alveolar-capillary membrane’s 
mechanical properties. The extracellular matrix plays a 
critical role in regulating this membrane, and changes in 
it, such as increased collagen deposition, can impede gas 
exchange. Smoking and exposure to secondhand smoke or 
household air pollution can damage the lungs and impair 
gas exchange in dogs and cats. The regulation of blood 
pH is interconnected between the respiratory and renal 
systems, with changes in pH affecting the production of 
hormones that stimulate red blood cell production. The 
circadian clock also plays a role in regulating blood pH 
through the expression of genes involved in carbon diox -
ide regulation. Therefore, maintaining healthy lung func -
tion and blood pH regulation is crucial for optimal health 
in dogs and cats.
3 Pathogenic agents that cause 
respiratory diseases in dogs and cats
3.1 Overview of common pathogens causing 
respiratory diseases
● Viruses: The most common viruses that cause respiratory 
infections in dogs and cats include canine parainfluenza 
virus (CPIV), canine adenovirus type 2 (CA V-2), canine 
distemper virus (CDV), feline herpesvirus 1 (FHV-1), 
and feline calicivirus (FCV).
● Bacteria: Bacterial respiratory infections in dogs and 
cats are typically secondary to viral infections or im -
munosuppression. Common bacterial pathogens in -
clude Bordetella bronchiseptica , Mycoplasma spp., 
Streptococcus spp., and Pasteurella spp.
● Fungi: Fungal respiratory infections in dogs and cats are 
less common but can be serious. The most common fun-
gal pathogens include Aspergillus spp., Cryptococcus 
spp., and Blastomyces spp.
● Parasites: Parasitic respiratory infections in dogs and 
cats are typically caused by lungworms, which include 
Aelurostrongylus abstrusus in cats and Angiostrongylus 
vasorum in dogs.
3.2 Modes of transmission for respiratory 
pathogens
3.2.1 Direct contact transmission
Respiratory pathogens can be transmitted through direct 
contact with an infected individual or their secretions, 
such as through coughing, sneezing, or touching contami -
nated surfaces (Sikkema et al., 2020). For instance, studies 
have shown that canine influenza virus can be transmitted 
through direct contact with an infected dog’s saliva, nasal 
discharge, or respiratory secretions (Song et al., 2011).
3.2.2 Indirect contact transmission
Respiratory pathogens can also be transmitted through indi-
rect contact with contaminated objects or surfaces ( Dhama 
et  al., 2020). For example, respiratory pathogens can be 
transmitted indirectly through shared water or food bowls, 
toys, bedding, or grooming equipment (Leung, 2021).
Aerosol transmission
Respiratory pathogens can be transmitted through the air 
as droplets or particles that are small enough to be inhaled. 
Aerosol transmission can occur through activities such 
as coughing, sneezing, or breathing, and is more likely 
to occur with highly contagious respiratory pathogens 
(Ghasemzadeh and Namazi, 2015).
Vector-borne transmission
Respiratory pathogens can also be transmitted through 
the bites of insects or ticks that act as vectors. However, 
this mode of transmission is relatively rare for respiratory 
pathogens in dogs and cats. Overall, understanding the dif -
ferent modes of transmission for respiratory pathogens is 
important for preventing and controlling their spread in 
both animal and human populations.
4 Host defense mechanisms in 
respiratory diseases in dogs and cats
The respiratory system is an important barrier against in -
vading pathogens in dogs and cats. In the event of an in -
fection, the respiratory system employs a variety of host
