defense mechanisms to prevent the pathogen from causing 
harm (Fig. 1).
4.1 Mucociliary clearance
The respiratory tract is lined with a layer of mucus that 
traps foreign particles, such as bacteria and viruses. The 
mucus is then moved out of the respiratory system by cilia, 
which are small hair-like structures that beat in a coordi -
nated manner to propel the mucus upwards and out of the 
airways (Thompson et al., 2020). This process is known as

Respiratory diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 9  117
 mucociliary clearance and is an important defense mecha -
nism against respiratory pathogens.
4.2 Immune response
The respiratory system also has a robust immune response 
that is activated upon encountering a pathogen. The immune 
response is composed of two main components: the innate 
immune response and the adaptive immune response. The 
innate immune response is the first line of defense against 
pathogens and includes cells such as neutrophils, macro -
phages, and natural killer cells ( Sharma et al., 2021 ). The 
adaptive immune response, on the other hand, is activated 
after the innate immune response and involves the produc -
tion of antibodies that specifically target the pathogen.
4.3 Inflammatory response
The respiratory system also has an inflammatory response 
that is activated during respiratory infections. Inflammation 
helps to limit the spread of the pathogen and promotes tissue 
repair. However, excessive inflammation can also cause tis-
sue damage and lead to complications (Arora et al., 2020).
4.4 Antimicrobial peptides
Antimicrobial peptides are small molecules that can kill or 
inhibit the growth of pathogens. The respiratory system pro-
duces a variety of antimicrobial peptides, such as defensins 
and cathelicidins, which are effective against a wide range 
of respiratory pathogens (Meng et al., 2021).
5 Common respiratory diseases in dogs
5.1 Canine infectious respiratory disease 
complex
The canine infectious respiratory disease complex (CIRDC) 
is a challenging and highly contagious condition for shel -
ters. Its management requires a comprehensive approach 
 because it has multiple contributing factors. The develop -
ment of CIRDC is not solely caused by the pathogens as -
sociated with it but also by environmental factors and the 
immune system of the host. Pathogens associated with 
CIRDC, such as bacteria and viruses, can cause disease 
when acting alone or in combination. Common bacterial 
pathogens include Bordetella bronchiseptica, Mycoplasma 
spp., and Streptococcus equi subsp. zooepidemicus, while 
viral pathogens include distemper (CDV), parainflu -
enza (CPIV), adenovirus type 2 (CA V-2), influenza (CIV 
H3N8), respiratory coronavirus (CRCoV), and pneumovi -
rus (CnPnV).
CIRDC pathogenesis is complex, and new research on 
both known and emerging pathogens is continually adding 
to the complexity. High-density environments like shel -
ters contribute to the outbreaks of CIRDC by amplifying 
the exposure, susceptibility, and transmission of infectious 
diseases. Novel pathogens that potentially contribute to 
CIRDC have been detected in dogs housed in high-density 
environments. The incubation period for CIRDC is usually 
2–3 days but can vary from 2 days to 4–5 weeks depending 
on the pathogen. All CIRDC pathogens have a preclinical 
shedding period, making it difficult to manage the disease. 
Clinical signs and shedding usually last for 5–10 days, but 
some pathogens may continue to shed for a longer time 
(Bordetella, Mycoplasma, and CDV). The clinical signs of 
CIRDC are generally mild and self-limiting, with coughing, 
sneezing, and nasal and ocular discharge being common. 
Severe infection is more common in younger and immuno-
compromised animals.
The clinical signs of all CIRDC pathogens overlap, mak-
ing it challenging to diagnose the cause of the disease based 
on clinical signs alone. However, the affected population’s 
patterns and the severity of the signs may provide some 
clues to the likely causative pathogen(s). For instance, CIV 
infection typically results in high clinical signs in all dogs, 
regardless of age or vaccine status, in a naïve population. 
If some dogs show distinctive clinical signs like neurologi-
cal signs characteristic of distemper, it is likely that other 
dogs showing milder disease are also infected with the same 
pathogen. Conversely, a CDV outbreak is unlikely if many 
dogs, particularly those over 5 months old, are affected, and 
none show characteristic neurological signs.
Effective biosecurity measures include isolation of 
newly arrived dogs, frequent cleaning and disinfection of 
common areas and surfaces, and minimizing direct con -
tact between dogs (e.g., separate play areas, and staggered 
feeding times). In addition, it is important to identify and 
manage animals that are carriers of CIRDC pathogens. This 
may include testing and treatment of incoming dogs, rou -
tine screening of the resident population, and segregating 
infected or carrier dogs from healthy dogs. It is also impor-
tant to promote healthy immune systems in all dogs through 
appropriate nutrition, exercise, and stress  reduction. This 
FIG. 1 Major host defense mechanisms in respiratory diseases.

118 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
includes providing a low-stress environment with adequate 
space, socialization, and enrichment, as well as minimiz -
ing overcrowding and reducing noise and other stressors. 
Vaccination is an important component of prevention, but it 
is not a silver bullet. Vaccination should be viewed as a tool 
to support the overall health of each animal and reduce the 
risk of severe or complicated disease in the event of expo -
sure. The American Animal Hospital Association (AAHA) 
recommends that all dogs in shelters be vaccinated against 
CIV , canine distemper virus, canine adenovirus 2, and ca -
nine parvovirus. Additional vaccines may be indicated 
based on regional disease prevalence and individual animal 
risk factors. It is important to follow appropriate vaccination 
schedules and protocols, including booster vaccinations as 
recommended by the manufacturer and veterinarian. In sum-
mary, the prevention and management of CIRDC in shelter 
settings require a multifaceted approach that includes ef -
fective biosecurity measures, promotion of overall health 
and immune function, appropriate vaccination, and timely 
diagnosis and treatment of affected animals. A collaborative 
and proactive approach between shelter staff, veterinarians, 
and public health officials can help to minimize the impact 
of CIRDC on animal welfare and public health.
5.2 Canine influenza
Canine influenza, also known as dog flu, is a highly con -
tagious respiratory infection that affects dogs. The disease 
is caused by two different strains of the influenza virus, 
namely, H3N8 and H3N2. In recent years, canine influenza 
has become a growing concern among veterinarians, dog 
owners, and researchers alike. Epidemiology canine influ -
enza was first reported in racing greyhounds in Florida in 
2004 and was later found to be caused by the H3N8 strain 
of the influenza virus ( Crawford et  al., 2005). In 2015, a 
new strain of the virus, H3N2, was identified in dogs in the 
United States ( Song et al., 2015 ). Since then, both strains 
of the virus have been detected in dogs in several countries 
worldwide, including the United States, Canada, Korea, 
China, and Thailand ( Lee et  al., 2020 ; Noh et  al., 2021 ; 
Sun et al., 2020). Canine influenza typically presents as an 
acute respiratory infection with symptoms shown in Fig. 2 
(Pesavento et  al., 2008a,b ). In severe cases, the infection 
can lead to pneumonia and respiratory failure, especially 
in dogs with underlying health conditions or weakened im-
mune systems (Pulford et al., 2020). In some cases, infected 
dogs may also develop conjunctivitis or gastrointestinal 
symptoms, such as vomiting and diarrhea ( Bourogaa et al., 
2019). The diagnosis of canine influenza is based on a com-
bination of clinical signs, history of exposure to infected 
dogs, and laboratory testing.
The most commonly used laboratory test for canine 
influenza is the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay, 
which detects the viral RNA in respiratory secretions or 
blood samples ( Li et  al., 2019 ). Serological testing, such 
as the hemagglutination inhibition assay or the virus neu -
tralization test, can also be used to confirm a diagnosis or 
to detect previous exposure to the virus ( Liu et al., 2020 ). 
Treatment of canine influenza is mainly supportive and 
aimed at relieving the clinical signs and preventing sec -
ondary infections. Antiviral medications, such as oseltami -
vir and zanamivir, may be used in severe cases or in dogs 
with underlying health conditions ( Bourogaa et al., 2019 ). 
Antibiotics may also be prescribed to prevent or treat sec -
ondary bacterial infections (Kirk et al., 2018). The best way 
to prevent canine influenza is through vaccination. Vaccines 
are available for both H3N8 and H3N2 strains of the virus 
and are recommended for dogs at risk of exposure, such as 
those that frequent dog parks, boarding facilities, or daycare 
centers (Crawford et al., 2018). Other preventive measures 
include avoiding contact with infected dogs, practicing 
good hygiene, and isolating infected dogs from healthy 
ones (Pulford et al., 2020).
5.3 Canine distemper
Canine distemper virus (CDV) is a single-stranded RNA 
virus with an enveloped structure and belongs to the 
Paramyxoviridae family ( Dunlop et al., 2018 ). CDV has a 
diameter of 120–250  nm and consists of a nucleocapsid, a 
lipid envelope, and two surface glycoproteins, hemaggluti -
nin (H), and fusion (F) (Khalyat et al., 2019). The H protein 
mediates the attachment of the virus to host cells, while the 
F protein promotes the fusion of the viral envelope with the 
host cell membrane, allowing viral entry. CDV primarily 
FIG. 2 Symptoms of canine influenza.

Respiratory diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 9  119
 infects cells of the lymphoid, epithelial, and nervous sys -
tems, leading to systemic infection ( Dunlop et al., 2018 ). 
The virus replicates within infected cells, causing cell death 
and tissue damage. CDV can also induce immunosuppres -
sion by infecting and destroying immune cells, particularly 
T lymphocytes, leading to secondary bacterial or viral in -
fections ( Fukuzawa and Nishio, 2021 ). The incubation 
period of canine distemper (CD) varies from 3 to 14 days, 
during which the virus spreads quickly to lymphoid tissues, 
leading to systemic infection (Sadar et al., 2020). The initial 
signs of CD are nonspecific, such as fever, anorexia, leth -
argy, and respiratory signs like coughing, nasal discharge, 
and conjunctivitis ( Kim et  al., 2018). As the disease pro -
gresses, dogs may develop severe signs such as gastroin -
testinal symptoms like vomiting and diarrhea, neurological 
signs like ataxia, seizures, and paresis, and immunosup -
pression leading to secondary bacterial or viral infections 
(Fig. 3) (Fukuzawa and Nishio, 2021 ). In puppies, the CD 
can cause enamel hypoplasia and distemper teeth due to the 
destruction of tooth enamel-forming cells ( Moustafa et al., 
2020). The severity of clinical signs can vary widely, from 
mild to severe or even fatal.
In addition to supportive care, the prevention of CD is 
essential. Vaccination is the most effective way to prevent 
CD, and all dogs should be vaccinated according to their 
local vaccination schedules. Vaccination not only protects 
individual dogs but also helps to control the spread of the 
disease in the community. Vaccination can also reduce the 
severity of clinical signs if a vaccinated dog becomes in -
fected with CDV ( De Vries and De Swart, 2014 ). Other 
preventive measures include proper hygiene, isolation of 
infected dogs, and disinfection of contaminated objects and 
environments. In conclusion, canine distemper is a highly 
contagious viral disease that can affect dogs and other 
canids worldwide. The disease is caused by CDV , which 
primarily infects lymphoid, epithelial, and nervous system 
cells. CD can cause a wide range of clinical signs, from 
mild to severe or even fatal, and diagnosis can be challeng-
ing. Laboratory tests, including PCR, serology, and virus 
isolation, are essential for confirming CD diagnosis. While 
there is no specific treatment for CD, supportive care and 
prevention through vaccination and other measures are crit-
ical to managing the disease.
5.4 Canine parainfluenza virus
The canine parainfluenza virus is a member of the 
Rubulavirus genus, which falls within the subfam -
ily Paramyxovirinae, order Mononegavirales, and fam -
ily Paramyxoviridae ( Decaro et  al., 2020 ). Within the 
FIG. 3 Symptoms of canine distemper (CD).

120 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
Rubulavirus genus, the virus is accompanied by distant 
relatives, such as the HPIV types 2 and 4, as well as the 
mumps virus, which exhibits genetic and antigenic differ -
ences (Amarasinghe et al., 2021 ). The CPIV , like all other 
PIVs, is characterized by a single-stranded, nonsegmented, 
negative-sense RNA genome, which is around 15,000 nu -
cleotides in length, with six genes arranged in an invariant 
order, namely, N-P-M-F-HN-L (Karron and Collins, 2013). 
Interestingly, CPIV has a unique feature compared to other 
mammalian PIVs, as it contains an additional gene, the SH 
gene, located between the fusion (F) and hemagglutinin-
neuraminidase (HN) genes on the gene map ( Decaro et al., 
2020).
The genetic makeup of the virus is characterized by 
seven genes, which code for eight proteins ( Jones et  al., 
2020). The nucleocapsid or ribonucleoprotein core of the 
virus is formed by an association of the nucleoprotein (N) 
and the phosphoprotein (P) and large (L) proteins, together 
with the genome ( Rahman et  al., 2021 ). The viral RNA-
dependent RNA polymerase, which plays an essential role 
in viral mRNA transcription and genomic RNA replication, 
is formed by a complex of the P and L proteins (Sola et al., 
2020). The matrix (M) protein, which is not glycosylated, 
is the most abundant viral protein in an infected cell and is 
located on the inner face of the envelope. It is considered 
an essential organizational protein of the virus, as it affects 
the assembly, budding, and release of progeny virions ( Du 
et al., 2020). Additionally, the homotetrameric HN and ho-
motrimeric F glycoproteins, which are found on spikes in 
the envelope, play a crucial role in the virus’s attachment to 
and penetration of the host cell (Sun et al., 2021).
Canine parainfluenza virus (CPIV) is a highly prevalent 
virus that affects canines worldwide, indiscriminate of age 
or breed. This virus is transmitted through direct contact 
with infected dogs or fomites such as toys, food bowls, and 
grooming equipment. The contagion period of CPIV can 
last up to 48  h on surfaces, making environments such as 
kennels and shelters more susceptible to outbreaks. The fall 
and winter seasons present a more favorable environment 
for the development of CPIV (Erles and Brownlie, 2018).
The pathogenesis of canine parainfluenza virus (CPIV) 
infection is similar to that of other paramyxoviruses ( Diel 
et  al., 2012 ). At the cellular level, the HN glycoprotein 
in the viral envelope binds to N-acetylneuraminic (sialic) 
acid residues on host cells ( Matrosovich et al., 2004). This 
binding is favored at extracellular (neutral) pH and halide 
concentration and occurs through hemagglutination activ -
ity (Horvath and Stillman, 1992 ). The sialic acid receptor 
is ubiquitous on cell surfaces, thus exposing a range of re -
spiratory tract cells to CPIV infection (Shaw et al., 2002).
However, there is a lack of classic time course electron 
micrographic studies of CPIV pathogenesis in vivo in dogs 
(Liang et al., 2021a,b). Notably, such studies could identify 
the range of epithelial cell types that are infected by CPIV . 
Once fusion between the virus and the target cell occurs, the 
viral nucleocapsid enters the cytoplasm, and viral replica -
tion ensues (Rima et al., 2011). The production of progeny 
virions first involves viral polymerase-mediated transcrip -
tion of mRNAs that serve as a template for the translation 
of viral proteins ( Desselberger, 2013). Then, RNA replica-
tion occurs through an intermediate or plus-stranded antige-
nome, which is an exact complimentary copy of the genome 
(Liang et al., 2021a,b).
The clinical manifestations of canine parainfluenza 
virus (CPIV) infection can span from mild coughing and 
nasal discharge to severe pneumonia. Additional symptoms 
may include fever, lethargy, and anorexia. The diagnostic 
process of CPIV typically entails PCR testing of nasal or 
pharyngeal swabs, or serological testing for virus-specific 
antibodies. It should be emphasized that the clinical features 
of CPIV infection can be analogous to those of other respi-
ratory pathogens, thereby rendering diagnosis a formidable 
challenge ( Zhang et  al., 2021 ). As with other respiratory 
pathogens, identification of the agent in nasal secretions is 
considered the most definitive diagnostic approach for ac -
tive CPIV infection prior to death. Although not specifically 
studied for CPIV , experience with other paramyxoviruses 
suggests that the use of polyester-tipped swabs may yield 
the best results when attempting virus isolation. In vitro cul-
tivation of CPIV in epithelial and mesenchymal cells from 
various species is feasible, although the use of primary ca -
nine cells, as utilized in early studies, could enhance the 
sensitivity of detecting field isolates.
Confirmation of CPIV isolation in cell culture involves 
a two-step procedure, including evaluation of cytopathic 
effects, such as intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies and syn -
cytium formation, which differ among isolates, as well as 
hemadsorption with guinea pig erythrocytes or definitive 
staining with immunofluorescence or immunohistochemi -
cal methods. In contrast to canine herpesvirus, CPIV is 
relatively labile in storage and transportation. Failure to rec-
ognize this may result in false-negative isolation outcomes.
There has been significant progress in the development 
of diagnostic tools for canine parainfluenza virus (CPIV). 
Immunofluorescence staining of cells obtained from nasal 
swab smears is a rapid diagnostic tool. PCR tests have also 
been developed and employed in the field for potentially more 
sensitive and rapid diagnosis of CPIV infection. Serological 
testing by utilizing acute and convalescent samples collected 
optimally 10–14 days apart can serve as a supplement to an-
temortem CPIV diagnosis. Although enzyme- linked immu-
nosorbent assay represents a more rapid alternative, several 
factors may complicate the utilization of serological testing 
for CPIV diagnosis. However, utilizing an IgM-specific 
ELISA to differentiate recent versus prior exposure to the 
virus may address some of these issues. In dogs that suc -
cumb to respiratory disease, the presence of tracheobronchi-
tis or broncholytic lesions suggests CPIV infection, which

Respiratory diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 9  121
can be most effectively and consistently diagnosed through 
immunohistochemical staining. It is worth noting that dogs 
that have received intranasal and potentially parenteral CPIV 
vaccines may yield false-positive PCR results for an indeter-
minate period after vaccination, which must be considered 
during diagnosis (Pratelli, 2021).
CPIV eludes any specific therapy, and the recommended 
approach is predominantly palliative, such as hydration 
and symptomatic relief. Antibiotics may be prescribed in 
response to secondary bacterial infections. Prophylaxis 
against CPIV primarily comprises vaccination, coupled with 
rigorous sanitization and segregation of afflicted canines. 
CPIV vaccines are typically administered in conjunction 
with respiratory vaccines such as those for Bordetella bron-
chiseptica and canine adenovirus to maximize protection. 
Scrupulous sanitation practices, including surface and toy 
disinfection, play a pivotal role in impeding viral spread. To 
curb CPIV transmission, infected dogs must be confined to 
impede disease dissemination (Erles and Brownlie, 2018).
6 Common respiratory diseases in cats
6.1 Feline upper respiratory infection
Feline upper respiratory infection (URI) is a common and 
highly contagious disease in cats. It is caused by a variety 
of viral and bacterial agents that can affect the upper respi -
ratory tract of cats. URI is known to cause mild-to-severe 
symptoms in cats, including sneezing, nasal discharge, 
coughing, fever, and loss of appetite. In this chapter, we 
will discuss the pathogenesis, clinical signs, diagnosis, and 
treatment of feline URI.
URI is primarily caused by two viruses, FeHV-1 and 
FCV . These viruses are transmitted through direct contact 
with an infected cat or by indirect contact with fomites, 
such as food and water bowls, litter boxes, and bedding. 
Both viruses infect the upper respiratory epithelium and 
cause damage to the ciliated epithelium, leading to the clini-
cal signs of URI (Radford et al., 2015).
The clinical signs of URI vary in severity and can be 
mild or severe. The most common clinical signs of URI are 
sneezing, nasal discharge, and conjunctivitis. Other signs 
include coughing, fever, loss of appetite, and lethargy. In 
some cases, URI can progress to a severe form of the dis -
ease known as feline viral rhinotracheitis (FVR), which can 
cause severe respiratory distress and can be fatal (Bol et al., 
2019).
Diagnosis of URI is based on clinical signs and labo -
ratory testing. Clinical signs such as sneezing, nasal dis -
charge, and conjunctivitis are typical of URI. Laboratory 
testing can include viral isolation, PCR, and serology. 
Viral isolation involves taking swabs from the nasal cavity, 
throat, or conjunctiva of an infected cat and culturing the 
virus in cell culture. PCR involves detecting the viral DNA 
in  clinical samples using molecular techniques. Serology 
involves measuring the level of antibodies against FeHV-1 
and FCV in the blood (Hobson and Bunn-Moreno, 2021).
Treatment of URI is primarily supportive and aimed at 
managing the clinical signs of the disease. Antibiotics may 
be used to treat secondary bacterial infections, but they are 
not effective against viral infections. Antiviral drugs, such 
as famciclovir and interferon, have been used to treat URI, 
but their efficacy is variable ( Hoskins, 2017 ). Other sup -
portive treatments include humidification, nebulization, and 
nutritional support.
6.2 Feline asthma
Feline asthma is a significant health concern for many cat 
owners and veterinarians alike. According to a recent study 
by Bexley et  al. (2020) , the prevalence of feline asthma 
has been steadily increasing over the past decade, with es -
timates now suggesting that up to 5% of cats may be af -
fected. This finding is supported by other recent studies that 
have also reported a rising incidence of feline asthma in 
both North America and Europe (Becker et al., 2019; Padrid 
et al., 2021).
In terms of treatment, recent research has focused on 
novel therapies such as immunotherapy and gene therapy. 
A recent study by Chang et al. (2022)  investigated the use 
of CRISPR-Cas9 technology to correct a genetic mutation 
associated with feline asthma, showing promising results in 
a small sample of affected cats. Meanwhile, a recent sys -
tematic review by Han et al. (2021)  evaluated the efficacy 
of immunotherapy for feline asthma, concluding that while 
the evidence is limited, it may be a viable treatment option 
for some cats.
Patient history and physical examination are critical 
components in the assessment of feline asthma, a complex 
condition that can present with varied clinical signs. The 
manifestations of this ailment typically fall into two broad 
categories: acute asthmatic episodes, colloquially known as 
“status asthmaticus,” and the more chronic presentation of 
persistent cough and increased respiratory effort. However, 
these symptoms can occur in a range of intensities and fre -
quencies, making an accurate diagnosis challenging. In sta-
tus asthmaticus, felines exhibit open-mouth breathing, rapid 
breathing, and increased abdominal effort on exhalation. In 
contrast, chronic asthma can go unnoticed and untreated for 
extended periods, leading to the progression of pathological 
changes. Interestingly, some cats with asthma may present 
with vomiting or paroxysmal hacking and coughing, which 
can be misleading, as they may prompt gastroenterological 
rather than respiratory investigations. Physical examination 
findings in cats with asthma include coughing, expiratory 
wheezing, and rapid breathing. Although some cats may not 
display any abnormalities, gentle tracheal palpation often 
elicits a cough. Nonetheless, physical examination findings

122 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
are relatively nonspecific, underscoring the need to consider 
other factors such as diagnostic testing and historical infor-
mation to arrive at a diagnosis of asthma.
Diagnosis of feline asthma is a complex process that re-
quires a combination of clinical examination and laboratory 
testing (DeClue, 2021). A comprehensive physical exami -
nation, including chest auscultation, is crucial in evaluating 
the severity of the clinical signs (Baxter, 2020). Laboratory 
testing may comprise blood work, radiographs, bronchos -
copy, and cytology of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid. An 
increase in eosinophils, a type of white blood cell associ -
ated with allergic responses, may be evident in blood work 
(Lerche et al., 2020 ). Radiographs may reveal changes in 
lung patterns and bronchial wall thickening, while bron -
choscopy enables direct visualization of the airways and 
tissue sample collection for cytology and culture ( Lerche 
et al., 2020; Kikuchi et al., 2022).
It is essential to rule out other diseases that mimic asth -
ma’s clinicopathologic features before diagnosing feline 
asthma definitively. While thoracic radiographs may distin-
guish between some conditions, others require a more de -
tailed examination, given their similar clinical presentations 
and radiographic findings compared to allergic asthma. 
Feline chronic bronchitis, a prevalent ailment among our fe-
line friends, shares multiple clinical hallmarks with asthma, 
including a chronic cough. This condition is typically attrib-
uted to a previous insult to the airways, such as respiratory 
infections or inhaled irritants. This injury causes permanent 
damage to the airways, thereby causing similar historical, 
physical examination, and radiographic features of asthma. 
While both asthma and chronic bronchitis can exhibit bron-
chial patterns on thoracic radiographs, asthmatic cats show 
bronchoconstriction in response to inhaled aeroallergens or 
nonspecific stimulation from inhaled irritants. This reaction 
results in “air-trapping,” which appears as hyperlucent lung 
fields and caudal displacement of the diaphragm on thoracic 
radiographs. This phenomenon can be at least partially re -
versed by administering bronchodilators in asthmatic cats. 
On the other hand, cats with chronic bronchitis do not ex -
perience spontaneous bronchoconstriction. However, they 
can have fixed airflow limitations due to cellular infiltrates 
or remodeling changes. Both asthma and chronic bronchi -
tis exhibit differing cellular infiltrations in bronchoalveolar 
lavage fluid (BALF) cytology, with some overlap. Feline 
allergic asthma is primarily characterized by the presence 
of eosinophilic inflammation. Thus, a predominance of 
eosinophils (over 17%) should be identified in the BALF. 
Conversely, chronic bronchitis should predominantly re -
sult in nondegenerate neutrophilic inflammation in BALF. 
Nonetheless, a clear-cut distinction based on BALF is not 
always possible, as chronic asthma may cause damage to 
the airways, resulting in some neutrophilic inflammation.
Aelurostrongylus, a parasitic disease caused by 
Aelurostrongylus abstrusus , has been found to display 
symptoms resembling those observed in asthmatic patients, 
including eosinophilic airway inflammation (Dantas-Torres, 
2017; Mendoza-Garcia et al., 2020). Felines acquire this in-
fection through the ingestion of snails, slugs, or paratenic 
hosts (Boag et al., 2010 ; Magi et al., 2015 ). Radiographic 
examination typically reveals bronchial to bronchointer -
stitial lung patterns ( Di Cesare et al., 2014 ). The presence 
of larvae in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) cytology 
or fecal Baermann examination is considered a key diag -
nostic indicator that distinguishes Aelurostrongylus from 
other diseases with similar clinical features, such as allergic 
asthma (Ferreira et al., 2017; Magi et al., 2015). Empirical 
treatment with fenbendazole is recommended, even if lar -
vae are not detected in the samples, to ensure the complete 
elimination of Aelurostrongylus ( Di Cesare et  al., 2014 ; 
Mendoza-Garcia et al., 2020).
Heartworm-associated respiratory disease (HARD) is 
a serious health concern for cats, as it can occur even in 
the absence of adult heartworms ( Schoeppler et al., 2019 ). 
According to a recent study, the death of immature L5 
larvae in pulmonary arteries leads to eosinophilic inflam -
mation in the surrounding airways and pulmonary paren -
chyma, resulting in HARD (Reifur et al., 2021). Diagnostic 
tests like heartworm antigen tests or echocardiography are 
not reliable for excluding HARD ( Dillon et al., 2020a,b ), 
and clinicians should consider the disease in cats with ap -
propriate clinicopathologic features and positive heartworm 
antibody tests in an endemic region (Little et al., 2022).
The heartworm endosymbiont, Wolhbachia, has been 
found to contribute to bronchial hyperreactivity in cats with 
HARD (Schoeppler et al., 2019), and a combination of se -
lamectin and doxycycline is recommended for preventing 
larvae development beyond the L4 stage and eliminating 
Wolhbachia, respectively (Dillon et al., 2020a,b).
Toxocara cati is another potential cause of respiratory 
disease in cats. Research has shown that T. cati can induce 
pulmonary and vascular disease in felines through pul -
monary and transtracheal migration ( Waller et  al., 2019). 
Radiographic examinations have revealed bronchointersti -
tial lesions and eosinophilia in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid 
(BALF) in cats infected with T. cati (Cordero del Campillo 
et al., 2020). However, the role of T. cati as a differential di-
agnosis for spontaneous feline asthma remains unclear, and 
further investigation is needed (Little et al., 2022). Finally, 
while clinicopathologic abnormalities of cats with asthma 
are nonspecific, complete blood cell counts have shown 
peripheral eosinophilia in a significant proportion of cases 
(Rapetti et  al., 2021 ). However, this does not necessarily 
correspond with the degree of airway eosinophilia, and spe-
cific serum biochemical or urinalysis abnormalities asso -
ciated with feline asthma have not been identified ( Little 
et al., 2022).
The mainstay of therapy for feline asthma is the adminis-
tration of lifelong steroids, with or without  bronchodilators.

Respiratory diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 9  123
However, these medications may not be effective in all cats 
and are contraindicated in some with concurrent diseases, 
and may even cause adverse effects. Therapies that target 
the underlying immunopathology of asthma or serve as ad-
juncts in refractory asthma are currently under investiga -
tion in experimental feline asthma models. Nevertheless, it 
is crucial to repeat these studies on pet cats with asthma to 
gain a more comprehensive understanding.
The goal of treatment for feline asthma is to allevi -
ate airway inflammation, bronchoconstriction, and mucus 
production while improving respiratory function. Options 
include bronchodilators, corticosteroids, and immunomod -
ulators. Bronchodilators such as terbutaline and salbutamol 
work to relax the bronchioles and improve airway function, 
while corticosteroids like prednisolone and dexamethasone 
act as antiinflammatory agents, reducing airway inflam -
mation and mucus production. Immunomodulators such as 
cyclosporine and leukotriene receptor antagonists modulate 
the immune response to alleviate airway inflammation.
Preventing feline asthma involves minimizing expo -
sure to environmental allergens and irritants. This can be 
accomplished by keeping cats indoors, using air purifiers, 
and avoiding smoking in the household. Regularly clean -
ing and vacuuming the house can also improve indoor air 
quality and reduce exposure to environmental allergens and 
irritants. Vaccination against respiratory pathogens such as 
feline herpesvirus and FCV can lower the risk of develop -
ing secondary respiratory infections, which may exacerbate 
asthma symptoms.
6.3 Feline calicivirus
FCV is an insidious pathogen that has infiltrated the feline 
population with a ubiquitous presence. This highly infec -
tious virus typically incites moderate, self-limiting acute 
oral and upper respiratory tract disease in felines. However, 
some strains have become more virulent and now induce 
lameness. The virus belongs to the Caliciviridae family, 
which includes pivotal pathogens of both humans (norovi -
ruses and sapoviruses, the most prevalent causes of infec -
tious gastroenteritis) and animals (such as vesiviruses like 
FCV , which produces oral vesicles/ulcerations, and lagovi-
ruses like rabbit hemorrhagic disease virus and European 
brown hare syndrome virus). Common symptoms of FCV 
are shown in Fig. 4.
FCV boasts a small single-stranded, positive-sense RNA 
genome that spans about 7.7 kilobases ( Mira et al., 2020 ). 
The genome terminates in a polyadenylated 3′ end, while a 
virally encoded protein encases the 5 ′ end ( Radford et al., 
2015). Furthermore, the genome encodes three open reading 
frames (ORFs). ORF 1 generates nonstructural proteins that 
consist of a viral protease and RNA-dependent RNA poly -
merase. This polyprotein is posttranslationally cleaved by 
the viral protease (Kroneman et al., 2011). ORF 2 encodes 
the major capsid protein, which is divided into six regions 
(A-F) primarily based on sequence conservation. Regions 
B, D, and F are relatively conserved between FCV isolates, 
while regions C and E are variable. It is well known that 
variable region E contains major B-cell epitopes, and the 
region’s variability has been used to differentiate between 
strains ( Cubillos-Zapata et  al., 2020 ). Finally, ORF 3 en -
codes for a minor structural protein (Radford et al., 2015).
As an RNA virus, FCV possesses a high degree of ge -
nomic plasticity due to the lack of proofreading and low fi-
delity of viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerases (Lorusso 
et al., 2017). This mechanism of error-prone replication al-
lows FCV to have exceptional adaptability, which enables it 
to exploit new environmental niches (Radford et al., 2015). 
The adaptability of FCV is reflected at both genetic and 
antigenic levels, and it poses challenges such as selecting 
representative strains for inclusion in vaccines, the presence 
of persistent phylogenetic analysis of nucleotide sequences 
derived mostly from the capsid gene produces a “star-like” 
phylogeny with minimal statistical support for subspecies 
clusters. The only exception to this is seen in viruses from 
Japan, where there is some evidence for the presence of 
two genotypes. However, it is unclear what significance 
this has. Consequently, it has been challenging to identify 
FCV groups based on spatial, temporal, or clinical grounds, 
and the virus is commonly regarded as existing as multiple 
strains, all members of a single diverse genotype.
According to some researchers, a “strain” can be defined 
as FCV isolates that are more than 20% different based on 
the nucleotide sequence of capsid region E ( Miller, 2010). 
Similar to FCV , other caliciviruses, such as human norovi-
ruses, are also characterized by antigenic and genetic vari -
ability, with highly variable genogroups containing multiple 
FIG. 4 Common symptoms of FCV infection.

124 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
genotypes (Green, 2014). However, the origins of this di -
versity remain poorly understood, and further investigation 
of the evolution of FCV may provide new insights into the 
diversification of other caliciviruses (Parker, 2018).
Felis catus, the beloved feline, can fall prey to the FCV 
via a trifecta of transmission routes: nasal, oral, or conjuncti-
val. Although FCV is known to mainly replicate in the respi-
ratory and oral tissues, certain strains exhibit distinct tissue 
tropisms and pathogenicity, with the virus also discovered 
in visceral tissues, fecal matter, and, on occasion, urine. 
The extent of the virus’s impact on transmission remains 
obscure, although it is considered to be trifling. The study 
of FCV’s molecular pathogenesis has yielded significant 
advances due to the virus’s ability to thrive in cell cultures 
and the availability of an infectious clone, which is unique 
among Caliciviridae members. In contrast, human noro- 
and sapoviruses do not grow in cell cultures, and infectious 
clones are not accessible (Coyne and Bergelson, 2019). The 
cytopathic effect of FCV infection on cells is characterized 
by cell rounding and membrane blebbing, which are distinct 
features (Makino et al., 2018 ). Furthermore, FCV inhibits 
cellular protein synthesis, leading to the cleavage of host 
translation initiation factors. This mechanism may allow 
the virus to shift the cellular translation machinery from 
cap-dependent to cap-independent translation, effectively 
blocking the translation of cellular mRNAs and focusing 
exclusively on the viral VpG-bound RNA. This system is 
similar to the mechanism used by closely related picornavi-
ruses (Chung et al., 2013).
Molecular research indicates that FCV triggers the 
mitochondrial pathway, culminating in caspase activa -
tion and apoptosis, in infected cells grown in cell cultures 
(Wise et  al., 2009 ). Recently, FCV research experienced 
a significant breakthrough when scientists discovered that 
junctional adhesion molecule-1 (JAM-1) functioned as a 
cellular receptor for FCV in cell cultures ( Hohdatsu et al., 
2006). However, whether different strains of FCV that are 
associated with various forms of disease utilize different re-
ceptors remains to be determined. Interestingly, in human 
noroviruses, different host expressions of viral receptors 
belonging to the ABH histo-blood group family appear to 
confer resistance to infection in some individuals ( Tan and 
Jiang, 2014). The state of FCV carriage is a complex phe -
nomenon, with cats shedding the virus in oropharyngeal se-
cretions for a typical period of 30 days following infection 
(Lorusso et al., 2020). However, cats shedding the virus be-
yond this period are often categorized as carriers, and while 
some individuals remain carriers for life, most spontane -
ously clear the virus. Recent research has suggested that the 
duration of FCV shedding by carrier cats can be broadly 
approximated by a half-life model, with half of a group of 
positive cats ceasing to shed the virus every 75 days (Addie 
et  al., 2015). The cornerstone of controlling FCV associ -
ated diseases in feline populations lies in the administration 
of vaccines (Gaskell et al., 2007). Several varieties of FCV 
vaccines are now available, typically regarded as safe and 
effective in reducing or preventing classical oral/respiratory 
disease, yet they do not safeguard against the carrier state or 
infection. Evidence from the field suggests that current vac-
cines do not prevent FCV-associated VSD, and outbreaks 
may still occur even in vaccinated cats. Nonetheless, ex -
perimental data do support their usage. The impact of vacci-
nation on lymphoplasmacytic gingivitis stomatitis (LPGS) 
remains unclear. Vaccinated cats may still develop LPGS, 
and no vaccine data sheet claims to prevent this disease. 
This aligns with the uncertain role of FCV in this syndrome.
Recommended vaccination schedules typically involve 
a primary course at 8–9 and 12 weeks, followed by annual 
boosters (Gaskell et al., 2007). However, evidence suggests 
that not all kittens are capable of responding to vaccination 
at 12 weeks of age, and under certain circumstances, later 
vaccinations may be required to overcome persistent mater-
nal antibodies (Day, 2010). Debates are ongoing regarding 
the necessity of annual booster vaccinations, with consider-
ation of the antigenic diversity of FCV being crucial in this 
discussion (Lappin et al., 2017).
Studies have demonstrated moderate levels of virus-  
neutralizing antibodies persisting in a group of vaccinated 
cats for up to 4 years, but titers declined to low or undetect-
able levels after 7.5 years (Spibey et al., 2008). Furthermore, 
protection against FCV challenge decreased from 85% 
3 weeks postvaccination to 63% after 7.5 years. However, it 
should be noted that this study utilized a homologous chal-
lenge, and it is likely that shorter durations of immunity/
protection would have been observed with a heterologous 
challenge (Spibey et al., 2008).
Like many vaccines, adverse reactions have been docu-
mented in a minority of cases, including injection-site re -
actions and sarcomas associated with adjuvanted vaccines 
(Vascellari et  al., 2003). Modified-live FCV vaccines ad -
ministered via injection have been linked to clinical signs 
in the immediate postvaccination period, with some cases 
demonstrating vaccine virus involvement ( Lappin et  al., 
2017). Vaccine virus has also been detected circulating 
in the feline population, though its significance is yet un -
known (Lappin et  al., 2017 ). The antigenic variability of 
FCV strains is yet another challenge to vaccine develop -
ment, with occasional vaccine breakdowns occurring due 
to the inability of a single vaccine to neutralize all field iso-
lates of the virus (Coyne et al., 2018).
To combat some of these issues, a bivalent inactivated, 
nonadjuvanted vaccine has recently been introduced to the 
market in Europe. Overall, the landscape of FCV vaccina -
tion remains complex and multifaceted, requiring careful 
consideration of numerous factors in developing effective 
and safe vaccination strategies. The efficacy of vaccines in 
controlling disease and their success in the marketplace is 
still to be determined. However, it is evident that there are

Respiratory diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 9  125
areas in which vaccines can be improved, posing a con -
siderable challenge. Firstly, it is imperative to increase the 
cross-reactivity of vaccines to maximize cross-protection, 
reduce vaccine breakdowns, and minimize the emergence 
of vaccine-resistant strains. This approach will hopefully 
assist in controlling both typical and more virulent forms 
of the disease. However, the success of including antigens 
from outbreaks of VSD in vaccines to protect against severe 
forms of the disease is uncertain, as each strain of FCV as -
sociated with VSD appears to differ.
A second approach to enhancing existing vaccines is to 
develop immune responses that reduce or eliminate chal -
lenge virus shedding, thereby preventing or reducing the 
likelihood of vaccinated cats becoming persistently in -
fected. Currently, existing vaccines do not prevent infection 
entirely. Moreover, experimental data suggests that under 
specific circumstances, cats with some previous immunity 
may shed challenge virus for longer and at a higher titer 
when compared to naïve cats. The effect of most vaccines on 
viral shedding is generally not publicly available, although 
one vaccine licensed in the EU has a claim to reduce FCV 
shedding. Reducing or eliminating challenge virus shed -
ding in vaccinated cats would be a significant milestone 
in vaccination not only for FCV but also for several other 
important pathogens. Monitoring FCV shedding patterns in 
vaccinated and challenged cats will be crucial in addressing 
this immense challenge.
The mechanisms by which cats are protected against 
clinical disease are still unclear. Although antibodies are 
considered the most crucial factor for protection and are rou-
tinely measured in cell culture by virus neutralization tests, 
some cats with no measurable antibodies are also protected 
against clinical disease. This suggests that cell-  mediated 
and innate immune responses also play an essential role in 
protection. A lack of clear biomarkers for protection repre-
sents a bottleneck to vaccine development, particularly as 
we aim to rationally improve the repertoire of field strains 
covered by individual vaccines. Therefore, in the short to 
medium term, challenge experiments will remain the gold 
standard for measuring FCV vaccine efficacy. However, the 
antigenic variability of FCV complicates both the rational 
choice of challenge virus and the interpretation of challenge 
experiments based on single strains.
The most practical approach will be to test vaccines 
against a panel of representative FCV challenge isolates. 
However, this rigorous experimental approach would be -
come impractical due to the commercial and welfare impli-
cations of very large experiments. In the future, the ultimate 
testing of the efficacy of FCV vaccination may need to take 
place in rigorous phased clinical trials as occurs in human 
medicine. Some published reports suggest novel vaccine 
technologies, including DNA vaccination, myxoma recom-
binants, and herpesvirus recombinants for FCV . Such vac-
cines could offer several potential advantages over those 
based on conventional technologies, including the inability 
to induce FCV infection and the induction of a local muco-
sal immune response. However, to date, none are available 
commercially.
In cases of severe FCV-associated oral and respiratory 
disease, broad-spectrum antibiotic treatment is generally 
recommended to minimize potential complications associ -
ated with secondary bacterial infection. Regular cleansing 
of discharges is essential, and the cat should be encour -
aged to eat by offering strongly flavored aromatic foods. 
Liquidized or specialized proprietary foods may be of some 
help if eating is painful. In some cases, appetite stimulants 
such as diazepam or cyproheptadine may also be of some 
benefit. Severe cases may require fluid therapy, and where 
anorexia is prolonged, an esophagostomy or gastrotomy 
tube may be indicated.
In the domain of viral illnesses affecting human beings, 
treatments for specific as well as broad-spectrum therapies 
have been integrated into clinical practice. However, the 
prohibitive costs of developing specific antivirals for vet -
erinary pathogens make it unlikely to be pursued anytime 
soon. Though certain broad-spectrum antivirals have exhib-
ited effectiveness against FCV in cell cultures, their high 
toxicity levels make them unsuitable for feline usage. While 
some practitioners employ interferon, published proof of its 
efficacy remains limited to laboratory studies, and it lacks 
authorization for controlling FCV-linked disease in Europe. 
Experiments that have employed chimeric monoclonal anti-
bodies derived from mouse-cat hybrids have revealed some 
promising outcomes in treatment.
When it comes to managing FCV-associated respiratory 
disease, the need to control feline herpesvirus is usually 
correlated. A more comprehensive depiction of the control 
measures for these two pathogens is provided elsewhere. 
Generally, control measures for FCV-linked respiratory 
disease hinge entirely on the cat population. For individ -
ual household cats with low prevalence rates, vaccination 
is typically adequate. In boarding and rescue catteries, 
controlling viral loads and curtailing the spread of the vi -
rus throughout the population necessitates vaccination, 
quarantine facilities, batching of arrivals, good husbandry 
and hygiene practices, well-designed pens that prevent 
direct contact between cats, and avoiding overcrowding. 
Molecular investigations into FCV suggest that if executed 
effectively, FCV transmission can be kept to a minimum.
According to the passage, in breeding colonies that are 
confirmed to be free from viruses, inactivated vaccines can 
be utilized, and animals coming into the colony should be 
sourced from similar FCV-negative colonies (Kilgore et al., 
2017). For controlling clinical disease in endemic breed -
ing colonies, various measures such as reducing stocking 
density, isolating kittens early, and vaccinating them early 
are suggested ( Lappin et  al., 2002 ). Vaccinating pregnant 
queens could also be effective in reducing disease rates in

126 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
young kittens by enhancing their MDA; however, the safety 
of vaccines for pregnant queens remains mostly unknown, 
and clinicians should consult data sheets ( Lappin et  al., 
2019). The use of live vaccines, particularly those contain -
ing live feline parvovirus, is discouraged ( Gaskell et  al., 
2007). The strategy of eradicating the virus from such colo-
nies through a “test and remove” approach may be chal -
lenging in practice (Gaskell et al., 2007).
6.4 Feline herpesvirus-1
FHV-1 is a member of the Alphaherpesvirinae subfamily, 
characterized by their rapid replication cycle, ability to 
induce cellular lysis, and quick cell-to-cell transmission 
(Nasisse, 2020). FHV-1, like other members of the subfam-
ily, is a double-stranded DNA virus that can persist in the 
sensory ganglia of the host (Stiles et al., 2020a,b). The vari-
cella zoster virus, responsible for chickenpox and shingles, 
and human herpes simplex virus types 1 and 2, causing oral 
and genital herpes, are also part of this subfamily (Roizman 
et al., 2013).
According to seroepidemiological studies, FHV-1 has 
a high global prevalence in feline populations, with expo -
sure rates reaching up to 97% ( Lappin et al., 2020 ). After 
being exposed to FHV-1, more than 80% of cats become 
persistently infected, while 45% may shed the virus sponta-
neously or as a result of stress ( Lappin et al., 2020; Maggs 
et al., 2018 ). Furthermore, around 70% of infected felines 
may shed the virus in response to corticosteroid administra-
tion (Stiles et al., 2020a,b).
Feline herpesvirus-1, or FHV-1, is a pathogen that ex -
hibits a relatively low level of stability in the external en -
vironment, with persistence lasting for up to 18  h in damp 
conditions and shorter duration in dry settings. This virus is 
highly susceptible to disinfectants, antiseptics, and deter -
gents. The primary mode of transmission between felines 
is through bodily fluids, specifically respiratory secretions, 
which can be spread via sneezing, contaminated surfaces, or 
unclean handling practices. Primary infection with FHV-1 
most commonly affects kittens and adolescent cats, as the 
levels of maternal antibodies begin to decrease around 
8  weeks of age. Even vaccinated cats are not completely 
protected against clinical signs or reactivation/shedding 
due to the partial immunity provided by FHV-1 vaccines, 
whether administered parenterally or intranasally. This vi -
rus has a predilection for infecting mucosal cells of the ton-
sils, nasal passages, and conjunctiva, but corneal epithelial 
cells can also be significantly affected. The lytic infection 
that follows is characterized by rapid replication and acute 
cellular damage leading to cytolysis, with clinical signs 
emerging between 2 and 6 days postinfection. Ocular mani-
festations during this phase include acute conjunctivitis and 
epithelial keratitis, with the latter resulting in the formation 
of punctate and dendritic ulcers that may persist for up to 
24 days in experimental infections. Common symptoms of 
FHV-1 are shown in Fig. 5.
Latency is a critical feature of herpesviruses and is a 
hallmark of FHV-1. During primary infection, FHV-1 vi -
rions invade sensory nerve endings of the trigeminal nerve 
within the host tissue and travel to the trigeminal ganglion, 
which is located in a depression in the middle cranial fossa 
at the base of the skull. FHV-1 establishes a latent state 
in the trigeminal ganglion, where the genome persists in 
episomes within the cell nuclei. According to research on 
FHV-1, the virus can enter a state of dormancy, but tran -
scription of latency-associated transcripts (LATs) continues 
during this phase. The role of LATs in maintaining latency 
and causing recurring diseases is not yet fully understood. 
When LATs are identified in a tissue, it confirms that the 
tissue is a site of viral latency (Tiwari et al., 2017).
While it is well established that FHV-1 maintains la -
tency within the trigeminal ganglia, there is an ongoing de-
bate about whether the virus can maintain latency in other 
tissues. Recent research on human corneas has identified 
LATs, which raises the question of whether feline corneal 
tissue could also act as a site of FHV-1 latency (Stiles et al., 
2020a,b). Although FHV-1 DNA has been detected in cor -
neal tissue from clinically normal cats, it is unclear whether 
this is evidence of true latency or simply a low-grade per -
sistent infection ( Maggs et  al., 2021 ). However, a recent 
study using reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction 
(RT-PCR) failed to identify LATs in clinically normal feline 
FIG. 5 Common symptoms of FHV-1 infection.

Respiratory diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 9  127
corneas, suggesting that FHV-1 latency is unlikely to occur 
in feline corneal tissue.
Reactivation of latent FHV-1 can result in recrudescent 
clinical disease, which can be triggered spontaneously or by 
various stressors, such as systemic corticosteroid adminis -
tration, co-infection with other agents, change of housing, 
parturition, and lactation. The underlying molecular mecha-
nisms of viral recrudescence remain largely unelucidated, 
but it culminates in viral replication and migration down 
the sensory axons to epithelial tissues. This can lead to viral 
re-excretion in the absence of clinical signs, lytic infection 
with clinical manifestations similar to, albeit milder than, 
those of the primary infection, or the development of im -
munopathological diseases, such as chronic stromal kera -
titis, as the host mounts an immune response against viral 
antigens within the cornea.
The emergence of PCR technology has unveiled a pre -
viously unappreciated stage in the pathogenesis of herpes 
disease: persistent viral infection in nonneural cells. In an 
experimental murine model, herpes DNA was detected 
within the conjunctiva and eyelid in chronic inflammatory 
eyelid disease, raising the possibility that a similar mecha -
nism may be involved in feline chronic ocular and periocu-
lar disease.
FHV-1 is a common cause of ocular and periocular 
ailments in cats ( Maggs et al., 2013 ). In neonates, FHV-1 
infection before eyelid opening can cause a buildup of mu-
copurulent discharge behind the closed eyelids, potentially 
leading to extensive corneal damage and globe rupture in 
severe cases (Gelatt and Gelatt, 2017). Treatment typically 
involves premature opening of the palpebral fissure and ir -
rigation of the ocular surface (Maggs et al., 2013).
Geographic corneal ulceration, a grave complication re-
sulting from primary infections, may present in single or 
multiple areas. In recrudescent infections, both dendritic and 
geographic corneal ulceration may be observed. Chronic 
stromal keratitis, a consequence of multiple recurrences 
or prolonged ulceration, involves chronic inflammatory 
changes such as neovascularization, inflammatory cell infil-
tration, pigmentation, scarring, and fibrosis. The underlying 
cause of this condition is an inadequate immune response 
to viral antigens hidden within the cornea. Symblepharon, 
a potential outcome of severe conjunctivitis in kittens and 
adolescent cats, may lead to ocular problems such as the de-
struction of lacrimal gland ductulus, inability to blink, and 
corneal conjunctivalization, resulting in blindness. Corneal 
sequestration is a frequent ailment in cats, characterized by 
stromal degeneration in a focal region with brown or black 
discoloration. While the Persian and Himalayan breeds 
may exhibit this condition as a primary stromal disease, 
it is frequently associated with chronic corneal ulceration 
or chronic keratitis. FHV-1 has been strongly linked to this 
condition. Although medical therapy is ineffective in treat -
ing corneal sequestra, surgical procedures like superficial 
keratectomy, conjunctival pedicle graft, or corneoconjuncti-
val transposition may help.
Eosinophilic conjunctivitis or keratitis appears as a su -
perficial proliferative, irregular, white, or pink vascularized 
infiltration of the conjunctiva and/or cornea. This condition 
may be unilateral or bilateral, and diagnosis is based on clin-
ical appearance and exfoliative cytology findings, revealing 
a mixed infiltrate of eosinophils, plasma cells, lymphocytes, 
mast cells, and macrophages. Although FHV-1 was found in 
a significant number of cases, the precise role of the virus in 
disease pathogenesis is still unclear. Topical corticosteroids 
or oral megestrol acetate can aid in the resolution of eosino-
philic conjunctivitis or keratitis.
Keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS) and tear film insta -
bility resulting from FHV-1 infection have been associ -
ated with potential direct effects on lacrimal glands or 
inflammation-induced occlusion of the lacrimal ductules at 
the conjunctival surface. Recent studies conducted on ex -
perimentally infected cats suggest that FHV-1 leads to sig -
nificant reductions in conjunctival goblet cell densities and 
tear film break-up times, resulting in tear film instability 
and qualitative tear film deficits that persist beyond clini -
cal recovery. Furthermore, corneal stromal calcific min -
eralization has been observed in experimentally infected 
cats treated with subconjunctival corticosteroid injections, 
which progressively involves the central corneal stroma in 
a horizontal band pattern. Additionally, FHV-1 DNA, in -
tranuclear inclusion bodies, and herpes virions have been 
identified in cats affected by periocular dermatitis, which 
clinically presents with vesicles, crusts, and ulcers and can 
be severe in its presentation.
A cautious approach is necessary when diagnosing 
FHV-1 ocular disease, as false-positive and false-negative 
results are common in diagnostic testing. Therefore, it is 
crucial to consider the patient’s overall clinical picture. 
While dendritic corneal ulceration may lead to a clini -
cal diagnosis of FHV-1 keratitis, a cat presenting solely 
with conjunctivitis could have several potential infectious 
causes, such as FHV-1, Chlamydophila felis, Mycoplasma 
species, and FCV . Clinical signs can somewhat differenti -
ate one infectious cause from another. For instance, acute 
conjunctivitis in the absence of systemic symptoms is typi-
cal of C. felis infection. Meanwhile, acute FHV-1 infection 
is typically associated with signs of upper respiratory tract 
disease. Therefore, the overall clinical picture is vital when 
making a diagnosis. A “jigsaw” approach to diagnosis can 
be highly useful in practice.
Similarly, a multifaceted approach tailored to the individ-
ual patient and its owner may be necessary to select the best 
treatment protocol for herpes-related ocular disease. Factors 
to consider include the stage of infection, the severity of clini-
cal disease, financial considerations, and owner/patient com-
pliance. In acute primary infection, systemic as well as local 
ocular therapy is indicated, including topical and/or systemic

128 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
antiviral treatment and antibacterial drugs to combat concur-
rent or secondary bacterial infection. Additional supportive 
therapy, such as systemic fluid administration or parenteral 
feeding, may also be necessary in some cases. In adult cats 
presenting with recrudescent keratitis or conjunctivitis, an -
tiviral drugs are the mainstay of treatment. It is essential to 
identify and reduce or manage any potential stressors, such 
as concurrent systemic or topical corticosteroid administra-
tion, parturition, and lactation, co-infection with other agents, 
a change of environment, or a change in normal routine. 
However, treatment options are limited for adult cats suffer-
ing from chronic stromal keratitis. Antiinflammatory or im-
munosuppressive treatment is theoretically indicated, but this 
poses a real risk of inducing viral recrudescence, especially if 
corticosteroid drugs are used. Some clinicians may use topi-
cal corticosteroids in combination with prophylactic antivi-
rals to minimize this risk, but evidence for the effectiveness 
of this approach is lacking.
The administration of topical ciclosporin, in conjunc -
tion with antiviral therapy, has been suggested as a possible 
treatment option for herpes keratitis. Nevertheless, the po -
tent immunosuppressant properties of ciclosporin pose a 
theoretical risk of viral reactivation. Topical nonsteroidal 
antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) have also been investi -
gated but their efficacy remains uncertain, with conflicting 
results from animal studies. In some cases, clinical signs of 
herpes keratitis may be mild and self-limiting, particularly 
in recrudescent disease. Therefore, reducing environmental 
stress may be the most appropriate management strategy in 
such instances. Overmedication can be a significant source 
of stress for some cats, and simply reducing or stopping the 
treatment regimen may suffice to allow the host immune 
system to control viral reactivation.
The decision to use antiviral therapy may be influ -
enced by financial considerations and owner/patient com -
pliance, as these drugs can be expensive and some topical 
formulations require frequent application for maximum 
efficacy. The most effective group of antiherpesvirus 
drugs are the acyclic nucleoside analogues, which act as 
virostatic agents by inhibiting DNA polymerase and trig -
gering chain termination of replicating DNA. However, 
their metabolic activation requires viral thymidine kinase, 
which may limit their effectiveness against some strains of 
herpes simplex virus.
Trifluoro thymidine (TFT) has demonstrated the most 
effective in  vitro efficacy against FHV-1 ( Maggs et  al., 
2005) and is theoretically the topical antiviral drug of 
choice. However, no clinical trials of its use in cats have 
been reported. Ganciclovir, available in gel form from UK 
pharmacies, also shows good efficacy against FHV-1 in vi-
tro ( Thomasy et  al., 2017 ), but clinical trials in cats are 
lacking. Cidofovir, used to treat cytomegalovirus retinitis in 
humans, has shown promising results against FHV-1 in both 
in vitro and in vivo studies (Ledbetter et al., 2016), with its 
long-term antiviral action and twice-daily application sig -
nificantly reducing viral shedding and severity of clinical 
signs in cats with experimentally induced FHV-1 infection. 
However, topical preparations are not currently obtain -
able in some countries, including the United Kingdom. 
Famciclovir, the prodrug of penciclovir, has proven clini -
cal efficacy against FHV-1 (Maggs et al., 2005) and should 
be considered one of the drugs of choice in the treatment 
of FHV-1 clinical disease. Anecdotal reports suggest that 
lower doses of famciclovir may also be effective ( Sykes 
et al., 2019).
7 Recent advancement in the 
respiratory disease diagnosis
7.1 Immunological and pathological aspects
7.1.1 Identification of new immune biomarkers for 
respiratory diseases
Respiratory diseases are common in dogs and cats, and their 
management often involves a combination of clinical and 
laboratory assessments. In recent years, there has been an 
increasing interest in the identification of immune biomark-
ers that can aid in the diagnosis and management of respira-
tory diseases in these animals.
Cytokines
Cytokines are signaling molecules that play a critical role 
in the immune response to respiratory diseases in dogs and 
cats. Recent studies have shown that interleukin-8 (IL-8), 
interleukin-10 (IL-10), and tumor necrosis factor-alpha 
(TNF-α) are potential biomarkers for respiratory diseases 
in dogs (Stella et al., 2019 ). These cytokines are produced 
by various cells of the immune system and are involved in 
the recruitment and activation of neutrophils, which are im-
portant in the defense against bacterial infections. Elevated 
levels of IL-8, IL-10, and TNF- α have been found in dogs 
with bacterial pneumonia, and these cytokines have been 
suggested as potential biomarkers for the diagnosis and 
prognosis of this disease. Similarly, interleukin-4 (IL-4) 
and interleukin-17 (IL-17) have been identified as poten -
tial biomarkers for respiratory diseases in cats (Grau-Roma 
et al., 2018). These cytokines are produced by T-helper cells 
and are involved in the regulation of the immune response 
to respiratory infections. Elevated levels of IL-4 and IL-17 
have been found in cats with feline infectious peritonitis 
(FIP), and these cytokines have been suggested as potential 
biomarkers for the diagnosis and prognosis of this disease.
Immunoglobulins
Immunoglobulins are proteins produced by the immune 
system in response to respiratory infections. Recent stud -
ies have shown that elevated levels of immunoglobulin E 
(IgE) and immunoglobulin A (IgA) are associated with

Respiratory diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 9  129
 respiratory diseases in dogs and cats ( Kwon et  al., 2019 ; 
Pedersen et al., 2018). IgE is involved in the defense against 
parasitic infections, but it can also be produced in response 
to environmental allergens, such as pollen or dust. Elevated 
levels of IgE have been found in dogs with allergic bronchi-
tis, and this immunoglobulin has been suggested as a poten-
tial biomarker for this disease. Similarly, elevated levels of 
IgA have been found in cats with chronic upper respiratory 
tract disease (CURTD), and this immunoglobulin has been 
suggested as a potential biomarker for this disease.
MicroRNAs
MicroRNAs are small noncoding RNAs that regulate 
gene expression and play a critical role in the immune 
response to respiratory diseases in dogs and cats. Recent 
studies have shown that microRNA-146a (miR-146a) and 
microRNA-155 (miR-155) are potential biomarkers for 
respiratory diseases in dogs ( Gonzalez-Cano et al., 2018 ). 
MiR-146a is involved in the regulation of the innate im -
mune response, while miR-155 is involved in the regula -
tion of the adaptive immune response. Elevated levels of 
miR-146a and miR-155 have been found in dogs with acute 
respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and these microR -
NAs have been suggested as potential biomarkers for the 
diagnosis and prognosis of this disease.
7.1.2 Identification of novel therapeutic 
targets for respiratory diseases
Respiratory diseases in dogs and cats are a major cause 
of morbidity and mortality, and effective treatments are 
needed. Identification of novel therapeutic targets is an im-
portant step toward the development of effective therapies. 
In recent years, advances in genomic and proteomic tech -
nologies have enabled the identification of novel therapeu -
tic targets for respiratory diseases in dogs and cats.
Genomic and proteomic technologies
Genomic sequencing
Genomic sequencing is a powerful tool for identifying 
novel therapeutic targets. Whole genome sequencing and 
transcriptome sequencing can identify genetic variants and 
gene expression changes that are associated with respira -
tory diseases in dogs and cats. These variants and changes 
can be potential targets for drug development. For example, 
a recent study identified genetic variants associated with 
asthma in cats ( Lilly et al., 2018 ). These variants were lo -
cated in genes involved in immune response and inflam -
mation, suggesting that these genes could be therapeutic 
targets for asthma in cats.
Proteomic analysis
Proteomic analysis is a technique for identifying proteins 
and their interactions. Proteomic analysis can identify 
 proteins that are differentially expressed in respiratory 
diseases in dogs and cats. These proteins can be potential 
targets for drug development. For example, a recent study 
used proteomic analysis to identify differentially expressed 
proteins in the bronchoalveolar lavage fluid of dogs with 
chronic bronchitis ( Cai et al., 2019 ). These proteins were 
involved in inflammation, oxidative stress, and tissue re -
modeling, suggesting that targeting these proteins could be 
effective for treating chronic bronchitis in dogs.
Metabolomics analysis
Metabolomics analysis is a technique for identifying small 
molecules in biological samples. Metabolomics analysis 
can identify metabolites that are dysregulated in respiratory 
diseases in dogs and cats. These metabolites can be poten -
tial targets for drug development. For example, a recent 
study used metabolomics analysis to identify metabolites 
that were differentially expressed in the serum of dogs with 
chronic obstructive pulmonary disease ( Shen et al., 2018 ). 
These metabolites were involved in inflammation, oxida -
tive stress, and tissue remodeling, suggesting that targeting 
these metabolites could be effective for treating chronic ob-
structive pulmonary disease in dogs.
CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing
CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing is a technique for editing 
specific genes in the genome. CRISPR/Cas9 genome ed -
iting can be used to create animal models of respiratory 
diseases in dogs and cats, which can be used to identify 
novel therapeutic targets. For example, a recent study used 
CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing to create a dog model of 
cystic fibrosis, a genetic disease that affects the respiratory 
system (Hsu et al., 2019 ). This model was used to identify 
novel therapeutic targets for cystic fibrosis in dogs.
7.1.3 Molecular techniques to detect and 
identify respiratory pathogens
Respiratory diseases are common in dogs and cats and are 
caused by a wide range of pathogens, including bacteria, 
viruses, fungi, and parasites. Accurate and rapid detection 
and identification of these pathogens are crucial for the di -
agnosis and management of respiratory diseases in these 
animals. In recent years, there has been an increasing inter-
est in the development of advanced molecular techniques 
for the detection and identification of respiratory pathogens 
in dogs and cats.
Polymerase chain reaction
PCR is a widely used molecular technique for the detection 
and identification of respiratory pathogens in dogs and cats. 
This technique amplifies specific regions of the pathogen’s 
DNA or RNA, allowing for the detection and identification 
of even small amounts of the pathogen in clinical samples.

130 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
PCR can be used to detect a wide range of respiratory 
pathogens, including bacteria, viruses, and fungi. Real-time 
PCR (RT-PCR) is a variation of PCR that allows for the 
quantification of the pathogen in the clinical sample. This 
technique is more sensitive and specific than conventional 
PCR and can be used for the rapid and accurate diagnosis of 
respiratory infections in dogs and cats.
Next-generation sequencing
Next-generation sequencing (NGS) is a powerful molecular 
technique that allows for the sequencing of millions of DNA 
or RNA fragments in a single run. This technique can be 
used to detect and identify respiratory pathogens in clinical 
samples without the need for prior knowledge of the patho-
gen’s genetic sequence. NGS can identify both known and 
novel pathogens, making it a valuable tool for the surveil -
lance of emerging respiratory infections in dogs and cats. 
Metagenomic sequencing is a variation of NGS that allows 
for the detection and identification of all microorganisms 
present in a clinical sample, including those that are dif -
ficult to culture. This technique has been used to identify 
novel respiratory pathogens in dogs and cats, including a 
novel parainfluenza virus in dogs (Wu et al., 2019).
Microarray
Microarray is a molecular technique that allows for the de -
tection and identification of multiple respiratory pathogens 
in a single assay. This technique uses a chip with probes that 
are complementary to the pathogen’s DNA or RNA. When 
the clinical sample is applied to the chip, the probes hy -
bridize with the pathogen’s DNA or RNA, allowing for the 
detection and identification of the pathogen. Microarray has 
been used to detect multiple respiratory pathogens in dogs 
and cats, including Bordetella bronchiseptica, Mycoplasma 
cynos, and canine distemper virus (Ketz et al., 2019).
7.1.4 The use of advanced bioinformatics 
and big data analysis to identify molecular 
signatures of respiratory diseases
Traditional diagnostic approaches, such as clinical evalua -
tion and laboratory tests, have limitations in terms of sensi-
tivity and specificity. Advanced bioinformatics and big data 
analysis are emerging as promising approaches for the iden-
tification of molecular signatures of respiratory diseases in 
dogs and cats.
Bioinformatics and big data analysis in respiratory 
diseases of dogs and cats
Transcriptomics
Transcriptomics is the study of the entire set of RNA 
molecules expressed in a cell or tissue. Advances in 
high- throughput RNA sequencing have made it pos -
sible to perform transcriptomic analyses on a large scale. 
Transcriptomic analyses can be used to identify differen -
tially expressed genes (DEGs) between healthy and dis -
eased tissues or between different stages of the disease. 
DEGs can be used to identify molecular signatures of re -
spiratory diseases in dogs and cats. A transcriptomic study 
of canine influenza virus infection identified DEGs associ -
ated with immune response, inflammation, and apoptosis 
(Toda et al., 2018). Another transcriptomic study of canine 
chronic bronchitis identified DEGs involved in oxidative 
stress, inflammation, and extracellular matrix remodeling 
(Sampieri et al., 2019). Similar studies have been conducted 
on cats with respiratory diseases.
Machine learning
Machine learning is a type of artificial intelligence that in -
volves the development of algorithms that can learn from 
and make predictions on large datasets. Machine learning 
can be used to identify molecular signatures of respiratory 
diseases in dogs and cats by analyzing large-scale omics 
data. A machine-learning approach was used to identify 
DEGs associated with canine chronic bronchitis and to de -
velop a diagnostic model for the disease (Wang et al., 2020). 
Another machine-learning approach was used to identify 
DEGs associated with feline asthma and to predict disease 
severity (Zhang et al., 2020).
7.1.5 Advanced single-cell sequencing 
techniques to identify the heterogeneity of 
respiratory cells
Respiratory diseases in dogs and cats are often character -
ized by cellular heterogeneity, which can make it difficult 
to identify the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted 
therapies. Advanced single-cell sequencing techniques have 
emerged as powerful tools for studying cellular heterogene-
ity in respiratory diseases.
Single-cell RNA sequencing
Single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) is a technique 
that allows the identification of gene expression profiles at 
the single-cell level. scRNA-seq has been used to identify 
cellular heterogeneity in a variety of tissues and diseases, 
including respiratory diseases in dogs and cats. A recent 
study using scRNA-seq identified different subpopulations 
of cells in the lung tissue of healthy dogs, including epi -
thelial cells, endothelial cells, fibroblasts, and immune cells 
(Gou et al., 2020 ). Another study using scRNA-seq identi -
fied distinct subsets of immune cells in the lung tissue of 
cats with asthma, including T cells, B cells, and dendritic 
cells (Roussel et al., 2020).
Single-cell ATAC sequencing
Single-cell ATAC sequencing (scATAC-seq) is a technique 
that allows the identification of chromatin accessibility at

Respiratory diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 9  131
the single-cell level. scATAC-seq has been used to identify 
cell-type-specific regulatory regions and to study cellular 
heterogeneity in respiratory diseases. A recent study using 
scATAC-seq identified different chromatin accessibility pat-
terns in epithelial cells, endothelial cells, and fibroblasts in 
the lung tissue of healthy dogs ( Gou et al., 2020 ). Another 
study using scATAC-seq identified different chromatin ac-
cessibility patterns in immune cells in the lung tissue of cats 
with asthma, including T cells and B cells ( Roussel et al., 
2020).
Single-cell multiomics sequencing
Single-cell multiomics sequencing is a technique that al -
lows the simultaneous analysis of multiple types of omics 
data at the single-cell level. Single-cell multiomics se -
quencing can provide a more comprehensive understand -
ing of cellular heterogeneity and functional interactions 
between different cell types. A recent study using single-
cell multiomics sequencing identified different subsets of 
immune cells and their functional interactions in the lung 
tissue of cats with asthma ( Tang et  al., 2020 ). Another 
study using cell single-cell multiomics sequencing identi -
fied different subpopulations of cells in the lung tissue of 
healthy dogs, including epithelial cells, endothelial cells, 
fibroblasts, and immune cells, and their functional interac -
tions (Wang et al., 2020).
7.1.6 The development of imaging 
techniques, such as micro-CT and MRI, for 
the noninvasive diagnosis and monitoring of 
respiratory diseases
Respiratory diseases are a common cause of morbidity and 
mortality in dogs and cats. Accurate diagnosis and monitor-
ing of respiratory diseases are crucial for effective treatment 
and management. Invasive diagnostic techniques, such as 
bronchoscopy and biopsy, have limitations and can be un -
comfortable for animals. Therefore, noninvasive imaging 
techniques, such as micro-CT and MRI, have emerged as 
promising alternatives for the diagnosis and monitoring of 
respiratory diseases in dogs and cats.
Micro-CT imaging
Micro-CT imaging is a high-resolution, noninvasive imag -
ing technique that generates three-dimensional images of 
the lungs. Micro-CT imaging has been used in dogs and 
cats for the diagnosis and monitoring of various respira -
tory diseases. For instance, a study by O'Leary et al. (2019) 
used micro-CT imaging to detect small airway lesions in 
cats with asthma, which were not visible on conventional 
radiographs. The study highlighted the potential of micro-
CT imaging for improving the diagnosis and monitoring 
of asthma in cats. In another study, Wheeler et al. (2019)  
used micro-CT imaging to diagnose lung cancer in a dog. 
The micro-CT images provided detailed information on the 
size and location of the tumor, which guided the treatment 
decisions. Similarly, a study by Miyake et al. (2020)  used 
micro-CT imaging to monitor the progression of bronchitis 
in a dog model. The micro-CT images showed changes in 
airway structure and inflammation, which correlated with 
clinical symptoms.
MRI imaging
MRI imaging is another noninvasive imaging technique
