that provides high-resolution images of the lungs. MRI 
imaging has been used in dogs and cats for the diagno -
sis and monitoring of various respiratory diseases. For 
example, Wessmann et al. (2019)  used MRI imaging to 
diagnose pulmonary fibrosis in a dog. The MRI images 
showed the characteristic pattern of fibrosis in the lung 
tissue, which confirmed the diagnosis. In another study, 
Lanza et  al. (2019)  used MRI imaging to monitor the 
progression of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in 
a cat model. The MRI images showed changes in lung 
function and inflammation, which correlated with clini -
cal symptoms. The study demonstrated the potential of 
MRI imaging for noninvasive monitoring of respiratory 
diseases in cats.
7.1.7 The application of microfluidics and 
lab-on-a-chip technology for the rapid and 
accurate diagnosis of respiratory diseases
Respiratory diseases are common in dogs and cats, and ac -
curate and rapid diagnosis is critical for effective treatment 
and management. Traditional diagnostic methods, such as 
culture and cytology, can be time-consuming and require 
specialized equipment and expertise.
Microfluidics and lab-on-a-chip technology
Microfluidics is a technology that deals with the behavior, 
control, and manipulation of small volumes of fluids in 
microscale channels. Lab-on-a-chip technology is a type 
of microfluidics that integrates multiple laboratory func -
tions, such as sample preparation, detection, and analy -
sis, into a single device. Microfluidics and lab-on-a-chip 
technology have several advantages for the diagnosis of 
respiratory diseases in dogs and cats, including high sen -
sitivity, specificity, and throughput, as well as low sample 
and reagent consumption. There are several applications 
of microfluidics and lab-on-a-chip technology for the di -
agnosis of respiratory diseases in dogs and cats. For ex -
ample, researchers have developed microfluidic devices 
for the rapid and sensitive detection of infectious agents, 
such as Bordetella bronchiseptica  and Mycoplasma spp., 
which cause respiratory infections in dogs and cats. 
These devices can detect the target pathogens in as little 
as 30  min, with high sensitivity and specificity. Other

132 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
 researchers have developed  lab-on-a-chip devices for the 
analysis of exhaled breath samples from dogs and cats. 
Exhaled breath contains a complex mixture of volatile 
organic compounds (VOCs) that can provide valuable in -
formation about the presence and severity of respiratory 
diseases. Lab-on-a-chip devices for breath analysis can 
detect and quantify specific VOCs associated with respira -
tory diseases, such as bronchitis and pneumonia, with high 
sensitivity and specificity. While microfluidics and lab-
on-a-chip technology hold great promise for the rapid and 
accurate diagnosis of respiratory diseases in dogs and cats, 
there are several challenges that must be addressed. One 
challenge is the development of devices that are easy to 
use and interpret by veterinarians with limited expertise in 
microfluidics and lab-on-a-chip technology. Another chal -
lenge is the standardization of protocols and procedures 
for sample collection, preparation, and analysis to ensure 
reliable and reproducible results across different devices 
and laboratories. In the future, microfluidics and lab-on-a-
chip technology for respiratory disease diagnosis in dogs 
and cats could be integrated with artificial intelligence 
and machine learning algorithms to improve accuracy and 
speed. These technologies could also be used for real-time 
monitoring and tracking of disease progression and treat -
ment response, enabling personalized and targeted thera -
pies for individual patients.
7.2 Biological and chemical analysis
7.2.1 Metabolomics and lipidomics analysis to 
study the changes in metabolic pathways and 
lipid profiles in respiratory diseases
Metabolomics and lipidomics are powerful tools that can be 
used to study the changes in metabolic pathways and lipid 
profiles in the respiratory diseases of dogs and cats. These 
techniques can provide a comprehensive understanding of 
the molecular mechanisms underlying respiratory diseases, 
leading to the identification of novel therapeutic targets and 
biomarkers.
Metabolomics analysis is a high-throughput tech -
nique that can be used to study the entire metabolome 
of an organism. The metabolome is the entire set of 
small molecules that are produced by an organism at a 
given time. Advanced metabolomics analysis techniques 
such as mass spectrometry and nuclear magnetic reso -
nance spectroscopy can be used to identify and quantify 
changes in metabolite expression in respiratory diseases 
of dogs and cats. These techniques can also be used to 
identify metabolic pathways that are affected by respi -
ratory diseases. Studies have shown that metabolomics 
analysis can provide a comprehensive understanding of 
the changes in metabolic pathways in respiratory dis -
eases of dogs and cats.
Lipidomics analysis is a high-throughput technique 
that can be used to study the entire lipidome of an or -
ganism. The lipidome is the entire set of lipids that are 
produced by an organism at a given time. Advanced lipi -
domics analysis techniques such as mass spectrometry and 
high-performance liquid chromatography can be used to 
identify and quantify changes in lipid expression in re -
spiratory diseases of dogs and cats. These techniques can 
also be used to identify lipid classes and lipid profiles that 
are affected by respiratory diseases. Studies have shown 
that lipidomics analysis can provide a comprehensive un -
derstanding of the changes in lipid profiles in respiratory 
diseases of dogs and cats.
7.2.2 Nanotechnology-based approaches for 
the delivery of drugs and gene therapies to the 
respiratory tract
Respiratory diseases are a major cause of morbidity and 
mortality in dogs and cats, and current therapies have limi -
tations in terms of efficacy, safety, and patient compliance. 
Advanced nanotechnology-based approaches offer prom -
ising solutions for the targeted delivery of drugs and gene 
therapies to the respiratory tract of dogs and cats. These ap-
proaches can improve therapeutic outcomes while reducing 
side effects and minimizing the need for invasive procedures.
Nanoparticle-based drug delivery systems
Nanoparticle-based drug delivery systems have been de -
veloped to improve the delivery of drugs to the respiratory 
tract of dogs and cats. These systems can protect drugs 
from degradation and clearance, enhance drug penetration, 
and target specific cell types or tissues. Various types of 
nanoparticles, such as liposomes, polymeric nanoparticles, 
and dendrimers, have been investigated for their potential in 
treating respiratory diseases in dogs and cats. Studies have 
demonstrated that these systems can improve the efficacy of 
drugs such as antibiotics, bronchodilators, and antiinflam -
matory agents in the respiratory diseases of dogs and cats 
(Makwana et al., 2014).
Nanoparticle-based gene delivery systems
Nanoparticle-based gene delivery systems have also been 
developed to improve the delivery of gene therapies to the 
respiratory tract of dogs and cats. These systems can protect 
DNA or RNA from degradation, enhance gene expression, 
and target specific cell types or tissues. Various types of 
nanoparticles, such as liposomes, polymeric nanoparticles, 
and viral vectors, have been investigated for their potential 
in treating respiratory diseases in dogs and cats. Studies 
have demonstrated that these systems can improve the ef -
ficacy of gene therapies such as RNA interference, gene re-
placement, and gene editing in respiratory diseases of dogs 
and cats.

Respiratory diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 9  133
Recent advances in nanotechnology have led to the de -
velopment of novel approaches for the delivery of drugs 
and gene therapies to the respiratory tract of dogs and cats. 
These include:
1. Nanoparticle-based inhalable powders: These powders 
can be easily delivered to the respiratory tract using in -
halation devices, and can provide sustained release of 
drugs or genes.
2. Self-assembling peptide-based nanocarriers: These 
nanocarriers can self-assemble in situ to form a gel-like 
structure that can provide sustained release of drugs or 
genes.
3. Magnetic nanoparticles: These nanoparticles can be 
guided to specific regions of the respiratory tract using 
magnetic fields, and can enhance drug or gene delivery 
to these regions.
7.3 Genetic and cellular aspects
7.3.1 Artificial intelligence and deep learning 
algorithms to analyze large datasets and 
develop predictive models for respiratory 
diseases
In recent years, advanced artificial intelligence (AI) and 
deep learning algorithms have emerged as powerful tools 
for analyzing large datasets and developing predictive mod-
els for various diseases, including respiratory diseases in 
animals. One recent study by Wong et al. (2021) used deep 
learning algorithms to develop a model for the early detec -
tion of respiratory disease in cats. The researchers collected 
clinical and laboratory data from 1104 cats, including re -
spiratory rate, heart rate, body temperature, blood pressure, 
and various blood parameters. The deep learning model was 
trained to identify patterns in this data and predict the like -
lihood of respiratory disease. The results showed that the 
model achieved an accuracy of 90.6% in predicting respira-
tory disease, demonstrating the potential of AI in diagnos -
ing respiratory diseases in cats.
Another study by Ribeiro et al. (2019)  focused on de -
veloping a predictive model for respiratory diseases in 
dogs using machine learning algorithms. The researchers 
collected data from 2082 dogs, including clinical signs, 
laboratory results, and imaging findings. They used a ma -
chine learning algorithm called random forest to develop 
a model that could predict the likelihood of respiratory 
disease in dogs. The results showed that the model had a 
sensitivity of 95.2% and a specificity of 88.9%, indicating 
its potential as a diagnostic tool for respiratory diseases 
in dogs. In addition to diagnosis, AI and deep learning al -
gorithms have also been used to predict the outcome of 
respiratory diseases in dogs and cats. For example, a re -
cent study by Chang et  al. (2020)  used a deep learning 
algorithm to predict the survival of dogs with pulmonary 
fibrosis. The researchers collected CT scans and clinical 
data from 123 dogs and trained the deep learning algo -
rithm to predict survival based on this data. The results 
showed that the algorithm achieved an accuracy of 92.7% 
in predicting survival, indicating its potential as a prog -
nostic tool for respiratory diseases in dogs. Overall, ad -
vanced AI and deep learning algorithms have shown great 
promise in analyzing large datasets and developing pre -
dictive models for respiratory diseases in dogs and cats. 
These tools have the potential to improve the accuracy of 
diagnosis and prognosis, leading to better outcomes for 
these animals. However, further research is needed to vali -
date these models and integrate them into clinical practice.
7.3.2 Synthetic biology techniques for the 
engineering of respiratory cells and with 
respiratory diseases
Synthetic biology techniques offer potential solutions to 
engineering respiratory cells and tissues in dogs and cats 
to treat respiratory diseases. One approach is to use 3D 
printing and tissue engineering techniques to create respira-
tory tissues. Tissue engineering is the process of creating 
functional tissues by combining cells, growth factors, and 
biomaterials in a scaffold to mimic the structure and func -
tion of native tissue. A recent study by Goh et al. (2020)  
used 3D printing to create a biodegradable scaffold for the 
engineering of tracheal tissues in dogs. The scaffold was 
seeded with canine tracheal epithelial cells and mesenchy -
mal stem cells, which differentiated into the appropriate cell 
types and formed functional tracheal tissues in vitro. This 
approach has the potential to be used for the engineering 
of other respiratory tissues, such as lung parenchyma, to 
treat respiratory diseases in dogs and cats. Another promis-
ing approach in synthetic biology is the engineering of cells 
to produce novel therapeutic agents. For example, a recent 
study by Bellingham et  al. (2019)  engineered bacteria to 
produce an antimicrobial peptide that could be used to treat 
respiratory infections in dogs. The engineered bacteria were 
designed to detect the presence of a specific bacterial patho-
gen, and then produce and secrete the peptide in response. 
This approach has the potential to be used for the targeted 
treatment of respiratory infections in dogs and cats. Gene 
editing techniques, such as CRISPR-Cas9, can also be used 
to modify the genetic code of respiratory cells to correct 
genetic mutations associated with respiratory diseases or to 
enhance their function. One example is the correction of a 
mutation in the CFTR gene, which is associated with cystic 
fibrosis, in airway epithelial cells derived from dogs. In a 
study by Li et al. (2021), CRISPR-Cas9 was used to correct 
the CFTR mutation, resulting in improved CFTR function 
in the corrected cells. This approach has the potential to be 
used for the treatment of respiratory diseases caused by ge-
netic mutations in dogs and cats.

7.4 Physiological aspects
7.4.1 The use of optogenetics and 
optoacoustics techniques for the real-time 
monitoring and manipulation of respiratory 
cells and tissues
Optogenetics is a technique that involves the use of light 
to control the activity of cells that have been genetically 
modified to express light-sensitive proteins. Optogenetics 
has been used to study a wide range of biological processes, 
including neuronal activity and gene expression. In the con-
text of respiratory diseases in dogs and cats, optogenetics 
can be used to selectively activate or inhibit specific cell 
types in the respiratory tract, allowing for precise control 
of respiratory function. One recent study used optogenetics 
to control airway smooth muscle tone in mice. The study 
found that optogenetic activation of airway smooth muscle 
cells could lead to bronchodilation, which could be useful in 
the treatment of respiratory diseases such as asthma (Huang 
et al., 2019). Another study used optogenetics to study the 
role of pulmonary sensory neurons in respiratory diseases. 
The study found that optogenetic inhibition of pulmonary 
sensory neurons could reduce airway hyperreactivity in 
mice with asthma-like symptoms (Mendelson et al., 2019).
Optoacoustics
Optoacoustics is a technique that involves the use of light 
to generate sound waves, which can be used to image and 
monitor biological tissues. Optoacoustics has been used to 
study a wide range of biological processes, including blood 
flow, oxygenation, and gene expression. In the context of 
respiratory diseases in dogs and cats, optoacoustics can be 
used to monitor respiratory function in real time, allowing 
for early detection and treatment of respiratory diseases. 
One recent study used optoacoustics to monitor oxygen 
saturation in the lungs of rats during mechanical ventila -
tion. The study found that optoacoustics could accurately 
measure changes in oxygen saturation in real time, provid -
ing valuable information for the management of respiratory 
distress ( Knieling et  al., 2019 ). Another study used opto -
acoustics to monitor gene expression in the lungs of mice 
with lung cancer. The study found that optoacoustics could 
detect changes in gene expression in real time, providing a 
potential tool for the early detection and treatment of lung 
cancer (Fernandez-Arias et al., 2020).
7.4.2 Electroencephalography and 
electromyography techniques for the 
noninvasive assessment of respiratory muscle 
function
Respiratory muscle weakness is a common problem in 
dogs and cats, particularly in aging animals or those with 
respiratory diseases. The assessment of respiratory  muscle 
function is crucial for the diagnosis and management of 
these conditions. Electroencephalography (EEG) and 
electromyography (EMG) are noninvasive techniques that 
can be used to assess respiratory muscle function in dogs 
and cats.
EEG is a technique that involves the measurement of 
electrical activity in the brain. In the context of respiratory 
muscle function, EEG can be used to assess the neural drive 
to respiratory muscles, which is an indicator of respiratory 
muscle strength. Recent advances in EEG technology have 
enabled the measurement of respiratory-related brain activ-
ity in dogs and cats, providing a noninvasive tool for the as-
sessment of respiratory muscle function. One recent study 
used EEG to assess the neural drive to respiratory muscles 
in dogs with respiratory diseases. The study found that dogs 
with respiratory diseases had lower neural drive to respira -
tory muscles compared to healthy dogs, indicating respira -
tory muscle weakness ( Hans et  al., 2019 ). Another study 
used EEG to assess the effect of a novel respiratory muscle 
training program on respiratory muscle function in dogs. 
The study found that respiratory muscle training led to an 
increased neural drive to respiratory muscles and improved 
respiratory muscle function (Beck et al., 2020).
EMG is a technique that involves the measurement of 
electrical activity in muscles. In the context of respiratory 
muscle function, EMG can be used to assess the activity 
of respiratory muscles during breathing. Recent advances 
in EMG technology have enabled the measurement of 
respiratory muscle activity in dogs and cats, providing a 
noninvasive tool for the assessment of respiratory muscle 
function. One recent study used EMG to assess respira -
tory muscle activity in cats with respiratory diseases. 
The study found that cats with respiratory diseases had 
reduced respiratory muscle activity during inspiration, 
indicating respiratory muscle weakness ( Rooney et  al., 
2017). Another study used EMG to assess the effect of a 
novel respiratory muscle training program on respiratory 
muscle function in dogs. The study found that respiratory 
muscle training led to increased respiratory muscle ac -
tivity during breathing and improved respiratory muscle 
function ( Beck et al., 2020 ).
7.4.3 The use of cardiopulmonary exercise 
testing to assess the aerobic capacity and 
respiratory function of respiratory diseases
Cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET) is a useful tool 
for evaluating the aerobic capacity and respiratory function 
of dogs and cats with respiratory diseases. CPET involves 
measuring various parameters, such as oxygen consumption 
(VO2), carbon dioxide production (VCO 2), minute ventila-
tion (VE), heart rate (HR), and blood lactate concentration, 
during exercise. In dogs with respiratory diseases, CPET 
has been used to evaluate the effects of different treatments, 
.

Respiratory diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 9  135
such as bronchodilators and corticosteroids, on exercise 
tolerance and respiratory function ( Johnson et  al., 2018 ). 
CPET has also been used to evaluate the aerobic capac -
ity of dogs with respiratory diseases, such as COPD and 
asthma, and to assess their response to exercise training 
programs ( Simpson et  al., 2017 ). In cats with respiratory 
diseases, CPET has been used to evaluate the effects of pul-
monary hypertension on exercise tolerance and to assess the 
response to treatment with sildenafil ( Woods et al., 2017 ). 
CPET can be performed using various exercise modalities, 
such as treadmill or cycle ergometry, and can be tailored to 
the individual animal’s capabilities and limitations (Johnson 
et al., 2020). The use of CPET in dogs and cats with respi -
ratory diseases can provide valuable information for both 
diagnosis and management of these conditions.
7.5 Clinical aspects
7.5.1 Diagnostic approaches for the 
differentiation of respiratory diseases with 
similar clinical symptoms
Differentiating respiratory diseases in dogs and cats with 
similar clinical symptoms can be challenging, but recent 
advancements in diagnostic approaches have improved our 
ability to identify specific conditions. One approach is the 
use of exhaled breath condensate (EBC) analysis, which al-
lows for noninvasive sampling of airway secretions. EBC 
contains various biomarkers, such as cytokines, leukotri -
enes, and nitric oxide, which can be used to differentiate be-
tween different respiratory diseases (Ljungvall et al., 2017). 
For example, EBC analysis has been used to differentiate 
between asthma and chronic bronchitis in dogs ( Krafft 
et al., 2017). Another approach is the use of matrix-assisted 
laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrome -
try (MALDI-TOF MS), which allows for rapid and accurate 
identification of bacterial and fungal pathogens from respi-
ratory samples ( Schmidt et  al., 2017 ). MALDI-TOF MS 
has been used to differentiate between bacterial and fungal 
respiratory infections in dogs and cats with similar clinical 
symptoms. In addition, advanced imaging techniques such 
as positron emission tomography (PET) and single-photon 
emission computed tomography (SPECT) have been used 
to differentiate between different respiratory diseases in 
dogs and cats. For example, PET imaging has been used 
to differentiate between idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis and 
chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis in dogs.
Finally, advancements in genetic testing have allowed 
for the identification of specific gene mutations that are 
associated with respiratory diseases in dogs and cats. For 
example, a mutation in the SLC26A4 gene has been iden -
tified as a cause of congenital sensorineural deafness in 
Dalmatians, which is also associated with a predisposition 
to chronic respiratory disease.
7.5.2 Advanced approaches for the staging 
and grading of respiratory diseases
Staging and grading of respiratory diseases in dogs and cats 
are important for treatment planning and prognosis deter -
mination. In recent years, advanced approaches have been 
developed to accurately stage and grade respiratory diseases 
in dogs and cats. One approach is the use of computed to -
mography (CT) imaging to stage respiratory diseases. CT al-
lows for detailed visualization of the respiratory system and 
can be used to determine the extent and severity of respira-
tory diseases such as pulmonary fibrosis, chronic bronchitis, 
and lung tumors (Banzato et al., 2019). CT can also be used 
to monitor disease progression and response to treatment. 
Another approach is the use of bronchoscopy to stage and 
grade respiratory diseases. Bronchoscopy allows for direct 
visualization of the airways and collection of samples for 
cytological and histological analysis ( Krafft et  al., 2019 ). 
Bronchoscopy can also be used to perform therapeutic in -
terventions such as bronchial lavage, airway stenting, and 
biopsy. In addition, advanced laboratory techniques such 
as NGS and proteomics have been used to grade respira -
tory diseases based on the molecular characteristics of the 
disease. NGS can be used to identify gene mutations, gene 
expression patterns, and microbial communities associated 
with respiratory diseases (Thomas et al., 2021). Proteomics 
can be used to identify and quantify proteins associated with 
respiratory diseases, which can provide valuable informa -
tion on disease severity and response to treatment ( Gouin 
et al., 2020). Finally, biomarker analysis has also been used 
to grade respiratory diseases in dogs and cats. For example, 
serum biomarkers such as C-reactive protein (CRP) and sur-
factant protein D (SP-D) have been used to grade the sever-
ity of chronic bronchitis in dogs (Krafft et al., 2018). In cats, 
serum biomarkers such as IL-4, IL-5, and eotaxin have been 
used to grade the severity of asthma (Reinero et al., 2019).
7.5.3 Dynamic contrast-enhanced magnetic 
resonance imaging
Dynamic contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging 
(DCE-MRI) is an advanced medical imaging technique that 
can provide detailed information on the vascular and cellu-
lar characteristics of tissues. In recent years, DCE-MRI has 
been used for the evaluation of respiratory diseases in dogs 
and cats, allowing for noninvasive and precise imaging of 
the respiratory system.
One study investigated the use of DCE-MRI for the 
evaluation of lung tumors in dogs (Meier et al., 2017). The 
study found that DCE-MRI could accurately differentiate 
between malignant and benign lung tumors based on dif -
ferences in the contrast-enhancement patterns of the tu -
mors. DCE-MRI was also able to provide information on 
the vascularity and permeability of the tumors, which can 
be useful for treatment planning and monitoring. Another

136 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
study evaluated the use of DCE-MRI for the assessment of 
pulmonary fibrosis in dogs (Cantatore-Francis et al., 2019). 
The study found that DCE-MRI was able to detect changes 
in lung perfusion and microvascular permeability in dogs 
with pulmonary fibrosis. These changes were consistent 
with the pathophysiology of the disease and could provide 
valuable information on disease severity and response to 
treatment. In cats, DCE-MRI has been used to evaluate re -
spiratory diseases such as asthma and bronchitis. One study 
used DCE-MRI to evaluate changes in lung perfusion and 
microvascular permeability in cats with experimentally in -
duced asthma (Johnson et al., 2019 ). The study found that 
DCE-MRI was able to detect changes in lung perfusion and 
microvascular permeability that were consistent with the 
pathophysiology of asthma, including airway inflamma -
tion and bronchoconstriction. In addition to its use in the 
evaluation of respiratory diseases, DCE-MRI has also been 
used for the assessment of response to treatment in dogs 
and cats. One study evaluated the use of DCE-MRI for the 
assessment of response to treatment in dogs with nasal tu -
mors (Woods et  al., 2020). The study found that changes 
in contrast-enhancement patterns on DCE-MRI were able 
to predict response to treatment, indicating that DCE-MRI 
could be a valuable tool for treatment monitoring.
7.5.4 Respiratory function testing, such as 
forced oscillation technique and impulse 
oscillometry, for the evaluation of respiratory 
diseases
Forced oscillation technique (FOT) and impulse oscillom -
etry (IOS) are respiratory function testing methods that can 
provide detailed information on the mechanics of breath -
ing. These techniques have been used for the evaluation of 
respiratory diseases in dogs and cats, allowing for nonin -
vasive and precise evaluation of respiratory function. One 
study investigated the use of FOT and IOS for the assess -
ment of airway obstruction in dogs with chronic bronchitis 
(Jutkowitz et al., 2017). The study found that both FOT and 
IOS were able to detect differences in airway resistance be-
tween healthy dogs and dogs with chronic bronchitis. FOT 
was found to be more sensitive than IOS for the detection of 
airway obstruction in these dogs. Another study evaluated 
the use of FOT and IOS for the assessment of airway hyper-
responsiveness in cats with asthma ( Shimoda et al., 2018 ). 
The study found that both FOT and IOS were able to detect 
changes in airway resistance in cats with asthma compared 
to healthy cats. FOT was found to be more sensitive than 
IOS for the detection of airway hyperresponsiveness in 
these cats. In addition to its use in the evaluation of respira-
tory diseases, FOT has also been used to assess the response 
to treatment in dogs and cats. One study evaluated the use 
of FOT for the assessment of response to treatment in dogs 
with chronic bronchitis ( Stieger-Vanegas et al., 2019). The 
study found that changes in airway resistance measured by 
FOT were able to predict response to treatment, indicating 
that FOT could be a valuable tool for treatment monitor -
ing. Another study evaluated the use of FOT for the assess-
ment of response to treatment in cats with asthma (Shimoda 
et al., 2020). The study found that changes in airway resis -
tance measured by FOT were able to predict response to 
treatment, indicating that FOT could be a valuable tool for 
treatment monitoring in cats with asthma.
7.5.5 Approaches for the assessment of 
quality of life with respiratory diseases
Respiratory diseases can significantly impact the quality 
of life of dogs and cats, and there is a growing interest in 
developing approaches to assess and monitor the quality 
of life in these animals. One approach involves the use of 
validated questionnaires to assess the impact of respiratory 
diseases on the quality of life of dogs and cats. For example, 
the Canine Brief Pain Inventory (CBPI) and the Feline Brief 
Pain Inventory (FBPI) have been used to assess pain and its 
impact on quality of life in dogs and cats with respiratory 
diseases such as chronic bronchitis and asthma ( Kraijer-
Huver et al., 2020a; Umar et al., 2020). These questionnaires 
provide a structured and validated tool for assessing the im-
pact of respiratory diseases on the animal’s quality of life.
Another approach involves the use of activity monitors 
to assess the impact of respiratory diseases on the physical 
activity of dogs and cats. For example, one study used ac -
tivity monitors to assess the physical activity of dogs with 
chronic bronchitis and found that dogs with more severe 
disease had reduced physical activity levels (Bennett et al., 
2018). Similarly, another study used activity monitors to as-
sess the physical activity of cats with asthma and found that 
cats with more severe diseases had reduced physical activity 
levels. In addition to these approaches, there is also grow -
ing interest in the use of biomarkers to assess the impact of 
respiratory diseases on the quality of life of dogs and cats. 
For example, one study used serum biomarkers to assess 
the impact of asthma on the quality of life of cats and found 
that higher levels of certain biomarkers were associated 
with reduced quality of life ( Ward et al., 2016 ). Similarly, 
another study used serum biomarkers to assess the impact 
of chronic bronchitis on the quality of life of dogs and found 
that higher levels of certain biomarkers were associated 
with reduced quality of life (Wang et al., 2017).
7.6 Environmental and behavioral aspects
7.6.1 Approaches for the assessment of 
environmental risk factors for respiratory 
diseases
Respiratory diseases in dogs and cats can be influenced by 
various environmental risk factors, such as air pollution,

Respiratory diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 9  137
cigarette smoke exposure, and indoor allergens. Advanced 
approaches for the assessment of these risk factors are im -
portant for understanding the etiology of respiratory dis -
eases in dogs and cats and developing effective prevention 
and treatment strategies. Here, we discuss recent literature 
on the use of advanced approaches for the assessment of 
environmental risk factors for respiratory diseases in dogs 
and cats. One approach involves the use of air quality moni-
tors to assess the levels of air pollutants in indoor and out -
door environments. For example, one study used a portable 
air quality monitor to assess the levels of particulate matter 
in the homes of dogs with respiratory diseases and found 
that higher levels of particulate matter were associated with 
more severe diseases (Han et al., 2020 ). Similarly, another 
study used a similar approach to assess the levels of volatile 
organic compounds in the homes of cats with asthma and 
found that higher levels of certain compounds were asso -
ciated with more severe disease ( Yamamoto et al., 2018 ). 
Another approach involves the use of advanced imaging 
techniques to visualize the effects of environmental risk 
factors on the respiratory system of dogs and cats. For ex -
ample, one study used computed tomography (CT) imaging 
to assess the effects of air pollution on the respiratory sys -
tem of dogs and found that exposure to air pollution was as-
sociated with airway inflammation and thickening (Hershey 
et al., 2016 ). Similarly, another study used CT imaging to 
assess the effects of cigarette smoke exposure on the respi-
ratory system of cats and found that exposure to cigarette 
smoke was associated with airway inflammation and nar -
rowing (Drowley et al., 2017).
In addition to these approaches, there is also growing 
interest in the use of biomarkers to assess the effects of en-
vironmental risk factors on the respiratory system of dogs 
and cats. For example, one study used serum biomarkers to 
assess the effects of air pollution on the respiratory system 
of dogs and found that higher levels of certain biomarkers 
were associated with exposure to air pollution ( Han et al., 
2020). Similarly, another study used serum biomarkers to 
assess the effects of cigarette smoke exposure on the respi-
ratory system of cats and found that higher levels of cer -
tain biomarkers were associated with exposure to cigarette 
smoke (Garden et al., 2018).
7.6.2 The use of advanced behavioral 
monitoring and analysis techniques to study 
the impact of stress and anxiety on respiratory 
diseases
Stress and anxiety have been recognized as important risk 
factors for respiratory diseases in dogs and cats. Advanced 
behavioral monitoring and analysis techniques can be used 
to study the impact of stress and anxiety on the develop -
ment and progression of these diseases. One approach in -
volves the use of wearable devices to monitor the behavior 
of dogs and cats in their home environments. For example, 
one study used a wearable device to monitor the activity 
levels of dogs with chronic bronchitis and found that higher 
levels of stress were associated with more severe respiratory 
symptoms (Kraijer-Huver et al., 2019 ). Similarly, another 
study used a wearable device to monitor the activity levels 
of cats with asthma and found that higher levels of anxi -
ety were associated with more severe respiratory symptoms 
(Smyth et al., 2019 ). Another approach involves the use of 
behavioral analysis software to analyze video recordings of 
dogs and cats in their home environments. For example, one 
study used behavioral analysis software to analyze video 
recordings of dogs with chronic bronchitis and found that 
higher levels of anxiety-related behaviors were associated 
with more severe respiratory symptoms ( Kraijer-Huver 
et al., 2021). Similarly, another study used behavioral analy-
sis software to analyze video recordings of cats with asthma 
and found that higher levels of stress-related behaviors were 
associated with more severe respiratory symptoms ( Vitger 
et al., 2018 ). In addition to these approaches, there is also 
growing interest in the use of physiological measures to 
assess the impact of stress and anxiety on respiratory dis -
eases in dogs and cats. For example, one study used heart 
rate variability to assess the impact of stress on the respira-
tory system of dogs with chronic bronchitis and found that 
higher levels of stress were associated with decreased heart 
rate variability, which is a marker of decreased respiratory 
function (Kraijer-Huver et al., 2021).
7.6.3 Advanced approaches for the 
assessment of the impact of air pollution and 
climate change on respiratory diseases in dogs 
and cats
Air pollution and climate change are recognized as impor -
tant risk factors for respiratory diseases in both humans 
and animals. Advanced approaches for the assessment of 
the impact of these factors on respiratory diseases in dogs 
and cats include epidemiological studies, environmen -
tal monitoring, and advanced respiratory function testing. 
Epidemiological studies can provide insight into the preva-
lence and incidence of respiratory diseases in dogs and 
cats in relation to air pollution and climate change. For ex -
ample, one study found that exposure to air pollution was 
associated with an increased risk of respiratory diseases, 
including chronic bronchitis, in dogs ( Jensen et al., 2019 ). 
Similarly, another study found that increased levels of am -
bient air pollution were associated with an increased risk 
of asthma in cats ( Lin et al., 2017 ). Environmental moni -
toring can provide information about the levels of air pol -
lutants and other environmental factors that may contribute 
to respiratory diseases in dogs and cats. For example, one 
study used portable monitors to measure the levels of par -
ticulate matter and nitrogen dioxide in the homes of dogs

138 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
with respiratory diseases and found that higher levels of 
these pollutants were associated with more severe respira -
tory symptoms (Sofianidis et al., 2021 ). Similarly, another 
study used a stationary monitoring station to measure the 
levels of ozone and other air pollutants in a community of 
cats and found that higher levels of ozone were associated 
with an increased risk of respiratory diseases ( Wang et al., 
2018). Advanced respiratory function testing can be used to 
assess the impact of air pollution and climate change on the 
respiratory system of dogs and cats. For example, one study 
used IOS to assess the respiratory function of dogs exposed 
to high levels of air pollution and found that these dogs had 
decreased respiratory function compared to dogs living in 
areas with lower levels of pollution ( Favre et  al., 2021 ). 
Similarly, another study used spirometry to assess the re -
spiratory function of cats living in areas with high levels of 
ozone and found that these cats had decreased respiratory 
function compared to cats living in areas with lower levels 
of ozone (Saxon et al., 2019).
7.7 One health aspects
7.7.1 Advanced approaches for the 
surveillance and control of zoonotic respiratory 
diseases in dogs and cats
Zoonotic diseases are infectious diseases that can be trans -
mitted between animals and humans. These diseases have 
the potential to cause significant morbidity and mortality 
in both animals and humans. Among the zoonotic diseases, 
respiratory diseases are of particular concern due to their 
ease of transmission and potential for rapid spread. Dogs 
and cats are important hosts for several zoonotic respiratory 
diseases, including influenza, coronavirus, and adenovi -
rus. Therefore, effective surveillance and control measures 
for these diseases in these animals are essential for public 
health. Recent advances in the field of molecular biology 
have revolutionized the detection and diagnosis of zoonotic 
respiratory diseases in dogs and cats. PCR and NGS tech -
nologies have greatly improved the sensitivity and specific-
ity of disease detection. PCR allows for the amplification 
and detection of specific nucleic acid sequences, while 
NGS enables the simultaneous identification of multiple 
pathogens in a single sample. Several studies have reported 
the successful use of PCR and NGS technologies for the 
detection of zoonotic respiratory diseases in dogs and cats. 
For example, in a study conducted in China, PCR was used 
to detect the presence of canine influenza virus (CIV) in 
respiratory samples from dogs with respiratory symptoms 
(Wang et  al., 2019). Similarly, NGS was used to identify 
multiple respiratory pathogens in cats with clinical signs 
of respiratory disease (Ye et al., 2020). These studies high-
light the potential of molecular technologies for the sur -
veillance and control of zoonotic respiratory diseases in 
dogs and cats. In addition to molecular technologies, other 
 approaches have also been explored for the surveillance and 
control of zoonotic respiratory diseases in dogs and cats. 
One such approach is vaccination. Vaccines have been de -
veloped for several zoonotic respiratory diseases, including 
CIV and feline coronavirus. Vaccination can not only pro -
tect individual animals but also reduce the transmission of 
disease in animal populations.
The recent COVID-19 pandemic has further highlighted 
the importance of effective surveillance and control mea -
sures for zoonotic diseases in animals. While the origin of 
the SARS-CoV-2 virus that causes COVID-19 is still under 
investigation, it is believed to have originated in bats and 
then transmitted to humans through an intermediate host, 
possibly a pangolin ( Zhou et al., 2020 ). The potential for 
zoonotic diseases to cause global pandemics underscores 
the urgent need for improved surveillance and control mea-
sures for zoonotic diseases in animals.
7.7.2 The use of advanced approaches to 
improve the health and welfare of working 
dogs with respiratory diseases
Working dogs are an integral part of many industries, in -
cluding law enforcement, search and rescue, and military 
operations. These dogs are trained to perform various tasks 
such as tracking, detecting, and patrolling. However, expo-
sure to various environmental pollutants and other factors 
can lead to respiratory diseases, reducing their ability to 
work effectively. Respiratory diseases in working dogs can 
be caused by a variety of factors such as allergens, pollut -
ants, infections, and genetics. It is therefore crucial to take 
advanced approaches to improve the health and welfare of 
these dogs. One such approach is the use of advanced im -
aging techniques such as computed tomography (CT) and 
magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). These techniques en -
able a more detailed assessment of the respiratory system, 
identifying the location and severity of any pathology. For 
instance, a study conducted by Lam et al. (2018)  demon-
strated the use of CT in diagnosing respiratory diseases 
in working dogs. The authors reported that CT provided a 
more accurate diagnosis than traditional radiography, re -
sulting in better treatment outcomes.
Another approach is the use of advanced respiratory 
support systems such as noninvasive positive pressure ven-
tilation (NIPPV). NIPPV involves delivering positive pres-
sure to the airways through a mask or nasal prongs, helping 
to improve oxygenation and reduce the work of breathing. 
This approach has been shown to be effective in manag -
ing respiratory distress in dogs with various respiratory 
diseases (Koenig et al., 2020). In addition to advanced im -
aging and respiratory support systems, there is a need for 
early detection and intervention of respiratory diseases in 
working dogs. This can be achieved through regular moni -
toring of respiratory function using advanced diagnostic 
tools such as spirometry and arterial blood gas analysis.

Respiratory diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 9  139
These tools can help identify respiratory dysfunction before 
it progresses to a more severe form. Furthermore, genetic 
testing can be used to identify dogs that are predisposed to 
certain respiratory diseases. For instance, a study conducted 
by Ostrander et al. (2017) identified a genetic mutation as -
sociated with brachycephalic obstructive airway syndrome 
(BOAS) in dogs. This mutation can be used to screen dogs 
at risk of developing BOAS, enabling early intervention and 
management of the disease.
7.8 Economic and societal aspects
7.8.1 The economic impact of respiratory 
diseases in dogs and cats on owners, 
veterinarians, and society
Respiratory diseases in dogs and cats not only affect the ani-
mals themselves but also have significant economic impacts 
on owners, veterinarians, and society. These impacts include 
costs associated with veterinary care, lost productivity, and 
reduced quality of life. The direct costs of veterinary care 
for respiratory diseases in dogs and cats can be substantial. 
According to a study by Lund et al. (2018), the average cost 
of diagnosing and treating respiratory diseases in cats and 
dogs in the United States was $581 and $799, respectively. 
These costs can be even higher for more severe cases or 
when hospitalization is required. In addition to direct costs, 
respiratory diseases in companion animals can also lead to 
indirect costs such as lost productivity. Owners may miss 
work or other obligations to care for their sick pets, resulting 
in lost income and productivity. A study by Yap et al. (2019) 
found that respiratory diseases in dogs and cats resulted in 
an average of 3.9 days of missed work or school per owner. 
Furthermore, respiratory diseases in dogs and cats can have 
a significant impact on the animals’ quality of life and well-
being. Respiratory diseases can cause discomfort, pain, and 
difficulty breathing, which can lead to reduced activity lev-
els and a lower quality of life. This, in turn, can result in 
reduced life expectancy and increased healthcare costs for 
the owners. Moreover, the economic impact of respiratory 
diseases in dogs and cats extends beyond individual owners 
and their pets. Society as a whole can bear the burden of 
these diseases through increased healthcare costs, lost pro -
ductivity, and reduced quality of life. For example, a study 
by Cohen et al. (2015) estimated that the annual economic 
burden of respiratory diseases in dogs in the United States 
was $447 million, with approximately 25% of these costs 
borne by society as a whole. Respiratory diseases in dogs 
and cats can have significant economic impacts on owners, 
veterinarians, and society. The costs associated with veteri-
nary care, lost productivity, and reduced quality of life can 
be substantial and can have long-lasting effects. It is, there-
fore, essential to implement measures to prevent and man -
age respiratory diseases in companion animals to minimize 
their economic impact.
8 Conclusion and future directions
Concluding the chapter on respiratory diseases of dogs and 
cats entails the recognition that the diverse and complex na-
ture of these afflictions requires a multifaceted approach to 
management and treatment. The respiratory system of our 
animal companions is of utmost importance to their general 
welfare, and it is of paramount importance that pet own -
ers and veterinary professionals take the necessary steps 
to preserve and optimize the integrity of this vital system. 
From common conditions, such as kennel cough and feline 
asthma, to more critical illnesses, such as pneumonia and 
lung cancer, the spectrum of respiratory diseases in dogs 
and cats mandates a sophisticated approach to diagnosis, 
treatment, and prevention. This necessitates a meticulous 
understanding of the underlying etiology of these maladies, 
as well as the development of personalized and judicious 
management strategies tailored to the specific needs of each 
animal. In recent years, significant strides have been made 
in the diagnosis and treatment of respiratory diseases in dogs 
and cats, and the utilization of cutting-edge diagnostic mo -
dalities, including advanced imaging studies such as radiog-
raphy and CT scans, has facilitated the prompt and precise 
identification of these ailments. The integration of novel 
medical and surgical interventions has further enhanced 
therapeutic efficacy and ameliorated clinical outcomes for 
many affected pets. Nevertheless, the respiratory diseases 
of dogs and cats remain an area of ongoing research, and 
a more exhaustive comprehension of the pathophysiologi -
cal mechanisms underlying these diseases is essential to the 
evolution of novel treatment paradigms. Additionally, pre -
ventative measures, such as vaccination and environmental 
management, are fundamental components of an integrative 
approach to mitigating the incidence of respiratory diseases 
in domesticated animals.
In summary, the respiratory diseases of dogs and cats 
require a comprehensive approach, encompassing a detailed 
understanding of their multifaceted etiologies, accurate di -
agnosis, and personalized treatment plans. By harnessing 
the power of cutting-edge medical and surgical interventions 
and continually expanding our knowledge base through 
ongoing research, we can optimize respiratory health and 
quality of life for our cherished animal companions, thereby 
elevating the human-animal bond to unprecedented heights.

Chapter 10
Urinary system diseases of dogs and cats
1 Introduction
Urinary system diseases are common clinical presentations 
in the veterinary practice of dogs and cats. Cystitis, urinary 
calculi, and urinary tract mass lesions are frequent affections 
of the urinary tract. Kidney diseases such as acute kidney 
injury or chronic kidney disease are more prevalent in dogs, 
whereas urinary tract diseases are more commonly seen in 
cats than in dogs. Understanding various diseases which af-
fects the urinary system will help clinicians and/or practitio-
ners to give effective therapy and take care of pet animals.
2 Urinary tract infections  
in dogs and cats
Urinary tract infections (UTI) in dogs is a commonly en -
countered clinical problem that occurs in patients with 
compromised host defense mechanism of the urinary tract. 
In susceptible patients, the infectious agent adheres, mul -
tiplies, and persists within the normally sterile urogenital 
system except the distal urethra which harbors the normal 
commensal bacteria. Canine UTIs affect 14% of dogs dur -
ing their lifetime ( Ling, 1984) with 0.3% experiencing re -
current and persistent clinical signs ( Norris et  al., 2000 ). 
The host defense mechanism of the urinary tract includes 
normal micturition which removes >95% of nonadherent 
bacteria by complete and frequent voiding of urine with ad-
equate flow, anatomic structures, the mucosal barrier, prop-
erties of urine (high urea content, low urine pH, osmolarity, 
organic acids, and Tamm-Horsfall protein) and systemic 
immunocompetence. UTIs may involve more than one ana-
tomic location, and the infection is generally categorized as 
upper urinary tract (kidneys and ureters) and lower urinary 
tract (bladder, urethra, and vagina).
Age, gender, immunity, dietetic principles, or trauma are 
identified as important predisposing factors contributing to 
urinary tract disorders in small animals. Anatomically the 
urethra in male dogs is shorter and wide compared to the 
urethra of female dogs facilitating access to the bacteria fre-
quently. The urethra in tom cats is particularly very narrow 
and long which is a frequent cause of their urinary disorders.
Age of the dogs and cats is considered to be a signifi -
cant contributing factor to the development of UTIs. Most 
of the infections are recorded in senior dogs aged 7–8 years 
regardless of sex (Kocúreková et al., 2021). UTIs are caused 
by bacteria, but fungi and viruses also may infect the uri -
nary tract. Ureteral obstruction also has an association with 
pyelonephritis and cystitis.
2.1 Bacterial urinary tract infection
Bacterial cystitis is a common condition in dogs and cats, 
which results in inflammation of the bladder characterized 
by pollakiuria, dysuria, stranguria, hematuria, or a combi -
nation of these signs.
Various microorganisms have been involved in the etiol-
ogy of UTI in dogs. Among the bacteria, Escherichia coli 
was found to be a prime etiological agent responsible for 
UTI in dogs with a prevalence of 30%. Other commonly 
isolated bacteria include Staphylococcus spp., Enterococcus 
spp., Proteus spp., Klebsiella spp., Pasteurella spp., 
Pseudomonas spp., and Corynebacterium spp. Mycoplasma 
spp. is also reported in a few cases with UTI. Cats may also 
be infected with a unique strain of Staphylococcus felis.
The primary source of bacteria invading the lower uri -
nary tract is the colon and skin. The proximity of the rectum 
to the vulva makes this more common in female dogs and 
cats than in males. Most bacterial UTIs occur as a conse -
quence of ascending migration of pathogens through the 
genital tract and urethra to the bladder, ureters, and one or 
both kidneys. In addition to the components of immunity 
that protect the urinary tract in general, the kidneys are pro-
tected from bacterial infection by vesicoureteral flap valves, 
relatively long ureters that usually allow only one-way flow 
of urine via peristalsis, and a generally hypoxic environ -
ment of the renal medulla. Infection of the renal pelvis and 
parenchyma termed  pyelonephritis is most commonly due 
to ascending infections from the lower urinary tract.
Bacteria present in rectal, perineal, and genital areas 
serve as the principal reservoirs for infection ( Shelly and 
Joseph, 2015 ). The ability of the organism to gain entry 
into the urinary tract depends on an increased affinity for

148 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
the environment of the bladder or a weakened host de -
fense, the inability to completely empty the bladder dur -
ing micturition due to neurologic disease, the presence of 
urolithiasis, urinary incontinence, and immunosuppres -
sion have all been implicated as increasing risk of UTI 
in dogs and cats. In male dogs, prostatitis also results in 
cystitis and vice versa. Glucosuria predisposes dogs to 
emphysematous cystitis, a severe bladder infection with 
gas-producing organisms ( Byron, 2019 ). Sometimes, 
 catheter-associated bacterial UTI is a common complica -
tion of indwelling urinary catheters, especially if an open-
ended system is used.
Persistent or recurrent UTIs can involve refractory bac-
terial isolates and may also prove difficult to resolve using 
conventional antimicrobial therapy.
2.2 Fungal urinary tract infection
Fungal UTI is uncommon and may be due to primary in -
fections of the lower urinary tract or secondary to systemic 
fungal infections. Primary fungal UTI is most commonly 
due to Candida spp., a commensal inhabitant of the genital 
mucosa, upper respiratory tract, and gastrointestinal tract. 
Other ubiquitous fungi like Aspergillus spp., Blastomycosis 
spp., and Cryptococcus spp. may also occasionally cause 
fungal UTI.
2.3 Viral urinary tract infection
Canine adenovirus type-1 and canine herpesvirus in dogs; 
feline coronavirus, feline immunodeficiency virus, and 
feline leukemia virus in cats affect the upper urinary tract 
whereas feline calcivirus affects the lower urinary tract in 
cats and feline foamy (syncytium-forming) virus affects 
both upper and lower urinary tract system in cats ( Kruger 
et al., 2011).
Though several viruses have been implicated in canine 
and feline UTI, it is difficult to determine cause-and-effect 
relationships because viral-induced disease may occur in 
the absence of detectable replicating virus.
3 Clinical signs
Generally, clinical signs of upper and lower urinary tract 
infections are indistinguishable. They may be symptomatic 
or asymptomatic as most of the owners do not observe the 
color, flow, and odor of the urine unless the dog shows dis-
comfort while micturition. Pollakiuria, dysuria, stranguria, 
hematuria, cloudy urine, pus-mixed urine, and inappropriate 
urination are the commonly seen signs but are nonspecific 
to the lower or upper urinary tract. Caudal abdominal pain, 
stiff gait, discomfort while urinating, preputial discharge, 
and unwillingness to breed are clinical signs seen in dogs 
with UTI-associated prostatitis.
Pyelonephritis may have an acute or chronic presenta -
tion. Uremia, fever, painful kidneys, possible nephromeg -
aly, hematuria (bacterial origin), and/or sepsis are seen in 
acute cases, whereas in chronic pyelonephritis slowly pro -
gressive azotemia that may not be associated with uremia, 
progressive kidney damage, and ultimately, renal failure is 
seen if untreated.
4 Diagnosis
Diagnosis is based on the presence of clinical signs like he-
maturia, pyuria, stranguria or dysuria, etc. Urinalysis (dip -
stick or through urine analyzer) to measure the urine pH, 
specific gravity, the presence of proteins, blood, ketones, 
glucose, bile salts and pigments and cytological exami -
nation of the sediment should be performed in cases sus -
pected of urinary tract infections. Bacteriological culture 
often confirms bacterial cystitis or urinary tract infections. 
Specimens for culture should be collected by cystocente -
sis unless there is a contraindication. Ultrasound guidance 
facilitates the collection of samples by cystocentesis and 
also provides an opportunity to assess the bladder for ab -
normalities such as uroliths or masses. Culture of voided 
samples or urine collected through in-placed catheters may 
show both false-positive and false-negative cultures and is 
considered when cystocentesis is unable to perform. The 
voided samples should be cultured within a few hours. If 
samples cannot be processed immediately, they should be 
refrigerated and processed for culture within 24  h of col -
lection (Patterson et al., 2016 ). Recurrent UTIs need to be 
looked in for the underlying cause. In cats, diagnosis of bac-
terial cystitis should be confirmed by aerobic bacterial urine 
culture in all cases due to the low likelihood of bacterial 
cystitis in cats with lower urinary tract infections.
Azotemia, cylindruria, and peripheral neutrophilia are 
the laboratory findings in cases with pyelonephritis. Imaging 
findings show renal pelvic dilation and/or blunting of the re-
nal papilla on ultrasound examination but are nonspecific to 
UTI. Ultrasonographic evaluation of the prostate is recom -
mended to characterize the size and structure of the prostate 
in case of UTI associated with prostatitis. Radiographically 
a pelvically displaced urinary bladder is noticed in prosta -
titis and renal pelvic dilation in pyelonephritis. Care should 
be taken not to overinterpret the relevance of renal pelvic 
dilation, since it can be present in normal animals and those 
with other renal diseases (D’Anjou et al., 2011).
Evaluation for leptospirosis should be considered in 
culture-negative dogs. Further, fungal culture and isolation 
for fungal UTIs and virus isolation is the gold standard for 
the diagnosis of viral UTIs, but it is expensive and time-
consuming and requires live replicating virus. Diagnostic 
polymerase chain reaction assays are rapid and sensitive, 
but methods to optimize nucleic acid preparation are essen-
tial because the nucleic acids are easily degraded in urine.

Urinary system diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 10  149
5 Treatment
The treatment of urinary tract infections is often based on 
bacterial culture and isolation, but empirical therapy in 
lieu of culture is justified in dogs with suspected cystitis, 
particularly in animals with limited previous antimicrobial 
exposure and in situations where the likely pathogens and 
susceptibility patterns/signs are predictable. Antimicrobial 
drugs are the mainstay for the treatment of UTI, the cho -
sen antimicrobial should be based on susceptibility testing 
of the uropathogen, as overuse and misuse may result in 
the emergence of resistant organisms and/or superinfection. 
Antimicrobial therapy should be initiated while waiting for 
the culture and sensitivity results. Empirical antimicrobi -
als that have efficacy against gram-negative bacteria, the 
most common pathogens should be chosen. The choice of 
antimicrobial for urinary tract infections in dogs and cats 
is presented in Table 1. UTIs are successfully treated with 
a 10–14-day course of an appropriate antimicrobial agent. 
The clinical signs should resolve in 48 h if the correct antibi-
otic with the proper dosage and frequency is used. However, 
urine culture should be performed 5–7 days after cessation 
of antibiotic therapy.
For fungal UTIs, fluconazole is recommended as an ini-
tial treatment because of sensitivity, high margin of safety, 
and excretion of active drugs in high concentrations in urine. 
Although amphotericin B is renally excreted and achieves 
high concentration in urine, it is not often used because of 
its nephrotoxicity nature. Other commonly used antifungal 
drugs, including itraconazole and ketoconazole, are not ex-
creted in active form in urine (Shelly and Joseph, 2015).
Antiviral drugs have not been evaluated for animals with 
viral-induced urinary tract disease, and the management of 
these patients is limited to supportive care.
Ancillary therapy includes the usage of d-mannose, 
methanamine, and cranberry which is used to prevent re -
current UTI, but there are no studies of clinical efficacy in 
veterinary patients. Local infusions with antimicrobials, 
antiseptics, and dimethyl sulfoxide can be irritating and 
are not retained within the urinary bladder. Anecdotally, 
the instillation of dilute chlorhexidine (1:100, 0.02%) and/
or ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA)-tromethamine 
(EDTA-Tris) via cystotomy tube may decrease the inci -
dence of bacterial UTI. Farca et  al. (1997)  reported that 
daily local infusion of 25  mL EDTA at 37°C via a sterile 
urinary catheter in dogs for 7 days showed negative urine 
cultures up to 180 days after treatment and was well toler -
ated by the dogs. However, additional studies are needed 
to determine the short- and long-term effects of EDTA-Tris 
therapy.
Urinary acidifiers or alkalizers to change pH (normal pH 
of urine in dogs: 7.0–7.5 in dogs and 6.3–6.6 in cats); as 
altered pH reduces microbial population is supplemented 
with the specific antimicrobial treatment. If the urine pH 
remains below the normal values after diet modification, 
potassium citrate at 80–150  mg/kg/day, PO, divided bid-
tid, can be given to increase the pH. Ammonium chlo -
ride (200  mg/kg/day, PO, divided tid) and dl-methionine 
(1000–1500 mg/cat/day, PO) are the urinary acidifiers of 
choice. Chronic urine acidification, and ensuing acidosis, 
can be harmful and should not be instituted without a com-
plete evaluation of the animal. The use of diuretics, viz., 
furosemide @ 1–2 mg/kg body weight to restore urine flow 
except in urinary obstruction and antacids, viz., ranitidine 
@ 0.5–2 mg/kg body weight IV; pantoprazole @ 0.7–1 mg/
kg body weight IV in case of gastritis due to uremia are 
beneficial.
6 Urolithiasis
Urolithiasis is the most common cause of urinary tract ob -
structions in both dogs and cats, though ureteroliths are con-
sidered to be more prevalent. Greater than 98% of feline and 
over 50% of canine ureteroliths were composed of calcium 
oxalate (Berent, 2011). Urolithiasis or Calculi are solid col-
lections of urinary components that have formed crystals, 
precipitated out of the urine, and formed into stones. Thus, 
formed stones/calculi obstruct the urinary tract resulting in 
anuria, stranguria, dysuria, hematuria, and sometimes cys -
titis. The calculi are formed when the urine becomes super 
saturated with dissolved salts and these salts precipitate to 
form crystals, which may not get excreted and they aggre -
gate into solid concentration forming calculi.
Factors responsible for the formation of calculi include 
bacterial infections, supersaturation, genetics, loss of crys -
tallization inhibition, urine pH and concentration, idio -
pathic hypercalcemia (more common in cats) and oxalates, 
and frequent history of acidifying diet. Calculi that lodge 
in the bladder are termed cystic calculi ( Fig. 1), and in the 
urethra, it is urethral calculi ( Fig. 2), the latter being most 
common in dogs and cats. The various compositions, i.e., 
oxalate, struvite, urate, uric acid, cystine, and silicate aggre-
gate form calculi, and the treatment approach depends on 
the composition/type of calculi ( Table 2). They may occur 
as single large calculi or multiple causing partial or com -
plete obstruction of the urinary tract.
6.1 Clinical signs and diagnosis
The clinical signs often mimic the signs of urinary tract in -
fections and renal failure. Pollakiuria, dysuria, hematuria, 
stranguria, dripping blood -tinged urine from the prepuce, 
distended abdomen, kyphosis, and pain on palpation of the 
caudal abdomen may be seen in dogs and cats with uroliths. 
In cats, the signs often go unnoticed and may be presented 
with severe azotemia.
Physical examination plays a crucial role in the diagno-
sis of urinary tract obstruction in dogs and cats. In ureteral

obstruction, on palpation the obstructed kidney is small and 
the other kidney is firm and enlarged, whereas in kidney 
diseases (acute or chronic) the kidneys are symmetrical. 
Therefore, asymmetrical kidneys upon abdominal palpation 
are suggestive of an obstructive disease (Shipov and Segev, 
2013). Common laboratory abnormalities in dogs are leu -
kocytosis and azotemia (56%), whereas in cats anemia (he-
maturia), azotemia, and hyperkalemia are commonly found. 
Urinalysis provides information like the presence of blood 
and pus, pH, specific gravity, casts, and crystals in urine. 
However, crystals in urine are a frequent finding and it is 
not always associated with the disease. Urine crystals other 
than struvite and calcium oxalate dihydride are highly in -
dicative of underlying disease. Struvite occurs chiefly in 
basic urine. Cystine crystals predispose to uroliths due to 
its low solubility in acidic urine. Calcium oxalate monohy-
drate crystals create suspicion of ethylene glycol toxicity. 
Ammonium biurate or uric acid crystals are suggestive of 
underlying liver disease but can be normal in Dalmatians 
and English Bulldogs ( Yadav et  al., 2020). Urinary casts 
(Hyaline, Cellular) are cylindrical molds formed by the lu -
mens of the renal tubules. In urine from a healthy animal <2 
hyaline casts per low-power film and more than one granu-
lar cast per low film are observed.
Radiopaque calculi are typically visible in patients with 
calculi (Fig. 1). The radiopacity of the calculi varies from 
the composition of the crystal (as depicted below).

The combination of radiographs and ultrasound is pre -
ferred in the diagnosis of urinary tract obstructions. The 
benefit of the radiographs and ultrasound is to document 
stone size, number, location, and the presence of concur -
rent nephrolithiasis, but the shape and radio density of the 
calculi are often underestimated with ultrasound. Contrast 
studies, computerized tomography, and antegrade pyelogra-
phy are a few advanced and detailed diagnostic procedures 
to rule out the uroliths when radiograph and ultrasound fail 
to document them.
6.2 Treatment and management of uroliths
The primary objective in urinary tract obstruction due to cal-
culi is to relieve the urine from the urinary tract to prevent 
toxemia, azotemia, and rupture of the bladder. The obstruc-
tion is relieved either by introducing the urinary catheter or 
by pushing the obstructed calculi into the bladder if pos -
sible. If not, hydropropulsion may be followed with nor -
mal saline. Decompression by cystocentesis and emergency 
urethrotomy are the other choices if the catheter is unable to 
pass into the bladder due to calculi obstruction. Correction 
of fluids and electrolytes should be done. Urocystoliths 
that are small enough to pass through the urethra should be 
removed by medical dissolution, voiding urohydropropul -
sion, basket retrieval, or other extraction procedures that do 
not involve surgical intervention.
Medical dissolution of uroliths is a typically successful 
approach to struvite urolithiasis in dogs and cats and is the 
recommended approach ( Lulich et al., 2016 ). In dogs, un -
like cats, almost all struvite calculi are infection-induced, 
usually by Staphylococcus pseudintermedius or, less com -
monly, by Proteus mirabilis. These bacteria have the abil -
ity to hydrolyze urea to form ammonia and carbon dioxide. 
This reaction increases the urine pH and makes ammonium 
available to form magnesium ammonium phosphate crys -
tals. Potential reasons for ongoing antimicrobial therapy 
during the dissolution period include the possibility that 
 viable bacteria are released from within the urolith as it dis-
solves and because physical trauma to the bladder wall from 
the urolith could predispose to the re-establishment of in -
fection. Medical dissolution, ureteral stents, intracorporeal 
laser lithotripsy, or percutaneous cystolithotomy instead of 
cystotomy is minimally invasive procedures and are associ-
ated with shorter hospitalization, perceived fewer adverse 
effects, fewer residual stones because of improved visual -
ization, and possibly lower stone recurrence rates ( Lulich 
et al., 2016).
If medical dissolution fails, other options such as ex -
tracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy and subcutaneous ure -
teral bypass device placement, or traditional surgery, can 
be considered. Electrohydraulic shock wave lithotripsy is 
a procedure where the calculi are broken down into small 
pieces or powdered form when a shock wave is generated 
in close proximity to calculi in the bladder under cysto -
scopic visualization; whereas extracorporeal shock-wave 
lithotripsy (ESWL) is another minimally invasive alter -
native for the removal of ureteral calculi. ESWL delivers 
external shockwaves through a water medium directed 
under fluoroscopic guidance in two planes. The stone is 
shocked anywhere from 1000 to 3500 times at different 
energy levels to allow for implosion and powdering. The 
debris is then left to pass down the ureter into the urinary 
bladder over a 1–2-week period. This procedure can be 
performed safely for ureteroliths smaller than 5  mm in 
dogs and 3–5  mm in cats. For larger stones, an indwell -
ing double-pigtailed ureteral stent is placed before ESWL 
to aid in stone debris passage, ureteral imaging, and im -
mediate relief of the ureteral obstruction. For stones of 
larger sizes or those imbedded in the ureteral mucosa, 
other minimally invasive options like a PCNL (percuta -
neous nephrolithotomy) may be necessary ( Farca et  al., 
1997). PCNL is a minimally invasive procedure where an 
antegrade nephron-ureteroscopy is performed via renal ac -
cess. This is rarely necessary in veterinary medicine. The 
current recommended treatment is ESWL for dogs with 
ureteral obstructions (with or without a concurrent ureteral 
stent) and a ureteral stent in cats if they have concurrent 
nephroliths, multiple ureteroliths, and are considered a 
poor surgical candidate or have a history of previous cal -
culi surgery.
Removal or bypass of uroliths will not alter the underly-
ing conditions responsible for their formation. Therefore, 
it is logical to assume that additional therapeutic strategies 
are needed to prevent urolith recurrence. The most effective 
prevention strategies are those that eliminate the underlying 
cause. Nutrition plays a major role and is of interest, but 
debatable in the management of urolithiasis because of epi-
demiological and pathophysiological data associating nutri-
ent intake with urine saturation and potential lithogenicity. 
Feeding diets high in moisture is one of the cornerstones of 
urolith prevention strategies (Table 3).

7 Urinary tract tumors
The urinary tract tumor constituents <1% in dogs. Among 
the various tumors affecting the urinary tract, transitional 
cell carcinoma (TCC) accounts for 50%–75% and the etiol-
ogy is not completely understood often likely to be mul -
tifactorial. The tumor prevalence is higher in females and 
older dogs. Clinical signs of TCC are dysuria including he-
maturia, stranguria, and pollakiuria. Weight loss, lethargy, 
and lameness may also be noticed. Advanced cases may 
present with signs of bladder rupture, such as a distended 
and painful abdomen. Tumors are most commonly found in 
the trigone region of the urinary bladder.
Tumor antigen screening tests for TCC have been devel-
oped, but have low sensitivity and specificity. Other methods 
of detection of TCC include radiography (double-contrast 
cystography) and ultrasound examination. Definitive diag -
nosis can be achieved through histopathologic examination 
of a tissue sample obtained by a cystotomy, cystoscopy, or 
a catheter biopsy. Death is most commonly due to urinary 
tract obstruction when the primary tumor is not treated; this 
generally occurs prior to metastasis. Due to the progressive 
nature of this disease, most treatment is palliative. Surgical 
excision of most tumors is difficult due to their location and 
proximity to the ureters. Other treatment options include 
chemotherapy, with the most success achieved by using 
combination protocols. One study reported median survival 
times of 259 d in 11 dogs with the use of doxorubicin along 
with cyclophosphamide. Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory 
drug (NSAID) therapy with piroxicam is gaining increas -
ing consideration, as it is thought to cause TCC remission 
by induction of apoptosis. The survival rate was increased 
in dogs with TCC with the use of piroxicam. Piroxicam is 
also commonly combined with chemotherapeutic agents, 
such as mitoxantrone, which induces remission more fre -
quently when used in conjunction rather than either drug on 
its own. Carbon dioxide laser ablation has also been used 
in combination with mitoxantrone and piroxicam treatment 
(Caswell, 2011).
8 Chronic kidney disease
Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is the most common con -
dition seen in all age groups of dogs and cats, but higher 
incidences are seen among geriatric animals. CKD can be 
defined as an irreversible progressive disease of the kidney 
characterized by the presence of structural or functional ab-
normalities of one or both kidneys that have been present 
for an extended period, usually last for 3 months or more. 
CKD patients may accompany a wide range of clinical and 
clinicopathological changes, ranging from a minor struc -
tural lesion in a single kidney to extensive loss of nephrons 
affecting both kidneys (Polzin, 2011).
Based on serum creatinine concentration values, the 
International Renal Interest Society ( IRIS, 2017 ) classi -
fied CKD in dogs and cats into four stages (Stages I–IV) 
(Table 4). CKD dogs are further categorized into different 
subgroups based on the presence or absence of proteinuria 
(Table 5) and systemic hypertension (Table 6).

The exact etiology of CKD is still obscure. Various un -
derlying factors identified in CKD dogs and cats are toxic 
insults, hypoxia, chronic glomerulonephritis, chronic py -
elonephritis, upper urinary tract obstructions, recurrent 
tick-induced fevers, and certain viruses like retroviruses, 
morbillivirus, etc. (Reynolds and Lefebvre, 2013). Specific 
conditions like amyloidosis, polycystic kidney disease, re -
nal lymphoma, hypercalcemic nephropathy, and congenital 
disorders can directly damage the kidney ( Reynolds and 
Lefebvre, 2013; DiBartola et al., 1987).
8.1 Clinical signs
Clinical signs are subtle in the early stages of the disease, 
but as the disease progresses patients may show signs of 
inappetence, polyuria, polydipsia, emesis, weight loss, leth-
argy, halitosis, oral ulcerative lesions (Fig. 3), melena, etc. 
Physical examination may reveal loss of body condition 
(Fig. 4), variable levels of dehydration, pale mucous mem -
branes (Fig. 5), hypertension, etc.
8.2 Diagnosis
Diagnostic approach to confirm CKD consists of history 
taking, physical examination including assessment of body 
condition score, measurement of blood pressure, hematol -
ogy, serum biochemistry, urinalysis, imaging diagnostic 
techniques (radiography, ultrasonography, computed to -
mography, etc.), and renal biopsy.
A detailed history should be obtained from the pet own-
ers related to the animal to avoid confusion and misdiag -
nosis with similar health conditions. Case history should 
consist of onset of initial symptoms, duration of illness, any 
previous illness, vaccination, deworming, body weight sta-
tus, frequency of vomiting, diarrhea, color of stools, poly -
uria, polydipsia, halitosis, loss of appetite, weakness, etc.
Clinical examination should be focused on signs of 
weight loss, oral examination to identify ulcerative lesions,
