Urine samples have to be collected by using appropriate-
sized urinary catheters in both male and female dogs, tom 
urinary catheters can be employed in male cats. Analysis 
of urine samples is done either by dipsticks or analyzers to 
evaluate urine specific gravity (USG), urine pH, urine sedi-
ment analysis, urine protein and creatinine ratio (UPCR), 
and other abnormal constituents. A urine culture is advis -
able in cases suspected of recurrent urinary infections or 
pyelonephritis.
Urinalysis results may vary in early kidney disease 
and progressive loss of concentrating ability occurs as the 
 disease progresses to a later stage of the disease. Inadequate 
concentrating ability is defined for cats as urine with a spe-
cific gravity of less than 1.035 and for dogs less than 1.030. 
Renal proteinuria can be glomerular and or tubular in origin 
due to excessive filtration, decreased tubular reabsorption, 
or both. Urine protein and creatinine ratios (UPCR)  > 2 
suggest glomerular range proteinuria, which is rare in cats 
compared with dogs. It is important to recognize that the 
UPCR does not differentiate renal proteinuria from pro -
teinuria associated with lower urinary tract inflammation; 
hence, the clinician has to confirm by assessing the patient 
and urine sediment.
Routine serum biochemical tests include total proteins 
(albumin and globulin), urea, creatinine, electrolytes (so -
dium, potassium, chloride, calcium, and phosphorous), and 
other analytes (e.g., thyroxine in an older cat) that help to 
identify the severity of the disease. Routine hematology 
helps to assess the severity of anemia, extent and type of 
inflammation, etc.
Hypertension is a common phenomenon in CKD patients, 
hence monitoring of blood pressure is essential at regular in-
tervals. Systolic blood pressure is typically measured by the 
Doppler or oscillometric methods in dogs and cats. Ultrasonic 
Doppler flow detector method is commonly used for estimat-
ing blood pressure in dogs and cats, which estimates arterial 
pressure (brachial artery, dorsal pedal artery, and saphenous 
artery) by detecting changes induced by blood flow during 
external compression by an inflatable cuff (Fig. 6).
8.2.1 Ultrasonographic examination  
of kidneys
Abdominal ultrasonography is an ideal noninvasive diag -
nostic modality to identify any structural abnormalities in 
FIG. 5 Pale mucus membranes in a CKD dog.
FIG. 6 Recording blood pressure in a dog with Doppler ultrasonographic technique.

Urinary system diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 10  157
kidneys and associated structures. A 5–8 MHz transducer is 
adequate for most dogs and an 8–15 MHz transducer is op-
timal for cats. The abdomen is prepared by clipping the hair 
and applying acoustic coupling gel to the skin. The kidneys 
are initially examined from the ventral abdomen with the 
animal in dorsal recumbency.
Ultrasonographic examination of the kidneys must be 
performed thoroughly to identify the size, shape, architec -
ture, and abnormal lesions in the renal parenchyma. The 
kidneys should have a smooth contour with a thin echo -
genic capsule. The sonographic appearance of the kidneys 
depends on the image plane and the particular location of 
the slice of the ultrasound beam.
Overall increased renal echogenicity and reduced cor -
ticomedullary definition have been described with con -
genital renal dysplasia, juvenile nephropathy, chronic 
inflammatory diseases, and end-stage kidney disease from 
a variety of causes in dogs and cats ( Lobetti et al., 1996 ; 
Felkai et al., 1997 ; Miyamoto et al., 1997 ; Walter et al., 
1987). In end-stage renal disease, kidneys are typically 
small, irregular, and diffusely echogenic with poor visu -
alization of the corticomedullary junction and internal re -
nal architecture ( Fig.  7). Reduced cortical echogenicity, 
multifocal hypoechoic areas, hypoechoic nodules, or hy -
poechoic masses may be seen with lymphosarcoma of 
the kidneys in the dog and cat. As focal or diffuse paren -
chymal lesions of the kidney have a variety of ultrasono -
graphic appearances, aspiration or biopsy of the kidney is 
recommended for diagnosis.
8.2.2 Abdominal radiographs
Radiographic examination of kidneys helps to locate the 
changes/alterations in the size and shape of the kidneys, 
but radiographic findings alone are insufficient to confirm 
the disease. Particularly, diffuse infiltrative renal diseases 
(inflammatory, metabolic, or neoplastic) resembles simi -
lar imaging features, the radiographic findings should be 
amalgamated with the observations of additional diagnostic 
techniques like imaging ultrasonography, computed tomog-
raphy, renal fine-needle aspiration cytology or biopsy to 
make a definitive diagnosis.
Focal or diffuse lesions in the renal parenchyma enhance 
the renal radio-opacity. Possible causes for radio-opaque le-
sions include renal calculi ( Fig.  8) or mineralization and 
dystrophic mineralization of renal parenchymal lesions 
such as cysts or neoplasms. A generalized increase in renal 
radiographic opacity is an uncommon finding and may be 
associated with diffuse mineralization of the renal paren -
chyma (nephrocalcinosis).
Patients with chronic renal disease commonly have 
small and irregular contours of kidneys. Renal mineraliza -
tion or nephrolithiasis may occur as a concurrent infection 
which can be diagnosed by urography. Expected findings 
include decreased contrast medium accumulation within the 
renal parenchyma, and poor opacification of the renal pel -
vis and ureter due to decreased renal function ( Hecht and 
Henry, 2020).
8.2.3 Renal biopsy
Kidney biopsy is an invasive diagnostic technique that in -
volves the collection of tissue material from the kidney in -
tended for histopathological or cytological examinations. 
Kidney biopsy is warranted in animals suspected of protein-
losing nephropathies, acute or chronic renal insufficiency, 
and renal tumors. Biopsy techniques used to collect tissue 
samples from the kidney include blind biopsy, radiological-
guided biopsy, keyhole biopsy, ultrasound-guided biopsy, 
FIG. 7 Left kidney showing loss of internal architecture in a CKD dog.
 FIG. 8 Ventrodorsal radiographic image with bilateral nephroliths.

158 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
laparoscopic-guided biopsy, and biopsy through laparot -
omy. Choice of the kidney biopsy technique depends on the 
animal species, its size, the operator’s experience, available 
equipment, and the clinical condition of the patient referred 
for biopsy (Vaden, 2005).
Ultrasound-guided biopsy is the most commonly used 
technique of kidney biopsy in dogs and cats. It consists of 
the collection of the kidney sample under ultrasound exami-
nation. This technique allows visualization of the kidney, 
evaluation of its size and internal structure, and depth of its 
location in the abdominal cavity, which enables the opera -
tor to precisely perform the kidney biopsy and minimize the 
risk of possible complications ( Rawlings et al., 2003). The 
kidney biopsy in anesthetized dogs may be carried out in 
the sternal position or the right or left lateral recumbency 
depending on the kidney from which the biopsy is to be 
collected. However, in cats the lateral position is preferable 
(Zatellia et al., 2005; Lees et al., 2011).
Contraindications for kidney biopsy include the absence 
of one kidney, pyonephrosis, perirenal abscesses, polycys -
tic kidney ( Fig.  9), hydronephrosis, severe kidney insuf -
ficiency, uncontrolled hypertension, bleeding disorders, 
severe anemia, extensive pyelonephritis, terminal kidney in-
sufficiency, and severe respiratory-circulatory insufficiency 
(Osborne et al., 1974; Haers et al., 2011).
8.2.4 Renal biomarkers
Renal biomarkers play a vital role in the early diagnosis of 
renal diseases and further facilitate early therapeutic inter -
vention in human as well as animal patients ( Kovarikova, 
2015). Urinary biomarkers can detect glomerular impair -
ment (albumin, immunoglobulin-G, C-reactive protein) 
and tubular impairment (acetyl-β-d-glucosaminidase, GGT, 
NGAL, RBP, clusterin, cystatin C, etc.) in early stages of 
renal diseases.
Symmetric dimethyl arginine (SDMA) is a highly sen -
sitive and specific renal biomarker in CKD dogs and cats. 
The levels of SDMA are increased months earlier than the 
rise of serum creatinine values. SDMA levels start elevated 
as early as a 40% reduction in GFR on the contrary serum 
creatinine levels are elevated only after 75% of nephrons 
gets damaged. Moreover, SDMA levels are independent of 
patient muscle mass ( Relford et  al., 2016 ). SDMA levels 
greater than 20  μg/dL ( <14 μg/dL: normal, 14–20  μg/dL: 
risk category) are typically seen in more advanced stages 
of kidney diseases (Courtesy of IDEXX, Westbrook, ME).
8.3 Management of CKD
The therapeutic approach to CKD should be tailored ac -
cording to each individual patient and stage of the disease. 
Frequent monitoring of the patient at regular intervals during 
the therapy allows the clinician to adjust the treatment based 
on the patient’s response. Guidelines recommended by IRIS, 
2017 for the management of CKD dogs and cats are
▪ Discontinue all the potentially nephrotoxic drugs irre -
spective of the severity of the disease.
▪ Identify the underlying causes for renal, prerenal, or 
postrenal disease if any and treatment should be given 
accordingly
▪ Avoid or minimize the renal proteinuria
▪ Restrict dietary intake of phosphorous
▪ Management of hypertension
▪ Consideration of renoprotective therapies includes renal 
diets, symptomatic therapy, correction of hormonal im -
balances, periodical reviews, etc.
Conservative medical management of CKD includes 
therapies other than treatment of active renal diseases (e.g., 
pyelonephritis, urinary obstruction), dialysis, or transplan -
tation. The therapies are designed to
1. Prevent and/or treat complications of decreased kidney 
function
2. Manage comorbid conditions that accompany kidney 
disease, and
3. Slow down loss of kidney function.
In planning conservative medical management, it is im-
portant to recognize and specifically treat active renal dis -
eases in the patient.
8.3.1 Management of GI signs of uremia
Gastrointestinal complications of CKD in dogs and cats 
include inappetence, nausea, vomiting, uremic stomatitis, 
halitosis, gastrointestinal hemorrhage, diarrhea, and hem -
orrhagic colitis. The treatment for these complications of 
CKD is largely symptomatic. Dietary changes, particularly 
protein restriction, may limit or ameliorate many of the gas-
trointestinal signs of uremia.
The management of prominent GI signs like anorexia, 
nausea, and vomiting can be managed by the administra -
tion of antacids, antiemetics, and cytoprotectant drugs. 
FIG.  9 Ultrasonographic image of a canine kidney showing multiple 
cysts.

Urinary system diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 10  159
The most commonly used antacid such as proton pump 
inhibitors (pantoprazole, omeprazole, rabeprazole, etc.) 
and H2 blockers (cimetidine, ranitidine, and famotidine, 
etc.) proved to be effective. Antiemetic agents like meto -
clopramide, ondansetron hydrochloride or dolasetron me -
sylate, and maropitant citrate can be given to arrest the 
emesis. A cryoprotectant drug such as sucralfate helps to 
smoothen the GI mucosa in cases of gastrointestinal ul -
cerations and hemorrhages due to uremia ( Perkovic et al., 
2002).
8.3.2 Management of hyperphosphatemia
The kidneys are the primary route of phosphorus excretion 
from the body. Any reduction in the glomerular filtration 
rate can create an accumulation of phosphorous within 
the body. Retention of excess phosphorus promotes renal 
secondary hyperparathyroidism, mineralization of tissues, 
and further progression of CKD. Hence, therapeutic goals 
should be designed to minimize phosphorus retention and 
hyperphosphatemia in CKD dogs and cats.
In stage I and II CKD patients, serum phosphorous 
levels remain normal because of a compensatory reduc -
tion in phosphorous reabsorption from the remaining 
intact nephrons. This compensatory adaptation is a con -
sequence of the phosphaturic effects of fibroblast growth 
factor 23 (FGF-23) and parathyroid hormones (PTH). 
Hyperphosphatemia stimulates the production of FGF-23 
and PTH levels even though phosphorous levels remain 
within the normal range initially. The development of 
hyperphosphatemia and consequent renal secondary hy -
perparathyroidism and impaired production of calcitriol 
occurs as the disease advances.
The first step in minimizing serum phosphorous is 
through restriction of phosphorus content in the foods. 
Commercial renal diets are manufactured with low phos -
phorus content and are often successful in achieving serum 
phosphorus targets in CKD Stage III. If commercial diets 
are not effective in maintaining serum phosphorous levels 
within the limits then phosphate binders should be incorpo-
rated along with diets. Intestinal phosphate-binding agents 
induce the formation of nonabsorbable salts of phosphorus 
within the lumen of the gastrointestinal tract, thus rendering 
phosphorus contained in the diet poorly absorbable.
The most commonly used intestinal phosphate-binding 
agents in dogs and cats are aluminum hydroxide, oxide, 
or carbonate @ 30–100  mg/kg/day, calcium salts (calcium 
acetate @ 60–90 mg/kg/day and calcium carbonate @ 90–
150 mg/kg/day) and lanthanum carbonate @ 30  mg/kg/day. 
The lanthanum carbonate is shown to be effective and is 
associated with minimal side effects. Therapy usually be -
gins at the lower end of the recommended dose range and is 
adjusted upward as needed every 4–6 weeks until the thera-
peutic target is reached (Elliot et al., 2006).
8.3.3 Metabolic acidosis
Metabolic acidosis occurs in less than 10% of cats with 
stages 2 and 3 CKD but in nearly 50% of cats with overt 
signs of uremia. Alkalinization therapy is indicated in CKD 
dogs and cats when blood pH level and bicarbonate con -
centration fall below the normal range. Shifting to a renal 
diet may improve acidosis by providing a pH-neutral diet. 
When diet alone is insufficient, administration of an alkalin-
izing salt, usually sodium bicarbonate (8–12  mg/kg po, ev-
ery 8–12 h) or potassium citrate (40–60 mg/kg every 8–12 h) 
can be tried. Potassium citrate offers the advantage of using 
a single drug to treat hypokalemia and acidosis. Response 
to alkalinization therapy should be assessed by performing 
blood gas analysis at weekly intervals after initiating ther -
apy and dosage adjusted until normalized.
8.3.4 Hypokalemia and hyperkalemia
Hypokalemia is the most common electrolyte abnormality 
seen in CKD dogs and cats due to inadequate potassium 
intake, increased urinary loss, and enhanced activation of 
the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system as a response to 
dietary salt restriction. Certain antihypertensive drugs like 
amlodipine may promote hypokalemia in cats with CKD.
Cats with hypokalemia should be given potassium sup -
plementation. Oral replacement is the safest and preferred 
route for administering potassium. Parenteral therapy is 
generally reserved for patients requiring emergency rever -
sal of hypokalemia or when they cannot accept oral therapy. 
Potassium gluconate or citrate are good choices for oral 
supplementation. Potassium citrate is initially given at a 
dosage of 40–60 mg/kg/day divided into two or three doses. 
If hypokalemic myopathy is present, it usually resolves 
within 1–5  days after initiating parenteral or oral potas -
sium supplements. Thereafter, potassium dosage should be 
adjusted based on the clinical response of the patient and 
serum potassium levels ( Lulich et  al., 1992; Henik et  al., 
1997).
Hyperkalemia occurs in advanced stages or end-stage 
renal disease in CKD dogs and cats. Emergency manage -
ment of hyperkalemia can be managed by parenteral ad -
ministration of sodium bicarbonate or glucose or insulin 
therapy based on the severity and condition of the patients.
8.3.5 Dehydration
Dehydration is a common complication of CKD and is of -
ten responsible for the deterioration of kidney function and 
promotes acute uremia. Because compensatory polydipsia 
prevents dehydration, ongoing fluid losses (pyrexia, vom -
iting, or diarrhea) or lack of access to drinking water, ex -
treme climatic conditions, and concurrent illnesses restrict 
fluid intake and promote dehydration. CKD cats are highly 
susceptible to chronic dehydration due to inadequate com -
pensatory polydipsia. Fluid administration is the mainstay

160 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
of therapy in dehydrated patients. The goal is to correct and 
prevent dehydration and its clinical effects. Acute correc -
tion of fluid is done by intravenous or subcutaneous admin-
istration depending on the severity of dehydration and the 
specific needs of the patient (Buranakarl et al., 2004).
8.3.6 Anemia
Anemia is most common in the later stages of CKD in dogs 
and cats. It occurs mainly due to insufficient production of 
erythropoietin, however iatrogenic and spontaneous blood 
loss, poor nutrition, iron deficiency, and reduced red blood 
cell lifespan augments the condition. Options for treating 
anemia of CKD include hormone replacement therapy. 
Erythropoietin therapy is generally the most effective ther -
apy, but the optimal therapeutic response depends on the 
underlying causes and severity of the disease.
Erythropoietin products most commonly used in dogs and 
cats include the recombinant human erythropoietin Epogen 
(EPO) and darbepoetin alpha (DPO). Administration of 
EPO has a dose-dependent increase in hematocrit, resulting 
in the correction of anemia and its associated clinical signs 
within approximately 2–8 weeks. Although EPO is usually 
effective in correcting anemia of CKD, initially, production 
of antibodies may be noticed (Cowgill et al., 1998).
Darbepoetin alfa is an erythropoiesis-stimulating agent, 
it has a longer duration of action and is less likely to induce 
anti-erythropoietin antibodies compared to EPO. The dose 
should be adjusted based on the response to therapy and 
periodical estimation of hematocrit values. Maintenance of 
normal hematocrit requires ongoing hormone therapy and 
monitoring. Failure to monitor the hematocrit and adjust the 
dose of DPO can result in severe polycythemia and death, 
particularly during the induction phase. Supplementation of 
iron dextran or iron sucrose is recommended for all patients 
receiving erythropoietin or darbepoetin therapy due to the 
depletion of iron reserves in the body.
8.3.7 Management of hypertension  
and proteinuria
Arterial hypertension is a common complication of CKD in 
dogs and cats and has been linked to renal, ocular, neuro -
logic, and cardiac complications. The diagnosis of arterial 
hypertension must be based on measuring blood pressure. 
ACEIs (e.g., enalapril and benazepril) and calcium channel 
blockers (e.g., amlodipine) are the preferred antihyperten -
sive drugs for dogs and cats with CKD, because they have 
the potential benefit of renoprotective actions. Clinical ex -
perience has shown amlodipine to be an effective antihy -
pertensive agent in dogs and cats with CKD ( Brown et al., 
2007; Plumb, 2008).
Appetizers, a variety of foods to stimulate appetite, 
hand feeding, and tube feedings such as nasogastric tubes 
or percutaneous enteric gastrotomy tubes have to be tried 
to  alleviate malnutrition in renal patients. Cases that are 
 refractory to medical therapy with severe uremia have to be 
managed by peritoneal dialysis (PD) or intermittent hemo -
dialysis (IHD) techniques to prolong the life of the patients. 
Patients with end-stage renal failure can plan for renal 
transplantation therapy.
8.4 Prognosis of CKD
The disease tends to be progressive in the advanced stages 
of CKD. Affected dogs may survive for months to a year 
or two depending on the management of the disease. Some 
cats have progressive diseases similar to dogs, but typi -
cally CKD progresses more slowly in cats. Patients in CKD 
stages III and IV should typically be evaluated every 3- to 
4-month intervals. Patients in CKD stages I and II often re-
quire less frequent monitoring, every 4–6 months approxi -
mately, once stable renal function has been established. 
However, patients with progressive CKD, proteinuria, or 
arterial hypertension should be monitored more frequently. 
Success of the therapy depends upon the early identification 
of the disease, the stage of disease, and effective therapeutic 
management of the disease.
9 Acute kidney injury
Acute kidney injury (AKI) is defined as a sudden decrease 
in renal function, resulting in a lack of excretion of nitrog -
enous waste substances like BUN and creatinine, leading to 
the accumulation of metabolic waste substances above the 
reference range. Sudden damage to nephrons results in the 
compromise of fluid, electrolyte, and acid-base regulatory 
functions of the kidney thereby establishing a state of azote-
mia in the body. The disease is characterized by depression, 
lethargy, weakness, anorexia, vomiting, diarrhea, dehydra -
tion, and change in urine output.
The etiology of AKI in dogs and cats includes toxic, in-
fectious, and ischemic causes that are the most common. 
Postrenal causes were due to obstruction or rupture of the 
urinary tract, obstruction might occur from uroliths, neo -
plasia, trauma, inflammation, fibrosis, blood or mucous, 
and congenital or acquired ureteral stenosis ( Cowgill and 
Francey, 2005).
A systematic diagnostic approach to diagnose AKI in -
cludes a detailed collection of history, a complete clinical 
examination to identify urinary output, dehydration, hypo -
tension, etc. Hematology, serum biochemistry to identify 
uremic changes in blood, microscopic agglutination test for 
leptospirosis, urinalysis to test specific gravity, proteinuria, 
and imaging diagnostic tests helps to confirm the disease.
Therapy involves the selection of appropriate antibiotics 
to treat infectious causes of renal failure; fluid therapy, ant-
acids, and antiemetics are to be given to counteract the ure-
mic effects of AKI. Specific antidotes and neutralizers must 
be given as per the prescribed dose rate in cases of toxic 
or chemical poisonings. Cases with severe azotemia might

Urinary system diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 10  161
require renal replacement therapies or renal transplanta -
tion. The mortality rate varies based on the cause, extent of 
damage, concurrent diseases, and timing of effectiveness of 
therapy, mortality associated with all causes of acute renal 
failure in dogs ranges from 56% to 80%.
