Chapter 11
Diseases of the reproductive system of 
male dogs and cats
1 Diseases of testes and epididymis
1.1 Cryptorchidism
Cryptorchidism is the most common congenital defect of 
testes in which one or both testes fail to descend naturally 
into the scrotal sac ( Memon and Sirinarumitr, 2005 ). The 
condition may be unilateral or bilateral. Testes may be 
retained in the abdominal cavity, inguinal canal, or in an 
ectopic subcutaneous location between the superficial in -
guinal ring and the scrotum ( Evans and Christensen, 1993; 
Peter, 2001). Right-sided cryptorchids are common, with 
inguinal retention being more common ( Kawakami et al., 
1984; Turba and Willer, 1988; Ruble and Hird, 1993; Yates 
et al., 2003). A higher incidence of the condition has been 
reported in dogs (varies from 0.80% to 9.8%) compared to 
cats (1.7%) (Felumlee et al., 2012).
1.1.1 Occurrence
Cryptorchidism is believed to be a hereditary disorder and 
reported to be more prevalent in certain breeds of dogs 
such as toy and miniature Poodles, Yorkshire terriers, 
Chihuahuas, Boxers, Miniature Schnauzers, Pekingese, 
Pomeranian, English bulldogs, and Dachshunds. A higher 
incidence has been recorded in purebred and inbred dogs 
compared to mixed-breed dogs ( Memon and Sirinarumitr, 
2005; Memon, 2007). Offsprings, from cryptorchid parents, 
tend to have a higher incidence ( Gubbels et al., 2009 ). In 
the cat, the heritable nature of this defect is poorly known 
but is suspected as the Persian cats are predisposed to crypt-
orchidism ( Johnston and Kustritz, 2001a ; Griffin, 2006 ). 
Cryptorchidism is believed to be a sex-limited autosomal 
recessive trait (Memon and Sirinarumitr, 2005 ). The exact 
mode of inheritance of cryptorchidism is not known, but 
it is believed to be a multiple-gene effect ( Willis, 1989 ; 
Amann and Veeramachaneni, 2007).
1.1.2 Clinical manifestation
The common clinical signs are the absence of one or both 
testicles, inability to successfully breed (if both testicles are 
undescended) along with increased aggression, unwanted 
territorial behavior, and marking. Some dogs with unilateral 
cryptorchidism may evidence poor fertility.
1.1.3 Diagnosis
A positive diagnosis of the condition can be arrived at by 
physical examination, ultrasonography, and hormonal as -
say. It is usual to make a tentative diagnosis of cryptorchi -
dism if the testes are not palpable within the scrotum by 
8–10 weeks of age in dogs. In cats and dogs, neonatal testes 
are small, soft, and move up and down in the inguinal ca -
nal prior to puberty; therefore, inspection prior to puberty 
may falsely suggest a diagnosis of cryptorchidism (Memon, 
2007; Sojka, 1980). Thus, a definitive diagnosis should be 
made when the pet achieves puberty (7–9  months) when 
the inguinal rings of most dogs are closed and the size of 
the testes is larger (Johnston et al., 2001; Ley et al., 2003).
Abdominally retained testes are not palpable and the 
inguinal lymph nodes and fat may feel like small inguinal 
testes (Schulz et al., 1996 ) which can lead to an incorrect 
diagnosis. Unlike dogs, it may be possible to visually dif -
ferentiate between a castrated cat and a cryptorchid one, by 
the presence of spines on the penis (postpuberty). In cats, 
the penile spines disappear or get atrophied by 6 weeks fol-
lowing complete castration (Johnston and Kustritz, 2001a). 
Adult intact cryptorchid dogs can be differentiated from 
castrated dogs by an enlarged prostate (Olson et al., 1992).
The retained testes can be visualized by careful ultraso-
nographic examination of the abdomen and inguinal area. 
In one study, the sensitivity of ultrasonography was 96.6% 
and 100% for the detection of abdominal testes and inguinal 
testes, respectively (Felumlee et al., 2012).

164 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
Bilateral cryptorchid and castrated male dogs can be dif-
ferentiated by IM administration of either GnRH or hCG 
which leads to an increase in testosterone in cryptorchid 
dogs. Dogs are administered either GnRH (20  mg/kg or 
50 mg/dog) or hCG (100  IU/dog) and blood samples are 
collected for testosterone assay 60  min before, and 60  min 
later for GnRH and 12 and 24 h later for hCG. A substantial 
increase in serum testosterone concentrations in the post -
test blood samples is diagnostic of cryptorchidism (Memon, 
2007; Johnston et  al., 2001 ; Ley et  al., 2003 ). Diagnosis 
of cryptorchidism can be confirmed by finding the retained 
testes using invasive techniques like exploratory laparot -
omy or laparoscopy but the potential complications should 
be considered (Vannozzi et al., 2002; Miller et al., 2004).
Radiography is unrewarding due to the small size and 
nondistinct tissue density of the retained testis ( Ley et al., 
2003). The serum anti‐Müllerian hormone (AMH) concen-
trations in cryptorchid and intact dogs were found to be sig-
nificantly higher than in castrated dogs (Gharagozlou et al., 
2014) and can serve as a useful test, yet still need to be 
standardized.
1.1.4 Complications
Hip dysplasia, patellar dislocation, underdeveloped eyelids, 
abnormally small eyes, defects of the penis and prepuce, 
and umbilical hernia are some congenital disorders associ -
ated with cryptorchidism in dogs ( Pendergrass and Hayes, 
1975). Few toms affected with cryptorchidism may also 
show congenital abnormalities like bilateral medial patellar 
luxation, congenitally shortened tail, kinked tail, tetralogy 
of Fallot, tarsal deformity, microphthalmia, and upper eye -
lid agenesis (Johnston and Kustritz, 2001a).
Cryptorchid pets are predisposed to the development of 
testicular neoplasia (Yates et al., 2003). Sertoli cell tumors 
are commonly associated with cryptorchidism followed by 
seminomas, in canines ( Reif and Brodey, 1965). The sper-
matic cord attached to a retained testis is predisposed to tor-
sion (Johnston et al., 2001 ). Retained testes are incapable 
of normal spermatogenesis because the temperature inside 
the body is too high for spermatogenesis. Retained testes 
are smaller and the diameter of the seminiferous tubules is 
reduced by up to 60% as compared to normal scrotal testes 
(Kawakami et al., 1988a ). A bilateral cryptorchid male is 
usually sterile ( Peter, 2001). However, a unilateral crypt -
orchid animal can produce viable sperm but with reduced 
semen quality and can often impregnate an estrual female 
(Memon, 2007 ). However, sexual activity and libido are 
normal in cryptorchid males as the retained testicles are 
capable of secreting testosterone. This is probably because 
the interstitial or Leydig cells are not affected by body tem-
perature. Affected pets have androgen-dependent disorders 
such as unwanted territorial behavior, aggression, and mal-
odorous urine (Johnston et al., 2001; Badinand et al., 1972; 
Kawakami et al., 1993, 1995; Scott et al., 2002).
1.1.5 Prevention and therapy
Due to their hereditary nature, the use of affected males, 
their parents, and their siblings for breeding should be 
strongly discouraged. Affected dogs should be neutered as 
they can pass their disease to their offspring and are at risk 
of developing testicular cancer and spermatic cord torsion if 
kept intact (Memon, 2007; Johnston et al., 2001).
Bilateral castration or orchiectomy is the treatment of 
choice for cryptorchidism. Several surgical approaches 
have been described for orchiectomy in both dogs and cats; 
however, a ventral midline approach and laparotomy are 
generally used. The surgical approach to finding and re -
moving the cryptorchid testis depends on its location ( Ley 
et  al., 2003). Laparoscopic procedures can be effectively 
used in identifying and removing retained testes in dogs 
and cats (Memon, 2007; Miller et al., 2004). Single or mul-
tiport laparoscopic‐assisted approaches have been used for 
orchiectomy in cryptorchid dogs (Miller et al., 2004; Runge 
et al., 2014). Laparoscopic cryptorchidectomy was consid -
ered a safe and useful approach for dogs with testes retained 
in the abdomen (Lew et al., 2005).
Medical therapies using GnRH or hCG ( Micuda, 
1971; Humke, 1977 ; Loerssen, 1990 ; Ravaszova et  al., 
1995; Feldman and Nelson, 1996 ) or surgical relocation 
of the retained testis in the scrotal sac have been described 
(Kawakami et al., 1988b, 1990, 1991 ) but are not recom -
mended. The authors strongly discourage therapy due to the 
hereditary nature of the disease.
1.2 Orchitis/epididymitis
Orchitis is inflammation of the testis and epididymitis is 
inflammation of the epididymides. The conditions may 
occur separately, jointly (orchi-epididymitis), or with ex -
tension to the vaginal tunic and adhesions to the scrotum 
(peri-orchi-epididymitis) (Lein, 1977). However, clinically 
the term orchitis is generally used to indicate any disease 
of the scrotal contents, including periorchitis, epididymitis, 
and orchitis itself, and is identified as a swollen painful 
testis (Foster, 2012).
1.2.1 Occurrence
Young dogs are commonly affected with orchitis/epididy -
mitis from 11 months to 10 years (Szasz et al., 1994; Kadota 
et  al., 1995; Kowalzik et  al., 1996). Orchitis/epididymitis 
may be caused by bacteria (Brucella canis, Escherichia coli, 
Proteus vulgaris, Pseudomonas mallei, Staphylococcus  
species, Streptococcus  species), Mycoplasma canis , 
Blastomycosis and other fungi, and canine distemper virus 
(Johnston et al., 2001 ; Ley et al., 2003 ). Infectious agents 
may reach up to the reproductive tract as ascending infec -
tion from the prostate or urethra, by bacteremia, viremia, 
and by direct entry through external trauma or puncture

Diseases of the reproductive system of male dogs and cats  Chapter | 11  165
wound. Scrotal cestodiasis and Rhodotorula glutinis (yeast) 
have been found to be associated with orchitis/epididymi -
tis. Trauma and autoimmune disease may also be respon -
sible for the development of orchitis and epididymitis (Ley 
et al., 2003). Rickettsial infections such as ehrlichiosis and 
Rocky Mountain spotted fever (Ober et al., 2004) can be as-
sociated with testicular or epididymal infection. Spermatic 
cord or testicle torsion, scrotal hernia, and scrotal dermati -
tis may be the other reasons for orchitis. In tom, rare cases 
of orchitis have been reported such as after infections with 
Mycobacterium species, Brucella species, feline infectious 
peritonitis virus, and other aerobic bacteria introduced by 
traumatic injury, such as bite wounds. Noninfectious lym -
phocytic orchitis also has been reported (Ley et al., 2003).
Autoimmune orchitis may occur due to trauma or in -
flammation of testicular tissue or idiopathic origin ( Ley 
et  al., 2003). Disruption of the blood testes barrier either 
directly by trauma or from inflammation within the testis 
allows access of the previously immunologically isolated 
spermatozoal antigens to the immune system, infiltration 
of lymphocytes into the testes, and sensitization of T cells. 
Both cell-mediated and humoral defense systems activate 
that results in the destruction of spermatogenic tissue and 
the formation of antisperm antibodies ( Tung and Mahi-
Brown, 1990). Autoimmune orchitis was also found to oc -
cur with lymphocytic thyroiditis in 32% of Beagle dogs in 
one colony ( Fritz et al., 1976 ). Idiopathic autoimmune or -
chitis was reported in two Labrador retrievers who had fo -
cal inflammatory lesions in 20%–40% of the seminiferous 
tubules, and azoospermia ( Edward Allen and Patel, 1982 ; 
Edward Allen and Longstaffe, 1982).
1.2.2 Clinical manifestation
Orchitis/epididymitis may be acute and symptomatic or 
chronic and asymptomatic. The acute form is character -
ized by the sudden onset of painful swelling of the scrotal 
contents (Fig. 1). The possible signs associated with acute 
orchitis/epididymitis may be pyrexia, lethargy, hind limb 
lameness, scrotal edema, and purulent preputial discharge 
(Lein, 1977; Ellington et al., 1993 ; Dahlbom et al., 1997 ). 
Male dogs with chronic orchitis/epididymitis have clinical 
complaints of nonpainful enlargement of scrotal contents 
and sometimes atrophy of the unaffected testis (Lein, 1977).
1.2.3 Diagnosis
An initial diagnosis of orchitis/epididymitis is usually done 
by visual inspection and palpation of the enlarged testes. 
In acute cases of orchitis/epididymitis, the affected testes 
are painful, enlarged, and firm on palpation (if palpable) 
in both male dogs and cats. Dogs with acute orchitis/epi -
didymitis may resist handling the scrotal contents because 
of pain. Other diagnostic tools, such as ultrasonography of 
the scrotum, testes, and epididymides; semen collection 
for evaluation and culture; fine needle aspiration (FNA) of 
the affected testes or epididymides; and testing for canine 
brucellosis are useful in ruling out the differentials like tes-
ticular torsion, incarcerated scrotal herniation, hydrocele, 
hematoma, abscessation, testicular neoplasia and sperm 
granuloma (Johnston et al., 2001; Ley et al., 2003).
The epididymides are enlarged and doughy. Fever may 
be present very early in the hematogenous phase of the in -
fection. When the condition becomes chronic, the testis un-
dergoes degeneration, fibrosis, and atrophy. The testes may 
be soft (atrophic) or very firm and irregular (fibrotic). Due 
to fibrosis, the epididymides are usually “woody” on palpa-
tion. The formation of adhesions between the scrotum and 
testes may prevent free movement of the testes within the 
scrotum (Lein, 1977).
Ultrasonographic findings of orchitis do not show a 
characteristic pattern of echogenicity, but a patchy hy -
poechoic pattern is an indication of testicular inflammation 
(Pugh and Konde, 1991 ). In epididymitis, the ultrasono -
graphic findings showed that the epididymides were irregu-
lar in contour and may contain either hypoechoic areas and 
flocculent material (suppurative disease), or both hypo- and 
hyperechoic areas, with or without mineralization (granulo-
matous disease) (Ellington et al., 1993).
Semen can be collected from male dogs for evalua -
tion and submission for cytology and culture. Many dogs 
with orchitis or epididymitis experience pain and will not 
ejaculate. If the dog can ejaculate, semen samples can be 
FIG. 1 Orchitis in a male dog showing enlarged scrotum. (Photo cour-
tesy Dr. Anil Langer, Subject Matter Specialist, Distt Samba Jammu, and 
Kashmir.)

166 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
submitted for aerobic, anaerobic, and mycoplasma cultures. 
The growth of more than 10,000 organisms per milliliter of 
a single organism is a significant indication of the disease 
(Johnston et al., 2001; Ley et al., 2003).
Fine needle aspiration (FNA) of the affected testes or 
epididymides provides a sample for cytological examina -
tion and aerobic, anaerobic, and mycoplasma cultures. 
Large numbers of polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs) 
are visualized in cases of suppurative orchitis/epididymi -
tis. Minimal or no exfoliative inflammatory response is 
observed in cases of granulomatous orchitis/epididymitis 
(Dahlbom et al., 1997). Dogs with acute orchitis or epididy-
mitis can tolerate FNA without sedation.
Orchitis, epididymitis, scrotal dermatitis, oligozoosper -
mia, and infertility all may be observed in the Brucella 
canis-affected dogs. Therefore, it is imperative to examine 
all the dogs for canine brucellosis, presented with scrotal 
enlargement, regardless of age or status as a breeding ani -
mal (Ley et al., 2003).
1.2.4 Therapy
Complete resolution or cure of orchitis or epididymitis is rare; 
therefore, the recommended treatment is the removal of af-
fected testes or orchiotomy (Johnston et al., 2001; Ley et al., 
2003). Antimicrobial therapy alone is rarely effective in the 
case of orchitis in dogs (Johnston et al., 2001; Ley et al., 2003); 
however, it should not be overlooked as a part of the treatment 
regimen. Dogs with bilateral orchitis/epididymitis should be 
castrated. In case of unilateral orchitis/epididymitis also, bilat-
eral castration is recommended and both the testis and epididy-
mis should be removed soon after the diagnosis; otherwise, 
atrophy of the contralateral testis may occur due to inflamma-
tion and increased intrascrotal temperature. However, in valu-
able stud dogs intended for breeding, unilateral orchiectomy 
sparing the nonaffected testis may be performed. Presurgical 
antibiotic therapy is useful to prevent the postsurgical com-
plication like the formation of a scirrhous cord, and a painful 
swelling of the remaining vasa deferens. Postsurgical antibiot-
ics and other supportive therapy are recommended (Johnston 
et al., 2001; Ley et al., 2003). Prognosis is better if neither atro-
phy nor fibrosis is evident by careful palpation and ultrasono-
graphic evaluation of the remaining testis.
1.3 Brucellosis
Canine brucellosis is caused by B. canis, a gram-negative, 
nonmotile, facultative intracellular coccobacillus bacteria 
(Galińska and Zagórski, 2013; von Bargen et al., 2012) that 
affects the entire reproductive system of male dogs. Cats 
can be considered an accidental host for brucellosis and 
usually becomes infected after contact with maintenance 
hosts such as infected cows (Garoussi et al., 2018). Cats can 
acquire the infection where B. abortus is endemic in cattle 
(Hariharan and Hariharan, 2017).
1.3.1 Occurrence
B. canis infection has worldwide distribution (Hensel et al., 
2018) except in Antarctica ( Gardner and Reichel, 1997 ). 
Outbreak reports of B. canis have progressively increased 
around the world in recent years ( Tymczak et  al., 2022). 
Incidence has been reported higher in stray dogs in compar-
ison with owned dogs ( Lovejoy et al., 1976 ; Brown et al., 
1976) probably due to the uncontrolled contact among stray 
dogs. There is no evidence of breed predisposition in dogs 
(Hollett, 2006; Santos et al., 2021). Anti-B. canis antibodies 
have been detected in domestic and wild canids (Carmichael 
and Greene, 1990; Oliveira-Filho et al., 2012) and domestic 
and wild felines (Oliveira-Filho et al., 2012; Larsson et al., 
1984; Almeida et  al., 2013 ). Some previous reports con -
sider felines to be resistant to brucellosis ( Carmichael and 
Greene, 1990). In one study, Brucella infection in cats was 
found as transiently mild and temporary infection mainly in 
male and stray cats aged 1–2 years (Garoussi et al., 2018).
Infected animals shed the organisms primarily through 
semen and urine, and to a lesser extent, through saliva and 
nasal secretions ( Johnson and Walker, 1992 ; Serikawa 
et  al., 1984; Carmichael and Joubert, 1988 ). Oral, nasal, 
conjunctival, and genital mucosa serve as common routes 
for B. canis  infection ( Santos et  al., 2021 ). The infection 
is primarily transmitted through ingestion or licking of 
contaminated materials or fomites and respiratory inhala -
tion. Sexual or venereal transmission can occur between in-
fected male and female dogs ( Ley et al., 2003 ). Therefore, 
the infection spreads rapidly among closely confined dogs. 
Infected dogs shed B. canis in the semen, particularly dur -
ing the first 8  weeks after infection; however, dogs may 
continue to shed the organism intermittently in the semen 
for years ( Hollett, 2006 ; Carmichael and Greene, 1990 ). 
Blood transfusions can be a source of infection of B. canis, 
as the organisms develop intermittent but persistent bac -
teremia (Hollett, 2006; Carmichael and Greene, 1990 ). B. 
canis have also been isolated from blood-sucking fleas and 
ticks; however, transmission via these parasites is yet to be 
confirmed (Peres et al., 1981). Once infected the dogs serve 
as a reservoir and act as a continuous source of infection 
(Hollett, 2006; Keid et al., 2017 ). Transmission of brucel -
losis from dogs to humans is quite rare and a slight but real 
zoonotic potential exists (Johnston et al., 2001).
1.3.2 Clinical manifestation
In males, the classical clinical signs of B. canis infection 
include epididymitis, orchitis, prostatitis, scrotal dermatitis, 
loss of libido, pain on palpation of the lower abdomen, oli -
gozoospermia, sperm abnormalities, and infertility (Johnston 
et al., 2001; Carmichael and Kenney, 1968; Olsen and Palmer, 
2014). Epididymitis has been reported to be the more com -
mon primary lesion than orchitis ( Carmichael and Kenney, 
1968). In chronic infections, testicular  atrophy  accompanying

Diseases of the reproductive system of male dogs and cats  Chapter | 11  167
teratozoospermia, sperm agglutination due to the formation 
of antisperm antibodies, and eventually spermatogenic arrest 
may be observed (Johnson and Walker, 1992; Carmichael and 
Kenney, 1968). Furthermore, unspecific signs such as uveitis, 
glomerulonephritis, osteomyelitis, disco-spondylitis, menin-
gitis, and pyogranulomatous dermatitis have been reported to 
occur in dogs infected with B. canis, probably secondary to 
bacteremia (Ley et al., 2003; Hofer et al., 2012; Kerwin et al., 
1992). Small testicular abscesses and prostate enlargement 
due to prostatitis with pelvic compression can be visualized 
by ultrasonography (Makloski, 2011).
Infected dogs often develop no clinical signs at all other 
than enlarged lymph nodes, especially the submandibular 
and retropharyngeal. Intermittent bacteremia may last for 
years. Fever is not a typical clinical feature in dogs whether 
infected naturally or experimentally. Episodic fever may 
be detected in the affected dogs by careful observation and 
monitoring, but it usually goes unobserved. Infected males 
usually remain unnoticed if they do not have reproductive 
activity (Makloski, 2011; Moore and Kakuk, 1969).
1.3.3 Diagnosis
A precise clinical diagnosis of canine brucellosis is not 
possible; therefore, laboratory tests are essential to make a 
definitive diagnosis. However, the laboratory diagnosis of 
B. canis  infection depends upon the stage of the disease. 
Culture and Isolation of B. canis  may be achieved from 
blood, lymph node aspirates, bone marrow, or infected 
tissues or discharges ( Carmichael and Shin, 1996 ). As B. 
canis infection has zoonotic potential, its culture poses a 
considerable risk for laboratory personnel therefore bio -
safety level 3 conditions are required (Wallach et al., 2004; 
Godoy et al., 1979 ; Sam et al., 2012 ). Blood culture is the 
most accurate test available in the first 8  weeks follow -
ing infection ( Johnson and Walker, 1992 ; Carmichael and 
Shin, 1996). Semen samples should be subjected to culture 
between 3 and 11 weeks after infection. After this period, 
due to intermittent shedding of B. canis in the semen with 
low concentrations, cultures are often negative (Carmichael 
and Greene, 1990 ). The organism should be isolated from 
urine samples mostly between 8 and 30 weeks postinfection 
(Carmichael and Greene, 1990 ; Greene and Carmichael, 
2012). As B. canis is a fastidious organism, therefore one 
negative culture does not rule out the disease.
Direct diagnosis of B. canis  infection can also be 
made by detecting the genomic DNA of the organism in 
biological samples using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) 
(Keid et  al., 2007 ). Whole blood is the sample of choice 
for PCR and should be preferred over serum ( Keid et al., 
2009). Semen and tissue samples may also be used for PCR 
(Greene and Carmichael, 2012 ). However, the absence of 
bacteremia, antimicrobial drug usage, and PCR inhibitors 
(heparin) in blood samples may also influence the PCR re -
sults (Greene and Carmichael, 2012).
Antibodies against B. canis  infection can be found 
2  weeks postinfection and can be detected via serology (Ruble 
and Hird, 1993). Serologic tests are useful diagnostic tools 
as infected dogs remain serologically positive for several 
months even in the absence of bacteremia. The frequently 
used serologic tests for the diagnosis of B. canis infection 
are tube agglutination test (TAT), rapid slide agglutination 
test (RSAT) ( George and Carmichael, 1974 ), rapid slide 
agglutination test with 2-mercaptoethanol (2ME-RSAT) 
(Badakhsh et al., 1982), and agar gel immunodiffusion test 
(AGID) (Myers et al., 1972). RSAT and 2ME-RSAT are the 
commonly used serologic tests for screening for B. canis in-
fection at kennels. As a semiquantitative test TAT is consid-
ered a confirmatory test for RSAT or 2ME-RSAT ( Greene 
and Carmichael, 2012 ; Carmichael and Greene, 1998 ). 
However, none of the serological tests is completely satis -
factory. False-positive results are commonly reported due 
to cross-reaction with other bacteria such as Pseudomonas, 
Bordetella bronchiseptica, Streptococcus, Staphylococcus, 
Salmonella, Yersinia enterocolitica , and Escherichia coli  
(Keid et  al., 2009 ; Wanke, 2004; Bounaadja et  al., 2009 ; 
Nielsen et al., 2007 ). Therefore, the final diagnosis should 
be confirmed by B. canis isolation by culture or PCR diag-
nostics (Keid et al., 2007, 2015).
Several enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) 
protocols have been reported for the diagnosis of B. canis 
infection with varying sensitivity and specificity according 
to the antigen used ( Johnson and Walker, 1992; Mateu-de-
Antonio et  al., 1994 ; Lucero et  al., 2010 ). However, this 
method is more sensitive than agglutination methods and 
AGID (Johnson and Walker, 1992; Wanke, 2004). ELISAs 
can detect antibodies in chronic cases which may be diag -
nosed negative by 2ME-RSAT and AGID ( Wanke et  al., 
2012). Antibodies can be detected by ELISA at 30  days 
postinfection, and the assay may be useful as a confirma -
tory test ( Lucero et  al., 2010 ; Barkha et  al., 2011 ; Ebani 
et al., 2003).
1.3.4 Therapy
The treatment of canine brucellosis with antibiotics is not 
encouraged, because even after antibiotic treatment there 
is uncertainty about the cure of the disease, and the risk 
of transmission of the disease to humans and other dogs 
persists ( Holst et al., 2012 ; Cosford, 2018 ). It is impera -
tive to know that antibiotic therapy does not eliminate 
B. canis ; therefore, the absence of the clinical signs af -
ter antibiotic therapy is not indicative of the absence of 
the infection. Singly housed pets may be castrated and 
administrated antibiotics to decrease bacteremia and sub -
sequent shedding of the organism ( Johnson and Walker, 
1992). The suggested antibiotic regimens include mino -
cycline (25 mg/kg orally once daily for 14 days) in combi -
nation with dihydrostreptomycin (5  mg/kg IM twice daily 
for 7 days) and tetracycline (30  mg/kg PO twice daily for

168 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
21  days) in combination with streptomycin (20  mg/kg 
1 M once daily for 14 days) ( Johnson and Walker, 1992 ; 
Nicoletti, 1991 ).
1.3.5 Prevention and control
Commercially available vaccines are not available for 
the prevention of canine brucellosis ( Santos et al., 2021 ). 
Therefore, control measures that need to be followed are (i) 
screening tests for dogs and kennels suspected of brucel -
losis, (ii) treatment or euthanasia of infected dogs, and (iii) 
elimination of the bacteria from the environment (Makloski, 
2011). Newly acquired dogs must be kept isolated for at 
least 1 month and should only be introduced in the kennel 
after two negative diagnostic test results with an interval of 
1  month. Kennels should be considered disease free only 
after all animals have been tested and found negative for 3 
consecutive months ( Johnson and Walker, 1992 ). Infected 
kennels must adopt stringent disinfection procedures and 
segregate feeding utensils and other materials to prevent the 
spreading of infection ( Makloski, 2011). B. canis does not 
survive for prolonged periods under environmental condi -
tions and can be quickly eliminated by most disinfectants 
including 1% sodium hypochlorite, 70% ethanol, etha -
nol/iodine solutions, glutaraldehyde, formaldehyde, etc. 
(Makloski, 2011 ). Equipment can be decontaminated by 
autoclaving at 120°C for at least 15  min or by dry heat at 
160–170°C for at least 1  h. Even, boiling for 10  min also 
inactivates the Brucella organism (Center for Food Security 
and Public Health, 2012). Dog owners and kennel employ-
ees should be properly educated about the transmission and 
zoonotic risk involved with B. canis  infection and avoid 
contact with infected dogs and secretions, especially during 
parturition or abortion. The development of effective and 
accurate B. canis-specific diagnostic methods and vaccines 
would be extremely helpful to prevent canine brucellosis.
1.4 Testicular neoplasm
Testicular neoplasia has been reported to be common in 
dogs while rare in cats ( Ley et al., 2003 ). Testicular neo -
plasia is the most common reproductive tract tumor and 
the second most commonly occurring tumor after skin 
neoplasia in dogs ( Johnston et al., 2001 ). There are three 
main types of testicular tumors: Sertoli cell tumor (SCT), 
seminoma (SEM), and interstitial (Leydig) cell tumor (ICT) 
(Kennedy et  al., 1998 ; Maclachlan and Kennedy, 2002 ; 
Gazin et al., 2022 ). Most of these tumors show benign be -
havior (Kennedy et al., 1998), the metastasis being reported 
rarely and associated mostly with seminomas ( Kennedy 
et al., 1998; Takiguchi et al., 2001). Testicular tumors may 
be unilateral or bilateral, and multiple cell types may be 
present (Johnston et al., 2001).
SCTs arise from the Sertoli cells/nurse cells of the 
seminiferous tubule. Mostly SCTs are slow-growing and 
noninvasive tumors that are usually firm, nodular, and pale 
yellow to gray. SCTs are either hormonally nonproductive 
or secrete high concentrations of estrogen and inhibin and 
cause the development of clinical signs of feminization. 
SEMs are the neoplasm of spermatogenic cells. These tu -
mors are slow growing, noninvasive, mostly hormonally si-
lent, usually soft on palpation, gray to white, and lobulated. 
ICTs arise from the cells in the interstitial space surround -
ing the seminiferous tubules. ICTs are also slow growing 
and noninvasive. ICTs are usually an incidental finding at 
necropsy and are almost always located in descended testes 
(Ley et al., 2003). They are usually hormonally silent, soft 
on palpation, and brown-orange on the cross section. Other 
tumors, such as fibrosarcoma, hemangiosarcoma, anaplas -
tic carcinoma, gonadoblastoma, embryonic carcinoma, 
sarcoma, lymphoma, and granulosa cell tumor, are rarely 
occurring tumors in the testis ( Johnston et  al., 2001 ; Ley 
et al., 2003).
1.4.1 Occurrence
Higher age and cryptorchidism are the main predispos -
ing factors for the development of canine testicular tu -
mors (Canadas et al., 2016 ; Ortega Pacheco et al., 2006 ). 
Neoplasia can occur in both descended and undescended 
testes; however, the frequency is higher in retained testes 
(Johnston et al., 2001; Ley et al., 2003) (Fig. 2). The mean 
age of dogs diagnosed with testicular tumors was 9–11 years 
(Gazin et al., 2022; Baioni et al., 2017; Grieco et al., 2008; 
Liao et al., 2009 ; Nascimento et al., 2020 ) with a range of 
2–19 years (Johnston et al., 2001). Certain breeds, including 
Shelties, Collie, Boxers, German Shepherds, Poodles, Fox 
Terriers, Afghan Hounds, Norwegian Elkhounds, Shetland 
sheepdogs, and Yorkshire Terriers, are predisposed to testic-
ular tumors (Gazin et al., 2022; Liao et al., 2009; Hohšteter 
et  al., 2014; Manuali et  al., 2020 ). SCT, SEM, and ICTs 
occur with about equal frequency in descended testes ( Ley 
et al., 2003). In retained testes, mostly SCT and SEM occur 
while the occurrence of ICT is very rare (Gazin et al., 2022; 
Liao et al., 2009; Nascimento et al., 2020). The exact etiol-
ogy of tumor formation continues to be poorly understood. 
It has been speculated that in cryptorchid testes, an altera -
tion in thermoregulation predisposes the testis to neoplasia 
(Ley et al., 2003).
1.4.2 Clinical manifestation
Scrotal or testicular enlargement is the usual complaint 
or clinical sign. Clinical signs specific to a paraneoplas -
tic syndrome may be observed in SCT-affected dogs. 
Clinical signs specific to metastasis may be seen in dogs 
with malignant tumors accompanied by distant metastases 
(Johnston et al., 2001). The tumor may be accompanied by 
infertility and dermatoses (acanthosis, seborrhoea) ( Peters 
et al., 2001).

Diseases of the reproductive system of male dogs and cats  Chapter | 11  169
1.4.3 Diagnosis
Sometimes pet owners are not aware of any problem and the 
neoplastic mass is found by veterinarian on routine physical 
examination, or examination for another problem. Palpation or 
ultrasound of the scrotum provides a presumptive diagnosis. 
Painless scrotal or testicular enlargement on physical exami-
nation and age at diagnosis provides a presumptive diagnosis 
of neoplasia instead of orchitis ( Johnston et  al., 2001; Ley 
et al., 2003). Pain develops in cases of rapid growth, bleed-
ing in the tumor, or upon cryptorchism. Azoospermia and/
or oligospermia are frequently present (Peters et  al., 2001). 
The neoplastic testis may or may not be significantly enlarged 
and lobulated. The contralateral testis may be either normal or 
atrophied. Atrophy of the contralateral testis may occur due 
to altered hormone production by the neoplastic tumor or in-
creased intrascrotal temperature or pressure necrosis caused 
by the enlarged testis (Johnston et al., 2001; Ley et al., 2003).
Ultrasonographic visualization of tumors may show 
disrupt internal architecture of the testis with hyper- or hy -
poechoic foci, which may or may not be surrounded by a 
well-defined hyperechoic capsule. However, tumor type 
cannot be differentiated by ultrasound ( Johnston et  al., 
2001). To determine the cause of the mass, either FNA, core 
biopsy, incisional biopsy, or excisional biopsy must be per-
formed (Ley et al., 2003).
The combination of clinical anamnesis, macroscopic 
pattern of the tumor, histological analysis, and immunohis-
tochemical characteristics can establish a correct diagnosis 
(Ciaputa et al., 2012).
1.4.4 Therapy
Bilateral orchiectomy is recommended; however, unilat -
eral orchiectomy may be considered in valuable breeding 
dogs (Johnston et  al., 2001; Ley et  al., 2003). In the case 
of cryptorchid animals, both testes should be removed. The 
prognosis is good after orchiectomy if there is no evidence 
of metastasis. In the case of metastases, the prognosis is 
guarded to grave and either chemotherapy or irradiation 
therapy is instituted after surgery. Further supportive treat -
ment is also needed in dogs that have concurrent male femi-
nizing syndrome with bone marrow suppression until the 
signs resolve but with a guarded prognosis (Ley et al., 2003).
1.5 Testicular torsion/spermatic cord torsion
Testicular torsion is more appropriately termed spermatic 
cord torsion.
1.5.1 Occurrence
The incidence is uncommon in dogs and is quite rare in cats 
(Mattoon and Davidson, 2021 ). The condition may occur 
in all age groups of dogs. No breed predisposition has been 
reported (Johnston et al., 2001).
1.5.2 Clinical manifestation
The common clinical signs reported with spermatic cord 
torsion include acute onset of abdominal pain, abdominal 
distention, acute scrotal/testicular swelling and pain, vom -
iting, lethargy, anorexia, stiff gait or reluctance to move, 
dysuria, hematuria, and pyrexia ( Pearson and Kelly, 1975; 
Koch et  al., 1997 ; Miyabayashi et  al., 1990 ; Heyneman 
et  al., 1996; Naylor and Thompson, 1979 ; Ganesh et  al., 
1994). The condition may be asymptomatic in cases of a 
low degree of spermatic cord torsion. Giuliano reported an 
asymptomatic and incidental finding of testicular torsion in 
a 4- to 5-month-old male cat presented for routine castration 
(Giuliano, 2013). Spermatic cord torsion is most commonly 
reported in conjunction with retained testes, which in some 
cases there is associated neoplasia. Neoplastic testes are 
heavier and more pendulous and may predispose to sper -
matic cord torsion ( Johnston et  al., 2001 ). Nonneoplastic 
testes are enlarged after torsion of the spermatic cord due 
to venous occlusion edema and inflammation ( Naylor and 
Thompson, 1979 ). Ischemic necrosis, intratesticular hem -
orrhage, and epididymal edema can be the  histological 
FIG.  2 Testicular neoplasia in a cryptorchid male dog (the large one: 
undescended right neoplastic testicle, and normal one: left descended tes -
ticle). (Photo courtesy Dr. Ankit Ahuja, Assistant Professor, Department 
of Veterinary Clinical Complex, DGCN College of Veterinary and Animal 
Sciences, Palampur, Himachal Pradesh.)

170 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
 findings of affected nonneoplastic testes ( Pearson and 
Kelly, 1975; Koch et al., 1997; Heyneman et al., 1996).
1.5.3 Diagnosis
A presumptive diagnosis of spermatic cord torsion is made 
based on clinical signs and the presence of concurrent crypt-
orchidism in the dog (Pearson and Kelly, 1975; Naylor and 
Thompson, 1979 ; Ganesh et  al., 1994 ). Ultrasonographic 
examination revealed a uniform decrease in parenchymal 
echogenicity in testes with a torsed spermatic cord (Mattoon 
and Davidson, 2021; Peter and Jakovljevic, 1992). The ab-
sence of blood flow to and from the affected testis may be 
observed using color Doppler ultrasonography ( Mattoon 
and Davidson, 2021 ). However, a definitive diagnosis can 
be achieved by exploratory surgery (Ley et al., 2003).
1.5.4 Therapy
The preferred treatment is surgical removal of the affected 
testis and spermatic cord. In the case of cryptorchidism, a 
heritable defect, bilateral orchidectomy is recommended 
(Johnston et al., 2001). Additional supportive care and treat-
ment may be needed in the perioperative period.
2 Diseases of the prostate
2.1 Benign prostatic hypertrophy/hyperplasia
Benign prostatic hypertrophy/hyperplasia (BPH) is the 
most common age-related disorder which is characterized 
by an increase in epithelial cell size (hypertrophy) and cell 
numbers (hyperplasia) of the prostate gland with the latter 
being more marked ( Johnston and Kustritz, 2001b ; Peter 
and Widmer, 2003).
2.1.1 Occurrence
BPH occurs in almost every intact male dog with a preva -
lence of 80% in ≥6 years and 95% in dogs ≥9 years old 
(Ruetten et  al., 2021 ) and a mean age of 8  years ( Read 
and Bryden, 1995 ). Prostatic volume in dogs with BPH 
was found to be 2–6.5 times higher than that of unaf -
fected dogs of similar body weight. BPH is very rare in 
cats ( Johnston and Kustritz, 2001c ). Age-related increase 
in 5 ά-dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a metabolite of testos -
terone formed from the action of the (inhibitable) enzyme 
5ά-reductase, is primarily responsible for BPH. Higher lev-
els of DHT are believed to stimulate the enlargement of the 
prostate by enhancing growth in the stromal and glandular 
compartments ( Memon, 2007 ). There is an increased es -
trogen/testosterone ratio in BPH-affected dogs. Estrogens 
enhance androgen receptors and act synergistically with 
an overproduction of DHT in potentiating the hyperplastic 
process (Barsanti and Finco, 1986). Due to hormone depen-
dency, BPH occurs spontaneously only in intact dogs or in 
castrated male dogs treated with androgens ( Johnston and 
Kustritz, 2001b).
2.1.2 Clinical manifestation
BPH affects nearly every intact male dog; however, not all 
dogs show clinical signs. Serous to serosanguineous fluid 
dripping from the urethra is the primary sign of BPH (Read 
and Bryden, 1995). Other clinical signs associated with BPH 
may include difficulty in urination, rectal tenesmus, constipa-
tion, hematuria, and hemospermia due to pressure caused by 
enlarging prostate both on the urethra and the rectum (Fig. 3). 
Occasionally, dysuria or stranguria may occur. Usually, sys-
temic signs of illness are not observed, and the affected dogs 
FIG. 3 Indicating how enlarged prostate compresses both urethra and rectum.

Diseases of the reproductive system of male dogs and cats  Chapter | 11  171
remain alert, active, and afebrile ( Memon, 2007; Johnston 
and Kustritz, 2001b; Peter and Widmer, 2003; Smith, 2008).
2.1.3 Diagnosis
Diagnosis of BPH is usually presumptive based on a thor -
ough history, clinical signs, physical examination, exami -
nation of prostatic fluid via semen collection or prostatic 
massage, prostatic imaging (ultrasonography or radiogra -
phy), and response to therapy (Memon, 2007; Smith, 2008). 
The complete blood count is usually normal. Bacterial cul -
tures of seminal fluid and urine are negative unless the in -
fection is superimposed on BPH ( Memon, 2007; Johnston 
and Kustritz, 2001b; Peter and Widmer, 2003).
The size and texture of the prostate can be accessed 
by transrectal palpation using a gloved, lubricated finger. 
A normal prostate can be palpated symmetric, smooth, bi-
lobed, and “walnut-shaped” with a dorsal median raphe. 
The cranial extent of the prostate may be difficult to palpate 
in severe cases of BPH; therefore, it may require simulta -
neous palpation of the prostate with the gloved finger and 
concurrent placing upward pressure on the caudal abdo -
men to move the prostate back within reach (Memon, 2007; 
Johnston and Kustritz, 2001b). Hemospermia is a common 
finding in manually collected semen. A prostatic wash or 
urethral brush technique may be used to collect prostate 
fluid or cells in case semen samples cannot be collected. 
Ultrasonography shows prostatomegaly with homogenous 
parenchyma, with or without a cavitating cystic lesion in 
BPH. Radiographic examination of the abdomen may reveal 
cranial displacement of the bladder and dorsal displacement 
of the colon in case of BPH; however, as a distinct entity 
the prostate with BPH may not be observed (Memon, 2007; 
Johnston and Kustritz, 2001b).
Definitive diagnosis of BPH can only be made by biopsy 
of the gland, either trans or perirectal, or transabdominally. 
Common histopathologic findings in BPH are dilated acini 
surrounded by smooth muscle and fibrous connective tis -
sue and the absence of inflammatory cells or organisms. 
Biopsy is an invasive technique and rarely used; therefore, 
BPH is most often diagnosed by confirmation of prostatic 
enlargement and exclusion of other prostatic gland disor -
ders (e.g., prostatitis, neoplasia) ( Memon, 2007; Johnston 
and Kustritz, 2001b; Peter and Widmer, 2003).
2.1.4 Therapy
Generally, dogs with BPH are treated only when they show 
clinical symptoms. The recommended treatment is castra -
tion for most dogs suffering from BPH. The prognosis for 
recovery is good and prostate involution starts soon after 
castration and the volume reduces by 50% within 3 weeks 
and by 70%–75% within 9 weeks. Serum DTH concentra -
tions also decrease and urethral bleeding ceases ( Memon, 
2007; Johnston and Kustritz, 2001b).
For valuable breeding dogs, treatments of BPH us -
ing various pharmacological agents have been suggested. 
Estrogenic compounds such as diethylstilbestrol and es -
tradiol cypionate have been used to treat BPH. However, 
these compounds are not recommended due to their poten -
tial side effects including thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, 
and fatal aplastic anemia ( Memon, 2007 ; Johnston and 
Kustritz, 2001b). Synthetic progestins like oral megestrol 
acetate, injectable medroxyprogesterone acetate, and im -
plant chlormadinone acetate have also been used to treat 
BPH ( Bamberg-Thalen and Linde-forsberg, 1993 ). These 
compounds also have complications and may exert negative 
feedback on the pituitary, decreasing gonadotropin release 
and serum testosterone concentration, therefore, are not rec-
ommended for the treatment of dogs with BPH ( Memon, 
2007; Johnston and Kustritz, 2001b ). Antiandrogen like 
flutamide has been described for the treatment of BPH in 
research dogs. Flutamide was reported as safe, effective, 
and well-tolerated in dogs; however, it is not approved for 
use in veterinary medicine in many countries ( Romagnoli, 
2006). Other compound like Win 49596, an androgen re -
ceptor antagonist, and FR145687, a steroid 5a-reductase 
inhibitor, also have been described to be used for reduc -
ing prostatic size in research dogs; however, these are not 
commercially available (Nakayama et al., 1997 ; Juniewicz 
et al., 1990).
Finasteride, a synthetic steroid 5 ά-reductase inhibitor 
can be used to reduce prostatic size in BPH-affected dogs 
without adversely affecting semen quality or serum testos -
terone concentration ( Sirinarumitr et al., 2001 ). However, 
finasteride is not approved for use in dogs in the United 
States (Memon, 2007).
A new development in the treatment of prostate disease 
is the use of GnRH agonists (Romagnoli, 2006; Trigg et al., 
2001). These compounds block steroidogenesis and thus 
can be utilized to control BPH, without side effects. GnRH 
agonist downregulates GnRH receptors at the gonadotropes 
in the pituitary gland and suppresses the function of the 
hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. This results in a de -
crease in the LH and FSH release, and ultimately decreased 
concentrations of gonadal steroid hormones (progesterone, 
testosterone) and their by-products. Deslorelin implants 
(0.5–1.0 mg/kg body weight) were successfully used in 
adult dogs and decreased prostate volume by >50% and 
serum testosterone by around 90% (relative to controls) at 
6 weeks after implantation (Romagnoli, 2006).
2.2 Prostatitis
Prostatitis is an inflammation of the prostate gland and oc -
curs often due to bacterial infection in dogs. Prostatitis can 
occur at any age but commonly occur in older dogs when 
the prostate is compromised by BPH or cysts, while rare or 
nonexistent in castrated dogs due to atrophy of the prostate

172 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
gland (Wallace, 2001). Prostatic infection may progress to 
the development of intraparenchymal abscesses ( Johnston 
and Kustritz, 2001b). Prostatitis is also less common in cats 
than in dogs, probably due to the rare occurrence of other 
predisposing factors, such as BPH and squamous metapla -
sia (Palmieri et al., 2022).
2.2.1 Occurrence
Infection occurs most commonly as ascending from the ure-
thra; however, hematogenous spread or extension from the tes-
tes, epididymis, or peritoneal cavity may occur (Dorfman and 
Barsanti, 1995). Prostatitis is usually caused by Escherichia 
coli or Proteus vulgaris infection. Other common isolates in-
clude Staphylococcus spp., Streptococcus spp., Pseudomonas 
spp., Klebsiella  spp. , Enterobacter spp. , Pasteurella, and 
Haemophilus. Mycoplasma spp. and/or Ureaplasma spp. 
are also possible opportunistic pathogens. Brucella canis 
can also infect the prostate. Fungi like Blastomyces derma-
titidis, Cryptococcus neoformans, and Coccidioides immitis 
may be the cause of infection in the prostate (Memon, 2007; 
Johnston and Kustritz, 2001b; Palmieri et al., 2022).
Most cases of prostatitis in cats begin secondary to 
the invasion of pathogens in the urinary tract ( Bartges and 
Barsanti, 2000). However, bacterial urinary tract infections 
occur very less frequently in cats than in dogs and only 1%–
2% of cats are affected during their lifetime ( Dorsch et al., 
2019). The most common isolate in cats is E. coli (Dorsch 
et al., 2019; Roura et al., 2002).
Except in mild cases, it is usually difficult to collect an 
ejaculate. The culture of the third fraction of the ejaculate 
or urine obtained by cystocentesis is indicated. Urinalysis 
will reveal pyuria, hematuria, bacteriuria, and perhaps an 
increase in squamous epithelial cells. The urine culture will 
usually be positive; gram-negative colony counts >105 mL−1 
are suggestive of infection (Memon, 2007).
2.2.2 Clinical manifestation
Clinical signs of prostatitis vary with the progression of the 
disease. The condition may be acute or chronic. Dogs with 
acute prostatitis may have a fever, anorexia, depression, 
straining to urinate or defecate, caudal abdominal pain, he -
maturia, pain on rectal palpation, and sporadically edema of 
the scrotum, prepuce, and hindlimb (Dorfman and Barsanti, 
1995). Dogs with chronic prostatitis may be asymptom -
atic or may have hematuria, lethargy, anorexia, straining 
to defecate, poor semen quality, infertility, decreased li -
bido, intermittent urethral discharge varying in character 
from clear to bloody or purulent ( Johnston and Kustritz, 
2001b; Palmieri et  al., 2022 ). In case prostatic abscesses 
become very large, the dog may have tenesmus or dysuria. 
Generalized peritonitis may develop due to the rupture of 
an abscess that results in lethargy, fever, pain, and vomiting 
(Peter and Widmer, 2003).
2.2.3 Diagnosis
Diagnosis of prostatitis is based on history, physical ex -
amination, transrectal examination, ultrasonography, radi -
ography, hematology, urinalysis, prostatic fluid analysis, 
and bacterial cultures ( Smith, 2008 ). In acute cases, the 
prostate is often very painful on palpation and is typi -
cally normal to slightly enlarged, while in chronically af -
fected dogs the prostate is often normally contoured with 
no pain (Smith, 2008). On ultrasonography of the infected 
prostate, focal, or diffuse hypoechoic changes, giving the 
parenchyma a mottled or “moth-eaten” appearance are 
visualized; occasionally, diffuse the slightly hyperechoic 
appearance of the prostate may be observed in chronic 
prostatitis. Prostatomegaly or rarely mineralization (miner-
alization is more common in chronic prostatitis than acute 
cases) within the prostate may be observed with abdominal 
radiographic examination ( Johnston and Kustritz, 2001b ). 
A neutrophilia with a left shift is a usual finding in dogs 
with acute prostatitis; however, the hemogram may be nor-
mal in chronic cases. Hematuria, pyuria, and bacteriuria are 
evident in urinalysis in dogs with either acute or chronic 
prostatitis ( Johnston and Kustritz, 2001b ). Prostatic fluid 
(collected either via ejaculation or prostatic wash) analysis 
will reveal numerous neutrophils with evidence of engulfed 
bacteria. In chronic prostatitis, the inflammatory compo -
nent may be reduced. Evaluation of prostatic fluid collected 
either via ejaculation or prostatic wash will show evidence 
of suppurative inflammation. The results of prostatic fluid 
cytology and culture generally correlate well with histology 
in clinical cases of prostatitis. However, tissue culture has 
been found more accurate in detecting prostatic infection 
(Smith, 2008).
2.2.4 Therapy
Prolonged antibiotic therapy is suggested for bacterial pros-
tatitis. The prostate is difficult to penetrate for many anti -
biotics because of pH differences in the blood versus the 
prostatic fluid, and lipid solubility and protein binding char-
acteristics of antibiotics. Antibiotics like chloramphenicol, 
erythromycin, trimethoprim, and fluoroquinolones, cipro -
floxacin, and enrofloxacin are lipid soluble antibiotics and 
should be chosen by culture and sensitivity of prostatic fluid 
and continued for 4–6 weeks (Memon, 2007; Johnston and 
Kustritz, 2001b; Smith, 2008). Follow-up evaluation of urine 
and prostatic fluid cultures is important prior to discontinu-
ance of therapy after 30 days to assure resolution of infec -
tion (Smith, 2008). If BPH is also present, castration along 
with medical management of prostatitis is recommended as 
the infection is more quickly controlled in castrated versus 
intact males (Memon, 2007; Johnston and Kustritz, 2001b). 
Initiating the antibiotics 5–7  days prior to castration will 
reduce the incidence of scirrhous cord. In valuable breeding 
dogs with prostatitis and concurrent BPH, castration may be

Diseases of the reproductive system of male dogs and cats  Chapter | 11  173
avoided and finasteride in addition to antibiotics should be 
given (Sirinarumitr et al., 2001). Prostatic abscesses can be 
life threatening and can result in septicemia, endotoxemia, 
and localized peritonitis. It should be considered a medical 
and surgical emergency, and requires rapid medical stabili-
zation by treating septicemia, shock, and surgical drainage 
(Wallace, 2001).
2.3 Prostatic cysts
Prostatic cysts are cavitating lesions with a distinct wall, 
containing clear to turbid fluid. They may be either within 
(retention/intraprostatic/true) or outside (para-prostatic) the 
prostatic parenchyma, classified as either true or retention 
cysts (intra-prostatic) and para-prostatic cysts ( Johnston 
and Kustritz, 2001b; Peter and Widmer, 2003).
Prostatic cysts (cystic prostatic disorder), commonly 
occur in older, large-breed dogs ( Johnston and Kustritz, 
2001b; Peter and Widmer, 2003 ). In cats, there are scarce 
reports of prostatic cysts, only a single case of the para-
prostatic cysts was reported in a 3-year-old neutered male 
domestic, short-haired cat with a history of pollakiuria 
(Palmieri et al., 2022). The origin of these cysts is obscure. 
Intra-prostatic cysts are hypothesized to be developed 
from the dilation of prostatic acini secondary to squamous 
metaplasia induced by endogenous or exogenous estrogen 
compounds. While, for para-prostatic, it is supposed that 
embryologic remnants of the female reproductive tract 
(Mullerian duct system or uterus masculinus) found in 
males become fluid-filled ( Johnston and Kustritz, 2001b ; 
Peter and Widmer, 2003 ). Intra-prostatic cysts often oc -
cur in association with BPH or other prostatic pathologies. 
Para-prostatic cysts are usually located near the prostate. 
These cysts are generally attached to the prostate via a stalk 
of tissue or adhesions. The para-prostatic cysts are often 
very large and can be palpated transabdominally ( Johnston 
and Kustritz, 2001b; Smith, 2008).
The clinical signs in prostatic cysts are like those ob -
served with other types of prostatic enlargements and gen -
erally become apparent only when the cyst reaches a size 
sufficient to cause pressure on adjacent organs. Associated 
symptoms may be tenderness, lethargy, dysuria, hematuria 
secondary to cyst hemorrhage, and straining during defe -
cation (due to compression of the rectum by a large cyst). 
Large cysts may result in abdominal distension ( Memon, 
2007; Johnston and Kustritz, 2001b).
Prostatic cysts are typically diagnosed by ultrasono -
graphic examination of the prostate and can be visualized 
as anechoic lesions. Prostatomegaly is visible on abdomi -
nal radiographs. Small cystic structures may not alter the 
prostate contour and are difficult to be diagnosed with tran-
srectal palpation. Very large para-prostatic cysts may be 
palpable on abdominal palpation but should be confirmed 
with ultrasonography. Prostatic cysts must be differentiated 
from the bladder and prostatic abscesses ( Memon, 2007 ; 
Johnston and Kustritz, 2001b ; Peter and Widmer, 2003 ; 
Smith, 2008).
Medical therapy for prostatic cysts has not been re -
ported. Surgical debridement, omentalization, marsupi -
alization, and placement of surgical drains have been the 
traditional therapies (Johnston and Kustritz, 2001b; Smith, 
2008). These therapies are often effective with some com -
plications. Ultrasound-guided drainage of cysts is also an 
acceptable method of treatment with the advantages of 
lower morbidity, lower costs, and improved outcome ver -
sus surgery (Boland et al., 2003 ). Castration or finasteride 
therapy to reduce prostate size is recommended before or 
concurrently with these other procedures ( Johnston and 
Kustritz, 2001b).
2.4 Prostatic neoplasia
Prostatic neoplasia is rare in dogs and approximately  
5%–7% of dogs with prostatic disease suffer from prostatic 
neoplasia. In cats, although prostatic disorders are extremely 
rare, prostatic carcinoma is the most reported prostatic le -
sion according to the literature available ( Palmieri et  al., 
2022). The most common neoplasm of the canine prostate 
is adenocarcinoma. However, other tumors like transitional 
cell carcinoma, leiomyosarcoma, and hemangiosarcoma 
have also been reported (Memon, 2007).
Prostatic adenocarcinoma commonly occurs in older 
intact and castrated dogs. Increased risk of carcinoma in 
castrated dogs has been reported (Teske et al., 2002; Bryan 
et  al., 2007 ). However, some believe, carcinoma of the 
prostate occurs with the same prevalence in sexually in -
tact and neutered dogs ( Shidaifat et al., 2007; Schrank and 
Romagnoli, 2020 ). Breed predisposition to prostatic ad -
enocarcinoma has not been reported, but generally, there is 
increased prevalence among medium- to large-sized dogs. 
Neoplastic changes in the prostate do not predispose dogs 
to other prostatic diseases ( Johnston and Kustritz, 2001b ). 
Prostatic carcinoma is androgen independent. It metasta -
sizes rapidly in ∼70%–80% of cases and the metastasis has 
been reported to regional lymph nodes, pelvic musculature, 
vertebral bodies, lung, liver, urethra and urinary bladder, co-
lon and rectum, spleen, heart, kidney, distant lymph nodes, 
and adrenal glands (Palmieri et al., 2022; Sun et al., 2017).
In most dogs, clinical signs are not apparent until late 
in the course of the disease, after the pressure is caused by 
increased prostate size and metastases. The most common 
presenting clinical signs are like other prostatic diseases 
that include prostatomegaly, painful abdominal palpa -
tion, stranguria, dysuria, hematuria, pyuria, constipation, 
tenesmus, anorexia, weight loss, pain and paresis of the 
hind limb (excluding those related to potential metasta -
ses) (Johnston and Kustritz, 2001b ; Palmieri et al., 2022 ). 
Metastasis to regional lymph nodes and pelvic bones is

174 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
commonly reflected in weight loss, emaciation, lumbar 
pain, and neurological deficits in the pelvic limbs ( Peter 
and Widmer, 2003; Smith, 2008).
On transrectal palpation, the gland is typically en -
larged and irregular which may be painful ( Memon, 2007; 
Smith, 2008). If a prostate is palpable on a transrectal exam 
in a castrated male, one should be suspicious of prostatic 
neoplasia ( Smith, 2008 ). Prostatomegaly, prostatic min -
eralization, regional lymphadenopathy, and evidence of 
metastasis to the lungs and skeleton may be visible on 
abdominal radiographs. Ultrasonographically, focal to dif -
fuse hyperechoic areas are seen in the neoplastic prostatic 
parenchyma. Prostatic contour is generally irregular and/or 
discontinuous (Johnston and Kustritz, 2001b; Smith, 2008). 
Leukocytosis and neutrophilia with a left shift have been 
reported with prostate adenocarcinoma. The most com -
mon serum chemistry profile changes in affected dogs in -
clude elevated alkaline phosphatase and hypoalbuminemia 
(Johnston and Kustritz, 2001b ; Peter and Widmer, 2003 ). 
Prostatic fluid may contain neoplastic prostatic cells, but for 
confirmatory diagnosis FNA or histopathologic examina -
tion of biopsy specimens is often necessary ( Johnston and 
Kustritz, 2001b; Peter and Widmer, 2003).
The prognosis for dogs with prostatic adenocarcinoma 
is grave, with a short survival life of 1–2 months after diag-
nosis (Memon, 2007). Prostatic tumors are often diagnosed 
after the development of clinical signs, and by this time, 
local or regional metastasis has already occurred ( Smith, 
2008). Euthanasia is often recommended after the diagnosis 
of prostatic neoplasia ( Memon, 2007 ; Peter and Widmer, 
2003). Treatment options for prostatic adenocarcinoma are 
limited. Surgical resection (prostatectomy) does not seem to 
be a good option for dogs, because it results in permanent 
urinary incontinence and high rates of morbidity and fail -
ure. Radiation therapy may improve the survival time, but 
local side effects such as colitis, urethritis, and cystitis make 
this option less acceptable. Chemotherapy may be a good 
option, but current protocols have limited success. In case 
of urethral obstruction, a cystostomy tube can be fixed to 
improve the life quality of the dog that is yet to debilitate by 
the disease ( Memon, 2007; Johnston and Kustritz, 2001b ; 
Peter and Widmer, 2003).
3 Diseases of penis and prepuce
3.1 Balanoposthitis
Balanoposthitis is inflammation of the glans penis (balani -
tis) and inflammation of the preputial mucosa (posthitis). 
The disease is common in dogs and rare in cats ( Johnston 
and Kustritz, 2001d,e ; Reeves and Thomas, 2003 ). Both 
prepuberal dogs and adult dogs are affected. No breed 
predisposition has been reported ( Johnston et  al., 2001 ). 
Etiological factors include allergies, trauma, foreign 
 objects,  micro-organism infection, neoplasia, urinary tract 
stones, and phimosis (Johnston and Kustritz, 2001d; Reeves 
and Thomas, 2003 ). The micro-organisms isolated from 
balanoposthitis generally are normal inhabitants of the pre-
puce. The most commonly isolated bacteria is E. coli; other 
bacteria include Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Streptococcus 
pyogenes, Staphylococcus aureus,  and Klebsiella sp. 
Mycoplasmas (more commonly) and ureaplasmas have 
been cultured from the prepuce of balanoposthitis-affected 
dogs. Canine herpesvirus (CHV) and calicivirus (rarely) 
(Johnston et  al., 2001 ; Reeves and Thomas, 2003 ) have 
been reported to be the viral causes of balanoposthitis in 
dogs. The most common sign of balanoposthitis is yellow-
green preputial discharge, varying from purulent to sangui-
nopurulent. The discharge may vary in volume and degree 
of purulence and may have a fetid odor (Nelson and Couto, 
2013). The penile skin and preputial mucosa may be nor -
mal, erythematous, or ulcerative; scanty to copious purulent 
material overlying the mucosa can be visible.
In chronic conditions, lymphoid follicles may be grossly 
visible. In viral balanoposthitis, vesicular or lymphoid nod-
ular lesions may be present ( Reeves and Thomas, 2003 ). 
Swelling of the prepuce and pain is rarely present except in 
cases of trauma or foreign objects. Diagnosis of the disease 
is usually done by visual or physical examination of the pe-
nis and prepuce. Sedation or anesthesia may be necessary 
for the complete extrusion of the penis. Bacterial and my -
coplasma cultures may be performed, but as most of them 
are normal inhabitants of the prepuce, the results may not be 
meaningful. Serologic testing or virus isolation can be per -
formed for the diagnosis of canine herpes virus ( Johnston 
and Kustritz, 2001d; Reeves and Thomas, 2003). Mild bala-
noposthitis may occur in many sexually mature dogs and 
resolves spontaneously without any treatment. Treatment 
includes correcting any predisposing factors, clipping long 
hair away from the opening of the prepuce, and thorough 
flushing of the preputial cavity with a mild antiseptic or 
sterile saline solution. In bacterial or mycoplasma infection, 
systemic and/or topical antibiotics can be prescribed as indi-
cated by culture and sensitivity tests (Johnston and Kustritz, 
2001d; Reeves and Thomas, 2003). Antihistamines or corti-
costeroids are suggested in balanoposthitis caused by atopic 
dermatitis (Johnston and Kustritz, 2001d).
3.2 Phimosis and paraphimosis
Phimosis is the inability of the male to protrude the penis 
from the prepuce ( Fig. 4 ). The condition has been rarely 
reported in dogs and cats (Johnston and Kustritz, 2001d,e). 
The condition occurs because of stenosis or stricture of 
the preputial opening and may be congenital or acquired 
(Papazoglou and Kazakos, 2002 ; Boothe, 2003 ). Trauma, 
cicatricial constriction after wound, preputial inflamma -
tion, preputial infection, and neoplasia are the common

Diseases of the reproductive system of male dogs and cats  Chapter | 11  175
acquired causes. In long-haired cats, preputial hairs en -
tangle the preputial opening and cause phimosis ( Reeves 
and Thomas, 2003 ). Clinical signs may include dysuria, 
hematuria, inability to copulate, or pain during erection. 
The treatment suggested is a surgical enlargement of the 
preputial orifice.
Paraphimosis is the inability to retract the erect or 
nonerect, protruded penis from the preputial sheath. 
Paraphimosis occurs commonly in dogs and is rare in cats 
(Johnston and Kustritz, 2001d,e). Clinical signs depend on 
the duration of the injury and severity. The penis may be 
normal or edematous, or in prolonged cases, the glans penis 
may be dry or excoriated, and in severe cases, penile gan -
grene may develop. The prescribed treatment is the replace-
ment of the penis after lubrication or surgical enlargement 
of the preputial orifice (Reeves and Thomas, 2003).
3.3 Priapism
A prolonged penile erection without sexual arousal is 
known as priapism or a persistent penile erection that leads 
to discomfort and difficult urination. Priapism is a very rare 
disorder in dogs and cats (Johnston and Kustritz, 2001d,e). 
The severe form may require surgical correction.
3.4 Penile neoplasia
Neoplasia of the penis is rare in dogs and extremely rare in 
cats (Johnston and Kustritz, 2001d,e ). The most common 
neoplasms are transmissible venereal tumors (TVTs) and 
squamous cell carcinomas in dogs ( Johnston and Kustritz, 
2001d; Reeves and Thomas, 2003). TVTs are transmissible 
tumors where neoplastic round cells are transferred from 
one to another host. TVTs are generally pink, nodular le -
sions, which vary in size and number. Large lesions usually 
have a cauliflower appearance (Reeves and Thomas, 2003). 
The lesions are often attached to the junction between the 
inner sheath of the prepuce and penile epithelium ( Foster, 
2012). Diagnosis of TVT can be made by physical examina-
tion, cytologic examination of swabs, imprint examination 
of tumors, and histologic evaluation (Purohit, 2008). TVTs 
are best treated with vincristine (0.025 mg/kg BW, slow I/V 
at 7 days interval, three treatments, or at least one treatment 
beyond resolution of clinical signs). However, spontaneous 
regression may occur within months of diagnosis. TVTs 
are immunogenic tumors; the host’s immune system plays 
a major role in inhibiting the growth and metastasis of the 
tumor (Ahuja et al., 2017 ). Surgical resection is the treat -
ment of choice for squamous cell carcinoma ( Foster, 2012; 
Reeves and Thomas, 2003).
