Chapter 13
Diseases of cardiovascular system of 
dogs and cats
1 Introduction
The arteries, veins, and capillaries that make up the circula-
tory system which are connected by a pump called the heart. 
The blood is substantially isolated from the body’s other ex-
tracellular fluid compartment, the interstitial fluid; which is 
the fluid that nourishes the cells, in all vertebrate species. It is 
a closed circulatory system when blood flows through blood 
vessels and travels unidirectionally from the heart along one 
of two circulatory pathways before returning to the heart. 
Invertebrate animals have open circulatory systems, where 
the circulatory fluid nourishes the internal organs directly 
despite possibly being pushed by a pumping heart.
Heart valves aid in directing blood flow in the right di -
rection. The signals that tell the heart muscle to contract in a 
predictable and ordered way are sent by an electrical system. 
And thousands of blood arteries, from the strong and big 
aorta to the smallest capillaries, act as the body’s transporta-
tion system for blood. Numerous variables, such as disease, 
genetics, and other pressures, can gradually impair heart 
function. Up to a degree, the heart can adjust, but eventually, 
its capacity will deteriorate and heart failure symptoms will 
appear. Let us first examine conditions, congenitally affect-
ing the heart muscle to better understand how this occurs, 
and then move on to conditions affecting the heart’s valves, 
blood arteries, and electrical conduction system (Fig. 1).
2 Congenital heart diseases
Congenital heart disease (CHD) is defined as a defect in the 
structure or function of the cardiocirculatory system that ex-
ists from birth, even if it is hardly identified years later. In 
most cases, a causal reason for cardiac abnormalities can -
not be determined, but they appear to be the outcome of 
an interaction between multiple genetic and environmental 
systems. Because many animals pass away before a heart 
abnormality can be adequately detected, it is challenging 
to estimate the true prevalence of CHD. As a result, there 
are breed variances for specific cardiovascular abnormali -
ties on a national and regional level. Aortic stenosis (or sub-
aortic) is the most prevalent abnormality in canines in some 
countries, followed by tetralogy of fallot (TF), patent ductus 
arteriosus (PDA), pulmonic stenosis (PS), ventricular sep -
tal defects (VSD), dysplasia of the atrioventricular valves 
(DA V), dysplasia of the left cranial vena cava (PCVC), and 
peritoneopericardial diaphragmatic hernia (PPDH).
2.1 Subaortic stenosis
The most frequent congenital heart abnormality found in 
large breeds of dogs is obstruction of the left ventricular out-
flow (LVOT) tract. Although there are valvular and supra -
valvular forms of aortic stenosis, the most prevalent kind in 
dogs is fibromuscular subaortic stenosis, which results in a 
fixed form. A dynamic type of LVOT may be present in some 
canines. Anomalies of the mitral valve complex have been 
seen coexisting with fixed and dynamic obstruction. Aortic 
stenosis in cats is rare; however, valvular and supravalvular 
variants have also been documented. Previous research on 
Newfoundland dogs revealed that SAS is a postnatal devel-
opment rather than a true congenital disease (Fig. 2).
Three different grades of severity have been described:
Grade 1 The interventricular septum below the aortic 
valve had tiny, elevated nodules of thickened 
endocardium as the lesion
Grade 2 Below the aortic valve, lesions created a narrow 
ridge of thickened fibrous endocardium that 
partially surrounded the LVOT
Grade 3 Just below the aortic valve, the LVOT was entirely 
encompassed by a fibrous band, ridge, or collar. 
Although sometimes puppies as young as a few 
weeks old may be afflicted by severe types of 
stenosis, the most severe kinds affect dogs over the 
age of 6 months

200 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
2.1.1 Breed predispositions
Large dog breeds, particularly German shepherds, 
Boxers, Rottweilers, Golden Retrievers, Samoyeds, and 
Newfoundlands (inherited condition), are most prone.
2.1.2 Pathophysiolgy of subaortic stenosis 
(SAS)
2.1.3 Clinical management
In severe situations, balloon catheter dilation may, at least 
temporarily, diminish the obstruction’s severity. Beta-
blockers are frequently used in the medical treatment of 
dogs with severe SAS in an effort to improve the func -
tion of the left ventricle and the ventricular diastolic in -
flow as well as to lessen the degree of LVOT blockage. 
Additionally, beta-blockers have a direct antiarrhythmic 
effect that lowers the risk of syncope and unexpected 
death. When there is a known possibility of hematogenous 
exposure to infectious organisms, prophylactic antibiotic 
therapy to prevent bacterial endocarditis should be taken 
into consideration.
2.2 Pulmonic stenosis (PS)
It may exist alone or in conjunction with other heart ab -
normalities. Dogs have been described as having two 
forms:
a) Type 1 pulmonary valve dysplasia: The commissures 
are united with a central orifice, and the valve leaflets 
appear slightly thickened.
FIG. 1 Anatomy of the cardiac conduction system.
FIG. 2 Stenotic aortic valve.

Diseases of cardiovascular system of dogs and cats  Chapter | 13  201
b) A moderate-to-severe thickening and hypoplasia of the 
valve leaflets as well as occlusion of the orifice by su -
perfluous valve tissue characterize Type 2 pulmonary 
valve dysplasia (Fig. 3).
2.2.1 Breed predispositions
Specially vulnerable breeds include the English Bulldog, 
Mastiff, Fox Terrier, Samoyed, tiny Schnauzer, Cocker 
Spaniel, and West Highland White Terrier.
2.2.2 Pathophysiology of PS
A congenital abnormality called pulmonic stenosis is 
marked by stenosis, or narrowing, of the outflow tract, 
which allows blood to pass from the heart to the lungs. This 
is most frequently brought on by a malformed valve with 
some fusion of the pulmonic valve leaflets. The pressure 
gradient across the valve determines the degree of pulmonic 
stenosis. A pressure gradient between 30 and 50 mmHg, be-
tween 50 and 80 mmHg, and above 80 mmHg, respectively, 
is indicative of mild, moderate, and severe illness. A normal 
life is possible for dogs with mild pulmonic stenosis. Dogs 
with severe pulmonic stenosis, however, exhibit clinical 
symptoms such as an inability to tolerate strenuous activ -
ity, dizziness, right-sided congestive heart failure, irregular 
heart rhythms, and, in rare cases, abrupt death.
2.2.3 Clinical management
For dogs with moderate-to-severe pulmonic stenosis, a mini-
mally invasive operation called a balloon valvuloplasty is the 
treatment of choice. A small incision will be made on your 
dog’s neck or groyne to accomplish the surgery, and a cathe-
ter will then be inserted into the vein and the dog’s heart. The 
stenotic pulmonic valve will then be crossed by the special-
ized balloon catheter, and the balloon will be inflated to split 
apart the valve leaflets and create a bigger opening, facilitat-
ing easier blood flow from the heart to the lungs.
2.3 Dysplasia of the atrioventricular 
valves (DAV)
A wide range of abnormalities, including anomalies in 
valve leaflets, chordae tendineae, and/or papillary muscles, 
have been found in dogs and cats with atrioventricular valve 
malformations. Atrioventricular valve dysplasia can mani -
fest either alone or in conjunction with other abnormalities.
2.3.1 Breed predispositions
Mitral dysplasia is more likely to occur in Great Danes, German 
Shepherds, Bull Terriers, Golden Retrievers, Newfoundlands, 
Dalmatians, Mastiffs, and cats. Cats, Old English sheepdogs, 
German Shepherds, Weimaraners, and Labrador retrievers have 
all been recorded to have tricuspid dysplasia (Figs. 4 and 5).
FIG. 3 Pulmonic stenosis.
FIG. 4 Mitral valve dysplasia.

202 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
2.3.2 Breed predispositions
Any dog breed can develop mitral and tricuspid valve 
abnormalities; however, some are thought to be predis -
posed. Such a predilection shows that these breeds have 
a genetic or heritable origin. Bull Terriers and German 
Shepherds are two breeds that have mitral valve dysfunc -
tion more frequently recognized. The Labrador Retriever 
is by far the breed where tricuspid valve dysfunction is 
diagnosed the most frequently. It has been established 
that this breed has a genetic basis behind it. Cats are 
occasionally diagnosed with A V valve abnormalities as 
well.
2.3.3 Pathophysiology of DVS
When mitral regurgitation is considerable, blood flows 
back into the left atrium, causing the left atrium to become 
overfilled with blood (and the left ventricle). These cham -
bers grow in an effort to hold the additional blood, which 
causes this. When regurgitation is severe, the chambers’ 
capacity to expand hits a limit, and pressure inside them 
starts to rise. When critical pressure is reached, fluid in -
side the left atrium-connected lung vessels starts to flow 
out (pulmonary edema), causing left-sided congestive 
heart failure to manifest clinically (CHF). The typical 
symptoms of left-sided congestive heart failure (CHF) 
are fast and laborious breathing (contrary to popular be -
lief, coughing is not a common clinical sign of congestive 
heart failure in dogs or cats). Advanced disease can cause 
a generalized decrease in blood flow to the body, which 
can lead to tiredness, an inability to exercise, loss of ap -
petite, and/or weight loss.
Similar to mitral valve dysplasia, tricuspid valve dyspla-
sia causes fluid to accumulate in bodily cavities instead of 
the lungs (pulmonary edema), most commonly the belly and 
less frequently the pleural space (chest cavity). Right-sided 
congestive heart failure in dogs often results in a visibly 
enlarged abdomen. This may be uncomfortable, especially 
while lying down, and may make it difficult to breathe, es -
pecially while sleeping or relaxing.
2.3.4 Clinical management
The primary goal of A V valve dysplasia treatment is to 
reverse congestive heart failure symptoms. Diuretics 
(frusemide, spironolactone), angiotensin-converting en -
zyme inhibitors (benazepril, enalapril), and the inodilator 
pimobendan are among the drugs that are frequently pre -
scribed. The kidneys must expel more salt and water as a re-
sult of the diuretic. As a result, the fluid in the lungs known 
as pulmonary edema is removed, which enhances your pet’s 
breathing.
The most effective treatment for right-sided congestive 
heart failure (fluid in the belly or chest cavity) is frequently 
repeated physical removal by your veterinarian (generally 
by using an appropriately sized needle or catheter under se-
dation). A beta blocker is frequently used to treat canines 
that have the above-discussed type of mitral valve dyspla -
sia, which results in a mitral valve that prevents blood from 
leaving the heart. The heart rate-slowing medication beta 
blockers can lessen (and in some cases completely eradi -
cate) the blockage caused by the mitral valve. This can po -
tentially reverse the thickness of the left ventricle if it is 
started early.
2.4 Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)
The ductus arteriosus in the fetus allows pulmonary arte -
rial blood to enter the descending aorta and bypass the un -
developed lungs, where it is oxygenated by the placenta. 
At birth, the rise in oxygen tension causes local prosta -
glandins to be inhibited, which results in the ductus’s 
functional closure, which is followed by anatomic closure 
in the weeks that follow. Blood shunts from the descend -
ing aorta to the pulmonary artery if the ductus fails to seal 
(Fig. 6).
2.4.1 Breed predispositions
Poodles, German shepherds, Collies, Pomeranians, 
Shetland, Maltese, English Springer spaniels, Keeshonds, 
and Yorkshire terrier canines are among the many overrepre-
sented breeds of dogs that are predisposed to PDA in Biches.
FIG. 5 Tricuspid valve dysplasia.

Diseases of cardiovascular system of dogs and cats  Chapter | 13  203
2.4.2 Pathophysiology
The effects of a PDA are mostly influenced by the ductus’s 
diameter and pulmonary vascular resistance. Because the 
aortic pressure is greater than the pulmonary artery pressure 
throughout the whole cardiac cycle, blood will shunt from 
the descending aorta to the pulmonary artery when pulmo -
nary vascular resistance is normal. As a result, the left atrium 
and left ventricle get enhanced venous return and higher 
pulmonary flow. Left ventricular eccentric hypertrophy, left 
atrial dilatation, and mitral insufficiency are all results of 
volume excess on the left side of the heart. Congestive heart 
failure on the left side might result from volume overload. 
Left-to-right shunting declines and  right-to-left shunting 
emerges when pulmonary vascular resistance rises.
2.4.3 Clinical management
In every case of left-to-right shunting, surgical PDA liga -
tion is advised as soon as possible following diagnosis. 
Without ligation, it is anticipated that more than 50% of 
cases will pass away within a year of diagnosis. Some 
dogs, most often those with minor shunts, may live a long 
life. Coil embolization, which involves transcatheter de -
livery of thin metal coils, offers an alternative to surgical 
ductus repair.
2.5 Ventricular septal defects (VSD)
The most prevalent kind of VSD in dogs is membranous/
perimembranous, and the other two types are outflow (in -
fundibular/supracristal), atrioventricular canal inflow, mus-
cle, and (trabecular). VSD may manifest either alone or in 
conjunction with other heart abnormalities (i.e., PS, pul -
monary atresia, truncus arteriosus, and double-outlet right 
ventricle).
2.5.1 Pathophysiology
The size of the defect and the relative resistance in the sys-
temic and pulmonary vascular beds dictate the physiologic 
effects of a VSD. Smaller defects (“restrictive” VSD) cause 
little to no functional disruption because pulmonary blood 
flow is only slightly increased. The quantity of flow to the 
pulmonary and systemic circulation is determined by the 
resistances of the two beds, however, if the defect is big 
(“nonrestrictive” VSD).
Initially, there is an excess of pulmonary vascular resis-
tance due to systemic vascular resistance, favoring left-to-
right shunting. The left ventricular diastolic pressure might 
rise as pulmonary flow increases due to increased venous 
return to the left atrium and left ventricle. When the left-
to-right shunt is significant, left ventricular failure is likely. 
The amount of left-to-right shunting typically decreases 
with time as the pulmonary vascular resistance rises. Blood 
shunting from left to right stops when pulmonary vascular 
resistance equals or exceeds systemic resistance, and right-
to-left shunting then starts.
2.5.2 Breed predispositions
Beagles, English Springer Spaniels, English bulldogs, and 
Keeshonds (whose genetic foundation has been established) 
are prone.
2.5.3 Clinical management
Surgery with cardiopulmonary bypass is required for the de-
finitive treatment of symptomatic or severe lesions, and it 
is rarely carried out. In dogs with significant VSD, pulmo -
nary artery banding can be utilized to induce supravalvular 
pulmonary stenosis and lessen the severity of left-to-right 
shunting. Congestive heart failure may need to be managed 
medically if surgical repair or palliation are not options. 
When there is a known possibility of hematogenous expo -
sure to pathogenic organisms, prophylactic antibiotic ther -
apy should be taken into consideration in patients with VSD.
2.6 Tetralogy of fallot (TF)
The largest ventricular septal defect, an aorta that crosses 
the left and right ventricles, obstruction of the right ventric-
ular outflow tract, and right ventricular hypertrophy are the 
FIG. 6 PDA.

204 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
characteristics of TF, the most prevalent cyanotic congenital 
heart condition. These defects are caused by an improper 
alignment of the embryologic conotruncal septum.
2.6.1 Breed predispositions
Samoyeds, Beagles, Bulldogs, and Keeshonds have a par -
ticular propensity.
2.6.2 Pathophysiology
Desaturated blood is pushed through the ventricular septal 
defect to mingle with blood flowing from the left ventricle 
as a result of the right ventricular outflow tract obstruction 
and increased right ventricular systolic pressure. Because 
chronic hypoxia increases renin production and erythropoi-
etin release, it may cause polycythemia.
2.6.3 Clinical management
The preferred technique of treating TF is definitive cor -
rection; however, because cardiopulmonary bypass is nec -
essary, this procedure is rarely carried out in veterinary 
medicine. Patients who exhibit clinical symptoms of se -
vere hypoxemia may find relief through surgically creating 
a systemic-to-pulmonary shunt. Exercise restriction and 
phlebotomy (to prevent hyperviscosity-related symptoms if 
polycythemia is present) are two medical therapy options. 
Because B-blockers lower right-to-left shunting by regu -
lating heart rate and preventing exercise, they have been 
shown to ameliorate symptoms.
2.7 Eisenmerger’s syndrome (ES)
Aorticopulmonary septal defect, PDA, VSD, and other con-
nections between the systemic and pulmonary circulations 
that cause right-to-left shunting of blood are examples of 
the ES.
2.7.1 Pathophysiology
When there is significant left-to-right shunting, the pul -
monary vasculature is exposed to higher blood flow and 
pressure, which frequently results in pulmonary vascular 
obstructive disease and higher pulmonary vascular resis -
tance. The shunt reverses as the pulmonary vascular re -
sistance approaches or exceeds systemic resistance, and 
cyanosis develops. Due to the right ventricle’s need to expel 
against strong pulmonary vascular resistance, it enlarges. 
Secondary polycythemia results from hypoxemic blood be-
ing infused into the kidneys.
2.7.2 Clinical management
Exercise should be limited, stress should be avoided, and 
occasional phlebotomy should be used to keep the PCV 
between 58% and 65%. In dogs with right-to-left shunting 
PDA, therapy with hydroxyurea has been shown to reduce 
the red blood cell volume and improve clinical symptoms.
2.8 Atrial septal defects (ASD)
Small animals with ASD have rare congenital heart abnor -
malities. They could show up as a single abnormality or as a 
component of a more complex deformity. ASD can be clas-
sified into four categories.
There are four types of atrial septal defects:
1. Ostium secundum, which affects the fossa ovalis.
2. Ostium primum, or partial atrioventricular canal defect, 
which is located in the lowermost part of the interatrial 
septum and linked to endocardial cushion defects.
3. Sinus venosus, which affects the superior part of the in-
teratrial septum.
4. Coronary sinus, which is situated in the posteroinferior 
angle of the atrial septum.
Small ASD typically does not have major hemodynamic 
effects. The shunt flow through an ASD does not produce 
a murmur since the pressures in the two atria are identi -
cal; however, a relative pulmonic stenosis murmur may be 
heard. 
2.9 Atrioventricular canal defects (AVC)
Complete A VC, also known as a complete endocardial 
cushion defect, comprises an anterior mitral valve leaflet 
and a septal leaflet of the tricuspid valve, as well as a VSD 
in the entrance section of the ventricular septum. Partial 
A VC or ostium primum ASD are the terms used to describe 
the defect when the ventricular septum is intact. Cats are 
more frequently than dogs reported to have A VC abnormali-
ties. All four chambers of patients with complete A VC are in 
communication with one another as a result of atrioventric-
ular septal abnormalities, insufficiency, or atrioventricular 
valves. In most cases, pulmonary hypertension and conges-
tive heart failure appear early.
3 Acquired heart diseases
In clinical practice, overweight dogs and canines with heart 
conditions are regularly seen. Poor nutrition, insufficient 
exercise, and management carelessness encourage obesity, 
which may cause cardiac illnesses. Cardiovascular disease 
is known to be brought on by a number of nutritional de -
ficiencies, including dietary protein, fat, vitamins, miner -
als, and trace elements ( Devi et  al., 2009 ). Due to atrial 
hypertension and left ventricular hypertrophy, a high-fat 
diet causes abdominal obesity in dogs as well as noticeably 
elevated blood pressure and heart rates.
The most common causes of congestive heart failure 
(CHF) are degenerative mitral valve disease (MVD) and

Diseases of cardiovascular system of dogs and cats  Chapter | 13  205
DCM ( Schober et  al., 2010 ). The most frequent cause of 
heart failure in dogs is chronic MVD, which progresses 
slowly and rarely exhibits any overt clinical heart disease 
symptoms prior to death ( Borgarelli et al., 2008 ; Schober 
et  al., 2010). The most prevalent heart condition in dogs, 
accounting for 75%–80% of all cardiac diseases, is myxo -
matous valve disease, also known as chronic mitral valve 
insufficiency (CMVI), which is caused by progressive myx-
omatous degeneration of either the mitral valve alone or 
together with the tricuspid valve, leading to incomplete co-
aptation of the leaflets and valvular regurgitation (Pedersen 
et al., 1996; Haggstrom et al., 2005; Borgarelli et al., 2008).
Small breed dogs are more susceptible to the disease 
than large breed dogs, and the prevalence of the condition 
tends to increase substantially in dogs who are 4–5  years 
old and older ( Buchanan, 1977 ; Borgarelli et  al., 2004 ). 
Clinically, it is crucial to identify CHF as soon as possible 
to save the animal’s life ( Schober et  al., 2010 ). Diastolic 
dysfunction plays a noteworthy role in the pathophysiology 
of cardiovascular disorders. Diastolic dysfunction symp -
toms and prognosis, which typically lead to systolic dys -
function, dictate the course of a disease ( Cavalcanti et al., 
2007). Left-sided congestive heart failure is indicated by 
an elevated left ventricular filling pressure ( Dabbah et al., 
2006). A pericardial effusion lowers cardiac output and 
eventually results in right-sided congestive heart failure 
when an excessively large volume of fluid accumulates 
in the pericardial sac with internal heart pressure elevated 
(Gugjoo et al., 2013c; Bodh et al., 2014).
3.1 Diagnosis
Heart disease can be diagnosed using a variety of diagnostic 
techniques, such as clinical examination, auscultation, tho -
racic radiography, electrocardiography, echocardiography, 
and cardiac biomarkers (Nakayama et al., 2001). The three 
most effective diagnostic techniques used to identify canine 
cardiac disorders were auscultation, electrocardiography, 
and roentgenography (Detweiler et al., 1961).
The degree and nature of the disease determine the clini-
cal indications of heart disease, which are initially asymp -
tomatic. A dog may exhibit more pronounced symptoms 
like exhaustion, a decreased desire to walk or exercise, 
difficulty breathing, loss of appetite, weight loss, a bloated 
tummy, difficulty sleeping, or coughing when heart disease 
develops into congestive heart failure (MacPete, 2018). The 
most useful component of the cardiac examination for iden-
tifying aberrant rhythms and heart sounds is auscultation.
3.2 Thoracic radiography
The most often utilized diagnostic method for heart prob -
lems is thoracic radiography (Thrall, 2007). A key indicator 
of cardiac disease is a change in heart size, which can be 
used to track the condition and its severity ( Buchanan and 
Bucheler, 1995; Hamlin, 1999). However, it is very diffi -
cult to give an accurate subjective assessment of whether 
the cardiac silhouette is inflated or malformed. Cardiac size 
is often examined by comparing the appearance of the car -
diac silhouette in a patient with examples of normal (Thrall, 
2007). It would be preferable to contrast the patient’s radio-
graphs with those of a healthy dog of the same breed when 
assessing the patient’s heart. Dogs’ hearts were measured 
in thoracic radiographs using the vertebral scale system by 
Bodh et al. (2016b) and Gugjoo et al. (2013a, b).
Measuring various heart dimensions and cardiothoracic 
ratios is one of the objective approaches for assessing the 
cardiac silhouette ( Hamlin, 1968 ). The length of the tho -
racic vertebral bodies and the dimensions of the cardiac pro-
file are compared using the vertebral heart scale (VHS), a 
technique for measuring the heart (Buchanan and Bucheler, 
1995). VHS for dogs often ranges from 8.7 to 10.7. In dogs 
with heart disease, VHS readings tend to rise ( Lamb et al., 
2001; Nakayama et  al., 2001 ), providing insight into the 
progression of the disease (Fig. 7).
For all the breeds except one, they recorded a trend for 
dogs with cardiac disease (but not respiratory disease) to 
have higher mean values on the scale than normal dogs of 
the same breed; however, at the optimal value of the scale 
for distinguishing between dogs of each breed with and 
without cardiac disease, the sensitivity and specificity were 
relatively low, in the range 58%–83%. Lamb et al. (2001)  
assessed the influence of VHS on the accuracy of the radio-
graphic diagnosis of cardiac disease. With the aid of three 
independent, blinded observers, they looked at the  thoracic 
FIG. 7 Illustration of vertebral heart scoring (VHS) calculation in a dog.

206 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
radiographs of 50 dogs with known cardiac disease, 26 
dogs with other thoracic diseases, and 50 dogs without any 
clinical signs of cardiovascular or respiratory disease. They 
recorded a VHS over 10.7 on the lateral radiograph as a 
moderately accurate sign of cardiac disease.
Similar to the previous study, Greco et  al. (2008)  ex -
amined the impact of right vs left recumbency on the com -
putation of the vertebral heart score (VHS) in 63 healthy 
dogs and discovered that right lateral recumbency was sig -
nificantly associated with a higher VHS (9.80.6 vs 9.50.8; 
P 0.0004). While there was no discernible effect of gender 
or dog size on VHS readings, they did observe a greater 
difference between left- and right-sided measures when tak-
ing the kind of thorax into account. In eight different dog 
breeds, including the Pug, Pomeranian, Yorkshire Terrier, 
Dachshund, Bulldog, Shih Tzu, Lhasa Apso, and Boston 
Terrier, Grant et al. (2013) described VHS measures.
The Pug, Pomeranian, Bulldog, and Boston Terrier 
groups had significantly higher VHS ( >9.70.5), while the 
Lhasa Apso group’s VHS was significantly affected by body 
condition score. A substantial increase in VHS of the Bulldog 
(P = 0.028) and Boston terrier (P = 0.0004) groups was linked 
to abnormal thoracic vertebrae. However, there was no dis-
cernible change in the thoracic depth-to-width ratio on VHS. 
Since data from dogs with cardiac disease and healthy dogs 
have a lot in common, measuring the cardiac silhouette does 
not help with the identification of cardiac disease.
This overlap happens in part because certain breeds 
have, particularly large-appearing hearts, and in part be -
cause dogs with concentric hypertrophy and those assessed 
in the early stages of their condition may not have any ma -
jor cardiac enlargement. There is also proof that women’s 
mean VHS measures are smaller than men’s ( Lamb et al., 
2001). There is still a sizable overlap between healthy dogs 
and dogs with cardiac illness, even when utilizing breed-
specific normal VHS ranges.
The accuracy ranges from 58% to 83% at the ideal VHS 
value for identifying cardiac from noncardiac diseased dogs 
of each breed ( Lamb et al., 2001 ). The drawbacks suggest 
the demand for an alternative diagnostic technique for ca -
nine heart disorders confirmatory diagnosis. Despite the 
poor reliability of clinical indications, CHF might never -
theless be suspected based on these indicators. The most 
widely used approach for the diagnosis of CHF is thoracic 
radiography, which is regarded as the “gold standard” in 
clinical diagnosis (Balbarini et al., 1991). However, the ra-
diograph’s sensitivity and specificity are questioned, par -
ticularly when heart and lung illnesses are present.
3.3 Electrocardiography
The electrocardiogram (ECG) is a strong noninvasive diag-
nostic technique that is frequently used to monitor heart rate 
(HR), cardiac rhythm, conduction integrity, and electrical 
axis as well as to identify cardiac problems in canines (Tilley, 
1985). Cardiac arrhythmias and intra-cardiac conduction ab-
normalities in dogs are frequent issues that are well under -
stood by ECG ( Gugjoo et al., 2014a ). Lannek published a 
thorough statistical analysis of the normal EKG of a normal 
dog in 1949. He also made observations on a number of ani-
mals that had aberrant electrocardiograms (Fig. 8).
Electrocardiography was utilized by Bohn et al. (1971)  
to investigate the effects of age, sex, and breed on canine 
atrial fibrillation, as well as the relationship between this 
condition and other underlying cardiac conditions and its 
prognostic importance. When diagnosing cardiac diseases 
in dogs, Taylor and Sittnikow (1968)  used auscultation, 
roentgenograms, and electrocardiograms. They discovered 
that while careful auscultation was the most important 
method, roentgenograms and electrocardiograms were the 
best for confirming a diagnosis of cardiac disease and gaug-
ing its severity. Electrocardiographic observations in Spitz, 
Doberman, Labrador, German Shepherd, and Mongrels 
were reported by Dhanapalan et  al. (1997) . They noticed 
breed differences in P wave and R wave amplitudes but 
not much in the QRS complex. According to Pereira et al. 
(2004), Cocker Spaniels with increased R wave amplitude, 
QRS duration, and deep Q wave in Lead II ECG were a 
good sign that they had cardiomyopathy (Figs. 9 and 10).
The ECG’s axis represents the main direction of the 
heart’s total electrical activity and serves as a crucial 
 diagnostic tool for cardiac disorders. The usual adult QRS 
FIG. 8 Pulmonary infiltration in an ECG of dog.

Diseases of cardiovascular system of dogs and cats  Chapter | 13  207
axis is leftward and downward, ranging from −30 degrees 
to +90 degrees. Left axis deviation is defined as the QRS 
axis deviating by 30–90 degrees (LAD). The QRS vector 
is pointed upward and to the left in this instance. Right 
axis deviation (RAD) is present if the QRS axis is between 
+90 and 180 degrees, or beyond +100 degrees if the adult 
range is considered. The QRS vector would point rightward 
and downward. Extreme axis deviation, in which the ven -
tricular vector is oriented upward and to the right, occurs 
when the QRS axis falls between −90 degrees and 180 de-
grees. Finally, if there is no prominent QRS deflection and 
the QRS complex is isoelectric or equiphasic in all leads, 
the axis is said to be ambiguous. Normal variation (physi -
ologic, frequently age-related change), left ventricular hy -
pertrophy, and conduction abnormalities such as left bundle 
branch block and left anterior fascicular block are some of 
the causes of LAD.
On the other hand, RAD could indicate a lung infection 
that has worsened, a tachycardia, a new high lateral MI (Qr 
pattern), or a pulmonary embolism ( Kashou and Kashou, 
2018). The diagnosis of heart illness also uses ambulatory 
electrocardiography (Holter monitoring and cardiac event 
recording) (Tilley et al., 2008).
3.4 Cardiac catheterization
Measurement of intracardiac pressure, blood oximetry, and 
selective angiocardiography are frequently included in the 
standard CC technique for the evaluation of congenital and 
acquired cardiac disorders. CC is most frequently used to 
treat congenital cardiac disorders (e.g., pulmonary stenosis 
or PDA). Advances in echocardiography have significantly 
decreased the necessity for routine CC for diagnosis (Tilley 
et al., 2008).
3.5 Echocardiography
The most adaptable imaging method for the investigation of 
heart disorders is echocardiography (Gugjoo et  al., 2014b, c, d;  
Bodh et al., 2016a ;). Through M-mode  echocardiography, 
which provides an image of the heart viewed during several 
cardiac cycles, a unidimensional perspective is obtained 
(Cornell et al., 2004). It is typically used to assess the linear 
cardiac dimensions of the major arteries and heart chamber 
walls. Body size and the diameters of the aorta, left atrial, 
left ventricular, septal, and posterior walls as well as the 
amplitude of motion in the mitral wall have been found 
to be significantly correlated (Lombard, 1984; Jacobs and 
Mahjoob, 1988; Della Torre et al., 2000).
Compared to body size and confirmation, body surface 
area closely correlates with echocardiographic parameters 
(Della Torre et al., 2000 ). In typical Beagle dogs, Crippa 
et al. (1992)  examined echocardiographic parameters and 
indices and discovered that in Beagles around 28  weeks 
old, the morphofunctional cardiac homogeneity is inde -
pendent of size and age. Boon (2011) performed M-mode 
echocardiography on 20 young, healthy dogs weighing 
between 9.8 and 28.6  kg and discovered statistically sig -
nificant correlations between body size and the dimen -
sions of the aortic, left atrial, left ventricular, septal, and 
posterior walls, as well as the amplitude of motion of the 
mitral valve.
In healthy dogs of several breeds, including Labrador 
retrievers and Indian Spitz, echocardiography has been used 
to standardize cardiac indices, and assess heart function 
(Gugjoo, 2011; Bodh, 2014). By comparing the left ventricu-
lar cavity dimensions, wall thickness, systolic time intervals, 
and fractional shortening of healthy, awake, non-exercising 
Greyhounds to previously reported normal echocardiographic 
values obtained from Mongrels and various other dog breeds, 
Snyder et al. (2005) found significant differences.
Congenital heart conditions like obstruction of the 
ventricular outflow, PDA, VSD, ASD, ToF, dysplasia of 
the mitral and tricuspid valves, and acquired heart con -
ditions like valvular disease, congestive (dilated) cardio -
myopathy (CCM), hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), 
pericardial effusion, etc., can all be evaluated using echo -
cardiography ( Bonagura, 1983 ; Gugjoo et  al., 2013c ; 
Bodh et al., 2014, 2016a ). It may be useful for assessing 
canines that already have pericardial illness. DCM can be 
identified using echocardiographic reference values since 
the values between ill and healthy dogs differ greatly 
(Koch et al., 1996 ).
FIG. 9 Placement of electrode in dogs.
FIG. 10 Placement of electrode in cats.

208 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
M-mode echocardiography was used by Rao et  al. 
(2008) to measure echocardiographic indices and they dis -
covered that it was a helpful method for identifying left ven-
tricular enlargement and impaired contractile performance 
in dogs with DCM. To assess the severity and prognosis of 
heart illness, evaluation of left ventricular diastolic function 
is crucial (Hori et al., 2008). In dogs with dilated cardiomy-
opathy, M-mode echocardiography is helpful for early and 
confirming the diagnosis as well as for quantifying the left 
ventricular dysfunction (Rao et al., 2008 ). Dogs with con -
gestive heart failure brought on by mitral valve disease were 
the subjects of baseline echocardiographic data reported by 
de Madron et al. (2011).
When combined with other diagnostic modalities, the 
M-mode echocardiograph is a useful diagnostic tool, ac -
cording to Gugjoo et al.’s (2014c, d) evaluation of numerous 
cardiac disorders and normal reference values in various 
dog breeds. A two-dimensional tomographic image of the 
various cardiac structures is produced via two-dimensional 
real-time ultrasonography (2D). This mode can be used to 
identify lesions such as cardiac tumors, pericardial effusion, 
valve anomalies, and heart size.
Standardized imaging planes and display formats for 
two-dimensional echocardiography in dogs and cats were 
advised by Thomas et  al. (1993) . He suggested the right 
parasternal site, the left caudal (apical) parasternal location, 
and the left cranial parasternal location as three transducer 
locations (windows) to obtain consistent imaging planes. 
Four two-dimensional echocardiographic methods for mea-
suring canine left atrial size were examined by Rishniw 
and Erb (2000) . At particular periods in the cardiac cycle, 
the left atrium was measured, and they discovered a sub -
stantial correlation between the LA’s size and body weight. 
Additionally, they gave 2D echocardiographic estimates of 
LA size in adult dogs together with echocardiographic data 
with reference intervals.
3.6 Doppler echocardiography (DE)
The three main varieties of DE are color Doppler (CD), 
continuous wave Doppler (CW-D), and pulse wave Doppler 
(PW-D). DE offers useful information on the hemodynamics 
of the heart, allowing any abnormality to be identified before 
any permanent anatomical or functional deformity occurs. 
Both the kind and the severity of heart disease can be deter-
mined. Blood flow is detected using the CD to determine di-
rection, PW-D to measure speed, and CW-D to detect more 
turbulent flow. Prior to the development of PW-D, mitral 
leaflet motion analysis using echocardiography was utilized 
to show poor early ventricular filling (Leischik et al., 2015).
When it comes to gathering physiological data on in -
tracardiac hemodynamics, DE has significant advantages 
over the currently employed invasive techniques. The most 
used method for directly analyzing diastolic function and 
indirectly analyzing atrial function is PWD, which was vali-
dated using invasive measures ( Appleton et al., 1994 ). By 
using Bernoulli’s approach, it is possible to determine from 
a measurement of the pressure gradient across a stenotic 
valve (Berger et al., 1984 ). Mean LA pressures and pres -
sure fluctuations are consistently correlated with mitral and 
pulmonary flow velocities (Appleton et al., 1994; Leischik 
et al., 2015). A number of complex parameters, such as left 
atrial pressure, relaxation, LV systolic pressure, ventricular 
suction, preload, heart rate, and atrial function, influence 
the mitral inflow velocity profile.
The pattern of LV filling defined by Doppler transmi -
tral flow has been extensively characterized in humans 
and validated in experimental dogs as a noninvasive 
method of assessing LV diastolic function ( Choong et al., 
1988). In five lightly sedated dogs, Appleton (1991)  
evaluated mitral flow velocity, mitral valve motion, and 
transmitral pressure gradient during 50 cardiac cycles of 
first- and second-degree atrioventricular block that were 
either spontaneous or atrial timed. They discovered that 
diastolic mitral regurgitation is a frequent finding that can 
be identified in patients with conduction problems using 
DE methods.
DE is useful for identifying DCM and mitral valve de -
generation in dogs, and it can be used to forecast chronic 
heart failure that results from both conditions ( Schober 
et al., 2010). The main discovery is that it makes it possible 
to quickly and effectively determine whether or not CHF is 
present. Additionally, the physical examination’s measure-
ment of respiratory rate was as effective in predicting CHF 
(Schober et al., 2010).
When a dog has degenerative mitral valve disease, the 
diagnosis of CHF is made by combining the clinical symp-
toms and the findings of multiple diagnostic tests, such as 
thoracic radiography, NT proBNP, or DE ( Chetboul et al., 
2009). With DE, it is possible to measure cardiac output 
and regurgitant volumes, quantify intracardiac shunts, and 
assess the systolic and diastolic function of the heart (Boon, 
2011). Although early stages of LV dysfunction are fre -
quently observed in healthy dogs older than 10  years or in 
asymptomatic dogs with heart disease, diastolic dysfunc -
tion significantly contributes to the pathogenesis and symp-
toms of a wide variety of cardiovascular illnesses (Schober 
and Fuentes, 2001).
Chetboul and Tissier (2003)  reviewed the reliability of 
traditional echo-Doppler testing in the diagnosis of canine 
MVD and the effects it has on cardiac remodeling, LV func-
tion, and blood pressure. They suggested several standard 
echo Doppler variables for asymptomatic dogs, mainly 
 including grading of MR severity, evaluation of pulmonary 
arterial pressures, assessment of filling pressures, and left 
heart changes using a planimetric method that may help in

Diseases of cardiovascular system of dogs and cats  Chapter | 13  209
predicting animals at risk for decomposition. They also sug-
gested serial echo Doppler examinations in dogs with MVD 
to identify and track these alterations over time and detect 
an ongoing worsening of the disease.
In dogs with mitral regurgitation, the degree of regur -
gitation is the primary determinant of left atrial size and 
disease severity ( Kittleson and Brown, 2012 ). Spectral or 
color flow Doppler ultrasound may be used to identify and 
quantify mitral regurgitation. The apical four-chamber view 
is where the regurgitant flow is most frequently oriented to 
the ultrasound beam. While color Doppler mapping is not 
accessible, spectral Doppler mapping can be utilized to lo -
cate the regurgitant jet. Systolic dysfunction, albeit uncom-
mon in small-breed dogs, can occur in myocardial infarcts 
and the last phases of chronic mitral valve insufficiency, 
where the influence of the insufficiency on contractile func-
tion may be reduced (Borgarelli et al., 2007).
Doppler echocardiographic measurements of pulmonary 
arterial pressure obtained from tricuspid or pulmonary re -
gurgitant jets are frequently used in the clinical diagnosis of 
pulmonary hypertension in dogs (Visser et al., 2016). Dogs 
may develop pulmonary hypertension as a primary condi -
tion or as a complication of a number of illnesses, such as 
pulmonary venous and left atrial hypertension, pulmonary 
thromboembolic disease, congenital cardiac abnormalities, 
such as reversed PDA, and chronic pulmonary diseases, 
such as chronic bronchitis or pulmonary fibrosis. These 
conditions include dirofilariasis, Cushing’s syndrome, and 
protein-losing nephropathy ( Bach et  al., 2006 ; Johnson, 
1996). In both human and veterinary medicine, severe pul -
monary hypertension has a bad prognosis since the underly-
ing reasons are not easily treatable ( Johnson et al., 1999 ; 
Kellum and Stepien, 2007).
Therefore, it is crucial in veterinary medicine to iden -
tify pulmonary hypertension early. Using Doppler echo -
cardiography and the modified Bernoulli equation applied 
to the peak velocity of tricuspid regurgitation or pulmo -
nary regurgitant flow, noninvasive prediction of PAP is 
possible ( Lee et al., 2015 ). To provide reference data for 
the diagnosis of various cardiac diseases in dogs, Doppler-
determined velocities and pressure gradients were mea -
sured in healthy Spitz and Labrador retriever dogs of 
various age groups.
3.7 Cardiac biomarker
A cardiac biomarker is a characteristic that, with the high -
est sensitivity and specificity feasible, can predict or di -
agnose heart disease, whether it is primary or secondary. 
Cardiovascular biomarkers are becoming more popular due 
to their efficiency, affordability, noninvasiveness, risk-free 
nature, quick turnaround time, and highly predictive testing. 
Aiming to further define the diagnostic facets of primary 
and secondary cardiac illnesses, numerous researchers have 
investigated various forms of cardiovascular markers during 
the past 30 years. The most thorough research in the veteri-
nary sector has been done on small animals, mostly dogs 
and cats.
N-terminal pro-BNP (NT-pro BNP), cardiac tropo -
nins I and T (cTnI and cTnT), atrial natriuretic peptide, 
endothelin, tumor necrosis factor (TNF), and C-reaction 
protein are currently the biomarkers with the highest 
predictability for cardiac diseases in veterinary clinical 
practice. These markers also show the greatest specific -
ity (Fonfara et al., 2010; Saunders et al., 2009 ). There has 
been a thorough examination of the structure, metabolism, 
application, reference values, and changes in various dis -
orders of troponin I and N-terminal proBNP in dogs and 
cats (Baisan et al., 2016 ).
Concentrations of specific enzymes and isoforms 
can be used to support the diagnosis of heart disorders 
since they show the continuous degenerative change. 
Immediately following any injury to a muscle or the 
heart, the quantity of creatine kinase in serum or plasma 
increases. By examining serial changes in serum creatine 
phosphokinase activity, Shell et al. (1971)  determined the 
extent of myocardial infarction in the conscious dog. They 
found that the method was suitable for determining infarct 
size over a wide range and for identifying changes in in -
farct size brought on by pharmacological and physiologi -
cal interventions.
When myocardial infarction occurred in eight conscious 
dogs, Hashimoto et al. (1985)  employed the concentration 
of plasma MM creatine kinase (CK) isoforms to detect it 
early. They discovered that the concentration of CKMM 
isoform increased right away. They come to the conclusion 
that plasma CKMM isoform quantification allows for the 
early detection of CK release indicative of infarction within 
1 h of the beginning of ischemia. In addition, biomarkers 
such as creatine kinase (CK) and its fraction CKMB are 
used to evaluate the heart function in various diseases or 
surgical procedures that cause myocardial damage, such as 
ischemia, myocardial necrosis, or percutaneous coronary 
intervention in humans (Apak et al., 2005).
This biomarker is generated upon damage to noncardiac 
muscles as well, making it nonspecific to myocardial tis -
sue. According to Apak et  al. (2005) , cardiac troponin T 
is a more accurate and sensitive indicator of myocardial 
damage than CK-MB. Despite this, the biomarkers should 
be considered in the context of the patient’s medical his -
tory, physical exam, and other diagnostic tests since they 
are not standalone examinations. The biomarkers discussed 
in this paper are the ones most frequently used to evaluate 
heart health and have the ability to diagnose the majority 
of diseases, although their reliability is still low and more 
research is needed (Baisan et al., 2016).

210 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
3.8 Treatment
The type of sickness should dictate the sort of treatment. 
Some congenital heart problems can be surgically fixed 
or rectified, while other disorders can be treated medi -
cally with one or more medications. For the management 
of inherited and acquired heart problems in dogs, cardiac 
surgery is becoming a more viable alternative. Compared 
to open cardiac repairs requiring cardiopulmonary bypass 
(CPB), which are now only carried out in a small number 
of specialized centers, other cardiac procedures are broadly 
available. While some cardiac procedures are solely consid-
ered palliative, others are conducted with the goal of curing 
the patient. Cardiac procedures included closed cardiac pro-
cedures, procedures carried out while the inflow occlusion 
was in place, and procedures carried out while using CPB.
The most popular form of treatment for canine dogs 
with symptomatic bradycardia is pacemaker therapy (Tilley 
et al., 2008). A low-sodium diet may be suggested for dogs 
with congestive heart failure to aid with the body’s fluid 
balance. The main objectives of treatment are to lessen 
heart muscle damage, prevent fluid buildup in the lungs, en-
hance circulation, control heart rate and rhythm, make sure 
that the blood is sufficiently oxygenated, and reduce the 
danger of blood clot development. Adult heartworms and 
larvae should be eradicated in cases of heartworm disease. 
In the end, success is defined as the resolution of symptoms, 
normal resting breathing and heart rate, and good quality of 
life for the dog.
3.9 Common drugs used
Heart disease in dogs can be treated with a wide variety of 
drugs. Furosemide, a diuretic, is a staple of treatment for 
canines with congestive heart failure (CHF) brought either 
by dilated cardiomyopathy or degenerative mitral valve dis-
ease (DMVD) (DCM). It improves urine production and 
is a crucial and efficient way to get rid of fluids that build 
up in dogs with cardiac issues. When a dog is experienc -
ing a heart failure crisis, using a diuretic may be lifesaving. 
Digoxin, a digitalis glycoside medication, increases the force 
of heart muscle contraction, slows the heart rate, and im -
proves the function of blood pressure receptors. The renin– 
angiotensin–aldosterone system (RAAS), which encourages 
fluid retention, vasoconstriction, and myocardial and vascu-
lar remodeling, is typically activated in severe heart disease.
In dogs with CHF, the use of ACE inhibitors (enalapril, 
benazepril, ramipril, and lisinopril) is linked to increased 
survival and quality of life. They can lower blood pressure, 
boost cardiac output, and stop blood from flowing backward 
due to a leaking heart valve ( Oyama, 2009). Pimobendan 
is a positive inotrope that works differently from conven -
tional inotropes like digoxin to promote contractility. This 
has the benefit of increasing contractility without signifi -
cantly raising myocardial oxygen demand. This simultane -
ous “inodilating” activity, which relaxes vascular smooth 
muscle and causes mild arterial vasodilation, is exceptional. 
Additionally, it increases a dog’s chance of surviving and 
quality of life, and it probably does the same for a dog with 
DMVD or DCM (Boswood, 2010).
As it widens arteries leading to the lungs, sildenafil is a 
drug first developed and used to treat heart-related chest dis-
comfort and pulmonary arterial hypertension. Additionally, 
it helps men with erectile dysfunction. Other kinds of medi-
cations can help breathing by bolstering the respiratory 
system’s muscles. Some drugs are prescribed to reduce or 
speed up heart rate, regulate arrhythmias, and avoid blood 
clots.
Included in the management of cardiac arrhythmias is: 
Mexiletine or atropine are common medications used to treat 
sinus arrhythmia. Digoxin and perhaps extended-release 
Diltiazem control atrial fibrillation. Theophylline or prop -
antheline are effective treatments for atrioventricular block. 
A pacemaker is occasionally required to be implanted surgi-
cally. In breeds prone to this illness, ventricular tachycardia 
(VT) may be treated with antiarrhythmic medicine. If the 
dog has acute VT, medications such as lidocaine, sotalol, 
and mexiletine may be administered.
Mexiletine or sotalol are used as medications for pre -
mature beat ( Cunningham and Roderick, 2019 ). In some 
instances, drugs are used to kill parasites in the circulatory 
system, such as heartworms. By giving enough calories and 
protein and controlling the production of cytokines, one can 
manage the potential causes of decreased appetite, such as 
pharmaceutical side effects, in dogs with cardiac issues. 
Coenzyme Q10 (CoQ10), vitamin E (as alpha-tocopherol), 
l-carnitine, taurine, and fish oil (omega-3 fatty acids) have 
all been studied specifically for their potential to prevent 
and treat a variety of heart conditions in dogs.
B vitamins and magnesium are two more supplements 
with promising early research that need further examination. 
Clear evidence for the effectiveness of several supplements 
on canine heart disease has been established by clinical 
observation and interventional trials with dogs of different 
breeds. Appropriate quantities of some dietary components 
have been demonstrated to prolong life, enhance life quality, 
lessen disease symptoms and physical signs, and lower mor-
tality rates in these animals (Dove, 2001). Stem cell therapy 
for heart conditions is a developing field (Saxena, 2014).
Puppies’ deciduous tooth stem cells (pDSCs) were used 
in a trial with numerous intravenous injections to treat dogs 
with valvular heart disease ( Petchdee and Sompeewong, 
2016). It has yet to be determined whether stem cell ther -
apy has the full potential to treat canine cardiac disease 
(Rajewski, 2017). Cardiovascular disease gene therapy is 
the cutting edge of novel therapeutic possibilities, and with

Diseases of cardiovascular system of dogs and cats  Chapter | 13  211
further research and thorough testing, it may set the stan -
dard for initial clinical treatment options ( Wolfram and 
Donahue, 2013).
