Chapter 14
Diseases of reproductive system of female 
dogs and cats
1 Diseases of ovary
1.1 Ovarian cyst
Cysts were defined as fluid-filled structures with a distinct 
wall that develop within the ovary (ovarian cyst) or near 
the ovary (par-ovarian cyst) ( Johnston et  al., 2001a ). The 
survey indicated that ovarian cyst was the most common 
ovarian pathology (80%) ( Dow, 1960), and the most com -
mon type of ovarian cyst was the follicular cyst ( Maya-
Pulgarin et  al., 2017 ; Knauf et  al., 2018 ; Farghali et  al., 
2020). Follicular structures of more than 8 mm in diameter 
present on the ovary prior to ovulation (during proestrus or 
estrus) or follicles of any size present post-ovulation (dur -
ing late estrus, diestrus, or anestrus) are considered follicu-
lar cysts ( Johnston et al., 2001a ). Follicular cysts may be 
single or multiple, may be unilateral or bilateral, and may 
be endocrinologically active or inactive ( Johnston et  al., 
2001a; Kumar et al., 2019). The other cystic ovarian struc-
tures reported in dogs and cats are luteal cysts, germinal 
cysts, cystic corpora lutea, cystic rete ovarii, cystic atretic 
follicles, and cystic granulosa cell tumors ( Johnston et al., 
2001a; Smith, 2003 ). Most of these cysts are hormonally 
inactive and have no clinical relevance ( Arlt and Haimerl, 
2016). The functional significance of these cysts is minimal 
unless they compress or destroy the adjacent ovarian archi-
tecture (Ortega-Pacheco et al., 2012).
1.1.1 Occurrence
Follicular cysts are common incidental findings in older 
bitches and queens (Ortega-Pacheco et al., 2012) with lower 
incidence in bitches than in queens (Smith, 2003). No breed 
predisposition has been found ( Johnston et  al., 2001a ). 
Follicular cysts, commonly arise from mature or atretic fol-
licles due to ineffective ovulatory mechanism that results in 
the persistence of follicles (Smith, 2003). The follicular cyst 
may be partially luteinized ( Smith, 2003). Follicular cysts 
may be functionally active due to their ability of secreting 
estrogen and can produce estrogen-mediated effects on the 
animal’s reproductive tract and extra reproductive systems 
(Johnston et al., 2001a). Follicular cysts could cause behav-
ioral disorders like prolonged estrus, bone marrow suppres-
sion, and uterine hyperplasia due to prolonged elevation of 
estradiol (Farghali et al., 2020).
1.1.2 Clinical manifestation
Affected cats and dogs may be asymptomatic or clinically 
healthy if the cysts are nonfunctional or produce very less 
amount of estrogen that could influence the animal’s behav-
ior and physiology. Ovarian and par-ovarian cysts often are 
accidental findings during ultrasonographic examination or 
abdominal surgery (usually routine OHE) in healthy bitches 
and queens (Ortega-Pacheco et al., 2012; Smith, 2003). The 
most common clinical sign exhibited by cats and dogs af -
fected with follicular cysts is irregular estrus cycles specially 
prolonged proestrus or estrus, when the cells lining secrete 
estrogen ( Keskin et  al., 2009 ). The physical changes as -
sociated with proestrus and estrus such as vulvar swelling 
and serosanguineous vulvar discharge are present (Johnston 
et  al., 2001a ). Prolonged anestrus and infertility are the 
other complaints associated with ovarian cysts. In chronic 
cases, symmetrical bilateral alopecia, bone marrow suppres-
sion, and cystic endometrial hyperplasia (CEH)/pyometra 
complex can occur due to prolonged elevation of estradiol 
(Ortega-Pacheco et al., 2012; Lopate and Foster, 2010).
1.1.3 Diagnosis
The diagnosis is based on behavioral signs, vaginal cytol -
ogy, hormone assays, ultrasonography, and histopathol -
ogy (Ortega-Pacheco et al., 2012 ; Eissa et al., 2017 ). The 
presence of cornified vaginal epithelial cells in vaginal 
cytological examination indicates an estrogenic influence. 
Serial measurement of estrogen in serum may be useful in

216 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
diagnosing follicular cyst in cats and dogs. The serum es -
trogen concentration of greater than 20 pg/mL is consistent 
with follicular activity. Therefore, prolonged proestrus or 
estrus along with persistently increased serum concentra -
tions of estrogen is indicative of chronic estrogen produc -
tion and this is most likely to be a follicular cyst in cats and 
dogs (Smith, 2003). Ultrasonography is the best way for the 
diagnosis of ovarian cysts in cats and dogs ( Smith, 2003). 
Ultrasonographic examination of ovaries will reveal one or 
more large follicles as hypoechoic to anechoic structures 
depending on the presence of the amount of luteal tissue 
(Ortega-Pacheco et  al., 2012 ). Histologic examination of 
ovarian cysts can be beneficial for the distinction between 
follicular cysts and cysts arising in the rete ovarii, par-
ovarian cysts, or subsurface epithelial structures ( Ortega-
Pacheco et al., 2012).
1.1.4 Therapy
Ovario-hysterectomy is the treatment of choice for ovar -
ian follicular cysts ( Johnston et  al., 2001a ). Ovario-
hysterectomy eliminates the risk of recurrence of the 
disease and severe concomitant metropathies (Sontas et al., 
2011a). Hormonal therapy may be an acceptable alterna -
tive to the ovariohysterectomy ( Knauf et  al., 2013 ) that 
includes the administration of GnRH and/or hCG to lutein-
ize the granulosa cell layer ( Lopate and Foster, 2010 ). In 
bitches, hormonal treatment regimes suggested are a single 
injection of GnRH (50–100 μg, I/M) or a single injection of 
hCG (100–1000 IU, I/M) or injection of hCG (500 IU, I/M) 
once daily for three consecutive days, or injection of hCG 
(1000 IU, half of which is administered I/V and remain -
ing half as S/C). If luteinization and a decrease in clinical 
signs have not occurred by 1  week after the hormonal re -
gime, treatment with GnRH or hCG can be repeated (Smith, 
2003). In queens, 25  μg of GnRH (I/M) or hCG (500 I/V 
once or 250 I/V on 2 consecutive days) will stimulate the 
formation of luteal tissue ( Smith, 2003). Variable success 
rates of hormonal treatment have been reported (Arlt et al., 
2011; Knauf et al., 2013 ). As the cats are induced ovula -
tors, the induction of ovulation can be achieved by allowing 
breeding in cats (Ortega-Pacheco et al., 2012). Aspiration of 
cystic fluid via laparotomy in the way described by Fayrer-
Hosken et  al. (1992)  or ultrasound-guided aspiration of 
cysts (Bassu et al., 2004 ) could be the other treatment op -
tions. Spontaneous regression of the cysts may also occur 
(Arlt and Haimerl, 2016). For the treatment of luteal cysts, 
serial PGF2α administration or ovariectomy has been sug -
gested (Lopate and Foster, 2010).
1.2 Ovarian remnant syndrome
Ovarian remnant syndrome (ORS) is a condition that occurs 
when functional ovarian tissue remains inside the body after 
ovariectomy or ovariohysterectomy (Wallace, 1991). It is an 
iatrogenic condition commonly seen in the bitch and queen 
(Wallace, 1991). Ovarian remnant syndrome is less com -
mon in dogs than in cats (Miller, 1995).
1.2.1 Occurrence
ORS may occur due to surgical error (incomplete removal 
of one or both ovarian tissues during ovariectomy or ovar -
iohysterectomy), ectopic ovarian tissue (localized in the 
broad ligament or proper ligament of the ovary), or auto-
transplantation (drooping of some ovarian tissue into the 
abdominal cavity) at the time of ovariectomy or ovariohys-
terectomy (Ball et al., 2010; Sontas et al., 2007). Due to the 
revascularization of the retained piece of ovarian tissue, it 
becomes functional and starts to produce estrogen and pro-
gesterone hormones that results in developing the signs of 
ORS (Kalina et al., 2017; Smith, 2003 ). Surgical error has 
been considered the most acceptable cause of ORS (Sontas 
et al., 2007), and may occur due to a small abdominal wall 
incision that makes it difficult to visualize, reach, and carry 
out the ligature of the ovary or ovaries, or due to improper 
ligation of ovarian tissues ( Ball et al., 2010; Kalina et al., 
2017). The right ovary is more predisposed to be the rem -
nant in the dog and cat due to its anatomical location ( Ball 
et al., 2010; Sontas et al., 2007).
1.2.2 Clinical manifestation
In dogs, the symptoms develop are characteristics of pro-
oestrus and oestrus such as vulvar swelling, mucoid to se -
rosanguinous vulvar discharge with behavioral symptoms 
of estrus like attractiveness to males and postural behav -
ior ( Johnston et  al., 2001a; Naiman et  al., 2014 ). Many 
bitches only have one or two of these symptoms. Signs in 
queens may include vocalization, affectionate head rub -
bing to owners, rolling, treading, lordosis, and attraction 
of males (Smith, 2003; Oliveira et al., 2012). However, all 
the queens with ORS do not show overt behavioral signs 
of estrus (Oliveira et al., 2012). In ORS, the onset of signs 
of estrus in cats and dogs may occur as early as a few days 
or as late as many years after OHE ( Miller, 1995; Smith, 
2003). False pregnancy and mammary gland development 
may be other reported clinical signs. False pregnancy asso-
ciated with ORS is more common in bitches than in queens 
(Smith, 2003).
1.2.3 Diagnosis
If an ovariohysterectomized/ovariectomized cat or dog 
shows symptoms of estrus behavior, it should be suspected 
for ORS. Diagnosis of ORS relies on history and clinical 
signs, and can be further by laboratory tests like vaginal 
cytology and hormonal analysis and/or laparotomy (Miller, 
1995; Feldman and Nelson, 2004).
In spayed dogs where proestrus or estrus symptoms, 
such as vulvar swelling and discharge, and willingness to

Diseases of reproductive system of female dogs and cats  Chapter | 14  217
stand, are apparent, the diagnosis can be simply made by 
vaginal cytology ( Oliveira et al., 2012 ). Predominant cor -
nified vaginal epithelial cells are indicative of elevated se -
rum estrogen concentrations and the presence of functional 
ovarian tissue (Johnston et al., 2001a).
In cats, vaginal cytological changes are more subtle than 
in bitches; therefore, in cats diagnosis is more dependent 
on a combination of clinical signs, hormonal assays, and 
laparotomy (Miller, 1995). However, an increased number 
of cornified vaginal epithelial cells and a distinct lessening 
of background mucus and debris represent estrogenic influ-
ences on the vaginal mucosa in cats (Smith, 2003).
The levels of progesterone and estradiol indicate the 
presence of ovarian tissue in cats and dogs ( Oliveira et al., 
2012). Serum progesterone concentration measurements 
are more specific than serum estradiol concentrations to di-
agnose ORS, as the ovary is the sole source of progesterone 
(Wallace, 1991). Evaluation of serum progesterone concen-
trations can be done 1–2 weeks after confirming the vagi -
nal cytology results. A serum progesterone concentration of 
greater than 2  ng/mL indicates the presence of functional 
luteal tissue on the ovarian remnant. If the bitch is showing 
signs of heat, luteinization of the follicle may be induced by 
administrating 50 μg of GnRH (I/M) or hCG (400  IU IV or 
1000 IU, half IV , half IM). Re-evaluation of serum proges-
terone concentration 2–3 weeks after injection of GnRH or 
hCG is done for verification of luteinization (Smith, 2003). 
Post-stimulation serum progesterone concentrations greater 
than 2 ng/mL are strong evidence of the presence of ovarian 
luteal tissue.
As cats are induced ovulaters, ovulation can be induced 
by copulation, manual stimulation, or administration of ex-
ogenous GnRH or hCG. Administration of GnRH (25  μg, 
I/M) or hCG (250  IU I/M) can stimulate ovulation of fol -
licles, formation of corpora lutea, and subsequently in -
crease in serum progesterone concentrations. The serum 
progesterone concentrations remain greater than 2  ng/mL 
for approximately 35–50  days after ovulation that indicate 
the presence of functional ovarian tissue. The serum pro -
gesterone should be measured 2–3  weeks after injection of 
GnRH or hCG (Smith, 2003).
A serum estradiol concentration greater than 20  pg/mL 
indicates follicular activity in bitches and queens. A single-
sample result may be inconclusive or produce an incorrect 
diagnosis as the serum estradiol concentrations are not 
consistent with the follicular activity ( Ball et al., 2010 ). In 
bitches, serum estrogen level increases during proestrus, 
reaches at peak toward the end of estrus, and rapidly de -
creases during estrus (standing estrus). Similarly, cats con -
tinue to display behavioral signs of estrus for a few days 
after serum estradiol concentrations decrease (Smith, 2003).
Another highly effective test for determining the pres -
ence of ovarian tissue in cats and dogs is the hormone assay 
for anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH). Therefore, a positive 
test for AMH would indicate the presence of ovarian tissue 
because ovaries are the sole source of AMH ( Place et al., 
2011; Yilmaz et al., 2015).
The diagnosis of ORS in bitches or queens using ultra -
sonography may be difficult and depends on the expertise 
of the examiner, the stage of the estrous cycle of the animal 
at the time of examination, and the size of the remnant tis -
sue (Ball et al., 2010 ). The ultrasonographic examination 
may miss residual tissue if it is quite small or if the animal 
is in anestrus ( Sontas et  al., 2007 ). Exploratory surgery 
may be a diagnostic option that enables a thorough exami -
nation of the ovarian pedicles and abdominal structures 
(Smith, 2003).
1.2.4 Therapy
Surgical removal of the ovarian remnant by exploratory lap-
arotomy is the treatment of choice ( Johnston et al., 2001a; 
Sontas et  al., 2007 ). Exploratory laparotomy in cats and 
bitches is performed either during estrus or during diestrus 
phases; during both the stages ovarian remnant is more vis-
ible because of an increase in the size due to the presence 
of the follicles or corpora lutea, respectively. However, due 
to the increased vascularity of the remnants during these 
phases, intraoperative bleeding could be a complication 
during the surgery. The intraoperative bleeding will be less 
during the diestrus phase than the estrus; however, signs 
of false pregnancy may develop postoperatively, and those 
usually subside without treatment in less than 4  weeks 
(Johnston et al., 2001a; Feldman and Nelson, 2004; Sontas 
et al., 2007). In cats, if the surgery is to be done during di -
estrus, the cat should be administered GnRH or hCG during 
behavioral estrus (Smith, 2003). Laparotomy is not advised 
during the anestrus phase of the estrus cycle in affected 
bitches or cats because the ovarian remnant tissue might be 
too small to be identified during this phase ( Smith, 2003; 
Sontas et  al., 2007). A thorough examination of the peri -
toneal cavity is necessary during the surgery, exploring the 
caudal poles of kidneys, the omentum, and the peritoneal 
walls, as these are common sites for the presence of the rem-
nant (Miller, 1995; Wallace, 1991; DeNardo et al., 2001 ). 
Both ovarian pedicles should be examined as remnants may 
occur bilaterally. Ovarian tissue should be excised carefully 
and submitted for histopathologic examination. If an ovar -
ian tissue is not identified, scar tissue should be removed at 
both ovarian pedicles (Johnston et al., 2001a). Postoperative 
serum progesterone levels assessment can be helpful to 
evaluate the success of the surgery.
As medical treatment of ORS, exogenous progestogens 
such as megestrol acetate or androgens like mibolerone 
have been reported ( Johnston et  al., 2001a ; Feldman and 
Nelson, 2004 ; Romagnoli, 2004 ). These compounds can 
inhibit the signs of ORS but do not solve the problem per -
manently and have adverse side effects; therefore, the use 
of these compounds is not recommended. The side effects

218 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
include increasing the incidence of mammary gland tumors, 
induction of growth hormone secretion and promotion of 
acromegaly condition, and suppression of adreno-cortical 
function (Oliveira et al., 2012).
1.3 Ovarian neoplasia
Ovarian neoplasms are uncommon in dogs and cats. The 
reported incidence of ovarian neoplasm ranges from 1% to 
6% in dogs and 0.7% to 3.6% in cats ( Klein, 2007; Sforna 
et al., 2003 ). However, the true incidence of ovarian neo -
plasia is unknown and may be biased by the fact that a 
large segment of the population is surgically neutered at an 
early age (Klein, 2007). Breeds such as German Shepherds, 
Terriers, Yorkshire, English Bulldogs, and Boxers have 
been found to be at higher risk of developing ovarian tumors 
(Bhoi et al., 2022).
1.3.1 Occurrence
Ovarian tumors occur most often in middle-aged to older 
cats and dogs; however, granulosa teratomas generally de -
velop in younger animals ( Klein, 2007 ). Approximately 
85% of ovarian tumors are unilateral ( Smith, 2003 ). The 
pathogenesis of ovarian neoplasia is unknown ( Johnston 
et  al., 2001a). Ovarian neoplasms are almost of primary 
ovarian origin and may arise from surface epithelium, sex 
cord-gonadostromal tissue, germ cells, or mesenchymal tis-
sues (Smith, 2003).
The tumors that arise from ovarian surface epithelium 
are papillary adenomas, papillary carcinomas, cystadeno -
mas, and cystadenocarcinomas. The epithelial tumors are 
common in dogs (40%–50% of reported canine ovarian neo-
plasms) and mostly are bilateral (Smith, 2003). Ovarian epi-
thelial tumors may be cauliflower-like or smooth, and may 
or may not be cystic ( Jergens and Shaw, 1987 ; Madewell 
and Theilen, 1987). Metastasis in epithelial tumors may oc-
cur (Klein, 2007; Smith, 2003 ). Epithelial tumors are ex -
tremely rare in the cat (Klein, 2007).
Granulosa cell tumor, thecoma, and luteoma are the 
tumors that arise from sex cord-gonadostromal tissue. 
Granulosa cell tumors are the second most commonly occur-
ring ovarian tumors in dogs (Johnston et al., 2001a). These 
tumors are usually unilateral and metastasis apparently is 
uncommon (Smith, 2003). In cats, sex cord- gonadostromal 
tumors are the most commonly occurring ovarian tumors. 
Of these, granulosa cell tumors are the most common, and 
half of them are malignant in nature ( Klein, 2007; Stein, 
1981; Norris et al., 1969).
The tumors that arise from germ cells are dysgermi -
nomas and teratomas. Dysgerminomas are the third most 
commonly occurring ovarian neoplasms (6%–12% of all 
ovarian neoplasms) in dogs and are generally unilateral 
(Smith, 2003). In cats, approximately 15% of ovarian neo -
plasms are dysgerminomas, and teratomas are reported 
rarely (Klein, 2007; Stein, 1981; Norris et al., 1969). Germ 
cell tumors specially teratomas have malignant potential, 
particularly in older animals.
Mesenchymal tumors are rare in dogs and cats. These 
include leiomyomas, fibromas neurofibromas, myomas, 
hemangiomas, and lymphangiomas (Smith, 2003).
1.3.2 Clinical manifestation
The dogs and cats affected with ovarian tumors may appear 
normal, may show a wide range of clinical signs, or may be 
critically ill. Small tumors may be inapparent. Many ovar -
ian neoplasms are functional and produce excessive estro -
gens and/or progestogens that lead to hormone-dependent 
changes. The affected animals may be suffered from nym -
phomania, prolonged estrus, swelling of the vulva, sanguin-
eous vulvar discharge, symmetric nonpruritic alopecia, and 
a pendulous abdomen ( Klein, 2007; Smith, 2003 ). Some 
bitches may have clinical signs of hyperadrenocorticism. 
Cystic endometrial hyperplasia/pyometra complex may de-
velop and the bitches may be lethargic and may develop 
polyuria, polydipsia, and inappetence. Certain nonspe -
cific symptoms such as anemia, inappetence, weight gain/
loss, gynecomastia, and receptivity to males may develop 
(Diez-Bru et al., 1998 ; Klein, 2007; Novotny et al., 2011 ; 
Abraham and Ravindran, 2012). In cats also, persistent es -
trus, alopecia, and cystic or adenomatous hyperplasia of the 
endometrium, signs of depression, vomiting, abdominal 
distension, and ascites are the associate signs (Klein, 2007). 
Animals with malignant tumors that have metastasized may 
have systemic signs of disease (Smith, 2003).
1.3.3 Diagnosis
Diagnosis of ovarian tumor is based on clinical findings, ra-
diographic, ultrasonographic, or histological examination, 
or a combination of these techniques (Bhoi et al., 2022). The 
clinical findings depend on the space occupied by intraab -
dominal tumor mass, hormonal disturbances caused by the 
tumor, and metastasis spread of the tumor (Itoh et al., 2007). 
Abdominal palpation may be helpful in palpating an abdom-
inal mass or intra-abdominal fluid accumulation in bitches 
and queens affected with ovarian neoplasia (Smith, 2003).
Abdominal radiography may be helpful to identify ovar-
ian masses. In radiographs, ovarian neoplasms are visible as 
soft tissue density masses caudal to the kidney, displacing 
abdominal structures (Root and Spaulding, 1994). However, 
definitive diagnosis is difficult by radiography.
Ultrasonography is the most useful technique to make 
a tentative diagnosis of ovarian neoplasia in bitches and 
queens (Smith, 2003). Ovarian tumors are visible by ultra -
sonography as rounded or irregular masses with variable 
or polylocular echotexture, caudal to the kidney ( Root and 
Spaulding, 1994). Abdominal radiography and ultrasonog -
raphy can also be helpful to assess the tumor size and its

Diseases of reproductive system of female dogs and cats  Chapter | 14  219
location. Apart from radiography and ultrasonography, a 
definitive diagnosis is only made by histological examina -
tion of the ovarian tissue (Silva et al., 2014).
As supportive evidence, vaginal cytologic examina -
tion and serum hormone analyses may be conducted in the 
bitches and queens showing signs of prolonged heat (Smith, 
2003). In critically ill animals, hematologic and serum bio-
chemical analyses should be performed to analyze the sta -
tus of the animal and provide supportive therapy.
1.3.4 Therapy
A complete ovariohysterectomy is the most preferred 
treatment for ovarian neoplastic cases in bitches and cats. 
A complete ovariohysterectomy is recommended consid -
ering the risk of metastasis and future uterine pathology 
(Johnston et  al., 2001a ; Bhoi et  al., 2022; Smith, 2003 ). 
The excised ovarian and uterine tissues should be submit -
ted for histologic examination. If metastasis is suspected, 
the area lymph nodes should be removed and submitted for 
histologic examination. Medical treatment against ovar -
ian neoplasms is not effective. Chemotherapy and radia -
tion therapy have been reported to be little effective against 
primary ovarian tumors. However, chemotherapeutics, like 
cisplatin, can be effectively used in case of metastases from 
an ovarian tumor (Smith, 2003).
2 Diseases of uterus
Diseases of canine and feline uteri fall primarily into two 
categories: (i) abnormalities of endometrial growth and re -
pair and (ii) uterine infections with associated endometritis 
(Schlafer, 2012). Neoplastic conditions of the tubular geni-
talia of the bitch, with the possible exception of leiomyomas 
(tumors that arise from smooth muscle cells), are uncom -
mon (Hagman, 2022). Uterine neoplasia is seemingly rare 
in cats (Stabenfeldt and Pedersen, 1991). Congenital abnor-
malities involving the uterus are relatively rare ( McIntyre 
et al., 2010). The most common problems are described.
2.1 Cystic endometrial hyperplasia pyometra 
complex
Cystic endometrial hyperplasia-pyometra complex 
(CEH-P) is an acute or chronic, poly-systemic, and poten -
tially life-threatening condition that affects middle-aged or 
older female dogs and cats ( Hagman, 2022). It is the most 
common uterine disorder encountered in bitches ( Bigliardi 
et  al., 2004; Kida et  al., 2006 ) that is usually diagnosed 
within 4 months of estrus ( Hagman, 2022). The disease is 
characterized by progressive pathological changes that oc -
cur in the uterine lining and set up of bacterial infection in 
the uterus that lead to the development of several clinical 
signs (De Bosschere et al., 2001; Kustritz and Barber, 2003; 
Agudelo, 2005).
2.1.1 Occurrence
CEH-P is a disease of middle-aged or older dogs ( Hagman 
et  al., 2014 ). CEH-P is a diestrual disorder of the adult 
ovary-intact bitches (Arora et al., 2006). The overall portion 
of female dogs that experienced pyometra was around 19% 
(Jitpean et al., 2012 ) to 30% ( Egenvall et al., 2001; Nagar 
et  al., 2008). In cats, the disease is relatively uncommon 
(Hagman et al., 2014 ). This is believed to depend on less 
progesterone dominance due to seasonality and induced 
ovulation (Hagman, 2022). CEH and pyometra can develop 
in nulliparous bitches and queens ( Kustritz and Barber, 
2003; Agudelo, 2005).
2.1.2 Etiology and pathogenesis
The development of CEH-P is believed to be similar in dogs 
and cats (Hagman, 2022 ). The etiology of CEH-P is com -
plex and poorly understood but involves both hormonal 
and bacterial factors in the development ( De Bosschere 
et  al., 2001; Hagman, 2022 ). Higher circulating proges -
terone is thought to mediate the development of CEH-P. 
Higher progesterone causes hyperplasia of the endome -
trium, especially of the superficial epithelium and the en -
dometrial glands, increases endometrial gland secretion, 
favors cervical closure, and suppresses myometrial con -
tractions ( Cox, 1970 ). The local leukocyte response and 
uterine resistance to bacterial infection also remain sup -
pressed under the influence of progesterone ( Wijewardana 
et  al., 2015; Hagman, 2018 ). Thus, prolonged exposure 
to progesterone leads to proliferation and cystic dilation 
of the glandular endometrium with fluid accumulation in 
the uterine lumen, and the development of CEH ( Hagman, 
2022). Sterile fluid may accumulate in the uterine lumen, 
with or without CEH, which is defined as hydrometra or 
mucometra or, more rarely, hemometra, depending on the 
type of fluid and its mucin content ( Hagman, 2022 ). In 
bitches, the severity of CEH increases with repeated es -
trous cycles because of the prolonged diestrus that follows 
every estrus. In cats, the development of CEH is influ -
enced by the retention of functional corpora lutea and may 
be seen after induction of ovulation without subsequent 
pregnancy (Kustritz and Barber, 2003 ).
The development of CEH allows opportunistic bacteria 
to colonize the cystic endometrial tissue. Over the time, 
the presence of bacteria triggers an inflammatory response 
that results in the accumulation of purulent exudate within 
the uterus and leads to the subsequent development of 
pyometra (Hagman, 2022). CEH-P may establish from an 
ascending infection from the vagina. The most commonly 
reported infection is Escherichia coli, other infections such 
as Staphylococci, Streptococci, and Pseudomonas aerugi-
nosa may also occur ( Agudelo, 2005; Arora et al., 2006 ). 
Some reports show that estrogens also influence the devel -
opment of pyometra (Johnston et al., 2001b). The estrogen

220 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
hormone causes an increase in progesterone receptors in 
the  endometrium, dilation of the cervix, allows bacterial 
ascent that reside as the normal vaginal flora and influence 
endometrial changes ( Agudelo, 2005). CEH develops as a 
result of repeated exposure of the estrogen-primed uterus 
to progesterone (Kustritz and Barber, 2003). Administration 
of high doses of estrogen and progesterone for prolonged 
intervals, uterine biopsies, uterine scarification, and uter -
ine irritants has also been found to be responsible for CEH 
development ( Nomura, 1994; Noakes et  al., 2001; De 
Bosschere et al., 2002).
2.1.3 Clinical manifestation
The clinical signs of the CEH-P complex may vary and 
depend on the severity of the disease. Generally, early 
stage of CEH is asymptomatic when there is no bacte -
rial infection in the uterus ( Fransson et al., 2004; Hagman 
et al., 2006 ). As the condition progresses to pyometra, the 
affected animal may show some common clinical signs. 
The most commonly observed clinical finding is a continu-
ous or intermittent muco-purulent to hemorrhagic vaginal 
discharge ( Jhonson, 1994; Harvey, 1998; Johnston et  al., 
2001b; Kustritz and Barber, 2003 ), occurring in around 
75% of the cases ( Lucas et al., 2000 ). However, the vagi -
nal discharge is absent in dogs with a closed-cervix pyo -
metra ( Davidson, 1995 ) and may not be observed in cats 
due to the careful cleaning habits of the queens (Macintire, 
1994; V on Reitzeinstein et  al., 2000 ). The systemic ill -
ness is often more severe in the closed cervix pyometra, 
and the uterus may become severely distended ( Jitpean 
et al., 2017 ). Nonspecific clinical signs include anorexia, 
vomiting, lethargy, abdominal pain on palpation, loss of  
weight, abnormal mucous membranes (pale, hyperemic, 
or toxic), and an unkempt appearance ( Jhonson, 1994; 
Barsanti, 1998; Kustritz and Barber, 2003; Jitpean et al., 
2014). Polyuria and polydipsia are not readily observed in 
cats as often as in dogs and have been reported only in 9% 
of the cases (Jhonson, 1994; Barsanti, 1998 ).
2.1.4 Diagnosis
The diagnosis of CEH-P complex is based on a combina -
tion of clinical signs, physical examination, and diagnostic 
tests. Complete blood count (CBC), serum biochemistry 
profile, radiography, ultrasonography, and vaginal cytol -
ogy are the commonly used diagnostic tests ( Hagman, 
2018, 2022 ). A detailed medical history of the patient 
may include whelping history; prior hormonal treatment 
(estrogen or progestogen) for estrus suppression or in -
duction, contraception, or pregnancy termination; time 
duration elapsed since completion of the most recent 
estrus; and antecedents of irregular cycling ( Agudelo, 
2005), followed by a thorough physical examination. 
Special attention should be given to the  reproductive 
history,  presence of vaginal discharge. Abdominal pal -
pation will be helpful to evaluate uterine enlargement 
(Hagman, 2022 ). Routine laboratory tests such as CBC, 
biochemical profile, and urinalysis can provide valuable 
information about the overall health status of the animal 
(Hagman, 2022 ). Increased white blood cell count (leuko -
cytosis with neutrophilia and left deviation with values, 
and monocytosis) and changes in biochemical parameters 
may indicate the presence of infection ( Johnston et  al., 
2001b). Hyperglobulinemia can be found in 30%–60% 
of the cases. Hyperproteinemia and hyperfibrinogenemia 
can be observed due to dehydration or inflammatory pro -
cess (Barsanti, 1998; Agudelo, 2005 ).
Radiography and ultrasonography are commonly used 
imaging techniques to assess the size of the uterus and de -
tect abnormalities. Radiography can confirm the uterine 
enlargement and can identify a uterus that emerges from 
the pelvis as a dilated, homogeneous, and sometimes sac -
culiform structure (Fig. 1) with dorsal and cranial displace-
ment of the small intestine (Owens and Biery, 1999; Thrall, 
2004). Ultrasonography is particularly useful in identifying 
the presence of cystic changes in the uterine lining and dif-
ferentiating between pyometra and other uterine diseases. 
When large volumes of fluid/pus are present in uterus detec-
tion by ultrasound is easier ( Qureshi et al., 2002). A uterus 
filled with pus often shows sacs of echogenic material on 
ultrasound examination (Fig. 2).
Vaginal cytology usually reveals severe leukocyte de -
generation, neutrophils, and some macrophages, plasma -
cytes, and lymphocytes ( Vandeplassche, 1991 ). Uterine 
culture can be performed to identify the type of bacte -
ria causing the infection and guide appropriate antibi -
otic selection. Vaginoscopy has also been recommended 
for direct observation of the hemorrhagic or mucopuru -
lent discharge originating from the uterus ( Goldston and 
Hoskins, 1997 ).
FIG.  1 Radiograph of a bitch with pyometra showing sacculations of 
pus filled uterus.

Diseases of reproductive system of female dogs and cats  Chapter | 14  221
2.1.5 Therapy
Like in dogs, pyometra in cats is also considered an emer -
gency (White, 1998). The prognosis for pyometra is gen -
erally favorable with prompt diagnosis and appropriate 
treatment. However, the condition can be life-threatening 
if left untreated ( Hagman, 2022). The treatment of CEH-P 
complex depends on several factors, such as severity of the 
disease, the overall health of the patient, and the owner's 
breeding plans. The two main treatment options are medi -
cal management and surgical removal of uterus and ova -
ries (Jhonson, 1994; Harvey, 1998; Johnston et al., 2001b; 
Agudelo, 2005). Medical management includes the use of 
prostaglandins to induce luteolysis and subsequent uterine 
evacuation (Hagman, 2022). This method is most suitable 
for patients with early-stage disease, minimal uterine en -
largement, and pets not suitable for surgery. Correction 
of fluid deficits, proper administration of antibiotics, and 
other supportive therapy are required. Close monitoring and 
follow-up examinations are essential to ensure complete 
resolution of the infection. Ovariohysterectomy (spaying) 
is the treatment of choice in most complex cases of CEH-P 
(Hagman, 2022). It provides a definitive cure by removing 
the uterus and ovaries, eliminating the hormonal influence, 
and preventing future pyometra. Surgical treatment is par -
ticularly recommended for animals with recurrent pyome -
tra, severe disease, or if the owner has no breeding plans 
(Hagman, 2022).
2.1.6 Prevention strategies
Prevention of CEH-P complex relies on controlling the re -
productive cycle and avoiding exposure to progesterone for 
prolonged periods. Spaying at an appropriate age, prefer -
ably before the first heat cycle, significantly reduces the 
risk of developing CEH-P complex. Responsible breeding 
 practices, such as proper timing of mating and regular vet -
erinary care, are also essential to minimize the occurrence 
of this disorder (Johnston et al., 2001b).
2.2 Metritis
Metritis is an inflammation of the uterus that usually occurs 
after pregnancy due to a bacterial infection. Factors such as 
prolonged or difficult delivery, mummified or decomposed 
pup, and retained fetuses or placentas may cause metritis 
(Johnston et al., 2001b). Escherichia coli bacteria are a com-
mon cause of infection of the uterus ( Orfanou et al., 2008). 
The primary sign of infection is a pus-like discharge from 
the vulva. Female dogs with metritis are usually depressed 
or feverish, have a reduced appetite, and may neglect their 
offspring. Pups may become restless and cry incessantly. 
The presence of a malodorous, red-brown, purulent, or san-
guinopurulent vulvar discharge may be the other finding. 
Bitches with metritis may develop shock due to severe de -
hydration (i.e., hypovolemic shock), septicemia, or endotox-
emia (Kustritz and Barber, 2003). The infection is diagnosed 
through physical examination, X-rays, ultrasonography, and 
laboratory tests. Treatment includes administering fluids, sup-
portive care, and antibiotics. The vaginal cytology of bitches 
or queens with metritis reveals large numbers of degenerate 
neutrophils (Kustritz and Barber, 2003). Medications can also 
be given to expel a retained fetus or placenta. Administration 
of broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy and symptomatic treat-
ment are required. Ecbolic agents like oxytocin and PGF2α 
may be used. Dogs with metritis may be recommended 
for ovariohysterectomy if future breeding is not required 
(Johnston et al., 2001b; Kustritz and Barber, 2003).
2.3 Subinvolution of placental sites
Subinvolution of placental sites (SIPS) is a disorder that 
occurs after whelping as a result of abnormal repair of 
the lining of the uterus (where the placenta was attached) 
(Johnston et al., 2001c). After giving birth, the uterus slowly 
returns to its normal size in a process called involution. 
Normally, a bloody discharge accompanies this process for 
up to 16 weeks after birth. In some dogs, the discharge lasts 
much longer ( Orfanou et al., 2009 ). The condition is most 
common in dogs less than 3 years old after their first lit -
ter. In the bitches with SIPS, regression or degeneration of 
trophoblastic cells does not take place normally; instead, 
the cells continue to invade deep into the glandular layer 
or even into the myometrium which prevents normal in -
volution (Johnston et al., 2001c ). Diagnosis is exclusively 
based upon history and clinical signs. There are no signs 
except for discharge from the uterus, which contains blood. 
Blood loss is usually not severe with this condition. It re -
solves on its own and usually does not recur. Administration 
of a single dose of 25–50 mg medroxyprogesterone may 
FIG.  2 Ultrasound picture of a bitch with pyometra showing sacs  
of echogenic material.

222 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
be helpful (Sontas et al., 2011b ). Low oral doses of a pro -
gestogen (megestrol acetate, 0.1 mg/kg body weight [bw] 
once daily for the first week, then 0.05 mg/kg bw once daily 
for the second week) have also been suggested ( V oorhorst 
et  al., 2013). Spaying is curative, but it is not necessary 
unless the bleeding is severe ( Kustritz and Barber, 2003 ). 
Methylergometrine maleate, a semisynthetic ergot alkaloid, 
has been suggested to be administered orally as an adjuvant 
therapy, to control bleeding (Rasool and Kumar, 2021).
2.4 Uterine neoplasia
Neoplasia of the canine and feline uterus is a rare occur -
rence in veterinary medicine, accounting for 0.3%–0.4% of 
all tumors (Brodey, 1970; Miller et al., 2003). The low inci-
dence is attributed to the surgical removal of the uterus and 
ovaries in most dogs at early or late ages. The most common 
canine uterine tumors are leiomyomas, which are benign 
mesenchymal tumors most frequently observed in the vagi-
nal tract of dogs ( Herron, 1983). In cats, adenocarcinomas 
and leiomyomas have been identified ( Miller et al., 2003 ). 
Leiomyomas are characteristically noninvasive, slow-
growing tumors that can be difficult to distinguish from 
their malignant epithelial counterparts (leiomyosarcoma) 
without histological evaluation ( Herron, 1983 ). Clinical 
signs reported in dogs related to uterine tumors include ab-
normal estrus cycles, tenesmus, stranguria, and abdominal 
distension from large space-occupying lesions (Stein, 1981; 
Sontas et  al., 2010b ; Bottcher et  al., 2012). Most tumors 
are, however, diagnosed during an elective ovariohyster -
ectomy ( Miller et  al., 2003 ). Given their benign nature, 
lipoleiomyomas and leiomyomas offer a good long-term 
prognosis with successful surgical excision (Herron, 1983). 
Diagnostic imaging is an important step in determining the 
tissue of origin of abdominal masses and subsequent plan -
ning for treatment. However, the size and nature of large 
uterine masses can make the interpretation of abdominal ra-
diographs and ultrasonography challenging (Percival et al., 
2018). When diagnosed clinically, surgical removal of the 
tumor is the treatment of choice (Pervical et al., 2018).
3 Diseases of vagina
3.1 Vaginal fold prolapse
Vaginal fold prolapse (VFP) is the protrusion of edematous 
vaginal tissue into or through the vulvar opening ( Sontas 
et al., 2010a; Alan et al., 2007). Traditionally, this condition 
has been referred to as vaginal hyperplasia, vaginal hyper -
trophy, and vaginal prolapse. But it is not a true prolapse, 
because the protrusion only affects the vaginal mucosa and 
the extremely edematous vaginal tissue protrudes in thick 
folds; therefore, the condition is better referred to as vaginal 
fold prolapse (Purswell, 2000).
There is the involvement of the entire vaginal wall in 
the case of “true” prolapse ( Ortega-Pacheco et al., 2012 ). 
True vaginal prolapse (protrusion of normal vaginal tis -
sue through the vulvar lips) is a very rare condition in the 
bitches. Dystocia, tenesmus, constipation, or forced extrac-
tion of the male penis during the genital tie contribute to the 
occurrence of true prolapse (Purswell, 2000; Smith, 2003). 
Also reported due to increased intra-abdominal pressure 
secondary to ascites, and altered perineal and vulvar con -
formation after an injury (Johnston et al., 2001d).
3.1.1 Occurrence
VFP almost always occurs in intact bitches during proestrus 
and estrus. Following hyperplasia of the stratified squamous 
epithelium, intracellular edema and spongiosis of the vagi -
nal mucosa occur as a result of an exaggerated response of 
the vaginal mucosa to estrogens (Sontas et al., 2010a; Alan 
et al., 2007). VFP is a very rarely reported condition in cats 
(Johnston et al., 2001e; McKelvey et al., 2014).
3.1.2 Clinical manifestation
The most common clinical sign is a protrusion of a small 
bulge or pear-shaped or doughnut-shaped tumor-like vagi -
nal mass from the vulvar opening is in intact bitches during 
proestrus and estrus (Sontas et al., 2010a; Galal et al., 2018) 
(Figs. 3 and 4). Normal serosanguineous vulvar discharge of 
proestrus or estrus may be observed (Smith, 2003). Licking 
of the mass, difficulty in urination, and inability to copulate 
may be observed in some bitches ( Sontas et al., 2010a ). If 
the vaginal tissue remains exposed, excoriation of mucosa 
and trauma may be observed (Manothaiudom and Johnston, 
1991; Sontas et al., 2010a).
FIG. 3 Vaginal fold prolapse in a bitch.

Diseases of reproductive system of female dogs and cats  Chapter | 14  223
3.1.3 Diagnosis
Diagnosis can be made by clinical findings of the protruded 
vaginal mass from the vulvar opening. The clinical signs of 
proestrus and estrus (characteristic serosanguineous estrous 
discharge, and the presence of estrous behavior), and vagi -
nal cytology results (presence of cornified vaginal epithelial 
cells) can confirm the influence of estrogen.
3.1.4 Therapy
The approach of the treatment depends on the severity of 
the prolapsed mass, tissue viability, and desirability of 
future breeding ( Sontas et  al., 2010a ). In most cases, the 
prolapsed mass regresses spontaneously with the onset of 
diestrus. However, recurrence at the subsequent estrous cy-
cle is very common ( Johnston et al., 2001d). Occasionally, 
a vaginal prolapse persists throughout pregnancy. Usually, 
prolapsed mass does not cause dystocia; however, some as-
sistance may require.
The treatment includes either decreasing estrogen stim -
ulus in the animal, removing the prolapsed tissue, or both 
(Johnston et al., 2001d).
As a conservative treatment, affected dogs may be in -
duced to ovulate (decreasing estrogen stimulus) with an in-
jection of either GnRH (2.2  μg/kg, I/M]) or hCG (1000  IU, 
IM). Regression of the prolapse starts following ovula -
tion induction by about 1  week ( Johnston et  al., 2001d ). 
However, recurrence of vaginal prolapse is possible in sub-
sequent proestrus or estrus. Medroxyprogesterone acetate 
(50 mg subcutaneously) has also been reported for success-
ful resolution of vaginal prolapse within 15  days in some 
bitches but not recommended (Johnston et al., 2001d).
Manual reduction of the prolapsed mass and placement 
of purse-string sutures have also been reported as the suc -
cessful treatment for vaginal prolapse in dogs. But due to 
discomfort and perivulvar trauma by the purse-string su -
tures, the technique is not recommended ( Johnston et  al., 
2001d).
Circumferential excision of prolapsed tissue can be 
performed in dogs with large peduncular vaginal prolapse 
or severely inflamed or devitalized prolapsed vaginal tis -
sue. The everted vaginal tissue is cut off and the cut edges 
of the vaginal wall are opposed using chromic catgut in a 
simple interrupted suture pattern. Recurrence is possible in 
some bitches after the excision of prolapsed tissue, during 
the subsequent proestrus or estrus ( Johnston et al., 2001d ; 
Smith, 2003).
Ovariectomy or OHE is performed to permanently 
correct the condition as the gonadal source of estrogen is 
eliminated. The prolapsed mass regresses shortly after the 
removal of the ovaries (Johnston et al., 2001d; Smith, 2003).
3.2 Vaginal neoplasia
Vaginal neoplasia includes the tumors arising from the 
vestibule or vagina and accounts for 2.4%–3% of all ca -
nine tumors ( Smith, 2003; McEntee, 2002). The majority 
of these tumors are benign ( Smith, 2003; Ortega-Pacheco 
et al., 2012 ). Leiomyomas are the most commonly occur -
ring benign vaginal tumors in bitches together with fibro -
mas (Fig. 5) and fibroleiomyomas; other benign tumors like 
lipomas (Fig. 6), polyps, melanomas, myxomas, and myxo-
fibromas are much less frequent ( Ortega-Pacheco et  al., 
FIG. 4 Vaginal fold prolapse in a stray bitch.
FIG. 5 Fibroma in a bitch.

224 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
2012). Among malignant vaginal tumor, Leiomyosarcoma 
is the most common ( Smith, 2003) and others such as ad -
enocarcinoma, fibrosarcoma, squamous cell carcinoma, 
hemangiosarcoma, osteosarcoma, mast cell tumor are 
much less frequently occurring ( Withrow and Vail, 2007 ; 
Furneaux, 1979 ). In cats, vaginal tumors are uncommon 
and benign leiomyomas are the most commonly reported 
tumors (Ortega-Pacheco et al., 2012).
Transmissible venereal tumor (TVT) also known as 
canine transmissible venereal tumor, infectious sarcoma, 
venereal granuloma, transmissible lymphosarcoma, or 
Sticker tumor, is a benign reticuloendothelial tumor of the 
dog (Purohit, 2008). TVT is the most commonly occurring 
vaginal tumor in tropical developing countries; however, it 
is relatively uncommon in the United States and Canada 
(Ortega-Pacheco et al., 2012).
3.2.1 Occurrence
Bitch at any age can be affected with vaginal neoplasia; 
however, the risk increases with the advancement of age in 
intact dogs (Thacher and Bradley, 1983; Smith, 2003). TVT 
is more common in young, free-roaming, intact bitches 
(Smith, 2003 ). Pathogenesis of vaginal/vulvar neoplasia 
(other than TVT) is unknown and may be dependent on the 
ovarian hormones (Johnston et al., 2001d). TVT arises from 
an allogeneic cellular transplant. Transmission of TVT oc -
curs through transplantation of neoplastic cells onto vaginal 
mucosa by an affected dog during coitus, and onto nasal 
and oral mucosa by licking of affected genitalia of self or 
other dogs ( Johnston et  al., 2001d ). TVT is a unique ex -
ample of a naturally occurring tumor that transmits as an 
allograft by cell transplantation, and the tumor becomes 
autonomous (Purohit, 2008). Metastasis of TVT is uncom -
mon, only occurring in puppies and immuno-compromised 
dogs (Purohit, 2008).
3.2.2 Clinical manifestation
The clinical signs commonly associated with vaginal neo -
plasia may include perineal enlargement, the presence of a 
mass within the vulva or protruding from the vulva (Fig. 7), 
mucoid, mucopurulent, or sanguineous vulvar discharge, 
vulvar licking, anorexia, weight loss tenesmus, dysuria, 
polyuria, and polydipsia ( Smith, 2003 ; Johnston et  al., 
2001d).
3.2.3 Diagnosis
Diagnosis of the vaginal tumors is made by physical ex -
amination and confirmed by cytology or histopathology 
of the mass ( Smith, 2003 ; Ortega-Pacheco et  al., 2012 ). 
Vaginoscopic examination may be helpful to localize the 
growth of the tumor within the vaginal canal ( Johnston 
et  al., 2001d). Differentiation of the tumors from vaginal 
fold prolapse can be made by evaluating the stage of the 
estrous cycle and the relationship of vaginal mass with the 
onset of signs, location of the mass, and failure of the mass 
to regress postestrus. A vaginal mass present in a spayed 
bitch, or in an intact bitch unrelated to the estrous cycle, 
should be considered a vaginal tumor ( Smith, 2003). TVT 
may be vegetative and ulcerated (Smith, 2003), and can be 
diagnosed by its typical cauliflower-like or nodular appear-
ance and by the presence of typical round cells in impres -
sion smears (Purohit et al., 2004).
3.2.4 Treatment
As most of the vaginal neoplasms are benign in nature, 
complete surgical resection is usually curative and the treat-
ment of choice (Smith, 2003; Ortega-Pacheco et al., 2012). 
FIG. 6 Lipoma in a bitch.
FIG. 7 A German Shepherd bitch with TVT.

Diseases of reproductive system of female dogs and cats  Chapter | 14  225
Sometimes, an episiotomy may be required for complete 
visualization of the tumor mass ( Johnston et  al., 2001d ). 
OHE at the time of surgical resection of vaginal masses 
may be beneficial as it eliminates the hormonal influence 
and the possibility of recurrence of the tumor (Smith, 2003; 
Johnston et  al., 2001d ). TVT responds readily to chemo -
therapy. Administration of vincristine (0.025  mg/kg body 
weight) slowly intravenously at weekly intervals causes 
complete regression of the tumor; two to seven therapies 
may require (Smith, 2003).
4 Other diseases
4.1 Canine pseudopregnancy
Canine clinical pseudopregnancy (CPP) as the name sug -
gests is a clinical entity observed in nonpregnant bitch with 
clinical signs like those observed in pregnant bitch such as 
nesting, weight gain, mammary enlargement, and lactation 
(Gobello et  al., 2001a ). CPP has been classified as overt 
(with clinical signs) or covert and researchers consider that 
physiological pseudopregnancy (covert) occurs in every 
nonpregnant ovarian cycle in bitches (Gobello et al., 2001a). 
CPP is one of the most common clinical entities observed in 
clinical evaluations with the prevalence of 5%–32% (Nagar 
et al., 2008; Kumar et al., 2011).
4.1.1 Etiology
The exact etiology of CPP continues to be poorly known. 
The pituitary hormone prolactin plays a central role in the 
pathophysiology of overt CPP, but its exact role is not com-
pletely understood ( Grunau et  al., 1996 ). CPP appears to 
be related to and dependent on a previous prolonged, and 
in most cases a very recent, exposure to elevated levels of 
progesterone. Further, it has been suggested, based on indi-
rect evidence, that pseudopregnancy may occur because of 
increased concentrations of prolactin or an increased sen -
sitivity to prolactin induced by a more rapid than the nor -
mal decline of progesterone levels in the late luteal phase 
(Smith and McDonald, 1974 ; Graff et  al., 1977 ). In fact, 
spaying or ovariectomy during the luteal phase (i.e., dur -
ing metestrus/diestrus) induces pseudopregnancy in some 
bitches ( Gobello et  al., 2001b ). The potential causes of 
overt pseudopregnancy were previously reviewed (Gobello 
et al., 2001a).
4.1.2 Clinical findings
Bitches with CPP evidence signs of whelping including 
mammary enlargement, nesting, vomiting, and mother -
ing behavior ( Kumar et  al., 2011 ; Gobello et  al., 2001a ). 
In a large survey in UK behavioral changes, collecting and 
mothering objects was the most frequently reported behav-
ioral sign (96%), and 97% had some aggression (Root et al., 
2018). The most reported physical sign in this study was 
enlarged mammary glands and/or milk production (89%). 
Thus, dogs are referred to when one or more of these signs 
are observed. Ultrasound examination in dogs with pseu -
dopregnancy is used to rule out pregnancy ( Kumar et al., 
2011). No specific finding is observed on the ultrasound 
scan of CPP bitches. A small proportion of bitches (0.9%) 
with CPP evidence focal widening of uterine horn with 
ovoid masses termed pseudo-placentational endometrial 
hyperplasia (Marino et al., 2021).
4.1.3 Therapy
The therapy depends upon the severity of behavioral signs, 
owners’ preference, concurrent disease, and cost ( Marino 
et al., 2021). Not all bitches require therapy and mild cases 
may resolve spontaneously ( Gobello et  al., 2001a ). The 
permanent solution to the condition is spaying and af -
fected bitches should be spayed during anestrus ( Gobello 
et al., 2001b; Lee et al., 2006 ). Medical therapy includes 
the use of sex steroids (estrogens, androgens, and proges -
tins) and dopamine agonists (bromocriptine, cabergoline, 
and metergoline). The use of sex steroids for therapy of 
CPP has become less common ( Marino et al., 2021 ) and 
48% of the bitches with CPP were treated with bromocrip -
tine at the dose rate of 10–100  μg/kg/day or cabergoline 
5 μg/kg/day for 5–10  days has been suggested for the re -
mission of behavioral signs of CPP ( Gobello et al., 2001a ; 
Nagar et al., 2008 ). Bromocriptine may evoke some vom -
iting and thus should be administered in divided doses and 
prior administration of promethazine is suggested ( Grunau 
et al., 1996).

Chapter 15
Diseases of endocrine system in  
dogs and cats
1 Introduction
The endocrine system comprises a network of ductless 
glands, and the hormones produced by the endocrine glands 
directly enter into the bloodstream (or) lymph (or) tissue 
fluids. The hypothalamus is the central gland that produces 
releasing hormones which controls the whole endocrine 
system and is placed at the base of the brain and link the 
endocrine system with the nervous system. The master 
gland or pituitary gland (or hypophysis) responds to the 
stimuli produced by the hypothalamus (releasing hormone) 
and produces stimulating hormones and are send to indi -
vidual organs. Endocrine organs include the thyroid gland, 
parathyroid gland, adrenal glands (medulla and cortex), 
pituitary gland (anterior and posterior), pancreas (islets of 
Langerhans), ovaries, and testes (Figs. 1 and 2).
Canines and felines, particularly dogs and cats, had kin 
endocrine abnormalities similar to humans. These compan-
ion animals shared the same living area with human beings 
and live with us until their demise, granting the opportu -
nity for precise observation studies of the disease process. 
Further long-term studies on companion animals made the 
availability of their genomes for additional inventive re -
search. Additionally, canine genomes had a higher degree of 
analogy with human counterparts than laboratory animals 
such as mice and rats ( Dackowski et al., 2002 ; Tan et al., 
2002). To a great extent, companion animals also serve as 
a animal models for human endocrine illness. On that ac -
count, this chapter encloses several endocrine disorders of 
companion animals.
2 Hypothyroidism
2.1 Anatomy and pathophysiology
Dogs and cats have a pair of thyroid glands, a pair of elon -
gated lobes, located in front of the neck, caudal to the lar -
ynx, on either side of the trachea, about the level of the fifth 
to eighth tracheal cartilage, and the size of the gland dif -
fers by breed and body weight of the animals. The thyroid 
hormone is very much essential for normal growth, main -
tenance, and metabolism. Iodine is the chief element that 
plays a vital role in thyroid hormone production and gland 
health. Hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism were con -
sidered to be the most important endocrinopathies in dogs 
and cats due to either less or higher secretion of thyroid 
hormones (Thyroxine; T4), respectively. Hypothyroidism 
leads to a sluggish metabolism, and the associated signs are 
dermatological and associated organ dysfunctions. Primary 
hypothyroidism results from lymphocytic thyroiditis, an au-
toimmune disease, and is common in adults, characterized 
by primary irreversible destruction of the thyroid gland or 
idiopathic thyroid degeneration. Secondary hypothyroid -
ism is associated with abnormal functioning (or) anatomi -
cal changes in the hypothalamus-pituitary axis leading to 
insufficient production of thyroid-stimulating hormone 
(TSH) from the pituitary gland. Tertiary hypothyroidism is 
rare and is attributable to deficient secretion of thyrotropin-
releasing hormone (TRH) from the hypothalamus (Fig. 3).
2.2 Clinical signs
Clinical signs like lethargy, obesity, puffy skin 
(Myxoedema), tragic facial expression, exercise intoler -
ance, mental dullness, hypothermia or cold intolerance, 
reduced drug metabolism, bradycardia, hypotension, and 
dermatological abnormalities include brittle hair coat, bi -
lateral symmetrical nonpruritic alopecia, dorsal scaling, hy-
perpigmentation, seborrheic dermatitis, rat tail appearance, 
discoloration of coat, circular alopecia, dry and thickened 
skin; either of the combinations would facilitate the suspect 
of hypothyroidism. Other signs, neurological changes like 
ataxia, hypermetria, head tilt, cranial nerve changes, ocular 
changes like corneal lipid deposition, and reproductive dis-
orders are also reported (Fig. 4).

230 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
FIG. 1 Endocrine system of dogs (L. Lokesh and B. Anil Kumar).
FIG. 2 The endocrine system of cats (L. Lokesh and B. Anil Kumar).
FIG. 3 Hypothalamo-pituitary and thyroid axis.

Diseases of endocrine system in dogs and cats   Chapter | 15  231
2.3 Diagnosis
Hypothyroidism is said to be over diagnosed endocrinop -
athy in canines due to long duration of preclinical phase 
and high test specificity. Confirmation of hypothyroidism 
is strenuous by virtue of diverse clinical signs and the un -
availability of a single appropriate laboratory test. However, 
lower-circulating thyroid hormone (T4) levels with high-
circulating TSH confirm hypothyroidism in most of the 
clinical cases. Nevertheless, normal TSH concentration is 
detected in more or less 13%–38% of hypothyroid dogs 
(Ramsey et  al., 1997 ). Hence, hypothyroidism should be 
excluded if dogs have normal TSH concentration. Besides 
that, the high reference range of both hormones in the canine 
population exasperates and makes it tough to confirm the 
same in dogs. Assessment of total T4 concentrationwould 
help in screening hypothyroidism due to its high test sen -
sitivity (89%–100%) ( Dixon and Mooney, 1999 ). If the 
dog has a low T4 concentration, further assessment of free 
T4 (fT4) and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is sug -
gested. The combination of T4, fT4, and TSH assessment 
effectively rules out hypothyroidism. On top of normal 
daily fluctuations, several medications (Trimethoprim-
Sulfamethoxazole, Phenobarbitone, Glucocorticoids, 
Ketoprofen, and Carprofen) and nonthyroidal illnesses 
(Euthyroid sick syndrome) pave the way to lower serum T4 
concentrations and also affect fT4 and TSH concentrations 
(Hall et al., 1993). Yet fT4 concentrations are less likely to 
be affected by concurrent illnesses (Kantrowitz et al., 2001; 
Torres et al., 2003). For that reason, thyroid testing will not 
be preferred to perform on systemically ill dogs. However, 
in certain unavoidable circumstances, if at all test is done 
on a dog with concurrent illness, the results should be inter-
preted cautiously. Wide variations of T3 concentration make 
it an impractical tool for the diagnosis of hypothyroidism.
FIG. 4 Clinical presentation of dogs affected with hypothyroidism. (A) Tragic face. (B) Rat tail appearance. (C) Hyperpigmentation. (D) Bilateral 
patchy alopecia.

232 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
2.4 Treatment
Levothyroxine is the standard of care for hypothyroidism 
owing to its low cost and high efficacy. According to the 
clinician, the preferred dose (0.02  mg/kg) should be given 
on an empty stomach, early morning, given once daily 
orally (or) initially twice daily (morning and evening) and 
followed by once daily. Lethargy generally builds on a few 
weeks of therapy and after 4–6  weeks of therapy. A recog-
nizable improvement would be noticed in most of the signs, 
while dermatological issues take months to resolve. Postpill 
reassessment has to be done 4 weeks after therapy, and the 
dose should be adjusted according to the test results. If the 
postpill concentration is lower than the reference range, the 
dose can be increased to 25% (or) the postpill concentration 
is higher than the reference range, the dose can be reduced 
to 25% and rechecked after 4  weeks. Reassessment should 
be done initially once every 4 weeks, and once the effective 
establishment of the dose is done, reassessment can be done 
once every 6 months. Importantly, levothyroxine should be 
administered cautiously in cardiac patients as it may cause 
cardiac abnormalities.
3 Hyperthyroidism
Hyperthyroidism also referred to as thyrotoxicosis, results in 
a multisystemic disorder due to the high production of thy-
roxine (T4) and triiodothyronine, which is frequently encoun-
tered in aged cats of more than 9 years of age (Caney, 2014).
3.1 Clinical signs
Systemic signs noticed in thyrotoxicosis are weight loss, 
polydipsia, polyuria, and polyphagia along with hyperactiv-
ity, vomiting, diarrhea, along with the accompanied derma-
tological issues like matted and greasy hair coat.
3.2 Diagnosis
Physically palpable enlargement of the thyroid gland, along 
with the elevated T4 level, confirms hyperthyroidism in 
cats. However, a small percentage of cats may have normal 
T4 levels in thyrotoxicosis. Thyroid scintigraphy confirms 
thyrotoxicosis in suspected cats. This condition also leads 
to cardiac and renal problems; hence, serum biochemical 
profile and echocardiography should be advised to rule out 
such concurrent illness.
3.3 Treatment
Therapy of hyperthyroidism could be targeted in four forms, 
as per the owner’s convenience and the health status of the 
cat. It could be practiced by oral medication (or) radioac -
tive iodine therapy (or) surgical intervention (or) dietary 
protocol.
Oral therapy involves antithyroid medications, which are 
readily available and less expensive. Some animals experi -
ence vomiting, anorexia, anemia, and fever with weakness.
Radioactive iodine therapy is less commonly available 
and is expensive. This therapy will be curative to the cats. 
However, these radioactive substances should be used only 
by licensed vets with the "as low as reasonably achievable" 
(ALARA) principle to avoid environmental contamination. 
Rarely improper (or) higher doses may lead to hypothyroid-
ism, necessitating thyroid hormone supplementation.
Surgical thyroidectomy would give a long-term and per-
manent cure in many cats. However, it is invasive and needs 
blood, cardiac and kidney evaluation before proceeding to 
surgical protocol, and there may be a chance for permanent 
damage to the parathyroid gland.
The dietary protocol involves the dietary restriction of 
iodine. Such long-term reduction in iodine may lead to an 
overall reduction in health status.
4 Diabetes mellitus
Diabetes mellitus (DM) is one of the following common re-
ported endocrine disorders in canines, with an overall preva-
lence of 0.3% to 1.3% (Guptill et al., 2003). This disorder is 
consistently reported in bitches and middle to older-aged pets.
4.1 Factors and pathophysiology
Disruption of carbohydrates, protein, fat, and metabolism 
will induce an absolute (or) relative insulin deficiency. 
Insulin, the pancreatic endocrine hormone, helps in the di -
etary conversion of glucose (the primary body's main en -
ergy source) from proteins in the blood and activates the 
liver cells and muscles to take up glucose from the blood, 
leading to hyperglycemia (Fig. 5).
Insulin-dependent DM (comparable with type 1 DM 
in humans) is associated with immune-mediated affection 
of beta cells of the pancreas responsible for insulin secre -
tion. Autoimmune mechanisms (in >50% of diabetic dogs), 
rarely pancreatic vacuolar degeneration and pancreatitis also 
account for the occurrence of DM ( Davison et al., 2008 ). 
Hypothyroidism, hyperadrenocorticism, other hormonal 
(or) iatrogenic insulin-resistance triggers were concur -
rently reported along with DM ( Hess et al., 2000). Insulin-
resistant (or) type 2 DM (similar to type 2 DM in humans) is 
most commonly reported in cats (O’Brien, 2002). Impaired 
insulin secretion and insulin resistance may have a genetic 
predisposition. Factors like a low (or) absence of physical 
activity and concurrent obesity may also precipitate the dis-
ease occurrence (Slingerland et al., 2009). Growth hormone 
excess due to a functional somatotrophic pituitary adenoma 
is also reported as the cause of diabetes mellitus in cats. 
Disorders such as progesterone-induced GH excess (or) hy-
percortisolism often precipitate DM (Fig. 6).

Diseases of endocrine system in dogs and cats   Chapter | 15  233
4.2 Clinical signs
Loss of weight with polyphagia, polyuria and polydipsia 
are the principle signs, and vomiting, along with poor coat 
quality, is also reported in most of the clinical cases.
4.3 Diagnosis
Pathognomonic clinical signs and fasting blood glucose 
estimation confirm the disease. The normal reported ref -
erence range of blood glucose levels is 80–120  mg/dL 
(4.4–6.6 mmoL/L). The high caloric meal may raise the 
value up to 250–300 mg/dL (13.6–16.5 mmoL/L). However, 
in typica a l DM case, the value will be above 400  mg/dL 
(22 mmoL/L) of blood glucose, with a range of 400–600 mg/
dL (22–33  mmoL/L) and above should be considered as 
DM. Usually kidney conserves glucose, but once blood 
sugar reaches 180 mg/dL or above (above the renal threshold 
limit), kidney removes excess glucose through urine, termed 
glucosuria (Kumar et al., 2014 ). High levels of stress also 
induce glucosuria and can be differentiated from DM by the 
assessment of serum fructosamine (a compound formed by 
FIG. 5 Pathophysiology of type 1 diabetes mellitus.
FIG. 6 Pathophysiology of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

234 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
a nonenzymatic covalent bond between a sugar (fructose 
or glucose) and a protein (largely albumin)) level. Stress 
induces sudden changes in blood glucose levels, but fruc -
tosamine gives collective of report of 2–3 weeks helping in 
identifying the cause ( Elliott et al., 1999 ). Elevated serum 
fructosamine concentration confirms diabetes mellitus.
4.4 Treatment
4.4.1 Dietary management
Dietary supplementation with high complex carbohydrates 
(>50% DM) and high fiber (>10% DM) are indicated to min-
imize the postprandial fluctuations in blood glucose and ad-
ditionally help to potentiate insulin action. High-soluble fiber 
(fruits, legumes, and oats) in the diet promotes insulin action 
by delaying gastric emptying and high intestinal transit time.
4.4.2 Insulin therapy in dogs
Humulin N (NPH) and Lente insulins (Caninsulin/
Vetsulin) are most commonly used at the starting dose of 
0.25–0.5 IU/kg twice a day in dogs. Lente insulin (mix -
ture of ultra-Lente and semi-Lente insulin) has to be given 
once daily as it has a longer duration of action compared 
to NPH. Nearly 30% of dogs have adequate glycemic con -
trol with once-a-day lente insulin therapy. Human recom -
binant insulin and pure pork insulin should be avoided in 
animals due to the development of anti-insulin antibodies. 
Long-acting insulins such as protamine zinc insulin (PZI), 
Glargine and Detemir are not recommended for the initial 
therapy and management.
4.4.3 Transsphenoidal hypophysectomy
Transsphenoidal hypophysectomy practice will not only 
cause remission of acromegaly but also quite often leads to 
the resolution of diabetes mellitus in cats (Meij et al., 2004).
5 Hyperadrenocorticism (HAC)  
(or) Cushing’s syndrome
5.1 Factors and pathophysiology
Hyperadrenocorticism (HAC) or Cushing’s syndrome is 
resulted due to chronic over production of cortisol and is 
commonly reported in older dogs above 8 years of age, and 
females are predisposed. Poodles, Dachshunds, Terriers, 
and Beagles are reported to be at high risk but rarely re -
ported in cats. Based on the primary cause, there are three 
forms of Cushing’s syndrome in dogs that are pituitary de -
pendent hyperadrenocorticism (PDH), adrenal-dependent 
hyperadrenocorticism (ADH), and iatrogenic HAC. PDA 
(functional corticotrophin adenoma) is most commonly 
(80%–85%) reported both in dogs and cats wherein, a pitu-
itary tumor may arise from the anterior lobe or the pars in -
termedia of the pituitary gland. In the remaining 15%–20%, 
it results due to ADH (functional adrenocortical adenoma or 
carcinoma), and rarely ectopic adrenocorticotropin secre -
tion or food-dependent hypercortisolism is reported in dogs 
(Galac et al., 2005, 2008 ). HAC is a significant, complex 
and dangerous disease with a wide array of clinical signs 
with further complications with other disorders like diabe -
tes mellitus usually (Fig. 7).
FIG. 7 Pathophysiology of hyperadrenocorticism (HAC) (or) Cushing’s syndrome.

Diseases of endocrine system in dogs and cats   Chapter | 15  235
5.2 Clinical signs
Excess steroid secretion in the body causes muscle weak -
ness, delayed wound healing, generalized neuropathies 
and coagulation abnormalities. Pathognomonic signs of 
Cushing’s disease includes pot-bellied abdomen, weight 
gain, muscle weakness, along with systemic signs like 
polyuria, polydipsia, polyphagia, hepatomegaly, dyspnea, 
exercise intolerance, reproductive disorders, classical der -
matological signs such as symmetrical nonpruritic bilateral 
truncal alopecia, hyperpigmentation, hypotonic thin skin, 
numerous comedones, prominent ventral abdominal vascu-
lature and scaling (Fig. 8).
5.3 Diagnosis
5.3.1 Serum biochemistry
Marked elevation in serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP), ala-
nine aminotransferase (AST), moderate hyperglycemia, hy-
percholesterolemia, hypertriglyceridemia, low blood urea 
and may also be combined with hypothyroxinemia.
5.3.2 Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) 
stimulation test
A most commonly used screening test and can help spon -
taneous differentiation of iatrogenic hyperadrenocorticism 
with high sensitivity in PDH (85%) and moderate sensitiv -
ity in ADH (65%). However, these results can be influenced 
by stress.
5.3.3 Low-dose dexamethasone suppression 
test
More sensitive and reliable test than the ACTH stimulation 
test; however, affected by stress and cannot detect iatro -
genic Cushing’s disease.
5.3.4 Urinary cortisol: Creatinine ratio
The urinary cortisol-to-creatinine ratio of above 300 is con-
sidered positive, and below 5 is negative. However, this test 
has a very low specificity. Other tests should be done in 
order to differentiate PDH and ADH, even after UC:CR 
test. These include the high-dose dexamethasone suppres -
sion test (HDDST), ultrasound of adrenal glands and en -
dogenous ACTH measurement.
5.4 Treatment
Hypophysectomy is preferred in dogs with pituitary tumors. 
The drug Trilostane (3–5  mg/kg) can be administered as a 
palliative therapy. In ADH cases, mitotane is the recom -
mended drug. Alternatively, radiotherapy and adrenalec -
tomy may also be done for quick recovery.
6 Hypoadrenocorticism (or) Addison’s 
disease
Hypoadrenocorticism is a primary disease of dogs resulting 
due to complete damage to adrenal glands causing insufficient 
production of corticosteroids, aldosterone, and cortisol. These 
steroid hormones are vital for the maintenance of blood vol-
ume, pressure, and to alleviate stress. Most of the cases are un-
derdiagnosed or misdiagnosed, as the physiological effect of 
this disorder is vague and also confused with other disorders.
6.1 Clinical signs
Addison’s disease is characterized by gastrointestinal dis -
orders (polydipsia), polyuria, hypovolemia, hypotension, 
poor stress tolerance, shivering with or without tremors and 
muscle stiffness.
6.2 Therapy
This disorder can be clinically managed with desoxycor -
ticosterone pivalate (DOCP), a prolonged-release suspen -
sion and is given subcutaneously once monthly. This drug 
controls serum electrolytes more effectively than other drug 
formulations, such as fludrocortisone ( Baumstark et  al., 
2014). Apart from this, dogs may also require daily oral 
medication with prednisolone.
Rarely, there may be sudden onset of clinical signs 
resulting in hormonal imbalances causing hypovolemic 
shock, collapse and renal failure, which is referred to as an 
Addisonian crisis.
7 Primary hypoparathyroidism
Primary hypoparathyroidism refers to the complete absence 
or deficiency of parathyroid hormone (PTH), resulting in 
hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia. This condition may 
FIG. 8 Bilateral alopecia and bruising of the skin in hyperadrenocorti -
cism (HAC) (or) Cushing’s syndrome.

236 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
happen due to accidental damage or removal of the parathy-
roid gland (iatrogenic) during thyroidectomy or trauma to 
the neck. Clinical signs are similar to hypocalcemia, such 
as tetany, muscle spasm and tonic-clonic seizures. It can be 
managed with intra venous calcium therapy followed by 
intramuscular and oral supplementation with calcium as di-
rected by a physician. However, long-term calcium therapy 
is indicated in this condition.
8 Primary hyperparathyroidism
Constant secretion of PTH will lead to primary hyper -
parathyroidism and resulting in hypercalcemia and hypo -
phosphatemia. This condition may also happen due to a 
functional parathyroid tumor. This is characterized by poly-
dipsia and polyuria along with weight loss, muscle wasting, 
muscle tremor, lethargy, and exercise intolerance.
9 Secondary hyperparathyroidism
Chronic kidney disease, calcium or vitamin D deficiency 
is related to secondary hyperparathyroidism. Many times, 
it is a complication of chronic kidney disease. Sometimes, 
high phosphorus intake leads to relative or total calcium de-
ficiency (secondary hypocalcemia) owing to high calcium 
binding in the gut and reduced absorption. Lifelong calcium 
supplementation with complete blood workouts at regular 
intervals along with dietary changes, can be used to manage 
this syndrome.
10 Hyperaldosteronism in cats
Hyperaldosteronism in cats is the most commonly reported 
adrenal cortical disorder. It occurs as a consequence of adre-
nocortical neoplasia or idiopathic adrenocortical hyperpla -
sia (Javadi et al., 2005). This causes rise in systemic arterial 
pressure due to profuse aldosterone secretion and further 
results in potassium depletion (hypokalemia). Classical 
signs are paroxysmal flaccid paresis, acute blindness due to 
retinal detachment, intraocular hemorrhage and target organ 
(kidney, heart or brain) damage. Elevated plasma aldoste -
rone: renin ratio confirms the disorder in cats. The fludro -
cortisone acetate suppression test is the indicated diagnostic 
test (Djajadiningrat-Laanen et al., 2008).
11 Sex-hormone dermatoses
Sex-hormone dermatoses occur due to gonadal or adrenal 
dysfunctions. Generally, in these conditions, systemic signs 
are not reported; however, ill-defined dermatological signs 
such as alopecia and lesions at caudal ventrum and genita -
lia, spread to the limbs, flanks and neck. Some cases may 
exhibit seborrheic skin lesions and ceruminous otitis ex -
terna. Identification of neoplasia (Sertolicell tumor/Leydig 
cell tumor/Seminoma) or abnormal sex hormone levels in 
blood help to diagnose this disorder. Adrenal-related sex-
hormone dermatoses can be diagnosed by pre- and post-
ACTH assessment.
12 Hyperestrogenism
Hyperestrogenism is commonly reported in intact fe -
male dogs owing to the conditions like polycystic ovar -
ian disease, ovarian neoplasia, and iatrogenic causes. 
Gynecomastia, vulvar hypertrophy, abnormal estrus cycle 
together with anemia, ecchymoses, petechiae, epistaxis, 
melena, or hematuria (due to bone marrow suppression) 
are frequently reported signs in this case. Commonly der -
matological manifestations encountered in these conditions 
are alopecia of the abdomen, neck and caudal aspects of 
the thighs, perineum, seborrhea, otitis externa, and second-
ary bacterial pyoderma and Malassezia pachy dermatitis. 
Diagnosis is made by eliminating other causes of dermatitis 
and by ultrasonography to delineate ovarian abnormalities. 
Ovariohysterectomy is the only permanent solution to re -
solve this condition (Fig. 9).
13 Hyperandrogenism
Testicular neoplasia or functional abnormalities in older 
male dogs would cause hyperandrogenism and are also re -
ported rarely in spayed females with pituitary dependent 
hyperadrenocorticism (PDH). The dermatological signs 
FIG. 9 Sex-hormone dermatoses characterized by hyperpigmentation of 
the ventral abdomen.

Diseases of endocrine system in dogs and cats   Chapter | 15  237
noticed are hyperplasia of tail gland and perianal gland, 
patchy hyperpigmentation in the anogenital area and seb -
orrheic dermatitis. Diagnosis is made by history, physical 
examination and assessment of blood testosterone levels. 
Positive response will be appreciated after castration and is 
considered as a therapeutic diagnosis. Ultrasonography is 
indicated for detecting nonpalpable testicular tumors.
14 Immune-mediated endocrine 
deficiency syndromes
Immune-mediated (or) autoimmune endocrine hormone 
deficiency syndrome (or) autoimmune polyglandular syn -
dromes are reported commonly in humans. It can be of two 
types, one is a type I autoimmune polyglandular syndrome 
which includes conditions like hypoparathyroidism, hy -
poadrenocorticism, cutaneous candidiasis and other, and 
type II autoimmune polyglandular syndrome comprising 
hypoadrenocorticism, primary hypothyroidism, insulin-
dependent diabetes mellitus, hyperthyroidism, myasthenia 
gravis, hypogonadism, celiac disease. In dogs, only type II 
autoimmune polyglandular syndrome is reported, incorpo -
rating hypoadrenocorticism and hypothyroidism. Primary 
hypothyroidism is commonly reported in dogs; however, 
hypoadrenocorticism and hypoparathyroidism are not un -
common in dogs but infrequent in cats. These conditions are 
considered to be the end stage of progressive autoimmune 
destruction and are associated with a high incidence of cir -
culating antibodies treatment.
