Chapter 16
Diseases of the nervous system  
of dogs and cats
1 Introduction
The nervous system is known as the “master system” because 
it regulates the operation of all other systems and organs. 
Except for blood vessels and some neurological elements, 
the nervous system is derived from ectoderm. Anatomically 
the nervous system is divided into two parts: central and pe-
ripheral. The central nervous system consists of the brain and 
spinal cord, which are located within the cranial cavity and 
spinal canal, respectively (vertebral canal). Higher functions 
such as intelligence, memory, emotions, and learning are 
housed in the central nervous system (Tables 1 and 2).
Cranial nerves, spinal nerves, and ganglia associated 
with cranial and spinal nerves comprise the peripheral ner -
vous system. There are 12 pairs of cranial nerves, and the 
number of spinal nerves varies by species.
The nervous system is functionally divided into afferent 
and efferent nervous systems. The afferent nervous system 
brings sensory information to the CNS, whereas the effer -
ent nervous system carries motor commands to muscles and 
glands. It contains both visceral and somatic components. The 
somatic nervous system provides voluntary control over skel-
etal muscle contraction. The visceral component, also known 
as the autonomic nervous system, provides involuntary in -
nervations to structures such as the heart, glands, and smooth 
muscle. This is also known as the “Self-controlling Nervous 
System.” The sympathetic nervous system and the parasym-
pathetic nervous system are subsets of the autonomic nervous 
system. Because sympathetic preganglionic neurons originate 
in the thoracolumbar region (T1 to L2 spinal segment), it is 
referred to as thoracolumbar outflow. Preganglionic neurons 
of the parasympathetic nervous system originate in the cranio-
facial region (general visceral nuclei + S2, S3, S4).
2 Cells of the nervous system
The cells of the nervous system are broadly classified into 
two categories: nerve cells or neurons, and supporting cells 
or neuroglial cells.
2.1 Neurons
The structural and operational components of the nervous 
system are called neurons. These cells are found in the white 
matter of the brain but are found in the gray matter of the 
spinal cord. These neurons are made up of an axon, a cell 
body, and dendrites. The nucleus is a group of nerve cell 
bodies found in the central nervous system. It is referred to 
as ganglia if it is located outside the central nervous system.
Neurons are classified anatomically into unipolar, bipo-
lar, and multipolar neurons based on the number of nerve 
processing ends extending from the cell body. Neurons are 
classified as Golgi type-I or type-II based on the length of 
their axon and dendrite. Golgi type-I neurons have a long 
axon and a short dendrite (for example, pyramidal cells of 
the cerebral cortex and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum), 
whereas Golgi type-II neurons have axon length equal to 
dendrite length (for example stellate cells of the cerebrum, 
cerebellum). Neurons are divided into two types based on 
their function: sensory neurons and motor neurons. Sensory 
neurons send impulses from the periphery to the CNS, while 
motor neurons send impulses from the CNS to muscles and 
glands. Upper motor neurons and lower motor neurons 
are the two types of motor neurons in the somatic nervous 
system. Upper motor neurons control voluntary muscular 
activity and have cell bodies in the brain, whereas lower 
motor neurons have cell bodies in the brain stem and spinal 
cord. Similarly, neurons in the autonomic nervous system 
are classified as postganglionic neurons or preganglionic 
neurons.
2.2 Neuroglial cells or supporting cells
The CNS contains four types of supporting cells: astrocytes, 
ependymal cells, oligodendrocytes, and microglial cells. 
Astrocytes are the largest and most numerous supporting 
cells. They play an important role in the nervous system 
as support cells. The blood-brain barrier is formed by as -
trocytes. Ependymal cells are mostly found in the choroid

240 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
plexus and the spinal canal’s ventricle. Cerebrospinal fluid 
is secreted by them. In the CNS, oligodendrocytes form 
myelin sheaths around axons. In the peripheral nervous 
system, it is carried by Schwann cells. Microglia cells are 
white blood cells, generally not found in the CNS. Their 
main function is to provide protection.
3 Cranial nerves
Cranial nerves are nerves that emerge from the brain di -
rectly. There are 12 pairs of cranial nerves that carry out 
various functions such as vision, hearing, sensation, and so 
on. Table 2 lists the functions and common signs of dys -
function of 12 pairs of cranial nerves:
4 Diagnosis of neurological problems  
in dogs and cats
Diagnosis of neurological disease needs multiple diagnos -
tic procedures or protocols to arrive at a definitive diag -
nosis. These may include blood analysis, imaging of the 
brain, cerebrospinal fluid analysis, and neurophysiology 
studies. The accuracy of diagnosis depends on the tests em-
ployed. A single test is not sufficient to arrive at a definitive 
diagnosis.

4.1 History and signalment
While taking a history, a series of questions should be asked 
to determine the most likely cause of the primary complaint. 
It must include information such as present complaint, pre-
vious illness, vaccination status, possible trauma, exposure 
to toxins, familial problems, current medication, and animal 
details such as age, breed, and gender, all of which aid in 
making a definitive diagnosis (LeCouteur, 2009a; Platt and 
Olby, 2015).
It is critical to determine the onset and progression of 
neurological disorders when diagnosing them. Neurological 
disorders are classified into the following categories based 
on their onset and progression:
A. Neonatal nonprogressive: This is a condition in which 
young animals do not develop gradually, but rather ap -
pear shortly after birth and remain unchanged through -
out their lives.
B. Acute progressive: This is a condition that develops af-
ter an acute insult and worsens rapidly or within 72 h of 
the event.
C. Acute nonprogressive: This is a condition that appears 
immediately or within 72  h of an event and remains 
unchanged.
D. Chronic progressive: This is a condition that develops 
gradually and has signs that worsen over a period of 
days, weeks, or months.
E. Episodic: The animal exhibits signs for a short period of 
time before returning to normalcy.
The most crucial diagnostic procedures for determin -
ing neurological illnesses are history and clinical signs. 
Before making a final diagnosis, it is important to be able 
to determine whether the condition is neurological or not. 
If it is neurological, should identify whether is it connected 
to the brain, spinal cord, or neuromuscular system? The 
clinical problem differential list should be created after lo -
calization. A memory aid like VITAMIN D or DAMN IT 
V system ( Table  3) can be used to finish the differential 
list without missing any medical conditions ( LeCouteur, 
2009a; Stassen, 2011). Signalment, onset, progression, and 
symmetry of neurological signs help to prepare a list of 
differentials.
4.2 Physical examination
Detailed physical examination is very important to iden -
tify and localize the neurological problem ( LeCouteur, 
2009a). Neurological disorder can manifest as deficit in 
movement coordination, balance, hearing, and vision. In 
cats, hindquarters weakness may result from a potassium 
deficit rather than from spinal damage. A thorough physi -
cal examination should always be performed to rule out 
any potential causes or disorders that could appear like

primary  neurological conditions. Musculoskeletal issues, 
metabolic illnesses, and cardiac arrhythmias are the most 
frequent conditions they imitate like primary neurological 
problems.
4.3 Neurological examination
An evaluation of the head, cranial nerves, gait and posture, 
neck, thoracic, limb, back, pelvic limb, anus, and tail are 
all included in a neurological examination. Examining 
each of them reveals details about how the nervous sys -
tem functions generally and aids in determining the precise 
neurological condition. It is crucial to conduct a detailed, 
in-depth, and objective evaluation of the nervous system. 
To get the most out of the neurological examination, no 
sedatives or tranquilizers should be utilized, and the ani -
mal must be quiet and comfortable. The main goals of a 
neurological examination are to define the condition, lo -
cate the affected area, and assess the severity of the damage 
(LeCouteur, 2009a).
4.3.1 Evaluation of head
When evaluating the head, one should assess for appropri -
ate head posture as well as any signs of muscular atrophy, 
a head tilt, and symmetry in the face, ears, eyes, and lips 
(Fig. 1). A vestibular N problem is linked to a head tilt issue 
(CN VIII). Problems with the brain or diencephalon can be 
indicated by head pressing and head turning. Cranial nerve 
V motor branch dysfunction is indicated by atrophy of the 
temporal or master muscles. Any aberrant position or move-
ment of the eyes could be caused by cranial nerve paraly -
sis or paresis of CN III, IV , VI, or VIII, whereas abnormal 
drooping of the ears, lips, or eyelid is linked to CN VII pa -
ralysis or paresis. Atypical pupil size is caused by cranial 
nerve III paresis. Tremors and head coordination issues are 
caused by cerebellum-related problems.
4.3.2 Evaluation of cranial nerves
Several tests are used to assess the cranial nerves; a list of fre-
quently used reflexes is provided in Table 4. Each test’s proce-
dure is simple and highly efficient at assessing nerve function.
Palpebral reflex
The trigeminal and facial nerves are assessed using the pal-
pebral reflex, which should touch a fingertip on the medial 
canthus of the eye (Schubert, 2010) as shown in Fig. 2. The 
animal responds with a motor reaction (CN VII) by blinking 
if the sensation is present (CN V).
Menace response
The menace response is produced by abruptly approaching 
the eye with a hand or finger as if simulating a blow to the

which generally results in blinking of the eyelids in normal 
animals (Schubert, 2010).
Pupillary light reflex
In a dim area, a high-intensity light source is used to execute 
the reflex as shown in Fig. 4. The light should be focused on 
the fundus of the eye. The instantaneous reflex is evoked by 
constriction of the pupil in the eye being examined (direct 
reaction), as well as the pupil in the opposite eye (indirect 
or consensual response).
Corneal reflex
A corneal reflex is performed by softly touching the corneal 
surface with a wet cotton swab or finger. Retraction of the 
globe and blinking indicate appropriate functioning of the 
cranial nerve V ophthalmic branch, motor innervations of 
VII, and cranial nerve VI.
Oculo-cephalic reflex
The head is moved from side to side, then up and down, 
resulting in normal rhythmic lateral and vertical movement 
of the globe, known as physiological nystagmus. After each 
movement, the head should be stabilized and the nystagmus 
should be checked. If the eyes continue to move, positional 
nystagmus occurs, which is consistent with a vestibule-  
cochlear N lesion (CN VIII). Any irregular eye movement 
that is unrelated to head movements is referred to as “dolls 
eye movement” (Schubert, 2010). It is caused by a lesion in 
the CN-III, IV , VI, and VIII.
Occulocardiac reflex
To elicit reflex bradycardia, an occulocardiac reflex is 
effected by simultaneously applying digital pressure to 
both globes. If reflex bradycardia is present, it shows 
that the sensory response of cranial nerve V and the 
parasympathetic reflex of cranial nerve X is functioning 
normally.

FIG. 3 Menace response is induced by quickly bringing a hand or finger up to the eye.

Jaw tone reflex
The jaw tone reflex is performed by opening and closing 
the mouth to test the integrity of the nerve that supplies the 
masticatory muscle (Schubert, 2010) as shown in Fig. 5.
Pharyngeal reflex or swallowing reflex
Inserting a finger or tongue depressor toward the pharynx 
causes a pharyngeal reflex. The presence of a swallowing or 
gag reaction shows that the cranial nerve IX is functioning 
appropriately (Schubert, 2010).
Licking reflex
The licking reflex is activated by moistening the tip of the 
nose as shown in Fig. 6. However, the animal licks indicate 
normal IX, X, and XII cranial nerve function.

Retraction reflex
The animal’s tongue is gently pulled to one side to per -
form the reflex. If the animal resists pulling and retracts its 
tongue, cranial nerve XII is working normally.
Auditory reflex or clap test
By clapping hands behind the ears as shown in Fig. 7, au-
ditory reflex testing was performed to check cranial nerve 
VIII ( Schubert, 2010 ). Any movement or jumping of the 
animal suggests that the nerve is functioning normally as 
shown in Fig. 8.
Facial sensitivity tests
Pricking the face with a needle or pinching with a hemostat 
is used to perform facial sensitivity tests as shown in Fig. 9. 
A pain response shows that cranial nerves V and VII are 
functioning normally (Schubert, 2010).
Palpation of neck muscle
To assess for atrophy, the neck muscles, particularly the 
sternocephalicus, brachiocephalicus, and trapezius mus -
cles, are palpated. If muscle mass is normal, so is cranial 
nerve XI function.

4.3.3 Evaluation of gait and posture
To analyze the animal’s gait, observe the animal while it 
is roaming freely as shown in Fig. 10, which always pro -
vides significant information. To localize the lesion, com -
monly used tests include hemistand, hemiwalking, and 
wheelbarrowing.
In hemistand and hemiwalking, lift one side of the ani -
mal’s limbs and support the animal as shown in Fig.  11. 
Then gently push the animal forward and sideways to en -
courage the animal to walk on one side of its body. This aids 
in determining which side of the body is impacted. During 
wheelbarrowing, either the thoracic or pelvic limbs of the 
animal are lifted, allowing the animal to walk exclusively 
on its fore or hind limbs as shown in Figs. 12 and 13. This 
aids in determining whether the lesion is in the forequarter 
or the hindquarter.
Hopping and conscious proprioception are employed to 
assess postural reactions. Lifting three limbs, enabling the 
animal to stand and hop on only one limb is used to assess 
hopping.
By gently moving the animal laterally to see if they can 
walk or hop as shown in Fig. 14. To test conscious proprio-
ception, the dorsal surface of the animal paw is turned to 
make touch with the ground ( Schubert, 2010). If the ani -
mal’s proprioceptive function is good, it will restore its paw 
to its natural position in a few seconds. A lack of conscious 
proprioception indicates a neurological problem; this is not 
evident in orthopedic problems.
4.3.4 Evaluation of neck, thoracic, limb, back, 
pelvic limb, anus, and tail
The most often used procedures to evaluate the thoracic 
limb, back, pelvic limb, anus, and tail include spinal cord 
reflexes, Babinskis sign , and cutaneous trunci  response.

When an animal is relaxed and lying on to its lateral, the

the thoracic and pelvic limbs are listed in Table 5.
4.4 Test on blood and serum
Blood and serum tests are crucial to determine whether 
other bodily systems or organs, such as the liver, kidneys, 
and heart, are involved in the emergence of neurologi -
cal symptoms or are dysfunctional. But it is important to 
choose these exams carefully. For instance, the diagnosis of 
hepatic encephalopathy, which can potentially result in neu-
rologic symptoms, depends on serum bile acids, albumin, 
the A/G ratio, aspartate aminotransferase, and total plasma 
protein. Similar to serum cholinesterase for poisoning with 
organ phosphorus and serum thyroxine and TSH levels for 
hypothyroidism.

4.5 Cerebrospinal fluid analysis
Ependymal cells of the choroid plexus, particularly through 
active transport processes, produce cerebrospinal fluid, 
which is then absorbed by arachnoid villi. The CNS is 
shielded from shock by the cerebrospinal fluid, which 
also nourishes the CNS parenchyma and aids in maintain -
ing intracranial pressure. CSF can be collected by lumbar 
puncture or the cerebellomedullary cistern. In general, the 
cerebellomedullary cistern is easier to execute, allows for 
more volume collection, and results in less blood contami -
nation (LeCouteur, 2009b). Some of the typical indications 
for cerebrospinal fluid examination include any inflamma -
tory or neoplastic condition, trauma, degenerative disorders, 
cord compression, and hydrocephalus. In cases of elevated 
intracranial pressure, brain herniation, mechanical instabil-
ity, fractures or subluxations of the cervical or cranial or -
gans, and anesthetic risk, the cerebrospinal fluid collection 
is contraindicated.
Cerebrospinal fluid often has a low protein and cell 
count. CSF produces coagulum or sediment when standing 
and is clear and colorless. The number of nucleated cells per 
liter is fewer than 5 × 106 they are sterile in culture and free 
of microbes. The range of specific gravity is 1.004–1.006. 
Total protein ranges between 8 and 30  mg% in dog and 8 
and 20 mg% in cat, albumin comprises about 80%–90% of 
total protein. Glucose concentration is roughly 60 mg/dL, or 
80% of plasma glucose concentration.
Idiopathic epilepsy, congenital hydrocephalus, func -
tional disorder, metabolic ailment, vertebral disease, and 
myelomalacia are a few situations when normal CSF is 
seen. A few CSF abnormalities and respective conditions 
are listed in Table 6.
4.6 Electroencephalography (EEG)
Electroencephalography is used to measure the electrical 
activity of the brain (Platt and Olby, 2015). EEG is noninva-
sive and painless. It can be used to diagnose conditions like 
hydrocephalus, encephalitis, head injuries, encephalopa -
thy, neoplasia, and epilepsy. EEG has a lot of diagnostic 
potential for diagnosing neurological disorders; it can de -
tect changes in brain activity over long periods of time and 
even after symptoms appear. EEG can be used to determine 
whether animals are at risk of developing neurological dis -
orders so that they can get early treatment. Unfortunately, 
EEG has never been used as a standard diagnostic proce -
dure in the treatment of canine and feline epilepsy.
4.7 Electromyography (EMG)
Electromyography measures the electrical activity of periph-
eral nerves and muscles ( LeCouteur, 2009b). This is very 
useful in locating nerve injuries, nerve root compression 
disorders of the neuromuscular junction and muscles, and 
peripheral nerves. EMG is usually performed using a needle 
electrode that is placed into the muscle and attached to an 
amplifier. These record the electrical activity of the muscle 
cells when they contract or relax. EMG is usually performed 
on the muscles of the face, limbs, and trunk, but can also 
be used to test nerve function in the brain. The test involves 
placing an electrode on a specific muscle or nerve (usually 
using local anesthesia) and recording its electrical activity.
4.8 Brainstem auditory evoked response (BAER)
The BAER test is used to evaluate the electrical activity of 
the auditory pathways through the brainstem. It can be used 
to diagnose hearing loss, evaluate nerve damage, and moni-
tor treatment for certain diseases that affect hearing and bal-
ance (Schubert, 2010). The test is typically performed by an 
audiologist who measures electrical activity in response to

clicking sounds delivered through earphones that are placed 
on the patient’s ears. The BAER test can also be used to 
diagnose a condition called congenital deafness in which 
newborn puppies and kittens are unable to hear.
4.9 Spinal cord evoked response
Spinal cord evoked response is the recording of electrical ac-
tivity, which is generated by stimulation of the nerve. When 
a peripheral nerve is stimulated, an action potential travels 
along the axon and enters the spinal cord via the dorsal root 
ganglion. This generates an “evoked response” in the spi -
nal cord, which can be recorded using surface electrodes or 
needle electrodes. A typical evoked response consists of a 
series of peaks, each corresponding to a different compo -
nent of the nerve fiber. These peaks are called compound 
action potentials (CAPs). Spinal cord evoked response is 
useful in diagnosing nerve root and spinal cord lesion.
4.10 Routine radiography
In veterinary medicine, radiography is the most often uti -
lized imaging technology. It is noninvasive, inexpensive, 
and gives a fast diagnosis of the majority of musculoskeletal 
disorders. Radiography is a significant tool in neurological 
examinations for finding abnormalities, fractures, neopla -
sia, and bone infection. It can also be utilized to detect de -
generation and infection in the intervertebral disc, which 
are the causes of nervous symptoms.
4.11 Myelography
The technique involves the injection of a radiopaque con -
trast medium into the subarachnoid space at the level of 
 interest under fluoroscopic guidance and visualizes the spi-
nal canal and surrounding structures ( LeCouteur, 2009b). 
This is done by injecting a contrast material (iohexol) into 
the spinal cord through a needle that goes into the sub -
arachnoid space. The contrast material is then visualized on 
X-rays or CT scans. This test is used to diagnose spinal cord 
tumors, fractures, infections, and other conditions affecting 
the spinal cord.
4.12 Computed tomography (CT)
Computed tomography is a noninvasive imaging technique 
used to assess internal structures and organs of the body. 
The procedure involves taking multiple X-rays from dif -
ferent angles, which are then compiled by a computer into 
cross-sectional images of the area being studied as shown 
in Fig.  15. As contrast media, diatrizoate meglumine and 
diatrizoate sodium are utilized. CT scans are quite useful in 
detecting acute bleeding and determining bone detail.
4.13 Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
Under a strong magnetic field, magnetic resonance imaging 
captures several plane pictures as shown in Fig.  16. It is 
better for soft tissue than CT, and intravenous gadolinium is 
used to identify an impaired blood-brain barrier.
4.14 Surgical biopsy
Surgical biopsy is an uncommon procedure that involves re-
moving a lesion for diagnostic purposes. A surgical biopsy 
is suggested for the diagnosis of meningoencephalopa -
thies, peripheral neuropathies, and neoplasia of the nervous 
system.

5.1 Epilepsy

5.1.1 Definition of epileptic seizure
A clinical manifestation of excessive and/or hypersyn -
dromic neuronal activity in the cerebral cortex is an epileptic 
seizure. Epilepsy is a condition characterized by frequent, 
irregular seizures. An intermittent electrical disturbance in 
the brain manifests itself externally as a seizure, ictus, fit, 
or convulsion. The main distinction between a seizure and 
epilepsy is that a seizure only occurs once, but epilepsy is a 
neurological disorder marked by two or more spontaneous 
seizures.
Greek term epilepsia, which means to take, seize, or at-
tack, is the root of the English word epilepsy. Hippocrates 
(460–377 BC) thought that the brain should be the source of 
epileptic convulsions ( Vite and Braund, 2010 ). According 
to distinct symptoms, epileptic convulsions were classified 
by Calmeil (1824). Later, epilepsy was divided into many 
categories by neurologist John Hughlings Jackson based 
on anatomical localization, physiological imbalance, and 
pathological process.
5.1.2 Epidemiology of epileptic seizure
The most prevalent neurological condition affecting dogs 
and cats is epilepsy. Epilepsy prevalence in the canine popu-
lation has been estimated to range from 0.5% to 5.0%, while 
it is roughly 0.5% in the cat population ( Vite and Braund, 
2010). In male dogs, a slightly greater prediction of epilepsy 
was noted. German Shepherds, Boxers, Cocker Spaniels, 
Labrador Retrievers, Beagles, Dachshunds, Keeshound, 
Vizla, and Shetland sheepdogs are particularly susceptible 
to genetic forms of epilepsy.
5.1.3 Common causes of epileptic seizure
There are numerous causes of epilepsy in dogs and cats. 
Congenital and familial problems, infections and inflam -
mation, metabolic disorders, neoplasia (cancer), nutritional 
disorders, and toxicities are the most common causes of 
epilepsy in dogs and cats. The most prevalent type is idio -
pathic epilepsy, which means that no cause can be found.
Genetics can cause epilepsy in dogs and cats. If a dog 
or cat is born with a genetic predisposition, seizures can be 
triggered by stress or illness. A variety of factors, includ -
ing genetic, congenital defects, or birth trauma, can cause 
congenital and familial epilepsy in dogs and cats. Canine 
idiopathic epilepsy, familial canine epilepsy, epilepsy as -
sociated with hippocampus atrophy or malformation, hy -
drocephalus, lysosomal storage disease, and lissencephaly 
are the congenital and familial disorders leading to epilepsy 
in dogs. Infections and inflammations such as rabies, ca -
nine distemper, feline polio encephalomyelitis, rickettsial 
meningoencephalitis, FIV , FIP, and FeLV can all cause epi-
lepsy in dogs and cats. The Clostridium bacteria are also a 
cause of epilepsy in dogs and cats. Epilepsy can be caused 
by metabolic problems such as calcium and magnesium de-
ficiency, hypoglycemia, hypoxia, and hepatic encephalopa-
thy. Toxicities of copper, lead, arsenic, OPC, chlorinated 
HC-DDT, BHC, and PCBs have been associated with epi -
lepsy in dogs and cats.
FIG. 16 A 7-year-old Great Dane is being prepared for an MRI to rule 
out cerebral hemorrhage.

Diseases of the nervous system of dogs and cats   Chapter | 16  251
Nutrition is thought to play a significant impact in this 
condition. If an animal does not receive adequate nutrients, 
it may develop neurological problems depending on the 
duration degree of deficiency. Epilepsy can be caused by 
a lack of vitamin B1, B6, B12, vitamin C, Omega-3 fatty 
acids, hypocalcemia, hyponatremia, hypochloremia, hyper-
phosphatemia, vitamin D deficiency, and taurine deficiency. 
The brain is the organ in the body that requires the most ox-
ygen. Neurons are extremely sensitive to variations in blood 
flow and oxygen levels. When there is a lack of oxygen or 
a decrease in blood flow to the central nervous system, the 
brain is deprived of oxygen, resulting in epilepsy. Trauma, 
vascular disorders, ischemia, and bleeding into the brain 
can deprive the neurons of oxygen, resulting in epilepsy. 
The most frequent form of neoplasia that produces seizures 
in canines and felines is brain tumors. Slowly expanding 
over time, they exert pressure on adjacent structures that 
may cause seizure activity. Meningioma is a form of tumor 
that arises from the tissues that cover the central nervous 
system, the meninges (CNS), which is a benign brain tumor 
but a deadly, aggressive kind of brain cancer. With a median 
age of onset of 6  years old, it most frequently affects dogs 
in their middle to later years. Another form of tumor of the 
central nervous system is ependymomas. Ependymomas 
can form anywhere in the brain or spinal cord; however, 
they are most frequently detected in the spinal cord.
5.1.4 Pathophysiology of epileptic seizure
Normal brain cells communicate with one another via elec-
trical and chemical signals. This communication is either 
excitatory or inhibitory. There is a balance between these 
two; anything that causes an imbalance between these two 
can be a potential cause of epilepsy. Epilepsy is caused by a 
cluster of nerve cells that are physically normal but electri-
cally abnormal or dysfunctional. As long as the abnormal 
discharge does not exceed the threshold level, there will be 
no problem. Every neural tissue has an excitability thresh -
old. If it exceeds the threshold level, neuronal depolarization 
occurs, which spreads to neighboring neurons and causes 
epilepsy. Other possible mechanisms for epileptic seizures 
in dogs and cats include abnormalities in the structure or 
function of ion channels, abnormalities in intracellular cal -
cium signaling pathways, increased effect of excitatory neu-
rotransmitters like glutamate, disruption of the blood-brain 
barrier, decreased effect of inhibitory neurotransmitters like 
GABA, and decreased blood flow to the brain.
5.1.5 Classification of epileptic seizure
Human seizures have classification systems; however, there 
is no commonly accepted classification system for seizures 
in dogs and cats. In small animal practice, the human clas -
sification system is occasionally used to explain seizures; 
however, this often leads to confusion because of subjective 
variations.
Epilepsy classification is based on etiology : Epilepsy 
is classified into three categories based on etiology as id -
iopathic epilepsy, symptomatic epilepsy, and cryptogenic 
epilepsy (Vite and Braund, 2010).
Idiopathic epilepsy: It is the most prevalent type and is an 
inherited disorder that can be familial (genetic) or congeni-
tal (present at birth). Idiopathic epilepsy is epilepsy caused 
by an unknown factor in which there is no anatomical brain 
abnormality. Clinically and neurologically, animals suffer -
ing from idiopathic epilepsy will appear normal between 
the two epilepsies. Idiopathic epilepsy is also known as true 
epilepsy, genetic epilepsy, and inherited epilepsy.
Symptomatic epilepsy : head injury, congenital anoma -
lies, storage illness, CNS infection, brain tumor, and sur -
gery can all cause symptomatic epilepsy. In symptomatic 
epilepsy, structural changes/pathology of the cerebrum is 
found, and the pathophysiology is well understood. There 
are two types of symptomatic epilepsy: focal symptomatic 
epilepsy and generalized symptomatic epilepsy. The etiol -
ogy of focal symptomatic epilepsy is structural lesions in 
the brain, which mainly affect one hemisphere of the cere -
brum. In contrast, generalized symptomatic epilepsy affects 
both hemispheres of the cerebrum. Symptomatic epilepsy 
is also known as secondary epilepsy and acquired epilepsy.
Cryptogenic epilepsy: it is a type of seizure disorder that 
cannot be explained by structural abnormalities in the brain 
and whose suspected cause remains obscure or hidden.
Epileptic seizures are classified into two types based on 
the involvement of cerebral hemispheres: primary general -
ized seizures and partial/focal seizures ( Vite and Braund, 
2010).
Primary generalized seizures: An epileptic seizure that 
displays early symptoms of activity involving both hemi -
spheres of the brain. The seizure primarily manifests in 
dogs and cats as sudden “convulsions” and unconscious -
ness. In addition, convulsions frequently involve salivation, 
urine, and/or excrement. Seizures that are atonic or myo -
clonic may also occur (though uncommon). Convulsions 
will always be involved in primary generalized seizures. 
Grand mal or generalized epileptic seizures are other names 
for primary generalized seizures.
Partial/focal seizures: A type of epileptic seizure that 
displays clinical symptoms and has its origins in a specific 
region of the brain. Focal motor, autonomic, or behavioral 
signs may appear alone or in combination with this type of 
seizure. The alternative names for partial/focal seizures are 
petit mal and focal epileptic seizure. Simple partial/focal 
seizures and complex partial/focal seizures are two general 
categories of focal seizures based on the level of conscious-
ness. Simple partial/focal seizures do not impair conscious-
ness, whereas complex partial/focal seizures cause the 
animal to lose consciousness.
Focal/partial seizures can evolve to become focal sei -
zure with secondary generalization. Focal seizure with sec-
ondary generalization is an epileptic episode that begins

252 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
in a localized area of the cerebral cortex and then extends 
to both hemispheres. Seizures in dogs and cats begin with 
localized motor, autonomic, and/or behavioral symptoms, 
followed by convulsions. Convulsions are frequently ac -
companied by salivation, urine, and/or feces.
5.1.6 Stages of epileptic seizure
Seizures differ in etiology and involvement of cerebral 
hemispheres, although they frequently follow the same pat-
tern. A seizure has four distinct phases: prodromal, early 
ictal (the “aura”), ictal, and postictal (Brewer, 2017).
In the prodrome stage, mood and behavior changes oc -
cur hours and days before the onset of true seizures. In the 
aura stage, the animal exhibits initial manifestations of sei-
zures such as licking, shivering, vomiting, urination, bark -
ing, and psychic occurrences. This period occurs between 
minutes and hours before the commencement of actual sei-
zures. It is quite difficult to distinguish between prodrome 
and aura stages in animals.
Actual seizure activity takes place during the stage of ic-
tus, which typically lasts for minutes to seconds. The brain 
tissue undergoes significant electrical changes during this 
time. The last phase, known as post-ictus, follows an ac -
tive seizure. Animals may experience thirst, an increase in 
appetite, and occasionally, blindness during this period of 
recovery. How long it takes for an animal to get back to nor-
mal depends on the type of seizure and the area of the brain 
that is affected. This stage often lasts from a few seconds to 
several days.
5.1.7 Clinical signs of epileptic seizure
Generalized seizures : Both dogs and cats are frequently 
diagnosed with generalized seizures. Because neurons on 
both sides of the cerebral cortex discharge electrical activ -
ity, the clinical signs of this type are diffused and bilater -
ally symmetrical, indicating that the entire brain is involved. 
Aura may or may not be present at the grand mal stage, but 
the animal will be unconscious, may fall to its side, and 
cries out what is known as an epileptic cry. Although there 
is no pain, an epileptic cry results from the constriction of 
larynx muscles and the gushing of air out. Head, neck, limb, 
face, and jaw muscles will all be symmetrically rigid at the 
same time. Animals may not be able to breathe, and if the 
body fails to get enough oxygen, their mucous membranes 
turn cyanotic. The characteristic of generalized epilepsy is 
that the animal recovers by urinating and defecating after 
the epilepsy.
Focal or partial seizure: The signs of a focal or partial 
seizure depend on which part of the cerebral cortex is ex -
hibiting aberrant electrical activity. There are three types 
of motor epilepsy: focal, psychomotor, and generalized. 
With no loss of consciousness, twitches in focal motor epi-
lepsy are restricted to one part of the body. Animals with 
 generalized motor seizures lose consciousness while mov -
ing their bodies in a gross way. There will be noticeable 
behavioral alterations in psychomotor epilepsy, either after 
the generalized motor seizure or during the seizure.
5.1.8 Differential diagnosis of epileptic 
seizure
The first step is to check that the owner’s description of 
the incident is indeed a seizure. Because the animal will 
be rarely presented during the ictal stage/period, a full his -
tory should be gathered to establish it as a seizure and to 
rule out other conditions that could be confused for seizure. 
Narcolepsy, spinal pain, cataplexy, syncope, tremors, and 
behavioral abnormalities are common conditions mistaken 
as epilepsy and may provide a diagnostic problem since they 
involve signs that are very common in epilepsy. Anemia, 
hepatic failure, renal dysfunction, hyperthyroidism in cats, 
hypoglycemia, electrolyte imbalances, myasthenia gravis, 
and intoxication are all potential causes of epilepsy. These 
disorders should be explored in the differential diagnosis of 
epilepsy.
Sudden falls and consciousness disturbances are hall -
marks of narcolepsy. Sleep often lasts between a few 
minutes and 20  min. Cataplexy is a sudden reduction of 
muscular tone in an awake animal that results in loss of 
voluntary muscle control. It lasts only a short while, and 
symptoms range from weakness to unexpected falling. 
The animal regains consciousness following the incident. 
Syncope is a brief loss of consciousness brought on by a 
reduction in blood flow to the brain. A thorough clinical his-
tory, in conjunction with physical and neurological exams, 
should be able to distinguish these episodic occurrences 
from seizure activity.
5.1.9 Diagnosis of epileptic seizure
Neurological issues in dogs and cats cannot be diagnosed 
with a single test alone; numerous diagnostic techniques 
must be used. A thorough physical and neurological ex -
amination, hematology, biochemistry, urine analysis, and 
survey radiographs of the abdomen and thorax are the 
minimal preliminary requirements for diagnosing epilepsy 
in small animal patients. The likelihood of discovering the 
cause is great if it is extracranial. When idiopathic epilepsy 
is suspected, all other potential causes should be ruled out. 
A thorough record of the incident should be obtained from 
the owner. Information should be gathered from the owner 
should include current medications, vaccination, deworm -
ing details, history of trauma or head injuries, a current 
medical issue, age at first seizure, frequency of seizures, and 
any febrile reactions. It is recommended to utilize a stan -
dardized questionnaire to gather all of these data more ef -
fectively and consistently. In situations indicating an active 
brain problem, the cerebrospinal fluid should be analyzed

Diseases of the nervous system of dogs and cats   Chapter | 16  253
since CNS pathology may be reflected in the cerebrospinal 
fluid. Computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance 
imaging (MRI) have been extremely useful in the diagnosis 
and treatment of epilepsy in animals.
5.1.10 Management of epileptic seizure
The therapeutic management of epileptic seizures is diffi -
cult and requires multiple hospital visits and medicines to 
manage the condition. When to begin antiepileptic therapy 
is crucial, and this decision is based on a number of fac -
tors. Antiepileptic therapy is typically started when an ani -
mal experiences more than two seizures within a 6-month 
period, when postepileptic symptoms are severe, when the 
seizure itself is severe, or when an animal experiences sta -
tus epilepticus or cluster epilepticus (Brewer, 2017). Owner 
compliance must be considered prior to beginning therapy, 
and if the owner strongly requests antiepileptic therapy, 
treatment may be started.
Antiepileptic drugs (AED)
Antiepileptic medications are administered over a lon -
ger period of time, so the ideal antiepileptic medication 
should be affordable, without any adverse effects, and 
have a long half-life to minimize the need for repeated oral 
doses. Unfortunately, no antiepileptic medicine currently 
on the market will meet all of the aforementioned require -
ments. Antiepileptic therapy’s primary goal is to decrease 
seizure frequency and duration as well as postepileptic 
consequences.
Phenobarbital sodium/phenobarbital
Phenobarbital belongs to the barbiturates class of medi -
cines. Barbiturates are CNS depressants; the degree of 
CNS depression is determined by the dose, method of ad -
ministration, drug pharmacokinetics, and species treated. 
Barbiturates do not have true analgesic action intrinsi -
cally. Barbiturates should be used with caution in cats due 
to their sensitivity to the respiratory depressive effects of 
barbiturates.
Despite being an older medication, many veterinar -
ians still use phenobarbital as the first-line treatment for 
epilepsy in dogs and cats due to its effectiveness, afford -
ability, capacity to treat epilepsy at low doses, and relative 
safety. Phenobarbital has a 90% bioavailability in dogs fol-
lowing oral administration. The drug is processed in the 
liver before being eliminated through the kidney. Dog and 
cat elimination half-lives range from 12 to 125  h and 34 to 
43 h, respectively. In patients with anemia, hypovolemia, 
cardiac or respiratory disease, and hypoadrenal function, 
phenobarbital should be used with caution. Patients with 
liver problems or animals with high barbiturate sensitivity 
should not administer phenobarbital. Dogs frequently expe-
rience a variety of negative side effects, such as anxiety or 
lethargy, depression, sedation, ataxia, polydipsia, polyuria, 
and polyphagia (Mandigers, 2013). In cats, weight gain and 
polydipsia/polyuria are the most often reported adverse ef -
fects. Oral administration of activated charcoal aids in the 
removal of the drug from the body in cases of phenobarbital 
toxicity.
Dosage advice for dogs : At first, administer 2–4  mg/kg 
PO in 2–3 doses per day. If ineffective, doses may be gradu-
ally increased up to a maximum of 18–20  mg/kg/day (di-
vided 2–3 times a day). Seizures may occur if the medicine 
is abruptly stopped.
Dosage advice for cats: The initial dose is 2 (1–2.5) mg/
kg every 12 h. Serum levels should be taken into consider -
ation before making any changes in the dosage.
Potassium bromide/KBr
Alkali metal bromides are a group of inorganic chemicals 
that includes potassium bromide, often known as kalium 
bromide or KBr. Potassium bromide is frequently utilized 
in patients suffering from phenobarbital hepatotoxicity. 
This is used as a primary antiepileptic medication as well 
as an adjuvant medication in conjunction with pheno -
barbital or primidone. KBr is absorbed in the small in -
testine, has a bioavailability of 60%–100% in dogs, and 
is eliminated through the kidney. In dogs and cats, the 
half-life is around 16–25  days and 10  days, respectively. 
The most common side effects described are sedation, 
polyphagia, polydipsia, polyuria, anorexia, vomiting, and 
constipation.
Dosage advice for dogs : Loading dose of 400–600  mg/
kg/day divided and administered with food it can be given 
over the course of 24  h or more gradually over the course 
of 5  days. Then proceed to the initial maintenance dose: 
20–30 mg/kg PO once a day.
Dosage advice for cats: 30 mg/kg PO once daily.
Phenytoin sodium
In dogs and cats, phenytoin is not often used as an antiepi -
leptic medication. In dogs, bioavailability after oral dosing 
is around 40%. It is metabolized in the liver and eliminated 
through the kidney. Phenytoin has a half-life of 2–8  h in 
dogs and 42–108 h in cats. Anorexia, vomiting, ataxia, and 
sedation are frequent side effects in dogs. Chronic ther -
apy patients also had hepatotoxicity and gingival hyper -
plasia. Cats suffer from ataxia, drowsiness, and anorexia. 
Thrombocytopenia and dermal atrophy syndrome were also 
seen in cats. Because the phenytoin accumulates easily in 
cats and can lead to toxicity, its usage in cats remains con -
troversial. The dose for treating epilepsy in cats is 2–3  mg/
kg daily PO, with a maximum of 20  mg/kg per week. 
Phenytoin must be administered regularly in dogs due to its 
short half-life; the recommended dose is 15–40  mg/kg PO 
three times each day.

254 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
Primidone
Primidone, a phenobarbital precursor, should not be admin-
istered to dogs that have a liver illness or who are sensitive 
to primidone. Because primidone has a high incidence of 
hepatotoxicity and behavioral side effects, many neurolo -
gists do not advise using it to control seizures. Primidone 
is thought to be more harmful to cats than to canines. 
Recommended dose for dogs: To start, administer 10–
30 mg/kg daily divided into 2–3 doses. Recommended dose 
for cats, take 11–22 mg/kg three times a day.
Diazepam
Diazepam is a benzodiazepine anxiolytic, muscle relax -
ant, hypnotic, appetite stimulant, and anticonvulsant drug. 
Diazepam is a lipid-soluble drug that is metabolized in the 
liver and excreted in the urine. Diazepam bioavailability 
varies depending on the species and route of administra -
tion. In dogs and cats, the serum half-life is 2.5–3.2 and 
5.5 h, respectively. Diazepam should be used with caution in 
animals with hepatic or renal disease, as well as in geriatric 
or debilitated animals. Diazepam is used as a second-line 
medication for oral maintenance management of seizures in 
cats. It is given at a dose of 0.5–1 mg/kg PO every 12 h. Dogs 
are given 1–2 mg/kg PO every 12 h, with the most prevalent 
side effects being sedation and polyphagia. Long-term di -
azepam dosing is ineffective because tolerance builds fast.
Nutritional management
Diet is frequently overlooked while managing canine and 
feline epilepsy. The brain’s main energy source is glucose. 
The brain cannot store anything, thus it needs a constant 
flow of glucose. Energy metabolism may be compromised 
in epileptogenic brain regions; hence, it is recommended to 
use sources of energy other than glucose that are not depen-
dent on pyruvate dehydrogenase activity. In rodent seizure 
models, dogs, and humans with epilepsy, medium-chain 
triglycerides offer medium-chain fatty acids (MCFAs) 
and ketones as auxiliary brain energy and can lower sei -
zures. Additionally, ketones and medium-chain fatty acids 
enhance brain mitochondrial activity and antioxidant de -
fense (Han et al., 2021). A sudden change in diet should be 
avoided in pets on anticonvulsant drugs, and new foods and 
ingredients should be introduced gradually.
5.1.11 Refractory epilepsy
When a patient’s quality of life is impaired by frequent 
or severe seizures or pharmaceutical side effects, epilepsy 
is considered to be refractory. Refractory epilepsy affects 
about one-third of dogs with epilepsy, making it a signifi -
cant issue in small animal medicine. For the treatment of 
refractory seizures in veterinary patients, a number of an -
tiepileptic medications have been studied, including ga -
bapentin, zonisamide, levetiracetam, and pregabalin ( Platt, 
2008). These antiepileptic medicines are frequently used in 
conjunction with main medications such as potassium bro -
mide and phenobarbital sodium (Table 7).
5.1.12 Status epilepticus and cluster epilepsy
Status epilepticus is characterized by continuous seizure ac-
tivity lasting more than 5 min or by the occurrence of more 
than one seizure within 5  min without an intervening inter-
val of normalcy. It can sometimes last 20–30 min or longer. 
In cluster epilepticus, a seizure occurs several times a day 
with at least 2  h of intervening period of normalcy, where 
the animal regains its consciousness and nervous system 
functions return to the baseline (Scislowicz, 2015).
Status epilepticus could have cluster epilepsy as a pre -
cursor. Approximately 60% of epileptic dogs will develop 
status epilepsy at some time in their life. The prognosis for 
status epilepticus is poor, about 25% of the hospitalized dogs 
will not survive until hospital discharge (Rossmeisl, 2013).
The goal of status epilepticus management is to stabilize 
the patient, stop the seizure activity, and minimize or correct 
the negative effects of status epilepticus. Standard anticon -
vulsant and anesthetic medications are administered intra -
venously (IV) to treat status epilepticus. To stop the seizure 
activity, diazepam, lorazepam, levetiracetam, midazolam, 
and ketamine are most frequently utilized. Mannitol is given 
intravenously at a dose of 0.25–1 g/kg to prevent side effects 
like neuronal necrosis, increased intracranial pressure, and 
cerebral edema. Additional diagnostic tests, such as MRI, 
EEG, and thorough hematobiochemical examination, may 
be performed once the patient has first stabilized.
5.2 Paralysis
Paralysis refers to a loss of neurological control of the pe -
ripheral organs, particularly the limbs. Paralysis may entail 
the loss of sensory function or motor function or some -
times both functions. There will be no voluntary move -
ment during the paralysis period. Infections (such as rabies 
and canine distemper), trauma, tumors, cysts, increased

 intracranial pressure, fracture of the skull/vertebral column, 
IVD protrusion, toxicities, and deficient diseases can all 
cause paralysis.
Spastic or flaccid paralysis is possible. The affected 
limb or part of the body will be contracted in spastic paraly-
sis, which is frequent in upper motor neuron paralysis. The 
affected area in flaccid paralysis will be relaxed, as seen in 
lower motor neuron disorders.
Paralysis is further classified based on the affected limb. 
Monoplegia is the paralysis of only one limb of an animal. 
In diplegia, animals’ two limbs are paralyzed. Hemiplegia 
is the paralysis of one side of the body’s limbs. Paraplegia is 
the paralysis of both rear limbs. Quadriplegia is the paraly-
sis of all four limbs.
5.2.1 Management of paralysis
The treatment is determined by the underlying cause. In 
general, nursing care is particularly important in the man -
agement of paralysis since the animal may develop bed 
sores due to a lack of voluntary movement; adequate bed -
ding should be provided to avoid/reduce the risks of bed 
sores. Along with physiotherapy (massage or/and swim -
ming), vitamin and mineral supplements are essential for 
improving nerve function. Acupuncture, laser therapy, and 
infrared therapy have also been demonstrated to aid in the 
rehabilitation of paralyzed limbs.
5.3 Meningitis/encephalitis/
meningoencephalitis
Meningitis is an inflammation of the meninges character -
ized by high body temperature, hyperesthesia, and muscle 
rigidity, particularly in the neck muscles. Encephalitis 
is a brain inflammation that begins with hyperexcitabil -
ity and progresses to paralysis and unconsciousness. 
Meningoencephalitis is characterized by inflammation 
of both the brain and the spinal cord in the same animal. 
Meningitis symptoms usually appear before encephalitis 
symptoms (John J Callanan, mSD).
Meningoencephalitis is uncommon when compared to 
infections of other organs. This is due to increased protec -
tion afforded to the nervous system by its barrier, rather 
than a lack of infectious pathogens. Infections of the neu -
rological system are frequently the result of an injury to the 
protective barrier. Sinusitis, otitis media or interna, spinal 
osteomyelitis, or discospondylitis can all cause direct exten-
sion of bacterial or mycotic infection to the CNS. Iatrogenic 
infections are possible from infected spinal needle or surgi-
cal tools. Bacterial endocarditis and septicemia are the pri -
mary source of CNS infection in dogs.
5.3.1 Etiology
The causes of meningitis, encephalitis, and encephalomy -
elitis are roughly characterized as bacterial, viral,  parasitic, 
fungal, protozoal, and idiopathic/immune-mediated. 
Infectious causes such as bacterial infections, viral infec -
tions, parasitic infections, protozoal infections, and fun -
gal infections can begin elsewhere in the body and enter 
the central nervous system via the sinuses, ear canal, or 
bloodstream, resulting in meningitis/encephalitis. Feline 
infectious peritonitis (FIP), cryptococcosis, and toxoplas -
mosis are the most prevalent causes of meningitis in cats. 
Leptospirosis, canine distemper, and rabies are the most 
common causes of central nervous system infection in 
dogs.
Idiopathic/immune-mediated CNS disease is a group of 
sporadic inflammatory diseases of the brain or spinal cord 
in the absence of infections or infectious agent. Based on 
histopathology results, three kinds of idiopathic/immune-
mediated CNS disease are recognized. Granulomatous 
meningoencephalitis, also known as inflammatory reticulo-
sis, neoplastic reticulosis, and lymphoreticulosis, is a kind 
of Idiopathic/immune-mediated CNS disease. It is most 
frequent in dogs aged 4–8  years old and affects all types 
and sizes. Necrotizing encephalitis is widespread from 
4 months to 10  years and is mostly seen in smaller breeds 
like Yorkshire Terriers and Bulldogs. Necrotizing meningo-
encephalitis, often known as Pug dog encephalitis, is a kind 
of meningoencephalitis. Pug, Chihuahua, Maltese, Terriers, 
Shih Tzu, and Pekinese are the most prevalent breeds be -
tween 6 months and 7 years old.
5.3.2 Clinical signs
Common meningitis signs include the acute onset of fever 
and chills, restlessness, and excitement brought on by mo -
tor irritability. Tonic neck and head spasms, as well as limb 
twitching, notably below the elbow and in the flank area. 
Tremor, convulsion, coma, uncoordinated gait, pressing of 
the head, and slow and irregular movement are the other 
signs. Typically, a disease course lasts 2–10 days.
Fever, altered mental status, circling, head pressing, 
clonic convulsion, muscular tremor, hyperesthesia, champ-
ing of the jaw, ataxia, and nystagmus are among the com -
mon signs of encephalitis.
5.3.3 Diagnosis and treatment
The utilization of history, clinical symptoms, CSF analysis, 
and imaging methods like MRI enables the most accurate 
and trustworthy diagnosis. To pinpoint the precise causes, 
serological tests, hematobiochemical analysis, and culture 
studies are also helpful.
Treatment depends on the underlying cause; neverthe -
less, antibiotics including ampicillin, metronidazole, tet -
racycline, fluoroquinolone, cephalosporins (third), and 
trimethoprim-sulfa are necessary to combat bacterial infec-
tions. To attain and sustain concentration in the CNS, higher 
dosages than usual are required, with bactericidal medica -
tions recommended over bacteriostatic ones.

256 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
5.4 Encephalomalacia
Encephalomalacia is a type of brain degeneration char -
acterized by demyelination, necrosis, and edema. 
Encephalomalacia causes brain tissue to soften. 
Encephalomalacia is divided into two types: leuco encepha-
lomalacia and polio encephaloma. The degeneration of 
white matter of the brain is known as leuco encephalomala-
cia, whereas the degeneration of gray matter of brain tissue 
is known as polio encephalomalacia.
5.4.1 Etiopathogenesis
Hepatic diseases that are either acquired or congenital can 
cause encephalomalacia. In acquired or congenital hepatic 
diseases, elevated amounts of ammonia and other toxic com-
pounds in the bloodstream may result in the degeneration of 
brain tissue. In lysosomal storage disease, a lack of lyso -
somal enzymes causes cellular substrates to build up and 
interfere with normal cell activity. One of the main causes 
of encephalomalacia is hypoxia and ischemia. Neurons are 
the brain tissue’s most susceptible components to hypoxia 
and ischemia. Necrosis of neurons and glial components 
occurs in hypoxia and ischemia. Different levels of brain 
tissue edema and degeneration can be caused by poison -
ing with lead, arsenic, mercury, salt toxicity, agriculture 
chemicals, antifreeze, herbicides, insecticides, and endo -
toxins. Encephalomalacia is also known to be caused by a 
deficiency of vitamin A, thiamine, vitamin E, and selenium.
5.4.2 Clinical signs
Common symptoms include varied degrees of paralysis, 
dullness, blindness, ataxia, head pressing, circling, muscu -
lar tremor, opisthotonus, convulsions, and coma. The dis -
ease can manifest itself in either an acute or chronic form. 
Muscle tremor, frothy salivation, champing of the jaw, head 
pressing, tonic and clonic convulsions, and nystagmus are 
noticed in the acute form, followed by death within 24 h. In 
the chronic form, common signs include anorexia, gait in 
coordination, circling, and head pressing.
5.4.3 Diagnosis and treatment
Encephalomalacia is diagnosed based on clinical findings 
and laboratory testing. Blood will have higher amounts of 
pyruvate and lactate and lower levels of thiamine in en -
cephalomalacia. There will be an increase in intracranial 
pressure. A uniform swelling and softening of the brain, as 
well as cavitations and laminar necrosis of the cortex, were 
found during the postmortem examination. Because en -
cephalomalacia is an irreversible disorder, only supportive 
care is provided. Along with thiamine and liver stimulants 
supplementation, measures should be taken to lower intra -
cranial pressure.

Diseases of integument system  
of dogs and cats
Superficial pyoderma is seen most commonly affecting 
the outermost layers of the epidermis. It is subdivided into 
(a) acute moist dermatitis and (b) Intertrigo complex.
Acute moist dermatitis: It is a rapidly progressive super-
ficial bacterial infection of animals caused by self-inflicted 
trauma, which may include licking, rubbing, or chewing 
due to flea and lice infestation, allergy, ear infection, local 
pain or irritation, dental problems, injection reaction, poor 
coat condition, inadequate grooming and hyperthyroidism 
(Medleau and Hnilica, 2006 ). It is common in dogs and 
rare in cats. Most cases occur in the summer and fall. Most 
lesions were found on the trunk base of the tail and anal 
glands, side thighs, neck and face. Clinically, a localized 
moist lesion is surrounded by a patch of erythema ( Fig. 1). 
If the central lesion is surrounded by papules or pustules, it 
is called a satellite lesion. Dermatitis is not limited to the 
surface and may be superficial or deep pyoderma (Thomas, 
2004a). Differential diagnoses may include demodicosis, 
dermatitis, cell carcinoma including mastocytoma, seba -
ceous adenocarcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma squamous 
cell and eosinophilic granuloma. Diagnosis: History of the 
presence of ear infection, or flea infestation. Important 
clinical signs include the presence of satellite lesions which 
suggests a deeper infectious process, requiring more ag -
gressive antibiotic treatment. Skin scraping and cytology—
show degraded neutrophils and often a mixture of bacteria 
(Hill et al., 1995).
Intertrigo complex (pyodermal dermatitis): The Intertrigo 
complex occurs when the skin folds are invaded by any 
disease-causing organisms. Other contributing factors are 
maceration of the skin due to over-grooming, stained with 
tears or urine. Although bacterial involvement is common, 
Intertrigo can occur due to a combined infection of bacteria 
with yeast and or surface Demodex. Various anatomical po-
sitions provide different microenvironments to enable organ-
isms to combine to reproduce and cause disease. These are 
usually the following: Bacteria— Staphylococcus interme-
dius, Pseudomonas spp., Yeast—Malassezia  pachydermatis, 
Malassezia honyodialis, Parasite—Demodex canis, Demodex  
gatoi (DeBoer, 1995).
Various forms of Intertrigo may be seen in lip folds, fa-
cial folds, vaginal folds, tail folds, labial folds, the crease 
between the digits, and folds in the scrotum. Diagnosis can 
be made by cytology of direct smear or acetate tape stained 
with DiffQuik to evaluate the type of bacteria and yeast. 
A skin scraping can be done to check for parasitic infection. 
Treatment may include cleaning of the affected area with 
broad spectrum topical applications and shampoo based on 
the etiological agents. If necessary, the underlying disease 
should be treated, e.g., reducing weight loss for obese ani -
mals, castration for reducing scrotal folds, dental treatment 
of gingivitis and allergy therapy (Hill et al., 1995).
Superficial infection (superficial pyoderma): Superficial 
infection is seen affecting the outermost surface of the skin 
and the intact hair follicle. The condition does not extend be-
yond the epidermis. Superficial pyoderma can be classified 
as: impetigo, folliculitis, dermatitis pyoderma, methicillin-  
resistant Staphylococcus aureus  and dry skin disease. 
Impetigo: is caused by Staphylococcus as secondary bacte-
rial infection associated with viral or bacterial diseases, poor 
hygiene and ectoparasitic infestation. Clinically noncystic 
pustules with or without itching, which may rupture, and 
form crust. Impetigo are found on the hairless area of the ab-
domen. Rupture and ulceration of these papules result in the 
loss of considerable amount of the epidermis ( Hall, 2004). 
Treatment can be done by application of antibacterial sham-
poo and solution containing benzoyl peroxides, chlorhexi -
dine for three times a week. Antibiotic ointment containing 
fusidic acid may be helpful in healing the ulcerated papules.
Mucocutaneous pyoderma: It is a bacterial infection 
found in German Shepherds due to Staphylococcus spp. 
The affected animal may present swollen, reddish areas 
with ulceration and encrustation at the mucocutaneous 
junction ( Fig.  2), at the margin of the eyelids and at the 
commissures of the urogenital junctions. Diagnosis can be 
made by clinical appearance, skin scrappings, cytological

258 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
examination and histopathology which may show hyper -
plastic growth of the epidermal layer, presence of pustules 
and desquamation of the epidermal layer (Hill et al., 1995). 
Treatment includes a thorough cleaning of the affected area 
with antibacterial wipes and application of topical prepara-
tions containing fusidic acid followed by systemic adminis-
tration of antibiotics.
Bacterial folliculitis: This condition is characterized by 
the formation of follicular pustules of the intact hair folli -
cles, caused by Staphylococcus intermedius and S. schleiferi 
and MRSA. Introduction of the causative organism in the 
body may occur due to parasitic infestation, an endocrine 
disorder, allergy, immunosuppression, faulty grooming and 
self-inflicting trauma ( Bloom, 2004 ). Clinically animals 
may show alopecia with scaling and pruritus. Epidermal col-
larettes may be evident with crust formation. Diagnosis can 
be made from skin scrappings, fungal examination and cy -
tological examination. Histopathology may present follicu-
litis, perifolliculitis and interfollicular superficial dermatitis. 
Treatment may include both topical and systemic antibiotics 
based on the type of bacterial infection (Thomas, 2004a).
Deep bacteria infection/deep pyoderma: This condition 
initially starts from the epidermis and dermis and may also 
extend to the subcutaneous tissue ( Fig.  3). Foreign body 
like harnesses and belts, random wounds, self-inflicting 
trauma, abscess, demodicosis and allergy may result in 
both local deep pyoderma or generalized deep pyoderma 
(DeBoer, 1995). Deep pyoderma may be seen as subcutane-
ous abscess, furunculosis, nasal folliculitis, chin pyoderma, 
pododermatitis, etc.
Subcutaneous abscesses are very common in aggressive 
felines which have a tendency to bite thus inoculating the 
bacteria present in the oral cavity in the biting wound which 
might end up forming an abscess on the face, neck, limbs 
and tail base (Medleau and Hnilica, 2006).
Furunculosis is another form of deep pyoderma where 
the infected follicles may rupture and spread the infection 
in the dermis, usually on the trunk and the areas where pres-
sure point develops. Small papules may rupture forming ul-
cerated, erythematous areas which may subsequently form 
a crust (Madleau and Hnilica, 2006).
Nasal folliculitis is most commonly found on the bridge 
of the nose which might extend to the surrounding part of 
the nose. Nasal folliculitis occurs due to the rooting habit of 
the animal or from an insect bite.
Canine acne or chin pyoderma is a form of furunculosis 
of the chin and lips in canines. This condition is charac -
terized by nonpainful, nonpruritic areas which might show 
severe serosanguineous discharge. Young puppies are more 
susceptible to trauma from continuous friction from toys 
or hard floors, allergies and hormonal imbalance ( Medleau 
and Hnilica, 2006).

Pododermatitis/interdigital pyoderma is another form 
of folliculitis which affects the interdigital spaces. Etiology 
may include a number of factors like fungal infection com-
bined with dermatophytosis, neoplasm, ectoparasites, or 
trauma. Pustules of various shapes and sizes may be present 
in the interdigital space, which might later become purulent 
or ulcerated, with serosanguineous exudation. The animal 
may show lameness depending upon the extent of the lesion 
and feet affected (Hall, 2004).
Botryomycosis or bacterial pseudomycetoma: This 
condition is caused by Staphylococcus spp., Pseudomonas 
spp., Proteus spp. and Streptococcus spp. which forms 
granuloma in the affected area. These causative organisms 
find their way into the deeper tissue by way of punctured 
or penetrating wounds, biting injuries and foreign body re -
action (Thomas, 2004a). Lesions are characterized by the 
formation of granuloma which is neither painful nor pru -
ritic containing colonies of bacteria that appear as purulent 
white color grains. Diagnosis can be made by the presence 
of bacterial colonies in the granuloma.
Mycobacterial infection: It is caused by Mycobacterium 
tuberculosis, M. bovis and M. tuberculosis-bovis. Infection 
occurs from contaminated milk and meat. Clinically af -
fected animals may show nodules on the skin of the head, 
neck and limb region ( Fig. 4 and 5 ) which may, later on, 
transform into an abscess or ulcerate discharging green or 
yellow content. The animal may show progressive weight 
loss, difficulty in breathing, gastrointestinal disorder and 
dyspnea along with pyrexia and swollen lymph nodes 
(Bloom, 2004). Diagnosis can be made by demonstration 
of acid-fast organisms in the biopsy material collected from 
the nodules or ulcers by staining with Ziehl-Neelsen stain, 
X-rays, bacterial culture and sensitivity test.
Feline leprosy syndrome: It is caused by Mycobacterium 
lepraemurium which affects the younger population of cats. 
This condition is characterized by single or multiple nod -
ules with a characteristic nonhealing fistula. These nodules 
painless, nonulcerating nodules are usually found distrib -
uted over the head and limbs only. Apart from the history 
and clinical signs, diagnosis can be made by demonstration 
of both intra- or extracellular acid-fast bacilli and cytologi-
cal study of the aspirate made from the nodule revealing 
caseous necrosis and panniculitis (Bloom, 2004). Treatment 
can be made by complete removal of cutaneous nodules. In 
patients where surgery is not an option, long-term antibiotic 
therapy of Clofazimine should be incorporated.
Actinomycosis: This condition is caused by Actinomyces 
spp., which is a commensal organism of the oral cavity and 
gut. The bacteria gain entry through wounds or tear in the 
soft tissue and forms painful abscess which contains yel -
low color granules in the visceral organs and as well as 
the skin. Diagnosis can be made by demonstration of the 
Gram-positive beaded filamentous organism when stained 
by Gram stain (Medleau and Hnilica, 2006).
Actinobacillosis: This is caused by Actinobacillus lig-
nieresii, which gets an entry into the soft tissue of the mouth 
by injury in the face and oral cavity. Clinically numerous 
painful abscess in the mouth and neck, which contains 
thick greenish white exudate with yellow sulfur granules. 
Diagnosis can be made by demonstration of Gram-negative 
bacteria. Cytology of the abscess content may reveal the 
presence of sulfur granules while histopathology may

Jacob).
FIG. 5 Mycobacterium infection on limbs. (Contributed by Dr. Jove Jacob).

260 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
suggest paniculitis. Treatment of this condition includes 
surgical drainage of the abscess with Sodium iodide and 
broad-spectrum antibiotic (Medleau and Hnilica, 2006).
Nocardiosis: It is caused by Nocardia asteroides and N. 
brasiliensis. The organism gets entry into the body through 
ingestion, inhalation and wound injury. Clinically there is 
inflammation of the subcutaneous tissue with the formation 
of a fistula. Lesions of nocardiosis are present in the ven -
tral part of the abdomen, limbs and foot pad. Diagnosis can 
be made based on the presence of Gram-positive acid-fast 
organism which appears as Chinese letters. Treatment con-
sists of cleaning of the lesion with antibiotic solution and 
administration of a combined antibiotic regime including 
ampicillin, sulfonamides, or cephalosporin ( Madleau and 
Hnilica, 2006).
Bubonic plague: This condition is caused by Yersinia 
pestis. The organism enters the body by ingestion of in -
fected rodents or by flea bites. Clinically Bubonic plague 
is characterized by abscess of lymph node, rise in tempera-
ture, septicemia and sometimes pneumonia. Diagnosis is 
made by history and clinical signs. The presence of Gram-
negative bipolar organisms in the affected lymph node is 
helpful. Confirmation of Yersinia organism by molecular 
techniques. Treatment is made by flushing the abscess with 
chlorhexidine solution followed by a long-term antibiotic 
course for at least 3 weeks (Toboada, 2000).
Aspergillosis: This condition is caused by Aspergillus 
fumigatus. The organism has special affinity toward the re-
spiratory system and the skin. Clinically, the condition is 
characterized by, mucosal nodules and mucohemorrhagic 
nasal discharge, accompanied by desquamation of nasal 
mucosa and epistaxis ( Madleau and Hnilica, 2006 ). Along 
with these, the organism also forms cutaneous nodules. 
Diagnosis can be made from the contents of the nodules, 
which may show presence of septate branching hyphae. 
Treatment with Fluconazole, Ketoconazole and Itraconazole 
proves to be effective (Campbell, 2004).
Blastomycosis: It is caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis. 
The organism gets entry into the body by inhalation of spore 
and causes systemic blastomycosis. Clinically, blastomyco-
sis can result in respiratory distress, eye problems like de -
tachment of the retina, inflammation of uvea and nervous 
symptoms, i.e., lameness and paralysis. Numerous ulcerat -
ing purulent nodules are found on the skin, face, claw and 
bridge of the nose. Diagnosis can be made by the demonstra-
tion of broad-based yeast with a double cell wall (Moriello, 
2004). Cytology of the nodules may reveal double-walled 
budding fungi with pyogranulomatous dermatitis. Treatment 
may include long-term antifungal drugs like fluconazole and 
amphotericin-B till the clinical signs subside.
Candidiasis: This condition is caused by Candida al -
bicans, Candida parapsilosis , which gains entry into 
the system through traumatized or injured skin surface 
and mucocutaneous junctions. Clinically, foul-smelling, 
 shallow, wet ulcerated areas covered with fibrinous de -
posits with an inflammatory zone are present. Diagnosis is 
made by demonstration of yeast from the exudates (Fig. 6). 
Histopathology may reveal hyperkeratosis and parakerato -
sis with the presence of yeast on the skin (Matousek, 2004). 
Treatment can be done by topical application of antifungal 
preparation or systemic administration of Ketoconazole, 
Itraconazole or Fluconazole.
Coccidiomycosis: It is caused by Coccidioides im -
mitis. The organism enters into the body by inhalation of 
the spore resulting into both cutaneous and systemic infec -
tion. Clinically the cutaneous form is presented with for -
mation of abscess distributed over the body surface, while 
the systemic disease is characterized by high rise of tem -
perature, difficulty in locomotion as the organism affects 
the bones. Moreover, there might be ocular problems like 
uveitis, blindness, etc. ( Moriello, 2004). Diagnosis can be 
made by demonstration of the endospore with double wall, 
along with evidence of pyogranuloma in the smear prepared 
from the cutaneous nodules ( Scott et  al., 2001 ). Advance 
molecular techniques including ELISA, PCR, complement 
fixation test, agglutination test can help in confirming the 
organism. Treatment includes a long-term antifungal course 
of Fluconazole, Itraconazole and Ketoconazole.
Cryptococcosis: This condition is caused by 
Cryptococcus neoformans . Organism gains entry into the 
body by inhalation of spore and is most commonly seen in 
animals which have direct or indirect contact with pigeon 
droppings. At the early phase of the infection, the organism 
affects the nasal sinuses, nasal cavity and the lungs where 
the organism continues to proliferate and spreads to the 
brain, eyes and lymph node. Clinically ulcerated granuloma 
is most commonly seen on the nose. Respiratory problems 
like mucopurulent nasal discharge, wheezing can be seen 
in animals. When the brain is affected the animal presents 
ocular disturbances, walking and coordination problem. 
Lymphadenopathy and cutaneous lesions are common 
on interdigital spaces, lips, nose and face ( Medleau and 
Hnilica, 2006). Diagnosis can be done by the history of ani-
mal residing or coming in contact with pigeon droppings. 
FIG. 6 Candida organism.

Diseases of integument system of dogs and cats   Chapter | 17  261
Biopsy of cutaneous nodules may present thin walled yeast 
with a clear refractile capsule ( Fig. 7). PCR, latex agglu -
tination test and ELISA can be helpful in the detection 
of the organism. Treatment includes surgical removal of 
the cutaneous nodules along with a long-term antifungal 
course of Itraconazole, Fluconazole, Amphotericin-B and 
Ketoconazole.
Dermatophytosis: This is a common condition in ca -
nines and felines affecting the stratum corneum and hair 
shaft caused by Microsporum canis , M. gypsum  and 
Trichophyton mentagrophytes . The affected animal pres -
ents exfoliative erythematous dermal lesion, seborrheic 
dermatitis lesion on the foot pad, scaling and crusting of 
the periocular region (Fig. 8) and different grades of alope-
cia with hyperpigmentation ( Madleau and Hnilica, 2006 ). 
Some animals may show circular areas of alopecia accom -
panied by scaling on the pinna which appears as “Cigarette 
ash.” Diagnosis can be made by examination of the hair 
shaft which emits apple green fluorescence when exam -
ined under Wood’s lamp (Thomas, 2004b). Demonstration 
of arthrospores in 10% Potassium hydroxide and fungal 
culture in Sabouraud’s dextrose agar using the Mackenzie 
method is useful in diagnosis. Histopathology of affected 
tissue reveals furunculosis, parakeratosis, orthokerato -
sis and perifolliculitis. Treatment includes bathing the 
animal with antifungal shampoo twice weekly. For se -
vere infection, systemic therapy should be started for at 
least 5–6 weeks and should be continued till two negative 
cultures.
Histoplasmosis: This condition is caused by Histoplasma 
capsulatum. The organism enters into the body by the inges-
tion and inhalation of the spores and affects the central ner-
vous system, skin, lymph nodes and eyes ( Mueller, 2004). 
Clinically the animal exhibits gastrointestinal disturbances, 
respiratory distress, fever, inappetency, defective vision 
and presence of ulcerated nodules on the body. Diagnosis 
is based on the presence of yeast with a halo around them 
(Fig. 9). Histology of the lesion shows dermatitis with in -
filtration of neutrophils with the intracellular organism. 
Treatment with fluconazole, amphotericin-B and itracon -
azole for a minimum of 4 months.
Lagenidiosis: It is caused by Lagenidium species. These 
organisms are a type of water molds that causes fungal in -
fection of the skin in animals that come in contact with such 
infected water. Clinically, the disease is characterized by an 
erythematous, localized area that may have nodules with 
hemorrhagic mucopurulent content. Diagnosis can be made 
by history of recent exposure to water bodies and the pres -
ence of granuloma on the body ( Moriello, 2004 ). Biopsy 
material may show the presence of branching hyphae with 
panniculitis, dermatitis, and infiltration of neutrophil, eo -
sinophil and giant cells. Immunomolecular technique like 
Western immunoblot and PCR is helpful to confirm the or-
ganism (Medleau and Hnilica, 2006 ). If the extremities of 
the limb have been affected severely, then amputation may 
be the only choice of treatment.
Malasseziosis: This is caused by Malassezia pachyder-
matis, M. globosa, M. sympodialis. The condition is char -
acterized by erythematous overgrowth of the epidermis,
