especially on the skin foldings and the pinna of the ear, 
neck, interdigital spaces, medial aspect of the thigh (Fig. 10A 
and B), axillae and abdomen (Thomas, 2004a). The affected 
area may show greasy seborrheic dermatitis and foul-  
smelling papules. Diagnosis can be made by the demon -
stration of the purple staining peanut-shaped fungi stained 
with Diff-Quik. Presence of lymphohistiocytic dermatitis 
with the presence of fungi in the biopsy material. Treatment 
with medicated shampoo containing Ketoconazole, 
Chlorhexidine, Miconazole, Selenium sulfide, or topical 
applications made from lime sulfur or Enilconazole may 
be effective (Scott et al., 2001 ). However, in severe cases, 
systemic administration of Itraconazole, Ketoconazole and 
Terbinafine is effective.
Pythiosis: It is caused by Pythium insidiosum which is 
an aquatic protozoan found in swampy and marshy areas. 
This condition is characterized by formation of numerous 
subcutaneous nodules which might rupture and may be cov-
ered with plaques. These ulcerating nodules are commonly 
seen on the inguinal area, feet, head and tail. Diagnosis can 
be made by history of exposure to swampy areas. Biopsy 
of the granuloma may show eosinophilic inflammation 
with dermatitis (Mueller, 2004). As detection of the fungal 
hyphae is difficult in the biopsy so molecular diagnostic 
technique, i.e., PCR, and ELISA is applied to identify the 
antigen. Treatment may include amputation of the limbs as 
antifungal drugs do not give good results.
Pseudomycetoma: It is caused by M. canis and T. men-
tagrophytes. This condition is characterized by purulent, 
nonpruritic, nonpainful nodules in the deeper layer of 
skin invading the dermis and subcutaneous tissue distrib -
uted on the body and tail ( Greene and Chandler, 1998 ). 
Diagnosis can be made by demonstration of fungus in the 
pyogranulomatous exudate. Cytology of nodular smear 
may present panniculitis and inflammation of the dermal 
layer with the presence of septate hyphae or pseudohyphae. 
Treatment includes complete removal of the nodules along 
with the administration of Itraconazole, Ketoconazole and 
Griseofulvin.
Sporotrichosis: This is caused by Sporothrix schenckii. 
Organism gains entry into the body either through penetrat-
ing wounds. These lesions are characterized by nonpainful, 
nonpruritic, nodules which are found distributed all over 
the body. The nodules are purulent in nature which might 
later discharge their content and get covered with plaque. 
Clinically Sporotrichosis is found in cutaneous form or 
cutaneolymphatic form. Diagnosis can be made by dem -
onstration of intra- or extracellular oval cigar-shaped uni -
cellular fungi in the smear made from the purulent nodules 
(Thomas, 2004a). Cytology of the nodule may reveal gran-
ulomatous dermatitis with increased infiltration of neutro -
phils. An immunofluorescent test and culture of the exudate 
may help in giving a confirmatory diagnosis ( Carlotti and 
Jacobs, 2000). Treatment can be done by Ketoconazole or 
Itraconazole.
Neosporosis: This condition is caused by Neospora 
caninum. Transplacental infection is the common mode 
of transmission. This condition is characterized by neuro -
muscular disorder. Clinically young animals may present 
lameness, paralysis, meningitis and encephalitis. While the 
older dogs present the cutaneous form of the disease with 
numerous, solid, fistulous nodules with ulceration on the 
face, neck, thorax, and perineum. Diagnosis can be made 
by demonstration of oval intracellular tachyzoites in the 
macrophages and keratinocytes collected from the nodular 
content (Curtis, 2004). Treatment can be done by antibiotics 
like Clindamycin and Trimethoprim-Sulfadiazine.
Leishmaniasis: It is caused by Leishmaniasis species. 
Organism enters into the body by blood-sucking flies be -
longing to Phlebotomus spp. Leishmaniasis is presented in 
Visceral and Cutaneous forms. The Visceral form shows 
inappetency, emaciation, pyrexia, conjunctivitis and hepa -
tosplenomegaly. While the cutaneous form is character -
ized by erythematous pustules on the skin and ulcerative 
dermatitis at the mucocutaneous junction, hyperkeratosis, 
periocular scaling and alopecia ( Madleau and Hnilica, 
2006). Cutaneous lesion is found distributed all over the 
body. Diagnosis can be by the demonstration of Leishmania 
amastigotes inside the macrophages ( Fig.  11). Molecular 
technique like ELISA, immunofluorescent technique, im -
munohistochemistry and PCR is useful in confirming the

organism ( Scott et  al., 2001 ). Histopathology may show 
parakeratosis, hyperkeratosis, perifolliculitis and round-
shaped, blue-colored Leishmania organism in the mac -
rophages. As Leishmaniasis does not have a cure, so the 
patient is given symptomatic treatment.
Otodectes infection: This infection is caused by mite 
named Otodectes cynotis. The mite lives on the skin surface 
of ears. Animals with this condition shows ear infection 
with increased waxy secretion from the ear canal, which 
appears as dirty brown accumulation in the ear and hence 
called “coffee ground” appearance. Secondary bacterial in-
fection is common with purulent exudate in the ear canal. 
Due to irritation in the ear canal and skin adjacent to the 
ear and face, self-inflicting injury and aural hematomas are 
very common. Diagnosis can be made by the presence of 
white flaky objects moving on the skin surface by the naked 
eye, or in the ear wax or superficial skin scrappings (Kennis, 
2004). Treatment can be done by cleaning the ear canal 
with antibiotic solution and application of medicated solu -
tion containing 10% fipronil solution. Animal with heavy 
mite infestation can be given spot on preparation containing 
Moxidectin, Selamectin or Ivermectin (Moriello, 2004).
Demodicosis: It is caused by D. canis , D. cornei  and 
D. ingai. Close contact with infected animal may transmit 
the infection. Demodicosis can result into immunosuppres-
sion by lowering T-lymphocytes. Demodicosis in found 
in cutaneous form, pododemodicosis form and demodec -
tic otitis form. Cutaneous demodicosis is characterized by 
erythematous lesion with scaling, alopecia and pruritus 
(Fig. 12). This form is commonly found in the periocular 
region. Pododemodicosis affects the footpad, interdigital 
space and appear edematous, erythematous, pyogenic le -
sion with intense pain and pruritus. Demodectic otitis is 
characterized by severe pruritic, erythematous lesion of 
ear with intense waxy deposits in the ear canal. Diagnosis 
can be made by demonstration of the mite in the deep skin 
scrappings and ear wax. Animals presented with seborrheic 
dermatitis should be examined for the presence of mite. 
Examination of the hair follicle and acetate tape impression 
is helpful in the identification of follicular mites (Matousek, 
2004; Bandi and Saikumar, 2013 ). Treatment can be done 
by topical solution containing lime sulfur, benzoyl peroxide 
and selenium sulfide. Amitraz can good results in patient 
with otitis and pododemodicosis.
Sarcoptic mange: Sarcoptic mange is caused by 
Sarcoptes scabiei var. canis. It is a very common infection 
of skin in dogs. However, it is not very common in cats. 
Wild foxes are considered to be the reservoir and carrier 
of this mite, which might spread in the shelter house and 
breeding house or pet animals coming in close contact. 
The mite sarcoptes has a tendency to burrow deep into the 
skin and results in the formation of papules on the body 
and limbs. Skin lesions are often seen on the hair less ar -
eas like the ventral side of abdomen, ear tips and elbows 
as papules covered with dry encrustation. Constant itchi -
ness may lead to self-inflicting injury like redness, tear of 
skin and laceration. Diagnosis can be made by demonstra -
tion of deep skin scrapings ( Bandi and Saikumar, 2013 ). 
Presence of the intact mite, mite eggs or mite feces on the 
skin, bedding material and kennels. Clinically, the affected 
area is reddish, hairless with encrustation of the skin le -
sion. Examination of biopsy material with demonstration of

FIG. 12 Demodicosis.

 hyperplasia of the skin, inflammatory cells with huge num-
ber of eosinophils. Presence of IgG antibodies can be dem-
onstrated by performing ELISA. Treatment can be made by 
Moxidectin and Selamectin topical application on the area 
(Bandi and Saikumar, 2013). Pets can be given a bath using 
5% Amitraz and 2%–3% lime sulfur. Parenteral drugs like 
1% Moxidectin and Ivermectin along with glucocorticoids 
can be effective. All the bedding material and kennel should 
be either incinerated. Environment containing the mites can 
be sprayed with permethrin solution. This is a zoonotic con-
dition, where it leads to constant irritation and scratching.
Trombiculiasis: Trombiculiasis is caused by Neotrombicula  
autumnalis, Walchi Americana and Eutrembicula spp. 
Neotrombicula are commonly found in grassland in coun -
tries with temperate climatic condition. However, this con-
dition is not a common skin infection in canine and feline 
and is also not considered to be zoonotic. Clinically, the le-
sion of these ectoparasite is seen in those part of the body 
which may be frequently come in contact with the ground 
like the paw and ear. The area has a characteristic bright, red 
dot like appearance, which is described as Paprika appear -
ance (Fig. 13). Affected area seems to be very itchy, with 
vesicle formation, development of wheals, eruptions and 
alopecia. Diagnosis can be made by demonstration of the 
mite appears to be bright red/orange dots of about 0.6 mm in 
length under microscope. Examination of biopsy material 
may show infiltration of eosinophils, with tissue destruc -
tion and sign of dermatitis (Portillo et al., 2020; Stekolvikov 
et al., 2014 ). Treatment can be done by using glucocorti -
coids to manage the pruritus. Spraying of fipronil 0.25% 
can be used as a preventive measure.
Hard tick infection: The most common hard ticks 
which affect the dog and cats are Rhipicephalus, Ixodes, 
Hemophysalis, Amblyomma and Dermacentor. Hard tick 
can affect both the felines and canines. As the tick has a 
nature to bite and suck blood from the skin, they result in 
irritation and sometimes there might be formation of granu-
lomatous growth usually called as tick head granuloma as 
the granuloma is formed when the tick body is removed 
by grooming, the head remains embedded deep in the skin 
resulting in chronic inflammation. Moreover, ticks are the 
potent carriers of protozoan, virus, bacteria and rickettsia 
(Jose et al., 2018 ). Diagnosis can be made by the demon -
strated of the tick and clinical sign. Treatment can be made 
by application of topical ascarides like Amitraz, Fipronil 
and Permethrin. Nowadays, roll-on or spot-on preparations 
containing acaricides may be advisable. Spraying the in -
fected environment with pyrethrin is useful.
Fleas: Fleas belonging to species Ctenocephalides canis 
is known to affect canines and may cause both nonflea allergy 
or flea allergy. It is documented that the flea saliva contains 
components which might induce both immediate type of hy-
persensitivity or delayed type of hypersensitivity. Animals 
having nonflea allergy may contain fleas on their hair coat 
but might not show any severe skin lesion except for a mild 
degree of moist dermatitis ( Motameni et al., 2014 ). While 
animals with flea allergy might present moist dermatitis with 
formation of innumerable papules, with crust formation loss 
of body hair and hyperpigmentation. Majority of the lesion 
are present on the back and ventral surface of the abdomen. 
Presence of numerous minute papules is called miliary der-
matitis, with heavy infiltration of eosinophilic. Diagnosis 
can be made by presence of intact fleas and flea dirt on the 
body and hair coat. Detection of blood mixed with flea feces 
by wet paper test can be useful. Another remarkable tech -
nique to confirm the by presence of flea is to demonstrate 
the presence of segments of Dipylidium caninum spp. in fe-
ces. Biopsy may present huge number of eosinophils with 
dermatitis ( Abdullah et  al., 2019 ). The lesion comprises 
reddish papules which may later get covered with dry crust 
(Fig. 14). Treatment is only effective when the population of 
flea is controlled. Application of pesticides like cypromazine 
and permethrin in the infested environment. Topical sprays 
contain fipronil is effective. Skin lesion can be treated with 
glucocorticoid like methylprednisolone is advised. For the 
hypersensitivity, administration of histamine along with an-
tibiotic may be effective.
Myiasis: By definition, myiasis means invasion of 
the skin and subcutaneous tissue with maggots of flies. 
Dipteran flies which usually gets attracted to the foul smell 
FIG. 13 Trombiculiasis infection.

Diseases of integument system of dogs and cats   Chapter | 17  265
of urine, feces and seeping wound when the flies belonging 
to the spp. Lucila, Calliphora, Chrysomyia, Sarcophaga and 
Musca. The flies usually lay eggs on body parts which is 
associated with excretion and necrosed area. Even the flies 
may eggs near the nasal orifice, where due to the passage 
of warm expired air aids in the hatching of eggs. The larva 
gradually dissolves the nearby skin and tissue by secreting 
enzymes. Clinically, lesions can be seen in around the uro -
genital opening, nose, mouth, eyes, infected and necrosed 
wounds and anal opening. Affected area appears wet, oozy 
necrotic tissue with presence of maggots ( Ali and Hossein, 
2016). Diagnosis can be made by the demonstration of 
fly larvae in the lesions ( Fig. 15). Treatment can be made 
by removal of the larvae by administration of Ivermectin. 
Affected area should be cleaned with antibacterial solution 
containing chlorhexidine. To hasten wound healing, some -
times debridement of the dead and nearby tissue is required.
Hook worm dermatitis: Ancylostomiasis is caused by 
Ancylostoma braziliense and Ancylostoma caninum. Pet 
dogs which spends most of the time in soil or kennels with un-
hygienic and infected environment. By nature, Ancylostoma 
enter the body by penetrating through the skin. Clinically, 
small papule like eruption on the skin especially in those 
area which remains in contact with earth. These papules on 
entry size can be seen in ventral side of the abdomen, thorax 
and paw. The area with reddish papules may present alopecia 
with itching (Qadir et al., 2011). The skin over the paw may 
show hyperkeratinization. Diagnosis can be made by dem -
onstration of Ancylostoma eggs (Brahmbhatt et al., 2015) by 
fecal floatation examination (Fig. 16). Examination of biopsy 
material may present intense eosinophilic infiltration, with 
perivascular dermatitis. Treatment can be done by adminis-
tration of mebendazole, fenbendazole and pyrantel pamoate. 
Transform the damp playing area into dry area to avoid sus-
ceptibility of parasitic ova. The kennel may be treated with 
sodium borate to inhibit hatching of Ancylostoma ova (Saari 
and Nikandu, 2006).
Pelodera dermatitis: Pelodera dermatitis is caused by 
Pelodera strongyloides. This parasite is found in dead, de -
caying land where the soil is considerably moist, which 
becomes convenient for the survival and viability of the 
parasitic ova. The larvae of the parasite after hatching have 
a tendency to penetrate through the skin of the animal 
which is in close contact with the soil. Clinically red color 
eruption may be seen accompanied by loss of hair. The 
region of the body commonly affected are the paw, legs, 
perineum and ventral surface of the skin over the sternum 
and abdomen. In chronic case, itching redness of the area 
is seen as the area might be subsequently infected by lichen 
and hyperpigmentation of the skin. Diagnosis can be made 
by the erythematous eruptions on the skin. Microscopical 
deep skin scrapping may reveal the larvae of Pelodera. 
Biopsy examination may present inflammation of the skin 
with eosinophilic infiltration, inflammation of the hair fol -
licles and development of furunculosis. Treatment can be 
made by administration of prednisolone to reduce itching

and  swelling. Antibiotics may be suggested if the affected 
area has been invaded by secondary bacterial infection. 
Washing of the body coat with salicylic acid is seen to be 
effective if followed by a subsequent dip comprising of 
2% lime sulfur. Treatment of the environment is equally 
important if the repeated infection of the parasite is to be 
stopped. The kennels can be treated with sodium borate 
and incineration of the affected bedding material (Saari and 
Nikandu, 2006).
Dracunculosis: Dracunculosis is caused by Dracunculus 
spp. Pet animals get the infection by eating the intermediate 
host of the parasite, i.e., a crustacean from a contaminated 
source of water. The larvae continue to develop in the sub -
cutaneous area of the leg region, while the female parasite 
returns to the skin surface and form a granuloma, so that 
when the animal visits any water body, the female may re -
lease the larvae through rupturing the granuloma. Clinically, 
focal or multifocal subcutaneous granuloma may be seen 
on the limb, abdomen and head ( Panciera and Stockholm, 
1988). The granuloma may be having a nonhealing fistulae 
and may be either itchy or painful. Diagnosis can be made 
by the history of visiting an unknown water body with sub-
sequent development of nodules on the body. Biopsy evalu-
ation may present a pseudocyst which might contain either 
the larval stage of the parasite or the adult nematode. The 
granuloma may also contain inflammatory cells, mostly 
eosinophils, necrotic tissue, debris and pus ( Garret et  al., 
2020). Best treatment is to dry out the nearby contami -
nated water source or decontamination of the water body 
to kill the parasitic larva. Animal can be treated by manual 
removal of the parasite by rolling up the entire parasite 
on a stick and surgical removal of the nodule. Drugs like 
thiabendazole and metronidazole work quite effectively in 
these infestation.
Dirofilaria infection: Dirofilariasis is caused by 
Dirofilaria immitis or D. repens. Pet animals get infection 
through the biting of mosquito or a biting fly. The interme-
diate host injects the larvae while sucking blood. The larva 
along with the blood circulation reaches the heart, where 
the larvae grow into mature size in the right ventricle. Due 
to increase in size the growing parasite occlude the entire 
right ventricle. Clinically itchy, reddish popular area which 
may turn into encrusted nodules ( Santoro et  al., 2019 ). 
These cutaneous lesions are common on the limbs, face 
and head. Diagnosis can be made based on the history of 
increased population of flies in the environment and pres -
ence of ulcerated nodules. Microscopical examination of 
the blood smear may demonstrate microfilaria. Knott’s test 
can be performed to demonstrate the microfilaria in blood 
(Fig. 17). Examination of biopsy material may demonstrate 
segments of microfilaria, huge number of eosinophils, sign 
of necrosis and pus ( Genchi et al., 2005 ). Treatment using 
melarsomine dihydrochloride and sodium thiacetarsamide 
seems to be effective.
Solar dermatitis: Pet animals like canine and felines who 
has a defective pigmentation in skin may show photosensi-
tivity. The animals may show various degree of sunburn due 
to the action of the harmful ultraviolet light, which might 
result into squamous cell carcinoma, carcinoma in situ and 
actinic keratoses. Clinically, older cats and dogs which are 
more to such skin condition. Animals which tends to play 
under the sun. Solar dermatitis can be seen to develop on the 
pinna of ear, eyelids, lips, nose and trunk. The affected area 
often show alopecia with ulceration, exudation and encrus-
tation. Diagnosis can be made based on the history of exces-
sive exposure to the sun. Biopsy examination may present 
hyperplasia of the epidermis and perivascular dermatitis. 
Keratinocytes may show presence of vacuolated epidermal 
cells and basophilic degeneration of elastin and dysplasia 
of the keratinocytes. In-situ carcinoma, the neoplastic cells 
may show hyperplasia and dysplasia which do not cross the 
basement membrane zone. Treatment can be done by us -
ing a sunscreen containing zinc oxide. Animals with severe 
skin reaction can be advised to use systemic prednisolone. 
Parenteral administration of Vitamin A and Beta-carotene is 
advised. In case of secondary bacterial infection, a course 
of antibiotic can be advised. However, it is best to avoid the 
sun exposure during day time.
Frost bite: Animals may suffer from frost bite due to 
prolonged exposure to freezing temperature or due to close 
contact with ice or freezing items. Normally the extremi -
ties of the body like toes, tip of the tail and tip of the pinna 
are affected. The affected part appears painful erythematous 
with dry necrosis and ulceration. Diagnosis can be made 
based on the history of exposure to freezing temperature 
for prolonged period and development of dry gangrene 
(Matousek, 2004). Treatment is made by surgical removal 
of the gangrenous part and advising appropriate antibiotics.
Callus: Callus is a skin condition which is characterized 
by thickening of the surface of skin due to prolonged ap -
plication of pressure by bony prominences which may re -
sult into obstruction of local blood supply and subsequent 
development of inflammation. Large breed dog which lives 
FIG. 17 Dirofilaria immitis larvae in blood smear.

Diseases of integument system of dogs and cats   Chapter | 17  267
or spends most of the time on hard surface like concrete 
and wood. Calluses are very common found on the bony 
prominences over the hock, sternum and elbows ( Fig. 18). 
These hyperkeratotic calluses are neither itchy or painful. 
Diagnosis can be made by the history and clinical signs. 
Examination of biopsy material may show hyperplasia, hy-
perkeratosis, parakeratosis, dilatations of the follicles and 
follicular keratosis ( Nishitani et al., 2017 ). Treatment can 
be made by altering the pets living environment by chang -
ing the hard budding surface to soft material.
Hygroma: Hygroma is a pathological condition charac -
terized by a cyst like growth over the area of bony promi -
nence on the skin. Clinically a swollen area with fluctuating 
fluid over the skin subjected to prolong pressure by the 
bony prominences. They are found over the elbows hock 
(Fig. 19) and sternum ( Johnston, 1975). Hygroma may be 
infected bacteria resulting into development of abscess with 
formation of fistula and also may transform into granulation 
tissue. Diagnosis can be made by the history and clinical 
signs. Cytological evaluation may show presence of hem -
orrhagic exudates without much inflammation. In hygroma 
with secondary bacterial infection may contain puss and in-
flammatory cells. Biopsy examination may demonstrate the 
presence of cyst like structure in the granuloma ( Angelou 
et  al., 2020 ). Treatment can be made by administration 
of a course of antibiotic in pyogranulomatous hygroma. 
Provision of soft bedding material can prevent the repeated 
trauma by the by the bony prominences on the skin.
Neoplastic condition:
Mast cell tumor: Of all the skin cancer, Mast cell tumor 
is considered to be one of the most common skin neoplastic 
condition in pet animals. Clinically, mast cell tumor is found 
in old animals, approximately about 8 years of age. As mast 
cell tumor is malignant in nature so they appear in various 
size and shape, which may be firm and soft (Midsorp, 2004). 
They might be either distinctly circumscribed or may be 
poorly demarcated with the adjacent tissue. Affected area 
may appear as a subcutaneous edematous, nodular or pap -
ule like or pedunculated growth on the skin. The size of the 
tumor may vary from a few millimeter to a few centimeter. 
The affected area may be alopecic or ulcerated with highly 
active vasculature. Most of the cancer growth is found in 
the head and face of cats, while in dogs, it might be pres -
ent in the paw, ventral side of the thorax, abdomen, back 
and in the inguinal region ( Kiupel et al., 2005 ). Diagnosis 
can be made from the biopsy material by demonstration of 
innumerable sheets of cells or tightly packed cords of cells 
which have huge amount of cytoplasm, distinct nuclei and 
bluish colored granules all over the cytoplasm (Fig. 20) and 
presence of intense infiltration of eosinophils (Weisse et al., 
2002). Treatment for grade I, focal tumors are removed sur-
gically along with excision of surrounding normal tissue of 
about 3 cm is advised. In case of diffused tumors, where sur-
gery is not fruitful, chemotherapy consisting of vinblastine, 
cyclophosphamide and prednisolone can be given. Other al-
ternative techniques including cryosurgery, electrosurgery 
and radiotherapy are also advised. Injecting deionized water 
or triamcinolone is yet another method of treatment.
Plasmacytoma: Plasmacytoma is a type of cancer which 
consists of plasma cells which may vary from few millime-
ter to a few centimeter, found on the body, paw, face and 
pinna. Plasma cells are derived from B lymphocytes which 
originates from the common lymphoid progenitor ( Ozkan 
FIG. 18 Callus.
FIG. 19 Hygroma.
 FIG. 20 Mast cell tumor.

268 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
et  al., 2014). These types of cancer are very common in 
aged animals, especially seen growing focally and singly 
with either a firm or soft consistency. The cancer may be 
pedunculated or ulcerated in appearance. Diagnosis can be 
made by examination of biopsy material collected from the 
affected area, with demonstration of clock faced nucleus 
distribution in the neoplastic cells, which is characteristic 
of plasmacytoma (Fig. 21). The condition can be confirmed 
by the presence of round cells which contain perinuclear 
halo and presence of mitotic body with pleomorphism. 
Treatment can be made by complete removal of the can -
cerous part. Plasmacytoma shows very low metastasis, so 
it is considered that once the cancer is removed it do not 
reoccurs. In felines, spread of cancer may be seen in to the 
lymph nodes (Rakich et al., 1989).
Transmissible venereal tumor: Transmissible venereal 
tumor is a malignant type of cancer of size up to 20  cm, 
which affects the external genitalia and sometimes the 
Internal genitalia. It is also called as Sticker’s tumor and ca-
nine transmissible venereal tumor. The cancer occurs due to 
close contact during coitus from one animal to another. But 
it has been documented that close contact with the tumor 
cell during grooming can also result into transmissible ve -
nereal tumor ( Milo and Smead, 2014 ). Clinically, reddish, 
irregular, pedunculated, hemorrhagic nodules may be seen 
on the external genitalia, face or sometimes on the limb. 
These nodules may grow either single or in a bunch of mul-
tiple nodule which may be firm or friable. Diagnosis can be 
made by history and clinical signs. Cytological examination 
of biopsy material may present numerous sheets of round 
cells which have abundant collagen stroma with numer -
ous mitotic body. Presence of blue cytoplasm with vacu -
oles ( Fig.  22) is another characteristic feature to confirm 
the condition (Varghese et al., 2012). Treatment is made by 
administration of chemotherapy. Drugs like vincristine and 
doxorubicin are found to be effective in transmissible vene-
real tumor. Surgical removal of the cancerous growth may 
also be advised. Radiotherapy may also be advised as the 
carcass cells are sensitive to radiation.
Epitheliotropic lymphoma: It is a type of cancer which 
consist of T-lymphocyte in dog and cat. The condition is 
seen in four clinical forms, i.e., exfoliative erythroderma, 
mucocutaneous ulceration ( Fig.  23), solitary or multiple 
nodules (Fig. 24) and plaque and infiltrative and ulcerative 
oral disease. Animals of about 9  years of age are mostly

FIG. 22 Transmissible venereal granuloma.
FIG. 23 Erythematous ulceration due to epitheliotropic lymphoma.
FIG. 24 Epitheliotropic lymphoma showing erythematous nodules and 
plaques on the ventral surface of abdomen.

Diseases of integument system of dogs and cats   Chapter | 17  269
 affected. Clinically, reddish plaques and nodules are seen 
on the abdomen. Mucocutaneous ulceration can be seen on 
the junction of gums and lips (Moore et al., 1994; Doe et al., 
1988). Diagnosis can be made by history and clinical signs 
examination of biopsy material collected from plaques or 
ulcers may reveal round neoplastic lymphoid cells with blu-
ish cytoplasm with lobular or indented nuclei. Examination 
of biopsy material may show infiltration of neoplastic lym-
phocyte into the dermis layer, follicles and sweat gland 
epithelium. Pautrier’s microabscess, i.e., aggregation of few 
neoplastic cells at multifocal local in the epidermal layer 
are pathognomonic. Treatment can be made by surgical re-
moval of single focal cancerous area. Whereas the multiple 
cancerous area are treated by chemotherapy consisting of 
vincristine, cyclophosphamide, prednisolone and metho -
trexate. Application of topical preparation is consistent of 
nitrogen mustard or propylene glycol.
Melanocytoma/melanoma: Melanoma or melanocytoma 
is defined as the intense proliferation of the melanocytes 
which may get transformed either into benign or malignant. 
Clinically these type of cancer occurs in aged dogs of about 
9 years of age. Melanocytoma normally occurs as single, well-
demarcated, alopecic, raised dark-colored wart-like or pedun-
culated growth of about 0.5–10.0 cm in diameter ( Fig.  25). 
These cancers are formed on the eyelid, muzzle, face, paws 
and body surface, melanoma appears as nonpigmented, dark-
colored, single which may vary in shape and grows up to 10 cm 
in diameter. Similar to melanocytoma, melanomas are found 
in scrotum, body coat, face, head, lip and digits. Diagnosis 
can be made by examination of biopsy material, which may 
demonstrate cells of various shape, i.e., oval, round, spindle 
or stellate cell containing considerable amount of cytoplasm 
containing black or green pigment. Neoplastic cells in mela-
noma appear pleomorphic with presence of pigments inside. 
Histopathology of tissue may show hyperplastic cells which 
may appear round, epithelial or spindle-shaped cells with vari-
ous degrees of pigmentation (Gillard et al., 2014). Treatment 
may be made by surgery with drugs like cisplatin, mitoxan-
trone, doxorubicin. Other than this, radiotherapy, photody -
namic therapy may also be suggested.
Squamous cell carcinoma: The older dogs and cats are 
affected by squamous cell carcinoma. Most of the squa -
mous cell carcinoma are found on the skin, paw and nail 
bed are reported to be the secondary cancerous lesion which 
has been metastasized from the lung. Due to cancer on leg, 
paw or nail bed, the affected animal may show lameness, 
without any pulmonary lesions or clinical signs. Diagnosis 
can be confirmed by the clinical signs, history and biopsy. 
Examination of biopsy material may reveal neoplastic cells 
with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and prominent nu -
cleus and nuclei. The neoplastic cells usually show atypical 
mitotic bodies and the characteristic laminated epithelial 
pearl ( Fig.  26) or cell nest ( Willcox et  al., 2019). As the 
prognosis is not good so treatment is usually not advised.

Chapter 18
Gastrointestinal disorders of dogs and cats
1 Esophageal disorders
Esophageal diseases show a limited amount of clinical signs 
and are easily misdiagnosed. The main symptom is regurgi-
tation, which is followed by respiratory distress along with 
dysphagia, odynophagia, and salivation. Esophageal dis -
orders in the dog and cat require emergency care ( Marks, 
2017).
Other nonspecific signs include weight loss, anorexia or 
voracious appetite, unkempt coat, and depression. Physical 
examination of the oral cavity and ventral neck region can 
be done for ruling out oropharyngeal disorders, dilation, or 
mass effects in the neck part of the esophagus.
Plain and contrast radiographs may reveal esophageal 
foreign bodies, dilation, strictures, thoracic masses, hia -
tal and diaphragmatic hernia, and gastroesophageal intus -
susceptions ( Mears and Jenkins, 1997 ). Radiographs will 
help to rule out aspiration pneumonia, pleural effusions, 
and pneumothorax which are serious complications of 
esophageal diseases. The presence of air in the esophagus 
may be due to aerophagia, megaesophagus, esophagitis, or 
an esophageal obstruction. Endoscopic examination of the 
esophagus allows visualization of intraluminal disorders, 
gastroesophageal reflux, esophagitis, strictures, diverticula, 
granuloma, and neoplasia. Serum biochemistry profiling is 
needed to assess systemic complications and possible risks 
of anesthesia along with hematology.
1.1 Megaesophagus
Megaesophagus is a disorder in which by esophagus losses 
tone and motility and flaccid dilation of the esophagus 
(Johnson et  al., 2009 ). Congenital megaesophagus has 
a higher prevalence in young dogs of certain breeds such 
as miniature schnauzer, fox terrier, German shepherd dog, 
Great Dane, German pointer, Rottweiler, bobtail, and Irish 
setter. Congenital idiopathic megaesophagus is common in 
puppies when they are started on solid food at about 4 weeks 
of age. Acquired-idiopathic megaesophagus usually has no 
known underlying etiology and occurs spontaneously in 
adult dogs between 7 and 15 years of age with no sex or 
breed predilection. Acquired megaesophagus with primary 
causes includes acquired myasthenia gravis, hypothyroid -
ism, hypoadrenocorticism, neuromuscular disorders such 
as botulism, polymyositis, polyradiculoneuritis, dysautono-
mia, bilateral vagal nerve damage, brainstem disease, lead 
toxicity, and organophosphate toxicity (Fig. 1).
Regurgitation is the most frequent sign of megaesopha-
gus in animals. As with other esophageal disorders, affected 
animals suffer from loss of body condition and secondary 
aspiration pneumonia. Routine hematobiochemical and 
urinalysis should be done to rule out potential secondary 
causes of megaesophagus. Thoracic radiography and/or 
an esophagram (barium study) reveal a diffusely dilated 
esophagus throughout the cervical and thoracic esophagus 
(Fig. 2). Routine hematology, serum biochemistry, urinaly-
sis and testing for myasthenia gravis (acetylcholinesterase 
receptor antibodies), hypoadrenocorticism (ACTH stimu -
lation test), and hypothyroidism (TSH, TT4, FT4) should 
be performed in all cases to investigate possible secondary 
causes of megaesophagus. Surgical correction is effective if 
done early in this disorder.
Megaesophagus without a primary cause is treated with 
elevated feedings of either gruel or meatball consistency of 
canned food giving small amounts frequently depending on 
the individual patient response and holding the dog in an 
upright position for 15 min after each feeding. Smooth mus-
cle prokinetic (e.g., metoclopramide or cisapride) therapy 
has been recommended for stimulating esophageal peristal-
sis in affected animals, however, having less effect on the 
striated muscle of the canine esophageal body ( Washabau, 
2003). Bethanechol (5–15 mg/dog PO TID) is shown to 
have significant pro-kinetic action in the therapy of this dis-
order. Oral sucralfate suspensions (1 g TID for large dogs, 
0.5 g TID for smaller dogs, and 0.25–0.5 g BID-TID for 
cats) for managing esophagitis in idiopathic megaesopha -
gus are recommended ( Tytgat et  al., 1995). High-calorie, 
high-energy feedings should be given for the management

272 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
of malnutrition. A common complication of megaesopha -
gus is aspiration pneumonia due to frequent regurgitation of 
food and water which should be treated aggressively with 
intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics, intravenous fluid 
therapy, nebulization, and coupage. Gastrostomy tubes can 
be placed in severe cases. Animals affected are at risk of 
aspiration pneumonia which can lead to death.
1.2 Esophagitis
Esophagitis denotes a localized or diffuse inflammation 
that may damage tissues of the esophagus. Etiology of 
esophagitis includes caustic or chemical (i.e., gastric acid, 
bile acids) injury, injury from esophageal foreign bodies, 
gastroesophageal reflux, radiation injury, idiopathic gener -
alized megaesophagus, and inflammation associated with 
malignancy. Anesthesia-induced gastroesophageal reflux 
is the most commonly reported cause in the veterinary lit -
erature. In cats, tetracyclines have the substantial potential 
to cause esophagitis ( Schulz et al., 2013 ). Esophagitis can 
cause esophageal hypomotility and thus gastroesophageal 
sphincter weakness by impairing the excitatory cholinergic 
pathways to the gastroesophageal sphincter.
Signs characteristic of esophagitis include regurgitation, 
salivation, odynophagia (inferred pain), an extension of the 
head and neck during swallowing, and avoidance of food 
(Sellon and Willard, 2003 ). Coughing may be observed in 
some animals with concurrent aspiration pneumonia.
The esophagus often appears normal on survey thoracic 
radiographs unless there is secondary dilation or aspira -
tion pneumonia. Barium contrast radiographs may reveal 
irregular mucosal surface, segmental narrowing, esopha -
geal dilation, stricture formation, and/or diffuse esophageal 
hypomotility. Endoscopy and biopsy are the most reliable 
means of diagnosing this disorder.
The treatment of esophagitis is directed at the under -
lying causes and preventing further injury by withholding 
oral food intake for 2–3 days while supporting the animal’s 
nutritional needs. Oral sucralfate suspensions at the dose 
rate of 0.5–1.0 g p.o., tid which may assist in healing of the 
FIG. 1 Classification of megaesophagus.
FIG. 2 (A) Megaesophagus plain radiography in dog revealing aerophagia in cervical esophagus and a triangular pocket of air in thoracic esophagus 
cranial to base heart. (B) Mega esophagus contrast study in a dog revealed dilated esophagus filled with barium contrast.

Gastrointestinal disorders of dogs and cats  Chapter | 18  273
mucosal surface are indicated in therapy for esophagitis 
(Marks et al., 2018). Antacids (e.g., calcium carbonate), H2-
blockers, and proton pump inhibitors were used to reduce 
the acidity of gastric secretions. The prokinetics metoclo -
pramide and cisapride are used to increase lower esophageal 
sphincter tone and increase gastric emptying (Wilson et al., 
2006). Cisapride is considered superior to metoclopramide. 
Oral antibiotics are required in animals with aspiration 
pneumonia or severe esophagitis. Restoration and mainte -
nance of adequate nutrition are of utmost importance. If the 
animal is willing to eat, feeding blenderized foods from an 
elevated position may be all that is needed.
1.3 Esophageal strictures
Esophageal stricture formation in dogs and cats mostly re -
sults from esophageal injury and esophagitis. Esophageal 
inflammation that extends through the mucosa into the sub-
mucosa and muscularis leads to collagen deposition and 
scarring. If the scarring is severe enough, an esophageal 
stricture develops. Other causes of esophageal stricture in -
clude congenital strictures, persistent right aortic arch, and 
extramural esophageal compression secondary to a mass. 
Approximately 80%–90% of strictures in dogs and cats are 
located in the intrathoracic esophagus, particularly between 
the heart base and gastroesophageal junction ( Adamama-
Moraitou et  al., 2002 ). Most strictures appear as focal 
circumferential narrowings formed by smooth, glistening-
white, fibrotic rings or ridges. The clinical signs of progres-
sive regurgitation and dysphagia are related to the severity 
and extent of the stricture. Animals with strictures may 
tolerate liquids better than solids. With progressive esopha-
geal narrowing and inflammation, affected animals develop 
complete anorexia, weight loss, and malnutrition. Some an-
imals also develop aspiration pneumonia. The diagnosis is 
based on clinical history and radiographic and endoscopic 
findings. Oral feedings should be withheld in cases of se -
vere stricture. Esophageal strictures are best managed with 
mechanical dilation with balloon dilatation catheters or 
bougienage tubes. Medical management includes pain med-
ication (butorphanol), omeprazole, and sucralfate similar to 
the treatment of esophagitis. Anti-inflammatory doses of 
corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone 0.5–1.0 mg/kg p.o. or i.m., 
bid) have been advocated to prevent fibrosis and restricture 
during the healing phase following esophageal dilation.
1.4 Esophageal foreign bodies
An esophageal foreign body (EFB) is any ingested item 
that fails to pass into the stomach after being swallowed. 
EFBs lodge most often at the thoracic inlet, the base of 
the heart, or the gastroesophageal sphincter, which are the 
least-distensible regions of the esophagus. The most fre -
quently reported EFBs in companion animals are bones, but 
large pieces of food, hairballs (trichobezoars), treats (dental 
chews, rawhide), and sharp objects (needles, fishhooks) can 
also become lodge. Relatively rare in cats, who are much 
more discriminatory eaters. Foreign bodies may injure the 
esophageal mucosa and cause complications such as esoph-
agitis, perforation, or stricture.
Clinical signs associated with an EFB include pain with a 
change in posture or head carriage, drooling (may or may not 
be bloody), regurgitation, repeated attempts to swallow, and 
anorexia. In severe cases, hematemesis and respiratory dis-
tress may predominate. Survey thoracic and cervical radio-
graphs are usually diagnostic for radiopaque foreign bodies 
and radiolucent objects can be identified if outlined by air, or 
they may require barium contrast radiography or esophagos-
copy (Fig.  3). Thoracic films should be reviewed carefully 
for evidence of air in the mediastinum, pleural effusion, or 
aspiration pneumonia. Free air or pleural fluid indicates per-
foration and associated mediastinitis, pleuritis, or pyothorax.
Esophageal foreign bodies should be removed promptly. 
Recently ingested food items, bones, and treats may be 
managed with relatively simple approaches, whereas a fish-
hook usually requires endoscopic or surgical removal. Items 
(particularly bone or other rigid material) that have been in 
the esophagus for prolonged periods (>24 h) may cause mu-
cosal necrosis; 1–4 these patients are probably best served 
by an endoscopic approach.
Specific therapy for esophagitis should include oral su -
cralfate suspensions (0.5–1.0 g p.o., tid). Anti-inflammatory 
doses of glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone 0.25–0.5  mg/
kg p.o., bid) should also be considered in those animals at 
risk for esophageal stricture. An injectable proton pump 
inhibitor (e.g., pantoprazole at 0.5–1.0  mg/kg i.v. given 
over 15 min) should be administered to mitigate additional 
esophageal damage secondary to gastric reflux. Parenteral 
antibiotics are indicated for patients with aspiration pneu -
monia and/or signs of pleural effusion or pneumomedias -
tinum. Surgery is indicated if endoscopy fails or if there is 
evidence of esophageal perforation. The overall prognosis 
for dogs with an EFB is fairly good; reported survival rates 
are 75%–95%.
FIG. 3 Right lateral radiography of a dog revealed radiodense foreign 
body in cervical esophagus in a dog.
