1.5 Esophageal tumors
Although very rare, esophageal neoplasia occurs occasion -
ally in dogs and cats. Squamous cell carcinomas, osteo -
sarcomas, leiomyomas ( Rolfe, 1994 ), and fibrosarcoma 
secondary to Spirocerca lupi (Fig. 4) have been reported. 
Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common feline esoph-
ageal tumor. Esophageal malignancies more commonly 
occurred in the caudal thoracic esophagus ( Ranen et  al., 
2004). Clinical signs are typically caused by mechanical 
obstruction and poor esophageal motility in the region of 
the tumor. Clinical signs of esophageal obstruction are pres-
ent and may occur progressively with the patient presenting 
with severe weight loss and malnutrition. Diagnosis is by 
thoracic radiographs, esophagram, and endoscopic biopsy 
(Willard et al., 2010 ). Surgical resection of the tumor and 
radiation therapy can be considered but overall the progno-
sis is very poor for the long term.
1.6 Gastroesophageal intussusception
Gastroesophageal intussusception (GEI) is a rare condition 
in dogs resulting from invagination of the stomach into the 
esophagus, and GEI combined with or without herniation 
of the spleen, duodenum, pancreas, and omentum (Patsikas 
et al., 2019). Young, male, medium-to-large breed dogs are 
overrepresented. In patients with the incompetence of the 
lower esophageal sphincter, vomiting during anesthesia for 
endoscopy can lead to temporary gastroesophageal intus -
susception that resolves spontaneously. Gastroesophageal 
intussusception is a true gastrointestinal emergency that 
may culminate in the death of the animal if untreated. The 
initial clinical signs are vomiting or regurgitation, dyspnea, 
hematemesis, and abdominal discomfort, and delayed in -
tervention may lead to a marked deterioration in condition, 
shock, respiratory and cardiac arrest, and death. Survey ra -
diographs and endoscopy for confirmation can be used in 
diagnosis. The recommended therapy is a brief period of 
stabilization followed by definitive endoscopic or surgical 
reduction.
1.7 Vascular ring anomalies
Vascular ring anomalies are congenital malformations of 
the major blood vessels of the body that result in esopha -
geal entrapment and constriction. The persistent right aor -
tic arch is the most common vascular ring anomaly found 
in dogs and cats. While vascular ring anomalies can arise 
from the abnormal development of the third, fourth, or 
sixth aortic arches, the most common is the persistence of 
the fourth right aortic arch (a.k.a. PRAA) which makes up 
95% of all cases in dogs and most of the cases in cats. More 
commonly affected dog and cat breeds include German 
shepherd, Irish setter, Boston terrier, German pinscher, 
Greyhound, Persian, and Siamese. Affected puppies and 
kittens are presented at a young age 2–6 months around the 
time of they are weaned from milk to solid food. Signs ob -
served include stunted animals with thin body conditions, 
voracious appetite, regurgitation, and sometimes even 
bulging of the neck in the region of the dilated esophagus. 
The diagnosis of a vascular ring anomaly is based upon a 
compatible history and the barium contrast radiographic 
finding of esophageal body dilation cranial to the base of 
the heart. They are best treated by conventional thoracot -
omy or interventional thoracoscopy. Medical management 
can be attempted through elevated feedings of a liquid diet 
as palliative but due to chronic regurgitation in affected 
animals, secondary aspiration pneumonia, and failure 
to thrive due to the inability to consume an appropriate 
amount of calories. Long-term prognosis is poor with this 
treatment option.
1.8 Dysautonomia
It is characterized by generalized and progressive dysfunc -
tion of the autonomic nervous system. Megaesophagus, 
esophageal hypomotility, and regurgitation are fairly con -
sistent findings. No definitive etiology has ever been es -
tablished. Physical examination findings consistent with 
dysautonomia include dry mucous membranes, pupillary 
dilation, prolapsed nictitating membranes, reduced or ab -
sent pupillary light reflex, bradycardia, and areflexic anus 
(Bexfield et al., 2006).
Survey or barium radiographs may reveal esophageal 
dilation and hypomotility gas-filled dilated stomach and 
bowels, reduced tear production in Schirmer tear tests, and 
atropine-insensitive bradycardia are findings consistent 
with the diagnosis.
Supportive care (e.g., artificial tears, elevated feedings, 
expressing the urinary bladder, antibiotics, etc.) is still the 
FIG. 4 Endoscopic view of nodules by Spirocera spp.

Gastrointestinal disorders of dogs and cats  Chapter | 18  275
basis of therapy in this disorder. Dogs and cats are reported 
to show mild improvement with parasympathomimetic 
drugs (e.g., bethanechol or metoclopramide).
2 Gastric disorders
2.1 Gastric dilatation and volvulus (GDV)
GDV is a life-threatening condition in dogs that will be 
started as fluid or gas accumulation in the stomach. If left 
untreated it will progress to volvulus and other organs are 
quickly compromised.
Etiology of this condition is unknown but numerous pre-
disposing factors (Glickman et al., 2000) are identified which 
include body conformation (deep chested large breeds, lean 
body size), diet (dry diets, once-daily feeding, eating more 
quickly, particles >30 mm in diameter have been shown 
to reduce the risk), behavioral traits (fearful temperament, 
experienced a stressful event, kenneling or a journey in the 
previous 24 h, aggression to people, stress may alter gastric 
motility or increase aerophagia), infection with nasal mites, 
colonization of the stomach with Sarcina ventriculi, and in-
flammatory bowel disease (Broome and Walsh, 2003).
The gas-filled stomach may rotate between 180 and 
360 degrees in a clockwise direction (Fig. 5). This can pro-
duce both local and systemic effects. The local effects of 
GDV are concerned with the blood supply to the gastric 
wall. Dislocation of the greater curvature of the stomach 
can cause dislocation of the spleen which may result in 
avulsion of the short gastric branches of the splenic artery 
(which lays in the gastrosplenic ligaments and supplies the 
gastric fundus). This leads to hemorrhage from the artery 
and  ischemic changes in the fundus. The pylorus and cardia 
of the stomach get obstructed due to the rotations which 
prevent gastric emptying and further expansion of the stom-
ach. This leads to increased tension in the gastric walls 
and compression of intramural blood vessels. The dilated 
stomach exerts pressure on the diaphragm, creating a de -
creased tidal volume and increased respiratory rate. Splenic 
displacement leads to venous congestion and splenomegaly. 
Avulsion of the splenic artery and thrombosis can result in 
partial or complete splenic torsion or infarction. Systemic 
effects are mainly due to obstruction of blood flow through 
the caudal vena cava and hepatic portal vein which causes 
a sudden decrease in the venous return, cardiac output, and 
hypotension. Vascular damage and poor perfusion cause 
hypoxia and tissue ischemia ( Sharp and Rozanski, 2014 ). 
Anaerobic metabolism due to hypoxia leads to the accumu-
lation of lactic acid in the circulation. Myocardial ischemia 
and cardiac arrhythmias are common findings in animals 
affected with GDV . Septic peritonitis (due to perforation 
of the gastric wall), systemic inflammatory response syn -
drome, and disseminated intravascular coagulation are the 
complication of GDV ( Uhrikova et al., 2013 ). Progressive 
distension of the abdomen, retching, unproductive vomit -
ing, and hypersalivation are the main presenting symptoms 
in the animals with GDV . As the condition progressed, ani-
mals become weak and recumbent. Clinical signs of shock, 
such as a weak pulse, tachycardia, prolonged CRT, and pale 
mucous membranes, may be present. Tachypnoea and dys-
pnea may also be present.
Diagnosis can be done mainly from the history, clini -
cal signs, and physical examination. Hematological ab -
normalities including leukocytosis and thrombocytopenia 
may be evident. Biochemical changes depend on the organs 
affected like elevated liver enzymes, bilirubin, BUN, and 
FIG. 5 Rotation of stomach in GDV .

276 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
creatinine. Radiographic examination is not required for di-
agnosis of GDV but it will help to differentiate from GD. 
Animals with GDV will reveal a typical double bubble ap -
pearance (Monnet, 2003). Free gases in the abdominal cav-
ity indicate perforation of the stomach.
GD without volvulus, abdominal effusion, food en -
gorgement, and abdominal masses has to be deferentially 
diagnosed with the help of abdominal radiography. Lateral 
abdominal radiography reveals two different gas-filled 
compartments indicating GDV (Fig. 6).
The primary aim is to stabilize the patient before surgi -
cal correction. The animal may be in shock, so fluid therapy 
at a shock dose (90  mL/kg) should be initiated as soon as 
possible (hypertonic crystalloid or colloid followed by iso -
tonic crystalloids). Avoid veins in the hind quarter as the 
caudal vena cava is obstructed ( Sullivan and Yool, 1998). 
Decompression and stabilization of the stomach can be 
achieved by orogastric intubation. If orogastric intubation is 
not possible, percutaneous decompression can be achieved 
by gastrocentesis with large bore needles caudal to the ribs 
on the side with maximum distension and tympany. The 
animals with GDV are suffering from severe discomfort 
which may be addressed with opioid analgesics (morphine 
or methadone at a dose of 0.1–0.3  mg/kg i.m. or fentanyl 
2–4 μg/kg i.v.). Oxygen supplementation will help the ani -
mals with respiratory discomfort. Broad-spectrum antibiot-
ics like cephazolin (22 mg/kg i.v. every 2 h) or a combination 
of ampicillin (22 mg/kg i.v. every 8 h), cefuroxime (20 mg/
kg), and enrofloxacin (5–10  mg/kg every 24  h) are recom -
mended because of the impaired gastric mucosal barrier. 
Once the animal is stabilized, surgical correction of gastric 
dilatation-volvulus is performed to de-rotate the stomach, 
evaluate the viability of the stomach and spleen, perform a 
gastrectomy or a splenectomy if needed, and pexy the stom-
ach to prevent reoccurrence.
Prevention of GDV in animals depends on several fac -
tors like avoiding heavy feeding (once daily) instead more 
frequent small quantity meals are preferred. Avoid foods 
with particle diameter  < 30 mm. Separate feeding to the 
dogs is preferred to reduce sudden intake. Reduce stress as 
it is a predisposing factor. Prophylactic gastropexy is indi -
cated in animals with a risk of GDV .
2.2 Gastritis
Gastritis is the term used for inflammation of the stomach 
characterized by vomiting. Based on the onset and dura -
tion of vomiting, gastritis is divided into acute or chronic. 
Sudden onset of vomiting is the main characteristic of acute 
gastritis whereas intermittent and prolonged vomiting is an 
indication of chronic gastritis. Gastritis is classified based 
on the onset, nature of predominant cellular infiltrate, pres-
ence of architectural abnormalities, and etiology (Fig. 7).
2.2.1 Acute gastritis
Dietary carelessness, consumption of coarse foreign bodies, 
plant materials, chemicals irritants, medication (NSAIDs, 
glucocorticoids), viral diseases (e.g., canine parvovirus, 
FIG. 6 Right later radiograph of nondescript dog showing gastric dila -
tion and volvulus dog with typical revealing double bubble appearance to 
the stomach—showing air dilation and a shelf of stomach wall from the 
twist in the stomach.
FIG. 7 Classification of gastritis.

Gastrointestinal disorders of dogs and cats  Chapter | 18  277
 feline panleukopenia, canine distemper), and bacterial in -
fections (e.g., Helicobacter spp.) are the main cause of 
acute gastritis (Webb and Twedt, 2003).
The predominant clinical sign is vomiting. V omitus may 
contain food, bile, froth, frank blood, digested blood, or evi-
dence of an ingested substance.
History and clinical signs may help in the diagnosis 
of acute gastritis. History of toxin ingestion or foreign 
body is indicative of the acute condition. The animal 
with a prying posture is suggestive of acute gastric pain. 
Radiographic evaluation with plain and contrast medium 
may help to find out the foreign bodies and the ulcers in 
the gastric mucosa. Endoscopy or gastric ultrasonography 
may be useful.
The treatment for acute gastritis may be initiated with 
complete gastric rest for 12–24  h with no oral food. Easily 
digestible bland food can be given in low quantity with in -
creased frequency. Isotonic crystalloids may be used to cor-
rect dehydration, relative polycythemia, hypokalemia, and 
hyponatremia with potassium supplementation. Stoppage 
of drugs (NSAID and steroid) is indicated in drug-induced 
gastritis. In case of protracted vomiting antiemetic’s like 
maropitant (1 mg/kg/day, s.c. or i.v., or 2  mg/kg/day, p.o.) 
or ondansetron (0.1–1  mg/kg, p.o. or i.v., bid) or metoclo -
pramide (0.3 mg/kg, p.o. or s.c., tid) can be used. Gastric 
protectants include H-2 receptor antagonists (cimetidine, 
ranitidine @ 2 mg/kg bid, famotidine @0.5 mg/kg bid), pro-
ton pump inhibitors (omeprazole @ 1 mg/kg p.o. o.d., pan-
toprazole @ 1 mg/kg i.v.), cytoprotectants (sucralfate), and 
synthetic prostaglandins (misoprostol @ 0.5–2.3 μg/lb) may 
be used in case of gastric ulceration.
2.2.2 Chronic gastritis
Chronic gastritis is characterized by intermittent vomit -
ing for more than 1–2  weeks. Chronic gastritis is classified 
based on the nature of cellular infiltrates (eosinophilic, lym-
phoplasmacytic, granulomatous, or lymphoid follicular), 
the presence of architectural abnormalities (atrophy, hyper-
trophy, fibrosis, edema, ulceration, or metaplasia), severity 
(mild, moderate or severe). Food allergy or intolerance is 
also a possible reason ( Patel et al., 2018 ). The most com -
mon clinical signs are intermittent vomiting (bile or food), 
anorexia, lethargy, and weight loss. The fungal infection 
may cause abdominal masses, lymphadenopathy, or ocu -
lar changes. Gastric foreign bodies, food allergies, irritant 
drugs, parasites, fungal infections, or bacterial infections 
are considered the cause of chronic gastritis.
An abdominal radiograph may reveal a diffusely thick -
ened gastric wall ( Fig.  8), the presence of foreign bodies 
(Fig. 9), and contrast radiography is required for identify -
ing gastric ulcers and radiolucent foreign bodies ( Fig. 10A 
and B). Endoscopic examination may reveal foreign bodies, 
hemorrhage, ulceration, abnormal content, parasites, or hy-
perplasia. Bacterial isolation of the gastric content is useful 
to know the Helicobacter spp. infection. Gastric biopsies 
are required to understand the cellular infiltrate.
2.2.3 Parasitic gastritis
Parasitic gastritis is comparatively rare in small animals; 
Spirocerca lupi, Gnathostoma spinigerum , Ollulanus tri -
cuspis (cats) , Physaloptera rara , Physaloptera canis , 
Heterobilharzia americana are the major culprit in para -
sitic gastritis 23. Antinematodal drugs like fenbendazole @ 
10 mg/kg or pyrantel pamoate @ 5 mg/kg can be effectively 
used to treat the parasitic gastritis.
2.2.4 Mycotic gastritis
Mycotic gastritis is characterized by fungal granulomas 
which may obstruct gastric outflow. Gastric phycomycosis 
is characterized by minute nonspecific changes to thicken -
ing mucosal folds of the gastric wall with outlet hindrance. 
Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungi that can cause 
FIG. 8 Chronic gastritis in a dog revealing diffusely thickened stomach 
wall.
FIG. 9 Right lateral radiograph of dog showing gravel sign in the stom -
ach due to a chronic, partial outflow obstruction. Small, radiopaque frag -
ments of ingesta accumulate in a distended pylorus.

278 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
subclinical or clinical granulomatous condition among 
other organs including the GI tract. Pyogenic granulomas 
are commonly encountered in Pythium insidiosum infection 
which may produce pyogenic granulomas in mucosa and 
submucosa of the stomach and different places of the GI 
tract (Amorim et al., 2016). Cryptococcus neoformans may 
also act as a cause of granulomatous gastritis which obstruct 
gastric outflow.
If the granulomas are obstructing gastric outflow, they 
should be removed surgically and treated with systemic 
antifungal drugs including itraconazole (10  mg/kg p.o. 
sid) and terbinafine (5–10  mg/kg p.o. sid) for 2–3  months 
post-surgery.
2.2.5 Gastritis due Helicobacter spp.
Helicobacter pylori  is considered as major pathogen in 
human beings, whereas the prevalence of H. pylori is not 
common in dogs and cats. H. felis, Helicobacter bizzozero-
nii, and Helicobacter heilmannii sensu stricto ( s.s.) are the 
predominant species isolated from canine and feline gastri-
tis cases ( Taillieu et al., 2022 ). H. pylori have been rarely 
identified in the canine stomach. Helicobacter spp. popu -
lations are frequently seen in the fundus and body of the 
stomach. “Triple therapy” with amoxicillin 20  mg/kg bid, 
metronidazole 10 mg/kg bid, and antacid famotidine or with 
three antibiotics (amoxicillin (20 mg/kg p.o. bid), clarithro-
mycin (7.5  mg/kg p.o. bid), and metronidazole (10  mg/kg 
p.o. bid) for 14 days) may be effective against Helicobacter 
organism. Alternative eradication therapy with tetracycline 
20 mg/kg BID and omeprazole 0.7 mg/kg o.d. administered 
orally for the next 10 and 14 days.
2.2.6 Gastritis due to other conditions
Portal hypertension due to hepatic disease leads to change in 
gastric flow, reduced epithelial turnover, hyperacidity, and 
raised serum bile acid concentration which in turn stimulate 
secretion of Gastrin-17 and finally ends up with apoptosis 
of gastric epithelial cells (Ozaki et al., 2002).
The mast cell tumor releases histamine which binds to 
H2 receptors on gastric parietal cells, and stimulate acid 
secretion.
Clearance of Gastrin-17 is mainly through the kidney, 
so renal diseases hamper the clearance of Gastrin-17 which 
lead to hypergastrinemia and increased gastric acid produc-
tion. It is the main cause of vomiting and gastric ulcer for -
mation in renal disease ( Peters et al., 2005 ). Renal failure 
also causes uremia and urea diffuses from interstitial fluids 
to the stomach, resulting in damage to the epithelial cell 
layer of the gastric wall.
Appropriate therapy has to be initiated to control the 
systemic illness is warranted to alleviate the gastritis is rec-
ommended along with proper diet. Gastric imaging and bi -
opsies are needed for further diagnosis.
2.2.7 Lymphocytic-plasmacytic gastritis and 
eosinophilic gastritis
Chronic gastritis is classified based on the nature of cellular 
infiltrate with lymphocyte and plasma cells or eosinophils. 
Lymphoplasmacytic gastritis is reported in Helicobacter 
spp. An infection is characterized with or without hyperpla-
sia of lymphoid follicles, infiltration of lymphocytes, and 
other inflammatory cells, including Russell bodies into the 
lamina propria layer of the stomach. Eosinophilic gastritis 
can be diffuse like widespread hypersensitivity reaction or 
focal. It may be due to an allergy to food or parasites or 
mastocytoma (Amorim et al., 2016).
Mild or moderate lesions can be treated symptomatically 
with a hypoallergic diet. In severe cases, immunosuppres -
sive therapy can be initiated with prednisolone 2 mg/kg/day 
and tapered to a minimum dose. In the case of  nonresponsive 
FIG. 10 (A) Contrast radiography showing radiolucent mango kernel in the pyloric area. (B) Mango kernel defecated after laxative therapy.

Gastrointestinal disorders of dogs and cats  Chapter | 18  279
dogs or prolonged steroid therapy, other drugs like azathio-
prine 2 mg/kg, p.o., every 24–48 h or cyclosporine 5 mg/kg, 
p.o., twice daily can be considered. Chlorambucil 2 mg/cat, 
p.o., every 48–72 h for 2–4 weeks then tapered to 2 mg every 
72–96 h may be a safer alternative to azathioprine in cats 
(p.o.). Delayed gastric emptying may respond to prokinetic 
agents (metoclopramide, erythromycin or cisapride).
2.2.8 Chronic atrophic gastritis
Chronic atrophic gastritis is characterized by diffuse lesions 
in the fundus and body of the stomach and reduced mucosal 
layer thickening as well as hypochlorhydria, achlorhydria, 
and a proportionally increased number of mucus- producing 
cells within the gland. Glandular atrophy mononuclear 
infiltration, regenerative glandular nesting and mucosal 
fibrosis and loss of feedback mechanism may lead to in -
creased serum gastrin level which causes gastric ulceration. 
Treatment options include dietary management and im -
mune suppression.
2.2.9 Chronic hypertrophic gastropathy
It can be focal or diffuse based on the hypertrophic le -
sions present in the gastric mucosa, muscularis, or both 
(Walter et al., 1985 ). Focal-type chronic hypertrophy was 
reported in animals with chronic administration of aspirin. 
Hypertrophic glandular gastritis is seen in Basenji dogs 
(diffused immune proliferative enteropathy) and other dogs 
(hypergastrinemia). Chronic hypertrophic pyloric hypertro-
phy is characterized by hypertrophy of the mucosal layer 
of the antropyloric stomach which obstructs gastric outflow 
and leads to projectile vomiting. Surgical correction of hy -
pertrophied tissue may be required.
2.3 Gastric/peptic ulceration
Ulcers are mucosal defects that penetrate through the mus -
cularis mucosa, and may be attributed to many etiologies, 
usually known as peptic ulcers. This includes ulcers in the 
stomach and duodenal mucosa as both are bathed by pepsin. 
Physical damage to the gastric mucosa, impaired mucosal de-
fense and chemical alteration to the mucosa and its repair pro-
cess can lead to gastric ulcer formation (Parrah et al., 2013).
2.3.1 Etiology of gastric ulcers
● Nonsteroidal and steroidal (glucocorticoid) anti-  
inflammatory drugs.
● Primary neoplastic conditions like stomach carcinoma, 
gastric intestinal lymphoma.
● Gastrinoma and disseminated mast cell disease.
● Exogenous toxins—ingestion of household cleaning 
chemical (phenol), lead, and various plants.
● Systemic diseases like hepatic, renal, Addison’s disease, 
or shock.
Gastric ulcers are classified according to depth (super -
ficial or deep), clinical presentation (acute or chronic), and 
anatomical location (glandular mucosal ulceration, general-
ized gastritis, focal duodenal ulceration, duodenal erosions, 
or duodenitis).
The major clinical sign of gastric ulceration is vomit -
ing, abdominal pain, hemoptysis, melena, weight loss, and 
anemia. Animals with gastric ulceration can be presented 
with or without melena or hemoptysis. Gastric or duodenal 
perforation may result in the sudden onset of fever, severe 
abdominal pain, weakness, abdominal distension, and death 
due to peritonitis.
History of NSAID therapy, ingestion of poisons, or 
other systemic diseases like hepatopathy or neoplasia may 
help to identify the cause. Anemia, hypoproteinemia, and 
uremia may be seen in animals with gastric ulcers indicat -
ing severity or other inciting causes. Diagnostic radiogra -
phy (plain and contrast) will help to identify the foreign 
bodies and ulcers. Endoscopy is considered as the gold 
standard for the diagnosis of ulcers and it helps to take 
the biopsy.
Treatment is primarily aimed to remove the underlying 
causes like NSAID or corticosteroid therapy, Helicobacter 
infection, foreign bodies, or alleviating systemic condi -
tions like hepatic, and renal disorders. Supportive therapy 
for ulcer healing includes maintaining mucosal perfusion, 
decreasing gastric acidity, protecting ulcer, and correcting 
secondary conditions may be considered.
Food is withheld initially to avoid stimulation of gastric 
acid and pepsin secretion followed by the diet recommenda-
tion for gastritis. Gastric acid secretion can be controlled by 
H2 blockers (cimetidine, ranitidine, or famotidine) or pro -
ton pump inhibitors (omeprazole, pantoprazole, lansopra -
zole, rabeprazole). The cytoprotective agents like sucralfate 
(dogs: 0.5–1 g, p.o., 2–3 times daily; cats: 0.25  g, p.o., 2–3 
times daily) or the prostaglandin E2 analog (misoprostol) 
can be considered. Perforated ulcers warrant surgical cor -
rection along with antibiotic therapy. Animals with perfo -
rated ulcers are having a poor prognosis.
3 Diseases of small intestine
The SI is basically a tube, beginning at the pylorus of the 
stomach and ending at the ileocolic valve. It is acting as 
an interface between the external environment (proximally 
from the mouth via the esophagus and stomach, and distally 
to the anus via the large intestine) and the body, and is both 
an absorptive surface and a barrier. It is divided arbitrarily 
into three anatomic segments: the duodenum proximally, 
then the jejunum, and finally the ileum distally. The SI mu-
cosa performs the intestinal barrier and absorptive functions 
and is comprised of an intestinal epithelium covering the 
lamina propria that hosts the local mucosal immune system 
and is surrounded by the submucosa and the outer muscle

280 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
layers. The small intestine is innervated by vagal, parasym-
pathetic, and sympathetic efferent fibers.
The basic functions of the SI are digestion, absorption, 
and elimination, which occur as a result of complex inter -
cellular interactions between epithelial cells, immune cells, 
mesenchymal and neuronal cells, and with luminal nutrients 
and microbes. Slow wave, segmental, and peristaltic con -
tractions of the SI are generated in response to spontaneous 
electrical activity. Segmental contractions slow intestinal 
transit and ensure mixing and digestion of nutrients until 
peristalsis propels the ingesta onwards.
The cardinal sign of the small intestinal disease is di -
arrhea. V omiting of blood may indicate gastric and/or up -
per GI bleeding (Fig. 11A and B), and copious volumes of 
bilious vomit are suggestive of upper GI obstruction. More 
distal obstructions of the SI may be infrequent vomiting of 
fecal-like material. Small intestinal diarrhea is normally of 
large volume and watery, with reduced frequency each day. 
Intussusceptions cause vomiting and a variable amount of 
jelly-like blood in feces. Nonspecific signs of SI disease, 
such as dehydration and weight loss, are readily apparent, 
and fever is sometimes present with infectious enteritis. 
Abdominal palpation is best performed with gradual, gentle, 
manual pressure on the abdomen. Free fluid within the peri-
toneal cavity should be detected by ballottement. Results of 
the hemogram, serum biochemistry, and urinalysis are often 
more reflective of hydration status, and to rule out diseases 
in other organ systems that may manifest with SI signs. 
Fecal sample examinations are important in diagnosis of 
small intestinal diseases. It includes direct fecal smear ex -
amination, rectal cytology, fecal concentration techniques, 
bacteriologic examination by routine culture or molecular 
fingerprinting, virologic examination, examination of pro -
tozoa, occult blood examination, α-protease inhibitor, and 
fecal calprotectin test ( Murphy et al., 2003 ). Serum folate 
and cobalamin concentration are markers of GI disease as 
well as indicators of the need for vitamin supplementation. 
Survey plain radiographs are most useful in the diagnosis 
of SI disease associated with vomiting, abdominal pain, 
and abnormal masses on palpation. Contrast radiography 
may confirm the presence of radiolucent foreign bodies, 
ulcers, and mucosal aberrations and assess the rate of intes-
tinal transit. Transabdominal ultrasound examination of the 
small intestine can detect layering of the wall, peristalsis, 
ileus, and luminal contents, and can measure SI wall thick-
ness. It is useful in the detection of lesions such as intussus-
ceptions, masses, radiolucent foreign bodies, intestinal wall 
thickening, and lymphadenopathy in chronic inflammatory, 
lymphatic, and neoplastic enteropathies.
3.1 Protein-losing enteropathy
Protein-losing enteropathy (PLE) is defined as the loss of 
protein from the intestines due to intestinal disease resulting 
in hypoalbuminemia and hypoglobulinemia ( Peterson and 
Willard, 2003). Strictly, any condition leading to abnormal 
protein loss from the intestines is a PLE.
Lymphangiectasia and alimentary tract lymphoma are 
the most common causes in adult dogs and young dogs 
hook worms and chronic intussusception are found to be 
the more common cause. The three basic mechanisms for 
protein loss are lymphatic obstruction or rupture (Intestinal 
lymphangiectasia), increased mucosal permeability because 
of mucosal infiltrates (e.g., inflammatory and neoplastic), 
and mechanical causes (e.g., ulcers, erosions, and conges -
tion) (Fig. 12).
Any age, breed, or sex of dog may develop PLE. 
However, breeds like Yorkshire Terriers, Soft-Coated 
Wheaten Terriers, Norwegian Lundehunds, and Basenjis 
are demonstrated to be at higher risk. Diarrhea, vomiting, 
and weight loss are the most common clinical signs of PLE 
in dogs (Vaden, 2008). Diarrhea is inconsistent and may not 
FIG. 11 (A) Haemorrhagic enteritis: Note the intestinal contents mixed with blood and blood clots. (B) Hemorrhagic enteritis: Note the RBCs in lamina 
propria and desquamated villi. Also note markedly engorged submucosal blood vessels (H & E, 100×).

Gastrointestinal disorders of dogs and cats  Chapter | 18  281
occur in some dogs. Other clinical signs including ascites, 
edema, and pleural effusion may occur mainly due to hy -
poalbuminemia. Pulmonary thromboembolism is also re -
ported due to antithrombin loss into the intestines.
PLE is often a diagnosis of exclusion. Patients typi -
cally have serum albumin ≤2.0 g/dL and other causes of 
hypoalbuminemia must be eliminated. PLN and hepatic in-
sufficiency are the two major differentials for this finding. 
Urinalysis/urine protein-to-creatinine ratio and hepatic func-
tion tests (e.g., serum bile acid concentrations) are typically 
needed to eliminate these syndromes. Measurement of fecal 
α1-PI concentrations is required for a definitive diagnosis. 
Changes on abdominal ultrasound can often be observed 
with PLE patients and may be indispensable in the detection 
of neoplastic masses, inflammatory infiltrates (which might 
permit diagnosis by fine-needle aspiration), and intussuscep-
tions. Ultrasound findings also may aid the clinician in de -
ciding whether to do endoscopic or full-thickness intestinal 
biopsies. In most cases when combined with the clinical pre-
sentation, laboratory tests, and imaging findings, histopatho-
logic analysis of endoscopic intestinal biopsies can lead to 
at least a provisional diagnosis and guide initial treatment.
The aims of therapy are to treat the underlying cause and 
to support the patient. There is no single treatment protocol 
as PLE has many underlying causes. The mainstay of treat-
ment for IL is feeding an ultra-low fat, highly digestible diet 
to minimize lacteal dilation and rupture. Anti-inflammatory 
or cytotoxic medications like prednisolone, azathioprine, 
and cyclosporin can be used in IL and IBD ( Bines, 2009). 
Monitoring the serum albumin concentration and body 
weight is probably the best way to monitor the patient’s re-
sponse to therapy.
3.2 Intestinal obstruction
Obstruction of the small intestine is a common reason 
for dysmotility, especially with luminal foreign bodies. 
Physical or mechanical obstructions can result from intra -
luminal foreign bodies, intramural masses, and extramural 
compression (Hayes, 2009). While these objects can lodge 
anywhere along the small or large intestine, there does not 
appear to be a predilection site, except that the jejunum, be-
cause of its length, many are diagnosed as lodged jejunal 
foreign bodies. Linear foreign bodies cause obstruction be-
cause of their ability to gather/pleat the intestine to cause 
partial or complete obstruction, and potential perforation, if 
not resolved. The severity of intestinal obstruction is clas -
sified according to a number of parameters including clini -
cal signs, site, and patency. If ingested nutrients are unable 
to pass beyond the point of obstruction, it is termed com -
plete obstruction ( Fig. 13). If some nutrients pass through 
the point of obstruction, even if only the liquid phase, it is 
termed partial obstruction (Fig. 14A and B). Functional ob-
structions result from generalized hypomotility or spasticity 
of a bowel segment ( Washabau, 2013). Foreign bodies can 
lodge anywhere along the small and large intestines, and 
there does not appear to be a predilection site, except that 
the jejunum, because of its length, is the most commonly af-
fected region. Linear foreign bodies may anchor around the 
base of the tongue, pylorus, or at more distal sites.
FIG. 12 Cause and common clinical signs of protein losing enteropathy.
FIG. 13 Part of small intestine after surgical correction of leaner foreign 
body by enterectomy.

282 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
Patients with complete intestinal obstruction often pres-
ent with acute signs of vomiting. Abdominal palpation, 
plain abdominal radiographs, or ultrasonographic imaging 
can be diagnostic if they reveal a foreign object or mass. In 
continuous radiographic imaging, failure of movement of a 
foreign body within 8 h and failure of the object to pass into 
the colon within 36 h are indications for surgery.
3.3 Intussusception
Intussusception is defined as the telescoping of a proximal 
segment of the GI tract, called the intussusceptum, into the 
lumen of the adjacent distal segment of the GI tract, called in-
tussuscipiens (Madrewar and Yaqub, 2016). Intussusception 
occurs when a migrating peristaltic wave reaches a fixed 
or noncontractile segment. Intussusceptions are generally 
more common in younger animals. Any disease that can 
disturb intestinal motility, such as viral enteritis, neoplasia, 
foreign bodies, and prior abdominal surgery, can lead to in-
tussusceptions (Allman and Pastori, 2013). Intussusceptions 
are generally more common in younger animals. A most 
common type is ileocolic intussusceptions. Hematochezia, 
vomiting, abdominal pain, and a palpable abdominal mass 
are major clinical findings observed. Palpation of a firm 
tubular elongated structure (thickened sausage-shaped) 
suggestive of intussusceptions. Radiographs will show a 
typical pattern of intestinal obstruction with gas and fluid-
filled dilated loops of the bowel if the obstruction caused by 
the intussusception is complete. In cases of partial obstruc-
tion, there may not be significant signs on plain radiographs 
and a barium contrast study may be needed to identify the 
problem. In transverse ultrasonographic sections, the intus-
susception appeared as a multilayered series of concentric 
rings, or a target-like lesion. In longitudinal sections, the 
intussusception appeared as multiple hyperechoic and hy -
poechoic parallel lines. Intussusceptions are treated surgi -
cally. Preoperative correction of dehydration, electrolyte, 
and acid-base deficits is essential. Acute ones may be re -
duced or resected, whereas chronic ones usually must be 
resected.
3.4 Dysmotility
Ileus has been defined as the functional inhibition of pro -
pulsive bowel activity, irrespective of pathogenetic mecha-
nism. Ileus is very dangerous for dogs and is a common 
sequel to parvoviral enteritis, abdominal surgery, pancre -
atitis, peritonitis, endotoxemia, hypokalemia and dysauto -
nomia (Harkin et al., 2002 ). Symptoms and signs of ileus 
include abdominal distention, nausea, vomiting, and vague 
discomfort. The main objective of the diagnostic effort is to 
find the underlying cause of this problem. Results of rou -
tine laboratory testing (complete blood count, serum chem-
istry, urinalysis) may reveal some information related to the 
underlying disease. Abdominal X-rays and ultrasound will 
help in finding various abnormalities including the presence 
of gas, fluid, mechanical obstruction (e.g., foreign body), 
tumor in the abdomen, and other such conditions (Fig. 15A 
and B). Barium contrast series X-ray may reveal delayed 
gastric emptying. As ileus is a result of other diseases or 
conditions, treating the underlying cause is of utmost im -
portance. Additionally, fluid therapy and prokinetics are 
also given to stimulate intestinal movements. In some cases 
of ileus, surgery is necessary to remove the blockage.
4 Disorders of large intestine
The large intestine contributes 20%–25% of the total (small 
and large) intestinal consists of the cecum, colon, rectum, 
and anal canal. The major functions of LI are the extraction 
of water and electrolytes and the control of defecation. The 
large intestine accomplishes these functions by regulating 
fluid transport, bacterial fermentation, motility, immune 
surveillance, and blood flow.
FIG. 14 Abdomen lateral radiography showing partial obstruction.

Gastrointestinal disorders of dogs and cats  Chapter | 18  283
4.1 Colitis
Colitis is inflammation of the colon characterized by 
chronic diarrhea, common in dogs but less frequent 
in cats. Colitis is classified based on duration as acute 
or chronic and based on the nature of cell type invad -
ing the intestinal lamina propria, muscularis, and/
or mucosa as lymphocytic-plasmacytic, eosinophilic, 
neutrophilic, histiocytic ulcerative colitis, or granulo -
matous ( Cerquetella et al., 2010 ). The etiology of coli -
tis is multifactorial, requiring the presence of antigens, 
compromised colonocyte health, and breaks in natural 
protective mechanisms ( Atreya et al., 2008 ). The etiol -
ogy for the colitis may be dietary factors (food allergy, 
deconjugated bile acids, unabsorbed fat, etc.), parasites 
(Trichuris vulpis , Giardiasis, Ancylostoma  spp., Coccidia  
spp., Tritrichomonas foetus  in cats, Balantidium coli , 
Toxoplasma gondii ), bacterial infections (clostrid -
ial infections, Salmonella  spp., Campylobacter  spp., 
Salmonella  spp.), fungal infections ( Histoplasma 
capsulatum , Pythium insidiosum ), algal infections 
(Prototheca), IBD, stress, immune mediated (increased 
permeability, reduced immune tolerance), genetic pre -
disposition, neoplasia (adenocarcinoma, lymphoma, ad -
enomatous polyps), and autoimmune conditions.
The common clinical sign of colitis is chronic or inter -
mittent large bowel diarrhea characterized by the presence 
of mucus, hematochezia, dyschezia, abdominal discomfort, 
tenesmus, and abdominal pain. Frequency and urgency of 
defecation may be increased but with a reduced quantity 
of feces. V omiting may or may not be present. Reduced 
weight gain is noticed in chronic cases; however, it is com-
mon with small intestinal disorders. Large bowel diarrhea 
can be differentiated from small bowel diarrhea following 
clinical signs.

4.2 Acute colitis
Acute colitis is a sudden onset of watery diarrhea with typi-
cal characteristics of large intestine diarrhea usually asso -
ciated with toxin (spoiled food). It is usually self-limiting, 
FIG. 15 (A) Right lateral radiograph of dog showing paralytic with dilated intestinal loop filled with air. (B) Right lateral contrast radiograph of dog 
showing severely distended intestinal loop.

284 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
responds well with empirical therapy, and has a good prog-
nosis. Treatment may include fluids therapy along with 
antibiotics (metronidazole) or sulfasalazine and/or dietary 
therapy (an easily digestible, hypoallergenic diet). Parasitic 
infestation may be ruled out before any treatment.
4.3 Chronic enteropathy
Chronic enteropathy (CE) is a term used for gastrointestinal 
diseases (anorexia, vomiting, and diarrhea) present for a dura-
tion of 3 weeks or longer, when other causes such as parasitic 
disease or neoplastic disease are ruled out. Based on response 
to the treatment, CE is divided into food-responsive enteropa-
thy, antibiotic-responsive enteropathy, immunosuppressant- 
responsive enteropathy (including steroid-responsive 
diarrhea) and nonresponsive enteropathy, and protein-losing 
enteropathy (Dandrieux and Mansfield, 2019 ; Jergens and 
Heilmann, 2022). Based on the predominant cell infiltrate, 
CE is again classified into (lymphocytic plasmacytic colitis), 
eosinophils (eosinophilic colitis), neutrophils (suppurative or 
neutrophilic colitis), macrophages (granulomatous colitis), or 
a combination thereof. Colitis is the term used for the inflam-
mation of the colon alone, whereas enterocolitis is used for 
inflammation of the entire GI tract. The term inflammatory 
bowel disease (IBD) is often used to refer to CE. One of the 
three factors is (a) the presence of bacteria in the intestinal 
lumen with potential dysbiosis in the luminal microbiome; 
(b) defective mucosal barrier function that allows contact of 
bacterial and/or food antigens with immune cells in the lam-
ina propria; and (c) an aberrant mucosal immune response to 
antigens is necessary to initiate CE.
Clinical signs include weight loss, anorexia, intermit -
tent vomiting, and diarrhea. Clinical signs mainly depend 
on the area of lesion in the GI tract like cranial abdominal 
pain in duodenal ulcers. Diarrhea may be large bowel or 
small bowel based on the content, frequency, the presence 
of blood, etc.
The diagnosis of CE is based on the recognition of clini-
cal signs, the exclusion of other causes, and the severity of 
the clinical case. The coprological examination is consid -
ered a preliminary test for screening GI parasites which can 
cause similar symptoms. Changes like anemia, eosinophilia, 
lymphopenia, and thrombocytosis can be seen in the blood 
values. Anemia is mainly due to iron deficiency, because of 
chronic GI blood loss, or to the chronic inflammatory state 
that occurs (Marchetti et al., 2010). The finding of eosino -
philia can be associated either with the presence of parasites 
or allergies or in cases of eosinophilic enteritis. Lymphopenia 
is a frequent finding in dogs with protein-losing enteropa -
thies along with thrombocytosis. Mild hypoalbuminemia is 
seen in CE due to malabsorption, the marked decrease is no-
ticed in protein-losing enteropathies (Craven and Washabau, 
2019). Liver enzymes (ALT and AST) may be slightly in -
creased during CEs, due to nonspecific reactive hepatitis 
linked to impaired intestinal absorption. Alterations in elec-
trolytes (sodium, potassium, chlorine) are usually found 
only in cases of severe symptoms with severe GI losses and 
may be associated with increased renal parameters (prerenal 
azotemia) for dehydration. Malabsorption in CE causes hy-
pocalcemia and hypocholesterolemia. Decreased serum co-
balamin may be seen in dogs with CE. In less severe cases, 
and in particular in dogs with food-responsive enteropathy, 
there may be no alterations, or in any case there may be 
slightly nonspecific alterations.
The radiographic examination will reveal foreign bodies 
in the GI tract. Ultrasound alterations that are frequently en-
countered during CIEs are hyperechogenicity of the mucosa, 
lymphangiectasia, abdominal lymphadenopathy, loss of dis-
tinction of stratigraphy, increased thickness of the intestinal 
wall, alterations of peristalsis, and presence of tumors.
The endoscopic examination will be done after a dietary 
trial and antibiotic therapy. Endoscopy or colonoscopy is 
used to localize the lesion, viz., erythema, friability, en -
hanced granularity, erosion, and ulceration. The purpose of 
the histopathologic evaluation of a biopsy specimen is to 
distinguish normal from pathologic tissue, to characterize 
the nature and severity of the alterations, and to provide a 
diagnosis of the type of inflammation.
The sequential management of chronic enteropathy is 
detailed in Fig. 16. The treatment of CEs involves a thera -
peutic trial includes a dietary change to be continued for 
a minimum period of about 3  weeks), the introduction of 
antimicrobials (tylosin, tetracycline ( Dandrieux et  al., 
2019), doxycycline, azithromycin, enrofloxacin, rifaximin 
(Menozzi et al., 2016), and metronidazole (Jergens, 1999)), 
but recently this step is replaced using probiotics, endos -
copy of the digestive tract with biopsy samples, and the ad-
ministration of an immunosuppressant.
A change in diet may help the animal to get rid of an 
adverse food reaction, food allergy, and/or food intolerance. 
Diet alone can help roughly 50% of CE patients ( Tolbert 
et  al., 2022 ). It also helps to change the microbiota in 
the intestine. Dietary intervention may include high fiber 
content (i.e., prebiotics), specific diets (hydrolyzed diet, 
limited- ingredient diet), reduction of fat, gluten-free diet, 
or parenteral nutrition. Improvement in the condition may 
be noticed within 14  days after changing diets, and several 
diets may need to be tested.
Oral antimicrobials may alleviate the symptoms in 
antibiotic-sensitive enteropathy. Oxytetracycline (10  mg/
kg, p.o., tid), metronidazole (10  mg/kg, p.o., bid), tylosin 
(5 mg/kg, p.o., o.d., or up to 20  mg/kg tid), or enrofloxa -
cin (10–15  mg/kg, o.d.) can be used to treat CE in dogs. 
Relapse of cases along with antibiotic resistance menace 
and changes in a pet’s gut microbiome due to prolonged 
use of antibiotics, the use of probiotics (i.e., Lactobacillus 
spp., Bifidobacterium spp., Saccharomyces spp.), are rec -
ommended before antibiotic trial.

Gastrointestinal disorders of dogs and cats  Chapter | 18  285
Sulfasalazine (and related drugs), which act as local 
anti-inflammatory action as the intestinal microflora release 
5-aminosalicylic acid, are often used in dogs with large 
bowel disorders. Other drugs include olsalazine (dogs: 10–
20 mg/kg, p.o., three times daily) and mesalamine (dogs: 
10 mg/kg, p.o., three times daily) may be recommended 
as they are having less side effects than sulfasalazine. The 
adverse effect of sulfasalazine is keratoconjunctivitis sicca 
and vasculitis which makes it not a suitable candidate for 
feline.
If the animal is not responsive to the above trials, histo-
logical examination of endoscopy-guided biopsies is rec -
ommended. Based on the type and severity of inflammatory 
infiltrate found, immunosuppressive can be initiated. The 
most used immunosuppressive drugs for CEs are cortico -
steroids (prednisolone 1–2  mg/kg every 12  h; 20% dosage 
reduction every 15–20  days and budesonide 1  mg/m2/day, 
p.o. in dogs, and 1  mg/cat/day, p.o., in cats), cyclosporine 
(3–5 mg/kg p.o. every 12 h or 24 h), chlorambucil (2–6 mg/
m2 p.o. every 24 h or 48 h), and azathioprine (1–2 mg/kg p.o. 
every 24 h).
Malabsorption due to CE may cause various deficiencies 
in vitamins and minerals like cobalamin, folate, calcium, 
and magnesium. Supplementation of cobalamin (20  mg/
kg, s.c., every 7  days), folate (1–5  mg/dog/day), calcium 
(10% calcium gluconate 0.5–1.5 mL/kg along with vitamin 
D—0.025–0.06 μg/kg/day) are recommended to correct the 
deficiencies.
Fecal microbial transplantation (also known as micro -
biome restoration therapy or MBRT) can restore gut micro-
biota, and has proven to be effective in both animals and 
humans.
4.4 Constipation, obstipation, and megacolon
Constipation is defined as absent, infrequent, or difficult 
defecation associated with the retention of feces within 
the colon and rectum. Prolonged constipation results in 
harder and drier feces that become impacted, as water is 
continuously absorbed through mucosa which results in 
excessively hard feces that defecation cannot occur this 
is known as obstipation. Chronic, recurrent constipation, 
and obstipation can result in megacolon, which refers to a 
flaccid distended, and extremely irreversibly dilated, and 
hypomotile colon that is not responsive to therapy. Severe 
colonic dilation, recurrent constipation, and obstipation due 
to idiopathic smooth muscle dysfunction lead to megaco -
lon in cats. Underlying causes and predisposing factors of 
constipation include dietary factors, environmental factors, 
painful defecation, anorectal or colonic obstruction, neuro -
muscular diseases eases, fluid and electrolyte disturbances, 
and drug-related effects.
Causes for constipation can be categorized as either me-
chanical obstruction or functional disorders. Mechanical 
obstructions include the narrowing of the pelvic canal 
which can happen due to pelvic fractures or luxations, 
prostatomegaly, enlargement of the iliac lymph nodes, or 
neoplasia: bony, prostatic, urogenital. Other causes for me-
chanical obstruction are a distal colonic or rectal foreign 
body, colonic or rectal neoplasia, strictures, and chronic, 
recurrent obstipation. Functional disorders can be dysauto -
nomia (rare), sacral spinal cord or pelvic nerve dysfunction, 
or autonomic ganglioneuritis in dogs (rare). Megacolon 
without any known cause comes under Idiopathic acquired 
megacolon.
The signs of constipation are usually evident to own -
ers with a history of reduced, absent, or painful defecation 
and producing very hard feces. In the case of megacolon, 
a history of prior recurrent episodes of constipation or ob -
stipation will be present. Affected cats are presented with 
anorexia, dehydration, weight loss, diarrhea, vomiting, 
and lethargy. Physical examination confirms the presence 
of colonic impaction in the affected animal. Feline severe 
idiopathic megacolon is characterized by abdominal pain 
and mesenteric lymphadenopathy. Also assess for contrib -
uting causes, including musculoskeletal and neurological 
FIG. 16 Sequential management of chronic enteropathy.

286 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
conditions. Radiography reveals pathognomonic signs in 
the diagnosis of constipation, obstipation, or megacolon. 
Colonoscopy, biopsy, and histopathology may be required 
to definitively diagnose neoplasia and other causes like in -
flammatory lesions, strictures, sacculations, and diverticula. 
Extraluminal mass lesions are detected by abdominal ul -
trasonography, whereas intraluminal mass lesions are best 
evaluated by endoscopy. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis, CT 
or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and electrophysio -
logic studies should be considered in animals with evidence 
of neurologic impairment. Hydration and electrolyte status 
are also important factors in the constipated cat which in -
cludes hypokalemia and hypocalcemia.
4.4.1 Management
The same principles of management can be applied in all 
cases:
1. Ensure removal of obstructing feces by 5 mL of sodium 
lauryl sulfoacetate, stimulant laxatives (bisacodyl), or 
emollient laxatives (sodium docusate @ 50  mg/cat p.o. 
bid) that have reportedly been used.
2. Ensure colonic motility and smooth passage of feces by 
laxatives and prokinetic agents like cisapride at 2.5  mg/
cat, bid, p.o.
3. Reducing fecal bulk is an important part of long-term 
management by increasing the amount of dietary fiber.
4. Ensure adequate hydration—fluid therapy is indicated 
to ensure adequate hydration. Wet food diets help to en-
sure adequate water intake and therefore help maintain 
hydration.
5. Manage underlying problems.
Megacolon is unmanageable to medical and dietary 
therapy; so, to be defined as having megacolon, a cat may 
have had several episodes of obstipation managed by enema 
as well as dietary trials and medical therapy with cisapride 
and an osmotic or emollient laxative; yet the cat will still 
obstruct with feces and then the only possible therapy is 
subtotal colectomy. A Subtotal colectomy is considered an 
important surgical treatment for feline idiopathic mega -
colon (Colopy-Poulsen et al., 2005 ). Nemeth et al. (2008)  
results emphasized the long-term effectiveness of subtotal 
colectomy with preservation of the ileocolic junction.

Chapter 19
Occular manifestation of infectious and 
noninfestious disease of dogs and cats
1 Introduction
The most important managemental practice for pet owners 
is proper eye care, and some of the most common ocular 
problems companion animals may experience are scratches, 
ulcers, dry eye, infection, and metabolic problems, leading 
to ocular problems. Various infectious problems leading to 
ocular problems include bacterial infection, viral infection, 
and parasitic infection. And among noninfectious causes of 
ocular problems in dogs and cats is an underlying metabolic 
problem.
2 Systemic diseases with ocular 
manifestation
2.1 Canine distemper
Canine distemper, a viral disease caused by the paramyxo -
virus virus, causes optic neuritis which is most commonly 
found in young pups of age 3–6 months of age or unvac -
cinated or immunocompromised adults (Fig. 1). Distemper 
ocular clinical manifestations include bilateral conjuncti -
vitis with a discharge that progresses from serous to mu -
copurulent (Fig. 2). The palpebral conjunctiva is the most 
affected. Lacrimal adenitis can cause decreased tear produc-
tion, which can lead to more severe conjunctivitis, corneal 
ulceration, and pain. When an animal recovers from a sys -
temic infection, the dry eye usually goes away. Distemper 
is not always suspected because conjunctival or lacrimal 
involvement has such mild systemic symptoms (Greene and 
Appel, 2006).
Another thing in CD-affected ones is the retrobulbar 
optic nerve, which includes the optic chiasm, and the op -
tic nerve head, which may be affected by the inflammation 
associated with optic neuritis, is a serious condition. The 
physiologic cup may not be present and the optic nerve 
head will seem high (swollen) with blurry edges when it is 
 affected. Also, optic neuritis may be accompanied by peri -
papillary edema, retinitis, and localized bleeding within the 
optic nerve head (Brooks, 2007).
Retinal degeneration and necrosis result in gray-to-pink 
irregular densities on the tapetal or non-tapetal fundus, or 
both. Where exudates dissect between the retina and cho -
roid, bullous or complete retinal detachment can occur. 
Chronic, dormant fundic lesions are linked to retinal atro -
phy and scarring.
These circumscribed, hyperreflective areas are known 
as gold medallion lesions and are associated with previ -
ous canine distemper infection ( Greene and Appel, 2006 ). 
Treatment is primarily symptomatic due to the lack of spe -
cific antiviral therapy. Acute optic neuritis or severe chorio-
retinitis should be treated with glucocorticoids administered 
systemically. Dry eyes should be treated with topical ciclo-
sporin and artificial tears twice daily. Corneal ulcers should 
also be treated several times a day with a topical broad-
spectrum antibacterial (Greene and Appel, 2006).
2.2 Infectious canine hepatitis
Infectious canine hepatitis (ICH) is a rarely recognized 
dog disease caused by canine adenovirus type 1 (CA V-1), 
a non-enveloped, icosahedral double-stranded DNA virus 
antigenically related to CA V-2. CA V-1 causes disease in 
wolves, coyotes, skunks, and bears, as well as encephali -
tis in foxes, but the variety of wildlife hosts is not as di -
verse as CDV . Ferrets are not affected. ICH is also known 
as Rubarth’s disease, after Carl Sven Rubarth, a veterinarian 
who described it in the late 1940s ( Sykes, 2014 ). CA V-1 
is spread through direct dog-to-dog contact or contact with 
contaminated fomites such as hands, utensils, and clothing. 
Ectoparasites like fleas and ticks can also act as mechanical 
vectors. The virus enters the body through the nose, con -
junctiva, or oropharynx and replicates within the tonsils be-
fore spreading to regional lymph nodes and the  bloodstream

290 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
via lymphatics ( Fig. 3). Following that, infection of hepa -
tocytes and endothelial cells occurs in a variety of tissues, 
including the lungs, liver, kidneys, spleen, and eye, result -
ing in hemorrhage, necrosis, and inflammation. The virus 
replicates in host cells’ nuclei, where crystalline arrays of 
virions form (Cabasso, 1962). Clinical signs usually appear 
after 4–9 days of incubation, though many dogs are likely to 
show no signs of illness. Three disease syndromes that over-
lap have been identified. The first type is an acute disease, 
which results in circulatory collapse, coma, and death af -
ter a brief illness lasting less than 24–48  h. The second and 
most commonly described syndrome is an acute disease, 
which is associated with significant morbidity and mortality 
rates ranging from 10% to 30%. Within 2 weeks, dogs with 
acute disease either recover or die. The third type is more 
chronic and occurs in dogs with partial immunity, with 
death due to hepatic failure occurring weeks (subacute dis -
ease) or months (chronic infection) after the initial infection 
(Sykes, 2014). Fever, tonsillitis, conjunctivitis, inappetence, 
lethargy, weakness, polydipsia, vomiting, hematemesis, di-
arrhea, cough, tachypnea, and icterus are all early signs of 
acute disease. Diarrhea may be accompanied by frank blood 
or melena. There are widespread petechial and ecchymotic 
hemorrhages as well as hematuria. Corneal edema (blue 
eye) (Fig. 4) occurs during the first week of illness and is 
caused by virus replication within corneal endothelial cells 
(Decaro et al., 2007).
In dogs recovering from acute illness, viral persistence 
within the renal glomeruli, uveal structures of the eye (the 
iris and ciliary body), and the cornea can trigger immune 
complex formation. In some dogs who survive, this causes 
glomerulonephritis with proteinuria, severe uveitis, and per-
sistent corneal edema. Anterior uveitis is characterized by 
an influx of inflammatory cells into the anterior chamber. 
Persistent corneal edema may persist for months and be as-
sociated with complications such as glaucoma. According to 
reports, the Afghan hound is susceptible to this complication 
(Curtis and Barnett, 1973, 1981 ). In physical examination 
performance using a slit lamp, there is significant corneal 
thickening and ciliary and episcleral injection. Uveitis 
could also be noticeable. In dogs with corneal edema, there 
have also been reports of corneal ulceration and elevated 
intraocular pressure, the latter of which can cause blindness 
(Curtis and Barnett, 1973 ). Dogs with significant corneal 
edema and uveitis should be treated with topical  ophthalmic 
FIG. 1 Direct manifestation of CD virus on ophthalmic tissue.
FIG. 2 Mucopurulent eye discharge.

Occular manifestation of infectious and noninfestious disease of dogs and cats  Chapter | 19  291
preparations that contain glucocorticoids and atropine to 
stop the development of glaucoma after fluorescein staining 
has revealed no signs of corneal ulceration.
3 Feline herpesvirus
Cats are most frequently infected with feline herpesvirus 
type 1 (FHV-1), which is a viral infection that causes ocu -
lar disease. It is a DNA virus that develops neural latency 
after primary infection and is a member of the subfamily 
α-herpesviridae. FHV-1 is known to have a site of latency 
in the trigeminal ganglion, although it can linger in ocular 
tissues, particularly the cornea, in a dormant state ( Stiles 
and Pogranichniy, 2008; Townsend et al., 2004). By virtue 
of its cytopathic effect on epithelial cells, FHV-1 causes up-
per respiratory tract disease (URTD) as well as conjuncti -
vitis or keratitis. Cats with ocular illness are likely to have 
both original infection and viral recrudescence. The most 
frequent eye conditions include keratitis with or without ul-
ceration (Fig. 5), corneal epithelial ulceration, and conjunc-
tivitis. Conjunctival hyperemia, with or without chemosis, 
lachrymation, and pain are signs of conjunctivitis. When 
there is discomfort or swelling, the nictitating membrane 
may occasionally be elevated. Corneal disease from FHV-1 
is almost always accompanied by conjunctivitis. Specific 
antiviral therapy should be used to treat conjunctivitis, 
corneal ulceration, or keratitis caused by FHV-1. Corneal 
ulcers caused only by FHV-1 should only affect the epithe-
lium. A secondary bacterial infection is likely to be pres -
ent in stromal ulcers, necessitating more strong  antibiotic 
FIG. 3 Mode of infection of ICH.
FIG. 4 Blue eye condition in dogs with raised liver enzymes (suggestive 
of ICH).
FIG. 5 Ulcerative keratitis.

292 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
therapy than would be used in the case of a viral ulcer. 
Debridement with a cotton swab should be used to remove 
away of any loose epithelium. It is not recommended to per-
form grid keratotomies on cats since this could exacerbate 
herpetic illness and cause the development of a corneal se -
questrum (La Croix et al., 2001 ). If epithelial ulceration is 
present, a broad- spectrum topical antibiotic, such as tobra -
mycin, should be used. It is important to constantly remove 
discharge and clean the eyes. Ophthalmic preparations used 
to treat feline herpesvirus type 1 infection in cats include 
cidofovir, ganciclovir, vidarabine, and the orally available 
tablet famciclovir given at 40 mg/kg. With the right medica-
tion and enough time, the prognosis for the resolution of 
FHV-1-related ocular surface illness is often fair to good, 
while some cats may experience recrudescent disease.
4 Ocular problems in canines and 
felines due to endocrine disease
The endocrine system is made up of several endocrine 
glands that are located in different parts of the animal 
body. This system is responsible for the secretion of hor -
mones that coordinate and control all the body activi -
ties. It is strictly linked to the central nervous system, as 
it diversifies its functions through the hypothalamus and 
pituitary gland ( Fabue et al., 2010 ; Kamboj et al., 2017 ). 
Endocrinopathies are manifested in a multi-organ fashion. 
Several endocrine disorders become apparent in the eye. 
Thus, the eye aids clinicians with valuable signs for the 
diagnosis and management of numerous endocrinopathies 
which can thus significantly reduce the morbidity related 
to these disorders including permanent visual dysfunction 
(Fabue et al., 2010 ). The most common endocrinopathies 
having ocular manifestations seen in small animals are 
diabetes mellitus (DM), hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing’s 
disease), hypoadrenocorticism (Addison’s disease), growth 
hormone imbalances, hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism 
and associated calcium imbalances ( Anoop et  al., 2020 ; 
Kamboj et al., 2017).
4.1 Diabetes mellitus
Diabetes mellitus (DM) is the most common endocrine 
disorder in small animals, possibly resulting in cataract 
formation, lens-induced uveitis, endothelial cell loss and 
pleomorphism, reduced corneal sensitivity, hyperlipidemia, 
retinopathy, keratoconjunctival changes, and other reti -
nopathies (Gelatt, 1975). It may also result in uveitis and 
poor corneal wound healing. The poodle dog breed has a 
significantly excess risk than German shepherds, Cocker 
Spaniels, Collies, and Boxers for the development of diabe-
tes (Marmor et al., 1982).
A cataract is the earliest and most common ocular le -
sion in DM (lesion within 5–6  months and approximately 
80% within 16 months of its diagnosis) (Beam et al., 1999). 
Cataract may occur in diabetic cats also but less frequently 
than in dogs (young ones are highly susceptible) and the 
reason may be attributed to the fact that aldose reductase 
activity is significantly lower in older cats than in dogs 
(Richter et al., 2002 ). The avascular lens is freely perme -
able to glucose, and by the process of diffusion, it enters 
the lens from the surrounding aqueous humor. Normally 
glucose is then converted to lactic acid via the anaerobic 
glycolytic pathway and then diffuses back out of the lens to 
enter circulation. However, in DM there will be saturation 
of the hexokinase enzyme by which glucose gets metabo -
lized through the polyol pathway to sorbitol and fructose, 
which are not freely diffusible. In the presence of high glu-
cose concentration, the enzyme aldose reductase not only 
catalyzes the reduction of glucose to sorbitol, but also it is 
upregulated and thereby increasing its activity. The trapped 
sorbitol and fructose in the lens act as hydrophilic osmotic 
agents, draw more water into the lens, and cause swelling 
and rupture of lens fibers, resulting in cataracts ( Fig.  6) 
(Muirhead and Hothersall, 1995).
DM-induced cataract may lead to leakage of lens pro -
teins and subsequently result in uveitis. It will be char -
acterized by low intraocular pressure, miosis, aqueous 
flare, corneal edema, and even congestion ( Woerdt et  al., 
1992). Spontaneous cataract resorption and subsequent 
FIG. 6 Development of cataract in hyperglycemic condition.

Occular manifestation of infectious and noninfestious disease of dogs and cats  Chapter | 19  293
 lens-induced uveitis are observed primarily in young dogs, 
especially in Afghan hound, American cocker spaniel, 
Boston terrier, miniature and toy poodle, and miniature 
schnauzer (Gelatt, 1975).
Diabetic dogs in comparison with normal dogs have 
significantly reduced corneal sensitivity, due to the neu -
ropathy of the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve, 
which causes neurotrophic keratopathy, resulting in loss of 
sensory innervation to the cornea. This diffuse neuropathy 
may subsequently lead to the development of corneal ulcers 
(Kathryn et al., 2003 ). In addition, the ocular surface dis -
ease in diabetes is characterized by a disorder of tear quan-
tity and quality, squamous metaplasia, and goblet cell loss 
(Dogru et al., 2001).
Hyperlipidemia is another common symptom in dia -
betic dogs and cats. Hypertriglyceridemia occurs in rela -
tive or absolute insulin deficiency and is associated with 
decreased lipoprotein lipase activity (Feldman and Nelson, 
2004). Hypercholesteremia may also occur due to its in -
creased synthesis or impaired clearance. Hyperlipidemia 
may result in corneal lipid deposits, lipemia retinalis 
(lipid-filled retinal vessels), and lipemic aqueous humor 
(Aguiree and Gross, 1980 ). Infrequent complications like 
atherosclerotic vascular diseases are reported in dogs and 
cats also ( Hess et al., 2002 ). Atherosclerosis, when asso -
ciated with diabetes mellitus and hypothyroidism, may 
cause increased permeability of the uveal vessels and pre -
disposes the animals to the development of lipemic uveitis 
(Sottiaux, 1999).
Diabetic retinopathy is the most common ocular mani -
festation of DM and develops earlier in diabetic dogs and 
its diagnosis is often impossible due to early development 
of cataracts which limits fundus examination ( Engerman 
and Kern, 1987). Retinal hemorrhages and microaneurysms 
(RH-MA) are considered markers of diabetic retinopathy 
in dogs. Retinopathy is a common finding in hypertensive 
cats with concurrent renal failure or hyperthyroidism and 
systemic hypertension. It is frequently seen in geriatric cats 
with ocular signs of bilateral intraocular hemorrhage, reti -
nal edema and detachment, development of inner retinal 
ischemic spots (cotton-wool), and vessel tortuosity, accom-
panied by a localized or generalized narrowing of retinal 
arterioles (Boxtel, 2003).
DM may cause changes in the pre-corneal tear film due 
to poor metabolic control and peripheral neuropathy of lac-
rimal gland innervation and hence result in the development 
of dry eye or keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS). Acinar cells 
of the lacrimal gland need insulin to stimulate its secretory 
component and its reduction may lead to decreased tear 
production. Schirmer tear test (STT) and mean tear film 
breakup time (TFBT) values will be lowered in DM patients 
(Cullen et al., 2005 ). KCS when occurring along with re -
duced corneal sensitivity makes the cornea prone to ulcer 
formation and subsequent complications.
4.2 Hyperadenocorticism (Cushing’s disease)
Cushing’s disease or hyperadrenocorticism (HAC) may re-
sult in ophthalmic problems due to excessive levels of corti-
costeroids. There will be subsequent development of retinal 
and corneal pathologies (Chopra et al., 2012).
Retinal changes associated with systemic hypertension 
cause increased hydrostatic pressure in choroid vasculature 
resulting in hemorrhage, non-inflammatory swelling of the 
optic nerve head (papilledema), retinal detachment with 
subretinal effusions, and retinal degeneration. Hemorrhages 
may result in focal scarring of the fundus and death of the 
involved photoreceptors, leading to the formation of blind 
spots. Ocular hypertension may also cause hyphema and sub-
sequent anterior or posterior uveitis (Plummer et al., 2007).
Hyperlipidemia associated with HAC may result in lipe-
mic aqueous humor (turbid aqueous humor due to leakage 
of lipoproteins as a result of increased vascular permeabil -
ity) and subsequent inflammation which may alter –blood-
aqueous barrier. Primary hyperlipidemia in certain breeds 
of dogs like Miniature Schnauzers, Beagles, and Shetland 
Sheepdogs is due to hereditary or familial lipoprotein dys -
regulation ( Bauer, 1995; Sato et  al., 2000 ), whereas sec -
ondary hyperlipidemia is acquired due to an underlying 
disorder affecting lipid metabolism including DM, HAC, 
and hypothyroidism (Barrie et al., 1993). Lipemic aqueous 
humor along with DM increases the risk of development of 
cataracts and lens-induced uveitis.
Excess cortisol in circulation may result in immunosup-
pression and may lead to the development of endophthal -
mitis due to lesions of the posterior uvea and retina and 
occasionally the anterior uvea. In addition, excessive circu-
lating cortisol places patients at risk for ectopic calcification 
and impaired vision (Plummer et al., 2007).
Increased osteoclastic activity due to HAC may lead 
to hypercalcemia and metastatic calcification resulting in 
calcium deposits in corneal stroma or superficial cornea 
known as band keratopathy that leads to keratitis and cor -
neal opacity (Ward, 1989). Corneal degeneration may occur 
with deposition of lipids or calcium, or both in hyperlipid -
emia associated with HAC (Laus et al., 2002).
Proptosis or exophthalmia and facial nerve paralysis is 
a common ocular manifestation of Cushing’s disease and 
may result in exposure to keratitis and subsequent corneal 
ulceration (Aterman and Greenberg, 1953).
Sudden acquired retinal degeneration (SARD) is a non-
inflammatory retinal syndrome, mostly associated with 
Cushing’s syndrome, in which there is degeneration and 
loss of photoreceptors cells in the retina. It is more com -
mon in female dogs above 7 years of age dogs with SARD 
presented with acute, bilateral blindness and initially has 
normal results from a fundus examination ( Komaromy 
et  al., 2016). Acute blindness from SARD has also been 
related to diseases of the pituitary-adrenal axis ( Plummer

294 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
et al., 2007 ). Animals that are presented with SARD have 
systemic clinical signs consistent with those of Cushing’s 
syndrome (Mattson et al., 1992).
4.3 Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison’s disease)
Hypoadrenocorticism (HOC) is very rare in dogs and cats 
and may cause ocular manifestations only when associated 
with other conditions like hypercalcemia. Naturally occur -
ring HOC is an uncommon canine disease and young, fe -
male dogs are mostly affected. HOC mostly results from 
immune-mediated destruction of adrenocortical layers, 
leading to deficiencies of mineralocorticoids and glucocorti-
coids (Klein and Peterson, 2010). The ocular manifestations 
include ptosis, blepharitis, blepharospasm, keratoconjuncti-
vitis with extreme photophobia, corneal ulcers, episcleritis, 
cataract, and papilloedema (Langston, 2008).
4.4 Growth hormone disorders
Growth hormone-related issues are common in cats but 
very rare in dogs. Adenomas of the pars distalis of the pi -
tuitary gland (resulting in blindness) cause oversecretion 
of growth hormone in cats, whereas in dogs, it is reported 
to be associated with prolonged progesterone treatment 
(Eigenmann and Venker-van Haagen, 1981 ). Deficiency 
of growth hormones (resulting in secondary hypothyroid -
ism) and subsequent pituitary dwarfism are ubiquitous in 
German shepherd dogs. The ocular manifestations will be 
subsequent to hypothyroidism acromegaly from overpro -
duction of growth hormones and exophthalmos as its ocular 
manifestation is seen in German shepherd dogs ( Fracassi 
et al., 2014). Other common ophthalmic manifestations in -
clude papilledema, systemic hypertension, signs secondary 
to DM, and blindness.
4.5 Hypothyroidism
Hypothyroidism is another common endocrinopathy in 
dogs (rare in cats). Ocular signs occur when it is associated 
with hyperlipidemia or hyperlipoproteinemia. Lipid-laden 
aqueous humor and associated uveitis are the most com -
mon ocular manifestation of hypothyroidism. Arcus lipoi -
des corneae (opaque ring of crystalline lipid deposits along 
and within the peripheral cornea near the limbus) is com -
mon in hypothyroid German shepherd dogs (Crispin, 1988). 
Hypothyroidism may result in some neurological changes 
(facial nerve paralysis and Horner’s syndrome) also due to 
segmental demyelination and axonopathy (Kern et al., 1989).
4.6 Hyperthyroidism
Hyperthyroidism is seen commonly in old cats (rare in 
dogs). In dogs, malignant neoplasm of the thyroid may 
cause  hyperthyroidism. The ocular manifestations (acute 
loss of vision, retinopathy with detachments, hyphema, sub-
retinal effusion, and hemorrhage) of hyperthyroidism in cats 
are associated with hypertension which may even go above 
160 mm of Hg (Maggio et al., 2000; Stiles et al., 1994).
4.7 Calcium disorders
Hypocalcemia can be caused by primary hypoparathyroid -
ism, renal failure, pancreatitis, eclampsia, and C-cell tu -
mors, resulting in excess secretion of calcitonin ( Delmere 
and Paterson, 1981). The characteristic ocular manifestation 
with hypocalcemia is cataract formation (because of an im-
balance with the active cation transport mechanism which 
brings osmotic imbalance and subsequent rupture of lens 
fibers) with a classic multifocal bilateral opaque appearance 
in the lens (Bassett, 1998; Evans and Kern, 1931). The pos-
sible reasons for hypercalcemia could be primary hyperpara-
thyroidism, hypercalcemia of malignancy, HOC, vitamin D 
toxicity, osteoclastic diseases, granulomatous diseases, renal 
failure, or hyperthyroidism ( Feldman and Nelson, 2004 ). 
Hypercalcemia causes metastatic calcification and the de -
velopment of band keratopathy (Aurbach, 1985).
In conclusion, several of the endocrinopathies in ani -
mals have ocular manifestations and treatment of the ocular 
signs is invariably aimed at or facilitated by treatment or 
control of the underlying cause.

Occular manifestation of infectious and noninfestious disease of dogs and cats  Chapter | 19  295
