Chapter 20
Diseases of ear in dogs and cats
1 Introduction
The ear is a sensory organ associated with hearing and equi-
librium, therefore known as the vestibulocochlear organ. 
The ear is composed of three parts: the external, middle, 
and internal ear.
2 Anatomy of ear of dogs and cats
2.1 Anatomy of external ear
External ear is made up of three elastic cartilages—annular, 
scutiform and auricular cartilages. Annular and auricular 
cartilages form the external ear canal, and the latter expands 
to form ear pinna. Scutiform cartilage connects the ear to 
the head.
Auricle (or) ear pinna is a visible portion of ear in the 
shape of a leaf or funnel with two surfaces, two borders, 
a base, and an apex. The anterior surface is concave and 
ridged, whereas the posterior surface is convex and covered 
with hair. The two borders (medial and lateral) unite to form 
an apex. Apex is blunt, and the base is broad (Ghosh, 1998) 
(Fig. 1).
External acoustic meatus is a canal that leads to the 
middle ear with a measurement of 5–10 cm length and 
4–5 mm width ( Ghosh, 1998 ). Initially, the canal is ver -
tical, about an inch and turns horizontally. The external 
acoustic meatus is cartilaginous in nature mostly, ex -
cept the deepest part of it, which is osseous in nature. 
Histologically, the ear canal comprises sebaceous and ce -
ruminous glands (modified apocrine tubular sweat glands) 
and hair follicles. The secretions of these glands form the 
ear wax or ear cerumen, which protects the ear canal by 
resisting the movement of the foreign body and maintains 
the tympanic membrane (junction between external and 
internal ear) moist and pliable. The carriage of the auricle 
or ear pinna is breed specific in dogs and in the case of 
cats, it is upright in nature ( Ghosh, 1998).
2.2 Anatomy of middle ear
The middle ear is located in the space between the tympanic 
membrane and the internal ear. This space is called a tym -
panic cavity with an irregular and biconcave shape within 
the petrous temporal bone.
The tympanic membrane is a thin semitransparent mem-
brane that separates the external auditory canal from the 
middle ear cavity. It consists of a large part that appears 
as pars tensa, and a small triangular portion called as pars 
flaccida. The first part can be visualized under otoscopic 
examination of the middle ear is the posterior portion of 
pars tensa (Shell, 1988).
The tympanic cavity is filled with air and covers most of 
the portion of the middle ear. The tympanic bulla is a part 
of the temporal bone, where the ventral portion of the tym-
panic cavity is present. Within the cavity, there is an open -
ing to the auditory tube. The tympanic nerve passes through 
the tympanic cavity near the maleus.
Auditory tube is a short canal connecting the nasophar -
ynx to the middle ear, and it helps to maintain atmospheric 
pressure in the middle ear by its connection with the phar -
ynx, due to which throat infection ascends to the middle ear 
(Ghosh, 1998).
Auditory ossicles include very small bones and are mal-
leus, incus, and stapes. They are arranged in a chain to con-
nect the tympanic membrane with an oval window of the 
internal ear. These bones attach to the tympanic wall by inter-
osseous ligaments. Vibrations of air that strike the tympanic 
membrane are amplified and transmitted across the middle 
ear cavity to the inner ear auditory receptors by the ossicles. 
Maleus is a hammer-shaped bone and its head articulates 
with incus. Whereas the incus is anvil shaped with its head ar-
ticulating with malleus and long process articulates with the 
head of the stapes with the help of the lenticular process. The 
stapes are stirrup-shaped, the head articulates with the long 
process of incus, and the base is fitted to an oval window. 
All these bones articulate together with the help of ligaments.

298 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
2.3 Anatomy of internal ear
It is the ear’s main portion called an organ of hearing and 
is situated within the petrous temporal bone, consists of 
a bony labyrinth that accommodates the membranous 
labyrinth. The space between two labyrinths is filled with 
perilymph (Resembles CSF). A bony labyrinth comprises 
vestibule, cochlea, and semicircular canals.
Vestibule is situated medial to the tympanic cavity 
and the cavity of vestibule lodges the utricle and saccule 
of membranous labyrinth. Cochlea has the appearance of 
the shell of a snail. Extract the basilar membrane from the 
edge of the lamina to the outer wall of the canal and di -
vide the canal into scala vestibule and scala tympani. These 
two scalae are continuous at the apex of the cochlea termed 
Helicotrema ( Ghosh, 1998 ). Semicircular canals are 3 in 
number, i.e., superior or anterior, posterior and lateral, and 
these canals are at right angles to each other ( Shell, 1988). 
Terminal parts of these tubes at the junctions with vestibule 
dilate to form the ampullae (Fig. 2).
Membranous labyrinth consists of the cochlear duct, 
saccule and utricle, 3 ducts of the semicircular canals. The 
membranous labyrinth cavity is filled with endolymph and 
compared to the saccule utricle is more prominent in size. 
The spiral tubes contain endolymph and the organ of corti 
is the organ of hearing.
Organ of corti is situated on the basilar membrane and 
contains hair cells, a tunnel of corti, a tectorial membrane, 
and a spiral ganglion. Hair cells are present on the basilar 
membrane in an outer and inner row. The tectorial mem -
brane is attached to the outer border of the spiral lamina. It 
is made of a gelatinous substance and overhangs hair cells. 
Spiral ganglions are situated on the bony spiral lamina. The 
axons of these spiral ganglionic nerve cells constitute the 
cochlear division of the auditory nerve. Vibrations received 
at the oval window are transmitted to the perilymph in the 
scala vestibule, causing fluid waves to occur in the endo -
lymph of the cochlear duct. As a result, the basilar mem -
brane moves, stimulating the hair cells of the organ of Corti 
and triggering an impulse in the cochlear portion of the 
eighth cranial nerve (Shell, 1988) (Fig. 3).
3 Diseases of external ear
3.1 Otitis externa
In general, inflammation of the ear is known as otitis and in 
specific, inflammation of the external ear is known as Otitis 
externa. Otitis externa is one of the chief complaints raised 
by pet owners to veterinarians due to multifactorial etiology.
Prevalence rate of Otitis externa in case of dogs is 
5%–20%, and in cats is 2%, low due to the upright na -
FIG. 1 Cartilages of the right external ear of dog.

Diseases of ear in dogs and cats  Chapter | 20  299
ture of the auricle and the absence of hair in the ear canal 
that enhances ventilation and drainage ( August, 1988 ). 
Breed wise incidence of otitis externa in dogs is re -
ported to be common among Cocker spaniels, Miniature 
poodles, Fox terriers, and Beagles and are at high risk. 
Among the cat breeds, Himalayan and Persians are at 
high risk ( Sparber et al., 2020 ). With respect to age wise, 
dogs aged 5 and 8  years are highly susceptible ( Grono 
and Frost, 1969 ) due to hypersensitivity diseases and 
disorders of keratinization. Cats between 1 and 2  years 
are highly susceptible due to early exposure and sensi -
tization to an ear mite, Otodetus cyanosis  (Orcutt et al., 
2011) (Table 1).
3.1.1 Primary factors
Parasites
External parasites associated in causing Otitis externa are ear 
mites like Otodectus cynotis, Sarcoptes scabei, Demodex ca-
nis, Demodex cati, Notoedres cati, Eutrombicula alfreddugesi 
FIG. 2 Schematic view of the tympanic membrane, middle ear, ossicles, and inner ear structures of dogs and cats.
FIG. 3 Anatomy of inner ear of dogs and cats.

300 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
and ear tick Otobius megnini (larval stage). Among these, the 
most commonly noticed parasites are Otodectus cynotis, an 
ear mite, and O. megnini, a spinose ear tick of dogs and cats 
play important role in causing otitis externa (Fig. 4).
Foreign bodies
Foreign bodies such as plant awns (Fox tail) and dirt are 
generally noticed on the ear after playing in a garden or 
open lands. Other foreign materials such as dried otic medi-
cations, dead insects and broken hairs that can be visualized 
under otoscopic examination.
Hypersensitivity diseases
The major cause of hypersensitivity disease in dogs and cats 
is atopic dermatitis and food allergy. It is reported that 55% 
of dogs with atopic dermatitis have concurrent otitis externa 
with 3%–5% ( Griffin et al., 2001 ), and 80% of dogs with 
food allergy have concurrent infections of otitis externa 
with 25% (Rosser, 2004). A less frequent cause of otitis ex-
terna is due to allergic contact dermatitis (ACD).
Disorders of keratinization
Keratinization defects could be due to endocrine dis -
orders like hypothyroidism, hyperadrenocorticism and 
sex- hormone imbalance; epithelialization disorders like se-
baceous adenitis, zinc-responsive dermatitis; glandular dis-
order like sebaceous gland hyperplasia. All these disorders 
may change the keratinization and cerumin production in 
the external ear canal leading to otitis externa ( Rosenfeld 
et al., 2014).
Auto immune diseases
Diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus, pemphigus 
vulgaris, pemphigus foliaceous, mucous membrane pem -
TABLE 1 Various factors causing otitis externa in dogs 
and cats (August, 1988; Rosser, 2004; Ettinger et al., 2016).

• Parasites
• Foreign bodies
• Hypersensitivity diseases
• Disorders of keratinization
• Autoimmune diseases
2 Predisposing Factors—These factors place dogs and 
cats at high risk.
• Ear canal maceration
• Treatment errors
• Obstructive ear disease
• Anal sac diseases
• Pyrexia
• Systemic diseases

for chronic otitis externa among cats and dogs.

• Otitis media

Diseases of ear in dogs and cats  Chapter | 20  301
phigoid, and cutaneous vasculitis cause otitis externa and 
skin lesions at other areas of the body.
3.1.2 Predisposing factors
Ear canal maceration
Usually, the ear canal of a dog has high relative humidity 
(August, 1988). If there is frequent wetting of the ear canal 
due to bathing or swimming increases the moisture in the 
ear canal which stimulates the activity of the ceruminous 
gland and secretes cerumin favoring the growth of microbes 
and leads to maceration of the ear canal.
Treatment errors
Improper use of antimicrobial preparations causes the 
proliferation of bacteria, e.g., Proteus mirabilis , and 
Pseudomonas aeruginosa  ( August, 1988 ). Also disuse of 
ear cleansing solutions causes irritation and maceration of 
the ear canal (Ghosh, 1998).
Obstructive ear disease
Decrease in the lumen of the ear canal due to inflamma -
tory polyps, tumors, congenital atresia cause obstruction in 
the ear canal and accumulation of cerumen in the ear canal 
which changes the ear environment and causes otitis externa.
Contribution of other predisposing factors like anal sac 
disease, pyrexia, systemic diseases leads to otitis externa in 
dogs and cats.
3.1.3 Perpetuating factors
Bacteria
Common commensals of the canine ear are Staphylococcus 
intermedius, micrococcus spp., and Coliforms occasionally, 
whereas the normal feline ear has Staphylococcus intermedius 
and Pasteurella multocida (Dickson and Love, 1983; McCarthy 
et al., 2009). These bacteria quickly colonize the ear canal when 
there is a change in the microenvironment of ear canal.
Yeast
The most commonly noticed fungal pathogen is Malassezia 
spp. and occasionally Candida spp., Aspergillus spp., 
Microsporum spp. and Trichophyton spp., Sporothrix 
schenki and paecilomyces spp. (Scott and Horn, 1987).
Otitis media
Inflammation of the middle ear is known as otitis media. It 
occurs due to extension of otitis externa, infection ascend -
ing to the eustachian tube, hematogenous route, tympanic 
rupture, tumors, and any foreign body in the external ear 
canal.
Progressive pathologic changes
In case of chronic ear canal inflammation, as the inflamma-
tion persists and results in epidermal hyperplasia, dermal 
hyperplasia, atrophy of sebaceous glands, and enlargement 
accompanied by inflammatory exudate ( Fig.  4). Due to 
severe inflammation, there will be a change in the micro -
climate of the ear which favors microbial growth and prolif-
eration which further enhances the inflammation and tissue 
changes.
3.1.4 Clinical presentations (or) different 
phases of Otitis externa (Ettinger et al., 2016)

3.1.5 Diagnosis
As multifactorial agents cause the disease, a detailed his -
tory is necessary for early diagnosis. In diagnosing Otitis 
externa, following step wise procedural examination and 
tests are recommended.
First step is examination from short distance. This 
helps diagnose the type of otitis externa. On close exami -
nation of the ear canal if it is pain on palpation and pus is 
noticed, it is suppurative otitis externa and if there is ex -
cessive cerumin production it is erythematous ceruminous 
otitis externa.

302 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
Second step is direct cerumen examination under low-
power magnification helps to detect ear mites or parasites in 
the ear canal and further cytologic examination and cultural 
examination which have greater diagnostic information re -
garding bacteria, fungi, yeast, neoplastic cells etc. helps to 
diagnose the type of microorganism causing otitis externa.
Cytologic examination procedure is easy to perform. 
Collect the otic exudate through ear swabs at the junction of 
the vertical and horizontal ear canal, then roll it on a glass 
slide and air dry it. Go with the appropriate staining pro -
cedures like Romanowsky stain, Lactophenol cotton blue 
stain, etc. by which different types of microorganisms under 
high power magnification can be appreciated.
Third step involves otoscopic examination and is used to 
evaluate the external ear canal and it helps in the identifica-
tion of otitis externa and otitis media. If any discomfort to 
an animal is noticed go with sedation. It is useful in diag -
nosing the ear canal for any ulcers, foreign bodies, tumors, 
the appearance of the tympanic membrane, polyps, etc.
Fourth step is dermatological examination in order to di-
agnose for any underlying skin diseases like scabies, ACD, 
atopic dermatitis, and food allergy dermatitis that are af -
fecting the external ear and further leading to otitis externa.
3.1.6 Treatment
Many cases of otitis externa are difficult to diagnose, espe-
cially when the condition is chronic and require more labo-
ratory test which is time-consuming. The main aim should 
be toward resolving primary causes, relieving inflamma -
tion, and removing microbial agents (Shell, 1988).
While treating the Otitis externa, the following proce -
dures and medications are indicated.
Cleaning of ear
It is basic and most important as it helps to diagnose any 
foreign body or tumor in the ear canal. Ear cleaning must 
be done twice or thrice a week. Pour ear cleansing liquid 
into the ear canal and massage the ear for 30 to 60  s which 
allows the pet to shake its head and then, clean the discharge 
oozing out from the ear canal with a cotton swab. A wide 
variety of ear cleaning agents are available in the market 
with different actions on the ear canal like surfactants, ceru-
minolytic agents, etc.
Local therapy with Acaricides
Otoacariasis is an infestation of the ear canal with ticks and 
mites most commonly seen in dogs and cats. Direct exami-
nation of cerumen under low power magnification is helpful 
in identifying ticks and mites. Use of acaricidal agents like 
Benzyl benzoate or Lindane (Chakrabarti, 2007) should be 
applied twice a week as the eggs of these mites will not de-
stroy easily. These mites not only survive in the ear but also 
in other parts of the body, especially in the lumbar region 
so it is advised to use Amitraz twice a week as an external 
application.
Topical antibacterial therapy
It is more effective rather than systemic therapy as bacteria 
present in cerumen and pus in the ear canal easily react with 
the topical antibiotic. The cytological examination needs to 
be done to identify the microorganism, whether it is rods 
or cocci and give appropriate antibiotics. For specific treat-
ment go with antibiotic sensitivity testing.
Topical antifungals therapy
Antifungal agents like Nystatin effectively works 
against Candida spp. infection and azole antifungals like 
Thiabendazole, Clotrimazole, Miconazole, Ketoconazole, 
Itraconazole, and Fluconazole will destruct the cell wall of 
microorganisms. Among these, Ketoconazole works against 
canine malassezia and Itraconazole for feline malassezia.
Corticosteroid therapy
It is especially indicated in chronic otitis externa cases. It 
helps to decrease the cerumen secretion, and reduce pain, 
pruritis and inflammatory swelling. In chronic cases, ste -
notic ears require Prednisone @ 2  mg/kg/day for 2  weeks. 
Dogs suffering from allergic otitis require topical otic corti-
costeroid, dimathyl sulfoxide (DMSO) @ 2 to 5 drops twice 
daily until the inflammation is controlled ( Lorenz et  al., 
2005).
Treatment of underlying skin diseases
Treat the skin diseases like scabies, atopic dermatitis, ACD 
with appropriate drugs that should not perpetuate to otitis 
externa. Recent studies say that some essential oils like 
Origanum vulgare, Salvia sclarea, etc., are used as alterna-
tive therapeutic agents and conventional drugs in bacterial 
otitis (Ebani et al., 2017). Contraindications are mandatory 
FIG. 5 Dog with otitis externa showing inflammatory exudates charac -
terized by enlarged ear with epidermal and dermal hyperplasia.

Diseases of ear in dogs and cats  Chapter | 20  303
in case of otitis as it may lead to ototoxicosis. Hence, ami -
noglycosides, chloramphenicol should not be used in case 
of a ruptured tympanic membrane.
Maintenance care
Application of medication must be carefully carried out 
and given adequate knowledge regarding otitis to owners. 
Advise the owners not to discontinue the treatment when 
the ear looks better before the infection gets resolved. 
Preventing water from entering the ear canal during swim -
ming or bathing will minimize maceration. Clipping of hair 
on the concave side of the ear pinna would decreases the 
humidity and increases ventilation to the ear canal.
3.2 Aural hematoma
Aural hematomas are subcutaneous fluctuating inflamma -
tions filled with hemorrhagic fluid due to traumatic rupture 
of capillaries that affect the ear pinna’s concave surface in 
dogs and cats ( Hewitt and Bajwa, 2020 ). It is a common 
condition in dogs with pendulous ears like Basset hound, 
Afghan hound, Cocker spaniel, Dachshund, Great Dane, 
etc.
In this condition, blood and serum accumulate in be -
tween the conchal cartilage and the skin of the ear ( Fig. 6). 
It is caused due to trauma, itching due to allergy, rupture 
of blood vessels within pinna due to repeated shaking of 
head, mites like Otodectes cyanotis  (50%) ( Hnilica and 
Patterson, 2016 ), Sarcoptes scabiei , lice infestation and 
auto immune disease of pinnal tissues. Clinical manifesta -
tions are mainly characterized by repeated shaking of head 
and rubbing of the ears, swelling either in inner or outer 
surface of the ear, ear appears as fluctuating, tendered on 
pressure. Pain on palpation, head is kept lowered at the af -
fected side. In chronic cases, the lesions become firm and 
fibrotic. Diagnosis can be done through aspiration at the af-
fected ear and will reveals the oozing of blood and serum. 
Treatment includes, if it is a mild cases we can go with hep-
arin, low anti-inflammatory dosage of oral glucocorticoids 
can be added ( Chakrabarti, 2007). Surgical intervention is 
required for draining out the accumulated blood and clo -
sure with mattress suture. Further checking for the presence 
of any underlying causes is needed in order to prevent the 
reoccurrence.
4 Disease of middle ear (or) otitis 
media
Inflammation of middle ear is called as otitis media. It is 
a most common disease that goes unnoticeably in veteri -
nary practice. The occurrence of this disease is 16% in 
acute otitis externa and 50%–80% in chronic otitis externa 
(Cole et al., 2006 ; Classen et al., 2016 ). It is a multifac -
torial disease includes infectious, allergic, environmental 
factors, etc.
4.1 Risk factors
4.1.1 Infectious causes
Infectious causes include bacteria like Streptococcus, 
Staphylococcus, E. coli, Pseudomonas, Proteus, Clostridium 
species, etc. Most common bacteria causing otitis media 
include is Streptococcus pneumonia, Haemophilus influ -
enza, Moraxella catarrahalis (Fraser, 1965; Denny, 1973). 
Among the Yeast, Malassezia canis and Candida spp. are 
common causes. Parasites causing Otocariasis in dogs and 
cats is otodectes cyanotis, and it causes rupture of tympanic 
membrane (Shell, 1988). Among fungal gents Aspergillus 
spp. infection is common.
4.1.2 Allergic causes
Primary factors are food hypersensitivity, canine atopic der-
matitis, and contact allergic reactions. Secondary factors in-
clude bacterial, yeast infections, and hyperplastic changes. 
Others include environmental factors (moisture, wet con -
ditions), foreign bodies, any trauma to ear, and metabolic 
diseases that decrease immunity, genetic predisposition, 
deficiency diseases, etc. can predispose to otitis media. The 
major route of infection is across the tympanic membrane 
where hair, foreign bodies, debris and exudate associated 
with external ear canal disease can cause inflammation, ne-
crosis, and rupture of the tympanic membrane and rarely by 
FIG. 6 Dog with aural hematoma showing accumulation of inflamma -
tory fluid in between the conchal cartilage and the skin of the ear.

304 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
hematogenous route and through the auditory tube ( Shell, 
1988). As discussed in otitis externa similar way, all the 
above factors cause the damage to middle ear and alter the 
microenvironment of the middle ear. Cats may develop oti-
tis media through the auditory tube as a sequel to upper re -
spiratory disease.
4.2 Clinical signs
Clinical signs are characterized by mild discomfort, pain, 
ottorrhea, head tilt toward the affected side, purulent dis -
charges from the external ear, mild pruritus, frequent 
shaking of head, scratching of ears, and will have hearing 
defects.
As the facial, sympathetic, and parasympathetic nerves 
line near the middle ear leads to facial nerve paralysis, 
Horner’s syndrome, and Keratoconjunctivitis sicca, respec-
tively of the ipsilateral side of affected ear (Chrisman et al., 
1999).
4.3 Diagnosis
4.3.1 Palpation
Careful palpation at the base of ear and temporomandibu -
lar joint region for any swelling and pain should be done. 
Examine the pharyngeal area for any inflammation, foreign 
body that may have spread to the middle ear via the audi -
tory tube ( Chrisman et al., 1999 ). The veterinarian should 
look for signs of head shaking, pawing at the ear, pain on 
opening mouth, signs of otitis externa, head tilt, facial nerve 
paralysis signs, Horner’s syndrome, ataxia. The signs of fa-
cial nerve paralysis, Horner’s syndrome, would distinguish 
otitis media from simple otitis externa.
4.3.2 Ear examination
For complete examination of the ear under the otoscope, a 
deep ear cleaning is required. For thorough examination of 
the ear, and to keep the animal comfort, heavy sedation (or) 
general anesthesia is necessary in most cases. If the ear is 
normal, we can visualize the tympanic membrane and ex -
ternal ear canal. The presence of debris, masses, ulceration, 
hyperplasia, (or) hyperkeratosis of the surrounding tissues 
may disturb the visualization of the tympanic membrane 
(Shell, 1988). By lavaging, the ear canal with normal saline 
removes the debris. In case of tympanic membrane rupture, 
antiseptic agents should not be used; even in dilute solu -
tions, it causes irreversible inner ear damage.
4.3.3 Cultural examination
Collect the samples of the material in the ear using cotton 
swabs, and culture the samples to identify the causative 
agent, conduct the antibiotic sensitivity test, and advise the 
correct antibiotic.
4.3.4 Myringotomy
This involves surgical incision into the ear drum (tympanic 
membrane), to relieve pain, and pressure and drain fluid. 
It is performed if the tympanic membrane is intact but dis -
colored and bulging. It is also performed for the purpose 
of obtaining samples for cytology and culture, and to drain 
fluid from the middle ear cavity. It is also used for treatment 
purposes in order to relieve pressure and pain caused by 
the fluid or inflammatory material within the middle ear. 
Myringotomy creates a small hole in the tympanic mem -
brane that heals rapidly if otitis media resolves ( Parker 
et  al., 2017 ). Most commonly used procedure is simple 
paracentesis, wherein, a blunt probe is inserted through the 
otoscope cone to perforate the tympanic membrane, and af-
ter perforation, 20 gauge needle is inserted into the perfo -
rated membrane and contents will be aspirated (Harvey and 
Ter Haar, 2016).
4.3.5 Radiographs
Radiographs may be helpful in the evaluation of otitis 
media. On a radiograph, we can detect any changes like 
thickening, and destruction to the structures of the ear. For 
obtaining quality radiographs ventro dorsal, oblique lateral 
views are needed. As many cases of otitis media are a se -
quela to chronic otitis externa, there will be a narrowing of 
the external ear canal which can be visualized under ven -
tro dorsal skull view ( Wiegand et al., 2019). In the case of 
chronic otitis media, thickened wall of the tympanic bulla 
is noticed. Even if the radiographs appear normal, that does 
not mean that your pet does not have otitis media because 
radiographic changes may not be visualized under X-rays 
for several weeks in acute cases of otitis media ( Shell, 
1988).
4.3.6 Advanced imaging
By computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance 
imaging (MRI), further evaluation of the tympanic bulla can 
be possible. CT is usually better in detecting bony changes, 
while MRI is better for detecting soft tissue abnormalities.
4.4 Treatment
It is done to remove inflammatory, infected or foreign ma -
terial from the bulla and to provide ventilation and drain -
age. Treatment is done by medical or surgical procedure or 
both depending upon the chronicity of disease. Primarily 
cleaning of the both external and middle ear canal is im -
portant. Debris can inactivate some topical medications and 
preventive medications from contacting infected tissues. 
Anesthesia is required to clean the deep ear canal, so that 
ear flushing will remove the debris. Use topical medication 
of antimicrobial drugs and corticosteroids directly to the 
affected area, after clearing the debris. Systemic  antibiotic

Diseases of ear in dogs and cats  Chapter | 20  305
therapy is also recommended. Based on culture and sen -
sitivity testing, specific antibiotic therapy is employed. 
Long-term use of aminoglycosides is avoided because of 
their toxicity effect. If culture is not obtained, broad spec -
trum antibiotics, such as Chloramphenicol, Cephalosporins, 
or Trimethoprim-sulfa are recommended. If no improve -
ment is seen in medical treatment, then opt for the surgical 
management.
In cases where exudate of the middle ear is noticed on 
otoscopy, a myringotomy may be performed and the middle 
ear cavity has to be irrigated with a warm saline solution af-
ter collection of samples. Certain ototoxic agents like ami -
noglycosides (gentamicin, neomycin), chloramphenicol, 
iodine, iodophor, cetrimide, chlorhexidine should not be used 
in case of the ruptured or perforated tympanic membrane. 
Complication of chronic otitis media is cholesteatoma, an 
epidermoid cyst caused by migration of stratified squamous 
epithelium from the externa ear canal to the affected middle 
ear through ruptured tympanic membrane ( Coyner, 2019). 
There is no specific treatment for facial nerve paralysis, 
Horner’s syndrome, and Keratoconjunctivitis sicca.
5 Disease of inner ear (or) otitis interna
Inflammation of the inner ear is called Otitis interna, and 
veterinary practitioners rarely notice this condition. It is as-
sumed that same organism causing otitis externa and media 
affects the internal ear. Almost half of the dogs showing 
peripheral vestibular syndrome is caused by otitis interna 
(Orlandi et al., 2020 ). The prolonged state of otitis media 
with no clinical significance will affect the internal ear. 
Inflammation of this internal ear impairs the 8th cranial 
nerve, loss of hearing ability and shows the signs of periph-
eral vestibular syndrome like head tilt, circling, falling to -
wards the affected side etc. (Orlandi et al., 2020). Diagnosis 
is not so simple in this conditions, where advanced diag -
nostic imaging techniques will be helpful in confirma -
tion. Employ systemic and topical antibiotic therapy with 
Cephalosporins, Chloramphenicol, etc., for 3 to 6 weeks. If 
the disease is caused by otitis externa or otitis media, go with 
the treatment as discussed above. The prognosis of disease 
is favorable if it is identified and treated earlier. Otherwise, 
in some cases, infection enters the brain stem and causes 
the brain stem abscess and meningitis (Barrs et al., 2007).
6 Deafness
Deafness is defined as the absence of perception of sound. 
It may be congenital or acquired as a result of infection, 
trauma, or degeneration of the cochlea. Deafness may be 
unilateral or bilateral. The most common cause of deafness 
is the hereditary type, usually associated with white pig -
mentation. This condition develops within 1–3  weeks after 
birth, secondary to stria vascularis degeneration.
Most hereditary deafness in dogs is pigment-associated, 
of the cochlea-saccular pathology type, and is specifically 
associated with either the recessive alleles of the piebald 
gene (S) or the dominant allele of the merle (M) gene. 
White pigmentation is specifically associated with either 
the recessive alleles of the piebald gene (S) or the dominant 
allele of the merle (M) gene. The piebald and merle genes 
suppress melanocytes, producing white or dilution of pig -
mentation in skin and hair, blue irises in some dogs, and 
disrupted function in the stria vascularis, resulting in deaf -
ness (Strain, 2012).
Other types of deafness include sensorineural (nerve) 
deafness and is caused due to loss of cochlear hair cells 
leading to loss of auditory function. Another is conduc -
tive deafness and is due to blockage of sound transmission 
through the external or middle ear. In case of conductive 
deafness, there will not be any cochlea damage.
6.1 Causes of deafness
Geriatric animals develop presbycusis (age-related hear -
ing loss) which is progressive with time and cannot be 
prevented or reversed. Ototoxicity results from administer-
ing a drug or chemical that directly or indirectly destroys 
cochlear hair cells, resulting in hearing loss or even total 
deafness. The most common cause of ototoxicity is due to 
the administration of aminoglycoside antibiotics, such as 
Gentamicin, Kanamycin, Neomycin, Tobramycin, and oth-
ers. Otitis of the middle ear or inner ear can produce tran -
sient or permanent deafness. Noise-induced hearing loss 
(NIHL) is caused primarily by loss of hair cells due to me -
chanical trauma, and extreme sounds can also damage the 
tympanum. NIHL is based on sound intensity and duration 
of exposure. Hearing loss can be vary depending on any 
of the above causes, and it may be unilateral or bilateral 
(Kent et  al., 2010 ). Unilaterally deaf animals show signs 
like inability to localize sound origins and generally orient 
toward the good ear. Bilaterally deaf animals do not respond 
to sound stimuli and are adapted to increased attention to 
other senses such as vision and vibration.
6.2 Diagnosis
Deafness is detected by brainstem auditory evoked response 
(BAER), also known as brainstem auditory evoked potential 
(BAEP). It detects electrical activity in the cochlea and au -
ditory pathways in the brain similar to electro cardio gram 
(ECG) which detects electrical activity of the heart. Each 
ear is tested individually, and the duration of test ranges 
from 10 to 15  min. Anesthesia may not be required unless 
the dog becomes extremely agitated. Small electrodes are 
placed under the skin of the scalp: one in front of each ear, 
one at the top of the head, and one between the shoulders. 
The response will be in the form of a wave consisting of a

306 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
series of peaks. First peak or Peak I is produced by the co -
chlear nerve, and later peaks are produced within the brain. 
The response from deaf ear is a flat line. Deafness is also 
diagnosed by Otoscopic examination of the external ear and 
tympanum and also by radiography of the tympanic bullae.
6.3 Therapy
Based on the type of deafness, we need to go with appropri-
ate therapy. Early intervention in ototoxicity may reduce or 
reverse loss but usually is not successful. Once developed, 
sensorineural deafness cannot be reversed, and its cause 
cannot be determined.
If the deafness is congenital, there is no specific treat -
ment to reverse the damage. However, such pets can be 
maintained by giving perfect training. Based on the interest 
of the owner, hearing aids can be used in pets as in humans. 
If it is conductive deafness caused due to more accumula -
tion of cerumen or any foreign body, go with appropriate 
therapy to regain the hearing capability. In case of inflam -
matory and infectious diseases, anti-inflammatory drugs 
and antimicrobials are indicated, whereas dogs with tumor 
in external ear need chemotherapy or radiation therapy 
(Ettinger et al., 2016).
7 Aural neoplasia
Neoplastic and non-neoplastic diseases of ear canal, form -
ing mass lesions in the dog and cat are similar in normal 
character and histology. However, the incidence of aural 
neoplasia is low in animal practice ( Gotthelf, 2004 ). The 
observation of a mass is a common clinical sign of aural 
neoplasia, however, an associated discharge is seen and 
consistent with otitis externa or media. Nervous signs such 
as facial paralysis, and vestibular abnormalities may be 
seen and may be differentially diagnosed of tumor invasion. 
Most of the malignant tumors local invasion is common and 
the frequency of the metastasis is less, however, in the case 
of cats during initial diagnosis, 5%–15% have reported the 
metastasis to regional lymph nodes and lungs ( MacEwen 
and Reviews, 1990).
The incidence of benign ear tumors in dogs is about 
40% of ear neoplasms, including ceruminous gland ad -
enoma, sebaceous gland adenoma, basal cell tumors, his -
tiocytomas, papillomas and fibromas, inflammatory polyps, 
and others (Berzon and Bunch, 1980; Pratschke, 2003; Fan 
and de Lorimier, 2004 ). Malignant tumors include squa -
mous cell carcinoma, carcinoma of undetermined origin, 
sebaceous cell carcinoma, and mesenchymal tumors such 
as melanomas, soft-tissue sarcomas, and hemangiopericy -
toma. Malignant neoplasms are more common than benign 
tumors in canine ear. Surgical resection is the best treat -
ment for malignant neoplasms involving the ear canal. The 
commonly noticed benign ear neoplasms in cats are ceru -
minous gland origin, while other tumor types are similar to 
dogs. Benign tumors originating in the cat’s pinna include 
basal cell epithelioma, rhabdomyoma, and hemangioma 
(Fan and de Lorimier, 2004). Other tumors like carcinoma, 
melanoma, and mast cell tumors may have benign charac -
teristics. In cats, 80% of tumors of the ear are malignant 
(London et al., 1996).

Chapter 21
Overview on diseases of blood and 
hematopoietic system in dogs and cats
Blood cells form and develop mostly in the bone marrow, 
that is, the tissue located in the cavities of bones. Blood 
performs a variety of important functions as it circulates 
throughout the body. It delivers oxygen and vital nutrients 
(such as vitamins, minerals, fats, and sugars) to the tis -
sues. It carries carbon dioxide to the lungs to be exhaled 
and waste products to the kidneys and liver to be eliminated 
from the body. It transports hormones, which are chemi -
cal messengers, to various parts of the body, allowing those 
parts to communicate with each other. Blood also includes 
cells that fight infection and control bleeding.
There are three cellular elements of blood: red blood 
cells, white blood cells, and platelets. Basically, red blood 
cells supply the body with oxygen, white blood cells pro-
tect against infection, and platelets start the formation of 
blood clots.
1 Hematopoietic system in animals
Blood supplies cells with water, electrolytes, nutrients, 
and hormones and removes waste products. The cellular 
elements supply oxygen ( RBCs), protect against foreign 
organisms and antigens ( WBCs), and initiate coagulation 
(platelets). Because of the diversity of the hematopoietic 
system, its diseases are best discussed from a functional 
perspective. The function may be classified as either normal 
responses to abnormal situations (e.g., leukocytosis and left 
shift in response to inflammation) or primary abnormali -
ties of the hematopoietic system (e.g., pancytopenia from 
marrow failure). Furthermore, abnormalities may be quan -
titative (i.e., too many or too few cells) or qualitative (i.e., 
abnormalities in function) (Cotter, 2022a,b,c,d).
The hematopoietic system includes the formed elements 
of the blood as well as the bone marrow, spleen, lymph 
nodes, and reticuloendothelial tissue. It is uniquely con -
structed to provide the body with a vast capacity for cell 
renewal. To balance the loss of mature cells and to provide 
for rapid expansion in response to bodily insults, cellular 
renewal must be maintained throughout life. The relative 
accessibility of the blood and bone marrow creates the po -
tential for providing early clues to the effects of toxic expo-
sure. A wide range of hematological disorders may follow 
exposure to such environmental agents as solvents, heavy 
metals, insecticides, nitrates, nitrites, and ionizing radiation 
(Tsongas, 1985; Smith, 1986).
2 Red blood cells in animals
The function of RBCs is to carry oxygen to the tissues at 
pressures sufficient to permit its rapid diffusion. This is ac-
complished through the following mechanisms: a carrier 
molecule, hemoglobin (Hgb); a vehicle (RBC) capable of 
bringing the intact Hgb to the cellular level; and a metab -
olism geared to protect both the RBC and the Hgb from 
damage. Interference with synthesis or release of Hgb, pro-
duction or survival of RBCs, or metabolism causes disease. 
Erythropoiesis is regulated by erythropoietin, which in -
creases in the presence of hypoxia and regulates RBC pro -
duction. In most species, the kidney is both the sensor organ 
and the major site of erythropoietin production, so chronic 
renal failure is associated with anemia. Erythropoietin acts 
on the marrow in concert with other humoral mediators to 
increase the number of stem cells entering RBC production, 
to shorten maturation time, and to cause early release of 
reticulocytes. Other factors that affect erythropoiesis are the 
supply of nutrients (e.g., iron, folate, or vitamin B 12) and 
cell-cell interactions between erythroid precursors, lym -
phoid cells, and other components of the hematopoietic mi-
croenvironment. Factors that may suppress erythropoiesis 
include chronic debilitating diseases and endocrine disor -
ders (Cotter, 2022a,b,c,d).
The principal metabolic pathway of RBC is glycoly -
sis, and the main energy source in most species is glucose. 
Glucose enters the RBC by an insulin-independent mecha -
nism, and most are metabolized to produce ATP and reduced 
nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADH). The energy of

310 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
ATP is used to maintain RBC membrane pumps so as to 
preserve shape and flexibility. The reducing potential of the 
NADH is utilized via the methemoglobin reductase path -
way to maintain the iron in Hgb in its reduced form (Fe2+).
The glucose not used in glycolysis is metabolized via a 
second pathway, the hexose monophosphate (HMP) shunt. 
No energy is produced via the HMP shunt; its principal ef -
fect is to maintain reducing potential in the form of reduced 
nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH). In 
conjunction with the glutathione reductase/peroxidase sys -
tem, NADPH maintains the sulfhydryl groups of globin in 
their reduced state.
Some disorders are the direct result of abnormal RBC 
metabolism and interference with glycolysis. Inherited defi-
ciency of pyruvate kinase, a key glycolytic enzyme, causes 
ATP deficiency, which leads to reduced RBC lifespan and 
hemolytic anemia. Excessive oxidant stress may overload 
the protective HMP shunt or methemoglobin reductase 
pathways, causing Heinz body hemolysis or methemoglo -
bin formation, respectively. Hemolytic anemia caused by a 
drug, such as acetaminophen in cats, is an example of this 
mechanism.
A decreased RBC (Fig. 4) mass (anemia) may be caused 
by blood loss, hemolysis, or decreased production. In acute 
blood loss anemia, RBCs are lost, but mortality is usually 
related to loss of circulating volume rather than to loss 
of RBC. Iron is the limiting factor in chronic blood loss. 
Hemolysis may be caused by toxins, infectious agents, con-
genital abnormalities, or antibodies directed against RBC 
membrane antigens. Decreased RBC production may re -
sult from primary marrow diseases (e.g., aplastic anemia, 
hematopoietic malignancy, or myelofibrosis) or from other 
causes such as renal failure, drugs, toxins, or antibodies 
directed against RBC precursors. Malignancy of RBCs or 
their precursors may be acute (e.g., erythroleukemia) or 
chronic (e.g., polycythemia vera). Animals with erythro -
leukemia are anemic despite having a marrow filled with 
rubriblasts, whereas those with polycythemia vera have 
erythrocytosis (Table 1).
Erythrocytosis in dogs and cats has most commonly 
been associated with dehydration, high-altitude environ -
ments, and renal and cardiovascular disease.
2.1 Absolute erythrocytosis
2.1.1 Primary versus secondary absolute 
erythrocytosis
Primary versus secondary absolute erythrocytosis , de -
fined by an increase in RBC mass, may be either primary or 
secondary. Primary erythrocytosis (i.e., PV) is a myelopro-
liferative disorder characterized by clonal proliferation of 
neoplastic erythroid stem cells that require little or no EPO 
for clonal expansion, growth, and differentiation. Normal 
negative feedback inhibition of erythrocytosis does not 
 occur, and EPO levels are usually low or undetectable. In a 
distinct subset of humans, primary polycythemia is due to a 
familial and congenital genetic mutation of the EPO recep-
tor. This truncated EPO receptor protein mutation lacks the 
cytoplasmic negative regulatory portion, resulting in non -
neoplastic primary erythrocytosis ( Furukawa et  al., 1997; 
Kralovics et al., 1997).
In dogs and cats, primary erythrocytosis is considered 
a rare neoplastic disease of young to middle-aged animals 
without apparent sex or breed predilection ( Peterson and 
Randolph, 1982, 1983 ). In contrast to the situation in hu -
mans, leukocytosis, thrombocytosis, increased leukocyte al-
kaline phosphatase, and increased vitamin B 12 and vitamin 
B12-binding capacity have not been reported in either feline 
or canine cases. Although splenomegaly in veterinary pa -
tients has been reported, hepatomegaly, hypertension, and 
hyperuricemia have not. In veterinary medicine, therefore, 
the term primary erythrocytosis is more appropriate than 
polycythemia vera. Secondary erythrocytosis is caused by 
altered regulatory activity or excessive production of EPO. 
If systemic hypoxia is present, the increased EPO produc -
tion results in an increased RBC mass capable of increased 
oxygen-carrying capacity, which represents an appropriate, 
compensatory response. As outlined in Table 2, appropriate 
secondary erythrocytosis most often results from cardio -
vascular disease, chronic pulmonary disease, hemoglobin -
opathies such as methemoglobin reductase deficiency (rare 
in veterinary patients), decreased 2,3-diphosphoglycerate 
(2,3-DPG) levels in RBCs, high altitude environments, 
massive obesity, or neurologic disease causing depressed 
respiratory center function and decreased alveolar ventila -
tion. Elevated EPO levels are expected in these situations. 
Inappropriate secondary erythrocytosis is characterized by 
increased EPO levels without evidence of a hypoxic stim -
ulus. In both veterinary and human patients, neoplasia is

considered the most common cause. Both benign and ma -
lignant tumors have been reported in humans and include 
neoplasms of the kidney, lung, liver, uterus, ovaries, adrenal 
glands, thymus, and central nervous system. Renal cysts, 
hydronephrosis, and renal transplantation have also been 
reported as causes in humans.
Clinically significant erythrocytosis is recognized by a 
repeatable increase in PCV . Differentiation of relative from 
absolute erythrocytosis is mandatory because treatment of 
the two forms differs significantly. Evidence of fluid loss, 
dehydration, or vascular redistribution consistent with rela-
tive erythrocytosis is usually identified at the initial evalua-
tion, and these signs are easily correctable with replacement 
fluid therapy and resolution of the inciting cause. The find-
ing of an elevated PCV and reticulocytosis is consistent 
with absolute erythrocytosis. More difficult, however, is the 
differentiation between primary and secondary causes. The 
history and physical examination findings, in addition to 
appropriate laboratory and imaging test results, may reveal 
an underlying cardiopulmonary (appropriate) or neoplas -
tic (inappropriate) disease associated with EPO-dependent 
secondary causes of erythrocytosis. Primary erythrocy -
tosis is a rare, EPO-independent hematopoietic neoplas -
tic disease. The diagnosis is often made after a thorough 
search has excluded other causes of erythrocytosis and an 
appropriately low serum EPO level has been documented. 
Phlebotomy is currently the primary therapy in all forms 
of clinically significant absolute erythrocytosis. Concurrent 
treatment with hydroxyurea or 32P may be useful in some 
cases, although the small number of reported cases in which 
these therapies have been used has typically combined drug 
therapy with phlebotomy. Therefore, it is difficult to state 
that these treatment modalities are superior to phlebotomy 
alone. It is equally difficult to predict long-term survival for 
the various forms of absolute erythrocytosis in veterinary 
patients because studies evaluating such survival have yet to 
be conducted. However, long-term survival of patients with 
primary erythrocytosis, and perhaps some forms of second-
ary erythrocytosis, may be expected with attentive medical 
management (Nitsche, 2004).
2.2 Anemia in dogs and cats
Anemia is defined as an absolute decrease in the red cell 
mass as measured by RBC count, hemoglobin concentra -
tion, and/or PCV . It can develop from loss, destruction, or 
lack of production of RBCs. Anemia is classified as re -
generative or nonregenerative (Table 3). With regenerative 
anemia, the bone marrow responds appropriately to the de-
creased red cell mass by increasing RBC production and

typically regenerative. Anemia caused by decreased eryth -

2.2.1 Clinical findings
Clinical signs in anemic animals depend on the degree of 
anemia, the duration (acute or chronic), and the underlying 
cause. Acute anemia can result in shock and even death if 
more than a third of the blood volume is lost rapidly and not 
replaced. In acute blood loss, the animal usually presents 
with one or more of the following:
● tachycardia
● pale mucous membranes
● bounding or weak peripheral pulses
● hypotension
The cause of the blood loss may be overt, e.g., trauma. 
If no evidence of external bleeding is found, a source of 
internal or occult blood loss must be sought, e.g., a rup -
tured splenic tumor, other neoplasia, coagulopathy, GI ul -
ceration, or parasites. If hemolysis is present, the animal 
may be icteric.
Animals with chronic anemia have had time to accom-
modate, and their clinical presentation is usually more indo-
lent with vague signs such as:
● lethargy
● weakness
● anorexia
These animals may have similar physical examination 
findings such as pale mucous membranes and weak periph-
eral pulses. The lack of expected clinical signs may alert 
the clinician to the time frame involved. Splenomegaly, ab-
dominal distention, and/or heart murmur may be present, 
depending on the underlying cause of anemia.
3 White blood cells in animals
The principal function of phagocytes is to defend against 
invading microorganisms by ingesting and destroying 
them, thus contributing to cellular inflammatory responses. 
There are two types of phagocytes: mononuclear phago-
cytes and granulocytes. Mononuclear phagocytes arise 
primarily from the marrow and are released into the blood 
as monocytes. They may circulate for hours to a few days 
before entering the tissues and differentiating to become 
macrophages. Granulocytes have a segmented nucleus and 
are classified according to their staining characteristics as 
neutrophils ( Fig.  1), eosinophils ( Fig.  2), or basophils. 
Neutrophils circulate for only a few hours before traveling 
to the tissues (Cotter, 2022a,b,c,d).
Pancytopenia (i.e., a decrease in all circulating hema -
tologic cell lines) can result from peripheral destruction of 
cells or a primary insult to the bone marrow. Many infec -
tious, immune-mediated, and neoplastic conditions have 
been associated with pancytopenia in dogs and cats. Bone 
marrow aspirates and/or core biopsy samples are generally 
required to fully characterize the marrow disease, espe -
cially in cases of decreased hematopoietic cell production. 
Understanding the mechanisms by which various disorders 
alter circulating blood or marrow cells may aid in devel -
oping a diagnostic and/or treatment plan. The prognosis in 
pancytopenic patients is variable and depends on the under-
lying cause (Kearns and Ewing, 2006).
Pancytopenia (in Greek, “pan” means “all”) is defined 
as decreased circulating numbers of all marrow cell lines: 
myeloid, erythroid, and megakaryocytic. Clinical signs 
related to pancytopenia are often nonspecific. Pallor and 
FIG. 1 Canine neutrophils.
FIG. 2 Canine eosinophil.

Overview on diseases of blood and hematopoietic system  Chapter | 21  313
bleeding tendencies, such as petechiae, are the most com -
mon clinical manifestations and are directly related to ane -
mia and thrombocytopenia, respectively. Most clinical signs 
are referable to the underlying condition. However, certain 
physical examination findings may help direct the diagnos-
tic course. An accurate and thorough history is essential in 
determining the cause of pancytopenia.
3.1 Decreased hematopoietic marrow cell 
production
Causes of decreased hematopoietic marrow cell produc -
tion include marrow hypoplasia or aplasia, bone marrow 
necrosis, marrow fibrosis/sclerosis, myelophthisis, and my-
elodysplastic syndrome (MDS). Many infectious, neoplas -
tic, inflammatory, or immune-mediated diseases can result 
in decreased cellular production by various mechanisms. 
Although hematopoietic marrow cells decrease in number, 
the overall cellularity of the marrow may increase, espe -
cially in cases of myelodysplasia, myelophthisis, and mar -
row necrosis.
3.2 Five distinct stages in the process of 
phagocytosis have been identified
1. Attraction of phagocytes (chemotaxis) to microorgan -
isms, antigen-antibody complexes, and other mediators 
of inflammation
2. Attachment to the organism
3. Ingestion
4. Fusion of cell lysosomes with ingested microorganisms 
and bacterial killing
5. Digestion
Eosinophils (Fig. 2), while having a role as phagocytes, 
also have more specific functions that include providing a 
defense against metazoan parasites and modulating the in -
flammatory process. They respond chemotactically to his -
tamine, immune complexes, and eosinophil chemotactic 
factor of anaphylaxis, a substance released by degranulat -
ing mast cells. Basophils are not true phagocytes but con -
tain large amounts of histamine and other mediators of 
inflammation. Eosinophilia and basophilia may be seen in 
response to systemic allergic reactions and invasion of tis -
sues by parasites.
4 Lymphocytes in animals
Lymphocytes ( Fig.  3) are responsible for both humoral 
and cellular immunity. Cells of the two branches of the im-
mune system cannot be differentiated morphologically, but 
they differ in their dynamics of production and circulation. 
Lymphocyte production in mammals originates in the bone 
marrow. Some of the lymphocytes destined to be involved 
in cellular immunity migrate to the thymus and differenti -
ate further under the influence of thymic hormones. These 
become T cells and are responsible for a variety of helper or 
cytotoxic immunologic functions. Most circulating lympho-
cytes are T cells, but T cells are also present in the spleen 
and lymph nodes. The B cells migrate directly to organs 
without undergoing modification in the thymus and are re -
sponsible for humoral immunity (antibody production).
Thus, lymphoid organs have populations of both B and 
T lymphocytes. In the lymph nodes, follicular centers are 
primarily B cells, and parafollicular zones are primarily 
T cells. In the spleen, most of the lymphocytes of the red 
pulp are B cells, whereas those of the periarteriolar lym -
phoid sheaths are T cells. The close association of T cells 
and B cells within lymphoid organs is essential to immune 
function.
Antibody molecules (immunoglobulins) fall into several 
classes, each with its own functional characteristics. For 
example, IgA is the principal antibody of respiratory and 
intestinal secretions, IgM is the first antibody produced in 
response to a newly recognized antigen, IgG is the principal 
antibody of the circulating blood, and IgE is the principal 
antibody involved in allergic reactions.
The humoral immune system also is related to both the 
nonspecific immune system and the cellular immune sys -
tem in other ways. Both “helper” (CD4) and “cytotoxic” 
(CD8) T cell classes have been described. Helper T cells 
recognize processed antigen and activate the humoral im -
mune response. Cytotoxic T cells, after sensitization by an-
tigen, are effector cells, which are especially important in 
antiviral immunity. Natural killer cells, which are a class 
of lymphocytes distinct from T cells and B cells, destroy 
foreign cells (e.g., neoplastic cells) even without prior sen -
sitization. Antigen processing by macrophages precedes the 
FIG. 3 Canine eosinophil and lymphocyte.

314 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
recognition of an antigen by lymphocytes. These complex 
processes are involved in routine surveillance against neo -
plastic cells and recognition of “self.”
5 Platelets in animals
Platelets (Fig. 4) form the initial hemostatic plug whenever 
hemorrhage occurs. They also are the source of a phospho-
lipid, which is needed for the interaction of coagulation 
factors to form a fibrin clot. Platelets are produced in the 
bone marrow from megakaryocytes, under the influence 
of thrombopoietin. Platelet production begins with the in -
vagination of the megakaryocyte cell membrane and the 
formation of cytoplasmic channels and islands. The cyto -
plasmic islands produce platelets by fragmentation from the 
megakaryocyte.
Local platelet aggregation is stimulated by ADP, with 
the ultimate formation of the primary platelet plug. The lo -
cal accumulation of fibrin and platelets is known as a hemo-
static plug. The fibrin clot that then forms is consolidated 
by the action of platelet contractile proteins.
Platelet disorders are either quantitative (thrombocyto -
penia or thrombocytosis) or qualitative (thrombocytopathy). 
Thrombocytopenia is one of the most common bleeding 
disorders in animals. In general, platelet counts must fall 
to <30,000/μL before the risk of hemorrhage increases. 
Consumption, destruction, or sequestration of platelets 
causes thrombocytopenia associated with increased produc-
tion by the bone marrow. Consumptive thrombocytopenia 
occurs with massive hemorrhage or with disseminated in -
travascular coagulation, secondary to a variety of diseases. 
Destruction occurs in immune-mediated thrombocytopenia, 
in which platelets become coated with antiplatelet antibod-
ies and are removed from circulation by the fixed phagocyte 
system. Excessive sequestration of platelets by an enlarged 
spleen (hypersplenism) may occur in conditions such as 
myeloproliferative diseases.
Decreased production of platelets in the marrow may be 
caused by drugs, toxins, or by primary marrow disorders 
such as aplasia, fibrosis, or hematopoietic malignancy. In 
primary marrow disorders, more than one hematopoietic 
cell line is often decreased, resulting in pancytopenia.
Ehrlichial infections should be considered in the differ -
ential diagnosis for cats and dogs with multiple cytopenias. 
This leads to petechial (Fig. 5) and ecchymotic hemorrhages 
(Fig. 6) in the ventral abdomen and nasal epistaxis (Fig. 7).
Thrombocytosis is rare and often idiopathic . It may 
be associated with primary marrow disease such as in mega-
karyocytic leukemia. It is often associated with chronic 
blood loss and iron deficiency because of increased platelet 
production in the marrow reacting to continued consump -
tion and loss.
5.1 Thrombocytopathies
Thrombocytopathies comprise a poorly defined group of 
diseases in which platelet numbers are normal but their func-
tion is impaired. V on Willebrand disease is characterized 
FIG. 4 Canine RBC’s and platelets.
FIG. 5 Petechial hemorrhage.

Overview on diseases of blood and hematopoietic system  Chapter | 21  315
primarily by a defect in platelet adhesion to the endothe -
lium. The platelets themselves are normal. Other hereditary 
disorders of platelet function have been described but are 
relatively rare. Probably the most common platelet function 
defect is the irreversible inhibition of thromboxane (which 
is necessary for platelet aggregation) caused by aspirin 
administration.
5.2 Bleeding disorders in dogs and cats
5.2.1 Definition
● Bleeding disorders are conditions in which the blood 
does not clot normally, causing a tendency to bleed ab -
normally or excessively after minor bumps or cuts.
5.2.2 Introduction
Systemic bleeding disorders responsible for spontaneous 
or inappropriate hemorrhage are common in dogs and cats. 
Most are acquired but some are inherited. Because bleeding 
disorders can be potentially life-threatening, it is imperative 
that a logical diagnostic approach be used to quickly estab-
lish the diagnosis and implement appropriate therapy. Such 
an approach requires a sound understanding of hemostasis 
and the pathophysiology of the disorders themselves.
5.3 Primary hemostasis
5.3.1 Platelet plug formation
When an injury occurs to a blood vessel, the first slowing of 
blood results from constriction of the vessel. Vascular spasm 
is mediated by nervous reflexes from the injured vessel and 
nearby tissues, local muscle spasm, and factors released 
from platelets and traumatized tissues. Platelets coming 
into contact with a traumatized vessel wall’s exposed sub -
endothelial collagen will adhere and change. The exposed 
tissue contains V on Willebrand’s factor (a.k.a. factor VIIIR: 
Ag or VWF) and fibronectin, contact proteins that activate 
the platelets and cause them to become “sticky.” The plate-
lets bind to the subendothelial collagen, and their contractile 
proteins forcefully eject multiple active factors that promote 
further adhesion, shape change, and granule release in ad -
joining platelets. This successive attraction forms a platelet 
plug, which can stop blood loss by itself in small vessels or 
larger vessels with small injuries. Platelets play an integral 
role in maintaining normal vascular integrity by closing the 
thousands of minute ruptures that occur daily in the body.
5.4 Secondary hemostasis
Clotting of the plasma secondary to the interaction of coag-
ulation factors. In larger vessels or more traumatized tissue, 
the fragile platelet plug forms a temporary seal, and a blood 
clot is required to stop the bleeding. Secondary hemosta -
sis involves the formation of fibrin on the surface of the 
platelet plug by coagulation factors. These factors, denoted 
by Roman numerals, circulate as inactive precursor forms 
of proteolytic enzymes. At the site of injury, they become 
converted to their active forms—the sequential activation 
of one factor leading to another is where the terminology 
of the “clotting cascade” originates. Although the coagula -
tion cascade is often divided into an extrinsic, intrinsic, and 
common pathway—done to allow visualization of the clot-
ting inside and outside the vascular system—these systems 
can and do often work together to trigger coagulation. The 
culmination of the activation and interaction of these clot -
ting factors is the creation of a fibrin framework over the 
unstable initial platelet plug, i.e., the blood clot.
5.4.1 Fibrinolysis
The process whereby the blood clot is removed once the 
integrity of the blood vessel is restored. Once a blood clot is 
FIG. 6 Ecchymotic hemorrhage.
FIG. 7 Epistaxis in a dog.

316 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
formed, it is essential that it is eventually dissolved so that 
adequate blood flow can be reestablished. Plasmin is a pro-
teolytic enzyme that digests fibrin fibers as well as factors 
V , VIII, XII, and prothrombin and causes the eventual lysis 
of the blood clot. As fibrin is cleaved by plasmin, it leaves 
behind cross‐linked fragments known as fibrin degradation 
products (FDPs) (Fig. 8).
5.5 Diseases of primary hemostasis
Platelet dysfunction is classically divided into extrinsic and 
intrinsic causes. Extrinsic disorders present with a defi -
ciency of an extrinsic protein necessary for platelet func -
tion. The most common cause of extrinsic disorders is von 
Willebrand Disease (VWD). Disorders of fibrinogen, either 
hypofibrinogenemia or dysfibrinogenemia, can also cause 
extrinsic defects because fibrinogen is necessary for plate -
let aggregation. Acquired forms of fibrinogen defects are 
much more common than genetic forms. Intrinsic disorders 
affect the function of the platelet. Defects can arise from 
abnormalities in membrane receptors, storage granules, or 
signal transduction (Boudreaux, 2012). Intrinsic platelet de-
fects that have been described in the veterinary literature in-
clude Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia (GT), Chediak-Higashi 
syndrome (CHS), cyclic hematopoiesis, leukocyte adhesion 
deficiencies, May-Hegglin anomaly, adenosine diphosphate 
(ADP) abnormalities, macrothrombocytopenia, and vari -
ous thrombopathies (Boudreaux, 2012). A defect in platelet 
function usually manifests itself as bleeding from mucosal 
surfaces, bruising, or in extreme cases, cavitary bleeding. 
When platelets are low in number but normal in function, 
the animal typically presents with petechiae or ecchymo -
sis due to the extravasation of red blood cells. Trophogens, 
secreted from platelets, are needed to maintain endothelial 
tight junctions and, when low, can lead to red blood cell 
leakage (Brooks and Catalfamo, 2010).
5.5.1 Von Willebrand disease
V on Willebrand factor (vWF) is thought to be an essential 
protein in the adhesion of platelets to areas of damaged en-
dothelium. It is synthesized by endothelial cells and mega -
karyocytes and stored in endothelial cells and, to a lesser 
degree, platelets. In its active form, vWF circulates as 
 various-sized molecules join together to make multimers that 
range in size from 500 to 200,000 kDa. The large-molecular- 
weight multimers are important in hemostasis because they 
are the most effective at supporting platelet adhesion. The 
most common inherited bleeding disorder in humans and 
dogs is vWD (Carr et al., 2009). It is caused by both struc -
tural and quantitative deficiencies of vWF, depending on 
the type, and has been classified into three different catego-
ries (Carr et al., 2009 ). Type 1 is the most common form 
of vWD and is characterized by a low concentration but 
normal function of all multimers. Most animals with type 
1 vWD have mild clinical signs that occur most commonly 
with trauma, hematuria, or deciduous tooth loss. There can 
be life-threatening intraoperative or postoperative hemor -
rhage in some cases (Brooks, 2010).
The activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) and 
activated clotting time (ACT) can be normal or prolonged 
in patients with vWD. Because vWF serves as a carrier 
molecule for FVIII, decreased concentrations of vWF are 
associated with decreased factor VIII levels. Prolongation 
of the aPTT or ACT usually occurs when the factor levels 
are below 30% of normal. If the FVIII is below 30%, a pro-
longed aPTT will be seen in patients with vWD.
Type 2 vWD is characterized by a low concentration of 
vWF with a preferential deficiency in the high-  molecular-
weight multimers. The lack of high-molecular-weight 
multimers makes platelet adhesion much less effective. 
A complete absence of all multimers characterizes type 3 
vWD (Carr et al., 2009; Brooks, 2010).
FIG. 8 Process of fibrinolysis.

Overview on diseases of blood and hematopoietic system  Chapter | 21  317
5.6 Disorders of coagulation
Disorders of coagulation make up a smaller percentage 
of inherited hemostatic disorders than primary hemostatic 
disorders.
5.6.1 Hemophilia A
Hemophilia A is a deficiency of factor VIII and the most 
common inherited deficiency of coagulation. This disor -
der has a well-characterized X-linked recessive inheritance 
pattern and is expressed in male individuals almost exclu -
sively. De novo mutations occur sporadically in individu -
als, leading to an acquired form of the disorder ( Brooks, 
1999). Clinical bleeding is inversely proportional to the 
relative factor levels in plasma as FVIII is instrumental in 
the propagation phase of coagulation. A severe deficiency 
in FVIII results in the inability to generate enough thrombin 
for mature clot formation ( Brooks, 2010 ). Hemarthrosis, 
subcutaneous bleeding, and prolonged bleeding from minor 
injuries are typical ( Smith, 2010). The diagnosis of hemo -
philia A is relatively straightforward in affected males. In 
the bleeding patient, a deficiency in the intrinsic pathway 
may be evident by a prolongation of the aPTT or ACT with 
a normal prothrombin time (PT).
5.6.2 Hemophilia B
Hemophilia B is a deficiency of FIX and is also called 
Christmas disease after the Canadian man was originally 
diagnosed with the disease (Ingram, 1976). Hemophilia B is 
an X-linked recessive trait but occurs much less frequently 
than hemophilia A. It is estimated to have an incidence of 
25% of hemophilia A (Brooks, 1999). It has a clinical pre -
sentation that is very similar to hemophilia A and has been 
found in many different breeds of dogs and cats ( Brooks, 
1999). The diagnosis of hemophilia B is similar to that of 
hemophilia A as factor analysis will demonstrate the defi -
ciency in the affected patients.
6 Neoplasia of the myeloid system
The myeloid division of the hematopoietic system includes 
the neoplasms derived from erythroid, granulocytic (neutro-
phil, eosinophil, and basophil) monocytic, and megakaryo-
cytic cell series and their progenitors. The major neoplastic 
expressions of the myeloid cell series are listed in Table 1 
under the general heading of neoplastic myeloproliferative 
diseases ( Moulton and Dungworth, 1978 ; Schalm et  al., 
1975). The predominant type of cellular differentiation is 
also listed. The term myeloproliferative disease implies a 
complex set of related diseases, not all of which are neo -
plastic, and includes the possibility of change in expression 
during the course of the disease. For example, the assumed 
genetic defect(s) responsible for the neoplastic process may 
occur in either a progenitor limited to differentiation into 
one cell series or a progenitor that may differentiate into 
one cell series, or a progenitor that may differentiate into 
more than one cell type. The occurrence of more than one 
neoplastic cell type may occur simultaneously or sequen -
tially with a change from one to a second during the course 
of the disease (for example, myelomonocytic and erythro -
leukemia). Also recognized is an association of these neo -
plasms with diseases that do not have a clearly neoplastic 
or clonal basis. The latter would include polycythemia vera 
characterized by excessive erythropoiesis and myelofibro -
sis with myeloid metaplasia. Dogs with polycythemia vera 
would be expected to have a packed cell volume of 65 to 
80, an absence of respiratory or cardiovascular disease 
that could be capable of inducing secondary polycythemia 
through a physiologic mechanism, and an absence of the 
usual tissue-invasive or destructive events of a myeloid neo-
plasm. McGrath (1974) described myelofibrosis with my -
eloid metaplasia as having a progressive and fatal course 
that does not appear to have been well documented in the 
dog as a naturally occurring disease. This process was first 
described in humans and has been recognized in cats, but it 
has been recognized only in experimentally irradiated dogs 
(Moulton and Dungworth, 1978).
6.1 Lymphoid system neoplasia
The anatomic classification presented in Table  4 is a bi -
nomial system with two parts to the designation for each 
neoplasm. The first part is based on the gross anatomic dis-
tribution of lesions in the body, and the second part is based 
on the histologic evaluation of the cell type and cellular 
organization in lesions. This binomial system, with minor

variations, has been proposed by several groups (Holmberg 
and Wilson, 1980 ). Malignant lymphoma is synonymous 
with lymphosarcoma, which is used in most other classi -
fications (Moulton and Dungworth, 1978). Malignant lym-
phoma is the designation for all lymphoid neoplasms other 
than lymphoid leukemias, which are a separate anatomic 
form, as described in the following section.
6.2 Anatomic pattern
6.2.1 Thymic form of malignant lymphoma
The largest lesion is located within the anterior mediasti -
num, reflecting the apparent original location of neoplas -
tic cell growth. Thymic epithelial remnants can usually be 
demonstrated histologically within the lymphoid neoplasm 
but are easily differentiated from the true thymoma of epi -
thelial cells. Thymic lymphomas are a relatively uncommon 
form of malignant lymphoma in the dog and are apparently 
composed of T lymphocytes ( Onions, 1979 ), as has been 
shown for similar cases in cats ( Holmberg et  al., 1976 ). 
Progression to lymph nodes and other organs occurs to a 
variable degree. Although only a limited number of cases 
were examined, earlier and more widespread dissemination 
has been observed in the dog than in the cat in which extra-
thymic dissemination is frequently minimal until the termi-
nal stages of the disease. Thymic lymphomas comprise 2% 
of the canine lymphoid neoplasms of one series ( Theilen 
and Maidwell, 1979).
6.2.2 Alimentary form of malignant lymphoma
The predominant tumor mass is located and appears to 
originate, within the wall of the alimentary· canal and the 
immediately associated mesenteric lymph nodes. The neo -
plastic involvement may progress to lymph nodes and other 
organs throughout the body, but the alimentary tract lesions 
remain prominent. The alimentary form is the second most 
frequent anatomic type in the dog; it comprises 7% to 45% 
of the cases, depending on geographic locations ( Theilen 
and Maidwell, 1979).
6.2.3 Multicentric form of malignant 
lymphoma
The multicentric form is characterized by bilateral sym -
metric enlargement of most, if not all, superficial lymph 
nodes, visceral lymph nodes, spleen, and liver. These tis -
sues are typically uniformly involved at the onset of clini -
cally recognized disease. Progression of the disease can 
lead to the involvement of any organ; the most commonly 
involved organs include the tonsils, lungs, kidneys, alimen-
tary canal, and bone marrow. Blood vascular involvement 
is detectable in 7% to 13% of animals at the time of recog -
nition of the clinical disease and generally is present only 
when there is bone marrow involvement ( Anderson et al., 
1969). In contrast to those of the true leukemia form, the 
abnormal lymphocyte numbers in the blood of animals with 
the multicentric form are typically low (when detectable) 
until the terminal stage of the disease, and the histologic 
pattern of hematopoietic organ involvement is different. 
Multicentric malignant lymphoma is the most common ana-
tomic form observed in the dog; it comprises 45% to 84% 
of cases, depending on the geographic location ( Moulton 
and Dungworth, 1978 ). The multicentric, alimentary, and 
thymic forms of malignant lymphoma have similar histo -
logic patterns of neoplastic localization in organs and ac -
count for approximately 90% of the lymphoid neoplasms 
in the dog. Lymph node involvement first occurs diffusely 
through the cortex with less involvement of medullary 
cords and sinusoids. Splenic involvement is initially within 
the white pulp compartment (follicles and/or periarteriolar 
lymphatic sheaths), although specific localization cannot be 
determined in advanced lesions. The early splenic lesions 
may be recognized as either focally distinct follicular in -
volvement or as linear accumulations within the periarte -
riolar lymphatic sheaths. Hepatic involvement is usually 
more prominent within the portal canals with less severe 
involvement along hepatic cords. Occasional cases are seen 
without diffuse sinusoidal involvement throughout the aci -
nar units without the portal canal accumulations. Lung in -
volvement is typically most prominent in periarteriolar and 
peribronchiolar locations.
6.3 Leukemic form (lymphocytic leukemia)
Lymphocytic leukemia is restricted in this anatomic classi-
fication to those lymphoid neoplasms that have, from incep-
tion, marked involvement of the blood, bone marrow, liver, 
spleen, and lymph nodes. Lymphocyte counts in the blood of 
30,000 to 150,000 are to be expected in true leukemia, which 
also has a different tissue localization than the malignant 
lymphoma forms. Early tissue localization in the leukemic 
form is in the splenic cords of the red pulp, the medullary 
cord of lymph nodes, ·and in a diffuse sinusoidal pattern in 
the liver. The bone marrow is diffusely involved from the on-
set of the disease. Lymphocytic leukemia is the least common 
form observed in the dog (less than 1% of lymphoid neo -
plasms). Biologically different acute (or blastic) and chronic 
(or small lymphocytic) forms of the disease have not been 
characterized in the dog.
6.4 Other miscellaneous forms of malignant 
lymphoma
Less than 10% of canine lymphoid neoplasms do not fit 
in one of the preceding categories. These miscellaneous 
forms include solitary or regionally restricted lesions 
(that is, cases with skin involvement). The spectrum of 
cases with significant skin involvement has not been well

Overview on diseases of blood and hematopoietic system  Chapter | 21  319
 characterized in the dog, although they comprise up to 
7% of the cases. Cases with multifocal skin lesions may 
be variants of advanced multicentric malignant lympho -
mas (Anderson et al., 1969 ), although the similarity to the 
mycosis fungoides complex of man should be evaluated 
(Kelley et al., 1972 ).
6.5 Histologic classification
Histologic evaluation of lymphoid neoplasms includes 
two components (see Table 3). First, one must characterize 
the pattern of neoplastic cell organization in the lesions as 
either nodular or diffuse ( Holmberg et al., 1976 ). Nodular 
follicular malignant lymphomas are not recognized as 
frequently in dogs (up to 16%) as they are in men (ap -
proximately 40%). The presence of a nodular pattern in 
peripheral lymph nodes has been recognized only in mul -
ticentric and alimentary forms of malignant lymphomas 
and was demonstrated to be of a B cell nature ( Holmberg 
et  al., 1976 ). Characterization and nomenclature of the 
predominant cell type in lymphoid neoplasms are the most 
variable aspects of the anatomic classification of lymphoid 
neoplasia in the dog. The criteria for the cytologic clas -
sifications are based on the evaluation of hematoxylin and 
eosin-stained histologic sections. Lesions must be prop -
erly trimmed and quickly fixed in buffered 10% formalin 
for evaluation. Cytologic features of lesion imprints or 
aspirates do correlate with the histologic appearance but 
are comparative. Evaluation is difficult because of slide 
imprint variation due to cell shrinkage, cell rupture, stain 
retention, and an inability to evaluate the anatomic asso -
ciation between individual cells and location within the 
lymph node. The morphologic criteria for the cytologic 
categories of malignant lymphoma and their use in the 
dog have been described ( Holmberg et al., 1976 ). The un-
differentiated or stem cell type is characterized by very 
uniform, round, large nuclei that lack chromatin clumping 
and have relatively small nuclei. The small amount of pale 
cytoplasm frequently has indistinct cell borders in histo -
logic sections. Canine lymphomas of this undifferentiated 
cell type that lack either the smaller lymphocytic or the 
histiocytic differentiation are uncommon. The histiocytic 
cell type of malignant lymphoma includes a range of cell 
types having in common a large vesicular nucleus with 
a large, prominent nucleolus and abundant, but variably 
staining, cytoplasm. This cell type has the largest nucleus 
of lymphoid neoplasms, which may be round, oval, or have 
nuclear indentations. The term histiocytic is used only in 
a descriptive sense to reflect the morphologic features that 
were previously believed to resemble a tissue histiocyte 
or macrophage cell type. This cell type is now recognized 
to reflect the same size and cytologic features seen in im -
munoblasts or large lymphocytes that are in the process of 
responding to foreign antigens.

Diseases and disorders of the

Diseases of the musculoskeletal system hinder the mobil -

well as for the pet parents. There are different musculoskel-
etal disorders in dogs and cats. Each got its own causes, 
symptoms, and treatment. Diseases of the musculoskeletal 
system can also indicate diseases of muscles, neurologic 
problems, toxins in the body, hormonal abnormalities, 
metabolic disorders, infectious diseases, blood and vascular 
disorders, poor nutrition, and birth defects (Adams, 2022).
Body movements depend on the muscular activity like 
to see, breathe, urinate, breed, chew, and swallow.

4 Bone disorders in dogs
Bone disorders in dogs are caused by an imbalanced diet, 
particularly an imbalance in trace minerals like copper, 
magnesium, and zinc. Other causes like trauma which in -
