322 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
Bones are the rigid structure of the body and protect the 
internal organs from damage. They possess bone marrow 
and act as a reservoir of body’s calcium and phosphorus.
4.1 Hypertrophic osteodystrophy
Hypertrophic osteodystrophy—also known as skeletal 
scurvy, canine scurvy, Moller-Barlow’s disease, osteodys -
trophy type 2, metaphyseal osteopathy, and metaphyseal 
dysplasia—is a developmental disease of young large- and 
giant-breed dogs. The most commonly affected bones are 
the radius, ulna, and tibia, and the disease is often bilateral 
(Balsa and Robinson, 2016).
4.1.1 Signalment
Age at diagnosis is typically 2 to 6 months (Towle and Breur, 
2012). Male dogs appear to be predisposed compared with 
females. At-risk breeds include the Great Dane, Chesapeake 
Bay retriever, Irish setter, boxer, German Shepherd dog, 
Golden and Labrador retrievers, and Weimaraner; this dis -
ease is heritable in Weimaraners (Abeles et al., 1999).
4.1.2 Diagnosis
Diagnosis is based on signalment, history, physical exami -
nation findings, and radiographic findings. Hypertrophic 
osteodystrophy is characterized by painful swelling of the 
metaphyseal region of long bones in the appendicular skel-
eton. Patients are often systemically ill with fever, lethargy, 
inappetence, or diarrhea. Radiographs are critical in con -
firming the diagnosis:
● The condition is characterized by a lucent line in the 
metaphyseal region parallel to the physis, also referred 
to as a double physis (Wisner and Pollard, 2007).
FIG. 1 Dog showing congenital abnormality due to mineral deficiency.
FIG. 2 Pup showing botulism—myopathy due to infectious origin.
FIG. 3 Dog X-ray showing hip dysplasia.

Musculoskeletal system in dogs and cats  Chapter | 22  323
● Periosteal or endosteal reaction in the region of the phy-
sis is typically present.
● Subperiosteal hemorrhage can result in new bone for -
mation, which is noted palisading along the periosteum 
and, in some patients, bridging the physis. The severity 
and duration of the disease influence the extent of new 
bone formation and, in some patients, may extend to the 
level of diaphysis (Wisner and Pollard, 2007). When the 
affected bone is examined histologically, necrosis of tra-
becular bone, inflammatory cellular infiltration, hemor-
rhage, and hemosiderin deposits are present. Subclinical 
fractures are common. Subperiosteal hemorrhage not 
only leads to new bone formation but can also result in 
synostosis; both can lead to disturbance of appropriate 
growth and resulting deformities (Peterson and Kutzler, 
2011; Towle and Breur, 2012).
4.1.3 Differential diagnosis
Differential diagnosis includes septic arthritis, septic phy -
sitis, secondary nutritional hyperparathyroidism, retained 
cartilage cores, hypertrophic osteopathy, and panosteitis. 
It is important to differentiate this disease from hypertro -
phic osteopathy, which is characterized by the deposition of 
periosteal new bone, most typically in the distal extremities 
and long bones. Hypertrophic osteopathy is thought to be a 
secondary disorder most often associated with pulmonary 
neoplasia (primary or metastatic) (Kustritz, 2007).
4.1.4 Treatment
Hypertrophic osteodystrophy is most commonly self-  
limiting in days to months; however, signs may last for 
months. For mild cases, supportive care with NSAIDs is 
recommended, while severe cases may require hospitaliza -
tion for more aggressive supportive care, fluid and nutri -
tional therapy, and injectable opioid analgesics. Affected 
patients should consume a complete and balanced, age-  
appropriate diet. Vitamin C and vitamin D therapies have 
been described, but there is no evidence that supplementa -
tion is helpful in disease treatment. Blood cultures are in -
dicated for immunocompromised patients. If cultures are 
positive, appropriate antibiotic support may be warranted 
(Schulz et al., 1991).
4.1.5 Prognosis
In mildly affected patients, the prognosis is excellent, but 
in severely affected patients, the disease may be fatal. 
Recurrence is possible, usually within months of the pri -
mary episode. As noted previously, the development of 
angular limb deformities is possible in severe cases and 
owners should be warned of this possibility. Client educa -
tion is essential because they will need to monitor the pet 
for growth deformities.
4.2 Pediatric bone diseases (panosteitis)
Panosteitis—also known as enostosis, eosinophilic panos -
teitis, juvenile osteomyelitis, and osteomyelitis of young 
German Shepherd dogs—is a self-limiting disease of the 
long bones of large- and giant-breed dogs. It most com -
monly affects the ulna, followed by the radius, humerus, 
femur, and tibia. The cause of panosteitis is unknown, but 
it may be the result of excessively high dietary protein or 
calcium administration that causes protein accumulation 
and/or vascular proliferation and local bone formation at 
nutrient foramina, which increases intraosseous pressures 
(Peterson and Kutzler, 2011).
4.2.1 Signalment
Age at diagnosis is most often 5 to 12  months; however, 
panosteitis may affect younger dogs and those up to 5 years 
of age. Males are more commonly affected than females. 
Breeds at risk of developing panosteitis include the Airedale 
terrier, Irish setter, German shorthaired pointer, Doberman 
pinscher, Afghan, Great Dane, Saint Bernard, Bernese 
mountain dog, Newfoundland, Golden and Labrador re -
trievers, and German Shepherd dog. Some small- and 
medium-sized breeds also appear to be at risk, including 
the Basset Hound, Chinese Shar-Pei, Miniature Schnauzer, 
Scottish terrier, and American cocker spaniel.
Weight is a contributing factor, and young dogs weigh -
ing more than 23  kg are at increased risk compared with 
those weighing less than 23  kg. Females and males over 
23 kg are three and five times, respectively, at greater risk 
(Towle and Breur, 2012).
4.2.2 Diagnosis
Diagnosis is based on signalment, history, physical exami -
nation findings, and radiographic findings. There are gen -
erally no systemic signs of illness. Physical examination 
findings include a shifting leg lameness and pain on palpa -
tion of the long bones. In some patients, pain is so severe 
that it impedes ambulation and can also result in hyporexia 
or unwillingness to eat and drink. Note that care must be 
taken during palpation to avoid eliciting pain by palpating/
compressing a nerve or other structure. In the acute phase, 
radiographs may be normal or show circumscribed cortical 
bone opacities within the medullary canal adjacent to the 
nutrient foramina. As the disease progresses, the medullary 
pattern changes to a coarser than normal trabecular pattern, 
and a progressive periosteal reaction may be present. The 
severity of radiographic signs does not necessarily parallel 
the severity of clinical signs.
4.2.3 Differential diagnoses
Differential diagnoses include hypertrophic osteodystrophy, 
osteochondritis dissecans, hip dysplasia, fragmented medial

324 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
coronoid process, and united anconeal process. Treatment 
In general, treatment does not appear to affect outcomes 
(Kustritz, 2007).
4.2.4 Therapy
Therapy includes exercise restriction and analgesics while 
the condition resolves. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory 
drugs (NSAIDs) are often sufficient to manage pain, but pa-
tients in severe discomfort require hospitalization with in -
jectable opioid agonists and intravenous fluid support. It is 
generally accepted that steroid and antibiotic administration 
is not necessary and should be avoided. Recurrence is pos -
sible, although severity appears to diminish as the patient 
ages. The main recommendation when attempting to treat 
and prevent panosteitis is ensuring that affected dogs and at-
risk puppies are fed an appropriate, complete, and balanced 
large-breed puppy diet without excessive protein.
4.2.5 Prognosis
Prognosis is generally good to excellent. Few dogs have 
long-term ramifications from panosteitis.
4.3 Avascular necrosis of the femoral head
Avascular necrosis of the femoral head—also known as 
Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease and osteochondritis dissecans 
of the femoral head—is characterized as noninflammatory 
local ischemia of the femoral head and neck, resulting in 
deformation and lameness. The vascular nature of this dis -
ease is suspected due to pathologic changes, which include 
necrosis of the trabecular bone followed by fragmentation 
after continued loading of the joint. The bilateral disease 
occurs in 12% to 16.5% of dogs (Towle and Breur, 2012).
4.3.1 Signalment
Most dogs present between 4 and 11  months of age, and 
there is no sex predilection. Small-breed dogs are most 
commonly affected, with toy and terrier breeds being at in-
creased risk. Due to the strong breed predilection, a heredi-
tary component is suspected. In miniature poodles and West 
Highland white terriers, the trait is autosomal recessive; 
therefore, owners of affected puppies should be counseled 
against breeding.
4.3.2 Diagnosis
Diagnosis is based on signalment, history, physical ex -
amination findings, and radiographic findings. Physical 
examination findings include a mild to severe, non-weight-
bearing lameness of the pelvic limbs. Mild cases may be 
subclinical; therefore, careful and thorough orthopedic 
examination is essential. Radiographs are usually diagnos -
tic, but some chondrodystrophic breeds are challenging. 
Computed tomography (CT) may be advised. Similarly, 
flexed ventrodorsal (“frog-leg”) radiography of the hip/pel-
vis may be preferred to the traditional extended-hip radiog-
raphy. Radiography or CT shows progressive radiopacity of 
the lateral epiphyseal area of the femoral head, followed by 
lysis of the femoral head in a “motheaten” or “apple-core” 
appearance. After lysis, the femoral head flattens, creating 
the potential for femoral neck fractures.
4.3.3 Differential diagnoses
Differential diagnoses include capital physeal trauma, 
epiphysitis, septic physitis, osteomyelitis, and neoplasia.
4.3.4 Treatment
In less than 25% of cases, lameness resolves with rest and 
NSAID therapy ( Kustritz, 2007). With this in mind, avas -
cular necrosis of the femoral head is most often considered 
a surgical disease. Surgical options are femoral head and 
neck ostectomy or total hip replacement. Given the lytic ap-
pearance of the femoral head, samples should be submit -
ted for culture and histopathologic assessment to rule out 
osteomyelitis and neoplasia. After femoral head and neck 
ostectomy, early return to function and aggressive physical 
rehabilitation is not only encouraged but essential to a suc -
cessful outcome.
4.3.5 Prognosis
Postoperative prognosis is good, with lameness resolving in 
84% to 100% of cases (Kustritz, 2007). Physical rehabilita-
tion after surgery may help ensure a positive outcome.
4.4 Multiple cartilaginous exostosis
Multiple cartilaginous exostosis—also known as osteo -
chondromatosis and multiple hereditary osteochondromata 
(or osteochondroma, if singular)—is a benign bone disease 
of multiple, cartilage-capped bony protuberances that arise 
from the surface of any bone formed by endochondral os -
sification. The bones most frequently affected are vertebrae, 
ribs, and long bones. The cause is unknown, and the condi-
tion may affect both dogs and cats. Exostosis may undergo 
malignant transformation to chondrosarcoma or osteosar -
coma (Doige et al., 1978).
4.4.1 Signalment
There are no known sex or breed predilections, although 
Great Danes, Saint Bernards, and Hounds appear overrepre-
sented. In dogs, the disease is inherited as an autosomal dom-
inant trait and is seen in young, growing patients. Exostosis 
appears and enlarges before skeletal maturity. In cats, the 
disease has been associated with the feline leukemia virus. 
Exostosis occurs more commonly after skeletal maturity.

Musculoskeletal system in dogs and cats  Chapter | 22  325
4.4.2 Diagnosis
Diagnosis is based on physical examination and radio -
graphic findings, with excisional biopsy and histologic 
examination important for definitive diagnosis. Physical 
examination findings depend on the location of the lesions 
and may indicate interference with locomotion. Pain may 
be present if exostosis is associated with a tendon, ligament, 
vessel, or spinal cord compression. Radiographic findings 
include single or multiple bony masses with a thin cortex 
and a medullary cavity that is confluent with the host bone 
and has a distinct trabecular pattern. In dogs, growth of 
the exostosis should cease with the closure of the adjacent 
growth plate, and, in animals diagnosed with exostosis, full-
body radiography is recommended as a monitoring tool.
4.4.3 Treatment
Treatment depends on the size and location of the lesion and 
associated clinical signs. Nonsurgical management may be 
attempted and includes rest and NSAID analgesics. Surgical 
management is often indicated for single or large exostosis, 
specifically those compressing the spinal cord.
4.4.4 Prognosis
Prognosis depends on the site and size of the lesions, 
ranging from excellent to guarded. In dogs, the prognosis 
is better if lesions stop increasing in size at the cessation 
of growth. After malignant transformation, the prognosis 
may be poor, depending on the location and type of tumor 
(Doige et al., 1978).
4.5 Slipped capital femoral epiphysis
Slipped capital femoral epiphysis—also known as femoral 
neck metaphyseal osteopathy, spontaneous femoral capital 
physeal fracture, and femoral capital physeal dysplasia syn-
drome—is nontraumatic, slow, progressive displacement of 
the proximal femoral metaphysis from the femoral epiph -
ysis through the physis. This disease is most common in 
cats but has also been reported in dogs, and the cause is 
unknown. It is not the same disease as a Salter-Harris type 
1 fracture of the femoral capital physis, which is acute and 
traumatic in origin. Signalment The most common age at 
presentation is 4.5 to 42  months. Maine coon and Siamese 
cats may be overrepresented; in one study, Maine coon cats 
were 12 times more likely than other breeds to develop this 
condition (Borak et al., 2015 ). Overweight, neutered male 
cats appear to be at risk (Towle and Breur, 2012).
4.5.1 Diagnosis
Diagnosis is based on signalment, history, physical examina-
tion findings, and radiographic findings. History and physi-
cal examination findings include acute or chronic pelvic limb 
lameness, pain on manipulation of the coxofemoral joint, and 
an inability to jump. Approximately one-quarter of cases are 
bilateral. Radiographic findings include a widening and lat-
eral displacement of the capital femoral growth plate with 
progressive resorption and sclerosis of the femoral neck.
4.5.2 Treatment
Surgical treatment is indicated and results in better long-
term outcome than medical management. Early in the dis -
ease process, reduction with internal fixation is possible 
with the use of multiple divergent wires to stabilize the 
physis. With more chronic disease, femoral head and neck 
ostectomy or total hip replacement is indicated. Among sur-
gical patients, post-discharge analgesia may consist of sub-
lingual buprenorphine or oral tramadol. After femoral head 
and neck ostectomy, early return to function and aggressive 
physical rehabilitation should be encouraged and are essen-
tial to a successful outcome.
4.5.3 Prognosis
Prognosis with surgical treatment, assuming no surgical 
complications, is good with primary fixation in acute cases 
or femoral head and neck ostectomy or total hip replace -
ment in chronic cases ( Fischer et  al., 2004 ; Liska et  al., 
2009). Complications associated with a particular surgery 
are outside the scope of this article and should be completely 
discussed with the owner before surgery. Physical rehabili-
tation after surgery may help ensure a positive outcome.
5 Joint disorders in dogs
Bones together form joints. Joint diseases are more prone 
due to damage or disorders that affect membrane, ligament, 
cartilage, and bone. In a joint, the ends of the bone are cov-
ered with cartilage and it helps in reducing the friction of 
the joint as it moves. The joints that are susceptible are hip 
joint, shoulder joint, knee (patellar luxation) joint, elbow 
joint, tarsal joint, and carpal joint. The musculoskeletal 
system comprises two types of muscles. They are smooth 
and skeletal muscles. Skeletal muscles are responsible for 
posture and movement, whereas the smooth muscle is re -
sponsible for facilitating the flow of blood and movement 
of food along the digestive tract. Tendons attach each end 
of a muscle to a bone. They are tough bands of connec -
tive tissue made up of a protein called collagen. They are 
located within sheaths. Ligaments connect one bone to an -
other. They surround joints which helps to support them. 
Ligaments are tough cords formed of connective tissue.
5.1 Clinical signs of musculoskeletal disorders
1. Weakness
2. Lameness

326 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
3. Limb swelling and
4. Joint dysfunction
Problems with muscles and skeleton include other dys -
function of other organ systems like urinary, digestive, 
and circulatory systems.
5.2 Lameness examination
Lameness examination is done when the animal is at rest 
and while in movement. If the animal is lame by the fore -
limb it puts its head up while putting weight on the fore -
limb and even the stride is also shortened. If the hind limb 
is lame, the animal drops its head while putting weight on 
the hindlimb. X-ray and ultrasonography can be used to 
diagnose lameness. An advanced diagnostic technique like 
arthroscopy is used. It is a minor surgery in which a flex -
ible tube called an endoscope is fixed. It is a noninvasive 
technique used for the diagnosis of lameness in animals. 
Animals were also examined for swelling, pain, instability, 
a grating or crackling sound, reduced range of motion, and 
wasting away of muscle.
6 Congenital musculoskeletal disorder
Abnormalities of the musculoskeletal system may be con -
genital (present at birth) or genetic (inherited) which may 
be neurologic in origin (Hanson, 2022)
(A) Dyschondroplasia: It is one of the hereditary skeletal 
disorders in which bones of the limbs or trunk and 
head are underdeveloped or deformed. It is commonly 
reported in Poodles and Scottish terriers in which the 
location of the lesion is limb and trunk or head, whereas 
the trunk and head are commonly affected in Alaskan 
malamutes, Basset Hounds, and Dachshunds. Among 
the breeds, affected malamutes will have a deficiency 
of red blood cells (anemia).
(B) Myopathies (muscular dystrophy) : Male dogs are 
commonly affected. Signs include muscular weaken -
ing, difficulty in swallowing, stiff gait, and loss of mus-
cle mass (Fig. 4). It is caused by a lack of protein that is 
responsible for the functioning of muscle membrane.
(C) Glycogen storage disease (glycogenosis): Glycogen is 
a complex carbohydrate that is normally stored in liver 
and muscles. The body converts glucose as a source of 
energy.
Common symptoms include
● Appetite loss
● Weakness and lethargy
● Enlarged liver
● Collapse
● Inability to get up
● Death
(D) Hip dysplasia: It is a common developmental disorder 
of the hip joint. This disorder can be congenital or in -
herited in many large breed dogs (Harari, 2022) (Fig. 3)
Common symptoms include
● Painful hips
● Bunny hopping
● Difficulty standing
● Difficulty climbing stairs or jumping
● Lameness
● Inability to exercise
● Loss of muscle mass in hind limbs
● Decreased range of motion
(E) Osteochondrosis: It is observed in young aged 
(4–8 months) large breed dogs. It affects joints of the 
shoulder, elbow, knee, and tarsal joints in order. In this 
disorder, the immature joint cartilage may get separated 
from the bone. The separated cartilage may float freely 
and cause inflammation and improper bone formation.
Common symptoms include
● Drooling more than usual
● Swallowing difficulty
● Stiffness
● Weakness
● Enlarged tongue
● Loss of muscle mass
● Tremors
● Deformed limbs
● Flat feet
● Resistant to exercise
FIG. 4 Dog showing generalized emaciation—hind bound condition.

Musculoskeletal system in dogs and cats  Chapter | 22  327
(F) Osteogenesis imperfecta : The long bones are more 
commonly affected and they tend to be fragile and 
loose joints. The cornea of the eye will have most prob-
ably a bluish tinge.
Common symptoms include
● Depression
● Reluctance to play
● Swollen joints
● Painful joints
● Grinding sound in the joints
● Stiffness
● Loss of muscle mass
● Lameness
(G) Osteopetrosis: It is a rare inherited disease that occurs 
in dogs. This shows signs of shortening of lower jaw, 
impacted molar teeth, and fragile long bones. Long 
bones including the skull replaced by a spongy type of 
bone instead of bone marrow.
(H) Miscellaneous
(a) Some dogs born without a feet—apodia
(b) without a certain bone in the limb—hemimelia
(c) Dogs born with split or missing toes—Lobster 
claw defect or ectrodactyly syndrome
(d) Dogs born with extra toes—polydactyly
(e) Dogs born with fused toes—syndactyly
7 Immune-mediated arthritis
Immune-mediated arthritis is comprised of a group of inflam-
matory but noninfectious affections of joints which respond 
to immunosuppressive therapy (Kohn, 2007). Inflammation 
is either due to the persistence of an antigenic material in 
the synovium of affected joints, possibly as sequel to previ-
ous infection, or to the deposition of immune complexes in 
synovium, derived from inflammatory lesions elsewhere in 
the body. Immune-mediated arthritis is typically a polyar -
thritis involving more than one joint. It is common in dogs 
and cats and is characterized by the major involvement of 
joints of locomotion. Idiopathic polyarthritis, systemic lupus 
erythematous (SLE) associated polyarthritis, drug-induced 
polyarthritis, polyarthritis of Greyhounds, and rheumatoid 
arthritis are some of the examples of polyarthritis most com-
monly reported in dogs (Thompson, 2005; Day and Bennett, 
2008). Immune-mediated arthritides have been categorized 
into erosive and nonerosive arthritis based on radiographic 
changes observed in joints and bone (Bennett, 2005).
7.1 Myopathies
Disease that causes damage to muscle or tissue is observed 
(Fig. 5). It can be congenital ( Fig. 6) or due to nutritional 
imbalances, injury, metabolic disturbances, tumor, or poi -
soning (Harari, 2022).
(A) Labrador retriever myopathy: It occurs in Labrador 
(yellow and black) under 5  months old. Signs include 
muscle wasting ( Figs.  7 and 8 ), stunted growth, and 
weakness. A definitive diagnosis includes urine test, 
muscle biopsy, and electromyography. Supplementation 
with l-carnitine may cause improvement in comfort of 
the animal.
FIG. 5 Dog showing muscular dystrophy of temporal muscle (myopathy).
FIG. 6 Congenital abnormality.

328 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
(B) Great Dane myopathy : Occurs in young Great 
Dane dogs. Signs include weakness, muscle wasting 
(Fig. 9), and muscle tremors after exercise. Definitive 
diagnosis includes blood test, muscle biopsy, and 
electromyography.
(C) Fibrotic myopathy: In this condition, normal tissue is 
replaced by thick connective tissues and degeneration 
of thigh muscles occurs. The cause is not known but 
the signs include permanent abnormal tightening, and 
lameness without pain.
(D) Myositis ossificans: It is a muscle disorder in which 
noncancerous bony deposits occur in the muscles and 
connective tissues. The cause is unknown. Dobermann 
pinschers are commonly affected especially the hip 
joint. Surgical removal of the bony mass is suggested.
(E) Polymyositis: It is an immune-mediated disor -
der which affects the adult dogs. It includes disease 
conditions like lupus erythematosus and myasthe -
nia gravis. Signs include depression, lack of energy, 
weakness, lameness, weight loss, muscle tenderness 
or pain, and wasting of muscles. Definitive diagnosis 
includes blood test, electromyography, and muscle bi-
opsy. Corticosteroids are used for treatment to cause 
immunosuppression.
(F) Masticatory myositis: It is an inflammatory condition 
of masticatory muscle. The exact cause is unknown. It 
can be due to autoimmune conditions. In acute cases, 
the animal has difficulty in opening jaw due to swol -
len muscles. In chronic cases in addition to these mus-
cle wasting and inappetence and weight loss will be 
present.
Diagnosis by blood tests and electromyography, if 
necessary skin biopsy and corticosteroid therapy can 
be given.
(G) Malignant hyperthermia: It is common in pigs and 
Greyhounds. It occurs due to inhalant anesthetics and 
stress. Signs include tachycardia, hyperpnoea, fever, 
muscle rigidity, and tightness. Fluid therapy, ice pack 
application, muscle relaxant, and corticosteroid can be 
given.
(H) Exertional myopathy (rhabdomyolysis) : This oc -
curs in heavy-working species like dogs. Insufficient 
blood supply to muscles after exercise leads to rhab -
domyolysis. Muscle pain and swelling after heavy 
exercise. Treatment includes fluid therapy, icepack 
application, muscle relaxant, and bicarbonates can be 
supplemented.

ing in temporal muscle.
FIG. 8 Dog showing generalized emaciation—musculoskeletal disorder.
FIG. 9 Native breed showing temporal muscle wasting and dystrophy.

Musculoskeletal system in dogs and cats  Chapter | 22  329
(I) Muscular or tendon trauma : Injury of muscle and 
associated tendons can cause myopathy in dogs.
● Abnormal contracture of shoulder muscles : 
Infraspinatus muscle contracture leads to tight -
ening of one or both shoulders. It occurs due to 
trauma and causes pain, lameness, and swelling of 
shoulder joint. The lameness is temporary, but a 
characteristic abnormal gait develops 2 to 4 weeks 
after injury. Other signs include the pulling in of the 
elbow toward the body, pulling away of the foreleg 
from the body, and external rotation of the carpus. 
The limb is moved in a circular motion with each 
stride of the leg. Treatment consists of the surgical 
removal of a portion of the muscle, including the 
cutting of a tendon. Limb and joint functions usu -
ally improve immediately following surgery, and 
the outlook for full recovery is excellent.
● Injury to biceps brachii tendon: It usually affects 
mature, large dogs. The injury may be direct, in -
direct, or due to overuse or migration of bone and 
cartilage fragments called joint mice . Persistent 
lameness worsens over time. The shoulder joint’s 
range of motion is reduced, and the shoulder muscles 
may waste away. Applying pressure to the biceps 
tendon while bending and extending the shoulder 
joint causes severe pain. X-rays and ultrasonography 
are often used to help confirm the diagnosis. In mild 
cases, the recommended treatments are rest and non-
steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs given by mouth. 
Severe cases can be treated with injections of an 
anti-inflammatory agent and rest. Chronic cases that 
are resistant to treatment of multiple corticosteroid 
injections or cases involving joint mice are treated 
through surgery. The outlook for recovery is good, 
although severe degeneration in long-term cases 
may cause lameness to persist after treatment.
● Quadriceps contracture (stiff stifle disease) : 
Tightening of the quadriceps muscles develops 
after improperly performed surgical operations 
mostly on young dogs. The bone, the connective 
tissue surrounding the bone, and the quadriceps 
muscles bond together. This leads to extension 
and disuse of the limb, porous and easily broken 
bones (osteoporosis), osteoarthritis, and bone and 
joint deformations. The affected limb is overex -
tended and often displaced. Surgery is usually re -
quired to remove the fibrous tissues that connect 
the bone and muscles and to restore motion in the 
stifle joint. Reconstruction of bone and soft tissues 
should be followed by the application of bandages 
that restrict the mobility of the joint. Physical ther-
apy is usually required after surgery. The outlook 
for recovery is guarded. Careful surgical repair of 
bone fractures can help prevent this condition.
● Achilles tendon disruption (dropped hock): This 
injury to the common Achilles tendon often affects 
working and athletic dogs. It is usually the result 
of trauma. The tendon can be partially or com -
pletely ruptured or torn away from the bone. Signs 
include a severe lameness that keeps the animal 
from putting weight on the leg, excessive bend -
ing of the tarsus (ankle), and a stance in which the 
heel touches the ground. Swelling, pain, and torn 
or thickened tendon ends may also be seen. X-rays 
are useful for diagnosis and may reveal fragments 
torn from the bone.
● Iliopsoas muscle trauma : Trauma to the muscle 
or tendon of the iliopsoas muscle (a pelvic muscle) 
can cause sudden or long-term lameness in active 
dogs. The injury can be diagnosed based on a vet-
erinarian’s exam findings, X-rays, and ultrasound 
findings. Treatment usually includes rest and non-
steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.
● Muscle tumors : It can be benign or malignant 
(cancerous). Malignant can spread to nearby 
muscle and clot and induce lameness. It can cause 
lameness and swelling diagnosis by tissue biopsy. 
Based on the type of tumor, chemotherapy and ra-
diation are given (Harari, 2022).
8 Canine diskospondylitis
Canine diskospondylitis is a disease that causes progres -
sive destruction of intervertebral disks and end plates and is 
usually caused by bacteria and is sometimes accompanied 
by neurologic deficits ( Figs. 10 and 11 ). It occurs in large 
and giant breed dogs ( Kornegay and Barber, 1980 ). Often 
males are more commonly affected than females. No age

dogs (Kornegay et al., 1979; Weitkamp, 1982).

9 Therapy for musculoskeletal system 
disorder
General application of acutherapy with emphasis on the 
musculoskeletal system and associated pain where it is most 
applied (Alimi et al., 2020).
There are 14 major meridian systems through which the 
energy (Chi) flows and which bear the 361 acupoints in the 
body where meridians are stimulated to either block or re -
lease the energy flow through acupressure or acupuncture 
(Xie and Rimar, 1994; Xie and Ortiz-Umpierre, 2006). These 
meridian systems are shown in Table 1 (Fig. 17 and Table 2).
9.1 Applications in the musculoskeletal system
Acupuncture has gotten wide acceptance as a noninvasive 
and less risky therapy for mitigating aches and inflamma -
tion through the stimulation release of neurochemicals and 
modulators (Han and Terenius, 1982; Zijlstra et al., 2003 ). 
Acupressure relieves pain and inflammation in muscles 
and joints by causing the secretion of natural painkillers 
(Utzerath, 2014). In many species of animals, it is,  therefore, 
an alternative therapy to musculoskeletal disorders ( Choi, 
2009; Crouch, 2009 ; Koski, 2011 ) with no radiographic 
improvement in the condition but marked clinical improve-
ment and success (Choi et al., 2016).
10 Musculoskeletal disorders of cats
Musculoskeletal disorders are based on injury to muscles, 
bones, and tendons. A cat’s ability to see, breathe, urinate, 
and eat, all rely on muscles, joints, and bones. That is why 
it is highly detrimental in dogs.
10.1 Inherited and developmental disorders
Rickets: Rickets is a disorder that occurs due to an absolute 
deficiency of vitamin D and low or normal calcium levels. 
Cats are unable to synthesize vitamin D (Cholecalciferol) in 
their skin when exposed to sunlight and so are reliant on an 
adequate dietary intake.
The main causes of bone disorders are dietary and ge -
netic imbalances.
10.2 Bone disorders in cats
Common bone disorders as follows.
10.2.1 Osteochondromatosis (multiple 
exostoses)
Multiple bony growths that arise from the surface of the 
long bones, and vertebrae.

10.2.2 Scottish fold osteodystrophy
This breed is more prone to deformities of the spine and 
paws due to developmental growth.
10.2.3 Osteomyelitis
It is inflammation of the bone caused by a bacterial infec -
tion that spreads to the bloodstream. Treatment with antibi-
otics will reduce the infection.
10.2.4 Nutritional osteopathy
It occurs due to nutritional imbalance and disturbances. 
There will be reduced bone mass, deformities, growths, 
fractures, and lose teeth.
10.3 Joint disorders in cats
These disorders may be present at birth or due to environ -
mental factors.
10.3.1 Patellar luxation (knee cap 
displacement)
It is a hereditary disorder in which knee malformation 
occurs.
10.3.2 Hip dysplasia
Abnormal development of hip joint which is prone to ar -
thritis. Lifestyle changes and weight management can mini-
mize the condition.
10.3.3 Osteoarthritis
It is a serious and irreversible condition that requires 
immediate treatment. Joint cartilage degenerates over 
time and leads to increased pain and loss of movement 
(Fig.  18). Osteoarthritis is the most common form of 
 arthritis that  affects synovial joints in mammalian spe -
cies ( Nganvongpanit et  al., 2017 ; Johnson et  al., 2016 ; 
Rothschild and Woods, 2012 ). Previously osteoarthritis 
has been termed osteoarthrosis, degenerative joint disease 
(DJD), degenerative arthritis, and arthritis deformans with 
varying specificity. Osteoarthritis is a disorder involving 
movable joints characterized by cell stress and extracellu -
lar matrix degradation initiated by micro- and macro-injury 
that activates maladaptive repair responses including pro-
inflammatory pathways of innate immunity. The disease 
manifests first as a molecular derangement (abnormal joint 
tissue metabolism) followed by anatomic, and/or physio -
logic derangements (characterized by cartilage degradation, 
bone remodeling, osteophyte formation, joint inflamma -
tion, and loss of normal joint function), that can culminate 
in illness (Kraus et al., 2015).
10.4 Muscle disorders in cat
10.4.1 Myopathies
Myopathies are disorders that affect cat’s muscle mem -
branes or fibers. The cause may be hereditary, trauma or 
injury, nutritional imbalances, poisoning, cancer, inflamma-
tory conditions, or metabolic disturbances (Fig. 19).
10.4.2 Myositides
Myositides are diseases that create inflammatory reactions 
in the muscles. These are caused by infections, parasitic dis-
eases, and immunity conditions.
10.4.3 Y ellow fat disease (steatitis)
Inflammation of fatty tissues due to excessive unsaturated 
fatty acids and vitamin E deficit diet. Management in -
cludes nutritional and dietary supplements along with pain 
medication.

11 Diagnosis and treatment of 
musculoskeletal disorders in dogs and 
cats
In all cases of musculoskeletal pain and lameness, diagnos-
tic procedures to determine the nature, extent, and exact lo-
cation of the injury must be performed. Evaluation of the 
source of pain and lameness always starts with a thorough 
history, inspection, and physical examination to look for 
sources of heat, swelling, and pain on manual palpation. In 
horses, hoof testers should be applied to determine whether 
pain can be elicited from structures within the hoof cap -
sule. Next, the gait and locomotion of the animal are evalu-
ated. In a weight-bearing lameness, the lame leg always 
bears less weight and often has a shorter duration of bearing 
weight. In swinging leg lameness, the lame leg abducts or 
adducts to avoid flexion of a painful joint. These findings 
can be measured objectively using a force plate or a com -
puterized gait analysis system. In horses, flexion tests of 
joints followed immediately by gait evaluation at a trot may 
help localize pain.
After determining which limb is lame, diagnostic anal -
gesia (intra-articular or perineural) can be used to localize 
the painful gait to a specific anatomic structure or a region 
of the affected limb. After localization, diagnostic imag -
ing techniques can be performed to evaluate the soft-tissue 
structures and bones. These diagnostic imaging procedures 
include radiography, ultrasonography, MRI, CT, nuclear 
imaging, and thermography. When joint sepsis is suspected, 
synovial fluid analysis of affected joints is necessary for di-
agnosis. After these procedures, a diagnosis can be made, 
treatment instituted, and a prognosis given based on the di-
agnosis, extent of disease, and expected response to therapy 
(Adams, 2022).
Diagnosis includes a regular examination of the follow-
ing factors
1. An orthopedic exam
2. An assessment of body and muscle condition
3. X-rays to see what joints and spines really look like
4. Blood work to evaluate the function of internal organs
FIG. 18 Cat showing hemiparesis.
FIG. 19 Kitten showing lower motor neuron hindlimb lesion.

11.1 Diagnostic approach
In juvenile patients, determining the correct diagnosis can be 
challenging because the clinician must understand developmen-
tal physiology (Tables 3 and 4) and how errors in development 
affect particular body systems. To properly diagnose juvenile 
orthopedic disease, it is important to obtain key information:
● Patient signalment: Age, breed, and sex.
● Accurate history, including:
● Origin of the dog, which can indicate the general 
care the dam and puppies received.
● History of any known trauma, which can help deter-
mine the presence of fractures or soft tissue injuries.
11.2 Therapeutic management
Adams (2022)  explained therapeutic options for diseases 
of the musculoskeletal system include rest, restricted or 
modified activity, immobilization of diseased or injured 
structures in splints and casts, NSAIDs, corticosteroid 
administration, physical therapy, acupuncture, extracorpo -
real shock wave therapy, and surgical repair. Therapeutic 
options for the management of musculoskeletal disorders 
have greatly expanded recently with the use of regenera -
tive medicine, in which growth factors and mesenchymal 
cell therapy have been used to augment healing. A return 
to a useful life for many animals is possible when diagno -
sis and subsequent treatment are done early in the disease 
process.
The treatment regimen includes modalities like:
1. Class IV K-laser therapy: Laser therapy speeds up the 
healing process and treats pain, swelling, and infection.

11.3 Ultrasonic beam therapy
A beam of pulsed ultrasound was used to treat musculoskel-
etal disorders in dogs and cats. Doses, which varied accord-
ing to the lesion, ranged from 0.2 to 3  watts/cm2 for 5  min 
in each treatment. In 63% of the cases, rapid and complete 
resolution occurred (Lang, 1980).

Chapter 23
Geriatric diseases of dogs and cats
1 Introduction
The increasing longevity of companion animals, such as 
dogs and cats, is accompanied by a heightened susceptibil -
ity to a spectrum of geriatric diseases. This growing concern 
for pet health and wellness has garnered the attention of both 
pet owners and medical professionals, as well as research -
ers, who seek to comprehend the underlying mechanisms 
of geriatric diseases and develop efficacious treatments. 
With a better understanding and effective management of 
geriatric diseases, the quality of life for aging pets can be 
significantly enhanced.
Aging is a general term that refers to the natural, grad -
ual succession of life stages that start with conception and 
proceed through development, maturation, and senescence. 
However, the phrase is most frequently used more specifi -
cally to describe the complex combination of biological 
changes that take place in elderly individuals and gradually 
lessen their capacity to maintain homeostasis when sub -
jected to internal physiological and external environmental 
stimuli. These modifications ultimately result in diminished 
vitality, greater susceptibility to illness, and ultimately mor-
tality. Age-related changes can sometimes be seen as advan-
tageous. For instance, older dogs and cats frequently exhibit 
good manners and have ingrained habits. Other changes that 
occur, like the graying of the muzzle or a mild decline in 
physical activity, are neither good nor bad. Changes brought 
on by disease, altered mobility, or the emergence of behav-
ioral issues are fewer desirable changes.
Age-related health problems in dogs and cats are be -
coming more and more prevalent. The geriatric population 
has particular demands and is more likely to have chronic 
ailment. However, there is very few scientific data avail -
able on physical examination impairments in this age range 
(Table 1). In primary care, 30%–40% of patients are elderly 
pets, and as dogs and cats live longer, this percentage is 
anticipated to rise. The aging process is accompanied by 
a decline in various physiological functions, leading to the 
development of age-associated diseases. In dogs and cats, 
cognitive decline is one of the most common and debili -
tating geriatric diseases, affecting memory, attention, and 
other cognitive functions. Arthritis is another common ge -
riatric disease, causing pain, inflammation, and mobility 
issues in affected animals. Heart disease, dental problems, 
and kidney disease are also prevalent in geriatric pets and 
can have serious consequences if left untreated.
The onset of geriatric diseases in pets is a result of a 
combination of factors; however, recent progress in veteri -
nary medicine has shed light on the intricate mechanisms 
that contribute to these conditions. This has led to innova -
tive and effective treatments that can improve the quality 
of life of our aging companions. One such example is the 
implementation of neuroprotective strategies like proper 
nutrition, physical activity, and mental stimulation, which 
have demonstrated success in reducing age-related cogni -
tive decline in both dogs and cats. As well, improvements 
in the diagnosis and management of diseases like arthritis, 
heart disease, and other common geriatric diseases have sig-
nificantly enhanced the well-being of senior pets.
2 Neural basis of cognitive decline  
in domestic dogs and cats during aging
Cognition, or the mental processes of perception, attention, 
learning, memory, and decision-making, is a vital aspect of 
animal behavior and welfare. Cognitive decline is a ubiqui-
tous phenomenon that occurs because of aging and affects a 
wide range of species, including our beloved domestic dogs 
and cats. These species are among the most popular pet 
choices, and their health and well-being are of paramount 
importance to pet owners, animal welfare organizations, 
and veterinary practitioners.

340  SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
2.1 Brain structure and function in aging
The investigation of alterations in cerebral anatomy and 
function during the aging process in canines and felines is 
crucial for the advancement of our understanding of aging 
(Hoffman et al., 2019 ). Such studies can provide valuable 
insights into the aging process and serve as the foundation 
for the development of therapeutic strategies aimed at miti-
gating age-related diseases in our companion animals.
The neuroanatomical structure of aging canines and fe -
lines exhibits morphological alterations paralleling those 
observed in human aging (Head et al., 2000). Specifically, a 
reduction in brain volume and neuronal density is observed, 
as well as an elevation in the quantity of glial cells. This 
decrease in brain volume may have a negative impact on 
cognitive functions such as memory retention, attentional 
processes, and learning ability. Furthermore, fluctuations 
in neurotransmitter levels and the appearance of amyloid 
plaques may also contribute to the decline in cognitive ca -
pacity (Cotman et al., 2002).
In addition to alterations in brain structure and cogni -
tive function, aging dogs and cats exhibit modifications 
in sensory processing as well. One prevalent age-related  
alteration is hearing loss in both species, while changes in 
the retina can result in vision impairment ( Cavanagh et al., 
2016). The examination of brain structure and function in 
aging dogs and cats holds significance not only for advanc-
ing our comprehension of aging but also for the design of 
treatments for geriatric diseases.
The reduction in cognitive capacities among aging ca -
nine and feline populations is a ubiquitous aspect of the 
senescence process; however, it may also indicate the pres-
ence of neurological disorders, such as dementia (Landsberg 
et al., 2012 ). To accurately assess cognitive function, sci -
entists frequently employ behavioral assessments, includ -
ing the Canine Cognitive Dysfunction Assessment and the 
Feline Cognitive Function Assessment. These evaluations 
gauge various cognitive competencies, including memory, 
learning, attention, and problem-solving abilities.
3 Neural mechanisms underlying 
cognitive decline in aging
The exact neural mechanisms responsible for the cognitive 
decline observed in aging domestic dogs and cats remain 
unclear. Despite this, a growing body of research has pro -
posed several potential contributing factors, including oxi -
dative stress, neuroinflammation, and neurodegeneration 
(Chetboul et al., 2018; Zhou et al., 2019).
3.1 Inflammatory pathways: Linking chronic 
inflammation to age-related diseases
Inflammation, an intricate and multifaceted mechanism, 
plays a vital role in maintaining the body’s stability. In re -
cent times, numerous studies have revealed a correlation 
between persistent inflammation and various age-related 
illnesses in both human and animal populations. Chronic 
inflammation refers to a sustained state of low-level in -
flammation that arises due to prolonged exposure to vari -
ous environmental stressors such as pathogens, oxidative 
stressors, and metabolic by-products. This exposure results 
in the activation of pro-inflammatory cytokines, which play 
a crucial role in the development of chronic inflammation. 
Studies in geriatric canines and felines have demonstrated 
a correlation between chronic inflammation and the on -
set of age-associated disorders, including osteoarthritis, 
cardiovascular disease, renal dysfunction, and cognitive 
impairment.
3.2 Oxidative stress
Oxidative stress is a complex phenomenon that is character-
ized by an imbalance between the production of reactive 
oxygen species (ROS) and the body’s antioxidant defense 
mechanisms (Fig. 1). It arises when there is an excessive 
generation of ROS, leading to damage to cellular macro -
molecules such as DNA, proteins, and lipids. This damage 
can have a profound impact on cellular function and con -
tribute to the development of various diseases. Oxidative 
stress occurs due to a variety of factors, including expo -
sure to environmental toxins, poor dietary habits, and ag -
ing. Additionally, certain diseases and conditions, such as

cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and neurodegenerative 
disorders, can increase the production of ROS and amplify 
oxidative stress.
The mechanisms of oxidative stress have been exten -
sively studied and documented in the scientific literature. 
The generation of ROS through normal cellular processes, 
such as mitochondrial respiration, or through exogenous 
sources, such as exposure to ionizing radiation, has been 
well established ( Sies, 2017 ; Valko et  al., 2007). The in -
teraction of ROS with cellular macromolecules, including 
cellular membrane lipids, has been extensively studied, 
and the formation of lipid peroxidation products has been 
shown to contribute to oxidative stress and promote inflam-
mation (Sies, 2017; Valko et al., 2007). The impact of oxi -
dative stress on cellular proteins has also been documented, 
with protein carbonyls serving as markers of oxidative 
stress-induced protein damage (Davies, 2005; Dukan et al., 
2000). Finally, the impact of oxidative stress on DNA, and 
the formation of 8-oxo-dG, has been extensively studied in 
the context of cancer development and progression ( Cooke 
et al., 2003; Klaunig and Kamendulis, 2004) (Fig. 2).
3.2.1 Interventions to mitigate oxidative stress
Mitigatory strategies aimed at abating oxidative stress can be 
classified into two overarching modalities: those predicated 
on the utilization of antioxidants and those that do not entail 
the utilization of antioxidants. Antioxidant-centered interven-
tions encompass the augmentation of dietary antioxidants, 
for instance, vitamins C and E, beta-carotene, and selenium, 
as well as the administration of antioxidant enzymes, such as 
superoxide dismutase (SOD) and catalase, with the objective 
of elevating the body’s antioxidant defense mechanisms and 
reducing the concentration of reactive oxygen species (ROS).
In contrast, nonantioxidant-centered interventions 
aim to regulate the sources of ROS generation and abate 
oxidative stress by modulating specific cellular path -
ways. One example of such an intervention is the modu -
lation of the Nrf2 pathway, which has been demonstrated 
to increase the expression of antioxidant genes and abate

oxidative stress. Moreover, interventions that target the

can also help in reducing oxidative stress.
4 Skin and coat changes
As our furry companion progresses through their geriatric 
years, it is common for them to experience alterations in 
their skin and coat. These modifications, brought about by 
a convergence of factors, including hormonal imbalances, 
compromised nutrient absorption, and a reduction in cel -
lular efficacy, necessitate a comprehensive understanding in 
order to properly attend to the needs of our aging pets and 
forestall the emergence of age-related dermatological af -
flictions. Hormonal imbalances, particularly those relating 
to thyroid dysfunction, represent a principal cause of skin 
and coat modifications in geriatric dogs and cats. Thyroid 
hormones are integral in regulating metabolic processes and 
skin health, and an imbalance in thyroid hormone levels can 
result in dermatological changes such as hair loss, thinning 
of the coat, and a loss of luster.
Another significant contributor to skin and coat changes 
in geriatric pets is a diminished capacity for nutrient ab -
sorption, particularly with regard to essential fatty acids like 
linoleic acid and arachidonic acid, which play a crucial role 
in maintaining the skin barrier and promoting healthy skin 
and coat growth. Furthermore, a deficiency in vitamins such 
as vitamin A and vitamin B12 can also contribute to skin and 
coat changes. In addition to the aforementioned factors, the 
aging process also leads to a decline in cellular functionality, 
including a reduction in skin elasticity and flexibility, and 
the manifestation of hyperkeratosis. These changes result 
in a thinning of the epidermal and dermal layers, shrinkage 
of hair follicles, and hair loss. Modifications in melanocyte 
production and tyrosinase activity within hair follicles also 
contribute to the production of white hairs, commonly ob -
served around the face and muzzle of geriatric dogs.
Furthermore, variations in sebum production may lead to 
the skin becoming scaly and the fur coat becoming dry and 
lackluster. A retrospective study has indicated that older dogs 
are more susceptible to developing cutaneous neoplasia, with 
the highest frequency of diagnoses occurring between the 
ages of 10 and 15. The most prevalent types of skin tumors in 
these cases include lipomas, adenomas, and mast cell tumors.
4.1 Understanding and managing skin problems 
in geriatric dogs and cats
As the age of our beloved companion animals progresses, 
the likelihood of them developing various skin diseases 
 increases, which can have a significant impact on their over-
all well-being and quality of life. The realm of skin prob -
lems afflicting geriatric pets encompasses a broad spectrum, 
ranging from seemingly benign dry skin to more ominous 
conditions such as neoplastic growths. In recent years, there 
have been marked advancements in the diagnostic and ther-
apeutic modalities available for the management of geriatric 
dermatological conditions. One such advancement, as noted 
by Davis et  al. (2018), is the utilization of dermatoscopy 
in the diagnosis of skin cancer in geriatric pets. This tool, 
which magnifies the skin and allows for a more detailed ex-
amination of cutaneous lesions, was found to significantly 
improve the accuracy of skin cancer diagnoses in a cohort 
of geriatric animals. The authors of this study therefore rec-
ommend that dermatoscopy be incorporated into the diag -
nostic armamentarium for skin cancer in geriatric pets.
5 Changes in body weight 
and condition
As the aging process unfolds in canines, a decrease in their 
basal metabolic rate becomes apparent, a consequence of 
the proportional modifications that ensue in their body com-
position. Such changes encompass a reduction in lean tissue 
and water, and a concomitant increase in the fat content. 
The study by Jang et al. (2018) sheds light on this phenom-
enon by evaluating the difference in body fat percentage 
between young adult dogs and their geriatric counterparts. 
The results revealed that while the former displayed a body 
fat percentage ranging between 15% and 20%, the latter ex-
hibited a body fat percentage that oscillated between 25% 
and 30%. While a trend of reduced physical activity among 
the majority of senior dogs is commonly observed, it is not 
an absolute trend. It is estimated that a canine’s total daily 
energy requirements may decline by as much as 30%–40% 
in the final third of their life due to the combined impact of 
decreased activity and metabolic rate, thereby exposing a 
subset of aging dogs to the elevated risk of obesity.
On the other hand, a greater proportion of dogs aged over 
12 years are underweight in comparison to other age groups, 
which can be linked to the age-related phenomenon of sar -
copenia in older dogs. Not all dogs, however, exhibit a re -
duction in physical activity as they progress into their senior 
years. Canines that preserve their level of physical activity 
may counteract the losses of lean body tissue that are associ-
ated with aging, thereby preventing substantial decreases in 
their basal metabolic rate. This highlights the crucial role that 
continued physical activity plays in aging dogs, especially in 
the maintenance of optimal body weight and overall health.
6 Musculoskeletal changes
The musculoskeletal system of geriatric canines and fe -
lines undergoes significant alterations because of the aging

Geriatric diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 23  343
 process. These changes can have a significant impact on the 
animal’s physical function, comfort, and quality of life.
6.1 Sarcopenia
The ubiquitous phenomenon of sarcopenia, characterized 
by the degenerative decline of musculature in a concomi -
tant decline of overall function and capacity, is a hallmark 
of the aging process in both domesticated felines and ca -
nines. The underlying etiology of sarcopenia is inherently 
multifactorial and intricate, influenced by various contrib -
uting factors such as physiological changes in hormone 
levels, fluctuations in nutritional status, and physical inac -
tivity. Studies have illustrated that sarcopenia in geriatric 
felines and canines is accompanied by a reduction in muscle 
strength, power, and endurance, leading to decreased mo -
bility, an increased propensity for falls and fractures, and 
impaired ability to perform basic activities of daily living. 
Furthermore, this decline in muscle mass and function is 
also correlated with decreased metabolic rate, exacerbat -
ing the risk of weight loss and increased vulnerability to 
infections.
Despite the significant impact of sarcopenia, the un -
derlying mechanisms responsible for the progressive de -
cline of musculature remain only partially understood. 
Nevertheless, current research suggests that sarcopenia is 
a result of a shift in the delicate balance between muscle 
protein synthesis and degradation, a reduction in the acti -
vation and proliferation of satellite cells, and alterations in 
crucial anabolic signaling pathways. Furthermore, a decline 
in hormones such as testosterone and insulin-like growth 
factor 1 (IGF-1) has also been implicated in the pathogen -
esis of sarcopenia in geriatric felines and canines. Given the 
detrimental effects of sarcopenia, the scientific community 
has focused considerable attention on developing clinical 
interventions to mitigate its progression in geriatric felines 
and canines. To this end, various strategies have been ex -
plored, including regular exercise and physical activity, 
dietary supplementation with essential amino acids, par -
ticularly leucine, and the administration of hormones such 
as testosterone and IGF-1. Research has demonstrated that 
these interventions are capable of maintaining muscle mass 
and function, as well as improving mobility, balance, and 
coordination in aging animals.
6.2 Osteoarthritis
The degenerative joint disease known as osteoarthritis is a 
widespread affliction that affects a considerable proportion 
of aging canines and felines. This pathological condition is 
the result of the cumulative and progressive wear and tear 
on the joints, resulting in the destruction of the cartilage, 
inflammation, pain, and a diminished capacity for mobility. 
Despite the vast body of research on the topic, the precise 
pathophysiology of osteoarthritis remains enigmatic and is 
believed to result from a confluence of biomechanical, bio-
chemical, and biological factors (Fig. 3).
Biomechanical factors, such as obesity, excessive joint 
loading, and atypical gait patterns, increase the likelihood 
of developing osteoarthritis by increasing mechanical stress 
on the joints, which exacerbates the destruction of the car -
tilage. Biochemical factors, including the presence of pro-
inflammatory cytokines and matrix metalloproteinases, 
have also been implicated in the etiology of osteoarthritis, 
contributing to the degradation of the cartilage matrix and 
subsequent destruction of the cartilage.
Biological factors, such as genetics and age, are also im-
portant considerations in the development of osteoarthritis. 
Certain breeds of dogs, for example, are predisposed to os-
teoarthritis due to their anatomy and size, and age-related 
alterations in the musculoskeletal system can raise the risk 
of developing this condition.
Diagnosis of osteoarthritis in aging canines and felines 
typically involves a comprehensive evaluation incorporating 
clinical signs, radiographic findings, and response to thera-
peutic interventions. Radiographic evidence of joint space 
reduction, subchondral bone sclerosis, and osteophyte for -
mation is considered a diagnostic hallmark of osteoarthritis.
The treatment of osteoarthritis in aging canines and fe -
lines necessitates a multimodal approach that addresses the 
pain and inflammation associated with the disease while 
concurrently addressing the underlying biomechanical and 
biochemical factors that contribute to its progression. This 
may involve weight management, physical therapy and

6.3 Osteophytosis
The phenomenon of osteophytosis, commonly referred to as 
the formation of exostoses in the skeletal system, is a ubiq-
uitous ailment observed in the geriatric population of both 
canines and felines and has been the object of extensive in-
vestigation within the veterinary medical community. The 
condition arises as a result of the gradual accretion of bony 
protuberances in articulations and is correlated with the de-
generative joint pathologies such as osteoarthritis. Studies 
have revealed that the inception of osteophytosis is due to the 
prolonged application of mechanical stress and pressure on 
the joints, leading to the manifestation of osseous outgrowths 
as a compensatory mechanism to the depreciation of articular 
cartilage. This progression is facilitated by the hyperproduc-
tion of osteoblasts, which are the cellular entities responsible 
for the formation of bone tissue. Thus, the appearance of 
osteophytes results in a further reduction in the joint cavity 
and a heightened mechanical stress, thereby exacerbating the 
degenerative changes in the articulation and inciting chronic 
pain and inflammation. It has been shown that the incidence 
of osteophytosis is particularly prevalent in the larger breeds 
of canines and felines with a history of joint trauma or physi-
cal inactivity. The build-up of exostoses in the joints results 
in a decline in joint function and mobility, causing substantial 
discomfort and agony in the affected animal.
The diagnosis of osteophytosis in geriatric domestic ani-
mals usually entails a combination of physical examination, ra-
diographic imaging, and clinical manifestations. Radiographic 
imaging can prove useful in detecting the existence of exos-
toses and evaluating the magnitude of joint degeneration. 
Physical examination may reveal joint discomfort, rigidity, and 
a diminished range of motion in the affected articulations.
7 Metabolic dysregulations: The 
interplay of aging and chronic diseases
Metabolic dysregulation is a growing concern among ge -
riatric dogs and cats, as it is associated with the develop -
ment of a range of age-related diseases, including diabetes, 
obesity, and fatty liver disease ( Colfax et  al., 2018 ). The 
interplay of aging and chronic diseases is thought to play a 
key role in the development of metabolic dysregulation in 
these animals (Hayes et al., 2019).
7.1 Diabetes mellitus
The manifestation of diabetes mellitus in geriatric felines 
and canines is a multifaceted and intricate pathological 
process that requires a comprehensive understanding of the 
underlying mechanisms to facilitate the implementation of 
efficacious treatment regimens and disease management 
strategies ( Münster et  al., 2020 ). At the forefront of the 
pathogenesis of diabetes in geriatric animals is a reduction 
in insulin secretion, which is a crucial hormone produced 
by the pancreas that is responsible for regulating glucose 
metabolism ( Strombeck, 2020 ). This reduction can arise 
from the pancreas failing to secrete enough insulin, or the 
onset of insulin resistance, which is characterized by cells 
becoming less responsive to insulin-mediated glucose regu-
lation (Nelson and Reusch, 2014 ). This leads to a state of 
hyperglycemia, characterized by an elevation in blood sugar 
levels.
Insulin resistance is a common condition seen in aging 
animals and is often the result of chronic inflammation, oxi-
dative stress, and hormonal imbalances ( de Laforcade and 
Freeman, 2019) (Fig. 4). Furthermore, there may also be a 
decline in beta cell function, which refers to the cells within 
the pancreas that are responsible for insulin production. With 
age, these cells may become damaged or deteriorate, thereby 
reducing insulin secretion and exacerbating hyperglycemia 
(Pöppl et al., 2020 ). In addition, the regulation of glucose 
metabolism in the liver may also be altered, contributing to 
the development of diabetes in geriatric animals. The liver is 
the central organ responsible for regulating the concentration 
of glucose in the bloodstream, and alterations in liver func-
tion may result in an increase in blood sugar levels (Roberts 
et al., 2015). These complex mechanisms highlight the im-
portance of a thorough understanding of the pathogenesis of 
diabetes in geriatric animals to facilitate the development of 
effective treatment and management strategies.
7.2 Obesity
The problem of obesity in geriatric canines and felines is 
a multifaceted phenomenon that arises from a confluence 
of intricate and interrelated factors, including both intrin -
sic and extrinsic elements. The intricate interplay of genetic 
predisposition, metabolic alterations, dietary imbalances, 
physical inactivity, hormonal fluctuations, and decreased 
muscle mass constitutes the underlying basis for this per -
vasive issue. With regard to metabolic changes, the slowing 
down of the metabolic processes in aging dogs and cats’ re-
sults in a decline in their energy requirements and a dimin -
ished capacity to metabolize surplus calories, thus leading 
to a progressive accumulation of fat stores and the eventual 
manifestation of obesity.
Genetic predisposition, a critical intrinsic factor, plays 
a crucial role in the etiology of obesity in geriatric dogs 
and cats, with certain breeds, such as Labrador Retrievers, 
Beagles, and Scottish Terriers, exhibiting a higher pro -
pensity toward obesity when compared to other breeds. 
Dietary imbalances, characterized by high caloric, fat and

Geriatric diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 23  345
sugar content, also contribute significantly to the develop -
ment of obesity in aging pets. The indiscriminate consump-
tion of table scraps, excessive treats, and unlimited access 
to food can exacerbate the problem, leading to excessive 
weight gain. Physical inactivity, due to underlying medical 
conditions such as joint pain, arthritis, and the like, can 
also play a critical role in the development of obesity in 
geriatric dogs and cats. Hormonal imbalances, including 
fluctuations in thyroid hormone levels, can also contribute 
to the development of obesity by altering the metabolism, 
resulting in weight gain. The decline in muscle mass and 
physical activity in aging pets also contributes significantly 
to the problem, with decreased energy expenditure and an 
inability to metabolize excess calories further exacerbating 
the issue and leading to the development of obesity.
7.3 Fatty liver disease
Hepatic lipidosis, otherwise referred to as fatty liver disease, 
is a prevalent pathological condition afflicting geriatric fe -
lines and canines, characterized by a pathological accumu -
lation of adipose tissue within the parenchymal cells of the 
liver (Center et al., 2021). Despite being a widely observed 
phenomenon, the underlying etiology remains poorly com-
prehended and continues to evade a comprehensive under -
standing. However, contemporary studies posit that this 
phenomenon is an outcome of the synergistic interplay be -
tween multiple pathogenic factors, including alterations in 
metabolic processes, insulin insensitivity, and diminished 
hepatic functional capacity (Deng et al., 2020).
The metabolic modifications, commonly observed in 
the elderly canines and felines, are thought to be a critical 
factor in the pathogenesis of fatty liver disease ( German, 
2020). With advancing age, the basal metabolic rate tends 
to diminish, resulting in reduced efficiency in the pro -
cessing and storage of lipids. This leads to the deposition 
of excessive amounts of adipose tissue within the liver, 
thereby leading to progressive hepatocellular damage and 
functional impairments. Insulin resistance, another crucial 
contributor to hepatic lipidosis, is a condition in which the 
body’s cells become refractory to insulin-mediated glucose 
uptake. This results in elevated circulating glucose levels 
and increased conversion of glucose into lipids, leading to 
the build-up of lipid droplets within the liver parenchyma 
(Clemmons, 2021).
Moreover, hepatic functional capacity is also implicated 
in the development of fatty liver disease. The liver is a mul-
tifunctional organ that plays a crucial role in the elimination 
of toxic substances and the storage of essential nutrients. In 
elderly canines and felines, the liver may exhibit a decline 
in functional capacity, resulting in the accumulation of adi-
pose tissue and other waste products, ultimately leading to 
liver damage and increased susceptibility to hepatic lipido-
sis (Byrne et al., 2022).
8 Oral and gingival diseases
The manifestation of oral and periodontal pathologies 
in the geriatric canine and feline populations is a ubiq -
uitous occurrence brought about by the accretion of

 supragingival and subgingival calculus. This pathological 
state arises from the interaction of a multitude of factors, 
including the build-up of oral microorganisms, modifica -
tions in oral anatomy and function, and systemic health 
perturbations. A prevalent oral alteration observed in aged 
domestic animals is tooth loss, which may be a conse -
quence of numerous causes, including trauma, periodonti -
tis, and dental caries. This tooth loss may result in gingival 
recession, exposing the roots of the residual dentition and 
rendering them more vulnerable to pathological processes 
such as injury and disease. In certain instances, tooth loss 
may also induce modifications to the mandibular form and 
function, thus affecting the animal’s ability to masticate 
and ingest food.
One of the primary etiological factors behind oral 
and gingival pathologies is the accumulation of oral 
bacteria. These oral microorganisms ferment sugars and 
other carbohydrates, producing a pellicle that adheres 
to the dentition and gums, and create an environment 
conducive to the growth and multiplication of oral bac -
teria, resulting in gingival inflammation and infection. 
Another factor contributing to oral and gingival patholo -
gies in geriatric canines and felines is the modifications 
in oral anatomy and function that occur with advanc -
ing age. With the progression of time, the oral cavity 
may undergo structural changes that make it more chal -
lenging to maintain optimal oral hygiene, leading to an 
increased risk for oral and gingival pathologies. For in -
stance, the teeth may become more brittle and prone to 
decay, while the gums may become more susceptible to 
disease and less resilient.
Systemic health issues such as diabetes and nephropathy 
may also play a role in the development of oral and gingival 
pathologies in geriatric domestic animals. These systemic 
health perturbations can alter oral anatomy and function, as 
well as compromise the animal’s immune system, thereby 
increasing the susceptibility to oral and gingival patholo -
gies. Moreover, geriatric canines and felines may also be 
susceptible to the development of oral tumors and infec -
tions, which may range from benign neoplasms such as 
papilloma’s to malignant neoplasms such as oral squamous 
cell carcinomas. These tumors and infections can cause 
oral discomfort, swelling, and difficulties in ingesting food, 
necessitating therapeutic interventions such as surgery or 
pharmacotherapy. It is therefore imperative to seek veteri -
nary attention in a timely manner to address these oral and 
gingival alterations in geriatric domestic animals. This may 
include routine dental prophylaxis, scaling, and polishing 
to eliminate calculus, as well as diagnostic tests such as 
radiography to identify and monitor underlying pathologi -
cal processes. In certain circumstances, medications and 
other forms of therapy may also be indicated to manage 
oral discomfort and reduce the severity of oral and gingival 
pathologies.
9 The role of the gut microbiome
The intricacies of the gut microbiome and its association 
with the health and overall welfare of both humans and ani-
mals has been a topic of significant interest in recent years, 
particularly within the field of geriatric medicine. This is 
due to mounting evidence suggesting a close relationship 
between the gut microbiome and various age-related dis -
eases (Rinninella et al., 2019). In dogs and cats, the gut mi-
crobiome has been observed to undergo alterations because 
of aging, which in turn has been implicated in the increased 
production of pro-inflammatory cytokines. These cytokines 
have been shown to play a significant role in the pathogen-
esis of a variety of geriatric diseases, such as arthritis in 
dogs (Suchodolski et al., 2019).
In addition to its impact on pro-inflammatory cytokine 
production, the gut microbiome has also been implicated in 
the development of several other geriatric diseases in these 
species. For instance, shifts in the gut microbiome have 
been associated with the emergence of liver disease in cats, 
as a result of the production of toxic metabolites that can 
cause harm to this organ ( Tress et al., 2021). Similarly, the 
gut microbiome has been shown to be a contributing factor 
in the development of kidney disease in dogs, as a result 
of its ability to produce uremic toxins ( Chen et al., 2019 ). 
Furthermore, there is evidence suggesting that the gut mi -
crobiome may also play a role in the development of cancer 
in dogs and cats, such as the increased production of carci -
nogenic metabolites in cats (Reddy et al., 2017).
10 Respiratory tract changes
The respiratory system, a central aspect within the physi -
ologies of geriatric felines and canines, is imperative in 
facilitating the vital process of gas exchange between the 
atmosphere and the circulatory medium. The lungs, the 
primary locus for this gaseous transfer, are tasked with 
absorbing oxygen and expelling carbon dioxide. With the 
progression of age, however, several deleterious alterations 
occur within the respiratory tract of geriatric dogs and cats, 
impairing their overall health and well-being. One of the 
most pronounced modifications that occur within the re -
spiratory system of geriatric animals is a decrease in lung 
elasticity, leading to a reduction in the lung’s capability to 
expand and contract with optimal efficacy. This reduction 
in lung compliance results in a diminished ability to inhale 
adequate volumes of air with each breath, leading to a drop 
in oxygen levels in the bloodstream, potentially inducing 
respiratory distress, fatigue, and lethargy.
Moreover, there is an increase in airway resistance within 
the respiratory tract of geriatric animals, characterized by a 
constriction of the airways, making it challenging for air to 
flow through them. This increment in airway impedance can 
result in dyspnea, particularly during physical exertion.

Geriatric diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 23  347
In conjunction with the decline in lung elasticity and 
increase in airway resistance, geriatric dogs and cats also 
exhibit a reduction in the number of functional alveoli, 
the microscopic sacs within the lungs where gas exchange 
takes place. The decrease in the alveolar count reduces the 
surface area available for gas exchange, causing a fall in 
oxygen levels in the bloodstream. Another crucial change 
that occurs within the respiratory tract of geriatric animals 
is a decline in the lung’s ability to clear mucus. Mucus, pro-
duced in the lungs to prevent the inhalation of particulate 
matter, experiences a reduction in its clearance, leading to 
its accumulation within the airways, resulting in airway ob-
struction and difficulty in breathing, along with wheezing 
and coughing.
Geriatric dogs and cats experience a decline in the 
efficiency of cilia, the minute hair-like structures within 
the airways responsible for the movement of mucus out 
of the lungs. The reduction in cilia efficiency leads to an 
accumulation of mucus in the airways and an increased 
likelihood of respiratory infections. There is an elevation 
in the production of histamine in response to allergens and 
irritants in geriatric animals, leading to an exacerbation of 
airway narrowing and difficulty in breathing, along with 
coughing, wheezing, and in severe cases, anaphylaxis. 
Finally, geriatric dogs and cats are also more vulnerable to 
respiratory infections, such as pneumonia, resulting from 
a decline in their immune function. Pneumonia, a critical 
ailment that causes inflammation and fluid accumulation 
in the lungs, results in dyspnea, coughing, and chest pain.
To mitigate the detrimental effects of respiratory tract 
changes in geriatric dogs and cats, pet owners should be 
vigilant in monitoring their pet’s breathing patterns and 
promptly seek veterinary care in the event of any observ -
able signs of labored breathing, coughing, or wheezing. 
Additionally, maintaining a healthy weight and reducing 
exposure to environmental pollutants can also significantly 
lower the likelihood of respiratory complications in geriat -
ric pets.
11 Understanding the pathobiology of 
cardiac senescence: Heart diseases
As the age of dogs and cats increases, the function of their 
heart changes just like in humans. Aging can cause a de -
cline in the heart’s ability to pump blood effectively and 
increase the risk of heart diseases ( Fig.  5). Some of the 
most common heart conditions that affect older dogs and 
cats include:
