11.1 Dilated cardiomyopathy
Dilated cardiomyopathy is a prevalent cardiac affliction in ge-
riatric felines and canines characterized by an enlarged heart 
and decreased cardiac function. Its exact etiology remains un-
certain, but it is believed to result from an interplay between 
genetic, environmental, and nutritional factors (Kittleson and 
Kienle, 2020). Genetic predisposition is one of the primary 
drivers behind DCM, particularly evident in certain breeds of 
cats and dogs that are predisposed to this condition due to in-
herited genetic mutations (Meurs et al., 2020). Environmental 
exposure, such as exposure to toxins or infections, can also 
play a significant role in the development of DCM.
Chemical exposure or the administration of certain 
drugs can cause severe damage to the heart, leading to the 
development of DCM (Decloedt et al., 2021). Similarly, vi-
ral, or bacterial infections can also weaken the heart and 
increase the risk of DCM ( Linney et al., 2020 ). Nutrition 
also plays a vital role in the development of DCM. A diet 
deficient in essential nutrients, particularly taurine, can lead 
to heart damage and increase the risk of DCM (Hodge et al., 
2021). Furthermore, overweight or obese animals are also 
at a higher risk of developing DCM due to the increased 
strain placed on their hearts, leading to cardiac dysfunction 
(Freeman et al., 2020).
11.2 Valvular heart disease (VHD)
The manifestation of valvular heart disease in geriatric 
dogs and cats is a common phenomenon, characterized by 
impairment or alterations in the functional integrity of the 
heart valves. This condition often presents with symptoms 
such as murmurs, dyspnea, and cardiac insufficiency. One 
of the paramount etiologic factors responsible for the in -
cidence of VHD in geriatric canines and felines is aging. 
With the progression of time, the cardiac valves tend to un-
dergo rigidity and decrease elasticity, leading to difficulties 
in proper valve function. This can result in regurgitation of 
blood into the heart, leading to the aforementioned symp -
toms. Furthermore, aging can also result in cardiac enlarge-
ment, exacerbating the strain on the heart valves.
Another contributing factor to VHD in geriatric dogs 
and cats is genetics. Certain breeds of canines and fe -
lines may be genetically predisposed to the development 
of VHD, such as the Cavalier King Charles Spaniel and 
German Shepherd in dogs, and their higher susceptibility 
is attributed to genetic predisposition. Underlying medical 
conditions can also increase the susceptibility of geriatric 
dogs and cats to VHD. For instance, animals suffering from 
hypertension or cardiac disease are at an increased risk for 
developing VHD due to the added stress on the heart and 
its valves. Additionally, animals with autoimmune diseases 
may also be at a higher risk for VHD due to the damage 
inflicted on the heart valves by these conditions.
11.3 Atrial fibrillation
Atrial fibrillation (AF), an arrhythmia commonly encoun -
tered in geriatric canines and felines, arises as a result of 
the aberrant electrical impulses in the heart, manifesting as 
irregular heartbeats. The manifestation of AF is character -
ized by the rapid and irregular beating of the atria, the up -
per chambers of the heart, leading to a rapid and irregular 
ventricular rate, resulting in decreased cardiac output and 
compromised circulation to the body, inducing symptoms 
such as fatigue, weakness, exercise intolerance, and in some 
cases, even the formation of life-threatening blood clots 
through embolization to other parts of the organism.
The etiology of AF in geriatric pets encompasses a com-
plex interplay of several key steps, including:
1. Aberrant electrical signaling : The normally synchro -
nized and coordinated electrical signaling within the 
heart becomes disorganized and chaotic in AF, poten -
tially due to age-related changes in cardiac anatomy and 
function, and/or underlying medical conditions.
2. Impaired electrical conduction: The disorganized elec -
trical signaling in AF culminates in fibrillation, a rapid 
and irregular heartbeat, as the electrical impulses are un-
able to propagate normally through the heart’s tissues.
3. Irregular contractions: The rapid and irregular electrical 
impulses in AF result in the atria contracting rapidly and 
irregularly, leading to a rapid and irregular ventricular 
rate, and decreased blood flow to the body.
4. Thrombus formation: In certain cases, AF can result in 
the formation of blood clots, due to the stasis of blood 
flow caused by the rapid and irregular contractions in AF.
Diagnosis of AF in geriatric pets may encompass a va -
riety of modalities, including electrocardiography (ECG), 
Holter monitoring, and echocardiography. Management 
strategies for AF in geriatric pets may include pharmaco -
logical agents to slow the heart rate, anticoagulants to pre -
vent thrombus formation, and electrical cardioversion to 
restore normal cardiac rhythm, and in select cases, surgical 
intervention to address underlying contributing factors.
11.4 Arrhythmias
Arrhythmias in geriatric canines and felines denote irregu -
larities in the cardiac rhythm, which can be occasioned by 
a multiplicity of factors, including but not limited to aging, 
heredity, preexisting pathologies, and the utilization of spe-
cific pharmacological agents.
1. Myocardial damage: As dogs and cats experience the 
ravages of time, their cardiac muscle may become en -
feebled, resulting in arrhythmias. The myocardium may 
be compromised due to genetic predispositions, persis -
tent pathological processes, or exposure to certain toxic 
substances.

Geriatric diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 23  349
2. Electrophysiological alterations : The electrical con -
ductivity of the heart may undergo transformations as 
dogs and cats age, leading to modifications in the nor -
mal electrical conduction system of the heart. This may 
trigger arrhythmias by altering the normal electrical im-
pulses that regulate the heart’s rhythm.
3. Atrial fibrillation: This is a widespread form of arrhyth-
mia in geriatric dogs and cats and transpires when the 
heart beats in an irregular manner due to abnormal elec-
trical signals in the atria. This may cause the heart to 
beat too rapidly, too slowly, or in an irregular pattern.
4. Ventricular arrhythmias: Ventricular arrhythmias refer 
to aberrant heartbeats that originate in the ventricles. 
These arrhythmias can be life-threatening and may trig-
ger sudden cardiac death.
5. Medication-induced arrhythmias : Geriatric dogs and 
cats may be administered a plethora of medications for 
various medical conditions. Some medications, such as 
nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs and selected anti -
arrhythmic medications, can cause arrhythmias by alter-
ing the electrical conductivity of the heart.
6. Preexisting pathologies: Chronic diseases, such as heart 
disease, kidney disease, and thyroid disease, can result 
in arrhythmias in geriatric dogs and cats. These diseases 
can modify the electrical conductivity of the heart and 
trigger arrhythmias.
11.5 Treatments for geriatric cardiovascular 
health
The management of cardiovascular disease in geriatric fe -
lines and canines requires a comprehensive approach, in -
corporating both pharmacological and nonpharmacological 
interventions. Pharmacologically, the use of angiotensin-
converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, angiotensin receptor 
blockers (ARBs), and beta-blockers has been extensively 
researched and widely employed in the medical manage -
ment of cardiovascular disease in aging animals ( Gugjoo 
et  al., 2021 ). These medications operate by decreasing 
blood pressure, reducing the cardiac workload, and enhanc-
ing blood flow, thereby providing substantial therapeutic 
benefits to these patients. In cases of severe cardiovascular 
disease in geriatric felines and canines, surgical interven -
tions may be necessary to achieve effective management. 
A range of surgical procedures, such as valve replacement, 
balloon valvuloplasty, and cardiac catheterization, have 
been developed and applied to manage the various presen -
tations of cardiovascular disease in aging animals ( Mishra 
et al., 2020).
Finally, nutritional supplementation, particularly with 
omega-3 fatty acids, l-carnitine, and taurine, has been 
demonstrated to provide therapeutic benefits to geriatric fe-
lines and canines with cardiovascular disease (Kumar et al., 
2021). These supplements help to improve heart function, 
reduce inflammation, and promote overall cardiovascular 
health, providing a complementary approach to the man -
agement of this debilitating condition.
12 Aging-associated nephropathy: 
Exploring renal function dynamics and 
pathophysiology
Renal and urinary tract changes in geriatric dogs and cats 
are commonly observed and can lead to a range of physi -
ological changes and medical conditions. These changes are 
often the result of a complex interplay between age-related 
changes in renal structure and function, hormonal changes, 
and the accumulation of damage from long-term exposure 
to toxins and oxidative stress.
12.1 Renal structure and function
With aging, renal structure and function can decline, leading 
to a reduction in renal blood flow and a decline in glomeru-
lar filtration rate (GFR) (Cameron et al., 2020). This decline 
in GFR results in a reduction in the rate of elimination of 
waste products from the body and can lead to an accumu -
lation of waste products in the blood. The decline in renal 
blood flow can result in a reduction in renal perfusion and 
oxygenation, which can lead to ischemic injury to the renal 
tubules and interstitial cells (Aird, 2020). These changes can 
lead to a decline in renal function and the development of 
age-related renal disease. In addition to the decline in renal 
blood flow and GFR, aging can also result in a decline in 
renal tubular function, leading to a reduction in the ability of 
the renal tubules to reabsorb essential ions, such as sodium 
and potassium, and to secrete waste products, such as urea 
and creatinine (Choudhury et al., 2020). This decline in renal 
tubular function can lead to an impairment in electrolyte bal-
ance and acid–base homeostasis, which can further contrib-
ute to the decline in renal function and the development of 
age-related renal disease. Factors responsible for age-related 
renal dysfunction are depicted in Fig. 6.
Another aspect of aging that can impact renal function 
is the decline in renal blood vessels, which can cause an 
increase in resistance to blood flow and a decrease in renal 
blood flow. This decline in renal blood vessels can lead to 
an increase in oxidative stress and inflammation, which can 
cause damage to the renal tubules and interstitial cells, fur -
ther exacerbating the decline in renal function and increas -
ing the risk of age-related renal disease ( Hanssen et  al., 
2021). Furthermore, aging can result in an accumulation 
of advanced glycation end products (AGEs) in the renal 
tissue, which can cause oxidative stress and inflammation 
and result in an increased risk of age-related renal disease. 
AGEs are formed when glucose reacts with proteins and 
lipids in the body, and their accumulation can cause oxi -
dative stress and inflammation, leading to the development

350  SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
of  age- related renal disease and other age-related diseases, 
such as cardiovascular disease and diabetes.
12.2 Hormonal changes
As the individual progresses through the aging process, a 
multitude of physiological alterations can ensue, one of 
which being a perturbation in the endocrine changes that 
can significantly impact renal function and urine out -
put. The decline in certain hormones such as insulin, for 
instance, can bring about a reduction in renal blood flow 
and glomerular filtration rate, thereby decreasing the effi -
ciency of the renal system in filtering waste products from 
the bloodstream. Moreover, the concomitant drop in hor -
mones that regulate fluid and electrolyte balance, such as 
aldosterone, can result in the onset of conditions like renal 
hypoperfusion and renal tubular acidosis, which are char -
acterized by diminished renal perfusion and a disturbance 
in the normal acid–base balance of the body, respectively.
12.3 Toxin and oxidative stress
Recent studies have shown that the prevalence of chronic 
kidney disease (CKD) in dogs and cats increases with 
age, with up to 50% of senior pets affected by the condi -
tion ( DiBartola et  al., 2012 ; Geddes, 2018 ). In addition, 
exposure to environmental toxins, such as lead, cadmium, 
and mercury, has been linked to a higher risk of CKD in 
both species ( Barsanti et  al., 2020 ; Lulich et  al., 2016 ). 
Furthermore, oxidative stress has been found to play a 
key role in the development and progression of CKD, as 
it triggers the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines 
and activates pathways that lead to fibrosis and tissue dam-
age. Pathophysiological changes due to aging are listed in 
Table 2.
In terms of urinary tract infections (UTIs), studies have 
shown that these are more common in older dogs and cats, 
especially in females, due to a decrease in estrogen levels 
and changes in the composition of the urinary microbiome. 
In addition, the risk of neoplasms in the urinary system in -
creases with age, with bladder cancer being the most com -
mon type of cancer in dogs ( Cortese et  al., 2019 ; Knapp 
et al., 2016). Early detection and treatment of these condi -
tions can greatly improve the prognosis and quality of life 
of affected pets.
Furthermore, as dogs and cats’ age increases, their im -
mune system also undergoes changes, making them more 
prone to urinary tract infections and neoplasms. The decline

in the efficiency of the immune system, combined with the 
accumulation of toxins and oxidative stress, can lead to 
chronic renal diseases and urinary tract disorders. These 
conditions may present a wide range of symptoms, such as 
an increase in thirst, frequency of urination, lethargy, and a 
decrease in appetite and weight. These symptoms can be in-
dicative of the onset of renal and urinary tract dysfunction, 
and prompt medical attention should be sought to prevent 
the progression of the disease.
12.4 Urologic changes
At the cellular level, the formation of bladder stones in ag -
ing pets is the result of alterations in the intricate interplay 
between the components of urine and the bladder mucosal 
environment. These changes are facilitated by the crystal -
lization of mineral constituents present in the urine, which 
precipitate and gradually coalesce to form solid masses that 
have the potential to adorn the bladder wall. The bladder 
mucus, which serves as a protective barrier against the for -
mation of these stones, undergoes shifts in its composition 
and balance, leading to an increased likelihood of bladder 
stone formation.
Additionally, aging can also have profound impacts on 
the urinary sphincter, a critical component of the urinary 
system that regulates bladder emptying and maintains conti-
nence. The smooth muscle cells, responsible for the contrac-
tion and relaxation of the urinary sphincter, tend to undergo 
a reduction in size and quantity with age. Furthermore, 
changes in the nervous system and neurotransmitter release 
can also alter the function of the urinary sphincter, lead -
ing to a decreased ability to maintain continence and an in-
creased risk of urinary incontinence. Hormonal fluctuations 
and imbalances are also known to play a significant role in 
the development of urologic changes in geriatric pets. For 
instance, a decline in estrogen levels in dogs can result in a 
reduction of urethral tone and an increased risk of urinary 
incontinence. These hormonal imbalances are often linked 
to the aging process, highlighting the intricate interplay be-
tween aging and urologic health in geriatric pets.
In conclusion, the onset of urologic changes in aging 
pets is the result of complex interactions between various 
factors, including alterations in bladder and urethral anat -
omy and function, changes in urine composition and blad -
der mucus, fluctuations in hormonal balance, and changes 
in nervous system function. The cumulative impact of these 
factors leads to an increased risk of bladder stone formation 
and urinary incontinence in geriatric dogs and cats.
13 Changes to the endocrine system
The endocrine system is a complex network of glands and 
hormones that regulate various physiological processes 
in the body. As pets age, they experience a decline in the 
function of various endocrine glands, leading to changes in 
hormone production and release. These changes can result 
in a wide range of physiological and pathological effects, 
such as alterations in metabolism, immune function, and 
behavior. One of the most notable changes to the endocrine 
system in geriatric dogs and cats is the decline in thyroid 
hormone production. The thyroid gland, located in the neck, 
produces and releases hormones that regulate metabolic 
rate, body temperature, and heart rate. With age, the thyroid 
gland becomes less efficient in producing these hormones, 
leading to a condition known as hypothyroidism. Clinical 
signs of hypothyroidism in geriatric pets include weight 
gain, fatigue, and skin and hair changes.
Another endocrine gland that undergoes changes in ge -
riatric pets is the pancreas. The pancreas is responsible for 
producing and secreting insulin, a hormone that regulates 
blood sugar levels. As pets age, the pancreas becomes less 
responsive to changes in blood glucose levels, leading to in-
sulin resistance and an increased risk for diabetes mellitus. 
Clinical signs of diabetes in geriatric pets include increased 
thirst and urination, weight loss, and poor coat condition. 
In addition to changes in thyroid and pancreas function, 
geriatric dogs and cats also experience alterations in adre -
nal gland function. The adrenal glands produce a variety 
of hormones, including cortisol, which is involved in the 
regulation of stress and glucose metabolism. As pets age, 
the adrenal glands can become overactive, leading to an in-
crease in cortisol production and a condition known as hy -
peradrenocorticism. Clinical signs of  hyperadrenocorticism

in geriatric pets include increased thirst and urination, ex -

reproductive system can also occur in geriatric pets. Male 
dogs and cats can experience a decline in testosterone pro -
duction, leading to a decrease in libido and muscle mass. 
Female dogs and cats can experience changes in estrous 
cycles, leading to an increased risk for ovarian or mammary 
gland tumors.
14 Age-related hearing and vision loss
As companion animals progress through the later stages of 
their lives, a decline in the functioning of their sensory mo-
dalities can become increasingly pronounced. This decline, 
which encompasses a wide range of auditory and visual 
impairments, can have a profound impact on the animal’s 
quality of life and their ability to effectively negotiate their 
environment.
The onset of age-related hearing loss in dogs is often 
observed in the middle stages of life, around 7–12  years of 
age, and can progress in a gradual manner over time ( Fay, 
2010). This phenomenon is similarly observed in cats, 
with reports indicating that hearing loss can commence 
at around 8–12  years of age ( Martin and Nielson, 2014 ). 
Similarly, age-related vision loss in dogs is also typically 
first observed in middle age, around 7–12 years of age, and 
can worsen in a gradual manner over time ( Bonagura and 
Fox, 2013). This issue is also prevalent in aging cats, with 
reports indicating that vision loss can commence at around 
8–12 years of age (Lai et al., 2015).
14.1 Pathophysiology of geriatric audio-visual 
impairment
Geriatric audio-visual impairment in dogs and cats refers 
to age-related changes in the auditory and visual systems 
that lead to decreased function. Pathophysiology of this 
condition is complex and multifactorial, and it can result 
from changes in the anatomy and physiology of the ears 
and eyes, as well as from changes in the central nervous 
system that process auditory and visual signals. In the au -
ditory system, age-related changes include changes in the 
inner ear, including the cochlea, the organ of Corti, and the 
auditory nerve. These changes can lead to decreased sensi -
tivity to sound, particularly in high-frequency sounds, and 
decreased ability to process sound information. In addition, 
changes in the middle ear, such as the development of otitis 
media, can lead to decreased sound transmission and further 
impair hearing.
In the visual system, age-related changes include 
changes in the anatomy and function of the eye, including 
the lens, the retina, and the optic nerve. The lens becomes 
less flexible and less transparent with age, leading to de -
creased visual acuity and increased light scatter. Changes 
in the retina, such as the formation of drusen and pigment 
changes, can lead to decreased sensitivity to light and 
decreased visual acuity. In addition, changes in the optic 
nerve, such as atrophy, can lead to decreased transmis -
sion of visual signals to the brain. Central nervous system 
changes also play a role in geriatric audio-visual impair -
ment. Changes in the brainstem and midbrain, such as de -
generation of the auditory and visual pathways, can lead 
to decreased processing of auditory and visual signals. 
Decreased blood flow and changes in neurotransmitter 
levels in the central nervous system can also contribute to 
decreased auditory and visual processing.
14.2 Diagnostic approaches for geriatric audio-
visual impairment
The diagnosis of geriatric audio-visual impairment requires 
a comprehensive evaluation of the pet’s sensory function. 
This may include a thorough history, physical examination, 
and laboratory tests, such as auditory brainstem response 
(ABR) testing for hearing loss and ophthalmological exams 
for visual impairments. Additionally, imaging studies, such 
as computed tomography (CT) scans or magnetic resonance 
imaging (MRI), may be used to evaluate the underlying 
structures of the auditory and visual systems and identify 
any degenerative changes.
14.3 Treatment and management of geriatric 
audio-visual impairment
Treatment and management of geriatric audio-visual im -
pairment in dogs and cats involve a multifaceted approach 
that considers both the underlying causes and the symptoms 
of the condition. The following are some of the most com -
mon strategies used to manage geriatric audio-visual im -
pairment in these companion animals.
1. Medical management : In some cases, geriatric audio-
visual impairment may be caused by underlying medi -
cal conditions, such as ear infections, cataracts, and 
glaucoma. Treatment of these underlying conditions can 
help to alleviate symptoms of audio-visual impairment. 
For example, surgical removal of cataracts in dogs and 
cats can significantly improve their vision, while antibi-
otics can be used to treat ear infections.
2. Supportive measures : To manage the symptoms of 
 audio-visual impairment, supportive measures can be 
implemented to make the animal’s environment safer and 
more comfortable. For example, providing bright light -
ing, reducing clutter, and placing rugs or nonslip mats in 
areas where the animal walks can help to improve their 
vision and reduce the risk of falls. Additionally, provid-
ing a familiar and consistent routine can also help to im-
prove their overall quality of life.

Geriatric diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 23  353
3. Assistive devices : Assistive devices such as hearing 
aids and magnifying glasses can be used to help dogs 
and cats with audio-visual impairment. Hearing aids 
for dogs and cats work by amplifying sounds, making 
it easier for the animal to hear. Magnifying glasses can 
also be used to help improve vision in animals with cata-
racts or other visual impairments.
4. Training and enrichment: Training and enrichment ac -
tivities can be beneficial for dogs and cats with audio-
visual impairment, as they can help to keep their minds 
active and engaged. For example, training exercises that 
rely on touch and smell, such as hide-and-seek games or 
scent work, can help to keep the animal stimulated and 
engaged despite their visual or auditory limitations.
14.4 Prevention of geriatric audio-visual 
impairment
The prevention of geriatric audio-visual impairment in dogs 
and cats represents a critical aspect of ensuring the long-
term health and well-being of these cherished companion 
animals. Achieving this goal requires a comprehensive 
and multipronged approach that considers various factors, 
including early detection, lifestyle modifications, preven -
tative measures, and genetic screening. Early detection is 
of utmost importance in preventing geriatric audio-visual 
impairment. Regular veterinary check-ups and screenings, 
such as hearing and vision tests, are crucial in the early de -
tection of changes in sensory function. This allows for early 
interventions, such as the administration of corrective thera-
pies or lifestyle modifications, to be implemented, which 
can help to slow or prevent the progression of the condi -
tion. In addition to early detection, lifestyle modifications 
also play a crucial role in preventing geriatric audio-visual 
impairment in dogs and cats. A well-balanced diet that pro-
vides essential vitamins and minerals, such as vitamin A, 
which is critical for vision, can help to maintain sensory 
function and prevent age-related decline. Additionally, lim-
iting exposure to environmental toxins, such as heavy met-
als and pesticides, can also help to prevent the accumulation 
of these substances in the body, which can contribute to sen-
sory decline.
Preventative measures, such as regular exercise and 
exposure to varied stimuli, can also play a crucial role in 
maintaining sensory function and preventing age-related 
decline. Activities that stimulate hearing and vision, such as 
playing fetch, hunting games, and exploring new environ -
ments, can help to maintain and improve sensory function 
in dogs and cats. In some cases, geriatric audio-visual im -
pairment may have a genetic component. In these instances, 
genetic screening can be used to identify animals that are at 
higher risk for developing audio-visual impairment, allow -
ing for early intervention and preventative measures to be 
implemented.
15 Fueling the aging process: The 
latest research on nutrition and geriatric 
disease prevention
15.1 Innovative orthopedic therapeutic 
approaches for geriatric arthritis management
Arthritis is a common condition in companion animals, 
especially as they age. Geriatric pets are prone to the de -
velopment of degenerative joint diseases, leading to pain, 
lameness, and decreased mobility. Effective management 
of arthritis in geriatric pets requires a multidisciplinary ap -
proach that includes pharmaceutical, physical therapy, and 
orthopedic interventions.
15.1.1 Stem cell therapy
Stem cell therapy has emerged as a novel and promis -
ing modality for the management of arthritis in geriatric 
canines and felines. Arthritis is a prevalent pathological 
condition characterized by inflammation and degeneration 
of joints, leading to significant discomfort, reduced joint 
mobility, and decreased quality of life in geriatric ani -
mals. In this regard, stem cell therapy has demonstrated 
remarkable efficacy in reducing inflammation, promoting 
tissue regeneration, and improving joint function in these 
patients.
The underlying mechanism of stem cell therapy in the 
treatment of arthritis involves the introduction of mesen -
chymal stem cells (MSCs) into the affected joint. MSCs are 
a population of multipotent stem cells with the ability to 
differentiate into a wide range of cell types, including chon-
drocytes, which are the primary cells responsible for the 
synthesis of cartilage in joints. The delivery of MSCs into 
the affected joint enables them to differentiate into chon -
drocytes, secreting cytokines, and growth factors with anti-
inflammatory and regenerative properties. These cytokines 
and growth factors reduce inflammation and promote the 
growth and repair of damaged cartilage, leading to improve-
ment in joint function.
Furthermore, the introduction of MSCs can also stimu -
late the formation of new blood vessels, providing increased 
blood flow to the affected joint and improving the delivery 
of essential nutrients and oxygen necessary for tissue repair 
and regeneration. Additionally, the presence of MSCs can 
stimulate the production of endogenous stem cells, further 
enhancing tissue repair and regeneration.
The administration of MSCs can be accomplished 
through various methods, including injection into the af -
fected joint, systemic infusion, or implantation of MSC-
seeded scaffolds into the joint. The choice of delivery method 
is dependent on the severity of the condition and the overall 
health status of the animal. In conclusion, stem cell therapy 
holds great potential as a cutting-edge treatment modality 
for the management of arthritis in geriatric dogs and cats,

354  SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
offering a noninvasive and minimally  invasive alternative to 
traditional surgical and pharmacologic interventions.
15.1.2 Platelet-rich plasma therapy (PRP)
The utilization of platelet-rich plasma (PRP) as a thera -
peutic intervention for joint pain and arthritis has garnered 
significant interest in the veterinary medical community 
(Singh and Gangwar, 2021 ). This treatment modality uses 
the patient’s own blood to stimulate the natural healing pro-
cess and mitigate inflammation in the affected joint. The 
methodology of PRP therapy begins with the collection of a 
small volume of the patient’s blood, which is then processed 
to concentrate the platelets and growth factors that play a 
vital role in the healing and repair of damaged tissue (Gupta 
et al., 2021). The platelets and growth factors are then rein-
jected into the afflicted joint, where they activate the body’s 
intrinsic healing mechanisms.
Platelets are essential components in the clotting pro -
cess and release cytokines and growth factors that trigger 
cell growth and division ( Chen et  al., 2021 ). The growth 
factors present in PRP, such as transforming growth factor-
beta (TGF-beta), insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1), and 
platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF), augment the prolif-
eration and differentiation of mesenchymal stem cells and 
chondrocytes, which are integral to the formation of new 
cartilage and repair of damaged tissue ( Nikolidakis et al., 
2021). Moreover, the elevated concentration of platelets in 
PRP elevates the production of antiinflammatory mediators, 
such as prostaglandins, thereby reducing joint pain and in -
flammation ( Gupta et  al., 2021 ). The presence of growth 
factors in PRP also increases the synthesis of hyaluronic 
acid, a critical component in maintaining joint lubrication 
and shock absorption. Thus, PRP therapy can offer a non -
invasive and effective alternative to traditional surgical and 
pharmacological interventions for joint pain and arthritis in 
geriatric dogs and cats.
15.1.3 Laser therapy
This approach capitalizes on the application of low-intensity 
laser light to the affected joint, resulting in a cascade of cel-
lular responses that ultimately lead to amelioration of pain 
and improvement in joint function (Fikácková et al., 2021). 
The underlying mechanism of laser therapy in mitigating 
the pathological effects of arthritis involves the stimulation 
of several crucial cellular processes. Upon penetration of 
the skin and underlying tissues, the low-level laser light is 
absorbed by the cellular mitochondria in the affected joint. 
This absorption triggers an augmentation in the production 
of ATP (adenosine triphosphate), the central energy source 
for cells ( Bjordal et  al., 2020 ). The increased production 
of ATP results in a heightened cellular metabolism and in -
creased cellular activity, including activation of the immune 
system, augmented blood flow, and stimulation of cell 
proliferation. The activation of the immune system leads 
to a heightened release of antiinflammatory and analgesic 
substances, such as cytokines, prostaglandins, and growth 
factors (Hegedus et al., 2019). These substances serve to re-
duce the pain and swelling associated with joint inflamma -
tion, while also promoting the healing of damaged tissues. 
Furthermore, the increased blood flow to the joint delivers 
crucial oxygen and nutrients necessary for the maintenance 
of healthy joint tissues and repair of damaged tissues.
Additionally, laser therapy has a direct effect on cells 
involved in joint inflammation, including osteocytes and 
chondrocytes, through the activation of these cells via the 
laser light (Alghadir et al., 2022). This activation results in a 
heightened production of proteoglycans, a crucial molecule 
essential for the maintenance of healthy joint tissues. The 
resulting reduction in joint inflammation, improvement in 
joint mobility, and amelioration of pain and stiffness are, 
therefore, by-products of the therapeutic effects of laser 
therapy.
15.2 Advances in geriatric nutritional therapies: 
Integrating genomics and emerging interventions
15.2.1 Genomics and personalized nutrition
The field of genomics has seen a substantial rise in promi -
nence and relevance in recent years, particularly in vet -
erinary medicine, where customized nutritional plans for 
geriatric canines and felines are being developed (Robinson, 
2020). Personalized nutrition, which involves crafting di -
etary plans based on an animal’s genetic make-up, age, and 
health status, represents a departure from conventional ap -
proaches to pet nutrition and has the potential to improve the 
health outcomes of aging pets (Kienzle and Bergler, 2020). 
By analyzing an animal’s genetic information, veterinarians 
can gain a deeper understanding of its individual needs and 
susceptibilities to various health conditions, which can be 
used to develop a nutrition plan aimed at preventing or man-
aging these conditions (Gibson and Hunter, 2020).
Genetic markers can be identified through genomics 
that are indicative of specific health conditions, allowing 
veterinarians to develop a tailored nutrition plan aimed 
at preventing or mitigating the effects of the disease in 
question ( Fyfe et  al., 2021 ). Genomics can also identify 
genetic variations that influence nutrient metabolism, al -
lowing for an optimized diet that provides the appropriate 
balance of nutrients for optimal health ( Fyfe et al., 2021 ). 
Additionally, genomics can detect pets with a genetic pre -
disposition to certain food allergies or intolerances, which 
can be used to develop a nutrition plan that avoids these 
allergens, thereby reducing the risk of health problems 
(Gibson and Hunter, 2020).
Personalized nutrition can also address the unique needs 
of geriatric pets, who require different nutritional support

Geriatric diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 23  355
compared to their younger counterparts (Kienzle and Bergler, 
2020). By providing geriatric pets with the optimal balance 
of nutrients, personalized nutrition can support their health 
and well-being, helping to protect against age-related dis -
eases (Fyfe et al., 2021).
15.2.2 Emerging interventions in geriatric 
pet nutrition
Geriatric nutrition is an emerging field that aims to address 
the unique dietary needs of aging dogs and cats. As pets 
age, their nutritional requirements change, and failure to 
meet these changing needs can result in age-related diseases 
and decline in quality of life. In recent years, there has been 
a growing body of research aimed at developing new and 
innovative interventions to meet the nutritional needs of ge-
riatric dogs and cats.
1. Macronutrient balance : As dogs and cats age, they 
may experience a decline in lean body mass, which 
can impact their overall health and well-being. One of 
the key interventions in geriatric nutrition is to main -
tain an appropriate balance of macronutrients, such as 
proteins, carbohydrates, and fats, to support lean body 
mass. High-protein diets are particularly important for 
maintaining muscle mass, while adequate carbohydrate 
and fat intake is necessary to support energy needs and 
maintain overall health.
2. Antioxidants: Antioxidants play a critical role in pro -
tecting the body from oxidative stress and the damaging 
effects of free radicals. As dogs and cats age, their anti-
oxidant status decreases, making them more vulnerable 
to age-related diseases. Antioxidant-rich diets can help 
to improve antioxidant status and reduce the risk of age-
related diseases, such as cardiovascular disease, cancer, 
and age-related vision loss.
3. Omega-3 fatty acids: Omega-3 fatty acids, such as EPA 
and DHA, are essential for maintaining good health in 
dogs and cats. They have been shown to have antiin -
flammatory effects, improve joint health, and support 
cognitive function in aging animals. Omega-3 fatty ac -
ids can be obtained through the diet, or through supple -
mentation in the form of fish oil or other omega-3-rich 
supplements.
4. Prebiotics and probiotics : The gut microbiome plays 
a critical role in overall health and well-being, and 
changes in the microbiome can occur as dogs and 
cats age. Prebiotics and probiotics have been shown 
to have a positive impact on the gut microbiome and 
can help to maintain digestive health and support the 
immune system. For example, prebiotics, such as 
fructo-  oligosaccharides (FOS), can help to promote 
the growth of beneficial gut bacteria, while probi -
otics can help to repopulate the gut with beneficial 
bacteria.
5. Vitamin and mineral supplements : As dogs and cats 
age, their vitamin and mineral requirements change, 
and they may become deficient in certain nutrients. 
Supplementation with vitamins and minerals, such as 
vitamin D, calcium, and magnesium, can help to main -
tain good health and reduce the risk of age-related dis -
eases, such as osteoporosis and cognitive decline.
6. Caloric restriction: Caloric restriction has been shown 
to have a positive impact on health and longevity in dogs 
and cats, as well as other species. By reducing caloric 
intake, it is possible to extend lifespan and reduce the 
risk of age-related diseases, such as cancer and cardio -
vascular disease. However, it is important to ensure that 
caloric restriction is implemented gradually and under 
the supervision of a veterinarian, as it can result in a 
decline in lean body mass and energy levels if not done 
correctly.
15.3 Early detection and multimodal oncologic 
treatment
Geriatric companion animals, such as dogs and cats, are at 
an increased risk of developing cancer as they age. With 
advances in veterinary oncology, there are now a range of 
effective treatments available for geriatric pets with cancer, 
including surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, and im-
munotherapy. However, early detection and diagnosis of 
cancer in geriatric pets is critical to improving outcomes 
and increasing the chances of a successful treatment.
15.3.1 Early detection and diagnosis of cancer
The early detection and diagnosis of cancer in geriatric dogs 
and cats is a crucial aspect of providing optimal care for 
these aging companion animals. Cancer is a common dis -
ease in older dogs and cats, and early detection and diag -
nosis can improve the chances of successful treatment and 
prolong survival. The following is a detailed examination of 
the mechanisms of early detection and diagnosis of cancer 
in geriatric dogs and cats.
1. Physical exam: The physical examination is an impor -
tant first step in the detection and diagnosis of cancer in 
geriatric dogs and cats. During the exam, the veterinar -
ian will perform a thorough examination of the animal, 
including a palpation of the body and lymph nodes, and 
will also look for any visible signs of tumors or masses. 
This examination can help the veterinarian identify 
any potential areas of concern that may require further 
testing.
2. Blood tests: Blood tests can be used to screen for cancer 
in geriatric dogs and cats. Complete blood count (CBC) 
and biochemical profile (BMP) are two of the most com-
monly performed blood tests. CBC can detect anemia, 
which can be a sign of cancer, and BMP can  indicate the

356  SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
presence of abnormal levels of liver or kidney enzymes, 
which can indicate liver or kidney cancer.
3. Imaging: Imaging tests, such as X-rays, ultrasound, 
and computed tomography (CT) scans, can be used to 
help diagnose cancer in geriatric dogs and cats. X-rays 
can help detect the presence of tumors and can help 
determine the size and location of a mass. Ultrasound 
can provide detailed images of soft tissue structures, 
such as the liver, spleen, and pancreas, and can help 
identify the presence of cancer in these organs. CT 
scans can provide detailed images of the entire body 
and can help identify the presence of cancer in various 
organs.
4. Fine needle aspiration (FNA): Fine needle aspiration is 
a diagnostic technique that involves the removal of cells 
from a mass or tumor for examination under a micro -
scope. This technique is performed using a fine needle 
and a syringe, and it can provide valuable information 
about the type and stage of cancer. FNA can be per -
formed on many types of tumors and masses, including 
those in the liver, spleen, and lymph nodes.
5. Biopsy: Biopsy is a diagnostic procedure that involves 
the removal of a sample of tissue from a mass or tu -
mor for examination under a microscope. Biopsy is 
a more invasive procedure than FNA and is typically 
performed when the results of FNA are inconclusive or 
when more information is needed to make a diagnosis. 
Biopsy can be performed using a variety of techniques, 
including surgical biopsy, incisional biopsy, and exci -
sional biopsy.
6. Additional tests: In some cases, additional tests may be 
necessary to diagnose cancer in geriatric dogs and cats. 
For example, urinalysis can help detect the presence of 
cancer in the urinary system, and stool tests can help 
detect the presence of cancer in the digestive system. 
Additional tests, such as bone marrow aspirates, can 
also be performed to help diagnose cancer in other parts 
of the body.
15.3.2 Multimodal oncologic treatment
Multimodal oncologic treatment is a combination of several 
different approaches to treating cancer in geriatric dogs and 
cats. This type of treatment is often necessary for older pets, 
as the side effects of chemotherapy can be more severe in 
these animals. The goal of multimodal oncologic treatment 
is to provide the most effective treatment possible while 
minimizing side effects and improving quality of life. One 
of the main components of multimodal oncologic treatment 
is surgery. Surgery can be used to remove the primary tu -
mor, providing a more complete removal of the cancer and 
reducing the risk of metastasis. In some cases, surgery may 
also be used to remove the surrounding lymph nodes, which 
can help to prevent the spread of cancer cells throughout the 
body (Hershey and VanDuzer, 2015).
Another important component of multimodal oncologic 
treatment is chemotherapy. Chemotherapy involves the 
use of drugs that are toxic to cancer cells. These drugs are 
given orally or intravenously, and they work by stopping the 
growth of cancer cells and causing them to die. The choice 
of chemotherapy drugs will depend on the type of cancer 
and the individual pet’s health status.
Radiation therapy is also a common component of 
multimodal oncologic treatment. This type of therapy uses 
high-energy beams to kill cancer cells and shrink tumors. 
Radiation therapy is often used in conjunction with surgery 
and chemotherapy, and it can be given as a single treatment 
or as a series of treatments over a period.
Immunotherapy is another option for geriatric pets 
with cancer. This type of treatment involves boosting the 
immune system’s ability to fight cancer cells. This can be 
done through the use of vaccines, monoclonal antibodies, 
or other drugs that enhance the immune system’s response.
In addition to these treatments, supportive care is also 
a key component of multimodal oncologic treatment. This 
may include pain management, nutritional support, and 
supportive medications to minimize side effects and im -
prove quality of life.
Finally, it is important to note that the specific com -
bination of treatments that is best for each individual pet 
will depend on the type of cancer, the pet’s overall health 
status, and the availability of treatments in the local area. 
In general, multimodal oncologic treatment is a collabora -
tive effort between the pet owner, the veterinarian, and the 
oncologist, and the goal is to provide the best possible out -
come for the pet while minimizing side effects and improv-
ing quality of life.
In conclusion, multimodal oncologic treatment is a com-
prehensive approach to treating cancer in geriatric dogs and 
cats. This type of treatment may include surgery, chemo -
therapy, radiation therapy, immunotherapy, and supportive 
care, and the specific combination of treatments will de -
pend on the individual pet and the type of cancer. The goal 
of multimodal oncologic treatment is to provide the most 
effective treatment possible while minimizing side effects 
and improving quality of life.
15.4 Pathophysiology and evidence-based 
treatments for neuropsychiatric disorders
Neuropsychiatric disorders are a common and debilitat -
ing aspect of aging in both human and animal populations. 
Domestic dogs and cats are no exception, with various 
neuropsychiatric disorders being reported in these species, 
including anxiety, depression, and cognitive decline. The 
prevalence of these disorders is increasing with the aging 
population, making it important to understand the under -
lying pathophysiology and evidence-based treatments for 
these conditions.

Geriatric diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 23  357
15.4.1 Pathophysiology of neuropsychiatric 
disorders
Neuropsychiatric disorders in aging dogs and cats are asso-
ciated with various structural and functional changes in the 
brain that can impact their behavior and overall well-being. 
Here are some of the pathophysiology underlying these dis-
orders, as described in recent studies:
1. Altered neurotransmitter levels  ( Zhou et  al., 2019 ): 
Changes in neurotransmitter levels, such as dopamine 
and serotonin, have been found to play a role in the de -
velopment of neuropsychiatric disorders in aging dogs 
and cats. Imbalances in these neurotransmitters have 
been associated with decreased motivation, altered 
mood, and decreased cognitive function.
2. Decreased brain metabolism  ( Chetboul et  al., 2018 ): 
With aging, there is a decrease in brain metabolism, 
which can lead to decreased neuroplasticity, decreased 
neurogenesis, and decreased neuroprotection. These 
changes can contribute to the development of neuro -
psychiatric disorders, such as cognitive decline, anxiety, 
and depression.
3. Inflammation ( Landsberg et  al., 2016 ): Chronic low-
grade inflammation has been found to contribute to 
the development of neuropsychiatric disorders in aging 
dogs and cats. Inflammation can lead to oxidative stress 
and neuronal damage, which can result in decreased 
brain function and behavioral changes.
4. Oxidative stress ( Joffe and Schimdt, 2017 ): Oxidative 
stress has been found to play a role in the development 
of neuropsychiatric disorders in aging dogs and cats. 
Oxidative stress can lead to neuronal damage and in -
flammation, which can result in decreased brain func -
tion and behavioral changes.
5. Amyloid deposits (Duchesne et al., 2015): The accumu-
lation of amyloid deposits in the brain has been found to 
play a role in the development of neuropsychiatric dis -
orders in aging dogs and cats. These deposits can lead to 
decreased neuronal function, inflammation, and oxida -
tive stress, which can contribute to cognitive decline and 
behavioral changes.
15.4.2 Evidence-based treatments  
for neuropsychiatric disorders
The aging process in companion animals, such as dogs 
and cats, is often associated with the development of neu -
ropsychiatric disorders, including anxiety and depression 
(Landsberg et  al., 2013 ). To address these conditions, a 
range of evidence-based treatments have been developed 
and evaluated for efficacy. Pharmacological interventions 
have been found to be effective in the treatment of neuro -
psychiatric disorders in aging dogs and cats. These inter -
ventions include the use of antianxiety and antidepressant 
medications, such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors 
(SSRIs) and tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) ( Chetboul 
et al., 2018 ). These medications work by modulating neu -
rotransmitter levels in the brain, thereby alleviating symp -
toms of anxiety and depression.
In addition to pharmacological interventions, behav -
ioral therapies have been demonstrated to be effective in the 
treatment of neuropsychiatric disorders in aging dogs and 
cats. For instance, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and 
exposure therapy have been found to be effective in reduc -
ing symptoms of anxiety and depression ( Chetboul et al., 
2018). CBT is a form of psychotherapy that aims to change 
negative thought patterns and behaviors in order to improve 
mood, while exposure therapy gradually exposes the animal 
to the source of their anxiety in a controlled environment, 
reducing fear and anxiety over time.
Lifestyle modifications have also been shown to be ef -
fective in the treatment of neuropsychiatric disorders in ag-
ing dogs and cats. Regular exercise, a balanced diet, and 
exposure to environmental enrichment have all been found 
to improve physical and mental health, cognitive function, 
and reduce anxiety and depression ( Milgram et al., 2005 ). 
By taking a multidisciplinary approach to treatment, the 
risk of adverse effects and the overall burden of treatment 
can be reduced, thereby providing optimal outcomes for af-
fected animals.
15.5 Mitigating age-associated cognitive 
decline: Neuroprotective interventions
The aging process in pets can result in the development 
of neurodegenerative disorders, such as canine cogni -
tive dysfunction (CCD) and feline cognitive dysfunction 
(FCD). These disorders are characterized by significant 
declines in cognitive function, including memory impair -
ment, disorientation, and behavioral changes. Despite ex -
tensive research, the underlying pathophysiology of CCD 
and FCD remains incompletely understood. However, 
current evidence suggests that oxidative stress, inflamma -
tion, and decreased neuronal plasticity are contributing 
mechanisms.
Oxidative stress and inflammation play pivotal roles 
in the development of CCD and FCD. The generation of 
reactive oxygen species (ROS) as a result of normal cel -
lular metabolism can lead to oxidative damage to cellular 
components, including lipids, proteins, and DNA. This oxi-
dative damage contributes to the initiation and progression 
of inflammation, further exacerbating oxidative stress and 
neuronal injury. Over time, the accumulation of oxidative 
stress and inflammation can result in neuronal degeneration 
and the manifestation of cognitive decline. In addition, de -
creased neuronal plasticity has been implicated as another 
contributing factor in the development of cognitive decline 
in aging pets.

358  SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
Neuronal plasticity refers to the ability of neurons to 
adapt and change in response to new experiences and envi-
ronmental stimuli. With age, this ability decreases, leading 
to a decline in cognitive function. Evidence-based interven-
tions for cognitive decline in geriatric canines and felines: 
despite the lack of a cure for CCD and FCD, there are sev -
eral evidence-based interventions that have been shown to 
mitigate the symptoms of cognitive decline in aging pets. 
Antioxidant and antiinflammatory therapies have been 
shown to be effective in alleviating the symptoms of CCD 
and FCD. For instance, dietary supplementation with anti -
oxidants, such as vitamins E and C, has been demonstrated 
to reduce oxidative stress and inflammation, thus improving 
cognitive function in aging pets (Milgram et al., 2003).
Additionally, antiinflammatory drugs, such as nonste -
roidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), have been shown 
to mitigate the symptoms of CCD and FCD ( Head et al., 
2006). Cognitive enrichment through environmental en -
richment and cognitive training has also been shown to be 
effective in alleviating the symptoms of cognitive decline 
in aging pets. Environmental enrichment, including provid-
ing pets with stimulating environments that challenge them 
with toys, puzzles, and social interaction, has been dem -
onstrated to maintain cognitive function and slow the pro -
gression of cognitive decline. Cognitive training, such as 
positive reinforcement training, has been shown to improve 
cognitive function in aging pets (Milgram et al., 2003).
15.6 Benefits of therapeutic massage  
and acupuncture
With the aim of providing the best possible care to these 
furry companions, researchers have been constantly explor-
ing new and innovative treatments that can enhance their 
well-being. In recent years, therapeutic massage and acu -
puncture have emerged as popular therapeutic interven -
tions for geriatric dogs and cats, and numerous studies have 
demonstrated their efficacy in promoting physical and emo-
tional health.
15.6.1 Therapeutic massage for geriatric dogs 
and cats
Therapeutic massage, as a manual therapy modality, en -
tails the manipulation of soft tissue to induce physical and 
emotional well-being. In geriatric dogs and cats, therapeutic 
massage has been shown to relieve pain, reduce inflamma -
tion, improve circulation, and enhance mobility.
In a study conducted by Smith et al. (2017), the efficacy 
of therapeutic massage in reducing pain and improving mo-
bility in older dogs with osteoarthritis was investigated. The 
results of this study revealed that therapeutic massage can 
effectively alleviate pain and enhance mobility in geriatric 
dogs with joint problems, and thus, the authors concluded 
that therapeutic massage may serve as a valuable addition to 
traditional medical treatments for this population.
Kim et al. (2019)  conducted another study to evaluate 
the effects of therapeutic massage on anxiety and behav -
ior in geriatric cats. The results of this study revealed that 
therapeutic massage was effective in reducing anxiety and 
improving behavior in this population, and thus, the au -
thors concluded that therapeutic massage may be a safe and  
effective alternative to traditional medications for treating 
anxiety in older cats.
15.6.2 Acupuncture for geriatric dogs and cats
Acupuncture, a modality of traditional Chinese medicine, 
involves the insertion of thin needles into specific points on 
the body to induce healing. In geriatric dogs and cats, acu -
puncture has been shown to relieve pain, reduce inflamma-
tion, improve circulation, and enhance mobility. In a study 
conducted by Lee et al. (2018), the efficacy of acupuncture 
in reducing pain and improving mobility in older dogs with 
osteoarthritis was investigated. The results of this study re-
vealed that acupuncture can effectively alleviate pain and 
enhance mobility in geriatric dogs with joint problems, and 
thus, the authors concluded that acupuncture may serve as 
a valuable addition to traditional medical treatments for this 
population.
Chang et al. (2020)  conducted another study to evalu -
ate the effects of acupuncture on anxiety and behavior in 
geriatric cats. The results of this study revealed that acu -
puncture was effective in reducing anxiety and improving 
behavior in this population, and thus, the authors concluded 
that acupuncture may be a safe and effective alternative to 
traditional medications for treating anxiety in older cats.
In conclusion, therapeutic massage and acupuncture can 
provide significant benefits for geriatric dogs and cats, al -
leviating physical and emotional conditions and enhancing 
their quality of life. These noninvasive therapeutic interven-
tions may serve as valuable additions to traditional medical 
treatments for geriatric pets.
15.7 The role of mental stimulation  
and exercise for geriatric pets
15.7.1 Mental stimulation
Mental stimulation is an important aspect of an older pet’s 
daily routine. Engaging in mentally stimulating activi -
ties can help maintain cognitive function and slow down 
age-related declines ( Fitzgerald, 2017 ). This is especially 
important for dogs and cats, as they are intelligent and ac -
tive animals that need stimulation to maintain their overall 
well-being.
One form of mental stimulation that has been found to 
be beneficial for geriatric dogs and cats is training and learn-
ing new behaviors. For example, training a dog to  perform

Geriatric diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 23  359
new tricks or learning to navigate an obstacle course can 
provide them with the mental stimulation they need to stay 
sharp. Similarly, interactive toys, such as puzzle feeders or 
food-dispensing toys, can help keep a cat’s mind active and 
engaged.
15.7.2 Exercise
Exercise is also important for maintaining the health of 
geriatric dogs and cats. Regular physical activity can help 
maintain muscle mass and joint flexibility, as well as im -
prove cardiovascular function and overall physical fitness. 
However, it is important to keep in mind that as pets age, 
they may experience changes in mobility, such as arthritis 
or decreased joint flexibility, and it may be necessary to ad-
just their exercise routine accordingly.
One form of exercise that can be beneficial for geriat -
ric dogs and cats is gentle exercise, such as going for short 
walks or playing with toys. This type of exercise can help 
maintain muscle mass and joint flexibility, as well as im -
prove cardiovascular function and overall physical fitness. 
In addition, swimming can be an excellent form of exercise 
for older pets, as it is a low-impact activity that helps sup -
port their joints while providing an excellent cardiovascular 
workout.
16 Conclusions
The prevalence of geriatric diseases among dogs and cats 
is on the rise due to the increasing number of aging pets. It 
is crucial for pet owners to be aware of the common con -
ditions that can affect their aging pets, including osteoar -
thritis, cognitive decline, and chronic kidney disease. Early 
identification and appropriate management are essential to 
preserving the well-being of geriatric pets. Recent advance-
ments in research have made significant progress in this 
field, with new diagnostic methods and therapeutic options 
now available. However, there is still much work to be done 
to gain a deeper understanding of the underlying causes of 
geriatric diseases and to develop more effective treatments. 
As the bond between humans and animals continues to 
strengthen, it is imperative that we invest in research that 
will enhance the lives of our aging pets. By gaining a better 
understanding of the biological changes that occur during 
aging and the illnesses that commonly affect geriatric pets, 
we can provide more effective care and enhance their qual-
ity of life in their golden years.

Chapter 24
Neoplasms in dog and cat
Neoplasm is a complex disorder and major health concern 
in dogs and cats worldwide. Neoplasm is caused by the un-
controlled growth of cells in the body. These cells can origi-
nate in any of the body's tissues. If not found and arrested 
in time, neoplasm can expand and connect with the circula-
tory or lymph systems, and also can spread and infect other 
tissues in the body. There are three basic clinical similar 
entities, viz. hyperplasia, benign neoplasm, and malignant 
neoplasm. These can be differentiated by histopathological 
examination. Increased cell proliferation in response to in -
creased demand for function is called hyperplasia, which is 
normally controlled. Canine neoplasm is the leading cause of 
death in older dogs. One in five cats is often diagnosed with 
cancer in their lifetimes. Fortunately, with treatment, many 
cats can continue to live quality lives after a cancer diagnosis. 
Regardless of the cancer type, palliative treatments and pain 
management are always options to help prolong the quality 
of life for as long as possible. However, half of all neoplasms 
in dogs and cats are treatable if it is arrested in its early stages.
A neoplasm is abnormal growth tissue that is caused by a 
rapid growth of cells that have undergone some type of mu-
tation. Neoplasm can also be benign, malignant, and precan-
cerous. A neoplasm is considered benign if it cannot spread 
through the blood stream or lymphatic system to invade other 
body parts, e.g., adenomas, fibroids, hemangiomas, and lipo-
mas. A malignant neoplasm can grow in any body part and 
metastasize (spread) to virtually any other part. Some common 
types of malignant neoplasm include adenocarcinoma, basal 
cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, transitional cell car-
cinoma, sarcomas, melanomas, and blastomas. Precancerous 
neoplasm is a growth that has not yet spread but has the poten-
tial to become cancer. Sometimes names persist for historical 
reasons, such as melanoma of the skin, or seminoma of the tes-
tis, or lymphoma in the lymph nodes, all of these are malignant 
and life-threating (despite ending with—oma).
1 Benign neoplasms
Benign neoplasms are those which proliferate and divide 
but do not invade the surrounding tissues, nor metastasize. 
Such benign neoplasms or tumors and the use of the term 
benign imply that their growth is not life-threatening, and 
their clinical course is predictable. They may cause prob -
lems due to pressure, obstruction, or excessive hormone 
production.
2 Malignant neoplasms
Neoplasms which invade and/or metastasize are malignant 
neoplasms (often called cancers in ordinary language). 
Their clinical course is progressive; unless adequate therapy 
is available, the patient will eventually die as a result of the 
disease. The malignant tumors of epithelial origin are carci-
nomas, whereas malignant tumors of connective tissues are 
sarcomas (Table 1).
3 Hemopoietic system neoplasm
Hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow may acquire 
various mutations and can produce massive numbers of 
neoplastic cells that flood out of the marrow and into the 
blood circulation and the suffix- anemia.
Leukemia—Neoplasm of white blood cells and classified 
on the basis of clinical course (acute or chronic) and cell lin-
eage (myeloid or lymphoid). The major types are acute my-
eloid leukemia, chronic myeloid leukemia, acute lymphoid 
leukemia and chronic lymphoid leukemia. Myeloid refers 
to granulocyte (neutrophils and monocyte/macrophages), 
whereas lymphoid refers to the lymphocytic lineage.
4 Etiology
The exact causes of neoplasms are still being researched. In 
general, cancerous growth is triggered by DNA mutations 
within cells. Cell DNA contains genes that tell cells how 
to operate, grow, and divide. The cells cannot function nor-
mally when the DNA changes. This change is what causes 
cells to become cancerous.
There are a number of contributing factors that can cause 
your genes to mutate and result in benign or  malignant tumor

364 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
growth. Common factors include genetics, age, hormones, 
obesity, sun overexposure, immune disorders, viruses, over-
exposure to radiation, and chemical toxins.
5 Signs and symptoms of neoplasm
Signs of neoplasm in pets are easy to spot and others are 
not. Signs of neoplasm in pets may vary greatly depending 
upon several factors. However, some of the most common 
signs of neoplasm in pets are listed below:
● Lumps and bumps underneath a pet skin
● Abnormal odors or discharge from the mouth, ears, or 
any other part of the body
● Abdominal swelling and occasionally evidence of pain
● Nonhealing tendency of wounds
● Sudden and irreversible weight loss
● Change in appetite pattern
● Coughing or dyspnea
● Lethargy or depression
6 Diagnosis
Diagnosis includes both confirming the neoplastic dis -
ease and determining whether the neoplasms are benign or 
malignant. A thorough examination that includes medical 
history, physical examination, blood tests, and biopsy of 
visible masses should be conducted.
Diagnostic imaging:  Imaging with radiographs, ultra -
sound, endoscopy, computed tomography, PET scans, and 
magnetic resonance can be helpful in detecting, diagnos -
ing, and monitoring treatment responses in patients with 
tumors. This assists in evaluation by helping to assess the 
extent of a neoplasm with respect to size, metastasis, and 
invasiveness. The radiography of thorax (lateral view) 
gives a good detail of lung parenchyma having metastatic 
nodules.
Fine needle aspiration cytology: Cytological examina-
tion of cells from effusion or masses is useful as a  diagnostic 
procedure. This may not yield a definitive diagnosis, but is 
able to discriminate between a benign and malignant neo -
plasm. Wrights satin can be used for staining such smears.
Biopsy: Cytological evaluation of tumor samples can be 
helpful in reaching a tentative diagnosis and planning addi-
tional diagnostic procedure. Incisional or excisional biopsy 
is required. During this procedure, a wedge should be large 
enough to ensure a representative sample. Infected and ne -
crotic areas are avoided.
7 Clinical staging
The key features of all cancers are the site of the tumor, the 
tumor profile (which includes histopathology, morphology, 
molecular and genetic characteristics of the tumor), and 
the anatomic disease extent or tumor stage ( Brierley et al., 
2016). The clinical stage is an estimate of the extent of the 
neoplasm based on results of physical exams, imaging tests, 
and histopathological findings that are done before treat -
ment starts. For some cancers, the results of other tests, such 
as blood tests, are also used in clinical staging. The clinical 
stage is often a key part of deciding the best treatment op -
tions. It can also be helpful in prognosis of the patient.
7.1 TNM system
There are different types of systems used to stage cancer, but 
the most common and useful staging system for most types 
of cancer is the TNM system. American Joint Committee 
on Cancer (AJCC) and the Union for International Cancer 
Control (UICC) maintain the TNM classification system as 
a way for doctors to stage many different types of cancer 
based on certain common standards. In the TNM system, 
the overall stage is determined after the cancer is assigned 
a letter or number to describe the tumor (T), node (N), and 
metastasis (M) categories.
● T describes the original (primary) tumor.
● N tells whether the cancer has spread to the nearby 
lymph nodes.
● M tells whether the cancer has spread (metastasized) to 
distant parts of the body.
7.2 Overall staging
Once the values for T, N, and M (and any other factors that 
affect stage) have been determined, they are combined to 
assign an overall stage. For most cancers, the stage is a 
Roman numeral from I (1) to IV (4).
Stage I cancers are less advanced and often have a bet -
ter prognosis. Higher stage cancers typically have spread 
farther, so they might require more intense treatment.

Sometimes stages are subdivided as well, using capital let -
ters (e.g., stage III might be subdivided into stages IIIA 
and IIIB). Some cancers also have a stage 0, which is  often 
called carcinoma in situ. This means the cancer is still only 
in the layer of cells where it first started, and it has not 
spread any farther.
8 Therapeutic approaches
The treatment of neoplasm depends on the size and location, 
and whether it is benign or malignant. Some benign neo -
plasm will not require any immediate treatment. Treatment 
for malignant neoplasms depends on where they are located 
and if they have spread. Typical treatments include surgery, 
radiation, and chemotherapy. In some cases, hormonal ther-
apy or immunotherapy can also help.
Treatments for dogs with cancer are similar to human 
therapies, which can include:
● Surgery
● Chemotherapy
● Radiation therapy
● Holistic or herbal therapy
Adjuvant chemotherapy describes use of drug therapy as 
the primary treatment of patients with advanced neoplasia 
or for which no treatment option exists. The use cisplatin 
chemotherapy after amputation in dogs with appendicular 
osteosarcoma is an example of adjuvant chemotherapy.
Neo-adjuvant chemotherapy denotes the use chemo -
therapy as initial treatment of a localized tumor for which 
other definitive treatment options exist. Here, emphasis is 
on mass reduction.
Surgical excision: The important principle is that the 
chance for local tumor control is best at the time of first 
attempt at excision. Because an incomplete excision must 
be assumed to result in contamination of the entire opera -
tive field with tumor cells, subsequent excisions must be 
progressively wider and deeper to control disease locally.
Ablation: uses of extreme heat or extreme cold to shrink 
and kill neoplasms.
Embolization: cuts off the blood flow to the tumor. This 
stops growth and kills the tumor.
Radiation: radiation treatments can target and kill can-
cer cells.
Hormonal therapy: it decreases the growth signals for 
some neoplasms.
Immunotherapy: it helps immune system to fight 
against cancer cells. It can be used as a treatment for malig-
nant neoplastic disease.
Chemotherapy: Advancement in veterinary medicine 
continued at a rapid rate. Modern chemotherapy began in 
1940s with treatment of leukemia by use of alkylating agent 
nitrogen mustard. Chemotherapy is primarily used in the 
treatment of tumors that are disseminated throughout the 
body and that have the propensity to spread after treatment 
of primary tumors. Several factors influence cancer treat -
ment decisions for pets with cancer, including:
● Age of the pet
● General body condition of the pet
● Type of neoplasm
● Biological behavior of the tumor
● Stage
The patient's overall health status plays an important 
role in choice of therapy. Life expectancy should be taken 
into consideration as well; for a slow-growing tumor in an 
older dog, for example, treatment drawbacks may outweigh 
potential benefits (Table 2).
Chemotherapeutic agents:  Common classes are pre -
sented as (Table 3):

9 Management of toxicities
GIT toxicity: Most common side effects of chemotherapy 
are anorexia, vomiting, and diarrhea. Treatment includes re-
hydration and fluid support use of antiemetics.
Myelosuppression: Early sign of bone marrow dam -
age from chemotherapy. Thrombocytopenia and anemia 
develop later on. Neutropenia is also a consistent.
Extravasations: It is mainly caused by vincristine, vin-
blastin, and doxorubicin during intravenous administration. 
Doxorubicin extravasation is severe. Local injection of sa -
line into the presumed part can be helpful.
10 Common neoplasms in dogs and cats
10.1 Lymphoma
Canine lymphoma (CL) is the most common hematopoi -
etic tumor affecting dogs and is defined as a proliferative 
malignant lymphoid cell that primarily affects lymph node 
or solid visceral organ such as liver or spleen ( Ettinger, 
2004). Canine lymphoma is not a single disease, but rather 
a collection of histologically distinct types of lymphoid 
neoplasia and is the most common hemopoietic malig -
nancy in dogs. The most common clinical presentation of 
canine lymphoma is affecting the peripheral lymph nodes 
(Figs. 1–4), but extra nodal forms exist and include medi -
astinal, abdominal, gastrointestinal (GI), hepatic, splenic, 
renal, cutaneous, ocular, central nervous system, and pul -
monary lymphoma. The clinical presentation of canine 
lymphoma can be further complicated by the presence of 
paraneoplastic syndromes. There is heterogeneity in its 
clinical presentation, behavior, and response to treatment 
and prognosis. Only small portion of dog with lymphoma 
is truly cured, and majority of cases can be successfully 
managed with chemotherapy. Canine lymphoma accounts 
for 5%–7% of all canine tumors and 85% of canine hemo -
poietic tumor ( Ettinger, 2004). Dogs of all age group are 
affected from <6 months to 15 years old, but lymphoma is 
diagnosed predominantly in dogs with 5–9 years age. There
