is no gender predilection ( Mirkes et al., 2014 ). Breeds re -
ported to experience a higher prevalence include Boxers, 
Chow Chows, German Shepherds, Poodles, Saint Bernard, 
English Bulldogs, Beagles, and Golden Retrievers. The rate 
of occurrence increases with age.
11 Anatomical classification
11.1 Multicentric lymphoma
It is the most common form of lymphoma. It is character -
ized by involvement of multiple lymph nodes usually on 
both sides of the diaphragm. Hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, 
bone marrow infiltrations, and other extranodal involvement 
may or may not be present. It accounts for approximately 
80% of all canine lymphoma. These dogs are often asymp -
tomatic, but 20%–40% of dogs will have anorexia, lethargy, 
fever, weight loss vomiting diarrhea, and melena. The dogs 
may develop superficial lymphadenomegaly, which is typi-
cally painless, rubbery, and discrete. With advance stage 
of disease, there may be hepato-splenomegaly and diffuse 
pulmonary infiltration (Ettinger, 2004). Lymphoma is lim -
ited to a single lymph node (stage1) or several lymph nodes 
in a region of body (stage2), with generalized, nonpainful 
lymphadenopathy (stage3). Secondary involvement of liver 
and/or spleen (stage4) or blood and bone marrow (stage5) is 
more common (Zandvliet et al., 2015).
11.2 Mediastinal lymphoma
Thymic or cranial mediastinal CL is more common in 
younger dogs and almost exclusively of T-cell origin 
(Fournel-Fleury et  al., 2002 ). The clinical signs include 
dyspnea, tachypnea, cough, polyuria, and polydipsia. This 
syndrome is characterized by pitting edema of head and 
neck resulting from a large mediastinal mass ( Fig. 5) that 
restricts venous return to the heart (Zandvliet et al., 2015).
11.3 Gastrointestinal lymphoma
Gastrointestinal lymphoma is a less prevalent form and 
accounts for 5%–7% of cases. It has been reported to be 
more common in males. It may be characterized by the 
presence of a solitary mass, multiple masses with or with -
out regional intraabdominal lymph node involvement, or 
as a diffusely infiltrating disease of one or more parts of 
the bowel. Commonly, the infiltration is multifocal and 
diffuse involving submucosa and lamina propria layers of 
the small intestines. There is also transmural infiltration of 
the serosa in same case. Histologically, it is challenging to 
FIG. 3 Cutaneous lymphoma.
FIG. 4 Prescapular lymphoma.
FIG. 5 Cranial mediastinal lymphoma.

368 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
distinguish from lymphoplasmacytic enteritis; in alimen -
tary lymphoma, lymphocytic and plasmacytic lymphoma 
inflammation can be adjacent or distant to the neoplastic 
population of cells ( Ettinger, 2004). GI lymphoma has no 
age, sex, or breed predisposition, the Boxer and Shar-pei 
are the most commonly reported breed. Ultrasonographic 
examination of the GI tract can be helpful in discriminat -
ing enteritis from intestinal lymphoma, but a definitive 
diagnosis will require a biopsy. In most cases endoscopic, 
mucosal biopsies is sufficient for obtaining a diagnosis, but 
full-thickness (transmural) biopsies or a clonality assay are 
required occasionally (Zandvliet et al., 2015).
11.4 Hepatic lymphoma
Primary hepatic canine lymphoma is relatively rare, and the 
prognosis is poor as compared to other anatomical forms 
of CL. Leukocytosis, neutrophilia, hypoalbuminemia, or 
hyperbilirubinemia reduced the likelihood of obtaining a 
complete response. Hypoalbuminemia may be associated 
with a shorter survival. Two forms of primary hepatic T-cell 
lymphoma (hepatosplenic and hepatocytotropic) both had a 
very poor prognosis (Keller et al., 2013).
11.5 Cutaneous lymphoma
Cutaneous lymphoma is typically a T-cell lymphoma and 
more frequently epitheliotropic than nonepitheliotropic. There 
is no known cause for cutaneous lymphoma, but being diag-
nosed with atopic dermatitis increases the risk for developing 
mycosis fungoides. Mycosis fungoides is a CD8+ T-cell lym-
phoma that mainly affects older dogs. Cutaneous epitheliotro-
pic T-cell lymphoma typically presents as a chronic multifocal 
skin disease, but may also affect the mucous (especially buc-
cal) and mucocutaneous junction. Skin lesions are variable in 
appearance and include diffuse erythema, scaling, focal hy-
popigmentation, plaques, and nodules.
11.6 Ocular lymphoma
Primary ocular CL is more commonly associated with sec -
ondary uveitis. Ocular lymphoma is mostly of B-cell origin 
and can present both as an intraocular mass, conjunctival 
disease and can affect extraocular structures like the palpe-
bral conjunctiva and lymphoid tissue of third eyelid. Ocular 
changes are seen in approximately 40% of cases, due to ei-
ther infiltration of lymphoma cells or paraneoplastic uveitis. 
The iris is often infiltrated and thickened. Fundic examina-
tion may demonstrate retinal detachment and optic nerve in-
filtration. Other ocular findings include posterior synechia, 
hypopyon, glaucoma, and hyphema. Out of dogs with mul-
ticentric lymphoma, 37% had ocular changes, making ocu-
lar signs the second most consistent presenting sign after 
lymphadenopathy.
11.7 Nervous system lymphoma
Nervous system lymphoma is relatively rare in dogs and can 
present both as central (brain and spinal cord) and peripheral 
nervous system disease. In case of primary brain lymphoma 
affects only brain and meninges, while in case of secondary 
nervous system lymphoma, both nervous and extra-nervous 
systems are involved. These pets may present with seizures, 
paralysis, paresis, or cranial nerve deficits. Peripheral ner -
vous system lymphoma may also occur as part of primary 
disease, part of multisystemic disease, or both.
11.8 Pulmonary lymphoma
Pulmonary involvement in CL is common and can be both 
primary and secondary. Respiratory signs are rare and in CL 
except when it leads to pleural effusion. In most cases, pul-
monary involvement is diagnosed on the basis of additional 
tests like thoracic radiography, CT scan, etc. Pulmonary 
lymphoma can result in alveolar, bronchial, and/or inter -
stitial infiltrates, pleural effusion, and lymphadenopathy. 
Thoracic radiography, tracheal washes, and bronchioalve -
olar lavage can be done to know the extent of pulmonary 
involvement.
11.9 Atypical forms of canine lymphoma
Canine lymphoma can affect any organ or location, and 
a wide variety of these atypical forms has been reported. 
Oral, periapical, nasal, vertebral, skeletal muscle, synovial 
membrane leading to ruptured cranial cruciate ligament, 
adrenal (resulting in hypoadrenocorticism), renal, urinary 
bladder, uterine, prostate, cardiac and pericardial involve -
ment may be seen.
11.10 Evaluating dogs with lymphoma: Staging
The appropriate management of dogs with canine lym -
phoma begins with a timely and accurate diagnosis, tak -
ing into account both tumor and patient characteristics. In 
the majority of cases, such animals present for veterinary 
attention because of clinical signs referable to painless pe -
ripheral lymphadenopathy or less commonly, to the effects 
of tumor infiltration of the spleen, liver, gastrointestinal 
tract, or bone marrow. A comprehensive clinical history 
and physical examination provide the basis for patient as -
sessment and management. The presence or absence of 
signs such as lethargy, inappetence, weight loss, polyuria/
polydipsia, and fever should be recorded. Clinical his -
tory taking should include questions regarding possible 
risk factors for lymphoma, including exposure to tobacco 
smoke or waste emissions and the use of chemicals (such 
as 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid) surrounding the dog’s 
environment.

Neoplasms in dog and cat  Chapter | 24  369
History taking should also include whether related ani -
mals have lymphoma or lympho-proliferative disorders. 
During the physical examination, the location and size of 
affected lymph nodes (LNs) should be assessed by accu -
rate two-dimensional measurement. Such measurements 
can then be used as a baseline against which subsequent 
measurements can be compared. The position of the liver 
and spleen relative to the costal arch should be recorded as 
fine-needle biopsy (FNB) of a peripheral LN, and the ex -
amination and interpretation of this sample should be done 
by a clinical pathologist. FNB is an accurate, quick, and 
cost-effective method of diagnosing the majority of canine 
lymphoma, although histological examination is required 
to diagnose certain limited forms of low-grade lymphoma. 
Pretreatment clinical staging according to WHO guidelines 
is shown.
Stage I: A single lymph node or anatomic location affected
Stage II: Multiple lymph nodes or anatomic site affected on one 
side of the diaphragm
Stage III: Multiple lymph nodes or anatomic site affected on both 
sides of the diaphragm
Stage IV: Stage I–II with liver and/or spleen involvement
Stage V: Stage I–IV with involvement of CNS or bone marrow or 
both
11.11 Therapy
Therapy is focused on the chemotherapeutic treatment of 
intermediate to high-grade multicentric canine lymphoma 
and for low-grade and extranodal forms of CL ( Zandvliet 
et al., 2015).
11.12 Chemotherapy
Many chemotherapy protocols have been developed and are 
effective for treatment. More complex chemotherapy proto-
cols incorporate a greater number of chemotherapy agents 
and offer dogs a longer remission and survival time. In ad -
dition, complex protocols require greater financial and time 
commitments from the owner. The simpler protocols are less 
expensive and have less chance for toxicity, but are associ-
ated with shorter remission and survival times. Single-agent 
chemotherapy yields lower response rates and is less effec-
tive than combination protocols. The choice of appropriate 
protocol depends on the patient, the owner, and the veteri -
narian administering the chemotherapy. Without treatment, 
median survival time is typically 30 days. Always measure 
lymph nodes prior to the start of chemotherapy, so disease 
response can be determined. The dog should be treated ac -
cording to the schedule unless prevented by a concurrent 
disease or adverse effects from prior therapy. A CBC should 
be performed at each treatment session. If the neutrophil 
count falls below 3000, therapy should be postponed and 
prophylactic antibiotics should be considered. Typically, a 
broad-spectrum antibiotic, such as Trimethoprim Sulfa or 
Ampicillin, is recommended when the pet is neutropenic. 
Toxicities to drugs are varied and can occur immediately 
after treatment or after chronic drug administration. The 
most common adverse effects include enterotoxicity, my -
elosuppression and nonspecific anorexia and malaise. If the 
patient develops signs of sepsis (including vomiting, bloody 
diarrhea, tachycardia, weakness, collapse, severe pyrexia, 
or hypoglycemia), the dog should be hospitalized and 
treated aggressively with intravenous fluids and antibiotics. 
Subsequent dose reductions are considered based on degree 
and type of toxicity experienced.
11.13 Glucocorticoid
Glucocorticoids induce lymphocyte and lymphoblast apop-
tosis are routinely used in the treatment of CL. Most dogs 
will experience complete response that typically lasts for 
60–90  days. Pretreatment with glucocorticoids prior to 
starting chemotherapy results in lower response rates and 
shorter remission periods ( Marconato, 2011 ). The ab -
sence of increased prostaglandin E2 level combined with 
no (Mohammed et al., 2004) or little (Asproni et al., 2014) 
COX-2 expression in neoplastic lymph nodes makes a role 
for (selective) COX-2 inhibitors in the treatment of CL 
unlikely.
11.14 Single-agent therapy
Various single-agent therapies have been described and in-
clude a monotherapy with (PEG-) l-asparaginase ( Teske 
et al., 1990a,b), and doxorubicin and mitoxantrone (Lucroy 
et al., 1998). All these protocols, a monotherapy with doxo-
rubicin, either as continuous (5x q3 weeks) or an intermit -
tent (induction followed by additional doses at the time 
of tumor progression) ( Higginbotham et al., 2013 ) appear 
most effective, but still less effective than a doxorubicin-
based multiagent protocol.
Drug Dose and route Schedule
Doxorubicin 30 mg/m2 IV On day first every 
3 weeks for four to six 
treatments
11.15 Multiagent therapy
There are many protocols, COP (Cytoxan [cyclophospha -
mide], Oncovin [vincristine], prednisolone), given for 6 weeks.
Multiagent therapy protocols are typically injection proto-
cols that combine cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin (hydroxy-
daunorubicin), vincristine (oncovin),  prednisolone (so-called 
CHOP), and often times l-asparaginase (l-CHOP). CHOP

370 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
protocols result in the highest response rate and longest re -
sponse durations and form the basis for most of the current 
protocols used for treating high-grade CL. Early protocols 
consisted of two phases, an initial more intensive protocol 
aimed at inducing a complete remission (induction phase), 
later followed by a lifelong less intensive protocol aimed at 
maintaining remission (maintenance phase). It was later shown 
that a continuous maintenance phase following induction of a 
complete response offered no treatment benefit, and as a re-
sult, total protocol length has gradually decreased. However, 
a 6-month protocol, i.e., an induction phase followed by a 
short maintenance protocol, is considered the standard of care 
(Piek et al., 1999). 12-week and 15-week protocols have been 
reported and appear equally effective. Increasing treatment 
intensity, either by increasing the number of drugs, drug dos-
ages or shortening dose intervals, has failed to improve treat-
ment outcome, but increases adverse events.

11.16 Rescue protocols
At the start of a chemotherapy protocol, the most chemo -
sensitive cells are easily killed. These cells are more likely 
to express the gene encoding for P-glycoprotein, the trans -
membrane, drug efflux pump associated with multidrug re-
sistance. Another reason for relapse is inadequate dose and 
frequency of administration of chemotherapy. Relapse may 
also be observed as sequelae to the failure to achieve high 
drug concentrations at certain anatomic sites, such as in the 
CNS. Novel drugs are indicated if the dog fails to achieve a 
durable remission in the induction phase. A durable remis -
sion is typically a response that last 14–21 days.
Rescue protocols are used in case of failure to respond 
to a first-line protocol or following relapse and include both 
single-agent and multiagent protocols. The choice of treat -
ment protocol varies depending on the moment of relapse in 
relation to the original (first-line) protocol, previously used 
drugs (e.g., cumulative cardiac toxicity of doxorubicin), 
and individual clinician’s preferences. Rescue protocols 
typically result in lower response rates, shorter durations of 
response (2–3 months) and tend to show more toxicity than 
first-line protocols.
11.17 Lymphoma in cats
Lymphoma is one of the most common cancers diagnosed 
in cats. Cats of any age, breed, and sex can be affected. 
Feline leukemia virus (FeLV) are considered the cause lym-
phoma in some cats. Cats with the feline immunodeficiency 
virus (FIV) are also at higher risk of developing lymphoma. 
Lymphoma of the digestive tract is the most common form 
and clinically characterized by vomiting, diarrhea, weight 
loss, or a decreased appetite. Lymphoma is initially very 
responsive to chemotherapy, but the remission is very com-
mon (70%) in treated cases. Majority of cats tolerate che -
motherapy well and have minimal side effects.
12 Mammary tumor
The mammary glands are frequent locations for the develop-
ment of tumors and forms second most common neoplasm 
in dogs and cats. Almost 90% of feline mammary tumors 
are malignant, meaning they have the potential to spread to 
other parts of the body. The most common sites of spread are 
the regional lymph nodes and lungs. Around 10% of feline 
mammary tumors are benign, meaning they will not spread 
except by local growth. Dog breeds at risk for developing 
mammary gland tumors include German Shepherds, toy and 
miniature Poodles, Spaniels, and Mongrels. The average age 
of dogs at diagnosis is 8–11 years. Appearance of mammary 
gland tumors in dogs can vary greatly. The tumors can be 
firm or soft, well-defined lumps or diffuse swellings (Figs. 6 
and 7). Mammary tumors primarily undergo metastasis to 
the regional lymph nodes or to the lungs ( Moulton, 1990). 
Nonspayed female dogs are at high risk for developing ma-
lignant mammary tumors, but all female dogs regardless of 
reproductive state remain at risk. Approximately 50% of 
these tumors are malignant, and complete surgical removal 
is recommended if cancer has not metastasized.
Mostly, canine mammary tumors are hormone depen -
dent and can be prevented if ovariohysterectomy (OH) 
is performed before 1  year of age. The risk of mammary 
tumors for dogs spayed before their first estrus is 0.05%. 
In  general, sexually intact female dogs have seven times 
more risk of developing mammary tumors compared to 
neutered animals. The initial diagnosis of a mammary

Neoplasms in dog and cat  Chapter | 24  371
 tumor in female dogs is very vague and based on age, mam-
mary lump, regional lymph node enlargement, dyspnea, and 
coughing in metastatic spread. On the other hand, in human 
patients, breast cancer is the most prevalent cancer. In these 
cases, increased survival is due to the advances in screening 
methods, early diagnosis, and breakthrough in treatments 
(Nounou et al., 2015).
The only definitive method for diagnosis of breast can -
cer is breast biopsy in human patients. To increase the diag-
nostic accuracy and eliminate false negative results clinical 
examination, diagnostic imaging and biopsy are performed 
simultaneously. In this regard, ultrasonography is a use -
ful noninvasive technique for directly imaging the internal 
and external anatomy of lymph nodes and differentiation of 
echotexture of benign and malignant tumors.
Classical modalities of cancer therapy include surgery, 
radiation, and chemotherapy ( Kumar and Pawaiya, 2010 ). 
A number of chemotherapeutic drugs have been used for 
the treatment of mammary tumors. One of the most effec -
tive anticancer agents are paclitaxel and docetaxel.
A recent veterinary study showed that neo-adjuvant 
chemotherapy with prednisolone administered to dogs with 
intermediate grade mast cell tumors resulted in tumor size re-
duction, ease of excision, and microscopically clean margins. 
Two major taxanes, namely paclitaxel and docetaxel, are 
widely used in the management of breast cancer in women 
(Crown et al., 2004) as adjuvant and neo-adjuvant therapies.
Carboplatin is a second-generation platinum chemothera-
peutic agent which reacts within and between DNA strands 
by forming DNA adducts. Carboplatin has an on specific ef-
fect on the cell cycle phase (Lavalle et al., 2012). Surgery re-
mains the treatment of choice for all the dogs with mammary 
gland tumors except in operable cases such as inflammatory 
carcinomas, distant metastasis, and patients with poor general 
condition. Several techniques have been described including 
lumpectomy, simple mastectomy, regional mastectomy, and 
unilateral or bilateral mastectomy (Novosad, 2003).
Surgical excision alone yields unsatisfactory results 
in dogs with malignant mammary tumors exhibiting lym -
phatic or vascular invasion because these tumors have high 
rates of recurrence and metastasis. Karayannopoulou et al. 
(2001) used the two drugs, i.e., 5-fluorouracil at the dose 
rate of 150  mg/m2 and cyclophosphamide at the dose rate 
of 100  mg/m2, weekly continuously for 4  weeks showed 
good effect on survival time and disease free duration on 
dogs. Other protocols include combination of doxorubicin 
(30 mg/m2/IV) and cyclophosphamide (50  mg/m2/oral). 
While doxorubicin was given on day one, and cyclophos -
phamide was given on 3rd, 4th, 5th, 6th day; repeat this 
cycle at every 21 day for three to six times.
The chemotherapy protocols for feline mammary tumor 
proposed by the literature consist of the use of doxorubicin 
as the only drug or in combination with cyclophosphamide, 
carboplatin as the only drug or in combination with doxo -
rubicin and mitoxantrone as the only drug or in combina -
tion with cyclophosphamide ( Kitchell et  al., 1999 ; Lana 
et al., 2007 ). As a rescue therapy, carboplatin can be used 
as a single drug or in combination with mitoxantrone and 
doxorubicin for feline mammary neoplasia with metastases 
(Novosad et al., 2006).
13 Hemangiosarcoma
This form of dog cancer is an incurable tumor of cells that 
line blood vessels, called endothelial cells. Although dogs 
of any age and breed are susceptible to hemangiosarcoma, 
it occurs more commonly in middle-aged or elderly dogs. 
Also, certain breeds have a much higher incidence including 
Golden Retrievers and German Shepherds. For this reason, 
we may recommend additional screening of these breeds af-
ter age 5. This form of dog cancer develops slowly and is 
essentially painless, so clinical signs are usually not evident 
until the advanced stages when the tumors are resistant to 
most treatments. Less than 50% of treated dogs survive more

FIG. 7 Mammary tumor.

372 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
than six months, and many die from severe internal bleeding 
before there is an opportunity to institute treatment.
The chemotherapeutic agent most commonly used for 
the chemotherapy of the hemangiosarcoma is doxorubicin 
as alone drug (Ogilvie et al., 1996). Combination of doxo-
rubicin along with cyclophosphamide ( Bulakowski et  al., 
2008) can also be performed. Doxorubicin can also be used 
as three-drug combination with cyclophosphamide and vin-
cristine in the management of hemangiosarcoma in dogs 
(Hammer et al., 2008).
14 Mast cell tumors
Mast cells can be found in all tissues of the body but typi -
cally form tumors on the skin in close to 20% of the canine 
population. They range from relatively benign to extremely 
aggressive. Certain breeds of dogs are at an increased risk 
for the development of this tumor, indicating that genetics 
might be a cause. Boxers are especially prone to this type of 
cancer. For the treatment of canine mast cell tumor, protocol 
comprises combination of vinblastine, prednisone, cyclo -
phosphamide, lomustine, etc. drugs.
Vinblastine is given at the dose rate of 2  mg/m2 intrave-
nously followed by four treatments at every 2 weeks; along 
with prednisone at the dose rate of 2 mg/kg orally once daily 
oral dose in 1st week and on 2nd and 3rd week at the dose rate 
of 1 mg/kg orally once daily and afterward at every  alternate 
day (Thamm et al., 2006). Other treatment protocol suggests 
the use of lomustine at the dose rate of 60–90  mg/m2 orally 
once every 3 weeks, four times (Rassnick et al., 1999).
15 Sarcoma
Soft tissue sarcomas are a broad category of tumors which 
arise from the connective tissues, muscle, cartilage, or ner -
vous tissues in dogs and cats. Soft tissue sarcomas make up 
about 15% of cancers of the skin affecting dogs and about 7% 
of cats. Fibrosarcomas are common in dogs (Figs. 8 and 9).
FIG. 8 Soft tissue sarcoma.
FIG. 9 Fibrosarcoma at interphalangeal joints of left hind limb.

Neoplasms in dog and cat  Chapter | 24  373
This form of dog cancer is the most common type of 
primary bone cancer in dogs, accounting for up to 85% of 
tumors that originate in the skeletal system. Although it 
mostly affects older large or giant breed dogs, it can affect 
dogs of any size or age. Osteosarcoma occurs in many ar -
eas, but it most commonly affects the bones bordering the 
shoulder, wrist, and knee ( Fig.  10). A major symptom is 
lameness in the affected leg or a swelling over the area that 
seems painful at the site.
16 Squamous cell carcinomas
It is most often found in the mouth and the nail beds of the 
toes. Early detection and complete surgical removal is the 
most common treatment. Fewer than 20% of dogs develop 
metastatic disease. Squamous cell carcinomas (SCC) of 
the tonsil and tongue are quite aggressive, and fewer than 
10% of dogs survive 1  year or longer despite treatment 
measures.
Cats: SCC arise from the cells lining the oral cavity 
and is the most common oral tumor in cats. Many cats 
with oral SCC exhibit signs such as drooling, foul odor, 
bleeding from the mouth, or difficulty eating. Whenever 
possible, surgery is the first line of choice for SCC. 
Unfortunately, due to the small size of a cat’s mouth and 
the relatively large size of the tumor found most often at 
the time of diagnosis, curative surgery is possible in less 
than 10% of cases. Surgery usually requires removing 
parts of the upper or lower jaw because of the tumor’s 
ability to invade bone and other deep structures in the 
mouth. Radiation and chemotherapy provide additional 
treatment options. The success rate of radiation and che -
motherapy is very less.
17 Mouth and nose cancer
This is a very common form of dog cancer, more so in the 
mouth than the nose. Symptoms include a mass on the gums 
(Fig. 11), bleeding, odor, or difficulty eating. Since many 
swellings are malignant, early, aggressive treatment is es -
sential. Cancer may also develop inside the nose of dogs. 
Bleeding from the nose, breathing difficulty, or facial swell-
ing are symptoms that may indicate nose cancer. Vincristine 
sulfate (@ 0.5–0.7 mg/m2, IV , once weekly for 4 weeks) has 
shown variable recovery in nose cancer.

18 Papilloma
Papilloma tumors are benign tumors that look like warts 
in dogs, although they can be uncomfortable and prob -
lematic for your pooch. If an infection develops, multiple 
hard, pale, cauliflower-like warts may be seen on your 
dog's lips, inside the mouth ( Fig.  12), and around the 
eyes. These tumors can be painful, and severe infections 
can make chewing and swallowing difficult for dogs with 
papilloma.
Papillomas generally go away after a few weeks, al -
though it can take months. Because these tumors are caused 
by a virus (papilloma virus) transmission can occur through 
direct contact with an infected dog or contaminated objects 
such as bedding or toys.
19 Canine transmissible venereal 
tumors
Canine transmissible venereal tumors are cauliflower-like, 
pedunculated, nodular, papillary, or multilobulated that is 
firm, though friable in structure. The size varies from a 
small nodule (in mm) to a large mass (more than 10  cm). 
The site of predilection is almost always located on the 
genitalia preferably deep within the preputial region and 
vagina (Figs. 13 and 14 ). Occasionally may be seen to ad -
jacent skin and oral ( Fig. 15 ), nasal, or conjunctival mu -
cosae. It is usually transmitted to genital organs during 
sexual intercourse but can affect the skin via the direct 
implantation of tumor cells during contact between skin 
and tumor masses. Canine transmissible venereal tumors 
(CTVT) grow rapidly and more rapidly in neonatal and 
immunosuppressed dogs. CTVT is the most common ca -
nine tumor in India.
Surgical excision and chemotherapy are effective treat -
ments; however, chemotherapy is considered the treat -
ment of choice. Vincristine sulfate (@ 0.5–0.7  mg/m2, IV , 
once weekly for 4–6 weeks) is quite effective. Adriamycin 
(30 mg/m2 for dogs weighing >10 kg; 1  mg/kg for dogs 
weighing ≤10 kg; IV , once every 3  weeks) and radia -
tion therapy are effective for those pets not responding to 
vincristine.

Chapter 25
Diseases of hepatobiliary system  
of dogs and cats
1 Introduction
Hepatobiliary dysfunction occurs in number of acute and 
chronic clinical conditions, including drug-induced hepato-
toxicity, infectious diseases, portosystemic shunts, congeni-
tal or neoplastic diseases, metabolic disorders, degenerative 
process, vascular injury, autoimmune diseases, and even 
blunt trauma (Zakim, 1985). Chronic hepatic disease dam -
ages the liver leading to hepatic fibrosis followed by cirrho-
sis and ascites. The diagnosis of hepatobiliary disorders is 
challenge to clinicians since clinical signs are often vague 
and nonspecific, especially in early or mild hepatobiliary 
diseases. Dogs and cats with jaundice and ascites condition 
should be differentiated from other than hepatic disorders. 
Sometimes the severity of clinical signs does not correlate 
well with degree of liver damage and the progression of 
diseases. Because of multitask potency of liver, no single 
test can accurately identify hepatic disease or its underlying 
cause; hence, a battery of test is required to assess hepato -
biliary disorders. Complete blood count, serum biochemi -
cal profile, urine analysis, survey of abdominal radiography 
or ultrasonography (Varshney and Hoque, 2002) are being 
considered for screening value. Nonstructural changes are 
difficult to be diagnosed by using ultrasonography alone. 
Hepatic damage can be monitored by histological and histo-
chemical evaluation of liver tissue (Doi et al., 1991; Fukao 
et  al., 2009 ). Extensive literature has been published on 
hepatobiliary dysfunctions and their remedies in dogs and 
cats. For effective treatment of hepatobiliary diseases, ther-
apy should aim to eliminate the causative factors by reduc-
ing hepatic inflammation, minimizing fibrosis, controlling 
complications, and initiating hepatic regeneration.
In this book chapter provided comprehensive approach 
for the diagnosis and management of hepatobiliary disor -
ders in dogs and cats. Further, this chapter discussed in de -
tail about pathophysiology, portal hypertension,  refractory 
ascites, significance of lab profile, role of serum  ascites al-
bumin gradient, abdominal ultrasound examination, abdom-
inocentesis, ascites fluid examination, modified prognosis 
score for ascites and treatment and management protocol 
of various conditions caused by hepatobiliary disorders of 
dogs and cats.
2 Clinical anatomy and physiology  
of hepatobiliary system
Liver is the largest gland in the body, which occupies  
3%–4% of the body weight in carnivores, and liver is lo -
cated between diaphragm cranially and stomach and intes -
tine caudally. Canine liver is not so symmetrical, with the 
proportion to right and left of median plane is about 3:2 ra-
tio. Dogs’ liver is divided in to left lateral, left medial, right 
lateral, right medial, quadrate, and caudate lobes ( Breton, 
2012). The gallbladder is located between the quadrate and 
right medial lobes, and it is partly attached and partly free 
(Singh, 2018). Hepatobiliary system comprised of hepato -
cytes, sinusoidal cells, and biliary epithelium among these 
hepatocytes make up approximately 60% of the hepatic pa-
renchyma with sinusoidal endothelial cells, hepatic stellate 
cells (Ito cells), liver-associated Kupffer cells and lympho -
cytes (Mann et al., 1998 ). The anatomy of the liver differs 
between dogs and cats. Dogs have two separate ducts a 
pancreatic duct and a bile duct. In cats, the bile duct joins 
the pancreatic duct; this may allow the reflux and mixing 
of gastric secretion with both pancreatic secretions and bile 
(Tim, 2018). The liver receives approximately 25% of the 
cardiac output through a dual vascular supply (i.e., portal 
and hepatic artery). Portal vein supply is approximately 
75%–80% of the blood to the liver and rest of the blood 
through hepatic artery.
Portal vein and hepatic artery enter through portal 
triad and mix together in the hepatic sinusoids. Sinusoidal

378 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
 endothelial cells (SECs) have large fenestrae and lack a 
basement membrane, and the sinusoids are considered a 
“leaky” capillary bed. After passing through the hepatic 
cords, sinusoidal blood drains into the hepatic central vein 
and then out of the liver through the hepatic veins, eventu -
ally reaching the caudal vena cava for return to the right 
atrium (Schmidt et al., 1980; Hess and Bunch, 1995). Liver 
serves several function-like metabolic activities including 
synthesis of plasma protein catabolism and storage of car -
bohydrates synthesis, degradation of lipids detoxification 
and excretion of many toxic agents the formation and elimi-
nation of bile ( Mann et  al., 1998 ). The liver parenchyma 
has regenerative capacity and helps to restore its normal 
function. In addition, liver possesses 70%–80% of reserve 
capacity to sustain liver injury.
3 Pathophysiology hepatobiliary 
disorders
Hepatobiliary disorders have been associated with mul -
tipathogenic etiology ( Table  1), and this pathogenesis 
depends on the innate body defense mechanism, nature 
of the infection/toxic metabolites. Liver has the potency 
to detoxify the toxins and destroy/eliminates the infec -
tions by their metabolism. If liver was unable to correct 
or meet out their required metabolic pathway, it leads 
disease pathway and develops clinical signs. However, 
liver has regenerative capacity; mostly, the clinical signs 
will be exhibited only after damage of 70%–75% of the 
hepatocytes.
Acute hepatic hepatitis mainly caused by infectious 
agents, drugs and toxins ( Table 1). During the acute hep -
atitis, sudden elevation of hepatic enzyme may be ob -
served especially in drug toxicity. If the hepatitis caused 
by pyrogenic organism, which decreases the removal 
of endotoxin through the hepatic circulation, further 
severity of acute hepatic failure leads development of 
Jaundice, disseminated intravascular coagulopathy and 
hepatic encephalopathy ( Rothuizen, 2011 ; Boomkens 
et al., 2004 ). According to the author experience, acute 
hepatitis in dogs mainly due to NSAIDs toxicity espe -
cially by paracetamol and meloxicam. This kind of tox -
icity is mainly reported as over-the-counter (OTC) drug 
administration by the pet parents and over dose/indis -
criminate use of medicines.
Progression of acute hepatitis leads to chronic hepati -
tis (Table 1). Acute followed by chronic hepatitis mainly 
due to (a) nonspecific and no clinical signs during the 
acute hepatitis, (b) poorly exhibited liver enzymes, (c) in -
complete and inappropriate treatment protocols followed 
in acute hepatitis, and (d) chronic or intermittently animal 
infected with hemoparasitic infection. The chronic hepa -
titis characterized by periportal inflammation,  fibrosis, 
 infiltration of inflammatory cells (lymphocytes and 
plasma cells) and periportal hepatocytes apoptosis and ne -
crosis. These pathological changes further cause inflam -
mation of liver parenchyma on portal area which leads to 
porto-portal, porto-central bridging fibrosis. Once fibro -
sis process starts, alteration in the normal architectures of 
liver lobes becomes  permanently disturbed, and this con -
dition is called liver cirrhosis. Cirrhosis of liver causes 
obstruction of normal blood flow to liver. Reduction of 
portal blood flow causes intrahepatic cholestasis, ascites 
and shunt. The complete cessation or reduction in portal 
blood flow due to narrowing of portal vein cause portal 
hypertension.

3.1 Portal hypertension
Change in the hepatic circulation leads to portal hyperten -
sion, and it is classified based on anatomical location as pre-
hepatic, intrahepatic, and posthepatic ( Buob et al., 2011 ). 
Prehepatic portal hypertension is associated with intralumi-
nal obstruction (e.g., congenital atresia or fibrosis, throm -
bosis, neoplasia) or extraluminal compression ( Johnson, 
1987a,b; Rothuzien et al., 2006) and cause increased resis-
tance to extrahepatic portal vein. Posthepatic portal hyper -
tension is caused by obstruction of the larger hepatic veins, 
i.e., posthepatic caudal vena cava and right atrium (Dunning 
et al., 1998: Stafford et al., 2004).
Pre- and posthepatic hypertensive lesions are mainly 
caused by obstruction, stenosis and constrictive vascular 
lesions which develop primarily increased resistance to 
flow in the hepatic vessels accordance with Ohm’s law. 
Intrahepatic portal hypertension leads to increased resis -
tance in the microportal circulation, sinusoids and small 
hepatic veins which cause architectural changes in the liver 
parenchyma (McEntee et al., 1998; Rothuzien et al., 2006). 
The characteristics of intrahepatic portal hyper tension are 
capillarization of the sinusoids, fibrosis, microthrombi in 
the intrahepatic vasculature and regenerative nodule forma-
tion. Further, mechanical obstruction and dynamic changes 
in sinusoidal tone leads to increases in the intrahepatic vas-
culature resistance ( Iwakiri and Goszmann, 2006 ; Bosch 
et al., 2010).
The consequence of portal hypertension is ascites, 
acquired portosystemic shunts, hepatorenal syndrome, 
hepatic encephalopathy, hepatopulmonary syndrome, por -
topulmonary syndrome, hepatic hydrothorax, spontaneous 
bacterial peritonitis, hyponatremia, hypersplenism and por-
tal hypertensive gastropathy. Among this ascites/refractory 
ascites, acquired portosystemic shunts and hepatorenal syn-
drome are the commonly associated hepatobiliary disorders 
in dogs (Buob et al., 2011).
3.2 Refractory ascites
Regarding refractory ascites in veterinary medicine, there 
is no specific definition. Hence, the definition for refractory 
ascites has been derived from International Ascites Club 
and human literatures. Ascites that cannot be mobilized or 
early recurrence of which (i.e., after therapeutic paracente -
sis) cannot be satisfactorily prevented by medical therapy. 
This includes two different subgroups (a) diuretic resistant 
ascites (refractory to dietary sodium restriction and inten -
sive diuretic treatment) and (b) diuretic intractable ascites 
(refractory to therapy due to the development of diuretic 
induced complications that preclude the use of an effective 
diuretic dosage). Recidivant ascites recurs at least on three 
occasions within 1 year despite prescription of dietary so -
dium restriction and adequate diuretic dosage (Arroyo et al., 
1996; Moore and Aithal, 2006; Gerbes and Gulberg, 2006).
Saravanan (2012) reported in his study that refractory as-
cites were noticed in 16 dogs (22.22%), of which three dogs 
showed recurrence within a month and the remaining 13 dogs 
after 1 month from the day of clinical presentation and stan-
dard therapeutic intervention. Among these 13 recurrent as-
citic dogs, one dog exhibited recurrence of ascites after 6th, 
8th, 11th, 13th, and 15th month during standard therapeutic 
intervention. However, three dogs exhibited ascites recur -
rence at 4th, 6th, 8th, and 10th month of standard therapeutic 
intervention. Cirrhotic patients with ascites were character-
ized by marked alterations in their splanchnic and systemic 
hemodynamics leading to splanchnic congestion, central 
hypovolemia and arterial hypertension with activation of va-
soconstrictor systems, such as renin-angiotensin and vasocon-
strictor systems with renal increase of sodium reabsorption. 
One of the most adverse consequences of such hemodynamic 
dysfunctions were the development of refractory ascites in 
which standard medical treatment with low sodium diet and 
diuretics is unable to resolve the ascites. Further massive asci-
tes and hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) are frequent complica-
tion of liver cirrhosis (Gerbes and Gulberg, 2006). Refractory 
ascites generally affect patients with advanced cirrhosis who 
may also develop HRS. Both the refractory ascites and HRS 
are the independent predictors of short survival (Schrier et al., 
1988; Arroyo et al., 1996; Salerno et al., 2010). HRS is the 
development of renal failure in patients with severe liver dis-
ease in the absence of any particular renal pathology. It is a 
functional rather than structural disturbance in renal function 
(Garcia-Tsao et  al., 2008). Author suggested that refractory 
ascites reported in his study may be due to poor obedience 
of pet owner with treatment follow-up or dietary excess of 
sodium (Salerno et al., 2010). Because most of the pet own-
ers discontinuing therapy once after their pets getting clinical 
response within few days of therapy, this also could be one of 
the reasons for the recurrence and diuretic resistance ascites 
which were observed in his study.
3.3 Stages of liver diseases
There are four stages of liver disease:
Stage 1: Inflammation—It is an early stage of liver dis-
ease, and liver becomes enlarged due to inflammation, 
infection or toxic insult to the body. In this stage, clini -
cal signs may not be observed/detected because liver 
can manage them self by their regenerative mechanism.
Stage 2: Fibrosis—This stage due to the persistent, un-
observed and untreated cases of stage 1 which leads by 
chronic inflammation of liver. In this stage, liver paren-
chymal tissue becomes start to scar formation and fur -
ther scar tissue starts replacing the healthy liver tissue. 
Once the liver parenchyma becomes fibrosed, it changes 
the architecture of the liver and alter/disturb the blood 
circulation within it, which causes poor blood perfusion 
to the liver parenchyma leads ischemia and cell death.

380 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
In the second stage of liver diseases, animal could ex -
hibit clinical signs and this can be reverted if diagnosed 
and treated early.
Stage 3: Cirrhosis —It is characterized by permanent 
scare tissue formation in the liver which causes hard and 
lumpy/irregular counter of liver. Once liver becomes 
developed with cirrhosis, it cannot be reverted by self-
healing or medical management. In this stage, animal 
shows signs of distended abdomen, ascites and Jaundice.
Stage 4: Liver failure (End stage of liver diseases) —
Progression of liver cirrhosis initiates liver failure. In 
this stage, liver could not work properly and damage 
to other organ and further leads multiorgan dysfunction 
and death.
4 Diagnosis of hepatobiliary disorders
The diagnosis of hepatobiliary diseases mainly based on the 
laboratory examination, ultrasonography and histopatho -
logical evaluation (Rothuizen et al., 2007 ). For the confir -
mative diagnosis of the hepatobiliary disorders, liver biopsy 
and bile fluid culture will help to proceed with medical or 
surgical management as well as to provide prognosis also. 
Ultrasound-guided liver biopsy and bile fluid aspiration are 
possible in most of the cases without any complications. 
Radiography and abdominal ultrasound have excellent non-
invasive diagnostic tool to assess morphological abnormali-
ties and evaluate liver parenchymal alteration (Kumar et al., 
2012a,b).
4.1 Signalment
Every clinical diagnosis starts with signalment and dis -
eases history, similarly in the diagnosis of various hepa -
tobiliary disorders also clinicians need to collect animal 
data, viz. breed, age and sex, plays important role in 
the diagnosis of hepatobiliary diseases in dogs and cats 
(Tables 2 and 3).
4.2 Food
Excessive intake of grapes and raisins in dogs and cats 
causes severe hepatic dysfunction. Similarly, ingestion of 
xylitol (artificial sweetener) also causes liver failure.
4.3 Drugs/medication
In a suspected case of drug-induced hepatic dysfunction, 
should collect the name of the drug, duration of the drug 
administration and also should check whether that drug 
will cause hepatic damage. Also, clinician should collect 
detailed drug history prescription, over-the-counter and al -
ternative medications in the when an unexplained increase 
in liver enzyme activity is detected, or in animals with evi -
dence of acute or chronic hepatic disease ( Kannan et  al., 
2019; Saravanan et al., 2021). Cats are uniquely susceptible 
to acetaminophen toxicosis than dogs. Phenobarbital has 
been associated with chronic hepatic disease and cirrhosis 
in dogs. Potentiated sulfonamides, carprofen, and diazepam 
were also causing severe hepatic damage if high dose or 
long-time administration (Johnson, 2010).
4.4 Previous diseases illness
Tick-borne infections include the Babesia spp., Hepatozoon 
spp., Ehrlichia spp., Anaplasma spp., Bartonella spp., are 
more common in pet animals. Liver is also one of the main

target organs of tick-borne intracellular diseases ( Jacobson

or previous history illness with ticks and tick-borne infec -

disorders.
4.5 Clinical signs
The clinical signs of early chronic hepatitis are vague and 
nonspecific, whereas signs will develop when liver dis -
eases become severe or complicated and more than 60%–
70% of the liver damage. Chronic hepatitis seemingly has 
a long subclinical phase consistent with the observation 
that up to 20% of dogs with CH have increased serum 
liver enzyme activities in the absence of clinical illness 
(Hoffmann et  al., 2006 ; Bexfield, 2017 ). The  common 
clinical signs of chronic hepatitis in dogs and cats are 
(Table 4) decreased appetite, lethargy/depression, icterus, 
ascites, polyuria/polydipsia, vomiting, diarrhea, hepatic 
encephalopathy, melena and abdominal pain ( Webster 
et al., 2019 ). Liver cirrhosis was characterized by inappe -
tence, halitosis, abdominal distension, weight loss, poly -
uria/polydipsia, melena and icterus ( Elhiblu et al., 2015 ). 
The reported clinical signs were also observed in other 
organ disfunction; hence, the suspected cases should be 
preliminary evaluated for liver enzymes followed by ul -
trasound examination to further confirm the hepatobiliary 
diseases in dogs and cats.
4.6 Laboratory examination
4.6.1 Hematology
Decreased level of hemoglobin, packed cell volume, red 
blood cell and increased level of total leukocyte count 
and neutrophils were recorded in liver cirrhosis ( Nottidge

4.6.2 Serum biochemistry
Estimation of liver enzymes like alkaline phospha -
tase (ALP), alanine aminotransferase (ALT), alanine 
 aminotransaminase (AST) and γ-glutamyl transferase 
(GGT) helps to determine the liver diseases (Breton, 2012). 
In addition to the estimation of serum bile acids (sBA), 
urea,  creatinine, glucose, total serum protein (TP), albumin,

Diseases of hepatobiliary system of dogs and cats   Chapter | 25  383
serum ammonia (NH3), prothrombin time (PT), activated 
partial thromboplastin time (APTT), fibrinogen will facili -
tate the assessment of hepatic damage in dogs ( Poldervaart 
et  al., 2009; Alvarez and Whittemore, 2009a,b ). Elevated 
liver enzymes are not always reliable indicator of liver 
diseases. Hence, liver biopsies (in dogs) or fine-needle as -
pirates (in cats) are essential for the diagnosis, initiate ap -
propriate treatment protocol and provide prognosis about 
the hepatobiliary disorders (Hoffmann, 2010).
Biliary obstruction (Cholestasis) causes bile flow disor-
ders into the intestine which leads to vitamin K deficiency, 
and it directly reflected by prolonged prothrombin time 
(Rothuizen et al., 2007). Similarly, hepatic cirrhosis causes 
hypoproteinemia and inadequate synthesis of clotting fac -
tors. Elevated prothrombin time (PT) and partial thrombo -
plastin time (PTT) are seen when there is more than a 75% 
reduction in functional hepatic mass (Center, 1996).
Hyperbilirubinemia and hypoalbuminemia are the 
common chronic hepatitis and decreased concentrations 
of blood urea nitrogen and cholesterol developed due to 
liver cirrhosis in dogs ( Webster et al., 2019 ). Albumin is 
synthesized by liver, greater than 60% hypoalbuminemia 
has been associated with hepatic dysfunction, and also it 
should be differentiated with other disorders, viz. kidney, 
gastrointestinal and circulatory sequestration and dilution 
(Hoffmann, 2010). Increased ALP, γ-glutamyl transferase, 
ALT, and total bilirubin were observed in gallbladder mu -
coceles (Choi et al., 2014).
Estimation of serum bile acid and ammonia is the 
most sensitive for the assessment of hepatic function, and 
it significantly increased with portosystemic shunting and 
cirrhosis ( Center, 1996; Gerritzen-Bruning et  al., 2006 ). 
Portosystemic shunting and severe hepatic dysfunction 
cause elevated ammonia in dogs. Because the liver was un-
able to synthesize sufficient glutamine or urea, which leads 
ammonia freely passes across membranes and blood-brain 
barrier. The major clinical signs observed with hyperam -
monemia are hepatic encephalopathy (Center et al., 1991).
Reduction in the level of total protein and albumin 
level in the ascitic dogs could be due to the primary role 
of liver in the synthesis of major plasma protein as well as 
site of degradation and synthesis of many other proteins, 
which has been influenced by liver diseases in many ways 
(Table 5) (Webster, 2005).
Significance of lab profile
● Significant increased level of ALT and AST with normal 
creatinine kinase is suggesting hepatocellular damage.
● Elevated AST level returning to the normal range could 
be a good indicator of prognosis, especially in animals 
with acute liver toxicity.
● In acute fulminant hepatitis, increased AST activities 
will be observed due to severe hepatocellular injury.
● GGT in relationship to ALP, ALP may be higher than 
GGT activities in hepatic lipidosis.
● In dogs, GGT is more specific for liver disease than 
ALP, but it has less sensitivity.
● In cats, GGT is more sensitive but less specific than ALP 
for hepatobiliary disease.
● Decreased serum albumin, cholesterol, blood urea ni -
trogen and hyperbilirubinemia may have reflected in 
hepatic insufficiency and also in end-stage cirrhotic 
change.
● Elevated total serum bilirubin concentration has been 
identified as a negative prognostic indicator.
● Elevated alkaline phosphatase and gamma-glutamyl 
transpeptidase are consistent with cholestasis.
● Increased bile acid and alkaline phosphatase good indi -
cator for cholangiohepatitis.
● Low bile acid and increased alkaline phosphatase sug -
gestive of steroid-induced hepatopathy.
● Elevated serum ALT, ALP, GGT, bile acids and biliru -
bin levels are most suggested indicator of hepatobiliary 
disorders.
4.6.3 Coagulation profile
Evaluation of coagulation status is very essential in hepatic 
disorders especially in chronic hepatitis. The coagulation 
disorders were also noticed in platelet defects, vitamin K 
deficiency and disseminated intravascular coagulation. The 
tests performed to detect coagulation disorder are buccal 
mucosal bleeding time, platelet count, prothrombin time, 
activated partial prothrombin time, fibrinogen, D dimer 
and thromboelastography ( Lawrence and Steiner, 2015 ). 
Estimation of coagulation profile is essential before per -
forming FNAC and liver biopsy.
4.6.4 Microbial culture
Bile samples can be obtained with percutaneous ultrasound-
guided cholecystocentesis to assess for inflammation, in -
fectious agents, and culture and susceptibility ( Harrison 
et  al., 2018). Common bacterial isolates of bile fluid by 
percutaneous USG guided, which include Escherichia coli, 
Enterococcus spp., Klebsiella spp., Clostridium spp. and 
Bacteroides spp. (Rivers et al., 1997; Tamborini et al., 2016; 
Harrison et al., 2018).
4.6.5 Serum ascites albumin gradient
Serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is being used to 
classify ascites as high-gradient and low-gradient asci -
tes (Runyon et al., 1992 ; Pembleton-Corbett et al., 2000 ). 
SAAG is calculated by subtracting the albumin concentra -
tion of the ascitic fluid from the albumin concentration of 
a serum specimen obtained on the same day. When the dif-
ference between serum albumin and ascitic fluid albumin is

384 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
more than 1.1 g/dL, it is considered as high-gradient ascites, 
whereas the difference is less than 1.1  g/dL, it is termed as 
low-gradient ascites ( Alleman, 2003 ; Tarn and Lapworth, 
2010). If SAAG is more than 1.1  g/dL have portal hyper -
tension and less than 1.1  g/dL said to be an unrelated to 
portal hypertension. Previously in human medicine SAAG 
has been well established for the diagnosis of ascites due 
to hepatopathy ( Beg et  al., 2001). Similarly, in dogs also 
SAAG provides to differentiate ascites of chronic liver dis-
eases from other organ dysfunction especially cardiovascu-
lar dysfunction (Saravanan et al., 2012, 2014a).
4.6.6 Urinalysis
Routine urinalysis in dogs and cats will help and differenti-
ate diseases like kidney insufficiency, ketosis, diabetes and 
also liver abnormalities. In the hepatobiliary disorders, low-
urine low-specific gravity ( <1.025) is common in chronic 
liver disease and congenital portosystemic shunt ( Parrah 
et al., 2013 ). Even though the presence of bilirubinuria is 
nonspecific in dogs, but a specific indicator of liver disease 
in cats ( Yadav et al., 2020 ). Urate and ammonium biurate 
crystals observed with hepatic disease especially in con -
genital PSS (Bexfield, 2015).
4.6.7 Diagnostic imaging
Abdominal ultrasound examination
Abdominal ultrasound examination is very much useful in 
the diagnosis hepatic and gallbladder diseases. USG along 
with hemobiochemical alterations may be used as a diag -
nostic tool for liver cirrhosis in dogs ( Elhiblu et al., 2015), 
and it is useful for identifying focal and diffuse liver disease 
or biliary disease (Fig. 5) (Gaschen, 2009; Hoffmann, 2010; 
Mahendran et al., 2017).

should be placed immediately behind the xiphisternum on

Radiography
Appreciable abdominal distension observed in dogs and 
cats should be first checked with abdominal survey radi -
ography to ruled out organomegaly, effusion and tumor/
mass. Abdominal radiography could diagnose the pres -
ence of hepatomegaly ( Fig. 14), small-sized liver, irregu -
lar liver margin, mass and tumor in the liver. Increased 
echogenic liver could be suggestive of chronic hepatitis, 
cirrhosis and tumor mass. Decreases in the abdominal 
details and ground glass appeared abdomen could be as -
sociated with abdominal effusion. Abdominal survey ra -
diography can diagnose alteration in the size and  contours 
of liver, but it could not diagnose changes in liver pa -
renchymal structure ( Bexfield and Watson, 2006, 2009 ; 
Gaschen, 2009 ).
Other imaging modalities
Other advanced imaging modalities like scintigraphy, 
magnetic resonance imaging and computed tomography 
are used in referral centers only because of the cost-
effective. Scintigraphy can be used in the diagnosis of 
portosystemic shunts, but by this method able to differ -
entiate between acquired and congenital hepatic shunts. 
Computed tomographic examination of the liver of dogs 
and cats has been used for diagnosis of hepatic shunts 
and vascular abnormalities ( Bexfield and Watson, 2006 ; 
Gaschen, 2009 ).
4.6.8 Abdominocentesis
Abdominocentesis is performed for diagnostic and thera -
peutic purpose. Diagnostic paracentesis could assist in 
timely identifying the pathological causes which are respon-
sible for the fluid accumulation or it can help for further 
investigative procedures which may be helpful in diagnos -
ing the diseases condition ( Papasouliotis and Dewhurst, 
2005). It can be done in patient on standing position or in 
left lateral recumbency with aseptic method. A site should 
be chosen 2–3  cm caudal to the umbilicus and 2–3  cm left 
of the midline for sampling. The bladder should be emp -
tied before abdominal paracentesis. A 22 or 20 G needle or 
catheter has been inserted at an angle of 45 degrees to the 
body wall. Fluid was collected directly into the sterile vials 
with or without EDTA for further analysis (Alleman, 2003; 
Rudolff, 2005).
Therapeutic abdominocentesis is very much needed in 
severe ascites or refractory ascitic condition to impair mobil-
ity and to reduce respiratory compromise (Trepanier, 2008; 
Bexfield and Watson, 2009 ). Abdominal  paracentesis has

been considered to be a sensitive technique for  collecting

Ascitic fluid analysis
The variation in the total protein concentration of the ascitic 
fluid in the patients with chronic liver could be a difference 
in serum protein concentration and in portal pressure and to 
be relatively independent of peritoneal permeability (Hoefs, 
1983). Blood-stained fluid usually due to traumatic tap, 
peritoneal carcinoma and ascitic fluids which remain ho -
mogeneously blood-stained fluid throughout the tap could 
indicate malignancy, pancreatitis, intestinal infarction and 
tuberculosis (Runyon et al., 1988; Alleman, 2003).
Runyon et  al. (1988) reported that the nonbiochemical 
tests (cell count, bacterial culture) and cytology of ascitic 
fluid had an important role in the evaluation of ascitic fluid. 
Chylons effusion could be easily recognized by their color 
(opaque) and confirmed by triglyceride concentration greater 
than 100 mg/dL in ascitic fluid (Alleman, 2003). Gupta et al. 
(1995) reported that the total protein (TP) of ascitic fluid was 
less than 25 g/L had a 100% diagnostic specificity, positive 
predictive value for a cirrhotic effusion whereas body weight 
sensitivity was less good at 76%, and the overall diagnostic 
accuracy was calculated at 88% (compared with 92% for se-
rum ascitic fluid albumin gradient of 11 g/dL).
The gross appearance of the ascitic fluid provides useful 
diagnostic information about the ascites and a clear straw 
colored ascitic fluid noticed in cirrhotic patient. Pembleton-
Corbett et al. (2000) suggested that portal hypertension is a 
predominant force in formation of transudative abdominal 
effusion in dogs with hepatobiliary disease and in dogs with 
other disorders. Basic tests are ascitic fluid analysis protein 
determination, total nucleated cell count (TNCC) and cytol-
ogy. Ascites due to liver disease is typically a pure transudate 
with total protein concentration of less than 2.5  g/dL and 
specific gravity between 1.010 and 1.015. Cytologically, the 
fluid had low cellularity with only a few mesothelial cells 
and neutrophils (Center, 2006).
4.6.9 Modified prognosis score for the ascites 
of hepatobiliary disorders in dogs
In human patient, various scoring systems are being used to 
assess the severity of disease and to determine the prognosis 
in patients with liver cirrhosis and its potential complications 
which include variceal gastrointestinal bleeding, coagulopa-
thy, ascites, hepatic encephalopathy and hepatocellular car-
cinoma. Strategies have been established to prevent some of 
these complications or to detect them at an early stage (Riley 
and Bhatti, 2001 ). In addition to the simple estimation of 
life expectancy, more complex issues must be taken into ac-
count, such as the capacity of a cirrhotic patient to withstand 
a given therapeutic intervention, or whether a given thera -
peutic option offers an acceptable chance of survival or not 
(Durand and Valla, 2008). But there were no such kind of 
scoring system available in  veterinary practices for ascites 
due to hepatobiliary disorders in dogs.
Saravanan (2012) was undertaken to develop a prognos-
tic score as a pilot study for ascites due to hepatopathies in 
dogs based on modified Child-Pugh score. Clinical mark -
ers such as serum bilirubin, serum albumin, prothrombin 
time, degree of encephalopathy and the presence of ascites 
parameter were modified for ascitic dogs, and prognosis of 
the animals was recorded (Table 7).
The scoring system allows for classifying the disease as 
5–6 which is considered Grade A (well-compensated dis -
ease) 7–9 as Grade B (significant functional compromise) 
and 10–15 as Grade C (decompensate disease). During his

study, mean value of modified prognosis score for ascitic 
dogs was 9.79 ± 0.19. In this present study, 42 (58.3%) and 
30 dogs (41.7%) showed moderate and severe form of ascites 
respectively. Diagnosis was done based upon clinical signs 
(abdominal distension and respiratory dyspnea) and USG 
examination. Severe form of ascites might be due to liver 
cirrhosis with recurrence of ascites, and he reported most of 
the dogs were found to have refractory ascites. Moreover, 
ascites formation depends on the balance  between the local 
transvascular filtration and lymph drainage (Henriksen and 
Moller, 2005). Thus, the amount of ascitic fluid production 
was governed by increased transinusoidal filtration of pro -
tein and fluid and by transperitoneal hydrostatic and oncotic 
pressure (Moller et al., 2005).
4.6.10 Biopsy/FNAC
WSA V A Liver Standardization Group (2006) has published 
standards for histological and clinical diagnosis of canine and 
feline liver diseases. Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) 
is minimally invasive and safe method to diagnose hepatic 
vacuolation and lymphoma, but it has limitation because 
misinterpretation of diseases may occur especially in chronic 
hepatitis, cirrhosis and lymphocytic cholangitis (Hoffmann, 
2010). Hence, liver biopsy is the ideal method for the con -
firmation of hepatobiliary diseases in human as well as in 
animals. Ultrasound-guided liver sampling either FNAC or 
liver biopsy is safe method for the diagnosis of various hepa-
tobiliary diseases in dogs and cats. For obtaining good liver 
biopsy sample, ultrasound-guided automated biopsy gun is 
essential (Bexfield, 2015). Before performing FNAC or bi -
opsy procedure, animal should be with normal coagulation 
profile (Hoffmann, 2010). Full-thickness liver biopsy sample 
could be obtained through laparoscopic method, but it should 
perform under general anesthesia. Even though limitation in 
the laparoscopic biopsy, gross view of liver and associated 
structure and sampling from accurate lesion area is possible.
5 Treatment and management
Successful management of hepatobiliary disorders depends 
on identifying root causes. Antibiotic treatment is indicated 
for active hepatic or biliary infection based on culture of 
bile or liver biopsy. Whenever treating the hepatobiliary dis-
orders, always treat secondary and extrahepatic causes, like 
septicemia, GI neoplasia or inflammatory bowel disease. 
Cholecystectomy is generally recommended over medical 
management of gallbladder mucoceles. If surgical manage-
ment is not opted, medical therapy with ursodeoxycholic 
acid, low-fat diet and antibiotics could help to prolong the 
life of the patient ( Besso et  al., 2000 ; Choi et  al., 2014 ; 
Parkanzky et al., 2019). Depending on the cause and sever-
ity of biliary disease, one must determine if urgent surgical 
care or conservative medical management is warranted. For 
the cholangiohepatitis and/or cholecystitis, cholecystec -
tomy can reduce morbidity and mortality in dogs. Medical 
management for this condition is with antibiotics (amoxicil-
lin/clavulanic acid and enrofloxacin), ursodeoxycholic acid 
and supportive care (Rivers et al., 1997; Center, 2009).
Selection of the most appropriate fluid for patients with 
hepatobiliary disease must be taken into consideration in asci-
tes, hypoalbuminemia, hyponatremia, hypokalemia, coagulop-
athies, and hyperlactatemia and whether preexisting acid-base 
disturbances put them at risk for HE ( Center, 2006; Kumar 
et al., 2013; Saravanan et al., 2013; Vijayakumar et al., 2013).
5.1 Treatment for ascites
● Therapeutic paracentesis should only be performed if 
the ascites is life threatening and concurrent plasma or 
albumin transfusion should be given if large-volume 
therapeutic paracentesis is performed.
● Frusemide (@ 1–2  mg/kg po, sc, iv every 8–12  h), it 
should use in combination with spironolactone and 
monitor for hypokalemia.
● Spironolactone (@ 2–4 mg/kg po every 24 h), an aldo -
sterone antagonist, it is diuretic of ascitic patients with 
portal hypertension and gradual onset of action over 
2–3 days (Bexfield, 2014).
5.2 Management of hepatic encephalopathy
● Oral administration of antibiotics (Ampicillin, amoxicil-
lin @ 10–25 mg/kg po, Metronidazole @ 7.5 mg/kg po ) 
reduces protein breakdown in the gut, and fermentable 
fiber (Lactulose @ 5–20  mL po every 8–12  h) dimin -
ishes the production, absorption of ammonia and speeds 
up gut transit (Bexfield and Watson, 2009).
● Protein restriction could help to reduce ammonia 
 absorption from the colon.
5.3 Drug induced toxicity
● Activated charcoal @ 2–5 g/kg orally
● N-acetylcysteine is the commonly used antidote for the 
paracetamol toxicity. N-acetylcysteine @ 140 mg/kg IV 
loading dose followed by @ 70  mg/kg IV every 6  h for 
six to seven administrations.
● Vitamin C @ 30 mg/kg PO or SQ every 6 h
● Cimetidine @ 5–10 mg/kg every 6–8 h IV , IM
● S-adenosyl methionine @ 18  mg/kg PO SID on an 
empty stomach
5.4 Other medications
● Sucralfate administrated (@ 1  g per 20  kg every 6–8  h) 
to protect gastrointestinal ulceration induced by drugs 
induced toxicity.

390 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
● H2 blockers (Ranitidine @ 2  mg/kg po, sc or slow iv 
every 12 h) and proton pump inhibitors (Pantoprazole @ 
1 mg/kg IV) to for gastroduodenal ulcer.
● Steroid treatment in dogs with chronic liver disease 
(Bexfield and Watson, 2009)
○ Steroids should be used in animals with (a) there is 
biopsy evidence of ongoing inflammation, (b) there 
is no fibrosis or only early, mild fibrosis associated 
with an inflammatory infiltrate, (c) infectious causes 
have been ruled out as far as possible.
○ Steroids should NOT be used in animals with  
(a) Known or suspected infectious conditions, includ-
ing ascending biliary tract infection, (b) Advanced, 
bridging fibrosis or noninflammatory fibrosis. There 
is no evidence that steroids slow progression and 
there is a high risk of serious adverse effects due to 
associated portal hypertension, (c) Ascites, which, in 
animals with liver disease, is mainly caused by por -
tal hypertension. The use of corticosteroids in cases 
of portal hypertension may precipitate gastrointes -
tinal ulceration, which, in turn, precipitates hepatic 
encephalopathy as a result of bleeding into the in -
testinal lumen. Steroids also further increase water 
retention, (d) Hepatic encephalopathy, in which the 
use of corticosteroids leads to protein catabolism 
and the production of ammonia and other encepha -
lopathic compounds, (e) Acute hepatitis animals 
usually have infectious disease or toxicity and carry 
a high risk of gastrointestinal ulceration. Steroids 
should be avoided unless there is a specific and defi-
nite indication.
● Corticosteroids @ 2.2  mg/kg for 7–14  days, they re -
sulted in a significant increase in survival time in canine 
chronic hepatitis (Strombeck et al., 1998).
● Idiopathic chronic inflammatory liver disease is often 
treated with antiinflammatory therapy (prednisolone, 
1–2 mg/kg/day tapered eventually to a dose of 0.5  g/kg/
day or every other day and/or azathioprine, 0.5  mg/kg/
day) when suspected immune mediated mechanisms are 
involved in chronic hepatitis.
● Other accepted pharmacologic agents include col -
chicine for hepatic fibrosis and ursodeoxycholic 
acid to protect against the toxic effects of bile acids 
(Lawrence and Steiner, 2015 ). The benefit of colchi -
cine (0.03  mg/kg/day) in liver disease in small ani -
mals. Used in cases of moderate to marked fibrosis 
that have been confirmed by biopsy. Monitor animals 
for bone marrow suppression and gastrointestinal side 
effects are common.
● Ursodeoxycholic acid is a bile acid modifier, antioxi -
dant, choleretic immunomodulatory and antiinflamma -
tory. It is a hydrophilic bile acid that displaces toxic 
hydrophobic bile acids and stimulates bile flow. Dose 
@ 10–15  mg/kg total orally daily preferably divided 
into two doses and given with food to increase bioavail-
ability. It is potentially indicated in most cases of liver 
disease, particularly if there is associated biliary stasis. 
However, it should be avoided in dogs with complete 
biliary obstruction because of its potential to cause gall 
bladder rupture (Webster et al., 2019).
● S-adenosyl methionine (@ 20  mg/kg PO once a day on 
an empty stomach; phytate salt: 8–10 mg/kg once a day). 
It increases intracellular cysteine leading to increased 
hepatic glutathione synthesis, increases methylation of 
phospholipids and DNA which promotes membrane 
stability and controls production of inflammatory cyto -
kines (Webster et al., 2019).
● Silymarin (milk thistle) is a potent antioxidant, anti -
inflammatory, antifibrotic and choleretic. Use dose @ 
50–200 mg/dog orally every 24 h.
● Penicillamine is the most readily available copper che -
lator against copper storage diseases in dogs @ 15  mg/
kg bid.
● Parenteral amino acids administration helps in the speed 
recovery from the hepatic insufficiency.
● Vitamin K @ 0.5–1.5  mg/kg, repeated three times at 
12-h intervals, has been clinically shown to ameliorate 
coagulation abnormalities liver disease.
5.5 Nutritional management
● Highly digestible, high-quality protein (cottage cheese, 
chicken, or soya) diet supplement should be fed to the 
hepatic insufficiency pets. Protein supplementation 
should monitor in hepatic encephalopathy and peri -
odical monitoring of serum albumin concentrations is 
essential during protein diet supplement in hepatic dys -
function (Bexfield and Watson, 2009).
● Protein intake should be restricted only in the presence 
of hyperammonemia, ammonium biurate crystalluria, or 
animals with hepatic encephalopathy.
● Sodium intake should be limited to 100 mg/100 kcal en-
ergy requirement in hypoalbuminemia dogs and cats in 
ascites animal.
6 Conclusion
Diagnosis and management of hepatobiliary disorders is a 
challenge to the pet practitioners; hence, the comprehensive 
approach is very much needed for the early diagnosis and 
initiating appropriate therapeutic protocol to manage hepa -
tobiliary disorders in dogs and cats.
● If the dogs and cats presented with poor treatment re -
sponse to inappetence followed by anorexia, clinician 
should check liver enzymes and abdominal ultrasound 
examination.

Diseases of hepatobiliary system of dogs and cats   Chapter | 25  391
● Chronic and intermittent tick and tick born infected pets 
should be periodically evaluate for liver function and 
abdominal ultrasound examination. Similarly, pets re -
ceiving drugs like steroids, antiepileptic and antifungal 
should be evaluated periodically.
● Those dogs and cats detected with any organ disorders 
must be checked for liver problem also.
● Package of practice should be followed to manage the 
hepatobiliary disorders.
