Chapter 26
Common toxicological phenomenon in 
dogs and cats
Paracelsus (1493–1541) statement: “All substances are poi-
son; there is none which is not a poison. The right dose dif-
ferentiates a poison from a remedy”
Toxicology is the study of poisons and their effects on living 
organisms and the environment. It is a multidisciplinary sci-
ence based on the cardinal principle, i.e., dose and response. 
The incidence of poisoning in animals is relatively low com-
pared to infectious, metabolic diseases, allergies, trauma, 
neoplasia, etc. (Peterson and Talcott, 2006; Klassen, 2019).
The most common companion animals are dogs ( Canis 
familiaris) and cats ( Felis silvestris catus). Dogs were do -
mesticated approximately 15,000  years ago and cats ap -
proximately 10,000 years ago. Dogs were used for hunting 
and guarding, and cats as predators of rodents. Globally, 471 
million dogs and about 370 million cats are kept as pets. 
The population of pet cats in India amounted to nearly 2 mil-
lion in the year 2018 and is predicted to reach approximately 
2.5 million by the end of the year 2023. The population of pet 
dogs in India accounted for around 19.5 million in the year 
2018 and is predicted to reach over 31 million by the end of 
the year 2023 (Cote and Khan, 2005; Driscoll et al., 2009). 
Toxicity in dogs and cats is due to accidental exposure, ma-
licious poisoning, therapeutic error, and secondary poison -
ing. The toxicants are either natural or man-made sources. 
Natural toxicants are plants, zootoxins (snakes, bees, wasps, 
ticks, scorpions, spiders, fish, and toads), microorganisms 
(mycotoxins, botulinum toxin), and minerals (lead, arsenic, 
fluoride, selenium, iron, copper, etc.). Most of the natural 
toxicants enter the body through the food chain. Man-made 
sources are pesticides, household products, drugs, food ad -
ditives, etc. The most common routes of toxicant exposure 
are the oral and dermal routes ( Alwood, 2009; American 
Association of Poison Control Centers, 2011; Koyasu et al., 
2020; Peterson and Talcott, 2006).
Unlike dogs, cats have  discriminating habits and appe -
tites, making them less likely to ingest things that are not 
good for them. But due to their grooming habits, cats are 
more at risk than dogs from toxicants that come into contact 
with their fur. Almost 95% of animal exposures to poisons 
are oral, only about 4% are dermal, and less than 2% are via 
other routes (Jason et al., 2014; Jull et al., 2011).
The features such as factors related to a toxicant, ex -
posure conditions, the subject, and environmental condi -
tions alter an animal’s response to toxicants. Dog breeds 
like collies and Australian shepherds are very susceptible 
to the anthelmintic ivermectin and the antidiarrheal lop -
eramide. Cats are highly susceptible to phenol poison -
ing. Greyhounds are most vulnerable to thiobarbiturates 
(Freedman and Wayne, 2017; Gwaltney-Brant, 2007; 
Vigne et al., 2004; Klassen, 2019).
Successful diagnosis of a definite poisoning is based on 
a complete history, circumstantial evidence, clinical signs, 
pathological evidence, analytical evidence, experimental 
evidence, and response to treatment. The complete history 
includes health history, diet, onset of action and clinical 
signs observed by the owner. The circumstantial evidence 
include housing and its management, food and water stor -
age, atmospheric pollution, poisonous plants, and animals 
around the vicinity of the house. The final diagnosis is a col-
lective outcome of all the evidence. Veterinarians must never 
suggest patient owners that an animal has been poisoned un-
less there is adequate evidence to support such a conclusion 
(American Veterinary Medical Association (A VMA), 2007; 
Babcock and Neihsl, 2006; Beasley et  al., 1999; Brown 
et al., 2007; Osweiler, 1996; Osweiler et al., 1985; Plumb, 
2011; Poppenga Robert, 2002; Puschner et al., 2007).
Treatment should be initiated at the earliest to maintain 
the vital functions. A few toxicants have specific antidotes. 
These antidotes counteract poisons either by receptor an -
tagonism or by chelation. The symptomatic and supportive 
care is imperative for the survival of the animal in poisoning 
which lacks a specific antidote ( Klassen, 2019; Liu et al., 
2008; Lubich and Mrvos, 2004; Rosedale, 2002).

396 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
1 Acetaminophen
Acetaminophen [ N-(4-hydroxyphenyl) acetamide] or 
paracetamol is an analgesic, antipyretic, and poor antiin -
flammatory drug. The single toxic dose of acetaminophen 
range from 50–100 mg/kg (cats) to 600 mg/kg (dogs). N- 
acetyl-para-benzoquinoneimine (NAPQI) is a toxic me -
tabolite of paracetamol which induces toxicity. In dogs, the 
liver is more susceptible, and in cats, the red blood cells 
are more sensitive to oxidative injury by N-acetyl-para- 
benzoquinoneimine due to glutathione depletion. The clini-
cal signs in dogs are anorexia, vomition, abdominal pain, 
icterus, lethargy, trembling, chemosis, tachycardia, tachy -
pnoea, facial, and paw edema. If methemoglobinemia is 
present, cyanosis, hemoglobinuria, and hematuria may also 
be observed. The most common clinical signs in cats include 
cyanosis or brown mucous membranes, methemoglobin -
emia, Heinz body formation, lethargy, anorexia, vomition, 
respiratory distress, edema of the face and paws, hypother -
mia, and icterus. The antidote for paracetamol poisoning in 
both dogs and cats is N-acetylcysteine. It is administered at 
140 mg/kg IV initial dose, followed by 70 mg/kg IV q 4–6 h 
for 7–17 doses. S-adenosyl-methionine (SAMe) 18 mg/kg/
day PO may reduce oxidative damage. Ascorbic acid (vita-
min C) 30 mg/kg PO, SQ, IV q 6 h acts as an antioxidant 
to reduce MetHb to Hb. In addition, symptomatic and sup -
portive therapy (Hinson et al., 2010; McConkey et al., 2009; 
Richardson, 2000; Wallace et al., 2002).
2 Acetone
Acetone is commonly seen in nail polish removers, varnishes, 
glues, and rubber cement. The route of exposure is oral, der-
mal, and inhalation. Clinical signs are nausea,  vomition, de-
pression, ataxia, stupor, and coma. The characteristic acetone 
odor is seen in the exhaled air. Treatment is largely symptom-
atic and supportive care (Klassen, 2019; Peterson and Talcott, 
2006).
3 Amitraz
Amitraz is a formamidine acaricide with activity against 
ticks, mites, and lice. It is effective against all forms of 
worms, i.e., eggs, larvae, and adults. Toxicity is mediated 
via alpha-2 adrenoceptors in the CNS, octopamine recep -
tors, and inhibition of monoamine oxidase enzyme. Clinical 
signs include hypersalivation, mydriasis, lethargy, ataxia, 
bradycardia, vomiting, dyspnoea, somnolence, hypothermia, 
tremors, and seizures. The alpha-2 adrenoceptor antagonist 
yohimbine at a dose of 0.11–0.2 mg/kg IV and atipamezole 
at a dose of 50 µg/kg IM can be used to treat amitraz toxicity. 
In addition, symptomatic and supportive therapy ( Andrade 
and Sakate, 2003; Hellmann et al., 2007; Hugnet et al., 1996; 
Oglesby et al., 2006; Queiroz et al., 2003).
4 Anticoagulant rodenticide
Anticoagulant rodenticides are brodifacoum, bromadiolone, 
chlorophacinone, coumafuryl, difenacoum, difethialone, di-
phenadione (diphacinone), pindone, valone, and warfarin. 
Dogs are intoxicated more commonly than cats or other do-
mestic animals. Secondary poisoning is also seen. Vitamin K is 
required for the activation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X.  
These clotting factors are activated by vitamin K via carbox-
ylation. In this carboxylation reaction, vitamin K (reduced 
form) is converted to vitamin K epoxide (oxidized form). 
Vitamin K epoxide is then converted back to vitamin K by 
vitamin K epoxide reductase. All anticoagulant rodenticides 
block vitamin K epoxide reductase enzyme and interfere with 
the regeneration of the active form of vitamin K, thereby in-
hibiting the synthesis of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X.  
The decrease in coagulation factors causes massive internal 
and external hemorrhages. Onset time is 2–5 days and the af-
fected animal dies due to tissue hypoxia. Intoxicated  animals 
with anticoagulant rodenticide-induced coagulopathy may 
spontaneously bleed from any site. The clinical signs are an-
orexia, weakness, coughing, epistaxis, dyspnoea caused by 
hemorrhage within the lung, acute anaemia, and hemorrhagic 
shock. Treatment includes specific therapy with vitamin K 1 
at the dose of 2.5–5.0 mg/kg PO q 24 h 5 days to 6 weeks 
or divided PO q12 h for first-generation anticoagulant toxi-
cosis. Vitamin K1 administration continued for 3–4  weeks 
with suspected second-generation anticoagulant toxicosis. 
Additionally, blood or plasma transfusions, oxygen therapy, 
antibiotics, and other supportive therapy (Sheafor and Couto, 
1999a,b; Stine and Brown, 2006).
5 Arsenic
Arsenic is a ubiquitous element and is one of the heavy 
metal having toxicological significance. Ingestion of 
 arsenic-containing ant and roach baits is the most common 
exposure in dogs and cats. Clinical signs of acute poisoning 
are vomition, diarrhea, dehydration, colic, trembling, stagger-
ing gait, hypotension, hind limb paralysis, coma, and death. 
Specific treatment with dimercaprol or British  Anti-Lewisite 
(BAL) may be required. In small animals, the dose of BAL 
is 2.5–5 mg/kg IM as a 10% solution in oil. Injections should 
be repeated every 4 h for the first 2 days, every 8 h on the 
third day, and twice a day for the next 10 days. Dosage and 
frequency of administration of BAL is specific. Other symp-
tomatic and supportive therapy is required ( Klassen, 2019; 
Plumb, 2011; Peterson and Talcott, 2006).
6 Bleaching powder
Most common household bleach preparations contain so -
dium hypochlorite at concentrations between 3% and 
6%. Hypochlorite salts are widely used as disinfectants,

Common toxicological phenomenon in dogs and cats  Chapter | 26  397
 deodorizers, and water purifiers. Chlorine bleaches are re -
spiratory and eye irritants. Clinical signs are irritation of 
the oropharynx, salivation, vomiting, abdominal pain, chlo-
rine odor in exhaled air, bleaching of the hair, coughing, 
retching, and dyspnoea. Areas of dermal contact should be 
washed with mild soap and rinsed with abundant clean wa-
ter, administration of milk or water to dilute the ingested 
bleaching solution and other symptomatic and supportive 
therapy (Klassen, 2019).
7 Detergents, soaps, and shampoos
Mild detergents, soaps, and shampoos contain anionic and 
cationic detergents, which are mild irritants. Toxicity is lim-
ited to the ocular, oral, or GI tract, which is usually mild and 
 self- limiting. Cats exposed to undiluted shampoos or other 
products containing sodium lauryl sulfate may develop signifi-
cant respiratory distress, dyspnoea, increased bronchial secre-
tions, cyanosis, and mild pulmonary edema within 1–3 h of 
inhalation during grooming. Toxicity is due to interference by 
the detergent with normal pulmonary surfactants. In addition, 
nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea are also seen. Dilution with milk 
or water, antiemetics, oxygen therapy, fluid therapy, and other 
general supportive and symptomatic care are recommended. 
For ocular exposures, irrigation of the eyes using tepid water or 
physiological saline is recommended (Plumb, 2011).
8 Ethanol
Ethanol intoxication is due to the ingestion of alcoholic 
drinks, raw bread dough, rotten apples, and indiscriminately 
using ethanol to treat ethylene glycol poisoning. It inhibits N-
methyl-d-aspartate glutamate receptors in the brain. Clinical 
signs are flatulence, bloating, abdominal pain, vomiting, 
retching, central nervous system depression, ataxia, lethargy, 
sedation, hypothermia, and metabolic acidosis. The smell 
of ethanol may be prevalent on the pet’s breath. Treatment 
for acidosis includes administration of sodium bicarbonate, 
fluid therapy, and supportive care ( V olmer and Meerdink, 
2002; Witmer and Fagerstone, 2003; Van Wuijckhuise and 
Cremer, 2003; Peterson and Talcott, 2006) (Fig. 1).
9 Grapes and Raisins
Grapes, raisins, sultanas, and currants may cause nephrotoxic-
ity in some dogs. The mechanism of action is unknown. The 
most common signs are lethargy, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, 
abdominal pain, diarrhea, uremic breath, excessive thirst, and 
excessive urination. Treatment includes decontamination, fluid 
therapy, antihistamines, and other supportive therapy (Eubig 
et al., 2005; Sutton et al., 2009).
10 Homemade and commercial play 
dough
Ingestion of homemade and commercial play dough causes 
severe hypernatremia in dogs. Commercial playdough 
contains 4.3% sodium. Clinical signs include vomiting, 
polydipsia, polyuria, tremors, hyperthermia, and seizures. 
Treatment includes decontamination, fluid, and supportive 
therapy (Peterson and Talcott, 2006).
11 Honey bees, wasps, and hornets
Wasps and hornets ( Vespidae) and Honey bees ( Apidae) 
possess a stinging apparatus with a modified ovipositor that 
is connected to a venom sac. They grasp the victim’s skin 
with their claws and insert their stinger into the skin. Vespids 
are generally able to withdraw their stingers and are capable 
of stinging again. The stinger of the honey bee is barbed 
so the stinger and venom sac remain attached to the vic -
tim’s skin when the bee flies away resulting in the insect’s 
death. The venom of apids contains melittin and formalde -
hyde. Venom of the vespids is a mixture of proteins, va -
soactive amines, peptides, acetylcholine, kinins, serotonin, 
hyaluronidase, and phospholipase A. Certain terrier breeds 
FIG. 1 Common household food toxicants for pets. (Courtesy: Vishnu Prabhu.)

398 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
and boxers are more sensitive to the venom. A single sting 
causes localized pain, erythema, and edema. Multiple stings 
cause anaphylaxis in dogs characterized by urticaria, pruri-
tus, angioedema, vomition, urination, weakness, respiratory 
and cardiovascular collapse, and seizures. Anaphylaxis in 
cats is characterized by pruritus, vocalization, hypersaliva -
tion, ataxia, and collapse. Treatment with antiemetics, an -
tihistamines, analgesics, anticonvulsants, and fluid therapy 
(Klassen, 2019; Peterson and Talcott, 2006).
12 Iron
Iron is a highly reactive element that triggers free radical 
production and lipid peroxidation. The target organ of tox -
icity is the gastrointestinal, cardiovascular, and hepatic tis -
sues. Toxicity by oral exposure is more common than by 
injectable route. Vitamin E deficiency enhances iron toxic-
ity. Sources include gestational supplements, multivitamins 
or minerals, fertilizers, iron-EDTA slug and snail baits, 
hand warmers, and oxygen absorber sachets. Initial clinical 
signs are bloody vomitus, diarrhea, depression, GI hemor -
rhage, abdominal pain, circulatory shock, tremors, meta -
bolic acidosis, coagulopathy, and death. Treatment includes 
chelation therapy with deferoxamine mesylate which forms 
a nontoxic complex with ferric iron and gets excreted in the 
urine, which imparts a “von rose” (reddish brown) color to 
the urine. It is administered at the dose of 15 mg/kg, slow 
IV infusion, or 40 mg/kg IM q 4–6 h. In addition, decon -
tamination, ascorbic acid, antihistamines, fluid, and oxygen 
therapy (Brutlag et al., 2012; Klassen, 2019).
13 Lead
Lead toxicity is referred to as plumbism. Sources include 
lead-based paint, solder, sinkers, car batteries, golf balls, 
toys, candy bar wrappers, fungicides, herbicides, and lead 
projectiles. Bone is a sink for lead. Dogs are more sus -
ceptible and rarely seen in cats due to their fastidious eat -
ing habits. Lead inhibits the sulfhydryl group of essential 
enzymes of cellular metabolism. Chronic lead poisoning 
causes depression of bone marrow and hypochromic mi -
crocytic anemia. Anemia is a result of aminolevulinic acid 
synthetase, δ-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase (ALAD), 
coproporphyrinogen decarboxylase, and ferrochelatase 
inhibition. Clinical signs include vomiting, diarrhea, an -
orexia, abdominal pain, regurgitation due to megaesopha -
gus, hyperesthesia, hysterical barking, muscular spasms 
lethargy, blindness, and seizures. In intoxicated cats, 
nystagmus and ataxia are seen. Treatment includes spe -
cific therapy with Ca-disodium EDTA. Dogs and cats are 
dosed at 25 mg/kg (as 1% solution in 5% dextrose), SC, 4 
times daily for 5 days. The total dose should not exceed 
2 g/day due to the risk of nephrotoxicosis. Improvement 
is normally seen within 24–48 h. British Anti-Lewisite 
and Penicillamine are other lead chelators. Sodium EDTA 
should not be used for chelation, because of the risk of hy -
pocalcaemia. Concurrent zinc, calcium supplementation, 
anticonvulsants, diuretics, and fluid therapy should be fol -
lowed (Akhtar et al., 2003; Toscano et al., 2003).
14 Metaldehyde
Metaldehyde is an active component in molluscicides used 
to control slugs and snails. Its toxicity is termed as “shake 
and bake syndrome.” Dogs often eat baits voraciously, 
whereas cats in contrast are more selective in their eating 
behavior. The mechanism of toxic action likely involves 
alteration of neurotransmitters such as GABA, serotonin, 
and norepinephrine in the brain. The most common clini -
cal signs in dogs include tachycardia, temporary blindness, 
nystagmus, hyperpnea, ataxia, seizures, acidosis, cyanosis, 
diarrhea, dehydration, hypersensitivity to noise, light, and 
touch, and hyperthermia. Uncontrolled hyperthermia can 
lead to disseminated intravascular coagulopathy and mul -
tiple organ failure. Treatment for metaldehyde  poisoning 
includes decontamination, anticonvulsant, and other sup -
portive and symptomatic treatment ( Haldand and Davis, 
2009; Richardson et al., 2003; Talcott, 2004).
15 Methylxanthines: Caffeine, 
theobromine, theophylline
Theobromine and caffeine of methylxanthines are of toxi -
cological significance in chocolate and beverages. Pets 
are frequently attracted to these foods and beverages. The 
mechanism of toxicity may be due to competitive inhi -
bition of cellular adenosine receptors, cellular calcium 
reuptake inhibition, and competition for benzodiazepine 
receptors. The clinical signs include vomiting, restless -
ness, panting, weakness, hyperaesthesia, cyanosis, hy -
pertension, tachycardia, cardiac arrhythmias, tachypnoea, 
polyuria, polydipsia, hyperthermia, ataxia, tremors, sei -
zures, and coma. Death may occur from cardiac or respi -
ratory failure. Treatment includes antiarrhythmic drugs, 
emetics, purgatives, diazepam, and fluid therapy ( Klassen, 
2019; Plumb, 2011; Hovda and Kingston, 1994 ) (Fig.1).
16 Mothballs
Mothballs contain naphthalene or paradichlorobenzene 
(i.e., 1,4-dichlorobenzene). Paradichlorobenzene (PDB) is 
an organochlorine insecticide less toxic than naphthalene. 
Cats are more sensitive than dogs and ingestion of a single 
mothball is potentially harmful for a companion animal. 
Toxicity is due to its irritant nature and depletion of cellular 
glutathione leading to an increase in free radical tissue inju 
ry. Clinical signs are vomiting, naphthalene-scented breath, 
methemoglobinemia, hemolytic Heinz body  anemia,

Common toxicological phenomenon in dogs and cats  Chapter | 26  399
 hemoglobinuria. Treatment is with emetics, activated char-
coal, and a saline cathartic. About 1% methylene blue at 
the dose of 4 mg/ kg IV in dogs and 1.5 mg/kg in cats for 
methemoglobinemia and fluid therapy (Klassen, 2019).
17 Mushroom poisoning
Mushroom ingestion can occur all year round, but is most 
frequently during September and October. The most toxic 
mushrooms contain amanitin toxins. The target organ of 
toxicity is the liver and kidney. Amanitin inhibits RNA 
polymerase II, resulting in decreased protein synthesis 
and cell death. Clinical signs are anorexia, nausea, vomi -
tion, diarrhea, colic, fatigue, dehydration, polyuria, and 
polydipsia. Treatment is decontamination, gastrointes -
tinal and liver protectants, and fluid therapy ( Klassen, 
2019; Peterson and Talcott, 2006 ).
18 Organophosphate and carbamate 
insecticides
Organophosphate and carbamate insecticides are the most 
commonly used agrochemicals. Cats are more susceptible 
to chlorpyrifos intoxication than dogs. Both groups of in -
secticides inhibit acetylcholinesterase (AChE) activity. 
Organophosphate inhibits acetylcholinesterase enzyme irre-
versibly by binding to the esteratic site. Carbamates inhibit 
the enzyme reversibly by binding to both anionic and este -
ratic sites. Clinical signs of acute poisoning are  generally 
divided into three major categories. Muscarinic signs in -
clude salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, miosis, 
bronchospasm, bradycardia, and emesis. Nicotinic signs 
include muscle tremors, ataxia, weakness, and paralysis. 
Central nervous system signs can range from severe depres-
sion to hyperactivity and seizures. Local effects upon dermal 
exposure include sweating and muscle fasciculations at the 
contact site. Treatment with specific antidotes, i.e., atropine 
and pralidoxime (2-pyridine aldoxime methyl chloride) or 
2-PAM for organophosphate poisoning. Carbamate poison-
ing is treated with only atropine as an antidote. Atropine is 
a competitive antagonist of Ach for muscarinic receptors. 
Pralidoxime is an enzyme reactivator. It reactivates the phos-
phorylated acetylcholine esterase enzyme by binding to the 
anionic site. AchE reactivators are not effective after the ‘ag-
ing’ of the phosphorylated enzyme. Aging is due to losing 
one alkyl or alkoxy group, leaving much more stable mono-
alkyl or monoalkoxy phosphorylated AChE. Atropine at the 
dose of 1–2 mg/kg. About ¼ of the dose is given IV and ¾ 
IM /SC followed by the same or half dose at 4–6 h intervals 
by IM or SC until clinical signs subside. Pralidoxime chlo -
ride at the dose of 20 mg/kg slow IV or SQ q 12 h slowly 
over 15–30 min. Other treatment options include decon -
tamination, GI protectants, antiemetics, anticonvulsants, and 
fluid therapy (Klassen, 2019; Plumb, 2011).
19 Paintballs
Paintball toxicosis is seen in dogs and rarely in cats. The 
potential ingredients in paintball include polyethylene 
glycol, glycerine, gelatin, sorbitol, dipropylene glycol, 
mineral oil, dye, ground pigskin, and water. Clinical signs 
include vomiting, ataxia, diarrhea, tremors tachycardia, 
weakness, hyperactivity, hyperthermia, blindness, and 
seizures. The main clinical pathologic changes include 
hypernatremia, hyperchloremia, acidosis, and hypoka -
lemia. Treatment includes decontamination, anticonvul -
sants, fluid therapy with 5% dextrose in water, or 2.5% 
dextrose in 0.45% saline, at 1.5–2 times maintenance, 
and IV potassium at a rate not to exceed 0.5 mEq/kg/h 
(Plumb, 2011 ).
20 Plant poisoning
Exposure to toxic ornamental plants is a relatively com -
mon occurrence, and cats appear to be more sensitive 
and at risk than dogs, presumably because they tend to 
chew plant leaves. The plants which are toxic to com -
panion animals are Liliaceae, Araceae, oleander ( Nerium 
oleander), castor bean ( Ricinus communis ), Jimson weed 
(Datura stramonium ), Dumbcane ( Dieffenbachia  spp.), 
Ficus (Ficus benjamina), Pittosporo (Pittosporum tobira ), 
Poinsettia ( Euphorbia pulcherrima ), Rhododendron 
(Rhododendrum hirsutum ), Tiger lily ( Lilium tigrinum ), 
Jessamine (Jasminum officinalis ), Tansy ragwort (Senecio 
jacobaea), etc. 
Acalypha hispida: It contains diterpene esters, euphorb 
latex. It causes gastroenteritis and eye irritant.
Aglaonema spp.: It contains insoluble calcium oxalate 
and soluble oxalates. It irritates the skin and mucous 
membrane, salivation, and vomiting.
Aloe spp.: It contains Barbaloin, anthraquinone glyco -
sides. It inhibits stomach acid secretion, inhibits water 
and electrolyte absorption, cathartic, abdominal cramp -
ing, and diarrhea.
Croton tiglium: V omiting, diarrhea, conjunctival hyper-
emia, punctate staining of the cornea, giddiness, delir -
ium, and convulsions. Crotin in seeds, tigliane phorbol 
esters in seed oil and sap.
Hosta spp.: Also known as Hosta lily or August lily. 
Some species contain saponins, which can cause vomit-
ing, diarrhea, depression, and anorexia.
Dieffenbachia spp.: Salivation, vomition, dysphagia, 
airway obstruction, stupor, corneal abrasion, and hy -
pocalcemic tetany. Diagnosis is mainly based on cir -
cumstantial evidence and history. There is no specific 
antidote for the plant toxicity. Treatment is symptomatic 
and supportive (Klassen, 2019; Oehme and Kore, 2006; 
Plumb, 2011) (Figs. 2–6).

400 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
21 Pyrethrins and pyrethroids
Pyrethrins are natural insecticides obtained from the flow -
ers of Chrysanthemum  spp. and pyrethroids are synthetic 
compounds. Commonly used insecticides for fleas, ticks, 
lice, and mosquitoes. Many combination products include 
a synergist (piperonyl butoxide) or an insect growth regu -
lator (IGR) such as methoprene, pyriproxyfen, hydropene, 
and fenoxycarb. Cats are more sensitive than most other 
species to pyrethrins and pyrethroids. The primary mode 
of action is inhibiting the inactivation of sodium channel 
opening which causes persistent depolarization resulting 
in spastic paralysis. Also inhibits GABA-gated chloride 
channels, Ca 2+–ATPase, and Ca2+-Mg3+-ATPase. Sensory 
nerve fibers are more susceptible to stimulation because 
of differences in sodium channel kinetics. Clinical signs 
include hypersalivation, hyper- or hypothermia, paraes -
thesia, “paw flicking,” vomiting, hyperexcitability, trem -
ors, ataxia, weakness, dyspnoea, seizures, and death. 
Treatment includes emetics, purgatives, anticonvulsants, 
atropine, and other supportive care ( Boland and Angles, 
2010; Wolansky and Harril, 2008; Zimmermann et  al., 
2009; Klassen, 2019 ).
22 Silica gel containing desiccant packs
Silica gel containing desiccant packs are moisture absorbents 
commonly found in shoe boxes, lamps, medication bottles, 
electronic equipment, and food items. The packs can be paper 
or plastic packets or plastic cylinders with powder, granular, 
or liquid contents. The main active ingredient is mainly silica 
gel and some can contain iron. It causes mild gastrointestinal 
irritation following oral exposure. Treatment is symptomatic 
and supportive care (Plumb, 2011).
23 Snake poisoning
Viperine envenomation is common in dogs. Cats are more 
resistant than dogs. Venom contains hemotoxins that al -
ter the clotting mechanism. Local clinical signs include 
FIG. 2 Target organ toxicity by different toxic indoor plants. (Courtesy: Harsha Sagar.)

Common toxicological phenomenon in dogs and cats  Chapter | 26  401
 angioedema, fang punctures–not always two punctures, 
may be multiple scratches, edema and swelling, bleeding 
from the bite site, erythema, ecchymosis, and lymphangi -
tis. Systemic clinical signs include hypotension, dyspnoea, 
weakness, epistaxis, hematuria, melena, retinal hemor -
rhage, excessive salivation, fasciculations, vomiting, diar -
rhea, and oliguria. Elapine venom contains neurotoxins. 
They act at presynaptic and postsynaptic sites at the neu -
romuscular junction. Neurotoxins inhibit the release of 
acetylcholine presynaptically and block neurotransmission. 
They also bind to cholinergic receptors in the neuromus -
cular junctions and antagonize the action of acetylcholine. 
Also, contain an acetylcholinesterase enzyme that de -
stroys acetylcholine. Both dogs and cats are susceptible. 
FIG. 3 Common toxic plants for pets. (Courtesy: Harsha Sagar and Vishnu Prabhu.)

402 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
Cats develop  primarily neurologic signs such as progres -
sive ascending flaccid paralysis, decreased nociception, 
CNS depression, diminished spinal reflexes, hypotension, 
respiratory depression, anisocoria, myoglobinemia, and 
hypothermia. In dogs, CNS depression, decreased spinal re-
flexes, muscle weakness, respiratory depression, vomiting, 
hypersalivation, hypotension, dyspnoea, dysphagia, muscle 
fasciculation, tachycardia, and hemolysis. Death occurs 
due to respiratory paralysis. Antivenom is the definitive 
antidote for venomous snakebite. The choice of antivenin 
depends on the species of snake involved. It may be either 
monovalent or polyvalent. The dose is 100 mL (total dose) 
of which 5–10 mL is injected into the tissues around the 
bite and the remainder is given by IV route. The dose of 
FIG. 4 Common toxic plants for pets. (Courtesy: Harsha Sagar and Vishnu Prabhu.)

Common toxicological phenomenon in dogs and cats  Chapter | 26  403
antivenin depends on the species of snake and the severity 
of envenomation. The use of corticosteroids in the treatment 
of pit viper envenomation is not recommended. Tetanus an-
titoxin should be administered to avoid clostridial infection 
after snake bite. Antibiotics, analgesics, antiemetics, fluid 
therapy, and other supportive care ( Berdoulay et al., 2005; 
Chrisman et al., 1996; Kerrigan et al., 1997; Seibold et al., 
2010; Woods and Young, 2011) (Fig. 7).
24 Toad poisoning
Colorado river toad (Bufo alvarius) and marine or cane toad 
(Bufo marinus) are the most common toads that cause toxicity.  
Toad venom contains bufogenins, bufotoxins,  dopamine, 
epinephrine, norepinephrine, serotonin, and bufotenine. 
Bufagenins and bufotoxins are digitalis-like substances. 
They inhibit the Na+/K+ ATPase pump in the cardiac cells. 
FIG. 5 Common toxic plants for pets. (Courtesy: Vishnu Prabhu, Harsha Sagar, Anushree.)

404 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
Normally, the Na+/K+-ATPase pumps sodium into the cell 
and potassium out of the cell. However, when this pump is 
inhibited, the cell relies on the Na+/Ca2+ pump to maintain its 
sodium gradient, which pumps sodium out and calcium into 
the cell. This results in increased intracellular calcium con-
centration leading to excessive cardiac stimulation, tachycar-
dia, ventricular fibrillation, and cardiac arrest. Bufotoxins are 
vasoconstrictors and add to the pressor effect of bufotenine to 
increase systemic vascular resistance. Clinical signs include 
hypersalivation, pawing at the mouth, brick-red mucous mem-
branes, hyperthermia, hyperkalemia, ataxia, collapse, and sei-
zures. Sinus tachycardia, sinus bradycardia, and ventricular 
arrhythmias are commonly observed. Treatment consists of 
flushing the oral cavity with water to remove venom, anticon-
vulsants, atropine, antiarrhythmic agents, and supportive care 
(Eubig, 2001; Roberts et al., 2000; Klassen, 2019).
FIG. 6 Common toxic plans for pets. (Courtesy: Vishnu Prabhu, Harsha Sagar, Anushree, and Devraj.)

Common toxicological phenomenon in dogs and cats  Chapter | 26  405
25 Xylitol
Xylitol is an artificial sweetener found in many food items 
(e.g., gum, candy), medications (e.g., drugs, vitamins), and 
dental care products (e.g., toothpaste, mouthwash), the sweet-
ener in products for diabetic patients. Dogs are most commonly 
affected. History and circumstantial evidence play a crucial 
role in the diagnosis of xylitol poisoning. Hypoglycemia, hy-
pokalemia, hypophosphatemia, and liver failure are potential 
problems with xylitol. Treatment involves symptomatic and 
supportive care ( Dunayer, 2004; Dunayer and Gwaltney-
Brant, 2006; Peterson and Talcott, 2006) (Fig. 1).
26 Zinc phosphide
Zinc phosphide is a common rodenticide. It reacts chemi -
cally in the acidic environment and liberates phosphine 
gas, which acts as a systemic poison. It blocks the enzyme 
cytochrome oxidase and also acts as an irritant to the GI, 
respiratory, or CNS effects. Clinical signs include anorexia, 
vomiting, hematemesis, melena, shock, anxiety, tremors, 
seizures, blindness, nystagmus, paddling, and disorienta -
tion. Phosphine gas imparts garlic or rotten fish smell to 
intoxicated animal breath or vomitus. Treatment includes 
gastric lavage with 5% sodium bicarbonate, emetics, de -
mulcents, protectants, anticonvulsants, and other symptom-
atic and supportive care ( Easterwood et  al., 2010; Gurjar 
et al., 2011; Peterson and Talcott, 2006).
27 Prevention
● Over-the-counter drugs are commonly available in 
homes. So appropriate pet proofing and client educa -
tion is important to prevent accidental or iatrogenic 
intoxication.
● Alcohol and alcohol-containing products should be ap -
propriately stored as they are dangerous for pets.
● Insecticides having low persistence in the environment 
should be used. All insecticides should be stored af -
ter proper labeling. After use, all the empty containers 
should be properly disposed of.
● Avoid potassium permanganate in viperine envenom -
ation as it exacerbates tissue damage.
● Alcohol should not be used to clean the snake bite 
wound as it causes vasodilatation and promotes the up -
take and spread of snake venom.

Chapter 27
Anesthesia and pain management  
in dogs and cats
Anesthesia means loss of feeling, which may be defined as 
a condition of unconsciousness produced by a process of 
controlled intoxication of the nervous system either locally 
or generally over the body resulting into lowered sensitivity 
and diminished motor response to afferent stimuli ( Lumb 
and Jones, 1997).
The evolution of veterinary anesthesia has been ex -
tensive in the later part of 1960s since its first use in 2250 
BC on a Babylonian clay table and the use of many crude 
physical methods to produce unconsciousness in 17th cen -
tury by Assyrians and Italians ( Aiello and Mays, 1998 ). 
Introduction of general anesthesia in small animal surgery 
turns out to be more widely accepted after introduction of 
barbiturates particularly after the discovery of thiopental 
sodium. Intravenous drug administration to provide anes -
thesia has evolved in the last decade to become popular al -
ternative to inhalation anesthesia (Fig. 1).
Total intravenous anesthesia (TIV A) is a technique of 
general anesthesia using a combination of agents given 
solely by the intravenous route and in the absence of all 
inhalation agents including nitrous oxide, which is gaining 
importance in recent years due to its simplicity to use in the 
field condition without involvement of much costly instru -
ments or equipment and skilled personnel ( Dundee and 
Wyqant, 1988). TIV A, a new intravenous drug delivery sys-
tem, allows anesthetics to vary anesthetic depth in response 
to clinical signs in a manner intuitively similar conventional 
to volatile systems, thus simplifying the administration of 
intravenous anesthesia. The result is an easy-to-use modern 
system of providing anesthesia, which allows rapid, precise, 
and independent control of amnesia, hypnosis, and analgesia.
Principally, the administration of anesthetic compounds 
in veterinary surgical maneuver is to facilitate the perfor -
mance of the operation of its own shake, by depriving the 
patient of the power of obstructing and frustrating its execu-
tion to his own detriment, by the violence of his struggles 
and the persistency of his resistance (Hall, 1996).
1 Preanesthetic preparation
1.1 Preparation of the animals on the day 
before experiment
Patient should receive the general health care, routine labo-
ratory and clinical investigations, vaccinations, deworming 
against both external and internal parasites. Routine gen -
eral clinical examination like recordings of temperature, 
pulse, respiration, and heart rate should be conducted be -
fore experiment. Routine examination of stool, urine analy-
sis, routine examination of blood for complete hemogram 
and biochemical estimations should be done to assess their 
health status before conducting the actual experiment. The 
patients are kept off-fed and off-water for 12 and 6 h, re-
spectively, before the commencement of anesthetic proce -
dure (Fig. 2).
1.2 Preparation of the animals prior  
to experiment
The patient is weighed just before the anesthetic pro -
cedure. The specific clinical findings, i.e., temperature, 
respiratory rate, heart rate and SPO 2 should be recorded. 
Afterward, the animal should be restrained on the op -
eration theater table in lateral recumbency, and pre -
anesthetic blood is collected from either radial vein or 
recurrent tarsal vein, the sites of which were prepared 
aseptically, for hematological studies and biochemical 
studies, if needed. Fluid administration should be ar -
ranged to correct the dehydration and electrolyte imbal -
ance if any as well as to provide drug by intravenous 
route. Preanesthetic antibiotics and corticosteroids 
should be administered prior to major surgery as re -
quired. Oxygen administration by nasal catheter, mask 
or tracheotomy under local anesthesia is indicated prior 
to general anesthesia (GA).

410 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
2 Vein cannulation
Patient is generally restrained in lateral recumbency. Then 
the areas above the recurrent tarsal vein and cephalic vein 
are washed with soap water followed by savlon and shaving 
of that area was done. The sites were washed with 70% al -
cohol followed by povidone iodine 5% solution. Either right 
or left recurrent tarsal vein or cephalic vein is cannulated as 
per the surgical procedure and recumbency with 20–24  G 
needle or IV catheter.
2.1 Endotracheal intubation during anesthesia
After induction of anesthesia, when the jaw muscles have 
been entirely relaxed, keeping the dog’s or cat’s head and 
neck in a straight line with one hand holding the top jaw, 
thumb, and forefinger either side of the jaw behind the ca -
nine teeth and holding the upper lips up and away from the 
teeth, patient’s tongue is pulled rostrally to spread open the 
larynx (Jackson et al., 2004). Then the blade of the laryngo-
scope is placed flat on the tongue with the tip of the blade 
depressing the tongue at the base of the epiglottis. The lu -
bricated tube is then used to depress the epiglottis on to the 
tongue and kept it there while the tube itself is advanced 
in front of the arytenoid cartilages into the trachea ( Cassu 
et al., 2003). Then the hidden inflation cuff is inflated, and 
the degree of inflation was determined by assessing the sig-
nal balloon outside. The diameters of the endotracheal tubes 
are within 2–15 mm as per the requirement (Fig. 3).
2.2 Monitoring
Anesthetic monitoring is important to sustain a proper plane 
of anesthesia. To prevent excessive stress to the cardiovas -
cular, respiratory and central nervous systems, it is neces -
sary to monitor them accordingly (Tarraga et al., 2000).
Anesthetic depth can be measured by inspection of the 
following signs like physical movement or jaw chewing, 
swallowing in response to stimulation, eye positioning, 
degree of muscle tone and presence or absence of corneal 
reflexes, palpebral reflexes, etc. Cardiac monitor is used to 
monitor the cardiovascular system containing heart rate, 
pulse pressure, mucous membrane color, and capillary refill 
time (Bayan et al., 2002; Bennett et al., 1998). Direct blood 
pressure measurement can give continuous hemodynamic 
condition of the animal and can be easily accomplished 
through catheterizing the dorsopedal artery. The respiratory 
system is evaluated by monitoring respiratory rate as well 
as volume. It can be anticipated by observing the emptying 
of the rebreathing bag of the anesthetic machine for the pe-
riod of respiratory cycles. Pulse oximetry and arterial blood 
gas analysis give information of the ventilatory efficiency. 
The ECG is helpful to monitor cardiac arrhythmias. Ocular 
reflexes are generally used to monitor the central nervous 
system. Ophthalmic ointment and solutions should be ap -
plied to the eyes during anesthesia (anesthesia in cat with 
Ketamine) to prevent corneal injury (Fig. 4).
FIG. 1 Prolapsed third eyelid under barbiturate anesthesia.
FIG. 2 Some anesthetic, preanesthetics, and local anesthetics.
FIG. 3 Endotracheal intubated anesthetized dog.

Anesthesia and pain management in dogs and cats   Chapter | 27  411
3 Postanesthetic care
After anesthesia or surgery recovery is started which ended 
until the animal was alert, ambulatory, and all physiologi -
cal parameters have returned to normal ranges ( Buhl et al., 
2001). Deflation of endotracheal tube cuff is done in lat -
eral recumbency when animal shows gag rejection reflex 
(Nogueira et al., 2003 ). When the anesthesiologist feels as 
the patient is out of caution, the IV catheter is removed. 
Monitoring of temperature is indicated to check hypother -
mia (less than 98°F) or hyperthermia (more than 103°F) 
if any which should be treated accordingly. V omition, hy -
peractivity, vocalization, etc., should be treated or checked 
accordingly.
All animals should be observed for 15  days after anes -
thetic procedure, and regular general clinical examinations 
should be done to assess their clinical status. Postoperative 
care including fluid therapy, antibiotics and dressings of 
the operative site and removal of suture should be done to 
the patients where applicable. Vitamin and mineral supple-
mentation with adequate nutritious food and drinking wa -
ter should be supplied to all the animals during the entire 
course of postanesthetic care.
4 General anesthesia
A general anesthetic to a fit dog should bear little risk to the 
animal’s life. Though the mortality rate is very low, mor -
bidity due to anesthesia, which is often overlooked, is not 
unusual. In human anesthesia, severe hypoxic brain dam -
age can decrease intelligence following general anesthesia, 
and similar happenings may happen in dogs. Owners may 
mention that their dog is never the same since the anesthe -
sia which may indicate a cerebral anoxic damage before 
surgery. Another more dramatic and obvious cause of post-
anesthetic morbidity in dogs is renal failure. Many elderly 
dogs suffer from some degree of interstitial nephritis or 
CKD, and in such animals, even mild renal hypoxia may 
prove critical within a relatively small time.
4.1 Preanesthetic agents
Preanesthetic agents are used to prepare the patient for 
administration of anesthetic agents. A good preanesthetic 
sedation reduces salivary secretions, facilitates smooth in -
duction, has anesthetic sparing effect during maintenance 
and by increasing the margin of safety.
There are four choices available.
1. Anticholinergics (Atropin sulfate, Hyoscine, 
Glycopyrrolate)
Anticholinergics are not regularly administered as com-
ponent of preanesthetic medication. Use of atropine or 
glycopyrrolate is indicated for animals with elevated 
resting vagal tone (e.g., brachycephalics) and proce -
dures likely to augment vagal stimulation (e.g., ocular 
surgery). Recommended dosages are: atropine 0.02–
0.04 mg/kg IV , IM, SC; hyoscine 0.01–0.02 mg/kg and 
glycopyrrolate 2–10 μg/kg IV , IM, SC.
2. Morphine and its substitutes (Morphine, Meperidine 
HCl, Methadone, Fentanyl, Etorphine, Butorphanol, 
Pentazocine)
They are generally used to provide analgesia in dogs. It 
provides better sedation with analgesia when combined 
with other sedatives. Morphine is inexpensive and is 
used in the dose of 0.25–1  mg/kg IM, SC. Intravenous 
morphine induces histamine release mainly if given 
as a rapid bolus, but measured administration is less 
likely to cause troubles. Oxymorphone causes a smaller 
amount vomiting than morphine and hydromorphone, 
so is better choice for patients with head trauma, eye 
injury and gastrointestinal disorders. Fentanyl is given 
@ 0.05–2 mg/kg by IV or IM, whereas butorphanol is 
given @ 0.01–0.05 mg/kg by IM or SC (cat).
3. Tranquilizers (Chlorpromazine HCl, Triflupromazine 
HCl, Promethazine HCl, Acepromazine, Alpha-2 
Agonists like Xylazine, medetomidine, etc., 
Benzodiazepine derivative like Diazepam)
Chlorpromazine HCl and Triflupromazine HCl are an -
tiemetic, central depressant with tranquilizing potency 
are used @ 1 mg/kg IMly in dog and cats. Acepromazine 
provides mild sedation at clinically prescribed dose 
(0.01–0.05 mg/kg IV , IM, SC). It is anti-arrhythmic but 
prolonged duration ( Mansell and Parry, 1992 ). It re -
quires at least 20  min for good effect even after IV in -
jection, and 30–45  min when given IM and longer for 
SC. Premedication dose of 0.04 mg/kg IM has minimum 
cardiovascular effect in healthy dogs.
Diazepam and midazolam are calming, minor tran -
quilizer with excellent muscle relaxation effect. They 
cause minimal cardiopulmonary depression. They may 
cause paradoxical excitement. They are best with other 
FIG. 4 Monitoring of anesthetized patient by cardiac monitor.

412 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
CNS depressants (e.g., ketamine). In canine, they are 
given @ 0.1–0.5 mg/kg by IV .
Xylazine is potent non-narcotic, sedative, and analge-
sic with CNS depression effect, whereas cardiovascular 
depression can be profound (Sharma and Kumar, 1986). 
It causes vomiting, hyperglycemia, diuresis, GIT motil-
ity depression, and platelet aggregation. Now it is largely 
displaced by medetomidine. In canine and feline, it is 
given @ 1–2 mg/kg by IM or SC (Andress et al., 1995).
Medetomidine causes less vomiting than xylazine. 
It is given @ 5–40  μg/kg IM, SC to produce sedation. 
Intravenous administration is associated with more se -
vere form of dysrhythmias, so generally is not recom -
mended. Time of sedation lasts approximately for 1  h. 
The pharmacologic property of medetomidine in dogs is 
very similar to those of xylazine in that it produces bra-
dycardia, hyperglycemia and increased urine production 
(Joubert and Lobetti, 2002).
Romifidine is the most recent alpha 2 agonists which 
reduces the amount required for the anesthetic induction 
in dose-dependent manner. It produces dose-dependent 
cardiovascular depression. It is given @ 10–80 μg/kg IM 
or SC.
4. Sedative/opioid combination (neuroleptanalgesia) is 
most accepted which provides better restraint and anal -
gesia as the combination is synergistic, not merely addi-
tive as preanesthetic medication.
Innovar-Vet contains 0.4 mg/mL of fentanyl and 20 mg/
mL of droperidol which are narcotic analgesic and 
tranquilizer. It is given @ 1  mL/10 kg IM or SC. 1:1 
methadone- acepromazine is effective and reliable re -
straint for dogs and cats which is given @ 1  mg of each 
methadone-acepromazine per kg of dogs and cats.
5 Parenteral anesthetic agents
5.1 Barbiturates
5.1.1 Thiopental sodium
In the United Kingdom, thiopental was introduced into vet-
erinary practice in 1937 and over the next 60 years came to 
be the most widely used induction agent, especially for cats 
and dogs ( Curtis and Evans, 1981 ). It is a thiobarbiturate 
which occurs as a bitter-testing, white to off-white crystal -
line powder or as a yellow white hydroscopic powder. It is 
soluble in water and alcohol. It is a weak organic acid pKa 
of 7.6. It is usually mixed with saline or water to form 2.5%, 
5.0%, 6.4% (1 g/mL), or 10% solution. Thiopental sodium 
has a shorter duration of activity partly due to its high af -
finity for fat (particularly blood fat) and partly because it is 
metabolized in the liver quite rapidly during the early stages 
of anesthesia (Reddy et al., 2003). When stored in dry form, 
thiopental sodium is stable. After reconstruction, solutions 
are stable for 3 days at room temperature and for 7 days un-
der refrigeration. However, as no preservative is present, it 
is recommended to be used within 24  h of reconstruction. 
As the solution age becomes turbid crystals precipitate re -
sulting in progressive loss of activity with the same level of 
toxicity and large quantities of solution is needed to produce 
desired effect. Thiopental is used @ 6–8 mg/kg body weight 
for rapid induction of shorter duration and 20–30 mg/kg for 
surgical anesthesia without premedication by solely intrave-
nous route (Grimm et al., 1998).
5.1.2 Pentobarbitone sodium
The solution of pentobarbitone has a very high pH, and the 
drug can only be given intravenously. Induction in unpremed-
icated dogs can be achieved at the dose of 20 mg/kg IV given 
the half dose as a rapid bolus and the remaining given titrated 
to effect. Maximum total dose for a fit dog is 25 mg/kg.
5.1.3 Thiamylal sodium
The solution of thiamylal has a very high pH like thiopental, 
and the drug can only be given intravenously @ 18–25 mg/kg.  
Recovery is through redistribution of the agent from the 
brain into the other tissues causes prolonged recovery with 
hang-overs lasting for 24 h or more.
5.2 Nonbarbiturate agents
5.2.1 Propofol
Propofol, 2,6-diisopropylphenol is a rapidly metabolized, 
nonbarbiturate sedative/hypnotic anesthetic drug ( Alves 
et  al., 2003; Murrel et  al., 2005 ) that is administered in -
travenously to small animals to induce sedation and anes -
thesia (Apaydin et al., 2006 ; Dorrington, 1989). It is now 
presented as free flowing oil in water emulsion containing 
10% (w/v) soybean oil, 1.2% (w/v) purified egg phosphate 
and 2.25% (w/v) glycerol. Propofol should be stored below 
22°C and above 4°C. It should be protected from light and 
need to shake well before use. Propofol emulsion supports 
bacterial growth and endotoxin production. Hence, once the 
ampoule is opened, unused portion should be discarded af -
ter 6 h. If diluted solution is needed, it is compatible with 5% 
dextrose in water (Lim et al., 2000). It is used @ 4–6 mg/kg 
body weight with premedication by solely intravenous route 
(Heldmann et al., 1999).
5.2.2 Ketamine
Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic which exerts signifi -
cant degree of analgesia by blocking the phenylcyclidine 
site in the ion channel associated with N-methyl-d-aspartate 
(NDMA) receptor.
It causes catalepsy, catatonia, amnesia along with an -
algesia. It is used at a dose rate of 10  mg/kg IV alone and 
5 mg/kg IV with diazepam @0.5  mg/kg IV for dogs and 
11–33 mg/kg IM for cats.

Anesthesia and pain management in dogs and cats   Chapter | 27  413
5.2.3 Tiletamine and Zolazepam (Telazol)
It is mainly used to provide deep sedation in dogs. Telazol 
up to 4  mg/kg IV to effect produces deep sedation or light 
anesthesia in both canine and feline. Side effects like emer-
gence delirium, respiratory depression, hypersalivation, 
etc., are common and manageable. Sedatives and opioids 
can be mixed to make the final constituent more effective so 
as to enhance sedation, analgesia and duration of effect, and 
reduce side effects. The drug can be given intramuscularly 
@ 6.6–13.2 mg/kg in dogs and 8.8–15.4 mg/kg in cats.
5.2.4 Propofol-thiopental sodium mixture  
as TIVA
Recently, a synergistic hypnotic interaction has been re -
ported between thiopental and propofol so that a combina -
tion of the agents has greater effects than either of the agents 
alone (Ko et al., 1999; Rashiq et al., 1998). This could result 
from pharmacological interaction, probably at the GABA 
receptor complex. Generally, a 1:1 volume mixture of pro -
pofol (1%) and thiopental (2.5%) is used such that 1  mL 
of the mixture contains 5  mg of propofol and 12.5  mg of 
thiopental.
5.2.5 Ketamine-Medetomidine
Medetomidine at 5–40 μg/kg added to ketamine at 2–5  mg/
kg given either IM or IV causes deep sedation and recum -
bency in canine. Butorphanol 0.1–0.4  mg/kg IV , IM can be 
included in this combination for better sedation, analgesia, 
and muscle relaxation.
5.2.6 Ketamine-Diazepam
This combination produces less cardiovascular depression 
than xylazine-ketamine. Diazepam @ 0.1–0.4  mg/kg and 
ketamine 5 mg/kg given IV as a bolus or titrated to effect, 
or IM injection produce recumbency and status similar to 
general anesthesia in 2–10 min (Ameerjan and Mohammad, 
1990).
5.3 Inhalational anesthesia
The advantages are patent airway, swift control of anes -
thetic depth, good control over anesthesia, fast and smooth 
recovery, and disadvantages are more pronounced cardio -
vascular depression with myocardial depression, hypoten -
sion, constant surveillance by anesthetist and bradycardia.
5.3.1 Anesthetic machine
It is a device where fresh gas flow of medical gas is gener -
ated and mixed with inhalation anesthetic agents (gaseous 
or volatile) for induction and maintenance of anesthesia. 
Most frequent type of machine which is used as continu -
ous flow anesthetic machine is Boyle’s machine which 
is designed to mix accurate fresh gas flow of medical 
gas with accurate inhalation anesthetic agents (gaseous 
or volatile), and it provides gas flow only on demand of 
patient’s requirement triggered by patient’s inspiration 
(Fig. 5).
5.3.2 Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)
Minimum alveolar concentration is the concentration of a 
vapor in alveoli that is required to prevent motor response or 
movement in 50% of subject in response to surgical stimuli 
or pain. It is used to compare strength or potency of inha -
lation anesthetics. A lower MAC value represents a more 
potent inhalation anesthetic (Fig. 6).
FIG. 5 Boyle’s apparatus and cardiac monitor.
FIG.  6 Cat under pain management after surgery (IM Pinning and 
Thomas Splint).

414 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
5.3.3 Nitrous oxide
It is a week, nontoxic anesthetic. Analgesia from nitrous 
oxide decreases inhalational anesthetic requirement; there -
fore, less cardiovascular depression occurs. It is given with 
20%–25% of oxygen to the lungs. The potency of nitrous 
oxide is only half that of human, so the sparing effect is not 
as obvious. Use of this agent is not extensive in dogs.
5.3.4 Halothane
It is noninflammable, nonirritant and nonexplosive inha -
lation anesthetic which may cause arrhythmias ( Bose and 
Kohli, 1983). MAC of halothane in dog is 0.8%. Vapor set-
ting is at 3%–4% at induction with oxygen flow at 60  mL/
kg/min and is reduced between 1% and 3% during the 
maintenance with oxygen flow at 20  mL/kg/min. This has 
been largely displaced by isoflurane. As anesthesia is deep-
ened by increasing halothane concentration, CO and arte -
rial pressure decrease further. HR usually remains constant. 
Bradycardia and postanesthetic shivering are also common 
(Lindgren, 1981). MAC of halothane in cat is 1.19%.
5.3.5 Isoflurane
It is used though it is more expensive than halothane, but 
now much more affordable and has replaced halothane both 
in human and veterinary practice universally. It is quicker 
anesthetic regarding stabilization and more rapid recovery 
than halothane due to its low blood gas solubility ( Kim 
et al., 2003). MAC in dogs is 1.3% and 1.61% in cats. Vapor 
setting is at 3%–4% in dogs at induction with oxygen flow 
at 60 mL/kg/min and is reduced between 1% and 3% dur -
ing the maintenance with oxygen flow at 20  mL/kg/min. 
Isoflurane as halothane induces a dose-dependent cardio -
vascular depression (Gunay and Unsaldi, 2000). Isoflurane 
causes more peripheral vasodilation than halothane, which 
is responsible for a low arterial blood pressure, but tissue 
looks more bright and pinky indicating better perfusion. 
Isoflurane is less prone to cause arrhythmia compared to 
halothane. It is with good cardiovascular stability, low blood 
solubility, and suitable for hepatic patients as it is resistant 
to hepatic metabolism.
5.3.6 Sevoflurane
It is one of the newest, noninflammable, and nonexplosive 
inhalation anesthetic. The anesthetic induction, recovery 
and intraoperative modulation of anesthetic depths of sevo-
flurane is faster than halothane and isoflurane. It is more 
expensive than halothane and isoflurane, but it is getting 
less expensive. Sevoflurane is less potent than halothane 
or isoflurane, but more potent than desflurane. MAC in 
dogs is 2.3% and 2.61% in cats. Sevoflurane induces dose-  
dependent cardiovascular depression to a degree similar to 
that of isoflurane. Analgesic property is minimal.
5.3.7 Desflurane
It is one of the newest, highly volatile, and less soluble in -
halation anesthetic. Cardiovascular effects of desflurane are 
similar with those of isoflurane ( Kleinsasser et  al., 2000). 
It has lower blood/gas partition coefficient than other inhal-
ants mentioned above, so control of anesthetic depth is the 
quickest among the volatile agents in veterinary practice 
(Dos et al., 2000). It has the least potency among the volatile 
anesthetics (MAC 7%–10% in canines). It is expensive as 
sevoflurane and requires electronically controlled vaporizer 
as it is boils at room temperature. Concentration of 12%–
18% for induction and 8%–10% for maintenance is required.
5.4 Local and regional anesthesia
Equipment:
Syringes: 0.2–10 mL as required.
Needle: 22–25 G needle.
Different types of local and regional anesthesia:
1. General tissue infiltration : It is also called field block 
where nerve endings are blocked by directly injecting or 
around into the incision or wound site.
2. Oral/Dental block: Excessive mouth opening must be 
avoided in cats to avoid impaired blood flow to cere -
brum to cause neurologic deficits or blindness.
Auriculopalpebral nerve block: Needle must be inserted 
subfacially over the midpoint of posterior third of zygo-
matic arch. 2–5 mL of local anesthetic required for dog.
Retrobulba nerve block: Special curved needle for retro-
bulba nerve block must be inserted through the lateral can-
thus of the eye. 3–5 mL of local anesthetic required for dog.
Maxillary nerve block : Needle is inserted in line 
with the eye just below the zygomatic arch and directed 
toward the pterygopalatine fossa to inject 2–4 mL of 2% 
local anesthetic.
Mandibulo-alveolar nerve block : The needle is in -
serted medial and parallel to the long axis of sixth molar 
with the points inclined toward mandible.
Infraorbital nerve block : The upper lip is lifted, 
and infraorbital foramen is palpated above third pre -
molar where slightly curved needle is inserted to inject 
0.5–2 mL of 2% local anesthetic.
Mental nerve block : Mental foramen is situated be -
low the first molar in dog and cat. The needle is in -
serted directly into the foramen to inject 0.5–2  mL of 
2% local anesthetic.
3. Block of thorax and thoracic limb : Needle is inserted 
caudal to proximal portion of ribs to inject 0.5–2  mL of 
2% local anesthetic per site.
4. Brachial plexus block: Needle is inserted on the axial side 
of the acromion and caudoventrally progressed to touch 
the axial side of scapula. Aspiration is done, and local an-
esthetic is injected as required (1/3 of total dose).

Anesthesia and pain management in dogs and cats   Chapter | 27  415
5. Testicular block: Needle is inserted directly to testicular 
body. Aspiration is done, and local anesthetic is injected 
as required (1/2 of total recommended dose).
6. Epidurals
Anterior epidural anesthesia.
Dog: Lumbosacral space is felt on dorsal midline 
just caudal to line drawn between highest point of iliac 
crests. 2–8 mL of local anesthetic is injected slowly.
Fossa is felt on dorsomedian, and 2.5-cm-long 22G 
needle is inserted to pass fibrous in.
Cat: Lumbosacral fossa is felt on dorsomedian 
and 2.5-cm-long 22G needle is inserted to pass fi -
brous intervertebral ligament and stopped as needle 
ceased to progress. 1  mL/2.5  kg bodyweight of local 
anesthetic is used.
Commonly used local anesthetics:
● Lignocaine hydrochloride 
It is an amide-type local anesthetic agent. It is avail-
able in aqueous form from 0.5% to 5%. It is twice potent 
than procaine. Onset of action is 10 min, and duration is 
approximately 60 min (Helbo Hensen et al., 1988).
● Mepivacaine hydrochloride
It is an amide-type local anesthetic agent. It is avail-
able from 1% to 2%. It is twice potent than procaine and 
less toxic than lignocaine. Onset of action is rapid, and 
duration is longer.
● Bupivacaine hydrochloride 
It is an amide-type long-acting local anesthetic 
agent. It is highly stable. It is available in 0.25%, 0.5%, 
0.75%, and 1%. It has longer duration of action than 
others. Onset of action is 10 min.
● Procaine hydrochloride
It is an ester-type local anesthetic agent. It is avail -
able in form of 2%. It is nonirritant in action. Onset of 
action is very fast, but duration is shorter. Adrenaline is 
used to increase the duration of action. 
6 Pain management in dogs and cats
Pain management is very important in veterinary practice. 
Alleviating pain is not only a professional obligation for the 
veterinarians but also a key contributor to successful case 
outcomes as well as enhancement of the veterinarian-client-
patient relationship.
Every types of tissue damage can be generators of pain. 
Infrequently, pain may occur in the deficiency of such caus-
ative factors. Understanding the mechanisms of pain is the 
key to its successful prevention and treatment.
A good pain management leads to:
1. a practice as one that is committed to sympathetic care;
2. optimum revival from illness, injury or surgery; and
3. improved quality of life.
Types of pain:
1. Physiologic pain : It occurs after noxious stimulation. 
It is characterized by high stimulus threshold, well-  
localized, transient and presence of somatosensations. 
2. Pathologic pain: It occurs when pain is augmented and 
sustained by molecular, cellular, and microanatomic 
changes which are jointly termed peripheral and central 
hypersensitization. Pathological pain is described by 
hyperalgesia, allodynia, expansion of the painful field 
beyond its original boundaries, and pain protracted be -
yond the expected time of inflammation and healing. In 
some conditions, genomic, phenotypic alters occur that 
cause the state known as neuropathic pain, whereby 
pain can be considered a disease of the central nervous 
system.
a. Visceral pain: Pain from deep visceral structure.
b. Non-neuropathic pain : Pain produced as conse -
quence of damage to the central nervous system.
3. Clinical pain:
a. Acute pain : Acute pain has been defined as pain 
that subsists during the expected time of inflam -
mation and trauma as well as healing after injury. 
Postoperative surgical pain is this kind of pain.
b. Chronic pain: It is defined as that which subsists be-
yond the expected duration after disease process or 
injury associated with acute pain.
7 Management of pain
As it is very important for a veterinarian to give “the re -
lief of animal pain and suffering,” it is necessary to choose 
proper management of pain (Vedpathak et al., 2009). It may 
be medicinal management or nonmedicinal management 
(Glowaski, 2002).
1. Analgesic medications:
a. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
b. Opioid pure agonists
c. Local anesthetics
d. Dissociative anesthetics
e. Alpha-2 agonists
2. Nonmedicinal management of pain:
a. Cryotherapy
b. Thermotherapy
c. Actinotherapy
d. Acupuncture
e. Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLST)
f. Transcutaneous Electrical Neuro-Stimulation (TENS)
g. Extracorporeal shock wave therapy (ESWT)
7.1 Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
NSAIDSs are mostly trusted to control moderate-to-  severe 
acute or chronic pain. The maximum cases that cause

416 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
pain have an inflammatory component. Nonsteroidal anti-  
inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are a core for management 
of chronic pain as well as for perioperative application. 
NSAIDs should be used for their central and peripheral 
effects in both canines and felines after consideration of 
hazard factors. There is no indication that any one of the 
veterinary-approved NSAIDs is connected with any greater 
or lesser occurrence or prevalence of adverse events. 
Basically, it provides analgesia by nonselective competitive 
inhibition of cyclo-oxygenase (COX-1) and COX-2 which 
reduces production of prostaglandins.
Carprofen: It is used in surgical pain at the dose rate of 
4–4.4 mg/kg by S/C, I/V , PO once/two divided dose daily 
up to 4 days.
Ketoprofen: It is used in surgical pain and chronic pain 
at the dose rate of 2 mg/kg by I/V , S/C, I/M once daily up to 
3 days and 1 mg/kg by PO once daily for 3 days.
Deracoxib: It is used in surgical pain, chronic pain, and 
dental pain at the dose rate of 3–4  mg/kg by PO once daily 
up to 7 days.
Firocoxib: It is used in surgical pain and chronic pain 
at the dose rate of 5 mg/kg by PO once daily up to 3 days.
Meloxicam: It is used in surgical pain and acute mus -
culoskeletal pain at the dose rate of 0.1  mg/kg by PO once 
daily or 4–0.2 mg/kg by S/C, I/Vly.
Robenacoxib: It is used in surgical pain and acute muscu-
loskeletal pain at the dose rate of 2 mg/kg by S/C ly once daily 
for 3 days or 1 mg/kg by PO once daily for 3 days in cats.
Etodolac: It is used in chronic pain at the dose rate of 
10–15 mg/kg by PO, S/C once daily.
7.1.1 NSAIDs for cats
Only two NSAIDs are recommended for felines: meloxi -
cam and robenacoxib. Injection form is advised while using 
meloxicam in cats, while robenacoxib can be used in cats once 
daily for 3 days after spaying, neutering, or orthopedic surgery.
7.1.2 Opioids
Opioids are the most valuable drug class for controlling 
acute pain. It plays a role in managing chronic pain also. 
Opioids can be used as a schedule drug, particularly in com-
bination with a tranquilizer or sedative (e.g., acetylproma -
zine, fentanyl, midazolam, diazepam, chlorpromazine, 
triflupromazine, etc.) when the patient’s analgesia is very 
much required. In canines, butorphanol produces limited 
somatic analgesia and very short duration of visceral or lo -
cal analgesia. Buprenorphine administered before surgery 
and throughout wound closure provided adequate analgesia 
in cats, than butorphanol. In felines, the subcutaneous route 
of opioid administration is not at all recommended. IM and 
IV routes are preferred both pre- and postoperatively in such 
patients. The oral transmucosal or buccal route of adminis-
tration for buprenorphine may also have clinical  efficacy as 
well. The individual effect of any opioid, including dura -
tion, may vary widely from patient to patient. The use of 
human commercial fentanyl patches in dogs is discouraged 
due to highly variable pharmacokinetics.
7.1.3 Local anesthetics
The choice of local anesthetics for analgesia is very much 
useful as this is the only class of drug that renders complete 
analgesia. Local anesthetics like procaine 5% have antibac-
terial activity, whereas 2% solution is bacteriostatic. The 
data in humans and animal studies reveal the predictable 
analgesic and anesthetic drug-sparing effects of local anes-
thetics also. So, local anesthetics are reported to be antimi -
crobial, immunomodulating and can diminish postoperative 
acute pain stress. They do not delay tissue healing after sur-
gery. Local anesthetics can be administered either directly 
at a simple incision site or at a specific nerve to offer anal -
gesia to a large region or area as needed. A discussion of the 
many local and regional blocks that can be utilized in dogs 
and cats is beyond the scope of these guidelines but can 
be found in several readily accessible resources, and most 
of those blocks can be readily learned by clinicians. Local 
anesthetics are considered safe than other analgesics.
7.1.4 Dissociative anesthetics
Ketamine, a dissociative anesthetic exerts significant degree 
of analgesia by blocking the phenylcyclidine site in the ion 
channel associated with N-methyl-d-aspartate (NDMA) re-
ceptor. Subanesthetic ketamine constant rate infusion (CRI) 
diminishes pain and has antihyperalgesic and antiallodynic 
effects in dogs. It is used at a dose rate of 10  mg/kg orally 
for every 8  h and 2–4  mg/kg I/Vly to control pain relief 
(Amarpal et al., 1994).
7.1.5 Alpha-2 agonists
Alpha-2 agonists like xylazine, medetomidine, etc., are ad-
ministered systematically to produce analgesia by binding 
with Alpha-2 adrenoreceptors situated in several areas like 
spinal cord and brain stem (Cullen and Reynoldson, 1993). 
Alpha-2 agonists and opioids, the two drug classes used 
together, are highly synergistic for sedation and analgesia. 
That allows low and even microdoses in combination with 
opioids to be clinically useful and minimizes the cardiovas-
cular effects. Alpha-2 agonists can produce analgesia when 
given epidurally or intrathecally also. Xylazine is used at a 
dose rate of 0.2–0.5 mg/kg I/Mly to control pain relief.
7.2 Others
1. Systemic Lidocaine
There is safety and beneficial effects of IV lidocaine 
on pain after abdominal surgery. Though IV lido -
caine is anesthetic sparing in dogs and cats, it exerts a

Anesthesia and pain management in dogs and cats   Chapter | 27  417
 pain-modifying effect in those species. The use of IV 
lidocaine in cats is contraindicated due to negative car -
diovascular effects, but successful use in clinical prac -
tice has been anecdotally reported.
2. Gabapentin
Gabapentin is an anticonvulsant with analgesic prop -
erties. Because of its efficiency and acceptability, ga -
bapentin is widely used with neuropathic and other 
maladaptive pain conditions. Using gabapentin in dogs 
and cats in DJD, chronic musculoskeletal pain is en -
couraging. It is used at a dose rate of 3–10 mg/kg orally 
for every 24 h.
3. Amantadine
Amantadine is in class of medications called adaman -
tanes. It exerts a pain-modifying effect as an N-methyl-
d-aspartate (NDMA) receptor antagonist and remains a 
drug of interest for chronic pain. Though it is not spe -
cifically for DJD, it is an adjunct to NSAIDs in dogs. It 
is used at a dose rate of 1–4 mg/kg orally for every 24 h.
4. Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs)
TCAs are the most useful medications for selective neu-
ropathic pain circumstances. In dogs, it is used for neu -
ropathic musculoskeletal pain.
5. Acetaminophen
Acetaminophen is contraindicated in cats. In dogs, it re-
vealed a pain-modifying effect in orthopedic surgery. It 
is used at a dose rate of 10–15 mg/kg orally for every 8 h.
6. Prednisolone
It is not currently used with NSAIDs. In case of pain as-
sociated with tumor and cancer associated with inflam -
mation, it is useful. It is used at a dose rate of 0.2–1 mg/
kg orally for every 12–24  h. Further tapering of initial 
dose is advised.
8 Pain management by some alternative 
solutions
Luckily, there are many other methods for dogs and cats 
which can help manage pain and extend quality of life.
8.1 Physical rehabilitation
Physical therapy is a therapy often used to help patients to 
recover from surgery or restore tissue function after an in -
jury. Similarly, there are many modalities used in animal 
physical rehabilitation that help reduce pain and inflamma-
tion to improve a pet’s comfort.
8.2 Thermal therapy
Heat and cryotherapy are such therapies which are fre -
quently used to recover circulation or reduce inflammation 
and swelling. Ice is added after surgical measures to help 
decrease pain and swelling, whereas heat can be added to 
sore muscles or stiff joints to provide circulation to the tis -
sues and joints.
8.3 Laser therapy
Laser therapy, also termed to as low-level light therapy 
or photobiomodulation, utilizes light to stimulate specific 
cells to decrease inflammation and pain connected with in -
flammation. The laser can also assist to restore damaged 
tissue by restoring function. Laser is frequently used on 
pets arthritis cases, malignant tumor patients, soft tissue 
injuries, or recovering from surgical procedures. Pets with 
neurologic diseases like intervertebral disk disease (IVDD), 
degenerative myelopathy, or DJD get benefit from laser to 
help regenerate nerve function.
8.4 Extracorporeal shockwave therapy
It employs high-energy sound waves which stimulate the 
tissue and causes a physiologic benefit. This leads to en -
dorphin release for pain management and encourages tissue 
healing. It can be successfully used for pets suffering from 
arthritis, muscle and tendon injuries, or irreparable bone 
fractures.
8.5 Therapeutic ultrasound
Therapeutic ultrasound is a device that uses low-energy 
sound waves to warm up the tissue for improving flexibility 
and promoting healing while decreasing pain and inflam -
mation. It is often used for pets with soft tissue trauma such 
as muscle and tendon strains or sprains.
8.6 Electrotherapy
TENS or transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation is a 
form of electrotherapy that is used to treat inflammation and 
acute pain. The therapy uses small electrodes that are placed 
directly on the skin over the trigger point. So it uses an elec-
trical current that is applied to a painful area to inhibit the 
sensory response to pain. Electrical stimulation can help in 
cases involving arthritis, postsurgical recovery or soft tis -
sue injuries or trauma. It helps the muscles strengthen or 
heal faster, it improves the variety of motion for the affected 
joint, it helps prevent muscle atrophy, and it helps prevent 
osteoporosis after surgery.
8.7 Pulsed electromagnetic field therapy
Pulsed electromagnetic field therapy improves the qual -
ity of life for older dogs, dogs with chronic pain and even 
young, fit dogs. Osteoarthritis is one of the most frequent 
health problems in older dogs, and many large dog breeds 
develop hip dysplasia over time. Dogs with these chronic

418 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
conditions can really benefit from pulsed electromagnetic 
field therapy. Both arthritis and hip dysplasia have been suc-
cessfully treated using PEMF for dogs. It is also used in 
arthritis, wounds, soft tissue trauma, neurologic conditions 
and postsurgical management.
8.8 Acupuncture
Acupuncture is a system that uses small needles inserted 
into specific points on the body, which cause a physiologic 
response. Dogs with arthritis, digestive problems, kid -
ney disease, hip dysplasia, epilepsy, asthma, and certain 
neurological disorders can get benefit from acupuncture. 
Acupuncture also stimulates nerves, which is beneficial 
for pets suffering from IVDD or degenerative myelopathy. 
Other pets that benefit from acupuncture are those with ar -
thritis or soft tissue injuries.
8.9 Therapeutic exercise
Therapeutic exercise is used in animal rehabilitation to help 
strengthen the weakened muscles associated with an injury 
or postoperative recovery. Arthritis causes pain in the joints 
leading to weakness in the muscles. Therapeutic exercises 
help improve strength and mobility in arthritic pets, and 
pets recovering from surgery or injury.
8.10 Hydrotherapy
Hydrotherapy uses water to help rehabilitate injuries of dog 
and to also relieve pain. It’s especially helpful for dogs who 
have conditions such as a torn ACL, hip dysplasia, degen -
erative joint disease, arthritis, or dogs who have been para-
lyzed or lost a limb. Hydrotherapy uses buoyancy, resistance, 
viscosity, and hydrostatic pressure to assist a dog move the 
injured joints they are trying to rehabilitate. Swimming in 
warm circulating water or walking on an underwater tread-
mill provides buoyancy while reducing pain on injured joints.
8.11 Massage
Massage and manual therapies are used to alleviate taut 
muscles and augment circulation to the tissues. Massage 
brings blood flow to the tissue, providing oxygen and nu -
trients to the area. It can reduce pain by decreasing mus -
cle spasms as well as improving the flexibility of joints. 
Massage can also decrease stress and anxiety.

Anesthesia and pain management in dogs and cats   Chapter | 27  419
