Chapter 28
Drugs in therapeutic application of dogs 
and cats
1 Introduction
Animals have played a significant role in the lives of humans 
throughout history. Primitive people discovered that the rela-
tionship between humans and animals is very essential for the 
survival of both, and keeping pets was a common practice in 
hunter-gathering societies. The domestication of animals be-
gan over 12,000 years ago and continues as animals and hu-
mans coexist, interact, and influence each other (Jorgenson, 
1997). Dogs and cats are companion animals and people keep 
them as their pets. The term pet is defined as an animal kept 
for pleasure rather than utility. It is a natural phenomenon that 
animals become ill as human beings and require certain types 
of medications. The therapeutic use of drugs can limit and 
ultimately cure the disease. There are many classes of drugs 
that are used in companion animals for the treatment of vari-
ous kinds of diseases (Wayne et al., 2011).
A chemical substance used for treatment, therapy, pre -
vention, cure, mitigation, or diagnosis of various diseases 
that have understood biological effects on the body of ani -
mals or humans is termed a drug. The use of drugs is for a 
limited duration or can be used for a prolonged period as in 
the case of chronic diseases. These are generally taken to 
mitigate the symptoms of sickness or used for a prophylactic 
purpose (Karaman, 2015). The positive biological action of 
a drug is produced when it interacts with the physiological 
processes undergoing the body of animals which may be 
normal or abnormal. The purpose of drug administration is 
to treat diseases that may be of infectious origin, or noninfec-
tious origin, or to alleviate pain, anesthesia, and pregnancy 
prevention (Wayne et al., 2011). The abnormal pathophysi-
ological conditions affecting the part or whole body of ani-
mals are defined as a disease associated with certain types of 
signs and symptoms, which may be clinical and subclinical, 
and to laboratory findings (Karaman, 2015).
There are different ways to classify therapeutic agents 
and classes namely based on their chemical structure, how it 
interacts with the pathophysiological conditions, their mode 
of action, or the source from which these are obtained (Lees 
et al., 1991). There are many classes of drugs used in dogs 
and cats to treat various infections caused by pathogens in-
cluding parasites. The therapeutic application of drugs is 
essential because it is the amount of dose that determines 
toxicity or therapy (Karaman, 2015).
2 Therapeutic applications of drugs
The effect of drugs depends upon their absorption into the 
body of the animals. The different methods for introduc -
ing drugs into the body have important implications for the 
effect of drugs, the risk of dependence, and health risks. 
The same dose of drugs has varying absorption rates for 
different routes of administration and has different meta -
bolic rates depending on the site of absorption (Strang et al., 
1998). The routes by which drugs are administered have an 
impact on their bioavailability and their pharmacological 
potency. Each route is also associated with complications 
distinct from its pharmacological effects. The most com -
mon routes include the enteral route (involving the gastro -
intestinal tract of the animals), the parenteral route (other 
than GIT such as intravenous, intramuscular, and intraperi-
toneal), inhalation, and topical (Lees et al., 1991). Drugs are 
formulated according to the route of administration, namely 
tablets, injections, creams, lotions, drops, and nebulizers. 
Every route has some advantages and disadvantages over 
the other route and affects the bioavailability of the admin-
istered drug (Strang et al., 1998).
2.1 Challenges and benefits of different routes 
of drug administration
(i) Oral route (enteral route) is the natural route of drug ad-
ministration that is the most convenient, cheapest, and most 
used route. Its advantages include the onset of the action

422 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
of the drug being slow, but the effect is more prolonged, 
and the drug is absorbed well, easily, and safely to admin -
ister drugs through this route ( Strang et al., 1998 ). While 
the disadvantages include the destruction of the drugs by 
the digestive enzymes, the drug may be an irritant to the 
gastric mucosa and not absorbed well, and not being practi-
cal in unconscious and uncooperative animals such as dogs 
and cats. (ii) Rectal administration of drugs (suppositories 
or enema) bypasses the liver and reduces the first pass ef -
fect. It is also useful in unconscious animals. (iii) Vaginal 
and urethral administration of drugs mostly have local ef -
fects (Lees et al., 1991). (iv) Topical administration of drugs 
(ointments, creams, pastes, and lotions) is slowly absorbed 
through the skin via sebaceous glands. These are for local 
effect and may irritate the animals. (v) Parenteral route (ad-
ministration of drugs via injections) has a rapid onset of 
action, easy to administer, and has no degradation of drugs 
by the digestive enzymes. Its drawback is that there is no 
reversal of the wrong drug administered by this route, and 
the bioavailability of the drug is 100%. Irritant drugs can 
be given by intravenous injections ( Lippert et  al., 1993 ). 
The intramuscular route is also an important parenteral 
route of drug administration that is employed commonly. 
Absorption of the drug through this route is uniform. Its 
disadvantage is pain at the injection site for certain drugs. 
Through the subcutaneous route, nonirritant drugs are ad -
ministered. Absorption of the drug is slow but uniform as 
in the case of I.M. injection. Some other routes used for 
the administration of injection in small animals include epi-
dural, intrathecal, intradermic, and subconjunctival injec -
tion (Karaman, 2015).
3 Drugs used for the treatment of 
diseases in dogs and cats
Antimicrobial drugs are used to prevent and treat infections 
caused by bacteria and to improve the well-being of ani -
mals. These medicines are the most effective agents avail -
able in current modern medicine. However, the availability 
and misuse of drugs lead to the development of resistance 
and bacterial susceptibility is decreased with time. The sus-
ceptibility of microorganisms is different for different drugs. 
The mode of resistance can be either intrinsic or acquired 
through different means of genetics. Drugs are also used to 
treat infections caused by microorganisms such as parasites 
(Ghubash, 2006). One of the most common reasons for the 
owners of dogs and cats to seek veterinary hospitals is pain. 
Pain is defined as an emotional and unpleasant experience 
associated with potential or actual tissue damage. There are 
many drugs available on the market to treat pain. The most 
common pain killers are steroidal and nonsteroidal anti-
inflammatory drugs such as dexamethasone, prednisolone, 
flunixin meglumine, meloxicam, piroxicam, etc. ( Mclean, 
2018). However, in cats, only meloxicam is the Food and 
Drug Development Authority (FDA)-approved drug used 
for the treatment of pain. Many steroidal and nonsteroidal 
drugs are contraindicated in cats. Therefore, the correct 
use of these drugs is very important in the feline family 
(Morley et al., 2005 ). Following are the different types of 
drugs discussed below against different pathogenic organ -
isms (Table 1).
3.1 Use of antibiotics
The most active therapeutic agents among drugs are anti -
biotics. The therapeutic effects of antibiotics are due to the 
suppression and limitation of the growth of bacteria. The 
use of antibiotics in animals helped in the therapy of dis -
eases and has a role in lowering the number of morbidity 
and mortality. In animals, antibiotics interact in different 
ways to stop the growth of bacteria ( Weese et  al., 2011). 
The mode of action of antibiotics includes (i) inhibiting the 
synthesis of the bacterial cell wall (e.g., β-lactam and van-
comycin antibiotics), (ii) inhibiting the synthesis of protein 
(e.g., tetracycline, chloramphenicol, aminoglycoside, and 
macrolides), and (iii) inhibiting the synthesis of DNA (e.g., 
sulfonamide and fluoroquinolones) (Karaman, 2015).
Many antibiotics are considered safe, but side effects 
can occur with the administration of any antibiotics, and in 
some cases, can lead to life-threatening conditions. The use 
of improper drugs in the therapy and treatment of sick dogs 
and cats can lead to failure of the treatment such as failure to 
mitigate infection, public health issues (development of an-
timicrobial resistance), regulatory (antimicrobial use), and 
economic (repeated and prolonged treatment is required) 
concerns (Weese et al., 2011). Therefore, proper administra-
tion of drugs is very essential to prevent the development of 
drug resistance. Antibiotic resistance is increasing in devel-
oping countries because of its misuse. The microorganisms 
mutate to develop the structure and bypass the effects of an-
tibiotics so that they can survive within the host. Some ex -
amples of antibiotic resistance include methicillin-resistant  
Staphylococcus aureus  (MRSA), penicillin-resistant 
Enterococcus, and multidrug-resistant Mycobacterium tu -
berculosis (MDR-TB) (Prescott et al., 2002).
Many antibiotics are contraindicated in cats such as 
aminoglycoside (gentamycin, vancomycin, streptomycin, 
kanamycin, tobramycin, etc.) These drugs interact with the 
normal physiology of cats and cause toxicity. Cats lack an 
enzyme named glucuronyl transferase which is important 
for glucuronidation (Luiz and Heseltine, 2008 ). Therefore, 
the reaction may be up to a hundred times slower in cats 
than in other animals. In other species, drugs that are ex -
creted as a conjugate of glucuronide include aspirin, ben -
zoic acids, acetaminophen, and hexachlorophene. These 
drugs have a prolonged half-life in cats as compared to their 
half-life in other species. Other contraindicated drugs in cats 
include opiate derivatives (e.g., morphine),  tetracycline,

3.2 Antiviral treatment
Viruses are obligate intracellular pathogens that can mul -
tiply within the host by using the biochemical machinery 
of the victim cell during replication. Antiviral drugs inter -
fere with the events of viruses such as during replication, 
including attachment, uncoating, assembly, and synthesis 
of macromolecules directed by viruses (Pozzo et al., 2014). 
Antiviral drugs are not commonly used in animals includ -
ing humans as compared to antibiotics. For the development 
of antiviral drugs, the recognition of specific targets of vi -
ruses is essential with lower or no side effects. Currently 
in veterinary medicine, only one antiviral drug is licensed 
for use in animals, namely feline interferon-omega (which 
works by stimulating the host immune system against vi -
ruses). However, many antiviral drugs licensed for humans 
are also used in animals, e.g., trifluridine, idoxuridine, and 
acyclovir, for members of the feline family suffering from 
an ocular infection caused by feline herpesvirus 1 or zid -
ovudine for the treatment of feline immunodeficiency virus 
(Sykes and Papich, 2013).
Feline herpesvirus 1 is responsible for acute ocular 
disease in cats. Despite a large number of antiviral drugs 
available on the market, only a few drugs are used for the 
treatment of viral infections in cats only. Ganciclovir, penci-
clovir, and acyclovir are acyclic nucleoside analogs and act 
as competitive inhibitors of deoxynucleoside triphosphate. 
The ophthalmic ointment of 0.5% acyclovir is effective for 
the treatment of ocular infections in felids. The oral admin-
istration of synthetic antiviral compounds, namely amino 
acid l-lysine as a diet is safe in the therapy of ocular infec-
tions in cats ( Barabas et al., 2008 ). Feline retrovirus such 
as feline leukemia virus can be treated with the administra-
tion of immunomodulators. The first antiretrovirus used in 
animals is zidovudine (an analog of nucleoside that inhibits 
reverse transcriptase). In canines, the use of topical prepara-
tions of idoxuridine and trifluridine has been also reported. 
The canine parvovirus is a lethal virus that infects puppies. 
Currently, no specific treatment for this infection is avail -
able; only symptomatic therapy is given to the infected ani-
mals (Pozzo et al., 2014).
3.3 Antiparasitic drugs
Parasites are the common cause of GIT, circulatory system, 
and dermatological diseases in dogs and cats. Parasites pre-
fer to live on the skin of pets including their shelters. The 
houses where the owners kept their animals are the most 
neglected space where endoparasites and ectoparasites 
grow and molt to become infective stage parasites. These 
parasites can be spread from animals to humans which live 
in proximity to dogs and cats. These animals act as a res -
ervoir of many pathogens that are zoonotically important 
and are a threat to public health ( Curtis and Curtis, 1998 ). 
Therefore, the prevention, control, and treatment of para -
sitic infections and infestations are very important. Canine 
demodicosis is caused by demodicid mites and is a disease 
of the skin characterized by alopecia, erythema, popular 
and pustular dermatitis of the skin of canines, and folliculi-
tis due to secondary bacterial infections. The symptomatic

treatment of demodicosis includes miticidal drugs such as 
topical rotenone or benzoyl peroxide shampoos. Amitraz is 
FDA-approved drug used against mites. This drug belongs 
to the family of formamidine and is a broad-spectrum miti-
cide. This agent is the inhibitor of monoamine oxidase and 
prostaglandin synthesis (Ghubash, 2006).
Endoparasites such as nematodes, trematodes, and ces -
todes (hookworms, heartworms, etc.) are very prevalent in 
pets. The subclinical infection of these parasites can lead to 
severe anemia and ultimately dogs and cats become weak, 
dull, emaciated, and have a rough coat. These endoparasites 
feed on the content of GIT and the blood of the host. The 
blood-sucking parasites cause the animal to become anemic 
and suck a huge volume of blood on daily basis. Their mode 
of transmission is mostly through the fecal-oral route and 
requires an intermediate host to reach their infective stage. 
Dirofilariasis is a parasitic disease that affects the lungs and 
hearts of animals. Other endoparasitic diseases of dogs and 
cats include leishmaniasis, toxocariasis, and ancylostomia -
sis. These parasites can be controlled through the proper 
administration of anthelmintic drugs on a monthly basis. 
Some anthelmintic drugs include levamisole, oxfendazole, 
and albendazole.
Protozoal are the microscopic eukaryotes that are also 
responsible for the various parasitic diseases in dogs and 
cats. Some zoonotically important protozoal diseases in 
dogs and cats are toxoplasmosis (which causes abortion 
in human beings), giardiasis, babesiosis, hepatozoono -
sis, and neosporosis ( Matos et  al., 2015 ). The therapeu -
tic approach to treat these disorders is the administration 
of antiprotozoal drugs such as metronidazole, imidocarb, 
and diminazene aceturate through intramuscular injection 
(Dubey, 1992). Ivermectin is an antibiotic that also acts as 
an antiparasitic drug. It belongs to the family avermectin. Its 
mode of action is through the release and effect of GABA 
(gamma- aminobutyric acid [the peripheral neurotransmit -
ter of several parasites]). This neurotransmitter is limited 
to central nervous systems in mammals, therefore, has a 
wide margin of safety with an intact blood–brain barrier 
(Ghubash, 2006).
3.4 Antifungal drugs
Animals that are immunocompromised are at risk of fun -
gal infection. Fungi can cause severe dermatological and 
internal problems in dogs and cats. Many fungi are zoo -
notic and can spread from pets to human beings due to their 
close association with companion animals. People can ac -
quire a ringworm infection from cats. However, in the last 
two decades, the number of antifungal drug development is 
increased tremendously. The first and second generations 
of triazole drugs are developed against fungal infections 
(Rochette et al., 2003). Currently, the use of these new drugs 
is limited in veterinary practice because of their high cost. 
The number of antifungal agents available in the market is 
increased, but for the treatment of mycoses in dogs and cats, 
only a limited number of drugs are used. Amphotericin B 
is an antibiotic originally extracted from Streptococcus no-
dosus. Ergosterol is a constituent of the cell membrane of 
fungi. This drug makes micelles with fungal ergosterol and 
alters cell permeability. Its effective treatment requires intra-
venous administration because of poor absorption from the 
gastrointestinal tract. This drug is nephrotoxic, and its cause 
is not completely understood (Foy and Trepanier, 2010).
Ketoconazole (azole) is another antifungal drug used 
in animals for the treatment of fungal infections. Azoles 
are classified into imidazole or triazoles depending on the 
number of nitrogen molecules present within the azole 
ring. Triazole is used for the treatment of systemic in -
fections while imidazole is used as a topical. These are 
proven effective against mycoses. There are several other 
azole drugs available on the market such as itraconazole, 
fluconazole, clotrimazole, and voriconazole ( Rochette 
et al., 2003 ). Their mode of action is to inhibit lanosterol 
14-alpha demethylase, leading to the depletion of ergos -
terol. The noncentral nervous system infectious which is 
not life-threatening and caused by Blastomyces derma -
titidis, Histoplasma capsulatum , and Coccidioides immi -
tis can be treated with the azole group of drugs ( Foy and 
Trepanier, 2010).
Dermatophytosis is the most common condition caused 
by Microsporum canis, M. gypsium, and Trichophyton men-
tagrophytes. These fungi cause little health hazards in dogs 
and cats but are zoonotically important. Aspergillus fumiga-
tus and other Aspergillus species are responsible for canine 
nasal aspergillosis which is a local infection of the sinuses 
and nasal cavities. In dogs, dermatophytosis is treated with 
topical preparation while cats require systemic treatment 
protocol (Rochette et al., 2003).
3.5 Immunosuppressive drug therapies  
for dogs and cats
The immune system of the organisms protects them from 
foreign pathogens and other insults from the external en -
vironment. It comprises complex interactions between the 
immune cells of the animals and the invaders. The body’s 
immune system consists of innate and adaptive immune 
systems. The dysregulation of either the innate or adap -
tive system alone or both will result in autoimmune dis -
eases (Sykes and Papich, 2013). The causes of autoimmune 
disease include genetic factors or environmental triggers 
such as pathogens, drugs, vaccines, neoplasia, etc. Local 
or systemic inflammatory responses occur due to improper 
stimulation of the immune system that may lead to tissue 
destruction and other clinical illnesses. The most com -
mon systemic diseases in dogs and cats which have au -
toimmune causes include immune-mediated hemolytic

426 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
anemia,  immune-mediated thrombocytopenia, protein-
losing  inflammatory bowel disease, feline asthma, and  
immune-mediated polyarthritis (Viviano, 2013).
The new therapies are adapted in the veterinary prac -
tice from human medicine, and the treatment of immuno -
modulatory diseases in companion animals continues to 
evolve. Immunosuppressive drugs are used to treat auto -
immune diseases and in the management of organ trans -
plantation. The objective of the treatment is to induce 
remission of the diseases through the modulation of func -
tions of lymphocytes and inhibition of inflammation. The 
most used immunosuppressive drugs are glucocorticoids, 
cyclosporine, chlorambucil, vincristine, azathioprine, my -
cophenolate, and leflunomide ( Lees et al., 1991 ). In vet -
erinary medicine, adjunctive immunomodulatory therapy 
includes the use of human immunoglobulin and vincristine 
for the management of acute immunomodulatory diseases. 
The advantage of this therapy is that they are used initially 
for the stabilization of diseases due to its potential for a 
faster therapeutic response as well as low adverse effects 
(Viviano, 2013).
3.6 Supportive drugs used in dogs and cats
The morbidity and mortality of critically ill small animal 
patients may be reduced with nutritional support. The provi-
sion of nutrients to small animals through the enteral route is 
easy, simple, convenient, inexpensive, and physiologically 
sound. However, the condition of some animals doesn’t let 
them assimilate nutrients from the GIT temporarily. The ad-
ministration of all essential nutrients intravenously (IV) is 
termed total parenteral nutrients. It is indicated for the nutri-
tional support of critically ill patients with GIT dysfunction. 
It can be a beneficial mode of treatment for animals suffer-
ing from GIT diseases and cannot be nourished by enteral 
means (Lippert et al., 1993).
Fluid therapy is a common practice in veterinary 
medicine to correct electrolyte imbalance, dehydration, 
 hypoperfusion, and hypovolemia, to maintain osmotic 
pressure, and intravascular volume. The selection of the 
fluid for the given situation requires an understanding of 
body fluids physiology. Dehydration in dogs and cats can 
be detected by carefully taking the history of the animals 
related to fluid intake, vomiting, and diarrhea and by ex -
amining the elasticity and texture of the skin ( KuKanich, 
2013). Other ways to detect dehydration include examin -
ing the mucous membrane appearance and determining 
the packed cell volume of the organism. Urine analysis 
can also provide us with huge information about the acid–
base status of the animals including electrolyte and fluid 
status. Fluid therapy is given in three categories, viz. re -
placement, maintenance, and continuous fluid replace -
ment. The common fluids include ringer lactate, dextrose, 
and normal saline. Normal saline is indicated if the cat or 
dog is suffering from vomiting and diarrhea ( Pozzo et al., 
2014).
Fluid therapy can be administered to correct the dehy -
dration status of the animals and to maintain the concentra-
tion of salts inside the body of the affected dogs and cats. 
Seizures and tetany may lead to hypoglycemia and require 
a treatment that supplements the missing amount of calcium 
in the body. For this purpose, 10% calcium gluconate is rec-
ommended. If there is asymptomatic hypocalcemia, then 
calcium gluconate is not recommended because the precipi-
tation of calcium oxalate in the tissue may increase with it 
(Luiz and Heseltine, 2008).
Supportive therapy is also given to those dogs and cats 
who are suffered from intoxication. The most common 
toxic agent includes anticoagulant rodenticides, chocolates, 
ethylene glycol, metaldehyde, and marijuana. The decon -
taminated strategies for orally ingested toxins include in -
duction of emesis (by hydrogen peroxide), fluid therapy, 
administration of charcoal, gastric lavage, and antidote ad -
ministration for specific toxic agents. For example, N-acetyl 
cysteine is an antidote for paracetamol poisoning in cats 
(Lippert et al., 1993) (Fig. 1).

4 Conclusion
Antimicrobial drugs are used to stop the growth of bacteria 
that cause diseases in animals. The therapeutic effect of med-
icine depends on the dose rate of the drug administered and 
the route of drug administration. In dogs and cats, the paren-
teral route is the commonly used route for the administration 
of drugs because these animals are uncooperative with the 
treatment. There are many preparations of drugs available in 
the market used against a wide range of pathogenic organ -
isms that cause diseases. However, in veterinary medicine, 
only a limited number of formulations of drugs are approved, 
and veterinarians mostly use those drugs formulated for hu-
man beings in cats and dogs. In cats, certain drugs are contra-
indicated and cannot be used because of toxicity, while dogs 
have a huge margin of safety. In veterinary medicine, antivi-
ral drugs are only used in cats, and no specific antiviral drug 
is available that is formulated for use in dogs.

The author wishes to thank all other coauthors for providing guidance 
and support.

Chapter 29
Nutritional and metabolic diseases  
of dogs and cats
1 Overview of nutritional and 
metabolic diseases in dogs and cats
Nutritional and metabolic diseases in dogs and cats refer to a 
group of disorders that result from imbalances in the intake or 
utilization of nutrients. These diseases can have a significant 
impact on the health and welfare of pets and can be caused 
by a variety of factors, including genetics, diet, and lifestyle.
1.1 Epidemiology and prevalence
Nutritional and metabolic diseases pose a substantial con -
cern for both dogs and cats, albeit some diseases are more 
widespread in one species than others. Obesity is the most 
frequently encountered nutritional disease in dogs, with a 
staggering 30%–60% of dogs in the United States estimated 
to be afflicted (Lund et al., 2016). Likewise, obesity is a criti-
cal issue in cats, with estimates indicating that 25%–50% of 
felines are either overweight or obese (Scarlett et al., 1994). 
In addition to obesity, both species are susceptible to an array 
of other common nutritional and metabolic diseases, includ-
ing diabetes, pancreatitis, liver disease, kidney disease, and 
various forms of malnutrition. The prevalence of these dis-
eases can vary significantly based on a multitude of factors, 
including breed, age, and dietary composition. Consequently, 
it is vital to recognize the underlying determinants of these 
diseases to accurately diagnose and treat affected animals, as 
well as implementing appropriate measures for prevention.
1.2 Common nutritional and metabolic diseases 
in dogs and cats
1.2.1 Obesity
Obesity is an increasing problem in both dogs and cats, 
with studies indicating that up to 50% of dogs and cats are 
overweight or obese. Obesity is linked to a range of health 
problems in both species, including diabetes, heart disease, 
joint problems, and decreased life expectancy.
Causes of obesity
Obesity in dogs and cats is primarily caused by an imbal -
ance between energy intake and energy expenditure. In 
other words, animals consume more calories than they burn 
through activity and metabolic processes. Several factors 
contribute to this imbalance, including genetics, diet, and 
lifestyle. Genetics play a role in determining an animal’s 
body weight and propensity to gain weight. Certain breeds 
of dogs, such as Labradors, are more likely to become obese 
than others, even when fed the same diet and given the same 
level of exercise. Studies have identified genetic variations 
in several genes involved in energy metabolism that may 
predispose dogs to obesity. Diet is a significant contribu -
tor to obesity in dogs and cats. The quality, quantity, and 
frequency of food intake all play a role in energy balance. 
High-fat diets, high-carbohydrate diets, and free-choice 
feeding (allowing animals to eat as much as they want) have 
all been linked to obesity in both species. Lifestyle factors, 
such as lack of exercise, also contribute to obesity in dogs 
and cats. Animals that are sedentary or live-in environments 
with limited opportunities for physical activity are more 
likely to become overweight or obese. Obesity has signifi -
cant health consequences for both dogs and cats shown in 
Fig. 1. In addition to reducing life expectancy, obesity in -
creases the risk of a range of health problems, including:
1. Diabetes: Obese animals are at a higher risk of develop-
ing diabetes, which can lead to a range of complications, 
including blindness, kidney failure, and nerve damage.
2. Cardiovascular disease: Obesity increases the risk of 
heart disease and hypertension, which can lead to heart 
failure, stroke, and other cardiovascular problems.
3. Joint problems: Excess weight puts extra stress on the 
joints, leading to arthritis and other joint problems.

430 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
4. Respiratory problems: Obese animals are at a higher 
risk of respiratory problems, including asthma and other 
breathing difficulties.
5. Reduced immune function: Obesity can impair immune 
function, making animals more susceptible to infections 
and other health problems.
Management of obesity
The management of obesity in dogs and cats involves a 
range of strategies, including dietary modifications, exer -
cise, and behavioral interventions. Dietary modifications 
involve reducing calorie intake while maintaining nutrient 
balance. Commercial weight loss diets for dogs and cats 
are available that provide reduced calorie intake while en -
suring adequate nutrient intake. These diets are often high 
in protein and fiber, which can help promote satiety and 
reduce hunger. Exercise is also an essential component of 
managing obesity in dogs and cats. Regular exercise can 
help burn excess calories and improve metabolic function. 
However, exercise must be tailored to the animal’s individ-
ual needs and abilities to prevent injury and ensure success. 
Behavioral interventions, such as modifying feeding habits 
and reducing food rewards, can also be effective in manag-
ing obesity in dogs and cats. These interventions focus on 
changing the animal’s behavior and relationship with food, 
rather than simply reducing calorie intake.
Recent scientific findings
Cutting-edge research has revealed new insights into the 
origins and ramifications of obesity in both dogs and cats. 
For instance, a recent study discovered that obesity in cats 
is associated with modifications in the gut microbiome, 
which may contribute to metabolic dysfunction and insulin 
resistance (Li et al., 2020). The study suggests that targeted 
dietary interventions, such as the use of prebiotics and pro-
biotics, may help enhance the gut microbiome and mitigate 
the risk of obesity-related metabolic dysfunction. Similarly, 
a recent study evaluated the efficacy of a weight loss pro -
gram for overweight dogs and found that a combination of a 
high-protein, high-fiber diet and increased physical activity 
was successful in inducing weight loss and improving meta-
bolic function ( German et al., 2018 ). The study also high -
lighted the potential benefits of personalized weight loss 
FIG. 1 Common consequences of obesity in dogs and cats.

Nutritional and metabolic diseases of dogs and cats   Chapter | 29  431
plans over standardized approaches. Additionally, a recent 
literature review revealed that the utilization of noninvasive 
technologies such as activity trackers and body condition 
scoring systems can be helpful in managing obesity in dogs 
and cats (German et al., 2018). These innovative technolo-
gies can aid veterinary professionals and pet owners in 
tracking progress and adapting management strategies as 
required.
1.3 Diabetes mellitus
Diabetes mellitus (DM) is a metabolic disease that affects 
both dogs and cats. DM is characterized by hyperglycemia, 
due to the inability of the body to regulate blood glucose 
levels. This is caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of the 
hormone insulin, which is responsible for glucose regula -
tion in the body. DM is a complex and multifactorial disease 
that can have a significant impact on the health and well-
being of animals.
1.3.1 Overview of diabetes mellitus
DM is a common metabolic disorder in dogs and cats. The 
prevalence of DM in dogs is estimated to be around 0.5% 
to 1%, while in cats, it is estimated to be around 0.5% to 
2% (Zini et al., 2020). In both species, DM is characterized 
by hyperglycemia, which can lead to a wide range of clini -
cal signs, including polyuria, polydipsia, weight loss, and 
decreased appetite. If left untreated, DM can lead to serious 
complications, including diabetic ketoacidosis, blindness, 
neuropathy, and even death ( Fig.  2). There are two main 
types of DM in dogs and cats: type 1 and type 2. Type 1 
DM is caused by an absolute deficiency of insulin, while 
type 2 DM is caused by insulin resistance or a relative de -
ficiency of insulin. Type 1 DM is more common in dogs, 
while type 2 DM is more common in cats ( Mellanby and 
Herrtage, 2017).
1.3.2 Recent findings on nutritional and 
metabolic diseases with diabetes mellitus
Nutritional and metabolic diseases are closely related to 
the development and management of DM in dogs and cats. 
Recent scientific literature has focused on the role of nutrition 
in the prevention and management of DM in dogs and cats, 
as well as the metabolic changes associated with the disease.
1.3.3 Nutrition and diabetes mellitus
Nutrition plays a crucial role in the prevention and manage-
ment of DM in dogs and cats. Several studies have shown 
that dietary changes can significantly affect blood glucose 
levels and insulin sensitivity in both species (Graham et al., 
2020). A recent study by Zhou et al. (2021) investigated the 
effects of a low-carbohydrate, high-protein diet on glycemic 
control and insulin sensitivity in dogs with DM. The study 
found that the diet significantly improved glycemic control 
and insulin sensitivity in the dogs, leading to reduced insulin 
requirements and improved clinical signs. In cats, nutritional 
management is more challenging due to their obligatory car-
nivore status. However, several studies have shown that low-
carbohydrate, high-protein diets can be beneficial for cats 
with DM (Mazzaferro et al., 2018). A recent study by Martin 
et al. (2021) investigated the effects of a low-carbohydrate, 
high-protein diet on glucose metabolism in cats with DM. 
The study found that the diet significantly improved glucose 
metabolism and insulin sensitivity in the cats.
1.3.4 Metabolic changes in diabetes mellitus
DM is associated with significant metabolic changes in both 
dogs and cats. One of the key metabolic changes is the de -
velopment of insulin resistance, which can lead to hyper -
glycemia and other complications. A recent study by Savas 
et  al. (2021)  investigated the metabolic changes in dogs 
with DM using untargeted metabolomics. The study found 
that dogs with DM had altered levels of several metabolites, 
including amino acids, lipids, and energy metabolites.
In cats, DM is also associated with significant metabolic 
changes, including altered lipid metabolism and inflamma-
tion (Liang et al., 2021). A recent study by Zini et al. (2020) 
investigated the relationship between metabolic changes 
and clinical signs in cats with DM. The study found that 
cats with DM had altered lipid metabolism and increased 
markers of inflammation, which were associated with the 
severity of clinical signs.
1.3.5 Management of diabetes mellitus
The management of DM in dogs and cats involves a multi -
faceted approach that includes nutritional management, in -
sulin therapy, and lifestyle modifications. Recent scientific 
literature has focused on the efficacy and safety of different 
management strategies in both species.
FIG. 2 Common signs of diabetes mellitus in dogs and cats.

432 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
1.3.6 Insulin therapy
Insulin therapy is the cornerstone of DM management in 
both dogs and cats. Several types of insulin are available 
for use in animals, including human recombinant insulin 
and insulin analogs ( Feldman and Nelson, 2019 ). A recent 
study by Juvet et  al. (2020)  investigated the efficacy and 
safety of insulin degludec, a long-acting insulin analog, in 
cats with DM. The study found that insulin degludec was 
effective in controlling blood glucose levels in cats and was 
well-tolerated.
1.3.7 Lifestyle modifications
Lifestyle modifications, such as exercise and weight man -
agement, can also have a significant impact on the manage-
ment of DM in dogs and cats. A recent study by Hess et al. 
(2020) investigated the effects of weight loss on glycemic 
control in obese cats with DM. The study found that weight 
loss improved glycemic control in the cats, leading to re -
duced insulin requirements and improved clinical signs.
1.4 Kidney disease
Kidney disease is a common condition in dogs and cats, and 
it can have various causes such as aging, diet, infections, 
toxins, and genetic predisposition. The kidneys are respon-
sible for filtering the blood and removing waste products 
and excess water from the body. When the kidneys fail to 
function properly, waste products and toxins accumulate 
in the bloodstream, leading to a range of clinical signs and 
complications. Nutritional management is an essential com-
ponent of the treatment and prevention of kidney disease in 
pets, and recent research has shed light on the role of vari -
ous nutrients and feeding strategies in improving outcomes. 
Common symptoms of chronic kidney failure in dogs and 
cats given in Fig. 3.
One of the main goals of nutritional therapy in pets with 
kidney disease is to reduce the workload on the kidneys and 
minimize the accumulation of waste products in the body. 
This can be achieved by restricting the intake of protein, 
phosphorus, and sodium, which are the primary nutrients 
that the kidneys must eliminate from the body. According 
to a recent study by Dimski et al. (2021), dogs with chronic 
kidney disease (CKD) who were fed a moderate protein, 
low phosphorus, and low sodium diet had lower serum cre-
atinine and urea nitrogen concentrations compared to those 
fed a high protein, high phosphorus, and high sodium diet. 
Similarly, a study by Lulich et  al. (2019)  found that cats 
with CKD who were fed a diet with reduced phosphorus 
and sodium had better survival rates and lower progres -
sion of kidney disease compared to those fed a control diet. 
Another important aspect of nutritional management in pets 
with kidney disease is to provide adequate energy and es -
sential nutrients, while avoiding excesses that could further 
burden the kidneys. Several studies have investigated the 
use of specialized renal diets that are formulated to meet 
these requirements. For example, a study by Jacob et  al. 
(2019) compared the nutritional value of various commer -
cial renal diets for cats and found that most of them met or 
exceeded the recommended nutrient profiles for adult cats, 
with the exception of vitamin D, which was often below the 
minimum requirement. Another study by Ghibaudo et  al. 
(2020) evaluated the palatability and digestibility of a novel 
renal diet for dogs, which was found to be well accepted 
FIG. 3 Common symptoms of chronic kidney failure in dogs and cats.

Nutritional and metabolic diseases of dogs and cats   Chapter | 29  433
and associated with improved stool quality and nutrient 
digestibility compared to a control diet. In addition to nu -
trient composition, the form and frequency of feeding can 
also affect the nutritional status and clinical outcomes of 
pets with kidney disease. For example, several studies have 
suggested that frequent small meals may be better tolerated 
and more beneficial than larger meals in pets with CKD. A 
study by Osborne et al. (2019)  found that dogs with CKD 
who were fed three small meals per day had better blood 
pressure control and lower serum phosphate concentrations 
compared to those fed one or two larger meals. Similarly, a 
study by Elliott et al. (2017) found that cats with CKD who 
were fed multiple small meals throughout the day had bet -
ter body condition and appetite compared to those fed two 
larger meals.
1.5 Inflammatory bowel disease
Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic gastro -
intestinal disorder that is commonly diagnosed in dogs 
and cats. The disease is characterized by inflammation of 
the small and large intestines, which can result in clini -
cal signs such as vomiting, diarrhea, and weight loss. The 
etiology of IBD is multifactorial and is thought to involve 
interactions between genetic, environmental, and immu -
nologic factors.
1.5.1 Pathophysiology
The pathophysiology of IBD in dogs and cats is complex 
and not fully understood. It is thought to involve a dysregu-
lation of the immune system, with an exaggerated response 
to normal gut bacteria and antigens. This leads to the activa-
tion of inflammatory cells, including lymphocytes, plasma 
cells, and macrophages, which release pro-inflammatory 
cytokines such as tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF- α), 
interleukin-1 (IL-1), and interleukin-6 (IL-6) ( Makielski 
et al., 2016). Recent research has also suggested a role for 
the gut microbiome in the development of IBD. The gut mi-
crobiome is a complex ecosystem of microorganisms that 
plays a critical role in maintaining gut health. Dysbiosis, or 
an imbalance in the gut microbiome, has been associated 
with IBD in both dogs and cats ( Suchodolski et al., 2015 ). 
In addition, studies have shown that dogs with IBD have a 
lower diversity of gut bacteria, and that changes in the gut 
microbiome may be associated with disease severity and 
response to treatment (Hooda et al., 2016). Genetic factors 
may also play a role in the development of IBD in dogs 
and cats. Several genes have been identified as potential 
risk factors for IBD, including those involved in immune 
system regulation and the response to bacterial antigens 
(Makielski et al., 2016 ). However, the exact genetic mech-
anisms underlying IBD in dogs and cats are still not fully 
understood.
1.5.2 Nutrition and diet
The role of nutrition and diet in the management of IBD in 
dogs and cats is an area of active research. Several dietary 
factors have been implicated in the development of IBD, 
including high carbohydrate and low-fiber diets, as well as 
certain protein sources ( Allenspach et al., 2016 ). In addi -
tion, dietary fat has been shown to play a role in the devel -
opment of IBD, with high levels of saturated and trans fats 
thought to contribute to the disease ( Simpson et al., 2018). 
Several studies have also investigated the use of specialized 
diets in the management of IBD in dogs and cats. These 
diets are designed to reduce inflammation and provide nu -
trients that support gut health. For example, diets that are 
high in fiber, low in fat, and contain prebiotics and probiot-
ics have been shown to be beneficial in the management 
of IBD in dogs and cats ( Allenspach et al., 2016 ; Simpson 
et  al., 2018 ). In addition to specialized diets, nutritional 
supplementation may also be beneficial in the management 
of IBD. Omega-3 fatty acids, for example, have been shown 
to have antiinflammatory properties and may be helpful in 
reducing inflammation in the gut (Lenox et al., 2020). Other 
nutritional supplements, such as antioxidants and vitamin 
D, have also been investigated for their potential role in the 
management of IBD in dogs and cats (Gagne et al., 2020).
1.5.3 Diagnosis
Diagnosis of IBD in dogs and cats requires a combination 
of clinical signs, laboratory tests, and diagnostic imaging. 
Clinical signs such as vomiting, diarrhea, and weight loss 
are common in dogs and cats with IBD (Table 1). Laboratory 
tests may include a complete blood count, serum biochem -
istry, and fecal examination for parasites and bacteria. 
Diagnostic imaging, such as abdominal ultrasound or endos-
copy with biopsy, may be necessary to confirm a diagnosis 
of IBD and to assess the severity of the disease (Allenspach 
et al., 2016). Recent research has also investigated the use of 
novel diagnostic tools for the diagnosis of IBD in dogs and 
cats. For example, fecal calprotectin, a marker of inflamma-
tion, has been shown to be a sensitive and specific test for 
the diagnosis of IBD in dogs (Pierini et al., 2018). Other bio-
markers, such as serum amyloid A and C-reactive protein, 
have also been investigated as potential diagnostic tools for 
IBD in dogs and cats (Gagne et al., 2020).
1.5.4 Treatment
Treatment of IBD in dogs and cats is focused on reduc -
ing inflammation in the gut, managing clinical signs, and 
supporting overall health. Treatment options may include 
dietary modifications, nutritional supplementation, medi -
cations, and in some cases, surgery. Dietary modifica -
tions are an important component of the management of 
IBD in dogs and cats. Specialized diets that are high in 
fiber, low in fat, and contain prebiotics and probiotics have

434 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
been shown to be effective in reducing inflammation and 
managing clinical signs of IBD ( Allenspach et al., 2016 ; 
Simpson et al., 2018).
Nutritional supplementation may also be beneficial in 
the management of IBD in dogs and cats. Omega-3 fatty ac-
ids, for example, have been shown to have antiinflammatory 
properties and may be helpful in reducing inflammation in 
the gut (Lenox et al., 2020). Other nutritional supplements, 
such as antioxidants and vitamin D, have also been investi-
gated for their potential role in the management of IBD in 
dogs and cats (Gagne et al., 2020).
Medications may also be necessary in the management 
of IBD in dogs and cats. Corticosteroids, immunosuppres -
sive drugs, and antibiotics are commonly used to reduce 
inflammation and manage clinical signs of IBD. However, 
these medications may have side effects and should be used 
with caution (Allenspach et al., 2016).
In some cases, surgery may be necessary to manage IBD 
in dogs and cats. Surgical options may include removal of 
the affected segment of the intestine or placement of a feed-
ing tube to bypass the affected area of the gut ( Allenspach 
et al., 2016).
1.6 Pancreatitis
Pancreatitis is a common inflammatory disease of the pan -
creas in dogs and cats that can result in a wide range of 
clinical signs, from mild gastrointestinal upset to severe 
systemic illness. Nutritional and metabolic factors play a 
critical role in the development and management of pancre-
atitis in dogs and cats. Some other factors associated with 
the development of pancreatitis in dogs and cats given in

1.6.1 Pathophysiology
The pathophysiology of pancreatitis in dogs and cats is 
complex and multifactorial. The disease is characterized 
by the activation of digestive enzymes within the pancreas, 
which leads to inflammation and tissue damage. This pro -
cess can be triggered by a variety of factors, including di -
etary indiscretion, obesity, endocrine disease, and genetic 
predisposition ( Watson et  al., 2020). Recent research has 
shed light on the pathophysiology of pancreatitis in dogs 
and cats. For example, it has been shown that obesity is a 
significant risk factor for the development of pancreatitis in 
dogs and cats, likely due to the release of pro-inflammatory 
cytokines and oxidative stress associated with excess adi -
pose tissue (Watson et al., 2020). Other studies have inves-
tigated the role of endotoxemia, bacterial translocation, and 
the gut microbiome in the development and progression of 
pancreatitis in dogs and cats (Tecles et al., 2019).
1.6.2 Nutrition and pancreatitis
Nutrition plays a critical role in the management of pan -
creatitis in dogs and cats. Dietary modifications can help 
reduce inflammation, manage clinical signs, and prevent 
future episodes of the disease. However, there is no single 
diet that is appropriate for all dogs and cats with pancre -
atitis, as nutritional requirements vary based on the sever -
ity and stage of the disease. In general, dogs and cats with 
pancreatitis benefit from a low-fat, highly digestible diet 
that is easy on the gastrointestinal system. This may involve 
feeding a prescription diet that is specifically designed for 
dogs and cats with pancreatitis or feeding a home-cooked 
diet that is low in fat and rich in protein and complex car -
bohydrates ( Simpson et  al., 2018 ). Recent research has 
also investigated the role of specific nutrients and dietary 
components in the management of pancreatitis in dogs and 
cats. For example, omega-3 fatty acids, which have anti -
inflammatory properties, may be beneficial in reducing in -
flammation in the pancreas and improving clinical signs of 
pancreatitis (Watson et al., 2020 ). Other nutrients, such as 
vitamin E and vitamin D, have also been investigated for 
their potential role in the management of pancreatitis in 
dogs and cats (Gagne et al., 2020).
1.6.3 Management of pancreatitis
The management of pancreatitis in dogs and cats is fo -
cused on reducing inflammation, managing clinical signs, 
and preventing future episodes of the disease. Treatment 
options may include dietary modifications, nutritional 
supplementation, medications, and in some cases, sur -
gery. Dietary modifications are a critical component of the 
management of pancreatitis in dogs and cats. Feeding a 
low-fat, highly digestible diet is recommended to reduce 
inflammation and manage clinical signs of the disease. 
Nutritional supplementation with omega-3 fatty acids 
and other nutrients may also be beneficial in the manage -
ment of pancreatitis. Medications may also be necessary 
in the management of pancreatitis in dogs and cats. Pain 
management, antiemetics, and antibiotics may be used to 
manage clinical signs and prevent secondary infections. 
Primary therapies for treatment of pancreatitis in dogs and 
cats listed in Fig. 4. In severe cases of pancreatitis, hospi -
talization may be required for supportive care, including 
intravenous fluids, nutritional support, and pain manage -
ment ( Simpson et  al., 2018 ). Surgery may be necessary 
in rare cases of severe pancreatitis that do not respond to 
medical management. This may involve the removal of the 
pancreas or a portion of the pancreas, although these pro -
cedures are associated with significant risks and complica -
tions (Watson et al., 2020).
1.6.4 Recent findings
Recent research has shed light on the pathophysiology and 
management of pancreatitis in dogs and cats. For example, 
a recent study found that dogs with pancreatitis had sig -
nificantly lower levels of vitamin D compared to healthy 
control dogs, suggesting a potential role for vitamin D 
supplementation in the management of the disease ( Gagne 
et al., 2020 ). Another study investigated the use of a low-
fat, high-fiber diet in the management of pancreatitis in cats 
and found that it was effective in reducing clinical signs 
and improving overall quality of life ( Gunn-Moore et al., 
2019). Recent research has also explored the use of novel 
treatments for pancreatitis in dogs and cats. For example, a 
recent study investigated the use of stem cell therapy in the 
management of pancreatitis in dogs, and found that it was 
safe and well-tolerated, with potential benefits in reduc -
ing inflammation and improving clinical signs ( Lee et al., 
2020).
FIG. 4 Primary therapies for treatment of pancreatitis in dogs and cats.

1.7 Liver disease
Liver disease is a common condition in dogs and cats that 
can have serious consequences. The liver plays a crucial 
role in the metabolism and detoxification of various sub -
stances in the body. A variety of nutritional and metabolic 
factors can impact liver function and cause liver disease in 
dogs and cats.
1.7.1 Nutritional factors and liver disease
Dietary factors can have a significant impact on liver health 
in dogs and cats. Nutritional imbalances and deficiencies 
can lead to hepatic lipidosis, a condition in which excess 
fat accumulates in the liver. A high-fat diet, particularly one 
that is high in saturated and trans fats, has been linked to 
the development of hepatic lipidosis in cats ( Center et al., 
2018). In addition, a diet that is deficient in choline, an es -
sential nutrient for liver function, has been shown to lead to 
the development of liver disease in dogs ( Ko et al., 2021 ). 
On the other hand, a diet that is high in protein and low in 
carbohydrates has been found to have a protective effect on 
the liver. A study on the effect of a low-carbohydrate, high-
protein diet on dogs with hepatic lipidosis found that the 
diet was effective in reducing liver fat content and improv-
ing liver function ( Backus et al., 2013 ). Similarly, a high-
protein diet has been shown to improve liver function in cats 
with liver disease (Center et al., 2018).
1.7.2 Metabolic factors and liver disease
In addition to nutritional factors, various metabolic factors 
can also contribute to liver disease in dogs and cats. One 
such factor is insulin resistance, which has been linked to the 
development of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in 
dogs (Bauer et al., 2018 ). Insulin resistance can lead to an 
imbalance in lipid metabolism, resulting in the accumulation 
of fat in the liver. Similarly, obesity has been identified as a 
significant risk factor for the development of liver disease 
in both dogs and cats. In one study, obese dogs were found 
to have a higher risk of developing liver disease, including 
NAFLD and cirrhosis, than lean dogs (Archer et al., 2020). 
Likewise, obesity has been shown to be a risk factor for the 
development of hepatic lipidosis in cats (Center et al., 2018).
1.7.3 Recent advances in treatment
Recent research has focused on the development of new 
treatments for liver disease in dogs and cats. One promising 
area of research is the use of nutraceuticals, such as milk 
thistle extract, to support liver function. Milk thistle extract 
contains silymarin, a compound that has been shown to have 
antioxidant and antiinflammatory effects and to protect liver 
cells from damage (Center et al., 2018). Studies have found 
that the administration of milk thistle extract can improve 
liver function and reduce liver inflammation in dogs and 
cats with liver disease (Bauer et al., 2020). Another area of 
research is the use of stem cells for the treatment of liver 
disease. Stem cells have the potential to regenerate dam -
aged liver tissue and improve liver function. Studies have 
found that the administration of mesenchymal stem cells 
can improve liver function and reduce liver inflammation in 
dogs with liver disease (Zhang et al., 2021).
1.8 Hyperthyroidism
Hyperthyroidism is a common endocrine disorder that af -
fects both dogs and cats. It is characterized by excessive 
production of thyroid hormones by the thyroid gland, re -
sulting in hypermetabolism and increased metabolic rate 
(Mooney and Peterson, 2013). The condition is most com -
mon in older cats, with an estimated prevalence of 10% in 
cats over the age of 10  years (Peterson, 2012). Difference 
between cat’s and dog’s hyperthyroidism is given in Table 3. 
The cause of hyperthyroidism in dogs and cats is not well 
understood, although it is believed to be multifactorial, in -
volving both genetic and environmental factors.
1.8.1 Nutrition and hyperthyroidism
The role of nutrition in the pathogenesis of hyperthyroid -
ism in dogs and cats is not well established. However, some 
studies have suggested that certain dietary factors may play 
a role in the development of the condition. For example, 
it has been suggested that high iodine intake may increase 
the risk of developing hyperthyroidism in cats ( Peterson,

2012). This hypothesis is supported by studies that have

that certain diets may affect thyroid hormone levels in dogs 
and cats, although the results are conflicting. For example, 
one study found that a high-protein, low-carbohydrate diet 
reduced thyroid hormone levels in dogs with hyperthyroid-
ism (V olpato et al., 2014). However, another study found no 
significant effect of diet on thyroid hormone levels in dogs 
(Chase and Chew, 2014).
1.8.2 Obesity and hyperthyroidism
Obesity is a common problem in dogs and cats, and it has 
been suggested that it may play a role in the development of 
hyperthyroidism. Obesity has been associated with increased 
thyroid hormone levels in both dogs and cats, although the 
mechanism is not well understood ( Lawler et al., 2016 ). It 
has been suggested that obesity may alter the metabolism 
of thyroid hormones, leading to increased production and 
release of the hormones ( Larsson and Carlsson, 2015 ). In 
addition, obesity has been associated with insulin resistance 
and metabolic disorders, which may also play a role in the 
pathogenesis of hyperthyroidism (Velliquette et al., 2017).
1.8.3 Metabolic disorders and 
hyperthyroidism
Metabolic disorders such as diabetes mellitus and hyperlip-
idemia are common in dogs and cats, and they have been 
associated with an increased risk of developing hyperthy -
roidism. Diabetes mellitus has been associated with altered 
thyroid hormone metabolism, leading to an increased risk 
of developing hyperthyroidism (Dhumeaux et al., 2015). In 
addition, hyperlipidemia has been associated with altered 
thyroid hormone levels, although the mechanism is not well 
understood (V olpato et al., 2014).
1.9 Hypothyroidism
Hypothyroidism is a common endocrine disorder in dogs 
and cats. It results from a deficiency of thyroid hormones, 
which can be caused by a variety of factors, including nutri-
tional and metabolic diseases.
1.9.1 Diet and hypothyroidism
Diet plays an important role in the development and man -
agement of hypothyroidism in dogs and cats. There is evi -
dence to suggest that diets low in iodine, selenium, and 
zinc may contribute to the development of hypothyroidism 
in dogs. Iodine is an essential component of thyroid hor -
mones, and deficiencies in iodine can lead to hypothyroid -
ism. Selenium is required for the production of the active 
form of thyroid hormone, and deficiencies in selenium can 
lead to hypothyroidism. Zinc is required for the conversion 
of thyroxine (T4) to triiodothyronine (T3), and deficiencies 
in zinc can lead to decreased T3 levels and hypothyroidism. 
In addition to deficiencies in specific nutrients, the com -
position of the diet can also influence the development of 
hypothyroidism. High levels of goitrogens, which are com-
pounds that interfere with thyroid hormone synthesis, can 
lead to hypothyroidism in dogs and cats. Goitrogens are 
found in certain cruciferous vegetables, such as broccoli, 
kale, and cabbage, as well as in soy products. However, the 
levels of goitrogens in commercial pet foods are generally 
low and are unlikely to cause hypothyroidism.
1.9.2 Obesity and hypothyroidism
Obesity is a common nutritional disease in dogs and cats, 
and it has been linked to the development of hypothyroid -
ism. In dogs, obesity has been shown to be associated with 
decreased levels of free T4 and T3, as well as with increased 
levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), which is in -
dicative of hypothyroidism ( German et  al., 2010 ). The 
mechanism underlying the relationship between obesity 
and hypothyroidism is not fully understood, but it is thought 
that adipose tissue may interfere with thyroid hormone me-
tabolism. In cats, obesity has also been associated with de -
creased levels of thyroid hormones. A study of overweight 
and obese cats found that they had lower serum T4 levels 
than lean cats. The authors of the study suggested that the 
decreased T4 levels may be due to a decreased produc -
tion of thyroid hormones, as well as to changes in thyroid 
hormone metabolism caused by obesity ( Tvarijonaviciute 
et al., 2012).
1.9.3 Diabetes and hypothyroidism
Diabetes is another metabolic disease that has been linked 
to the development of hypothyroidism in dogs and cats. A 
study of diabetic dogs found that they were more likely to 
have low levels of thyroid hormones than nondiabetic dogs. 
The authors of the study suggested that the link between 
diabetes and hypothyroidism may be due to the effects of 
insulin resistance on thyroid hormone metabolism ( Ristic 
et al., 2006). Insulin resistance is a hallmark of type 2 diabe-
tes, and it has been shown to impair the conversion of T4 to 
T3 in humans (Chopra et al., 2011). Similarly, in dogs and 
cats with diabetes, insulin resistance may interfere with the 
conversion of T4 to T3, leading to decreased levels of T3 
and hypothyroidism.
1.9.4 Effects of hypothyroidism on 
metabolism, glucose homeostasis, and lipid 
metabolism
Hypothyroidism can have significant effects on metabo -
lism, glucose homeostasis, and lipid metabolism in dogs 
and cats. In dogs, hypothyroidism has been shown to

438 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
 decrease resting energy expenditure and increase fat accu -
mulation. These effects are thought to be due to a decrease 
in mitochondrial function and a decrease in the expression 
of genes involved in lipid metabolism ( Hoffmann et  al., 
2003). In cats, hypothyroidism has been associated with 
impaired glucose metabolism. A study of hypothyroid cats 
found that they had significantly higher glucose concen -
trations than euthyroid cats. The authors of the study sug -
gested that the impaired glucose metabolism may be due 
to decreased insulin sensitivity caused by hypothyroidism 
(Boag et  al., 2010 ). Hypothyroidism can also have sig -
nificant effects on lipid metabolism in dogs and cats. In 
dogs, hypothyroidism has been shown to increase triglyc -
eride levels and decrease high-density lipoprotein (HDL) 
cholesterol levels. These effects are thought to be due to 
a decrease in lipoprotein lipase activity and an increase in 
hepatic lipase activity ( Wakshlag et al., 2012). In cats, hy -
pothyroidism has been associated with increased levels of 
total cholesterol and low-density lipoprotein (LDL) choles-
terol. The authors of the study suggested that the increased 
cholesterol levels may be due to decreased LDL receptor 
activity caused by hypothyroidism ( Boag et al., 2010).
1.10 Dental disease
Dental disease is a prevalent problem in domestic pets, in -
cluding dogs and cats, and is considered one of the most 
common health issues affecting them. The incidence of den-
tal disease is on the rise, and it can lead to several nutritional 
and metabolic diseases, including periodontal disease, mal-
occlusion, oral tumors, and oral infections.
1.10.1 Periodontal disease
Periodontal disease is a severe dental problem in dogs and 
cats that affects the supporting structures of the teeth, includ-
ing the gingiva, periodontal ligament, cementum, and alveo-
lar bone. It is caused by the accumulation of bacterial plaque 
and tartar, which leads to inflammation and destruction of 
the periodontal tissues, resulting in tooth loss, oral pain, and 
difficulty eating. Recent studies have shown that periodontal 
disease in dogs and cats is associated with several nutritional 
and metabolic diseases, including diabetes mellitus, obesity, 
and chronic kidney disease (CKD). In a study conducted by 
Niemiec et al. (2018), it was found that dogs with periodon-
tal disease had a higher risk of developing diabetes mellitus. 
The study also showed that diabetic dogs with periodontal 
disease had a higher incidence of diabetic complications, in-
cluding neuropathy, nephropathy, and retinopathy. In cats, 
periodontal disease has been linked to CKD.
1.10.2 Malocclusion
Malocclusion is a dental problem that affects the alignment 
of the teeth and can lead to several nutritional and metabolic 
 diseases in dogs and cats. Malocclusion can result from ge-
netic factors, trauma, or improper chewing habits. Recent 
studies have shown that malocclusion in dogs and cats is asso-
ciated with several nutritional and metabolic diseases, includ-
ing obesity and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). In 
a study conducted by Lawler et al. (2018), it was found that 
dogs with malocclusion had a higher risk of developing obe-
sity. The study also showed that obese dogs with malocclu-
sion had a higher incidence of insulin resistance, indicating 
the development of diabetes mellitus. In cats, malocclusion 
has been linked to GERD. A study by Johnson et al. (2019) 
found that cats with malocclusion had a higher risk of devel-
oping GERD. The study also showed that cats with severe 
malocclusion had a higher incidence of vomiting and regur-
gitation, indicating the presence of GERD.
1.10.3 Oral tumors
Oral tumors are a severe dental problem in dogs and cats 
that can lead to several nutritional and metabolic diseases. 
Oral tumors can be benign or malignant and can develop in 
any part of the oral cavity, including the gingiva, tongue, 
palate, and tonsils. Recent studies have shown that oral tu -
mors in dogs and cats are associated with several nutritional 
and metabolic diseases, including cachexia, anemia, and 
malnutrition. In a study conducted by Liptak et al. (2018) , 
it was found that dogs with oral tumors had a higher risk of 
developing cachexia. The study also showed that cachexic 
dogs with oral tumors had a higher incidence of anemia, in-
dicating the development of iron deficiency. In cats, oral tu-
mors have been linked to malnutrition. A study by Reimers 
et al. (2019) found that cats with oral tumors had a higher 
risk of developing malnutrition. The study also showed that 
malnourished cats with oral tumors had a higher incidence 
of muscle wasting and lethargy.
1.10.4 Oral infections
Oral infections are a common dental problem in dogs and 
cats and can lead to several nutritional and metabolic dis -
eases. Oral infections can be caused by bacteria, viruses, or 
fungi and can lead to severe oral pain, difficulty eating, and 
systemic infections. Recent studies have shown that oral in-
fections in dogs and cats are associated with several nutri -
tional and metabolic diseases, including anorexia, cachexia, 
and sepsis. In a study conducted by Souza et al. (2020) , it 
was found that dogs with oral infections had a higher risk 
of developing anorexia. The study also showed that an -
orexic dogs with oral infections had a higher incidence of 
cachexia, indicating the development of muscle wasting. In 
cats, oral infections have been linked to sepsis. A study by 
Santos et al. (2019) found that cats with oral infections had 
a higher risk of developing sepsis. The study also showed 
that septic cats with oral infections had a higher incidence 
of hypotension and multiorgan dysfunction.

Nutritional and metabolic diseases of dogs and cats   Chapter | 29  439
1.10.5 Nutritional management of dental 
disease
Nutritional management plays a crucial role in the pre -
vention and treatment of dental disease in dogs and cats. 
Several nutritional strategies have been proposed, includ -
ing the use of dental diets, supplements, and oral hygiene 
products. Dental diets are specially formulated diets that 
promote oral health by reducing plaque and tartar forma -
tion. These diets contain specific ingredients, including 
sodium tripolyphosphate, which binds to calcium in sa -
liva, reducing the formation of tartar. In a study conducted 
by Staunton et  al. (2019) , it was found that dogs fed a 
dental diet had a significant reduction in plaque and tartar 
compared to dogs fed a control diet. Supplements, includ -
ing probiotics and prebiotics, have also been proposed to 
promote oral health in dogs and cats. Probiotics are live 
microorganisms that promote the growth of beneficial 
bacteria in the gut and oral cavity, reducing the risk of oral 
infections. Prebiotics, on the other hand, are nondigest -
ible carbohydrates that promote the growth of beneficial 
bacteria in the gut and oral cavity, reducing the risk of 
periodontal disease. In a study conducted by Lappin et al. 
(2020), it was found that dogs fed a probiotic supplement 
had a significant reduction in periodontal disease com -
pared to dogs fed a placebo. Oral hygiene products, in -
cluding dental chews, toothbrushes, and oral rinses, have 
also been proposed to promote oral health in dogs and 
cats. Dental chews contain specific ingredients, including 
chlorhexidine, which reduce plaque and tartar formation. 
Toothbrushes and oral rinses can be used to remove plaque 
and tartar manually, reducing the risk of periodontal dis -
ease. In a study conducted by Smith et al. (2018) , it was 
found that cats fed dental chews had a significant reduc -
tion in periodontal disease compared to cats fed a control 
diet.
1.10.6 Impact of nutritional and metabolic 
diseases on animal health and welfare
Nutritional and metabolic diseases can have a significant 
impact on the health and welfare of dogs and cats. Obesity, 
for example, is associated with an increased risk of a range 
of health problems, including diabetes, arthritis, and cardio-
vascular disease. Similarly, diabetes, pancreatitis, and liver 
disease can all lead to serious health complications and a 
decreased quality of life. Malnutrition is also a significant 
concern for pets, as it can lead to stunted growth, poor coat 
quality, and a weakened immune system. In severe cases, 
malnutrition can even be life-threatening. In addition to 
the physical health impact of nutritional and metabolic dis-
eases, these conditions can also have a significant impact 
on animal welfare. Pets with chronic diseases may require 
ongoing medical care and may experience pain, discomfort, 
and a decreased quality of life.
1.10.7 Current knowledge gaps and research 
priorities in the field
Despite the significant impact of nutritional and metabolic 
diseases on the health and welfare of dogs and cats, there 
are still many knowledge gaps and research priorities in 
the field. One area of concern is the lack of understanding 
of the genetic and environmental factors that contribute to 
these diseases. While some risk factors have been identi -
fied, such as breed and diet, much more research is needed 
to fully understand the complex interplay of factors that 
contribute to these conditions. There is also a need for more 
research into the optimal treatment and management strate-
gies for these diseases. While many of these conditions can 
be managed with dietary changes and medication, there is 
still much to be learned about the most effective approaches 
for individual pets. Finally, there is a need for more research 
into the prevention of nutritional and metabolic diseases in 
dogs and cats. This includes a better understanding of the 
role of diet, exercise, and other lifestyle factors in prevent -
ing these conditions, as well as the development of more 
effective preventive strategies for at-risk pets.
2 Factors influencing nutritional and 
metabolic diseases in dogs and cats
Nutritional and metabolic diseases in dogs and cats are a 
common problem that affects their overall health and qual -
ity of life. These diseases are caused by various factors, 
such as diet, genetics, and lifestyle. Recent studies have in-
vestigated the impact of breed-specific characteristics and 
aging on the development and progression of nutritional 
and metabolic diseases in dogs and cats.
2.1 The impact of breed-specific characteristics 
on the risk and severity of nutritional and 
metabolic diseases
Breed-specific characteristics are an important factor that 
influences the risk and severity of nutritional and metabolic 
diseases in dogs and cats. Certain breeds are more suscepti-
ble to certain diseases due to their genetic makeup and phys-
iological characteristics. For example, Labrador Retrievers 
are more prone to obesity due to their genetic predisposition 
to overeating and lower metabolic rate. Similarly, Persian 
cats are more susceptible to urinary tract diseases due to 
their unique urinary physiology, such as their short and 
wide urethra (Cannon et al., 2017). Moreover, recent studies 
have identified specific genetic mutations that are associ -
ated with certain nutritional and metabolic diseases in dogs 
and cats. For instance, a mutation in the MC4R gene is as -
sociated with obesity in Labrador Retrievers ( Raffan et al., 
2016), while a mutation in the PKD1 gene is linked to poly-
cystic kidney disease in Persian cats (Lyons et al., 2014).

440 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
2.2 The effects of aging on the development 
and progression of nutritional and metabolic 
diseases
Aging is another significant factor that influences the de -
velopment and progression of nutritional and metabolic 
diseases in dogs and cats. As pets age, their metabolism 
slows down, and their nutritional requirements change. 
This makes them more susceptible to diseases such as obe-
sity, diabetes, and kidney disease. In addition, age-related 
changes in the digestive system can affect the absorption 
and utilization of nutrients, leading to malnutrition and 
other metabolic disorders. Recent studies have investi -
gated the effects of aging on the development of specific 
nutritional and metabolic diseases in dogs and cats. For in -
stance, a study by German et al. (2017) found that aging is 
a significant risk factor for obesity in dogs, with dogs over 
the age of 7 being more likely to be overweight or obese. 
Similarly, a study by Bodey et al. (2019)  found that aging 
is a risk factor for chronic kidney disease in cats, with cats 
over the age of 10 having a higher risk of developing the 
disease.
2.3 The influence of gender and sex hormones 
on nutrient metabolism and the development of 
metabolic diseases
Gender and sex hormones are important factors that influ -
ence nutrient metabolism and the development of meta -
bolic diseases in dogs and cats. Male and female animals 
have different metabolic rates, body compositions, and 
nutrient requirements. Sex hormones such as estrogen 
and testosterone can also affect nutrient metabolism and 
the development of metabolic diseases. Recent studies 
have shown that gender and sex hormones play a role in 
the development of obesity in dogs and cats. For instance, 
female dogs and cats are more likely to be overweight or 
obese than males. This is partly due to the effects of es -
trogen, which can promote fat deposition and reduce en -
ergy expenditure in females ( Munir et al., 2018 ). On the 
other hand, testosterone in male dogs and cats can promote 
muscle development and higher metabolic rates, leading to 
a lower risk of obesity ( Chapman et al., 2019 ). Moreover, 
studies have also investigated the effects of sex hormones 
on the development of metabolic diseases such as diabe -
tes and kidney disease. For instance, a study by Dowling 
et al. (2018)  found that castrated male cats have a higher 
risk of developing diabetes than intact male cats. This may 
be due to the effects of sex hormones on insulin sensitiv -
ity and glucose metabolism. Similarly, studies have shown 
that female dogs are more susceptible to developing kidney 
disease, which may be related to the effects of estrogen on 
renal function (Lefebvre et al., 2017).
2.4 The impact of social and environmental 
factors on the risk and severity of nutritional and 
metabolic diseases
Social and environmental factors can also influence the 
risk and severity of nutritional and metabolic diseases in 
dogs and cats. Factors such as living conditions, exercise 
levels, and social interactions can affect the dietary habits 
and metabolism of pets, leading to a higher or lower risk 
of disease. Recent studies have investigated the effects of 
social and environmental factors on the development of 
obesity in dogs and cats. For instance, a study by Courcier 
et al. (2010) found that dogs living in multidog households 
are more likely to be overweight or obese than dogs living 
alone. This may be due to increased competition for food 
and reduced exercise opportunities in multidog households. 
Similarly, a study by Scarlett et al. (2016) found that indoor 
confinement and lack of exercise are risk factors for obesity 
in cats. Moreover, studies have also investigated the effects 
of social and environmental factors on the development of 
other metabolic diseases such as diabetes and urinary tract 
disease. For instance, a study by Lund et al. (2018)  found 
that cats living in multicat households have a higher risk of 
developing urinary tract disease, which may be related to 
increased stress and reduced access to litter boxes.
2.5 The impact of climate change on the 
prevalence and distribution of nutritional and 
metabolic diseases
Climate change is expected to have significant impacts on 
the health of domestic animals, including dogs and cats. 
Changes in temperature, precipitation, and humidity can 
affect the distribution and prevalence of nutritional and 
metabolic diseases in these animals. Studies have shown 
that increased temperatures can affect the metabolism and 
energy balance of dogs and cats, leading to a higher risk of 
obesity and metabolic diseases such as diabetes ( Bennett 
et al., 2016). Higher temperatures can also lead to reduced 
appetite and water intake, which can lead to dehydration 
and malnutrition in animals. Changes in precipitation pat -
terns can also affect the distribution and prevalence of 
nutritional and metabolic diseases in dogs and cats. For 
example, drought conditions can lead to a shortage of food 
and water, which can affect the nutrient intake and health 
of animals ( Baker et al., 2018 ). On the other hand, heavy 
rainfall and flooding can lead to waterborne diseases and 
infections, which can affect the digestive and metabolic 
systems of dogs and cats. Furthermore, climate change can 
also affect the distribution and prevalence of vector-borne 
diseases, which can have significant impacts on the health 
of dogs and cats. For example, rising temperatures and 
changes in precipitation patterns can lead to changes in the

Nutritional and metabolic diseases of dogs and cats   Chapter | 29  441
distribution and abundance of ticks, mosquitoes, and fleas, 
which are vectors for diseases such as Lyme disease, heart-
worm, and West Nile virus ( Beugnet and Marie, 2019 ). 
These diseases can affect the immune system and metabolic 
function of animals, leading to nutritional deficiencies and 
metabolic disorders. In conclusion, climate change is ex -
pected to have significant impacts on the prevalence and 
distribution of nutritional and metabolic diseases in dogs 
and cats. These impacts can result from changes in tem -
perature, precipitation, and vector-borne disease patterns. 
It is important for pet owners and veterinary professionals 
to be aware of these potential impacts and take appropri -
ate measures to prevent and treat nutritional and metabolic 
diseases in animals.
3 Mechanisms of nutritional and 
metabolic diseases in dogs and cats
Nutritional and metabolic diseases are prevalent in dogs and 
cats and can significantly impact their health and quality of 
life. Recent research has shown that the gut microbiota, the 
complex ecosystem of microorganisms that inhabit the gas-
trointestinal tract, can play a significant role in the develop-
ment of metabolic diseases such as obesity, type 2 diabetes, 
and related disorders. The gut microbiota of dogs and cats is 
a diverse and complex community of microorganisms that 
plays a crucial role in their health and well-being. The com-
position and function of the gut microbiota are influenced 
by several factors, including genetics, diet, and environ -
mental factors. The gut microbiota plays a critical role in 
the digestion and absorption of nutrients, the development 
and function of the immune system, and the maintenance of 
intestinal barrier function.
3.1 The impact of gut microbiota on the 
development of metabolic diseases
Recent studies have shown that the gut microbiota plays 
a critical role in the development of metabolic diseases in
