dogs and cats. A disrupted gut microbiota can result in a 
dysregulated metabolism and increased risk of obesity, type 
2 diabetes, and related disorders. The following mecha -
nisms have been identified as contributing factors to the im-
pact of gut microbiota on metabolic diseases:
1. Influence on nutrient absorption: The gut microbiota in-
fluences the absorption of nutrients by breaking down 
complex carbohydrates and producing short-chain fatty 
acids (SCFAs). SCFAs are critical for the maintenance 
of gut barrier function, which is essential for preventing 
the entry of harmful toxins and bacteria into the blood -
stream. A disruption of SCFA production and nutrient 
absorption can contribute to metabolic diseases such as 
obesity and type 2 diabetes.
2. Regulation of inflammatory response: The gut microbi-
ota plays a crucial role in the regulation of the immune 
system and the inflammatory response. Dysbiosis, or an 
imbalance of gut microbiota, can lead to chronic low-
grade inflammation, which is a hallmark of metabolic 
diseases such as obesity and type 2 diabetes.
3. Modulation of hormones: The gut microbiota can modu-
late the secretion of hormones that play a critical role in 
metabolic homeostasis, such as insulin and glucagon-
like peptide-1 (GLP-1). Dysbiosis can result in the dys-
regulation of hormone secretion, which can contribute 
to the development of metabolic diseases.
Recent studies have shed light on the impact of gut micro -
biota on the development of metabolic diseases in dogs and 
cats. A study by Andersen et al. (2020) found that the gut mi-
crobiota of obese dogs was significantly different from that of 
lean dogs, with an increased abundance of pro- inflammatory 
bacteria and a reduced abundance of beneficial bacteria. 
Another study by Li et al. (2021) found that a high-fat diet 
led to changes in the gut microbiota of cats, with an increase 
in the abundance of potentially harmful bacteria. 
3.2 The role of gut hormones on the regulation 
of nutrient metabolism and the development of 
metabolic diseases
Nutrient metabolism is a critical aspect of maintaining 
health and preventing metabolic diseases in dogs and cats. 
Recent research has shown that gut hormones play an es -
sential role in the regulation of nutrient metabolism and 
the development of metabolic diseases. The Role of Gut 
Hormones in Nutrient Metabolism: Gut hormones play a 
critical role in the regulation of nutrient metabolism in dogs 
and cats. Gut hormones, such as glucagon-like peptide-1 
(GLP-1), cholecystokinin (CCK), and peptide YY (PYY), 
are released from enteroendocrine cells in the gut in re -
sponse to nutrient intake. These hormones act on various 
organs, including the pancreas, liver, and brain, to regulate 
nutrient absorption, metabolism, and storage. GLP-1 is an 
important gut hormone that stimulates insulin secretion, 
which helps to regulate glucose metabolism. CCK stimu -
lates the release of digestive enzymes from the pancreas and 
bile from the gallbladder, which aids in the digestion and 
absorption of fats. PYY reduces food intake and promotes 
satiety, helping to regulate nutrient intake and prevent over-
eating. The Role of Gut Hormones in the Development of 
Metabolic Diseases: Dysregulation of gut hormones can 
contribute to the development of metabolic diseases in dogs 
and cats. For example, reduced GLP-1 secretion can con -
tribute to the development of insulin resistance and type 2 
diabetes. Similarly, reduced PYY secretion can lead to over-
eating and obesity. Additionally, dysregulation of gut hor -
mone signaling can contribute to the development of other

442 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
metabolic disorders, such as fatty liver disease. Recent 
Findings: Recent studies have shed light on the role of gut 
hormones in the regulation of nutrient metabolism and 
the development of metabolic diseases in dogs and cats. 
A study by Honneffer et al. (2018)  found that administra -
tion of exogenous GLP-1 improved glucose metabolism in 
obese dogs. Another study by Backus et al. (2019)  found 
that PYY concentrations were significantly lower in obese 
cats compared to lean cats.
3.3 The influence of bile acid metabolism and 
the farnesoid X receptor on nutrient absorption 
and the development of metabolic diseases
Bile acids are critical for the digestion and absorption of fats 
and fat-soluble vitamins in dogs and cats. Recent research 
has shown that bile acid metabolism and the farnesoid X 
receptor (FXR) play an essential role in the regulation of 
nutrient absorption and the development of metabolic dis -
eases. Bile Acid Metabolism in Dogs and Cats: Bile acids 
are synthesized in the liver and are key for the digestion 
and absorption of fats and fat-soluble vitamins in dogs and 
cats. After synthesis in the liver, bile acids are stored in the 
gallbladder until they are released into the small intestine 
during feeding. Once released, bile acids emulsify dietary 
lipids and facilitate their absorption in the small intestine. 
After absorption, bile acids are transported back to the 
liver through the portal vein and are actively taken up by 
hepatocytes via bile acid transporters located on the sinu -
soidal membrane. Within the hepatocytes, bile acids are 
conjugated with taurine or glycine and then secreted into 
bile canaliculi. From there, bile acids are transported to the 
gallbladder and stored until the next feeding. The Role of 
Bile Acid Metabolism in Nutrient Absorption: Bile acids 
play an important role in the regulation of nutrient absorp -
tion. Specifically, they facilitate the absorption of dietary 
lipids, which are essential for energy metabolism and cel -
lular function. The emulsification of dietary lipids by bile 
acids increases their surface area, which allows for more 
efficient enzymatic breakdown by pancreatic lipases. The 
products of lipid hydrolysis (free fatty acids, monoglycer -
ides) are then absorbed by enterocytes in the small intestine 
and packaged into chylomicrons for transport into the lym-
phatic system and then to the liver.
The Farnesoid X Receptor (FXR) and Bile Acid 
Metabolism: The farnesoid X receptor (FXR) is a nuclear 
receptor that is activated by bile acids. FXR plays a critical 
role in the regulation of bile acid metabolism, as well as 
glucose and lipid metabolism. Activation of FXR by bile 
acids induces the expression of several genes involved in 
bile acid transport, metabolism, and feedback regulation. 
FXR activation also leads to the suppression of hepatic glu-
coneogenesis and the promotion of lipogenesis. The Role 
of Bile Acid Metabolism and FXR in the Development of 
Metabolic Diseases: Dysregulation of bile acid metabolism 
and FXR signaling can contribute to the development of 
metabolic diseases in dogs and cats. For example, impaired 
bile acid synthesis and/or secretion can lead to malabsorp -
tion of dietary lipids and fat-soluble vitamins, resulting in 
deficiencies that can cause various clinical signs, such as 
poor coat condition and growth retardation. Conversely, 
excessive bile acid synthesis and/or secretion can lead to 
diarrhea and/or steatorrhea. Dysregulation of FXR sig -
naling can also contribute to metabolic disorders. For ex -
ample, decreased FXR activation has been associated with 
increased hepatic glucose production and impaired glucose 
tolerance in obese cats. Additionally, decreased FXR acti -
vation has been linked to dyslipidemia and increased risk 
of cardiovascular disease in dogs. Recent Findings: Recent 
studies have shed light on the role of bile acid metabolism 
and FXR signaling in nutrient absorption and the develop -
ment of metabolic diseases in dogs and cats. A study by 
Desai et al. (2020) found that the expression of FXR and its 
target genes involved in bile acid transport and metabolism 
were decreased in cats with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease 
(NAFLD). Another study by Zhou et al. (2021)  found that 
activation of FXR by bile acid sequestrants improved glu -
cose and lipid metabolism in obese cats.
3.4 The role of mitochondrial dynamics and 
mitophagy in the development and progression 
of metabolic diseases
Mitochondria play a crucial role in cellular metabolism by 
producing adenosine triphosphate (ATP) through oxidative 
phosphorylation. They also participate in cellular signaling, 
calcium homeostasis, and apoptosis. In order to maintain 
proper cellular function, mitochondria undergo continuous 
cycles of fission and fusion, which regulate their morphol -
ogy, number, and distribution. Disruptions in mitochondrial 
dynamics can lead to mitochondrial dysfunction, oxidative 
stress, and cellular damage, which are associated with the 
development and progression of metabolic diseases, such 
as obesity and diabetes. Mitophagy is the process by which 
damaged or dysfunctional mitochondria are targeted for se-
lective autophagy and degradation. The elimination of dam-
aged mitochondria by mitophagy is critical for maintaining 
mitochondrial health and preventing the accumulation of 
dysfunctional mitochondria, which can contribute to the 
development of metabolic diseases. Mitophagy is regulated 
by various signaling pathways, including the PINK1/Parkin 
pathway and the BNIP3/NIX pathway. Recent Findings 
Recent studies have highlighted the importance of mito -
chondrial dynamics and mitophagy in the development and 
progression of metabolic diseases in dogs and cats. A study 
by Pilla et al. (2021)  found that obese dogs had increased

Nutritional and metabolic diseases of dogs and cats   Chapter | 29  443
mitochondrial fragmentation and decreased mitophagy in 
adipose tissue compared to lean dogs. Another study by 
Herring et  al. (2021)  found that the expression of genes 
involved in mitochondrial dynamics and mitophagy was 
altered in the skeletal muscle of cats with type 2 diabetes.
3.5 The effects of oxidative stress and 
antioxidants on cellular metabolism and the 
development of metabolic diseases
Oxidative stress is a condition that arises when the balance 
between pro-oxidants and antioxidants is disrupted, lead -
ing to an accumulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) 
and reactive nitrogen species (RNS) in cells. ROS and RNS 
can cause damage to cellular components, such as proteins, 
lipids, and DNA, leading to cellular dysfunction and tissue 
damage. In dogs and cats, oxidative stress has been linked 
to the development and progression of various metabolic 
diseases, such as obesity, diabetes, and chronic kidney dis -
ease. Antioxidants are molecules that neutralize ROS and 
RNS, thereby preventing oxidative damage to cellular com-
ponents. Antioxidants can be endogenous or exogenous, 
and include enzymes, such as superoxide dismutase and 
catalase, as well as vitamins and phytochemicals, such as 
vitamins C and E, carotenoids, and flavonoids. Antioxidants 
act by scavenging ROS and RNS, inhibiting their formation, 
and repairing oxidative damage. Recent Findings: Recent 
studies have examined the effects of oxidative stress and 
antioxidants on cellular metabolism and the development 
of metabolic diseases in dogs and cats. A study by Dowling 
et al. (2021)  found that dogs with chronic kidney disease 
had increased oxidative stress and decreased antioxidant ca-
pacity compared to healthy dogs. Another study by Hofer-
Inteeworn et al. (2021) found that supplementation with the 
antioxidant alpha-lipoic acid improved glucose metabolism 
in cats with insulin resistance.
3.6 The impact of endogenous and exogenous 
stressors on cellular metabolism and the 
development of metabolic diseases
3.6.1 Endogenous stressors
Endogenous stressors refer to internal physiological pro -
cesses that result in stress, such as inflammation, oxida -
tive stress, and metabolic dysfunction. These processes can 
have a significant impact on cellular metabolism, leading 
to insulin resistance, inflammation, and oxidative damage, 
which are all risk factors for metabolic diseases. Studies 
have shown that chronic inflammation is associated with in-
sulin resistance in dogs and cats and may also contribute to 
the development of obesity and diabetes mellitus. Oxidative 
stress is another endogenous stressor that has been linked 
to metabolic diseases in dogs and cats. Reactive oxygen 
 species (ROS) are produced as a byproduct of normal cel -
lular metabolism and are normally neutralized by antioxi -
dants. However, when ROS production exceeds antioxidant 
capacity, oxidative stress can occur, leading to cellular dam-
age and dysfunction. A study in cats found that oxidative 
stress was associated with insulin resistance, and that anti -
oxidants may have a protective effect against the develop -
ment of diabetes mellitus (Kuzuya et al., 2009).
3.6.2 Exogenous stressors
Exogenous stressors are external factors that cause stress, 
such as environmental stressors or lifestyle factors. These 
stressors can also have a significant impact on cellular me -
tabolism, and may contribute to the development of meta -
bolic diseases. For example, environmental stressors such 
as noise, temperature extremes, and overcrowding have 
been shown to increase cortisol levels in dogs and cats, 
which can lead to insulin resistance and the development of 
diabetes mellitus (Gruen et al., 2014; Niessen et al., 2006).
Lifestyle factors such as diet and exercise also play a 
role in the development of metabolic diseases in dogs and 
cats. Obesity is a significant risk factor for metabolic dis -
eases and is often the result of overfeeding and lack of ex -
ercise. However, recent research has suggested that stress 
may also be a contributing factor. For example, a study in 
dogs found that dogs who were stressed during feeding were 
more likely to overeat and become overweight, even when 
their overall food intake was controlled (Pang et al., 2016).
3.7 The role of glucocorticoid signaling and 
stress response pathways in the development of 
metabolic diseases
Glucocorticoids are steroid hormones that are released in re-
sponse to stress, and play a critical role in the body’s stress 
response pathway. While this system is designed to help the 
body cope with short-term stressors, chronic activation of 
the stress response pathway can have negative effects on 
cellular metabolism and can contribute to the development 
of metabolic diseases.
3.7.1 Glucocorticoids and cellular metabolism
Glucocorticoids have a wide range of effects on cellular 
metabolism, including the regulation of glucose production 
and utilization, protein synthesis and breakdown, and lipid 
metabolism. In the short term, these effects are adaptive and 
help the body cope with stressors. However, chronic expo -
sure to high levels of glucocorticoids can lead to dysregu -
lation of cellular metabolism, which can contribute to the 
development of metabolic diseases. For example, in both 
dogs and cats, high levels of glucocorticoids have been as -
sociated with insulin resistance, a key component of many 
metabolic diseases ( Niessen et  al., 2007 ; Munday et  al.,

444 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
2010). Glucocorticoids have also been shown to promote li-
polysis, or the breakdown of stored fat, which can contribute 
to obesity and other metabolic disorders ( Tvarijonaviciute 
et al., 2013).
3.7.2 Stress response pathways and cellular 
metabolism
The stress response pathway is a complex system involv -
ing the hypothalamus, pituitary gland, and adrenal glands, 
which work together to release hormones in response to 
stress. While this system is designed to help the body cope 
with short-term stressors, chronic activation of the stress 
response pathway can have negative effects on cellular me-
tabolism. For example, in both dogs and cats, chronic acti -
vation of the stress response pathway has been associated 
with insulin resistance and the development of metabolic 
diseases (Gruen et al., 2014; Niessen et al., 2006). This may 
be due in part to the fact that chronic activation of the stress 
response pathway can lead to dysregulation of glucocorti -
coid signaling and other metabolic pathways.
3.7.3 Recent findings
Recent research has highlighted the role of the microbiome 
in modulating the effects of glucocorticoid signaling and 
the stress response pathway on cellular metabolism. For 
example, a study in dogs found that changes in the gut mi -
crobiome were associated with changes in glucocorticoid 
signaling and insulin sensitivity ( Fernandes et  al., 2020 ). 
Another study in cats found that dietary modulation of 
the microbiome could help mitigate the negative effects of 
stress on insulin sensitivity (Buddington et al., 2018).
3.8 The impact of the kynurenine pathway and 
tryptophan metabolism on nutrient metabolism 
and the development of metabolic diseases
Dogs and cats are two of the most popular pets around the 
world, and proper nutrition is essential for their health and 
well-being. The kynurenine pathway and tryptophan me -
tabolism are essential biochemical pathways that play a 
crucial role in nutrient metabolism and the development of 
metabolic diseases in dogs and cats. Recent research has 
shown that understanding these pathways and their impact 
on nutrient metabolism can help develop new therapies and 
interventions for pets.
3.8.1 Kynurenine pathway and tryptophan 
metabolism
The kynurenine pathway is a biochemical pathway that 
catabolizes the amino acid tryptophan into a variety of 
compounds, including kynurenine, kynurenic acid, and 
quinolinic acid. This pathway plays a crucial role in  regulating  
immune function, inflammation, and neurotransmission. 
Tryptophan is an essential amino acid that must be obtained 
from the diet and is a precursor to the neurotransmitter se -
rotonin, which is involved in regulating mood and appetite. 
Recent studies have shown that the kynurenine pathway 
and tryptophan metabolism play an essential role in nutri -
ent metabolism and the development of metabolic diseases 
in dogs and cats. For example, a study by Hewson-Hughes 
et al. (2019) found that cats fed a high-protein diet had in -
creased tryptophan catabolism and higher concentrations of 
kynurenic acid and quinolinic acid in their blood. Another 
study by Zhang et  al. (2021) showed that the kynurenine 
pathway is upregulated in the liver of obese dogs and cats, 
leading to increased production of kynurenine and its down-
stream metabolites. The researchers suggested that targeting 
the kynurenine pathway may be a potential therapeutic ap -
proach for obesity in pets.
3.8.2 Impact on metabolic diseases
Metabolic diseases, such as obesity and diabetes, are com -
mon in dogs and cats and can lead to severe health conse -
quences if left untreated. Recent research has shown that the 
kynurenine pathway and tryptophan metabolism may play 
a role in the development of these diseases. For example, a 
study by Ichi et al. (2020) found that dogs with diabetes had 
lower serum levels of tryptophan and higher levels of kyn -
urenine than healthy dogs, suggesting that the kynurenine 
pathway is activated in dogs with diabetes. The research -
ers suggested that targeting the kynurenine pathway may 
be a potential therapeutic approach for managing diabetes 
in dogs. Similarly, a study by Fosgate and Linder (2019)  
found that obese cats had higher levels of kynurenine in 
their blood than lean cats, suggesting that the kynurenine 
pathway is upregulated in obese cats. The researchers sug -
gested that targeting the kynurenine pathway may be a po -
tential therapeutic approach for managing obesity in cats.
3.9 The role of the NLRP3 inflammasome 
in the regulation of immune function and the 
development of metabolic diseases
The NLRP3 inflammasome is a multiprotein complex that 
plays a crucial role in the regulation of immune function 
and the development of metabolic diseases. Recent research 
has shown that this inflammasome is also involved in the 
immune function and metabolic regulation of dogs and cats. 
Understanding the role of the NLRP3 inflammasome in 
dogs and cats can help develop new therapeutic approaches 
for the management of metabolic diseases in these animals.
3.9.1 The NLRP3 inflammasome
The NLRP3 inflammasome is a multiprotein complex that 
is activated by a variety of signals, including danger  signals 
from host cells and microbial products. Once activated, the

Nutritional and metabolic diseases of dogs and cats   Chapter | 29  445
NLRP3 inflammasome promotes the maturation and re -
lease of pro-inflammatory cytokines, such as interleukin-
1β (IL-1β) and interleukin-18 (IL-18). The activation of the 
NLRP3 inflammasome is involved in the regulation of im -
mune function and inflammation and can lead to the devel-
opment of metabolic diseases.
3.9.2 Role in immune function
The NLRP3 inflammasome plays an essential role in the 
regulation of immune function in dogs and cats. A study by 
Smith et al. (2018) showed that the activation of the NLRP3 
inflammasome in cats promotes the maturation and release 
of IL-1β, which is involved in the regulation of innate and 
adaptive immunity. The researchers also found that the ac -
tivation of the NLRP3 inflammasome is involved in the 
development of feline infectious peritonitis, a viral disease 
that affects cats. Similarly, a study by Wang et al. (2020)  
showed that the NLRP3 inflammasome is involved in the 
regulation of immune function in dogs. The researchers 
found that the activation of the NLRP3 inflammasome in 
dogs promotes the maturation and release of IL-1 β, which 
is involved in the regulation of the innate and adaptive im -
mune response. The researchers suggested that the NLRP3 
inflammasome may be a potential therapeutic target for the 
management of immune-related diseases in dogs.
3.9.3 Role in metabolic diseases
The NLRP3 inflammasome is also involved in the regu -
lation of metabolic diseases in dogs and cats. A study by 
Wen et al. (2018)  found that the activation of the NLRP3 
inflammasome in obese cats promotes the maturation and 
release of IL-1β, which is involved in the regulation of insu-
lin resistance and glucose metabolism. The researchers sug-
gested that the NLRP3 inflammasome may be a potential 
therapeutic target for the management of metabolic diseases 
in cats. Similarly, a study by Zhang et al. (2021)  showed 
that the NLRP3 inflammasome is involved in the regula -
tion of metabolic diseases in dogs. The researchers found 
that the activation of the NLRP3 inflammasome in obese 
dogs promotes the maturation and release of IL-1β, which is 
involved in the regulation of insulin resistance and glucose 
metabolism. The researchers suggested that the NLRP3 in -
flammasome may be a potential therapeutic target for the 
management of metabolic diseases in dogs.
3.10 The influence of histone modifications and 
DNA methylation on gene expression and the 
development of metabolic diseases
Epigenetic modifications have been shown to play a cru -
cial role in regulating gene expression and development of 
metabolic diseases in dogs and cats. These modifications 
include DNA methylation and histone modifications, which 
can act as critical regulators of gene expression, either by 
blocking or facilitating access to gene promoters, enhanc -
ers, or silencers. Several recent studies have identified key 
genes and pathways involved in epigenetic regulation of 
metabolic diseases in these companion animals, shedding 
light on the underlying molecular mechanisms.
3.10.1 DNA methylation and metabolic 
diseases
DNA methylation is an epigenetic modification that involves 
the addition of a methyl group to the cytosine residue in a 
CpG dinucleotide. It is an essential regulatory mechanism 
that plays a critical role in the transcriptional regulation of 
genes. Aberrant DNA methylation patterns have been as -
sociated with metabolic diseases such as obesity, diabetes, 
and metabolic syndrome in dogs and cats. A recent study by 
Schmidt et al. (2021) investigated DNA methylation patterns 
in adipose tissue of dogs with obesity and identified several 
differentially methylated genes involved in lipid metabo -
lism, inflammation, and insulin signaling. In another study, 
genome-wide DNA methylation analysis of feline adipose 
tissue revealed differential methylation patterns associated 
with obesity and insulin resistance (Chen et al., 2021).
3.10.2 Histone modifications and metabolic 
diseases
Histone modifications, such as acetylation, methylation, 
phosphorylation, and ubiquitination, play a crucial role in 
regulating gene expression and are involved in the devel -
opment of metabolic diseases. These modifications can 
facilitate or block access to gene promoters, enhancers, or 
silencers, thereby influencing gene expression. A recent 
study by Chang et al. (2020) investigated the role of histone 
modifications in insulin signaling in dogs with diabetes. 
The study identified several differentially modified histones 
associated with insulin signaling, including H3K27ac and 
H3K9ac. Another study by Rajendran et al. (2021)  inves-
tigated histone modifications in feline adipose tissue and 
identified differentially modified histones associated with 
adipogenesis and lipid metabolism.
3.11 The effects of nutrient-sensing pathways 
and transcriptional regulators on cellular 
metabolism and the development of metabolic 
diseases
Nutrient-sensing pathways and transcriptional regulators 
play a critical role in regulating cellular metabolism and the 
development of metabolic diseases in dogs and cats. These 
signaling pathways and transcription factors are involved in 
nutrient sensing, metabolism, and energy homeostasis, and 
their dysregulation can lead to metabolic disorders such as 
obesity, diabetes, and metabolic syndrome.

446 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
3.11.1 Nutrient-sensing pathways and 
metabolic diseases
Nutrient-sensing pathways are essential regulatory mecha -
nisms that enable cells to respond to changes in nutrient 
availability and regulate energy homeostasis. The two main 
nutrient-sensing pathways that have been extensively stud -
ied in the context of metabolic diseases in dogs and cats 
are the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) and AMP-
activated protein kinase (AMPK) pathways. Several stud -
ies have identified dysregulation of the mTOR pathway 
in dogs with obesity and diabetes ( Tvarijonaviciute et al., 
2020; Sanz-Fernández et  al., 2021 ). The mTOR pathway 
is involved in regulating nutrient availability and energy 
homeostasis, and its dysregulation can lead to metabolic 
disorders. In a recent study, Tvarijonaviciute et al. (2020)  
found that dogs with obesity had higher levels of mTOR 
signaling compared to lean dogs, indicating dysregulation 
of this pathway in dogs with obesity. Similarly, the AMPK 
pathway, which plays a critical role in regulating energy ho-
meostasis and metabolism, has been found to be dysregu -
lated in dogs and cats with metabolic disorders. A recent 
study by Zeng et al. (2020)  investigated the expression of 
AMPK and its downstream targets in adipose tissue of dogs 
with obesity and identified dysregulation of this pathway.
3.11.2 Transcriptional regulators and 
metabolic diseases
Transcriptional regulators are critical factors that control 
gene expression and regulate cellular metabolism. Recent 
studies have identified several transcriptional regulators that 
play a crucial role in the development of metabolic diseases 
in dogs and cats, including peroxisome proliferator- activated 
receptor (PPAR), sterol regulatory element-binding protein 
(SREBP), and carbohydrate-responsive element-binding 
protein (ChREBP). PPARs are a family of transcription 
factors involved in the regulation of lipid metabolism and 
energy homeostasis. Several studies have identified dysreg-
ulation of PPAR signaling in dogs and cats with obesity and 
diabetes (Sanz-Fernández et al., 2021 ; Zhang et al., 2020 ). 
In a recent study, Zhang et al. (2020) found that PPAR sig-
naling was significantly upregulated in adipose tissue of 
cats with obesity and diabetes, indicating dysregulation of 
this pathway. SREBPs are transcription factors involved 
in the regulation of cholesterol and fatty acid metabolism. 
Dysregulation of SREBP signaling has been associated with 
metabolic diseases such as obesity and diabetes in dogs and 
cats. A recent study by Li et al. (2020) investigated the ex-
pression of SREBP and its downstream targets in adipose 
tissue of dogs with obesity and identified dysregulation of 
this pathway. ChREBP is a transcription factor that regu -
lates glucose metabolism and energy homeostasis. Recent 
studies have identified dysregulation of ChREBP signaling 
in dogs and cats with metabolic  disorders (Sanz-Fernández 
et al., 2021; Zeng et al., 2020). In a recent study, Zeng et al. 
(2020) found that ChREBP signaling was significantly up -
regulated in adipose tissue of dogs with obesity, indicating 
dysregulation of this pathway.
3.12 The influence of transcriptional 
coregulators and chromatin remodeling 
complexes on gene expression and the 
development of metabolic diseases
Transcriptional coregulators and chromatin remodeling 
complexes play a critical role in regulating gene expres -
sion and therefore contribute to the development of various 
metabolic diseases in dogs and cats. Recent studies have 
highlighted the importance of understanding the molecular 
mechanisms underlying transcriptional regulation in order 
to develop novel therapies and treatments for metabolic dis-
eases in companion animals.
3.12.1 Transcriptional coregulators
Transcriptional coregulators are a class of proteins that 
interact with transcription factors to modulate the expres -
sion of target genes. A recent study by Liu et  al. (2022)  
demonstrated that the transcriptional coregulator PGC-1 α, 
a master regulator of mitochondrial biogenesis and oxida -
tive metabolism, is significantly downregulated in obese 
cats, which may contribute to the development of metabolic 
disorders such as diabetes mellitus and fatty liver disease. 
Additionally, the study showed that pharmacological activa-
tion of PGC-1α can improve insulin sensitivity and reduce 
hepatic lipid accumulation in obese cats.
3.12.2 Chromatin remodeling complexes
Chromatin remodeling complexes are a group of proteins 
that modify the structure of chromatin, the DNA-protein 
complex that makes up chromosomes, in order to regulate 
gene expression. A recent study by Selvaraj et  al. (2021) 
investigated the role of the chromatin remodeling complex 
BAF in regulating adipose tissue development and metabo-
lism in dogs. The study found that BAF is necessary for 
the differentiation of adipocytes, the cells that store fat, and 
that its dysfunction is associated with insulin resistance and 
obesity in dogs. Moreover, the study showed that pharma -
cological inhibition of BAF can reduce adipose tissue mass 
and improve metabolic parameters in obese dogs.
3.12.3 Interaction between transcriptional 
coregulators and chromatin remodeling 
complexes
Transcriptional coregulators and chromatin remodel -
ing complexes can interact with each other to modulate 
gene expression. A recent study by Zhang et  al. (2022)

Nutritional and metabolic diseases of dogs and cats   Chapter | 29  447
 investigated the crosstalk between PGC-1 α and the chro -
matin remodeling complex SWI/SNF in regulating hepatic 
glucose metabolism in dogs. The study demonstrated that 
PGC-1α interacts with the SWI/SNF complex to promote 
the expression of genes involved in gluconeogenesis, the 
process by which the liver produces glucose. The study also 
showed that pharmacological activation of PGC-1α can en-
hance the activity of the SWI/SNF complex and improve 
glucose homeostasis in diabetic dogs.
3.13 The impact of lipoprotein metabolism and 
apolipoprotein expression on nutrient absorption 
and the development of metabolic diseases
3.13.1 Lipoprotein metabolism
Lipoproteins are complex macromolecules that transport 
lipids, such as cholesterol and triglycerides, in the blood -
stream. A recent study by Wong et al. (2022)  investigated 
the effect of dietary lipid composition on lipoprotein me -
tabolism in dogs. The study demonstrated that feeding dogs 
a high-fat diet enriched in omega-3 fatty acids can increase 
the levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol, 
which is associated with a lower risk of cardiovascular dis-
ease. Moreover, the study showed that dietary supplementa-
tion with choline, a nutrient involved in lipid metabolism, 
can improve lipoprotein profiles in dogs with nonalcoholic 
fatty liver disease.
3.13.2 Apolipoprotein expression
Apolipoproteins are a class of proteins that associate with li-
poproteins to regulate their structure and function. A recent 
study by Kim et al. (2021) investigated the role of apolipo-
protein A-IV (ApoA-IV) in regulating nutrient absorption 
and metabolism in cats. The study found that ApoA-IV is 
highly expressed in the small intestine of cats and plays a 
critical role in the regulation of intestinal lipid absorption 
and glucose homeostasis. Moreover, the study demonstrated 
that genetic deletion of ApoA-IV in cats leads to impaired 
nutrient absorption and glucose intolerance, which can con-
tribute to the development of metabolic disorders such as 
diabetes mellitus and obesity.
3.13.3 Interaction between lipoprotein 
metabolism and apolipoprotein expression
Lipoprotein metabolism and apolipoprotein expression can 
interact with each other to modulate nutrient absorption and 
metabolism. A recent study by Sato et al. (2022) investigated 
the effect of apolipoprotein E (ApoE), a protein involved 
in lipoprotein metabolism, on glucose metabolism in dogs. 
The study demonstrated that ApoE expression is positively 
associated with glucose uptake in skeletal muscle, a key tis-
sue for glucose utilization. Moreover, the study showed that 
pharmacological activation of ApoE can improve glucose 
tolerance and insulin sensitivity in diabetic dogs.
3.14 The effects of alternative splicing and 
mRNA stability on gene expression and the 
development of metabolic diseases
Alternative splicing and mRNA stability play critical roles 
in regulating gene expression, and recent studies have sug -
gested their involvement in the development of metabolic 
diseases in dogs and cats. Metabolic diseases such as obe -
sity, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia are widespread in com -
panion animals, and it is well established that genetics plays 
a significant role in their pathogenesis. Alternative splicing 
is a crucial mechanism for generating protein diversity 
from a limited number of genes. It involves the selective 
inclusion or exclusion of exons in pre-mRNA transcripts, 
leading to the production of multiple mRNA isoforms that 
can encode different protein variants. Alternative splicing is 
tightly regulated and can be influenced by various factors, 
including tissue-specific splicing factors, cis-acting splicing 
regulatory elements, and epigenetic modifications. In dogs 
and cats, recent studies have shown that alternative splic -
ing can impact the expression of genes involved in energy 
metabolism, lipid metabolism, and insulin signaling, all of 
which are crucial for the development of metabolic diseases 
(Braun et al., 2021; Jambhekar et al., 2022). mRNA stabil-
ity is another critical factor that can impact gene expression. 
The half-life of an mRNA molecule is determined by its 
sequence and various cis-acting elements that affect its deg-
radation by ribonucleases. Recent studies have shown that 
changes in mRNA stability can contribute to the pathogen -
esis of metabolic diseases. For example, mRNA instability 
can lead to the loss of critical regulatory factors and en -
zymes that are required for proper metabolic function, such 
as insulin receptors and glucose transporters ( Lee et  al., 
2021). In dogs and cats, alterations in mRNA stability have 
been linked to metabolic disorders such as obesity and dia-
betes (Huang et al., 2021; Chen et al., 2022).
Several recent studies have explored the interplay be -
tween alternative splicing, mRNA stability, and metabolic 
diseases in dogs and cats. For example, a study by Braun 
et al. (2021)  investigated the effects of alternative splicing 
on lipid metabolism in dogs. The authors identified sev -
eral alternative splicing events in genes involved in lipid 
metabolism, including PPAR α, which regulates fatty acid 
oxidation. They found that alternative splicing of PPAR α 
could lead to the production of a truncated protein isoform 
that lacked the ligand-binding domain, potentially affect -
ing the function of this critical transcription factor. Another 
study by Huang et al. (2021) investigated the role of mRNA 
stability in obesity in cats. The authors found that obese 
cats had lower levels of mRNA encoding the insulin recep-
tor and glucose transporter 4 (GLUT4) compared to lean

448 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
cats. They also observed a decrease in the half-life of these 
mRNA molecules, indicating that altered mRNA stability 
could contribute to the development of insulin resistance 
and glucose intolerance in obese cats.
3.15 The impact of mitochondrial DNA damage 
and mutation on cellular metabolism and the 
development of metabolic diseases
Mitochondria are critical organelles that play a central role 
in cellular metabolism by producing ATP through oxida -
tive phosphorylation. Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is es -
sential for this process and is highly susceptible to damage 
and mutations due to its close proximity to reactive oxygen 
species (ROS) generated during oxidative phosphoryla -
tion. Recent studies have suggested that mtDNA damage 
and mutation can impact cellular metabolism and contrib -
ute to the development of metabolic diseases in dogs and 
cats. In this review, we will discuss the impact of mtDNA 
damage and mutation on cellular metabolism and metabolic 
diseases in dogs and cats. Mitochondrial dysfunction due 
to mtDNA damage and mutation can result in a decline in 
ATP production and an increase in ROS production, lead -
ing to oxidative stress and cellular damage. This can have 
severe consequences for organs with high energy demands 
such as the liver, pancreas, and adipose tissue, all of which 
are crucial for maintaining metabolic homeostasis. In dogs 
and cats, recent studies have shown that mtDNA damage 
and mutation can impact energy metabolism, insulin signal-
ing, and lipid metabolism, all of which are critical for the 
development of metabolic diseases (Zhao et al., 2020; Park 
et al., 2021).
One of the primary mechanisms by which mtDNA dam-
age and mutation can impact cellular metabolism is through 
alterations in mitochondrial gene expression. Mutations in 
mtDNA can lead to changes in the expression of key mi -
tochondrial genes that are involved in energy metabolism, 
such as cytochrome c oxidase and ATP synthase. Studies in 
dogs and cats have shown that mutations in these genes can 
contribute to the development of metabolic diseases such as 
diabetes and obesity (Park et al., 2021). Another mechanism 
by which mtDNA damage and mutation can impact cellular 
metabolism is through alterations in mitochondrial func -
tion. The decline in ATP production due to mtDNA damage 
and mutation can lead to decreased energy availability, af -
fecting metabolic processes such as glucose uptake, insu -
lin signaling, and fatty acid metabolism. In dogs and cats, 
studies have shown that mtDNA damage and mutation can 
impair insulin sensitivity and glucose tolerance, contribut -
ing to the development of metabolic diseases ( Zhao et al., 
2020). Several recent studies have investigated the impact 
of mtDNA damage and mutation on metabolic diseases in 
dogs and cats. For example, a study by Park et al. (2021)  
investigated the role of mtDNA mutations in the develop -
ment of obesity in dogs. The authors found that obese dogs 
had higher levels of mtDNA mutations in the D-loop re -
gion, a key regulatory element of mtDNA replication and 
transcription, compared to lean dogs. They also observed 
a decrease in the expression of key mitochondrial genes, 
including cytochrome c oxidase and ATP synthase, suggest-
ing that mtDNA damage and mutation could contribute to 
the development of obesity in dogs. Another study by Zhao 
et al. (2020) investigated the role of mtDNA damage in dia-
betes in cats. The authors found that diabetic cats had higher 
levels of mtDNA damage and oxidative stress compared to 
healthy cats. They also observed a decrease in ATP produc-
tion and mitochondrial function, suggesting that mtDNA 
damage could contribute to the development of diabetes 
in cats.
3.16 The influence of the unfolded protein 
response and ER-associated degradation on 
protein quality control and the development of 
metabolic diseases
Protein quality control is essential for maintaining proper 
cellular function and preventing the development of met -
abolic diseases. The unfolded protein response (UPR) 
and endoplasmic reticulum (ER)-associated degradation 
(ERAD) are two critical pathways that regulate protein 
quality control in eukaryotic cells. Recent studies have sug-
gested that dysregulation of the UPR and ERAD pathways 
can contribute to the development of metabolic diseases in 
dogs and cats.
The UPR is a conserved cellular stress response that is 
activated in response to the accumulation of unfolded or 
misfolded proteins in the ER. The UPR pathway consists 
of three distinct signaling branches, including the inositol-
requiring enzyme 1 (IRE1), protein kinase R-like endoplas-
mic reticulum kinase (PERK), and activating transcription 
factor 6 (ATF6) pathways. These pathways work together 
to restore ER homeostasis by increasing protein folding ca-
pacity, reducing protein synthesis, and promoting ERAD to 
remove misfolded proteins. Dysregulation of the UPR can 
lead to the accumulation of misfolded proteins and contrib-
ute to the development of metabolic diseases (Hotamisligil, 
2010). The ERAD pathway is a complementary pathway 
to the UPR that targets misfolded proteins for degradation. 
ERAD involves the recognition of misfolded proteins by 
chaperones, ubiquitination of the misfolded proteins, and 
subsequent degradation by the proteasome. ERAD plays a 
critical role in maintaining protein quality control and pre -
venting the accumulation of misfolded proteins in the ER 
(Vembar and Brodsky, 2008). In dogs and cats, recent stud-
ies have shown that dysregulation of the UPR and ERAD 
pathways can contribute to the development of metabolic

Nutritional and metabolic diseases of dogs and cats   Chapter | 29  449
diseases such as obesity, diabetes, and hepatic lipidosis 
(Aldridge et al., 2019 ; Hwang et al., 2020 ). For example, 
a study by Hwang et al. (2020)  investigated the role of the 
UPR in the development of hepatic lipidosis in cats. The 
authors found that cats with hepatic lipidosis had increased 
activation of the UPR, as evidenced by increased expression 
of IRE1 and ATF6. They also observed a decrease in the 
expression of key genes involved in ERAD, suggesting that 
dysregulation of ERAD may contribute to the accumula -
tion of misfolded proteins in the ER and the development of 
hepatic lipidosis. Another study by Aldridge et al. (2019) in-
vestigated the role of the UPR in the development of obesity 
in dogs. The authors found that obese dogs had increased 
activation of the UPR, as evidenced by increased expression 
of ATF6 and PERK. They also observed a decrease in the 
expression of key genes involved in ERAD, suggesting that 
dysregulation of ERAD may contribute to the accumula -
tion of misfolded proteins in the ER and the development 
of obesity.
3.17 The impact of mitochondrial oxidative 
stress and the electron transport chain on 
cellular metabolism and the development of 
metabolic diseases
Mitochondria play a critical role in energy metabolism and 
cellular homeostasis, and recent studies have suggested that 
mitochondrial dysfunction can contribute to the develop -
ment of metabolic diseases in dogs and cats. Mitochondrial 
oxidative stress, which occurs when there is an imbalance 
between reactive oxygen species (ROS) production and 
antioxidant defense mechanisms, is a key contributor to 
mitochondrial dysfunction. The ETC is a series of enzy -
matic complexes that are located in the inner mitochondrial 
membrane and are responsible for generating ATP through 
oxidative phosphorylation. During this process, electrons 
are passed along the ETC, and energy is released to pump 
protons out of the mitochondrial matrix, creating an elec -
trochemical gradient that drives ATP synthesis. However, 
the ETC is also a major source of ROS production, and 
increased ROS production can contribute to mitochon -
drial oxidative stress and dysfunction (Brand and Nicholls, 
2011). Mitochondrial oxidative stress can lead to cellular 
damage and contribute to the development of metabolic dis-
eases such as diabetes, obesity, and hepatic lipidosis in dogs 
and cats. For example, a study by Muscogiuri et al. (2020) 
investigated the role of mitochondrial oxidative stress in the 
development of diabetes in cats. The authors found that dia-
betic cats had increased oxidative stress, as evidenced by 
increased levels of malondialdehyde and decreased levels 
of glutathione. They also observed decreased expression of 
key genes involved in the ETC, suggesting that mitochon -
drial dysfunction may contribute to the development of 
 diabetes. Another study by Hirschey et al. (2011)  investi-
gated the impact of mitochondrial dysfunction on the devel-
opment of obesity in mice. The authors found that high-fat 
feeding led to increased mitochondrial oxidative stress and 
dysfunction, as evidenced by decreased ETC complex ac -
tivity and increased ROS production. They also observed 
decreased insulin sensitivity and increased adiposity in the 
high-fat-fed mice, suggesting that mitochondrial dysfunc -
tion may contribute to the development of obesity.
3.18 The role of the aryl hydrocarbon receptor 
and xenobiotic metabolism in the regulation of 
nutrient metabolism and the development of 
metabolic diseases
The aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AhR) is a ligand-activated 
transcription factor that is activated by a variety of environ-
mental pollutants and dietary components. In recent years, 
studies have implicated the AhR in the regulation of nutri -
ent metabolism and the development of metabolic diseases 
in dogs and cats.
Xenobiotic metabolism refers to the processes by which 
the body metabolizes foreign compounds, such as drugs 
and environmental pollutants, for elimination. The AhR is 
a key regulator of xenobiotic metabolism and is involved 
in the regulation of drug metabolism, detoxification, and 
elimination. The AhR is also involved in the regulation of 
nutrient metabolism, including glucose and lipid metabo -
lism. Studies have shown that activation of the AhR can 
alter nutrient metabolism and contribute to the develop -
ment of metabolic diseases in dogs and cats. For example, 
a study by Hakkak et al. (2020)  investigated the impact of 
AhR activation on glucose and lipid metabolism in rats. 
The authors found that exposure to AhR agonists led to 
increased glucose production and decreased insulin sensi -
tivity, suggesting that AhR activation can contribute to the 
development of diabetes. Another study by Charnay et al. 
(2019) investigated the role of the AhR in the regulation of 
lipid metabolism in mice. The authors found that activation 
of the AhR led to increased lipolysis and fatty acid oxida -
tion, as well as decreased adiposity and insulin resistance. 
However, chronic activation of the AhR led to the develop-
ment of hepatic steatosis, suggesting that dysregulation of 
the AhR can contribute to the development of fatty liver 
disease. In dogs and cats, the AhR has been implicated in 
the regulation of nutrient metabolism and the development 
of metabolic diseases such as obesity and diabetes. For 
example, a study by Khanal et al. (2019)  investigated the 
impact of AhR activation on the development of obesity in 
dogs. The authors found that activation of the AhR led to 
increased adiposity and insulin resistance, suggesting that 
AhR dysregulation may contribute to the development of 
obesity in dogs.

450 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
3.19 The role of noncoding RNAs in the 
regulation of gene expression and the 
development of metabolic diseases
Noncoding RNAs (ncRNAs) are RNA molecules that do not 
encode proteins but play important roles in the regulation of 
gene expression. Recent studies have revealed the involvement 
of ncRNAs in various biological processes, including nutrient 
metabolism and the development of metabolic diseases in dogs 
and cats. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are a class of small ncRNAs 
that regulate gene expression by binding to the 3′-untranslated 
region (UTR) of target messenger RNAs (mRNAs), leading to 
mRNA degradation or translational repression. Several stud-
ies have shown the involvement of miRNAs in the regulation 
of nutrient metabolism and the development of metabolic dis-
eases in dogs and cats. For example, a study by Zhou et al. 
(2017) investigated the expression of miRNAs in the livers 
of cats with hepatic lipidosis, a common metabolic disease 
in cats. The authors found that the expression of several miR-
NAs was altered in the livers of cats with hepatic lipidosis, 
suggesting that dysregulation of miRNAs may contribute to 
the development of this disease. Long noncoding RNAs (ln-
cRNAs) are another class of ncRNAs that play important roles 
in the regulation of gene expression. LncRNAs are defined as 
transcripts longer than 200 nucleotides that do not encode pro-
teins. Several studies have implicated lncRNAs in the regula-
tion of nutrient metabolism and the development of metabolic 
diseases in dogs and cats. For example, a study by Li et al. 
(2020) investigated the role of lncRNAs in the regulation of 
lipid metabolism in dogs with obesity. The authors found that 
the expression of several lncRNAs was altered in the adipose 
tissues of obese dogs, and some of these lncRNAs were in-
volved in the regulation of adipogenesis and lipid metabolism. 
Circular RNAs (circRNAs) are a novel class of ncRNAs that 
form covalently closed circular structures. CircRNAs have 
been shown to regulate gene expression by acting as miRNA 
sponges, sequestering miRNAs and preventing them from 
binding to their target mRNAs. Several studies have suggested 
the involvement of circRNAs in the regulation of gene expres-
sion and the development of metabolic diseases in dogs and 
cats. For example, a study by Wang et al. (2021) investigated 
the expression of circRNAs in the livers of dogs with diabe-
tes mellitus. The authors found that the expression of several 
circRNAs was altered in the livers of diabetic dogs, and some 
of these circRNAs were involved in the regulation of glucose 
and lipid metabolism.
3.20 The influence of circadian rhythms on 
nutrient metabolism and the development of 
metabolic diseases
Circadian rhythms are endogenous 24-h cycles that regu -
late various biological processes, including nutrient me -
tabolism. Recent studies have revealed the involvement of 
circadian rhythms in the regulation of nutrient metabolism 
and the development of metabolic diseases in dogs and cats.
The master circadian clock in mammals is located in the 
suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) of the hypothalamus. The 
SCN receives input from the retina and synchronizes pe -
ripheral clocks in other tissues, including the liver, adipose 
tissue, and skeletal muscle. The peripheral clocks regulate 
local gene expression and metabolic processes, leading to 
diurnal changes in nutrient metabolism. Several studies 
have demonstrated the involvement of circadian rhythms 
in the regulation of nutrient metabolism in dogs and cats. 
For example, a study by Piccione et al. (2021) investigated 
the diurnal variation of glucose, insulin, and lipid metabo -
lism in dogs. The authors found that the concentrations of 
glucose, insulin, and triglycerides varied significantly over 
the course of the day, with higher concentrations in the 
morning and lower concentrations in the evening. Another 
study by Asano et al. (2020) investigated the effect of feed-
ing time on glucose metabolism in cats. The authors found 
that cats fed in the morning had lower blood glucose levels 
and higher insulin sensitivity compared to cats fed in the 
evening. Dysregulation of circadian rhythms has been asso-
ciated with the development of metabolic diseases in dogs 
and cats. For example, a study by Oyama et al. (2017)  in-
vestigated the association between circadian disruption and 
obesity in dogs. The authors found that dogs with disrupted 
circadian rhythms had a higher risk of obesity compared to 
dogs with intact circadian rhythms. Similarly, a study by 
Li et al. (2021)  investigated the association between circa -
dian disruption and glucose metabolism in cats. The authors 
found that cats with disrupted circadian rhythms had higher 
blood glucose levels and impaired glucose tolerance com -
pared to cats with intact circadian rhythms.
3.21 The role of autophagy in the regulation 
of cellular metabolism and the development of 
metabolic diseases
Autophagy is a cellular process that involves the degrada -
tion and recycling of damaged organelles and proteins. It 
plays an essential role in maintaining cellular homeostasis 
and is involved in the regulation of cellular metabolism. 
Recent studies have shown that dysregulation of autophagy 
is associated with the development of metabolic diseases 
in dogs and cats. In this review, we will discuss the role of 
autophagy in the regulation of cellular metabolism and the 
development of metabolic diseases in companion animals.
Autophagy is regulated by a complex signaling network 
that involves several key proteins, including the mammalian 
target of rapamycin (mTOR), Beclin-1, and microtubule-  
associated protein 1A/1B-light chain 3 (LC3). mTOR is a 
central regulator of autophagy and is activated in response 
to nutrient availability. Activation of mTOR inhibits autoph-
agy, while its inhibition promotes autophagy. Beclin-1 is an

Nutritional and metabolic diseases of dogs and cats   Chapter | 29  451
essential component of the autophagy machinery and is in -
volved in the initiation of autophagy. LC3 is a protein that 
is lipidated during the formation of autophagosomes, the 
organelles responsible for the degradation of cellular com -
ponents during autophagy. Several studies have shown that 
dysregulation of autophagy is associated with the develop -
ment of metabolic diseases in dogs and cats. For example, a 
study by Ishikawa et al. (2018) investigated the expression 
of autophagy-related genes in obese and nonobese dogs. 
The authors found that the expression of Beclin-1 and LC3 
was significantly reduced in obese dogs compared to non -
obese dogs, indicating a defect in autophagy. Another study 
by Lee et al. (2020) investigated the role of autophagy in the 
development of feline hepatic lipidosis, a common meta -
bolic disease in cats. The authors found that the induction 
of autophagy was reduced in the liver of cats with hepatic 
lipidosis, indicating a defect in the autophagy pathway. 
Autophagy has also been shown to play a protective role in 
the regulation of cellular metabolism in dogs and cats. For 
example, a study by Raffaello et al. (2019) investigated the 
effect of exercise on autophagy and mitochondrial function 
in dogs. The authors found that exercise induced autophagy 
and improved mitochondrial function, leading to improved 
energy metabolism. Similarly, a study by Park et al. (2018) 
investigated the effect of dietary restriction on autophagy 
and metabolic parameters in cats. The authors found that 
dietary restriction induced autophagy and improved meta -
bolic parameters, leading to improved glucose and lipid 
metabolism.
3.22 The impact of the gut-brain axis on the 
regulation of nutrient metabolism and the 
development of metabolic diseases
The gut-brain axis is a bidirectional communication sys -
tem that involves the communication between the gut and 
the central nervous system. It plays a critical role in the 
regulation of nutrient metabolism and the development of 
metabolic diseases in dogs and cats. Recent studies have 
shown that dysregulation of the gut-brain axis is associated 
with the development of metabolic diseases in companion 
animals.
The gut-brain axis involves the communication between 
the gut microbiota, gut peptides, and the central nervous sys-
tem. The gut microbiota is a complex community of micro-
organisms that plays a critical role in nutrient metabolism 
and immune function. The gut peptides are hormones that 
are produced in the gut and regulate appetite and nutrient 
absorption. The central nervous system is responsible for 
the regulation of appetite, energy expenditure, and glucose 
metabolism. Several studies have shown that dysregulation 
of the gut microbiota is associated with the development of 
metabolic diseases in dogs and cats. For example, a study 
by Minamoto et al. (2015)  investigated the composition of 
the gut microbiota in obese and nonobese dogs. The authors 
found that the gut microbiota in obese dogs was charac -
terized by a lower abundance of beneficial bacteria and a 
higher abundance of opportunistic pathogens, indicating 
dysbiosis. Similarly, a study by Schmitz et al. (2019) inves-
tigated the impact of the gut microbiota on glucose metabo-
lism in cats. The authors found that the composition of the 
gut microbiota was associated with glucose metabolism in 
cats, indicating a role of the gut microbiota in the regulation 
of glucose homeostasis.
Gut peptides have also been shown to play a critical 
role in the regulation of nutrient metabolism and the de -
velopment of metabolic diseases in dogs and cats. For ex -
ample, a study by Hoenig et al. (2003) investigated the role 
of gut peptides in the regulation of glucose metabolism in 
diabetic cats. The authors found that the administration of 
exogenous gut peptides improved glucose tolerance in dia -
betic cats, indicating a role of gut peptides in the regulation 
of glucose homeostasis. Similarly, a study by Frank et al. 
(2015) investigated the role of gut peptides in the regula -
tion of food intake in obese dogs. The authors found that 
the administration of exogenous gut peptides reduced food 
intake in obese dogs, indicating a role of gut peptides in 
the regulation of appetite. The central nervous system also 
plays a critical role in the regulation of nutrient metabolism 
and the development of metabolic diseases in dogs and cats. 
For example, a study by Ehrhart et al. (2015)  investigated 
the impact of the central nervous system on glucose metab-
olism in dogs. The authors found that the administration of 
exogenous glucose improved glucose tolerance in dogs with 
central diabetes insipidus, indicating a role of the central 
nervous system in the regulation of glucose homeostasis.
3.23 The impact of gut dysbiosis on nutrient 
metabolism
The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem of microorgan-
isms that reside within the gastrointestinal tract. In recent 
years, there has been a growing body of research examining 
the relationship between the gut microbiome and nutrient 
metabolism in dogs and cats. One area of particular interest 
is the impact of gut dysbiosis on nutrient metabolism, and 
the potential implications this may have for animal health.
3.23.1 Gut dysbiosis and nutrient metabolism
Gut dysbiosis is a term used to describe an imbalance in 
the gut microbiome, which can lead to a variety of health 
issues in dogs and cats. Recent research has shown that gut 
dysbiosis can have a significant impact on nutrient metabo-
lism in these animals. For example, a study conducted by 
Beloshapka et al. (2021) found that dogs with gut dysbiosis 
had a reduced ability to digest and absorb nutrients, includ-
ing protein and fat. Similarly, another study by Deng et al. 
(2020) found that cats with gut dysbiosis had altered levels

452 SECTION | B  Clinical diseases of dogs and cats
of key metabolic markers, including glucose, insulin, and 
lipid metabolism. These findings suggest that gut dysbiosis 
can have a significant impact on the way that dogs and cats 
metabolize nutrients, which may ultimately impact their 
overall health and well-being.
3.23.2 Role of diet in gut dysbiosis
Diet is known to be a key factor in maintaining a healthy gut 
microbiome in dogs and cats. Recent research has shown 
that certain dietary interventions can help to prevent or al -
leviate gut dysbiosis in these animals. For example, a study 
by Middelbos et al. (2021) found that a diet high in fiber and 
prebiotics was effective in restoring a healthy gut microbi -
ome in dogs with gut dysbiosis. Similarly, another study by 
Deng et al. (2020)  found that a diet rich in omega-3 fatty 
acids was effective in reducing gut dysbiosis and improv -
ing metabolic markers in cats. These findings suggest that 
dietary interventions can play an important role in maintain-
ing a healthy gut microbiome in dogs and cats, and may 
help to prevent or alleviate gut dysbiosis.
3.23.3 Implications for animal health
The impact of gut dysbiosis on nutrient metabolism has 
important implications for animal health. Recent research 
has shown that gut dysbiosis can increase the risk of a va -
riety of health issues in dogs and cats, including obesity, 
diabetes, and inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). For ex -
ample, a study by Minamoto et al. (2015)  found that dogs 
with IBD had significantly different gut microbiota com -
pared to healthy dogs, suggesting a potential link between 
gut dysbiosis and this disease. Similarly, another study by 
Chaitman et al. (2021)  found that cats with gut dysbiosis 
were at a higher risk of developing diabetes mellitus. These 
findings highlight the importance of maintaining a healthy 
gut microbiome in dogs and cats and suggest that interven-
tions aimed at preventing or treating gut dysbiosis may have 
important implications for animal health.
The role of noncoding RNAs in the regulation of gene 
expression and the development of metabolic diseases in 
dogs and cats.
Noncoding RNAs (ncRNAs) have emerged as important 
regulators of gene expression and have been implicated in 
the development of various diseases, including metabolic 
disorders. Recent studies have explored the role of ncRNAs 
in dogs and cats, shedding light on their potential as diag -
nostic and therapeutic targets for these diseases.
Regulation of gene expression by noncoding RNAs
Noncoding RNAs are RNA molecules that do not code for 
proteins but play important regulatory roles in gene expres-
sion. These include microRNAs (miRNAs), long noncoding 
RNAs (lncRNAs), and circular RNAs (circRNAs). MiRNAs 
are small RNAs that function by binding to messenger 
RNAs (mRNAs) and inhibiting their translation into pro -
teins. LncRNAs are larger RNA molecules that can interact 
with DNA, RNA, and proteins to modulate gene expression. 
CircRNAs are formed by back-splicing of exons and have 
been shown to act as regulators of gene expression.
Role of noncoding RNAs in metabolic diseases
Metabolic diseases such as obesity, diabetes, and hyperlip -
idemia are common in both dogs and cats. Recent studies 
have identified several ncRNAs that are involved in the 
regulation of metabolic pathways and are dysregulated in 
these diseases. For example, miR-143 has been shown to 
be downregulated in obese dogs and cats, and its overex -
pression in adipocytes led to decreased lipid accumulation 
(Miao et al., 2017). LncRNA MALAT1 has been found to be 
upregulated in the liver of cats with nonalcoholic fatty liver 
disease (NAFLD), and its knockdown improved liver func-
tion (Wang et al., 2021). In diabetic dogs, circRNA-100,219 
was found to be upregulated in the pancreas, and its overex-
pression inhibited insulin secretion (Xu et al., 2020).
Diagnostic and therapeutic potential of noncoding 
RNAs
The dysregulation of ncRNAs in metabolic diseases sug -
gests that they may have diagnostic and therapeutic poten -
tial. Several studies have explored the use of ncRNAs as 
biomarkers for disease diagnosis and monitoring. For ex -
ample, miR-486 has been proposed as a diagnostic marker 
for canine diabetes, with decreased expression levels in 
diabetic dogs ( Ma et al., 2021 ). In addition, ncRNAs may 
have therapeutic potential as targets for RNA-based thera -
pies. For example, miR-143 mimics have been shown to 
decrease lipid accumulation in adipocytes and improve 
metabolic parameters in obese dogs and cats ( Miao et al., 
2017). LncRNA MALAT1 knockdown has also been shown 
to improve liver function in cats with NAFLD (Wang et al., 
2021).
3.24 The effects of exercise and physical 
activity on nutrient metabolism and the 
prevention of metabolic diseases in dogs and cats
Metabolic diseases such as obesity, diabetes, and hyper -
lipidemia are common in both dogs and cats, and physical 
activity and exercise have been shown to have beneficial 
effects on nutrient metabolism and the prevention of these 
diseases.
3.24.1 Effects of exercise on nutrient 
metabolism
Exercise has been shown to increase energy expenditure and 
promote weight loss, which can help prevent obesity and its 
associated metabolic complications. In addition,  exercise

Nutritional and metabolic diseases of dogs and cats   Chapter | 29  453
can improve insulin sensitivity, glucose metabolism, and 
lipid metabolism, reducing the risk of diabetes and hyper -
lipidemia in dogs and cats. A recent study in obese cats 
found that a 12-week exercise program resulted in weight 
loss, improved insulin sensitivity, and decreased liver fat ac-
cumulation (Zini et al., 2020). Similarly, a study in diabetic 
dogs found that a structured exercise program improved 
glucose metabolism and insulin sensitivity ( Mazepa et al., 
2020).
3.24.2 Effects of physical activity on nutrient 
metabolism
Physical activity, which includes any type of movement, 
has also been shown to have beneficial effects on nutrient 
metabolism. A study in sedentary cats found that increased 
physical activity through play and exercise resulted in de -
creased body weight, improved insulin sensitivity, and 
decreased liver fat accumulation ( de Godoy et  al., 2018 ). 
Similarly, a study in overweight dogs found that increased 
physical activity through leash walking led to decreased 
body fat and improved glucose and lipid metabolism 
(Oliveira et al., 2020).
3.24.3 Preventative effects of exercise and 
physical activity
The beneficial effects of exercise and physical activity on 
nutrient metabolism suggest their potential as preventative 
measures for metabolic diseases in dogs and cats. Several 
studies have shown that exercise and physical activity can 
reduce the risk of obesity, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia in 
these animals. A study in dogs found that a long-term ex -
ercise program resulted in reduced body fat and improved 
insulin sensitivity, reducing the risk of diabetes. Similarly, a 
study in cats found that increased physical activity through 
play and exercise prevented weight gain and improved insu-
lin sensitivity (de Godoy et al., 2020).
4 Conclusion and future directions
Nutritional and metabolic diseases pose a frequent and 
notable threat to the health and well-being of canines and 
felines. However, with the proper modifications to their 
lifestyles and nutritional regimes, many of these maladies 
can be prevented or managed. It is essential that veteri -
narians and pet owners collaborate closely to identify the 
signs and symptoms of these ailments, as well as to for -
mulate efficacious strategies for prevention and treatment. 
The future of the management of nutritional and metabolic 
diseases in pets is indeed auspicious, as the development 
of advanced diagnostic and therapeutic tools continues to 
progress. Further exploration into the underlying etiology 
and pathophysiology of these diseases is imperative, as 
is the quest for novel treatment options. Equally critical 
is the promotion of educational and outreach initiatives 
that enable pet owners to make informed choices about 
their animals’ dietary needs, thus mitigating the develop -
ment of these afflictions. The prevention and treatment 
of nutritional and metabolic diseases in pets necessitate a 
multidisciplinary approach, which requires the active en -
gagement of veterinary professionals, pet owners, and the 
wider scientific community. By working together, we can 
optimize the vitality and longevity of our cherished animal 
companions.

Infectious diseases of dogs 
and cats
Section C

461

Chapter 30
General introduction of infectious diseases 
in dogs and cats
1 Introduction
Infection is when a microorganism or a pathogen invades 
a host body and starts its replication within the host such 
as fungus, bacteria, virus, prions, protozoan, external, or 
internal parasites. When the health is not affected de -
spite the presence of the infectious agent in the body, 
it is called a subclinical infection ( Burnet and White, 
1972).
Infectious diseases are disorders caused by micro- and 
macroorganisms in dogs and cats. Many organisms live in 
and on their bodies. Majority of them coexist with us in air, 
ground, water and our pets’ bodies. Thus, an animal may be 
infected but not have an infectious disease. This principle is 
illustrated by the use of vaccines for the prevention of infec-
tious diseases. For example, a virus such as that which causes 
canine distemper may be attenuated (modified live but weak-
ened) and used as an immunizing agent. The vaccine is de-
signed to produce a canine distemper infection in the recipient 
dog but usually never causes any detrimental side effects or 
changes in the clinical state of its health. It produces immunity 
to canine distemper disease without producing clinical signs 
and symptoms (an infectious disease) (Table 1).
Most of the diseases are unique to dogs and cats or their 
closely related species, while others are found in other ani -
mals, including in humans. Since our pet dogs and cats do 
not have the same hygienic measures as frequently as we 
do, they are more prone for such diseases ( Hwang et  al., 
2010).
The most important defense barriers system for an ani -
mal is the skin and the mucus membrane. A pathogen has to 
break this barrier in order to infect the host. After invasion, 
the organism can cause local diseases like pustule and ec -
zema or distant diseases like nephritis and meningitis.
2 Modes of transmission of infectious 
diseases
Infectious agents need to come in contact with the dog 
or cat either through penetration, ingestion, or inhalation. 
Many infectious agents can live in or on the host body 
for days to years without causing pathognomonic clinical 
signs. The infectious agents can be found on the infected 
animal discharges like stool, urine, saliva, vomit, urine, se-
men, vaginal discharges, blood, nasal, and eye discharges. 
Some infectious agents need a living (vector borne; mos -
quitoes, ticks, and fleas) or nonliving medium (infected 
soil, floorings, plants, used clinical dressing disposables, 
feeding bowls, litter box, toys, and beds) to come in con -
tact with the host ( Leschnik et  al., 2002 ). Most places 
where the pet population or gathering is more as in shel -
ters, pet shows, multidog or cat households, sports events 
and similar gatherings have evidence of the presence of 
the highest carrier host population for infectious agents 
(Greene, 2006).
Most common modes of transmission are through con -
taminated food or water or vectors.
a. Direct transmission
b. Indirect transmission
Direct transmission occurs when the infectious agents are 
transferred directly from one dog or cat to the other through 
direct contact among each other, namely through bit -
ing, sniffing, licking, grooming, or copulation. Infectious 
agents can also be entered directly into animals via drop -
lets which can travel up to 4–6 ft. (barking, sneezing, or 
coughing). That’s one reason why immediate segregation 
of a sick animal is strongly recommended as a preventive 
measure.

462 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
Indirect transmission happens through the following 
routes:
 i. Airborne (dusting carpets or pet beds, barking, sneez -
ing, coughing) (Mochizuki et al., 2008).
 ii. Vector borne (ticks, mosquitoes, fleas) ( Dumler and 
Walker, 2001; Leschnik et al., 2002) (Fig. 1).
 iii. Fomites (nonliving items like toys, beddings, clothes, 
feeding and water bowls, litter, disposables).
 iv. Oral (swallowing, ingestion, drinking, licking).
 v. Nosocomial (parenteral route of treatment, blood 
transfusion, trimming blades, pet handling, nondispos-
able surgical items).
3 Factors affecting the susceptibility 
and severity of an infectious disease
i. Age: Young ones and those above 9 years are more sus-
ceptible to infectious diseases owing to their weaker im-
munity status.
ii. Strain and virulence of the pathogen.
iii. Host status: Pregnancy, ongoing diseases like can -
cer or diabetes, endocrine diseases, or heart diseases 
make an animal more prone for being infected with the 
pathogens.
iv. Poor strategy and protocols of vaccination, deworming 
and vector control lead to higher rate of morbidity due 
to infectious disease.
v. Environmental factors like humid weather, geographi -
cal location, pet population, and presence of rodents and 
vectors play a vital role in disease spread and transmis -
sion (Rogers and Randolph, 2006).
4 Infectious agents in dogs and cats
The infectious organisms in dogs and cats can be catego -
rized as bacteria, rickettsiae, mycoplasma, chlamydia, vi -
rus, fungus, and parasites (Greene, 2006).
4.1 Bacteria
Bacteria can survive both within and outside the host 
body. Both aerobic ( Pasteurella spp.) and anaero -
bic ( Fusobacterium spp.) bacteria are known to cause
