General introduction of infectious diseases in dogs and cats  Chapter | 30  463
 infectious diseases in dogs and cats. Most commonly the 
bacteria with a capsule ( Streptococcus spp.) around itself 
are known to be pathogenic. Some of them produce toxins 
which lead to alteration in the balanced homeostasis of the 
host (Clostridium spp.).
4.2 Rickettsiae
Rickettsiae are mostly intracellular parasites in dogs and 
cats, named after an American pathologist Howard T. 
Ricketts. They are transmitted to the host mostly by arthro-
pod vectors. They commonly cause fever and rashes with 
pathogenesis similar to dengue fever. They are the prime 
hemoprotozoan which cause primary and secondary hemo-
stasis disorders in dogs.
4.3 Mycoplasma
Synonym Pleuropneumonia like organism. These are the 
smallest prokaryotic organisms with cells without a cell 
wall and belong to three families, namely Mycoplasma, 
Acholeplasma, and Ureaplasma. They are anaerobic, fastid-
ious gram-negative rods and usually affect ocular lesions, 
arthritis, respiratory, and gastrointestinal systems.
4.4 Virus
It is famously known to be the bridge between the living 
and the dead. Instead of a living organism, viruses are 
nucleic acid fragments (DNA or RNA), carried in a pro -
tein structure which obligatorily needs a living organism to 
replicate itself. They can be both species specific (retrovi -
ruses in cats; FIV/FeLV) and transmissible between species 
(Rabies-Lentivirus).
4.5 Fungi
Fungi are the large microorganisms which are mostly dis -
persed in soil or air leading to common skin and respiratory 
infections in cats and dogs (Malasseziosis). They exist as 
either yeast or molds.
4.6 Parasites
Parasites of dogs and cats can be characterized as ecto- and 
endoparasites. Ectoparasites mostly cause skin lesions, 
hair loss and allergy (Fleas and lice). Some act like vec -
tors for hemoprotozoan diseases (ticks) ( Leschnik et al., 
2002). Endoparasites are basically classified as ascarids 
(roundworms), cestodes (tapeworm), and trematodes 
(flukes). Preventive measures such as regular deworming 
and ectoparasite controls are well known to control their 
parasitism.
Confirmation of Otodectes cynotis in a cat on clinical presentation.
5 Clinical diagnosis of infectious 
diseases
Laboratory tests are the mainstay to confirm the pres -
ence of microorganisms in the given animal patient ( Nolte 
and Caliendo, 2011 ). Specific recommended tests for any

464 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
 particular disease and pathogen are discussed in detail in 
the following chapters. Most of the tests, especially the 
blood works though recommended to be done only in the 
veterinary labs or veterinary specific machines, can be run 
by a human grade machine. But this is not applicable for 
certain biomarkers and hormonal assays ( Greenlee et al., 
2004). It is the duty of the attending veterinary specialist 
to see that the recommended tests have the required speci -
ficity, sensitivity, and efficiency. Currently, most of the 
viral and bacterial diseases are preferred to be confirmed 
either by demonstration of the pathogen either on direct 
microscope or through polymerase chain reaction (PCR) 
(Cockerill III, 2003). It is the fact that no single diagnostic 
aid is 100% specific or 100% sensitive, but it is always 
advisable to have an in-house lab to lessen the time of 
sample processing and examination. Henceforth, for faster 
diagnosis and a better outcome of treatment, tests like vi -
rus isolation, histopathology, and PCR may need a sup -
portive lab setup which may be out of scope for a single 
private veterinary setup to afford ( Oikarinen et al., 2009 ). 
Parasitological techniques are mostly recommended to be 
done in house labs. Most of the major viral diseases can be 
diagnosed as bedside tests using commercially available 
serological rapid assays.
Pulmonary tumor in a cat with feline immunodeficiency virus infection.
Pale white mucus membrane in a cat with severe anemia in FeLV infection.
Rapid test kits in clinical practice to diagnose canine parvovirus infection.

General introduction of infectious diseases in dogs and cats  Chapter | 30  465
Heterogeneous echogenicity with hyperechoic focal lesion in liver of a dog 
with babesiosis.
6 Treatment of infectious diseases
Antibiotics, antiparasitics (both endoparasite and ectopara -
sites), and other antimicrobials are widely used in our small 
animal veterinary practice. Mostly either based on confir -
matory diagnosis or based on the animals signalment, clini-
cal anamnesis, clinical signs, and symptoms, it is always 
advised to select an antimicrobial based on the best pos -
sible outcomes and suitability for the given animal patient. 
For example, antibiotics like enrofloxacin are highly suit -
able for intestinal bacterial pathogens but not suitable for 
puppies due to possibilities of bone marrow suppression 
effects (Dowers et al., 2002). Antivirals like famciclovir are 
recommended for certain viral diseases in kittens but at the 
same time can lead to heavy immunosuppression side ef -
fects. Best medical decision can be made with respect to the 
usage of a particular antimicrobial by considering follow -
ing factors in veterinary practice which are important in the 
view of the author:
a. Availability and affordability by the pet parents.
b. Confirmatory diagnosis of the pathogens.
c. Clinical status and ability to handle the drug by the vet-
erinary patient.
d. Mode of action, possible collateral damage and un -
wanted concerns of a particular drug and treatment plan 
to counter them.
Most of the antimicrobials can alter the gut flora and lead to 
nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Hence, it is recommended 
to give antacids and pre/probiotics whenever long term or 
high dosage is required. Third-generation cephalosporins, 
fluoroquinolones, and tetracyclines can be a good combina-
tion to deal with combination of facultative, aerobic, and 
special organisms like mycoplasma. It is in the interest of 
the author to avoid antacids 2  h before or after the antimi -
crobials as antacids tend to inhibit their absorption through 
the gut. Cephalosporin and most of the tetracycline (except 
Doxycycline) absorption may also be impaired in the pres -
ence of food in the gut. Drugs like amoxicillin and metro -
nidazole are preferred to give with food. Purulent materials 
like pus, conditions like acidosis and low oxygen tension 
can delay or inhibit the effects of an antimicrobial too. 
Hence, aseptic cleaning and debridement of a wounded site 
of stabilization of metabolic/respiratory acidosis conditions 
are equally important.
Emergency whole blood transfusion in a dog with babesiosis.

466 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
7 Prevention and control
Not all infectious diseases are preventable. Term vaccina -
tion should not be mistaken with the term immunization, 
in the literature. Theoretically, no vaccination can provide 
100% immunity in a given dog and cat animal. Also most of 
the major life-threatening diseases are preventable through 
vector control and vaccinations. Proper regular deworming 
and ectoparasite control also plays a vital role in disease pre-
vention (Day et al., 2010 ). Several studies have evidenced 
that proper cleaning of the premises with regular antiviral 
and antiectoparasite chemicals has saved lots of outbreaks, 
especially in the setups like multipet households, shelters, 
and animal birth control camps. Following are a few recom-
mendations adopted from several international guidelines 
and daily practice experience for the prevention and control 
of infectious diseases in veterinary medicine:
● Ensuring proper quarantine protocols for new rescues in 
shelters or new animals before introducing them to an 
existing population or house.
● Regular disinfection with recommended disinfectants 
and limited population of the animals in a given space.
● Scientific construction facilities for dogs and cat shel -
ters and boarding houses.
● Proper ventilation and sunlight into the premises.
● Immediate identification of the sick animals and segre -
gation from the healthy population.
● Synchronized bathing and cleaning the premises proto -
cols. Youngest ones should be cleaned out first followed 
by the older ones.
● Avoiding contact with environments and objects that 
might be contaminated with infectious agents (e.g., dis-
posing off belongings of a sick dog or cat).
● Encouraging hand hygiene (washing hands with soap 
and water or using an alcohol-based hand sanitizer) by 
all staff of the veterinary setups and/or house members 
both when entering and leaving the facility.
● Regular veterinary checkups and early identification 
and isolation of potentially infectious dogs from other 
dogs in the group.
● Balanced food and regular supplementation of essential 
fatty acids and multivitamins specially in young and old 
pets.
● Regular vaccinations, deworming and vector control on 
the animals as well for the premises and house.
● Dogs should receive all core vaccines as appropri -
ate for their age in accordance with published guide -
lines and maintain a current vaccination status as per 
the American Animal Hospital Association’s (AHAA) 
Canine Vaccination Guidelines ( American Animal 
Hospital Association (AAHA) Canine Vaccination 
Task Force et  al., 2011 ), which were researched and 
 developed by experts in the field of infectious diseases 
and immunology.
● Proper management of the animal waste and excreta 
in the house, residential communities, and different 
 veterinary-related organizations.

also for constant support and guidance in its preparation.

Chapter 31
Clinical signs and symptoms of infectious
diseases in dogs and cats
1 Introduction
Over the last few years of small animal medicine, it has 
been noticed that the infectious diseases in cats and dogs 
have been evolving and their clinical findings keep chang -
ing. Clinical findings in small animal infectious diseases 
can vary depending on the organism causing the infection. 
But most of them include fever and loss of appetite (Skyes, 
2014). A veterinary clinician has to plan the line of treatment 
based only on clinical findings. Where mild infections may 
respond to basic home remedies and medicines, some are 
life-threatening infections and need immediate medical at -
tention (Greene, 2012). The detailed elaboration of clinical 
signs and symptoms with respect to the etiology, pathophys-
iology and treatment plan is beyond the scope of this chap-
ter and has been discussed in the following chapters of this 
book. Nevertheless, the information provided in this chapter 
will change over a period of time. However, the author has 
tried to structure this chapter in a way that it will help the 
veterinary clinicians to understand the association between 
the clinical findings and infectious diseases in dogs and cats.
Table 1 shows the 20 most common clinical signs due 
to infectious diseases, observed by the veterinary clinicians 
routinely in general outpatient wards.
2 General clinical findings of infectious 
diseases in dogs and cats
2.1 Acute collapse
Acute collapse is one of the common presentations in dogs 
and cats especially in night emergency conditions. It can 
easily bring the pet parents and the clinician into deep stress 
preventing a proper diagnosis. But a systematic approach 
and excellent skills of history taking and physical exami -
nation can elevate this problem ( King and Boag, 2007 ). 
Hypovolemic shock due to severe anemia, dehydration as in 
canine or feline parvovirus infection, high fever, infectious 
polyarthritis, overt and nonovert bleeding disorders due to 
tick borne diseases, neurologic disorders such as in case of 
distemper or cerebral babesiosis, caval syndrome and sepsis 
in case of bacterial pyometra or leptospirosis are often seen 
in dogs and cats (Côté et al., 2017).
2.2 Abdominal enlargement
Presentation of the dog and cat with acute abdominal pain 
is common in veterinary practice. The general causes of ab-
dominal pain include: distension of a hollow viscus or organ 
capsule; ischemia; traction; and inflammation secondary to 
a variety of conditions. It is a relatively common sign in con-
ditions like feline infectious peritonitis in cats (wet form) 
and infectious canine hepatitis in puppies. The prognosis 
of the patient is hugely dependent upon the type and nature 
of the intraperitoneal contents. Free fluids indicate ascites 
and confined fluids can be due to pyometra, uroabdomen or 
cyst (Greene, 2012). Other differentials may include nonin-
fectious conditions like fecolith, pregnancy, organomegaly 
(neoplasia), intestinal obstructions, gastric dilatation/vol -
vulus and pneumoabdomen (e.g., postsurgical intestinal 
rupture). Abdominal imaging should be performed in most 
cases of acute abdominal pain, as soon as the patient is suf-
ficiently stable. In case of ascites, abdominal fluid should 
be obtained and classified as exudate, transudate, modified 
transudate, chylous effusion and hemorrhagic effusion to 
plan further lines of treatment (Holt and Brown, 2007).
2.3 Anorexia
Dogs and more commonly the cats are less food driven when 
compared to the other species. Hence, anorexia or hyporexia 
seems to be one of the most common clinical signs of a dog 
or a cat with infectious diseases ( Mooney and Peterson, 
2012). There can be changes in the hematology and bio -
chemistry blood reports, radiograph and ultrasound imaging.
2.4 Behavioral changes
Any kind of pain or conditions which affect the nervous system 
or musculoskeletal system can lead to changes in the behavior 
Clinical signs and symptoms of infectious 
diseases in dogs and cats
Abhishek Kalundia
Small Animal Emergency & Critical Care Department, Cornerstone Pet Clinic, Hyderabad, Telangana, India

470 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
of a cat or dog. Circling, aimless howling, tremors and hiding 
can be signs of various infectious diseases (Horwitz and Mills, 
2009). Pets with viral infections like rabies can be presented 
with furious and dumb forms (Rupprecht et al., 2010).
2.5 Lethargy and weakness
Lethargy is a state of dullness and listlessness with a lack of 
energy. Weakness is a lack of muscle strength. Lethargy and 
weakness are common presenting signs in first-opinion prac-
tice but can be difficult to distinguish for both the owner and 
clinician. They may be primary signs but are more commonly 
secondary to another disease process ( Lindley and Watson, 
2010). There are many conditions where an infectious organ-
ism leads to lethargy and weakness in a pet’s body. A full 
anamnesis and physical examination well help the clinician 
to take the logical decision w.r.t. diagnostic and treatment 
plans. Vector-borne diseases like ehrlichiosis, babesiosis and 
leishmaniasis are commonly presented with these signs (Côté 
et al., 2017). Initially, a full biochemical profile to include 
creatine kinase and total thyroxine (T4) is needed. A full 
blood count and white cell differential count should be ob -
tained, looking for evidence of (or lack of) a stress leuko -
gram. Additionally, urinalysis should be performed and 
blood pressure measured. From the results of these tests, the 
clinician can determine the best next step in the investigation, 
e.g., further biochemical testing, abdominal/thoracic imag -
ing, electrocardiography, echocardiography or endoscopy 
(King and Boag, 2007; Mooney and Peterson, 2012).
2.6 Hyperthermia and pyrexia
A raised rectal temperature is a common finding on physical 
examination. It is important for the clinician to determine 
the cause of the raised rectal temperature and to differen -
tiate pyrexia from hyperthermia ( King and Boag, 2007 ). 
Hyperthermia is rarely associated with infectious diseases 
in dogs and cats. It is mostly produced due to increased 
physical activity, increased ambient temperature as in sum-
mer season or due to increased metabolic rates as seen in 
malignancy. It is very important to differentiate hyperther -
mia from pyrexia, which is actually a result of inflammatory 
mediators like IL-1 from leukocytes in response to endog -
enous or exogenous pyrogens. Pyrexia is defined when a 
dog or cat has rectal temperature above 39.2*C or 102.5*F 
(Côté et al., 2017).
2.7 Epistaxis, sneezing, and nasal discharge
Epistaxis can be unilateral or bilateral. But when talking 
about infectious diseases, it’s mostly bilateral epistaxis. 
Mostly due to vector borne diseases (Rogers and Randolph, 
2006), aspergillosis and other clotting factor disorders. 
Sneezing is mostly due to the irritation of the nostrils due to 
the blood clots (Dumler and Walker, 2001; Liebenberg et al., 
2013). Hematology and biochemistry are useful, as they may 
highlight an underlying systemic illness or evidence of a 
bleeding disorder. A coagulation profile will similarly high-
light any deficiency of the clotting system and is also use -
ful prior to nasal biopsy (King and Boag, 2018). Serological 
tests for Aspergillus are available, but results are unreliable 
and must be interpreted carefully in the context of other 
clinical findings (Cooke, 2005). Radiography: generally the 
DVIO view is the most useful, revealing either increased 
soft tissue opacity and/or loss of turbinate detail ( Schmiedt 
et al., 2005). As the disease progresses there may be loss of 
the bony nasal septum. The tumor may also extend into the 
frontal sinus with increased soft tissue density filling one or 
both sinuses. Rhinoscopy allows direct visualization of the 
tumor (or area of abnormality on radiographs) and allows for 
collection of biopsy samples (Schmiedt et al., 2006; Fig. 1).
2.8 Oral and dental problems
The mouth can also act as a sentinel to the general health of 
the animal, as color changes in the oral mucous membranes 
are often readily noticed by pet parents and are important 
features during a veterinary examination (Reiter and Smith, 
2005). Many viral infections like feline calicivirus and oral 
resorptive disease can be seen accompanied by stage III or 
IV periodontitis, halitosis and gingivitis in cats. Bacterial 
infections leading to abscess can also be presented with se-
vere pain, dysphagia and halitosis in cats and dogs (Ettinger 
et al., 2016; Fig. 2).
2.9 Ear problems
Disorders of the ears are some of the most common presen-
tations in first-opinion canine practice; rarely will a day go 
by when a practitioner doesn’t need to deal with a case of

Clinical signs and symptoms of infectious diseases in dogs and cats  Chapter | 31  471
ear disease. They can often be a source of frustration for the 
vet and owner and a source of much discomfort for the dog. 
Ear problems can be presented clinically as ear scratch -
ing, head shaking, face rubbing, aural malodor, otorrhea, 
erythema of the pinna, nystagmus, ataxia, paresis and head 
tilt (Bensignor and Forsythe, 2012 ). Chronic otitis can be 
commonly presented due to canine yeast infection and sar -
coptic mange in puppies and adult dogs. Whereas common 
causes of otitis in new kittens are due to otodectic mites 
and fungal infections. Old dogs and brachycephalic breeds 
are prone for infectious and suppurative ceruminous otitis 
media secondary to bacterial and fungal infections and/or 
infected tumor mass. Severe otitis media or interna can be 
associated with head tilt presentation toward the affected 
ear canal side and also seizures (Carlotti et al., 2008; Miller 
et al., 2013; Fig. 3).
2.10 Lumps and bumps
Lump, swelling, nodule, bump, tumor, boil, abscess and 
mass are commonly seen in canine and feline practice. 
When it comes to infectious origin, they are mostly asso -
ciated with as simple as tick bites or due to canine furun -
culosis due to Staphylococcus intermedius. Submandibular 
and other peripheral lymph node enlargement can be seen in 
case of hemoprotozoan diseases and neoplasia. A detailed 
history and clinical examination of the animal patient can 
help a clinical to plan the treatment accordingly ( Carlotti, 
2005).
2.11 Lesions of the paw
Paws being weight bearing and first thing to constantly 
come in contact with the ground are vulnerable for many 
infectious and allergic lesions. Cercarial dermatitis and 
trombiculosis are commonly seen in many large breed dogs 
staying in backyard farm kind of husbandry. Interdigital 
spaces should also be examined in a well-lighted room for 
the presence of demodicosis, dermatophytosis, bacterial 
furunculosis and bacterial pyogranulomas. Hyperkeratosis 
of the pedal is commonly noticed in dogs with canine dis -
temper viral infection (Carlotti et al., 2008; Ghubash, 2012; 
Miller et al., 2013; Pin et al., 2008).
2.12 Problems related to the anus, perineum, 
and tail
Many dogs with diseases of the tail or anus present with 
tenesmus, dyschezia, fecal incontinence and chewing or 
licking of the tail base, perineum, inguinum or hindlimbs. 
FIG. 1 Bilateral epistaxis in a dog with canine ehrlichiosis.
 FIG. 2 Periodontitis and gingivitis in a cat with FIV infection.

472 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
These signs are not exclusive to specifically anal or tail 
problems. They can also be caused by skin infections or ir-
ritations (with fleas being the number one suspect) or be -
havioral problems. While many pet owners will attribute 
anal irritation to worms, in the majority of cases worms are 
the least likely cause (Hall et al., 2005). Tail fold intertrigo 
and myiasis is one of the common clinical presentations in 
canine practice. Dogs and cats with parasitism of gastroin -
testinal tract can also show signs of tenesmus, dyschezia 
and anal sac infections accompanied by secondary bacterial 
overgrowth (Scott et al., 2001). A per rectal examination is 
warranted to rule out prostate enlargement, peri-anal tumor, 
bleeding wound in the rectum, abscess, anal glands infec -
tion and impaction.
3 System-wise clinical findings of 
infectious diseases in dogs and cats
3.1 The cardiovascular system
Infections on the cardiovascular system are fairly rare 
when it comes to today’s small animal practice. General 
malaise, anorexia weight loss, exercise intolerance and 
coughing and abdominal swelling in case of the right side 
of the heart are involved (angiostrongylus vasovarum and 
dirofilaria  immitis). Careful auscultation can reveal muf -
fled heart sounds, murmurs and gallop rhythms based on 
the  pathophysiology. Bacterial or viral (canine parvovirus) 
endotoxemia can lead to neutrophilic leukocytosis with 
left shift, prerenal azotemia and elevated hepatic enzyme 
activities in the blood reports ( Lichtensteiger et al., 2003 ). 
Radiograph reveals left and right atrial enlargement with 
abnormalities in the electrocardiograph readings. Caval 
syndromes have also been demonstrated by 2D echocar -
diography (Ware, 2011).
3.2 The gastrointestinal system
Infections of the buccal cavity, upper and lower gastro -
intestinal tracts, are the most common reasons for an 
animal’s veterinary visits in daily practice. Anorexia, 
dysphagia, jaw champing, ptyalism, bleeding from gums, 
halitosis and in extreme cases epiphora and exophthal -
mos can be seen in infection of oral cavities. Viral in -
fections like papillomavirus can cause papillomas in the 
oral cavity of dogs. Whereas in cats, one can notice a 
pathognomonic “faucitis” near the tonsil in case of feline 
calicivirus infection. Animals with infectious esophagi -
tis can also exhibit regurgitation. Dogs with infectious 
or noninfectious gastritis will nonspecifically have pics, 
anorexia, weight loss, emesis, depression and cranial 
abdominal pain on gentle palpation ( Holt and Buckley, 
2018). Intestinal infections will lead to acute or chronic 
diarrhea, watery, mucoid or hemorrhagic diarrhea with 
foul odor ( Carmichael, 2005 ). Ascariasis can lead to typi -
cal “pot-bellied” appearance in puppies. Feline panleu -
kopenia virus ( Parrish and Kawaoka, 2005 ; Stuetzer and 
Hartmann, 2014 ), feline coronavirus ( Addie and Jarrett, 
1992), feline calicivirus ( Di Martino et al., 2016 ) and fe -
line astroviruses ( Sabshin et al., 2012 ; Soma et al., 2020 ) 
are among the most commonly known enteric pathogens 
(Abayli and Can-Sahna, 2022 ). Blood reports may reveal 
increased alkaline phosphatase activities and neutrophilia 
(Wees and Evason, 2020 ; Fig. 4).
3.3 The eye
Bilateral or unilateral lacrimation with or without con -
junctivitis is commonly seen in dogs with eye infections. 
Depending on the location of the lesion, ocular infections 
may cause keratitis, anterior or posterior uveitis with sec -
ondary glaucoma (Wyman and Boeve, 2007). In dogs both 
bacteria (leading to keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and viruses 
like canine distemper virus are known to cause ocular in -
fections (Gould and McLellan, 2014 ). In cats, chlamydio -
sis, feline herpesvirus-1, mycoplasma and feline calicivirus 
are common etiologies. In worldwide veterinary practice, 
rickettsial diseases are commonly known to cause uveitis 
and hyphema ( Wees and Evason, 2020 ). In case of sus -
pected glaucoma, if a tonometer is not readily available, 
IOP can be gauged by assessing the ease with which the 
FIG. 3 Otitis externa due Staphylococcus infection in a dog.

Clinical signs and symptoms of infectious diseases in dogs and cats  Chapter | 31  473
globe can be indented with a blunt probe (such as a ther -
mometer bulb) and comparing this with the contralateral 
eye. A glaucomatous eye will be tense, whereas a uveitic 
eye will be soft and easily indented ( Bexfield and Lee, 
2014; Figs. 5–7).
3.4 The hematopoietic and lymphoreticular 
system
Lymphadenopathy, tumors and masses are fairly common 
in feline practice due to feline leukemia virus. Viral anemia 
as in feline immunodeficiency virus (FeLV), feline infec -
tious peritonitis (FIP) and canine/feline parvovirus infection 
(CPV/FPV) is common. Mycobacterium granulomas are 
also documented in both dogs and cats. Mediastinal mass 
with secondary horner’s syndrome is seen in FeLV . Some 
infectious diseases are associated with production of anti -
bodies which are directed to the host body’s own antigen. 
Immune-mediated thrombocytopenia, immune-  mediated 
polyarthritis, immune-mediated glomerulonephritis, immune-
mediated dermatopathies and immune-mediated hemolytic 
anemia are commonly encountered in small animal prac -
tice. Ecchymosis, petechiation and fever are commonly 
accompanied with infectious diseases of lymphatic and 
lymphoreticular systems. Radiographs and  ultrasonography 
FIG. 4 Hemorrhagic gastritis in a dog with Hepatozoon canis infection.
FIG. 5 Fluorescein dye uptake positive-indicative of corneal ulcer.
FIG. 6 Purulent discharge from eyes in a dog with canine distemper.

474 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
may reveal splenomegaly (Hwang et al., 2010 ; Liebenberg 
et al., 2013; Fig. 8).
3.5 The integumentary system
Increased hair loss, erythema and pruritus are the most com-
mon clinical signs encountered in patients with ectoparasite 
infestations. Demodisocis and bacterial dermatitis can lead 
to alopecia and pododermatitis (Carlotti et al., 2008; Miller 
et al., 2013). Dermatophytosis is commonly known to cause 
malodor and papules/pustules. Pruritus, excoriations, crust-
ing, scaling and pinnae-pedal reflex is commonly demon -
strated in puppies with scabies and lice infestations. Intense 
pruritus, erythema and pustules are commonly seen in dogs 
with pledora dermatitis, hookworm larvae penetration and a 
few bacterial skin diseases (Jackson and Marsella, 2012; King 
and Boag, 2018). Pyoderma with different clinical features 
such as moist dermatitis, intertrigo, impetigo, folliculitis and 
deep pyoderma can be bacterial, viral, fungal or parasitic in 
dogs and cats. Greasiness, lichenification and recurrent ery-
thema and hyperkeratosis are commonly noted in dogs with 
atopy dermatitis. Chronic bacterial infections and mites are 
known to cause otitis in cats. Skin scraping test, trichogram 
may reveal mites and other microorganisms (Fossum, 2019).
3.6 The hepatobiliary system pancreas and spleen
Dogs with leptospirosis canine adenovirus-1 and herpes 
virus will commonly show jaundice, anorexia, polyuria, 
polydipsia, emesis, diarrhea, ascites, depression and py -
rexia. Such dogs can also have hepatomegaly and ptyalism. 
Cats and dogs with infectious peritonitis can show acute ab-
dominal pain with or without emesis, necrotizing splenitis 
and hepatitis can be seen in dogs with salmonellosis and 
adenovirus-1. Lymphoplasmacytic splenitis is commonly 
found in ehrlichiosis, brucellosis and hemobartonellosis. 
Both ultrasonography and radiography are helpful to con -
firm hepato-splenomegaly ( Hwang et al., 2010 ; Holloway 
and McConnell, 2014; Fig. 9).
3.7 The musculoskeletal system
A thorough physical examination is the mainstay to localize 
the musculoskeletal pain. Most common musculoskeletal 
infections are caused by bacteria either by hematogenous 
FIG.  7 Severe oculonasal discharge and lesions in a kitten with cat  
flu infection.
FIG. 8 Splenomegaly in a dog with canine monocytic ehrlichiosis.
FIG. 9 Severe icterus in a dog with IMHA secondary to hemoprotozoal

Clinical signs and symptoms of infectious diseases in dogs and cats  Chapter | 31  475
route or via external skin wounds. Infective arthritis can 
have swollen joint appearance with or without erythema, 
fluid accumulation and local lymphadenopathy. An acute 
muscle atrophy can also be indicative of infectious arthritis. 
Monoarthritis and pauciarthritis (inflammation of up to five 
joints either symmetrical or asymmetrical) are commonly 
seen in dogs with Lyme disease ( Coughlan and Miller, 
2006). Spinal pain, neurological deficits and wastage of 
paraspinal muscles can be seen on bacterial, fungal and vi -
ral discospondylitis. Feline toxoplasmosis and Hepatozoon 
canis have been associated with infective myopathies. 
Radiographically in such conditions, evidence of gas densi-
ties within soft tissue can be seen ( Leschnik et al., 2002 ; 
Wees and Evason, 2020).
3.8 The nervous system
The nervous system has no secondary lymphoid tissue and 
low humoral defense mechanism. Hence, it is easier for 
an infection to establish itself rapidly in nervous systems. 
Nonrhythmic lameness with seizures and ataxia is com -
monly seen in dogs with neosporosis. Dogs and cats with 
infectious origin can have circling, tremors, proprioceptive 
deficits, CN III-XII deficits and spinal pain with muscle 
atrophy (Bradshaw et  al., 2004). Common infections like 
pseudorabies, neosporosis, distemper, toxoplasmosis, cryp-
tococcosis, neurobartenellosis, tick-borne diseases, and 
rabies are associated with multifocal CNS signs in dogs. 
Tetanus is a well-known bacterial infection causing mus -
cle spasm. And botulism toxins can lead to tetraparesis 
(Leschnik et al., 2002; Wees and Evason, 2020).
3.9 The peritoneal cavity
Acute abdominal pain with ascites, fever and shock can be 
seen on cats and dogs associated with canine adenovirus-1, 
FIP, FeLV , toxoplasmosis, actinomycosis and mycobacte-
rium (Boyce et al., 2011). The intraperitoneal content can be 
transudate (protein content <20 g/L) and exudate (protein 
content >20 g/L). In radiograph pathognomonic “ground 
glass” appearance can be evident (Mirahsanti et al., 2022).
3.10 The reproductive system
A wide range of organisms can cause infection in pregnant 
and nonpregnant female cats and dogs and fertility problems 
in male cats and dogs. Vaginitis may be presented with an-
amnesis of constant vulvar lucking and mucoid or mucopu-
rulent discharge. Intrauterine pathologies like hematometra 
and cystic endometrial-pyometra complex can be confirmed 
through ultrasonography studies. Sometimes expulsion of 
premature fetuses is seen in animals associated with septi -
cemia as in conditions like brucellosis, toxoplasmosis and 
tick-borne diseases. Transmissible venereal granuloma can 
be commonly presented with growth and inflammation of 
male reproductive organs and vulva in bitches. Infectious 
organisms can also clinically lead to orchitis, posthitis, 
bacterial prostatitis, epididymitis and genital herpes virus 
signs. Prostatic abscess is commonly documented in dogs 
with E.coli infection. Such conditions in male dogs can be 
presented with hemorrhagic, mucoid or mucopurulent dis -
charge from the penis (Johnston et al., 2001; Fig. 10).
3.11 The respiratory system
Infectious diseases causing sneezing, nasal discharge, 
coughing, wheezing and dyspnea are more common in cats 
and dogs kept in shelters or boarding due to overcrowding 
(e.g., kennel cough and cat flu). In severe and chronic con -
ditions, nasal swelling pain, irritation open mouth breath -
ing, pyrexia, dysphonia, submandibular lymphadenopathy 
can be seen in upper respiratory tract infections ( Byun 
et al., 2009). Cat flu (feline herpes virus, feline calicivirus, 
bordetella and chlamydiosis) can additionally cause an -
orexia, oculonasal discharge, ulcerative keratitis, shifting 
lameness and oral ulcerations. Feline reovirus, protozoal 
infections, aspergillosis and mycoplasmosis are associated 
with dyspnea and crackles wheezing on auscultation (Wees 
and Evason, 2020).
3.12 The urinary system
The urinary tract comprises kidneys, ureters, bladder, ure -
thra and prostate. Clinical features of infection in the urinary 
system can be pollakiuria, stranguria, urinary incontinence, 
dysuria, hematuria, urinary plugs and foul odor ( Greenlee 
et al., 2004). The affected cat or dog may be found squatting 
more frequently to pass urine (pollakiuria), straining to pass 
urine (dysuria/stranguria), licking around the genitals or an 
FIG. 10 Infected uterus of a dog suffering with Pyometra.

476 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
unusual discharge from the genitals. Although there is some 
overlap between the terms, dysuria is usually an observed 
painful or abnormal urination, whereas stranguria refers 
to a very diminished urine flow (usually only a few drops 
passed). Alternatively, the owner may be concerned about 
incontinence, hematuria polydipsia or polyuria/polydipsia 
(PU/PD). Problems of urinary tract infection can be relaps-
ing in nature or re-infected after stopping the treatment or 
superinfected by additional organisms. Tubulointerstitial re-
nal diseases can be clinically presented with fever, polyuria/
polydipsia, abdominal pain and depression ( Mohammed 
et al., 2006 ). Urine-specific gravity (USG) helps to deter -
mine the nature of pathophysiology and organisms involved 
in the morbidity (USG <1.008 = hyposthenuria; USG 1.008 
to 1.012 = isosthenuria; USG 1.013 to 1.029 = azotemia, re-
nal failure; USG 1.030 and above: Normal). Blood reports 
may reveal azotemia and leukocytosis ( Wees and Evason, 
2020).

Chapter 32
Parasitic diseases of dogs and cats
1 Introduction
Companion animals include dogs and cats which play a vital 
role in society, improving the physiological and psychologi-
cal well-being of humans. The health of people that have pets 
with them is healthier as compared to nonpet humans, and 
they visit hospitals less frequently and use fewer medications, 
have lower cholesterol and blood pressure (Tangtrongsup and 
Scorza, 2010). Although pets offer many health benefits to 
the well-being of humans, it also has certain health hazards 
such as a diverse range of zoonotic and infectious diseases 
including parasitic diseases along with fungal and bacterial 
infections (Tangtrongsup and Scorza, 2010).
Parasites are known to cause certain important diseases 
in humans transmitted from companion animals (dogs 
and cats) which are zoonotically important ( Arruda et al., 
2021). The increasing number of dogs and cats and their 
close association with people have posed serious public 
health concerns. Dogs and cats are the sources of various 
pathogens. Most of them which are zoonotic can be dan -
gerous for the health of people worldwide. According to 
the epidemiological point of view, the gastrointestinal tract 
parasites of dogs and cats are regarded as the most impor -
tant parasites ( Tangtrongsup and Scorza, 2010 ). The most 
frequent parasites of dogs and cats are belonging to pro -
tozoa and helminths such as Echinococcus, Dipylidium, 
Giardia, Taenia, Ancylostoma, Cystoisospora, Toxocara, 
Uncinaria, Trichuris, Toxascaris, and Capillaria. However, 
Echinococcus, Toxocara, and Ancylostoma are among the 
most important ones epidemiologically (Alho et al., 2018).
The transmission of parasites in dogs and cats is generally 
through the fecal-oral route. The general life cycle of para -
sites in dogs and cats consists of certain stages, out of them 
some are completed inside the host, and some are completed 
outside the host. The adult worms lay eggs in the intestine 
of dogs and cats which are shed through feces in the out -
side environment. The dispersed form may be oocysts, cysts, 
eggs, or larvae which are deposited in the environment by 
fecal route (Alho et al., 2018). When these eggs get a favor-
able environment, eggs containing larvae grow, molt, and 
 become infective. When the host ingests these larvae, be -
come infected, and the cycle starts again which completes 
their life cycle inside the host. Certain parasites of dogs and 
cats require an intermediate host for the completion of their 
life cycle such as Echinococcus species (Wright et al., 2020).
The mode of transmission of parasites to their host is 
different for different species of parasites. Some of them 
transmit to their hosts through the fecal-oral route (the 
most adopted mechanism of transmission), others can in -
fect animals via the penetration of larvae through the skin 
(cutaneous route of transmission), and some infect via the 
intermediate host or by a paratenic host. The infestation of 
parasites varies from asymptomatic to severe clinical mani-
festations, especially in kittens, puppies, and immunocom -
promised animals (Robertson and Thompson, 2002).
Numerous studies have elaborated that the infection rate 
of parasites in dogs and cats is more in younger pets as com-
pared to older animals ( Tangtrongsup and Scorza, 2010 ). 
The prevalence of intestinal parasites is less in household 
animals as compared to shelter animals. This might be due 
to the high population in the shelter and close contact among 
them. Although there is an availability of efficacious drugs 
against the parasites in the market and owners and veterinar-
ians are interested to control them, intestinal parasitic infec-
tions are still abundant in dogs and cats (Baneth, 2011).
2 Zoonotic and economic importance 
of parasitic diseases
In recent years, the population of dogs and cats in urban areas 
has been growing, and therefore, they are becoming closer to 
human beings. In the present era, domestic dogs and cats are 
considered family members, and they remain in close contact 
with the people in society (Tangtrongsup and Scorza, 2010). 
Although their close association is beneficial for their owners 
and pets, this also increased the behavioral and psychological 
disorders in animals and the risk of certain parasitic diseases 
in people. Due to the vulnerability of pets to infections of 
various parasites, they can become a source of transmission 
of certain zoonotically important species of parasites to their

480 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
owners. Cats and dogs are the hosts of many intestinal para-
sites (Robertson and Thompson, 2002).
Humans can get parasitic infections from dogs and cats 
accidentally when they contact infective oocysts and eggs 
from soil contaminated with feces of infective dogs and cats, 
unwashed vegetables, and fruits, or by direct contact with 
the victimized animals. However, the transmission of para-
sitic eggs or oocysts in humans is still believed to be from 
contaminated soil. The route of transmission is the same as 
that of animals, i.e., the fecal-oral route (Alho et al., 2018). 
Pets play a vital epidemiological role in the transmission of 
these parasites when they shed eggs, oocysts, cysts, or lar -
vae with their feces contaminating the surrounding environ-
ment. However, these are not fully developed and remained 
uninfected by their owner because they require a favorable 
condition for molting and to reach an infective larval stage 
3 to become an agent for the transmission of parasitic dis -
eases to other animals including human beings ( Robertson 
and Thompson, 2002).
The distribution of zoonotic diseases associated with 
companion animals is highly affected by the movement 
of animals which acts as a mean for the transmission and 
relocation of pathogens and vectors they harbor. Humans 
carry their pets with them from one place to another which 
increased the risk of the spreading of zoonotic infections in 
the world. Therefore, it is important to maintain the health 
of animals to ensure their proper well-being (Baneth, 2011).
3 Role of ectoparasites in the 
transmission of infections
The continuous cat and dog relocation within and between 
the countries poses a global public health and veterinary 
concern. The profession of veterinary faces serious chal -
lenges in dealing with these issues. The veterinarian can 
play a special role in reducing risks to pet owners and the 
public, maintaining biosecurity, and ameliorating the health 
of animals. They can educate the owners about the problems 
associated with the relocation of animals if not properly fol-
lowed the rules set for the well-being of animals and the 
prevention of spreading vector-borne diseases ( Montoya-
Alonso et al., 2017). Cats and dogs are important reservoirs 
and hosts of many protozoal and helminthic pathogens trans-
mitted by vectors such as arthropods. The most common ar-
thropods include ticks, mosquitoes, and fleas which transmit 
pathogens to dogs and cats. Ticks are the ectoparasites that 
are responsible for the transmission of various parasites in 
these pets which include Ehrlichia canis, Anaplasma platys, 
Hepatozoon canis, and Babesia vogeli. Ctenocephalides fe-
lis is known as cat flea and acts as an intermediate host for 
the transmission of Dipylidium caninum and is involved in 
zoonotic pathogen transmissions such as Bartonella hense-
lae, B. clarridgeiae, and Rickettsia felis in cats. The other 
species of this flea, namely Ctenocephalides canis, is found 
in dogs and is responsible for spreading the same above-
mentioned zoonotic pathogens (Noack et al., 2021).
Mosquitoes are also important ectoparasites that feed on 
the blood of their hosts and are responsible for the transmis-
sion of various pathogens to dogs and cats including humans 
(Montoya-Alonso et al., 2017). Mosquitoes are involved in 
the transmission of certain nematodes, viz. Dirofilaria spp. 
and Brugia spp. in dogs and cats. About 70 species of mos-
quito (mainly Aedes, Culex, and Anopheles) are considered 
vectors of Dirofilaria repens and D. immitis in dogs and cats 
and cause subcutaneous and heartworm diseases in them re-
spectively (Noack et al., 2021) (Fig. 1).
FIG. 1 Mechanism of transmission of diseases from animals to humans.

Parasitic diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 32  481
4 Protozoal diseases of dogs and cats
Protozoa are eukaryotic organisms that cause many diseases 
in animals as well as some zoonotic diseases that may trans-
fer from animals to humans due to close contact of compan-
ion animals with their owners. The infective stage of some 
protozoa is called sporozoite. While trophozoite is a term ap-
plied to that stage of the protozoa in the host which feeds and 
grows until division commences. Some protozoa have alter-
nating life cycle stages between the proliferative stage (e.g., 
trophozoites) and dormant stage (cyst). A cyst can survive a 
harsh environment outside of the host and is responsible for 
the transmission of the disease. Some of the diseases of dogs 
and cats caused by protozoa are discussed below.
4.1 Toxoplasmosis
Coccidia is an obligate intracellular protozoan parasite that 
is classified into several distinct genera, viz. Neospora, 
Toxoplasma, Isospora, Besnoitia, Hammondia, Sarcocystis, 
Cyclospora, and Cryptosporidium, normally found in the 
intestinal tract ( Calero-Bernal and Gennari, 2019 ). The 
Apicomplexan intracellular protozoan parasite Toxoplasma 
gondii is responsible for toxoplasmosis which is present 
worldwide. T. gondii requires two hosts for the completion 
of its life cycle and virtually can infect all warm-blooded 
animals. Domestic cats including all other members of the 
feline family are definitive hosts, while all other warm-
blooded animals are considered intermediate hosts includ -
ing humans and dogs. However, felines can also act as 
intermediate hosts of T. gondii (Kostopoulou et al., 2017 ). 
T. gondii is prevalent worldwide and capable of infecting 
birds and animals. Cats shed the oocysts of this parasite in 
their feces which is only the mechanism for the transmis -
sion of diseases to other organisms. Animals can acquire 
this infection through the ingestion of infective oocysts 
from contaminated food, water, soil, or some other mate -
rials. The excystation of oocysts rapidly occurs in the in -
testine of the host developing into a highly infective form 
of tachyzoite ( Dantas-Torres and Figueredo, 2006 ). The 
excystation depends upon the pH, temperature, bile salts, 
and trypsin present in the intestinal environment of the 
host. After the formation of tachyzoites, the establishment 
of cysts in the tissue occurs. If any member of the feline 
consumes the infected tissue or contaminated fecal mate -
rial, they get infected and shed oocysts in their feces, and 
in this way, the cycle repeats. People acquire this infection 
through the accidental consumption of feline fecal mate -
rial, contaminated water and food, and undercooked meat 
having cysts. There is also transplacental transmission from 
the mother to her offspring or through transfusion of blood 
(Al-Malki, 2021). Acute infection is mostly asymptomatic 
in cats. Other symptoms include anorexia, fever, blind -
ness, cough, jaundice, and diarrhea. The clinical signs in 
dogs include tremors, ataxia, and paralysis along with the 
previously described symptoms. Its diagnosis can be made 
through microscopic examination of a blood smear, sero -
logical tests, hemagglutination test, indirect hemagglutina -
tion test, ELISA, and PCR. Antibiotics can be administered 
to treat this infection such as sulfadiazine (Fig. 2).
FIG. 2 Mechanism of transmission of toxoplasmosis from definitive hosts to intermediate hosts including humans.

482 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
4.2 Giardiasis
The parasite Giardia is frequently detected in animals. 
There are at least four species of Giardia that infect domes-
tic animals including human beings and become the cause 
of giardiasis. These are flagellate species that are found in 
the intestinal tract of domestic and wild animals including 
birds. The four morphologically distinct species are Giardia 
psittaci and G. ardeae which infect birds, G. microti which 
cause disease in voles and muskrats, and Giardia duodena-
lis (also called G. lamblia or G. intestinalis) form a complex 
that infect a wide variety of warm-blooded animals (Szwabe 
and Błaszkowska, 2017). Its life cycle is comprised of two 
stages, viz. the trophozoite (active and motile form found in 
the intestine) and the cyst (environmentally resistant stage 
responsible for the transmission). The cysts of Giardia can 
survive outside the host environment for months in cold and 
wet conditions but are susceptible to a dry and hot environ-
ment. On the other hand, trophozoites can be shed in the 
feces of cats and dogs who suffered from diarrhea but are 
unable to survive outside the host environment for a sig -
nificant time. The prevalence of giardiasis is more in young 
dogs and cats as compared to old ones (Matos et al., 2015). 
The mode of transmission of cysts is through the fecal-oral 
route. Animals can ingest them with contaminated food and 
become infected. Excystation of these cysts inside the small 
intestine (duodenum) occurs with the help of gastric and 
pancreatic enzymes. The trophozoites which are originated 
become attached to the lining of the intestine and become 
the source of pathogenesis (Matos et al., 2015).
The pathogenic contribution of Giardia includes disrup-
tion of normal intestinal microflora, toxin production, in -
flammation and inhibits the normal enzymatic production 
of enterocytes. The clinical signs in dogs and cats range 
from subclinical to slight abdominal discomfort or may be-
come severe enough to cause cramping and abdominal pain. 
Soft to watery diarrhea having mucus on the surface and a 
strong smell is observed in dogs and cats which is usually 
self-limited in immunocompetent pets. Its diagnosis can be 
made depending on the findings of trophozoites in direct wet 
mount fecal smear. Other methods include centrifugal fecal 
flotation, enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), 
or polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Metronidazole is the 
drug of choice for the treatment of diarrhea and giardiasis 
in dogs and cats (Matos et al., 2015).
4.3 Babesiosis
Babesiosis is a tick-borne disease that is caused by in -
traerythrocytic apicomplexan parasites of the genus Babesia 
that infect a wide variety of domestic and wild animals in -
cluding humans. Its mode of transmission is through the 
bite of infective ticks which transfer the causative agent to 
healthy animals upon their feed ( Dalrymple et  al., 1992). 
The stages of their life cycle include sporozoite, mero -
zoite, and trophozoite. Babesia canis , B. rossi, B. vogeli,  
B. gibsoni, B. conradae, and B. microti are responsible for 
babesiosis in dogs while B. felis is the causative agent for 
babesiosis in cats. However, the prevalence of babesiosis 
in a feline is rare compared to canines. The pathological 
changes that occur in the host vary depending on the type 
of the species that infect the immune status of the host, age, 
and concurrent infection (Esch and Petersen, 2013).
The most clinical signs of babesiosis in canines and 
felines include hemolytic anemia and systemic inflamma -
tory response syndrome. Hemolytic anemia occurs due to 
the destruction of red blood cells (extravascular and intra -
vascular hemolysis). The clinical signs of acute babesiosis 
in dogs and cats include fever, anorexia, dehydration, ane -
mia, icterus, and lethargy. Babesiosis can be diagnosed by 
detecting Babesia spp. in stained blood smear, or flow cy -
tometry. PCR and serological testing can also be employed 
to detect babesiosis. Imidocarb dipropionate is the drug of 
choice for the treatment of babesiosis. While some other 
drugs can also be used to treat this infection such as dimina-
zene aceturate (Dalrymple et al., 1992).
4.4 Hepatozoonosis
Hepatozoonosis is caused by the apicomplexan parasite 
Hepatozoon species. These parasites infect dogs, and only 
a few subclinical cases of this disease are diagnosed in cats 
so far. All species of hepatozoon share a common life cycle 
consisting of an invertebrate definitive host and a verte -
brate intermediate host. Unless other vector-borne diseases 
spread through the bite of arthropod vectors, this is also a 
vector-borne disease and spread only through the ingestion 
of a vector (definitive host) containing Hepatozoon oocysts. 
The definitive host of this disease are blood-sucking inverte-
brates such as flies, fleas, ticks, mites, tsetse flies, sand flies, 
mosquitoes, lice, leeches, and bugs and the intermediate 
hosts include a wide variety of animals such as mammals, 
birds, amphibians, reptiles, and marsupials (Irwin and Traub, 
2006). The other modes of transmission include eating meat 
containing small tissue cysts (termed monozoic, cystozoites, 
or dizoic cysts) and transplacental transmission. The impor-
tant species of Hepatozoon are H. canis, H. Americanum, 
and H. felis with the first two causing disease in dogs and the 
third in cats, respectively (Dubey et al., 1990). The H. canis 
infection in dogs varies from subclinical in healthy dogs to 
severe and life-threatening in anemic and lethargic animals. 
The clinical symptoms include fever, anorexia, lethargy, 
weight loss, muscle pain, and discharge from the eyes and 
nose. It can be diagnosed microscopically (observation of 
neutrophils containing parasites), an indirect fluorescent an-
tibody test for anti-H. canis antibody detection, and ELISA. 
Imidocarb dipropionate is the drug of choice for the treat -
ment of hepatozoonosis in dogs (Dubey et al., 1990).

Parasitic diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 32  483
4.5 Neosporosis
Neospora caninum  is the causative agent of neosporo -
sis in dogs and other animals. It is a protozoan parasite 
that causes myositis and encephalomyelitis in animals. 
The natural mode of transmission of N. caninum  is only 
transplacental. This parasite closely resembles those of 
Toxoplasma gondii ( Dubey et  al., 2020 ). This parasite is 
also responsible for paralysis and death in dogs and causes 
mortality of neonates and abortion in cattle, buffalo, goats, 
sheep, and mares. The clinical signs of neosporosis in dogs 
include ascending paralysis (hind legs are more severely 
affected than the front legs), paralysis of the jaw, swallow -
ing difficulty, and flaccidity and atrophy of the muscles. 
Subclinically infected mothers can transmit pathogens 
to their fetuses which are born infected ( Petersen, 2009 ). 
There is no report of neosporosis in cats, but felines are 
susceptible and can become infected experimentally. The 
severity of this disease is more in lactating cats as com -
pared to nonlactating cats. An indirect fluorescent antibody 
test can be used to identify this disease. The choice of treat-
ment includes clindamycin, pyrimethamine, or sulfadia -
zine (Dubey et al., 2020; Petersen, 2009).
5 Internal parasitic diseases of dogs  
and cats
Many helminths infect cats and dogs and lead to the mor -
bidity and mortality of the host. Generally, these helminths 
include nematodes, trematodes, and cestodes. The main 
route of transmission of the disease is the fecal-oral route, 
but many parasites require an intermediate host for their de-
velopment to become infective and cause disease in their 
definitive host. The reproduction of parasites including 
sexual and asexual mode of reproduction occur inside the 
definitive host while in the intermediate host only the devel-
opment and growth of the infective stage of parasites occur. 
Here are discussed certain parasitic diseases of dogs and 
cats (Kumsa et al., 2019).
5.1 Dirofilariasis (heartworm disease)
Canine and feline heartworm disease is caused by the fi -
larial nematode parasite Dirofilaria immitis  which is an 
important endoparasite from both economic and patho -
logic points of view. This protozoan parasite is transmitted 
by mosquitoes. The definitive host of this parasite is dogs 
while cats are also infected by D. immitis. The main site of 
the worm and initial damage is in the pulmonary arteries, 
and the heart is only involved in the last stage of the disease 
(Ballweber et al., 2010). Sexual reproduction of D. immitis 
occurs in the pulmonary arteries and newborn microfilariae 
are released into the circulatory system of the host. The oc-
currence of this infection is more severe in cats which act 
as atypical hosts. In cats, death occur by just a few adults 
or developing filariae. Dogs and cats are the most impor -
tant mammalian species infected by D. immitis worldwide 
(Kumsa et al., 2019).
Unlike other nematodes, they exhibit a complex life 
cycle comprising multiple stages of development in both 
definitive host and intermediate host (mosquito). They 
have no free-living stage and live as obligate endopara -
sites mainly in the pulmonary artery and lobar arteries of 
the host (canines). Mosquitoes acquire microfilaria during 
blood feeding on the infected host and act as a vector. In 
the mosquito, they migrate from the midgut to Malpighian 
tubules where morphological changes occur in them and 
become first-stage larvae. After molting several times, they 
change into the L3 stage, and transmission to a healthy ver-
tebrate host occurs when mosquitoes again feed on them 
(Colella et al., 2020 ). The clinical manifestation of dirofi -
lariasis in dogs and cats is usually chronic, and mostly in -
fected animals do not show the clinical symptoms of this 
disease for a long time. Gradually symptoms of this disease 
develop with a chronic cough followed by dyspnea, weak -
ness, anorexia, weight loss, and dehydration. Crackles are 
heard over the caudal lobe of the lungs. These parasites are 
prevalent worldwide and their clinical signs in dogs include 
mild persistent cough, anorexia, and exercise intolerant. 
There is an obstruction in the flow of blood and right-side 
heart failure occurs. Cats are very less immunologically in-
tolerant as compared to dogs and as a result, clinical symp-
toms are different in cats in contrast to dogs ( Kumsa et al., 
2019). Clinical symptoms in cats include labored breathing, 
chronic cough, vomiting, and even death with no apparent 
appearance of other clinical signs. In cats, the death of mi -
crofilariae results in severe pulmonary symptoms, and this 
condition is termed heartworm-associated respiratory dis -
ease (Ballweber et al., 2010).
Diagnosis of heartworm can be made through the de -
tection of circulating microfilariae or blood tests for adult 
female antigens. Different serological, molecular, and para-
sitological tests are available to find different developing 
stages of parasites in the host. Microscopically, they can 
also be detected in direct blood smear. Further diagnostic 
procedures can also be adopted such as radiographs and 
electrocardiography. The treatment protocol for D. immitis 
infection in dogs requires a prolonged drug therapy regi -
men, restriction of exercise, and sometimes even surgery. 
When the worm burden is high in the right cardiac cham -
ber, surgical therapy is advised along with the symptomatic 
treatment for the pulmonary and cardiac signs. Restriction 
of exercise and cage rest is essential to improve cardiopul -
monary circulation and pulmonary hypertension reduction 
(Ballweber et al., 2010 ). The current therapy includes the 
prevention of this parasite using medications such as mac -
rocyclic lactones, e.g., ivermectin, moxidectin, and milbe -
mycin oxime (Kumsa et al., 2019) (Fig. 3).

484 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
5.2 Leishmaniasis
Leishmaniasis is caused by Leishmania species. There 
are two forms of this disease, namely the cutaneous form 
and the visceral form caused by L. mexicana and L. infan-
tum, respectively. It is usually transmitted through the bite 
of a female sandfly (phlebotomine). There is also a verti -
cal transmission of leishmaniasis in dogs and cats either 
through the transplacental or transmammary route. Dogs 
are zoonotically important because they act as a reservoir 
host and can transmit the infection to human beings. The 
clinical signs of L. infantum  infection in dogs vary from 
asymptomatic to fatal ( Curtis, 2004). The clinical signs in 
canine and feline include splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and 
enlarged lymph nodes. The cutaneous form of the diseases 
in cats and dogs is characterized by initially a single papule 
which is enlarged into a nodule and may become ulcerative. 
While the visceral form of the disease is characterized by 
loss of body weight, depression, serosanguineous nasal 
discharge, splenomegaly, rough hair coat, and generalized 
lymphadenopathy. Other clinical signs of a visceral form 
may include vomiting, diarrhea, and melena. There is also 
nonpruritic alopecia, excessive epidermal scale with thick -
ening, depigmentation, hyperkeratosis, and chapping of 
food pads and muzzle occur in both forms of leishmaniasis 
(Curtis, 2004).
5.3 Toxocariasis
Toxocariasis is a disease caused by roundworm Toxocara 
cati and Toxocara canis which are common gastrointestinal 
helminths of cats and dogs, respectively. Their transmis -
sion occurs through the fecal-oral route. Healthy animals 
can acquire infection through the ingestion of embryonated 
eggs or tissue of paratenic hosts containing infective larvae. 
Transplacental transmission during the gestation period 
from mother to fetus or transmammary during lactation in 
young kittens and pups is also possible (Solano-Gallego and 
Baneth, 2011). Dogs and cats are the definitive hosts. After 
the ingestion of eggs, infective larvae hatch in the intestine 
and their juvenile stage fails to develop into mature worms, 
start wandering inside the body of the host and cause dam -
age to tissue from where they travel. There are two types of 
migration of larvae in the host, viz. visceral larval migration 
and cutaneous larval migration depending on the immune 
status of the victim. If a dog or cat is somewhat resistant to 
infection, then there will be cutaneous migration and vice 
versa (Kumsa et al., 2019).
The symptoms of toxocariasis and the degree of the host 
damage caused by migrating larvae vary depending on the 
tissue invaded, age of the dogs and cats, number, location, 
and developmental stage of the worms (Solano-Gallego and 
Baneth, 2011). The most sensitive organs include the lungs, 
liver, eyes, and the central nervous system. The clinical 
manifestation of light infection of Toxocara in young and 
adult dogs and cats is usually asymptomatic or merely asso-
ciated with no weight gain. Stillbirths occur due to prenatal 
infection, and those who survived will die within 3  weeks 
of birth (Kumsa et al., 2019). The other clinical symptoms 
of this disease include fever, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, 
lower respiratory symptoms such as bronchospasm, urti -
caria, pneumonia, vomiting, diarrhea, and in some animals 
constipation, obstruction of the intestine, rupture of the 
intestine, gallbladder, bile duct, and pancreatic duct may 
occur ( Solano-Gallego and Baneth, 2011 ). If there is the 
involvement of the CNS, then encephalopathy and other 
FIG. 3 Transmission of heartworms from infected animals to healthy animals via mosquito (vector).

Parasitic diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 32  485
neurological symptoms may occur. There is granuloma for-
mation in the retina if the eyes are involved. The visceral 
form of diseases can be diagnosed based on immunologi -
cal tests such as ELISA. Albendazole (anthelmintic drug) is 
the treatment of choice for this disease. But as far as ocular 
signs are concerned, vitrectomy along with anthelmintics 
and corticosteroids can be opted for (Genchi et al., 2019).
5.4 Ancylostomiasis
Hookworms are the cause of Ancylostomiasis in dogs and 
cats which include Ancylostoma caninum , Ancylostoma 
ceylanicum, and Ancylostoma braziliense . The survival 
ability of hookworms increases in tropical climates.  
A. tubaeforme only infects cats and other species of wild 
felids. Ancylostoma is transmitted through the fecal-oral 
route. The third larval developmental stage is the infective 
stage of Ancylostoma which can withstand both cold and 
heat but is not able to face extreme dryness. A. caninum in 
dogs can also be transmitted through transmammary route. 
These parasites suck a large proportion of blood from the 
host and make them anemic ( Solano-Gallego and Baneth, 
2011). However, the severity of the disease depends on the 
age of the animals, the nutritional status of dogs and cats, 
and the worm burden. Ancylostomiasis is characterized by 
bloody diarrhea, anemia, hypoproteinemia, and death can 
also occur. In the case of cutaneous larval migrans, hyperke-
ratinization, acanthosis, and serpentine tracks are observed 
which are made by recently passed larvae in interdigital 
skin. Eggs shed with feces can be diagnosed with a micro -
scope. Supportive therapy should be administered before 
specific treatment in case of acute infection of dogs and 
cats. The treatment of choice for Ancylostomiasis hook -
worms includes oral administration of pyrantel pamoate or 
febantel (Solano-Gallego and Baneth, 2011).
6 Ectoparasites infesting dogs and cats
Ectoparasites act as vectors and reservoirs for many patho -
gens and prefer to infest dogs and cats where they transmit 
various diseases and are directly or indirectly involved in de-
teriorating the health of animals. The most common ectopar-
asites include ticks, mites, fleas, and lice. Ctenocephalides 
canis and Ctenocephalides felis are the fleas of dogs and 
cats respectively. C. felis is a vector for several pathogens 
such as Bartonella clarridgeiae, B. henselae, and Rickettsia 
felis which cause various diseases in cats and dogs. Fleas 
also act as the intermediate host for certain helminths such 
as Dipylidium caninum (Baneth, 2011).
Ticks are the most important ectoparasites that affect the 
health of dogs and cats worldwide. Ticks feed on the blood 
of the host which makes them anemic and prone to vari -
ous diseases. Ticks are also responsible for the paralysis of 
the host. Ticks are vectors and reservoirs for many  zoonotic 
pathogens such as Anaplasma, Ehrlichia, Borrelia, and 
Rickettsia which cause emerging zoonotic diseases in hu -
mans as well (Eckert et al., 2001).
Lice are also one of the most important ectoparasites 
of domestic animals including dogs and cats. In infested 
pets, they may cause dermatological lesions, unthriftiness, 
anemia, biting and rubbing, alopecia due to scratching, and 
secondary skin infections. The lice of dogs are Trichodectes 
canis, Heterodoxus spiniger, and Linognathus setosus while 
there is only one louse of cat, namely Felicola subrostra-
tus which is prevalent worldwide (Wright et al., 2020). All 
these ectoparasites are directly involved in restlessness, 
rough hair coat, loss of appetite, weight loss, and anemia.
6.1 Scabies
Scabies is a disease of the skin caused by sarcoptic mange 
which is nonseasonal and highly contagious. It makes skin 
pruritic. The causative agent of this disease in burrowing 
mites is known as Sarcoptes scabiei. This disease affects 
several mammalian species and the variant responsible for 
scabies in dogs is S. scabiei var. canis. In contrast, S. acari-
osis is a mite responsible for a pruritic skin condition in 
cats, but this disease is rare (Dantas-Torres et al., 2020). The 
transmission of mites from infected animals to healthy ani-
mals occurs through direct contact, but it can also be trans-
mitted indirectly through fomites. The most common sites 
of infestation in dogs and cats are elbow, hocks, pinna mar-
gins, and periocular skin which are clinically characterized 
by pruritic and papulocrustous dermatosis. The infestation 
of mites can be detected by skin scraping or ELISA. The 
common treatment protocol for this is the use of acaricidal 
drugs such as amitraz, fipronil, and ivermectin ( Nguyen 
et al., 2021) (Table 1).
7 Control of parasitic diseases in dogs 
and cats
Dogs and cats are companion animals that are naturally ex-
posed to a variety of parasites, including endoparasites and 
ectoparasites. These parasites are prevalent worldwide, and 
many of them are of zoonotic concern. Therefore, there is 
an urgent need to minimize the risks of transmission of par-
asites and morbidity through environmental hygiene, good 
nutrition, year-round preventive measures for ectoparasites 
which acts as a vector for the transmission of various dis -
eases, and deworming practices for the endoparasites of 
companion animals (Dubey et al., 2009).
Endoparasites prevention must be started at a young age 
of animals and be supported with proper nutrition and hy -
giene. The maintenance of cleanliness in the houses is very 
important to prevent the contamination of food as most of 
the parasites are transmitted through the fecal-oral route. 
When litter boxes are used for pets, fecal material daily

 removal and disposal is very necessary. The area where 
dogs are kept and their breeding facilities must be disin -
fected with an effective disinfectant such as 1% sodium 
hypochlorite solution, chloroxylenol, chlorocresol, or 10% 
iodine to reduce and kill the protozoon cysts, helminths 
eggs, and larvae (Baneth et al., 2016).
Proper nutrition of the animals is also essential to en -
hance the immunity of the pets which ultimately helps them 
to fight infection. Ticks and other insects such as fleas, and 
mosquitoes are also sources of disease transmission. For the 
prevention and control of these insects, an insect killer and 
repellent must be used on the premises where dogs and cats 
are kept reducing or even vanishing vector-borne insects. 
Whenever an infection is identified, proper treatment of the 
animals with an efficacious drug is necessary to further pre-
vent the damages caused by them (Xhaxhiu et al., 2009).
8 Conclusion
In this chapter, we have discussed certain parasitic diseases 
of dogs and cats. These animals are the definitive hosts 
of many parasites and can act as a reservoir for the trans -
mission of diseases to other healthy individuals. Humans 
can acquire infection from companion animals because of 
their close association with them. The proper knowledge of 
the parasitic diseases of dogs and cats is very essential to 
prevent them. Many parasitic drugs such as antiprotozoal, 
anthelmintics, and antiacaricides are developed that are ef -
fective against a wide range of parasites and can kill them. 
To control the diseases caused by parasites, the proper de -
worming of the animals is important.

and support.

Chapter 33
Mycoplasma, Rickettsia, and Chlamydia 
diseases of dogs and cats
1 Introduction
There are numerous opportunistic and vector-borne ill -
nesses that affect dogs and cats worldwide, including 
mycoplasmal, rickettsial, and chlamydial diseases. Our 
understanding of these agents has increased because to the 
creation of sensitive, specific PCR assays, and PCR is cur -
rently the tool of choice for diagnosing and differentiating 
various species (Willi et al., 2010 ). This presentation aims 
to shed light on the potential significance of mycoplasmal, 
rickettsial, and chlamydial illnesses in dogs and cats with 
regard to their origin, symptoms, modes of transmission, 
diagnosis, and treatment.
1.1 Mycoplasma infections in dogs and cats
Mycoplasma species are regarded as typical flora in the up-
per respiratory system, although their role in lower respira-
tory tract infections is controversial. Because Mycoplasma 
infections in cats and dogs are rarely found cytologically 
and must be detected by a specific culture or polymerase 
chain reaction (PCR), they are challenging to diagnose 
(Dear, 2020).
1.1.1 Etiology and different species
Fastidious organisms without a cell wall, mycoplasmas 
are the smallest known free-living organisms (0.3–0.8 m 
in length) and are members of the Mollicutes class (the 
name means “soft skin”). They were initially discovered 
in dogs in Japan in 1934 ( Baseman and Tully, 1997 ). 
Many organisms require sterols to thrive, whereas spe -
cies of Ureaplasma require urea to ferment. Seven dif -
ferent Ureaplasma species and more than 120 different 
Mycoplasma species have been identified. The range of 
mycoplasma species that infect or are present in dogs and 
cats is still not fully characterized because precise species 
identification has been difficult (Spergser and Rosengarten, 
2007). Future Mycoplasma species discovery is projected 
to increase as a result of molecular technology utilization. 
Some Mycoplasma species can infect a variety of host spe-
cies. Mycoplasmas are notoriously challenging to grow on 
cell-free media, and some, like hemotropic mycoplasmas, 
have never been successfully cultured in the lab (Hartmann 
et al., 2010 ). All mammalian species’ mucous membranes 
include commensal microorganisms called mycoplasmas. 
Numerous Mycoplasma species colonizing simultaneously 
is not unusual. Mycoplasmas are associated with kerato -
conjunctivitis and/or upper respiratory tract disease in cats, 
reproductive disease and urinary tract infections in dogs, 
and lower respiratory tract disease, skin and soft tissue 
infections, meningoencephalitis, and arthritis in both cats 
and dogs (Beauchamp et al., 2011). It has been challenging 
to assess mycoplasmas’ role in ocular, upper respiratory, 
and urogenital tract disease because they are frequently 
isolated from the genitalia and upper respiratory tracts of 
healthy dogs and cats. Recent research has revealed that 
Mycoplasma prevalence is higher in cats with conjunctivi -
tis or URTD than in healthy cats (Holst et al., 2010).
Mycoplasmas can act as secondary invaders when other 
harmful viruses and bacteria are present, or when the typi -
cal host defenses are weakened by ailments like neoplasia 
or immunosuppressive drugs. Mycoplasmas are usually 
associated with pneumonia or systemic disease in young 
animals (1 year). Mycoplasma cynos  ( M. cynos ) has been 
linked to a more pathogenic lower respiratory illness in 
dogs ( Rycroft et  al., 2007 ), whereas infection with other 
species like Mycoplasma spumans , Mycoplasma canis , 
and Mycoplasma gateae could not cause it. It appears that 
pathogenecity varies among different Mycoplasma species 
(Rosendal, 1978 ). On the other hand, no correlation be -
tween the feline infection with Mycoplasmas in their lower 
urinary tract and lymphoplasmacytic pododermatitis was 
found using molecular approaches ( Bettenay et al., 2007 ) 
(Table 1).
Small ( <1 mm), discoid-shaped, cell wall-free he -
motropic mycoplasmas (hemoplasmas), which are in -
timately connected to the red blood cells of affected 
animals. They used to go by the names Haemobartonella

490 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
and Eperythrozoon species, and they are the infectious 
anemia-causing agents in a number of mammalian spe -
cies. As our understanding of bacterial genomic sequences 
has grown, these entities under the genus Mycoplasma 
have been reclassified as hemotropic mycoplasmas. 
Hemoplasma infections can cause acute hemolysis, which 
is accompanied by anorexia, lethargy, dehydration, weight 
loss, and unexpected animal mortality. The ability to study 
hemotropic mycoplasmas has been constrained by the in -
ability to culture these organisms in  vitro. However, re -
cently created species-specific PCR assays enable a more 
thorough assessment of the etiology and epidemiology of 
Hemoplasma infections in cats and dogs ( Neimark et al., 
2001).
1.1.2 Transmission of mycoplasmosis
Lower respiratory tract infections are often thought to 
have an endogenous cause; upper respiratory tract infec -
tions with canine and feline mycoplasmas are common, 
albeit not consistently so. However, because the viru -
lence traits of canine and feline mycoplasmas have not 
been well confirmed, the possibility of external trans -
mission cannot be fully ruled out. Each Mycoplasma  
species’ specific location and relative abundance inside 
the respiratory system are unclear. The mucous mem -
branes of the gastrointestinal tract and urogenital system 
can also harbor some Mycoplasma   species that are con -
nected to respiratory disorders. Different Mycoplasma  
species may be discovered in dogs, cats, and other 
 animals ( Rosendal, 1979 ). Even though fleas or ticks 
have been suggested as potential natural carriers, the 
 manner of hemoplasmas transmission is still unknown 
(Novacco et al., 2010 ).
1.1.3 Signs of Mycoplasmosis in dogs and cats
Infections with Mycoplasma typically affect the urogenital 
and pulmonary systems. In immunocompromised patients 
and neonates, mycoplasmas can potentially result in sys -
temic infections ( Bébéar and Bébéar, 2002 ). Clinical ex -
aminations of feline and canine pulmonary Mycoplasma 
infections are scarce. Most isolates have been obtained 
from the lung tissues of animals that had died of pneu -
monia; among the most frequently seen clinical symptoms 
were fever, emaciation, lethargy, dyspnea, chronic cough, 
and crackles. Chronic Mycoplasma colonization has been 
detected in dogs with primary ciliary dyskinesia ( Kirchner 
et  al., 1990 ). When a dog was necropsied for unrelated 
reasons, it was discovered that it also had mild, acute 
symptoms consistent with infected canine tracheobronchi -
tis in addition to pneumonia macroscopic lesions. Other 
dogs in the same kennel noticed comparable symptoms, 
and they all fully recovered. Experimentally, M. cynos  
infection caused tiny pneumonia lesions in dogs, but no 
clinical symptoms were seen. Early phases of the micro -
scopic pathology of naturally occurring and experimental 
Mycoplasma pneumonia in dogs and cats include puru -
lent bronchitis and bronchiolitis, with different degrees 
of bronchiectasis and epithelial destruction. Bronchitis 
obliterans, interstitial pneumonia, bronchial and bronchio -
lar epithelial hyperplasia, and peribronchial and perivas -
cular lymphoid hyperplasia are among the latter phases 
(Rosendal, 1978 ). Mycoplasmas colonize both ciliated 
and nonciliated surfaces in the respiratory tract and are 
normally segregated from systemic body sites ( Hooper 
et al., 1985).
1.1.4 Diagnosis of mycoplasmosis
Traditional biological techniques have been used to iden -
tify Mycoplasma and make a laboratory diagnosis of my -
coplasmal infections, including morphology, cultural traits, 
physiological and serological features (Razin, 2006). While 
the conventional tests continue to be very important in the 
diagnosis of Mycoplasma, novel assays based on molecu -
lar analysis of genomic DNA, ribosomal RNAs, eukary -
otic proteins, and lipids are beginning to take their place. 
Because of this, it is possible to forecast that the molecular 
tests will soon replace the conventional tests as the pre -
ferred approach for identifying Mycoplasma, especially in 
the case of slow-growing and/or extremely picky species. 
The two volumes of Methods in Mycoplasmology offer 
an organized and thorough overview and evaluation of the 
conventional methods for identifying mycoplasmas ( Razin

Serological tests have been utilized frequently, especially 
for determining the species and strains of Mycoplasma. In 
some instances, mycoplasmosis can be diagnosed using 
tests based on the principles of immunobinding ( Kotani 
and McGarrity, 1986 ), immunoblotting ( Rastawicki et al., 
1996), immunoperoxidase tests ( Bencina and Bradbury, 
1992), and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA 
or EIA), which uses polyclonal or monoclonal antibodies 
(Ferwerda et al., 2001).
