1.2 Rickettsial infections in dogs and cats
In order to group viruses and small, obligatory, intracellular 
gram-negative bacteria known as rickettsiae, which are fre-
quently used to identify viruses-caused illnesses ( Gillespie 
et al., 2009). In North America, rickettsial-related illness in 
dogs is rather prevalent. The two conditions that are most 
frequently identified are ehrlichiosis and Rocky Mountain 
spotted fever. The obligatory intracellular parasites known 
as rickettsial agents are spread by ticks. Deciduous forests, 
warm temperatures, and higher humidity all encourage the 
growth of ticks, which in turn encourages the spread of rick-
ettsial agents (Stiles, 2000).
1.2.1 Etiology, signs, and methods  
of transmission
In general, canine and feline vector-borne infections of 
rickettsial agents, including those in the genera Anaplasma, 
Ehrlichia, Neorickettsia, and Rickettsia, are significant and 
frequent. These pathogens can cause disease that is clini -
cally undetectable to severe and even lethal ( Allison and 
Little, 2013 ). For the maintenance of infection in nature 
and for transfer from infected to native hosts, all canine and 
feline rickettsial diseases need a vector. Transmission by 
contaminated blood products or unintentional direct con -
tact with infected vertebrate or vector tissues has also been 
documented (Leiby and Gill, 2004 ). The majority of these 
agents are primarily transmitted by arthropods, mainly ticks 
and fleas; however, some species of the genus Neorickettsia 
are also spread by digenean trematodes (flukes). Arthropods 
are the primary means of rickettsial pathogen transmission. 
For the majority of these diseases, transmission times have 
not been identified, but generally speaking, for the tick-
borne rickettsial agents, transmission is thought to occur 
within the first 4–24 h of tick attachment ( Nicholson et al., 
2010). When a dog or cat consumes an intermediate host 
that contains infective metacercariae carrying the bacteria, 
rickettsial agents on trematode vectors are then transmitted 
to the intermediate host (Bowman et al., 2009) (Table 3).
1.2.2 Diagnosis of rickettsial agents
Microscopic visualization
Since members of the Anaplasmataceae family infect he -
matopoietic cells, many of them can be observed under a 
microscope in a variety of clinical samples, such as periph-
eral blood, bone marrow, tissue aspirates, and body fluids 
like CSF and synovial fluid. Cytologic samples are pre -
ferred since normal histopathologic sections cannot reveal 
the organisms without immunohistochemistry ( Dawson 
et  al., 2001 ). Peripheral blood typically contains germs 
from the genera Ehrlichia and Anaplasma. Bacteria grow 
through binary fission within cytoplasmic vacuoles despite 
having an average diameter of less than 0.5  m to generate 
microcolonies or morulae (Popov et al., 1998). Morulae can 
reach a diameter of 4–6  μm and can contain numerous or 
few different species. The two morphologic forms of bacte-
ria that have been classified in terms of their ultrastructure 
are dense-cored cells, which are more loosely packed, and 
reticulate cells, which are firmly packed inside of morulae. 
A single morula frequently includes only one sort of bacte-
rium, not both, as opposed to a mix. This variability may be 
the cause of the different cytoplasmic inclusion appearances 
seen by light microscopy (Popov et al., 1998).

1.2.3 Culture
The only venues where rickettsial agents can be successfully 
isolated in cell culture are frequently research labs. Culture 
is not used as a diagnostic strategy when a specific research 
requirement emerges, such as the confirmation of the exis -
tence of a novel agent, evidence of vector transmission, or the 
description of an agent from a new host species. Culture iso-
lation is more time-consuming than molecular or serologic 
techniques for routine diagnostics, but it is necessary for the 
detailed description and comprehensive characterization of 
organisms in clinical specimens (Wellman et al., 1988).
1.2.4 Serology
Serologic techniques, such as indirect fluorescent antibody 
(IFA) assays and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays 
(ELISA), have long been a mainstay for confirming clini -
cal suspicion of a rickettsial disease due to the difficulties 
associated with isolating rickettsial organisms in culture 
and identifying some agents in peripheral blood using PCR 
(Carrade et al., 2009).
1.2.5 Immunohistochemistry/in situ 
hybridization/immunocytochemistry
It is feasible to show the presence of various rickettsial 
agents in tissue samples using immunohistochemistry 
(IHC) or in situ hybridization (ISH) techniques; however, 
these methods have typically been used for research rather 
than clinical diagnoses (Headley et al., 2009). A variation of 
this method known as avidin-biotin immunoperoxidase can 
be used to detect Rickettsia rickettsii in human skin biopsies 
(Dumler et al., 1990).
1.2.6 Molecular methods
Molecular diagnostic methods based on PCR detection of 
unique nucleic acid sequences can be used to confirm ac -
tive infection with Ehrlichia spp., Anaplasma spp., and 
Neorickettsia spp. Several commercial assays are also avail-
able to detect substances like Rickettsia spp. that are not 
frequently picked up by PCR, depending on the technology 
employed. However, antemortem specimens have shown 
that this method has inadequate sensitivity ( Sirigireddy 
et al., 2006).
1.2.7 Treatment
Doxycycline is thought to be the best treatment for rickett -
sial infections ( Nicholson et al., 2010 ). The ACVIM con -
sensus statement recommends doxycycline (10  mg/kg PO 
q24 h for 28  days) for the treatment of ehrlichiosis ( Neer 
et  al., 2002); a similar regimen is used for the treatment 
of clinical disease caused by Anaplasma phagocytophilum 
and R. rickettsii. Prompt doxycycline treatment is necessary 
when rickettsial etiology is suspected because  waiting too 
long to begin treatment can be fatal. The majority of dogs 
show clinical improvement within 1–2  days after starting 
antibiotic therapy; nevertheless, all but the worst cases did 
not respond to doxycycline treatment, indicating that there 
may be another underlying reason. A single course of treat-
ment may not be able to entirely eradicate an Ehrlichia or 
Anaplasma spp. infection, even though the clinical con -
dition improves, especially if it is only administered for 
a shorter amount of time (14  days as opposed to 28  days) 
(Schaefer et al., 2007 ). As a last resort, Ehrlichia spp. and 
Anaplasma spp. can also be treated with imidocarb and 
rifampin ( Schaefer et  al., 2008 ). Concomitant supportive 
care, such as blood transfusion, parenteral fluid administra-
tion, and/or prednisone, may be helpful in individuals who 
are more seriously affected, even though corticosteroids 
may trigger relapse and recrudescence in patients with sub-
clinical infections (Neer et al., 2002).
1.3 Chlamydial infections in dogs and cats
Chlamydia is one of the most prevalent zoonotic diseases 
that afflict animals and birds, according to Krawiec et al. 
(2015). Dogs and cats make up the majority of domestic 
animals that reside in densely populated areas and human 
dwellings ( Wieliczko and Płoneczka-Janeczko, 2010 ). 
After being exposed to the sickness, dogs and cats are still 
susceptible to getting it and can also transmit it to people 
(Holst et al., 2006).
1.3.1 Etiology
The Chlamydiales order and Chlamydiaceae family con -
tain only chlamydial organisms. In the genus Chlamydia, 
only two species, Chlamydia trachomatis and C. psittaci, 
have been identified ( Storz and Page, 1971 ). Chlamydiae 
are similar to bacteria in that they reproduce by binary fis -
sion and have a cell wall consisting of both RNA and DNA. 
In contrast to bacteria, it exclusively replicates inside host 
cells. As a result, the organisms are necessary intracellular 
parasites, similar to viruses. Since extracellular propagation 
has never been effective, the growth of the organism also 
requires living cells, such as those found in tissue culture, 
embryonated eggs, or lab animals ( Jones, 1974 ). The ap -
pearance of compact intracytoplasmic microcolonies that 
are stained with iodine can be used to identify the C. tra-
chomatis species. Sodium sulfadiazine stops embryonated 
eggs from growing. It is mostly a parasite of humans and 
is connected to urogenital infections, ocular illnesses, and 
neonatal pneumonia ( Shewen, 1980). One strain has also 
been linked to an endemic mouse pneumonitis ( Storz and 
Page, 1971). Chlamydia psittaci is recognized by dispersed 
microcolonies that do not stain with iodine and resist inhibi-
tion by sodium sulfadiazine. Along with a large number of 
wild mammals and more than 100 different domestic and

Mycoplasma, Rickettsia, and Chlamydia diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 33  495
wild bird species, the majority of domestic animals are sus-
ceptible to infection. Occasional human illness can result 
from contact with diseased animals (Storz and Page, 1971).
1.3.2 Signs and transmission
The natural transmission of chlamydial infections is consid-
ered to occur through fomites and close contact with other 
animals that are affected and their aerosols. It is uncertain 
if venereal transmission occurs in animals. According to 
O'Dair et al. (1994), pets frequently have an incubation pe-
riod of 3–5 days. Some symptoms include:
Canine chlamydia infection
Dog chlamydial infections have not been thoroughly explored; 
however, they have been connected to a number of ailments 
in dogs. Since chlamydial antibodies have been discovered 
in as many as 50% of clinically healthy dogs in serological 
tests, chlamydial infections do exist (Weber et al., 1977). Scott 
(1968) isolated chlamydiae from a dog with conjunctivitis 
and determined that they were the cause of superficial kera-
titis in German Shepherds (V oigt et al., 1966). An encepha-
litic condition in dogs was connected to the infection when 
chlamydiae were discovered in eggs, and antibodies were 
discovered in the serum of afflicted animals ( Giroud et  al., 
1954). Chlamydia taken from a dog with the same illness in-
duced cerebral and pulmonary problems after intracerebral 
injection of mice (Contini, 1956). Dog chlamydial infections 
have not been thoroughly explored; however, they have been 
connected to a number of ailments in dogs. Since chlamydial 
antibodies have been discovered in as many as 50% of clini-
cally healthy dogs in serological tests, chlamydial infections 
do exist (Weber et al., 1977). Scott (1968) isolated chlamydiae 
from a dog with conjunctivitis and determined that they were 
the cause of superficial keratitis in German Shepherds (V oigt 
et al., 1966). An encephalitic condition in dogs was connected 
to the infection when chlamydiae were discovered in eggs, 
and antibodies were discovered in the serum of afflicted ani-
mals (Giroud et al., 1954). Chlamydia taken from a dog with 
the same illness induced cerebral and pulmonary problems 
after intracerebral injection of mice (Contini, 1956).
Feline chlamydial infection
C. psittaci was first isolated by Baker from cats with pneumo-
nia (Baker, 1942). More recent investigations have identified 
the common conjunctivitis-causing bacteria ( Yerasimides, 
1960). A single mucoid or mucopurulent conjunctivitis may 
be present in these cats, and the contralateral eye may be -
come affected 5–7 days later. Chemosis, which occurs fre -
quently, has little effect on the cornea. The disease can be 
spread through contact with cats, most frequently via aerosol. 
When tetracycline ointment is given topically, the affected 
cats recover fast, but untreated cases will go away on their 
own. These untreated cats’ conjunctivitis frequently returns 
every 10–14  days. Some recovered cats still harbor latent 
infections, which infects catteries and spreads an enzootic 
disease. When kittens are delivered to unwell queens, their 
eyes may be open when they should not. They may also have 
acute conjunctivitis. These kittens’ conjunctival scrapings 
exhibit classic chlamydial inclusions, but searches for chla-
mydiae in the queens’ cervix have been unsuccessful (Cello, 
1971). Occasionally, these kittens’ necropsies reveal histo -
logical but subclinical pneumonia, and they may eventually 
deteriorate and pass away (Jubb et al., 2012). This condition 
was recently found in a litter of abandoned kittens ( Blanco 
et al., 1975). Recovering cats have a low level of resistance 
to infection (Cello, 1971). The egg-attenuated organism vac-
cine is indicated in high-risk situations since it has been dem-
onstrated to reduce the incidence and severity of the disease 
(Mitzel and Strating, 1977). It has been shown that the feline 
pathogen can spread to people; as a result, the owner of many 
infected cats developed follicular conjunctivitis ( Schachter 
et al., 1969). The feline organism is thought to have first de-
veloped while hunting birds or mice (Shewen, 1980). In this 
context, it’s critical to keep in mind that Baker first identified 
feline chlamydial pneumonia on farms while investigating 
calf pneumonia (Storz, 1971) as shown in Figs. 1 and 2.
FIG. 1 Acute conjunctivitis with chemosis in a cat infected with C. felis 
(Sykes, 2005).
FIG. 2 Chronic conjunctivitis with mucopurulent ocular discharge in a 
cat infected with C. felis (Sykes, 2005).

496 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
1.3.3 Diagnosis
Chlamydial infection must be distinguished from other in -
fectious and noninfectious causes of feline conjunctivitis. 
Since clinical symptoms cannot identify infections brought 
on by FCV, FHV-1, and C. felis, and mixed infections might 
happen, a microbiological assay is required for an accurate 
diagnosis. It is not recommended to use the Giemsa-stained 
conjunctival smear examination for chlamydial inclu -
sions as a reliable means of identifying feline chlamydial 
infection. Sometimes inclusions are inconspicuous, and 
frequently, they do not show up until the beginning of a 
disease (Wills, 1986). False-positive outcomes can occur if 
they are confused with either inclusion brought on by topi -
cal medications like Neosporin (commonly known as “blue 
bodies”) or melanin granules seen in the cytoplasm of con-
junctival cells (von Bomhard et al., 2003). Serum antibody 
titers measured by indirect immunofluorescence exhibited 
a significant connection with recent infection. Compared 
to 95% of cats with C. felis infection, 10% of uninfected 
cats have titers 32 ( Wills et al., 1988 ). Sadly, a diagnosis 
is typically required prior to a significant rise in antibody 
titer, and reliable serologic testing is hard to come by. There 
are numerous ELISA antigen kits available for the diagno -
sis of Chlamydia trachomatis infection. They differ in their 
specificities (80%–90%) and sensitivities (25%–80%) for 
chlamydial detection, particularly when compared to cell 
culture, which is thought to as the “gold standard” for chla-
mydial diagnosis (Pointon et al., 1991). These assays might 
be useful in cases where other, more accurate diagnostics 
are not accessible. After inoculating cell monolayers, in -
tracytoplasmic chlamydial inclusions are detected in cell 
culture by fluorescent antibodies. Specialized chlamydial 
transport media with the right antimicrobials are required to 
sustain chlamydial viability. You can buy these media from 
the lab. It is difficult, expensive, and time-consuming to iso-
late in cell culture. Issues with storage and delivery may 
affect the sensitivity of cell culture, and some samples may 
be dangerous for monolayers in cell culture. The sensitivity 
of culture may vary between laboratories depending on the 
equipment and level of technical understanding. Compared 
to traditional techniques like culture and ELISA, diagnos -
tic PCR tests are more expedient, less expensive, and fre -
quently more accurate. Human chlamydial infections are 
now frequently diagnosed with them, and C. felis tests are 
becoming more readily available. PCR has a high sensitiv -
ity and specificity when samples are obtained and preserved 
properly (Sykes et al., 1999 ). To collect samples from the 
conjunctival sac, use a cotton swab that has been moistened 
in saline. The biggest problem with PCR methods is false 
positives caused by contamination, which can occur both 
before and after samples are sent to the lab. Veterinarians 
taking samples for PCR should contact the lab for advice 
on sample collection and handling in order to minimize 
contamination that happens outside the lab. Additionally, 
they must guarantee that each extraction run in the lab in -
cludes both a positive control and a negative control. Broad-
spectrum chlamydial PCR, which is required to screen for 
non-C. felis  chlamydiae such Neochlamydia hartmannel -
lae, is currently only available in a small number of research 
institutes. More research is required on the connection be -
tween these species and disease before recommending 
widespread testing for these organisms in cats with con -
junctivitis (McDonald et al., 1998).
1.3.4 Treatment
Chlamydiae can be eliminated by tetracyclines, erythromy-
cin, rifampin, fluoroquinolones, and the azalide azithromy-
cin ( Isselbacher et  al., 1987 ). Contrary to popular belief, 
neither sulfonamides nor chloramphenicol are effective 
against C. felis. Doxycycline is the favored medication for 
treatment since it performs better than azithromycin, even 
when used daily ( Owen et  al., 2003 ). Systemic doxycy -
cline (5 mg/kg q12 h) is used to treat the C. felis infection 
for 3  weeks in study colonies ( Sykes et  al., 1999). There 
has been a considerable clinical improvement and organ -
ism elimination by day 2 after the start of therapy. Given 
that doxycycline has a long half-life, a once-daily dosage 
of 10  mg/kg is probably more effective and convenient. 
Another study discovered that systemic doxycycline treat -
ment was superior to twice-daily topical therapy using 1% 
chlortetracycline ointment ( Sparkes et  al., 1999 ). Recent 
research showing that chlamydial infections in cats are sys-
temic can be used to explain why topical treatment alone 
is unsuccessful. Occasionally, it took longer than 3  weeks 
of treatment to entirely get rid of spontaneous infections 
caused by C. felis. Every 6–8 h, systemic treatment should 
be used with topical tetracycline ointments, according to 
certain publications. A minimum of 6–8  weeks of therapy 
is also advised, especially for cats from catteries ( Greene, 
2006). Nevertheless, following the cessation of clinical in -
dications, medication should normally be continued for a 
further 2 weeks. As it is in patients with chlamydial arthri -
tis, it is likely that the organism will be more difficult to 
eradicate in persistent infections ( Leirisalo‐Repo, 1993 ). 
However, recurrent occurrences typically include numer -
ous cats and poor cooperation. All cats must receive the full 
course of antibiotic therapy, and proper quarantine and sani-
tation must be maintained. This could be hard to do if there 
is a problem with a large cat population. Since secondary 
bacterial infections have healed, concurrent viral infections 
like FHV-1 and FCV can also be a problem. Often, these 
infections respond quickly to antimicrobial therapy. If FCV 
infection is still a possibility, a bleach to detergent solution 
of 1:32 is suggested for general disinfection. When tetracy-
clines are administered in the last 2–3 weeks of pregnancy 
in queens or in the first few months of life in kittens, there

Mycoplasma, Rickettsia, and Chlamydia diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 33  497
is a chance that the kittens’ teeth will become permanently 
discolored. There is not much proof that doxycycline harms 
cats in these ways, and it has a lesser affinity for binding 
calcium than other tetracyclines. To lower the danger of 
esophagitis brought on by doxycycline, a syringe should be 
used to provide a doxycycline suspension or a water bolus 
after the consumption of pills. Despite the fact that penicil-
lin is only supposed to be inhibitory, a 4-week course of 
amoxicillin-clavulanic acid totally eradicates C. felis  in 
experimentally infected cats, and there is no recurrence 
6 months after the conclusion of treatment. This might take 
the place of tetracyclines for the effective treatment of chla-
mydiosis in young kittens (Sturgess et al., 2001).
2 Conclusion
Animals require care that is specific to their requirements. 
Opportunistic agents enter animal barriers when immu -
nological state, a critical component, declines. Ticks and 
other vectors are also significant in the spread of several 
illnesses among pets. The majority of these illnesses may 
be found in the blood of animals that seem healthy, which is 
something veterinarians should be aware of. It is crucial to 
prevent these people from spreading iatrogenic infections. 
In instance, prior to giving blood, animals that will serve 
as donors should be checked for any relevant illnesses and 
shown to be seronegative or PCR negative (depending on 
the screened pathogen).

1 Introduction
Dogs and cats suffer from an array of diseases caused by 
pathogenic bacterial organisms. Some of these bacteria are 
found in the gastrointestinal tracts as normal inhabitants 
commonly the Enterobacteriaceae, while some are found 
in the habitat comprising water bodies ambient air or veg -
etation. The earlier are mostly Gram-negative, causing gas-
trointestinal symptoms via production of endotoxins while 
the later are mostly Gram-positive that produce endotoxins 
with potential integumentary system symptoms. These bac-
teria spread via air, water, contact, feco-oral or by invasion 
of resident bacteria in the presence of stress. Owing to the 
fact that dogs and cats are close to humans; many of these 
bacterial diseases are zoonotic in nature, spreading from the 
pets to the humans, humans to the pets or in both directions. 
A wide range of antibiotics are available for the treatment of 
these diseases either single therapy or combination therapy 
with recorded good recovery rates as some show some lev-
els of resistance which may arise from wrong regimentation 
or plasmid-related.
2 Salmonellosis
2.1 Cause
Salmonella enterica  subspecies; S. enterica , S. galli -
nae, S. arizonae , S. indica , S. houtenae , and S. salamae 
(Guibourdenche et al., 2010).
2.2 Hosts
Dogs, cats, other vertebrates, birds and insects ( Bagcigil 
et al., 2007).
2.3 Spread
Apparently, healthy pets intermittently shed organisms in 
feces; contaminating feed and water (Pépin et al., 2005).
2.4 Clinical signs
Acute cases manifest 3–5  days post exposure with fever, 
malaise, lethargy, anorexia, abdominal pain and enteritis 
characterized by watery, mucoid or bloody diarrhea (Morse 
and Duncan, 1975).
2.5 Pathology
Gross lesions include mesenteric lymphadenopathy, epithe-
lial sloughing of ileum, caecum and colon.
Microscopic lesions include mesenteric lymphadenitis, 
shortened villi, neutrophilic infiltration of lamina propria, 
thrombosis of intestinal capillaries and hemorrhages (Tauni 
and Österlund, 2000).

502 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
2.6 Diagnosis
Clinical signs ( Stiver et  al., 2003 ), culture and isolation 
and sero/molecular diagnosis like ELISA, PCR and IFAT 
(Oliveira et al., 2003).
2.7 Treatment
Ampicillin, enrofloxacin ( Marks et al., 2002 ), oxytetracy-
cline, gentamicin, amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, ciprofloxa -
cin, neomycin and chloramphenicol (Li et al., 2012).
2.8 Prevention
Eliminating infection source by employing strict biosecu -
rity measures and animal quarantine (Lefebvre et al., 2008).
3 Colibacillosis
3.1 Cause
Escherichia coli (Sancak et al., 2004) including enterotoxi-
genic E. coli (ETEC); enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) and 
verocytotoxic E. coli (Hammermueller et al., 1995).
3.2 Hosts
Dog, cat and most warm-blooded animals ( Sancak et  al., 
2004).
3.3 Spread
Fecal-oral route ( Clooten et  al., 2008 ; McFarland, 2006 ; 
Fig. 1).
3.4 Pathogenesis
Oral, intrauterine or ascending genital inoculation is fol -
lowed by proliferation and subsequent colonization of gas -
trointestinal, reproductive or urinary tract (Beutin, 1999).
3.5 Clinical signs
Intestinal forms, usually termed granulomatous colitis pres-
ent marked weight loss, anorexia, watery and nonbloody 
diarrhea in kittens or hematochezia (Beutin, 1999).
Extraintestinal forms present septicemia, otitis externa 
(Baba and Fukata, 1981), cholecystitis, pyelonephritis, cys-
titis and pyometra (Wadås et al., 1996; Figs. 2 and 3).
3.6 Pathology
Macroscopic lesions include thickened colon wall, colonic 
and jejunal lymphadenomegaly, hemorrhages and narrow -
ing of large intestinal lumens (Baba and Fukata, 1981).
Microscopically, periodic acid Schiff positive macro -
phages infiltrating intestinal mucosa, mucosal ulcerations 
and necrosis of goblet cells (Wadås et al., 1996).
3.7 Diagnosis
Clinical signs, bacterial culture and isolation, patho -
logical lesions, sero/molecular diagnosis such as FISH

(Van Kruiningen et al., 1965), PCR (Hammermueller et al., 
1995), antigen K-serotyping (Yoshida et al., 2019).
3.8 Differential diagnosis
Gastrointestinal foreign body.
Canine parvovirus (Wadås et al., 1996).
3.9 Treatment
Enrofloxacin at 10  mg/kg q24h P·O for 8  weeks ( Craven 
et al., 2010 ), trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole combination, 
ampicillin or oxytetracycline (Moyaert et al., 2017).
3.10 Prevention
Strict hygiene such as hand washing and preventing pet 
food contamination (Kataoka et al., 2010).
4 Klebsiellosis
4.1 Cause
Klebsiella species (Wareth and Neubauer, 2021).
4.2 Hosts
Dogs, cats, humans and many mammals ( Fecteau et  al., 
1997; Wilson and Madigan, 1989).
4.3 Spread
From fecal contamination of soil, water and vegetation 
(Guo et al., 2016).
4.4 Clinical signs
Enteritis accompanied by vomiting, watery, mucoid or 
bloody diarrhea and hematochezia ( Roberts et  al., 2000 ). 
Others include wound infection, urinary tract infection, cir-
culatory system infections and pneumonia ( Sedighi et al., 
2020).
4.5 Pathology
Gross signs include thickened and hemorrhagic small in -
testinal serosae, ecchymotic hemorrhages on epicardium, 
generalized lymphadenopathy, distended gall bladder, con-
gested lungs, liver and kidneys (Roberts et al., 2000).
Microscopically, extensive necrotic areas around small 
intestinal mucosa, disseminated intravascular coagulation 
in intestinal capillaries, necrosis of glandular and intestinal 
crypt cells (Roberts et al., 2000).
4.6 Diagnosis
Clinical signs (Roberts et al., 2000 ), bacterial culture ( Das 
et  al., 2020) and molecular diagnosis such as ERIC-PCR 
(Seifi et al., 2016).
Differential diagnoses
– Salmonellosis.
– Parvovirus enteritis (Seifi et al., 2016).
4.7 Treatment
Gentamicin, enrofloxacin, chloramphenicol or combination 
of ceftriaxone-sulbactam (Das et al., 2020).
5 Yersiniosis
5.1 Cause
Yersinia species, commonly Y. pestis, Y. pseudotuberculo-
sis, and Y. enterocolitica (Stamm et al., 2013).
5.2 Hosts
Dogs, cats and many mammals (Rosner et al., 2010).
5.3 Spread
Sporadic outbreaks through food-borne route (Fredriksson-
Ahomaa et al., 2006) or interaction with infected dogs/cats 
(Fenwick et al., 1994; Fig. 4).
FIG. 3 Consider the pus-filled uterine horns with engorged blood vessels.

504 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
5.4 Pathogenesis
Yersinia organism on ingestion invades gastrointestinal 
tracts and binds to B1 integrins on host cells ( Hu et  al., 
2010) facilitated by enteric acidic conditions and tempera -
ture optimal for expressing chromosomal encoded protein 
“invasion” (Pepe and Miller, 1993).
5.5 Clinical signs
Yersiniosis exhibits three clinical forms; the bubonic, sep -
ticemic and pneumonic plaque which are all rare in dogs 
(Schaffer et al., 2020 ) but more common in cats presented 
with dyspnea and hemoptysis (Gage et al., 2000), acute gas-
troenteritis with bloody diarrhea, fever, mesenteric lymph -
adenopathy (Vlachaki et al., 2007), depression, dehydration 
and death within few days (Philbey et al., 1991).
5.6 Pathological findings
Grossly, enteric forms show fluid-filled small intestines 
and colon which are having congested and roughened mu -
cosae (Slee and Button, 1990 ); mesenteric lymphadenopa-
thy characterized by enlargement, congestion and edema 
(Philbey et al., 1991).
Septicemic show bacteremia with multiple organ in -
flammation and necrosis while pneumonic with diffuse 
necrotizing pneumonia of lower respiratory tract ( Stenseth 
et al., 2008 ). Bubonic show multicentric necrosupporative 
lymphadenitis with several bacterial colonies, vasculitis, 
thrombosis, hemorrhages, necrotic foci and roughened 
hepatic surfaces ( Brown and Davis, 1989 ), thick fibrinous 
exudates on lungs, petechial hemorrhages and epicardial 
oedema resulting to bleeding into intestinal tract ( Bin-Kun 
et al., 1994).
5.7 Diagnosis
Clinical signs, bacterial culture, pathological findings 
(Aleksić et  al., 1991 ) and sero-molecular diagnosis like 
MALDI-TOF-MS, confirmation using real-time PCR 
(Schaffer et  al., 2020 ), PFGE or FT-IR ( Fredriksson-
Ahomaa et al., 2006).
5.8 Treatment
Ampicillin/sulbactam sodium, enrofloxacin and intrave -
nous fluids such as lactated Ringer’s solution at 50 mg/kg 
IV Q8hourly, 10 mg/kg IV Q24 hour and 80 mL/kg/day ini-
tially, maintenance at 60 mL/kg/day respectively ( Schaffer 
et al., 2020).
5.9 Differential diagnoses
Bacterial hepatitis
Leptospirosis (Schaffer et al., 2020).
5.10 Prevention
Minimize dog-cat-human contact and among pets 
(European Food Safety Authority and European Centre for 
Disease Prevention and Control, 2012) and vaccination with 
“Yersiniavac” (Gill, 1996).
6 Bartonellosis
6.1 Cause
Bartonella henselae (Deng et al., 2012).
6.2 Hosts
Cats are primary reservoir hosts, humans (Jaffe et al., 2018), 
dogs and several mammals (Olarte et al., 2012).
6.3 Spread
Blood-sucking arthropods; lice, biting flies, fleas and ticks 
ingest the intraerythrocytic bacteria from blood stream and 
inoculate it to either a primary reservoir or accidental hosts 
(Regier et al., 2016; Fig. 5).
6.4 Pathogenesis
Upon inoculation, the bacteria colonize organs such as 
spleen, bone marrow, kidneys, endothelial cells ( Da Silva 
et al., 2017 ), erythrocytes and CD34 + progenitors ( Brook

et  al., 2017 ) followed by recurring bacteremia ( Maeno 
et al., 1999) and vascular damage (Dehio, 2005).
6.5 Clinical signs
Though commonly self-limiting, subclinical bacteremia, 
encephalitis, fever, lymphadenomegaly, ocular disease 
(Uveitis and neuroretinitis), endo and myocarditis and skin 
inflammation (Mazur-Melewska et al., 2015).
6.6 Pathology
Pulmonary nodules, lymphadenopathy, kidney enlargement 
and splenomegaly (Morales et al., 2007).
Histological includes dermatitis, panniculitis, pyogran -
ulomatous lymphadenitis, endocarditis, hepatitis, granu -
lomatous rhinitis ( Cross et  al., 2008 ), polyarthritis and 
meningitis (Kordick et al., 1999).
6.7 Diagnosis
Clinical signs, pathological lesions, bacterial culture in 
BAPGM-PCR (Oteo et al., 2017), sero/molecular like PCR 
(Chomel et al., 2006), western immunoblot, FISH, IFA and 
ELISA (Varanat et al., 2009).
6.8 Treatment
Doxycycline-pradofloxacin at 5  mg/kg PO 12  h for 
4–5  weeks in cats or doxycycline alone at 5  mg/kg 12 
hourly followed by second regimen in 5–7  days in dogs 
(Breitschwerdt, 2017).
6.9 Prevention
Vector control using acaricidal collars, spray-on and spot-
on (Lappin et al., 2013).
7 Tularaemia
7.1 Cause
Francisella tularensis (Feldman et al., 2003).
7.2 Hosts
Cats (Staples et al., 2006), dogs (Meinkoth et al., 2004) and 
several mammals (Morner and Mattsson, 1983). Ticks serve 
as reservoir hosts (Kwit et al., 2019).
7.3 Spread
Dogs and cats acquire infection via arthropod bites, inges -
tion, direct contact with infected tissues or mechanical trans-
mission by deer-flies and mosquitoes (Cherry et al., 2019).
7.4 Pathogenesis
Upon entrance of organism via arthropod bite (Klock et al., 
1973) or direct contact with infected tissues; it proliferates

within macrophages and hematogenously spread through -

7.5 Clinical signs
Cat infections are usually nonclinical; clinical manifesta -
tions include fever, lymphadenopathy, anorexia, listless -
ness, dehydration, pneumonia, icterus, draining abscess and 
oro-lingual ulcerations (Woods et al., 1998).
Dogs present acute pyrexia, anorexia, lymphadenopa -
thy, necrotizing fasciitis ( Gustafson and DeBowes, 1996 ), 
mucopurulent oculonasal discharges and dermal pustules 
(Damon and Johnson, 1944).
7.6 Pathology
Gross lesions include splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, lymph-
adenoma in dogs and cats (Rhyan et al., 1990).
Histological lesions include several small, grayish, yel -
low or white necrotic foci in spleen, lungs and liver, multi -
focal fibrin necrotic pneumonia (Donnelly and Behr, 2000) 
and Peyer’s patches involvement (Rhyan et al., 1990).
7.7 Diagnosis
Clinical signs, postmortem findings (Gustafson and DeBowes, 
1996), bacterial culture and PCR (Ikäheimo et al., 2000).
7.8 Treatment
Gentamicin at 6.6 mg/kg IM/IV/SC q24h or divided q12h 
or 8 h.
Doxycycline at 5 mg/kg PO q24 to 12 h.
Chloramphenicol at 50  mg/kg PO/IM q12h in cats or 
loading dose of 100 mg/kg followed by 50 mg/kg PO/IM 
q8h maintenance in dogs (Feldman et al., 2003).
7.9 Prevention
Acaricidal use, minimizing direct contact with hunting pets 
and prompt veterinarian care for supposedly sick pets (Kwit 
et al., 2019).
8 Campylobacteriosis
8.1 Cause
Campylobacter jejuni and C. coli (Corry and Atabay, 2001).
8.2 Hosts
Dogs, cats, wild birds, pigs, cattle and sheep ( Simpson 
et al., 1981; Stern et al., 1992).
8.3 Spread
Asymptomatic animals, human sewage, wild birds, manure 
run-offs from feces in animal farms contaminate surface 
water and shallow wells (Olson et al., 2008).
8.4 Pathogenesis
Induced neutrophilic intestinal inflammation by activation 
of NF-KB which stimulate production of neutrophil che -
mokine IL-8 and migration of neutrophils across epithelia 
through chemotactic n-formyl peptides and 12-LOX metab-
olites production that cause enteritis (Murphy et al., 2011).
8.5 Clinical signs
Enteritis in puppies and kittens seen as loose, watery, mu -
coid or bloody diarrhea, intermittent vomiting, anorexia and 
fever (Murphy et al., 2011).
8.6 Pathology
Gross and histological changes such as mucosal fibrosis, 
epithelial injury, shortened villi, crypt dilatation, lacteal 
dilatation, neutrophilic inflammation, lymphangiectasia, 
mucosal atrophy and eosinophilic inflammation ( Maunder 
et al., 2016).
8.7 Diagnosis
Clinical signs, bacterial culture, pathological findings 
(Maunder et  al., 2016 ) and molecular diagnosis such as 
PCR (Abu-Halaweh et al., 2005).
8.8 Treatment
Macrolides such as azithromycin, erythromycin or fluoro -
quinolones are drugs of choice (Marks et al., 2002).
9 Listeriosis
9.1 Cause
Listeria monocytogenes  and L. ivanovii  ( Maurice Bilung 
et al., 2018).
9.2 Hosts
Dogs, cats, sheep, pigs, horses, camels, birds, humans, cat -
tle and buffalo (Sizonenko et al., 2019).
9.3 Spread
Ingestion of food and water contaminated with feces, or 
other secretions (Brugère-Picoux, 2008).

Bacterial diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 34  507
9.4 Pathogenesis
Inoculation followed by migration to target organ, recep -
tors attachment, invasion into epithelia aided by phagocytic 
vacuole, vacuole escape (Dhama et al., 2015) and activation 
of virulence factors such as hemolysin and bile salt hydro -
lase that help in adhesion, intracellular multiplication and 
pathogenicity (Osanai et al., 2013; Vera et al., 2013; Fig. 6).
9.5 Clinical signs
Diarrhea, vomiting, fever, laborious breathing, encephali -
tis seen as ataxia, convulsions, torticollis, muscle pain and 
death (Goulet et al., 2013), abortion, mastitis, repeat bread-
ing, endometritis, skin ulcerations, dermatitis and tonsilitis 
(Läikkö et al., 2004; Figs. 7–9).
9.6 Pathology
Grossly abscess and softening of medulla, brainstem discol-
oration (Rocha et al., 2013 ), splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, 
hemorrhages in liver and spleen (Dhama et al., 2015).
Histological lesions include spinal myelitis, perivascu -
lar lymphocytic cuffing, micro-abscesses on brainstem, vas-
culitis, oedema (Rocha et al., 2013), multifocal necrosis in 
liver and spleen (Dhama et al., 2015).
9.7 Diagnosis
Culture, isolation and identification of bacteria ( Brugère-
Picoux, 2008), pathological findings ( Rocha et al., 2013 ), 
PCR, agglutination test, CFT, HAIT and ELISA ( Benetti 
et al., 2013; Dhama et al., 2014).

Anton test by dropping infected material in rabbit’s con-
junctiva to produce conjunctivitis or keratoconjunctivitis 
within 24–36 h (Brugère-Picoux, 2008).
9.8 Treatment
β-Lactam with or without trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, 
erythromycin, vancomycin or fluoroquinolones ( Temple 
and Nahata, 2000).
9.9 Prevention
Implementation of good management and biosecurity 
(Brugère-Picoux, 2008).
10 Nocardiosis
10.1 Cause
Nocardia farcinica and N. nova of N. asteroides complex 
(Kiska et al., 2002).
10.2 Hosts
Dogs (Eroksuz et al., 2016), cats, birds and domestic/wild/
zoo mammals (Leger et al., 2009).
10.3 Spread
Inhalation, ingestion or subcutaneous transmission from 
soil, water or plant of spore-like cell fragments ( Brown-
Elliott et al., 2006; Chedid et al., 2007).
10.4 Pathogenesis
Following ingestion or secondary penetrating injury 
(Eroksuz et al., 2016), it spread to adjacent tissues via lym-
phatics causing sloughing and devitalization, necrosis and 
ischemia (Soto et al., 2014).
10.5 Clinical signs
Fever, jaundice, uveitis, keratitis, sulfur-like granules in 
wound exudates (Marks et al., 2002), vertebral osteomyelitis 
(Soto et al., 2014), pneumonia, pyothorax (Bali et al., 2000), 
peritonitis (Tilgner and Anstey, 1996), dermatitis, cellulitis 
and fistulous draining tracts (Ramos-Vara et al., 2007).
10.6 Pathology
Multifocal coalescing pyogranulomatous abscess in lungs, 
liver, heart, spleen, kidneys, pulmonary lymph nodes with 
thickened and opaque meninges, petechial hemorrhages 
in epicardium and diaphragmatic surfaces of heart grossly 
(Soto et al., 2014; Figs. 10–13).
Microscopic findings include lymphoplasmacytic and 
neutrophilic inflammatory reactions in Virchow-Robin 
spaces, meningitis, granulomas with necrotic centers, sinu-
soidal hepatitis, Kupffer cells activation and cloudy swell -
ing in the liver (Eroksuz et al., 2016).
FIG.  11  Coronal section of left frontal lobe showing multifocal-  
coalescing abscesses (arrows) (Eroksuz et al., 2016).
FIG. 12 Multifocal, pyogranulomatous nephritis (arrow) (Eroksuz et al., 
2016).

510 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
10.7 Differential diagnosis
Subcutaneous form should be differentiated from 
Rhodococcosis, Corynobacteriosis, Actinomycosis, 
Dermatophilosis (Malik et al., 2004 ) and canine distemper 
(Eroksuz et al., 2016).
10.8 Diagnosis
Clinical signs, pathological findings, molecular diagnosis 
such as PCR ( Eroksuz et al., 2016 ), bacterial culture aug -
mented with biochemical tests (Malik, 2007).
10.9 Treatment
Amoxicillin and clarithromycin at 20 and 62.5–125 mg/kg 
BID.
Doxycycline at 5 mg/kg BID in cats.
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole at 15–40  mg/kg BID 
(Malik, 2007).
Ampicillin-erythromycin with or without trimethoprim-
sulfamethoxazole (Luque et al., 2002).
11 Staphylococcal infections
11.1 Cause
Staphylococcus species (Zakošek Pipan et al., 2019).
11.2 Hosts
Dogs, cats and several mammals (Wertheim et al., 2005).
11.3 Spread
Dam’s milk in puppies ( Zakošek Pipan et al., 2019 ), skin-
to-skin contact, aerosols from sneezing, coughing and sa -
liva (Malik et al., 2004).
11.4 Pathogenesis
The bacteria upon invasion of inner tissues ( Malik et  al., 
2004) employ its different virulence markers in form of en-
zymes or other molecules to elicit damages that result to 
clinical manifestations (Tomasello et al., 2021).
11.5 Clinical signs
Otitis, pyoderma, urinary tract infections, toxic shock syn -
drome/necrotizing fasciitis, arthritis, osteomyelitis, perito -
nitis, ocular infection, septicemia ( Tomasello et al., 2021), 
superficial dermatitis, bacterial folliculitis, follicular pap -
ules/pustules (Bannoehr and Guardabassi, 2012 ), and con-
junctivitis (Sganga et al., 2020; Figs. 14 and 15).
11.6 Pathology
Cutaneous gross findings of pyogenic granulomatous called 
bacterial pseudomycetoma, distended abdomen, catarrhal 
gastroenteritis, lymphadenopathy, congested liver, spleen, 
pancreas and meninges (Zakošek Pipan et al., 2019).
Histological lesions include eosinophilic Splendore-
Hoeppli material surrounding bacterial colonies, nodular 
panniculitis ( Sah et  al., 2018 ), acute interstitial pneumo -
nia and myocardial necrosis with mineralization ( Zakošek 
Pipan et al., 2019; Figs. 16 and 17).
11.7 Diagnosis
Clinical signs (Carroll et al., 2021), bacterial culture (Malik 
et  al., 2004 ), and postmortem/biopsy findings ( Turner, 
2021).
11.8 Treatment
Amoxicillin and clavulanic acid followed by clindamycin 
or cephalexin, topical fusidic acid, chlorhexidine and mi -
conazole shampoo and phage therapy (Malik et al., 2004).
11.9 Prevention
Live-attenuated/inactivated vaccines (bacterins) against 
pyoderma (Carroll et al., 2021).
12 Streptococcal infections
12.1 Cause
Streptococcus species (Britton and Davies, 2010).
FIG. 13 Multifocal, coalescing abscesses in the cerebral cortex (H&E) 
(Eroksuz et al., 2016).

Bacterial diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 34  511
12.2 Hosts
Dogs, cats, poultry and several marine/terrestrial mammals 
(Bannister et al., 1985).
12.3 Spread
Through contaminated milk ( Schäfer‐Somi et  al., 2003 ), 
in-utero infection, during parturition ( Bjurström, 1993 ), 
 skin-to-skin contact, bite wounds ( Loubinoux et al., 1997 ) 
and indirect contact (Weese et al., 2009).
12.4 Pathogenesis
The hyperproduction of proinflammatory cytokines leads 
to hyperinflammatory response which results to increased

vascular permeability, vasodilation, increased coagulation 
and migration of inflammatory cells to site of infection 
(Schäfer‐Somi et al., 2003).
12.5 Clinical signs
Purulent nasal discharges, cough, sinusitis, dyspnea, pneu -
monia, abscesses, toxic shock syndrome, meningitis, poly -
arthritis and osteomyelitis in cats (Blum et al., 2010).
Abortion, septicemia, dermatitis, pneumonia, endocar -
ditis, necrotizing fasciitis, keratitis, lower urinary tract in -
fections, arthritis, cholangitis and meningoencephalitis in 
dogs (Pesavento et al., 2008; Figs. 18–21).
12.6 Pathology
Suppurative bronchoalveolar pneumonia, pleuritis, pyo -
granulomatous meningoencephalitis, necrosupporative  
peritonitis in cats ( Blum et  al., 2010 ). Encephalitis, 
 endocarditis with thickened and mottled dark red valves, 
pulmonary consolidation, dark red and rubbery lungs 
and dermal cavitations are gross findings in dogs ( Lamm 
et al., 2010 ).
Histological lesions include diffuse mixed neutro -
philic, histiocytic and lymphocytic infiltrations, valvular 
expansions with fibrin, cellular debris and neutrophils 
(Blum et al., 2010 ). Neutrophils mixed with fibrin, mac -
rophages, lymphocytes and plasma cells expanding me -
ninges and Robin-Virchow space ( Irwin and Parry, 1999 ) 
and distended vascular lumina in multiple organs ( Lamm 
et al., 2010).
12.7 Diagnosis
Clinical signs, postmortem findings, bacterial culture 
(Blum et  al., 2010 ) and DNA extraction using PCR ( Oh 
et al., 2015).
12.8 Treatment
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole combination for weeks is 
drug of choice for eradication (Byun et al., 2009).
12.9 Prevention
Sick pets should be isolated and veterinarian to wear protec-
tive clothing prior to handling (Weese et al., 2009).

13 Tetanus
13.1 Cause
Tetanospasmin produced by Clostridium tetani  ( Popoff, 
2020).
13.2 Hosts
Most animal species including dogs and cats ( Smith et al., 
1975).
13.3 Spread
Wound contamination with tetani spores from soil 
(Bytchenko, 1981).
13.4 Pathogenesis
Spores enter wound and vegetate under anaerobic condi -
tions to produce potent neurotoxin tetanospasmin ( Popoff, 
2020). This enters peripheral nerves at infection site, spinal 
cord neuronal cell bodies, brainstem and later across syn -
apse to bind irreversibly to interneurons meant to inhibit 
recurrent firing of motor neurons as well as contraction of 
FIG. 19 Bite-wound immediately after shaving and dressing under an -
esthesia with hydrogen peroxide. Synolux (Amoxi-clav), vitamin C and 
ketoprofen were injected (Strep).
FIG. 20 Same wound 4 days after treatment initiation.
FIG. 21 Bite sites after 3 weeks.

514 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
flexor and extensor muscles leading to sustained spasm 
(Sanford, 1995; Figs. 22 and 23).
13.5 Clinical signs
Localized spastic paralysis seen as trismus, stiff limbs 
(Burkitt et al., 2007) or generalized presented as mild body 
spasm, erect ears, wrinkled forehead and hyperthermia after 
incubation of 5–10 days (Sprott, 2008).
13.6 Differentials
Polymyositis, strychnine intoxication, spinal trauma, hypo-
calcemia and meningoencephalitis (Sprott, 2008).
13.7 Diagnosis
Clinical signs with wound, electromyography ( De Risio 
et  al., 2006 ), serum TeNT detection, ELISA and PCR 
(Huang et al., 2013).
13.8 Prevention
Two shots of formaldehyde inactivated TeNT immunization 
at 3–4 weeks interval (Van Galen et al., 2017).
13.9 Treatment
Intravenous TAT, penicillin G at 25  mg/kg for 7  days, 
 diazepam-acepromazine/chlorpromazine-phenobarbital 
and fluid therapy (Sprott, 2008).
14 Pasteurellosis
14.1 Cause
Pasteurella multocida (Klein and Cunha, 1997).
14.2 Hosts
Cats, dogs and many mammals (Morris and McAllister, 1992).
14.3 Spread
Through bite wounds.
14.4 Clinical signs
Fever, headache, nuchal rigidity, nausea and meningitis 
with altered level of consciousness (Green et al., 2002).
14.5 Diagnosis
Clinical signs, organism isolation and PCR ( Dousse et al., 
2008).
14.6 Treatment
Penicillins or third-generation cephalosporins. 
Chloramphenicol is recommended if beta-lactam antibiotic 
allergy exists (Tun et al., 2018).
14.7 Prevention
Proper pet oral, feed and kennel hygiene to avoid inocula -
tion (Green et al., 2002).
15 Clostridium perfringens infection
15.1 Cause
Clostridium perfringens (Kokai-Kun et al., 1994).
15.2 Hosts
Dogs (Argenti et al., 1987 ), cats ( Marks et al., 2002 ) and 
several mammals (Songer and Meer, 1996).
15.3 Spread
Ingesting food contaminated with bacterial spores ( Bartlett 
et al., 1972) or disruption of intestinal flora causing sporula-
tion (Marks et al., 2002).

15.4 Clinical signs
Diarrhea which may be mild self-limiting or progressing 
to acute hemorrhagic with intestinal mucosa inflammation 
(Cave et al., 2002) and fever (Kather et al., 2006).

Clinical signs, ELISA, PCR ( Marks et al., 2002 ) and fecal 
endospores Gram-staining (Marks et al., 1999).

Ampicillin, erythromycin, metronidazole and tetracycline 
(Kather et al., 2006).
16 Clostridium difficile infection
16.1 Cause
Clostridium difficile (Marks et al., 2002).
16.2 Hosts
Cats, dogs and several species mostly young (Arroyo et al., 
2004).
16.3 Spread
Ingestion of spores (Marks et al., 2002).
FIG. 23 Structure of tetanus toxin (TeNT) and schematic representation of its mode of action. H C = receptor-binding domain; H N = translocation do-
main; LC = light chain or enzymatic domain containing the enzymatic site. TeNT is transported from contaminated wound to the central nervous system 
by retrograde axonal transport through motor neurons and possibly sensory neurons. In the spinal cord and brain, TeNT targets inhibitory interneurons 
blocking the release of glycine and GABA. This results in muscular hyperactivity subsequent to stimuli (e.g., touch, light, noise, temperature) as a result 
of the absence of inhibitory control. Tetanus (Popoff, 2020).

16.4 Pathogenesis
Proliferation of toxin-producing strains in the GIT to pro -
duce toxin A, B and binary CD that causes C. diffile-induced 
diarrhea (Lefebvre et al., 2006 ) due to damaged intestinal 
epithelial cells (Nale et al., 2012).
16.5 Clinical signs
Subclinical carrier to fatal acute hemorrhagic diarrheal syn-
drome of small and large intestinal origin (Cave et al., 2002).
16.6 Diagnosis
Clinical signs ( Cave et  al., 2002 ), fecal toxin detection, 
culture and isolation, ELISA and real-time PCR ( Lefebvre 
et al., 2006).
16.7 Treatment
Metronidazole 10–15/kg P·O q12h or 15  mg/kg/q12h I·V 
for 5 days (Marks et al., 2002).
17 Brucellosis
17.1 Cause
Brucella abortus, B. canis, B. neotomae, and B. melitensis 
(Xavier et al., 2009).
17.2 Spread
Via coitus (Hubbard et al., 2018), close contact/ingestion of 
tissues, raw milk or other secretions from infected animals 
(Woldemeskel, 2013).
17.3 Hosts
Dogs, cats, humans and several mammals ( Xavier et  al., 
2009).
17.4 Pathogenesis
Entry via digestive/respiratory mucosa is followed by epi -
thelial invasion through M cells ( Cosford, 2018 ) and re -
cruiting GTPases and lipopolysaccharides. These evade 
phagocytosis, antimicrobial peptides release, nitric oxide 
and free radicals that induce pro-inflammatory response via 
IFN-ý to produce lesions (Chacón-Díaz et al., 2015).
17.5 Pathology
Metritis, placentitis, lymphadenitis, gastritis, epididymitis, 
orchitis, prostatitis, bronchopneumonia, omphalitis, arthri -
tis and enteritis (Xavier et al., 2009).
17.6 Clinical signs
Loss of vigor, reproductive failure, abortions between 45 
and 55  days of gestation ( Xavier et  al., 2009 ) with sero -
sanguineous viscous to grayish-green vaginal discharges 
(Santos et al., 2021), ocular disease, disco spondylitis, urine 
retention, fever, submandibular and retropharyngeal lymph-
adenopathy, scrotal enlargement, testicular abscess and 
prostatitis (Makloski, 2011).
17.7 Diagnosis
Agent isolation with biochemical tests (Santos et al., 2021) 
or MALDI-TOF-MS (Lista et al., 2011) from urine or whole 
blood (Alton et al., 1975), PCR, ELISA and CFT (Azevedo 
et al., 2004).
17.8 Treatment
Oxytetracycline for 4  weeks combined with streptomy -
cin in first week ( Zoha and Walsh, 1982), enrofloxacin or 
doxycycline- rifampicin (Mateu-de-Antonio and Martin, 1995).
17.9 Prevention and control
Using screening tests, treating/euthanizing infected animals 
and environmental elimination (Hollett, 2006).
18 Helicobacter infections
18.1 Cause
Helicobacter pylori (Leib and Duncan, 2005).
18.2 Hosts
Dogs, cats, humans and other animals ( Leib and Duncan, 
2005).
18.3 Spread
Is unclear; fecal-oral spread is hypothesized because H. py-
lori can be cultured from cat feces (Dunn et al., 1997).
18.4 Pathogenesis
They contain large quantities of the enzyme urease, which 
results in production of ammonia and bicarbonate from urea 
that alters the pH surrounding the bacteria and helps them 
colonize the acidic environment of the stomach (Lecoindre 
et al., 2000).
18.5 Clinical signs
Gastritis and chronic vomiting (Leib and Duncan, 2005).

Bacterial diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 34  517
18.6 Pathology
Spiral bacteria can be seen within mucus covering the sur -
face epithelium, within gastric pits, glandular lumen and 
parietal cells (Yamasaki et al., 1998).
18.7 Diagnosis
Endoscopic examination, exploratory celiotomy, gastric bi-
opsy, brush cytology or indirectly by rapid urease testing of 
gastric mucosal samples (Sousa et al., 2017).
18.8 Treatment
Amoxicillin, metronidazole, azithromycin and famotidine or 
combination therapy for 1 week (Neiger and Simpson, 2000).
19 Pseudomoniasis
19.1 Cause
Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
19.2 Hosts
Dog, cat, human and other mammals (Płókarz et al., 2022).
19.3 Spread
Transmission between humans and other mammals via bio-
film formation (Shehab and Al-Rubaii, 2018).
19.4 Pathogenesis
Production of biofilm (Shehab and Al-Rubaii, 2018) along 
with neuraminidase that may release terminal sialic acid 
residues from sialated gangliosides that helps buccal im -
plantation of organism (Soong et al., 2006).
19.5 Clinical signs
Cutaneous ulcers, hemorrhagic crusts, erythematous pap -
ules (Hillier et al., 2006 ), systemic and urinary tract infec -
tions, otitis externa ( Robinson et al., 2019 ), conjunctivitis, 
rhino sinusitis, periapical tooth abscesses and periodontal 
disease (Riggio et al., 2011).
19.6 Diagnosis
Clinical signs, DNA extraction (Płókarz et al., 2022), PCR, 
microtiter plate method (O'Toole, 2011).
19.7 Treatment
Enrofloxacin, ciprofloxacin, gentamicin and ceftazidime 
(Dégi et al., 2021).
