522 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats

523

Chapter 35
Fungal diseases of dogs and cats
1 Introduction
With the use of increasingly potent immunosuppressive 
drug regimens for longer periods of time, fungus infections 
in pets have become more frequent in recent years, as has 
the use of antifungal medications. Early diagnosis for more 
successful therapy has been a focus, as has the search for 
novel, more potent antifungal drugs as well as those with 
distinct mechanisms of action. This presentation aims to 
give an overview of several fungi diseases in animals, de -
scribe the use of some diagnostic tools, and highlight some 
of the most effective antifungal medications ( Gionfriddo, 
2000).
2 Mechanisms of immunosuppression in 
dogs and cats
Single-agent glucocorticoid therapy was the gold standard 
for treating immune-mediated diseases in animals for a very 
long time. Glucocorticoids have nonselective effects on the 
host immune system, which include cytokine inhibition 
and release, reduced macrophage Fc receptor expression 
and function, decreased phagocytosis, diminished macro -
phage antigen processing and presentation, and diminished 
lymphocyte counts ( Tizard, 2009). The cell-mediated Th1 
response, which is in charge of defense against fungi, is in-
hibited. Unfortunately, glucocorticoids alone are frequently 
insufficient to treat severe immune-mediated disease mani-
festations, and because of their unpleasant side effects in 
dogs, veterinarians frequently supplement glucocorticoids 
with other immunosuppressants approved by the FDA. 
These include alkylating drugs (such as cyclophosphamide 
and chlorambucil), folic acid antagonists (such as metho -
trexate), and nucleotide analogues (such as azathioprine 
(Archer, 2017 ). Mycophenolate and leflunomide limit B 
and T cell proliferation and clonal expansion by preventing 
purine and pyrimidine production (Tizard, 2009).
According to published case studies, administration of 
cyclosporine might increase the risk of development of op-
portunistic fungal infections in dogs. This may be because 
cyclosporine inhibits T helper cell activities, which are cru-
cial for the host’s defense against fungal infection. A gene 
transcription factor called nuclear factor of activated T cells 
is triggered when cyclosporine enters the T cell and binds 
to cyclophilin, blocking calcineurin (an intracellular phos -
phatase). As a result, the Th1 response is suppressed, and 
IL-2 and IFN-g production is reduced. Cyclosporine dosage 
affects how much immunosuppression a dog experiences 
(Archer et al., 2014).
3 Opportunistic fungal infections
Opportunistic mycoses, which are rarely harmful to im -
munocompetent hosts, are suddenly emerging as important 
disease-causing agents in immunocompromised dogs and 
cats. The majority of opportunistic fungi, in contrast to 
endemic mycoses like histoplasmosis, blastomycosis, and 
sporotrichosis, lack sufficient distinctive morphologic traits 
to permit genus- or species-level classification solely based 
on morphology, necessitating culture or molecular testing 
for definitive identification. As a result, many practitioners 
will come with these fungi for the first time, whether a his-
tologic investigation of a skin biopsy or a cytologic exami-
nation of a lymph node aspirate results in a diagnosis of 
fungal infection without further identification or classifica-
tion. Fortunately, with a thorough histologic or cytologic 
description, morphologic criteria including pigmentation, 
hyphal diameter, frequency of septation, and tissue distribu-
tion can typically be divided into therapeutically relevant 
categories with a complete histologic or cytologic descrip -
tion (Archer et al., 2014; Dedeaux et al., 2018).
Animals on two immunosuppressive medicines, one of 
which is cyclosporine, or canines on any three immunosup-
pressive drugs, according to the researchers, are at the great-
est risk of opportunistic fungal infection. Natural sources 
of immunocompromise, in addition to medication therapy, 
may predispose to opportunistic mycoses. Candida spp. uri-
nary tract infection in diabetic dogs and cats, as well as dis-
seminated aspergillosis and hyalohyphomycosis in German 
Shepherd dogs with suspected familial multifactorial

524 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
 immunodeficiency, Pneumocystis pneumonia in miniature 
dachshunds with combined variable immunodeficiency, 
systemic mold infection in young dogs with Imerslund-
Grasbeck syndrome, and phaeohyphomycosis ) Erles et al., 
2018). As a result, the goal of this study is to make it easier 
to recognize and treat fungal saprophyte infections, with an 
emphasis on infections linked to immunosuppressive phar -
macological therapy (Dedeaux et al., 2018).
3.1 Phaeohyphomycosis
They are saprophytic fungi which create pigmented 
(or dematiaceous) yeast or hyphae in tissue, result -
ing in phaeohyphomycosis. Curvularia, Exophiala, 
Fonsecaea, Lecytophora, Microsphaeropsis, Moniliella, 
Mycoleptodiscus, Phialophora, Ramichloridium and 
Scolecobasidium. Cutaneous inoculation is the most com -
mon source of infections of the skin, subcutaneous tissue, 
and central nervous system, as well as widespread disease 
(Bernhardt et al., 2014).
The development of cutaneous lesions in regions in con-
tact with soil, like nose, ears, and fingers, is the characteris-
tic sign of phaeohyphomycosis in immunocompetent cats. 
Direct injection induces infection, which leads to granulo -
matous inflammation that lasts for months ( Krockenberger 
et al., 2010).
Pigmented lesions can be mistaken for melanoma they 
seldom spread beyond the lymph nodes in their region. 
Systemic spread is unusual and has a poor prognosis. 
Animals with a central nervous system infection had a poor 
to fatal prognosis, but new research suggests that combining 
surgery with medication may improve mortality ( Meason-
Smith et al., 2017).
3.2 Hyalohyphomycosis
Infection induced by fungi that develop hyphal elements in 
tissue with nonpigmented (or hyaline) walls is known as hya-
lohyphomycosis. These septate hyphae generally branch at 
acute angles and may have patches of globose swelling, partic-
ularly at the hyphae’s end or between septations (Guarner and 
Brandt, 2011). The majority of these species lack other distin-
guishing morphologic traits, making further identification dif-
ficult. Acremonium, Chrysosporium, Fusarium, Geosmithia, 
Oxyporus, Paecilomyces, Purpureocillium, Pseudallescheria 
and its asexual form (anamorph), Scedosporium, Sagenomella, 
Geomyces, Schizophyllum, Scopulariopsis, Lecythophora, and 
Westerdykella have been documented to cause the disease 
(Armentano et al., 2013). This category excludes aspergillo-
sis which has typical clinical presentations and morphologic 
features (narrow, straight-walled septate hyphae branched at 
acute angles, occasionally with conidia and conidiophores 
when lesions are in the nasal cavity) ( Guarner and Brandt, 
2011). Aspergillus fumigatus causes sinonasal aspergillosis, 
while Aspergillus terreus and Aspergillus deflectus induce  
systemic aspergillosis. When culture or sequencing isn’t 
conducted, other kinds of aspergillosis may be indistin -
guishable from hyalohyphomycosis, and hence may be 
classified into that category. Aspergillus caninus  (previ -
ously Phialosimplex caninus) and Aspergillus alabamensis 
develop irregular hyphae and many round to ovoid fungal 
forms in tissue of immunosuppressed dogs ( Sigler et  al., 
2013).
Hyalohyphomycosis affects dogs more frequently than 
cats, with large-breed dogs being the most typically af -
fected. In immunocompetent pets, symptoms include poor 
body condition, fever, lameness, lymphadenomegaly, os -
teomyelitis, diskospondylitis, pneumonia, and chorioreti -
nitis beside central nervous system and ocular indications, 
which are comparable to those seen in systemic aspergil -
losis (Cook et  al., 2015). The kidney, liver, spleen, heart, 
bone marrow, skin, bladder, pancreas, thyroid, and adrenal 
gland have all been described as infection sites (Ribas et al., 
2015). The prognosis is bleak to bad, and large mortality 
rates have been observed (Sigler et al., 2013). When immu-
nosuppressive drugs are used to treat hyalohyphomycosis in 
dogs, the clinical course may differ in two ways from that of 
immunocompetent dogs. First, the disease could be limited 
to the skin with no signs of systemic spread ( Kano et al., 
2011). Second, like phaeohyphomycosis, animals on immu-
nosuppressive therapy may respond more readily to medical 
therapy than immunocompetent cases, but only if cyclo -
sporine can be discontinued and other immunosuppressant 
medications can be tapered (Armstrong et al., 2012).
3.3 Eumycotic mycetoma
Chronic pyogranulomatous lesions associated with the 
growth of fungal colonies that appear histologically as ag -
gregates of fungal hyphae and grossly as tissue grains are 
referred to as “eumycotic mycetoma.” Mycetomas are fur -
ther divided into two types based on the causative fungus: 
pigmented fungi that generate black-grain mycetoma and 
nonpigmented fungi that cause white-grain mycetoma. 
Black-grain mycetomas are darkly colored nodular lesions 
with draining tracts in the epidermis and subcutaneous tis -
sue caused by the direct implantation of fungi from the soil 
(Sun et al., 2013). Bone may be involved in some lesions. In 
pets, Cladophialophora bantiana , Curvularia lunata , and 
Madurella spp. have been identified as the causal agents of 
black-grain mycetoma (Guillot et al., 2004). Psychromonas 
boydii or Acremonium species are the most common causes 
of white-grain mycetomas, which appear as chronic body 
wall or intra-abdominal granulomas months to years after 
a contaminated penetrating wound or surgical site, espe -
cially after dehiscence. A draining tract or mass involving 
the body wall, an intra-abdominal mass, or peritonitis are all 
possible clinical symptoms ( Allison et al., 1989 ). Because

Fungal diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 35  525
the causative agents of eumycotic mycetoma are naturally 
resistant to antifungal drugs, vigorous surgical excision of 
all affected tissues with broad margins is the preferred treat-
ment. Unfortunately, the position of the lesion may prevent 
full excision. Debulking the lesions followed by long-term 
triazole therapy, on the other hand, may improve quality of 
life for a long time due to the slow growth of the lesions 
that are uncommon to spread beyond surrounding tissues 
(Janovec et al., 2016).
3.4 Microsporum canis
As pets and companion animals, cats are becoming in -
creasingly popular abandoned and available for adoption at 
animal shelters for nearly nothing. Buying pricey purebred 
cats from breeding facilities is also popular. Animals are ac-
quired from communities in both circumstances and may 
be infected with diseases that are transmissible to humans, 
whether visible or not. Microsporum canis-induced derma-
tophytosis is the most common zoonosis that can arise in 
such circumstances ( Chermette et  al., 2008 ). Rapid turn -
over of cats of unknown status, promiscuity, and financial 
limits for healthcare all enhance the danger of spread and 
persistence of M. canis in shelters where suitable antifungal 
treatments are either absent or incomplete. Asymptomatic 
carriage is common, with cats infected without showing any 
clinical indications (Mignon and Losson, 1997).
3.5 Sporothrix brasiliensis
Research in Sporothrix taxonomy has resulted in the iden -
tification of a clinically important clade that includes four 
dimorphic species: S. brasiliensis, S. schenckii, S. globosa, 
and S. luriei, which are distinct from environmental clades 
that include S. chilensis, S. pallida, and S. mexicana, which 
cause occasional infections in virulence profiles, antifungal 
susceptibilities, and geographic ranges of species (Marimon 
et al., 2007). Trauma with soil and plant materials is the tradi-
tional transmission route for pets. S. brasiliensis outbreaks, 
on the other hand, are frequently caused by alternate routes 
of transmission such as animal-animal or animal-human  
transmission (Rodrigues et al., 2016). Unfortunately, sporo-
trichosis in cats is not a notifiable disease. To comprehend 
the epidemic scenario caused by S. brasiliensis, some as -
pects of the host-pathogen-environment interplay must be 
considered, such as cats’ high susceptibility to the fungal 
species; the high virulence of S. brasiliensis circulating dur-
ing epidemics associated with a recent introduction of the 
pathogen in an urban feline population. Regarding some 
aspects of cat behavior, including toileting habits in touch 
with soil, sharpening nails in the environment, behavior 
during mating, and territorial disputes that frequently result 
in scratches or bites that transmit the fungus to additional 
hosts, should also be considered (Alba-Fierro et al., 2016).
3.6 Aspergillosis
In animals, aspergillosis refers to a variety of diseases rang-
ing from localized infections to lethal systemic infections, 
as well as allergic reactions produced by Aspergillus fungi 
(Seyedmousavi et  al., 2015 ). This genus contains several 
saprobic filamentous fungi that are typically found in soil, 
decaying plants, and on seeds and grains, with the ability 
to infect different living animal hosts ( Heitman, 2011 ). 
Despite the fact that the genus has over 300 species, ani -
mal aspergilloses are primarily caused by Ammophilus fu-
migatus and a few other species ( Heitman, 2011 ). There 
are 22 sections under classification of genus Aspergillus 
like Aspergillus, Fumigati, Circumdati, Terrei, Nidulantes, 
Ornati, Warcupi, Candidi, Restricti, Usti, Flavipedes, and 
Versicolores (Peterson et al., 2008 ). In animals, aspergillo-
sis is largely a respiratory disease that can spread to other 
areas of the body. However, tissue preference differs by spe-
cies. Aspergillosis can occur in healthy animals as a result 
of stress or other immune-compromising disorders ( Zmeili 
and Soubani, 2007).
In pets, the most common symptoms of aspergillosis 
are sinonasal, bronchopulmonary, and disseminated infec -
tions (Barrs and Talbot, 2014). The most common causative 
agent of sinoorbital aspergillosis in cats with underlying 
illness (such as feline Immunodeficiency Virus and Feline 
Leukemia Virus) is Aspergillus felis, followed by cryptic 
species of the section Fumigati, such as A. udagawae and 
A. viridinutans (Barrs et al., 2013) (Fig. 1).
3.7 Mucormycosis
Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused 
by fungi belonging to the Mucorales order of the old 
Zygomycetes class ( Hoffmann et  al., 2013 ). Rhizopus, 
Mucor, Rhizomucor, Lichtheimia (previously Absidia), 
Apophysomyces, Cunninghamella, and Saksenaea are the 
most frequently identified sections within the order. The 
Mucorales’ native habitat is soil away from rotting or -
ganic matter. Fungi can also be present in the air, food, and 
dust, both indoors and outdoors ( Hoffmann et  al., 2013 ). 
Mucormycosis is identical in epidemiology, portal of entry, 
localization, and formation of lesions in domesticated and 
wild animals. Infection with Mucorales members are seen 
in hosts who are immunocompromised or otherwise debili-
tated due to metabolic problems (Jensen et al., 1992). Some 
incidences of mucormycosis in dogs and cats have been 
identified as a cause of enteritis or systemic dissemination 
(Awadin et al., 2015).
3.8 Candidiasis
Candida is classed based on phylogenetic relationships into 
around 200 species, 15 of which have been isolated from

526 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
infected people and animals ( Yapar, 2014). Candida albi-
cans, Candida glabrata , Candida parapsilosis , Candida 
tropicalis, and Candida krusei are the most common patho-
gens. Odds (1988)  classified these species as commensal 
and facultatively harmful since they are widely present in 
the microbiota of healthy individuals. While C. albicans  
and Candida glabrata appear to be found in warm-blooded 
hosts, other infectious Candida species have been discov -
ered in the environment. Infections are mainly generated 
by commensally precolonized strains rather than vertical or 
longitudinal transmission; hence, the zoonotic potential is 
regarded minimal (Odds et al., 2006).
Candidiasis can be superficial, affecting the skin, gas -
trointestinal, and urogenital tract mucosal membranes. 
Candidemia or localized infection of internal organs can re-
sult from fungus dissemination. Veterinary candidiasis lacks 
epidemiological data and a comprehensive examination of 
risk factors ( Pohlman and Chengappa, 2013 ). Cutaneous 
candidiasis is common in dogs and is often associated with 
atopy, immunosuppressive disorders, or immunosuppressive 
pharmacological treatment similar to Malassezia infections 
(Moretti et al., 2004). In pets, systemic candidiasis is uncom-
mon. However, surgery and trauma by foreign bodies can 
introduce Candida into deeper tissue or the peritoneal cav -
ity, resulting in granuloma formation or peritonitis (Burgess 
and Gaunt, 2014 ). Candidiasis of the urinary tract appears 
as candiduria and cystitis and is commonly associated with 
antibiotic treatment for past bacterial infections or diabetes 
mellitus. Disseminated candidiasis has been observed with 
a variety of symptoms that can include myocarditis, endo -
carditis, and endophthalmitis. Candidiasis can also occur as 
a result of bacterial infections. It should be considered as a 
possibility, especially if the hosts are resistant to antibiotic 
therapy (Álvarez-Pérez et al., 2016) (Fig. 2).
3.9 Blastomycosis
Blastomycosis is caused by infection with Blastomyces 
dermatitidis spores, which is most typically transmitted 
through inhalation. Moisture-rich, acidic soil with decaying 
vegetation or animal feces are ideal conditions for fungus 
growth (Klein et  al., 1986 ). Klein et  al. (1986)  proposed 
that environmental dampness plays a key role in the spread 
of spores. The Mississippi, Missouri, and Ohio river val -
leys are among the areas with the highest occurrence of 
blastomycosis. The disease is also prevalent in the middle 
Atlantic and southern states, and the southern Canadian 
waterways, whereas outbreaks have been observed in other 
areas ( Cote et  al., 1997 ). Infection happens when dog or 
cat inhales conidiophores. However, localized disease can 
also be caused via inoculation. Dogs are more commonly 
afflicted than other animals (Miller et al., 1990). After inha-
lation, infectious conidia are phagocytized by alveolar mac-
rophages and converted from the mycelial to the yeast phase 
(aided by normal body temperatures). The yeast forms are 
thick-walled structures with a diameter of (8–12  μm) that 
lack a capsule and bud to produce daughter cells with 
broad attachments. Yeast can cause a localized infection or 
spread hematogenously or via lymphatics to distant organs 
(Feldman and Ettinger, 2010).
In dogs, young large breeds (2–4  years) of both sexes 
are typical targets for blastomycosis ( Arceneaux et  al., 
1998). Symptoms appear weeks to months after the in -
fection occurs as: anorexia, depression, lethargy, weight 
loss, cachexia, and fever. Dissemination occurs through 
lymphatic and hematogenous pathways and appears in the 
eye, skeletal system, skin, and lymph nodes. Symptoms 
are frequently linked to more than one location at the same 
time. In dogs with pulmonary infection, indications such 
FIG. 1 Exophthalmos (A), mass in the left pterygopalatine fossa (B), and ulceration of the hard palate (C) due to retrobulbar fungal granulomas in cats 
with sino-orbital aspergillosis (Barrs et al., 2012).

Fungal diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 35  527
as tachypnea, dyspnea, cyanosis, or respiratory distress 
occur in 65%–85% of the time. Lymphadenopathy affects 
30%–50% of cases and might be mistaken for lymphosar -
coma if a lymph node aspirate or biopsy is not performed 
(Legendre, 1998). In 20%–50% of dogs, ocular involvement 
manifests as chorioretinitis, anterior uveitis, retinal detach -
ment, and secondary glaucoma ( Kerl, 2003). In 10%–15% 
of cases, there is bone involvement, with lesions most typi-
cally occurring over epiphyseal regions below the elbow or 
stifle (Feldman and Ettinger, 2010). Cutaneous symptoms, 
such as nodules, papules, or plaques of various sizes that 
drain sero-sanguineous to purulent exudate, are described 
in 30%–50% of cases. Involvement of the central nervous 
system (CNS) is unusual in dogs with blastomycosis, oc -
curring in less than 5% of cases. Respiratory blastomycosis 
may be linked to pulmonary thromboembolism ( McGuire 
et al., 2002). Blastomycosis is a rare fungus that affects cats. 
It’s uncertain whether age, breed, or sex play a role in the 
likelihood of infection in them ( Miller et al., 1990 ). Feline 
symptoms are comparable to those seen in dogs except that 
cats are more likely to develop CNS disease and big cutane-
ous abscesses (Feldman and Ettinger, 2010).
3.10 Histoplasmosis
Infection with the soil-borne, dimorphic fungus 
Histoplasma capsulatum  causes histoplasmosis. This or -
ganism can withstand extremes in temperature and is most 
commonly found in damp soil containing bird or bat ex -
crement. The Ohio, Missouri, and Mississippi river valleys 
in the United States have the highest number of instances; 
nevertheless, outbreaks can develop in other areas if envi -
ronmental circumstances promote fungal growth. In soil, 
Histoplasma capsulatum  has a free-living mycelial stage 
with free-living microconidia (2–5  μm) or macroconidia 
(5–18 μm) that can infect mammals. Histoplasma organ -
isms have a thin clear halo enclosing a round or crescent-
shaped basophilic cytoplasm that is (2–4  μm) in diameter. 
In most cases, the entrance route is assumed to be respira -
tory. Oral exposure may be feasible in animals with only 
gastrointestinal indications ( Clinkenbeard et  al., 1988 ). 
Once an active infection has been established, the infection 
can spread to any organ. The lungs, gastrointestinal system, 
lymph nodes, spleen, liver, bone marrow, eyes, and adrenal 
glands are the most usually affected organs. In dogs, the 
incubation period is 12–16  days. Point-source outbreaks 
in dogs can occur when they are exposed to highly pol -
luted surroundings. Histoplasmosis can affect both cats 
and dogs equally. Most dogs with histoplasmosis are large 
young breeds. Males are predisposed in a small way, and 
hunting breeds like Brittanys, Pointers, and Weimaraners 
may be overrepresented. Dogs usually show signs of GI 
or respiratory sickness, but rarely both. The most common 
clinical manifestation of histoplasmosis is disseminated 
FIG. 2 Macroscopic lesions: pustular and crusting dermatitis in a Labrador Retriever. Alopecia and crusts affect the face, ears, and legs (A); pustules and 
mottled hyperpigmentation are observed in the abdomen (B); and a whitish-gray exudate in the oral cavity (C) (Declara et al., 2022).

528 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
 histoplasmosis with gastrointestinal involvement. Weight 
loss, hypoalbuminemia, intestinal blood loss (melena or he-
matochezia), and tenesmus are all common GI symptoms 
associated with minor or huge intestinal diarrhea. In up to 
50% of cases, hepatosplenomegaly develops. With pulmo -
nary involvement, coughing, tachypnea, dyspnea, or pleu -
ral effusion would occur associated with fever, anorexia, 
sadness, and significant weight loss. Histoplasmosis, un -
like blastomycosis, is rarely linked with bone, ophthal -
mic, or cutaneous lesions ( Feldman and Ettinger, 2010 ). 
In cats, histoplasmosis is most common among cats under 
the age of 4 years old, regardless of breed or sex. Infection 
with the feline leukemia virus is not linked to an increased 
risk of infection. Weight loss, depression, fever, anorexia, 
and anemia are nonspecific illness symptoms. Dyspnea, 
tachypnea, and abnormal lung sounds are all symptoms 
of pulmonary involvement. Dissemination causes lymph -
adenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow in -
volvement is common and can be linked to a variety of 
cytopathies. Lesions of the skin, eyes, joints, and mouth 
are infrequent. Osteolytic lesions of the distal appendicular 
skeleton can occur as a result of bone involvement, result -
ing in lameness (Clinkenbeard et al., 1989).
3.11 Coccidiomycosis
Coccidiomycosis is a systemic fungus caused by 
Coccidioides immitis, a soil saprophyte that thrives in sandy, 
alkaline soils in semiarid environments. C. immitis grows as 
a mycelium with thick-walled, barrel-shaped arthroconidia 
(2–4 μm) broad and (3–10  μm) long in the environment. 
The arthroconidia grow to form a spherule (20–200  μm) 
in diameter after inhalation. Dogs are more commonly in -
fected than cats in companion animals. C. immitis’s spread 
is restricted to the lower Sonoran life zone. The southern 
United States, Mexico, and Central and South America 
are all included. Epidemics can be triggered by a trend of 
high rainfall followed by drought. Dust storms and earth -
quakes aid in the transmission of disease. Coccidiomycosis 
is sometimes known as valley fever or San Joaquin valley 
fever, after the regions where it is most commonly recorded 
(Feldman and Ettinger, 2010). The respiratory route is used 
for exposure and infection. However, direct inoculation of 
infective spores causes localized subcutaneous infection. In 
dogs, the incubation period is 1–3 weeks. An inflammatory 
reaction is triggered, resulting in clinical respiratory symp -
toms in the respiratory tract. Other organ systems may be 
involved if spread occurs, including the bones, eyes, heart, 
pericardium, testicles, brain, spinal cord, and visceral or -
gans. People are deemed immune when an infection has 
resolved, but this is not the case for dogs and cats ( Greene 
and Troy, 1995).
Signs in dogs, like other systemic mycoses, appear in 
different breeds like boxers, pointers, Australian shepherds, 
beagles, Scottish terriers, Doberman pinschers, and cocker 
spaniels ( Feldman and Ettinger, 2010 ). The symptoms in 
dogs are largely respiratory in nature, and they may be subtle 
or present only as minor respiratory indications after expo -
sure. Immune response is ineffective in a small percentage 
of animals, and clinical symptoms worsen. The most com -
mon sign is chronic cough that may be dry, or even moist 
and productive. Respiratory lesions can lead to pneumonia, 
which is a serious condition associated with fever, weight 
loss, and anorexia ( Greene and Troy, 1995). In addition to 
respiratory involvement, osseous lesions affect 65% of dogs 
and are sometimes accompanied by draining skin nodules 
(Feldman and Ettinger, 2010 ). Regional lymphadenopathy 
may be detected in conjunction with appendicular skeletal 
abnormalities, but peripheral lymphadenopathy is uncom -
mon. The renal or gastrointestinal systems may be impli -
cated. Infections of the myocardium or pericardium can 
cause cardiac arrhythmias or restrictive pericarditis, leading 
to right or left-sided heart failure ( Greene and Troy, 1995). 
Seizures, behavioral changes, and coma with granulomatous 
meningoencephalitis are symptoms of a CNS illness due to 
coccidiomycosis. Ocular lesions involving the anterior and 
posterior segments are common with coccidiomycosis, but 
they are less common than with other systemic fungal infec-
tions (Kerl, 2003). In comparison to dogs, cats are relatively 
immune to coccidiomycosis. Coccidiomycosis in cats has 
no evident age, breed, or sex predilection. Dermal injection 
with fungus causes skin lesions that can appear in masses, 
or can be linked with abscess or drainage. Localized lymph-
adenopathy with draining lesions is possible. Fever, inappe-
tence, and weight loss are common symptoms in cats with 
this disease. About 25% of infected cats have respiratory 
symptoms similar to those found in dogs (Greene and Troy, 
1995). Ocular disease, including retinal detachment and 
uveitis or iritis, affects about 12% of cats, but CNS involve-
ment is rare (Gionfriddo, 2000).
3.12 Cryptococcosis
Cryptococcosis is caused by a number of Cryptococcus spe-
cies. The most clinically significant agent is Cryptococcus 
neoformans, which survives at normal body temperatures. 
Cryptococcosis, unlike other fungal illnesses, does not 
have a specific geographic distribution. C. neoformans  is 
a saprophytic, spherical, yeast-like fungus with a huge het -
eropolysaccharide capsule (1–30 μm in diameter) that does 
not pick up typical cytologic stains ( Gerds-Grogan and 
Dayrell-Hart, 1997). Cryptococcus reproduces via budding. 
Buds can break off at various phases of development, re -
sulting in differences in the size of organisms in the tissues. 
Environmental sources are most likely to be found around 
avian habitats or in eucalyptus tree leaf and bark litter. The 
most important vector is assumed to be the pigeon; the pi -
geon’s elevated body temperature is thought to protect it

Fungal diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 35  529
from sickness (Chuck and Sande, 1989). Unlike other fungal 
illnesses, cryptococcosis affects cats at a similar or higher 
rate than dogs. The respiratory tract is the most common 
entry point for infection. Cryptococcus is unencapsulated 
in the environment and can be as tiny as 1  μm, allowing it 
to colonize the lungs more easily. Organisms invade the up-
per or lower respiratory system after deposition in tissues, 
where they replenish their capsules. The capsule obstructs 
the natural immune response and organism removal of the 
host. In cats and dogs, CNS involvement is common and can 
develop from hematogenous spread or extension from nasal 
cavity disease (Beatty et al., 2000 ). Corticosteroid therapy 
has aggravated infection in dogs and cats ( Gerds-Grogan 
and Dayrell-Hart, 1997 ). Concurrent feline leukemia virus 
(FeLV) and feline immunodeficiency virus (FIV) infec -
tions in cats reduce the chances of a positive therapeutic 
response. However, it’s unclear if FeLV or FIV-positive cats 
are more susceptible to cryptococcosis (Jacobs et al., 1997). 
Immunosuppression has not been demonstrated to enhance 
the risk of cryptococcosis in dogs. There are no evident age 
or gender preferences. In several research, Siamese cats are 
overrepresented (Malik et al., 1992).
Nasal or facial deformities, a tumor projecting from the 
nares, nasal discharge, sneezing, respiratory sounds, or a 
change in voice are all possible symptoms. In 40%–50% 
of cases, skin lesions appear, while ophthalmic and CNS 
symptoms appear in about 15% of cases. Blindness from 
retinal detachment and granulomatous chorioretinitis can 
also occur ( Gionfriddo, 2000 ). Depression, behavioral 
changes, ataxia, vestibular indications, and blindness are 
some of the neurologic symptoms. Lungs are less usually 
afflicted, and cats rarely show symptoms of lower respira -
tory tract disease. Weight loss, listlessness, and anorexia 
are all prevalent symptoms of chronic disease ( Beatty 
et al., 2000). In dogs, affected cases are usually under four, 
though an older dog may be affected. Overrepresented 
breeds include Great Danes, Doberman Pinschers, Labrador 
Retrievers, and American Cocker Spaniels. Seizures, ataxia, 
central vestibular illness, papilledema, cervical discomfort, 
tetraparesis, and multifocal cranial nerve involvement are 
some of the most common symptoms ( Berthelin et  al., 
1994). Granulomatous chorioretinitis, retinal hemorrhage, 
and optic neuritis are all possible ocular disorders. In rare 
situations, skin rashes, fever, and peripheral lymphadenopa-
thy might be detected. Lethargy and weight loss are typical 
unspecific symptoms (Kerl, 2003) (Fig. 3).
3.13 Paracoccidioidomycosis
Paracoccidioidomycosis is an enzootic mycosis caused by 
inhaling infective Paracoccidioides spp. conidia that found 
in the environment. P . brasiliensis and P . lutzii, two dimor-
phic fungi belonging to the Ajellomycetaceae family, cause 
the disease which is the major systemic mycosis reported in 
dogs in Latin American countries (Coutinho et al., 2015).
4 Mycotoxins and mycotoxicoses
Mycotoxins are fungal-derived compounds that are harm -
ful to (warm-blooded) animals. Mycotoxins are secondary 
metabolites created by the metabolism of acetates, meval -
onates, malonate, and certain amino acids through a series 
of biochemically simple intermediary products ( Aupanun 
et al., 2016). Contamination of animal feeds with mycotox-
ins is a global issue, and the production of mycotoxins is un-
questionably one of the major threats to their health (Kabak 
FIG. 3 Case 1. (A) Cat presenting a firm subcutaneous swelling over the forehead, bilateral ocular seropurulent secretion, and polyp-like mass in the 
nostrils. (B) Case 1 after the disappearance of all the clinical signs initially presented, which occurred after 6 months of fluconazole therapy (Brito-Santos 
et al., 2019).

530 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
et al., 2006 ). Fungal genus, structure, and (or) method of 
action are used to classify mycotoxins. A single species of 
fungus can create one or more mycotoxins, while various 
fungal species can produce distinct mycotoxins. Aflatoxins, 
ochratoxins, trichothecenes, zearalenone, fumonisins, trem-
orgenic toxins, and ergot alkaloids are the most common 
mycotoxins that affect animal health (Kensler et al., 2011). 
Mycotoxins result in reduced immunity associated with se-
rious disorders known as acute or chronic mycotoxicoses 
that vary by species and host vulnerability. Acute myco -
toxicoses have a quick onset with visible toxic response, 
whereas the most common type of mycotoxicoses develops 
after a long period of exposure to low doses of the toxin(s) 
(Reeves et al., 2004).
Tremorgenic mycotoxicosis has been linked to the in -
take of a range of moldy foods in dogs, including cereals, 
walnuts, almonds, and peanuts, as well as nonspecific rub -
bish. Canines are more likely to be affected than other do -
mestic animals, owing to their proclivity for scavenging; 
poisoning of multiple dogs in the same household has also 
been observed. The fungi of the genus Penicillium are the 
most common donors of tremorgenic mycotoxins ( Barker 
et al., 2013). Aflatoxin B1, B2, G1, G2, and M1, ochratoxin 
A, patulin, and toxins generated by Fusarium molds, such 
as fumonisins (B1, B2, and B3), trichothecenes (princi -
pally nivalenol, deoxynivalenol, T-2, and HT-2 toxin), and 
zearalenone, are the mycotoxins of greatest importance in 
terms of food safety ( Bennett et al., 2007 ). The most dan -
gerous compounds are aflatoxins and ochratoxins, which 
have been found to be genotoxic, meaning they can damage 
DNA and cause cancer in animals. Aflatoxins are difura -
nocoumarol lactons by structure, and roughly 20 variants 
have lately been discovered. The most common aflatoxins 
are B1, B2, G1, and G2, with toxicity decreasing in the or -
der AFB1  > AFG1 > AFB2 > AFG2. Ochratoxin A (OTA, 
the most dangerous), B, C (ethylester OTA), and D are 
all polyketide derivatives of dihydroisocoumarin. Barley, 
ray, oat, wheat, rice, maize, beer, coffee, tea, wine/raisins, 
spices, and porcine products (meat, viscera) and other meat 
and meat products of nonruminant animals exposed to this 
form of mycotoxin are among the sources ( Kensler et al., 
2011).
5 Diagnosis and treatment of mycotic 
infections in dogs and cats
The fungal organism is visualized on cytology and/or histol-
ogy, which typically presents a nodular to diffuse pyogranu-
lomatous inflammatory pattern. The diagnostic sensitivity 
of fungal stains like Gomori-methenamine silver or peri -
odic acid-Schiff can be improved. Fungus culture and iden-
tification of the fungal species based on morphology and 
pigmentation traits by specialized laboratories are used to 
make a definitive diagnosis. Only few times the molecular 
methods have been utilized to identify harmful fungus spe-
cies (Maeda et al., 2008) as shown in Table 1.
6 Conclusion
Over the past few decades, fungi have become more preva-
lent and are responsible for a wide range of illnesses, from 
minor local infections to severe morbidity and mortality in 
animals. Fungal infections can either be restricted to the 
body’s surface or they can develop into systemic infec -
tions, which are characterized by the fungus entering the 
body and then spreading to other tissues. Most fungi infec -
tions are contracted by the skin, ingestion, or inhalation. 
Some fungal infections that affect pets are zoonotic, mean-
ing that animals can spread the sickness to the owner. The 
lack of distinct early-stage signs and symptoms, the dwin -
dling number of clinical mycologists, the expense, and the 
absence of quick and precise diagnostic procedures make 
it difficult to diagnose fungal infections in dogs and cats. 
Reduced morbidity, mortality, and treatment costs are all

benefits of early  detection of a fungal infection. Fungal ill -
nesses are typically treated with chemotherapy. Few agents 
have been approved for widespread usage of antifungal 
medications in pets, and these medications are sometimes 
quite expensive and hazardous to animals. As a result, sys -

Chapter 36
Common viral diseases of dogs and cats
1 Viral diseases of dogs
1.1 Canine adenovirus
There are two types of canine adenovirus (CA V): canine 
adenovirus type 1 (CA V-1), and canine adenovirus type 2 
(CA V-2) (Fig. 1). CA V-1 causes infectious canine hepatitis 
(ICH or Rubarth’s disease), while CA V-2 (Kennel cough) 
is associated with the respiratory type of disease in dogs 
(Chander et al., 2021).
1.1.1 Etiology
Canine adenovirus (CA V) is a nonenveloped icosahe -
dral double-stranded DNA virus, belonging to the family 
Adenoviridae and genus Mastadenovirus. It is further di -
vided to serotype CA V-1 and CA V-2 based on genetic and 
antigenic characteristics ( Ozkan Timurkan et  al., 2018 ). 
Some common differences between the two serotypes are 
stated in Table 1.
1.1.2 Epidemiology
CA Vs occur worldwide and are endemic in dogs. Other 
species such as red foxes, wolves, and coyotes are highly 
susceptible. CA V-1 is a life-threatening disease in puppies, 
while CA V-2 is common among dogs used for breeding. 
CA Vs are moderately resistant to the environment, thus usu-
ally occurring in crowded and poor hygienic environments 
of puppies. The occurrence of CA V-2 has been reported 
in many countries such as Canada, Italy, Brazil, and India 
(Balboni et al., 2013; Ramidi et al., 2019; Silva et al., 2014).
1.1.3 Transmission
CA V-1 is transmitted via the oronasal route through direct 
and indirect contact with viruses shed in oronasal secre -
tions, urine, and feces during the acute phase of infection 
(Sykes, 2014a ). The CA V-2 is highly contagious and 
transmitted via nasal secretions ( Evermann and Kennedy, 
2011). Recovered dogs from adenoviral infection and vac -
cinated dogs do serve as carriers and can shed the virus 
 continuously for a prolonged period of time, thus serving as 
a source of infection to puppies and pregnant dogs (Taguchi 
et al., 2011).
1.1.4 Clinical manifestation
The CA V-2 is characterized by respiratory disorders due 
to its affinity for the epithelium of the upper respiratory 
tract, hence clinical signs such as tonsillitis, pharyngitis, 
tracheitis, and bronchitis ( Mochizuki et al., 2008 ). CA V-2 
has been reported to infect the intestinal tract, which is the 
predilection site for CA V-1. The CA V-1 is mostly asymp-
tomatic but also manifests with multisystemic symptoms 
which cause acute or chronic disease syndromes. Clinical 
signs vary based on major organ injury which includes in -
appetence, lethargy, vomiting, diarrhea, pyrexia, tonsilli -
tis, conjunctivitis, and corneal edema (classical blue eye) 
(Sykes, 2014a). CA V-1 infection in pregnancy may result 
in stillbirths or weak puppies that die within a few days 
post whelping. Neurological signs which are common with 
wild animals have been reported in puppies (Hornsey et al., 
2019). The predominant organ injury with CA V-1 is the 
liver, where it causes hepatic necrosis.
1.1.5 Diagnosis
Diagnosis of CA V-1 and CA V-2 is usually based on virus isola-
tion from oronasal swabs and fecal samples. CA V-1 and CA V-2 
can be difficult to differentiate in the laboratory by hemagglu-
tination and neutralization tests, especially when the infection 
manifests with multisystemic signs (Parthiban et al., 2014).
1.1.6 Treatment, prevention, and control
There is no specific therapy for CA Vs infection, but broad-
spectrum antibiotics and symptomatic supportive therapy 
are usually instituted ( Chethan et  al., 2021 ). Vaccination

534 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
with CA V-1 and CA V-2 (Fig. 2)-modified live vaccines is 
highly effective, and immunity develops about 5 days post-
vaccination. The duration of immunity after vaccination is 
about 9  years ( Tizard, 2021 ). Vaccination should be car -
ried out in series for puppies, a booster at 6  months, and 
a second booster at age 1  year. Adult dogs in proximity to 
pregnant dogs and puppies should receive regular boosters 
to minimize viral shedding. Avoid overcrowding of pup -
pies, and the environment should be regularly cleaned and 
disinfected.
1.2 Influenza virus—H3N8, H3N2
Canine influenza virus (CIV) is caused mainly by H3N8 
and H3N2; both infections occur in dogs and manifest 
as mild upper respiratory tract symptoms ( Parrish and 
V oorhees, 2019).
1.2.1 Etiology
Canine influenza viruses (CIVs) are members of the genus 
influenza A viruses (IA Vs), among the family orthomyxo-
viridae. The two popular strains that have emerged are the 
H3N8 which originated from equine ( Fig.  3) ( Crawford 
et al., 2005), and H3N2 which originated from avian (Song 
et  al., 2008 ). Table  2 shows some differences between 
H3N2 and H3N8 strains.
1.2.2 Epidemiology
Canine influenza A H3N8 was first reported in United States 
and has continued to spread across the states ( Pecoraro 
et  al., 2014). However, H3N2 virus was first detected in 
South Korea, but cases have been reported in United States, 
Thailand, Canada, and China (Zhu et al., 2015). Dogs of all

ages are generally susceptible to CIV with a morbidity rate 
of 60%–80% in kennel outbreaks. H3N2 has been reported 
in cats and manifested with respiratory signs. Break of the 
species barrier is common with influenza A viruses, but ad-
aptation to a new species is not common (Collisson, 2020). 
Mutation keeps occurring as influenza A virus  circulates in 
dogs; thus, subtypes such as H1N1 and H5N1 have been 
reported in dogs, but transmission to other dogs has not 
occurred.
1.2.3 Transmission
CIV is transmitted through direct or indirect contact with na-
sal secretions and also by aerosol. Transmission easily occurs 
in conditions of a large gathering of dogs such as kennels.
FIG. 2 A structural model of Canine Adenovirus Serotype 1 (A) and Serotype 2 vaccines (B). (Creative Biolabs.)
FIG. 3 A schematic diagram showing the origination of canine influenza virus H3N8 from the horse. (Today’s Veterinary Practice.)

536 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
1.2.4 Clinical manifestation
The incubation period is 2–3  days, hence a rapid manifes -
tation of influenza-like signs such as nasal discharge, an -
orexia, sneezing, lethargy, cough, and ocular discharge.
1.2.5 Diagnosis
Clinical signs of CIV are similar to signs of other respiratory 
pathogens infecting dogs, hence making diagnosis difficult. 
A good diagnosis of CIV depends on the timing of the sample 
collection for agent detection tests. Viral isolation is done us-
ing either Madin-Darby canine kidney (MDCK) cells or em-
bryonated chicken eggs. RT-PCR targeting the matrix gene 
is a reliable test for the diagnosis of CIV (Shu et al., 2011).
1.2.6 Treatment, prevention, and control
Treatment is mostly by supportive therapy and also using 
a broad-spectrum antibiotic to prevent or treat secondary 
bacterial pneumonia and provide conditions for the im -
mune system to respond ( Collisson, 2020). During an out -
break, quarantine of affected kennels is crucial to mitigate 
the spread of the virus. Vaccination against CIV (especially 
H3N2) using killed adjuvant vaccines is being carried 
out in the United States and South Korea. Currently, live-  
attenuated influenza vaccines are available for the control 
and prevention of H3N8 (Nogales et al., 2017). Considering 
the antigenic drift tendency of the influenza virus, the de -
velopment of a surveillance and control strategy for emerg-
ing influenza virus in dogs is necessary (Xie et al., 2016).
1.3 Canine parainfluenza virus
CPIV-5 is a highly contagious respiratory disease in dogs 
and it is one of the culprits of canine infectious respiratory 
disease (CIRD).
1.3.1 Etiology
PIV-5 is an enveloped, nonsegmented, single-stranded RNA 
virus belonging to the family Paramyxoviridiae, genus 
Rubulavirus (Charoenkul et al., 2021).
1.3.2 Epidemiology
Canine parainfluenza virus type 5 (CPIV-5) causes respi -
ratory disease in dogs with global occurrence. It has been 
reported in several host species such as pigs, cattle, ham -
sters, ferrets, monkeys, calves, lesser pandas, and guinea 
pigs (Zhai et al., 2017).
1.3.3 Transmission
CPIV-5 is shed in nasal secretions 6–8  days postinfection; 
hence, it spread through contact with secretions or via aero-
sols. A cross-species transmission has been reported in coy-
otes, ferrets, and rodents, but no evidence of transmission 
from dogs to humans (Charoenkul et al., 2021).
1.3.4 Clinical manifestation
CPIV-5 causes mild-to-moderate upper tract respiratory dis-
ease in dogs. It is characterized by sudden onset of fever, 
coughing, serous nasal discharge, and malaise (Baümgartner, 
2019). Severe signs develop due to co-infection with viruses 
or bacteria (Kennel cough syndrome) CPIV-5 can manifest 
as neurological disorders, especially in puppies showing 
signs such as encephalitis, seizures, myoclonus, and poste -
rior paresis.
1.3.5 Diagnosis
The clinical signs are similar to other respiratory diseases; 
hence, confirmatory diagnosis relies on viral isolation, and 
molecular detection by RT-PCR from nasal or throat swabs. 
The serological test can also detect the presence of canine 
parainfluenza virus 5, but the result can be complicated in 
vaccinated dogs (MacLachlan et al., 2016).
1.3.6 Treatment, prevention, and control
There is no treatment for CPIV-5 but symptomatic therapy. 
A warm and humid environment should be provided. In the 
case of pneumonia, broad-spectrum antibiotics should be ad-
ministered. Available vaccines are usually included in com-
bination (multivalent) products that also protect against other 
canine viral and microbial pathogens. The vaccine does not 
totally protect the dog against CPIV-5, but will lessen the 
severity and complications during the course of an infection.
1.4 Canine reovirus
It is caused by mammalian reovirus (MRV) which affects a 
wide range of mammals including dogs. It causes symptom-
atic or asymptomatic infection in dogs.

1.4.1 Etiology
MRV is a double-stranded RNA virus that is small in size, a 
nonenveloped icosahedral virus belonging to the Reoviridae 
family and genus Orthoreovirus (Fig. 4). The specie MRV has 
three serotypes: MRV-1, MRV-2, and MRV-3 which have been 
known to occur in dogs (Decaro and Buonavoglia, 2011).
1.4.2 Epidemiology
Mammalian reovirus has a global occurrence, infecting 
dogs and most mammals. There is an equal geographical 
distribution of the three serotypes in dogs. Co-infection of 
various reovirus serotypes is not uncommon in dogs and 
depends on exposure to the virus. Reovirus seropositivity in 
the healthy dog population is high and comparable to that of 
the human population (Hwang et al., 2014).
1.4.3 Transmission
MRVs are shed in feces and nasal discharges; hence, trans-
mission is via aerosol and feco-oral.
It usually spread among dogs in kennels, boarding, and 
breeding facilities.
1.4.4 Clinical manifestation
MRV in dogs can be symptomatic or asymptomatic but is 
mostly associated with other diseases. The virus has an af -
finity for cells in the respiratory tract which manifests as 
nasal discharge, sore throat, conjunctivitis, and pneumonia. 
It is also found in the gastrointestinal tract with signs like 
diarrhea, dehydration, lethargy, and weight loss. There is a 
possibility of extending to the nervous system causing en -
cephalitis (Knipe et al., 2013).
1.4.5 Diagnosis
Diagnosis is difficult through clinical examination due to the 
similarities of symptoms to other diseases. A  confirmatory 
diagnosis is by viral culture and isolation from a fecal 
sample or nasal discharges and electron microscopy. These 
methods are not sensitive, hence the use of PCR which is 
more sensitive, rapid, and specific ( Muscillo et al., 2001 ). 
Serological testing indicated that dogs are so much exposed 
to reovirus, but are difficult to isolate from dogs with respi-
ratory disease (Sykes, 2014b).
1.4.6 Treatment, prevention, and control
No recommended treatment protocol, but supportive ther -
apy is given based on prevailing clinical signs. Infected 
dogs should be treated in isolation. Avoid overcrowding of 
dogs and monitor them so as to avoid sniffing on feces of 
other dogs because exposure to reovirus infection increases 
with age and in dogs housed outdoors.
1.5 Coronavirus
Canine coronavirus (CCoV) is a highly contagious and in -
fectious disease in dogs all over the world. There are three 
major types of canine coronavirus: canine enteric coronavi-
rus (CECoV), pantropic canine coronavirus (pCCoV), and 
canine respiratory coronavirus (CRCoV).
1.5.1 Etiology
Canine coronavirus is a single-stranded, enveloped, positive-
sense RNA virus (Fig.  5) that belongs to the order Nidovirales,  
family Coronaviridae, subfamily Orthocoronavirinae, which  
has four genera; Alphacoronavirus, Betacoronavirus, Gamma-
coronavirus, and Deltacoronavirus ( Alfano et  al., 2020 ). 
CECoV and pCCoV belong to the genus Alphacoronavirus, 
species, Alphacoronavirus-1, while CRCoV belongs to 
Betacoronavirus (Abd et al., 2021 ) (Fig. 6). CECoV con -
tains two distinct genotypes, CCoV-I and CCoV-II. CCoV-II 
can be further divided into CCoV-IIa and CCoV-IIb, with a 
proposed variant of CCoV-IIc (He et al., 2020).

1.5.2 Epidemiology
CCoV is widespread among the dog population with world-
wide distribution, and it is characterized by high morbid -
ity and low mortality, pCCoV and virulent CCoV-II strains 
can be fatal, especially in puppies. CECoV has been widely 
reported in Japan, Brazil, Greece, Britain, China, Italy, 
Vietnam, Australia, France, and Belgium (Agnihotri, 2018). 
CRCoV is a significant etiologic component of canine in -
fectious respiratory disease and also occurs globally.
1.5.3 Transmission
CECoV and pCCoV are transmitted by direct contact with in-
fected fecal matter or objects contaminated by infected feces. 
CRCoV is transmitted via aerosol from respiratory secretions

Common viral diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 36  539
(Haake et al., 2020). Overcrowding and an unhygienic environ-
ment aid the transmission of CCoV . The incubation period from 
ingestion to clinical signs is 1–4 days. The duration of illness is 
2–10 days in most dogs, but viruses are shed for 2 weeks.
1.5.4 Clinical manifestation
CECoV infections are mostly mild, subclinical, and self-
limiting in dogs. It has an affinity for the intestinal cells where it  
replicates, destroying the cells in the process and manifest-
ing signs such as inappetence, vomiting, diarrhea, lethargy, 
dehydration, fever, and a painful abdomen. However, severe 
hemorrhagic diarrhea can occur due to co-infection by other 
enteric viruses. pCCoV is hypervirulent and multisystemic 
in its clinical signs manifestation causing lethargy, hemor -
rhagic diarrhea, ataxia, and seizures ( Haake et  al., 2020). 
CRCoV has an affinity for upper respiratory tracts in dogs, 
especially those in crowded or stressful condition. The virus 
attacks the cells lining of the lungs, causing damage, and 
allowing other opportunistic bacteria. Clinical signs include 
sneezing, coughing, lacrimation, nasal discharge, fever, dys-
pnea, lethargy, and inappetence (Mitchell et al., 2013).
1.5.5 Diagnosis
CCoV is diagnosed by viral culture and isolation, and 
electron microscopy, but both methods are less sensitive. 
Serology is used for monitoring the disease prevalence. 
Molecular detection by PCR is more sensitive and reliable.
1.5.6 Treatment, prevention, and control
There is no specific treatment for CCoV; hence, supportive 
therapy and symptomatic treatment are used. Treatments 
such as fluid therapy, oral antinausea medications, oral 
antidiarrheal medications, gastrointestinal prescription 
foods, probiotics to re-establish gastrointestinal flora, 
anti-inflammatories, and/or cough medicine for coughing 
in dogs with CRCoV are used to mitigate the symptoms. 
Antibiotics are administered to prevent secondary bacte -
rial infections. Withholding food for 24  h after diarrhea 
ceases and gradually reintroducing small amounts of food 
may be the only required treatment. Early medical inter -
vention is the key to the successful treatment of severe 
cases. Canine coronavirus vaccines are available but not 
recommended for all dogs and will be administered based 
on a dog’s lifestyle and risk assessment. Most CCoV vac -
cines are designed based on the classical CCoV-IIa strains, 
hence less effective against CCoV-I. There are differences 
in current circulating CCoV-IIa in comparison with the 
classical CCoV-IIa strains; thus, effectiveness is uncertain 
(He et al., 2020 ).
1.6 Rotavirus infection
Canine rotavirus causes an infectious viral intestinal disease 
in dogs, especially puppies.
1.6.1 Etiology
Canine rotavirus is a nonenveloped, double-stranded 
RNA with a segmented genome, belonging to the family 
Reoviridae, genus rotavirus (Fig. 7). There are eight species 
of rotavirus (A–H), but canine rotavirus belongs to Group 
A which happens to be zoonotic, and serotypes G3, P3, and 
P5A are commonly isolated in dogs (Attoui et al., 2012).
FIG. 7 A schematic structure of rotavirus showing the inner, intermediate, and outer structures. (Viralzone.)

540 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
1.6.2 Epidemiology
Canine rotavirus infection occurs globally in dogs, causing 
mild disease in puppies, but antibody serological surveys 
showed a high prevalence in adult dogs ( de Grazia et  al., 
2007). Dogs with weak immune systems and those living in 
overly stressed environments are most at risk for the infection.
1.6.3 Transmission
Canine rotavirus is transmitted by direct contact with con -
taminated fecal matter. The interspecies transmission also 
occurs among heterologous strains, leading to strain diver -
sity in new hosts (Mosallanejad et al., 2015).
1.6.4 Clinical manifestation
Canine rotavirus is asymptomatic in adult dogs, and mild in 
older pups, but causes acute or moderate enteritis in pups 
less than 2  weeks old where it manifests as diarrhea, an -
orexia, lethargy, fever, and vomiting. Generally, patients 
recover within 2 weeks; however, there are reports of fatal 
severe enteritis in dogs under 2  weeks old ( Ortega et  al., 
2017).
1.6.5 Diagnosis
The serological test is used for monitoring antibodies in dog 
populations (Fig. 8). Viral culture and isolation from the fe-
cal sample are also used. RT-PCR is more effective in the 
identification of species and serotypes.
1.6.6 Treatment, prevention, and control
Treatment is symptomatic which includes fluid therapy, 
dietary restrictions, and administration of antibiotics to 
prevent secondary infection. Infected dogs should be iso -
lated and strict hygiene should be applied in handling feces 
from infected dogs. Puppies should be allowed to suckle 
adequately within the first 2 weeks of their life.
1.7 Astrovirus infection
1.7.1 Etiology
Canine astrovirus (CaAstV) is a small nonenveloped, 
positive-sense RNA virus with a wide host range. They 
belong to the family Astroviridae, which has two genera: 
Mamastrovirus (mostly in mammals) and Avastrovirus 
(found in humans, cows, pigs, sheep, deer, mink, dogs, cats, 
mice, bats, dolphins, rats, chickens, and turkeys (Zhu et al., 
2011).
1.7.2 Epidemiology
CaAstV is globally distributed among diarrheic and healthy 
dogs (Li et al., 2018 ). Dogs less than a year old are more 
susceptible to the infection which can lead to gastroenteri -
tis, especially during co-infection with other enteroviruses 
(Zhou et al., 2017a ). Canine astrovirus (CaAstV) was first 
identified in the United States and has since been reported in 
dogs from Europe, the Far East, and South America (Caddy 
and Goodfellow, 2015).
1.7.3 Transmission
CaAstVs are transmitted via the fecal-oral route either by 
direct contact with feces or the consumption of contami -
nated food or water ( Roach and Langlois, 2021 ). Canine 
astroviruses are antigenically and genetically hetero -
geneous due to an error-prone polymerase and frequent 
recombination events between strains, hence, their abil -
ity to spread among different host species ( Wohlgemuth 
et al., 2019 ).
FIG. 8 Step-by-step methodology for serological detection of canine rotavirus.

Common viral diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 36  541
1.7.4 Clinical manifestation
Astroviruses infect diverse hosts and are typically associated 
with gastrointestinal illness, but can also vary from asymp-
tomatic to encephalitis depending on the host and viral geno-
type (Wohlgemuth et al., 2019). CaAstV was reported more in 
dogs with symptoms of gastroenteritis such as diarrhea, fever, 
anorexia, lethargy, etc. than in asymptomatic ones indicating a 
potential role in canine diarrhea (Martella et al., 2012).
1.7.5 Diagnosis
CaAstVs are characterized by genetic heterogeneity, mak -
ing confirmatory diagnosis difficult (Stamelou et al., 2022). 
Electron microscopy observations have been used on stool 
samples ( Fig.  9). The serological test includes the use of 
an indirect immunofluorescence assay to identify specific 
IgGs. Molecular diagnosis is mostly through RT-PCR, but 
qRT-PCR assay is more sensitive due to its ability to differ-
entiate the capsid gene.
1.7.6 Treatment, prevention, and control
There is no treatment protocol for CaAstV infection, but 
symptomatic therapy involves fluid therapy, administra -
tion of antiemetics, antibiotics, and probiotics. Dogs that 
tested positive should be isolated. Good hygiene and sani -
tation are essential to prevent the invasion and spread of 
the virus.
1.8 Calicivirus infection
1.8.1 Etiology
Caliciviruses belong to the family Caliciviridae which is 
currently divided into five genera; Norovirus, Sapovirus, 
Vesivirus, Lagovirus, and Nebovirus. The genera are  further 
divided into several species, of which canine calicivirus 
is under Vesivirus genera. Viruses under this family are 
RNA, nonenveloped, small, positively charged, and single-
stranded (Martella et al., 2015).
1.8.2 Epidemiology
Canine norovirus, sapovirus, and vesivirus are the known 
genera that have been isolated in asymptomatic and diar -
rheic dogs ( Caddy, 2018). Canine norovirus has been iso -
lated in Italy and Portugal. It has genetic heterogeneity 
which allows for its combination with norovirus from other 
animal species leading to diverse strains. Canine sapovirus 
has been detected in diarrheic dogs in UK and Japan. No 
isolation of Canine sapovirus has occurred in healthy dogs. 
Canine vesivirus or calicivirus has been detected in Italy, 
Brazil, and Japan.
1.8.3 Transmission
Canine caliciviruses are transmitted through direct contact 
with saliva, secretions, and feces containing shed viruses.
1.8.4 Clinical manifestation
Symptoms of canine calicivirus are associated with gastro -
enteritis with recovery after a few days. Tropism to other 
cells may occur, leading to other neurological signs and, 
in some instances, glossitis, balanitis, or vesicular vaginitis. 
Isolates from such cases were feline caliciviruses (Vesivirus 
genus) and were likely acquired from cats.
1.8.5 Diagnosis
Calicivirus-like particles have been occasionally identified by 
electron microscopy (Fig. 10) in specimens from dogs with 
diarrhea. Serological tests are mostly used for survey screen-
ing. PCR-based diagnoses are more accurate and reliable.
1.8.6 Treatment, prevention, and control
Treatment is by supportive therapy. Infected dogs should be 
isolated from dogs and other species of animals. Humans 
should maintain strict precautions when attending to in -
fected dogs.
1.9 Canine parvovirus infection
Canine parvovirus (CPV) is a highly contagious, acute, 
virulent, and fatal viral disease that causes gastroenteritis 
in dogs.
1.9.1 Etiology
CPV is a small, single-stranded, nonenveloped DNA vi -
rus that belonged to the family Parvoviridae, subfamily 
Parvovirinae, and the genus protoparvovirus. CPV has two 
FIG. 9 A image of astrovirus under an electron microscope. (From Bosch, 
A., Pintó, R.M., Guix, S., 2014. Human astroviruses. Clin. Microbiol. Rev. 
27 (4), 1048–1074. https://doi.org/10.1128/CMR.00013-14.)

542 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
strains designated as CPV-1 (now under genus bocavirus) and 
CPV-2. CPV-2 is further divided into three variants: CPV-2a, 
CPV-2b, and CPV-2c (Decaro and Buonavoglia, 2012).
1.9.2 Epidemiology
Canine parvovirus is one of the commonest causes of se -
vere viral diarrhea disease in dogs worldwide ( Qi et al., 
2020). CPV is an important cause of mortality and mor -
bidity in dogs, and other Canidae like wolves, foxes, and 
coyotes ( Zhou et al., 2017b ). Puppies less than 4  months 
of age are more susceptible to CPV , also inadequately vac-
cinated and unvaccinated adult dogs. CPV-2c has been re -
ported in some continents of the world ( Lin et al., 2016 ) 
(Fig.  11). Generally, certain breeds such as Rottweilers, 
German Shepherds, Dobermans, Terriers, etc., are pre -
disposed to parvovirus infection ( Houston et  al., 1996 ). 
Outdoor accessibility and season have been identified 
as risk factors for parvoviral enteritis ( Sykes, 2014a ). 
However, the seasonal patterns vary with locations ( Kalli 
et al., 2010).
1.9.3 Transmission
CPV is transmitted via feco-oral through direct contact 
with feces and vomitus from infected dogs and also con -
taminated fomites. Infected dogs begin to shed the vi -
rus a few days prior to the manifestation of symptoms, 
and it declines after 7  days ( Fig.  12). Hence, subclini -
cal infections shed the virus for a longer period and are 
widespread.
1.9.4 Clinical manifestation
The incubation period for CPV infection is 3–7  days, af -
ter which signs such as anorexia, lethargy, fever, depres -
sion, vomiting, diarrhea (mucoid or hemorrhagic) (Fig. 13), 
tachypnea, and dehydration are observed. These signs could 
be worsened due to the CPV variants, coinfection, and re -
combination, hence making control difficult. Cases of sub -
clinical infection mostly occur in puppies with intermediate 
MDA titers and adult dogs. The severity of clinical signs 
depends on factors such as virus strain and immune com -
petency of the infected dog, which is affected by stressors 
FIG.  10 An electron microscope image of Canine calicivirus. (From

Common viral diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 36  543
such as weaning and overcrowding, maternal antibody, and 
the presence of concurrent infections such as other enteric 
viral and parasitic infections. Clinical blood pictures usu -
ally reveal leukopenia due to lymphopenia and neutrophilia 
(Sykes, 2014b). Concurrent pulmonary infections may lead 
to the onset of respiratory distress.
1.9.5 Diagnosis
Presumptive diagnosis for CPV infection is made from 
the history, signalment, and clinical signs. On observation 
of clinical signs, a serological test is used to detect IgM 
 antibodies against CPV (Fig. 14). ELISA kits are available 
to detect CPV in the feces of puppies, but are only reliable 
within the first 7  days of infection and are less sensitive. 
More sensitive methods of detecting CPV antigen in feces 
include viral isolation, electron microscopy, latex aggluti -
nation, fecal hemagglutination, immunochromatography, 
PCR, and counterimmuno-electrophoresis ( Schmitz et al., 
2009; Sharma et al., 2018). RT-PCR is more sensitive than 
conventional PCR (Segev et al., 2022).

1.9.6 Treatment, prevention, and control
There is no treatment protocol for CPV infection; hence, 
therapy is mostly supportive and symptomatic. Due to differ-
ences in variants, co-infection, and recombination, there is no 
specific approach to the control of CPV infection. Generally, 
management of CPV cases should involve admission, fluid 
therapy, administration of antimicrobials, analgesics, anti-
emetics, anthelmintics, and enteral nutritional support. It is 
essential to isolate infected dogs. The CPV strain and variant 
used for the manufacture of vaccines do not predispose the 
vaccine to failure. Although the use of killed or live attenuated 
vaccine in puppies should be influenced by age at the time 
of vaccination ( Altman et  al., 2017 ). Inadequate vaccina -
tion, poor vaccine guidelines compliance (Table 3), and poor 
management system of the kennel are predisposing factors 
to CPV vaccine failure and infection (Ogbu et al., 2021). It 
is necessary to monitor MDA considering their interference 
could lead to vaccine failure. In an endemic area,  veterinarians

recommend last puppy vaccination should be earlier than the 
vaccination schedule guideline. The manipulation of the vac-
cination interval against the manufacturer guidelines is also a 
risk factor (Kelman et al., 2020). Dog owners and veterinar-
ians shoulder follow the recommended vaccination guidelines 
by professional bodies within a particular location.
1.10 Canine bocaparvovirus
This is a virus of carnivores that causes hemorrhagic enteri-
tis in dogs.
1.10.1 Etiology
There are six carnivore bocaparvoviruses (CBPV) desig -
nated as 1–6, but only CBPV-1, CBPV-2, and CBPV-3 have 
been reported in dogs (Piewbang et al., 2018).
1.10.2 Epidemiology
CBPV was previously not considered a causative agent of 
disease in dogs, but it has been identified to cause enteritis, 
respiratory disease, and hepatitis in dogs especially pup -
pies (Choi et al., 2016 ). CBPV-1 and 2 have been reported 
in shelter dogs in Italy, Canada, Turkey ( Isidan and Turan, 
2021), and Brazil (Bodewes et al., 2014).
1.10.3 Transmission
CBPV is transmitted via the fecal-oral route in dogs and 
also through the transplacental route.
1.10.4 Clinical manifestation
CBPV-1 infections are mostly subclinical but can be fatal in 
puppies and geriatric dogs where it causes intestinal, respira-
tory, and reproductive disorders. It manifests during immuno-
suppression with signs like diarrhea, dyspnea, and anorexia 
(Kapoor et al., 2012). CBPV-2 is associated with a respiratory 
disease where it causes dyspnea and interstitial pneumonia, and 
also sometimes presents with enteritis (Bodewes et al., 2014). 
CBPV-3 has an affinity for liver tissues and is thus associated 
with hepatitis occurring as a co-infection (Li et al., 2013).
1.10.5 Diagnosis
A serological test is used to screen out mild and subclini -
cal cases. Other methods of detection include liquid-phase 
 immune-electron microscopy, immunohistochemistry, specific 
PCR, and random PCR in combination with next-generation 
sequencing of the intestinal sample (Bodewes et al., 2014).
1.10.6 Treatment, prevention, and control
Canine bocaparvovirus infection is mostly subclinical in 
dogs but has a high rate of co-infection with enteric viruses 
such as CPV-2, canine coronavirus, and circovirus. The 
treatment is supportive and symptomatic as in other enteric 
viruses. Canine bocaparvovirus should be considered when 
puppies suddenly die with respiratory signs or enteric dis -
ease or with heart failure.
1.11 Louping illness
Louping illness is an acute tick-borne viral disease that 
causes encephalitis in sheep and other animal species in -
cluding dogs.
1.11.1 Etiology
Louping illness in dogs is caused by the Louping-ill virus 
(LIV) which is a single-stranded RNA virus belonging to 
the family Flaviviridae and genus Flavivirus. The strain as-
sociated with sheep is responsible for the disease in dogs 
(Dagleish et al., 2018).
1.11.2 Epidemiology
LIV is primarily a disease of sheep that is composed of 
multiple subtypes that tend to cluster geographically around 
Europe, especially in the United Kingdom, Ireland, Spain, 
Turkey, Scandinavia, and Russia ( Clark et al., 2020 ). LIV 
infects livestock, mammals, some avian species, and even 
humans. It has been reported in dogs, due to the interaction 
between dogs and ticks (Abdullah et al., 2016).
1.11.3 Transmission
LIV is transmitted to dogs by the sheep tick ( Ixodes rici-
nus) (Fig. 15). LIV infects so many animal species, but the

disease is subclinical in wildlife which serve as reservoir. 
Dogs also aid to carry infected ticks from the endemic to 
the nonendemic area, contributing to the zoonotic cycle of 
the disease.
1.11.4 Clinical manifestation
LIV has an affinity for the nervous system, clinical signs 
include fever, ataxia, trembling, salivation, coma, and death 
when there is encephalitis.
1.11.5 Diagnosis
LIV is monitored in dogs using the serological test. 
Definitive diagnosis is through viral isolation, RT-PCR, and 
nested PCR are used through RNA extraction from brain 
tissue or infected blood.
1.11.6 Treatment, prevention, and control
There is no available treatment for LIV infection after the 
manifestation of clinical signs, but supportive therapy is 
through sedation of the animal, despite the prognosis is 
mostly guarded. Considering LIV is primarily a disease of 
sheep, preventive measures involve tick control, avoidance 
of tick-infested areas during outdoor activities, vaccination 
of sheep, and possible vaccination of shepherd and hunting 
dogs (Dagleish et al., 2018 ). Action needed to prevent the 
emergence of LIV in the nonendemic area should include 
the availability of diagnostic tools, good animal care, and 
monitoring and surveillance of LIV among imported dogs 
(Chomel, 2011).
1.12 Pseudorabies
Pseudorabies is a fatal and highly contagious disease in pigs 
but can cause disease in dogs and other domestic animals. 
Other names for Pseudorabies include Aujeszky’s disease, 
infectious bulbar, and mad itch.
1.12.1 Etiology
Pseudorabies is caused by Porcine herpesvirus 1 an envel -
oped, DNA virus, double-stranded, and linear belonging to 
the family Herpesviridae, subfamily Alphaherpesvirinae 
(Fig. 16).
FIG.  15 A sheep tick ( Ixodes ricinus ) responsible for the Louping ill 
 virus transmission.
FIG. 16 Schematic diagram of Pseudorabies virus.

Common viral diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 36  547
1.12.2 Epidemiology
Pseudorabies is a WOAH-listed notifiable disease that 
causes diseases in mammals except pigs which happen to 
be the natural host. There is a global occurrence of pseudo-
rabies in the pig industry, where it causes 100% mortality in 
pigs less than 2 weeks of age. It usually infects dogs around 
pig farms and dogs that travel in packs. In North America, 
the swine industry is free from pseudorabies, but dogs get 
infected from contact with the feral population ( Pedersen 
et al., 2018).
1.12.3 Transmission
Pseudorabies virus is transmitted through the fecal-oral 
route and via droplets primarily in pigs. Dogs are also in -
fected through the ingestion of raw infected pork meat and 
feral meat.
1.12.4 Clinical manifestation
Pseudorabies virus replicates in the tonsils, nasal and pha -
ryngeal tissues, then invades the lymph nodes, spleen, and 
brain where they continue to replicate. In dogs, these inva -
sion leads to clinical signs like fever, excessive salivation, 
dyspnea, pruritis (mad itch), seizures, erratic behavior, hy -
peresthesia, paralysis, and sudden death. The prognosis is 
guarded as infected dogs die within 2–3 days postinfection 
(Abbate et al., 2021).
1.12.5 Diagnosis
Diagnosis of Pseudorabies in dogs begins with history and 
signalment on possible exposure to pigs, swine feral, inges-
tion of raw meat, and recent exposure to farm. Serological 
methods such as ELISA, immunodiffusion, and viral neu -
tralization are usually used to screen the pig population. 
Definitive diagnosis is done through histopathology, viral 
isolation, direct fluorescent antibody examination, and PCR 
techniques.
1.12.6 Treatment, prevention, and control
There is no treatment for pseudorabies in dogs and other an-
imals, except for pigs that survive the infection and become 
latent carriers. The classic and atypical PrV infection usu -
ally results in the death of the dog. Protective precautions 
should be used when handling suspected cases and tissues. 
The disease can be prevented by avoiding exposure to pigs, 
pig farms, swine feral, avoid ingestion of raw pork and rats. 
There should be a surveillance system for PrV infection in 
wildlife in the nonendemic region to monitor possible spill-
over into domestic animals (Abbate et al., 2021).
1.13 Rabies
Rabies is a viral zoonotic disease that causes progressive 
and deadly inflammation of the brain and spinal cord.
1.13.1 Etiology
Rabies virus is a bullet-shaped ( Fig.  17), negative-sense, 
 single-stranded RNA virus belonging to the genus Lyssavirus, 
family Rhadoviridae, and order Mononegavirales (Rupprecht 
et al., 2017).
1.13.2 Epidemiology
Rabies virus occurs globally and is endemic in developing 
countries, tropical, subtropical, and temperate regions of 
Africa, Asia, the Americas, and Australia. The rabies virus 
infects all warm-blooded animals, but there is specie spe -
cific geographic distribution of variants among terrestrial 
carnivores and bats (Table 4) (Real and Childs, 2006).
FIG. 17 Schematic diagram showing the bullet shape of the Rabies virus and some important components.

548 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
1.13.3 Transmission
Rabies virus is transmitted mostly through the saliva of 
rabid animals making contact with broken skin or mucous 
membranes via a bite, lick, or scratch. Other uncommon 
means of transmission include the transplant of infected or-
gans, and the consumption of infected meat into the gastro-
intestinal tract with abrasions (Fisher et al., 2018).
1.13.4 Clinical manifestation
Upon infection, the virus moves from point of entry and 
along neurons to the spinal cord and brain where they rep -
licate leading to the manifestation of symptoms. The time 
needed for the manifestation depends on the incubation pe-
riod which ranges from 2  weeks to 6  years due to the dis -
tance between the site of infection to the brain. Generally, 
initial signs are fever, tingling, burning, and prickling sen -
sation at the injection site. From the CNS, clinical symp -
toms are presented in two forms: furious form (anterior 
horn cell dysfunction) and paralytic form (peripheral nerve 
dysfunction). Signs of the furious form include hyperactiv-
ity, hydrophobia, aerophobia, and excitable behavior. Death 
occurs after a few days due to cardio-respiratory arrest. 
The paralytic form manifests with less excitability, gradual 
muscle paralysis around the inoculation site, and the devel-
opment of a coma, leading to death.
1.13.5 Diagnosis
Diagnosis begins with the history and signalment of the 
dog, then clinical signs such as phobic spasms, paralysis, 
and excitation. However, these are not enough to make a 
definitive diagnosis. Serological tests for the detection of 
rabies in serum and cerebrospinal fluids include ELISA, 
RFFIT, and FA VN. PCR and sequence-based amplification 
are used to detect rabies in saliva, tears, CSF, urine, and 
skin biopsies. At postmortem, fluorescent antibody testing 
of brain tissue and viral isolation of cell culture are used for 
confirmatory diagnosis.
1.13.6 Treatment, prevention, and control
There is no treatment for rabies virus infection in dogs, 
but it is a top-priority reportable disease. It is a zoonotic 
disease and is preventable with vaccination. Canine rabies 
vaccination of dogs is the lowest cost and highest impact -
ful investment in vaccine-preventable infectious diseases. 
Lyssaviruses circulation in bats which are reservoirs has 
served as a major challenge in causing spillage to other 
animals.
1.14 Canine distemper
Canine distemper is a highly contagious viral disease that 
causes multisystemic infection in different species of carni-
vores, especially dogs.
1.14.1 Etiology
Canine distemper virus (CDV) is a single-stranded, non-
segmented, negative-sense RNA virus belonging to the fam-
ily Paramyxoviridae, and genus morbiliviru. Using analysis 
of the level of amino acid diversity within and between phy-
logenetic clusters of the Hemagglutinin (H) gene, different 
geographic lineages of CDV have been identified. Presently, 
the eight identified lineages are America 1, America 2, Asia 
1, Asia 2, Europe 1, Europe 2 (Europe-wildlife), Europe 3 
(Arctic-like), and South Africa.
1.14.2 Epidemiology
CDV is a globally distributed disease with incidence still 
on the increase worldwide despite the massive use of vac -
cination among the dog population. There is a variation of 
circulating strains of CDV in the world due to major genetic 
variability of the H gene ( Panzera et al., 2012 ). Pantropic 
canine distemper has been detected in various wild canids 
such as wolves, raccoons, pandas, bears, foxes, minks, civ-
ets, hyenas, and large felids like lions and tigers ( Beineke 
et al., 2015).
1.14.3 Transmission
CDV is transmitted through direct contact with infected 
blood, urine, saliva, or respiratory droplets, and contact with 
contaminated fomites. Droplet transmission is common due 
to frequent coughing and sneezing of an infected dog, hence 
making CDV common during cold weather conditions. This 
is also aided by the resistance of CDV to cold. There has 
been transmission to noncarnivore species and nonhuman
