primates, thus indicating the tendency of CDV to mutate 
and cross-species barriers (Beineke et al., 2015).
1.14.4 Clinical manifestation
Canine distemper virus is pantropic (multisystemic) affect-
ing the gastrointestinal, respiratory, skin, immune, and cen-
tral nervous systems (Fig. 18). The symptoms can be mild, 
severe, and even fatal, especially in puppies. Symptoms 
can take up to 14  days to manifest as fever, pain, sneezing, 
coughing, lethargy, dyspnea, nasal and ocular discharges, 
diarrhea, vomiting, inappetence, pneumonia, skin sores, 
and thickening of nose and foot pads. Neurological signs 
are similar to rabies and include head tilt, salivation, pa -
ralysis, paresis, muscle twitching, circling, involuntary eye 
movements, and seizures. These neurological signs can 
sometimes be absent and appear 4 weeks postinfection.
1.14.5 Diagnosis
Serological tests for CDV can be done using ELISA on 
samples such as CSF and peripheral blood. It is usually 
difficult to differentiate between natural infection and vac -
cination response. Viral antigen immunofluorescent assay 
or RT-PCR is used for confirmatory diagnosis from many 
samples such as blood, urine, discharges, and biopsies from 
footpads.
1.14.6 Treatment, prevention, and control
There is no treatment for CDV infection, but supportive 
and symptomatic treatments are rendered. This intervention 
should be immediate and intensive to help the dog recover. 
However, some neurological signs may persist even after 
the recovery of the patient. CDV can be prevented through 
the vaccination of puppies and adult dogs. The puppies 
should be vaccinated at 6  weeks of age, repeated after 3 
or 4 weeks until they are 16  weeks old. Immunity may be 
stable for over 3 years, but the period to repeat vaccination 
depends on the endemicity of CDV in the particular loca -
tion. Dogs unvaccinated should be maintained under strict 
hygiene, sanitation, and a healthy diet and avoid exposure to 
infected dogs or locations. Although vaccination has been 
effective, CDV is still a major burden for dogs, wild ani -
mal populations, and nonhuman primates (Uhl et al., 2019). 
The antigenic variability of CDV , breaking of species barri-
ers, increasing host range, and maintenance among wildlife 
hosts, has been a hindrance to the eradication of the disease.
2 Viral diseases of cats
2.1 Feline herpes virus
The feline herpes virus causes a disease that affects the 
eyes, skin, and upper respiratory system of cats.
2.1.1 Etiology
Feline herpesvirus (FHV-1; felid herpesvirus 1 (FeHV-1)) 
is an enveloped, double-stranded DNA virus that belongs 
to the family Herpesviridae, subfamily Alphaherpesvirinae, 
and genus Varicellovirus. It is closely related to canine 
 herpesvirus-1 and porcine herpesvirus-1. There is only one 
serotype of the virus, and it is relatively homogenous ge -
netically (Gaskell et al., 2007).
FIG. 18 An image showing organs and their likely clinical signs seen in Canine distemper infection.

550 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
2.1.2 Epidemiology
FHV-1 is a main infectious agent of domestic and wild fe -
lines worldwide. It is endemic in most populations, and its 
prevalence depends on the population density of felines in 
such locations (Henzel et al., 2015).
2.1.3 Transmission
FHV-1 is transmitted through direct contact with oral, na -
sal, and ocular secretions from infected cats. A newly in -
fected cat begins to shed and transmit the virus within a day 
postinfection.
2.1.4 Clinical manifestation
FHV-1 infects the upper respiratory tract causing sneezing, 
coughing, fever, and inappetence, followed by ocular and 
nasal discharges, sometimes with excessive drooling and sal-
ivation. Conjunctivitis and corneal ulcer may also result. In se-
vere cases, the skin around the face turns red, swollen, crusty, 
and the occurrence of alopecia (Gould, 2011) (Fig. 19).
2.1.5 Diagnosis
PCR test is reliable for diagnosis but does not differentiate the 
active form from the chronic carrier form of FHV-1. Hence, 
diagnosis with PCR should be aided with clinical signs, phys-
ical examination, history, and signalment of the cat.
2.1.6 Treatment, prevention, and control
Skin defects from FHV-1 are usually treated with the topi -
cal use of nucleoside analogs. Secondary bacterial infec -
tions are kept in check using broad-spectrum antibiotics. 
Cats showing clinical signs should be isolated immediately 
and the space should be sanitized. Avoid overcrowding of 
cats in shelters and their exposure to stressors. Modified live 
 virus vaccines and adjuvanted inactivated virus vaccines are 
 commercially available and are capable of reducing symp -
toms of the disease during an outbreak.
2.2 Feline calicivirus
Feline calicivirus (FCV) is a highly infectious respiratory 
pathogen of domestic cats.
2.2.1 Etiology
Feline calicivirus (FCV) is a single-stranded positive-sense 
RNA virus belonging to the family Caliciviridae, genus 
Vesivirus. FCV mutates easily forming new strains that 
have the capacity to infect vaccinated or recovered cats. The 
strains differ in the severity of the disease that they cause, 
but the majority cause mild disease.
2.2.2 Epidemiology
FCV is persistent and causes sporadic outbreaks globally. 
It has a high prevalence in the cat population, especially in 
multicat households ( Coyne et al., 2006 ). The high preva -
lence may also be a result of the high resistance of FCV in 
the environment ( Najafi et  al., 2014) and the presence of 
several strains among domestic and wild cats.
2.2.3 Transmission
FCV is transmitted via direct contact with infected oral, 
 nasal, and ocular secretions.
2.2.4 Clinical manifestation
FCV can manifest as mild or severe respiratory infection 
and oral disease. Mild signs include sneezing, coughing, 
fever, nasal congestion, and secretions from the nose and 
eyes. In severe cases, there is swelling and ulceration of the 
tongue and mouth, lethargy, lameness, and inappetence.
2.2.5 Diagnosis
Diagnosis is by viral isolation or RT-PCR.
2.2.6 Treatment, prevention, and control
No specific treatment protocol, but supportive therapy in -
volves fluid therapy, broad-spectrum antibiotics, mucolytic 
agents, and tender loving care. Vaccination is recommended 
twice at 9 and 12  weeks of age, followed by an annual 
booster. FCV is stable in the environment and resistant to 
many disinfectants. Hence, vaccinated and recovered cats 
are not protected for life due to strain variability.
2.3 Feline leukemia virus
2.3.1 Etiology
Feline leukemia virus (FeLV) is an enveloped RNA vi -
rus belonging to the family Retroviridae, subfamily 
Orthoretrovirinae, and genus Gammaretrovirus. FeLV has 
three subtypes designated FeLV-A, FeLV-B, and FeLV-C.
FIG. 19 A red, swollen, crusty, and alopecic face of cat infected by feline 
herpesvirus 1. (From Gould, D., 2011. Clinical practice. J. Feline Med. 
Surg. 13, 333–346. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jfms.2011.03.010.)

Common viral diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 36  551
2.3.2 Epidemiology
FeLV occurs worldwide as a major cause of death in do -
mestic cats. It also occurs among wild felids. There is a de-
crease in the prevalence for some decades, due to extensive 
surveillance and vaccination.
2.3.3 Transmission
FeLV is transmitted through long exposure to salivary se -
cretions. Other means of transmission include bite, trans -
placental, through milk, mechanically by fleas, and through 
blood transfusion.
2.3.4 Clinical manifestation
Clinical signs of FeLV include lethargy, paleness, stoma -
titis, fever, leukemia, and lymphoma, leading to immune 
suppression bone marrow disorders and hematopoietic neo-
plasia (Fig. 20).
2.3.5 Diagnosis
Serological tests using ELISA kits are used to screen for 
FeLV , where it detects the presence of free FeLV particles 
(FeLV P27) which are present in the blood at the early and 
late stages of infection. Indirect immunofluorescent anti -
body assay (IFA) test and PCR are used for confirmation 
of the infection. Other nonclinical testing includes qPCR, 
qRT-PCR, and anti-FeLV Nab ( Westman et  al., 2019 ). 
Diagnosing FeLV infection can be complicated as a result 
of varying infection outcomes over a period of time due 
to fluctuations in viremia and the host’s immune system 
(Hofmann-Lehmann and Hartmann, 2020).
2.3.6 Treatment, prevention, and control
There is no specific treatment against FeLV infection, 
but supportive treatments are given against second -
ary bacterial infection and anemia. Cats should be kept 
indoors to avoid exposure to FeLV-infected cats. Cats 
in shelters should be screened to isolate infected cats. 
There should be continuous surveys and vaccination 
against FeLV , especially in locations with a high popula -
tion of cats. Despite the vaccination offers inadequate 
protection, cat owners should be encouraged to vacci -
nate against FeLV .
2.4 Feline distemper/feline panleukemia
Feline panleukopenia/feline distemper/feline parvovirus is 
a highly contagious and infectious disease in cats especially 
kittens and unvaccinated cats which can be mild, severe, 
and even fatal.
2.4.1 Etiology
Feline panleukopenia virus (FPV) is a small, single-
stranded, nonenveloped, linear DNA virus belonging to the 
family Parvoviridae, subfamily Densovirinae, and genus 
Protoparvovirus. FPV is mostly (95%) caused by feline par-
vovirus (FPV) and sometimes (5%) by canine parvovirus 
(CPV) variants, specifically CPV-2a, b, and c (Barrs, 2019).
2.4.2 Epidemiology
Feline panleukopenia occurs worldwide in cats, especially 
in unvaccinated and incompletely vaccinated kittens with a 
mortality rate of 50%–90% (Porporato et al., 2018).
2.4.3 Transmission
FPV is transmitted by the fecal-oral route and by di -
rect contact with the environment or fomites contami -
nated with infected cats’ saliva, urine, feces, and vomit. 
Transplacental and breast milk transmission occur be -
tween queen and kitten. Infected cats can shed the virus 
for about 2 days, but the virus can survive in the environ -
ment for several years.
FIG. 20 Some common clinical symptoms of feline leukemia virus.

552 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
2.4.4 Clinical manifestation
FPV invades, replicates, and kills cells of the bone mar -
row, intestines, skin, and developing fetus. The clinical 
signs vary from mild to severe based on the degree of 
invasiveness and symptoms include fever, lethargy, de -
pression, inappetence, diarrhea, vomiting, dehydration, 
emaciation, abdominal pain, rough hair coat, bruised 
skin, and gum ( Fig. 21 ). It also causes abortion in preg -
nant queens.
2.4.5 Diagnosis
FPV is usually screened using an ELISA test and confirmed 
by viral isolation and PCR (Jacobson et al., 2021). However, 
cats with a history of exposure and the presence of leuko -
penia and anemia are usually considered during tentative 
diagnosis.
2.4.6 Treatment, prevention, and control
There is no specific treatment for FPV , but supportive and 
symptomatic therapies are helpful. There is an effective 
vaccine against FPV which can be given once or twice, 2 
or 4 weeks apart. Due to the persistence of FPV in the en -
vironment, equipment and facilities within a contaminated 
shelter should be carefully disinfected or replaced.
2.5 Feline coronavirus
Feline coronaviruses (FCoV) cause two major diseases in 
cats, feline enteric coronavirus (FECV) and feline infec -
tious peritonitis virus (FIPV). FECV infection is mostly 
asymptomatic or mild and restricted to the intestine, while 
FIPV is fatal causing infectious peritonitis (Fig. 22).
2.5.1 Etiology
FECV is a single-stranded, enveloped, positive-sense RNA 
virus ( Fig.  23) belonging to Coronaviridae, subfamily 
Orthocoronavirinae, genera; Alphacoronavirus, and spe -
cies, Alphacoronavirus-1 ( dos Santos et  al., 2020 ). There 
are two serotypes of FCoV: serotype I and II. FIPV devel -
ops from the mutation of a virulent form of FECV in in -
fected domestic cats (Tekes and Thiel, 2016).
2.5.2 Epidemiology
FECV and FIPV occur globally in domestic cats and some 
wild Felidae especially those of young age. The prevalence of 
FCoV is high among the cat population globally, but there is a 
variable geographical distribution of serotypes I and II. FIP is 
a major cause of death in cats; however, morbidity is low due 
to the need for mutation of virulent FCoV to occur. The epi-
demiology of FIP depends on healthy carriers of FCoV by do-
mestic cats, their constant shedding of the virus, and persistent 
infection of the colon and other organs (Kipar et al., 2010).
2.5.3 Transmission
Feline coronavirus (FCoV) is naturally transmitted through 
the fecal-oral route.
2.5.4 Clinical manifestation
FECV invades the cat via the oral route, infecting and rep -
licating in the enterocytes, restricted to the intestinal tract. 
It manifests as vomiting, diarrhea, and self-limiting gastro-
enteritis. In the case of FIP, virulent FCoV invades the vil -
lous cells of the intestine, mutates, replicates, and spreads 
through monocyte-associated cells leading to viremia, and 
A 
B 
FIG. 21 Diarrhea (A) and vomiting (B) are common signs of feline distemper.

Common viral diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 36  553
compromising the immune cells ( Desmarets et al., 2016 ). 
Clinical signs include inappetence, fever, dyspnea, ema -
ciation, distended abdomen, abdominal edema, depression, 
seizures, tremors, etc. (Sweet et al., 2022) (Fig. 24).
2.5.5 Diagnosis
FECV and FIPV vary in virulence but are difficult to dis -
tinguish by regular diagnostic methods. Several diagnostic 
procedures are needed to differentiate FCoV . It should in -
volve consideration of history, signalment, clinical signs, 
pathological abnormalities, and RT-PCR ( Felten and 
Hartmann, 2019).
2.5.6 Treatment, prevention, and control
There are no approved treatments for FCoV; however, sev-
eral therapeutic compounds have been explored and devel -
oped. In recent years, two novel molecules (GS-441524 
and GC376) have raised hopes given the encouraging re -
sults, but some concerns about the use of these molecules 
persist (Delaplace et al., 2021 ). Avoid sharing feeders and 
drinkers at kitten shelters. A commercially available intra -
nasal  temperature-sensitive vaccine is effective when ad -
ministered at 16 weeks of age and the second dose is given 
3 weeks later. However, most kittens are already infected 
before 16  weeks of age, reducing the vaccine’s efficacy 
(Addie, 1998). Cat breeders should include FCoV in their 
annual screening test for diseases such as FeLV , FIV , etc. 
Newly purchased cats should be quarantined and screened 
for FCoV before adding it to the shelter.
2.6 Feline immunodeficiency virus
Feline immunodeficiency virus (FIV) is a virus of domestic 
cats that attacks the immune system, making the cats sus -
ceptibility to infections.
2.6.1 Etiology
Feline immunodeficiency virus (FIV) is an enveloped 
single-stranded RNA virus belonging to the Retroviridae 
family, genus lentivirus, with seven phylogenetic subtypes 
designated as A–F and U-NZenv.
2.6.2 Epidemiology
Feline immunodeficiency virus (FIV) is a disease of domes-
tic cats with worldwide distribution. It is known to infect 
species of Felidae and Hyaenidae. FIV eventually leads to 
feline immunodeficiency disease in domestic cats while the 
pathogenic potential in wild felids is less known. It is com-
mon among cats of middle age between 5 and 10 years old.
2.6.3 Transmission
FIV is transmitted through a deep bite from an infected cat 
due to the presence of the virus in the saliva ( Fig. 25). The 
transmission also occurs between the queen and kitten dur-
ing pregnancy, delivery, and nursing. Aggressive male and 
FIG. 22 Feline Coronavirus shed by asymptomatic and mildly infected cats.
FIG. 23 A schematic structure of Feline Coronavirus.

554 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
FIG. 24 Systems affected by feline enteric coronavirus and feline infectious peritonitis.

Common viral diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 36  555
outdoor cats are most vulnerable due to fights and injury 
from a territorial dispute.
2.6.4 Clinical manifestation
FIV targets mainly the immune system, making the cat 
susceptible to secondary infections and manifest signs like 
weakness, fever, lethargy, inappetence, salivation, diarrhea, 
lymph node enlargement, abscesses, abortion, stillbirth, con-
junctivitis, leukemia, lymphoma, and behavioral changes. 
Clinical manifestation of FIV occurs in three phases: latent 
infection, feline AIDs, and terminal phase. The latent phase 
has no symptoms and usually lasts for years. Feline AIDs 
occurs when the cat is immunocompromised and suscepti -
ble to secondary infection; hence, the symptoms are related 
to the secondary infection. It occurs years post-infection. 
The terminal phase occurs within 2–3 months, with severe 
infections such as cancer, immune-mediated disease, neu -
rologic disease, etc.
2.6.5 Diagnosis
Diagnosis usually relies on antibody screening by ELISA, 
and confirmation using Western blot. FIV diagnosis can be 
complicated due to increasing travel by cats and the intro -
duction of new FIV isolates not recognized by screening 
assays (Frankenfeld et al., 2019).
2.6.6 Treatment, prevention, and control
There is no treatment for FIV in cats, but efforts are made 
to prolong the latent phase. In the occurrence of symptoms, 
treatments involve medications against secondary infec -
tions, fluid therapy, immune boosters, anti-inflammation, 
nutrient diet, and parasite control. Commercial vaccines 
against FIV are available, and render protection but are not 
completely effective. It also results in false positives when 
testing for FIV antibodies. Other preventive measures in -
clude keeping cats indoors, putting cats on a leash when 
outdoors, and always screening new cats for FIV .

Chapter 37
Zoonotic diseases of dogs and cats
Dogs and cats play an astonishing range of roles in the hu­
man society. Their roles in society are expanding, whether 
as companions or assuming special roles for assistance or 
therapy by volunteers or human health professionals. From 
pets to sporting companions to service dogs, canines add  
a measurable degree of quality to the world of the humans 
they share their lives with while choosing cats as companion 
may help in reducing stress and anxiety and keep the house 
pest free. Also cats are quiet and required low maintenance. 
In spite of all these roles, they are also responsible for trans­
mitting several zoonotic diseases to the human beings, and  
some of them are even life threatening. Zoonosis is an infec­
tious disease that has jumped from a nonhuman animal to  
humans. Zoonotic pathogens may be bacterial, viral, or para­
sitic, or may involve unconventional agents and can spread  
to humans through direct contact or through food, water,  
or the environment. They represent a major public health 
problem around the world due to our close relationship 
with animals in agriculture, as companions and in the natu­
ral environment (WHO). The diseases associated with dogs  
include rabies, capnocytophagosis, ringworm and external  
parasites, tularemia, brucellosis, leptospirosis, campylobac­
terosis, salmonellosis, cryptosporidiosis, giardiasis, infec­
tions with pathogenic E. coli, echinococcosis, cutaneous and  
visceral larval migrans, yersiniosis, mange, and MRSA. The  
zoonotic diseases associated with cats include rabies, capno­
cytophagosis, pasteurellosis, cat scratch disease, ringworm, 
sporotrichosis, tularemia, plague, Q fever, and external 
parasites, campylobacterosis, salmonellosis, infections with  
pathogenic E. coli , cryptosporidiosis, giardiasis, toxoplas­
mosis, and MRSA. Transmission of zoonotic diseases from 
pet animals is primarily by direct contact, ingestion, indirect 
contact with insect vectors and contaminated inanimate ob­
jects, or inhalation of aerosolized materials.
1 Viral diseases
1.1 Rabies
Rabies is a severe viral disease that affects the central 
nervous system (CNS) of mammals. Once the clinical 
sign appears, survival is very rare in animals as well as in 
humans. Rabies virus is a neurotropic virus in the genus 
Lyssavirus, family Rhabdoviridae. Closely related viruses, 
called rabies­related lyssaviruses or nonrabies lyssaviruses, 
are maintained in bats and can cause illnesses identical to 
rabies. Rabies is most often transmitted from animal to 
animal in a bite. It can also be acquired by other forms of 
contact with infectious saliva or neurological tissues, typi ­
cally through mucous membranes or breaks in the skin. All 
species of mammals can probably contract rabies, but only 
a limited number also act as reservoir hosts. Reservoir hosts 
are mostly members of the families Canidae (dogs, jackals, 
coyotes, wolves, foxes, raccoon dogs), Mustelidae (various 
skunks, ferret badgers), Viverridae (mongooses, genets), 
and Procyonidae (raccoons), and the order Chiroptera 
(bats). Progressive paralysis and abrupt behavioral changes 
are frequent in cats with rabies. Additionally, they might be 
agitated, pant, or they might even attack other animals, hu ­
mans, or things. Usually, rabies symptoms in animals are 
followed by death within a few days. People can develop 
rabies symptoms days to months after exposure (Fig. 1).
1.1.1 Zoonotic importance
Rabies, caused by a virus, is almost invariably fatal in hu ­
mans. All variants of rabies virus are thought to be zoonotic. 
Clinical cases have also been caused by Duvenhage virus, 
EBLV 1, EBLV 2, Australian bat lyssavirus, Mokola virus, 
and Irkut virus. Humans are probably susceptible to other 
rabies­related lyssaviruses as well. Vaccines can protect 
pets and livestock, as well as people exposed to these ani ­
mals, and human illness can be prevented by administering 
antibodies and a series of vaccinations, provided exposure 
is recognized before the symptoms appear. However, people 
in impoverished countries do not always have access to ef ­
fective postexposure prophylaxis. Within 14 days of the sus­
pected dog bite, postexposure treatment with repeated doses 
of human rabies immunoglobulin (HRIG) can prevent the 
disease. The likelihood of contracting rabies can be drasti ­
cally decreased by washing the wound with water and liq ­
uid soap (Lucas et al., 2007).

560 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
1.2 Noroviruses
Norovirus infection is a major cause of endemic and epidemic 
acute gastroenteritis. These viruses have been classified into 
seven genogroups on the basis of the major capsid protein, 
VP1. Noroviruses GI, GII, and GIV can infect humans, 
GII pigs, GIII and GV ruminants and mice, and GVI and 
GVII dogs. A heterogeneous single­strand RNA virus in the 
Caliciviridae family, noroviruses cause contagious diseases.
1.2.1 Zoonotic importance
Human sporadic and epidemic gastroenteritis is primarily 
brought on by noroviruses ( Summa et al., 2012 ). Humans 
of any age can be impacted by this virus. The virus can 
be discovered in the digestive system, and as a result, can 
be found in the feces or diarrhea of the affected canines. 
Humans can contract it from tainted food or water, and the 
infection spreads quickly among people due to fecal ­oral 
route. Patients with acute gastroenteritis should think about 
receiving serum treatment ( Wolf et al., 2009 ). In humans, 
antibodies against canine norovirus were also reported in 
veterinarians, who experienced high risk.
2 Fungal diseases
Zoonotic fungal diseases constitute social and occupational 
hazards for humans that are exposed to and closely interact 
with infected animals. Contact with fungus­contaminated en­
vironments as well as objects of animal rearing and restraint is 
considered important in natural dissemination of these diseases.
2.1 Dermatophytosis
Dermatophytosis is an integumentary fungal disease and 
is of public health and economic significance. It is an im ­
portant occupational mycozoonoses of dairymen, animal 
handlers, livestock farmers, pet owners, veterinarians, etc. 
(Ruben, 2010).
It is caused by a group of highly specialized pathogenic 
fungi collectively referred to as “dermatophytes,” which are 
the most common agents of superficial mycoses in animals 
and humans, and are thus recognized as a public health men­
ace worldwide. This group of closely related fungi compris­
ing 40 identified species in the dermatophytic genera that 
include Microsporum, Trichophyton, and Epidermophyton 
cause infection of the stratum corneum of the epidermis and 
keratinized tissues such as skin, hair, and nails of humans 
and animals (Popoola et al., 2006).
Majority of zoonotic dermatophytes are caused by four 
species: Microsporum canis (usually derived from pet ani ­
mals, particularly cats and dogs), Trichophyton verrucosum 
(usually derived from cattle), Arthroderma vanbreuseghe ­
mii (usually derived from cats and dogs), and Arthroderma 
benhamiae (usually derived from guinea­pigs).
Ecologically, dermatophytes are classified as zoophilic, 
anthropophilic, or geophilic depending on their major res ­
ervoir in nature (animals, humans and soil, respectively). 
Zoophilic dermatophytes may result in zoonoses when hu ­
mans are exposed to these organisms.
2.1.1 Zoonotic importance
In case of human, infection results most often from direct 
contact with an infected animal, but may also be acquired 
indirectly through contact with a contaminated environment, 
such as fungus­bearing hair and scales from infected animals. 
The most common agents of infection identified were the 
zoophilic species: Microsporum canis, Trichophyton menta-
grophytes, and T. verrucosum. Usually, close interactions of 
humans with domestic animals through nomadic lifestyle, 
animal farming, domestic livestock keeping or pet owner ­
ship promote the prevalence of dermatophytic infections.
3 Parasitic diseases
Parasites are responsible for some of the most important 
and well­recognized zoonotic infectious diseases transmit ­
ted from companion animals to man globally.

3.1 Toxoplasmosis
3.1.1 Etiology
Toxoplasma gondii is a tissue cyst ­forming coccidium. In 
most cases, infection is subclinical, but devastating disease 
can occur ( Cenci­Goga et  al., 2011 ). The virulence of 
T. gondii  strains is highly variable and dependent on the 
genotype of the parasite.
3.1.2 Hosts and life cycle
Cats are the definitive hosts for T. gondii, but all warm ­
blooded vertebrates including man may serve as intermedi­
ate hosts and potentially be infected by the stage bradyzoites 
in meat, by sporulated oocysts or by intrauterine tachyzoites 
(Elmore et al., 2010 ). Transmission mainly occurs through 
a sexual cycle in the definitive host and asexually, through 
carnivorous behavior and by vertical transmission. The 
asexual phase of T. gondii development takes place in vari­
ous tissues of herbivorous or omnivorous intermediate hosts 
and is linked to a sexual phase of development in the intes­
tine of felids, the definitive hosts. The parasite can invade 
the gut, become systemic, and localize in vital organs such 
as muscle and the nervous system.
3.1.3 Zoonotic importance
In case of humans, the main sources of infections are ac ­
quired from eating undercooked or raw meat, such as pork 
and lamb. However, the prevalence of T. gondii infection 
in human populations that do not consume meat or eat it 
well­cooked suggests that the acquisition of infection from 
the environment, via oocysts in soil, water or on uncooked 
vegetables, may also play an important role in transmission. 
Some of the facts suggest that only a small proportion of 
infected people acquire infection congenitally (Lindsay and 
Dubey, 2011). In case of domestic cats, latent infections 
with T. gondii  are common throughout the world. After 
primary infection, cats spread Toxoplasma oocysts in their 
feces within 3–10 days and shedding continues for approxi­
mately 7–21 days (median 8  days), with up to hundreds of 
millions of oocysts shed in the feces of a single infected cat 
(Dubey, 2001). Afterward, the direct risk for cat owners is 
limited. It is said that T. gondii infects up to a third of the 
human population of the world.
3.1.4 Diagnosis
Confirmatory diagnosis can be done by the isolation of the 
parasite from various tissues, detection of specific DNA 
by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or by carrying out 
serological tests. Currently, routine diagnosis of toxoplas ­
mosis relies mainly on the use of serological assays that 
are available for both man and animals such as the Sabin ­
Feldman dye test, indirect fluorescent antibody test (IFAT), 
enzyme­linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) or various 
 agglutination tests. Also over the past two decades, PCR ­
based tests have been developed to detect parasite DNA in 
human and animal tissues.
3.1.5 Prevention and control
Control measures should be aimed at the prevention of oo ­
cyst shedding in order to reduce infection of people with 
T. gondii  ( Tenter et  al., 2000 ). The risk for exposure to 
T. gondii parasites is greatest in cats that prey on wildlife 
and live outdoors or in farms. Kittens are very susceptible 
to infection and shed greater quantities of oocysts. Certain 
measures needs to be taken for prevention in case of hu ­
mans such as collecting feces in litter trays for ultimate dis­
posal in rubbish destined for landfills, which are designed 
to prevent waste materials leaking into groundwater. Also 
do not consume undercooked meat or drink contaminated 
groundwater as it may be infected by sporulated oocysts. 
The control of human toxoplasmosis also relies on the 
avoidance of direct or indirect exposure to cat feces. Proper 
fecal handling, litter tray management, removal of feces 
from public areas and yards and hand hygiene are critical. 
Litter trays should be thoroughly cleaned every day so that 
any potential oocysts do not have time to sporulate (i.e., in 
about 48 h) (Dubey et al., 2011). People, particularly those 
vulnerable to infection, such as pregnant women and the 
immunosuppressed, should avoid this task. Similarly, drink­
ing unfiltered surface water or accidental ingestion of soil 
must be avoided.
3.2 Leishmaniosis
3.2.1 Etiology
Leishmaniosis (or leishmaniasis) is a complex of mamma ­
lian diseases caused by diphasic protozoans of the genus 
Leishmania (Kinetoplasta, Trypanosomatidae). The leish ­
maniosis affects man and domestic and wild animals world­
wide. It is endemic in many tropical and subtropical regions 
of the Old and New World.
3.2.2 Hosts and life cycle
In case of leishmaniosis, the most transmission cycles are 
zoonotic, involving reservoir hosts such as rodents, marsu ­
pials, edentates, monkeys, domestic dogs, and wild canids. 
Only a few Leishmania species are strictly anthroponotic 
(i.e., transmitted directly from person to person via sand 
flies). Dogs are the major reservoir for canine and human 
L. infantum infection, in an area that stretches from Portugal 
to China and across South, Central and parts of North 
America, with the exception of Oceania. Main mode of nat­
ural transmission of L. infantum between animals and from 
animals to man occurs usually by the bite of a phlebotomine 
sand fly species (Diptera, Psychodidae, Phlebotominae) 
of the genera Phlebotomus (Old World) and Lutzomyia

562 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
(New  World). Leishmania completes its life cycle in the 
sand fly, which harbors the flagellated extracellular pro ­
mastigote form and in a mammal where the intracellular 
amastigote form develops, while blood feeding a female 
sand fly ingests Leishmania and then transmits the infec ­
tive stages (metacyclic promastigotes) during a subsequent 
blood meal. The infective promastigotes inoculated by the 
sand fly are phagocytosed in the mammalian host by macro­
phages and other phagocytic cells, in which they transform 
to amastigotes. Proven modes of nonsand fly transmission 
in dogs include infection through transfused blood products 
(Owens et  al., 2011 ) from blood donors that are carriers 
of infection ( Tabar et al., 2008 ), vertical ( Boggiatto et al., 
2011) and venereal transmission (Silva et al., 2009).
3.2.3 Zoonotic importance
Human leishmaniosis, caused by several species of 
Leishmania, comprises a heterogeneous group of diseases. 
These include visceral leishmaniosis (VL), which involves 
internal organs and is fatal if untreated, and the cutaneous 
(CL) and mucocutaneous forms, which affect the skin or 
mucocutaneous junctions and may heal spontaneously, 
leaving disfiguring scars ( Murray et  al., 2005 ). The main 
predisposing factors or risk factors for human infection in ­
clude age, poor socioeconomic conditions, malnutrition and 
immunosuppressive conditions (Alvar et al., 2006).
3.2.4 Diagnosis
For the confirmatory diagnosis, the most common tech ­
niques used for disease detection in man and animals in ­
clude microscopical observation, i.e., cytology, biopsy or 
immunohistochemistry, and serological and molecular 
techniques.
3.2.5 Prevention and control
Control measures mainly include medical treatment, indi ­
vidual use of sand fly repellents in dogs, canine vaccines, 
and immunomodulating drugs. People are commonly 
treated with a short course of amphotericin B (Murray et al., 
2005), while moderately to severely sick dogs are usually 
treated with a combination of a 1 ­month course of meglu ­
mine, antimoniate, or miltefosine and a long ­term course 
of allopurinol. Generally, treatment in dogs leads to a clini­
cal cure and decreased parasite load. However, complete 
parasitological cure in the majority of dogs appears to be 
unlikely (Solano­Gallego et al., 2009).
3.3 Giardiasis
3.3.1 Etiology
There are several species of the intestinal protozoan 
parasites which belongs to the genus Giardia that infect 
 numerous hosts, ranging from mammals to amphibians 
and birds. Currently, six Giardia species are accepted: 
Giardia agilis , Giardia ardeae , Giardia muris , Giardia 
microti, and Giardia psittaci  infecting various species of 
animals, while Giardia duodenalis  infects man and many 
other mammals.
3.3.2 Hosts and life cycle
Giardia is a very common intestinal protozoal parasite of 
dogs, cats, livestock, and wildlife. G. duodenalis  causes 
giardiasis in man and in most mammals. The life cycle of 
Giardia is direct and the infective stage of the parasite, the 
cyst, is immediately infectious when released into the feces. 
When ingested by the host, cysts exist in the duodenum, 
releasing the trophozoites. The latter undergo repeated mi ­
totic division in the gut lumen and form environmentally 
resistant cysts. Cysts pass through the intestine in feces and 
are spread by contaminated water, food and fomites and by 
direct physical contact (Feng and Xiao, 2011). Cysts remain 
infectious for months in cool, damp areas and accumulate 
in the environment.
3.3.3 Zoonotic importance
The zoonotic significance of Giardia infection is not clear. 
Although people share the same G. duodenalis assemblages 
with animals with which they have close contact, such as 
household dogs, it is not known how frequently infection is 
actually acquired from household animal contact or whether 
both people and pets acquire it from a common source, such 
as contaminated water. Undoubtedly, people also commonly 
infect each other. Giardiosis in animals is often subclinical, 
but has been associated with the occurrence of diarrhea and 
illness in puppies and kittens (Thompson, 2004).
3.3.4 Diagnosis
For the identification of cyst and trophozoite stages of 
Giardia infection stool examination can be performed in 
direct fresh stool smears or by flotation for cysts. Rapid 
detection of Giardia antigen can be made using immuno ­
chromatographic kits, by immunofluorescence, ELISA or 
PCR in a suitably equipped parasitology laboratory ( Feng 
and Xiao, 2011).
3.3.5 Prevention and control
The prevention of giardiasis in man is closely associated 
with the provision of clean fresh water and adequate sewage 
systems. Boiling or filtering water from the environment 
before drinking it is essential and removal of infected feces 
from infected animals or people followed by proper disin ­
fection is necessary. Adherence to personal hygiene habits 
such as washing hands and cleaning fresh food is important 
in limiting infection.

Zoonotic diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 37  563
3.4 Echinococcosis
3.4.1 Etiology
The genus Echinococcus includes several species and 
genotypes of zoonotic cestodes (tapeworms) such as 
Echinococcus granulosus , E. multicularis , etc. The adult 
stages of these cestodes occur in the intestines of canids and 
felids without clinical relevance. The larval stages develop 
in tissues of various organs of a variety of mammalian inter­
mediate hosts, including man as aberrant hosts.
3.4.2 Hosts and life cycle
The main source of transmission of E. granulosus is a dog­
sheep cycle in pastoral regions however; other potential 
intermediate hosts can be involved. Wild felines and domes­
tic cats have occasionally been found to harbor intestinal 
stages. Although cats are more likely to be infected with 
E. multilocularis  than dogs, their zoonotic significance is 
estimated to be small, based on the low level of egg excre ­
tion. Dogs, on the other hand, may play a very important 
role in the transmission to man, but they probably do not 
contribute significantly to the contamination of rodent habi­
tats as compared with foxes (Hegglin and Deplazes, 2013). 
By means of defecation, the eggs are typically excreted 
fully developed and infectious (containing an oncosphere 
larva) in the environment. These eggs are found to be highly 
resistant and the E. multilocularis eggs survive in the envi­
ronment for up to 8  months; however, they are sensitive to 
desiccation. Eggs can be dispersed from the deposition sites 
either by being washed away or carried by flies and other 
vectors (Eckert et al., 2011).
3.4.3 Zoonotic importance
There are different ways by which humans are exposed to 
eggs of Echinococcus spp. and the most important sources 
of infection are handling of definitive hosts and oral up of 
contaminated water, food, or soil. The direct exposure to 
these eggs of Echinococcus spp. is influenced by occupa ­
tion and behavior, especially a close human ­animal bond. 
Domestic transmission of E. granulosus eggs from pet, stray 
and working dogs are particularly important in areas with 
inadequate educational standards and veterinary control. 
Echinococcus eggs may also adhere to tires, shoes, or ani ­
mal paws, resulting in more widespread dispersal and con ­
tamination of the environment, including human dwellings.
3.4.4 Diagnosis
In case of definitive host, intestinal infections with E. gran-
ulosus or E. multilocula are typically subclinical. The diag­
nosis of this infection in dogs or cats has been carried out by 
egg isolation methods, coproantigen ELISAs and PCR tests 
for E. granulosus s. l. and for E. multilocularis (Craig et al., 
2015). These techniques can also be used for the examina ­
tion of fecal samples collected in the environment.
3.4.5 Prevention and control
Comprehensive control programs can be carried out for 
prevention and control purpose which includes control of 
stray dogs, slaughter supervision and public education cam­
paigns, routine anthelmintic treatment of dogs and vaccina­
tion of sheep. A treatment schedule individually designed 
for pets based on infection risks (e.g., free roaming, uncon­
trolled access to rodents or offal) can improve treatment effi­
ciency against cestodes. For the treatment purpose, monthly 
administration of praziquantel to dogs is recommended in 
order to reduce environmental contamination with eggs. 
However, even strict compliance of the pet owners will not 
reduce the environmental contamination with eggs.
3.5 Sarcoptes scabiei
3.5.1 Introduction
Sarcoptic mange is a highly contagious mite infestation 
caused by a mite named sarcoptic scabiei. It is also known 
as canine scabies or Scabies. S. scabiei is a type of burrow­
ing mite which burrows into the skin and cause severe itch­
ing, which can result in the formation of scabs and severe 
hair loss. It is of zoonotic importance as it may affect other 
animals including humans. It is worldwide in distribution. 
The condition can become severe if not treated leading to 
thickening of the skin and weeping sores. These mites are 
ectoparasites in nature and burrow deep into the skin and 
forming tunnels. Infestations can occur anywhere on the 
body, but are more common in areas where the skin is thin 
and wrinkled, such as skin of ears, muzzle, face, and elbows 
(Diwakar and Diwakar, 2017).
3.5.2 Etiology
S. scabiei mites belong to the class Arachnida, superorder 
Acariformes, order Sarcoptiformes, suborder Oribatida, 
Infraorder Desmonomata, and the group Astigmata. 
Sarcoptes scabiei belongs to the superfamily Sarcoptoidea 
and family Sarcoptidae along with many other ectoparasitic 
mites of mammals. There are several varieties of S. scabiei 
which affects all domestic mammals and man.
3.5.3 Host and life cycle
In case of dogs, Sarcoptic scabiei canis  is responsible for 
causing sarcoptic mange so for this mite the final host is 
dog. Sarcoptic mange is highly contagious and spread 
through direct contact with the infected animal and need 
no intermediate host. The mites are obligate parasites usu ­
ally spend their entire life on a dog. The causative mite has 
a lifecycle of 17 to 21  days. Adult Sarcoptes scabiei mites

564 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
live 3 to 4 weeks in the host’s skin. After mating, the female 
burrows into the skin, depositing 3 to 4 eggs in the tunnel 
behind her. These tunnels can actually reach the length of 
several centimeters. The eggs hatch in 3–8  days producing 
hexapod (6 legs) larvae which, in turn, move about on the 
skin surface, eventually molting into their nymphal stage. 
The larvae mature into nymphs which have 8 legs. The 
nymph then molts into an adult while it is still in the burrow. 
The adults move on the skin surface where they mate, and 
the cycle begins again with the female burrowing and lay ­
ing eggs. Generally, the mating of these mites takes place 
on the skin of the host and the presence of the sarcoptic 
mite causes intense itching on the skin. They dig into and 
through the skin, causing intense itching from an allergic 
reaction to the mite, and crusting that can quickly become 
infected. Hair loss and crusting frequently appear first on 
elbows and ears. Skin damage can occur from the dogs in ­
tense scratching and biting. Secondary skin infection is also 
common. The dog will chew and scratch its skin constantly. 
This leads to the loss of large amounts of hair, especially on 
the legs and belly. Eventually, the skin will become thick ­
ened and will darken (Diwakar and Diwakar, 2017).
3.5.4 Diagnosis
One of the best methods for diagnosing sarcoptic mange in 
dogs is deep skin scrapings. Multiple deep skin scrapping 
needs to be taken as parasite remains deep into the skin. 
Other diagnostic aids such as enzyme ­linked immunosor­
bent assay (ELISA) for the serological diagnosis of canine 
sarcoptic mange has been evaluated. A characteristic clini ­
cal sign, although non ­specific, is the pinnal ­pedal reflex. 
This is a sign suggestive of sarcoptic mange. Differential 
diagnoses should include contact dermatitis, atopy flea or 
food allergy, pelodera dermatitis, pediculosis, cheyletiello ­
sis, otodectic dermatitis, dermatophytosis, seborrheic der ­
matitis, generalized pyoderma or folliculitis, and bacterial 
hypersensitivity (Fig. 2).
3.5.5 Zoonotic importance
It is a nonseasonal parasite that can be found in dogs of all 
ages and breeds however young dogs of less than 1  year of 
age are mostly affected. Canine scabies is of public health 
importance as 50% of human cases may result from han ­
dling of infected dogs. Human patients usually recover 
spontaneously after infected dog are cured ( Diwakar and 
Diwakar, 2017).
3.5.6 Prevention and control
Treatment should be started as early as possible. Firstly, the 
hair should be clipped and bathing of dog should be done 
with an antiseborrheic shampoo to remove crust and other 
debris. Benzoyl peroxide (2%–3%) and chlorhexidine ­
based shampoos (3%–4%) are commonly recommended. 
Shampooing can be done weekly or more often, as neces ­
sary. Thereafter, acaricidal dip should be given thoroughly. 
Amitraz has been an effective miticide if used three times 
at 2­week interval. Synthetic pyrethroids like deltamethrin 
have also been found very defective in treating the cases of 
canine scabies in 1:250 and 1:500 dilutions twice at 10  day 
interval (Sharma et al., 1991). For intense pruritis, systemic 
corticosteroids may be administered, i.e., Prednisone or 
Prednisolone @0.5 to 1.0  mg/kg body weight orally daily 
for 2–5  days. Ivermectin and its related drugs are found 
quite effective in scabies. Single subcutaneous injection of 
200 to 400 micro gram ivermectin and selamectin @6  mg/
kg in a topical preparation as a unit dose was reported to 
cure scabies ( Six et al., 2000 ). Therapy may take months 
for a complete response to occur. There is a need to clean 
the premises with the help of parasiticidal spray as well to 
control the spread of mites. Separate the infected animal 
from the healthy ones as soon as possible. Proper treatment 
of the infected animal should be done. Regular de­worming 
and vaccinations of the animal should be done. Regular vis­
its to the veterinarian will help maintain the dog’s overall 
health and detect underlying conditions that could weaken 
the dog’s immune system. Regular cleaning of canine prem­
ises should be done with the help of any parasiticidal spray 
to control the spread of mites.
3.6 Cheyletiella blakei
3.6.1 Introduction
Cheyletiella blakei is an ectoparasite of domestic cats which 
is extremely annoying and causes persistent and pruritic 
dermatosis in cats. They remain often underdiagnosed in 
their natural hosts. It is of zoonotic importance, i.e., it can 
FIG.  2  Skin scrapings showing different developmental stages of 
Sarcoptes scabiei.

Zoonotic diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 37  565
be transmitted from the cats to humans. It has got world ­
wide distribution. The site of predilection of the mite is 
head, neck, dorsum, and sometimes crawl in and out of the 
nostrils of cats.
3.6.2 Etiology
Cheyletiella blakei belongs to class Arachnida and super ­
family Trombidiformes (Prostigmata). The adult mites are 
large mites which may be up to 500 by 265  μm and vis ­
ible to the naked eye (Foley, 1991). The body of the mite is 
ovoid, legs are short and have sharp chelicerae for piercing 
the host. The shape of the sense organ on the first pair of 
legs is conical (Schmeitzel, 1988).
3.6.3 Hosts and life cycle
The entire life cycle is on cats and is completed in about 
15 days. There are five developmental stages in the life cycle, 
i.e., egg, larva, nymph I, nymph II, and adult. The adult mite 
attaches eggs to hair ( Foley, 1991). The Cheyletiella mite 
can be present even in animals in good physical condition. 
Long­haired coat cats are more susceptible and can be easily 
transferred to humans. The mite most commonly infests the 
head and face of cats and produces mild eczema­like lesions 
and pruritus. The most characteristic clinical signs are mov­
ing white flakes along the dorsal midline and head of the cat 
and hence called walking dandruff (Foley, 1991).
3.6.4 Diagnosis
The most common and easy method for diagnosis is to comb 
the dandruff­like flakes on black paper and movement of 
debris will be visualized. Sometimes, cellophane tape can 
also be used to entrap mites collected from the hair coat and 
viewed under the compound microscope. Skin scrapings are 
not required.
3.6.5 Zoonotic importance
The mites are quite mobile, and therefore, they can spread 
by direct contact. Sometimes, fomites can also spread the 
mites. The incidence is more seen in cats having long ­hair. 
The Cheyletiella mite produces a nonspecific cutaneous 
scaling with or without pruritus. The lesions on humans 
vary from vesicles to papules, most often on the trunk and 
in particular at locations where the infested animal is held 
against the person’s body (Parish and Schwartzman, 1993).
3.6.6 Prevention and control
The mites are very sensitive to most topical acaricidal prep­
arations, like carbamates and fipronil. Antiseborrheic sham­
poos are helpful in removing heavy scales and crusts prior 
to the use of acaricides. Regular use of topical acaricidal 
shampoos can be used in susceptible cats, their in ­contact 
animals and surroundings.
3.7 Cutaneous larva migrans
3.7.1 Etiology
Cutaneous larva migrans (CLM) is mainly caused by the 
larvae of hookworms, especially those of dogs and cats, viz. 
Ancylostoma caninum and A. braziliense. There are several 
other nematodes which are associated with the disease in ­
clude Uncinaria stenocephala, Bunostomum phlebotomum, 
Gnathostoma spinigerum, Dirofilaria sp., and Strongyloides 
westeri. The disease is worldwide in distribution. Factors 
such as tropical climate, overcrowding, and poor hygiene 
and sanitation problems contribute to the causation. Among 
travelers returning from tropical countries, CLM is the most 
frequent skin disease ( Bouchaud et  al., 2001 ). There are 
various synonyms given for this disease such as creeping 
eruption, plumber’s itch, sand worm, duck hunters itch, and 
epidermatitis linearis migrans are used to describe CLM.
3.7.2 Host and life cycle
Stray dogs play a major role in the environmental con ­
tamination with the helminth eggs. Presence of stray dogs, 
open defecation by both stray and pet dogs, improper fe ­
cal disposal is the conducive factors for the persistence of 
Ancylostoma and Toxocara eggs in the environment. The 
third­stage, L ­3 larvae are considered to be the infective 
stage which penetrates the skin of the host (dog and man). 
In dogs, L­3 stage develops into adult but no such develop­
ment occurs in man (CDC, 2013). Pale membranes, anemia, 
weight loss, bloody stool, weakness, poor growth in pup ­
pies and stunted growth in young animals are the common 
symptoms observed in ancylostomosis (Soulsby, 1982).
3.7.3 Zoonotic importance
In case of humans, the clinical features of CLM vary 
from nonspecific dermatitis to typical creeping eruption 
(Karthikeyan and Thappa, 2002 ). First of all an erythema ­
tous itchy papule is observed followed by about 2–3  mm 
thick, raised pink or flesh colored swollen lesion then there 
is formation of linear, serpentine (serpiginous), or bizarre 
tracks. Lesions are mostly observed on the feet, lower legs, 
and buttocks, but also occur on the arms, hands, and face. 
Sometimes Ancylostoma caninum  larvae may migrate to 
the human intestine, causing eosinophilic enteritis ( CDC, 
2013). CLM patients usually have a history of visiting pub­
lic places commonly accessed by stray dogs. Walking bare 
foot on or sleeping/working in contaminated soil are other 
important factors responsible for CLM in humans (Mohanty 
et al., 2012).
3.7.4 Diagnosis
Diagnosis is mainly based on clinical presentation along the 
relevant history of occupational exposure or recent travel to 
endemic regions. To detect larva and confirm the  diagnosis,

566 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
epiluminescence microscopy is an effective noninvasive 
method. In dogs, coprological examination is performed 
for diagnosis, but molecular studies are needed for species 
identification.
3.7.5 Prevention and control
In case of dogs, treatment mainly includes dichlorvos, pyr ­
antel pamoate, febantel, fenbendazole, and mebendazole. In 
case of humans, if the patient does not undergo treatment, 
complications like impetigo and local or general allergic 
reactions can occur ( Caumes, 2000 ). Such complications 
and long duration of the disease make treatment manda ­
tory. The treatment of choice is ivermectin (a single dose 
of 200  lg kg−1 body weight). Albendazole (400  mg a day 
per os for 3  days) is also effective. Topical application of a 
10%–15% thiabendazole is also effective.
3.8 Visceral larva migrans
3.8.1 Etiology
There are various synonyms given for this disease such as 
toxocarosis, larval granulomatosis, etc. It occurs due to lar­
vae of T. canis and T. cati. Larvae of Ascarissuum, swine 
roundworm could occasionally cause infection in man. It is 
worldwide in distribution with high prevalence in subtropi­
cal countries.
3.8.2 Host and lifecycle
Transmission of this disease mainly occurs when the in ­
fected dogs contaminate the soil with Toxocara sp. eggs, 
and ingestion of these eggs is major route of infection. 
Multiple factors include pica or geophagia, poor hygiene, 
eating raw vegetables, contact with puppies and exposure to 
public places and parks with contaminated soil ( Dar et al., 
2008). Ingestion of raw organs and meat from paratenic 
hosts (pigs, lamb, rabbits, chicken) also leads to the disease 
(English, 2006). Toxocarosis causes serious disease in pups 
whereas in adult dogs usually remains asymptomatic. This 
parasite is responsible for causing serious blood loss, ane ­
mia, acute gastrointestinal hemorrhages, poor growth, loss 
of condition, and sometimes an enlarged abdomen ( Kagira 
and Kanyari, 2000). Death may occur in severe cases.
3.8.3 Zoonotic importance
Most of the time this infection remains asymptomatic. In 
humans, the clinical manifestations mainly depend upon 
the site of larval migration, and the most important sites 
are liver, lungs, heart, and CNS. Fever, hepatomegaly, liver 
necrosis, splenomegaly, eosinophilia (Thakkar et al., 2012), 
and myocarditis are the important clinical manifestations. 
Pulmonary involvement can result in cough, wheeze, dys ­
pnea and pneumonia, or asthma. Signs such as seizures, 
neuropsychiatric symptoms, or encephalopathy could be 
seen during CNS involvement (Jagannath et al., 2009).
3.8.4 Diagnosis
In case of dogs, fecal examination can be done for diagno ­
sis of parasitic ova in the feces while in case of humans, 
serological tests like enzyme ­linked immunosorbent assay 
and imaging techniques such as ultra ­sonography, CT scan 
and MRI could also be used to aid in diagnosis ( Jagannath 
et al., 2009). Sometimes liver biopsy can also be performed 
in diagnosing visceral larva migrans (VLM).
3.8.5 Prevention and control
For the treatment of toxocarosis, a variety of anthelmintic 
drugs are used. Administration of corticosteroids can be 
used in order to suppress the intense allergic manifesta ­
tions of the infection. By controlling the Toxocara infec ­
tion in dogs and cats will reduce the number of infectious 
eggs in the environment and reduce the risk of infection for 
people. It is found that Toxocara eggs have a strong protec­
tive layer, which allows the eggs to survive in the environ ­
ment for months or even years under the right conditions. 
Therefore, many common disinfectants are not effective 
against Toxocara eggs, but extreme heat has been shown to 
kill the eggs. Prompt removal of animal feces can help pre­
vent infection since the eggs require 2 to 4 weeks to become 
infective once they are passed out of the animal.
3.9 Ocular larva migrans
3.9.1 Etiology
Ocular larva migrans (OLM) also known as Toxocaral Retinitis 
is mainly caused by larvae of T. canis and T. cati. Occasionally, 
Baylisascaris procyonis, raccoon roundworm can lead to OLM 
in humans (Brasil et al., 2006). The two main clinical presenta­
tions of toxocariasis are VLM and OLM. The syndromes VLM 
and OLM can be caused by infection with the migrating larvae 
of other kinds of parasites which cause symptoms similar to 
those caused by migrating Toxocara larvae.
3.9.2 Host and lifecycle
Ocular toxocariasis occurs when a microscopic Toxocara 
larva enters the eye and causes inflammation and scarring 
on the retina. OT typically occurs only in one eye and can 
cause irreversible vision loss.
3.9.3 Zoonotic importance
In case of humans, ocular toxocarosis is mostly observed in 
older children and young adults. OLM is usually unilateral 
and there is decrease in visual acuity, strabismus, or leuko­
coria (Shields, 1984). Most common presenting manifesta­
tions are impairment of visual acuity and leukocoria.

Zoonotic diseases of dogs and cats  Chapter | 37  567
3.9.4 Diagnosis
The tentative diagnosis can be done on the basis of clini ­
cal signs but for confirmatory diagnosis ELISA on serum 
samples can be performed to diagnose the disease (Shields, 
1984).
3.9.5 Prevention and control
In the presence of ocular larva migrans, treatment is di ­
rected toward suppressing intraocular inflammation by glu­
cocorticoid therapy. In addition, antihelminthic drugs such 
as diethylcarbamazine or albendazole should be given to 
eradicate the infection completely. Vitrectomy may be per­
formed, if needed, to improve vision and remove granulo ­
mas (Small et al., 1989).
4 Bacterial diseases
4.1 Brucellosis
Brucellosis in canine is an infectious zoonotic disease 
caused by Brucella canis, which has been reported world ­
wide, and is a major public health concern due to close con­
tact between dogs and humans. In dogs, canine brucellosis 
manifests with abortion outbreaks, reproductive failure, 
enlargement of lymph nodes, and occasionally affects the 
osteoarticular system, although the occurrence of asymp ­
tomatic infections in dogs are not uncommon. Infection of 
dogs occurs mostly by the oronasal route when in contact 
with contaminated tissues such as aborted fetuses, semen, 
urine, and vaginal secretions. The diagnosis in dogs is 
largely based on serologic methods. However, serologic di­
agnosis of canine brucellosis remains very challenging due 
to the low accuracy of available tests. Molecular diagnostic 
methods have been increasingly used in the past few years. 
Treatment of infected dogs is associated with a high fre ­
quency of relapse and should be employed only in selected 
cases.
4.1.1 Zoonotic importance
In humans, the disease is associated with a febrile syn ­
drome, commonly with nonspecific symptoms including 
splenomegaly, fatigue, and weakness. In humans, con ­
tact with contaminated fluids from infected dogs is an 
important source of infection, and it is an occupational 
risk for veterinarians, breeders, laboratory workers, 
among other professionals who deal with infected ani ­
mals or biological samples. Many Brucella  species have 
been identified, including B. melitensis , B. abortus , and 
B. suis , which caused human brucellosis. However, B. 
canis has received less attention as a common pathogen 
in human brucellosis infections ( Seleem et  al., 2010 ). 
Despite the fact that B. canis  is not the cause of bru ­
cellosis in people, farmer populations that had a history 
of exposure to B. canis ­infected canine bodily fluids 
were more frequently the target of reported cases. The 
incubation phase may continue for a few months or 1 to 
4 weeks ( Lucero et al., 2010 ).
In the endemic zone, the individuals may be asymptom­
atic or even exhibit severe clinical signs, such as fever, night 
sweats, and low back pain, which should be distinguished 
from tuberculosis and other cancers ( Hasanjani Roushan 
et al., 2004). In order to prevent the disease’s consequences 
and after effects, brucellosis should be treated. Combination 
therapies, which are frequently used to treat brucellosis, in­
volved taking doxycycline along with either streptomycin 
or rifampin for 6  weeks ( Pappas et  al., 2005 ). Currently, 
there are no commercially available vaccines for prevention 
of canine brucellosis. Therefore, development of novel and 
improved diagnostic methods as well as the development 
of efficacious and safe vaccination protocols are needed for 
an effective control of canine brucellosis and its associated 
zoonotic risk.
4.2 Leptospirosis
Leptospirosis is a bacterial disease that affects many 
mammals, including humans and dogs; dogs can trans ­
mit the bacteria to humans, but the frequency of trans ­
mission and highest risk exposures are poorly understood 
(Fig. 3).
4.2.1 Zoonotic importance
Leptospirosis, known as Weil’s disease in people, can 
cause extremely serious liver and kidney disease, but the 
transmission from dogs to humans is rare. Humans usually 
contract this disease from exposure to contaminated water. 
Leptospirosis in humans is mostly brought on by aerobic 
spirochete L. interrogans . Leptospirosis is a widespread 
zoonosis that is mostly spread to people via polluted en ­
vironmental sources, such as contaminated soil, water, 
urine, or animal tissue. However, domestic animals, such as 
dogs, can play a significant role in leptospirosis transmis ­
sion in endemic locations. Rodents are the main reservoirs 
for leptospirosis ( Moore et al., 2006 ). The primary routes 
of Leptospirosis transmission involve mucosal surfaces of 
the human body, such as the eye, vagina, nose, mouth, or 
erosive lesions, which come into direct touch with contami­
nated urine. This infection typically takes around 10 days to 
incubate (ranging from 2 to 26 days). Numerous symptoms 
including fever, nonproductive cough, headache, muscu ­
loskeletal discomfort, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, alveolar 
hemorrhage, and even meningitis, can accompany leptospi­
rosis (Sehgal, 2006). Doxycycline, ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, 
penicillin, amoxicillin, and ampicillin are a few antibiot ­
ics that have been successfully used to treat this disease 
(Kobayashi, 2001).

568 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
4.3 Bordetella bronchiseptica
Bordetella bronchiseptica, a gram­negative rod­shaped bac­
teria, belongs to the genus Bordetella and causes bronchitis. 
Animals with upper respiratory infections, such as dogs and 
cats, frequently carry the infection, which is transmitted to 
people by aerosol. Canines that have B. bronchiseptica can 
develop acute tracheobronchitis, which presents as a raspy, 
kennel cough ­like cough. This organism has been shown 
to be resistant to cephalosporins and macrolides, but mul ­
tiple studies have shown that it is sensitive to fluoroquino ­
lones and Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (Egberink et al., 
2009).
4.3.1 Zoonotic importance
B. bronchiseptica infections in humans are relatively rare, 
pneumonia and upper respiratory infections can occur in 
dog owners who have the bacterium (Ner et al., 2003).
4.4 Campylobacteriosis
Gram­negative bacteria called Campylobacter spp., notably 
Campylobacter jejuni and Campylobacter coli, commonly 
cause campylobacter enteritis. This bacterium typically 
dwells in the digestive tracts of several mammals. The main 
way that campylobacter is spread is through direct contact 
with diseased animals or their products. The main cam ­
pylobacter reservoirs are dogs and puppies. For instance, 
a research found that campylobacter was isolated from 
roughly 47% of the dog fecal sample ( Janda et al., 2006 ). 
Campylobacter enteritis has an incubation period of 1 to 
7 days.
4.4.1 Zoonotic importance
In case of humans, majority of patients have fever, nausea, 
diarrhea, and stomach pain. Also, more than 50% of the in­
fected patients may have bloody diarrhea. In some cases, 
convulsion and seizures may be seen ( Gazaigne et  al., 
2008). This illness typically resolves on its own and does 
not require antibiotic treatment. Consideration should be 
given to hydration and electrolyte balance correction. In 
individuals with severe illness, fluoroquinolone, macro ­
lide, or aminoglycoside antibiotic therapy is recommended 
(Ternhag et al., 2007).
4.5 Capnocytophaga infection
This infection is caused by gram ­negative bacterium 
Capnocytophaga canimorsus which is the normal commen­
sal of the oropharyngeal tract of dogs and cats.

4.5.1 Zoonotic importance
The pathogen, which primarily infects humans through dog 
bites, can result in a severe sepsis, especially in old, im ­
munocompromised, or asplenic patients. The pathogen can 
also cause meningitis, osteomyelitis, arthritis, lung abscess 
or empyema, and endocarditis, all of which are deadly ill ­
nesses. Additionally, particularly in people with impaired 
immune systems, hemolytic uremic syndrome and throm ­
botic thrombocytopenic purpura can be linked to capnocy ­
tophaga septicemia ( Biedermann and Deligne, 2003 ). The 
data from the literature have shown that the estimated mor­
tality rate from capnocytophaga septicemia is one ­third of 
the infected patients. Therefore, third ­generation cephalo­
sporins should be used as early empirical therapy in indi ­
viduals who have been bitten by a dog ( Jolivet­Gougeon 
et al., 2007).
4.6 Coxiella burnetii infection
4.6.1 Zoonotic importance
Humans get Q fever from the obligatory intracellular gram­
negative bacteria C. burnetii. Normally, the disease spreads 
to people by aerosols and direct contact with the bodily flu­
ids of infected animals. Despite the fact that dogs are not the 
primary carriers of C. burnetii, a study showed that about 
10% of farm dogs carried the pathogen ( Cosman et  al., 
2013). In addition, C. burnetii was found to be transferrable 
from an infected parturient dog to a human in a different 
investigation by Buhariwalla and colleagues. The patients 
also experienced the Q fever symptoms of fever, chills, 
nausea, vomiting, and a strong cough. In chest radiography, 
opacity is a frequent finding, and during auscultation during 
a physical examination, crackles may be audible. According 
to this investigation, the incubation period lasted between 
8 and 12  days following contact with the diseased animal. 
Fluoroquinolones or doxycycline are effective treatments 
for C. burnetii patients (Patel et al., 2011).
4.7 Methicillin resistance Staphylococcus 
aureus
Methicillin resistance Staphylococcus aureus  (MRSA) is 
a common cause of infection ­related death in people. This 
pathogen has reportedly been isolated from a variety of ani­
mals, including pigs, horses, cattle, cats, and dogs, accord ­
ing to several studies. Some of them had the opinion that 
companion animals were the primary carriers of MRSA, as 
they could pass the infection to their owners directly.
4.7.1 Zoonotic importance
It appears that patients with impaired immune systems are 
more likely to contract MRSA from animals. However, 
other data suggested that these bacteria could spread to 
healthy people who own an affected animal. Treatment of 
infections brought on by MRSA does not improve with 
the use of conventional antistaphylococcal drugs. As a re ­
sult, modern medications like vancomycin, linezolid, and 
daptomycin are frequently used to treat MRSA infections 
(Morgan, 2008).
4.8 Salmonella
Salmonella species are anaerobic, mobile, gram ­negative 
bacilli that thrive in the large intestine of many animals, 
particularly in the canine’s mesenteric lymph nodes and the 
distal portion of the colon.
4.8.1 Zoonotic importance
Several infectious illnesses, including gastroenteritis, en ­
teric fever, bacteremia, and osteomyelitis, can also infect 
humans through the digestive system (fecal transmission). 
The most frequent clinical manifestations of Salmonella 
in humans and dogs are gastrointestinal illnesses; how ­
ever, the majorities of infected animals or people are as ­
ymptomatic and can shed the virus through feces for up 
to 6 weeks, which allows it to spread to other animals or 
people. Salmonella species are more common in develop ­
ing countries than they are in developed ones ( Leonard, 
2014). Salmonella infections should be treated with anti ­
biotics from different families, such as fluoroquinolones, 
beta­ lactams, and macrolides. Although an antibiogram 
should be taken into consideration for people who have the 
infection (Leonard et al., 2011).
4.9 Staphylococcus intermedius
S. intermedius  is a gram ­positive, coagulase ­producing 
bacteria that often resides in the front of the nasal cav ­
ity of a variety of species, including dogs, pigeons, and 
horses. According to recent research, this pathogen might 
also be isolated from healthy dogs’ gingiva ( Hoekstra and 
Paulton, 2002).
4.9.1 Zoonotic importance
Although S. intermedius  is not a typical zoonotic disease 
that affects humans, studies have shown that it is a possible 
pathogen linked to dog bite wounds and that cellulitis can 
occur in patients. It’s crucial to differentiate this bacterium 
from Staphylococcus aureus. Effective treatments for this 
infection include penicillin and amoxicillin ­clavulanate 
(Armstrong III et al., 2004).
4.10 Yersinia enterocolitica
A gram ­negative coccobacillus zoonotic pathogen called 
Y. enterocolitica causes yersiniosis in both humans and 
animals. Birds, pigs, deer, and cattle are a few of the  major

570 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
Y. enterocolitica  reservoirs. In some investigations, the 
pathogen was isolated from dog bite wound ( Fredriksson­
Ahomaa, 2007).
4.10.1 Zoonotic importance
When the pathogen invades the mucosal surface of the co ­
lon, patients may first show no symptoms. However, wa ­
tery or bloody diarrhea may then appear. Additionally, the 
infection may involve Peyer’s patches and exhibit symp ­
toms of appendicitis ( Abdel­Haq et al., 2000 ). Most cases 
of Y. enterocolitica are self ­limited and do not require an ­
tibiotic treatment; however, patients with severe infection 
and those who are immunocompromised should be treated 
with an aminoglycoside and doxycycline together.
4.11 Cat scratch disease (Bartonella henselae)
Bartonella henselae and, less frequently, other Bartonella spe­
cies are the bacteria that cause cat scratch disease (CSD). Cats 
can contract the disease from flea bites, blood transfusions, or 
fights with other affected cats. The bacteria is most likely to be 
present in young cats (under 1 year of age), stray or shelter cats, 
cats that are currently or have previously had flea infestations, 
and cats that hunt. Cats have been exposed to the germs be­
tween one­third and 50% of the time. Even while the majority 
of infected cats do not show symptoms, some cats may have 
a moderate sickness with a temperature that lasts for around 
2–3 days. Rarely, the illness can make cats exhibit more se­
vere symptoms like vomiting, red eyes, enlarged lymph nodes, 
exhaustion, and/or decreased appetite. Compared to cats, 
Bartonella infection in dogs is less common but more likely to 
result in sickness. The CSD bacteria may cause a mild infec­
tion with a small, raised, solid bump at the site of the scratch 
and lymph node swelling near the site of the scratch. This oc­
curs 1–3 weeks after exposure (for example, a cat scratch or 
lick). The infection can also cause fever, and less commonly 
eye infection, muscle pain, or more severe symptoms.
4.11.1 Zoonotic importance
The germs can spread to people when they lick or scratch an 
infected cat. Anyone can contract CSD, although those un ­
der the age of 15 and those with compromised immune sys­
tems are more likely to become ill than healthy individuals.
4.12 Plague (Yersinia pestis)
Yersinia pestis, a bacterium that may infect humans and ani­
mals, is what causes the plague. Fleas can spread the infec­
tion to rats and other small animals in the western United 
States. People and animals (dogs and cats) that are bitten 
by infected fleas are at risk. Cats and dogs are both capable 
of contracting the plague and passing it on to people. The 
majority of flea ­related illnesses affect both humans and 
animals; however contact with animals that have the plague 
can also make people ill. A sick cat’s coughing up infectious 
droplets into the air can also expose people to the disease. 
Fevers, poor appetites, lack of energy, and swollen lymph 
nodes on their necks that can resemble wounds are some of 
the symptoms of plague in cats. Cats that have plague pneu­
monia may cough or have breathing problems.
4.12.1 Zoonotic importance
Travelers and residents of rural areas may be at risk. 
Additionally, those who have animal contact (such as 
those who sleep with pets) and hunters may be in danger. 
Particularly vulnerable to the pandemic are cats. To lower 
the risk of human illness, owners should limit human con ­
tact with sick pets and seek veterinarian care as soon as 
possible. The most prevalent type of plague among humans 
is bubonic. Bubonic plague symptoms include painful, en ­
larged lymph nodes, high fever that appears out of nowhere, 
chills, headache, and weakness. More severe symptoms 
may result from other types of plague, such as septicemic 
plague and plague pneumonia.
