1 Introduction
People like to keep pets as their companion animals, and 
during the last 50 years, their number has increased in so -
ciety. The social role of dogs and cats has changed. They 
live in close contact with human beings, and therefore, the 
attention toward the welfare of these animals is increased 
(Mackenzie et al., 2014). Due to close contact with humans 
and animals, the chances for the spread of zoonotic and 
anthroponotic diseases have increased. These animals can 
transmit diseases to human beings and vice versa. A human 
may acquire resistant genes or microbes not only from food 
animals but also from dogs and cats via contact ( Ru et al., 
2017).
One health is a concept that deals with the intercon -
nection among animals, humans, and the environment. 
Household pets can act as a reservoir of various zoo -
notic diseases and may transmit microbes to their owners 
(Duquette and Nuttall, 2004). A contaminated environment 
in which both humans and animals are living can also be the 
source of the transmission of many infectious diseases from 
animals to humans (Duquette and Nuttall, 2004). Although 
the organisms that are responsible for the occurrence of in-
fection are different from the pathogens that infect human 
beings, it is not always the case because many zoonotic 
microscopic pathogens cause diseases in both humans and 
pets (David et al., 2020).
Many emergent pathogens are not only limited to ani -
mals but diagnosed in humans as well ( Mackenzie et  al., 
2014). The development of antimicrobial drug resistance in 
human medicine has highlighted the problem of resistance 
occurrence in animals against the drugs used for the treat -
ment of infectious diseases ( Alanis, 2005). The antibiotic 
resistance in the bacterial pathogens of dogs and cats may 
be less severe than that of pathogenic microbes isolated 
from human beings. This may be due to less exposure of 
dogs and cats to antimicrobial drug therapy and the short 
duration of treatment because they are seldom hospitalized. 
The second reason is that the animals whose immune sys -
tem is compromised are less likely to be treated with potent 
and broad-spectrum medicines (Prescott et al., 2002).
Nowadays, resistance is a major problem in the control 
and treatment of many infectious diseases. If we give medi-
cation against a pathogen, only nonresistant pathogens will 
be diminished but resistant microbes will continue to grow 
and multiply. The microbes which are resistant to three or 
more drugs are known as multidrug-resistant pathogens. 
There are many methods through which bacteria acquire 
resistant genes and become resistant too ( Kroemer et  al., 
2014). Transposons are the small pieces of the bacterial 
genome that facilitate the spread and incorporation of mul -
tiple resistant genes into the victim genome or plasmids 
(Gandolfi-Decristophoris et  al., 2013 ). The antimicrobial 
susceptible bacteria acquire resistant genes through conju -
gation, transformation, and transduction ( Tenover, 2006). 
The horizontal transfer of resistant genes from one microbe 
to the other is the main mediator of antibiotic resistance.
Anthelmintic drugs are used for the prevention and con-
trol of parasitic worms. Benzimidazole is a broad-spectrum 
drug used to control gastrointestinal worms. The improper 
use of these drugs has resulted in the emergence of resis -
tant strains of parasites that are no longer effectively pre -
ventable with these drugs. However, the alternate use of 
antiparasitic drugs can prevent the spread and emergence 
of resistant variants ( Gokbulut et  al., 2007 ). Vaccination 
plays a significant role in the prevention of infectious dis -
eases and is used for prophylactic purposes. Viruses and 
bacteria continuously change their genetic material through 
mutation. This property of pathogens results in the develop-
ment of resistance against specifically developed vaccines 
(Klingborg et al., 2002). So that it is important to assess the 
pathogens of various infectious diseases which are resistant 
Chapter 38
Drug resistance of infectious diseases  
of dogs and cats

574 SECTION  | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
to  already-developed drugs. In this way, we can limit them, 
and the efficacy of drugs can also be maintained.
2 Emerging drug resistance leads 
to global threat and its economic 
importance
There are many reasons for our concern regarding the 
emergence of resistance and a decrease in the efficacy of 
drugs. Microbial resistant results in the failure of treat -
ment and is a life-threatening situation for critically ill 
patients (Mackenzie et al., 2014 ). Dogs and cats live very 
close to human beings. A unique aspect of this associa -
tion may result in the transmission of resistant strains of 
bacteria, particularly Gram-negative bacteria, and various 
other pathogens. The close sharing of living will result in 
the transfer of interspecies pathogens from animals to hu -
mans and vice versa. The emergence of multidrug- resistant 
microbes in dogs and cats has imposed serious health 
problems ( Wongsawan et  al., 2021). The shared environ -
ment of dogs and cats with people has increased the risk 
for the spread and transmission of antimicrobial-resistant 
microbes to human beings. The horizontal transfer of re -
sistant genes between pets and humans is also a risk factor 
for the emergence of drug resistance (Duquette and Nuttall, 
2004). Prolonged therapy with antibiotics such as vancomy-
cin leads to a low-level development of resistance that is not 
detectable in laboratories. The resistant pathogen may also 
spread and become the source of broader infection, which 
is difficult to control, and require more time, and expensive 
protocols (Tenover, 2006).
3 Accelerating factors responsible for 
drug resistance of infectious diseases of 
companion animals
Improper treatment of dogs and cats leads to many health 
problems such as the development of drug resistance (refer 
to Fig. 1), prolonged duration of illness, repeated therapy, 
and regulatory and public health concerns ( Weese et  al., 
2019). Resistance to antibacterial drugs is mostly associated 
with frequent exposure of animals to hospitals or prolonged 
hospitalization, extensive wound, and immune suppression. 
The prophylactical use of antibiotics in dogs and cats at vet-
erinary hospitals could also be the cause of the development 
of antibiotic-drug-resistant bacteria.
3.1 Role of mutation
There are many scenarios through which mutation leads to 
drug resistance. The mutation is a critical mechanism that 
results in resistance occurrence. It can turn a drug from an 
antagonistic drug into an agonistic drug. Most bacteria are 
haploid and have a short duration of a cycle which makes 
them the best candidate for the mutation. Mutation of rifam-
picin and streptomycin arises which lead to serious health 
concern and limited the use of a single drug in therapy. 
However, the mutation in synthetic drugs such as fluoroqui-
nolones and oxazolidines is readily less (Guardabassi et al., 
2004).
3.2 Antigenic shift and antigenic drift
The point mutation in the genome of pathogens results in 
little phenotypic changes and is known as antigenic drift. 
While the antigenic shift arises from the genetic reassort -
ment of gene sequence between the two viruses affecting 
the same cell such as influenza viruses. Both these phenom-
ena play an essential role in the emergence of drug resis -
tance (Alanis, 2005).
3.3 Misuse of antimicrobial drugs
Improper medication and inadequate doses of drugs given 
to pets for the treatment of infectious diseases result in anti-
microbial resistance. Similarly, the misusing and overusing 
of drugs may lead to the development and spread of an -
tibiotic, anthelmintic, or antiprotozoal-resistant organisms 
(Alanis, 2005).
3.4 Emergence of new pathogenic variants
Mutation, antigenic shift, antigenic drift, conjugation, trans-
formation, or transduction will result in minor changes in 
the genome sequence of the pathogenic organism which 
remains no longer susceptible to already available drugs 
used against them. The emerging new pathogenic variants 
are stronger than the previous ones (Berrafato et al., 2019).
4 Antimicrobial drug resistance in dogs 
and cats
For therapeutic and prophylactic, proposed antimicrobial 
drugs are commonly used in companion animals. The 
widespread use of broad-spectrum antibiotics in small 
animals is reported worldwide. The most frequently used 
drugs are beta-lactams (amoxicillin), cephalosporin, lin -
cosamides, fluoroquinolones, macrolides, tetracycline, 
and trimethoprim in small animal practice ( Kawamura 
et al., 2017 ). The ability of bacteria to develop antibiotic 
resistance has complicated the treatment of the diseases. 
Antibiotics act in many ways to limit the bacteria such as 
interference with the synthesis of the cell wall, inhibiting 
the synthesis of protein, interference with the synthesis of 
nucleic acid, bacterial membrane disruption, and metabolic 
pathway inhibition (Tenover, 2006).

Drug resistance of infectious diseases of dogs and cats   Chapter | 38  575
4.1 Antibacterial drug resistance
Many factors make microbes resistant to one or more than 
one classes of antibiotics (Weese et al., 2011; Rankin et al., 
2017). They are maybe intrinsically resistant to drugs or 
may acquire resistance by mutation, or through the acquisi-
tion of other bacterial-resistant genes. Bacteria incorporate 
the acquired resistant genes in their genome and produce 
enzymes that destroy the antibacterial drugs used against 
them and prevent drugs to reach their intrinsic targets, mod-
ifying the target site of the drug, or making an alternative 
pathway of metabolism that bypasses the action of the drugs 
(Tenover, 2006).
Many infections caused by resistant bacteria to com -
monly used antibiotics now have become an important 
global healthcare threat. These infections are not only 
prolonging the duration of the disease, but they are also 
very costly to diagnose and treat significantly ( Alanis, 
2005). Extended-spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL) or 
ampicillinase C (AmpC) producing Enterobacteriaceae, 
methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus pseudintermedius  
(MRSP), methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus  
(MRSA), and multidrug resistant Gram-negative non -
fermenting bacteria have emerged in sick and healthy 
companion animals (dog and cat) ( Harrison et al., 2014 ). 
Humans are at risk to acquire these resistant bacteria 
from infected or carrier animals which poses a serious 
public health concern ( Kawamura et al., 2017 ; Ru et al., 
2017).
4.2 Antifungal drug resistance
The drugs which kill or stop the growth of pathogenic fungi 
that become the source of infection is known as antifungal 
drugs. Like antibiotic resistance, the occurrence of resis -
tance in antifungal drugs is also possible when fungi no lon-
ger respond to the drugs used against them. There are three 
types of antifungal drugs used for the infectious diseases 
of fungi in dogs and cats. The emergence of resistance in 
these medicines will greatly impair the therapy of infection 
and limit treatment options, e.g., Candida auris can become 
resistant to all three types of antifungal drugs (Talbot et al., 
2015). Therefore, its control is very difficult. Fungal infec-
tions are not only limited to the outer skin like ringworm 
infection but they can also cause severe and life- threatening 
conditions if they reach internal organs, especially the brain. 
If antifungal treatment is limited, the severe infections of 
the heart, blood, brain, and eye caused by invasive fungi 
will be difficult to cure (Prescott et al., 2002).
Naturally certain types of antifungal drugs are not ef -
fective against some species of fungi, e.g., Aspergillus is 
resistant to fluconazole. Resistance can also occur when an 
ill dog or cat is frequently exposed to antifungal medicines 
(Talbot et al., 2015). Furthermore, the use of fungicides in 
agriculture is also contributing to the development of drug 
resistance in animals because their residues appear in the 
diet of animals. The resistance is observed in the follow -
ing fungi, viz. Aspergillus and Candida species including 
Candida auris (Prescott et al., 2002).
FIG. 1 Development of drug resistance.

576 SECTION  | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
4.3 Vaccinal resistance
Veterinarians usually recommend vaccination to prevent the 
occurrence of diseases ( Ge et al., 2011 ). The strains used 
in vaccines are less or even not pathogenic which provoke 
the host immune system to produce antibodies against the 
administered antigens. With the advent of new strains of 
viruses and bacteria which causes diseases, the protection 
provided by vaccines is reduced over time ( Aubert, 1992). 
Therefore, the vaccination of pets with the previous vac -
cinal strain along with the new strain is required to fully 
protect the dogs and cats from the attack of pathogens. The 
commonly used vaccines against different infectious dis -
eases in dogs and cats include a vaccine for rabies, parvo -
virus vaccine, canine distemper virus vaccine, calicivirus 
vaccine, etc. (Klingborg et al., 2002).
5 Emergence and spread of resistance in 
the drugs used against parasitic infections 
of dogs and cats
Antiparasitic drugs are a vital tool for the control and pre -
vention of parasitic diseases in animals including dogs and 
cats. The loss of efficacy of antiprotozoal and anthelmintic 
drugs can seriously affect the welfare and health of compan-
ion animals ( Bengtsson and Greko, 2014 ). As they live in 
close association with human beings, if not properly treated 
against all types of ectoparasite and endoparasite may lead 
to the spread of infection from animals to humans. Improper 
therapy also contributed to the emergence of a resistant 
strain that poses serious public health risks (Ru et al., 2017).
5.1 Antiprotozoal drug resistance
The main line of defense against protozoal diseases in ani -
mals is chemotherapy which is commonly used to prevent 
and control the diseases caused by protozoa. This defense 
against protozoal diseases is being eroded by the emergence 
of drug resistance. Now many pathogenic species are no 
longer susceptible to commonly used drugs. Polymerase 
chain reaction, cloning of genes, and monoclonal antibodies 
against the proteins which become resistant to drugs can be 
used to recognize. The mechanism behind the development 
of antiprotozoal drug resistance is that there is a decrease in 
the uptake of the drug due to loss of transporters, parasitic 
export of drugs by P-glycoproteins and other ATPase, loss of 
the activation of the drug is the main mechanism for the resis-
tance in Giardia and Trichomonas species, and alteration of 
drugs targets also lead to the development of drug resistance.
5.2 Anthelminthic drug resistance
Anthelmintic macrocyclic lactone is currently only the class 
of drug used to control Dirofilaria immitis. Macrocyclic 
 lactones include moxidectin and ivermectin (Berrafato et al., 
2019). These drugs are commercially available to treat heart-
worm disease in dogs and cats. The efficacy of these drugs 
in low doses is 100% for the prevention of third-stage larvae 
(L3) of D. immitis, but the higher dose of these drugs can 
also diminish circulating microfilaria (Mf) in the blood ves-
sels of the infected host. These drugs show their mechanism 
of action by stimulating the attachment of D. immitis with 
polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs) and peripheral blood 
mononuclear cells (Mavropoulou et al., 2014). Currently, re-
sistance in the efficacy of ivermectin and moxidectin is ob-
served. Resistance to a drug is associated with the Mf strain 
of D. immitis which reduced the efficacy of macrocyclic lac-
tone anthelmintics (Berrafato et al., 2019; Table 1).
6 Possible ways to conserve drug 
efficacy and prevent drug resistance
We need to improve the guidelines used for the prescription 
of drugs in dogs and cats so that we can cope with the chal-
lenge of drug resistance. Drug efficacy can be achieved by 
the appropriate selection of drugs based on pathogen culture 
and testing for the susceptibility of the drug ( Wongsawan 
et al., 2021). The rational and judicious use of medicine by 
the veterinarian may result in the prevention of drug resis -
tance. The effective control of the spread of resistant organ-
isms or their resistant genes especially from patients treated 
with broad-spectrum medicines at hospitals may limit the 
emergence of drug resistance ( Prescott et  al., 2002 ). The 
responsible use of drugs should prevent resistance to drugs 
(Duquette and Nuttall, 2004).
7 Future perspective
The emergence of resistant strains of pathogens that are 
least or not even susceptible to already discovered drugs 
is the most serious challenge that seeking the attention of 
the world. Drug resistance is increasing in pets, but the 
rate of discovery and formulation of new and effective 
drugs is slow and does not meet the medicinal demands. 
The currently, discovered antibiotics disrupt the mecha -
nism of bacterial central dogma, but they have evolved new 
and alternate metabolic pathways to bypass the action of 
drugs used against them (Petchiappan and Chatterji, 2017). 
The identification of new metabolic pathways and stress-
associated pathways for the bacteria will play a key role 
in the discovery of new drugs. Targeting small RNAs and 
antimicrobial peptides would facilitate in the near future 
to combat drug resistance. Due to the loss of efficacy of 
many drugs, there is a need for the development of new and 
novel therapeutic strategies for the control of multiresistant 
strains of pathogens. If antimicrobial resistance is not con -
trolled, diseases which seem to be very simple will become 
very dangerous (Singleton et al., 2020).

8 Conclusion
The present pace of anthelmintic, antibiotic, antiparasitic, 
or novel targets for vaccine discovery is not sufficient to 
combat the emergence of drug resistance, necessitating the 
importance of the identification of new strategies and tech-
niques. Most drugs target the process of central dogma or 
the metabolism of the cell wall, and there is a requirement 
to recognize the new targets for the discovery of drugs. The 
improper use of drugs leads to the development of drug-
resistant in dogs and cats.

and support.

Chapter 39
Diagnostic techniques of infectious 
diseases of dogs and cats
Disease diagnosis is a step-by-step rule out procedure in -
volving various analytical approaches to diagnose a dis -
ease. Diagnostic techniques are various methods which 
are used for diagnosing of a disease. Infectious diseases 
in dogs and cats are primarily caused by infectious agents 
like virus, bacteria, parasite, fungi, and rickettsial diseases. 
There are various diagnostic techniques which are broadly 
grouped under following categories according to clinical 
approaches:
1. Clinical pathological techniques
2. Microbiological techniques
3. Necropsy and histopathological techniques.
1 Clinical pathological techniques
Clinical pathological techniques are the first approach used 
for diagnosis of diseases. Examination of blood, serum, 
plasma, urine, and other body fluids collected from the clin-
ical cases of affected dogs and cats are the representative 
samples used for diagnosis. Following are the important ex-
aminations can performed under this:
 (i) Hematological examination
 (ii) Biochemical examination
 (iii) Urine examination
 (iv) Cytological examination.
(1) Hematological examination: It includes parameters re -
lated to complete blood count (CBC), RBCs, WBCs, 
and platelets. RBC parameters include hemoglobin, 
total erythrocytes count, pack cell volume, erythrocytic 
indices: MCH, MCV , and MCHC.
2 Microbiological techniques
This section include isolation and culturing of bacteria, 
 virus and fungus etc.
3 Necropsy and histopathological 
technique
This section discusses postmortem examination of carcass 
and microscopic examination of tissue.
4 Diagnostic interpretation of common 
diseases in dogs and cats
4.1 Bacterial diseases
a. Brucellosis: Bacterial disease of dog caused by B. canis.
■ Hematologic and biochemical values are either unal-
tered or nonspecific in canine brucellosis.
■ Hyperglobulinemia (β and γ) with concomitant hy -
poalbuminemia has been the most consistent finding 
in chronically infected dogs.
■ Examination of aspirates or biopsy samples from en-
larged lymph nodes usually reveals lymphoid hyper-
plasia with large numbers of plasma cells. Abortion 
noticed in bitches after 50 days of gestation. Male 
dog showed Orchitis and Epididymitis. Aborted foe-
tus showed bronchopneumonia.
■ Cerebrospinal fluid analysis results are pleocytosis, 
primarily consisting of neutrophils, and increased 
protein concentration with meningoencephalitis, but 
they are unremarkable when diskospondylitis alone 
is present:
b. Leptospirosis: Bacterial disease.
■ Hematologic findings in typical cases of canine lepto-
spirosis include leukocytosis and thrombocytopenia.
■ Leukocyte counts fluctuate depending on the stage 
and severity of infection.
■ Leukopenia, common in the leptospiremic phase, 
develops into leukocytosis with a left shift. In later 
stages, white blood cell counts usually range from 
16,500 to 45,000 cells/μL.

582 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
■ Thrombocytopenia is often a prognostic manifesta -
tion of severe cases of leptospirosis, and the degree 
correlates with the severity of respiratory distress 
and radiographic pulmonary changes.
■ Anemia of mild severity is often observed in dogs 
with leptospirosis. It is usually nonregenerative, 
which may reflect: the presence of acute oliguric 
renal failure with over hydration; decreased erythro-
cyte production from chronic renal failure or chronic 
inflammatory disease; or acute (less than 4-day dura-
tion blood loss from tissue thrombosis and/or acute 
pulmonary or GI hemorrhage).
■ The majority of dogs with leptospirosis are azotemic 
on initial examination. Increases in serum urea nitro-
gen and creatinine concentrations are found in dogs 
with varying severity of kidney disease.
■ Hypoalbuminemia can be observed, * (likely from 
proteinuria or SIRS), and the serum albumin:globulin 
ratio is usually reduced.
■ Hyponatremia, hypochloremia, hypokalemia, and 
hyperphosphatemia are present in most cases, 
whereas hyperkalemia develops only in dogs with 
terminal oliguric renal failure.
■ Hypoglycemia is occasionally present with severe he-
patic failure. Hepatic dysfunction may be apparent in 
some dogs, but it usually is less dramatic than renal 
failure or is associated with concurrent renal failure. 
Liver damage is demonstrated by increased serum 
alanine aminotransferase, aspartate aminotransferase, 
lactate dehydrogenase, and alkaline phosphatase activ-
ities and bilirubin concentration. The increase in serum 
alkaline phosphatase activity is often proportionally 
greater than that of alanine aminotransferase activity.
■ Bilirubin concentration may be increased in serum 
and urine, and the magnitude is usually proportional 
to the degree of liver impairment and is a very com-
mon finding. Marked bilirubinuria usually precedes 
hyperbilirubinemia.
■ Serum bilirubin peaks by days 6–8 after onset of dis-
ease. Increased sulfobromophthalein retention (more 
than 5%) can be found in acute leptospirosis before 
the onset of icterus and in dogs that later develop 
chronic active hepatitis.
■ Increased serum amylase and lipase activities may re-
sult from their release from inflamed hepatic and small 
intestinal tissues and from decreased renal excretion.
■ Increased serum amylase and lipase activities and in-
creased pancreatic lipase immunoreactivity are found 
in some dogs with apparent secondary pancreatitis.
■ Serum cardiac troponin concentrations have been 
increased in some dogs, suggesting myocardial 
damage.
■ Serum creatine kinase activity is increased when 
skeletal muscle inflammation occurs.
■ Urinalysis is very often characterized by glycosuria, 
tubular or glomerular proteinuria, and bilirubinuria 
and, in some cases, by increased numbers of granular 
casts, leukocytes, and erythrocytes in the sediment.
■ Some dogs have an increased ratio of protein to 
creatinine in their urine in the presence of a low-  
cellularity urinary sediment, which indicates the 
kidney as the source of the urine protein.
■ The concurrent presence of glycosuria or casts with 
proteinuria can be explained by acute tubular injury.
■ Findings of predominantly low- and sometimes 
high-molecular weight urine proteins are compatible 
with tubular and glomerular sources, respectively, 
although glomerular pathology is not a primary fea -
ture of leptospirosis, which is predominantly a tubu-
lointerstitial nephritis.
c. Actinomycosis
■ Animals with extensive chronic disease have mild-to-
moderate nonregenerative anemia, leukocytosis with 
a mild-to-moderate left shift and monocytosis, hy -
poalbuminemia, and hyperglobulinemia, which may 
be marked. Pleuritis, peritonitis, visceral abcess and 
arthritis commonly observed in affected animals.
d. Mycobacterium infections
■ Clinical laboratory findings in mycobacterial infec -
tions are frequently nonspecific and include moder -
ate leukocytosis and anemia.
■ The anemia, which is usually nonregenerative, is 
reportedly macrocytic in some cats with intestinal 
infections.
■ Normal-to-reduced serum albumin levels and hyper-
globulinemia are frequently apparent.
■ Hypercalcemia may be present as a result of the 
granulomatous inflammation as observed in other 
mycobacterial infections.
■ With MAC infection, dogs have had anemia, leu -
kocytosis, lymphopenia, hypoalbuminemia, and in -
creased liver enzyme activities.
■ Cats typically have anemia, neutrophilic leukocyto -
sis, and hyperglobulinemia.
e. Nocardia infection (Nocardiosis)
■ Animals with nocardiosis often have nonregen -
erative anemia, neutrophilic leukocytosis with a 
left shift, monocytosis, and sometimes marked 
hyper glo  bulinemia.
■ Hypercalcemia associated with granulomatous dis -
ease has been reported.
4.2 Viral diseases
4.2.1 Canine distemper
● Catarrhal or purulent exudate is present on the nasal 
and pharyngeal mucosa. Pururlent bronchopneumia is 
a prominent feature noted in animals. Hyperkeratosis

in foot pad. Conjuctivitis and encephalitis may also be 
observed. Abnormal hematologic findings include an 
absolute lymphopenia caused by lymphoid depletion. 
This frequently persists in very young dogs with rapidly 
progressive systemic or neurologic signs.
● Thrombocytopenia (as low as 30,000 cells/ μL) and re -
generative anemia have been found in experimentally 
infected neonates (aged less than 3  weeks) but have not 
been consistently recognized in older or spontaneously 
infected dogs.
● Intracytoplasmic or intranuclear inclusion bodies 
detected in desqumated cells of exudates. Intracyto -
plasmic distemper inclusions can be detected in the 
early phase of disease by examination of stained pe -
ripheral blood films, in some circulating neutrophils 
of affected dogs and less often in circulating lympho -
cytes, and with even less frequency in monocytes, and 
erythrocytes.
● Wright-Leishman-stained inclusions in lymphocytes are 
large (up to 3 μm), single, oval, gray structures, whereas 
erythrocytic inclusions (which are most numerous in 
polychromatophilic cells) are round and eccentrically 
placed and appear light blue.
● The sizes of erythrocytic inclusions are between those 
of metarubricyte nuclei and Howell-Jolly bodies.
● The magnitude and type of serum biochemistry changes 
in acute systemic infections are nonspecific.
● Total protein analysis includes decreased albumin and in-
creased α- and γ-globulin concentrations in non-neonates.
● Some puppies infected prenatally or neonatally with 
CDV have marked hypoglobulinemia from persistent 
immunosuppression caused by the virus.
Rabies (Hydrophobia/Lyssa/Rage)
● Diagnosis of rabies is based on symptoms if they are 
typical. No hematologic or serum biochemical changes 
are characteristic or specific for rabies.
● Biochemical changes in CSF have been minimal in 
experimentally infected dogs and have been rarely re -
ported in natural infections.
● Increased CSF protein (110–150  mg/dL) and leuko -
cytes (120–1140 cells/ μ L), with small lymphocytes 
predominating, have been reported in dogs with post -
vaccinal rabies encephalomyelitis. Fluorescent antibody 
test (FAT) on impression smears from the brain prefer -
able hippocampus, medulla oblongata and cerebellum. 
Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies (Negri bodies) are 
observed in tissue section too.
● Feline panleukopenia: This disease is fatal febrile dis -
ease of feline, characterized by severe panleukopaenia, 
agraulocytosis, and intranuclear inclusion bodies in epi-
thelial of small intestine.
● Canine parvovirus 2: Cardiac form observed in pup -
pies of 2-8  weeks of age, with sudden death due to 
myocardial necrosis. Intestinal form observed in all 
age groups and is cahracterized by vomition, haem -
orrhagic and necrotic enteritis with leukopaenia. 
Intranuclear inclusion bodies are found in intestinal 
epithelial cells.
Infectious canine hepatitis:
● Early hematologic findings in ICH include leukopenia 
with lymphopenia and neutropenia.
● Neutrophilia and lymphocytosis occur later in dogs with 
uncomplicated clinical recovery.
● An increased number of dark-staining (activated) lym -
phocytes and nucleated erythrocytes may be found.
● Serum protein alterations, detectable only on serum 
electrophoresis, are a transient increase in α 2-globulin 
by 7  days postinoculation and by a delayed increase 
in γ-globulin, which peaks 21-day postinoculation. 
Albuminuria recorded in affected dogs. Elevated SGPT 
and SGOT level. Intranuclear inclusion bodies in tonsils 
and liver biopsy.
4.3 Fungal diseases
● Microsporum canis:  Ring worm, commonly seen in 
dogs and cats. Wood’s light- ultraviolet light in dark -
ened room, making it possible to recognize the mild 
infection.
● Blastomycosis
● On preliminary laboratory evaluation, a mild normo -
cytic, normochromic anemia develops that can be attrib-
uted to chronic inflammation.
● Most dogs have a moderate leukocytosis (17,000–30,000 
white blood cell count per microliter) with a mild left 
shift, and lymphopenia is common.
● They usually have hyperglobulinemia and hypoalbumin-
emia. The increased globulin concentrations are caused 
by an increase in α2-globulin and a polyclonal increase 
in immunoglobulins.
● The only other biochemical change that may be seen is 
hypercalcemia of granulomatous disease.
● Coccidiomycosis
● Hematologic changes may include mild nonregenerative 
anemia and moderate neutrophilic leukocytosis, often 
with a left shift and monocytosis.
● Eosinophilia of blood and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), 
common in human coccidioidomycosis, is quite variable 
in animals.
● Hyperglobulinemia and hypoalbuminemia are common, 
reflecting a chronic, persistent inflammatory disease.
● Hypercalcemia unassociated with bone lesions has not 
yet been described in affected dogs or cats, but has been 
found with other systemic mycoses and in some human 
patients.

584 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
● An osteotrophic factor similar to that causing humoral 
hypercalcemia of malignancy has been postulated.
● Cryptococcosis
● Changes in the complete blood cell count and chemis -
try panel in animals with cryptococcosis are generally 
nonspecific.
● Mild-to-moderate nonregenerative anemia; leukocyto -
sis, often with monocytosis; and eosinophilia have been 
reported as the most common findings.
● Dogs with severe disseminated disease may have a 
marked neutrophilia with a left shift.
● The serum biochemical profile may reflect specific or -
gan involvement in patients with disseminated disease.
● Histoplasmosis
● The most common hematologic abnormality in both 
dogs and cats with disseminated histoplasmosis is nor -
mocytic, normochromic, nonregenerative anemia.
● The anemia probably results from chronic inflammatory 
disease, Histoplasma infection of the bone marrow, and 
intestinal blood loss in GI disease.
● Thrombocytopenia may be observed in as many 
as one-half of dogs and one-third of cats with 
histoplasmosis.
● Leukocyte counts are variable. Neutrophilic leukocy -
tosis with monocytosis and eosinopenia is found most 
frequently.
● Leukopenia has also been reported. In a survey of neu -
tropenic dogs, histoplasmosis was associated as a risk 
factor.
● Severe pancytopenia has been observed in some cats; no 
hematologic abnormalities were identified in others.
● Histoplasma organisms may be found during routine 
blood film examination in circulating monocytes, neu -
trophils, and, rarely, eosinophils.
● Performing 1000-cell differential counts or examining 
buffy coat smears will enhance detection of infected 
cells.
● Biochemical profiles are usually unremarkable in dogs 
with pulmonary histoplasmosis.
● Hypoalbuminemia is a fairly consistent finding in cats 
with disseminated histoplasmosis.
● Some cats have had hyperproteinemia, hyperglobulin -
emia, mild hyperglycemia or hyperbilirubinemia, and 
elevations of alanine aminotransferase activities.
● Dogs with disseminated disease may have hypopro -
teinemia with severe hypoalbuminemia as a result of 
intestinal blood loss or protein losing enteropathy. 
Involvement of the liver in affected dogs may cause 
hypoalbuminemia; hyperbilirubinemia; elevated serum 
alanine aminotransferase, aspartate aminotransferase, 
and/or alkaline phosphatase activities; and abnormal re-
sults on liver function tests.
● Hypercalcemia (probably associated with granuloma -
tous disease) has been reported in several cats.
4.4 Other diseases
● Salmon disease of dogs: Disease is associated with in-
gestion of salmon, trout and other fish. Suffered dogs 
showed anorexia, vomition diarrohea. Postmortem 
examination showed enlarged lymphnode and spleen 
along with elementary bodies in reticulo-endothelial 
cells.
● Canine ehrlichiosis
● In the acute phase, typical hematologic abnormalities 
include a characteristic moderate-to-severe thrombocy -
topenia, a mild anemia, and leukopenia.
● The thrombocytopenia is the hallmark of the acute stage 
and is characterized by megathrombocytosis.
● The chronic form of is characterized by bone marrow 
hypoplasia and impairment of all bone marrow cells, 
thus resulting in pancytopenia.
● Granular lymphocytosis has been recognized as an oc -
casional feature of E. canis infection.
● Affected dogs had absolute lymphocyte counts ranging 
from 5200 to 17,200 cells/μL with cytoplasmic granular-
ity typical of well-differentiated lymphocytic leukemia.
● The most frequent serum chemistry abnormalities in -
clude hyperproteinemia, hyperglobulinemia, hypoal -
buminemia, and elevated alanine aminotransferase and 
alkaline phosphatase activities.

4.6 Dogs
● Hematologic changes during the course of infection in -

elevated mean corpuscular volume.
● The blood leukocyte count often decreases with neutro-

4.7 Cats
● Infected cats developed mild-to-moderate reductions in 
erythrocyte count, hematocrit, and hemoglobin concen-
tration, with increases in circulating reticulocyte counts 
and reductions in the myeloid-to-erythroid ratio on bone 
marrow examination.
● Increased concentrations of serum total protein and 
globulins with decreased albumin concentrations were 
observed.
● Increased globulin concentrations were attributed to in -
creases in α-2 globulin, β-globulin, and γ-globulin con-
centrations through the course of illness.
● Serum muscle enzyme activities (aspartate aminotrans -
ferase and CK) were increased.
● Alterations in serum metal concentrations, blood, 
plasma, and brain cholinesterase activities, and plasma 
and erythrocyte lipid peroxidation were also found.
a. Coccidiosis
b. Neosporosis
● Hematologic and biochemical findings have 
been variable, depending on the organ system of 
involvement.
● With muscle disease, CK and aspartate aminotrans -
ferase activities have been increased. Serum ALT 
and alkaline phosphatase activities are increased in 
dogs that develop hepatic inflammation.
● CSF abnormalities have included mild increases in 
protein (over 20 but under 150  mg/dL) and nucle -

numbers, included lymphocytes, monocytes and 
macrophages, neutrophils, and eosinophils. Thus, 
mononuclear cells seem to predominate.
● CSF analysis results can be within reference limits in 
some dogs.
● Eosinophilic pleocytosis has been observed in rare 
instances in dogs when N. caninum is present.
c. Toxoplasmosis
● Toxoplasmosis gondii infection
■ Routine hematologic and biochemical parameters 
may be abnormal in cats and dogs with acute sys-
temic toxoplasmosis.
■ Nonregenerative anemia, neutrophilic leukocyto -
sis, lymphocytosis, monocytosis, and eosinophilia 
are most commonly observed.
■ Leukopenia of severely affected cats may per -
sist until death and is usually characterized by 
an absolute lymphopenia and neutropenia with 
an inappropriate left shift, eosinopenia, and 
monocytopenia.
■ Biochemical abnormalities during the acute phase 
of illness include hypoproteinemia and hypoalbu-
minemia. Hyperglobulinemia has been detected in 
some cats with chronic toxoplasmosis.
■ Marked increases in serum alanine aminotransfer-
ase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase activi -
ties have been noted in animals with acute hepatic 
and muscle necrosis.
■ Dogs generally have increased serum ALT and al-
kaline phosphatase activities with hepatic necro -
sis, but this occurs less frequently in cats.
■ Serum creatine kinase (CK) activity is also in -
creased in cases of muscle necrosis.
■ Serum bilirubin levels have been increased in 
animals with acute hepatic necrosis, especially 
cats that develop cholangiohepatitis or hepatic 
lipidosis.
■ Cats or dogs that develop pancreatitis may show 
increased serum amylase and lipase activities, al -
though these are inconsistent.
■ Cats often show proteinuria and bilirubinuria.
■ Cats with pancreatitis may have reduced se -
rum total calcium with normal serum albumin 
concentrations
d. Babesiosis
● In dogs:
■ B. canis
■ B. gibsoni
● The clinical pathologic changes of babesiosis 
are nonspecific; the primary hematologic ab -
normalities are anemia and thrombocytopenia.
● The prevalence of thrombocytopenia is higher 
than that in dogs with ehrlichiosis, and throm -
bocytopenia is generally a feature of canine 
babesiosis, regardless of whether concurrent 
anemia is present.
● A mild, normocytic, normochromic anemia is 
generally noted in the first few days after infec-
tion, and the anemia then becomes macrocytic, 
hypochromic, and regenerative as the disease 
progresses.
● Leukocyte abnormalities are inconsistently ob-
served but may include leukocytosis (with or 
without a left shift), neutrophilia, neutropenia, 
lymphocytosis, eosinophilia, or leukopenia.

● There are no pathognomonic biochemical or

● Common biochemical findings observed in 
North American dogs with babesiosis in -
clude hyperglobulinemia and mildly increased 
liver enzyme activities and less commonly 
hyperbilirubinemia.
● Urinalysis abnormalities may include bilirubi -
nuria, hemoglobinuria, proteinuria, and, in rare 
cases, granular casts.
● Hypokalemia may be found in severely af -

● In cats
■ B. felis
● In feline babesiosis, which is caused by B. felis, 
the anemia is typically macrocytic, hypochro -

● No characteristic change in total or differential 
leukocyte counts occurs, and thrombocytopenia 
is an inconsistent finding.
● Cats infected with B. felis typically have elevated 
serum hepatic aminotransferase enzyme activity 
and total bilirubin concentrations.
● Serum protein values are usually within reference

occur.
● Renal parameters are unaffected. Although vari -
ous electrolyte abnormalities were reported, no 
consistent pattern has been found.

Chapter 40
One Health approach of infectious 
diseases of dogs and cats
1 Introduction
A One Health approach considers how changing environ -
ments play a part in the risks of infectious and chronic dis -
eases that affect both people and nonhuman animals. One 
Health philosophy has been validated by recent cases of sick-
ness onset (Daszak et al., 2013). The expanding detrimental 
effects of zoonotic infections (those transmitted from animals 
to people) on both human and animal health have been made 
public by recent global disease outbreaks. Additionally, it is 
now well established that environmental changes, such as 
population expansion, agricultural intensification, climate 
change, and human encroachment on wildlife habitats, are 
the primary drivers of the introduction of many zoonotic ill-
nesses (Woolhouse and Gowtage-Sequeria, 2005).
The number of people is growing and settling in new 
areas. As a result, more people today have pets, livestock, 
and other domestic, wild animals living with them. Animals 
play a significant role in our life, whether it's for compan -
ionship, food, fiber, livelihoods, travel, sport, or education. 
When animals and humans come into close contact, there is 
a higher chance that diseases will be transmitted from one 
to the other. In addition, the earth's climate has changed as a 
result of land use practices including intensive farming and 
deforestation. International trade and travel have increased 
the movement of people, animals, and animal products, 
which can open up new opportunities for diseases to spread 
to animals. Therefore, diseases can quickly spread across 
international borders and around the globe. These changes 
have caused endemic and newly emerging zoonotic diseases 
to spread more widely. Zoonotic diseases afflict millions of 
people and animals annually all over the world (Fig. 1).
These zoonotic diseases caused by dogs include:
● Ringworm
● Salmonellosis
● Leptospirosis
● Lyme disease
● Campylobacter infection
● Giardia infection
● Cryptosporidium infection
● Roundworms
● Hookworms
● Tapeworms
● Scabies
● Harvest mites
● Rabies
Rabies, caused by Lyssa virus, is almost invariably fatal in 
humans. Certain infectious organisms, such as the bacteria 
Salmonella and Campylobacter and the protozoan disease 
caused by Giardia, can cause severe gastroenteritis. 
Leptospirosis, known as Weil's disease in people, can 
cause extremely serious liver and kidney disease but the 
transmission from dogs to humans is rare. Humans usually 
contract this disease from exposure to contaminated water.
Roundworms ( Toxocara canis ) and tapeworms 
(Echinococcus species) can cause liver problems, but illness 
in people from these causes is rare. Direct handling of in -
fected dog feces can potentially cause an infection of round-
worms in a susceptible person. Echinococcus tapeworm 
infections are starting to become more common in areas of 
Canada and the United States where they had not been rec-
ognized before (see handout “Echinococcosis in Dogs” for 
more information on this disease). Transmission to humans 
can result from ingestion of eggs released in an infected 
dog’s feces.
Zoonotic skin diseases including ringworm, caused 
by the fungus Microsporum canis and scabies, caused by 
the mite Sarcoptes scabiei, Cheyletiella mites, and harvest 
mites (Trombicula species) are transmitted relatively easily 
to people through direct physical contact.

588 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
2 Bordetella bronchiseptica
Bordetella bronchiseptica, a gram-negative rod-shaped bac-
teria, belong to the genus Bordetella and cause bronchitis. 
Animals with upper respiratory infections, such as dogs and 
cats, frequently carry the infection, which is transmitted to 
people by aerosol. Canines that have B. bronchiseptica can 
develop acute tracheobronchitis, which presents as a raspy, 
kennel cough-like cough. Although B. bronchiseptica infec-
tions in humans are relatively rare, pneumonia and upper 
respiratory infections can occur in dog owners who have 
the bacterium ( Ner et  al., 2003 ). This organism has been 
shown to be resistant to cephalosporins and macrolides, but 
multiple studies have shown that it is sensitive to fluoro -
quinolones and trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole ( Egberink 
et al., 2009).
3 Brucella
It is frequently spread to people by eating unpasteurized 
dairy products. Many Brucella species have been identi -
fied, including B. melitensis, B. abortus, and B. suis, which 
caused human brucellosis. However, B. canis has received 
less attention as a common pathogen in human brucellosis 
infections (Seleem et al., 2010). Despite the fact that B. canis 
is not the cause of brucellosis in people, farmer populations 
that had a history of exposure to B. canis-infected canine 
bodily fluids were more frequently the target of reported 
cases. The incubation phase may continue for a few months 
or 1–4 weeks (Lucero et al., 2010).
In the endemic zone, the individuals may be asymptom-
atic or even exhibit severe clinical signs, such as fever, night 
sweats, and low back pain, which should be distinguished 
from tuberculosis and other cancers ( Hasanjani Roushan 
et al., 2004). In order to prevent the disease's consequences 
and after effects, brucellosis should be treated. Combination 
therapies, which are frequently used to treat brucellosis, in-
volved taking doxycycline along with either streptomycin 
or rifampin for 6 weeks (Table 1) (Pappas et al., 2005).
4 Campylobacter
Gram-negative bacteria called Campylobacter spp., notably 
Campylobacter jejuni and Campylobacter coli, commonly 
cause Campylobacter enteritis. This bacterium typically 
dwells in the digestive tracts of several mammals. The 
main way that Campylobacter is spread is through direct 
contact with diseased animals or their products. The main 
Campylobacter reservoirs are dogs and puppies. For in -
stance, a research found that Campylobacter was isolated 
from roughly 47% of the dog fecal sample ( Janda et  al., 
2006). Campylobacter enteritis has an incubation period 
of one to seven days. The majority of patients have fever, 
nausea, diarrhea, and stomach pain. Also, more than 50% 
of the infected patients may have bloody diarrhea. In some 
cases, convulsion and seizures may be seen ( Gazaigne 
et al., 2008). This illness typically resolves on its own and 
does not require antibiotic treatment. Consideration should 
be given to hydration and electrolyte balance correction. 
In individuals with severe illness, fluoroquinolone, macro -
lide, or aminoglycoside, antibiotic therapy is recommended 
(Ternhag et al., 2007).
5 Capnocytophaga
The oropharyngeal tract of dogs and cats normally con -
tains the gram-negative bacterium Capnocytophaga cani -
morsus. The pathogen, which primarily infects humans 
through dog bites, can result in a severe sepsis, especially 
in old, immunocompromised, or asplenic patients. The 
pathogen can also cause meningitis, osteomyelitis, arthritis, 
lung abscess or empyema, and endocarditis, all of which 
are deadly illnesses. Additionally, particularly in people

One Health approach of infectious diseases  Chapter | 40  589
with impaired immune systems, hemolytic uremic syn -
drome and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura can be 
linked to Capnocytophaga septicemia. The data from the 
literature have shown that the estimated mortality rate from 
Capnocytophaga septicemia is one-third of the infected pa-
tients. Therefore, third-generation cephalosporins should 
be used as early empirical therapy in individuals who have 
been bitten by a dog (Jolivet-Gougeon et al., 2007).
6 Coxiella burnetii
Humans get Q fever from the obligatory intracellular gram-
negative bacteria C. burnetii. Normally, the disease spreads 
to people by aerosols and direct contact with the bodily flu-
ids of infected animals. Despite the fact that dogs are not the 
primary carriers of C. burnetii, a study showed that about 
10% of farm dogs carried the pathogen ( Cosman et  al., 
2013). In addition, C. burnetii was found to be transferrable 
from an infected parturient dog to a human in a different 
investigation by Buhariwalla and colleagues. The patients 
also experienced the Q fever symptoms of fever, chills, 
nausea, vomiting, and a strong cough. In chest radiography, 
opacity is a frequent finding, and during auscultation during 
a physical examination, crackles may be audible. According 
to this investigation, the incubation period lasted between 
8 and 12 days following contact with the diseased animal. 
Fluoroquinolones or doxycycline are effective treatments 
for C. burnetii patients (Patel et al., 2011).
7 Rabies
The single-strand RNA virus that causes rabies is a mem -
ber of the Rhabdoviridae family. An old illness with a high 
fatality rate in both the human and animal populations is 
rabies infection. According to World Health Organization 
data, rabies infection causes between 30,000 and 70,000 
deaths globally each year ( Krebs et  al., 2004 ). The ma -
jority of rabies infections in animals are carried by dogs. 
While raccoons, bats, and foxes are the main sources of 
rabies transmission in industrialized countries, the major -
ity of infected people in underdeveloped countries contract 
the disease from dog bites. In a US study, a rabies control 
campaign was carried out by heavily immunizing house -
hold dogs and lowering the rabies infection. Depending on 
the site of the inoculating wound and the quantity of gen -
erated viruses, the incubation period for rabies can range 
from 4 days to several years. Agitation, anxiety, confusion, 
hallucinations, and hydrophobia are possible symptoms in 
patients. Within 14  days of the suspected dog bite, post -
exposure treatment with repeated doses of human rabies 
immunoglobulin (HRIG) can prevent the disease. The like-
lihood of contracting rabies can be drastically decreased 
by washing the wound with water and liquid soap ( Lucas 
et al., 2007).
8 Noroviruses
A heterogeneous single-strand RNA virus in the 
Caliciviridae family, noroviruses cause contagious diseases. 
Human sporadic and epidemic gastroenteritis is primarily 
brought on by noroviruses ( Summa et al., 2012 ). Humans 
of any age can be impacted by this virus. The virus can 
be discovered in the digestive system, and as a result, can 
be found in the feces or diarrhea of the affected canines. 
Humans can contract it from tainted food or water, and the 
infection spreads quickly among people due to fecal-oral 
route. Patients with acute gastroenteritis should think about 
receiving serum treatment (Wolf et al., 2009).
9 Leptospira
Leptospirosis in humans is mostly brought on by aerobic 
spirochete L. interrogans . Leptospirosis is a widespread 
zoonosis that is mostly spread to people via polluted en -
vironmental sources, such as contaminated soil, water, 
urine, or animal tissue. However, domestic animals, such as 
dogs, can play a significant role in leptospirosis transmis -
sion in endemic locations. Rodents are the main reservoirs 
for leptospirosis ( Moore et al., 2006 ). The primary routes 
of leptospirosis transmission involve mucosal surfaces of 
the human body, such as the eye, vagina, nose, mouth, or 
erosive lesions, which come into direct touch with contami-
nated urine. This infection typically takes around 10 days to 
incubate (ranging from 2 to 26 days). Numerous symptoms 
including fever, nonproductive cough, headache, muscu -
loskeletal discomfort, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, alveolar 
hemorrhage, and even meningitis, can accompany leptospi-
rosis (Sehgal, 2006). Doxycycline, ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, 
penicillin, amoxicillin, and ampicillin are a few antibiotics 
that have been successfully used to treat this disease (Fig. 2) 
(Kobayashi, 2001).
10 Methicillin resistance Staphylococcus 
aureus
Methicillin resistance Staphylococcus aureus  (MRSA) is 
a common cause of infection-related death in people. This 
pathogen has reportedly been isolated from a variety of ani-
mals, including pigs, horses, cattle, cats, and dogs, according 
to several studies. Some of them had the opinion that com -
panion animals were the primary carriers of MRSA, as they 
could pass the infection to their owners directly. However, 
it appears that patients with impaired immune systems are 
more likely to contract MRSA from animals. However, 
other data suggested that this bacterium could spread to 
healthy people who own an affected animal. Treatment of 
infections brought on by MRSA does not improve with 
the use of conventional antistaphylococcal drugs. As a re -
sult, modern medications like  vancomycin,  linezolid, and

590 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
daptomycin are frequently used to treat MRSA infections 
(Morgan, 2008).
11 Pasteurella
Pasteurella species are gram-negative coccobacilli found 
mostly in animals. Pasteurella spp. are common bacte -
ria found in the upper respiratory tracts of dogs and cats. 
Pasteurella infection can be passed on to humans through 
both direct and indirect contact, such as dog or cat bites or 
licks, and even cat scratches ( Oehler et al., 2009 ). This or-
ganism is responsible for several infectious diseases in hu -
mans. The most common infection caused by it is soft tissue 
infection, meningitis, bone and joint infections, and respi -
ratory infections. The author showed that Pasteurella spp. 
was the most common organism recovered from dog and 
cat bites in a prospective research conducted in the United 
States ( Talan et  al., 1999 ). Second- and third-  generation 
cephalosporins, macrolides, fluoroquinolones, cotrimoxa -
zole, and penicillin can all be used to treat Pasteurella in-
fections (Lloret et al., 2013).
12 Salmonella
Salmonella species are anaerobic, mobile, gram-negative 
bacilli that thrive in the large intestine of many animals, 
particularly in the canine's mesenteric lymph nodes and 
the distal portion of the colon. Several infectious illnesses, 
including gastroenteritis, enteric fever, bacteremia, and os -
teomyelitis, can also infect humans through the digestive 
system (fecal transmission). The most frequent clinical 
manifestations of Salmonella in humans and dogs are gas -
trointestinal illnesses; however, the majorities of infected 
animals or people are asymptomatic and can shed the virus 
through feces for up to 6 weeks, which allows it to spread 
to other animals or people. Salmonella species are more 
common in developing countries than they are in developed 
ones. Salmonella infections should be treated with antibiot-
ics from different families, such as fluoroquinolones, beta-
lactams, and macrolides. However, an antibiogram should 
be taken into consideration for people who have the infec -
tion (Leonard et al., 2011).
13 Staphylococcus intermedius
S. intermedius is a gram-positive, coagulase-producing bac-
teria that often resides in the front of the nasal cavity of 
a variety of species, including dogs, pigeons, and horses. 
According to recent research, this pathogen might also be 
isolated from healthy dogs' gingiva ( Hoekstra and Paulton, 
2002). Although S. intermedius is not a typical zoonotic dis-
ease that affects humans, studies have shown that it is a pos-
sible pathogen linked to dog bite wounds and that cellulitis 
can occur in patients. It's crucial to differentiate this bacte -
rium from Staphylococcus aureus. Effective treatments for 
this infection include penicillin and amoxicillin-clavulanate 
(Armstrong et al., 2004).
14 Yersinia enterocolitica
A gram-negative coccobacillus zoonotic pathogen called Y. 
enterocolitica causes yersiniosis in both humans and animals. 
Birds, pigs, deer, and cattle are a few of the major Y. entero-
colitica reservoirs. In some investigations, the pathogen was 
isolated from dog bite wound. When the pathogen invades 
the mucosal surface of the colon, patients may first show no 
symptoms. However, watery or bloody diarrhea may then ap-
pear. Additionally, the infection may involve Peyer's patches 
and exhibit symptoms of appendicitis ( Abdel-Haq et  al., 
2000). Most cases of Y. enterocolitica are self-limited and do 
not require antibiotic treatment; however, patients with severe 
infection and those who are immunocompromised should be 
treated with an aminoglycoside and doxycycline together.
15 Zoonotic diseases of cats
Infections caused by viruses, bacteria, fungi, protozoa, 
nematodes, or arthropods that can be spread to people by 
domestic cats, Felis catus. Some of these illnesses are in -
festations or re-emerging infections brought on by zoonotic 
pathogens spread by cats. The cat may occasionally show 
signs of infection and other times the cat may not show any 
symptoms. People who contract an infection may  experience 
severe diseases and clinical symptoms. This is based on the

person's age and immune system. These infections are more 
likely to affect people who live near cats. However, due to 
the transmission from cat excrement and other bodily se -
cretions, people who do not own cats as pets are equally 
susceptible to contracting these illnesses (Chomel, 2014).
Through cat bites, scratches, or other direct skin or mu-
cous membrane contact, people can contract cat-associated 
illnesses. This includes giving an animal a “kiss” or allow -
ing it to lick your mouth or nose. When the cat's mouth is 
exposed to the virus, mucous membranes are quickly af -
fected. When human contact is made with animal saliva, 
urine, or other bodily fluids or secretions, pathogens can 
also infect the human host. Infection may result from acci -
dentally ingesting fecal particles. An individual can contract 
a feline zoonosis by breathing in aerosols or droplets vom -
ited up by the cat (Stull et al., 2015).
Cats with certain infectious illnesses, including salmo -
nellosis and campylobacteriosis, exhibit outward signs of 
illness. Some illnesses, such toxoplasmosis and cat scratch 
disease, go undetected and are spread by cats that appear to 
be healthy.
16 Campylobacteriosis
Campylobacteriosis is a disease caused by the bacteria 
Campylobacter that can affect both humans and animals. 
People can contract Campylobacter infection through in -
gesting tainted food or water or by coming into contact 
with the feces (poop) of infected animals, including cats. 
Campylobacter can sometimes infect you through an open 
wound, but it usually spreads when individuals don't wash 
their hands after handling animals, food, feces, toys, or 
beds. Cats frequently contract the disease by consuming 
tainted raw meat, and they then excrete the bacteria in their 
feces.
Anyone can contract Campylobacter, but those under 
the age of 5, those over 65, and those with compromised 
immune systems are more likely to develop serious sick -
ness. Cats may seem healthy and exhibit no symptoms of 
Campylobacter infection, or they may have bloody diar -
rhea. Fever, stomach cramps, and diarrhea (frequently 
bloody) can all occur in people. V omiting and nausea may 
also be present along with the diarrhea. Typically, symp -
toms appear 2–5 days after infection and remain for around 
a week (Ohio Department of Health, 2015).
17 Cat scratch disease (Bartonella 
henselae)
Bartonella henselae and, less frequently, other Bartonella 
species are the bacteria that cause cat scratch disease 
(CSD). Cats can contract the disease from flea bites, blood 
transfusions, or fights with other affected cats. The germs 
can spread to people when they lick or scratch an infected 
cat. The bacteria are most likely to be present in young cats 
(under 1 year of age), stray or shelter cats, cats that are cur-
rently or have previously had flea infestations, and cats that 
hunt. Anyone can contract CSD, although those under the 
age of 15 and those with compromised immune systems are 
more likely to become ill than healthy individuals.
Cats have been exposed to the germs between one-third 
and 50% of the time. Even while the majority of infected 
cats do not show symptoms, some cats may have a mod -
erate sickness with a temperature that lasts for around 
2–3  days. Rarely, the illness can make cats exhibit more 
severe symptoms like vomiting, red eyes, enlarged lymph 
nodes, exhaustion, and/or decreased appetite. Compared to 
cats, Bartonella infection in dogs is less common but more 
likely to result in sickness.
The CSD bacteria may cause a mild infection with 
a small, raised, solid bump at the site of the scratch and 
lymph node swelling near the site of the scratch. This oc -
curs 1–3 weeks after exposure (e.g., a cat scratch or lick). 
The infection can also cause fever, and less commonly eye 
infection, muscle pain, or more severe symptoms.
18 Cat tapeworm (Dipylidium caninum)
The cat tapeworm is a parasite transferred to dogs, cats, and 
people through the consumption of infected fleas. Although 
this parasite is widespread in cats, it rarely makes pets or 
people sick. When a cat or person swallows an infected flea, 
the tapeworm is disseminated. When cats brush themselves, 
fleas may be ingested. Pet flea treatment can assist avoid 
infection. Being infected by this tapeworm requires swal -
lowing a flea, thus the chance of contracting it is incredibly 
rare. The majority of cases involve kids.
In most cases, cats are not harmed by tapeworms, and 
they rarely make them sick. Sometimes the parasite can be 
identified by looking for tapeworm segments that resem -
ble rice crawling close to the anus or in recently excreted 
feces. A dog may lose weight if it has a severe infection. 
People seldom get Dipylidium  infections, which typically 
have no symptoms. The presence of tapeworm segments 
that resemble rice crawling close to the anus or in recently 
excreted matter might occasionally serve as a sign of this 
disease.
19 Cryptosporidiosis (Cryptosporidium 
spp.)
The parasite Cryptosporidium, also known as Crypto for 
short, is the source of the sickness known as cryptosporidi-
osis, which is contracted by unintentionally ingesting an 
infected person's or animal's feces. Following contact with 
an infected person or animal, crypto is spread by eating 
stool carrying the germ or by poop in contaminated food or 
water. For instance, ingesting potable water for recreation,

592 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
 consuming unclean water from a lake or river, or touching 
their mouth after handling an infected animal can all result 
in Crypto infection?
Anyone can contract Crypto, but those with compro -
mised immune systems are more vulnerable, especially to 
severe illness. Although it is uncommon, cats might occa -
sionally carry the parasite without displaying any symptoms 
of sickness. Constant, watery diarrhea with cramps, nausea, 
vomiting, and abdominal discomfort are some symptoms. 
Usually, the symptoms resolve after 1–2 weeks.
20 Giardiasis (Giardia duodenalis)
Giardia is a parasite that can be found on surfaces, in food, 
water, or soil that has come into contact with human or ani-
mal waste. Giardia is spread by drinking contaminated wa-
ter or eating contaminated food that has been contaminated 
with the parasite's tiny excrement after coming into touch 
with an infected person or animal. Giardia can be con -
tracted from cats with very little risk. Typically, the specific 
strain of Giardia that sickens humans is not the same one 
that affects cats. Giardia can affect everyone, although the 
following populations are at higher risk:
● individuals who travel internationally;
● those who come into touch with young toddlers wearing 
diapers;
● those who engage in sexual activity with a Giardia-
infected person;
● individuals who consume untreated water from a spring, 
lake, river, or other natural water source.
Giardia-infected cats may experience diarrhea, oily feces, 
or dehydration. Giardia can cause nausea, vomiting, ab -
dominal pain, diarrhea, gas, and other symptoms. It is possi-
ble to be infected, nevertheless, yet not show any symptoms 
of sickness. 
21 Hookworm (Ancylostoma 
tubaeforme, Ancylostoma braziliense, 
Uncinaria stenocephala)
Small worms called hookworms can spread when they 
come into touch with contaminated sand or soil. People can 
contract hookworm illness by sitting, kneeling, or walking 
barefoot on ground that has been contaminated with ani -
mal feces. Cats can contract the parasite by consuming it in 
the environment or through the milk or colostrum of their 
mothers.
A hookworm infection can affect anyone. Hookworm 
infections in kittens can be fatal, and they can also result 
in anemia and weight loss. When a person has hookworm 
infection, they may develop an itching reaction and develop 
a red squiggly line where the parasite larvae have moved 
under the skin. Animal hookworms do not survive in an in-
fected person, in contrast to human hookworms, therefore 
symptoms usually go away on their own in 4–6 weeks with-
out the need for medical attention.
22 MRSA (methicillin-resistant 
Staphylococcus aureus)
Common bacteria like Staphylococcus aureus are typically 
found on both human and animal skin. MRSA is a strain 
of Staphylococcus aureus that has developed an antibiotic 
resistance. Skin infections, pneumonia (lung infections), 
and other illnesses can all be brought on by MRSA. Direct 
interaction between humans and animals can result in the 
transmission of MRSA (touching). MRSA can be carried by 
cats who are healthy and transferred to people.
A MRSA infection can strike anyone. Although skin, 
respiratory, and urinary tract infections are all common in 
cats, MRSA infection is not always visible in them. The 
majority of MRSA carriers do not exhibit any symptoms. 
The most typical form of MRSA infection in people is a 
cutaneous infection. Rarely can MRSA spread to the lungs 
or bloodstream and become life-threatening if untreated.
23 Plague (Yersinia pestis)
Yersinia pestis, a bacterium that may infect humans and 
animals, is what causes the plague. Fleas can spread the 
infection to rats and other small animals in the western 
United States. People and animals (dogs and cats) that are 
bitten by infected fleas are at risk. Cats and dogs are both 
capable of contracting the plague and passing it on to peo -
ple. The majority of flea-related illnesses affect both hu -
mans and animals; however, contact with animals that have 
the plague can also make people ill. A sick cat's coughing 
up infectious droplets into the air can also expose people 
to the disease.
Travelers and residents of rural areas, may be at risk. 
Additionally, those who have animal contact (such as 
those who sleep with pets) and hunters may be in danger. 
Particularly vulnerable to the pandemic are cats. Fevers, 
poor appetites, lack of energy, and swollen lymph nodes on 
their necks that can resemble wounds are some of the symp-
toms of plague in cats. Cats who have plague pneumonia 
may cough or have breathing problems.
To lower the risk of human illness, owners should limit 
human contact with sick pets and seek veterinarian care as 
soon as possible. The most prevalent type of plague among 
humans is bubonic. Bubonic plague symptoms include 
painful, enlarged lymph nodes, high fever that appears out 
of nowhere, chills, headache, and weakness. More severe 
symptoms may result from other types of plague, such as 
septicemic plague and plague pneumonia.

One Health approach of infectious diseases  Chapter | 40  593
24 Rabies
Cat owners should get cats vaccinated against rabies. Rabies 
spreads through contact with saliva or brain/nervous system 
tissue from an infected animal, usually through scratches or 
bites. Rabies is a prevalent disease in India in both wild and 
domestic animals.
Progressive paralysis and abrupt behavioral changes 
are frequent in cats with rabies. Additionally, they might 
be agitated, pant, or they might even attack other animals, 
humans, or things. Usually, rabies symptoms in animals are 
followed by death within a few days. People can develop 
rabies symptoms days to months after exposure. If a person 
has been bitten by a cat, there should be immediate washing 
of the wound followed by post bite vaccination.
25 Ringworm
Ringworm is an infection brought on by a fungus that can 
affect both human and animal skin, hair, and nails. Direct 
physical contact (touching) with an animal or human who 
has ringworm or environmental exposure are the two ways 
that it spreads. Ringworm can affect anyone. While some 
cats with ringworm infections may not exhibit any symp -
toms, others frequently develop small patches of scaly or 
crusty skin and hair loss around their ears, faces, or legs. 
The most frequent victims are kittens.
People who have ringworm infections often have itchy 
skin, which can happen anywhere on the body. The skin 
may become red, scale, crack, or develop a ring-shaped 
rash. Hair loss may occur whether the infection is on the 
beard or the scalp. Infected nails may develop a discolor -
ation, grow thick, or collapse.
26 Roundworms (Toxocara spp.)
Toxocariasis is an infection that is brought on by round -
worm, a parasite. Cats' intestines frequently contain round-
worms. In their feces, cats excrete roundworm eggs. By 
ingesting roundworm eggs from the environment, such as 
dirt tainted with cat excrement, people and cats are sus -
ceptible to developing roundworms. Roundworms are con-
tagious and can infect anyone. The majority of the time, 
kittens do not appear unwell, but those that do may exhibit 
signs such as minor diarrhea, dehydration, a rough coat, and 
a pot-bellied appearance.
There are two types of illness associated with round -
worms in people. Ocular toxocariasis happens when round-
worm larvae migrate to the eye and can cause vision loss, 
eye inflammation, or damage to the retina. Typically, only 
one eye is affected. Visceral toxocariasis happens when the 
roundworm larvae migrate to various body organs (like the 
liver, lungs, or central nervous system) and can cause fever, 
fatigue, coughing or wheezing, or abdominal pain.
27 Salmonellosis (Salmonella spp.)
Salmonella organisms, which are most frequently 
spread through contaminated food, cause salmonellosis. 
Salmonella can also transfer from humans to cats and from 
humans to other humans.
By consuming contaminated food or coming into con -
tact with animal waste, people might catch an infection. 
Salmonella can infect cats when they consume infected ro -
dents, birds, or pet food, particularly raw pet food. Anyone 
can contract a Salmonella infection, but those with com -
promised immune systems, those over 65, and children un-
der the age of 5 are more likely to develop serious disease. 
Typically, adult cats don't exhibit symptoms of illness. Cats 
who are infected could develop diarrhea. Diarrhea, fever, 
and cramping are possible symptoms. Symptoms often ap -
pear 6 h to 4 days after infection and continue 4–7 days.
28 Sporotrichosis (Sporothrix spp.)
An infection known as sporotrichosis is brought on by a 
fungus. The fungus normally enters the body through a 
cut or scrape in the skin, but it has also been linked to ani -
mal bites or scratches, notably those from cats. Anyone is 
susceptible to contracting sporotrichosis, but those who 
work with plant material (such moss, roses, or hay) or 
come into contact with diseased animals are particularly 
vulnerable. People who have compromised immune sys -
tems are more susceptible to infection, especially dissem -
inated diseases.
Sporotrichosis in cats can range from having no symp -
toms to becoming a deadly condition. Small draining 
wounds that later become elevated lumps when the surface 
is worn away are frequently the first symptoms. The condi-
tion may then get worse.
The location of the fungus's growth affects the sporotri-
chosis symptoms.
● Cutaneous (skin) form: 1–12  weeks after exposure, a 
tiny, painless lump first appears. The bump, which may 
be red, pink, or purple, enlarges until it resembles an 
open sore or ulcer that heals very slowly. The original 
bump may be followed by others.
● Disseminated form: The infection in this form damages 
the bones and internal organs.
● Pulmonary form: signs and symptoms include fever, 
chest discomfort, shortness of breath, and cough. The 
pulmonary and disseminated types:
29 Tick-borne diseases
Pets are susceptible to infections spread by ticks, such as 
Lyme disease, tularemia, ehrlichiosis, babesiosis, and other 
illnesses. A veterinarian should be consulted by pet  owners

594 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
to determine the best tick prevention methods for their ani-
mals. The risk of tick-borne illnesses for both you and your 
pets can be decreased by treating pets for ticks. The bite 
of an infected tick allows the transmission of tick-borne 
pathogens. Small amounts of saliva are secreted by the tick 
into the animal's or person's skin during the feeding pro -
cess. Tick exposure is a possibility for people and animals 
that spend time in tick habitat (grassy, forested, or brushy 
environments). Ticks can be found in and around the ears, 
eyelids, beneath collars, between the back legs, between the 
toes, and around the tail of cats.
To limit the risk of sickness, rapidly remove ticks from 
pets. Depending on the type of infection, the symptoms 
of tick-borne disease in pets might vary, or they may not 
exhibit any symptoms at all. People might have a variety 
of symptoms from tick-borne infections, but they typically 
include fever, chills, body aches, and occasionally a rash. 
Some tick-borne illnesses can be fatal or extremely serious. 
If you have been exposed to tick habitat or have been bit -
ten by a tick and exhibit any of these symptoms, consult a 
healthcare professional (Table 2).
30 Toxoplasmosis (Toxoplasma gondii)
To limit the risk of sickness, rapidly remove ticks from pets. 
Depending on the type of infection, the symptoms of tick-
borne disease in pets might vary, or they may not exhibit 
any symptoms at all. A parasite that can be found in soil, 
water, meat, or the feces of infected animals, especially 
cats, causes the disease toxoplasmosis.
People can contract toxoplasmosis by eating under -
cooked meat or shellfish or by coming into touch with cat 
excrement. By consuming infected rodents, birds, or other 
small animals, cats catch the disease. Once the parasite has 
shed, it contaminates the surroundings or the cat's litter box 
by dispersing in the cat's feces. Consuming tainted food or 
water can cause an infection in a person. People can con -
tract the illness if they don't wash their hands after touching 
cat waste or cleaning a cat's litter box.
Toxoplasmosis can affect anyone, but those with com -
promised immune systems are more prone to have severe 
sickness. Infected pregnant women can transmit the parasite 
to their unborn child, which may cause birth abnormalities. 
Although cats with toxoplasmosis rarely show symptoms, 
the parasite can persist in feces for up to 3 weeks after in -
fection. Toxoplasmosis usually has no symptoms in healthy 
persons, but in rare cases, ocular illness or mild flu-like 
symptoms may appear. Toxoplasmosis can cause more se -
vere problems, such as brain damage, in people with com -
promised immune systems. Due to the possibility of birth 
abnormalities, pregnant women who may have been ex -
posed should speak with their doctor.
31 Tularemia (Francisella tularensis)
Francisella tularensis bacteria are the cause of the disease 
tularemia. Although it can infect dogs and cats, it is primar-
ily seen in small mammals like rabbits and rodents. Tick 
bites, contact with infected animals, breathing in the germs, 
and contaminated food or water are all ways that the bac -
teria might spread. Cats can contract the disease from tick 
bites, eating or killing infected rodents or small mammals, 
or both. Infections can also spread to people through cat 
bites and scratches.
Anyone can contract tularemia, but those who spend a 
lot of time in the great outdoors, go hunting, or prepare and 
butcher wild game are more likely to come into contact with 
the F . tularensis bacteria. Yellowed eyes, tiredness, lymph 
gland swelling, fever, and other symptoms of infection can 
all occur in infected cats. Tularemia manifests itself in sev-
eral ways in humans. The most typical symptoms of infection 
are fever, ulceration, and swollen lymph nodes. Chills, head-
aches, joint discomfort, muscular aches, and weakness are 
some other symptoms. The respiratory system, throat, and 
eyes can all become infected with the F . tularensis bacteria.
32 Prevention
Proper litter box cleaning is the most effective way to reduce 
the risk of contracting a zoonotic disease from your cat. 
Litter box should be places away from the kitchen and/or 
food storage areas. Furthermore, use of disposable  litter box 
liners also helps. The litter should not be dumped  because
