it could potentially aerosolize an infectious agent. The litter 
box should be cleaned at least twice a month with hot wa -
ter, letting the hot water stand in the box for at least 5  min. 
This simple cleaning technique will kill the Toxoplasma 
organism. Pet owners should thoroughly wash hands after 
cleaning the litter box, post pet grooming or bathing. The 
bedding material of pets should be separate. Animal and in-
sect bites should be avoided. The pets should be vaccinated 
against diseases such as rabies.
33 Conclusion
The interdisciplinary obstacles that currently exist between 
ecological, evolutionary, and environmental sciences and 
human and veterinary medicine must be removed for this 
One Health idea to succeed. Although it rarely happens, all 
domestic animals, including dogs, cats, birds, horses, cows, 
sheep, goats, and rabbits, have the potential to transmit 
diseases to humans. The majority of these possible infec -
tions can be prevented if pet owners practice fundamental 
hygiene standards, including hand washing.

597

Chapter 41
Prevention and control of infectious 
diseases
1 Introduction
Infectious disease is defined as an illness due to a pathogen 
or its toxic product, which arises through transmission from 
an infected person, an infected animal, or a contaminated 
inanimate object to a susceptible host ( Van Seventer and 
Hochberg, 2017). The management of infectious diseases 
can be achieved only by understanding the determining 
factors of the transmission of disease. The likelihood of 
a disease occurrence in a population is nearly inevitable. 
Nevertheless, the probability of an animal contracting a dis-
ease when exposed to an agent depends upon the dynamic 
relationship between the host, agent, and the environment.
The word prevention originated from the Latin word 
“preventionem” which stands for action of stopping or 
anticipation. “Prevention” is a highly valued term from a 
clinician’s perspective in the context of infectious disease. 
Unlike the other clinical maladies, a disease caused by an 
infectious agent can be prevented and kept under control 
when appropriate measures are taken. Control measures 
play a vital role in limiting the spread of an infectious dis -
ease. Prevention strategies aim at severing the bridge of 
transmission of the agents and their relationship with the 
host and environment. Therefore, control of a disease is an 
amalgam of continuous disease surveillance, monitoring 
when in a state of an outbreak, adapting appropriate mitiga-
tion strategies to control the transmission and selection of 
necessary treatment. The chapter will cover factors influ -
encing prevention of a disease, nature of canine and feline 
populations, the relationship between pathogen/agent-host-
environment, role of vaccinations, and control strategies in 
case of an outbreak in dog and cat populations.
2 Domesticated populations
Canines and felines are the top domesticated animals in the 
world. They have also gained importance in the society. 
Hence, the infectious diseases that affect them tend to have 
an indirect impact on humans as well as the community.
2.1 Canine population
The domesticated dog ( Canis familiaris) has a worldwide 
distribution with a population size of 700 million around 
the globe ( Hughes and Macdonald, 2013 ). Dogs can be 
owned, i.e., they are under the ownership of humans and 
depend on them for food, shelter, and movement. Whereas 
the second type is unowned (stray) one they do not have hu-
man supervision but indirectly depends on humans to fulfill 
their needs (Matter et al., 2000). Irrespective of the type of 
ownership both groups are equally susceptible to infections. 
Major infectious diseases affecting the canine population 
are Parvo viral enteritis, canine distemper, infectious canine 
hepatitis, leptospirosis, rabies, kennel cough, etc. Most in -
fectious diseases are preventable with appropriate measures. 
For example, Parvo viral enteritis has a sporadic occurrence 
that is again dependent on many factors, like immunity sta-
tus, stress factors, age, geographical distribution, strain, etc. 
The disease is completely preventable with immunization. 
Therefore, when there is an outbreak, the infection needs to 
be properly contained and controlled to limit the repercus -
sion and transmission.
In general, the dog populations have the same kind of 
characteristics, viz. management, housing, and husbandry; 
hence, the type of shortcomings in the prevention strategies 
is also similar. The prevention strategies to combat infec -
tious diseases are elaborated in the latter part.
2.2 Feline population
The feline population is generally categorized into two 
based on their housing and ownership, confined cats and 
non-confined cats. Confined cats are strictly reared indoors 
and are under ownership. Whereas non-confined or free-
roaming cats are semi-owned or unowned (Bradshaw et al., 
1999). Strictly confined cats are highly socialized and their 
health is continuously monitored by owners. Semi-owned 
cats are free-roaming they do not completely depend upon 
one owner for food or shelter, in such condition’s owners

598 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
become unaware of the health issues or history of exposure 
to pathogens. They tend to roam in small colonies and live 
where there is availability of food. Felines form a colony 
of three or more sexually mature cats living and feeding 
in close proximity ( Slater, 2005). Though they live among 
humans they tend to have strong wild instincts. The ma -
jor difference in such a free-roaming population from that 
of single-ownership pets is that owners may extend some 
comfort, food, shelter, and emergency care, but they hardly 
provide adequate protection against infections, neither pro-
vide parasite control nor vaccinations. Another important 
concern with feline populations is that they are seasonally 
polyoestrus and are induced ovulators. The chances of preg-
nancy are alarmingly high throughout the year (Deag et al., 
2000). Infant mortality and morbidity due to infectious dis-
eases are high among cats. The major infectious diseases 
affecting cats are feline infectious peritonitis, feline leuke -
mia virus infection, feline immunodeficiency virus infec -
tion, and feline respiratory disease. Most infectious diseases 
are preventable yet for most unowned or semi-owned cats 
the prognosis are grave. When an owner no longer wants to 
take the ownership, they rather abandon them in the streets, 
under the notion that their welfare is better when they are 
unowned rather than in shelter homes.
3 Factors influencing infectious diseases 
progression and its prevention
The seven factors that influence infectious disease progres-
sion and its prevention are host, pathogen, transmission, 
methods of transmission, environment, maintenance of dis-
ease and immunoprophylaxis (Fig. 1).
3.1 Hosts
Hosts are the living organisms which harbor the infectious 
agent and can support the sustenance of the agent. They 
are an essential part of a disease cycle. The development 
of the agent occurs in the host. The host’s susceptibility or 
infectiousness depends upon its ability to spread or transmit 
the diseases. For example, dogs are generally susceptible to 
parvo-viral enteritis, and they transmit the disease to other 
dogs. The susceptibility within a species depends upon the 
age, immunity status and the influencing environmental sta-
tus. Canine parvo viral enteritis is commonly transmitted 
among the nonimmunized pups of the age group 3  weeks 
to 6 months. An animal does not have the ability to transfer 
the infectious agent as soon as in its infected by an agent, 
such a period, i.e., a period between the entry of the organ-
ism/agent to the period of excretion of the agent is referred 
to as prepatent period (parasite), eclipse phase (virus), and 
latent period (bacterium). The period between the exposure 
of the organism to the period of clinical demonstration of 
the disease refers to incubation period. There are different 
types of hosts (Fig. 2):
Definitive hosts/final host : A host in which the sexual 
stages of development of an infectious agent takes place. 
They are often the last link in a dynamic process, e.g., 
Taenia pisiforms in dogs.
Primary host : A host which helps in the maintenance 
of infectious agent in a population. Infectious agent relies 
of the primary host for existence therefore also known as 
maintenance host, e.g., dogs infected with distemper virus.
Secondary host: It is a susceptible host that are addition-
ally involved in the life cycle of an infectious agent. They 
are also called as aberrant hosts.
Paratenic host: A host which mechanically transfers an 
agent. They do not take part in any developmental stages of 
the life cycle. This term is usually used in helminthology.
Intermediate host: A host in which agent undergoes de-
velopmental stages before it moves to the final host, fre -
quently in an asexual reproduction, e.g., larval stages of 
Ctenocephalides spp. are the intermediate host for the tape-
worm infestation in dogs.
Amplifier host: A host in which the infectious agent mul-
tiply abundantly. The host remains asymptomatic through -
out the cycle.
Hibernating host: A host in which the infectious agent 
remains dormant without multiplication, e.g., hibernating 
snakes infected with Japanese encephalitis virus.
Incidental (dead-end or accidental) host : A host that 
harbors the agent but do not transmit it to the other hosts.
Biological vector : A animal (usually an arthropod) in 
which an infectious agent undergoes either a developmental 
stage or its multiplication before its transmission to definite 
host, e.g., ticks in anaplasma infection in dogs.
3.2 Pathogen
A pathogen is defined as an organism causing disease to a 
host. Pathogens are diverse and comprises of virus, bacteria 
FIG. 1 Factors influencing infectious diseases progression and its prevention.

Prevention and control of infectious diseases  Chapter | 41  599
as well as unicellular and multicellular eukaryotes (Balloux 
and van Dorp, 2017). The three main characteristics of the 
pathogen are infectivity, virulence, and stability. Infectivity 
is the proportion of the organism required to cause a disease 
in the host. It varies from a host to host, as the host’s immu-
nity come into play when exposed to an infectious agent. It 
also depends upon the strains of the pathogen. The infective 
dose of a particular pathogen affecting more than one spe -
cies can be different.
Infectivity is quantified in terms of the infectious dose 
50 (ID50), the amount of agent required to infect 50% of a 
specified host population. This proves that the infectivity 
of a pathogen can only be explained in relation with the 
hosts. Virulence is defined as the ability of the pathogen to 
infect the host and cause the disease ( Sharma et al., 2017). 
Virulence reflect the biochemical properties of the pathogen 
pertaining to its ability to produce toxins, cell proteins, im-
mune response inhibitors, adhesion, colonization, and inva-
sion. Stability refers to the length of the time a pathogen 
can survive outside in body of the host. Some pathogens 
can stabilize themselves only for a short period and are very 
labile, e.g., spirochetes—Leptospira. Whereas some patho-
gens can survive in the environment for longer period due to 
their adaptive mechanisms, e.g., Bacillus anthracis.
3.3 Transmission
Transmission is the transfer of pathogenic organisms from 
one host to the other. The infectious agent leaves the host 
through a portal of exit and enter the next susceptible host 
through a portal of entry. Infectious diseases can be trans -
mitted from host–host through a plethora of mechanisms in-
cluding direct-aerosol, bite, transplacental, transmammary 
indirect-airborne, vector-borne, and intermediate hosts. The 
cornerstone of epidemiology is to prevent the spread of the 
infectious agent from host to host. Further, prevention of 
any type of contact which may result in disease transmis -
sion is a more pragmatic way to handle a disease outbreak.
The significant elements in population medicine are 
their density, movement, environmental management, and 
breeding stock. The population density is the number of 
individuals within a species in a specific geographic lo -
cale, in this context, it means the number of individuals in 
a population in a particular area/cage/house. For example, 
for an adult Dalmatian dog, the minimum floor space re -
quirement required is 9.51  ft.2, when housing a group of 
animals, the floor space should meet or exceed the mini -
mum requirement to ensure good welfare ( Normando 
et  al., 2014 ). The second element is animal movement, 
despite the rules and regulations laid down by the World 
Organization for Animal Health (WOAH) the legal and il -
legal transport of animals both livestock and exotic ones 
have led to many outbreaks of infectious diseases. Since 
animal movement is not as easier as human movement 
there is still hope to control the contact or the spread of dis-
ease. There are pieces of evidence that points to the spread 
of diseases due to the animal movement. Infections asso -
ciated with heartworm ( Dirofilaria immitis ), ehrlichiosis 
(Ehrlichia canis ), echinococcosis ( Echinococcus granu -
losus and E. multilocularis ), babesiosis ( Babesia canis ), 
and leishmaniosis have a high probability to transfer with 
the movement of domestic pets into the United Kingdom 
and to many other countries ( Trotz-Williams and Trees, 
2003; Ferroglio et al., 2005). The unknown spread of these 
above-mentioned infections happened due to a lack of 
necessary preventive measures including usage of anthel -
minthic, insecticide-treated collars, and lack of screening 
for endemic infections before pet travel. The third element 
is the environmental management of the facilities to which 
the population is exposed.
FIG. 2 Types of hosts.

600 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
For instance, if a dog or a cat is exposed to the high mois-
ture content from improper drying of the skin coat, there 
is a high probability of fungal or yeast infections, contact 
dermatitis, etc. Similarly, in the case of Leptospirosis infec-
tion, the water stagnation in the surrounding area or the high 
rodent population in the area can contribute to the spread of 
the disease (Van de Maele et al., 2008). The fourth element, 
breeding stock, selection of the breeding stock is as impor -
tant as the other three elements. Good breeding stock can 
aid in raising a healthier future population. Certain breed -
ing lines can give rise to immunocompromised individuals 
or can be prone to certain genetic impediments which may 
lead to disease-susceptible individuals. Irrespective of the 
type of population all four elements remain as a marker for 
infection control programs.
There are several ways how an infection can spread 
from one host to the other. The two main modes of trans -
mission are horizontal transmission and vertical transmis -
sion (Fig. 3).
3.3.1 Horizontal transmission
It is the transmission of disease from one segment of the 
population to the other. Popular examples of such transmis-
sion are influenza virus infections among dogs from one 
shelter to the other. Horizontal transmission can be further 
divided into direct and indirect forms.
The transmission of an infection from an infected host 
to a susceptible host through a direct contact or through the 
discharges from the infected host is called as direct form. 
Transmission of canine distemper from urine and discharges 
to an unvaccinated host is an example for direct form.
Indirect transmission is the transmission which involves 
a living, inanimate or intermediate vehicle between the host 
and susceptible organisms. The intermediate vehicle is of -
ten called as a vector (living carrier), e.g., insects. The dura-
tion and the course of a disease varies from one disease to 
the other. When there is more than one vector involved in a 
disease, the life cycle of the disease becomes complex. In an 
infection where biological vectors aid in the transmission of 
an infection they are named as vector-borne infection.
3.3.2 Vertical transmission
Infections which are spread from one generation to the other 
when in utero or when in in ovo are referred to as vertically 
transmitted diseases. Transmission through milk is also con-
sidered as vertical transmission (Davison et al., 1999).
 (1) Hereditary-transmitted diseases : They are carried 
within the genome of either parent. In infections 
caused by retrovirus, integrated DNA copies in the 
host’s genome are transferred hereditarily.
 (2) Congenitally transmitted diseases : Refers to the dis -
eases commonly acquired either in utero or in ovo.
The infection can spread from a generation to another if 
the mother/dam has a pre-existing condition or if the dam 
acquires an infection during gestation period. Further nu -
tritional deficiency can contribute to the risks of perinatal 
infections. Transmission of the diseases can follow at any 
stages of embryonic development, which can result in abor-
tion, still births, teratoma, or innate infections postdelivery.
Germinative transmission
It refers to infections pertaining to the superficial layers of 
the ovary or diseases of the ovum.
Transplacental transmission
Transmission to the embryo can happen transplacentally 
or through fetal circulation. For example, kittens can get 
infected with feline panleukopenia virus transplacentally, 
as the virus is small and can cross the placenta in early 
pregnancy.
Ascending infection
When there is an uphill infection from lower genital area 
to the amnion and placenta, it is commonly considered as 
ascending infection. Example: staphylococcus and strepto -
coccus infection.
FIG. 3 Modes of transmission.

Prevention and control of infectious diseases  Chapter | 41  601
Infections during parturition are often reported due the 
transmission of pathogens from lower genitals to the fetus 
at birth. Example herpes virus infections. The exposure 
of new pathogens to fetus can be detrimental as it can af -
fect their immunological status of the fetus. Hence, leads 
to the risk of misinterpretation of the non-self-antigen as 
self-antigens.
Transovarian and trans-stadial transmission
Certain arthropods like mites, ticks, transmit viruses, bac -
teria, and protozoa from one generation to another through 
their eggs such transmissions are called as transovarian 
transmission, e.g., canine babesiosis causes severe anemia 
in dogs it is transmitted by Dermacentor and Hemaphysalis 
ticks. Some arthropods transmit these infectious organisms 
from one generation to another through stadial transmis -
sion, i.e., from one stage of the development to another. On 
the contrary, some are capable of transovarian, trans-stadial 
and sexual transmission, e.g., African swine fever virus is 
primarily maintained in the tick Ornithodoros moubata by 
these three methods of transmission.
3.4 Methods of transmission
Ways in which the infectious agent comes in contact with 
the sites in the host can be listed as (Fig. 4).
3.4.1 Contact
Transmission by contact is the transfer of the infectious or-
ganism to the host without the involvement of the external 
factors. This method of transmission focuses on the patho -
gens that are shed from surface of the body and gain entry 
through the body surface. Most of the agents needs some de-
gree of trauma to complete the transmission process, e.g., a 
bite injury is required for lyssa virus to gain entry to the sur-
face of the host’s body. It is challenging for infectious agents 
to cross the skin surface, when the skin barrier is resilient.
In case of spirochetes—Leptospira they require soft and 
water sunken skin to penetrate, even in the absence of an 
injury. They pierce the intact skin through screwing motion 
and gain their entry.
3.4.2 Ingestion
Ingestion is a method of transmission where an infectious 
agent gain entry to the host with the help of a mechanical 
agent, e.g., contaminated feed, water, mechanical vectors, 
etc., depending upon the type and predilection site of the 
pathogens the route of infection differs. When the predilec-
tion site is intestines, organisms are excreted through feces. 
On invasion of blood, the exit can be through urine, e.g., 
Salmonella (Hatta and Smits, 2007 ). In cases of excretion 
through breath—reovirus.
3.4.3 Inoculation
An introduction of a pathogen by puncture or through a 
wound is called transmission by inoculation. It is also a 
form of contact transmission. Example arthropods inoculate 
the pathogenic organism through their bite—canine filaria-
sis is spread through the bite of the mosquitos ( Abd Rani 
et al., 2010).
3.4.4 Aerial transmission
Airborne transmission of infectious agents, frequently over 
long distances, is often defined as indirect, although it is 
more correctly classified as direct because no intermediate 
vehicle is involved. Aerial transmission is the transmission 
of infectious agent through contaminated air. Plethora of in-
fections are transmitted aerially. Infectious organisms like 
bacteria, virus, and fungi are spread through contaminated 
air causing widespread of the diseases. The expired air from 
the infected animal gets transferred to the susceptible ani -
mal through inhalation. Aerosol transmission is the trans -
mission by droplets of the size less than 5  μm. This may 
be a residue of the evaporated dry particle called nuclei. 
Respiratory droplets are relatively heavier; therefore, they 
fall down after emission, but the smaller droplets contain 
live infectious agent and can persist in contaminated air for 
longer period. Larger droplets of size 100  μm settle within 
2 m, whereas smaller droplets of size 5–20  μm containing 
infectious agent linger in the environment for extended 
period and area ( Jones and Brosseau, 2015 ; Gralton et al., 
2011). The airborne infections are highly influenced by en-
vironment factors such as relative humidity and tempera -
ture. Other factors that influence the aerial transmission are 
pH of the air, wind speed, extend of air pollution and salin-
ity (Sooryanarain and Elankumaran, 2015).
3.4.5 Coitus
Infections that are spread from one animal to the other 
through sexual contact is called as venereal diseases or 
FIG. 4 Methods of transmission.

602 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
transmission of disease by coitus. These pathogens of -
ten have predilection on the genital area which causes the 
excretion of the organisms during sexual contact. Canine 
brucellosis is an example for sexually transmitted diseases. 
Large number of bacteria are shed via vaginal secretions 
and semen. The main clinical sign of the infection is in -
fertility in either sex or abortion in late gestational period. 
The aborted dam will continue excreting the bacteria for 
4–5 weeks post-abortion (Santos et al., 2021). Canine trans-
missible venereal tumor is another infection that has vene -
real transmission among dogs. They form febrile, ulcerating 
type tumor growths in the genital area which can be spread 
via mating, biting, licking, and sniffing of the tumor site.
3.4.6 Iatrogenic transmission
Iatrogenic transmission is the transmission of the infectious 
disease in a hospital or clinic set-up, during a medical pro -
cedure like blood transfusions, nonaseptic surgical proce -
dures or reuse of needles or intravenous catheters.
3.5 Environment
During transmission cycle, infectious pathogen can be at 
various stages. Stages involving different environments 
both inside and outside the host and other vectors involved. 
These environments can be broadly divided into: environ -
ment within the host and external environment.
3.5.1 Environment within the host
Host has various defense mechanisms like humoral antibod-
ies, special reactive cells, phagocytes and other chemical 
which discourage the invasion of the pathogens inside the 
body. The mechanisms make the internal environment hos-
tile. In contrast, the parasites/pathogens evolved to break 
the defense strategies of the host and to compete with the 
other agents. These involve resistant cuticles to resist the 
hydrochloric acid in the stomach, an intracellular stage of 
development, encystment, immunosuppression, and re -
duced immunogenicity ( Capron and Capron, 1992 ). Some 
possess capsules that protect them against phagocytosis, for 
example, Pneumococcus spp. Many of the parasites have 
impressive fecundity in order to ensure greater survivability 
against the lethal conditions inside the host.
3.5.2 External environment
External environment is presented with numerous threats, 
viz. low temperatures, ultraviolet rays, desiccation, etc. 
Desiccation and low temperatures are not lethal, these fluc-
tuations make it rather challenging to multiply. Many agents 
partially protect themselves from desiccation by being dis -
charged feces and urine. They are also shed into advanta -
geous surroundings to withstand uncertainties. Leptospires 
persist longer in paddy fields and are found to thrive  better 
in monsoon season ( Goldstein, 2010). Some organism hi -
bernates to survive for longer period; they form spores and 
cyst that are resilient to external conditions. Viruses like 
poxviruses are resistant to desiccation and can survive for 
long periods in dry infected scab material. Certain agents 
may also survive in inanimate material in the environment, 
which may therefore act as a vehicle; example, food con -
taminated with Salmonella spp.
3.6 Maintenance of disease
There are numerous strategies to maintain or preserve the 
cycle of transmission and create conducive conditions 
to continue the infection course. The five strategies are 
(Fig. 5):
3.6.1 Dodging of external environment
Certain agents dodge the stage in the external environment 
by choosing vertical, venereal, and vector  transmission. 
FIG. 5 Strategies for the maintenance of diseases.

Prevention and control of infectious diseases  Chapter | 41  603
Therefore, they avoid the risk of surviving in harsh 
environment.
3.6.2 Resistant forms
Another strategy to survive in the harsh environment is to 
form conducive environment around the organism like a 
shell or a resistant structure. They serve as a strong pro -
tection from heat and desiccation. Bacillus and clostridium 
bacteria form spore which are resistant against high boiling 
temperatures and severe desiccation (Wiencek et al., 1990). 
Fungi also produce spores, but they are relatively less re -
sistant than bacterial spores. Parasites form cysts to remain 
viable for months to years, until a favorable environment for 
multiplication is obtained.
3.6.3 Rapidly in and rapidly out
In this strategy, the infectious agent enters and exits the host 
rapidly which leaves lesser amount of time for an immuno-
logical response. This strategy is commonly found when the 
number of susceptible hosts are higher and housed in closed 
proximity. For example, in case of respiratory infections the 
agent spreads rapid from one host to the other within a span 
of 24 h. In such infections, morbidity rate will be high.
3.6.4 Persistence within the host
Some infectious agents can survive within the host for life 
time. This is attributable to the immune status of the host. 
When agents get accustomed to the host immune system, 
they adapt themselves to live within the host and rely on 
the host for survival. These conditions may lead to latency 
or immunosuppression and tolerance. Latency/immunosup-
pression are when the agent persists inside and the host, do 
not elicit any clinical symptoms, provided the immune sys-
tem is strong and active. The agents are maintained within 
the host for years or life time with general or agent-specific 
immunosuppression.
3.6.5 Expansion of host range
For better survival and maintenance, agents infect wide 
range of hosts. About 50% of the pathogenic infections 
have humans and animals as hosts. They can survive and 
multiply their number in all these hosts. Therefore, they are 
likely to be over-presented as emerging and re-emerging in-
fections with varying antigenicity.
3.7 The classical triad: Agent-host-environment 
relationship
The complex interaction of agents (bacteria, viruses, pro -
tozoans, parasites, fungi, and prions), host (animals), and 
environmental factors give rise to the outcome of infectious 
disease (Fig. 6). The factors governing the environment of-
fer a suitable ground for the agent and host to interact. The 
succeeding agent-host interactions determine the outcome 
of exposure. These interactions undergo a cascade of stages 
such as infection, recovery, or death. This relationship is 
also known as the epidemiological triad. The above concept 
forms the foundation of epidemiology and the cornerstone 
of infectious diseases.
Subsequently, after the exposure to the agent, there are 
two stages: colonization and infection. Colonization refers 
to the entry of a pathogen and multiplication of the pathogen 
at the site of entry, it could be through the respiratory tract, 
digestive tract, etc. Colonization does not necessarily mean 
disease causation, for that, pathogens have to invade and 
cause disruption in the host tissues to a level where normal 
functions are disturbed. Thus, resulting in the demonstration 
of clinical symptoms, in turn, causing the infection/disease. 
The exposure of the pathogen to a susceptible host resulting 
FIG. 6 The classical triad.

604 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
in a disease’s outcome is also influenced by the agent’s in -
fectivity, virulence, and pathogenicity. Simultaneously, the 
vulnerability of the host to disease is also important (Li and 
Baker, 2012).
Latent infections too play a significant role from a pub-
lic health point of view. For instance, if the immunity of the 
host is resilient, it leads to the elimination of the pathogen 
otherwise, leads to incomplete elimination. In such cases, 
the pathogen becomes dormant and it is called latent infec-
tion. On exposure to a suitable environment, these infec -
tions can recur and cause a full-fledged disease.
3.8 Immunoprohylaxis
Immunity is an active process of recognition and destruction 
of self from non-self-particles that enters the body. Foreign 
or non-self-particles refers to the infectious organisms or 
cancer cells or graft tissues. Immunity can be basically 
divided into two innate immunity and passive immunity. 
Innate immunity indicates the defense mechanism of the 
body that are inherited by birth. On the other hand, pas -
sive immunity is the defense mechanism that are acquired 
after an exposure to specific antigen or an infectious agent. 
It is called as adaptive immunity as it is acquired during 
the life time in response to adaptation. Passive immunity is 
portioned into humoral immunity and cell-mediated immu-
nity. In humoral immunity, non-self-particles are destroyed 
using antibodies; however in cell-mediated immunity, cell 
phagocytosis is used as weapon to destroy or dispose-off the 
foreign materials (Carroll and Isenman, 2012).
Immunoprophylaxis refers to the prevention of infec -
tious diseases by the process of immunization. On stimu -
lation of the body either by actual disease exposure or by 
vaccine, body prepares to defend on subsequent exposure to 
those specific antigens. The immune response can be trig -
gered either by the presence of the whole agent or a met -
abolic product of the agent. Immunity can be transferred 
passively by administration of components of the humoral 
or cell-mediated that are procured from the sensitized do -
nor. This can be beneficial for therapeutic purposes in an 
initial stage of an infection.
3.8.1 Maternally derived antibodies
Canines and felines have endotheliochorial type of placenta. 
When a dam is exposed to an infection or an immunization 
protocol, her body produces antibodies in response to that 
specific antigen. Such antibodies are readily circulated in 
the body mixing with the fetus’s blood. Only 2%–18% of 
the antibodies produced in the body of a dam can cross pla-
centa and reach the fetus. Majority of the immunoglobulins 
are received through colostrum. The antibodies attained in 
the circulation of new-born pups and kittens’ aids in the 
survival during post-delivery especially when they are co -
lostrum deprived. The immunoglobulins in milk are at its 
highest concentration immediately after delivery and per -
sists in low concentration throughout the nursing period. 
IgG and IgM play a pivotal role in a new-born’s immune 
mechanism. During initial days of nursing, these immu -
noglobulins are absorbed in the duodenum and jejunum 
through membrane receptors situated on the intestinal epi -
thelium. There is maximum absorption in first 24 h of birth 
and gradually declines ( Figs. 7 and 8 ). Secretory IgA also 
plays an important role in defense mechanism, protecting 
from upper respiratory and enteric infections (Decaro et al., 
2005). Their mechanism of action is inhibition of adher -
ence of pathogens at the mucosal surface and simultaneous 
neutralization. As the maternally derived antibodies decline 
in the circulation the young ones start to become suscep -
tible infections. They begin to start synthesizing their own 
antibodies to combat the infectious diseases. The produc -
tion of antibodies is stimulated by the level of circulating 
maternally derived antibodies. When the level of MDA 
falls below the threshold level, it triggers the production of 
FIG. 7 A day-old Rottweiler pups nursing. (Sara’s Birds & Exotic Animal Hospital.)

Prevention and control of infectious diseases  Chapter | 41  605
 antibodies. There are no absolute numbers for the threshold 
limit; however, the ratio between the decline of MDA and 
dose of the pathogenic/vaccine antigen is considered.
3.8.2 Active immunization
Vaccination kindles active immunity by administration of 
the antigenic extracts and whole cultures of infectious or -
ganisms to the host. Immunization refers to the successful 
induction of immune response. Not all vaccinations end in 
successful immunization as the level of MDA is different in 
different animals. Clinical vaccination of pet animals ma -
jorly concentrates on the infectious diseases that are com -
monly found in that geographical area and are limited to 
disease caused by viruses, bacteria, and protozoans.
Conventional whole organism vaccines are of two 
types live attenuated or modified live and inactivated or 
killed vaccine. In order to remove the unwanted aller -
gic reaction to the proteins and to increase the potency, 
newer types of vaccines are developed. The usage of live 
agents is being modified by genetic deletion. Newer non -
infectious vaccines are making use of subunit fractions of 
purified agents or synthetic peptides molded by genetic 
recombination.
Live whole organism in vaccine has the ability to stimu-
late both cell-mediated immunity and sustained humoral im-
munity in comparison with the inactivated or purified ones. 
The components in the vaccines must be modified or attenu-
ated in order to retain the immunogenicity and replication in 
the concerned host without producing the infection.
Attenuation of agents is established by adapting them to 
unusual hosts, by subjecting them to extended storage, or by 
serial passage in tissue culture. Intentional genetic manipu-
lations are other ways for attenuation (Minor, 2015).
Inactivated whole vaccine components are subjected 
to several forms of denaturation without terminating the 
 immunogenicity. Treatments with heat and light, chemical 
treatments are established for the inactivation process, but 
these are considered to relatively ineffective as it can cause 
reactions in the injection site. On addition of adjuvants and 
inactivating compounds, host becomes vulnerable for local 
and allergic reactions. On the contrary, noninfectious vac -
cines are preferred as they lack the risk of producing the 
disease. Nevertheless, these vaccines do not imitate natural 
infection and therefore may not generate adequate mucosal 
immunity (Basta et al., 2008). In comparison with the modi-
fied live vaccine, inactivated vaccine has short duration of 
response. It might take 2–3  weeks for the full protection 
nonetheless the protection produced is sufficient for routine 
uses. If the animals are partially protected, there is a risk 
of mild or subclinical infections if they are exposed to the 
specific agents.
4 Disease control and prevention 
strategies
Control of a disease refers to the general reduction of mor -
bidity and mortality in a population due to a specific dis -
ease. Eradication of a disease refers to the extinction of an 
infectious agent from a particular geographical area. Main 
strategies are doing nothing, quarantine, euthanasia, vacci -
nation, and therapeutic chemotherapy (Fig. 9).
4.1 Doing nothing
It is not exactly a control mechanism, but in this strategy, 
intervention is not recommended. The disease is allowed 
to take its natural course, which means that incidence of 
an infectious disease may get reduced by natural changes 
in the host-environment-parasite relationships without 
intervention.
FIG. 8 A day-old Persian kittens nursing. (Vetbug clinic.)

606 SECTION | C  Infectious diseases of dogs and cats
4.2 Quarantine
Quarantine is a very valuable strategy that still holds strong 
in case of any outbreak of a disease. It is the isolation of the 
an individual or a group of animals that are either infected 
or suspected of an infection (Figs. 10 and 11). Basic idea is 
to separate the infected animals from susceptible animals. 
There are rules governing the import of animals like dogs, 
cats, and zoo animals from other countries ( Wang et  al., 
2010). In such movements of animals, quarantine is an abso-
lute necessity to avoid transboundary transmission of infec-
tious diseases. They need to be quarantine for about 6 weeks 
and health certificate should be issued. The period of quar -
antine depends upon the incubation period of the agent, time 
taken for an infected animal to become infectious.
4.3 Euthanasia
Dogs or cats infected with untreatable zoonotic diseases 
can be considered for mercy killing or euthanasia. Another 
strategy is test and removal. An animal is tested for a par -
ticular disease and removed if it is positive for the test in 
question. Normally pet animals are not euthanized on regu-
lar basis. They are euthanized only when the quality of their 
life is compromised and for zoonotic reasons. In developing 
countries, rabies is one of the strong reasons to euthanize 
dogs as it is untreatable and zoonotic. Canines and felines 
have the capability to transmit the disease to wide-range of 
hosts. In such conditions, euthanasia is crucial to block the 
spread (Underwood et al., 2013).
4.4 Vaccination
It is an integral part of any control programs. All pet and 
domesticated animals should be vaccinated against all en -
demic disease existing in that geographical area. There are 
core and noncore vaccines that should be mandatorily fol -
lowed routinely. Vaccinations can be taken on strategic or 
emergency basis. Strategic vaccinations are carried out to 
prevent incursion of the disease from endemic areas and to 
limit the spread of the disease in endemic area. Vaccination 
can be performed both within and around a region where 
an outbreak occurs; this strategy is called dampening-down 
vaccination. Dogs are generally vaccinated for canine parvo-
virus, distemper, canine hepatitis, and rabies (core vaccines) 
(Figs. 12 and 13). Noncore vaccines include Bordetella bron-
chiseptica, Borrelia burgdorferi, and Leptospira depending 
upon the exposure risk. Cats are generally vaccinated for 
Panleukopenia (feline distemper), feline calcivirus, feline 
herpesvirus type I (feline rhinotracheitis), and rabies (core 
vaccines) (Fig. 14). Noncore includes feline leukemia virus, 
FIG. 9 Disease control and prevention strategies.
FIG. 10 Dog in quarantine. (Thrissur Pet Clinic, Kerala, India.)

Prevention and control of infectious diseases  Chapter | 41  607
Bordetella, Chlamydophila felis , and feline immunodefi -
ciency virus (Larson and Schultz, 2021).
4.5 Therapeutic chemotherapy
When in sporadic outbreaks of infections, therapeutic man-
agement of diseases takes an upper hand in controlling 
the diseases. For instance, in case of sporadic out breaks 
of parvo viral infections, quarantine in combination with 
therapeutic approach stands to hold the ground. Dogs are 
provided with antimicrobials to combat the secondary bac -
terial infection together with intravenous fluids and platelet 
supplements, etc. In case of Leptospira infections, antibiot-
ics like tetracyclines along with intravenous fluids and di -
alysis are needed.
An infection control program is necessary regardless of 
the nature and number of the population in question. It is

a time-consuming as well as an expensive task to develop 
such control strategies. It requires a great number of the 
workforce to curate policies and regulations with regard to 
the prevention and outbreak programs. Veterinary practitio-
ners play the role of a frontier in risk assessment and iden -
tification of emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases 
and their prevention measures (Gibbs and Gibbs, 2012). The 
risk of zoonotic infections is high among households these 
days as animals share an unbreakable relationship with hu -
mans. The risk of the spread of fungal infections is high 
from dogs and cats to pet owners. Therefore, there is more 
need for awareness, training, and vaccination programs to 
protect the welfare of humans and animals.
According to the classical model of Leavell and Clark 
(1965), the prevention strategies can be categorized into pri-
mary, secondary, and tertiary.
4.5.1 Primary
Based on the classic model of Leavell and Clark (1965), in-
fectious disease prevention activities can be categorized as 
primary, secondary, or tertiary. Primary prevention occurs 
at the predisease phase and aims to protect populations, so 
that infection and disease never occur. For example, measles 
immunization campaigns aim to decrease  susceptibility 
 following exposure. The goal of secondary prevention is to 
halt the progress of an infection during its early, often asymp-
tomatic stages so as to prevent disease development or limit 
its severity; steps are important for not only improving the 
prognosis of individual cases but also preventing infectious 
agent transmission. For example, interventions for secondary 
prevention of hepatitis C in injection drug user populations 
include early diagnosis and treatment by active surveillance 
and screening (Miller and Dillon, 2015). Tertiary prevention 
focuses on diseased individuals with the objective of limit -
ing impact through, for example, interventions that decrease 
disease progression, increase functionality, and maximize 
quality of life. Broadly, public health efforts to control infec-
tious diseases focus on primary and secondary prevention ac-
tivities that reduce the potential for exposure to an infectious 
agent and increase host resistance to infection.
A unique characteristic of many infectious diseases is 
that exposure to certain infectious agents can have conse -
quences for other individuals because an infected person 
can act as a source of exposure. Some pathogens (e.g., STI 
agents) are directly transmitted to other people, while oth -
ers (vector-borne disease (VBD) agents) are transmitted 
indirectly.
5 Conclusion
Infectious diseases are preventable with awareness, under -
standing the transmission process, comprehension on incu-
bation period, agent viability, immunization, prophylactic 
chemotherapy, surveillance, and monitoring. The relation -
ship between the agent-host-environment plays a critical 
role in controlling a disease progression; while charting the 
standard operating procedure to control or prevent a disease, 
the key step is to gain complete knowledge and information 
about the disease. When a disease is partially controlled, 
there is always a risk of re-emergence. Evolutionary changes 
in their genetic constitution attribute to their re-emerging 
characteristics. When an agent evolves after mutation, their 
key features get modified, which makes them unpredictable 
and perilous to control. Therefore, caution should be taken 
in formulating a strategy that is appropriate for a disease. 
After achieving the control over transmission and morbid -
ity, it is mandatory to opt for a complete surveillance in 
regular intervals.
